mɛɹænə stʊd bɪhaɪn ðə bæɹiɝ ʃi kəd niðɝ si nɔɹ fil, hɛd haɪ ən hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst əz ɪf ə ʃɔl wɝ lupt oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹmz. ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ toʊneɪlz. ʃi wɑtʃt ɪm ən ðə klæn tʃifs wɪð kul aɪz, laɪt bɹaʊn flɛkt wɪð jɛloʊ. maɪ sɪstɝz də nɑɾ ɔl ɹilaɪz haʊ vɛɹi mʌtʃ wi nid ju, ʃi hæd toʊld ɪm ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn ðɪs vɛɹi ɹum, bʌɾ ɔl ʌv əs u swɔɹ wɪl də wʌtɛvɝ jə æsk ðət wəd nɑt vaɪəleɪt ðə θɹi oʊðz. hi hæd dʒʌst wækənd wən ʃi keɪm wɪð sɔɹɪliə ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ. niðɝ sim tə kɛɹ əɾ ɔl ðəɾ i wɑz stɪl ɪn ə ɹoʊb, wɪð oʊnli wʌn baɪt teɪkən fɹəm ɪz bɹɛkfəs bɹɛd. aɪ hæv mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl skɪl ɪn nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən ən miɾieɪʃən. maɪ sɪstɝz əv ʌðɝ skɪlz. lɛɾ əs sɝv ju, əz wi plɛdʒd. lemi sɝv ju. wi nid ju, bʌt juv səm niɾ ʌv ʌs, tu.

Merana stood behind the barrier she could neither see nor feel, head high and hands folded at her waist as if a shawl were looped over her arms. Aes Sedai to her toenails. She watched him and the clan chiefs with cool eyes, light brown flecked with yellow. My sisters do not all realize how very much we need you, she had told him this morning in this very room, but all of us who swore will do whatever you ask that would not violate the Three Oaths. He had just wakened when she came with Sorilea escorting her. Neither seemed to care at all that he was still in a robe, with only one bite taken from his breakfast bread. I have more than a little skill in negotiation and mediation. My sisters have other skills. Let us serve you, as we pledged. Let me serve you. We need you, but you have some need of us, too.

ɛvɝ pɹɛzənt, ɑlɑnə leɪ nɛsəld ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz bɹeɪn. ʃi wɑz wipɪŋ əɡɛn. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi wɛp soʊ ɔfən. hi hæd fɔɹbɪɾən əɹ tə kʌm nɪɹ ɪm ənlɛs sʌmənd, əɹ liv əɹ ɹum wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛskɔɹɾ ə meɪɾənz - ðə sɪstɝz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɪm hæd bɪn faʊn ɹumz læs naɪt, ɪn ðə pæləs wɛɹ i kəd kip ən aɪ ɑn əm - bʌɾ i hæd sɛns tɪɹz fɹəm ðə moʊmənt ʃi bɑndəd hɪm, tɪɹz ən ə ɹɔ ɡɹif laɪk biɪŋ ɹɪp baɪ klɔz. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz lɛs, səmtaɪmz mɔɹ, jɛɾ ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ. ɑlɑnə ɔlsoʊ hæd toʊld ɪm i niɾəd ðə swɔɹn sɪstɝz, skɹimd ɪɾ əɾ ɪm faɪnəli, wɪð əɹ feɪs ɹɛɾ ən tɪɹz ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks, bɪfɔɹ lɪɾɝəli ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz pɹɛzəns. ən ʃi hæd spoʊkən ə sɝvɪŋ, tu, ðoʊ hi daʊɾɪd ðət mɛɹænəz pɹɛzən tæsks wɝ wʌɾ iðɝ hæɾ ɪn maɪnd. pɝhæps səm sɔɹɾ ə lɪvɝi wəd meɪk ɪt klɪɹ?

Ever present, Alanna lay nestled in a corner of his brain. She was weeping again. He could not understand why she wept so often. He had forbidden her to come near him unless summoned, or leave her room without an escort of Maidens - the sisters who had sworn to him had been found rooms last night, in the Palace where he could keep an eye on them - but he had sensed tears from the moment she bonded him, tears and a raw grief like being ripped by claws. Sometimes it was less, sometimes more, yet always there. Alanna also had told him he needed the sworn sisters, screamed it at him finally, with her face red and tears rolling down her cheeks, before literally running from his presence. And she had spoken of serving, too, though he doubted that Merana's present tasks were what either had in mind. Perhaps some sort of livery would make it clear?

ðə klæn tʃifs wɑtʃt mɛɹænə wɑtʃ ðɛm. nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə flɪkɝ ʌv ən aɪlæʃ bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛɹ θɔts.

The clan chiefs watched Merana watch them. Not so much as the flicker of an eyelash betrayed their thoughts.

"ðə waɪz wʌnz əv toʊl jə wɛɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stænd," ɹænd sɛd blʌnli. sɔɹɪliə hæd toʊld ɪm ðeɪ nu, bʌt ðə fækt wʊɾə bɪn klɪɹ fɹəm ðə læk ə sɝpɹaɪz wən ðeɪ fɝst sɔ mɛɹænə fɛtʃ ən kɝtsi. "juv sin əɹ bɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪ ən pɔɹ jəɹ ti. juv sin əɹ kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz aɪ seɪ. ɪf jə wɑnt, əl əv əɹ dæns ə dʒɪɡ." kənvɪnsɪŋ ði il ðəɾ i wɑz nɑɾ ɑn ði ɛn ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ liʃ wɑz ðə moʊs niɾəd sɝvəs ɛni ʌv ðə sɪstɝz kəd də hɪm ɹaɪt naʊ. hi wəɾ əv əm ɔl duɪŋ dʒɪɡz, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi.

"The Wise Ones have told you where the Aes Sedai stand," Rand said bluntly. Sorilea had told him they knew, but the fact would have been clear from the lack of surprise when they first saw Merana fetch and curtsy. "You've seen her bring the tray and pour your tea. You've seen her come and go as I say. If you want, I'll have her dance a jig." Convincing the Aiel that he was not on the end of an Aes Sedai leash was the most needed service any of the sisters could do him right now. He would have them all doing jigs, if necessary.

mændələn ədʒʌstəd ðə ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin pætʃ oʊvɝ ɪz ɹaɪɾ aɪ, ðə weɪ hi dɪd wən i wɑntəɾ ə moʊmən tə θɪŋk. ə θɪk pʌkɝd skɑɹ ɹæn ʌp ɪz fɔɹhɛd fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə lɛðɝ pætʃ ən hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ɪz moʊsli bɔl hɛd. wən i faɪnəli spoʊk, ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl lɛs blʌn ðən ɹænd. "sʌm seɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl də ɛniθɪŋ tə hæv wʌt ʃi wɑns."

Mandelain adjusted the gray-green patch over his right eye, the way he did when he wanted a moment to think. A thick puckered scar ran up his forehead from behind the leather patch and halfway across his mostly bald head. When he finally spoke, it was only a little less blunt than Rand. "Some say an Aes Sedai will do anything to have what she wants."

ɪndɪɹiən loʊɝd hɛvi waɪɾ aɪbɹaʊz ən pɪɹd daʊn ɪz lɔŋ noʊz əɾ ɪz ti. ʌv oʊnli ævɝɪdʒ haɪt fəɹ ən il mæn, hi wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd baɪ hæf ə hænd, jɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm sim lɔŋ. ðə hiɾ ə ðə weɪst əpɪɹd tə hæv mɛltəɾ əweɪ ɛvɹi spɛɹ aʊns ə flɛʃ ən ə fju mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz. hɪz tʃikboʊnz stʊɾ aʊt ʃɑɹp, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ ɛmɹəlz sɛɾ ɪn keɪvz. "aɪ də nɑt laɪk spikɪŋ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ." hɪz dip, ɹɪtʃ vɔɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz ə ʃɑk, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət ɡɔn feɪs. "wʌɾ ɪz dʌn, ɪz dʌn. lɛt ðə waɪz wʌnz dil wɪð ðɛm."

Indirian lowered heavy white eyebrows and peered down his long nose at his tea. Of only average height for an Aiel man, he was shorter than Rand by half a hand, yet everything about him seemed long. The heat of the Waste appeared to have melted away every spare ounce of flesh and a few more besides. His cheekbones stood out sharp, and his eyes were emeralds set in caves. "I do not like speaking of Aes Sedai." His deep, rich voice was always a shock, coming from that gaunt face. "What is done, is done. Let the Wise Ones deal with them."

"bɛɾɝ tə spik ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɑɡz," dʒænwɪn sɛd maɪldli. wɪtʃ wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɡɹeɪɾ ə ʃɑk, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɪz fɪɹs feɪs. "wɪðɪn ə fju mʌnθs, lɛs ðən hæf ə jɪɹ ət moʊst, ɛvɹi ʃeɪɾoʊ hu kən bi wɪl bi dɛd - əɹ meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn." dʒʌs kəz ɪz vɔɪs wɑz sɑf dɪd nɑt min i wɑz. ði ʌðɝ tu nɑɾəd; mændələn smaɪld iɡɝli.

"Better to speak of the Shaido dogs," Janwin said mildly. Which was almost as great a shock, coming from his fierce face. "Within a few months, less than half a year at most, every Shaido who can be will be dead - or made gai'shain." Just because his voice was soft did not mean he was. The other two nodded; Mandelain smiled eagerly.

ðeɪ stɪl simd ʌnkənvɪnst. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd bɪn ðə pɹəfɛst ɹizən fəɹ ðɪs miɾɪŋ, ən noʊ lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ nɑt biɪŋ ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt. nɑɾ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt - ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd meɪd tʃɹʌbəl lɔŋ ɪnʌf - dʒʌs nɑɾ ɑn ðə seɪm peɪdʒ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɪz bʊk. ðeɪ dɪd pɹɛzən pɹɑbləmz, ðoʊ. θɹi klænz dʒɔɪnɪŋ tɪmoʊlənz maɪæɡoʊmə, ɔlɹɛɾi nɪɹ kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, maɪt wɛl bi eɪbəl tə də əz dʒænwɪn sɛd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u kəd nɑt bi meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn ən kəd nɑt bi kɪld. səm wɝ mɔɹ kɹɪɾɪkəl ðən ʌðɝz. "wʌɾ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz?" hi æskt.

They still seemed unconvinced. The Shaido had been the professed reason for this meeting, and no less important for not being the most important. Not unimportant - the Shaido had made trouble long enough - just not on the same page with the Aes Sedai in his book. They did present problems, though. Three clans joining Timolan's Miagoma, already near Kinslayer's Dagger, might well be able to do as Janwin said, but there were those who could not be made gai'shain and could not be killed. Some were more critical than others. "What of the Wise Ones?" he asked.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪkeɪm ənɹiɾəbəl; nɑɾ ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd də ðət soʊ wɛl əz il. feɪsɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ dɪd nɑt fɹaɪɾən ðɛm, nɑt wɛɹ ɪt ʃoʊd, ət list; noʊ wʌn kəɾ aʊtʃɹʌn dɛθ, soʊ il bɪlivd, ən ə hʌnʒɹəd ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ə ɹeɪdʒ kəd nɑt meɪk ə loʊn il loʊɝ ðə veɪl wʌns ɹeɪzd. bʌt lɝnɪŋ ðət waɪz wʌnz hæd teɪkən pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz hæd hɪɾ əm laɪk wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sʌn ɹaɪz baɪ naɪɾ ən ðə mun baɪ deɪ ɪn ə blʌd-ɹɛd skaɪ.

For a moment their faces became unreadable; not even Aes Sedai could do that so well as Aiel. Facing the One Power did not frighten them, not where it showed, at least; no one could outrun death, so Aiel believed, and a hundred Aes Sedai in a rage could not make a lone Aiel lower the veil once raised. But learning that Wise Ones had taken part in the fighting at Dumai's Wells had hit them like watching the sun rise by night and the moon by day in a blood-red sky.

"sɑɝɪn tɛlz mi ɔlmoʊst ɔl ə ðə waɪz wʌnz wɪl ɹʌn wɪð ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ," ɪndɪɹiən sɛɾ ət læst, ɹɪlʌktənli. sɑɝɪnd wɑz ðə waɪz wʌn u hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm fɹəm ɹɛd spɹɪŋz, klæn hoʊld ə ðə koʊdʒɹə. əɹ pɝhæps "fɑloʊd" wɑz nɑt ðə ɹaɪt wɝd; waɪz wʌnz sɛldəm dɪd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, moʊst ə ðə koʊdʒɹə waɪz wʌnz, ən ðə ʃiæn ən ðə dɛɹn, wəd ɡoʊ nɔɹθ wɪð ðə spɪɹz. "ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz wɪl bi . . . dɛlt wɪð . . . baɪ waɪz wʌnz." hɪz maʊθ twɪstəd wɪð dɪsɡʌst.

"Sarinde tells me almost all of the Wise Ones will run with the algai'd'siswai," Indirian said at last, reluctantly. Sarinde was the Wise One who had followed him from Red Springs, clan hold of the Codarra. Or perhaps "followed" was not the right word; Wise Ones seldom did. In any case, most of the Codarra Wise Ones, and the Shiande and the Daryne, would go north with the spears. "The Shaido Wise Ones will be . . . dealt with . . . by Wise Ones." His mouth twisted with disgust.

"ɔl θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ." dʒænwɪnz vɔɪs wɑz ivən sɑftɝ ðən juʒəwəl. hi bɪlivd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑn tə. waɪz wʌnz teɪkɪŋ pɑɹɾ ɪn bæɾəl vaɪəleɪɾɪd kʌstəm əz oʊld əz ði il.

"All things change." Janwin's voice was even softer than usual. He believed, but he did not want to. Wise Ones taking part in battle violated custom as old as the Aiel.

mændələn sɛɾ ɪz kʌp daʊn wɪð ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd kɛɹ. "kɔɹhuən wɪʃɪz tə si dʒɛɹ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə dʒɹim ɛnz, ən soʊ də aɪ." laɪk beɪl ən ɹəɑɹk, hi hæd tu waɪvz; ði ʌðɝ tʃifs hæɾ oʊnli wʌn itʃ, ɪksɛp tɪmoʊlən, bʌɾ ə wɪɾoʊd tʃif sɛldəm ɹɪmeɪn soʊ lɔŋ. ðə waɪz wʌnz sɔ tə ðəɾ ɪf i dɪd nɑt. "wɪl ɛni ʌv əs ɛvɝ si ðə sʌn ɹaɪz əɡɛn ɪn ðə θɹi-foʊld lænd?"

Mandelain set his cup down with exaggerated care. "Corehuin wishes to see Jair again before the dream ends, and so do I." Like Bael and Rhuarc, he had two wives; the other chiefs had only one each, except Timolan, but a widowed chief seldom remained so long. The Wise Ones saw to that if he did not. "Will any of us ever see the sun rise again in the Three-fold Land?"

"aɪ hoʊp soʊ," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. əz ðə plaʊ bɹeɪks ði ɝθ ʃæl i bɹeɪk ðə laɪvz ə mɛn, ən ɔl ðət wɑz ʃæl bi kənsumd ɪn ðə faɪɝ ə hɪz aɪz. ðə tʃɹʌmpəts ʌv wɔɹ ʃæl saʊn əɾ ɪz fʊtstɛps, ðə ɹeɪvənz fiɾ əɾ ɪz vɔɪs, ən i ʃæl wɛɹ ə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz. ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɡeɪv lɪɾəl hoʊp fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp vɪktɝi oʊvɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən oʊnli ə tʃæns ə ðæt. ðə pɹɑfəsi ʌv ɹɪɾiən, ði il pɹɑfəsi, sɛɾ i wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm. ðə bliknəs swɛp θɹu ðə klænz kəz ə hɪm ən eɪntʃən kʌstəmz wɝ ɹɪpt əpɑɹt. ivən wɪθaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, smɔl wʌndɝ ɪf səm tʃifs pɑndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt tə fɑloʊ ɹænd ælθɹ, dʒɹæɡənz ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz əɹ noʊ. "aɪ hoʊp soʊ."

"I hope so," Rand said slowly. As the plow breaks the earth shall he break the lives of men, and all that was shall be consumed in the fire of his eyes. The trumpets of war shall sound at his footsteps, the ravens feed at his voice, and he shall wear a crown of swords. The Prophecies of the Dragon gave little hope for anything except victory over the Dark One, and only a chance of that. The Prophecy of Rhuidean, the Aiel Prophecy, said he would destroy them. The bleakness swept through the clans because of him and ancient customs were ripped apart. Even without the Aes Sedai, small wonder if some chiefs pondered whether they were right to follow Rand al'Thor, Dragons on his arms or no. "I hope so."

"meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, ɹænd ælθɹ," ɪndɪɹiən sɛd.

"May you always find water and shade, Rand al'Thor," Indirian said.

æftɝ ðeɪ lɛft, ɹænd sæt fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪndə hɪz kʌp, faɪndɪŋ noʊ ænsɝz ɪn ðə dɑɹk ti. faɪnəli hi sɛɾ ɪt bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɹeɪ ən pʊʃt ɪz slivz daʊn. mɛɹænəz aɪz wɝ ɪntɛn ɑn hɪm, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl aʊɾ ɪz θɔts. ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns əbaʊt hɝ, tu. hi hæd toʊld əɹ tə steɪ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ənlɛs ʃi kəd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz. daʊtləs ʃi sɔ noʊ ɹizən waɪ ʃi ʃəd nɑt kʌm aʊt naʊ ðə klæn tʃifs wɝ ɡɔn. kʌm aʊt, ən dɪɡ aʊt wʌt hæd bɪn sɛd.

After they left, Rand sat frowning into his cup, finding no answers in the dark tea. Finally he set it beside the tray and pushed his sleeves down. Merana's eyes were intent on him, as if trying to pull out his thoughts. There was a hint of impatience about her, too. He had told her to stay in the corner unless she could hear voices. Doubtless she saw no reason why she should not come out now the clan chiefs were gone. Come out, and dig out what had been said.

"du jə θɪŋk ðeɪ bɪliv aɪ dæns ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹɪŋz?" hi sɛd.

"Do you think they believe I dance on Aes Sedai strings?" he said.

jʌŋ nɛɹɪʃmə ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd, bʌɾ i hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə bɔɪ faɪv əɹ sɪks jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ. hi ɡlænst ət mɛɹænə əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ði ænsɝ, ən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ . . . də nɑt noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."

Young Narishma gave a start. In truth, he was a little older than Rand, but he had the look of a boy five or six years younger. He glanced at Merana as though she had the answer, and shifted his shoulders uncomfortably. "I . . . do not know, my Lord Dragon."

dæʃivə blɪŋkt ən stɑp mɝmɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. tɪltɪŋ ɪz hɛd, bɝd-laɪk, hi aɪd ɹænd saɪdweɪz. "dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪ?"

Dashiva blinked and stopped murmuring to himself. Tilting his head, bird-like, he eyed Rand sideways. "Does it matter, so long as they obey?"

"ɪt mæɾɝz," ɹænd sɛd. dæʃivə ʃɹʌɡd, ən nɛɹɪʃmə fɹaʊn θɔtfəli; niðɝ sim tə ʌndɝstænd, jɛt meɪbi nɛɹɪʃmə kəd kʌm tə.

"It matters," Rand said. Dashiva shrugged, and Narishma frowned thoughtfully; neither seemed to understand, yet maybe Narishma could come to.

mæps lɪɾɝd ðə stoʊn flɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðə θɹoʊn ɑn ɪts deɪz, ɹoʊld əɹ foʊldəɾ əɹ spɹɛɾ aʊt wɛɹ i hæd lɛf ðɛm. hi ʃɪftəd səm wɪð ðə toʊ ʌv ɪz but. soʊ mʌtʃ tə bi dʒʌɡəld ət wʌns. nɔɹðɝn kɛɹhin ən ðə maʊntənz kɔl kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, ən ðə ɹidʒən ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi. ɪljən ən ðə pleɪnz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ aʊt tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ði aɪlən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ɔl ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz. ɡildən ən pɑɹɾ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə. muvmən ən kʌlɝ ɪn ɪz hɛd. luz θɝɪn moʊn ən læft ɪn ðə dɪstəns, feɪn mæd mʌɾɝz ə kɪlɪŋ ði æʃəmən, kɪlɪŋ ðə fɔɹseɪkən. kɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. ɑlɑnə stɑpt wipɪŋ, kʌɾɪŋ æŋɡwɪʃ səbdud bɪniθ ə θɪn θɹɛɾ ʌv æŋɡɝ. ɹænd skɹʌbd ɪz hænz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, pɹɛsɪŋ hɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tɛmpəlz. wʌt hæɾ ɪt bɪn laɪk tə bi əloʊn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz oʊn skʌl? hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl.

Maps littered the stone floor behind the throne on its dais, rolled or folded or spread out where he had left them. He shifted some with the toe of his boot. So much to be juggled at once. Northern Cairhien and the mountains called Kinslayer's Dagger, and the region around the city. Illian and the Plains of Maredo out to Far Madding. The island of Tar Valon and all the surrounding towns and villages. Ghealdan and part of Amadicia. Movement and color in his head. Lews Therin moaned and laughed in the distance, faint mad mutters of killing the Asha'man, killing the Forsaken. Killing himself. Alanna stopped weeping, cutting anguish subdued beneath a thin thread of anger. Rand scrubbed his hands through his hair, pressing hard against his temples. What had it been like to be alone inside his own skull? He could not recall.

wʌn ə ðə tɔl dɔɹz oʊpən tə ədmɪt wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz u wɝ stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ɹaɪəlɪn, wɪð vɪvəd jɛloʊ-ɹɛd hɛɹ ən ə ɡɹɪn fəɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə əpɪɹ plʌmp. fəɹ ə meɪɾən, ɛniweɪ. "bɹəleɪn sɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ ən ənʊɹə lɹəsən wɪʃ tə si ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn," ʃi ənaʊnst. hɝ vɔɪs wɛn fɹəm wɔɹm ən fɹɛnli ɑn ðə fɝs neɪm tə koʊld ən flæɾ ɑn ðə sɛkənd wɪθaʊt dɪstɝbɪŋ əɹ ɡɹɪn.

One of the tall doors opened to admit one of the Maidens who were standing guard in the corridor. Riallin, with vivid yellow-red hair and a grin for everything, actually managed to appear plump. For a Maiden, anyway. "Berelain sur Paendrag and Annoura Larisen wish to see the Car'a'carn," she announced. Her voice went from warm and friendly on the first name to cold and flat on the second without disturbing her grin.

ɹænd saɪɾ ən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə lɛɾ əm ɛntɝ, bʌt bɹəleɪn dɪd nɑt weɪt. ʃi stɔɹmd ɪn, ə sʌmwʌt kɑmɝ ənʊɹə əɾ əɹ hilz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃaɪd slaɪtli ət ðə saɪɾ ə dæʃivə ən nɛɹɪʃmə, ən stɛɹd kjʊɹiəsli wən ʃi sɔ mɛɹænə stændɪŋ ɪn əɹ kɔɹnɝ. nɑt soʊ bɹəleɪn.

Rand sighed and opened his mouth to let them enter, but Berelain did not wait. She stormed in, a somewhat calmer Annoura at her heels. The Aes Sedai shied slightly at the sight of Dashiva and Narishma, and stared curiously when she saw Merana standing in her corner. Not so Berelain.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?" ʃi dɪmændəd, bɹændɪʃɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ i hæd hæd dɪlɪvɝd tə hɝ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ʃi stɔkt əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ tə ʃeɪk ɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz. "waɪ æm aɪ tə ɹɪtɝn tə min? aɪ hæv ɡʌvɝnd wɛl hɪɹ ɪn jəɹ neɪm, ən jə noʊ ɪt. aɪ kəd nɑt stɑp koʊləveɪɪɹ hævɪŋ hɝsɛlf kɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ət list aɪ stɑpt əɹ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə lɔz jə meɪd. waɪ æm aɪ tə bi sɛn əweɪ? ən waɪ æm aɪ toʊl baɪ lɛɾɝ? nɑt tə maɪ feɪs. baɪ lɛɾɝ! θæŋk fəɹ maɪ sɝvəsəz ən dɪsmɪs laɪk ə klɝk huz dʌn kəlɛktɪŋ ðə tæksəz!"

"What is the meaning of this, my Lord Dragon?" she demanded, brandishing the letter he had had delivered to her this morning. She stalked across the floor to shake it under his nose. "Why am I to return to Mayene? I have governed well here in your name, and you know it. I could not stop Colavaere having herself crowned, but at least I stopped her changing the laws you made. Why am I to be sent away? And why am I told by letter? Not to my face. By letter! Thanked for my services and dismissed like a clerk who's done collecting the taxes!"

ivən fjʊɹiəs, ðə fɝst ə min wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl wɪmən ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. blæk hɛɹ fɛl ɪn ʃaɪnɪŋ weɪvz tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, fɹeɪmɪŋ ə feɪs tə meɪk ə blaɪn mæn stɛɹ. ə mæn kəɾ izəli dʒɹaʊn ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz. tədeɪ ʃi wɔɹ ʃɪmɝɪŋ sɪlvɝ sɪlk, θɪn ən klɪŋɪŋ ən mɔɹ suɾəd tə ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ə lʌvɝ ɪn pɹaɪvət. ɪn fækt, hæd ðə nɛklaɪn bɪn ə hɛɹ loʊɝ, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə wɛɹ ðə dʒɹɛs ɪn pʌblɪk. əz ɪt wɑz, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi ʃʊd. hi hæd toʊl hɪmsɛlf wən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðət lɛɾɝ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz kəz i hæd tu mʌtʃ tə də ən noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɝ. ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, hi ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ tu mʌtʃ; fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi hæd bɪɡʌn filɪŋ ðət ðət wɑz - nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɹɔŋ, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst.

Even furious, the First of Mayene was one of the most beautiful women Rand had ever seen. Black hair fell in shining waves to her shoulders, framing a face to make a blind man stare. A man could easily drown in her dark eyes. Today she wore shimmering silver silk, thin and clinging and more suited to entertaining a lover in private. In fact, had the neckline been a hair lower, she would not have been able to wear the dress in public. As it was, he was not sure she should. He had told himself when writing that letter that it was because he had too much to do and no time for arguing with her. The truth was, he enjoyed looking at her too much; for some reason, he had begun feeling that that was - not exactly wrong, but almost.

əz sun əz ʃi əpɪɹd, luz θɝɪn ɡeɪv oʊvɝ ɹæntɪŋ tə hʌm sɔfli, ðə weɪ hi dɪd wən ædmaɪɹɪŋ ə wʊmən. əbɹʌpli ɹænd ɹilaɪzd i wɑz θʌmɪŋ ɪz ɝloʊb, ən fɛlt ə ʃɑk. ɪnstɪŋktɪvli, hi nu ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls luz θɝɪn dɪd wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, laɪk ðə hʌmɪŋ. hi pʊʃt ɪz hæn tə hɪz saɪd, bʌt fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪt wɑntəd tə ɹaɪz tə hɪz ɪɹ əɡɛn.

As soon as she appeared, Lews Therin gave over ranting to hum softly, the way he did when admiring a woman. Abruptly Rand realized he was thumbing his earlobe, and felt a shock. Instinctively, he knew that was something else Lews Therin did without thinking, like the humming. He pushed his hand to his side, but for an instant it wanted to rise to his ear again.

bɝn ju, ðɪs ɪz maɪ bɑɾi! ðə θɔt wɑz ə snɑɹl. maɪn! luz θɝɪnz hʌm stɑpt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən kənfjuʒən; wɪθaʊɾ ə saʊnd, ðə dɛd mæn flɛd, bæk ɪndə ðə dipəst ʃædoʊz ə ɹændz bɹeɪn.

Burn you, this is my body! The thought was a snarl. Mine! Lews Therin's hum stopped in surprise, and confusion; without a sound, the dead man fled, back into the deepest shadows of Rand's brain.

ɹændz saɪləns hæɾ ən ɪfɛkt. bɹəleɪn loʊɝd ðə lɛɾɝ, ən əɹ æŋɡɝ ɹəsiɾəd. ə lɪɾəl. aɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪz, ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ðət hiɾəd ɪz tʃiks. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən - "

Rand's silence had an effect. Berelain lowered the letter, and her anger receded. A little. Eyes fixed on his, she drew a deep breath that heated his cheeks. "My Lord Dragon - "

"ju noʊ waɪ," hi kʌɾ ɪn. lʊkɪŋ oʊnli əɾ əɹ aɪz wɑz nɑɾ izi. ɑdli, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ mɪn wɝ ðɛɹ. vɛɹi ɑd. hɝ vjuɪŋz wəd bi noʊ hɛlp naʊ. "wɛn jə ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðət si foʊk ʃɪp ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðəɹ wɑz ə fɛloʊ weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑk wɪð ə naɪf."

"You know why," he cut in. Looking only at her eyes was not easy. Oddly, he found himself wishing Min were there. Very odd. Her viewings would be no help now. "When you returned from that Sea Folk ship this morning, there was a fellow waiting on the dock with a knife."

bɹəleɪn tɔst əɹ hɛd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "hi keɪm noʊ kloʊsɝ ðən θɹi stɛps. aɪ wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ ə dʌzən ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz ən lɔɹd kæptən ɡælɛn." nɹɛl hæd lɛd səm ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz tə dəməaɪz wɛlz, bʌt ɡælɛn kəmændəd ðə ɡɑɹdz əz ə hoʊl. ʃi hæɾ eɪt hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm ɪn ðə sɪɾi əsaɪd fɹəm ðoʊz u ɹɪtɝnd wɪð nɹɛl. "ju ɪkspɛk mi tə tɝn teɪl kəz ʌv ə kʌtpɝs?"

Berelain tossed her head contemptuously. "He came no closer than three steps. I was accompanied by a dozen of the Winged Guards and Lord Captain Gallenne." Nurelle had led some of the Winged Guards to Dumai's Wells, but Gallenne commanded the Guards as a whole. She had eight hundred of them in the city aside from those who returned with Nurelle. "You expect me to turn tail because of a cutpurse?"

"doʊn pleɪ ðə ful," hi ɡɹaʊld. "ə kʌtpɝs, wɪð ə dʌzən soʊlʒɝz ɝaʊn ju?" kʌlɝ flɛɹɾ ɪn əɹ tʃiks; ʃi nu, ɔl ɹaɪt. hi ɡeɪv əɹ noʊ tʃæns fəɹ pɹoʊɾɛsts əɹ ɛkspləneɪʃənz əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ fulɪʃnəs. "dɑbɹeɪn tɛlz mi hiz ɔlɹɛɾi hɝd wɪspɝz ɪn ðə pæləs ðət jə bɪtʃɹeɪd koʊləveɪɪɹ. ðoʊz u səpɔɹɾəd əɹ maɪt bi əfɹeɪd tə seɪ bu tə mi, bʌt ðəl peɪ tə hæv ə naɪf stʌk ɪndə ju." ən feɪl, tu, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə dɑbɹeɪn; ðət wɑz biɪŋ teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv. "bʌt ðeɪ woʊn əv ə tʃæns, kəz jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə min. dɑbɹeɪn wɪl teɪk jəɹ pleɪs hɪɹ əntɪl ɪleɪn kleɪmz ðə sʌn θɹoʊn."

"Don't play the fool," he growled. "A cutpurse, with a dozen soldiers around you?" Color flared in her cheeks; she knew, all right. He gave her no chance for protests or explanations or any other foolishness. "Dobraine tells me he's already heard whispers in the palace that you betrayed Colavaere. Those who supported her might be afraid to say boo to me, but they'll pay to have a knife stuck into you." And Faile, too, according to Dobraine; that was being taken care of. "But they won't have a chance, because you are going back to Mayene. Dobraine will take your place here until Elayne claims the Sun Throne."

ʃi spləɾɝd əz ɪf i hæd dʌmp koʊld wɔɾɝ daʊn əɹ dʒɹɛs. hɝ aɪz ɡɹu deɪnʒɝəsli lɑɹdʒ. hi hæd bɪn ɡlæd wən ʃi stɑp biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm, bʌt naʊ hi wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ. əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɪksploʊd, ənʊɹə tʌtʃt əɹ ɑɹm, ən əɹ hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊnd. ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lɔŋ lʊk, ən bɹəleɪnz spʌɾɝz səbsaɪɾɪd. ʃi smuðd əɹ skɝts ən vɪɡɝəsli skwɛɹɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ɹænd lʊkt əweɪ heɪstəli.

She spluttered as if he had dumped cold water down her dress. Her eyes grew dangerously large. He had been glad when she stopped being afraid of him, but now he was not so sure. As she opened her mouth to explode, Annoura touched her arm, and her head whipped around. They exchanged a long look, and Berelain's sputters subsided. She smoothed her skirts and vigorously squared her shoulders. Rand looked away hastily.

mɛɹænə hʌvɝɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wɔɹd. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi hæd stɛpt əkɹɔs ən dɑdʒ bæk - haʊ ɛls kəd ʃi stæn ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌt ʃi kəd nɑt pɑsəbli dɪtɛkt? wən ɪz hɛd tɝnd, ʃi muv bækwɝɾ əntɪl ʃi ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃt ðə wɔlz, hɝ aɪz nɛvɝ livɪŋ hɪm. baɪ hɝ feɪs, ʃi wʊɾə pɔɹɾ ɪz ti ɛvɹi deɪ fəɹ tɛn jɪɹz tə hɪɹ wʌt wɑz biɪŋ sɛd.

Merana hovered at the edge of the ward. He wondered whether she had stepped across and dodged back - how else could she stand right on top of what she could not possibly detect? When his head turned, she moved backward until she almost touched the walls, her eyes never leaving him. By her face, she would have poured his tea every day for ten years to hear what was being said.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," bɹəleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ, "ðɛɹ ɪz stɪl ðə mæɾɝ ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz wɔɹm hʌni; ðə kɝv ə hɝ lɪps wʊɾə spɑɹk θɔts ə kɪsəz ɪn ə stoʊn. "ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs hɑɹɪn ɪz nɑt pliz tə bi lɛf sɪɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ ʃɪp soʊ lɔŋ. aɪ hæv vɪzəɾəd wɪð əɹ ə nʌmbɝ ə taɪmz. aɪ kən smuð ðə dɪfəkəltiz ðɛɹ, wɪtʃ aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn kæn. aɪ bɪliv ðə si foʊk ɑɹ vaɪɾəl tə jə wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən mɛnʃən ðɛm. jə ɑɹ kɹuʃəl ɪn ðɛɹ pɹɑfəsiz, ðoʊ ðeɪ sim ɹɪlʌktən tə seɪ ɪɡzækli haʊ."

"My Lord Dragon," Berelain said, smiling, "there is still the matter of the Atha'an Miere." Her voice was warm honey; the curve of her lips would have sparked thoughts of kisses in a stone. "The Wavemistress Harine is not pleased to be left sitting on her ship so long. I have visited with her a number of times. I can smooth the difficulties there, which I hardly think Lord Dobraine can. I believe the Sea Folk are vital to you whether or not the Prophecies of the Dragon mention them. You are crucial in their prophecies, though they seem reluctant to say exactly how."

ɹænd stɛɹd. waɪ wɑz ʃi stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd tə kip ə dɪfəkəl dʒɑb ðət hæɾ ɔfɝd fju θæŋks fɹəm kɛɹhinɪn ivən bɪfɔɹ səm bɪɡæn wɑntɪŋ tə kɪl hɝ? ʃi wɑz ə ɹulɝ, juz tə dilɪŋ wɪð ɹulɝz ən ɛmbəsiz, nɑt stʃɹit θʌɡz ən naɪvz ɪn ðə dɑɹk. wɔɹm hʌni əɹ noʊ wɔɹm hʌni, ɪt wɑz nɑt fəɹ ɛni dɪzaɪɝ tə steɪ nɪɹ ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃi hæd . . . wɛl, ɔfɝd hɝsɛlf tə hɪm . . . wʌns, bʌt ðə hɑɹd fækt wɑz ðət min wɑz ə smɔl kʌntʃɹi, ən bɹəleɪn juzd əɹ bjuɾi əz ə mæn wəɾ ə sɔɹd, tə kip əɹ læn fɹəm biɪŋ swɑloʊd baɪ ɪts mɔɹ paʊɝfəl neɪbɝ, tiɹ. ən ðɛɹ, sɪmpəl əz ðæt, hi hæɾ ɪt. "bɹəleɪn, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɛls aɪ kən də tə ɡɛɹənti min fəɹ ju, bʌɾ əl ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɛni - " kʌlɝz swɝl soʊ stʃɹɔŋli ɪn ɪz hɛd ðəɾ ɪz tʌŋ fɹoʊz. luz θɝɪn kækəld. ə wʊmən u noʊz ðə deɪnʒɝ ən ɪzən əfɹeɪɾ ɪz ə tʃɹɛʒɝ oʊnli ə mædmæn wəd spɝn.

Rand stared. Why was she struggling so hard to keep a difficult job that had offered few thanks from Cairhienin even before some began wanting to kill her? She was a ruler, used to dealing with rulers and embassies, not street thugs and knives in the dark. Warm honey or no warm honey, it was not for any desire to stay near Rand al'Thor. She had . . . well, offered herself to him . . . once, but the hard fact was that Mayene was a small country, and Berelain used her beauty as a man would a sword, to keep her land from being swallowed by its more powerful neighbor, Tear. And there, simple as that, he had it. "Berelain, I don't know what else I can do to guarantee Mayene for you, but I will write out any - " Colors swirled so strongly in his head that his tongue froze. Lews Therin cackled. A woman who knows the danger and isn't afraid is a treasure only a madman would spurn.

"ɡɛɹəntiz." bliknəs ɪnɡʌlf hʌni, ən æŋɡɝ bʌbəld əɡɛn, koʊl ðɪs taɪm. ənʊɹə plʌkt ət bɹəleɪnz sliv, bʌt ʃi peɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ hid. "waɪl aɪ sɪɾ ɪn min wɪð jəɹ ɡɛɹəntiz, ʌðɝz wɪl sɝv ju. ðəl æsk ðɛɹ ɹɪwɔɹdz, ən ðə sɝvəs aɪ dɪd hɪɹ wɪl bi feɪɾəd ən oʊld, waɪl ðɛɹz ɪz bɹaɪɾ ən nu. ɪf ðə haɪ lɔɹd wɪɹɑmɑn ɡɪvz jə ɪljən ən æsks min ɪn ɹɪtɝn, wʌt wɪl jə seɪ? ɪf i ɡɪvz jə mʊɹændi, ən ɔltɑɹə, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ klɪɹ tə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən?"

"Guarantees." Bleakness engulfed honey, and anger bubbled again, cold this time. Annoura plucked at Berelain's sleeve, but she paid the Aes Sedai no heed. "While I sit in Mayene with your guarantees, others will serve you. They will ask their rewards, and the service I did here will be faded and old, while theirs is bright and new. If the High Lord Weiramon gives you Illian and asks Mayene in return, what will you say? If he gives you Murandy, and Altara, and everything clear to the Aryth Ocean?"

"wɪl jə sɝv ɪf ɪt stɪl minz livɪŋ?" hi æskt kwaɪətli. "ju wɪl bi aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt, bʌt nɑɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ maɪnd." luz θɝɪn læft əɡɛn, ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət ɹænd nɪɹli blʌʃt. hi ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ, bʌt səmtaɪmz ðə θɪŋz luz θɝɪn θɔt. . . .

"Will you serve if it still means leaving?" he asked quietly. "You will be out of my sight, but not out of my mind." Lews Therin laughed again, in such a way that Rand nearly blushed. He enjoyed looking, but sometimes the things Lews Therin thought. . . .

bɹəleɪn kənsɪɾɝd ɪm wɪð stʌbɝn aɪz, ən i kəɾ ɔl bʌt si ðə kwɛstʃənz biɪŋ toʊɾɪd ʌp bɪhaɪn ənʊɹəz, ðə kɛɹfəl tʃuzɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ tə æsk.

Berelain considered him with stubborn eyes, and he could all but see the questions being toted up behind Annoura's, the careful choosing of which to ask.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən əɡɛn fəɹ ɹaɪəlɪn. "æn ɛɛs sədaɪ hæz kʌm tə si ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn." ʃi mænədʒ tə saʊn koʊld ən ənsɝɾən ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "hɝ neɪm ɪz kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn." ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋli hænsəm wʊmən swɛpt ɪn ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ, aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ə bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛɾ ən dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɡoʊld ɔɹnəməns, ən ɪt simd ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæpən ət wʌns.

The door opened again for Riallin. "An Aes Sedai has come to see the Car'a'carn." She managed to sound cold and uncertain at the same time. "Her name is Cadsuane Melaidhrin." A strikingly handsome woman swept in right behind her, iron-gray hair gathered in a bun atop her head and decorated with dangling gold ornaments, and it seemed everything happened at once.

"aɪ θɔt jə wɝ dɛd," ənʊɹə ɡæspt, aɪz nɪɹli stɑɹɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd.

"I thought you were dead," Annoura gasped, eyes nearly starting out of her head.

mɛɹænə dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə wɔɹd, hænz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt. "noʊ, kædzueɪn!" ʃi skɹimd. "ju mʌsnt hɑɹm hɪm! jə mʌs nɑt!"

Merana darted through the ward, hands outstretched. "No, Cadsuane!" she screamed. "You mustn't harm him! You must not!"

ɹændz skɪn tɪŋɡəld əz sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə ɹum ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, pɝhæps mɔɹ ðən wʌn, ən swɪfli muvɪŋ wɛl klɪɹ ə bɹəleɪn, hi siz hoʊld ə ðə sɔɹs, flʌɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð seɪɾɪn, filɪŋ ɪt fɪl ði æʃəmən. dæʃivəz feɪs twɪtʃt əz i ɡlɛɹd fɹəm wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ənʌðɝ. dɪspaɪt ðə paʊɝ i hɛld, nɛɹɪʃmə ɡɹæspt ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt wɪð boʊθ hænz ən əsum ðə stæns kɔld lɛpɝɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹi, ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə dʒɹɔɪŋ. luz θɝɪn snɑɹəld ə kɪlɪŋ ən dɛθ, kɪl əm ɔl, kɪl əm naʊ. ɹaɪəlɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ veɪl, ʃaʊɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ən sʌɾənli ə dʌzən meɪɾənz wɝ ɪn ðə ɹum, veɪlɪŋ, spɪɹz ɹɛɾi. ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ðət bɪɹ-leɪn stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ əz ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn hæd ɡɔn mæd.

Rand's skin tingled as someone in the room embraced saidar, perhaps more than one, and swiftly moving well clear of Berelain, he seized hold of the Source, flooding himself with saidin, feeling it fill the Asha'man. Dashiva's face twitched as he glared from one Aes Sedai to another. Despite the Power he held, Narishma grasped his sword hilt with both hands and assumed the stance called Leopard in the Tree, on the brink of drawing. Lews Therin snarled of killing and death, kill them all, kill them now. Riallin raised her veil, shouting something, and suddenly a dozen Maidens were in the room, veiling, spears ready. It was hardly surprising that Bere-lain stood gaping as if everyone had gone mad.

fəɹ sʌmwʌn u hæd kɑzd ɔl ðæt, ðɪs kædzueɪn simd ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ʌnəfɛktɪd. ʃi lʊkt ət ðə meɪɾənz ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ɡoʊldən stɑɹz ən munz ən bɝdz sweɪɪŋ dʒɛnli. "tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɹoʊ disən ɹoʊzɪz ɪn nɔɹðɝn ɡildən meɪ bi nɪɹ tə dɛθ, ənʊɹə," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌɾ ɪts nɑt kwaɪt ðə ɡɹeɪv. oʊ, də kɑm daʊn, mɛɹænə, bɪfɔɹ jə fɹaɪɾən sʌmwʌn. wʌn wəd θɪŋk jə wʊɾə ɡɹoʊn ə lɪɾəl lɛs ɪksaɪɾəbəl sɪns pʊɾɪŋ ɔf nɑvəs waɪt."

For someone who had caused all that, this Cadsuane seemed remarkably unaffected. She looked at the Maidens and shook her head, golden stars and moons and birds swaying gently. "Trying to grow decent roses in northern Ghealdan may be near to death, Annoura," she said dryly, "but it is not quite the grave. Oh, do calm down, Merana, before you frighten someone. One would think you would have grown a little less excitable since putting off novice white."

mɛɹænə oʊpən ən kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ, lʊkɪŋ əbæʃt ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ən ðə tɪŋɡəlɪŋ vænɪʃt əbɹʌpli. ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹilis seɪɾɪn, ðoʊ, nɔɹ dɪd ði æʃəmən.

Merana opened and closed her mouth, looking abashed of all things, and the tingling vanished abruptly. Rand did not release saidin, though, nor did the Asha'man.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" hi dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ ədʒɑ?" ɹɛd, baɪ mɛɹænəz ɹiækʃən, bʌt fəɹ ə ɹɛd sɪstɝ sɪmpli tə wɔk ɪn laɪk ðɪs, əloʊn, wəd ɹikwaɪɝ suəsaɪɾəl kɝədʒ. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?"

"Who are you?" he demanded. "What Ajah?" Red, by Merana's reaction, but for a Red sister simply to walk in like this, alone, would require suicidal courage. "What do you want?"

kædzueɪnz ɡeɪz lɪŋɡɝɾ ɑn ɪm fəɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə moʊmənt, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. mɛɹænəz lɪps pɑɹɾəd, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən lʊkt ət hɝ, ɹeɪzɪŋ wʌn aɪbɹaʊ, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. mɛɹænə æktʃəli  ɹɛɾənd ən loʊɝɾ əɹ aɪz. ənʊɹə wɑz stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə nukʌmɝ əz ɪf əɾ ə ɡoʊst. əɹ ə dʒaɪənt.

Cadsuane's gaze lingered on him for no more than a moment, and she did not answer. Merana's lips parted, but the gray-haired woman looked at her, raising one eyebrow, and that was that. Merana actually reddened and lowered her eyes. Annoura was still staring at the newcomer as if at a ghost. Or a giant.

wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd, kædzueɪn swɛpt əkɹɔs ðə ɹum tə ðə tu æʃəmən, dɑɹk ɡɹin dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts swɪʃɪŋ. ɹænd wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðə filɪŋ ðət ʃi ɔlweɪz muvd ɪn ðət ɹʌʃɪŋ ɡlaɪd, ɡɹeɪsfəl jɛt weɪstɪŋ noʊ taɪm ən əlaʊɪŋ nʌθɪŋ tə ɪmpid hɝ. dæʃivə stɛɹɾ əɹ ʌp ən daʊn, ən snɪɹd. ɔlðoʊ lʊkɪŋ ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə feɪs, ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi əpɪɹd tə noʊɾəs nɛɹɪʃməz hænz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd wən ʃi pʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ʌndɝ ɪz tʃɪn, muvɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd bɪfɔɹ i kəd dʒɝk bæk.

Without a word, Cadsuane swept across the room to the two Asha'man, dark green divided skirts swishing. Rand was beginning to get the feeling that she always moved in that rushing glide, graceful yet wasting no time and allowing nothing to impede her. Dashiva stared her up and down, and sneered. Although looking him straight in the face, she did not seem to notice, any more than she appeared to notice Narishma's hands on his sword when she put a finger under his chin, moving his head from side to side before he could jerk back.

"wʌt lʌvli aɪz," ʃi mɝmɝd. nɛɹɪʃmə blɪŋkt ənsɝteɪnli, ən dæʃivəz snɪɹ tɝn tə ə ɡɹɪn, bʌɾ ə næsti wʌn ðət meɪɾ ɪz fɔɹmɝ smɝk laɪthɑɹɾɪd ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən.

"What lovely eyes," she murmured. Narishma blinked uncertainly, and Dashiva's sneer turned to a grin, but a nasty one that made his former smirk lighthearted in comparison.

"du nʌθɪŋ," ɹænd snæpt. dæʃivə hæd ðə ɡɔl tə ɡlaʊɝ əɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ sʌlənli pɹɛsɪŋ ə fɪs tə hɪz tʃɛst ɪn ðə səlut ði æʃəmən juzd. "wʌt dʒju wɑn hɪɹ, kædzueɪn," ɹænd wɛn ɑn. "lʊk ət mi, bɝn ju!"

"Do nothing," Rand snapped. Dashiva had the gall to glower at him before sullenly pressing a fist to his chest in the salute the Asha'man used. "What do you want here, Cadsuane," Rand went on. "Look at me, burn you!"

ʃi dɪd, tɝnɪŋ dʒʌst əɹ hɛd. "soʊ jə ɑɹ ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. aɪɾ əv θɔɾ ivən ə tʃaɪld laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn cʊɾə tɔt jə ə fju mænɝz."

She did, turning just her head. "So you are Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn. I'd have thought even a child like Moiraine could have taught you a few manners."

ɹaɪəlɪn pʊt ðə spɪɹ fɹəm əɹ ɹaɪt hænd wɪð ðoʊz klʌtʃt bɪhaɪn əɹ bʌkəlɝ ən flæʃt meɪɾən hæntɔk. fəɹ wʌns, nʌn læft. fəɹ wʌns, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə tɔk wɑz nɑɾ ə dʒoʊk əbaʊt hɪm. "bi izi, ɹaɪəlɪn," hi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hænd. "ɔl ə ju, bi izi."

Riallin put the spear from her right hand with those clutched behind her buckler and flashed Maiden handtalk. For once, none laughed. For once, Rand was sure the talk was not a joke about him. "Be easy, Riallin," he said, raising a hand. "All of you, be easy."

kædzueɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə baɪpleɪ tu, dɝɛktɪŋ ə smaɪl tə bɹəleɪn. "soʊ ðɪs ɪz jəɹ bɹəleɪn, ənʊɹə. ʃiz mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl ðən aɪ hæd hɝd." ðə kɝtsi ʃi meɪd, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd, wɑz kwaɪt dip, jɛt sʌmhaʊ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ʌv oʊbaɪsəns, noʊ hɪn ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn ɛni weɪ lɛs. ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz ə kɝɾəsi, noʊ mɔɹ. "maɪ leɪɾi fɝst ə min, aɪ mʌst spik wɪð ðɪs jʌŋ mæn, ən aɪ wəd ɹɪteɪn jəɹ ædvaɪzɝ. aɪv hɝd juv ʌndɝteɪkən mɛni duɾiz hɪɹ. aɪ wəd nɑt kip jə fɹəm ðɛm." ɪt wɑz əz klɪɹ ə dɪsmɪsəl əz kəd bi, ʃɔɹɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɔɹ oʊpən.

Cadsuane ignored the byplay too, directing a smile to Berelain. "So this is your Berelain, Annoura. She is more beautiful than I had heard." The curtsy she made, bowing her head, was quite deep, yet somehow without any suggestion of obeisance, no hint that she was in any way less. It truly was a courtesy, no more. "My Lady First of Mayene, I must speak with this young man, and I would retain your advisor. I've heard you have undertaken many duties here. I would not keep you from them." It was as clear a dismissal as could be, short of holding the door open.

bɹəleɪn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd ɡɹeɪʃəsli, ðən smuðli tɝn tə ɹænd ən spɹɛɾ əɹ skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi soʊ dip ðəɾ i wɝid wɛðɝ ʃi wəd ɹɪmeɪn ivən əz kloʊðd əz ʃi wɑz. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi ɪntoʊnd, "aɪ æsk jəɹ kaɪn pɝmɪʃən tə wɪðdʒɹɔ."

Berelain inclined her head graciously, then smoothly turned to Rand and spread her skirts in a curtsy so deep that he worried whether she would remain even as clothed as she was. "My Lord Dragon," she intoned, "I ask your kind permission to withdraw."

ɹændz ɹɪtɝn baʊ wɑz nɑt soʊ pɹæktəst. "ɡɹæntəd, maɪ leɪɾi fɝst, əz jə wɪʃ." hi ɔfɝɾ əɹ ə hænd, tə hɛlp əɹ ɹaɪz. "aɪ hoʊp jəl kənsɪɾɝ maɪ pɹəpoʊzəl."

Rand's return bow was not so practiced. "Granted, my Lady First, as you wish." He offered her a hand, to help her rise. "I hope you will consider my proposal."

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, əl sɝv jə wɛɹɛvɝ ən haʊɛvɝ jə dɪzaɪɝ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ɔl hʌni əɡɛn. fəɹ kædzueɪnz bɛnəfɪt, hi səpoʊzd. ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ flɝteɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, oʊnli dɪtɝməneɪʃən. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɑɹɪn," ʃi æɾəd ɪn ə wɪspɝ.

"My Lord Dragon, I will serve you wherever and however you desire." Her voice was all honey again. For Cadsuane's benefit, he supposed. There was certainly no flirtation on her face, only determination. "Remember Harine," she added in a whisper.

wən ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn bɹəleɪn, kædzueɪn sɛd, "ɪts ɔlweɪz ɡʊd tə si tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪ, doʊn jə θɪŋk, mɛɹænə?" mɛɹænə ɡɑɡəld, hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ bɪtwin ɹænd ən ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd sɪstɝ. ənʊɹə lʊkt əz ðoʊ oʊnli wɪlpaʊɝ hɛld əɹ əpɹaɪt.

When the door closed behind Berelain, Cadsuane said, "It's always good to see children play, don't you think, Merana?" Merana goggled, head swiveling between Rand and the gray-haired sister. Annoura looked as though only willpower held her upright.

moʊst ə ðə meɪɾənz fɑloʊd bɹəleɪn, əpɛɹənli dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz tə bi noʊ kɪlɪŋ, bʌt ɹaɪəlɪn ən tu ʌðɝz ɹɪmeɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ, stɪl veɪld. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn koʊɪnsɪɾəns ðət ðəɹ wɑz wʌn fəɹ itʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ. dæʃivə ɔlsoʊ sim tə θɪŋk ɛni deɪnʒɝ pæst. hi lin bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl wɪð ə fʊt pɹɑpt, lɪps muvɪŋ saɪlənli, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, əpɛɹənli wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Most of the Maidens followed Berelain, apparently deciding there was to be no killing, but Riallin and two others remained before the door, still veiled. It might have been coincidence that there was one for each Aes Sedai. Dashiva also seemed to think any danger past. He leaned back against the wall with a foot propped, lips moving silently, arms folded, apparently watching the Aes Sedai.

nɛɹɪʃmə fɹaʊn kwɛstʃənɪŋli ət ɹænd, bʌt ɹænd oʊnli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðə wʊmən wɑz dɪlɪbɝətli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹəvoʊk hɪm. ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz, waɪ pɹəvoʊk ə mæn ʃi mʌs noʊ kəd stɪl hɝ, əɹ kɪl hɝ, wɪθaʊɾ ɪɡzɝɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf? luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝd ðə seɪm θɪŋ. waɪ? waɪ? stɛpɪŋ ɑntu ðə deɪz, ɹænd tʊk ʌp ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ fɹəm ðə θɹoʊn ən sæt, weɪɾɪŋ tə si wʌt wəd hæpən. ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə səksid.

Narishma frowned questioningly at Rand, but Rand only shook his head. The woman was deliberately trying to provoke him. The question was, why provoke a man she must know could still her, or kill her, without exerting himself? Lews Therin muttered the same thing. Why? Why? Stepping onto the dais, Rand took up the Dragon Scepter from the throne and sat, waiting to see what would happen. The woman was not going to succeed.

"ɹæðɝ ɔɹneɪt, wʊdn jə seɪ?" kædzueɪn sɛd tə ənʊɹə, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊnd. əsaɪd fɹəm ɔl ði ʌðɝ ɡoʊld, bɹɔd bænz ʌv ɪt ɹæn ɝaʊn ðə wɔlz əbʌv ðə mɪɹɝz, ən ðə kɔɹnɪsəz wɝ nɪɹli tu fiɾ ʌv ɡoʊldən skeɪlz. "aɪv nɛvɝ noʊn wɛðɝ kɛɹhinɪn əɹ tɛɹənz oʊvɝdu wɝs, bʌɾ iðɝ kən meɪk ən ɛbu dɑɹi blʌʃ, əɹ ivən ə tɪŋkɝ. ɪz ðəɾ ə ti tʃɹeɪ? aɪ wəd laɪk sʌm, ɪf ɪts fɹɛʃ, ən hɑt."

"Rather ornate, wouldn't you say?" Cadsuane said to Annoura, looking around. Aside from all the other gold, broad bands of it ran around the walls above the mirrors, and the cornices were nearly two feet of golden scales. "I've never known whether Cairhienin or Tairens overdo worse, but either can make an Ebou Dari blush, or even a Tinker. Is that a tea tray? I would like some, if it's fresh, and hot."

tʃænəlɪŋ, ɹænd skupt ʌp ðə tʃɹeɪ, hæf ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə si ðə mɛɾəl kɝoʊd fɹəm ðə teɪnt, ən wɑftɪɾ ɪt tə ðə θɹi wɪmən. mɛɹænə hæd bɹɔɾ ɛkstʃɹə kʌps, ən fɔɹ stɪl stʊɾ ənjuzd ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ. hi fɪl θɹi, ɹipleɪs ðə tipɑɾ ən weɪɾəd. ɪt floʊɾəd ɪn mɪdɛɹ, səpɔɹɾəd baɪ seɪɾɪn.

Channeling, Rand scooped up the tray, half expecting to see the metal corrode from the taint, and wafted it to the three women. Merana had brought extra cups, and four still stood unused on the tray. He filled three, replaced the teapot and waited. It floated in midair, supported by saidin.

θɹi vɛɹi dɪfɹənt wɪmən ɪn əpɪɹəns, ən θɹi dɪstɪŋkli dɪfɹən ɹiækʃənz. ənʊɹə lʊkt ət ðə tʃɹeɪ mʌtʃ əz wʌn maɪɾ ə kɔɪl vaɪpɝ, ɡeɪv ə taɪni ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ən tʊk ə smɔl stɛp bæk. mɛɹænə dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən sloʊli pɪkt ʌp ə kʌp wɪð ə hæn ðət tʃɹɛmbəl slaɪtli. noʊɪŋ ə mæn kəd tʃænəl ən biɪŋ fɔɹs tə si ɪt wɝ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə seɪm. kædzueɪn, ðoʊ, tʊk əɹ kʌp ən snɪf ðə veɪpɝz wɪð ə pliz smaɪl. nʌθɪŋ kəd tɛl əɹ wɪtʃ ə ðə θɹi mɛn hæd pɔɹd ðə ti, jɛt ʃi lʊkt əkɹɔs əɹ kʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹænd, laʊnʒɪŋ wɪð wʌn lɛɡ oʊvɝ ði ɑɹm oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɛɹ. "ðæts ə ɡʊd bɔɪ," ʃi sɛd. ðə meɪɾənz pæst ʃɑk lʊks əbʌv ðɛɹ veɪlz.

Three very different women in appearance, and three distinctly different reactions. Annoura looked at the tray much as one might a coiled viper, gave a tiny shake of her head, and took a small step back. Merana drew a deep breath and slowly picked up a cup with a hand that trembled slightly. Knowing a man could channel and being forced to see it were not at all the same. Cadsuane, though, took her cup and sniffed the vapors with a pleased smile. Nothing could tell her which of the three men had poured the tea, yet she looked across her cup straight at Rand, lounging with one leg over the arm over his chair. "That's a good boy," she said. The Maidens passed shocked looks above their veils.

ɹænd kwɪvɝd. noʊ. ʃi wəd nɑt pɹəvoʊk hɪm. fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɹizən, ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑntəd, ən ʃi wəd nɑt! "aɪ wɪl æsk wʌn mɔɹ taɪm," hi sɛd. stʃɹeɪnʒ, ðəɾ ɪz vɔɪs kəd bi ðət koʊld; ɪnsaɪd, hi wɑz hɑɾɝ ðən ðə hɑɾəst faɪɝz ə seɪɾɪn. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt? ænsɝ, əɹ liv. baɪ ðə dɔɹ əɹ ə wɪndoʊ; jəɹ tʃɔɪs."

Rand quivered. No. She would not provoke him. For whatever reason, that was what she wanted, and she would not! "I will ask one more time," he said. Strange, that his voice could be that cold; inside, he was hotter than the hottest fires of saidin. "What do you want? Answer, or leave. By the door or a window; your choice."

əɡɛn mɛɹænə bɪɡæn tə spik, ən əɡɛn kædzueɪn saɪləns hɝ, ðɪs taɪm baɪ ə ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. "tə si ju," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "aɪ æm ɡɹin ədʒɑ, nɑt ɹɛd, bʌɾ aɪ hæv wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ lɪvɪŋ, ən aɪ hæv feɪs mɔɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ðən ɛni fɔɹ ɹɛdz, meɪbi ðən ɛni tɛn. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ hʌntəd ðɛm, jə ʌndɝstænd, bʌɾ aɪ sim tə hæv ə noʊz." kɑmli, ə wʊmən seɪɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn tə mɑɹkət wʌns əɹ twaɪs ɪn əɹ laɪf. "sʌm fɔt tə ðə bɪɾɝ ɛnd, kɪkɪŋ ən skɹimɪŋ ivən æftɝ ðeɪ wɝ ʃildɪɾ ən baʊnd. səm wɛpt ən bɛɡd, ɔfɝɪŋ ɡoʊld, ɛniθɪŋ, ðɛɹ vɛɹi soʊlz, nɑt tə bi teɪkən tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. stɪl ʌðɝz wɛp fɹəm ɹɪlif, mik əz læmz, θæŋkfəl faɪnəli tə bi dʌn wɪð ɪt. laɪts tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ ɔl wip, ət ði ɛnd. ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛft fəɹ əm bʌt tɪɹz ət ði ɛnd."

Again Merana began to speak, and again Cadsuane silenced her, this time by a sharp gesture without looking away from him. "To see you," she said calmly. "I am Green Ajah, not Red, but I have worn the shawl longer than any other sister living, and I have faced more men who could channel than any four Reds, maybe than any ten. Not that I hunted them, you understand, but I seem to have a nose." Calmly, a woman saying she had been to market once or twice in her life. "Some fought to the bitter end, kicking and screaming even after they were shielded and bound. Some wept and begged, offering gold, anything, their very souls, not to be taken to Tar Valon. Still others wept from relief, meek as lambs, thankful finally to be done with it. Light's truth, they all weep, at the end. There is nothing left for them but tears at the end."

ðə hiɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪn ɹeɪdʒ. tʃɹeɪ ən mæsɪv tipɑt hɝɾəld əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, smæʃɪŋ ə mɪɹɝ wɪð ə θʌndɝəs kɹæʃ ən baʊnsɪŋ bæk ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ʌv ɡlæs, hæf-flæɾənd pɑt spɹeɪɪŋ ti, tʃɹeɪ spɪnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ bɛn dʌbəl. ɛvɹiwʌn dʒʌmpt ɪksɛp kædzueɪn. ɹænd lɛp fɹəm ðə deɪz, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪz nʌkəlz hɝt. "ɪz ðət səpoʊz tə fɹaɪɾən mi?" hi ɡɹaʊld. "du jə ɪkspɛk mi tə bɛɡ, əɹ tə bi θæŋkfəl? tə wip? ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ kəd kloʊz maɪ hæn ən kɹʌʃ ju." ðə hæn i hɛld ʌp ʃʊk wɪð fjʊɹi. "mɛɹænə noʊz waɪ aɪ ʃʊd. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz waɪ aɪ doʊnt."

The heat inside him erupted in rage. Tray and massive teapot hurtled across the room, smashing a mirror with a thunderous crash and bouncing back in a shower of glass, half-flattened pot spraying tea, tray spinning across the floor bent double. Everyone jumped except Cadsuane. Rand leaped from the dais, clutching the Dragon Scepter so hard his knuckles hurt. "Is that supposed to frighten me?" he growled. "Do you expect me to beg, or to be thankful? To weep? Aes Sedai, I could close my hand and crush you." The hand he held up shook with fury. "Merana knows why I should. The Light only knows why I don't."

ðə wʊmən lʊkt ət ðə bæɾɝd ti θɪŋz əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə wɝld. "naʊ jə noʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, kɑm əz ɛvɝ, "ðæɾ aɪ noʊ jəɹ fjutʃɝ, ən jəɹ pɹizɛnt. ðə laɪts mɝsi feɪdz tə nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ə mæn u kən tʃænəl. səm si ðəɾ ən bɪliv ðə laɪt dɪnaɪz ðoʊz mɛn. aɪ də nɑt. hæv jə bɪɡʌn tə hɪɹ vɔɪsəz, jɛt?"

The woman looked at the battered tea things as if she had all the time in the world. "Now you know," she said at last, calm as ever, "that I know your future, and your present. The Light's mercy fades to nothing for a man who can channel. Some see that and believe the Light denies those men. I do not. Have you begun to hear voices, yet?"

"wʌt dʒju min?" hi æsk sloʊli. hi kəd fil luz θɝɪn lɪsnɪŋ.

"What do you mean?" he asked slowly. He could feel Lews Therin listening.

ðə tɪŋɡəl ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz skɪn, ən i vɛɹi nɪɹli tʃænəld, bʌɾ ɔl ðət hæpənd wɑz ðət ðə tipɑt ɹoʊz ən floʊɾəd tə kædzueɪn, tɝnɪŋ sloʊli ɪn ði ɛɹ fəɹ əɹ tə ɪɡzæmɪn. "sʌm mɛn u kən tʃænəl bɪɡɪn tə hɪɹ vɔɪsəz." ʃi spoʊk ɔlmoʊst æbsənli, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə flæɾənd sfɪɹ ə sɪlvɝ ən ɡoʊld. "ɪɾ ɪz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə mædnəs. vɔɪsəz kənvɝsɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, tɛlɪŋ əm wʌt tə du." ðə tipɑt dʒɹɪftəd dʒɛnli tə ðə flɔɹ baɪ hɝ fit. "hæv jə hɝɾ ɛni?"

The tingle returned to his skin, and he very nearly channeled, but all that happened was that the teapot rose and floated to Cadsuane, turning slowly in the air for her to examine. "Some men who can channel begin to hear voices." She spoke almost absently, frowning at the flattened sphere of silver and gold. "It is a part of the madness. Voices conversing with them, telling them what to do." The teapot drifted gently to the floor by her feet. "Have you heard any?"

stɑɹtlɪŋli, dæʃivə ɡeɪv ə ɹɔkəs læf, ʃoʊldɝz ʃeɪkɪŋ. nɛɹɪʃmə wɛɾ ɪz lɪps; hi maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə wʊmən bɪfɔɹ, bʌt naʊ hi wɑtʃt əɹ kloʊsli əz ə skɔɹpiən.

Startlingly, Dashiva gave a raucous laugh, shoulders shaking. Narishma wet his lips; he might not have been afraid of the woman before, but now he watched her closely as a scorpion.

"aɪ wɪl æsk ðə kwɛstʃənz," ɹænd sɛd fɝmli. "ju sim tə fɝɡɛt. aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." jə ɑɹ ɹil, ɑɹən ju? hi wʌndɝd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ. luz θɝɪn? səmtaɪmz ðə mæn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz dʒɹu hɪm. luz θɝɪn? hi wɑz nɑt mæd; ðə vɔɪs wɑz ɹil, nɑɾ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. nɑt mædnəs. ə sʌɾən dɪzaɪɝ tə læf dɪd nɑt hɛlp.

"I will ask the questions," Rand said firmly. "You seem to forget. I am the Dragon Reborn." You are real, aren't you? he wondered. There was no answer. Lews Therin? Sometimes the man did not answer, but Aes Sedai always drew him. Lews Therin? He was not mad; the voice was real, not imagination. Not madness. A sudden desire to laugh did not help.

kædzueɪn saɪd. "ju ɑɹ ə jʌŋ mæn u hæz lɪɾəl aɪdiə wɛɹ hiz ɡoʊɪŋ əɹ waɪ, əɹ wʌt laɪz əhɛd. jə sim oʊvɝɹɔt. pɝhæps wi kən spik wən jə ɑɹ mɔɹ sɛɾəld. hæv jə ɛni əbdʒɛkʃən tə maɪ teɪkɪŋ mɛɹænə ən ənʊɹə əweɪ fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl? aɪv sin niðɝ ɪn kwaɪt səm taɪm."

Cadsuane sighed. "You are a young man who has little idea where he is going or why, or what lies ahead. You seem overwrought. Perhaps we can speak when you are more settled. Have you any objection to my taking Merana and Annoura away for a little while? I've seen neither in quite some time."

ɹænd ɡeɪpt ət hɝ. ʃi swupt ɪn, ɪnsʌltɪd hɪm, θɹɛɾənd hɪm, kæʒəwəli ənaʊnst ʃi nu əbaʊt ðə vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən wɪð ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə liv ən tɔk wɪð mɛɹænə ən ənʊɹə? ɪz ʃi mæd? stɪl noʊ ænsɝ fɹəm luz θɝɪn. ðə mæn wɑz ɹil. hi wɑz!

Rand gaped at her. She swooped in, insulted him, threatened him, casually announced she knew about the voice in his head, and with that she wanted to leave and talk with Merana and Annoura? Is she mad? Still no answer from Lews Therin. The man was real. He was!

"ɡoʊ əweɪ," hi sɛd. "ɡoʊ əweɪ, ænd. . . ." hi wɑz nɑt mæd. "ɔl ə ju, ɡɛɾ aʊt! ɡɛɾ aʊt!"

"Go away," he said. "Go away, and. . . ." He was not mad. "All of you, get out! Get out!"

dæʃivə blɪŋkt ət hɪm, tɪltɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ðən ʃɹʌɡd ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. kædzueɪn smaɪld ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðəɾ i hæf-ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə tɛl ɪm əɡɛn i wɑz ə ɡʊd bɔɪ, ðən ɡæðɝɾ ʌp mɛɹænə ən ənʊɹə ən hɝɾɪd əm təwɔɹd ðə meɪɾənz, hu wɝ loʊɝɪŋ ðɛɹ veɪlz ən fɹaʊnɪŋ wɝidli. nɛɹɪʃmə lʊkt əɾ ɪm tu, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli. faɪnəli ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɔn, ən i wɑz əloʊn. əloʊn.

Dashiva blinked at him, tilting his head, then shrugged and started for the door. Cadsuane smiled in such a way that he half-expected her to tell him again he was a good boy, then gathered up Merana and Annoura and herded them toward the Maidens, who were lowering their veils and frowning worriedly. Narishma looked at him too, hesitating until Rand gestured sharply. Finally they were all gone, and he was alone. Alone.

kənvʌlsɪvli hi hɝl ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. ðə spɪɹ-pɔɪn stʌk kwɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ʌv wʌn ðə tʃɛɹz, ðə tæsəlz sweɪɪŋ.

Convulsively he hurled the Dragon Scepter. The spear-point stuck quivering in the back of one the chairs, the tassels swaying.

"aɪ æm nɑt mæd," hi sɛd tə ði ɛmpti ɹum. luz θɝɪn hæd toʊld ɪm θɪŋz; hi wəd nɛvɝ əv ɪskeɪpt ɡəlinəz tʃɛst wɪθaʊt ðə dɛd mænz vɔɪs. bʌɾ i hæd juz ðə paʊɝ bɪfɔɹ i ɛvɝ hɝd ðə vɔɪs; hi hæd fɪɡjɝɾ aʊt haʊ tə kɔl laɪtnɪŋ ən hɝl faɪɝ ən fɔɹm ə kənstʃɹʌk ðət hæd kɪl hʌnʒɹədz ə tʃɹɑləks. bʌt ðɛn, meɪbi ðət hæd bɪn luz θɝɪn, laɪk ðoʊz mɛmɹiz ə klaɪmɪŋ tʃɹiz ɪn ə plʌm ɔɹtʃɝd, ən ɛntɝɪŋ ðə hɔl ə ðə sɝvəns, ən ə dʌzən mɔɹ ðət kɹɛpt ʌp ɑn ɪm ənəwɛɹz. ən meɪbi ðoʊz mɛmɹiz wɝ ɔl fænsiz, mæd dʒɹimz ʌv ə mæd maɪnd, dʒʌs laɪk ðə vɔɪs.

"I am not mad," he said to the empty room. Lews Therin had told him things; he would never have escaped Galina's chest without the dead man's voice. But he had used the Power before he ever heard the voice; he had figured out how to call lightning and hurl fire and form a construct that had killed hundreds of Trollocs. But then, maybe that had been Lews Therin, like those memories of climbing trees in a plum orchard, and entering the Hall of the Servants, and a dozen more that crept up on him unawares. And maybe those memories were all fancies, mad dreams of a mad mind, just like the voice.

hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz peɪsɪŋ, ən kəd nɑt stɑp. hi fɛlt əz ɪf i hæd tə muv əɹ ɪz mʌsəlz wəd tɛɹ ɪm əpɑɹɾ ɪn spæzəmz. "aɪ æm nɑt mæd," hi pæntɪd. nɑt jɛt. "aɪ æm nɑt - " ðə saʊn ə ðə dɔɹ oʊpənɪŋ meɪɾ ɪm wɝl, hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ mɪn.

He realized he was pacing, and could not stop. He felt as if he had to move or his muscles would tear him apart in spasms. "I am not mad," he panted. Not yet. "I am not - " The sound of the door opening made him whirl, hoping for Min.

ɪt wɑz ɹaɪəlɪn əɡɛn, səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt stɑki wʊmən ɪn ə dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs, wɪð hɛɹ mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ ðən nɑɾ ən ə blʌn feɪs. ə hæɡɝd, ɹɛd-aɪd feɪs.

It was Riallin again, supporting a short stocky woman in a dark blue dress, with hair more gray than not and a blunt face. A haggard, red-eyed face.

hi wɑntəd tə tɛl əm tə ɡoʊ əweɪ, tə liv ɪm əloʊn. əloʊn. wɑz i əloʊn? wɑz luz θɝɪn ə dʒɹim? ɪf oʊnli ðeɪ wəd liv hɪm. . . . ɪdʒɹin tɑɹsən wɑz ðə hɛɾ ə ðə skul i hæd faʊndəd hɪɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, ə wʊmən soʊ pɹæktəkəl i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi bɪlivd ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ sɪns ʃi kəd niðɝ si nɔɹ tʌtʃ ɪt. wʌt kəd ɹədus əɹ tə ðɪs steɪt?

He wanted to tell them to go away, to leave him alone. Alone. Was he alone? Was Lews Therin a dream? If only they would leave him. . . . Idrien Tarsin was the head of the school he had founded here in Cairhien, a woman so practical he was not sure she believed in the One Power since she could neither see nor touch it. What could reduce her to this state?

hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ. mæɾ əɹ nɑt, əloʊn əɹ nɑt, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls tə də wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn. nɑɾ ivən ðɪs smɔl duɾi. hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ?" hi æskt, meɪkɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əz dʒɛntəl əz i kʊd.

He made himself turn toward her. Mad or not, alone or not, there was no one else to do what had to be done. Not even this small duty. Heavier than a mountain. "What is the matter?" he asked, making his voice as gentle as he could.

sʌɾənli wipɪŋ, ɪdʒɹin stʌmbəl tə hɪm ən kəlæpst əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. wən ʃi wɑz koʊhɪɹən ɪnʌf tə tɛl əɹ stɔɹi, hi fɛlt laɪk wipɪŋ tu.

Suddenly weeping, Idrien stumbled to him and collapsed against his chest. When she was coherent enough to tell her story, he felt like weeping too.


tʃæptɝ naɪntin


CHAPTER 19

daɪmənz ən stɑɹz


Diamonds and Stars

mɛɹænə fɑloʊd kloʊsli əz ʃi dɛɹɾ ɑn kædzueɪnz hilz, ə hʌnʒɹəd kwɛstʃənz bʌbəlɪŋ ɑn əɹ tʌŋ, bʌt kædzueɪn wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən huz sliv jə plʌkt. ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd u ʃi noʊɾəst, ən wɛn. ənʊɹə hɛld əɹ saɪləns, tu, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm dʒɹɔn əlɔŋ ɪn ði ʌðɝz weɪk daʊn ðə pæləs kɔɹɪɾɝz, daʊn flaɪts ə stɛɹz, pɑlɪʃt mɑɹbəl ət fɝst, ðən pleɪn dɑɹk stoʊn. mɛɹænə ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ ɡɹeɪ, ən fɛlt ə moʊməns pæŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə wʊmən, ɹɪli, bʌɾ ənʊɹə wɔɹ ðə stili lʊk ʌv ə ɡɝl ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, dɪtɝmən tə bi bɹeɪv. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt nɑvəsɪz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tʃɪlʒɹən. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ - ən kloʊzd ɪt, ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪ bʌn bɑbɪŋ əhɛɾ ə hɝ wɪð ɪts dæŋɡəlɪŋ munz ən stɑɹz ən bɝdz ən fɪʃ. kædzueɪn wɑz . . . kædzueɪn.

Merana followed closely as she dared on Cadsuane's heels, a hundred questions bubbling on her tongue, but Cadsuane was not a woman whose sleeve you plucked. She decided who she noticed, and when. Annoura held her silence, too, the pair of them drawn along in the other's wake down the palace corridors, down flights of stairs, polished marble at first, then plain dark stone. Merana exchanged glances with her sister Gray, and felt a moment's pang. She did not know the woman, really, but Annoura wore the steely look of a girl on her way to the Mistress of Novices, determined to be brave. They were not novices. They were not children. She opened her mouth - and closed it, intimidated by the gray bun bobbing ahead of her with its dangling moons and stars and birds and fish. Cadsuane was . . . Cadsuane.

mɛɹænə hæd mɛɾ əɹ wʌns bɪfɔɹ, əɹ ət lis lɪsən tə hɝ ən bɪn spoʊkən tə, wən ʃi wɑz ə nɑvəs. sɪstɝz hæd kʌm fɹəm ɛvɹi ədʒɑ tə si ðə wʊmən, fɪld wɪð ən ɑ ðeɪ kəd nɑt haɪd. wʌns kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn hæd bɪn ðə stændɝd baɪ wɪtʃ ɛvɹi nu ɛntʃɹi ɪndə ðə nɑvəs bʊk wɑz dʒʌdʒd. əntɪl ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, nʌn hæd kʌm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪn əɹ laɪftaɪm u kəd mætʃ ðət stændɝd, mʌtʃ lɛs sɝpæs ɪt. ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn, hɝ laɪk hæd nɑt wɔkt əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz. ə ɹəfjuzəl tə æksɛp səlɛkʃən əz ə sɪɾɝ wɑz ənhɝɾ ʌv, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz sɛd ʃi hæd ɹəfjuzd, ən ət lis twaɪs. ɪt wɑz sɛd ʃi hæd spɝn biɪŋ ɹeɪz hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, tu. ɪt wɑz sɛd ʃi wʌns vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə taʊɝ fəɹ tɛn jɪɹz kəz ðə hɔl ɪntɛndəd tə ɹeɪz əɹ æmɪɝlɪn. nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ spɛn ə deɪ mɔɹ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ðən æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi. wɝɾ ə kædzueɪn keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ, stɔɹiz tə meɪk sɪstɝz ɡeɪp, ædvɛntʃɝz tə meɪk ðoʊz u dʒɹimd ə ðə ʃɔl ʃɪvɝ. ʃi wəɾ ɛn ə lɛdʒən əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə ʃɔl hæd ɡɹeɪs mɛɹænəz ʃoʊldɝz fəɹ oʊvɝ twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz wən kædzueɪn ənaʊnst əɹ ɹitaɪɝmən fɹəm ðə wɝld, hɝ hɛɹ ɔlɹɛɾi sɑləd ɡɹeɪ, ən ɛvɹiwʌn əsumd əɹ lɔŋ dɛd wən ði il wɔɹ ɪɹʌptəɾ ənʌðɝ twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz ɑn, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɑz θɹi mʌnθs oʊld, ʃi ɹiəpɪɹd, əkʌmpənid baɪ tu wɔɹɾɝz, mɛn lɔŋ ɪn ðə tuθ jɛt stɪl hɑɹɾ əz aɪɝn. ɪt wɑz sɛd kædzueɪn hæd hæd mɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ðən moʊst sɪstɝz hæd ʃuz. æftɝ ði il ɹitʃɹiɾəd fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn, ʃi ɹɪtaɪɹd wʌns mɔɹ, bʌt səm sɛd, mɔɹ ðən hæf-sɪɹiəsli, ðət kædzueɪn wəd nɛvɝ daɪ soʊ lɔŋ əz ivən ə spɑɹk ʌv ædvɛntʃɝ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə wɝld.

Merana had met her once before, or at least listened to her and been spoken to, when she was a novice. Sisters had come from every Ajah to see the woman, filled with an awe they could not hide. Once Cadsuane Melaidhrin had been the standard by which every new entry into the novice book was judged. Until Elayne Trakand, none had come to the White Tower in her lifetime who could match that standard, much less surpass it. In more ways than one, her like had not walked among Aes Sedai for a thousand years. A refusal to accept selection as a Sitter was unheard of, yet it was said she had refused, and at least twice. It was said she had spurned being raised head of the Green Ajah, too. It was said she once vanished from the Tower for ten years because the Hall intended to raise her Amyrlin. Not that she had ever spent a day more in Tar Valon than absolutely necessary. Word of Cadsuane came to the Tower, stories to make sisters gape, adventures to make those who dreamed of the shawl shiver. She would end a legend among Aes Sedai. If she was not already. The shawl had graced Merana's shoulders for over twenty-five years when Cadsuane announced her retirement from the world, her hair already solid gray, and everyone assumed her long dead when the Aiel War erupted another twenty-five years on, but before the fighting was three months old, she reappeared, accompanied by two Warders, men long in the tooth yet still hard as iron. It was said Cadsuane had had more Warders over the years than most sisters had shoes. After the Aiel retreated from Tar Valon, she retired once more, but some said, more than half-seriously, that Cadsuane would never die so long as even a spark of adventure remained in the world.

ən ðəɾ ɪz ðə sɔɹɾ ə nɑnsɛns ðət nɑvəsɪz bæbəl, mɛɹænə ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf fɝmli. ivən wi daɪ ɪvɛntʃəwəli. jɛt kædzueɪn wɑz stɪl kædzueɪn. ən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz sɪstɝz u hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi æftɝ ælθɹ wɑz teɪkən, ðə sʌn wəd nɑt sɛt tənaɪt. mɛɹænə muvd əɹ ɑɹmz tə ədʒʌst əɹ ʃɔl ən ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə pɛɡ ɪn əɹ ɹum. ɹɪdɪkjələs. ʃi niɾəd noʊ ɹimaɪndɝz ə hu ʃi wɑz. ɪf oʊnli ɪt hæd bɪn sʌmwʌn ʌðɝ ðən kædzueɪn. . . . ə pɛɹ ʌv waɪz wʌnz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə maʊθ ʌv ə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ wɑtʃt əm pæs, koʊl peɪl aɪz ɪn stoʊni feɪsəz bɪniθ ðɛɹ dɑɹk hɛd skɑɹvz. ɛdʒɹə ən leɪn. boʊθ kəd tʃænəl, ən kwaɪt stʃɹɔŋli; ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ɹɪzən haɪ hæd ðeɪ ɡɔn tə ðə taʊɝ əz ɡɝlz. kædzueɪn wɛn baɪ wɪθaʊt simɪŋ tə noʊɾəs ðə waɪldɝz' dɪsəpɹəbeɪʃən. ənʊɹə dɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ, slɛndɝ bɹeɪdz sweɪɪŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. mɛɹænə kɛpt əɹ oʊn aɪz ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz.

And that is the sort of nonsense that novices babble, Merana reminded herself firmly. Even we die eventually. Yet Cadsuane was still Cadsuane. And if she was not one of those sisters who had appeared in the city after al'Thor was taken, the sun would not set tonight. Merana moved her arms to adjust her shawl and realized it was hanging on a peg in her room. Ridiculous. She needed no reminders of who she was. If only it had been someone other than Cadsuane. . . . A pair of Wise Ones standing in the mouth of a crossing corridor watched them pass, cold pale eyes in stony faces beneath their dark head scarves. Edarra and Leyn. Both could channel, and quite strongly; they might have risen high had they gone to the Tower as girls. Cadsuane went by without seeming to notice the wilders' disapprobation. Annoura did, frowning and muttering, slender braids swaying as she shook her head. Merana kept her own eyes on the floor tiles.

əndaʊɾɪdli ɪt wəd fɔl tə hɝ naʊ, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ tə kædzueɪn ðə . . . kɑmpɹəmaɪz . . . ðət hæd bɪn wɝkt aʊt wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz læs naɪt, bɪfɔɹ ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ bɹɔt tə ðə pæləs. ənʊɹə dɪd nɑt noʊ - ʃi wɑz noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt - ən mɛɹænə hæd smɔl hoʊp ðət ɹæfɛlə əɹ vɛɹɪn wəɾ əpɪɹ, əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls ʃi maɪt sʌmhaʊ fɔɪs ðə duɾi ɑntu. ɪt wɑz ə kɑmpɹəmaɪz, ɪn ə weɪ, ən pɝhæps ðə bɛs ðət kəd bi ɪkspɛktəɾ ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, jɛt ʃi stʃɹɔŋli kwɛstʃənd wɛðɝ kædzueɪn wəd si ɪt soʊ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi ðə wʌn tə kənvɪns hɝ. bɛɾɝ tə pɔɹ ti fəɹ ðoʊz kɝs mɛn fəɹ ə mʌnθ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ fɹi wɪð əɹ tʌŋ wɪð jʌŋ ælθɹ. noʊɪŋ waɪ hi hæd meɪɾ əɹ sɝv ti wɑz noʊ bɑm fəɹ biɪŋ sild ɔf fɹəm ɛvɹi ædvæntɪdʒ ʃi maɪɾ əv ɡeɪn fɹəm ɪt. ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ θɪŋk ʃi hæd bɪn kɑɾ ɪn səm tɑvɝən swɝlɪŋ ə ðə pæɾɝn ðən bɪliv ðəɾ ə jʌŋ mænz aɪz, laɪk pɑlɪʃt blu-ɡɹeɪ dʒɛmz, hæd sɛɾ əɹ bæbəlɪŋ fɹəm pjʊɹ fɹaɪt, bʌɾ iðɝ weɪ, ʃi hæd hændəɾ ɔl ði ædvæntɪdʒ tə hɪm ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ. ʃi wɪʃt. . . .

Undoubtedly it would fall to her now, explaining to Cadsuane the . . . compromise . . . that had been worked out with the Wise Ones last night, before she and the others were brought to the palace. Annoura did not know - she was no part of it - and Merana had small hope that Rafela or Verin would appear, or anyone else she might somehow foist the duty onto. It was a compromise, in a way, and perhaps the best that could be expected under the circumstances, yet she strongly questioned whether Cadsuane would see it so. She wished she did not have to be the one to convince her. Better to pour tea for those cursed men for a month. She wished she had not been so free with her tongue with young al'Thor. Knowing why he had made her serve tea was no balm for being sealed off from every advantage she might have gained from it. She would rather think she had been caught in some ta'veren swirling of the Pattern than believe that a young man's eyes, like polished blue-gray gems, had set her babbling from pure fright, but either way, she had handed all the advantage to him on a tray. She wished. . . .

wɪʃɪŋ wɑz fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. ʃi hæd nəɡoʊʃieɪɾəd kaʊnləs tʃɹiɾiz, mɛni ʌv wɪtʃ hæɾ æktʃəli  əkɑmplɪʃt wʌt wɑz ɪntɛndəd; ʃi hæɾ ɛndəd θɹi wɔɹz ən stɑp tu dʌzən mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ bɪɡæn, feɪs kɪŋz ən kwinz ən dʒɛnɝəlz ən meɪɾ əm si ɹizən. ivən soʊ. . . . ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf pɹɑməsɪŋ ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ ʌɾɝ wʌn wɝɾ ə kəmpleɪnt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ðət mæn meɪɾ əɹ pleɪ ðə meɪdsɝvən ɪf oʊnli siɑnɪd wəd pɑp ɝaʊn ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ, əɹ mɑsʊɝi, əɹ feɪlʒɹɪn, əɹ ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl. laɪt! ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd blɪŋk əɹ aɪz ən faɪn ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ sɪns livɪŋ sɑlədɑɹ hæd bɪn ə bæd dʒɹim.

Wishing was for children. She had negotiated countless treaties, many of which had actually accomplished what was intended; she had ended three wars and stopped two dozen more before they began, faced kings and queens and generals and made them see reason. Even so. . . . She found herself promising that she would not utter one word of complaint no matter how often that man made her play the maidservant if only Seonid would pop around the next corner, or Masuri, or Faeldrin, or anyone at all. Light! If only she could blink her eyes and find that everything since leaving Salidar had been a bad dream.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, kædzueɪn lɛɾ əm stʃɹeɪt tə ðə smɔl ɹum ðət bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə ʃɛɹd, dip ɪn ðə baʊəlz ə ðə pæləs. wɛɹ ðə sɝvəns lɪvd. ə taɪt wɪndoʊ, sɛt haɪ ɪn ðə wɔl jɛt lɛvəl wɪð ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ʌv ə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ aʊtsaɪd, lɛɾ ɪn ə lɪɾəl stʃɹim ə laɪt, bʌt ðə ɹum simd mɝki. kloʊks ən sæɾəlbæɡz ən ə fju dʒɹɛsəz hʌŋ fɹəm pɛɡz ɪn ðə kɹækt, jɛloʊɪŋ plæstɝ wɔlz. ɡaʊudʒɪz mɑɹd ðə bɛɹ wʊɾən flɔɹ, ðoʊ səm ɛfɝt hæd bɪn meɪd tə smuð ðɛm. ə taɪni bæɾɝd ɹaʊn teɪbəl stʊɾ ɪn wʌn kɔɹnɝ, ən ən ikwəli biɾən wɑʃstæn ɪn ənʌðɝ, wɪð ə tʃɪp beɪsən ən pɪtʃɝ. mɛɹænə aɪd ðə smɔl bɛd. ɪt dɪd nɑt lʊk ðət mʌtʃ nɛɹoʊɝ ðən ðə wʌn ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə ʃɛɹ wɪð siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi, tu dɔɹz fɑɹðɝ daʊn. ðət ɹum wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ baɪ pɝhæps ə peɪs itʃ weɪ, bʌt nɑt mɛn fəɹ θɹi. kɔɪɹən ən ði ʌðɝz stɪl hɛld ɪn ði il tɛns pɹɑbli wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl əz pɹɪznɝz.

Surprisingly, Cadsuane led them straight to the small room that Bera and Kiruna shared, deep in the bowels of the palace. Where the servants lived. A tight window, set high in the wall yet level with the paving stones of a courtyard outside, let in a little stream of light, but the room seemed murky. Cloaks and saddlebags and a few dresses hung from pegs in the cracked, yellowing plaster walls. Gouges marred the bare wooden floor, though some effort had been made to smooth them. A tiny battered round table stood in one corner, and an equally beaten washstand in another, with a chipped basin and pitcher. Merana eyed the small bed. It did not look that much narrower than the one she was forced to share with Seonid and Masuri, two doors farther down. That room was larger by perhaps a pace each way, but not meant for three. Coiren and the others still held in the Aiel tents probably were much more comfortable as prisoners.

niðɝ bɛɹə nɔɹ kaɪɹunə wɑz pɹɛzənt, bʌt deɪdʒiən wɑz, ə plʌmp, peɪl wʊmən u wɔɹ ə θɪn sɪlvɝ tʃeɪn ɪn əɹ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ, wɪð ə ɹaʊn munstoʊn dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd. hɝ dɑɹk kɛɹhinɪn dʒɹɛs bɔɹ fɔɹ θɪn stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ðə bɑɾəs, ən ʃi hæɾ æɾəd slæʃɪz ɪn ðə skɝts, waɪt fəɹ əɹ ədʒɑ. ə jʌŋɡɝ dɔɾɝ ʌv wʌn ə ðə lɛsɝ haʊsəz, ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz maɪndəd mɛɹænə ʌv ə paʊɾɝ pɪdʒən. wən kædzueɪn ɛntɝd, deɪdʒiən ɹoʊz ɑn əɹ toʊz ɪkspɛktənli.

Neither Bera nor Kiruna was present, but Daigian was, a plump, pale woman who wore a thin silver chain in her long black hair, with a round moonstone dangling in the middle of her forehead. Her dark Cairhienin dress bore four thin stripes of color across the bodice, and she had added slashes in the skirts, white for her Ajah. A younger daughter of one of the lesser Houses, she had always minded Merana of a pouter pigeon. When Cadsuane entered, Daigian rose on her toes expectantly.

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹum, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə stul wɪð ən ɪkskjus ʌv ə bæk. kædzueɪn tʊk ðəɾ ən saɪd. "ti, pliz. tu sɪps ʌv wʌt ðət bɔɪ pɔɹd, ən aɪ cʊɾə juz maɪ tʌŋ tə soʊl ə ʃu."

There was only one chair in the room, little more than a stool with an excuse of a back. Cadsuane took that and sighed. "Tea, please. Two sips of what that boy poured, and I could have used my tongue to sole a shoe."

ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪmiɾiətli sɝaʊndəd deɪdʒiən, ðoʊ feɪnli, ən ə dɛntɪd tɪn tipɑt ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, floʊz ə faɪɝ hiɾɪŋ ðə wɔɾɝ əz ʃi oʊpən ə smɔl bɹæs-baʊn ti tʃɛst.

The glow of saidar immediately surrounded Daigian, though faintly, and a dented tin teapot rose from the table, flows of Fire heating the water as she opened a small brass-bound tea chest.

wɪð noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs fəɹ pleɪs tə sɪt, mɛɹænə sɛɾəld ɑntu ðə bɛd, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn ðə lʌmpi mætʃɹəs waɪl ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɔɹɾɝ əɹ θɔts. ðɪs maɪt wɛl bi əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ə nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən əz ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ ʌndɝteɪkən. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ənʊɹə dʒɔɪn hɝ, pɝtʃɪŋ ɑn ðə lɪp ə ðə mætʃɹəs.

With no other choice for place to sit, Merana settled onto the bed, adjusting her skirts and shifting on the lumpy mattress while she tried to order her thoughts. This might well be as important a negotiation as she had ever undertaken. After a moment, Annoura joined her, perching on the lip of the mattress.

"aɪ teɪk ɪt baɪ jəɹ pɹɛzəns, mɛɹænə," kædzueɪn sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, "ðæt teɪlz ə ðə bɔɪ səbmɪɾɪŋ tə ɪleɪɾə ɑɹ fɔls. doʊn lʊk soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd, tʃaɪld. dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ dɪdnt noʊ jəɹ . . . əsoʊsieɪʃənz?" ʃi ɡeɪv ðət wɝd sətʃ ə twɪst, ɪt saʊndəɾ əz fɪlθi əz ɛni soʊlʒɝz ɛkspləɾɪv. "æn ju, ənʊɹə?"

"I take it by your presence, Merana," Cadsuane said abruptly, "that tales of the boy submitting to Elaida are false. Don't look so surprised, child. Did you think I didn't know your . . . associations?" She gave that word such a twist, it sounded as filthy as any soldier's expletive. "And you, Annoura?"

"aɪ æm hɪɹ oʊnli tə ædvaɪz bɹəleɪn, ðoʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪɾ ɪz, ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd maɪ ædvaɪs baɪ kʌmɪŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs." ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən hɛld əɹ hɛɾ ʌp, vɔɪs kɑnfəɾənt. ʃi wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ θʌmz fəɹ ɔl ʃi wɑz wɝθ, ðoʊ. ʃi kəd nɑt də wɛl ət ðə nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ɪf ʃi wɑz ðət tʃɹænspɛɹənt. "fɔɹ ðə ɹɛst," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "aɪ hæv ɹitʃt noʊ dɪsɪʒən əz jɛt."

"I am here only to advise Berelain, though the truth of it is, she ignored my advice by coming in the first place." The Taraboner woman held her head up, voice confident. She was rubbing her thumbs for all she was worth, though. She could not do well at the negotiating table if she was that transparent. "For the rest," she said carefully, "I have reached no decision as yet."

"ə waɪz dɪsɪʒən, ðæt," kædzueɪn mɝmɝd, wɪð ə pɔɪntəd lʊk ət mɛɹænə. "ɪt simz ðəɾ ɪn ðə læs fju jɪɹz fɑɹ tu mɛni sɪstɝz əv fɝɡɑɾən ðeɪ pəzɛs bɹeɪnz, əɹ dɪskɹɛʃən. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm wən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹitʃt ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒənz æftɝ kɑm dɪlɪbɝeɪʃən, wɪð ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɔlweɪz ɪn ðə fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ θɔts. dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt ðə sɑntʃ ɡɝl ɡɑt fɹəm mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ælθɹ, ənʊɹə. wɔk tu nɪɹ ə fɔɹdʒ-faɪɝ, ən jə kən bi bɝn bædli."

"A wise decision, that," Cadsuane murmured, with a pointed look at Merana. "It seems that in the last few years far too many sisters have forgotten they possess brains, or discretion. There was a time when Aes Sedai reached their decisions after calm deliberation, with the good of the Tower always in the front of their thoughts. Just remember what the Sanche girl got from meddling with al'Thor, Annoura. Walk too near a forge-fire, and you can be burned badly."

mɛɹænə lɪftəɾ əɹ tʃɪn, wɝkɪŋ əɹ nɛk tə iz ɪts taɪtnəs. ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf stɑp. ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt stæn ðət fɑɹ əbʌv hɝ. nɑt ɹɪli. dʒʌs haɪɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ. "ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk . . ." tu dɪfəɾənt, bʌt wɝs tə stɑp ən stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ. ". . . wʌɾ ɑɹ jəɹ ɪntɛntʃənz, kædzueɪn?" ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə meɪnteɪn dɪɡnəɾi. "ɑbviəsli, juv bɪn . . . hoʊldɪŋ jɝsɛlf əsaɪd . . . əntɪl naʊ. waɪ hæv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə . . . əpɹoʊtʃ . . . ælθɹ ət ðɪs pɝtɪkjəlɝ taɪm? jə wɝ . . . ɹæðɝ ʌndəpləmæɾɪk . . . wɪð hɪm."

Merana lifted her chin, working her neck to ease its tightness. Realizing what she was doing, she made herself stop. The woman did not stand that far above her. Not really. Just higher than any other sister. "If I may ask . . ." Too diffident, but worse to stop and start over. ". . . what are your intentions, Cadsuane?" She struggled to maintain dignity. "Obviously, you have been . . . holding yourself aside . . . until now. Why have you decided to . . . approach . . . al'Thor at this particular time? You were . . . rather undiplomatic . . . with him."

"ju maɪɾ əz wɛl əv slæpt ɪz feɪs," ənʊɹə pʊɾ ɪn, ən mɛɹænə kʌlɝd. ʌv ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, ənʊɹə ʃʊɾə bɪn hævɪŋ ðə hɑɹɾɝ taɪm wɪð kædzueɪn baɪ fɑɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ wɝdz.

"You might as well have slapped his face," Annoura put in, and Merana colored. Of the two of them, Annoura should have been having the harder time with Cadsuane by far, but she was not the one stumbling over her words.

kædzueɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn pɪɾiɪŋ staɪl. "ɪf jə wɑnə si wʌɾ ə mæn ɪz meɪɾ ʌv, pʊʃ ɪm fɹəm ə dɝɛkʃən i dʌzn ɪkspɛkt. ðɛɹz ɡʊd mɛɾəl ɪn ðət bɔɪ, aɪ θɪŋk, bʌt hiz gɑnə bi dɪfəkəlt." stipəlɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ʃi pɪɹɾ əkɹɔs əm ət ðə wɔl, mjuzɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "hi hæz ə ɹeɪdʒ ɪn ɪm fɪt tə bɝn ðə wɝld, ən i hoʊlz ɪt baɪ ə hɛɹ. pʊʃ ɪm tu fɑɹ ɔf bæləns. . . . fɔ! ælθɹz nɑt soʊ hɑɹd jɛɾ əz lɑɡən əblɝ əɹ mæzɹim teɪm, bʌɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz əz dɪfəkəlt, aɪ fɪɹ." hɪɹɪŋ ðoʊz θɹi neɪmz təɡɛðɝ kloʊv mɛɹænəz tʌŋ tə ðə ɹuf ə hɝ maʊθ.

Cadsuane shook her head in pitying style. "If you want to see what a man is made of, push him from a direction he doesn't expect. There's good metal in that boy, I think, but he's going to be difficult." Steepling her fingers, she peered across them at the wall, musing to herself. "He has a rage in him fit to burn the world, and he holds it by a hair. Push him too far off balance. . . . Phaw! Al'Thor's not so hard yet as Logain Ablar or Mazrim Taim, but a hundred times as difficult, I fear." Hearing those three names together clove Merana's tongue to the roof of her mouth.

"ju hæv sin lɑɡən ən teɪm boʊθ?" ə stɛɹɪŋ ənʊɹə sɛd. "teɪm, hiz fɑloʊɪŋ ælθɹ, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ." mɛɹænə mænədʒ tə swɑloʊ ə ɹɪliv saɪ. teɪlz ə dəməaɪz wɛlz hæd nɑt hæd taɪm tə spɹɛd jɛt. ðeɪ wʊd, ðoʊ.

"You have seen Logain and Taim both?" a staring Annoura said. "Taim, he is following al'Thor, so I hear." Merana managed to swallow a relieved sigh. Tales of Dumai's Wells had not had time to spread yet. They would, though.

"aɪ də hæv ɪɹz tə kætʃ ɹumɝz, tu, ənʊɹə," kædzueɪn sɛɾ əsɝbɪkli. "ðoʊ aɪ kəd wɪʃ aɪ dɪdnt, fəɹ wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ ə ðət pɛɹ. ɔl maɪ wɝk θɹoʊn əweɪ tə bi dʌn oʊvɝ. ʌðɝz' əz wɛl, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd maɪ ʃɛɹ. ən ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ ðiz blækoʊts, ðiz æʃəmən." teɪkɪŋ ə kʌp fɹəm deɪdʒiən, ʃi smaɪld wɔɹmli ən mɝmɝd θæŋks. ðə ɹaʊnd-tʃikt waɪt simd ɹɛɾi tə kɝtsi, ðoʊ ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz ɹitʃɹit tə ə kɔɹnɝ ən foʊld əɹ hænz. ʃi hæd bɪn lɔŋɡɝ ə nɑvəs, ən æksɛptɪd, ðən ɛniwʌn ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi, bɛɹli əlaʊd tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɡeɪnɪŋ ðə ɹɪŋ baɪ ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl ən ðə ʃɔl baɪ ən aɪlæʃ. deɪdʒiən wɑz ɔlweɪz sɛlf-ɪfeɪsɪŋ ɝaʊn ʌðɝ sɪstɝz.

"I do have ears to catch rumors, too, Annoura," Cadsuane said acerbically. "Though I could wish I didn't, for what I hear of that pair. All my work thrown away to be done over. Others' as well, but I did my share. And then there are these blackcoats, these Asha'man." Taking a cup from Daigian, she smiled warmly and murmured thanks. The round-cheeked White seemed ready to curtsy, though all she did was retreat to a corner and fold her hands. She had been longer a novice, and Accepted, than anyone in living memory, barely allowed to remain in the Tower, gaining the ring by a fingernail and the shawl by an eyelash. Daigian was always self-effacing around other sisters.

bɹiðɪŋ ðə stim fɹəm əɹ tikʌp, kædzueɪn wɛn ɑn, sʌɾənli tʃæɾɪŋ plɛzənli. "ɪt wɑz lɑɡən, pɹæktəkli ɑn maɪ dɔɹstɛp, ðət lʊɹd mi əweɪ fɹəm maɪ ɹoʊzɪz. fɔ! ə skʌfəl əɾ ə ʃip fɛɹ cʊɾə lʊɹd mi fɹəm ðoʊz laɪt-kɝs plæns. wʌts ðə pɔɪn ɪf jə juz ðə paʊɝ, bʌt də ɪt wɪθaʊt, ən jə ɡɹoʊ tɛn θaʊzən θɔɹnz fəɹ ɛvɹi - fɔ! aɪ æktʃəli  kənsɪɾɝd teɪkɪŋ ði oʊθ əz ə hʌntɝ, ɪf ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn wəɾ əlaʊ ɪt. wɛl. ɪt wɑz ə naɪs fju mʌnθs, tʃeɪsɪŋ daʊn lɑɡən, bʌt wʌns i wɑz teɪkən, ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ ɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əpild əz mʌtʃ əz ðə ɹoʊzɪz. aɪ wɑndɝɾ ə bɪt, tə si wʌɾ aɪ kəd faɪnd, pɝhæps ə nu wɔɹɾɝ, ðoʊ ɪts ə bɪt leɪt fəɹ ðəɾ ɪn ɛni fɛɹnəs tə ðə mæn, aɪ səpoʊz. ðən aɪ hɝɾ ə teɪm, ən aɪ wɑz ɔf tə sɑldɑiə əz fæst aɪ kəd ɹaɪd. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪksaɪtmən laɪk ə mæn u kən tʃænəl." əbɹʌpli hɝ vɔɪs hɑɹɾənd, ən əɹ ɡeɪz. "wɝ iðɝ ə jə ɪnvɑlvd ɪn ðət . . . vɪlnəs . . . ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ði il wɔɹ?"

Breathing the steam from her teacup, Cadsuane went on, suddenly chatting pleasantly. "It was Logain, practically on my doorstep, that lured me away from my roses. Phaw! A scuffle at a sheep fair could have lured me from those Light-cursed plants. What's the point if you use the Power, but do it without, and you grow ten thousand thorns for every - Phaw! I actually considered taking the oath as a Hunter, if the Council of Nine would allow it. Well. It was a nice few months, chasing down Logain, but once he was taken, escorting him to Tar Valon appealed as much as the roses. I wandered a bit, to see what I could find, perhaps a new Warder, though it's a bit late for that in any fairness to the man, I suppose. Then I heard of Taim, and I was off to Saldaea as fast I could ride. There's nothing for a bit of excitement like a man who can channel." Abruptly her voice hardened, and her gaze. "Were either of you involved in that . . . vileness . . . right after the Aiel War?"

dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, mɛɹænə ɡeɪv ə kənfjuz stɑɹt. ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz aɪz spoʊk ə ðə blɑk ən ðə hɛdzmənz æks. "wʌt vɪlnəs? aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt."

Despite herself, Merana gave a confused start. The other woman's eyes spoke of the block and the headsman's axe. "What vileness? I don't know what you are talking about."

ðəɾ əkjuzɪŋ ɡlɛɹ hɪɾ ənʊɹə soʊ hɑɹd, ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl ɔf ðə bɛd. "ði il wɔɹ?" ʃi ɡæspt, stɛɾiɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "ðə jɪɹz æftɝ, aɪ spɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ðə soʊ-kɔld ɡɹæn koʊəlɪʃən mɔɹ ðən ə neɪm."

That accusing glare hit Annoura so hard, she almost fell off the bed. "The Aiel War?" she gasped, steadying herself. "The years after, I spent trying to make the so-called Grand Coalition more than a name."

mɛɹænə lʊkt əɾ ənʊɹə wɪð ɪntʃɹəst. ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ hæd skɝid fɹəm kæpəɾəl tə kæpəɾəl æftɝ ðə wɔɹ, ɪn ə fjuɾəl ɛfɝt tə hoʊl təɡɛðɝ ði əlaɪəns ðət hæd fɔɹmd əɡɛns ði il, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ənʊɹə wɑz wʌn ə ðɛm. ʃi kəd nɑt bi ðət bæɾ ə nəɡoʊʃieɪɾɝ ɪf ʃi wɑz. "soʊ dɪɾ aɪ," ʃi sɛd. dɪɡnəɾi. sɪns sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ æftɝ ælθɹ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪteɪn mʌtʃ ə ðæt. ðə fju skɹæps ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ wɝ tu pɹɛʃəs tə luz. ʃi meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs kɑm, ən fɝm. "wʌt vɪlnəs dʒju min, kædzueɪn?"

Merana looked at Annoura with interest. A good many of the Gray Ajah had scurried from capital to capital after the war, in a futile effort to hold together the alliance that had formed against the Aiel, but she had never known Annoura was one of them. She could not be that bad a negotiator if she was. "So did I," she said. Dignity. Since setting out after al'Thor from Caemlyn, she had not retained much of that. The few scraps remaining were too precious to lose. She made her voice calm, and firm. "What vileness do you mean, Cadsuane?"

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən sɪmpli weɪv ðə kwɛstʃən əweɪ, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ spoʊkən ðə wɝd.

The gray-haired woman simply waved the question away, as though she had never spoken the word.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, mɛɹænə wʌndɝd wɛðɝ kædzueɪnz wɪts maɪt bi wɑndɝɪŋ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɪt hæpənɪŋ tə ə sɪstɝ, bʌt moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd ɡoʊ ɪndə ɹitʃɹiɾ ət ðə kloʊs ə ðɛɹ lɪvz, fɑɹ fɹəm ðə stʃɹæɾədʒəmz ən tɝbjələns ðət nʌn bʌt sɪstɝz ɛvɝ nu. fɑɹ fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn, ɔfən əz nɑt. hu kəd seɪ wʌt bɪfɛl əm bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnd? wʌn lʊk ət ðə klɪɹ, stɛɾi ɡeɪz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ oʊvɝ ðət tikʌp kwɪkli dɪsɑbjuzd əɹ ʌv ɛni sətʃ noʊʃən. ɛniweɪ, twɛnti-jɪɹ-oʊl vɪlnəs, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt hæd bɪn, sɝɾənli kəd nɑt hoʊld ə kændəl tə wʌt ðə wɝl kənfɹʌntəd naʊ. ən kædzueɪn stɪl hæd nɑɾ ænsɝɾ əɹ ɝɪdʒənəl kwɛstʃənz. wʌd ʃi ɪntɛnd? ən waɪ naʊ?

For a moment, Merana wondered whether Cadsuane's wits might be wandering. She had never heard of it happening to a sister, but most Aes Sedai did go into retreat at the close of their lives, far from the stratagems and turbulence that none but sisters ever knew. Far from everyone, often as not. Who could say what befell them before the end? One look at the clear, steady gaze regarding her over that teacup quickly disabused her of any such notion. Anyway, twenty-year-old vileness, whatever it had been, certainly could not hold a candle to what the world confronted now. And Cadsuane still had not answered her original questions. What did she intend? And why now?
