bɪfɔɹ mɛɹænə kəɾ æsk əɡɛn, ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə wɝ hɝɾɪd ɪn baɪ kɔɹəl hoʊviən, ə bɔɪɪʃli slɪm jɛloʊ wɪð θɪk blæk aɪbɹaʊz ən ə mæs ə ɹeɪvən hɛɹ ðət ɡeɪv əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə waɪld əpɪɹəns noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ nitli ʃi dʒɹɛst, ən ʃi ɔlweɪz dʒɹɛs fəɹ ə kʌntʃɹi dæns, wɪð mæsəz ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn əɹ slivz ən bɑɾəs ən ʌp ðə saɪdz ə hɝ skɝts. ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɹum tə muv, wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl ɪn ðɪs kənfaɪn speɪs. kɔɹəl nɛvɝ feɪl tə sim əmjuzd, wʌtɛvɝ hæpənd, bʌt naʊ ʃi wɔɹ ə waɪd smaɪl sʌmwɛɹ bɪtwin dɪsbɪlif ən aʊtʃɹaɪt læftɝ. kaɪɹunəz aɪz flæʃt ɪn ə feɪs ə fɹoʊzən ɛɹəɡəns, waɪl bɛɹə fjumd, maʊθ taɪɾ ən fɔɹhɛd kɹist. əntɪl ðeɪ sɔ kædzueɪn. mɛɹænə səpoʊz ðət fəɹ ðɛm, ɪt mʌs bi əz ɪf ʃi hæd faʊn hɝsɛlf feɪs tə feɪs wɪð əlɪn dɪfɛl əɹ sɛvlænə məsoʊ əɹ ivən mæbɹiəm ɛn ʃɛɹid. ðɛɹ aɪz bʌlʒd. kaɪɹunəz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt.

Before Merana could ask again, the door opened and Bera and Kiruna were herded in by Corele Hovian, a boyishly slim Yellow with thick black eyebrows and a mass of raven hair that gave her something of a wild appearance no matter how neatly she dressed, and she always dressed for a country dance, with masses of embroidery on her sleeves and bodice and up the sides of her skirts. There was barely room to move, with so many people in this confined space. Corele never failed to seem amused, whatever happened, but now she wore a wide smile somewhere between disbelief and outright laughter. Kiruna's eyes flashed in a face of frozen arrogance, while Bera fumed, mouth tight and forehead creased. Until they saw Cadsuane. Merana supposed that for them, it must be as if she had found herself face to face with Alind Dyfelle or Sevlana Meseau or even Mabriam en Shereed. Their eyes bulged. Kiruna's jaw dropped.

"aɪ θɔt jə wɝ dɛd," bɛɹə bɹiðd.

"I thought you were dead," Bera breathed.

kædzueɪn snɪft ɪɹɪɾəbli. "aɪ æm ɡɹoʊɪŋ taɪɝɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ ðæt. ðə nɛkst ɪmbɪsil aɪ hɪɹ ɪt fɹəm ɪz gɑnə jɛlp fəɹ ə wik." ənʊɹə bɪɡæn stʌɾiɪŋ ðə toʊz ə hɝ slɪpɝz.

Cadsuane sniffed irritably. "I am growing tired of hearing that. The next imbecile I hear it from is going to yelp for a week." Annoura began studying the toes of her slippers.

"jul nɛvɝ ɡɛs wɛɹ aɪ faʊn ðiz tu," kɔɹəl sɛɾ ɪn əɹ lɪltɪŋ mʊɹændiən æksɛnt. ʃi tæp ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ ʌptɝnd noʊz, ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd wən əbaʊt tə tɛl ə dʒoʊk, əɹ wʌt ʃi sɔ əz wʌn. spɑts ə kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn bɛɹəz tʃiks, ən lɑɹdʒɝ ɪn kaɪɹunəz. "bɛɹə ðəɹ wɑz sɪɾɪŋ mik əz ə maʊs ʌndɝ ði aɪz ə hæf ə dʌzən ə ðoʊz il waɪldɝz, hu toʊl mi boʊld əz jə pliz ðət ʃi kʊdn kʌm wɪð mi əntɪl sɔɹɪliə - oʊ, naʊ ðət wʊmənz ə hɛɹɹəɾən tə ɡɪv jə naɪtmɛɹz, ʃiz - aɪ kʊdn əv bɛɹə əntɪl sɔɹɪliə wɑz dʌn wɪð əɹ pɹaɪvət tʃæt wɪð ði ʌðɝ əpɹɛntəs. əɹ dɑɹlɪŋ kaɪɹunə, ðɛɹ."

"You'll never guess where I found these two," Corele said in her lilting Murandian accent. She tapped the side of her upturned nose, the way she did when about to tell a joke, or what she saw as one. Spots of color appeared in Bera's cheeks, and larger in Kiruna's. "Bera there was sitting meek as a mouse under the eyes of half a dozen of those Aiel wilders, who told me bold as you please that she couldn't come with me until Sorilea - oh, now that woman's a harridan to give you nightmares, she is - I couldn't have Bera until Sorilea was done with her private chat with the other apprentice. Our darling Kiruna, there."

ɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə mæɾɝ ə spɑts. kaɪɹunə ən bɛɹə ɹɛɾənd tə ðɛɹ hɛɹ, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə miɾ ɛniwʌnz aɪ. ivən deɪdʒiən stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm.

It was no longer a matter of spots. Kiruna and Bera reddened to their hair, refusing to meet anyone's eye. Even Daigian stared at them.

ɹɪlif sɝdʒ θɹu mɛɹænə ɪn wʌndɝfəl weɪvz. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə bi ðə wʌn tə ɪkspleɪn haʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ ɪntɝpɹəɾəd ðət ɹɛtʃɪɾ ælθɹz ɔɹɾɝz ðət ðə sɪstɝz wɝ tə oʊbeɪ ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɹɪli əpɹɛntəsɪz; ðəɹ wɝ noʊ lɛsənz ɪnvɑlvd, ʌv kɔɹs. wʌt kəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt lɑɾ ʌv waɪldɝz, sævədʒəz ət ðæt, titʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz laɪk tə noʊ wɛɹ ɛvɹiwʌn fɪt. dʒʌst? bɛɹə əɹ kaɪɹunə kəd tɛl haʊ ælθɹ hæd læft - læft! - ən sɛɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns tə hɪm ən i ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi oʊbiɾiənt pjupəlz. noʊ wʌn wɑz hævɪŋ ən izi taɪm bɛndɪŋ əɹ nɛk, list ʌv ɔl kaɪɹunə.

Relief surged through Merana in wonderful waves. She would not have to be the one to explain how the Wise Ones had interpreted that wretched al'Thor's orders that the sisters were to obey them. They were not really apprentices; there were no lessons involved, of course. What could a great lot of wilders, savages at that, teach Aes Sedai? It was just that the Wise Ones liked to know where everyone fit. Just? Bera or Kiruna could tell how al'Thor had laughed - laughed! - and said it made no difference to him and he expected them to be obedient pupils. No one was having an easy time bending her neck, least of all Kiruna.

jɛt kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt dɪmæn ɛkspləneɪʃənz. "aɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə dɔɡz dɪnɝ," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌt nɑɾ ə bʌkət fɹəm ðə mɪɾən. lemi si ɪf aɪ hæv ðə stʃɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt. jə tʃɪlʒɹən u stæn ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ə lɔfəli ɹeɪzd æmɪɝlɪn əv naʊ sʌmhaʊ əsoʊsieɪɾəd jʊɹsɛlvz wɪð ði ælθɹ bɔɪ, ən ɪf jə ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm ðiz il wɪmən, aɪ əsum jə teɪk ɪz əz wɛl." hɝ ɡɹʌnt wɑz dɪsɡʌstəɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə maʊθfʊl ə ɹɑɾən plʌmz. ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ʃi pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɝ tikʌp, ðən fɪks ðə pɛɹ əɡɛn. "wɛl, wʌts wʌn tʃɹizən mɔɹ əɹ lɛs? ðə hɔl kən pʊt jə ɑn jəɹ niz fɹəm hɪɹ tə tɑɹmən ɡdən fəɹ pɛnəns, bʌt ðeɪ kən oʊnli teɪk jəɹ hɛdz wʌns. wʌɾ ə ðə ɹɛst, aʊɾ ɪn ði il kæmp? ɔl ɪleɪɾəz, aɪ səpoʊz. hæv ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ . . . əpɹɛntəst . . . ðɛmsɛlvz? nʌn ʌv əs əv bɪn əlaʊɾ əz kloʊs əz ðə fɝst ɹoʊ ʌv tɛns. ðiz il sim tə hæv noʊ lʌv ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Yet Cadsuane did not demand explanations. "I expected a dog's dinner," she said dryly, "but not a bucket from the midden. Let me see if I have the straight of it. You children who stand in rebellion against a lawfully raised Amyrlin have now somehow associated yourselves with the al'Thor boy, and if you are taking orders from these Aiel women, I assume you take his as well." Her grunt was disgusted enough for a mouthful of rotten plums. Shaking her head, she peered into her teacup, then fixed the pair again. "Well, what's one treason more or less? The Hall can put you on your knees from here to Tarmon Gai'don for penance, but they can only take your heads once. What of the rest, out in the Aiel camp? All Elaida's, I suppose. Have they also . . . apprenticed . . . themselves? None of us have been allowed as close as the first row of tents. These Aiel seem to have no love of Aes Sedai."

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ, kædzueɪn," kaɪɹunə ænsɝd, soʊ ɹɛd-feɪst ʃi əpɪɹɾ əbaʊt tə kætʃ faɪɝ. "wi hæv bɪn kɛpt əpɑɹt." mɛɹænəz aɪz waɪɾənd. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hɝd kaɪɹunə saʊn dɛfɝɛntʃəl.

"I do not know, Cadsuane," Kiruna answered, so red-faced she appeared about to catch fire. "We have been kept apart." Merana's eyes widened. She had never before heard Kiruna sound deferential.

bɛɹə, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi stʊd stʃɹeɪt, jɛt ʃi sim tə stʃɹeɪɾən hɝsɛlf fəɹ ən ənplɛzən tæsk. "ɪleɪɾə ɪz nɑt - " ʃi bɪɡæn hiɾɪdli.

Bera, on the other hand, drew a deep breath. She already stood straight, yet she seemed to straighten herself for an unpleasant task. "Elaida is not - " she began heatedly.

"ɪleɪɾə ɪz oʊvɝæmbɪʃəs, əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən meɪk aʊt," kædzueɪn bɹoʊk ɪn, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd soʊ əbɹʌpli ðət mɛɹænə ən ənʊɹə boʊθ stɑɹɾəd bæk ɑn ðə bɛd, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm, "ænd ʃi meɪ bi ə kətæstʃɹəfi sɪmɝɪŋ, bʌt ʃiz stɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ɹeɪz baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪn fʊl əkɔɹɾəns wɪð ðə lɔz ə ðə taʊɝ."

"Elaida is overambitious, as near as I can make out," Cadsuane broke in, leaning forward so abruptly that Merana and Annoura both started back on the bed, though she was not looking at them, "and she may be a catastrophe simmering, but she is still the Amyrlin Seat, raised by the Hall of the Tower in full accordance with the laws of the Tower."

"ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɪz ə lɔfəl æmɪɝlɪn, waɪ hæv jə nɑɾ oʊbeɪɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹɪtɝn?" ɔl ðət bɪtʃɹeɪd bɛɹəz læk ə kəmpoʊʒɝ wɑz ðə stɪlnəs ə hɝ hænz ɑn əɹ skɝts. oʊnli ə mɑɹkt ɛfɝt tə kip fɹəm klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ smuðɪŋ kəd hoʊld əm soʊ moʊʃənləs.

"If Elaida is a lawful Amyrlin, why have you not obeyed her order to return?" All that betrayed Bera's lack of composure was the stillness of her hands on her skirts. Only a marked effort to keep from clutching or smoothing could hold them so motionless.

"soʊ wʌn ə jə hæz ə lɪɾəl bækboʊn." kædzueɪn læf sɔfli, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz dɪd nɑt lʊk mɝθfəl əɾ ɔl. linɪŋ bæk, ʃi sɪpt əɹ ti. "naʊ sɪt daʊn. aɪ hæv ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz."

"So one of you has a little backbone." Cadsuane laughed softly, but her eyes did not look mirthful at all. Leaning back, she sipped her tea. "Now sit down. I have a great many more questions."

mɛɹænə ən ənʊɹə ɹoʊz, ɔfɝɪŋ ðɛɹ pleɪsəz ɑn ðə bɛd, bʌt kaɪɹunə sɪmpli stʊd piɹɪŋ ət kædzueɪn wɝidli, ən bɛɹə ɡlænst əɾ əɹ fɹɛnd, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. kɔɹəl ɹoʊld əɹ blu aɪz, ɡɹɪnɪŋ bɹɔdli fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ.

Merana and Annoura rose, offering their places on the bed, but Kiruna simply stood peering at Cadsuane worriedly, and Bera glanced at her friend, then shook her head. Corele rolled her blue eyes, grinning broadly for some reason, but Cadsuane did not seem to care.

"hæf ðə ɹumɝz aɪ hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, "kənsɝn ðə fɔɹseɪkən biɪŋ lus. ɪt wəd hɑɹdli bi ə sɝpɹaɪz, wɪð ɔl ɛls, bʌt juv ɛni ɛvəɾəns, fəɹ əɹ əɡɛnst?"

"Half the rumors I hear," she said, "concern the Forsaken being loose. It would hardly be a surprise, with all else, but do you have any evidence, for or against?"

bɪfɔɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ, mɛɹænə wɑz ɡlæd tə bi sɪɾɪŋ; bɪfɔɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ, ʃi nu wʌt lɔnʒɹi fɛlt ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə lɔnʒɹɪsəz mæŋɡəl. kædzueɪn dɪɾ ɔl ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ, dɑdʒɪŋ fɹəm tɑpɪk tə tɑpɪk soʊ jə nɛvɝ nu wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ nɛkst. kɔɹəl hɛld əɹ pis ɪksɛp fəɹ tʃʌklɪŋ naʊ ən ðən əɹ ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ən deɪdʒiən dɪd nɑɾ ivən də ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs. mɛɹænə kɑt ðə wɝst, hɝ ən bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə, jɛɾ ənʊɹə wɑz sɝɾənli nɑt spɛɹd. ɛvɹi taɪm bɹəleɪnz ædvaɪzɝ ɹɪlækst, θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə klɪɹ, kædzueɪn skjuɝɾ əɹ ənu.

Before very long, Merana was glad to be sitting; before very long, she knew what laundry felt going through the laundress's mangle. Cadsuane did all the questioning, dodging from topic to topic so you never knew what was coming next. Corele held her peace except for chuckling now and then or shaking her head, and Daigian did not even do that, of course. Merana caught the worst, her and Bera and Kiruna, yet Annoura was certainly not spared. Every time Berelain's advisor relaxed, thinking she was in the clear, Cadsuane skewered her anew.

ðə wʊmən wɑntəd tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, fɹəm ði ælθɹ bɔɪz əθɔɹəɾi wɪð ði il tə waɪ ə si foʊk weɪvməstʃɹəs wɑz æŋkɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, fɹəm wɛðɝ mɔɪɹeɪn tʃɹuli wɑz dɛd tə wɛðɝ ðə bɔɪ ɹɪli hæd ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd tʃɹævlɪŋ ən wɛðɝ bɹəleɪn hæd bɛɾəd ɪm əɹ hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɪt. wʌt kædzueɪn θɔɾ ə ði ænsɝz wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə seɪ, ɪksɛpt wʌns, wən ʃi lɝn ðəɾ ɑlɑnə hæd bɑndəɾ ælθɹ, ən haʊ. hɝ maʊθ kəmpɹɛs tə ə θɪn laɪn ən ʃi fɹaʊn ə hoʊl ðoʊ ðə wɔl, bʌt waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪkspɹɛs dɪsɡʌst, mɛɹænə θɔɾ ə kædzueɪn seɪɪŋ ʃi hæd kənsɪɾɝd teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ hɝsɛlf.

The woman wanted to know everything, from the al'Thor boy's authority with the Aiel to why a Sea Folk Wavemistress was anchored in the river, from whether Moiraine truly was dead to whether the boy really had rediscovered Traveling and whether Berelain had bedded him or had any intention of it. What Cadsuane thought of the answers was impossible to say, except once, when she learned that Alanna had bonded al'Thor, and how. Her mouth compressed to a thin line and she frowned a hole though the wall, but while everyone else expressed disgust, Merana thought of Cadsuane saying she had considered taking another Warder herself.

ði ænsɝ wɑz ɪɡnɝəns ɪntaɪɝli tu ɔfən tə sut, bʌt seɪɪŋ jə dɪd nɑt noʊ feɪl tə kwɛntʃ kædzueɪnz æpətaɪt; ʃi ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛvɹi læst ʃɹɛɾ ən pɑɹɾəkəl jə dɪd noʊ, ivən ɪf jə dɪd nɑt noʊ jə nu ɪt. ðeɪ mænədʒ tə kip ə lɪɾəl bæk, moʊst ʌv wʌt hæd tə bi kɛp bæk, jɛɾ ə fju sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ θɪŋz keɪm aʊt ðət weɪ, səm vɛɹi sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, ivən fɹəm ənʊɹə, hu, ɪt tɝn aʊt, hæd bɪn ɹəsivɪŋ dɪteɪld lɛɾɝz fɹəm bɹəleɪn ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə deɪ ðə ɡɝl ɹoʊd nɔɹθ. kædzueɪn dɪmændəɾ ænsɝz, bʌt ɡeɪv nʌn, ən ðət wɝid mɛɹænə. ʃi wɑtʃt feɪsəz ɡɹoʊ dɔɡd ən dɪfɛnsɪv ən əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk, ən wʌndɝd wɛðɝ əɹ oʊn lʊk ðə seɪm.

The answer was ignorance entirely too often to suit, but saying you did not know failed to quench Cadsuane's appetite; she required every last shred and particle you did know, even if you did not know you knew it. They managed to keep a little back, most of what had to be kept back, yet a few surprising things came out that way, some very surprising, even from Annoura, who, it turned out, had been receiving detailed letters from Berelain almost from the day the girl rode north. Cadsuane demanded answers, but gave none, and that worried Merana. She watched faces grow dogged and defensive and apologetic, and wondered whether her own looked the same.

"kædzueɪn." ʃi hæd tə meɪk wʌn mɔɹ ɛfɝt. "kædzueɪn, waɪ hæv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə teɪk ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɪm naʊ?" ən ənblɪŋkɪŋ ɡeɪz mɛt hɝz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən kædzueɪn tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə.

"Cadsuane." She had to make one more effort. "Cadsuane, why have you decided to take an interest in him now?" An unblinking gaze met hers for a moment, then Cadsuane turned her attention to Bera and Kiruna.

"soʊ ðeɪ æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə kɪdnæp ɪm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ ɛmpti kʌp fəɹ deɪdʒiən tə ɹifɪl. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd bɪn ɔfɝd ti. kædzueɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən ən toʊn wɝ soʊ nutʃɹəl ðət mɛɹænə wɑntəd tə tɛɹ əɹ oʊn hɛɹ. ælθɹ wəd nɑt bi plizd ɪf i lɝn kaɪɹunə hæd ɹɪvil ðə kɪdnæpɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ ɪnədvɝɾəntli; kædzueɪn juzd ɛni slɪp ə jəɹ tʌŋ tə pɹaɪ aʊt mɔɹ ðən jə mɛn tə seɪ. ət lis ðə dɪteɪlz ə hɪz tʃɹitmən hæd nɑt kʌm aʊt. hi hæd meɪd pleɪn haʊ dɪsplizd i wəd bi ɪf ðət hæpənd. mɛɹænə θæŋk ðə laɪt ðət ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt steɪɪŋ wɪð ɛni wʌn sʌbʒɪkt fəɹ lɔŋ.

"So they actually managed to kidnap him right out of the palace," the gray-haired woman said, holding out her empty cup for Daigian to refill. No one else had been offered tea. Cadsuane's expression and tone were so neutral that Merana wanted to tear her own hair. Al'Thor would not be pleased if he learned Kiruna had revealed the kidnapping, however inadvertently; Cadsuane used any slip of your tongue to pry out more than you meant to say. At least the details of his treatment had not come out. He had made plain how displeased he would be if that happened. Merana thanked the Light that the woman was not staying with any one subject for long.

"ju ɑɹ ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz teɪm? ən jə ɑɹ ʃʊɹ ðiz blækoʊts dɪdn ɝaɪv ɑn hɔɹsəz?" bɛɹə ænsɝd ɹɪlʌktənli, ən kaɪɹunə sʌlənli; ðeɪ wɝ əz sɝɾən əz ðeɪ kəd bi; noʊ wʌn hæɾ æktʃəli  sin ði æʃəmən kʌm əɹ dɪpɑɹt, ən ðə . . . hoʊl . . . ðət bɹɔɾ əm ɔl cʊɾə əv bɪn meɪd baɪ ælθɹ. wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt sæɾəsfaɪ əɾ ɔl, ʌv kɔɹs.

"You are sure it was Taim? And you are sure these blackcoats didn't arrive on horses?" Bera answered reluctantly, and Kiruna sullenly; they were as certain as they could be; no one had actually seen the Asha'man come or depart, and the . . . hole . . . that brought them all here could have been made by al'Thor. Which did not satisfy at all, of course.

"θɪŋk! jə ɑɹən sɪli ɡɝlz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, əɹ ʃʊdn bi. fɔ! jə mʌst əv noʊɾəst sʌmθɪŋ."

"Think! You aren't silly girls any longer, or shouldn't be. Phaw! You must have noticed something."

mɛɹænə fɛlt ɪl. ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz hæd spɛn hæf ðə naɪɾ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌt ðɛɹ oʊθ mɛn bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ɪt mɛn ɪɡzækli wʌt ðeɪ hæd sɛd, wɪð noʊ luphoʊlz tə ɹɪɡəl θɹu. ət læst ivən kaɪɹunə kənsiɾɪd ðət ðeɪ mʌs dɪfɛn ən səpɔɹɾ ælθɹ əz wɛl əz oʊbeɪ, ðət stændɪŋ əsaɪɾ ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst wɑz nɑt pɝmɪɾəd. wʌt ðət maɪt min wən ɪt keɪm tə ɪleɪɾə ən ðə sɪstɝz lɔɪəl tə hɝ ɹɪli kənsɝnd noʊ wʌn. ət list, noʊ wʌn ədmɪɾəd ɛni kənsɝn. ðə mɪɹ fækt ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd wɑz stʌnɝ ɪnʌf. bʌt mɛɹænə wʌndɝd wɛðɝ bɛɹə əɹ kaɪɹunə hæd jɛt ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi hæd. ðeɪ maɪt dʒʌs faɪn ðɛmsɛlvz əpoʊzɪŋ ə lɛdʒənd, nɑt tə mɛnʃən wʌtɛvɝ sɪstɝz bɪsaɪdz kɔɹəl ən deɪdʒiən hæd tʃoʊzən tə fɑloʊ hɝ. wɝs. . . . kædzueɪnz aɪz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn əɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɡɪvɪŋ əweɪ nʌθɪŋ, dɪmændɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. wɝs, mɛɹænə wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət kædzueɪn nu ðət vɛɹi wɛl.

Merana felt ill. She and the others had spent half the night arguing over what their oath meant before deciding it meant exactly what they had said, with no loopholes to wriggle through. At last even Kiruna conceded that they must defend and support al'Thor as well as obey, that standing aside in the slightest was not permitted. What that might mean when it came to Elaida and the sisters loyal to her really concerned no one. At least, no one admitted any concern. The mere fact of what they had decided was stunner enough. But Merana wondered whether Bera or Kiruna had yet realized what she had. They might just find themselves opposing a legend, not to mention whatever sisters besides Corele and Daigian had chosen to follow her. Worse. . . . Cadsuane's eyes rested on her for a moment, giving away nothing, demanding everything. Worse, Merana was sure that Cadsuane knew that very well.

hɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə pæləs kɔɹɪɾɝz, mɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ɡɹiɾɪŋz fɹəm hæf ə dʌzən meɪɾənz ʃi nu, dʒʌs tʃɹɑɾəd ɹaɪt baɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn, nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz biɪŋ ɹud. tʃɹɑɾɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ izi ɪn hil buts. ðə ful θɪŋz wɪmən dɪd fəɹ mɛn! nɑt ðət ɹænd hæɾ æskt əɹ tə wɛɹ ðə buts, bʌt ʃi pʊɾ əm ɑn ðə fɝs taɪm wɪð ɪm ɪn maɪnd, ən ʃi hæd sin ɪm smaɪl. hi laɪk ðɛm. laɪt, wʌt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt buts! ʃi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv ɡɔn tə koʊləveɪɪɹz əpɑɹtməns. ʃɪvɝɪŋ, blɪŋkɪŋ bæk ənʃt tɪɹz, ʃi bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn.

Hurrying along the palace corridors, Min ignored greetings from half a dozen Maidens she knew, just trotted right by without a word in return, never considering that she was being rude. Trotting was not easy in heeled boots. The fool things women did for men! Not that Rand had asked her to wear the boots, but she put them on the first time with him in mind, and she had seen him smile. He liked them. Light, what was she doing, thinking about boots! She should never have gone to Colavaere's apartments. Shivering, blinking back unshed tears, she began to run.

əz juʒəwəl, ə nʌmbɝ ə meɪɾənz wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz bɪsaɪd ðə tɔl dɔɹz wɝkt wɪð ɡɪldɪd ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌnz. ðɛɹ ʃoʊufə hʌŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən ðɛɹ spɪɹz leɪ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ niz, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ kæʒəwəl əbaʊt ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ lɛpɝdz, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə kɪl. juʒəwəli meɪɾənz meɪd mɪn ənizi, fəɹ ɔl ðeɪ wɝ fɹɛnli ɪnʌf. tədeɪ, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv kɛɹɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ veɪld.

As usual, a number of Maidens were squatting on their heels beside the tall doors worked with gilded rising suns. Their shoufa hung about their shoulders and their spears lay across their knees, yet there was nothing casual about them. They were leopards, waiting for something to kill. Usually Maidens made Min uneasy, for all they were friendly enough. Today, she would not have cared if they were veiled.

"hi ɪz ɪn ə faʊl tɛmpɝ," ɹaɪəlɪn wɔɹnd, bʌt meɪd noʊ muv tə stɑp hɝ. mɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ɹændz pɹɛzəns wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ənaʊnst. ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ koʊɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə sɛɾəl hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ ʃi hæd kʌm. ɪksɛp ðət ɹænd meɪɾ əɹ fil seɪf. bɝn hɪm! ʃi hæd nɛvɝ niɾəd ɛniwʌn tə fil seɪf bɪfɔɹ.

"He is in a foul temper," Riallin warned, but made no move to stop her. Min was one of the few allowed to enter Rand's presence without being announced. She straightened her coat and tried to settle herself. She was not sure why she had come. Except that Rand made her feel safe. Burn him! She had never needed anyone to feel safe before.

dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, ʃi stɑpt, əɡæst. ɔɾəmætɪkli, ʃi pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə pleɪs wɑz ə ʃæmbəlz. ə fju ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ʃɑɹdz klʌŋ tə səm ə ðə mɪɹɝ fɹeɪmz, bʌt moʊst ə ðə ɡlæs leɪ skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. ðə deɪz wɑz ɑn ɪts saɪd, ðə θɹoʊn ðət hæd stʊɾ ətɑp ɪt dʒʌst ɡɪldɪd flɪndɝz wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn smæʃt əɡɛnst ə wɔl. wʌn ə ðə stænd-læmps, hɛvi aɪɝn bɪniθ ðə ɡɪlt, hæd bɪn twɪstəɾ ɪndə ə hup. ɹænd sæɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ tʃɛɹz ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ɑɹmz dæŋɡəlɪŋ ən hɛd bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ. stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. ɪmədʒəz dænst əbaʊɾ ɪm ən kʌlɝɾ ɔʊɹəz flɪkɝɾ ən flɛɹd; hi wɑz laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðæt. ʃi hæd noʊ niɾ ʌv ɪluməneɪɾɝz wən ɹænd əɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɪn saɪt. hi dɪd nɑt muv əz ʃi wɔk fɑɹðɝ ɪndə ðə ɹum. hi dɪd nɑt sim əwɛɹ ə hɝ əɾ ɔl. ʃæɾɝd bɪts ə mɪɹɝ kɹʌntʃt bɪniθ əɹ buts. ə faʊl tɛmpɝ, ɪndid.

Just inside the room, she stopped, aghast. Automatically, she pushed the door shut behind her. The place was a shambles. A few glittering shards clung to some of the mirror frames, but most of the glass lay scattered across the floor. The dais was on its side, the throne that had stood atop it just gilded flinders where it had been smashed against a wall. One of the stand-lamps, heavy iron beneath the gilt, had been twisted into a hoop. Rand sat in one of the smaller chairs in his shirtsleeves, arms dangling and head back, staring at the ceiling. Staring at nothing. Images danced about him and colored auras flickered and flared; he was like Aes Sedai in that. She had no need of Illuminators when Rand or an Aes Sedai was in sight. He did not move as she walked farther into the room. He did not seem aware of her at all. Shattered bits of mirror crunched beneath her boots. A foul temper, indeed.

ivən soʊ, ʃi fɛl noʊ fɪɹ. nɑɾ ə hɪm; ʃi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən ɹænd hɑɹmɪŋ hɝ. fəɹ hɪm, ʃi fɛlt ɪnʌf tə nɪɹli pɝdʒ ðə mɛmɹi ʌv koʊləveɪɪɹz əpɑɹtməns fɹəm əɹ hɛd. ʃi hæd lɔŋ sɪns ɹɛkənsaɪl hɝsɛlf tə biɪŋ hoʊpləsli ɪn lʌv. nʌθɪŋ ɛls mæɾɝd, nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz ən ʌnsəfɪstɪkeɪɾɪd kʌntʃɹimən, jʌŋɡɝ ðən ʃi, nɑɾ u əɹ wʌɾ i wɑz, nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz dum tə ɡoʊ mæɾ ən daɪ ɪf i wɑz nɑt kɪl fɝst. aɪ doʊn ivən maɪn hævɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ hɪm, ʃi θɔt, ən nu haʊ taɪtli ʃi wɑz kɑɾ ɪf ʃi kəd laɪ tə hɝsɛlf. ðæt, ʃi hæd fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə æksɛpt; ɪleɪn hæɾ ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm, ə kleɪm ɑn hɪm, ən soʊ dɪd ðɪs eɪvinhə wʊmən ʃi hæd jɛt tə mit. wʌt kəd nɑt bi mɛndɪd mʌs bi lɪvd wɪð, soʊ hɝ æn dʒæn ɔlweɪz sɛd. ɪspɛʃli wən jəɹ bɹeɪnz hæd ɡɔn sɑft. laɪt, ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn kipɪŋ əɹ wɪts.

Even so, she felt no fear. Not of him; she could not begin to imagine Rand harming her. For him, she felt enough to nearly purge the memory of Colavaere's apartments from her head. She had long since reconciled herself to being hopelessly in love. Nothing else mattered, not that he was an unsophisticated countryman, younger than she, not who or what he was, not that he was doomed to go mad and die if he was not killed first. I don't even mind having to share him, she thought, and knew how tightly she was caught if she could lie to herself. That, she had forced herself to accept; Elayne had a part of him, a claim on him, and so did this Aviendha woman she had yet to meet. What could not be mended must be lived with, so her Aunt Jan always said. Especially when your brains had gone soft. Light, she had always prided herself on keeping her wits.

ʃi stɑp bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə tʃɛɹz, wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ hæd dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə θɪk wʊɾən bæk soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðə pɔɪn stʊɾ aʊt nɪɹli ə hæn bɪhaɪnd. ɪn lʌv wɪð ə mæn u dɪd nɑt noʊ, hu wəd sɛn əɹ əweɪ ʃəɾ i ɛvɝ bɪkʌm əwɛɹ. ə mæn ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz ɪn lʌv wɪð hɝ. ən wɪð ɪleɪn, ən ðɪs eɪvinhə, tu; ðæt, ʃi ɹʌʃt baɪ. wʌt kəd nɑt bi mɛndɪd. . . . hi wɑz ɪn lʌv wɪð əɹ ən ɹəfjuz tə ədmɪɾ ɪt. dɪɾ i θɪŋk ðət dʒʌs kəz mæd luz θɝɪn tɛləmən hæd kɪl ðə wʊmən i lʌvd, hi wɑz feɪɾɪd tə əz wɛl?

She stopped beside one of the chairs, where the Dragon Scepter had driven into the thick wooden back so hard that the point stood out nearly a hand behind. In love with a man who did not know, who would send her away should he ever become aware. A man she was sure was in love with her. And with Elayne, and this Aviendha, too; that, she rushed by. What could not be mended. . . . He was in love with her and refused to admit it. Did he think that just because mad Lews Therin Telamon had killed the woman he loved, he was fated to as well?

"aɪm ɡlæd jə keɪm," hi sɛd sʌɾənli, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ. "aɪv bɪn sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ əloʊn. əloʊn." hi ɡeɪv ə bɪɾɝ bɑɹk ʌv ə læf. "hɹɪd fɛl ɪz dɛd."

"I'm glad you came," he said suddenly, still staring at the ceiling. "I've been sitting here alone. Alone." He gave a bitter bark of a laugh. "Herid Fel is dead."

"noʊ," ʃi wɪspɝd, "nɑt ðət swit lɪɾəl oʊl mæn."

"No," she whispered, "not that sweet little old man."

hɝ aɪz stʌŋ. "hi wɑz tɔɹn əpɑɹt." ɹændz vɔɪs wɑz soʊ taɪɝd. soʊ ɛmpti. "ɪdʒɹin feɪntɪd wən ʃi faʊn hɪm. ʃi leɪ ɪn ə stupɝ hæf ðə naɪt, ən wɑz nɪɹli ɪnkoʊhɪɹənt wən faɪnəli ɹaʊzd. wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ət ðə skul ɡeɪv əɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ slip. ʃi wɑz ɪmbɛɹəst əbaʊt ðæt. wən ʃi keɪm tə mi, ʃi stɑɹɾəd kɹaɪɪŋ əɡɛn ænd. . . . ɪt hæd tə bi ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. wʌɾ ɛls kəd tɛɹ ə mæn lɪm fɹəm lɪm?" wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi smækt ə fɪs daʊn ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ ɑɹm soʊ hɑɹd ðə wʊd kɹikt. "bʌt waɪ? waɪ wɑz i kɪld? wʌt kəɾ i hæv toʊl mi?"

Her eyes stung. "He was torn apart." Rand's voice was so tired. So empty. "Idrien fainted when she found him. She lay in a stupor half the night, and was nearly incoherent when finally roused. One of the other women at the school gave her something to make her sleep. She was embarrassed about that. When she came to me, she started crying again and. . . . It had to be Shadowspawn. What else could tear a man limb from limb?" Without raising his head, he smacked a fist down on the chair arm so hard the wood creaked. "But why? Why was he killed? What could he have told me?"

mɪn tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk. ʃi tʃɹuli dɪd. mæstɝ fɛl wɑz ə fəlɑsəfɝ; hi ən ɹænd dɪskʌst ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm ðə minɪŋ ə pɑɹts ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən tə ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə hoʊl ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. hi lɛɾ əɹ bɑɹoʊ bʊks, fæsəneɪɾɪŋ bʊks, ɪspɛʃli wɛɹ ʃi hæd tə wɝk tə pʌzəl aʊt wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ sɛd. hi hæd bɪn ə fəlɑsəfɝ. hi wəd nɛvɝ lɛn əɹ ə bʊk əɡɛn. sətʃ ə dʒɛntəl oʊl mæn, ɹæpt ʌp ɪn ə wɝld ə θɔɾ ən stɑɹɾəld wən i noʊɾəst ɛniθɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪt. ʃi tʃɹɛʒɝɾ ə noʊɾ i hæd ɹɪɾən tə ɹænd. hi hæd sɛd ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ðət ʃi dɪstʃɹæktəd hɪm. ən naʊ hi wɑz dɛd. laɪt, ʃi hæd hæd tu mʌtʃ ə dɛθ.

Min tried to think. She truly did. Master Fel was a philosopher; he and Rand discussed everything from the meaning of parts of the Prophecies of the Dragon to the nature of the hole into the Dark One's prison. He let her borrow books, fascinating books, especially where she had to work to puzzle out what it was they said. He had been a philosopher. He would never lend her a book again. Such a gentle old man, wrapped up in a world of thought and startled when he noticed anything outside it. She treasured a note he had written to Rand. He had said she was pretty, that she distracted him. And now he was dead. Light, she had had too much of death.

"aɪ ʃʊdn əv toʊl ju, nɑt laɪk ðæt."

"I shouldn't have told you, not like that."

ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt; ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd ɹænd kɹɔs ðə ɹum. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt əɹ tʃik. waɪpɪŋ əweɪ tɪɹz. ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ.

She gave a start; she had not heard Rand cross the room. His fingers brushed her cheek. Wiping away tears. She was crying.

"aɪm sɑɹi, mɪn," hi sɛd, sɔfli. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə vɛɹi naɪs pɝsən ɛnimɔɹ. ə mæn ɪz dɛd kəz ə mi, ən ɔl aɪ kən də ɪz wɝi waɪ hi wɑz kɪld."

"I'm sorry, Min," he said, softly. "I am not a very nice person anymore. A man is dead because of me, and all I can do is worry why he was killed."

flɪŋɪŋ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm, ʃi bɛɹiɾ əɹ feɪs əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp kɹaɪɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. "aɪ wɛn tə koʊləveɪɪɹz əpɑɹtməns." ɪmədʒəz flæʃt ɪn əɹ hɛd. ði ɛmpti sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ɔl ðə sɝvəns ɡɔn. ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌt naʊ ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn, ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ðə wɝdz tʌmbəlɪŋ aʊt. "aɪ θɔt, sɪns juɾ ɛɡzaɪl hɝ, meɪbi ðəɹ wɑz səm weɪ ɝaʊn ðə vjuɪŋ aɪ hæɾ ə hɝ." koʊləveɪɪɹ hæd bɪn wɛɹɪŋ wʌt mʌst əv bɪn əɹ faɪnəst ɡaʊn, dɑɹk sɪlk ðət ɡlɪsənd, wɪð fɔlz ə dɛləkəɾ eɪdʒd-aɪvɝi soʊvɹə leɪs. "aɪ θɔt fəɹ wʌns ɪt dɪdn əv tə bi ðət weɪ. jəɹ tɑvɝən. jə kən tʃeɪnʒ ðə pæɾɝn." koʊləveɪɪɹ hæd dɑn ə nɛkləs ən bɹeɪslɪts ʌv ɛmɹəlz ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps, ən ɹɪŋz wɪð pɝlz ən ɹubiz, ʃʊɹli hɝ bɛs pisəz, ən jɛloʊ daɪmənz hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ə fɛɹ ɪməteɪʃən ə ðə kɹaʊn ə kɛɹhin. hɝ feɪs. . . . "ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. hæŋɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ə ðə bɪdpoʊsts." bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz ən pɹoʊtʃɹuɾɪŋ tʌŋ ɪn ə blækənd, swoʊlən feɪs. toʊz ə fʊɾ əbʌv ði oʊvɝtɝn stul. sɑbɪŋ hɛlpləsli, mɪn sæɡd əɡɛns hɪm.

Flinging arms around him, she buried her face against his chest. She could not stop crying. She could not stop trembling. "I went to Colavaere's apartments." Images flashed in her head. The empty sitting room, all the servants gone. The bedchamber. She did not want to remember, but now she had begun, she could not stop the words tumbling out. "I thought, since you'd exiled her, maybe there was some way around the viewing I had of her." Colavaere had been wearing what must have been her finest gown, dark silk that glistened, with falls of delicate aged-ivory Sovarra lace. "I thought for once it didn't have to be that way. You're ta'veren. You can change the Pattern." Colavaere had donned a necklace and bracelets of emeralds and firedrops, and rings with pearls and rubies, surely her best pieces, and yellow diamonds had been arranged in her hair, a fair imitation of the crown of Cairhien. Her face. . . . "She was in her bedchamber. Hanging from one of the bedposts." Bulging eyes and protruding tongue in a blackened, swollen face. Toes a foot above the overturned stool. Sobbing helplessly, Min sagged against him.

hɪz ɑɹmz wɛn ɝaʊn əɹ sloʊli, dʒɛnli. "oʊ, mɪn, juv mɔɹ peɪn ðən plɛʒɝ fɹəm jəɹ ɡɪft. ɪf aɪ kəd teɪk jəɹ peɪn, aɪ wʊd, mɪn. aɪ wʊd."

His arms went around her slowly, gently. "Oh, Min, you have more pain than pleasure from your gift. If I could take your pain, I would, Min. I would."

sloʊli ɪt pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd ðəɾ i wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, tu. laɪt, hi tʃɹaɪd soʊ hɑɹd tə bi aɪɝn, tə bi wʌɾ i θɔt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn mʌst, bʌɾ ɪt kʌɾ ɪm wən sʌmbɑɾi daɪd kəz ə hɪm, koʊləveɪɪɹ pɹɑbli noʊ lɛs ðən fɛl. hi blɛd fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn hɑɹmd, ən tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn i dɪd nɑt.

Slowly it penetrated that he was trembling, too. Light, he tried so hard to be iron, to be what he thought the Dragon Reborn must, but it cut him when somebody died because of him, Colavaere probably no less than Fel. He bled for everyone harmed, and tried to pretend he did not.

"kɪs mi," ʃi mʌmbəld. wən i dɪd nɑt muv, ʃi lʊkt ʌp. hi blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ ənsɝteɪnli, aɪz naʊ blu, naʊ ɡɹeɪ, ə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ. "aɪm nɑt tizɪŋ." haʊ ɔfən hæd ʃi tiz hɪm, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz læp, kɪsɪŋ hɪm, kɔlɪŋ ɪm ʃifɝɾɝ kəz ʃi dɛɹd nɑt seɪ hɪz neɪm fəɹ fɪɹ i maɪt hɪɹ ðə kɝɛs? hi pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪt kəz i θɔt ʃi wɑz tizɪŋ ən wəd stɑp ɪf ʃi bɪlivd ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əfɛk hɪm. hɑ! æn dʒæn ən æn ɹænə sɛd jə ʃəd nɑt kɪs ə mæn ənlɛs jə ɪntɛndəd tə mɛɹi hɪm, bʌɾ æn mɹən sim tə noʊ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ə ðə wɝld. ʃi sɛd jə ʃəd nɑt kɪs ə mæn tu kæʒəwəli kəz mɛn fɛl ɪn lʌv soʊ izəli. "aɪm koʊld ɪnsaɪd, ʃifɝɾɝ. koʊləveɪɪɹ, ən mæstɝ fɛl. . . . aɪ nid tə fil wɔɹm flɛʃ. aɪ nid. . . . pliz?"

"Kiss me," she mumbled. When he did not move, she looked up. He blinked at her uncertainly, eyes now blue, now gray, a morning sky. "I'm not teasing." How often had she teased him, sitting on his lap, kissing him, calling him sheepherder because she dared not say his name for fear he might hear the caress? He put up with it because he thought she was teasing and would stop if she believed it did not affect him. Hah! Aunt Jan and Aunt Rana said you should not kiss a man unless you intended to marry him, but Aunt Miren seemed to know a little more of the world. She said you should not kiss a man too casually because men fell in love so easily. "I'm cold inside, sheepherder. Colavaere, and Master Fel. . . . I need to feel warm flesh. I need. . . . Please?"

hɪz hɛd loʊɝd soʊ sloʊli. ɪt wɑz ə bɹʌðɝz kɪs, ət fɝst, maɪld əz mɪlk-wɔɾɝ, suðɪŋ, kʌmfɝɾɪŋ. ðən ɪt bɪkeɪm sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl suðɪŋ. dʒɝkɪŋ əpɹaɪt, hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl əweɪ. "mɪn, aɪ kænt. aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt - "

His head lowered so slowly. It was a brother's kiss, at first, mild as milk-water, soothing, comforting. Then it became something else. Not at all soothing. Jerking upright, he tried to pull away. "Min, I can't. I have no right - "

sizɪŋ tu hænfəlz ə hɪz hɛɹ, ʃi pʊld ɪz maʊθ bæk daʊn, ən æftɝ ə lɪɾəl waɪl, hi stɑp faɪɾɪŋ. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən wɛðɝ əɹ hænz bɪɡæn tɛɹɪŋ ət ðə leɪsəz ə hɪz ʃɝt fɝst əɹ ɪz ət hɝz, bʌɾ ʌv wʌn θɪŋ ʃi wɑz æbsəlutli ʃʊɹ. ɪf i ivən tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp naʊ, ʃi wɑz gɑnə fɛtʃ wʌn ə ɹaɪəlɪnz spɪɹz, ɔl ə ðɛm, ən stæb hɪm.

Seizing two handfuls of his hair, she pulled his mouth back down, and after a little while, he stopped fighting. She was not certain whether her hands began tearing at the laces of his shirt first or his at hers, but of one thing she was absolutely sure. If he even tried to stop now, she was going to fetch one of Riallin's spears, all of them, and stab him.

ɑn əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn pæləs, kædzueɪn stʌɾid ði il waɪldɝz ʃi sɔ əz wɛl əz ʃi kəd wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɑbviəs. kɔɹəl ən deɪdʒiən fɑloʊɾ ɪn saɪləns; ðeɪ nu hɝ wɛl ɪnʌf baɪ naʊ nɑt tə dɪstɝb əɹ wɪð tʃæɾɝ, wɪtʃ kəd nɑt bi sɛɾ ʌv ɔl ðoʊz u pɔzd ə fju deɪz əɾ ɑɹɪlɪnz lɪɾəl pæləs bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɛn əm ɑn. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni waɪldɝz, ɛvɹi wʌn stɛɹɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ɪf ət fli-ɹɪɾən kɝz kʌvɝd wɪð ɹʌnɪŋ sɔɹz, tʃɹækɪŋ mʌɾ oʊvɝ ə nu ɹʌɡ. səm pipəl lʊkt əɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ɑ əɹ æɾɝeɪʃən, ʌðɝz wɪð fɪɹ əɹ heɪt, bʌt kædzueɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin kəntɛmp bɪfɔɹ, nɑɾ ivən fɹəm waɪtkloʊks. ivən soʊ, ɛni pipəl u pɹədust soʊ mɛni waɪldɝz ʃəd bi sɛndɪŋ ə ɹɪvɝ ʌv ɡɝlz tə ðə taʊɝ.

On her way out of the Sun Palace, Cadsuane studied the Aiel wilders she saw as well as she could without being obvious. Corele and Daigian followed in silence; they knew her well enough by now not to disturb her with chatter, which could not be said of all those who paused a few days at Arilyn's little palace before she sent them on. A great many wilders, every one staring at the Aes Sedai as if at flea-ridden curs covered with running sores, tracking mud over a new rug. Some people looked at Aes Sedai with awe or adoration, others with fear or hate, but Cadsuane had never seen contempt before, not even from Whitecloaks. Even so, any people who produced so many wilders should be sending a river of girls to the Tower.

ðət wəɾ əv tə bi sin tə ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum wɪð kʌstəm ɪf nid bi, bʌt nɑt naʊ. ði ælθɹ bɔɪ niɾəd tə bi kɛpt ɪntʃɹiɡd ɪnʌf ðəɾ i əlaʊɾ əɹ nɪɹ hɪm, ən ɔf-bæləns ɪnʌf ðət ʃi kəd nʌdʒ ɪm wɛɹ ʃi wɑntəd wɪθaʊɾ ɪm ɹilaɪzɪŋ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ðət mʌs bi kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ səpɹɛst. nʌθɪŋ kəd bi əlaʊd tə ɪnfluəns hɪm, əɹ ʌpsɛt hɪm, ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ. nʌθɪŋ.

That would have to be seen to eventually, and to the Pit of Doom with custom if need be, but not now. The al'Thor boy needed to be kept intrigued enough that he allowed her near him, and off-balance enough that she could nudge him where she wanted without him realizing. One way or another, anything that might interfere with that must be controlled or suppressed. Nothing could be allowed to influence him, or upset him, in the wrong way. Nothing.

ðə ʃaɪni blæk koʊtʃ wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd bɪhaɪn ə peɪʃən tim ə sɪks mætʃt ɡɹeɪz. ə sɝvɪŋ mæn ɹʌʃt tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ peɪntəd wɪð ə pɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ stɑɹz ətɑp ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin stʃɹaɪps, boʊɪŋ tə ðə θɹi ʌv əm tɪl ɪz bɔl hɛd wɑz nɪɹli lɛvəl wɪð ɪz niz. hi wɑz ɪn ʃɝt-slivz ən bɹitʃɪz. sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə ðə sʌn pæləs, ʃi hæd nɑt noʊɾəst ɛniwʌn ɪn lɪvɝi jɛt, ɪksɛpt ə fju wɛɹɪŋ dɑbɹeɪnz kʌlɝz. noʊ daʊt ðə sɝvəns wɝ ənʃʊɹ wʌt tə wɛɹ ən əfɹeɪd tə meɪk ə mɪsteɪk.

The shiny black coach was waiting in the courtyard behind a patient team of six matched grays. A serving man rushed to open the door painted with a pair of silver stars atop red and green stripes, bowing to the three of them till his bald head was nearly level with his knees. He was in shirt-sleeves and breeches. Since coming to the Sun Palace, she had not noticed anyone in livery yet, except a few wearing Dobraine's colors. No doubt the servants were unsure what to wear and afraid to make a mistake.

"aɪ meɪ skɪn ɪleɪɾə wən aɪ kən leɪ hænz ɑn hɝ," ʃi sɛɾ əz ðə koʊtʃ lɝtʃt ɪndə moʊʃən. "ðæt ful tʃaɪld əz meɪd maɪ tæsk nɪɹli ɪmpɑsəbəl."

"I may skin Elaida when I can lay hands on her," she said as the coach lurched into motion. "That fool child has made my task nearly impossible."

ən ðən ʃi læf soʊ əbɹʌpli ðət deɪdʒiən stɛɹd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ aɪz. kɔɹəlz smaɪl waɪɾənd ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən. niðɝ ʌndɝstʊd, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɪkspleɪn. ɔl ə hɝ laɪf, ðə fæstəst weɪ tə ɪntʃɹəst əɹ ɪn ɛniθɪŋ hæd bɪn tə tɛl əɹ ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. bʌt ðɛn, oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd ən sɛvənti jɪɹz hæd pæst sɪns ʃi læst ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ə tæsk ʃi kəd nɑt pɝfɔɹm. ɛni deɪ naʊ maɪt bi hɝ læst, bʌt jʌŋ ælθɹ wəd bi ə fɪɾɪŋ ɛn tə ɪɾ ɔl.

And then she laughed so abruptly that Daigian stared before she could control her eyes. Corele's smile widened in anticipation. Neither understood, and she did not try to explain. All of her life, the fastest way to interest her in anything had been to tell her it was impossible. But then, over two hundred and seventy years had passed since she last encountered a task she could not perform. Any day now might be her last, but young al'Thor would be a fitting end to it all.


tʃæptɝ twɛnti


CHAPTER 20

pæɾɝnz wɪðɪn pæɾɝnz


Patterns Within Patterns

kəntɛmptʃwəsli sɪvænə stʌɾid əɹ dʌsti kəmpænjənz, siɾəd ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð əɹ ɪn ðə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ. ðə nɪɹli lifləs bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd pɹəvaɪɾəd ə bɪɾ ə kul ʃeɪd, ən ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ɹænd ælθɹ hæd hɝl dɛθ leɪ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz tə ðə wɛst, jɛt ði ʌðɝ wɪmənz aɪz ʃɪftəd wɪð ən ɛɹ ə lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ʃoʊldɝz. wɪθaʊt swɛt tɛns, nʌn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə klin hɝsɛlf pɹɑpɝli, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə heɪsti wɑʃɪŋ ə feɪs ən hænz ət deɪz ɛnd. eɪt smɔl sɪlvɝ kʌps, ɔl dɪfɹənt, sæt baɪ hɝ saɪɾ ɑn ðə dɛd livz, ən ə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ, fɪld wɪð wɔɾɝ, ðət hæd bɪn dɛntɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹitʃɹit.

Contemptuously Sevanna studied her dusty companions, seated in a circle with her in the small clearing. The nearly leafless branches overhead provided a bit of cool shade, and the place where Rand al'Thor had hurled death lay more than a hundred miles to the west, yet the other women's eyes shifted with an air of looking over shoulders. Without sweat tents, none had been able to clean herself properly, no more than a hasty washing of face and hands at day's end. Eight small silver cups, all different, sat by her side on the dead leaves, and a silver pitcher, filled with water, that had been dented in the retreat.

"iðɝ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɪz nɑt fɑloʊɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, "ɔɹ hiz bɪn əneɪbəl tə faɪn ʌs. iðɝ kɑntɛns mi."

"Either the Car'a'carn is not following," she said abruptly, "or he has been unable to find us. Either contents me."

səm ə ðɛm æktʃəli  dʒʌmpt. ʃənz ɹaʊn feɪs peɪld, ən moʊdʒɹə pæɾəd əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. wʊɾə əv bɪn pɹɪɾi ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ tɔl, ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪ tə mʌðɝ ɛvɹiwʌn wɪðɪn ɹitʃ. əlɹiz bɪkeɪm mʌtʃ tu ɪntɛn ɑn stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ skɝts ɔlɹɛɾi nitli spɹɛɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, ətɛmptɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ wʌt ʃi dɪd wɑnə tə si. mɹəz θɪn maʊθ dʒɹu daʊn, bʌɾ u kəd seɪ wɛðɝ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz' oʊpən fɪɹ ə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn əɹ əɹ oʊn? ðeɪ hæd ɹizən tə bi əfɹeɪd.

Some of them actually jumped. Tion's round face paled, and Modarra patted her shoulder. Modarra would have been pretty if she was not so tall, if she did not always try to mother everyone within reach. Alarys became much too intent on straightening skirts already neatly spread around her, attempting to ignore what she did not want to see. Meira's thin mouth drew down, but who could say whether for the others' open fear of the Car'a'carn or her own? They had reason to be afraid.

tu fʊl deɪz sɪns ðə bæɾəl, ən fjuɝ ðən twɛnti θaʊzən spɪɹz hæd ɡɹupt ɝaʊn sɪvænə. θɛɝɑvə ən moʊst ə ðə waɪz wʌnz u hæd bɪn tə ðə wɛst wɝ stɪl æbsənt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɔl ðə ɹɛst u wɝ taɪd tə hɝ. səm ə ðə mɪsɪŋ ʃʊɹli wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ bæk tə kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, bʌt haʊ mɛni wəd nɛvɝ əɡɛn si ðə sʌn ɹaɪz? noʊ wʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝd sətʃ ə slɔɾɝ, soʊ mɛni dɛɾ ɪn soʊ ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm. ivən ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ wɝ nɑt tʃɹuli ɹɛɾi tə dæns ðə spɪɹz əɡɛn soʊ sun. ɹizən tə bi əfɹeɪd, jɛt nʌn fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ ɪt, dɪspleɪɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən soʊl ɑn jəɹ feɪs laɪk ə wɛtləndɝ, oʊpən ən neɪkəd fəɹ ɔl tə si. ɹiɑli ət list sim tə ɹilaɪz ðət mʌtʃ. "ɪf wəɹ tə də ðɪs θɪŋ, lɛɾ əs də ɪt," ʃi mʌɾɝd, stɪf wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. ʃi wɑz wʌn u hæd dʒʌmpt.

Two full days since the battle, and fewer than twenty thousand spears had grouped around Sevanna. Therava and most of the Wise Ones who had been to the west were still absent, including all the rest who were tied to her. Some of the missing surely were making their way back to Kinslayer's Dagger, but how many would never again see the sun rise? No one remembered such a slaughter, so many dead in so short a time. Even the algai'd'siswai were not truly ready to dance the spears again so soon. Reason to be afraid, yet none for showing it, displaying heart and soul on your face like a wetlander, open and naked for all to see. Rhiale at least seemed to realize that much. "If we are to do this thing, let us do it," she muttered, stiff with embarrassment. She was one who had jumped.

sɪvænə tʊk ðə smɔl ɡɹeɪ kjub fɹəm əɹ paʊtʃ ən pleɪst ɪɾ ətɑp ðə bɹaʊn livz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə sɝkəl. sʌmɛɝɪn pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz, linɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ɪɡzæmɪn ɪɾ əntɪl ʃi əpɪɹɾ ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə fɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ blaʊs. hɝ noʊz nɪɹli tʌtʃt ðə kjub. ɪntʃɹəkət pæɾɝnz kʌvɝɾ ɛvɹi saɪd, ən kloʊs ʌp jə kəd si smɔlɝ pæɾɝnz wɪðɪn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, ən stɪl smɔlɝ ɪnsaɪd ðoʊz, ən ə hɪn ʌv wʌt sim smɔlɝ jɛt. haʊ ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn meɪd, ðə taɪniəst soʊ faɪn, soʊ pɹɪsaɪs, sɪvænə hæd noʊ aɪdiə. wʌns ʃi hæd θɔt ðə kjub stoʊn, bʌt ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɝɾən. jɛstɝdeɪ ʃi hæd dʒɹɑpt ɪɾ æksədɛntəli ɑn səm ɹɑks wɪθaʊt mɑɹɪŋ wʌn laɪn ə ðə kɑɹvɪŋ. ɪf ɪt wɑz kɑɹvɪŋ. ðə θɪŋ mʌs bi ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil; ðət ðeɪ nu.

Sevanna took the small gray cube from her pouch and placed it atop the brown leaves in the middle of the circle. Someryn put her hands on her knees, leaning over to examine it until she appeared in danger of falling out of her blouse. Her nose nearly touched the cube. Intricate patterns covered every side, and close up you could see smaller patterns within the larger, and still smaller inside those, and a hint of what seemed smaller yet. How they could have been made, the tiniest so fine, so precise, Sevanna had no idea. Once she had thought the cube stone, but she was no longer certain. Yesterday she had dropped it accidentally on some rocks without marring one line of the carving. If it was carving. The thing must be a ter'angreal; that they knew.

"ðə smɔləs floʊ pɑsəbəl ə faɪɝ mʌs bi tʌtʃt laɪtli ðɛɹ, ɑn wʌt lʊks laɪk ə twɪstəd kɹɛsən mun," ʃi toʊl ðɛm, "æn ənʌðɝ ðəɹ ɑn ðə tɑp, ɑn ðət mɑɹk laɪk ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt." sʌmɛɝɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd vɛɹi kwɪkli.

"The smallest flow possible of Fire must be touched lightly there, on what looks like a twisted crescent moon," she told them, "and another there on the top, on that mark like a lightning bolt." Someryn straightened very quickly.

"wʌt wɪl hæpən ðɛn?" əlɹiz æskt, koʊmɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ɪt simd ən æbsəntmaɪndɪd dʒɛstʃɝ, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz faʊnd weɪz tə ɹimaɪn ɛvɹiwʌn ðəɾ əɹ hɛɹ wɑz blæk ɪnstɛɾ ə kɑmən jɛloʊ əɹ ɹɛd.

"What will happen then?" Alarys asked, combing her hair with her fingers. It seemed an absentminded gesture, but she always found ways to remind everyone that her hair was black instead of common yellow or red.

sɪvænə smaɪld. ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt. "aɪ wɪl juz ɪt tə sʌmən ðə wɛtləndɝ u ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi."

Sevanna smiled. She enjoyed knowing what they did not. "I will use it to summon the wetlander who gave it to me."

"ðæt mʌtʃ jə toʊld əs ɔlɹɛɾi," ɹiɑli sɛɾ ɪn ə saʊɝ vɔɪs, ən ʃən blʌnli æskt, "haʊ wɪl ɪt sʌmən hɪm?" ʃi maɪt fɪɹ ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌt nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ɛls. sɝɾənli nɑt sɪvænə. bəlɪn laɪtli stʃɹoʊk ðə kjub wɪð wʌn boʊni fɪŋɡɝ, hɝ sʌn-blitʃt aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹɔn daʊn.

"That much you told us already," Rhiale said in a sour voice, and Tion bluntly asked, "How will it summon him?" She might fear Rand al'Thor, but not a great deal else. Certainly not Sevanna. Belinde lightly stroked the cube with one bony finger, her sun-bleached eyebrows drawn down.

meɪnteɪnɪŋ ə smuð feɪs, sɪvænə ɪɹɪɾəbli pɹɪvɛntɪɾ əɹ hænz fɹəm fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ə nɛkləs əɹ ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. "aɪ hæv toʊl jə ɔl jə nid noʊ." kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ niɾəd, ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn nɛsəsɛɹi. ʌðɝwaɪz ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl bi bæk wɪð ðə spɪɹz ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz, iɾɪŋ hɑɹd bɹɛɾ ən dʒɹaɪd mit. əɹ ɹæðɝ ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl bi ɑn ðə muv istwɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɛni saɪn ʌv ʌðɝ sɝvaɪvɝz.

Maintaining a smooth face, Sevanna irritably prevented her hands from fingering a necklace or adjusting her shawl. "I have told you all you need know." Considerably more than they needed, in her opinion, but it had been necessary. Otherwise they would all be back with the spears and the other Wise Ones, eating hard bread and dried meat. Or rather they would all be on the move eastward, watching for any sign of other survivors.

wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɛni saɪn ə pɝsut. wɪð ə leɪt stɑɹt, ðeɪ maɪt stɪl kʌvɝ fɪfti maɪlz bɪfɔɹ hɔltɪŋ. "wɝdz wɪl nɑt skɪn ðə bɔɹ, mʌtʃ lɛs kɪl ɪt. ɪf juv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kɹip bæk tə ðə maʊntənz ən spɛn jəɹ laɪvz ɹʌnɪŋ ən haɪɾɪŋ, ðən ɡoʊ. ɪf nɑt, ðən də wʌt jə mʌst, ən əl də maɪ pɑɹt."

Watching for any sign of pursuit. With a late start, they might still cover fifty miles before halting. "Words will not skin the boar, much less kill it. If you have decided to creep back to the mountains and spend your lives running and hiding, then go. If not, then do what you must, and I will do my part."

ɹiɑliz blu aɪz stɛɹd flæt dɪfaɪəns, ən ʃənz ɡɹeɪ. ivən moʊdʒɹə lʊk daʊtfəl, ən ʃi ən sʌmɛɝɪn leɪ ðə moʊst sɑlədli ɪn əɹ ɡɹæsp.

Rhiale's blue eyes stared flat defiance, and Tion's gray. Even Modarra looked doubtful, and she and Someryn lay the most solidly in her grasp.

sɪvænə weɪɾəd, aʊtwɝdli kɑm, ənwɪlɪŋ tə tɛl əm əɡɛn əɹ æsk. ɪnsaɪd, hɝ stʌmək tʃɝnd wɪð æŋɡɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt bi biɾən kəz ðiz wɪmən hæd peɪl hɑɹts.

Sevanna waited, outwardly calm, unwilling to tell them again or ask. Inside, her stomach churned with anger. She would not be beaten because these women had pale hearts.

"ɪf wi mʌst," ɹiɑli saɪɾ ət læst. ɛksɛptɪŋ ði æbsən θɛɝɑvə, ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd moʊst ɔfən, bʌt sɪvænə hæd hoʊps ə hɝ. ðə spaɪn ðət ɹəfjuz tə bɛn əɾ ɔl wɑz ɔfən ðə moʊs mæliəbəl wʌns ɪt ɡeɪv weɪ. ðət wɑz əz tʃɹu fəɹ wɪmən əz mɛn. ɹiɑli ən ði ʌðɝz tɝn ðɛɹ aɪz tə ðə kjub, səm fɹaʊnɪŋ.

"If we must," Rhiale sighed at last. Excepting the absent Therava, she resisted most often, but Sevanna had hopes of her. The spine that refused to bend at all was often the most malleable once it gave way. That was as true for women as men. Rhiale and the others turned their eyes to the cube, some frowning.

sɪvænə sɔ nʌθɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪn fækt, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nʌθɪŋ, ðeɪ kəd kleɪm ðə kjub feɪl tə wɝk, ən ʃi wəd nɛvɝ noʊ.

Sevanna saw nothing, of course. In fact, she realized that if they did nothing, they could claim the cube failed to work, and she would never know.

əbɹʌpli, ðoʊ, sʌmɛɝɪn ɡæspt, ən mɹə ɔlmoʊst wɪspɝd, "ɪt dʒɹɔz mɔɹ. lʊk." ʃi pɔɪntəd. "faɪɝ ðəɹ ən ðɛɹ, ən ɝθ, ən ɛɹ ən spɪɹət, fɪlɪŋ ðə ɹʌnəlz."

Abruptly, though, Someryn gasped, and Meira almost whispered, "It draws more. Look." She pointed. "Fire there and there, and Earth, and Air and Spirit, filling the runnels."

"nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm," bəlɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ kəd bi fɪl mɛni weɪz, aɪ θɪŋk. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðə floʊz . . . twɪst . . . ɝaʊn sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz nɑt ðɛɹ." hɝ fɔɹhɛd fɝoʊd. "ɪt mʌs bi dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə meɪl pɑɹt, əz wɛl."

"Not all of them," Belinde said. "They could be filled many ways, I think. And there are places where the flows . . . twist . . . around something that is not there." Her forehead furrowed. "It must be drawing the male part, as well."

sɛvɹəl dʒɹu bæk ə lɪɾəl, ʃɪftɪŋ ʃɔlz, bɹʌʃɪŋ skɝts əz ðoʊ tə ɹʌb əweɪ dɝt. sɪvænə wʊɾə ɡɪvən ɛniθɪŋ tə si. ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ. haʊ kəd ðeɪ bi sətʃ kaʊɝdz? haʊ kəd ðeɪ lɛɾ ɪt ʃoʊ?

Several drew back a little, shifting shawls, brushing skirts as though to rub away dirt. Sevanna would have given anything to see. Almost anything. How could they be such cowards? How could they let it show?

faɪnəli moʊdʒɹə sɛd, "aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf wi tʌtʃt ɪt wɪð faɪɝ ɛlswɛɹ."

Finally Modarra said, "I wonder what would happen if we touched it with Fire elsewhere."

"paʊɝ ðə kælbɑks tu mʌtʃ əɹ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ, ən ɪt meɪ mɛlt," ə mænz vɔɪs sɛɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ. "ɪt kəɾ ivən ɛks - "

"Power the callbox too much or in the wrong way, and it may melt," a man's voice said out of the air. "It could even ex - "

ðə vɔɪs kʌɾ ɔf əz ði ʌðɝ wɪmən sɝdʒ tə ðɛɹ fit, piɹɪŋ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. əlɹiz ən moʊdʒɹə wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə dʒɹɔ ðɛɹ bɛl naɪvz, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd noʊ niɾ ə stil wən ðeɪ hæd ðə wʌn paʊɝ. nʌθɪŋ muvd əmʌŋ ðə sʌn-stʃɹikt ʃædoʊz, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə bɝd.

The voice cut off as the other women surged to their feet, peering in among the trees. Alarys and Modarra went so far as to draw their belt knives, though they had no need of steel when they had the One Power. Nothing moved among the sun-streaked shadows, not so much as a bird.

sɪvænə dɪd nɑt stɝ. ʃi hæd bɪliv pɝhæps ə θɝɾ ʌv wʌɾ ə ðə wɛtləndɝ hæd toʊl hɝ, nɑɾ ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðɪs, ɪn tʃɹuθ, bʌt ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz kædɑɝz vɔɪs. wɛtləndɝz ɔlweɪz hæd mɔɹ neɪmz, bʌt ðət wɑz ɔl i hæd ɡɪvən. ə mæn ə mɛni sikɹəts, ʃi səspɛktəd. "teɪk jəɹ pleɪsəz əɡɛn," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd. "æn pʊt ðə floʊz bæk wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ. haʊ kən aɪ sʌmən ɪm ɪf jə fɪɹ wɝdz?"

Sevanna did not stir. She had believed perhaps a third of what of the wetlander had told her, not including this, in truth, but she recognized Caddar's voice. Wetlanders always had more names, but that was all he had given. A man of many secrets, she suspected. "Take your places again," she ordered. "And put the flows back where they were. How can I summon him if you fear words?"

ɹiɑli swʌŋ ɝaʊnd, maʊθ ɡeɪpɪŋ ən aɪz ɪnkɹɛdʒələs. əndaʊɾɪdli wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ʃi nu ðeɪ hæd stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ; ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ klɪɹli. sloʊli, ənizəli, ðeɪ sɛɾəld ɪn ðə sɝkəl əɡɛn. ɹiɑli dɑn ə flæɾɝ feɪs ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls.

Rhiale swung around, mouth gaping and eyes incredulous. Undoubtedly wondering how she knew they had stopped channeling; the woman was not thinking clearly. Slowly, uneasily, they settled in the circle again. Rhiale donned a flatter face than anyone else.

"soʊ jə ɑɹ bæk," kædɑɝz vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ði ɛɹ. "du juv ælθɹ?"

"So you are back," Caddar's voice said from the air. "Do you have al'Thor?"

sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz toʊn wɔɹn hɝ. hi kəd nɑt noʊ. bʌɾ i dɪd. ʃi əbændən ɔl ʃi hæd pɹipɛɹd tə seɪ. "noʊ, kædɑɝ. bʌt wi stɪl mʌs tɔk. əl mit jə ɪn tɛn deɪz wɛɹ wi fɝs mɛt." ʃi kəd ɹitʃ ðət væli ɪn kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ sunɝ, bʌt ʃi niɾəd taɪm tə pɹipɛɹ. haʊ dɪɾ i noʊ?

Something in his tone warned her. He could not know. But he did. She abandoned all she had prepared to say. "No, Caddar. But we still must talk. I will meet you in ten days where we first met." She could reach that valley in Kinslayer's Dagger sooner, but she needed time to prepare. How did he know?

"wɛl ðət jə toʊl ðə tʃɹuθ, ɡɝl," kædɑɝ mɝmɝd dʒɹaɪli. "ju wɪl lɝn aɪ də nɑt laɪk biɪŋ laɪd tə. meɪnteɪn ðə weɪlaɪn fəɹ loʊkeɪʃən, ən əl kʌm tə ju."

"Well that you told the truth, girl," Caddar murmured dryly. "You will learn I do not like being lied to. Maintain the wayline for location, and I will come to you."

sɪvænə stɛɹɾ ət ðə kjub ɪn ʃɑk. ɡɝl? "wʌt dɪd jə seɪ?" ʃi dɪmændəd. ɡɝl! ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv əɹ ɪɹz. ɹiɑli vɛɹi pɔɪntɪdli dɪd nɑt lʊk ət hɝ, ən mɹəz maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn ə smaɪl, ɑkwɝd kəz soʊ sɛldəm juzd.

Sevanna stared at the cube in shock. Girl? "What did you say?" she demanded. Girl! She could not believe her ears. Rhiale very pointedly did not look at her, and Meira's mouth twisted in a smile, awkward because so seldom used.

kædɑɝz saɪ fɪl ðə klɪɹɪŋ. "tɛl jəɹ waɪz wʌn tə kəntɪnju duɪŋ ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃiz duɪŋ - nʌθɪŋ ɛls - ən əl kʌm tə ju." ðə fɔɹs peɪʃəns ɪn ɪz toʊn skɹeɪp laɪk ə ɡɹɪst-stoʊn. wən ʃi hæd wʌt ʃi wɑntəd fɹəm ðə wɛtləndɝ, ʃi wəd dʒɹɛs ɪm ɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn waɪt. noʊ, ɪn blæk!

Caddar's sigh filled the clearing. "Tell your Wise One to continue doing exactly what she is doing - nothing else - and I will come to you." The forced patience in his tone scraped like a grist-stone. When she had what she wanted from the wetlander, she would dress him in gai'shain white. No, in black!

"wʌt dʒju min, jəl kʌm, kædɑɝ?" saɪləns ænsɝd. "kædɑɝ, wɛɹ ɑɹ ju?" saɪləns. "kædɑɝ?"

"What do you mean, you will come, Caddar?" Silence answered. "Caddar, where are you?" Silence. "Caddar?"

ði ʌðɝz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ənizi ɡlænsɪz.

The others exchanged uneasy glances.

"ɪz i mæd?" ʃən sɛd. əlɹiz mʌɾɝd ðəɾ i mʌs bi, ən bəlɪn æŋɡɹəli dɪmændəd tə noʊ haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ wɝ tə kəntɪnju ðɪs nɑnsɛns.

"Is he mad?" Tion said. Alarys muttered that he must be, and Belinde angrily demanded to know how long they were to continue this nonsense.

"əntɪl aɪ seɪ tə stɑp," sɪvænə sɛd sɔfli, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kjub. ə pɹɪkəl ə hoʊp wɝm θɹu hɝ tʃɛst. ɪf i kəd də ðɪs, ðən ʃʊɹli hi kəd dɪlɪvɝ wʌɾ i hæd pɹɑməst. ən meɪbi. . . . ʃi wəd nɑt hoʊp tu mʌtʃ. ʃi lʊkt ʌp θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz ðət nɪɹli mɛɾ əbʌv ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ðə sʌn stɪl hæɾ ə weɪ tə klaɪm tə ɪts pik. "ɪf hiz nɑt kʌm baɪ mɪddeɪ, wɪl ɡoʊ." ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə ɪkspɛk ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɡɹʌmbəl.

"Until I say to stop," Sevanna said softly, staring at the cube. A prickle of hope wormed through her chest. If he could do this, then surely he could deliver what he had promised. And maybe. . . . She would not hope too much. She looked up through the branches that nearly met above the clearing. The sun still had a way to climb to its peak. "If he has not come by midday, we will go." It was too much to expect they would not grumble.

"soʊ wi sɪt hɪɹ laɪk stoʊnz?" əlɹiz tɔst əɹ hɛɾ ɪn ə pɹæktəst weɪ, swipɪŋ ɔl ə hɝ hɛɹ oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ. "fɔɹ ə wɛtləndɝ?"

"So we sit here like stones?" Alarys tossed her head in a practiced way, sweeping all of her hair over one shoulder. "For a wetlander?"

"wʌtɛvɝ i pɹɑməs ju, sɪvænə," ɹiɑli sɛd wɪð ə skaʊl, "ɪt kænɑt bi wɝθ ðɪs."

"Whatever he promised you, Sevanna," Rhiale said with a scowl, "it cannot be worth this."

"hi ɪz mæd," ʃən ɡɹaʊld.

"He is mad," Tion growled.

moʊdʒɹə nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə kjub. "wʌɾ ɪf i kən stɪl hɪɹ?"

Modarra nodded toward the cube. "What if he can still hear?"

ʃən snɪf dɪsmɪsɪvli, ən sʌmɛɝɪn sɛd, "haʊ ʃəd wi kɛɹ ɪf ə mæn hɪɹz wʌt wi seɪ? bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt ɹɛlɪʃ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm."

Tion sniffed dismissively, and Someryn said, "How should we care if a man hears what we say? But I do not relish waiting for him."

"wʌɾ ɪf hiz laɪk ðoʊz wɛtləndɝz ɪn blæk koʊts?" bəlɪn kəmpɹɛst əɹ lɪps tɪl ðeɪ nɪɹli mætʃt mɹəz.

"What if he is like those wetlanders in black coats?" Belinde compressed her lips till they nearly matched Meira's.

"du nɑt bi ɹɪdɪkjələs," əlɹiz snɪɹd. "wɛtləndɝz kɪl sətʃ mɛn ɑn saɪt. wʌtɛvɝ ði ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ kleɪm, ðət mʌst əv bɪn ðə wɝk ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ɹænd ælθɹ." ðət neɪm pɹədust ə peɪn saɪləns, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt læst.

"Do not be ridiculous," Alarys sneered. "Wetlanders kill such men on sight. Whatever the algai'd'siswai claim, that must have been the work of the Aes Sedai. And Rand al'Thor." That name produced a pained silence, but it did not last.

"kædɑɝ mʌst əv ə kjub laɪk ðɪs wʌn," bəlɪn sɛd. "hi mʌst əv ə wʊmən wɪð ðə ɡɪf tə meɪk ɪt wɝk."

"Caddar must have a cube like this one," Belinde said. "He must have a woman with the gift to make it work."

"æn ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɹiɑli meɪɾ ə nɔɪz ə dɪsɡʌst ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. "ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð hɪm, lɛɾ əm kʌm. wɪl dil wɪð əm əz ðeɪ dɪzɝv."

"An Aes Sedai?" Rhiale made a noise of disgust in her throat. "If there are ten Aes Sedai with him, let them come. We will deal with them as they deserve."

mɹə læft, ə dʒɹaɪ saʊn əz nɛɹoʊ əz əɹ feɪs. "aɪ θɪŋk jə ɔlmoʊs bɪɡɪn tə bɪliv ðeɪ dɪd kɪl deɪseɪn."

Meira laughed, a dry sound as narrow as her face. "I think you almost begin to believe they did kill Desaine."

"wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ!" ɹiɑli snɑɹəld.

"Watch your tongue!" Rhiale snarled.

"jɛs," sʌmɛɝɪn mɝmɝɾ æŋkʃəsli. "kɛɹləs wɝdz maɪt bi hɝd baɪ ðə ɹɔŋ ɪɹz."

"Yes," Someryn murmured anxiously. "Careless words might be heard by the wrong ears."

ʃənz læf wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən ənplɛzənt. "ðə lɑɾ ə jə hæz lɛs kɝədʒ ðən wʌn wɛtləndɝ." wɪtʃ meɪd sʌmɛɝɪn snæp bæk, ʌv kɔɹs, ən moʊdʒɹə tu, ən mɹə spoʊk wɝdz ðət wʊɾə bɹɔɾ ə tʃælənʒ hæd ðeɪ nɑt bɪn waɪz wʌnz, ən əlɹiz spoʊk hɑɹʃɝ, ən bəlɪnd. . . . ðɛɹ skwɑbəlɪŋ ɪɹəteɪɾəd sɪvænə, ðoʊ ɪt ɡɛɹəntid ðeɪ wəd nɑt kənspaɪɝ əɡɛns hɝ. bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt waɪ ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn fəɹ saɪləns. ɹiɑli fɹaʊn ət hɝ, oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ, ən ɪn ðət moʊmən ðeɪ hɝd wʌt ʃi dɪd. sʌmθɪŋ ɹʌsəld ɪn ðə dɛd livz əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. noʊ il wəd meɪk soʊ mʌtʃ nɔɪz, ivən ɪf ɛni wəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ waɪz wʌnz ənbɪddən, ən noʊ ænəməl wəd kʌm soʊ nɪɹ pipəl. ðɪs taɪm, ʃi ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit wɪð ði ʌðɝz.

Tion's laugh was short and unpleasant. "The lot of you has less courage than one wetlander." Which made Someryn snap back, of course, and Modarra too, and Meira spoke words that would have brought a challenge had they not been Wise Ones, and Alarys spoke harsher, and Belinde. . . . Their squabbling irritated Sevanna, though it guaranteed they would not conspire against her. But that was not why she raised a hand for silence. Rhiale frowned at her, opening her mouth, and in that moment they heard what she did. Something rustled in the dead leaves among the trees. No Aiel would make so much noise, even if any would approach Wise Ones unbidden, and no animal would come so near people. This time, she rose to her feet with the others.

tu ʃeɪps əpɪɹd, ə mæn ən ə wʊmən, bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪnʌf bɹæntʃəz ʌndɝfʊt tə weɪk ə stoʊn. dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, ðeɪ stɑpt, ən ðə mæn bɛn ɪz hɛd slaɪtli tə spik tə ðə wʊmən. ɪt wɑz kædɑɝ, ɪn ə nɪɹli blæk koʊt wɪð leɪs əɾ ɪz nɛk ən ɹɪsts. ət list i dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ə sɔɹd. ðeɪ sim tə bi ɑɹɡjuɪŋ. sɪvænə ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə hɪɹ sʌmθɪŋ ə ðɛɹ wɝdz, jɛt ðə saɪləns wɑz kəmplit. kædɑɝ stʊd nɪɹli ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən moʊdʒɹə - tɔl fəɹ ə wɛtləndɝ, əɹ ivən fəɹ ən il - ən ðə wʊmənz hɛd ɹitʃt noʊ haɪɝ ðən ɪz tʃɛst. əz dɑɹk ə feɪs ən hɛɹ əz hi, ən bjuɾəfəl ɪnʌf tə taɪɾən sɪvænəz maʊθ, ʃi wɔɹ bɹaɪt ɹɛd sɪlk, kʌt tə ɪkspoʊz ivən mɔɹ ə hɝ bʊzəm ðən sʌmɛɝɪn ʃoʊd.

Two shapes appeared, a man and a woman, breaking enough branches underfoot to wake a stone. Just short of the clearing, they stopped, and the man bent his head slightly to speak to the woman. It was Caddar, in a nearly black coat with lace at his neck and wrists. At least he did not wear a sword. They seemed to be arguing. Sevanna should have been able to hear something of their words, yet the silence was complete. Caddar stood nearly a hand taller than Modarra - tall for a wetlander, or even for an Aiel - and the woman's head reached no higher than his chest. As dark of face and hair as he, and beautiful enough to tighten Sevanna's mouth, she wore bright red silk, cut to expose even more of her bosom than Someryn showed.

əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə wʊmən kɔl hɝ, sʌmɛɝɪn dʒɹu kloʊs tə sɪvænə. "ðə wʊmən əz ðə ɡɪft," ʃi wɪspɝd wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə pɛɹ. "ʃi wivz ə bæɹiɝ." pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps, ʃi æɾəd, ɹɪlʌktənli, "ʃi ɪz stʃɹɔŋ. vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ." fɹəm hɝ, ðət mɛn sʌmθɪŋ ɪndid. sɪvænə hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ʌndɝstænd waɪ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ dɪd nɑt kaʊn əmʌŋ waɪz wʌnz - waɪl biɪŋ θæŋkfəl ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt, fəɹ əɹ oʊn seɪk - bʌt sʌmɛɝɪn pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ə wʊmən nɪɹ əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ʃi. baɪ hɝ toʊn, sɪvænə səspɛktəd ðɪs wʊmən wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ.

As if thinking of the woman called her, Someryn drew close to Sevanna. "The woman has the gift," she whispered without taking her eyes from the pair. "She weaves a barrier." Pursing her lips, she added, reluctantly, "She is strong. Very strong." From her, that meant something indeed. Sevanna had never been able to understand why strength in the Power did not count among Wise Ones - while being thankful that it did not, for her own sake - but Someryn prided herself that she had never encountered a woman near as strong as she. By her tone, Sevanna suspected this woman was stronger.

ɹaɪt ðɛn, ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən kəd muv maʊntənz əɹ bɛɹli laɪɾ ə kændəl. ʃi mʌs bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə feɪs, jɛt səm sɪvænə hæd sin dɪd nɑt. ðət mʌs bi haʊ kædɑɝ kəd pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðət wɑz haʊ hi kəd faɪn əm ən kʌm. soʊ sun; soʊ kwɪkli. pɑsəbɪləɾiz ənfoʊldəd, ən hoʊp ɡɹu. bʌt bɪtwin ɪm ən hɝ, hu kəmændəd?

Right then, she did not care whether the woman could move mountains or barely light a candle. She must be Aes Sedai. She did not have the face, yet some Sevanna had seen did not. That must be how Caddar could put his hand on ter'angreal. That was how he could find them and come. So soon; so quickly. Possibilities unfolded, and hope grew. But between him and her, who commanded?

"stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ ɪndə ðæt," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd. hi maɪt stɪl bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ θɹu ɪt.

"Stop channeling into that," she ordered. He might still be able to hear through it.

ɹiɑli ɡeɪv əɹ ə lʊk ðət dɪd nɑt stɑp ʃɔɹɾ ə pɪɾi. "sʌmɛɝɪn ɔlɹɛɾi dɪd, sɪvænə."

Rhiale gave her a look that did not stop short of pity. "Someryn already did, Sevanna."

nʌθɪŋ kəd spɔɪl əɹ mud. ʃi smaɪld ən sɛd, "vɛɹi wɛl. ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ sɛd. lemi də ɔl ə ðə tɔkɪŋ." moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd; ɹiɑli snɪft. sɪvænə kɛpt əɹ smaɪl. eɪ waɪz wʌn kəd nɑt bi meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn, bʌt soʊ mɛni wɔɹn-aʊt kʌstəmz hæd bɪn sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɾ ʌðɝz maɪt fɑloʊ.

Nothing could spoil her mood. She smiled and said, "Very well. Remember what I said. Let me do all of the talking." Most of the others nodded; Rhiale sniffed. Sevanna kept her smile. A Wise One could not be made gai'shain, but so many worn-out customs had been set aside already that others might follow.

kædɑɝ ən ðə wʊmən stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd, ən sʌmɛɝɪn wɪspɝɾ əɡɛn. "ʃi stɪl hoʊlz ðə paʊɝ."

Caddar and the woman started forward, and Someryn whispered again. "She still holds the Power."

"sɪt nɛks tə mi," sɪvænə toʊld əɹ heɪstəli. "tʌtʃ maɪ lɛɡ ɪf ʃi tʃænəlz." haʊ ðət ɡæld. bʌt ʃi mʌs noʊ.

"Sit next to me," Sevanna told her hastily. "Touch my leg if she channels." How that galled. But she must know.

ʃi sæt, foʊldɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz ʌndɝ, ən ði ʌðɝz dʒɔɪn hɝ, livɪŋ ə speɪs fəɹ kædɑɝ ən ðə wʊmən. sʌmɛɝɪn sæt kloʊs ɪnʌf ðət ðɛɹ niz tʌtʃt. sɪvænə wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ ə tʃɛɹ.

She sat, folding her legs under, and the others joined her, leaving a space for Caddar and the woman. Someryn sat close enough that their knees touched. Sevanna wished she had a chair.

"aɪ si ju, kædɑɝ," ʃi sɛd fɔɹməli, ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪz ɪnsəlt. "sɪt, jə ən jəɹ wʊmən."

"I see you, Caddar," she said formally, in spite of his insult. "Sit, you and your woman."

ʃi wɑntəd tə si haʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹiæktəd, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz ɑɹtʃ ən aɪbɹaʊ ən smaɪl læzəli. hɝ aɪz wɝ əz blæk əz hɪz, əz blæk əz ə ɹeɪvənz. ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz lɛɾ ə lɪɾəl koʊlnəs ʃoʊ. hæd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðə wɛlz nɑɾ əlaʊd ɹænd ælθɹ tə bɹeɪk fɹi, ðeɪ ʃʊɹli wʊɾə kɪld əɹ kæptʃɝɾ ɛvɹi wʌn. ðɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌs bi əwɛɹ ə ðæt, sɪns kædɑɝ pleɪnli nu wʌt hæd hæpənd, jɛt ʃi lʊkt ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ əfɹeɪd.

She wanted to see how the Aes Sedai reacted, but all she did was arch an eyebrow and smile lazily. Her eyes were as black as his, as black as a raven's. The other Wise Ones let a little coldness show. Had the Aes Sedai at the wells not allowed Rand al'Thor to break free, they surely would have killed or captured every one. This Aes Sedai must be aware of that, since Caddar plainly knew what had happened, yet she looked anything but afraid.

"ðɪs ɪz mzə," kædɑɝ sɛd, loʊɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə speɪs lɛft fəɹ hɪm. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi dɪd nɑt laɪk tə kʌm wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ. pɝhæps i fɪɹd naɪvz. "aɪ toʊl jə tə juz ə sɪŋɡəl waɪz wʌn, sɪvænə, nɑt sɛvən. səm mɛn maɪt bi səspɪʃəs." fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi simd əmjuzd.

"This is Maisia," Caddar said, lowering himself to the ground, a little short of the space left for him. For some reason, he did not like to come within arm's reach. Perhaps he feared knives. "I told you to use a single Wise One, Sevanna, not seven. Some men might be suspicious." For some reason, he seemed amused.

ðə wʊmən, mzə, pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts ʌndɝ wən i ɡeɪv əɹ neɪm, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð ə fjʊɹi ðət ʃʊɾə stʃɹɪpt ɪz haɪɾ əweɪ. pɝhæps ʃi hæd θɔt tə kip əɹ aɪdɛntəɾi hɪɾən. ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ðoʊ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi sæt bɪsaɪd hɪm, hɝ smaɪl ɹɪtɝnɪŋ soʊ sʌɾənli ɪt maɪt nɛvɝ əv ɡɔn. nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, sɪvænə wɑz θæŋkfəl ðət wɛtləndɝz wɔɹ ðɛɹ ɪmoʊʃənz ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz.

The woman, Maisia, paused in the act of smoothing her skirts under when he gave her name, glaring at him with a fury that should have stripped his hide away. Perhaps she had thought to keep her identity hidden. She said nothing, though. After a moment she sat beside him, her smile returning so suddenly it might never have gone. Not for the first time, Sevanna was thankful that wetlanders wore their emotions on their faces.

"ju hæv bɹɔt ðə θɪŋ ðət kən kəntʃɹoʊl ɹænd ælθɹ?" ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɡlæns ət ðə pɪtʃɝ ʌv wɔɾɝ. wən i wɑz soʊ ɹud, waɪ ʃəd ʃi kəntɪnju ðə fɔɹmz? ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪm biɪŋ soʊ wən ðeɪ mɛt bɪfɔɹ. pɝhæps ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛmboʊldən hɪm.

"You have brought the thing that can control Rand al'Thor?" She did not even glance at the pitcher of water. When he was so rude, why should she continue the forms? She did not remember him being so when they met before. Perhaps the Aes Sedai emboldened him.

kædɑɝ ɡeɪv əɹ ə kwɪtsɪkəl lʊk. "waɪ, wən jə də nɑɾ əv hɪm?"

Caddar gave her a quizzical look. "Why, when you do not have him?"

"aɪ wɪl," ʃi sɛd lɛvəli, ən i smaɪld. soʊ dɪd mzə.

"I will," she said levelly, and he smiled. So did Maisia.

"wɛn jə du, ðɛn." hɪz smaɪl ʃaʊɾəd ə daʊɾ ən dɪsbɪlif. ðə wʊmənz mɑkt. ə blæk ɹoʊb kəd bi faʊn fəɹ hɝ, tu. "wʌɾ aɪ hæv wɪl kəntʃɹoʊl ɪm wʌns hiz teɪkən, bʌɾ ɪt kænɑɾ oʊvɝkʌm hɪm. aɪ woʊn ɹɪsk ɪm faɪndɪŋ aʊɾ əbaʊt mi əntɪl juv ɪm sɪkjʊɹ." hi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ ʃeɪmd ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst baɪ ði ædmɪʃən.

"When you do, then." His smile shouted of doubt and disbelief. The woman's mocked. A black robe could be found for her, too. "What I have will control him once he is taken, but it cannot overcome him. I won't risk him finding out about me until you have him secure." He did not appear shamed in the slightest by the admission.

sɪvænə fɔɹs daʊn ə stæb ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. wʌn hoʊp ɡɔn, bʌɾ ʌðɝz ɹɪmeɪnd. ɹiɑli ən ʃən foʊldəd ðɛɹ hænz ən stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, bɪɑn ðə sɝkəl, bɪɑn hɪm; hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝθ lɪsnɪŋ tə. ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Sevanna forced down a stab of disappointment. One hope gone, but others remained. Rhiale and Tion folded their hands and stared straight ahead, beyond the circle, beyond him; he was no longer worth listening to. Of course, they did not know everything.

"wʌɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ? kən ðɪs θɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛm?" ɹiɑli ən ʃən stɑpt piɹɪŋ bɪɑn ðə tʃɹiz. bəlɪnz aɪbɹaʊz twɪtʃt, ən mɹə æktʃəli  lʊkt ət hɝ. cʊɾə əv kɝs ðɛɹ læk ə sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl.

"What of Aes Sedai? Can this thing control them?" Rhiale and Tion stopped peering beyond the trees. Belinde's eyebrows twitched, and Meira actually looked at her. Sevanna could have cursed their lack of self-control.

kædɑɝ wɑz əz blaɪn əz ɔl wɛtləndɝz, ðoʊ. hi θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft. "du jə min tə seɪ jə mɪst ælθɹ bʌt kæptʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ? jə ɡɹæbd ət ði iɡəl ən kɑɾ ə fju lɑɹks!"

Caddar was as blind as all wetlanders, though. He threw back his head and laughed. "Do you mean to say you missed al'Thor but captured Aes Sedai? You grabbed at the eagle and caught a few larks!"

"kæn jə pɹəvaɪd ðə seɪm fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ. ʃʊɹli hi hæd bɪn pɹɑpɝli kɝɾiəs bɪfɔɹ.

"Can you provide the same for Aes Sedai?" She wanted to grind her teeth. Surely he had been properly courteous before.

hi ʃɹʌɡd. "pɝhæps. ɪf ðə pɹaɪs ɪz ɹaɪt." ɪt wɑz dʌs tə hɪm, ʌv noʊ moʊmənt. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, mzə ʃoʊd noʊ kənsɝn iðɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɪf ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ʃi mʌs bi.

He shrugged. "Perhaps. If the price is right." It was dust to him, of no moment. For that matter, Maisia showed no concern either. Strange, if she was Aes Sedai. But she must be.

"jɔɹ tʌŋ tɔsɪz bɹaɪt kʌlɝz ɑn ðə wɪnd, wɛtləndɝ," ʃən sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "wʌt pɹuf ə ðɛm əv ju?" fəɹ wʌns, sɪvænə dɪd nɑt maɪn ðət ʃi hæd spoʊkən aʊɾ ə tɝn.

"Your tongue tosses bright colors on the wind, wetlander," Tion said in a flat voice. "What proof of them have you?" For once, Sevanna did not mind that she had spoken out of turn.

kædɑɝz feɪs taɪɾənd fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ɪf i wɝ ə klæn tʃif, əz ɪf i hæd hɝd ði ɪnsəlt, bʌɾ ɪn ən ɪnstən i wɑz ɔl smaɪlz wʌns mɔɹ. "æz jə wɪʃ. mzə, pleɪ wɪð ðə kælbɑks fəɹ ðɛm."

Caddar's face tightened for all the world as if he were a clan chief, as if he had heard the insult, but in an instant he was all smiles once more. "As you wish. Maisia, play with the callbox for them."

sʌmɛɝɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ skɝts, pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ nʌkəlz əɡɛnst sɪvænəz θaɪ əz ðə ɡɹeɪ kjub ɹoʊz ə peɪs ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɪt baʊns bæk ən fɔɹθ əz ðoʊ tɔs fɹəm hæn tə hænd, ðən tɪltəɾ ən spʌn ɑn wʌn kɔɹnɝ laɪk ə tɑp, fæstɝ ən fæstɝ, əntɪl ɪt blɝd.

Someryn shifted her skirts, pressing her knuckles against Sevanna's thigh as the gray cube rose a pace into the air. It bounced back and forth as though tossed from hand to hand, then tilted and spun on one corner like a top, faster and faster, until it blurred.

"wʊd jə laɪk tə si hɝ bæləns ɪɾ ɑn əɹ noʊz?" kædɑɝ æskt wɪð ə tuθi ɡɹɪn.

"Would you like to see her balance it on her nose?" Caddar asked with a toothy grin.

taɪt-aɪd, ðə dɑɹk wʊmən stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, hɝ smaɪl klɪɹli fɔɹs naʊ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hæv dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf, kædɑɝ," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. bʌt ðə kjub - ðə kælbɑks? - kəntɪnjud wɝlɪŋ.

Tight-eyed, the dark woman stared straight ahead, her smile clearly forced now. "I think I have demonstrated quite enough, Caddar," she said coldly. But the cube - the callbox? - continued whirling.

sɪvænə weɪɾəd ə sloʊ kaʊn ə twɛnti bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "ðæɾ ɪz səfɪʃənt."

Sevanna waited a slow count of twenty before saying, "That is sufficient."

"ju meɪ stɑp naʊ, mzə," kædɑɝ sɛd. "pʊɾ ɪt bæk wɛɹ ɪt wɑz." oʊnli ðən dɪd ðə kjub sloʊli dɪsɛnd, nɛslɪŋ dʒɛnli ɑn ɪts ɝɪdʒənəl spɑt. dɑɹk əz ʃi wɑz, ðə wʊmən lʊk peɪl. ən fjʊɹiəs.

"You may stop now, Maisia," Caddar said. "Put it back where it was." Only then did the cube slowly descend, nestling gently on its original spot. Dark as she was, the woman looked pale. And furious.

hæd ʃi bɪn əloʊn, sɪvænə wəɾ əv læft, ən dænst. əz ɪt wɑz, ʃi hæd dɪfəkəlti meɪnteɪnɪŋ ə smuð feɪs. ɹiɑli ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ tu bɪzi stɛɹɪŋ dɪsdeɪnfəli ət mzə tə noʊɾəs. wʌt wɝkt ɑn wʌn wʊmən wɪð ðə ɡɪft wəd wɝk ɑn ənʌðɝ. noʊ nid wɪð sʌmɛɝɪn ən moʊdʒɹə, pɝhæps, bʌt ɹiɑli, ən θɛɝɑvə. . . . ʃi kəd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tu iɡɝ, nɑt wən ði ʌðɝz nu ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kæptɪvz.

Had she been alone, Sevanna would have laughed, and danced. As it was, she had difficulty maintaining a smooth face. Rhiale and the others were too busy staring disdainfully at Maisia to notice. What worked on one woman with the gift would work on another. No need with Someryn and Modarra, perhaps, but Rhiale, and Therava. . . . She could not appear too eager, not when the others knew there were no Aes Sedai captives.

"ʌv kɔɹs," kædɑɝ wɛn ɑn, "ɪt wɪl teɪk ə lɪɾəl taɪm tə pɹəvaɪd jə wɪð wʌt jə wɪʃ." hi tʊk ɑn ə slaɪ lʊk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɾ ɪt; pɝhæps ənʌðɝ wɛtləndɝ wəd nɑɾ əv sin. "aɪ wɔɹn ju, ðə pɹaɪs wɪl nɑt bi smɔl."

"Of course," Caddar went on, "it will take a little time to provide you with what you wish." He took on a sly look, trying to hide it; perhaps another wetlander would not have seen. "I warn you, the price will not be small."

ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, sɪvænə lin fɔɹwɝd. "æn ðə weɪ jə tʃɹævəl hɪɹ soʊ kwɪkli? haʊ mʌtʃ tə meɪk əɹ titʃ əs ðæt?" ʃi mænədʒ tə kip iɡɝnəs fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd ðə kəntɛmpt ʃi fɛl keɪm θɹu. wɛtləndɝz wəd də ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ɡoʊld.

In spite of herself, Sevanna leaned forward. "And the way you traveled here so quickly? How much to make her teach us that?" She managed to keep eagerness from her voice, but she was afraid the contempt she felt came through. Wetlanders would do anything for gold.

pɝhæps ðə mæn hɝɾ ɪt; hɪz aɪz sɝɾənli waɪɾənd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹɪɡeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz. hi stʌɾid ɪz hænz, ən ɪz maʊθ kɝl feɪnli. waɪ ʃəɾ ɪz smaɪl sim plizd? "ðæɾ ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ ʃi dʌz," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs əz smuð əz ɪz pɑmz, "nɑt baɪ hɝsɛlf. ɪts laɪk ðə kælbɑks. aɪ kən pɹəvaɪd jə wɪð sɛvɹəl, bʌt ðə pɹaɪs ə ðoʊz ɪz ivən haɪɝ. aɪ daʊt wʌt juv ɡlin fɹəm kɛɹhin wɪl bi ɪnʌf. fɔɹtʃənətli, jə kən juz ðə . . . tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑksəz tə teɪk jəɹ pipəl tə ɹɪtʃɝ lænz."

Perhaps the man heard it; his eyes certainly widened in surprise before he could regain control. Such as it was. He studied his hands, and his mouth curled faintly. Why should his smile seem pleased? "That is not something she does," he said in a voice as smooth as his palms, "not by herself. It is like the callbox. I can provide you with several, but the price of those is even higher. I doubt what you've gleaned from Cairhien will be enough. Fortunately, you can use the . . . traveling boxes to take your people to richer lands."

ivən mɹə wɑz hɑɹd-pɹɛs tə kip əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən fɹəm bɪkʌmɪŋ tu ævəd. ɹɪtʃɝ lænz, ən noʊ nid tə meɪk ə weɪ θɹu ðoʊz fulz fɑloʊɪŋ ɹænd ælθɹ.

Even Meira was hard-pressed to keep her expression from becoming too avid. Richer lands, and no need to make a way through those fools following Rand al'Thor.

"tɛl mi mɔɹ," sɪvænə sɛd kuli. "ɹɪtʃɝ lænz maɪt bi ʌv səm ɪntʃɹəst." nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ fɝɡɛt ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, ðoʊ. kædɑɝ wəd ɡɪv əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ i hæd pɹɑməs bɪfɔɹ ʃi dɪklɛɹɾ ɪm dætsæŋ. əz wɛl ðəɾ i sim tə laɪk wɛɹɪŋ blæk. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nid tə ɡɪv ɪm ɛni ɡoʊl ðɛn.

"Tell me more," Sevanna said coolly. "Richer lands might be of some interest." Not enough to make her forget the Car'a'carn, though. Caddar would give her everything he had promised before she declared him da'tsang. As well that he seemed to like wearing black. There would be no need to give him any gold then.

ðə wɑtʃɝ ɡɑstɪd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, meɪkɪŋ noʊ saʊnd. ɪt wɑz wʌndɝfəl wʌt jə kəd lɝn wɪð ə kælbɑks, ɪspɛʃli ɪn ə wɝld wɛɹ ðəɹ sim tə bi oʊnli tu ʌðɝz. ðət ɹɛd dʒɹɛs wɑz izi tə fɑloʊ, ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ lʊk bæk ivən tə si wɛðɝ səm ə ðoʊz soʊ-kɔld il wɝ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ðɛm. ɡɹeɪndəl meɪnteɪn ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts ðət hɪɾ əɹ tʃɹu fɔɹm, bʌt sɑmaɪl hæd dʒɹɑp hɪz, ɡoʊldən-bɪɹɾəd əɡɛn ən dʒʌs hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz tɔlɝ ðən ʃi. hi hæd lɛt ðə lɪŋk bɪtwin əm dɪzɑlv, tu. ðə wɑtʃɝ wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðət wɑz waɪz, ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ ə sɑmaɪlz vɔntɪd bɹeɪvɝi wɑz ɹɪli stupɪɾɪti ən blaɪndnəs. bʌt ðə mæn dɪd hoʊl seɪɾɪn; pɝhæps i wɑz nɑt kəmplitli ʌnəwɛɹ ə hɪz deɪnʒɝ.

The watcher ghosted through the trees, making no sound. It was wonderful what you could learn with a callbox, especially in a world where there seemed to be only two others. That red dress was easy to follow, and they never looked back even to see whether some of those so-called Aiel were trailing them. Graendal maintained the Mirror of Mists that hid her true form, but Sammael had dropped his, golden-bearded again and just head and shoulders taller than she. He had let the link between them dissolve, too. The watcher wondered whether that was wise, under the circumstances. He had always wondered how much of Sammael's vaunted bravery was really stupidity and blindness. But the man did hold saidin; perhaps he was not completely unaware of his danger.

ðə wɑtʃɝ fɑloʊɾ ən lɪsənd. ðeɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə. ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ, dʒɹɔn dɝɛkli fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, kəd niðɝ bi sin nɔɹ dɪtɛktəɾ ɪksɛp baɪ hu wildɪɾ ɪt. blæk flɛks floʊɾəd əkɹɔs ɪz vɪʒən. ðəɹ wɑz ə pɹaɪs, tə bi ʃʊɹ, wʌn ðət ɡɹu wɪð itʃ jus, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə peɪ ðə pɹaɪs wən ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. biɪŋ fɪld wɪð ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wɑz ɔlmoʊs laɪk nilɪŋ bɪniθ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, bæskɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ɡlɔɹi. ðə ɡlɔɹi wɑz wɝθ ðə peɪn.

The watcher followed and listened. They had no idea. The True Power, drawn directly from the Great Lord, could neither be seen nor detected except by who wielded it. Black flecks floated across his vision. There was a price, to be sure, one that grew with each use, but he had always been willing to pay the price when it was necessary. Being filled with the True Power was almost like kneeling beneath Shayol Ghul, basking in the Great Lord's glory. The glory was worth the pain.

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ hæd tə hæv jə wɪð mi," sɑmaɪl ɡɹaʊld, stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ə dɛd vaɪn. hi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli bɪn ət hoʊm əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɪɾiz. "ju ænsɝɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd kwɛstʃənz fəɹ əm dʒʌs biɪŋ ðɛɹ. aɪ kən hɑɹdli bɪliv ðət sɪli ɡɝl hɝsɛlf æktʃəli  sədʒɛstəd wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd." hi bɑɹkt ə læf. "pɝhæps aɪm tɑvɝən maɪsɛlf."

"Of course I had to have you with me," Sammael growled, stumbling over a dead vine. He had never really been at home away from the cities. "You answered a hundred questions for them just being there. I can hardly believe that silly girl herself actually suggested what I wanted." He barked a laugh. "Perhaps I'm ta'veren myself."

ə bɹæntʃ ðət pɑɹʃəli blɑkt ɡɹeɪndəlz pæθ flɛkst əweɪ əntɪl ɪt snæpt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp kɹæk. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ əz ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə stʃɹaɪk əɹ kəmpænjən. "ðæt sɪli ɡɝl wɪl kʌɾ aʊt jəɹ hɑɹɾ ən iɾ ɪt, ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns." ðə bɹæntʃ flu əsaɪd. "aɪ hæv ə fju kwɛstʃənz ə maɪ oʊn. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt jə wəd kip jəɹ tʃɹus wɪð ælθɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ ðən jə mʌst, bʌt ðɪs . . . ?"

A branch that partially blocked Graendal's path flexed away until it snapped with a sharp crack. For a moment it hung in the air as if she intended to strike her companion. "That silly girl will cut out your heart and eat it, given half a chance." The branch flew aside. "I have a few questions of my own. I never thought you would keep your truce with al'Thor any longer than you must, but this . . . ?"

ðə wɑtʃɝz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz. ə tʃɹus? ə kleɪm əz ɹɪski əz ɪt wɑz fɔls, baɪ ɔl ɛvəɾəns.

The watcher's eyebrows rose. A truce? A claim as risky as it was false, by all evidence.

"aɪ dɪdn ɝeɪnʒ ɪz kɪdnæpɪŋ." sɑmaɪl ɡeɪv əɹ wʌɾ i pɹɑbli θɔt wɑz ə ɹaɪ lʊk; hɪz skɑɹ meɪɾ ɪt mɔɹ ə snɑɹl. "mɛsænə hæɾ ə hæn ɪn ɪt, ðoʊ. meɪbi dɪmɑndɝɾ ən sɛmɝhɪdʒ əz wɛl, dɪspaɪt haʊ ɪɾ ɛndəd, bʌt mɛsænə sɝɾənli. pɝhæps jə ɔt tə ɹikənsɪɾɝ wʌt jə θɪŋk ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd minz əbaʊt livɪŋ ælθɹ ənhɑɹmd."

"I didn't arrange his kidnapping." Sammael gave her what he probably thought was a wry look; his scar made it more a snarl. "Mesaana had a hand in it, though. Maybe Demandred and Semirhage as well, despite how it ended, but Mesaana certainly. Perhaps you ought to reconsider what you think the Great Lord means about leaving al'Thor unharmed."

ɡɹeɪndəl kənsɪɾɝd ðæt, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət ʃi tʃɹɪpt. sɑmaɪl kɑɾ əɹ baɪ ði ɑɹm, kipɪŋ əɹ ɑn əɹ fit, bʌɾ əz sun əz ʃi ɹiɡeɪn əɹ bæləns, ʃi dʒɝk fɹi. ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, ivən ɡɪvən wʌt hæd hæpən bæk ɪn ðət klɪɹɪŋ. ɡɹeɪndəlz ɹil ɪntʃɹəst wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl plʌk fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl, bʌt ʃi wəɾ əv flɝɾɪd, dʒʌs tə pæs ən aʊɝ, wɪð ə mæn ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə kɪl əɹ wʌn u wɑntəd tə kɪl hɝ. ði oʊnli mɛn ʃi nɛvɝ flɝɾɪd wɪð wɝ ðoʊz ə ðə tʃoʊzən u stʊɾ əbʌv əɹ fəɹ ə taɪm. ʃi nɛvɝ æksɛptɪd biɪŋ ðə lɛsɝ ʌv ɛni pɛɹ.

Graendal considered that, so much so that she tripped. Sammael caught her by the arm, keeping her on her feet, but as soon as she regained her balance, she jerked free. Interesting, even given what had happened back in that clearing. Graendal's real interest was always the most beautiful plucked from among the most powerful, but she would have flirted, just to pass an hour, with a man she intended to kill or one who wanted to kill her. The only men she never flirted with were those of the Chosen who stood above her for a time. She never accepted being the lesser of any pair.

"ðɛn waɪ kəntɪnju wɪð ðɛm?" hɝ vɔɪs dʒɹɪp moʊltən lɑvə, ɔlðoʊ nɔɹməli ʃi hæɾ ɛkskwəzət kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz. "ælθɹ ɪn mɛsænəz hænz ɪz wʌn θɪŋ; ælθɹ ɪn ðɪs sævədʒəz ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. nɑt ðət ʃɪl əv mʌtʃ tʃæns əɾ ɪm ɪf jə ɹɪli ɪntɛn sɛndɪŋ əm ɔf tə lut. tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑksəz? wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ ɡeɪm ðɛɹ? də ðeɪ hoʊl kæptɪvz? ɪf jə θɪŋk əl titʃ əm kəmpʌlʃən, ɪɹeɪs ɪt fɹəm jəɹ maɪnd. wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən wɑz nɑt nɛɡlədʒəbəl. əl nɑt ɹɪsk stʃɹɛŋkθ ən skɪl ɹɪzaɪɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, ɪn hɝ, əɹ ɪn sʌmwʌn ʃi titʃəz. əɹ juv ə baɪndɝ hɪɾən əweɪ wɪð jəɹ ʌðɝ tɔɪz? fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, wɛɹ wɝ jə ɝliɝ? aɪ də nɑt laɪk hævɪŋ tə weɪt!"

"Then why continue with them?" Her voice dripped molten lava, although normally she had exquisite control over her emotions. "Al'Thor in Mesaana's hands is one thing; al'Thor in this savage's is something else. Not that she'll have much chance at him if you really intend sending them off to loot. Traveling boxes? What is your game there? Do they hold captives? If you think I will teach them Compulsion, erase it from your mind. One of those women was not negligible.
