I will not risk strength and skill residing together, in her, or in someone she teaches. Or do you have a binder hidden away with your other toys? For that matter, where were you earlier? I do not like having to wait!"

sɑmaɪl stɑpt, ɡlænsɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə wɑtʃɝ stʊd vɛɹi stɪl. swɑðd ɪn fænklɔθ ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz aɪz, hi hæd noʊ wɝi ðəɾ i wəd bi sin. oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz i hæd lɝn ɛkspɝtiz ɪn mɛni ɛɹiəz sɑmaɪl skɔɹnd. ɪn səm i feɪvɝd, tu.

Sammael stopped, glancing behind them. The watcher stood very still. Swathed in fancloth except for his eyes, he had no worry that he would be seen. Over the years he had learned expertise in many areas Sammael scorned. In some he favored, too.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənɪŋ sʌɾənli, slaɪsɪŋ əweɪ hæf ʌv ə tʃɹi, meɪd ɡɹeɪndəl dʒʌmp. ðə splɪt tʃɹʌŋk lin dʒɹʌŋkənli. naʊ ʃi ɔlsoʊ nu sɑmaɪl hɛl tə ðə sɔɹs.

The gateway opening suddenly, slicing away half of a tree, made Graendal jump. The split trunk leaned drunkenly. Now she also knew Sammael held to the Source.

"dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ wɑz tɛlɪŋ əm ðə tʃɹuθ?" sɑmaɪl sɛd mɑk-ɪŋli. "smɔl ɪnkɹisəz ɪn keɪɑs ɑɹ əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz lɑɹdʒ. ðəl ɡoʊ wɛɹ aɪ sɛn ðɛm, də əz aɪ wɪʃ, ən lɝn tə bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð wʌɾ aɪ ɡɪv ðɛm. əz wɪl ju, mzə."

"Did you think I was telling them the truth?" Sammael said mock-ingly. "Small increases in chaos are as important as large. They will go where I send them, do as I wish, and learn to be satisfied with what I give them. As will you, Maisia."

ɡɹeɪndəl lɛɾ əɹ ɪluʒən feɪɾ ən stʊd ɡoʊldən-hɛɹɾ əz hi, əz fɛɹ əz ʃi hæd bɪn dɑɹk. "ɪf jə kɔl mi ðəɾ əɡɛn, əl kɪl ju." hɝ vɔɪs hɛld ivən lɛs ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən əɹ feɪs. ʃi mɛn ɪt. ðə wɑtʃɝ tɛnst. ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd, wʌn ə ðə tu wəd daɪ. ʃəɾ i ɪntɝfɪɹ? blæk flɛks spɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz, fæstɝ, fæstɝ.

Graendal let her Illusion fade and stood golden-haired as he, as fair as she had been dark. "If you call me that again, I will kill you." Her voice held even less expression than her face. She meant it. The watcher tensed. If she tried, one of the two would die. Should he interfere? Black flecks sped across his eyes, faster, faster.

sɑmaɪl mɛɾ əɹ stɛɹ wɪð wʌn dʒʌst əz hɑɹd. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ u wɪl bi nɛbli, ɡɹeɪndəl," hi sɛd, ən stɛp θɹu hɪz ɡeɪtweɪ.

Sammael met her stare with one just as hard. "Remember who will be Nae'blis, Graendal," he said, and stepped through his gateway.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stʊd lʊkɪŋ ət ði oʊpənɪŋ. ə vɝɾɪkəl sɪlvɝ slæʃ əpɪɹɾ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd, bʌt bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɡeɪtweɪ bɪɡæn tə əlaɪn, ʃi lɛt ɡoʊ ðə wiv, sloʊli, ðə stʃɹik ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ tə ə pɔɪn bɪfɔɹ wɪŋkɪŋ aʊt. ðə pɹɪk-lɪŋ vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə wɑtʃɝz skɪn əz ʃi ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ əz wɛl. wɪð ə fɪks feɪs, ʃi fɑloʊd sɑmaɪl, ən ɪz ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ.

For a moment she stood looking at the opening. A vertical silver slash appeared off to one side, but before her gateway began to align, she let go the weave, slowly, the streak shrinking to a point before winking out. The prick-ling vanished from the watcher's skin as she released saidar as well. With a fixed face, she followed Sammael, and his gateway closed behind her.

ðə wɑtʃɝ smaɪl kɹʊkədli bɪhaɪn ɪz fænklɔθ skʌlkɝz mæsk. nɛbli. ðəɾ ɪkspleɪnd wʌt hæd bɹɔt ɡɹeɪndəl tə hil, wʌt hæd steɪɾ əɹ fɹəm kɪlɪŋ sɑmaɪl. ivən ʃi wəd bi blaɪndɪd baɪ ðæt. ən ivən ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɹɪsk fəɹ sɑmaɪl ðən kleɪmɪŋ tʃɹus wɪð luz θɝɪn, ðoʊ. ənlɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd dɪlaɪɾəd ɪn sɛɾɪŋ ɪz sɝvəns wʌn əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ, tə si hu wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ. oʊnli ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs kəd stænd nɪɹ ɪz ɡlɔɹi. bʌt tədeɪz tʃɹuθ nid nɑt bi təmɑɹoʊz. ðə wɑtʃɝ hæd sin tʃɹuθ tʃeɪnʒ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz bɪtwin ə sɪŋɡəl sʌnɹaɪz ən sʌnsɛt. mɔɹ ðən wʌns i hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪt hɪmsɛlf. hi kənsɪɾɝd ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ən kɪlɪŋ ði eɪt wɪmən ɪn ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd daɪ izəli; hi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ nu haʊ tə fɔɹm ə tʃɹu sɝkəl. ðə blæk flɛks fɪld ɪz aɪz, ə hɔɹəzɑntəl blɪzɝd. noʊ, hi wəd lɛt ðət ɹʌn ɪts kɔɹs. fəɹ naʊ.

The watcher smiled crookedly behind his fancloth skulker's mask. Nae'blis. That explained what had brought Graendal to heel, what had stayed her from killing Sammael. Even she would be blinded by that. An even greater risk for Sammael than claiming truce with Lews Therin, though. Unless, of course, it was true. The Great Lord delighted in setting his servants one against another, to see who was stronger. Only the strongest could stand near his glory. But today's truth need not be tomorrow's. The watcher had seen truth change a hundred times between a single sunrise and sunset. More than once he had changed it himself. He considered going back and killing the eight women in the clearing. They would die easily; he doubted they knew how to form a true circle. The black flecks filled his eyes, a horizontal blizzard. No, he would let that run its course. For now.

tə hɪz ɪɹz, ðə wɝl skɹimd əz i juz ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ tə ɹɪp ə smɔl hoʊl ən stɛp aʊtsaɪd ðə pæɾɝn. sɑmaɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tʃɹuli hi spoʊk. smɔl ɪnkɹisəz ɪn keɪɑs kəd bi ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz lɑɹdʒ.

To his ears, the world screamed as he used the True Power to rip a small hole and step outside the Pattern. Sammael did not know how truly he spoke. Small increases in chaos could be every bit as important as large.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn


CHAPTER 21

swʊvən naɪt


Swovan Night

naɪt keɪm sloʊli oʊvɝ ɛbu dɑɹ, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə waɪt bɪldɪŋz ɹɪzɪstɪŋ dɑɹknəs. smɔl nɑts ən bʌntʃəz ə swʊvən naɪt ɹɛvəlɝz wɪð lɪɾəl spɹɪɡz ʌv ɛvɝɡɹin ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ dænst ɪn ðə stʃɹits bɪniθ ə bɹaɪt θɹi-kɔɹɾɝ mun, fju kæɹiɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə læntɝn əz ðeɪ ɡæmboʊl tə ðə mjuzɪk ə fluts ən dʒɹʌmz ən hɔɹnz ðət dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ɪnz ən pæləsəz, dænsɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ fɹəm wʌn sɛɾ ə fɛstɪvəɾiz tə ənʌðɝ, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ðə stʃɹits leɪ ɛmpti. ə dɪstən dɔɡ bɑɹkt, ən ənʌðɝ, kloʊsɝ, ænsɝd fjʊɹiəsli əntɪl ɪt sʌɾənli jɛlpt ən fɛl saɪlənt.

Night came slowly over Ebou Dar, the glow of the white buildings resisting darkness. Small knots and bunches of Swovan Night revelers with little sprigs of evergreen in their hair danced in the streets beneath a bright three-quarter moon, few carrying so much as a lantern as they gamboled to the music of flutes and drums and horns that drifted from inns and palaces, dancing their way from one set of festivities to another, but for the most part the streets lay empty. A distant dog barked, and another, closer, answered furiously until it suddenly yelped and fell silent.

bælənst ɑn ɪz toʊz, mæt lɪsənd, aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ ðə munʃæɾoʊz. oʊnli ə kæt muvd, slɪŋkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit. ðə slæp ə ɹʌnɪŋ bɛɹ fit feɪɾəd. ði oʊnɝ ʌv wʌn pɛɹ ʃəd bi stæɡɝɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝ bliɾɪŋ. əz i bɛnt, hɪz fʊt kɪkt ə klʌb əz lɔŋ əz ɪz ɑɹm ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz; hɛvi bɹæs stʌdz ʃoʊn ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ðət wʊɾə bɹoʊkən ɪz skʌl fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi waɪpt ɪz naɪf ɑn ðə ɹæɡəd koʊt wɔɹn baɪ ðə mæn əɾ ɪz fit. oʊpən aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ðə naɪt skaɪ fɹəm ə dɝɾi, kɹis feɪs. ə bɛɡɝ, baɪ ðə lʊk ən smɛl ə hɪm. mæt hæd nɑt hɝɾ ə bɛɡɝz ətækɪŋ pipəl, bʌt meɪbi taɪmz wɝ hɑɹɾɝ ðən i θɔt. ə lɑɹdʒ dʒut sæk leɪ nɪɹ wʌn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd. ðə fɛloʊz sɝɾənli hæd bɪn ɑptəmɪstɪk əbaʊt wʌt ðeɪ wəd faɪn ɪn ɪz pɑkəts. ðə θɪŋ cʊɾə kʌvɝɾ ɪm fɹəm hɛd tə niz.

Balanced on his toes, Mat listened, eyes searching the moonshadows. Only a cat moved, slinking along the street. The slap of running bare feet faded. The owner of one pair should be staggering, and the other bleeding. As he bent, his foot kicked a club as long as his arm on the paving stones; heavy brass studs shone in the moonlight. That would have broken his skull for sure. Shaking his head, he wiped his knife on the ragged coat worn by the man at his feet. Open eyes stared at the night sky from a dirty, creased face. A beggar, by the look and smell of him. Mat had not heard of beggars attacking people, but maybe times were harder than he thought. A large jute sack lay near one outstretched hand. The fellows certainly had been optimistic about what they would find in his pockets. The thing could have covered him from head to knees.

tə ðə nɔɹθ, əbʌv ðə sɪɾi, laɪt sʌɾənli bɝst ɪn ðə skaɪ wɪð ə hɑloʊ bum əz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ stʃɹiks ʌv ɡɹin ɪkspændəɾ ɪn ə bɔl, ən ðən ənʌðɝ ɪɹʌpʃən ʃaʊɝd ɹɛd spɑɹkəlz θɹu ðə fɝst, ðən ə blu, ən ə jɛloʊ. ɪluməneɪɾɝz' naɪtfloʊɝz, nɑɾ əz spɛktækjəlɝ əz ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn ɪn ə munləs, klaʊɾi skaɪ, jɛt stɪl ðeɪ tʊk ɪz bɹɛθ. hi kəd wɑtʃ faɪɹwɝks tɪl i fɛl oʊvɝ fɹəm hʌŋɡɝ. neɪlzin hæd spoʊkən ʌv ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ - laɪt, wɑz ðəɾ oʊnli ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ? - bʌt noʊ mɔɹ naɪt-flaʊɝz keɪm. wən ɪluməneɪɾɝz meɪd ðə skaɪ blum, əz ðeɪ sɛd, ðeɪ plæntəd mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ flaʊɝz. pleɪnli sʌmwʌn wɪð kɔɪn hæd meɪɾ ə pɝtʃəs fəɹ swʊvən naɪt. hi wɪʃt i nu hu. ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ u wəd sɛl naɪtfloʊɝz wəd sɛl mɔɹ ðən ðæt.

To the north, above the city, light suddenly burst in the sky with a hollow boom as glittering streaks of green expanded in a ball, and then another eruption showered red sparkles through the first, then a blue, and a yellow. Illuminators' nightflowers, not as spectacular as they would have been in a moonless, cloudy sky, yet still they took his breath. He could watch fireworks till he fell over from hunger. Nalesean had spoken of an Illuminator - Light, was that only this morning? - but no more night-flowers came. When Illuminators made the sky bloom, as they said, they planted more than four flowers. Plainly someone with coin had made a purchase for Swovan Night. He wished he knew who. An Illuminator who would sell nightflowers would sell more than that.

slɪpɪŋ ðə naɪf bæk ʌp ɪz sliv, hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz hæt fɹəm ðə peɪvmən ən wɔkt əweɪ hɝidli, hɪz buts ɛkoʊɪŋ, ə saʊn ɛmpti əz ðə stʃɹit. moʊst ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊz hɪɹ ʃoʊd nɑɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə laɪt. ə bɛɾɝ pleɪs fəɹ mɝɾɝ pɹɑbli kəd nɑt bi faʊn ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ði ɪntaɪɝ ɪnkaʊntɝ wɪð ðə θɹi bɛɡɝz hæd læstəɾ oʊnli ə mɪnəɾ əɹ tu ən hæd bɪn sin baɪ noʊ wʌn. ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi, jə kəd faɪn θɹi əɹ fɔɹ faɪts ɪn ə deɪ ɪf jə wɝ nɑt kɛɹfəl, bʌt ði ɑdz ə feɪsɪŋ tu sɛts ə ɹɑbɝz ɪn wʌn deɪ simd əbaʊɾ əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ði ɑdz ə ðə sɪvəl ɡɑɹd ɹəfjuzɪŋ ə bɹaɪb. wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə hɪz lʌk? ɪf oʊnli ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs wəd stɑp ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi dɪd nɑt ɹʌn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dɔɾəl iðɝ, wʌn hæn ɑn ə hɪl bɪniθ ɪz koʊɾ ən ən aɪ oʊpən fəɹ ɛniwʌn muvɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. hi sɔ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə fju klʌmps ə pipəl kəvɔɹɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit, ðoʊ.

Slipping the knife back up his sleeve, he gathered his hat from the pavement and walked away hurriedly, his boots echoing, a sound empty as the street. Most shuttered windows here showed not a glimmer of light. A better place for murder probably could not be found in the city. The entire encounter with the three beggars had lasted only a minute or two and had been seen by no one. In this city, you could find three or four fights in a day if you were not careful, but the odds of facing two sets of robbers in one day seemed about as great as the odds of the Civil Guard refusing a bribe. What was happening to his luck? If only those bloody dice would stop rolling in his head. He did not run, but he did not dawdle either, one hand on a hilt beneath his coat and an eye open for anyone moving in the shadows. He saw nothing but a few clumps of people cavorting along the street, though.

ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, ðə teɪbəlz hæd bɪn klɪɹɾ əweɪ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju nɪɹ ðə wɔlz. ðə fluɾɪsts ən ðə dʒɹʌmɝ meɪd ʃɹɪl mjuzɪk fəɹ fɔɹ læfɪŋ laɪnz ə pipəl duɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi hæf pæɾɝn-dæns ən hæf dʒɪɡ. wɑtʃɪŋ, hi kɑpiɾ ə stɛp. aʊtlæn mɝtʃəns ɪn faɪn wʊlənz lɛpt ɹaɪɾ əlɔŋ wɪð loʊkəlz ɪn bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlk vɛsts əɹ ðoʊz jusləs koʊts slʌŋ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. hi mɑɹkt aʊt tu ʌv ðə mɝtʃəns fəɹ ðə weɪ ðeɪ muvd, wʌn slɛndɝ ən wʌn nɑt, jɛt boʊθ wɪð ə laɪt ɡɹeɪs, ən sɛvɹəl loʊkəl wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛst, ðə dip nɛklinz aʊtlaɪn baɪ ə lɪɾəl leɪs əɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, bʌt nʌn ɪn sɪlk. nɑt ðəɾ i wəd ɹəfjuz tə dæns wɪð ə wʊmən ɪn sɪlk, ʌv kɔɹs - hi hæd nɛvɝ tɝn daʊn ə dæns wɪð ɛni wʊmən ʌv ɛni eɪdʒ əɹ steɪʃən - bʌt ðə ɹɪtʃ wɝ ɪn ðə pæləsəz tənaɪt, əɹ ðə hoʊmz ə ðə wɛlθiɝ mɝtʃəns ən mʌnilɛndɝz. ðoʊz foʊk nɪɹ ðə wɔlz, kætʃɪŋ ðɛɹ bɹɛθ fəɹ ðə nɛks dæns, hæd ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɛɹiɾ ɪn mʌɡz ɔfən əz nɑt, əɹ wɝ snætʃɪŋ fɹɛʃ mʌɡz fɹəm tʃɹeɪz kæɹid baɪ skɝiɪŋ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən laɪkli wəd sɛl əz mʌtʃ waɪn tənaɪɾ əz ɪn ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi wik. eɪl, tu; ðə loʊkəl foʊk mʌst əv noʊ teɪs tə ðɛɹ tʌŋz.

In the common room of The Wandering Woman, the tables had been cleared away except for a few near the walls. The flutists and the drummer made shrill music for four laughing lines of people doing what appeared to be half pattern-dance and half jig. Watching, he copied a step. Outland merchants in fine woolens leaped right along with locals in brocaded silk vests or those useless coats slung on their shoulders. He marked out two of the merchants for the way they moved, one slender and one not, yet both with a light grace, and several local women wearing their best, the deep necklines outlined by a little lace or a great deal of embroidery, but none in silk. Not that he would refuse to dance with a woman in silk, of course - he had never turned down a dance with any woman of any age or station - but the rich were in the palaces tonight, or the homes of the wealthier merchants and moneylenders. Those folk near the walls, catching their breath for the next dance, had their faces buried in mugs often as not, or were snatching fresh mugs from trays carried by scurrying serving women. Mistress Anan likely would sell as much wine tonight as in an ordinary week. Ale, too; the local folk must have no taste to their tongues.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ ənʌðɝ stɛp ə ðə dæns, hi kɑt kɛɹə əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə hɝi baɪ wɪð ə tʃɹeɪ, pɪtʃɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs laʊɾ əbʌv ðə mjuzɪk tə æsk ə fju kwɛstʃənz ən fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ən ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ɪz dɪnɝ, ɡɪldɪd fɪʃ, ə tæŋi dɪʃ ðət mɪstʃɹəs ɑnənz kʊk pɹipɛɹd tə pɝfɛkʃən. ə mæn niɾəd ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ tə kip ʌp ɪn ðə dæns.

Trying another step of the dance, he caught Caira as she tried to hurry by with a tray, pitching his voice loud above the music to ask a few questions and finishing with an order for his dinner, gilded fish, a tangy dish that Mistress Anan's cook prepared to perfection. A man needed his strength to keep up in the dance.

kɛɹə flæʃt ə sʌltʃɹi smaɪl əɾ ə fɛloʊ ɪn ə jɛloʊ vɛst u ɡɹæbd ə mʌɡ fɹəm əɹ tʃɹeɪ ən dʒɹɑpt ɪz kɔɪn ɑn ɪt, bʌt fəɹ wʌns ʃi hæd noʊ smaɪl fəɹ mæt. ɪn fækt, ʃi mænədʒ tə kəmpɹɛs əɹ maʊθ tə ə θɪn laɪn, noʊ smɔl fit. "jɔɹ lɪɾəl ɹæbət, æm aɪ?" wɪð ə tɛlɪŋ snɪf, ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪmpeɪʃənli. "ðə bɔɪ ɪz tʌkt ɪndə hɪz bɛd, wɛɹ i ʃəd bi, ən aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ lɔɹd neɪlzin ɪz, əɹ hɑɹnən, əɹ mæstɝ veɪnɪn, əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. ən kʊk sɛd ʃi woʊn fɪks ɛniθɪŋ bʌt sup ən bɹɛd fəɹ ðoʊz əz ɑɹ dʒɹaʊnɪŋ ðɛɹ tʌŋz ɪn waɪn. ðoʊ waɪ maɪ lɔɹd wɑns ɡɪldɪd fɪʃ wən hiz ə ɡɪldɪd wʊmən weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɹum, aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ kʊdn seɪ. ɪf maɪ lɔɹd wɪl ɪkskjuz mi, səm pipəl nid tə wɝk fəɹ ðɛɹ kɹʌst." ʃi swupt əweɪ, pɹɑfɝɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪ ən smaɪlɪŋ fɪt tə splɪɾ əɹ feɪs əɾ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn saɪt.

Caira flashed a sultry smile at a fellow in a yellow vest who grabbed a mug from her tray and dropped his coin on it, but for once she had no smile for Mat. In fact, she managed to compress her mouth to a thin line, no small feat. "Your little rabbit, am I?" With a telling sniff, she went on impatiently. "The boy is tucked into his bed, where he should be, and I don't know where Lord Nalesean is, or Harnan, or Master Vanin, or anybody else. And Cook said she won't fix anything but soup and bread for those as are drowning their tongues in wine. Though why my Lord wants gilded fish when he has a gilded woman waiting in his room, I'm sure I couldn't say. If my Lord will excuse me, some people need to work for their crust." She swooped away, proffering her tray and smiling fit to split her face at every man in sight.

mæt fɹaʊn æftɝ hɝ. ə ɡɪldɪd wʊmən? ɪn ɪz ɹum? ðə tʃɛst ʌv ɡoʊld ɹɛstəd naʊ ɪn ə smɔl hɑloʊ bɪniθ ðə kɪtʃən flɔɹ, ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə stoʊvz, bʌt ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd dʒɹʌm laɪk θʌndɝ sʌɾənli.

Mat frowned after her. A gilded woman? In his room? The chest of gold rested now in a small hollow beneath the kitchen floor, in front of one of the stoves, but the dice in his head drummed like thunder suddenly.

ðə saʊnz ə mɛɹəmən feɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl əz i sloʊli klaɪm ðə stɛɹz. ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz dɔɹ, hi pɔzd, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə daɪs. tu ətɛmps tə ɹɑb ɪm soʊ fɑɹ tədeɪ. twaɪs ɪz skʌl cʊɾə bɪn bɹoʊkən. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət dɑɹkfɹɛn hæd nɑt sin hɪm, ən noʊ wʌn kəd kɔl əɹ ɡɪldɪd, bʌt. . . . hi fɪŋɡɝɾ ə hɪlt ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, ðən tʊk ɪz hæn əweɪ əz ə wʊmən flɛɹɾ ɪn ɪz θɔts, ə tɔl wʊmən fɔlɪŋ wɪð ðə hɪlt ʌv ə naɪf pɹoʊtʃɹuɾɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts. hɪz naɪf. lʌk wəd dʒʌst əv tə bi wɪð hɪm. saɪɪŋ, hi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

The sounds of merriment faded a little as he slowly climbed the stairs. In front of his door, he paused, listening to the dice. Two attempts to rob him so far today. Twice his skull could have been broken. He was sure that Darkfriend had not seen him, and no one could call her gilded, but. . . . He fingered a hilt under his coat, then took his hand away as a woman flared in his thoughts, a tall woman falling with the hilt of a knife protruding between her breasts. His knife. Luck would just have to be with him. Sighing, he pushed open the door.

ðə hʌntɝ ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd meɪɾ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ tɝnd, hɛftɪŋ ɪz ʌn-stʃɹʌŋ tu ɹɪvɝz baʊ, hɝ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd dʒɹɔn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. hɝ blu aɪz fæsən ɑn ɪm pɝpəsfəli, ən əɹ feɪs fɪkst ɪtsɛlf ɪn dɪtɝməneɪʃən. ʃi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹʌb ɪm wɪð ðə baʊ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɛt wʌt ʃi wɑntəd.

The Hunter that Elayne had made her Warder turned, hefting his un-strung Two Rivers bow, her golden braid drawn over her shoulder. Her blue eyes fastened on him purposefully, and her face fixed itself in determination. She looked ready to drub him with the bow if she did not get what she wanted.

"ɪf ðɪs ɪz əbaʊɾ oʊlvɝ," hi bɪɡæn, ən sʌɾənli ə twɪst ə mɛmɹi ənfoʊldəd, ə mɪs θɪn oʊvɝ wʌn deɪ, wʌn aʊɝ ɪn ɪz laɪf.

"If this is about Olver," he began, and suddenly a twist of memory unfolded, a mist thinned over one day, one hour in his life.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hoʊp, wɪð sintʃæn tə ðə wɛst ən waɪtkloʊks tə ði ist, noʊ hoʊp ən oʊnli wʌn tʃæns, soʊ hi ɹeɪz ðə kɝl hɔɹn ən blu, nɑt ɹɪli noʊɪŋ wʌt tə ɪkspɛkt. ðə saʊn keɪm ɡoʊldən əz ðə hɔɹn, soʊ swiɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ. ɪɾ ɛkoʊd, ən ði ɝθ ən hɛvənz sim tə sɪŋ. waɪl ðət wʌn pjʊɹ noʊt hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ə fɑɡ bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz, əpɪɹɪŋ fɹəm noʊwɛɹ, θɪn wɪsps, θɪkənɪŋ, bɪloʊɪŋ haɪɝ, əntɪl ɔl wɑz əbskjʊɹɾ əz ɪf klaʊdz kʌvɝd ðə lænd. ən daʊn ðə klaʊdz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, əz ðoʊ daʊn ə maʊntənsaɪd, ðə dɛd hɪɹoʊz ə lɛdʒənd, baʊn tə bi kɔl bæk baɪ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hɪmsɛlf lɛd, tɔl ən hʊk-noʊzd, ən bɪhaɪn keɪm ðə ɹɛst, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd. soʊ fju, bʌɾ ɔl ðoʊz ðə wil wəd spɪn aʊɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn tə ɡaɪd ðə pæɾɝn, tə meɪk lɛdʒən ən mɪθ. mɪkəl ə ðə pjʊɹ hɑɹt, ən ʃɪvən ðə hʌntɝ bɪhaɪn ɪz blæk mæsk. hi wɑz sɛd tə hɛɹəl ði ɛn ʌv eɪdʒəz, ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv wʌt hæd bɪn ən ðə bɝθ ʌv wʌt wɑz tə bi, hi ən ɪz sɪstɝ kɑliən, kɔl ðə tʃuzɝ, hu ɹoʊd ɹɛd-mæskt əɾ ɪz saɪd. æmɑɹɪsu, wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ə ðə sʌn ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn əɹ hænz, ən peɪədʒɹɪɡ, ðə ɡoʊldən-tʌŋ pismeɪkɝ, ən ðɛɹ, kæɹiɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ baʊ wɪð wɪtʃ ʃi nɛvɝ mɪst. . . .

There was no hope, with Seanchan to the west and Whitecloaks to the east, no hope and only one chance, so he raised the curled Horn and blew, not really knowing what to expect. The sound came golden as the Horn, so sweet he did not know whether to laugh or cry. It echoed, and the earth and heavens seemed to sing. While that one pure note hung in the air, a fog began to rise, appearing from nowhere, thin wisps, thickening, billowing higher, until all was obscured as if clouds covered the land. And down the clouds they rode, as though down a mountainside, the dead heroes of legend, bound to be called back by the Horn of Valere. Artur Hawkwing himself led, tall and hook-nosed, and behind came the rest, little more than a hundred. So few, but all those the Wheel would spin out again and again to guide the Pattern, to make legend and myth. Mikel of the Pure Heart, and Shivan the Hunter behind his black mask. He was said to herald the end of Ages, the destruction of what had been and the birth of what was to be, he and his sister Calian, called the Chooser, who rode red-masked at his side. Amaresu, with the Sword of the Sun glowing in her hands, and Paedrig, the golden-tongued peacemaker, and there, carrying the silver bow with which she never missed. . . .

hi pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lin əɡɛnst ɪt. hi fɛl dɪzi, deɪzd. "ju ɑɹ ʃi. bɝdʒɪt, fəɹ tʃɹu. bɝn maɪ boʊnz tə æʃ, ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl. haʊ? haʊ?"

He pushed the door shut trying to lean against it. He felt dizzy, dazed. "You are she. Birgitte, for true. Burn my bones to ash, it's impossible. How? How?"

ðə wʊmən ə lɛdʒənd ɡeɪv ə ɹɪzaɪn saɪ ən pɹɑpt ɪz baʊ bæk ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ nɛks tə hɪz spɪɹ. "aɪ wɑz ɹɪpt aʊɾ əntaɪmli, hɔɹnsaʊndɝ, kæst aʊt baɪ mɑɡiɾin tə daɪ ən seɪv baɪ ɪleɪnz bɑndɪŋ." ʃi spoʊk sloʊli, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm əz ɪf tə bi ʃʊɹ i ʌndɝstʊd. "aɪ fɪɹd jə maɪt ɹɪmɛmbɝ u aɪ juz tə bi."

The woman of legend gave a resigned sigh and propped his bow back in the corner next to his spear. "I was ripped out untimely, Hornsounder, cast out by Moghedien to die and saved by Elayne's bonding." She spoke slowly, studying him as if to be sure he understood. "I feared you might remember who I used to be."

stɪl filɪŋ hɪt bɪtwin ði aɪz, hi flʌŋ hɪmsɛlf skaʊlɪŋ ɪndə ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz teɪbəl. hu ʃi juz tə bi, ɪndid. fɪsts ɑn hɪps, ʃi kənfɹʌntəɾ ɪm tʃælənʒɪŋli, noʊ wɪt dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə bɝdʒɪɾ i hæd sin ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ. ivən əɹ kloʊðz wɝ ðə seɪm, ðoʊ ðɪs ʃɔɹt koʊt wɑz ɹɛɾ ən ðə waɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz jɛloʊ. "ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv noʊ ən kɛpt ɪt fɹəm mi, tʃɹu? aɪ wɪɹi ʌv sikɹəts, bɝdʒɪt, ən ðeɪ hɑɹbɝ sikɹəts əz ə ɡɹeɪn bɑɹn hɑɹbɝz ɹæts. ðeɪv bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪz ən hɑɹts. ivən nɪneɪiv ɪz twaɪs ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, naʊ."

Still feeling hit between the eyes, he flung himself scowling into the armchair beside his table. Who she used to be, indeed. Fists on hips, she confronted him challengingly, no whit different from the Birgitte he had seen ride out of the sky. Even her clothes were the same, though this short coat was red and the wide trousers yellow. "Elayne and Nynaeve know and kept it from me, true? I weary of secrets, Birgitte, and they harbor secrets as a grain barn harbors rats. They've become Aes Sedai, eyes and hearts. Even Nynaeve is twice a stranger, now."

"ju hæv jəɹ oʊn sikɹəts." foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛsts, ʃi sæɾ ɑn ðə fʊɾ ə hɪz bɛd. ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt ət hɪm, jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i wɑz ə tævɝn pʌzəl. "fɔɹ wʌn, juv nɑt toʊld əm jə blu ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. ðə smɔləst ə jəɹ sikɹəts fɹəm ðɛm, aɪ θɪŋk."

"You have your own secrets." Folding her arms under her breasts, she sat on the foot of his bed. The way she looked at him, you would have thought he was a tavern puzzle. "For one, you've not told them you blew the Horn of Valere. The smallest of your secrets from them, I think."

mæt blɪŋkt. hi hæɾ əsum ðeɪ hæd toʊl hɝ. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi wɑz bɝdʒɪt. "wʌt sikɹəts də aɪ hæv? ðoʊz wɪmən noʊ maɪ toʊneɪlz ən dʒɹimz." ʃi wɑz bɝdʒɪt. ʌv kɔɹs. hi lin fɔɹwɝd. "meɪk əm si ɹizən. jəɹ bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ. jə kən meɪk əm də əz jə seɪ. ðɪs sɪɾi hæz ə pɪt-tʃɹæp əɾ ɛvɹi kɹɔsɪŋ, ən aɪ fɪɹ ðə steɪks ɡɹoʊ ʃɑɹpɝ baɪ ðə deɪ. meɪk əm kʌm əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ɪts tu leɪt."

Mat blinked. He had assumed they had told her. After all, she was Birgitte. "What secrets do I have? Those women know my toenails and dreams." She was Birgitte. Of course. He leaned forward. "Make them see reason. You're Birgitte Silverbow. You can make them do as you say. This city has a pit-trap at every crossing, and I fear the stakes grow sharper by the day. Make them come away before it's too late."

ʃi læft. pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ ən læft! "ju hæv ðə ɹɔŋ ɛnd, hɔɹnsaʊndɝ. aɪ də nɑt kəmæn ðɛm. aɪm ɪleɪnz wɔɹɾɝ. aɪ oʊbeɪ." hɝ smaɪl bɪkeɪm ɹufəl. "bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ. feɪθ ə ðə laɪt, aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ aɪ stɪl æm ðət wʊmən. soʊ mʌtʃ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ wɑz ən nu hæz feɪɾəd laɪk mɪs bɪniθ ðə sʌmɝ sʌn sɪns maɪ stʃɹeɪnʒ nu bɝθ. ɪm noʊ hɪɹoʊ naʊ, oʊnli ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə meɪk maɪ weɪ. ən əz fəɹ jəɹ sikɹəts. wʌt læŋɡwədʒ də wi spik, hɔɹnsaʊndɝ?"

She laughed. Put a hand over her mouth and laughed! "You have the wrong end, Hornsounder. I do not command them. I am Elayne's Warder. I obey." Her smile became rueful. "Birgitte Silverbow. Faith of the Light, I'm not sure I still am that woman. So much of what I was and knew has faded like mist beneath the summer sun since my strange new birth. I'm no hero now, only another woman to make my way. And as for your secrets. What language do we speak, Hornsounder?"

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ . . . ən stɑpt, ɹɪli hɪɹɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd dʒʌst æskt. noʊsɑn aɪɝoʊ ɡeɪveɪn doʊmɝəkoʊʃi, dɪaɪnɛnməpɝvin? spik wi wʌt læŋɡwədʒ, saʊndɝ ə ðə hɔɹn? ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz nɛk tʃɹaɪd tə stænd. "ði oʊl blʌd," hi sɛd kɛɹfəli. nɑɾ ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ. "æn ɛɛs sədaɪ wʌns toʊl mi ði oʊl blʌd ɹʌnz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn - wʌɾ ɑɹ jə blʌɾi wɛl læfɪŋ ət naʊ?"

He opened his mouth . . . and stopped, really hearing what she had just asked. Nosane iro gavane domorakoshi, Diynen'd'ma'purvene? Speak we what language, Sounder of the Horn? The hair on his neck tried to stand. "The old blood," he said carefully. Not in the Old Tongue. "An Aes Sedai once told me the old blood runs strong in - What are you bloody well laughing at now?"

"ju, mæt," ʃi mænədʒd waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə dʌbəl oʊvɝ. ət list ʃi wɑz nɑt spikɪŋ ði oʊl tʌŋ ɛni mɔɹ iðɝ. ʃi nʌkəld ə tiɹ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. "sʌm pipəl spik ə fju wɝdz, ə fɹeɪz əɹ tu, kəz ə ði oʊl blʌd. juʒəwəli wɪθaʊɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ seɪ, əɹ nɑt kwaɪt. bʌt ju. . . . wʌn sɛntəns jəɹ ən ɛɝoʊni haɪ pɹɪns ən ðə nɛkst ə fɝs lɔɹɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən, æksɛn ən ɪɾiəm pɝfɛkt. noʊ, doʊnt wɝi. jəɹ sikɹəɾ ɪz seɪf wɪð mi." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "ɪz maɪn wɪð ju?"

"You, Mat," she managed while trying not to double over. At least she was not speaking the Old Tongue any more either. She knuckled a tear from the corner of her eye. "Some people speak a few words, a phrase or two, because of the old blood. Usually without understanding what they say, or not quite. But you. . . . One sentence you're an Eharoni High Prince and the next a First Lord of Manetheren, accent and idiom perfect. No, don't worry. Your secret is safe with me." She hesitated. "Is mine with you?"

hi weɪvd ə hænd, stɪl tu flæbɝɡæstɪd tə bi əfɛndəd. "du aɪ lʊk laɪk maɪ tʌŋ flæps?" hi mʌɾɝd. bɝdʒɪt! ɪn ðə flɛʃ! "bɝn mi, aɪ kəd juz ə dʒɹɪŋk." bɪfɔɹ ðət wɑz aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ i nu ɪt wɑz ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ tə seɪ. wɪmən nɛvɝ -  "ðæt saʊnz ðə ɹaɪt noʊʃən tə mi," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ kəd juz ə pɪtʃɝ ʌv waɪn, maɪsɛlf. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, wən aɪ sɔ jud ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi, aɪ nɪɹli swɑloʊd maɪ tʌŋ."

He waved a hand, still too flabbergasted to be offended. "Do I look like my tongue flaps?" he muttered. Birgitte! In the flesh! "Burn me, I could use a drink." Before that was out of his mouth he knew it was the wrong thing to say. Women never -  "That sounds the right notion to me," she said. "I could use a pitcher of wine, myself. Blood and ashes, when I saw you'd recognized me, I nearly swallowed my tongue."

hi sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn dʒɝkt, stɛɹɪŋ.

He sat up straight as if he had been jerked, staring.

ʃi mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz wɪð ə mɛɹi twɪŋkəl ən ə ɡɹɪn. "ðɛɹz ɪnʌf nɔɪz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum, wi kəd tɔk wɪθaʊt biɪŋ oʊvɝhɝd. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ wʊdn maɪn sɪɾɪŋ ən lʊkɪŋ ə bɪt. ɪleɪn pɹitʃɪz laɪk ə təvən kaʊnsəlɝ ɪf aɪ oʊɡəl ə mæn fəɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ə hɑɹtbit."

She met his gaze with a merry twinkle and a grin. "There's enough noise in the common room, we could talk without being overheard. Besides, I wouldn't mind sitting and looking a bit. Elayne preaches like a Tovan councilor if I ogle a man for longer than a heartbeat."

hi nɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ i θɔt. ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz toʊld ɪm təvænz wɝ ə stɑɹk ən dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ pipəl, əbstimiəs tə ðə pɔɪn ə peɪn; ət lis ðeɪ hæd bɪn, ə θaʊzən jɪɹz ɡɔn ən mɔɹ. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ ɡɹoʊn. ɑn ðə wʌn hænd, ə tʃæns tə tɔk wɪð bɝdʒɪt - bɝdʒɪt! hi daʊɾɪd i wəɾ ɛvɝ ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə ʃɑk - bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ, hi daʊɾɪd i wəd bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ ðə mjuzɪk daʊnstɛɹz fəɹ ðə nɔɪz ə ðoʊz daɪs ɹætlɪŋ ɪn ɪz skʌl. ʃi mʌs bi ə ki tə ɪt, sʌmhaʊ. ə mæn wɪð ɛni bɹeɪnz wəd klaɪm aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ ɹaɪt naʊ. "ə pɪtʃɝ əɹ tu saʊnz faɪn tə mi," hi toʊl hɝ.

He nodded before he thought. Other men's memories told him Tovans were a stark and disapproving people, abstemious to the point of pain; at least they had been, a thousand years gone and more. He was not sure whether to laugh or groan. On the one hand, a chance to talk with Birgitte - Birgitte! he doubted he would ever get over the shock - but on the other, he doubted he would be able to hear the music downstairs for the noise of those dice rattling in his skull. She must be a key to it, somehow. A man with any brains would climb out the window right now. "A pitcher or two sounds fine to me," he told her.

ə stɪf sɔl bɹiz ʌp fɹəm ðə beɪ kæɹiɾ ə tʌtʃ ə kulnəs, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, bʌt ðə naɪt fɛlt əpɹɛsɪv tə nɪneɪiv. mjuzɪk ən snætʃɪz ə læftɝ dʒɹɪftəɾ ɪndə ðə pæləs, ən feɪnli fɹəm wɪðɪn əz wɛl. ʃi hæd bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd tə ðə bɔl baɪ taɪlɪn hɝsɛlf, ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə tu, bʌɾ ɔl dɪklaɪnd, wɪð vɛɹiɪŋ dɪɡɹiz ə pəlaɪtnəs. eɪvinhə hæd sɛd ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn dæns ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə də wɪð wɛtləndɝ mɛn, wɪtʃ meɪd taɪlɪn blɪŋk ənsɝteɪnli. fəɹ hɝsɛlf, nɪneɪiv wʊɾə laɪk tə ɡoʊ - oʊnli ə ful pæst ʌp ɛni tʃæns tə dæns - jɛt ʃi nu ɪf ʃi hæd, ʃi wʊɾə dʌn ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, sæt sʌmwɛɹ wɝiɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə tʃu hɝ nʌkəl tə ə nʌb.

A stiff salt breeze up from the bay carried a touch of coolness, for a wonder, but the night felt oppressive to Nynaeve. Music and snatches of laughter drifted into the palace, and faintly from within as well. She had been invited to the ball by Tylin herself, and Elayne and Aviendha too, but all declined, with varying degrees of politeness. Aviendha had said there was only one dance she was willing to do with wetlander men, which made Tylin blink uncertainly. For herself, Nynaeve would have liked to go - only a fool passed up any chance to dance - yet she knew if she had, she would have done exactly what she was doing, sat somewhere worrying and trying not to chew her knuckle to a nub.

soʊ ðəɹ ðeɪ ɔl wɝ, klɑzəɾɪd ɪn ðɛɹ əpɑɹtməns wɪð tɑm ən dʒulɪn, æŋkʃəs əz keɪdʒ kæts, waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ meɪd mɛɹi. wɛl, ʃi wɑz, ɛniweɪ. wʌt kəd bi kipɪŋ bɝdʒɪt? haʊ lɔŋ dɪɾ ɪt teɪk tə tɛl ə mæn tə pɹizɛn hɪmsɛlf fɝs θɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ? laɪt, ðə hoʊl ɛfɝt wɑz jusləs, ən ɪt wɑz lɔŋ pæs taɪm fəɹ bɛd. lɔŋ pæst. ɪf ʃi kəɾ oʊnli slip, ʃi kəd pʊɾ əweɪ mɛmɹiz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋz hɔɹəbəl dʒɝniz baɪ boʊt. wɝst ʌv ɔl, hɝ wɛðɝ sɛns toʊld əɹ ə stɔɹm wɑz ɑn ðə weɪ, toʊld əɹ ðə wɪnd ʃəd bi haʊlɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ən ðə ɹeɪn ʃiɾɪŋ daʊn soʊ θɪk noʊ wʌn kəd si tɛn fit. ɪt hæd teɪkən əɹ səm taɪm tə ʌndɝstæn əbaʊt ðə taɪmz ʃi lɪsən tə ðə wɪn ən sim tə hɪɹ laɪz. ət list, ʃi θɔt ʃi ʌndɝstʊd. ənʌðɝ kaɪndə stɔɹm wɑz kʌmɪŋ, nɑt waɪn əɹ ɹeɪn. ʃi hæd noʊ pɹuf, bʌt ʃi wəɾ iɾ əɹ slɪpɝz ɪf mæt kɔθən wɑz nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt sʌmhaʊ. ʃi wɑntəd tə slip fəɹ ə mʌnθ, ə jɪɹ, tə fɝɡɛt wɝiz əntɪl læn wækən əɹ wɪð ə kɪs laɪk ðə sʌn kɪŋ wɪð tɑliə. wɪtʃ wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs, ʌv kɔɹs; ðət wɑz oʊnli ə stɔɹi, ən ə vɛɹi ɪmpɹɑpɝ wʌn ət ðæt, ən ɛniweɪ, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bɪkʌm ɛni mænz pɛt, nɑɾ ivən lænz. ʃi wəd faɪn hɪm, ðoʊ, sʌmhaʊ, ən bɑn ɪm hɝz. ʃi wʊd. . . . laɪt! ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt ði ʌðɝz wəd stɛɹ ət hɝ, ʃi wʊɾə peɪs ðə soʊlz aʊɾ ə hɝ slɪpɝz!

So there they all were, closeted in their apartments with Thom and Juilin, anxious as caged cats, while everyone else in Ebou Dar made merry. Well, she was, anyway. What could be keeping Birgitte? How long did it take to tell a man to present himself first thing in the morning? Light, the whole effort was useless, and it was long past time for bed. Long past. If she could only sleep, she could put away memories of the morning's horrible journeys by boat. Worst of all, her weather sense told her a storm was on the way, told her the wind should be howling outside and the rain sheeting down so thick no one could see ten feet. It had taken her some time to understand about the times she Listened to the Wind and seemed to hear lies. At least, she thought she understood. Another kind of storm was coming, not wind or rain. She had no proof, but she would eat her slippers if Mat Cauthon was not part of it somehow. She wanted to sleep for a month, a year, to forget worries until Lan wakened her with a kiss like the Sun King with Talia. Which was ridiculous, of course; that was only a story, and a very improper one at that, and anyway, she was not about to become any man's pet, not even Lan's. She would find him, though, somehow, and bond him hers. She would. . . . Light! If she had not thought the others would stare at her, she would have paced the soles out of her slippers!

ði aʊɝz wɔɹ ɑn. ʃi ɹɛɾ ən ɹeɪ-ɹɛd ðə ʃɔɹt lɛɾɝ mæt hæd lɛft wɪð taɪlɪn. eɪvinhə sæt kwaɪətli bɪsaɪɾ əɹ haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ, kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə peɪl ɡɹin flɔɹ taɪlz əz juʒəwəl, ən ɔɹnətli ɡɪldɪd lɛðɝ-baʊn kɑpi ʌv ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ oʊpən ɑn əɹ niz. noʊ æŋzaɪəɾi ðɛɹ, nɑt tə si, bʌt ðən ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt tɝn ə hɛɹ ɪf sʌmwʌn stʌft ə vaɪpɝ daʊn əɹ dʒɹɛs. sɪns ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə pæləs ʃi hæd dɑn ði ɪntʃɹəkət sɪlvɝ nɛkləs ʃi wɔɹ nɪɹli deɪ ən naɪt. ɪksɛpt ɑn ðə boʊt tʃɹɪp; ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk ɪt, ðɛn. aɪdli, nɪneɪiv wʌndɝd waɪ ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ əɹ aɪvɝi bɹeɪslət. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən oʊvɝhɝd kɑnvɝseɪʃən, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɪɾ əntɪl ɪleɪn hæɾ ɪts laɪk, wɪtʃ meɪd lɪɾəl sɛns. ən mæɾɝd əz lɪɾəl əz ðə bɹeɪslət, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə lɛɾɝ kɔl fɹəm əɹ læp. ðə sɪɾɪŋ-ɹum stænd-læmps meɪd ɹiɾɪŋ izi, ðoʊ mæts ənfɔɹmd, bɔɪɪʃ hæn dɪd pɹɛzən dɪfəkəltiz. ɪt wɑz ðə kɑntɛns ðət klɛntʃt nɪneɪivz mɪɾəl ɪndə nɑts.

The hours wore on. She read and re-read the short letter Mat had left with Tylin. Aviendha sat quietly beside her high-backed chair, cross-legged on the pale green floor tiles as usual, an ornately gilded leather-bound copy of The Travels of Jain Farstrider open on her knees. No anxiety there, not to see, but then the woman would not turn a hair if someone stuffed a viper down her dress. Since returning to the palace she had donned the intricate silver necklace she wore nearly day and night. Except on the boat trip; she had said she did not want to risk it, then. Idly, Nynaeve wondered why she no longer wore her ivory bracelet. There had been an overheard conversation, something about not wearing it until Elayne had its like, which made little sense. And mattered as little as the bracelet, of course. The letter called from her lap. The sitting-room stand-lamps made reading easy, though Mat's unformed, boyish hand did present difficulties. It was the contents that clenched Nynaeve's middle into knots.

ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ hɪɹ bʌt hiɾ ən flaɪz, ən wi kən faɪn plɛnti ʌv ðoʊz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn.

There's nothing here but heat and flies, and we can find plenty of those in Caemlyn.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə dɪdn tɛl ɪm ɛniθɪŋ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"Are you sure you didn't tell him anything?" she demanded.

əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, dʒulɪn pɔzd wɪð ɪz hæn oʊvɝ ðə stoʊnz bɔɹd, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə lʊk ʌv aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd ɪnəsəns. "haʊ ɔfən mʌst aɪ seɪ soʊ?" aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd ɪnəsəns wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz mɛn dɪd bɛst, ɪspɛʃli wən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɪlti əz fɑksəz ɪn ðə hɛnjɑɹd. ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ðət ðə kɑɹvɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə bɔɹdz ɹɪm wɑz ə fɑksəz.

Across the room, Juilin paused with his hand over the stones board, giving her a look of outraged innocence. "How often must I say so?" Outraged innocence was one of the things men did best, especially when they were guilty as foxes in the henyard. Interesting that the carving around the board's rim was of foxes.

tɑm, siɾəd əkɹɔs ðə læpəs-ɪnleɪd teɪbəl fɹəm ðə θif-kætʃɝ, lʊkt əz lɪɾəl ðə ɡlimən ɪn ɪz faɪnli kʌt koʊɾ ə bɹɑnz wʊl, əz i dɪd ðə mæn u hæd wʌns bɪn kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz lʌvɝ. nɑɹld ən waɪt-hɛɹd, wɪð lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən θɪk aɪbɹaʊz, hi wɑz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd peɪʃəns fɹəm ɪz ʃɑɹp blu aɪz tə hɪz but soʊlz. "aɪ kæn si haʊ wi kəd hæv, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ɡɪvən ðət jə toʊld əs nɛks tə nʌθɪŋ əntɪl tənaɪt. jə ʃʊɾə sɛn dʒulɪn ən mi."

Thom, seated across the lapis-inlaid table from the thief-catcher, looked as little the gleeman in his finely cut coat of bronze wool, as he did the man who had once been Queen Morgase's lover. Gnarled and white-haired, with long mustaches and thick eyebrows, he was frustrated patience from his sharp blue eyes to his boot soles. "I can't see how we could have, Nynaeve," he said dryly, "given that you told us next to nothing until tonight. You should have sent Juilin and me."

nɪneɪiv snɪf laʊdli. əz ɪf ðoʊz tu hæd nɑt bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ ɝaʊn laɪk tʃɪkənz wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz ɔf ɛvɝ sɪns ðeɪ ɝaɪvd, pɹaɪɪŋ ɪndə hɝ ən ɪleɪnz əfɛɹz ɑn mæts seɪ-soʊ. ðoʊz θɹi kəd nɑt bi təɡɛðɝ tu mɪnəts wɪθaʊt ɡɑsəpɪŋ, iðɝ. mɛn nɛvɝ kʊd. ðeɪ. . . . ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt wɑz, ʃi ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, juzɪŋ ðə mɛn hæd nɛvɝ əkɝd tə ðɛm. "juɾ əv ɡɔn ɔf kəɹaʊzəŋ ən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɪð hɪm," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "doʊn tɛl mi jə wəd nɑt." ðət mʌs bi wɛɹ mæt wɑz, livɪŋ bɝdʒɪt tə kul əɹ fiɾ ət ði ɪn. ðət mæn wəd faɪn səm weɪ tə sɛt ðə hoʊl skim ɝaɪ.

Nynaeve sniffed loudly. As if those two had not been running around like chickens with their heads off ever since they arrived, prying into her and Elayne's affairs on Mat's say-so. Those three could not be together two minutes without gossiping, either. Men never could. They. . . . The truth of it was, she admitted reluctantly, using the men had never occurred to them. "You'd have gone off carousing and drinking with him," she muttered. "Don't tell me you would not." That must be where Mat was, leaving Birgitte to cool her feet at the inn. That man would find some way to set the whole scheme awry.

"ænd wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd?" linɪŋ bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz, piɹɪŋ aʊɾ ət ðə naɪt θɹu ðə waɪt-peɪntəɾ aɪɝn bælkəni, ɪleɪn ɡɪɡəld. ʃi wɑz tæpɪŋ əɹ fʊt, ðoʊ haʊ ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt wʌn tun fɹəm ɔl ðoʊz floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz ə wʌndɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz ə naɪt fəɹ . . . kəɹaʊzəŋ."

"And what if they had?" Leaning beside one of the tall arched windows, peering out at the night through the white-painted iron balcony, Elayne giggled. She was tapping her foot, though how she could make out one tune from all those floating in the darkness was a wonder. "It is a night for . . . carousing."

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ bæk. ɪleɪn hæd bɪn ɪnkɹisɪŋli pəkjuljɝ ɔl naɪt. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn bɛɾɝ, ʃi wʊɾə səspɛktəd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd bɪn snikɪŋ aʊt tə snætʃ sɪps ʌv waɪn. ɡʌlps ʌv ɪt, æktʃəli . ivən ɪf ɪleɪn hæd nɑt bɪn ʌndɝ əɹ aɪ, ðoʊ, ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. itʃ ə ðɛm hæd hæɾ ə ɹæðɝ ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð tu mʌtʃ waɪn, ən niðɝ hæɾ əɡɛn lɛt hɝsɛlf əv mɔɹ ðən ə sɪŋɡəl kʌp əɾ ə taɪm.

Nynaeve frowned at her back. Elayne had been increasingly peculiar all night. If she had not known better, she would have suspected the other woman had been sneaking out to snatch sips of wine. Gulps of it, actually. Even if Elayne had not been under her eye, though, that was impossible. Each of them had had a rather unfortunate experience with too much wine, and neither had again let herself have more than a single cup at a time.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn u ɪntʃɹəsts mi," eɪvinhə sɛd, kloʊzɪŋ ðə bʊk ən sɛɾɪŋ ɪt bɪsaɪd hɝ. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə kənsɪɾɝ haʊ ɑd ʃi lʊkt, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn ə blu sɪlk dʒɹɛs. "əmʌŋ ʌs, ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝz ɑɹ kɪld əz sun əz faʊnd, ən nɑt klæn, sɛpt, səsaɪəɾi əɹ fɝst-sɪstɝ wɪl ɹeɪz ə hæn ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst. ɪf dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn ɪz ə ʃædoʊ-ɹʌnɝ, waɪ dʌz taɪlɪn mɪtsoʊbɑɹ nɑt kɪl hɪm? waɪ də wi nɑt?"

"It is Jaichim Carridin who interests me," Aviendha said, closing the book and setting it beside her. She refused to consider how odd she looked, sitting on the floor in a blue silk dress. "Among us, Shadowrunners are killed as soon as found, and not clan, sept, society or first-sister will raise a hand in protest. If Jaichim Carridin is a Shadow-runner, why does Tylin Mitsobar not kill him? Why do we not?"

"mæɾɝz ɑɹ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ kɑmplɛks hɪɹ," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd wʌndɝd ðə seɪm. nɑt waɪ kæɹaɪɾɪn wɑz nɑt kɪld, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt waɪ hi wɑz stɪl əlaʊd tə kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz i wɪʃt. ʃi hæd sin ɪm ɪn ðə pæləs ðət vɛɹi deɪ, æftɝ ʃi hæd bɪn hændəd mæts lɛɾɝ, æftɝ ʃi hæd toʊl taɪlɪn wʌɾ ɪt kənteɪnd. hi hæd spoʊkən wɪð taɪlɪn əbʌv ən aʊɝ ən dɪpɑɹɾəd wɪð əz mʌtʃ ɑnɝ əz wən i ɝaɪvd. ʃi hæd mɛn tə dɪskʌs ɪt wɪð ɪleɪn, bʌt ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv wʌt mæt nu, ən haʊ, kɛpt ɪntʃɹuɾɪŋ. ðət mæn wəd meɪk tʃɹʌbəl. hi wʊd, sʌmhaʊ. ðɪs bɪznəs wɑz gɑnə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɛniwʌn sɛd. bæd wɛðɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ.

"Matters are a little more complex here," Nynaeve told her, though she had wondered the same. Not why Carridin was not killed, of course, but why he was still allowed to come and go as he wished. She had seen him in the palace that very day, after she had been handed Mat's letter, after she had told Tylin what it contained. He had spoken with Tylin above an hour and departed with as much honor as when he arrived. She had meant to discuss it with Elayne, but the question of what Mat knew, and how, kept intruding. That man would make trouble. He would, somehow. This business was going to go wrong no matter what anyone said. Bad weather was coming.

tɑm klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "taɪlɪn ɪz ə wik kwin, ən kæɹaɪɾɪn ði æmbæsəɾɝ ʌv ə paʊɝ." pleɪsɪŋ ə stoʊn, hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə bɔɹd. hi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ hi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əlaʊd. "baɪ dɛfənɪʃən, ə waɪtkloʊk ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ kænɑt bi ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd; ət list, ðæts haʊ ɪts dɪfaɪn ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt. ɪf ʃi ɝɛsts hɪm, əɹ ivən tʃɑɹdʒəz hɪm, ʃɪl faɪn ə waɪtkloʊk lidʒən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kən blɪŋk. ðeɪ maɪt liv əɹ ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt ʃid bi ə pʌpət fɹəm ðən ɑn, stʃɹɪŋz pʊl fɹəm ðə doʊm ə tʃɹuθ. ɑɹən jə ɹɛɾi tə kənsid jɛt, dʒulɪn?" ðə θif-kætʃɝ ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ðən bɛn tə ə fjʊɹiəs stʌɾi ʌv ðə bɔɹd.

Thom cleared his throat. "Tylin is a weak queen, and Carridin the ambassador of a power." Placing a stone, he kept his eyes on the board. He sounded as though he was thinking aloud. "By definition, a Whitecloak Inquisitor cannot be a Darkfriend; at least, that's how it is defined in the Fortress of the Light. If she arrests him, or even charges him, she'll find a Whitecloak legion in Ebou Dar before she can blink. They might leave her the throne, but she'd be a puppet from then on, strings pulled from the Dome of Truth. Aren't you ready to concede yet, Juilin?" The thief-catcher glared at him, then bent to a furious study of the board.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əɹ ə kaʊɝd," eɪvinhə sɛd dɪsɡʌstɪdli, ən tɑm ɡeɪv əɹ ən əmjuz smaɪl.

"I did not think her a coward," Aviendha said disgustedly, and Thom gave her an amused smile.

"ju hæv nɛvɝ feɪst sʌmθɪŋ jə kəd nɑt faɪt, tʃaɪld," hi sɛd dʒɛnli, "sʌmθɪŋ soʊ stʃɹɔŋ jəɹ oʊnli tʃɔɪs ɪz tə fli əɹ bi kənsumd əlaɪv. tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊl dʒʌdʒmən ɑn taɪlɪn tɪl jə hæv." fəɹ səm ɹizən, eɪvinhəz feɪs ɹɛɾənd. nɔɹməli, ʃi hɪɾ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz soʊ wɛl əɹ feɪs wɑz laɪk stoʊn. "aɪ noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. "wil faɪn pɹuf ivən peɪdʒɹən naɪl mʌst æksɛpt." ʃi skɪp bæk ɪndə ðə ɹum. noʊ, ʃi dænst. "wi wɪl dɪsɡaɪz aʊɝsɛlvz ən fɑloʊ hɪm."

"You have never faced something you could not fight, child," he said gently, "something so strong your only choice is to flee or be consumed alive. Try to hold judgment on Tylin till you have." For some reason, Aviendha's face reddened. Normally, she hid her emotions so well her face was like stone. "I know," Elayne said suddenly. "We'll find proof even Pedron Niall must accept." She skipped back into the room. No, she danced. "We will disguise ourselves and follow him."

sʌɾənli, ɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪleɪn stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ə ɡɹin ɛbu dɑɹi ɡaʊn, bʌɾ ə dəmɑni wʊmən ɪn θɪn klɪŋɪŋ blu. nɪneɪiv lɛpt ʌp bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp, ən əɹ maʊθ taɪɾənd wɪð ɛksæspɝeɪʃən ət hɝsɛlf. dʒʌs kəz ʃi kəd nɑt si ðə wivz ət ðə moʊmənt wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə bi stɑɹɾəld baɪ ɪluʒən. ʃi dɑɹɾɪd ə ɡlæns ət tɑm ən dʒulɪn. ivən tɑmz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən. ʌnkɑnʃəsli ʃi tʊk ə fɝm ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. ɪleɪn wɑz gɑnə ɹɪvil ɛvɹiθɪŋ! wʌt wɑz ðə mæɾɝ wɪð hɝ?

Suddenly, it was no longer Elayne standing there in a green Ebou Dari gown, but a Domani woman in thin clinging blue. Nynaeve leaped up before she could stop, and her mouth tightened with exasperation at herself. Just because she could not see the weaves at the moment was no reason to be startled by Illusion. She darted a glance at Thom and Juilin. Even Thom's mouth hung open. Unconsciously she took a firm grip on her braid. Elayne was going to reveal everything! What was the matter with her?

ɪluʒən wɝk bɛs ðə kloʊsɝ jə steɪd tə wʌt wɑz ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ, ɪn ʃeɪp ən saɪz ət list, soʊ bɪts ə ði ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs flæʃt θɹu ðə dəmɑni ɡɑɹmən əz ɪleɪn wɝl tə ɪɡzæmɪn hɝsɛlf ɪn wʌn ə ðə ɹumz tu lɑɹdʒ mɪɹɝz. ʃi læft ən klæpt əɹ hænz. "oʊ, hɪl nɛvɝ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi. əɹ ju, nɪɹ-sɪstɝ." əbɹʌpli ə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən sæt bɪsaɪd nɪneɪivz tʃɛɹ, wɪð bɹaʊn aɪz ən jɛloʊ bɹeɪdz stʃɹʌŋ wɪð ɹɛd bidz dʒʌs ðə ʃeɪɾ ə hɝ snʌɡ-fɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ə foʊldəd sɪlk. ʃi wɑtʃt ɪleɪn kwɪtsɪkli. nɪneɪivz hæn taɪɾənd ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. "ænd wi kæn fɝɡɛt ju," ɪleɪn bæbəld ɑn. "aɪ noʊ dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ."

Illusion worked best the closer you stayed to what was there before, in shape and size at least, so bits of the Ebou Dari dress flashed through the Domani garment as Elayne whirled to examine herself in one of the room's two large mirrors. She laughed and clapped her hands. "Oh, he will never recognize me. Or you, near-sister." Abruptly a Taraboner woman sat beside Nynaeve's chair, with brown eyes and yellow braids strung with red beads just the shade of her snug-fitting dress of folded silk. She watched Elayne quizzically. Nynaeve's hand tightened on her braid. "And we can't forget you," Elayne babbled on. "I know just the thing."

ðɪs taɪm, nɪneɪiv sɔ ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn ɪleɪn. ʃi wɑz fjʊɹiəs. siɪŋ ðə floʊz biɪŋ woʊvən əbaʊt hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑt tɛl əɹ wʌɾ ɪmədʒ ɪleɪn ɡeɪv hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪt tʊk lʊkɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə mɪɹɝz tə də ðæt. eɪ si foʊk wʊmən stɛɹd bæk ət hɝ, əɡæst, wɪð ə dʌzən beɪɡɛmd ɹɪŋz ɪn əɹ ɪɹz ən twaɪs əz mɛni ɡoʊldən mədæljənz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃeɪn ɹʌnɪŋ tə hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋ. əsaɪd fɹəm ðə dʒuəlɹi, ʃi wɔɹ waɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz ə bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɡɹin sɪlk ən nɑɾ ə stɪtʃ ɛls, ðə weɪ wɪmən ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ dɪɾ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə lænd. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ɪluʒən. ʃi wɑz stɪl disənli kloʊðd ʌndɝ ðə wivɪŋ. bʌt. . . . bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɹəflɛkʃən ʃi sɔ ðoʊz ə tɑm ən dʒulɪn, boʊθ faɪɾɪŋ ɡɹɪnz.

This time, Nynaeve saw the glow around Elayne. She was furious. Seeing the flows being woven about herself did not tell her what image Elayne gave her, of course. It took looking into one of the mirrors to do that. A Sea Folk woman stared back at her, aghast, with a dozen begemmed rings in her ears and twice as many golden medallions dangling from the chain running to her nose ring. Aside from the jewelry, she wore wide trousers of brocaded green silk and not a stitch else, the way women of the Atha'an Miere did out of sight of land. It was just Illusion. She was still decently clothed under the weaving. But. . . . Beside her reflection she saw those of Thom and Juilin, both fighting grins.

ə stʃɹæŋɡəl skwɔk ɪɹʌptəd fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt. "kloʊs jəɹ aɪz!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə mɛn ən bɪɡæn lipɪŋ əbaʊt, weɪvɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz, ɛniθɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ dʒɹɛs ʃoʊ θɹu. "kloʊs ðɛm, bɝn ju!" oʊ. ðeɪ hæd. bɹɪsəlɪŋ wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, ʃi stɑp keɪpɝɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt faɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz ɡɹɪnz ɛnimɔɹ, ðoʊ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, eɪvinhə wɑz læfɪŋ kwaɪɾ oʊpənli, ɹɑkɪŋ tə ən fɹoʊ.

A strangled squawk erupted from her throat. "Close your eyes!" she shouted at the men and began leaping about, waving her arms, anything to make her dress show through. "Close them, burn you!" Oh. They had. Bristling with indignation, she stopped capering. They were not fighting those grins anymore, though. For that matter, Aviendha was laughing quite openly, rocking to and fro.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ skɝts ə dʒɝk - ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ, ðə si foʊk wʊmən sim tə plʌk əɾ əɹ tʃɹaʊzɝz - ən fɪkst ɪleɪn wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ. "stɑp ðɪs, ɪleɪn!" ðə dəmɑni wʊmən stɛɹd bæk, maʊθ oʊpən ən aɪz waɪd wɪð ɪnkɹədulɪɾi. oʊnli ðən dɪd nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz haʊ æŋɡɹi ʃi wɑz; ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs bɛkən fɹəm dʒʌs bɪɑn ði ɛdʒ ə saɪt. ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ʃi slæmd ə ʃil bɪtwin ɪleɪn ən ðə sɔɹs. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə. ʃildɪŋ sʌmwʌn u ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl ðə paʊɝ wɑz nɑɾ izi ivən wən jə wɝ ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ. wʌns, əz ə ɡɝl, ʃi hæd swʌŋ mæstɝ luhənz hæmɝ əɡɛnst ɪz ænvəl əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd, ən ðə ʃɪvɝ ʌv ɪt ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ tə hɝ toʊz. ðɪs wɑz əbaʊt twaɪs ðæt. "lʌv ə ðə laɪt, ɪleɪn, ɑɹ jə dʒɹʌŋk?"

Nynaeve gave her skirts a jerk - in the mirror, the Sea Folk woman seemed to pluck at her trousers - and fixed Elayne with a glare. "Stop this, Elayne!" The Domani woman stared back, mouth open and eyes wide with incredulity. Only then did Nynaeve realize how angry she was; the True Source beckoned from just beyond the edge of sight. Embracing saidar, she slammed a shield between Elayne and the Source. Or rather, she tried to. Shielding someone who already held the Power was not easy even when you were the stronger. Once, as a girl, she had swung Master Luhhan's hammer against his anvil as hard as she could, and the shiver of it ran all the way to her toes. This was about twice that. "Love of the Light, Elayne, are you drunk?"

ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn ðə dəmɑni wʊmən feɪɾəd əweɪ, ən soʊ dɪd ðə dəmɑni wʊmən. nɪneɪiv nu ðə wiv wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, bʌt ʃi stɪl ɡlænst ət ðə mɪɹɝ ən dʒɹu ə ɹɪliv bɹɛθ tə si nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə ðəɹ ɪn jɛloʊ-slæʃt blu.

The glow around the Domani woman faded away, and so did the Domani woman. Nynaeve knew the weave was gone from around herself, but she still glanced at the mirror and drew a relieved breath to see Nynaeve al'Meara there in yellow-slashed blue.

"noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd sloʊli. kʌlɝ bɝn ɪn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, əɹ nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli. hɝ tʃɪn ɹoʊz, ən əɹ vɔɪs fɹɔstəd. "aɪ æm nɑt."

"No," Elayne said slowly. Color burned in her face, but it was not embarrassment, or not entirely. Her chin rose, and her voice frosted. "I am not."

ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ bæŋd oʊpən, ən bɝdʒɪt stæɡɝɾ ɪn wɪð ə bɹɔd smaɪl. wɛl, pɝhæps ʃi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt stæɡɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ənstɛɾi. "aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk jə ɔl tə ɹɪmeɪn əweɪk fəɹ mi," ʃi sɛd bɹaɪtli. "wɛl, jəl bi ɪntʃɹəstəd tə hɪɹ wʌɾ aɪ hæv tə seɪ. bʌt fɝst. . . ."

The door to the corridor banged open, and Birgitte staggered in with a broad smile. Well, perhaps she did not quite stagger, but she was decidedly unsteady. "I did not expect you all to remain awake for me," she said brightly. "Well, you'll be interested to hear what I have to say. But first. . . ."

wɪð ðə tu stɛɾi stɛps ə sʌmwʌn kæɹiɪŋ kənsɪɾɝəbəl dʒɹɪŋk ɪnsaɪd, ʃi vænɪʃt ɪndə hɝ ɹum.

With the too steady steps of someone carrying considerable drink inside, she vanished into her room.

tɑm stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ dɔɹ wɪð ə bɪmjuzd ɡɹɪn, dʒulɪn wɪð ən ɪnkɹɛdʒələs wʌn. ðeɪ nu hu ʃi wɑz, ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt. ɪleɪn dʒʌst ɡlɛɹd daʊn əɹ noʊz. fɹəm bɝdʒɪts bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ keɪm ə splæʃɪŋ, əz ɪf ə pɪtʃɝ hæd bɪn ʌpɛndəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. nɪneɪiv ɪkstʃeɪnʒd pʌzəld lʊks wɪð eɪvinhə.

Thom stared at her door with a bemused grin, Juilin with an incredulous one. They knew who she was, the truth of it. Elayne just glared down her nose. From Birgitte's bedchamber came a splashing, as if a pitcher had been upended on the floor. Nynaeve exchanged puzzled looks with Aviendha.

bɝdʒɪt ɹiəpɪɹd wɪð əɹ feɪs ən hɛɹ dʒɹɪpɪŋ ən əɹ koʊt soʊk fɹəm ʃoʊldɝz tə ɛlboʊz. "naʊ maɪ wɪts ɑɹ klɪɹɝ," ʃi sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə bɔl-fʊɾɪd tʃɛɹz wɪð ə saɪ. "ðæt jʌŋ mæn əz ə hɑloʊ lɛɡ ən ə hoʊl ɪn ðə bɑɾəm ə hɪz fʊt. hi ivən aʊt-dʒɹæŋk bɛslən, ən aɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk waɪn wɑz wɔɾɝ tə ðət læd."

Birgitte reappeared with her face and hair dripping and her coat soaked from shoulders to elbows. "Now my wits are clearer," she said, settling into one of the ball-footed chairs with a sigh. "That young man has a hollow leg and a hole in the bottom of his foot. He even out-drank Beslan, and I was beginning to think wine was water to that lad."

"bɛslən?" nɪneɪiv sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs ɹaɪzɪŋ. "taɪlɪnz sʌn? wʌt wɑz i duɪŋ ðɛɹ?"

"Beslan?" Nynaeve said, her voice rising. "Tylin's son? What was he doing there?"

"waɪ dɪd jə əlaʊ ɪt, bɝdʒɪt?" ɪleɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "mæt kɔθən wɪl kɝʌp ðə bɔɪ, ən ɪz mʌðɝ wɪl bleɪm ʌs."

"Why did you allow it, Birgitte?" Elayne exclaimed. "Mat Cauthon will corrupt the boy, and his mother will blame us."

"ðə bɔɪ ɪz ðə seɪm eɪdʒ əz ju," tɑm toʊld əɹ ɪn stʌfi toʊnz.

"The boy is the same age as you," Thom told her in stuffy tones.

ə bæfəld lʊk pæs bɪtwin nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. wʌt wɑz ɪz pɔɪnt? ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðəɾ ə mæn dɪd nɑɾ ətʃiv ɪz pɹɑpɝ wɪts, sətʃ əz ðeɪ wɝ, əntɪl tɛn jɪɹz leɪɾɝ ðən ə wʊmən.

A baffled look passed between Nynaeve and Elayne. What was his point? Everyone knew that a man did not achieve his proper wits, such as they were, until ten years later than a woman.

ðə pʌzəlmən feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪleɪnz feɪs, ɹipleɪs baɪ fɝmnəs ən noʊ lɪɾəl æŋɡɝ əz ʃi foʊkəst ɑn bɝdʒɪɾ əɡɛn. wɝdz wɝ gɑnə bi sɛd, wɝdz boʊθ wɪmən maɪt ɹəɡɹɛt təmɑɹoʊ.

The puzzlement faded from Elayne's face, replaced by firmness and no little anger as she focused on Birgitte again. Words were going to be said, words both women might regret tomorrow.

"ɪf jə ən dʒulɪn wɪl liv əs naʊ, tɑm," nɪneɪiv sɛd kwɪkli. ɪt wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli ənlaɪkli ðeɪ wəd si ðə niɾ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn. "ju nid jəɹ slip tə bi fɹɛʃ fɝs θɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ." ðeɪ sæt ðɛɹ, ɡeɪpɪŋ əɾ əɹ laɪk bɛl fulz, soʊ ʃi meɪɾ əɹ toʊn fɝmɝ. "naʊ?"

"If you and Juilin will leave us now, Thom," Nynaeve said quickly. It was extremely unlikely they would see the need on their own. "You need your sleep to be fresh first thing in the morning." They sat there, gaping at her like belled fools, so she made her tone firmer. "Now?"

"ðɪs ɡeɪm wɑz dʌn twɛnti stoʊnz əɡoʊ," tɑm sɛd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə bɔɹd. "wʌt dʒju seɪ wi ɡoʊ daʊn tə əɹ oʊn ɹum ən stɑɹɾ ənʌðɝ? əl spɑt jə tɛn stoʊnz tə pleɪs əz jəl ɛni taɪm dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm."

"This game was done twenty stones ago," Thom said, glancing at the board. "What do you say we go down to our own room and start another? I'll spot you ten stones to place as you will any time during the game."

"tɛn stoʊnz?" dʒulɪn jɛlpt, skɹeɪpɪŋ bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ. "wɪl jə ɔfɝ mi fɪʃ bɹɔθ ən mɪlk-bɹɛd, əz wɛl?"

"Ten stones?" Juilin yelped, scraping back his chair. "Will you offer me fish broth and milk-bread, as well?"

ðeɪ ɑɹɡjuɾ ɔl ðə weɪ aʊt, bʌɾ ət ðə dɔɹ, itʃ ə ðɛm ɡlæns bæk ɪn sʌlən ɹɪzɛnmənt. ʃi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst əm tə ɹɪmeɪn əweɪk ɔl naɪt dʒʌs kəz ʃi hæd sɛn əm tə bɛd.

They argued all the way out, but at the door, each of them glanced back in sullen resentment. She would not put it past them to remain awake all night just because she had sent them to bed.

"mæt woʊn kɝʌp bɛslən," bɝdʒɪt sɛd dʒɹaɪli əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə mɛn. "aɪ daʊt naɪn fɛðɝ dænsɝz wɪð ə ʃɪploʊɾ ə bɹændi kəd kɝʌp hɪm. ðeɪ wʊdnt noʊ wɛɹ tə bɪɡɪn."

"Mat won't corrupt Beslan," Birgitte said dryly as the door closed behind the men. "I doubt nine feather dancers with a shipload of brandy could corrupt him. They wouldn't know where to begin."

nɪneɪiv wɑz ɹɪliv tə hɪɹ ɪt, ðoʊ sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɑɾ əbaʊt ðə wʊmənz toʊn - laɪkli ðə dʒɹɪŋk - bʌt bɛslən wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ði ɪʃu. ʃi sɛd soʊ, ən ɪleɪn æɾəd, "noʊ, hi ɪzənt. jə ɡɑt dʒɹʌŋk, bɝdʒɪt! ən aɪ fɛlt ɪt. aɪ stɪl fil tɪpsi ɪf aɪ doʊn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt. ðə bɑn ɪz nɑt səpoʊz tə wɝk ðət weɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ doʊn fɔl oʊvɝ ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ɪf ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz dʒɹɪŋk tu mʌtʃ." nɪneɪiv θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz.

Nynaeve was relieved to hear it, though something was odd about the woman's tone - likely the drink - but Beslan was not at all the issue. She said so, and Elayne added, "No, he isn't. You got drunk, Birgitte! And I felt it. I still feel tipsy if I don't concentrate. The bond is not supposed to work that way. Aes Sedai don't fall over giggling if their Warders drink too much." Nynaeve threw up her hands.

"doʊn lʊk ət mi ðət weɪ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd. "ju noʊ mɔɹ ðən aɪ du. ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz əv ɔlweɪz bɪn mɛn ən wɪmən bɪfɔɹ. meɪbi ðæts ðə dɪfɝəns. meɪbi wəɹ tu əlaɪk." hɝ ɡɹɪn wɑz skjud slaɪtli. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn nɪɹ ɪnʌf wɔɾɝ ɪn ðət pɪtʃɝ. "ðæt maɪt bi ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz."

"Don't look at me that way," Birgitte said. "You know more than I do. Aes Sedai and Warders have always been men and women before. Maybe that's the difference. Maybe we are too alike." Her grin was skewed slightly. There had not been near enough water in that pitcher. "That might be embarrassing, I suppose."

"ɪf wi kəd steɪ wɪð wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt?" nɪneɪiv sɛd taɪtli. "sʌtʃ əz mæt?" ɪleɪn hæɾ əɹ maʊθ oʊpən fəɹ ə ɹitɔɹt tə bɝdʒɪt, bʌt ʃi kloʊzd ɪt kwɪkli, ðə ɹɛd spɑts ɪn əɹ tʃiks moʊs dɛfənətli ʃəɡɹɪn ðɪs taɪm. "naʊ," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn. "wɪl mæt bi hɪɹ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əɹ ɪz i ɪn ðə seɪm ɹivoʊltɪŋ steɪɾ əz ju?"

"If we could stay with what is important?" Nynaeve said tightly. "Such as Mat?" Elayne had her mouth open for a retort to Birgitte, but she closed it quickly, the red spots in her cheeks most definitely chagrin this time. "Now," Nynaeve went on. "Will Mat be here in the morning, or is he in the same revolting state as you?"

"hi maɪt kʌm," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə kʌp ə mɪn ti fɹəm eɪvinhə, hu ʌv kɔɹs sæt daʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪleɪn fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ ə moʊmənt, ðɛn, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, foʊldəɾ ʌp əɹ lɛɡz ən sæt bɪsaɪd hɝ!

"He might come," Birgitte said, taking a cup of mint tea from Aviendha, who of course sat down on the floor. Elayne frowned at her a moment, then, of all things, folded up her legs and sat beside her!

"wʌt dʒju min, hi maɪt?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. ʃi tʃænəld, ən ðə tʃɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɪn floʊɾəd oʊvɝ tə hɝ, ən ɪf ɪt bæŋ tə ðə flɔɹ, ʃi mɛn ɪt tə. dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ tu mʌtʃ, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. wʌt wɑz nɛkst? "ɪf i ɪkspɛks əs tə kʌm tə hɪm ɑn hænz ən niz . . . !"

"What do you mean, he might?" Nynaeve demanded. She channeled, and the chair she had been sitting in floated over to her, and if it banged to the floor, she meant it to. Drinking too much, sitting on the floor. What was next? "If he expects us to come to him on hands and knees . . . !"

bɝdʒɪt tʊk ə sɪp ə ðə ti wɪð ə ɡɹeɪtfəl mɝmɝ, ən ɑdli, wən ʃi lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv əɡɛn, ʃi dɪd nɑt sim soʊ ɪntɑksəkeɪɾəd. "aɪ tɔkt ɪm aʊɾ ə ðæt. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i wɑz ɹɪli sɪɹiəs. ɔl i wɑns naʊ ɪz ən əpɑlədʒi ən θæŋks."

Birgitte took a sip of the tea with a grateful murmur, and oddly, when she looked at Nynaeve again, she did not seem so intoxicated. "I talked him out of that. I don't think he was really serious. All he wants now is an apology and thanks."

nɪneɪivz aɪz pɑpt. ʃi hæd tɔkt ɪm aʊɾ ə ðæt? əpɑlədʒaɪz? tə meɪtʃɹim kɔθən? "nɛvɝ," ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

Nynaeve's eyes popped. She had talked him out of that? Apologize? To Matrim Cauthon? "Never," she growled.

"fɔɹ wʌt?" ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə noʊ, əz ɪf ðət mæɾɝd. ʃi pɹitɛndəd nɑt tə si nɪneɪivz ɡlɛɹ.

"For what?" Elayne wanted to know, as if that mattered. She pretended not to see Nynaeve's glare.

"ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, ən nɪneɪivz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊnd. ðə wʊmən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ saʊndəɾ ɪntɑksəkeɪɾəd əɾ ɔl. "hi sɛz i wɛn ɪndə ðə stoʊn, hɪm ən dʒulɪn, tə fɹi ðə pɛɹ ə jə fɹəm ə dʌnʒən jə kʊdn ɪskeɪp ɑn jəɹ oʊn." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli, ɪn wʌndɝ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ wʊɾə dʌn ðət fəɹ ɛniwʌn ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɡeɪɾəl. nɑt ðə stoʊn. hi sɛz jə ɡeɪv ɪm ə bækhændəd θæŋks ən meɪɾ ɪm fil i ɔt tə bi ɡɹeɪtfəl jə dɪdn kɪk hɪm."

"The Stone of Tear," Birgitte said, and Nynaeve's head whipped around. The woman no longer sounded intoxicated at all. "He says he went into the Stone, him and Juilin, to free the pair of you from a dungeon you couldn't escape on your own." She shook her head slowly, in wonder. "I don't know that I would have done that for anyone short of Gaidal. Not the Stone. He says you gave him a backhanded thanks and made him feel he ought to be grateful you didn't kick him."

ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, ɪn ə weɪ, bʌɾ ɔl dɪstɔɹɾəd. ðəɹ mæt hæd bɪn wɪð ðət mɑkɪŋ ɡɹɪn ə hɪz, seɪɪŋ i wɑz ðəɹ tə pʊl ðɛɹ tʃɛsnəts ɔf ðə faɪɝ əɹ səm sʌtʃ. ivən ðən i hæd θɔɾ i kəd tɛl əm wʌt tə du. "oʊnli wʌn ə ðə blæk sɪstɝz wɑz ɑn ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ðə dʌnʒən," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd, "ænd wi hæd teɪkən kɛɹ ə hɝ." tʃɹu, ðeɪ hædn jɛt bɪn eɪbəl tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ʃildɪd. "bɛləl wɑzn ɹɪli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ʌs, ɛniweɪ - ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tə lʊɹ ɹænd. mɔɪɹeɪn meɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv kɪl hɪm, baɪ ðɛn, fəɹ ɔl wi noʊ."

It was true, in a way, but all distorted. There Mat had been with that mocking grin of his, saying he was there to pull their chestnuts off the fire or some such. Even then he had thought he could tell them what to do. "Only one of the Black sisters was on guard in the dungeon," Nynaeve muttered, "and we had taken care of her." True, they hadn't yet been able to figure out how to open the door, shielded. "Be'lal wasn't really interested in us, anyway - it was just to lure Rand. Moiraine may already have killed him, by then, for all we know."

"ðə blæk ədʒɑ." bɝdʒɪts vɔɪs wɑz flæɾɝ ðən ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. "ænd wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. mæt nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ðɛm. jə oʊ hɪm θæŋks ɑn jəɹ niz, ɪleɪn. boʊθ ə jə du. ðə mæn dɪzɝvz ɪt. ən dʒulɪn, əz wɛl."

"The Black Ajah." Birgitte's voice was flatter than the floor tiles. "And one of the Forsaken. Mat never mentioned them. You owe him thanks on your knees, Elayne. Both of you do. The man deserves it. And Juilin, as well."

blʌd ɹʌʃt tə nɪneɪivz feɪs. hi hæd nɛvɝ mɛnʃənd . . . ? ðət dɪspɪkəbəl, dɪspɪkəbəl mæn! "aɪ wɪl nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz tə meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, nɑɾ ɑn maɪ dɛθbɛd."

Blood rushed to Nynaeve's face. He had never mentioned . . . ? That despicable, despicable man! "I will not apologize to Matrim Cauthon, not on my deathbed."

eɪvinhə lin təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ ni. "nɪɹ-sɪstɝ, əl seɪ ðɪs dɛləkətli." ʃi lʊkt ən saʊndəɾ əbaʊɾ əz dɛləkəɾ əz ə stoʊn poʊst. "ɪf ðɪs ɪz tʃɹu, juv toʊ təwɔɹd mæt kɔθən, jə ən nɪneɪiv. ən juv meɪɾ ɪt wɝs sɪns, dʒʌs baɪ ði ækʃənz aɪ hæv sin."

Aviendha leaned toward Elayne, touching her knee. "Near-sister, I will say this delicately." She looked and sounded about as delicate as a stone post. "If this is true, you have toh toward Mat Cauthon, you and Nynaeve. And you have made it worse since, just by the actions I have seen."

"toʊ!" nɪneɪiv ɪkskleɪmd. ðoʊz tu wɝ ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs toʊ fulɝi. "wi ɑɹən il, eɪvinhə. ən mæt kɔθən ɪz ə θɔɹn ɪn ðə fʊt tə ɛvɹibɑɾi hi mits."

"Toh!" Nynaeve exclaimed. Those two were always talking about this toh foolery. "We aren't Aiel, Aviendha. And Mat Cauthon is a thorn in the foot to everybody he meets."

bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz nɑɾɪŋ. "aɪ si. jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt, eɪvinhə. bʌt wʌt mʌst wi du? jəl əv tə hɛlp mi, nɪɹ-sɪstɝ. aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə tʃɹaɪ tə bɪkʌm il, bʌɾ aɪ . . . aɪ wɑn jə tə bi pɹaʊɾ ə mi."

But Elayne was nodding. "I see. You are right, Aviendha. But what must we do? You will have to help me, near-sister. I don't intend to try to become Aiel, but I . . . I want you to be proud of me."

"wi wɪl nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz!" nɪneɪiv snæpt.

"We will not apologize!" Nynaeve snapped.

"aɪ hæv pɹaɪɾ ɪn noʊɪŋ ju," eɪvinhə sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ ɪleɪnz tʃik laɪtli. "æn əpɑlədʒi ɪz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, jɛt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə mit toʊ, naʊ."

"I have pride in knowing you," Aviendha said, touching Elayne's cheek lightly. "An apology is a beginning, yet not enough to meet toh, now."

"ɑɹ jə lɪsnɪŋ tə mi?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "aɪ sɛd, əl - nɑt - əpɑlədʒaɪz!"

"Are you listening to me?" Nynaeve demanded. "I said, I will - not - apologize!"

ðeɪ wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɔkɪŋ. oʊnli bɝdʒɪt lʊkt ət hɝ, ən ðə wʊmən wɔɹ ə smaɪl nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm aʊtʃɹaɪt læftɝ. nɪneɪiv θɹɑɾəld əɹ bɹeɪd wɪð boʊθ hænz. ʃi hæd noʊn ðət ðeɪ ʃʊɾə sɛn tɑm ən dʒulɪn.

They went right on talking. Only Birgitte looked at her, and the woman wore a smile not far from outright laughter. Nynaeve throttled her braid with both hands. She had known that they should have sent Thom and Juilin.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu


CHAPTER 22

smɔl sækɹəfaɪsɪz


Small Sacrifices

skwɪntɪŋ ʌp ət ðə saɪn əbʌv ði ɪnz ɑɹtʃt dɔɹ, ə kɹudli dʒɹɔn wʊmən wɪð ə wɔkɪŋ stæf piɹɪŋ hoʊpfəli ɪndə ðə dɪstəns, ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi wɝ bæk ɪn əɹ bɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ʌp wɪð ðə sʌn. nɑt ðət ʃi kəɾ əv slɛpt. mɔl hɛɹə skwɛɹ stʊɾ ɛmpti bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju kɹikɪŋ ɑks-æn dɑŋki-kɑɹts ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə mɑɹkəts, ə skæɾɝɪŋ ʌv wɪmən bælənsɪŋ hjudʒ bæskəts ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ə wʌn-lɛɡəd bɛɡɝ sæt wɪð ɪz boʊl əɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ə ði ɪn, ðə fɝst ə mɛni hu wəd dɑt ðə skwɛɹ leɪɾɝ; ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən ɪm ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk, ɪnʌf tə fiɾ ɪm fəɹ ə wik ivən naʊ, bʌɾ i tʌkt ɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɹæɡəd koʊt wɪð ə tuθləs ɡɹɪn ən weɪɾəd ɑn. ðə skaɪ wɑz stɪl ɡɹeɪ, jɛt ðə deɪ ɔlɹɛɾi pɹɑməs tə skɔɹk. kipɪŋ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən wɛl ɪnʌf tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə hit wɑz ə pɹɑbləm ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ.

Squinting up at the sign above the inn's arched door, a crudely drawn woman with a walking staff peering hopefully into the distance, Elayne wished she were back in her bed instead of up with the sun. Not that she could have slept. Mol Hara Square stood empty behind her except for a few creaking ox-and donkey-carts on their way to the markets, a scattering of women balancing huge baskets on their heads. A one-legged beggar sat with his bowl at a corner of the inn, the first of many who would dot the square later; she had already given him a silver mark, enough to feed him for a week even now, but he tucked it under his ragged coat with a toothless grin and waited on. The sky was still gray, yet the day already promised to scorch. Keeping concentration well enough to ignore the heat was a problem this morning.

ðə læst ɹɛmnəns ə bɝdʒɪts mɔɹnɪŋ-æftɝ hɛd ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ oʊn, dwɪndəlɪŋ bʌt nɑt jɛt ɡɔn. ɪf oʊnli hɝ smɔl əbɪləɾi wɪð hilɪŋ hæd nɑt pɹuv tu smɔl. ʃi hoʊpt eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt wəd mænədʒ tə lɝn sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl əbaʊt kæɹaɪɾɪn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ɪn ðɛɹ ɪluʒən dɪsɡaɪzɪz. nɑt ðət kæɹaɪɾɪn wəd noʊ ɛni ʌv əm fɹəm ə ʃumeɪkɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bi kɛɹfəl. ʃi fɛl pɹaɪd ðəɾ eɪvinhə hæd nɑɾ æsk tə kʌm əlɔŋ hɪɹ, hæɾ ɪn fæk bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən. eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt bɪliv ʃi niɾəd ɛniwʌn tə wɑtʃ hɝ, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd wʌt wɑz nidfəl.

The last remnants of Birgitte's morning-after head remained in the back of her own, dwindling but not yet gone. If only her small ability with Healing had not proved too small. She hoped Aviendha and Birgitte would manage to learn something useful about Carridin this morning, in their Illusion disguises. Not that Carridin would know any of them from a shoemaker, of course, but it was best to be careful. She felt pride that Aviendha had not asked to come along here, had in fact been surprised at the suggestion. Aviendha did not believe she needed anyone to watch her, to make sure she did what was needful.

wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ dʒɹɛs, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. blu ən kɹim, wɪð ə bɪɾ ə kɹim-kʌlɝd vændælɹə leɪs, ðə ɡɑɹmən dɪd meɪk əɹ fil dʒʌst ə tʌtʃ . . . ɪkspoʊzd. ði oʊnli taɪm ʃi hæd bɔkt ət dɑnɪŋ ə loʊkəl fæʃən wɑz waɪl ʃi ən nɪneɪiv tʃɹævəl tə tæntʃəkoʊ wɪð ðə si foʊk, bʌɾ ɪn ɪts oʊn weɪ, ɛbu dɑɹi fæʃən wɑz ɔlmoʊst. . . . ʃi saɪɾ əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪleɪ. eɪvinhə ʃʊɾə kʌm tə liɾ əɹ baɪ ðə hænd.

With a sigh, she straightened her dress, though there was no need. Blue and cream, with a bit of cream-colored Vandalra lace, the garment did make her feel just a touch . . . exposed. The only time she had balked at donning a local fashion was while she and Nynaeve traveled to Tanchico with the Sea Folk, but in its own way, Ebou Dari fashion was almost. . . . She sighed again. She was just trying to delay. Aviendha should have come to lead her by the hand.

"aɪ wɪl nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz," nɪneɪiv sɛd sʌɾənli əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi klʌtʃt əɹ oʊn ɡɹeɪ skɝts wɪð boʊθ hænz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən əz ðoʊ mɑɡiɾin hɝsɛlf weɪɾəd ɪnsaɪd. "aɪ woʊnt!"

"I will not apologize," Nynaeve said suddenly at her shoulder. She clutched her own gray skirts with both hands, staring at The Wandering Woman as though Moghedien herself waited inside. "I won't!"

"ju ʃʊɾə wɔɹn waɪɾ æftɝ ɔl," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd, ɝnɪŋ ə səspɪʃəs saɪdweɪz ɡlæns. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi æɾəd, "ju dɪd seɪ ɪt wɑz ðə kʌlɝ fəɹ fjunɝəlz." wɪtʃ pɹədust ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌt ʃi hæd mɛn əɾ ɔl. ðɪs wəd bi dɪzæstɝ ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt kip pis əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. bɝdʒɪt hæd hæd tə sɛɾəl fəɹ ən ɪnfjuʒən ə ɝbz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bɪɾɝ mɪks ət ðæt, kəz nɪneɪiv kleɪmd ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə tʃænəl. ʃi hæd ɡɔn ɑn ɪn ðə moʊs dʒɹəmæɾɪk mænɝ əbaʊt fjunɝəl waɪt biɪŋ ði oʊnli suɾəbəl kʌlɝ, ɪnsɪstəd ʃi wɑz nɑt kʌmɪŋ, əntɪl ɪleɪn dʒɹæɡd əɹ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ əpɑɹtməns, ən ənaʊnst ət lis twɛnti taɪmz sɪns ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz. pis hæd tə bi kɛpt, bʌt. . . . "ju əɡɹid tə ðɪs, nɪneɪiv. noʊ, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛni mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs bʊliɪŋ ju. jə əɡɹid. soʊ stɑp sʌlkɪŋ."

"You should have worn white after all," Elayne murmured, earning a suspicious sideways glance. After a moment, she added, "You did say it was the color for funerals." Which produced a satisfied nod, though it was not what she had meant at all. This would be disaster if they could not keep peace among themselves. Birgitte had had to settle for an infusion of herbs this morning, and a particularly bitter mix at that, because Nynaeve claimed she was not angry enough to channel. She had gone on in the most dramatic manner about funeral white being the only suitable color, insisted she was not coming, until Elayne dragged her out of their apartments, and announced at least twenty times since that she would not apologize. Peace had to be kept, but. . . . "You agreed to this, Nynaeve. No, I don't want to hear any more about the rest of us bullying you. You agreed. So stop sulking."

nɪneɪiv spləɾɝd, aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ waɪd wɪð aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ʃi wɑz nɑt tə bi daɪvɝɾɪd, ðoʊ, dɪspaɪt wʌn fɪɹsli ɪnkɹɛdʒələs "sʌlkɪŋ?" ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "wi nid tə dɪskʌs ðɪs fɝðɝ, ɪleɪn. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi soʊ heɪsti. ðəɹ mʌs bi ə θaʊzən ɹizənz waɪ ðɪs woʊnt wɝk, tɑvɝən əɹ noʊ tɑvɝən, ən mæt kɔθən ɪz naɪn hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm."

Nynaeve spluttered, eyes going wide with outrage. She was not to be diverted, though, despite one fiercely incredulous "Sulking?" under her breath. "We need to discuss this further, Elayne. There is no need to be so hasty. There must be a thousand reasons why this won't work, ta'veren or no ta'veren, and Mat Cauthon is nine hundred of them."

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə lɛvəl lʊk. "dɪd jə dɪlɪbɝətli tʃuz ðə bɪɾɝəst ɝbz ðət wəd wɝk ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ?" waɪd-aɪɾ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ tɝn tə waɪd-aɪɾ ɪnəsəns, bʌt ɹɛd steɪnd nɪneɪivz tʃiks. ɪleɪn pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd, mʌɾɝɪŋ. ɪleɪn wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ʃi stʌk aʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ, tu. sʌlki wɑz nɑɾ ivən ɪn ɪt, ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ.

Elayne gave her a level look. "Did you deliberately choose the bitterest herbs that would work this morning?" Wide-eyed outrage turned to wide-eyed innocence, but red stained Nynaeve's cheeks. Elayne pushed open the door. Nynaeve followed, muttering. Elayne would not have been surprised if she stuck out her tongue, too. Sulky was not even in it, this morning.

ðə smɛl ə bɹɛdz beɪkɪŋ wɑftɪd fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz, ən ɔl ðə ʃʌɾɝz wɝ oʊpən tə ɛɹ aʊt ðə kɑmən ɹum. ə plʌmp-tʃik sɝvɪŋ wʊmən stændɪŋ ətɑp ə tɔl stul stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn tɪptoʊz tə teɪk daʊn bɪdʒɹæɡəld ɛvɝɡɹin bɹæntʃəz fɹəm əbʌv ðə wɪndoʊz, waɪl ʌðɝz ɹipleɪs teɪbəlz ən bɛntʃɪz ən tʃɛɹz ðət mʌst əv bɪn teɪkən əweɪ fəɹ ðə dænsɪŋ. ðɪs ɝli, noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz əbaʊt, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə skɪni ɡɝl ɪn ə waɪɾ eɪpɹən, swipɪŋ hæf-hɑɹɾɪdli wɪð ə bɹʌʃ-bɹum. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi ɪf əɹ maʊθ hæd nɑt sim sɛɾ ɪn ə kɑnstən paʊt. ðəɹ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli lɪɾəl mɛs, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ ɪnz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi ɹaɪəɾəs, ivən laɪsɛntʃəs, dʊɹɪŋ fɛstəvəlz. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɪʃt ʃi cʊɾə sin ɪt, ðoʊ.

The smell of breads baking wafted from the kitchens, and all the shutters were open to air out the common room. A plump-cheeked serving woman standing atop a tall stool stretched on tiptoes to take down bedraggled evergreen branches from above the windows, while others replaced tables and benches and chairs that must have been taken away for the dancing. This early, no one else was about, except for a skinny girl in a white apron, sweeping half-heartedly with a brush-broom. She might have been pretty if her mouth had not seemed set in a constant pout. There was surprisingly little mess, considering that inns were supposed to be riotous, even licentious, during festivals. A part of her wished she could have seen it, though.

"kʊd jə dɝɛk mi tə mæstɝ kɔθənz ɹumz?" ʃi æsk ðə skɪni ɡɝl wɪð ə smaɪl, pɹɑfɝɪŋ tu sɪlvɝ pɛniz. nɪneɪiv snɪft. ʃi wɑz taɪɾ əz ðə skɪn ɑn ə fɹɛʃ æpəl; ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ðə bɛɡɝ wʌn kɑpɝ!

"Could you direct me to Master Cauthon's rooms?" she asked the skinny girl with a smile, proffering two silver pennies. Nynaeve sniffed. She was tight as the skin on a fresh apple; she had given the beggar one copper!

ðə ɡɝl aɪɾ əm sʌlənli - ən sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə kɔɪnz əz wɛl - ən mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ saʊɝ ðət saʊndəd laɪk, "ə ɡɪldɪd wʊmən læs naɪɾ ən leɪɾiz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ." ʃi ɡeɪv dɝɛkʃənz ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə skɔɹn ðə pɛniz, bʌɾ ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, ðə ɡɝl snætʃt ðə sɪlvɝ fɹəm əɹ hænd wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə wɝɾ ə θæŋks, pɔzɪŋ oʊnli tə tʌk əm ɪndə ðə nɛk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs, ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz, bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɛt tə swɪŋɪŋ əɹ bɹum əz ɪf tə bit ðə flɔɹ tə dɛθ. pɝhæps ʃi hæɾ ə pɑkət soʊn ɪn ðɛɹ.

The girl eyed them sullenly - and surprisingly, the coins as well - and mumbled something sour that sounded like, "A gilded woman last night and ladies this morning." She gave directions grudgingly. For a moment Elayne thought she intended to scorn the pennies, but on the point of turning away, the girl snatched the silver from her hand without so much as a word of thanks, pausing only to tuck them into the neck of her dress, of all places, before she set to swinging her broom as if to beat the floor to death. Perhaps she had a pocket sewn in there.

"ju si," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "ju mɑɹk mi, hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ɪz ətɛnʃənz ɑn ðət jʌŋ wʊmən. ðæts ðə sɔɹɾ ə mæn jə wɑn mi tə əpɑlədʒaɪz tə."

"You see," Nynaeve grumbled under her breath. "You mark me, he tried to push his attentions on that young woman. That's the sort of man you want me to apologize to."

ɪleɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli lɛd ðə weɪ ʌp ðə ɹeɪləs stɛps ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum. ɪf nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt stɑp kəmpleɪnɪŋ. . . . ðə fɝs hɔlweɪ ɑn ðə ɹaɪt, ðə ɡɝl hæd sɛd, ən ðə læs dɔɹ ɑn ðə lɛft, bʌɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, baɪɾɪŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp.

Elayne said nothing, only led the way up the railless steps at the back of the room. If Nynaeve did not stop complaining. . . . The first hallway on the right, the girl had said, and the last door on the left, but in front of it, she hesitated, biting her lower lip.

nɪneɪiv bɹaɪɾənd. "ju si ɪts ə bæɾ aɪdiə naʊ, doʊn ju? wi ɑɹən il, ɪleɪn. aɪ laɪk ðə ɡɝl wɛl ɪnʌf, fəɹ ɔl ʃiz fɝɛvɝ fɑndəlɪŋ ðət naɪf ə hɝz, bʌt dʒʌs θɪŋk ə ði æbsəlut dʒɹɪvəl ʃi tɔkt. ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl. jə mʌs noʊ ɪɾ ɪz."

Nynaeve brightened. "You see it's a bad idea now, don't you? We aren't Aiel, Elayne. I like the girl well enough, for all she's forever fondling that knife of hers, but just think of the absolute drivel she talked. It's impossible. You must know it is."

"wi dɪd nɑɾ əɡɹi tə ɛniθɪŋ ɪmpɑsəbəl, nɪneɪiv." kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs fɝm tʊk ən ɛfɝt. səm ʌv wʌɾ eɪvinhə hæd sədʒɛstəd, əpɛɹənli ɪn ɔl sɪɹiəsnəs. . . . ʃi æktʃəli  hæd sədʒɛstəd lɛɾɪŋ ðə mæn swɪtʃ ðɛm! "wʌt wi dɪɾ əɡɹi tə ɪz kwaɪt pɑsəbəl." bɛɹli. ʃi ɹæp laʊdli ɑn ðə pænəl dɔɹ wɪð əɹ nʌkəlz. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɪʃ kɑɹvd ɑn ðə dɔɹ, ə ɹaʊn θɪŋ wɪð stʃɹaɪps ən ə snaʊt. ɔl ə ðə dɔɹz hæd dɪfɹən kɑɹvɪŋz, moʊst ə fɪʃ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ.

"We did not agree to anything impossible, Nynaeve." Keeping her voice firm took an effort. Some of what Aviendha had suggested, apparently in all seriousness. . . . She actually had suggested letting the man switch them! "What we did agree to is quite possible." Barely. She rapped loudly on the paneled door with her knuckles. There was a fish carved on the door, a round thing with stripes and a snout. All of the doors had different carvings, most of fish. There was no answer.

nɪneɪiv pʌft aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ ʃi mʌst əv bɪn hoʊldɪŋ. "pɝhæps hiz ɡɔn aʊt. wɪl dʒʌst əv tə kʌm bæk ənʌðɝ taɪm."

Nynaeve puffed out a breath she must have been holding. "Perhaps he has gone out. We'll just have to come back another time."

"æt ðɪs aʊɝ?" ʃi ɹæpt wʌns mɔɹ. "ju seɪ hi ɔlweɪz laɪz əbɛd wən i kæn." stɪl noʊ saʊn fɹəm ɪnsaɪd.

"At this hour?" She rapped once more. "You say he always lies abed when he can." Still no sound from inside.

"ɪleɪn, ɪf bɝdʒɪɾ ɪz ɛni ɪndəkeɪʃən, mæt ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf dʒusi əz ə fɪɾəlɝ læs naɪt. hi woʊn θæŋk əs fəɹ weɪkɪŋ hɪm. waɪ doʊnt wi dʒʌst ɡoʊ əweɪ ən - "

"Elayne, if Birgitte is any indication, Mat got himself juicy as a fiddler last night. He won't thank us for waking him. Why don't we just go away and - "

ɪleɪn lɪftəd ðə lætʃ ən wɛn ɪn. nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd wɪð ə saɪ ðət cʊɾə bɪn hɝd bæk ɪn ðə pæləs.

Elayne lifted the latch and went in. Nynaeve followed with a sigh that could have been heard back in the Palace.

mæt kɔθən wɑz spɹɔld ɑn ɪz bɛɾ ətɑp ðə nɪɾəd ɹɛd kʌvɝlət, ə foʊldəd klɔθ laɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz ən dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɑntu ðə pɪloʊ. ðə ɹum wɑz nɑt vɛɹi taɪɾi dɪspaɪt ði æbsəns ə dʌst. ə but stʊɾ ɑn ðə wɑʃstænd - ðə wɑʃstænd! - nɛks tə ə waɪt beɪsən fʊl ʌv ənjuzd wɔɾɝ, ðə stænd-mɪɹɝ sæɾ əskju, əz ɪf i hæd stʌmbəld ɪndə ɪɾ ən sɪmpli lɛft ɪt tɪltəd bæk ʃɑɹpli, ən ɪz ɹɪŋkəl koʊt leɪ tɔst əkɹɔs ə læɾɝ-bæk tʃɛɹ. hi wɔɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðət blæk skɑɹf i sim nɛvɝ tə teɪk ɔf, ən ði ʌðɝ but. ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd dæŋɡəl fɹəm ɪz ənleɪst ʃɝt.

Mat Cauthon was sprawled on his bed atop the knitted red coverlet, a folded cloth lying over his eyes and dripping onto the pillow. The room was not very tidy despite the absence of dust. A boot stood on the washstand - the washstand! - next to a white basin full of unused water, the stand-mirror sat askew, as if he had stumbled into it and simply left it tilted back sharply, and his wrinkled coat lay tossed across a ladder-back chair. He wore everything else, including that black scarf he seemed never to take off, and the other boot. The silver foxhead dangled from his unlaced shirt.

ðə mədæljən meɪɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪtʃ. ɪf i ɹɪli wɑz laɪɪŋ ðəɹ sɑɾən wɪð dʒɹɪŋk, ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɹimuv ɪɾ ənfɛlt. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə faɪn aʊt haʊ ðə θɪŋ əbzɔɹb ðə paʊɝ. faɪndɪŋ aʊt haʊ ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ wɝkt wɑz ə fæsəneɪʃən tə hɝ, bʌt ðət fɑkshɛd wɑz ɔl ðə pʌzəlz ɪn ðə wɝld ɹoʊld ɪndə wʌn.

The medallion made her fingers itch. If he really was lying there sodden with drink, she might be able to remove it unfelt. One way or another, she intended to find out how the thing absorbed the Power. Finding out how almost anything worked was a fascination to her, but that foxhead was all the puzzles in the world rolled into one.

nɪneɪiv kɑɾ əɹ sliv ən dʒɝkt əɹ hɛd təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ, saɪlənli maʊðɪŋ "əslip" ən sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt. pɹɑbli ənʌðɝ pli tə ɡoʊ.

Nynaeve caught her sleeve and jerked her head toward the door, silently mouthing "asleep" and something else she could not make out. Probably another plea to go.

"liv mi əloʊn, nɹɪm," hi mʌmbəl sʌɾənli. "aɪ toʊl jə bɪfɔɹ; aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə nu skʌl. ən kloʊz ðə dɔɹ sɔfli, əɹ əl pɪn jəɹ ɪɹz tə ɪt."

"Leave me alone, Nerim," he mumbled suddenly. "I told you before; I don't want anything but a new skull. And close the door softly, or I'll pin your ears to it."

nɪneɪiv dʒʌmpt, ən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl əɹ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ, bʌt ʃi stʊɾ əɹ ɡɹaʊnd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt nɹɪm, mæstɝ kɔθən."

Nynaeve jumped, and tried to pull her toward the door, but she stood her ground. "It is not Nerim, Master Cauthon."

ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm ðə pɪloʊ, hi juz boʊθ hænz tə lɪf ðə klɔθ ə tʃɹaɪfəl ən skwɪntɪɾ əɾ əm wɪð ɹɛɾənd aɪz.

Raising his head from the pillow, he used both hands to lift the cloth a trifle and squinted at them with reddened eyes.

ɡɹɪnɪŋ, nɪneɪiv meɪd noʊ ɛfɝɾ əɾ ɔl tə haɪɾ əɹ plɛʒɝ əɾ ɪz ɹɛtʃɪd steɪt. wʌɾ ɪleɪn kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ət fɝst wɑz waɪ ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡɹɪn, tu. hɝ wʌn ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ tu mʌtʃ hæd lɛft əɹ wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌt pɪɾi ən sɪmpəθi fəɹ ɛniwʌn soʊ snɛɹd. ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd ʃi fɛl bɝdʒɪts hɛd θɹɑbɪŋ stɪl, ən ɪt keɪm tə hɝ. sɝɾənli ʃi kəd nɑt laɪk bɝdʒɪt dʒɹaʊnɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn dʒɹɪŋk, wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizən, bʌt niðɝ kəd ʃi laɪk ðə θɔt ðəɾ ɛniwʌn kəd də ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl bɛɾɝ ðən əɹ fɝst wɔɹɾɝ. ə ɹɪdɪkjələs θɔt. ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ. bʌt sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ, tu.

Grinning, Nynaeve made no effort at all to hide her pleasure at his wretched state. What Elayne could not understand at first was why she wanted to grin, too. Her one experience with drinking too much had left her with nothing but pity and sympathy for anyone so snared. In the back of her mind she felt Birgitte's head throbbing still, and it came to her. Certainly she could not like Birgitte drowning herself in drink, whatever the reason, but neither could she like the thought that anyone could do anything at all better than her first Warder. A ridiculous thought. Embarrassing. But satisfying, too.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəd hɔɹsli, ðən wɪnst ən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "ɪts ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt."

"What are you doing here?" he demanded hoarsely, then winced and lowered his voice. "It's the middle of the night."

"ɪts mɔɹnɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "doʊn jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ tɔkɪŋ wɪð bɝdʒɪt?"

"It's morning," Nynaeve said sharply. "Don't you remember talking with Birgitte?"
