"kʊd jə nɑt bi soʊ laʊd?" hi wɪspɝd, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, ðeɪ pɑpt oʊpən əɡɛn. "bɝdʒɪt?" sɪɾɪŋ ʌp əbɹʌpli, hi swʌŋ ɪz lɛɡz oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd. fəɹ ə taɪm i dʒʌst sæt ðɛɹ, piɹɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz, ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz ən ðə mədæljən swɪŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪts θɔŋ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. ət læst i tɝn ɪz hɛd tə lʊk əɾ əm bɑlfəli. əɹ pɝhæps ɪz aɪz dʒʌs meɪɾ ɪt sim soʊ. "wʌt dɪd ʃi tɛl ju?"

"Could you not be so loud?" he whispered, closing his eyes. The next instant, they popped open again. "Birgitte?" Sitting up abruptly, he swung his legs over the side of the bed. For a time he just sat there, peering at the floorboards, elbows on his knees and the medallion swinging from its thong around his neck. At last he turned his head to look at them balefully. Or perhaps his eyes just made it seem so. "What did she tell you?"

"ʃi ɪnfɔɹmd əs ə jəɹ dɪmænz, mæstɝ kɔθən," ɪleɪn sɛd fɔɹməli. ðɪs mʌs bi haʊ ɪt fɛl tə stæn bɪfɔɹ ðə hɛdzmənz blɑk. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə kip əɹ hɛd haɪ ən feɪs wʌtɛvɝ keɪm pɹaʊdli. "aɪ wɪʃ tə θæŋk jə fɹəm maɪ hɑɹt fəɹ ɹɛskjuɪŋ mi fɹəm ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ." ðɛɹ, ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn, ən ɪt hæd nɑt hɝt. nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

"She informed us of your demands, Master Cauthon," Elayne said formally. This must be how it felt to stand before the headsman's block. There was nothing for it but to keep her head high and face whatever came proudly. "I wish to thank you from my heart for rescuing me from the Stone of Tear." There, she had begun, and it had not hurt. Not very much.

nɪneɪiv stʊd ðɛɹ, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ, hɝ lɪps ɡɹoʊɪŋ taɪɾɝ ən taɪɾɝ. ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt gɑnə liv əɹ tə də ðɪs əloʊn. ɪleɪn ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ʃi θɔt, ən tʃænəld ə θɪn floʊ ʌv ɛɹ ðət flɪk nɪneɪivz ɝloʊb laɪk ə snæpɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ. ðə wʊmən klæpt ə hæn tə hɝ ɪɹ ən ɡlaʊɝd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn sɪmpli tɝn kuli bæk tə mæstɝ kɔθən ən weɪɾəd.

Nynaeve stood there, glowering, her lips growing tighter and tighter. The woman was not going to leave her to do this alone. Elayne embraced the Source almost before she thought, and channeled a thin flow of Air that flicked Nynaeve's earlobe like a snapping finger. The woman clapped a hand to her ear and glowered, but Elayne simply turned coolly back to Master Cauthon and waited.

"aɪ θæŋk ju, tu," nɪneɪiv mʌmbəl sʌlənli ət læst. "fɹʌm ðə hɑɹt."

"I thank you, too," Nynaeve mumbled sullenly at last. "From the heart."

ɪleɪn ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. wɛl, hi hæɾ æskt əm tə spik mɔɹ sɔfli. ən i dɪd sim tə hɪɹ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi ʃɹʌɡd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt.

Elayne rolled her eyes in spite of herself. Well, he had asked them to speak more softly. And he did seem to hear. Strangely, he shrugged with embarrassment.

"oʊ, ðæt. ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ. laɪkli θɪŋ, juɾ əv ɡɑɾən jɝsɛlf fɹi ɪn ənʌðɝ tɪk wɪθaʊt mi." hɪz hɛd sæŋk tə hɪz hænz, ən i pɹɛs ðə dæmp klɔθ tə hɪz aɪz wʌns mɔɹ. "ɑn jəɹ weɪ aʊt, wəd jə æsk kɛɹə tə bɹɪŋ mi səm waɪn-pʌntʃ? ə slɛndɝ ɡɝl, pɹɪɾi, wɪð ə wɔɹm aɪ."

"Oh, that. It was nothing. Likely thing, you'd have gotten yourself free in another tick without me." His head sank to his hands, and he pressed the damp cloth to his eyes once more. "On your way out, would you ask Caira to bring me some wine-punch? A slender girl, pretty, with a warm eye."

ɪleɪn kwɪvɝd. nʌθɪŋ? ðə mæn dɪmændəɾ ən əpɑlədʒi, ʃi hʌmbəl hɝsɛlf tə ɡɪv ɪt, ən naʊ ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ? hi wɑz nɑt dɪzɝvɪŋ ə sɪmpəθi əɹ pɪɾi! ʃi stɪl hɛl seɪaɪdɑɹ, ən ʃi kənsɪɾɝd θʌmpɪŋ ɪm wɪð ə mʌtʃ θɪkɝ floʊ ðən ʃi hæd juzd ɑn nɪneɪiv. nɑt ðət ðət wəd də ɛni ɡʊd soʊ lɔŋ əz i wɔɹ ðə fɑkshɛd. ðən əɡɛn, ɪt hʌŋ lus, nɑt tʌtʃɪŋ hɪm. dɪɾ ɪɾ ɔfɝ ðə seɪm pɹətɛkʃən wən ɪt wɑz nɑt . . . ?

Elayne quivered. Nothing? The man demanded an apology, she humbled herself to give it, and now it was nothing? He was not deserving of sympathy or pity! She still held saidar, and she considered thumping him with a much thicker flow than she had used on Nynaeve. Not that that would do any good so long as he wore the foxhead. Then again, it hung loose, not touching him. Did it offer the same protection when it was not . . . ?

nɪneɪiv ɛndəɾ əɹ spɛkjəleɪʃən baɪ lʌnʒɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, fɪŋɡɝz klɔd. ɪleɪn mænədʒ tə pʊt hɝsɛlf bɪtwin əm ən siz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz. fəɹ ə stʃɹɛtʃt moʊmən ðeɪ stʊd noʊz-tə-noʊz ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə dɪfɝəns ɪn ðɛɹ haɪts; wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, nɪneɪiv faɪnəli ɹɪlækst, ən ɪleɪn fɛlt ɪt wɑz seɪf tə ɹilis hɝ.

Nynaeve ended her speculation by lunging for him, fingers clawed. Elayne managed to put herself between them and seize the other woman by the shoulders. For a stretched moment they stood nose-to-nose except for the difference in their heights; with a grimace, Nynaeve finally relaxed, and Elayne felt it was safe to release her.

ðə mæn stɪl hæɾ ɪz hɛd baʊd, ɔl ʌnəwɛɹ. wɛðɝ ðə mədæljən pɹətɛktəɾ ɪm əɹ nɑt, ʃi kəd snætʃ ɪz bɑstɑv fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ən biɾ ɪm tɪl i haʊld. ʃi fɛl hit ɹaɪz ɪn əɹ feɪs: ʃi hæd stɑp nɪneɪiv fɹəm ɹuɪnɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, oʊnli tə θɪŋk ə ɹuɪnɪŋ ɪt hɝsɛlf. wɝs, baɪ ðə smɝki, sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd lɪɾəl smaɪl ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪv hɝ, ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl wʌt hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ hɛd.

The man still had his head bowed, all unaware. Whether the medallion protected him or not, she could snatch his bowstave from the corner and beat him till he howled. She felt heat rise in her face: She had stopped Nynaeve from ruining everything, only to think of ruining it herself. Worse, by the smirky, self-satisfied little smile the other woman gave her, she knew very well what had been in her head.

"ðɛɹ ɪz mɔɹ, mæstɝ kɔθən," ʃi ənaʊnst, skwɛɹɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðə smaɪl vænɪʃt fɹəm nɪneɪivz feɪs. "wi ɔlsoʊ wɪʃ tə əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ dɪleɪɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ ɪn ɡɪvɪŋ jə jəɹ mʌtʃ dɪzɝv θæŋks. ən wi əpɑlədʒaɪz . . . hʌmbli . . ." ʃi stʌmbəld ə lɪɾəl ɑn ðæt. ". . . fəɹ ðə weɪ wɪv tʃɹiɾəd jə sɪns." nɪneɪiv stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə bɛsitʃɪŋ hæn ðət ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd. "tə ʃoʊ ðə dɛpθ ʌv əɹ ɹəɡɹɛt, wi ʌndɝteɪk ðə fɑloʊɪŋ pɹɑməsəz." eɪvinhə hæd sɛɾ ən əpɑlədʒi wɑz oʊnli ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. "wi wɪl nɑt bɪlɪɾəl əɹ dɪmin jə ɪn ɛni weɪ, nɔɹ ʃaʊɾ ət jə fəɹ ɛni ɹizən, nɔɹ . . . nɔɹ ətɛmp tə ɡɪv jə ɔɹɾɝz." nɪneɪiv wɪnst. ɪleɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd tu, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp. "ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ jəɹ du kənsɝn fəɹ əɹ seɪfti, wɪl nɑt liv ðə pæləs wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ jə wɛɹ wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ən wɪl lɪsən tə jəɹ ædvaɪs." laɪt, ʃi hæd noʊ wɪʃ tə bi il, noʊ wɪʃ tə də ɛni ʌv ðɪs, bʌt ʃi wɑntəɾ eɪvinhəz ɹɪspɛkt. "ɪf jə . . . ɪf jə dɪsaɪd ðət wəɹ . . ." nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə sɪstɝ-waɪf - ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə wɑz ɪndisənt! - bʌt ʃi dɪd laɪk hɝ. ". . . ɑɹ pʊɾɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz ɪn nidləs deɪnʒɝ . . ." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ eɪvinhəz fɔl ðət ɹænd hæd kɑt boʊθ ðɛɹ hɑɹts. ən mɪnz əz wɛl. ". . . wɪl æksɛp bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ə jəɹ tʃuzɪŋ . . ." feɪɾ əɹ tɑvɝən əɹ wʌtɛvɝ, wʌt wɑz, wɑz. ʃi lʌv boʊθ wɪmən laɪk sɪstɝz. ". . . ən kip əm wɪð əs əz lɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl." bɝn ðə mæn fəɹ duɪŋ ðɪs tə hɝ! ɪt wɑz nɑt mæt kɔθən ʃi mɛnt. "ðɪs aɪ swɛɹ baɪ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ." ʃi bɹiðd ɪn əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹʌn ə maɪl. nɪneɪiv wɔɹ ə feɪs laɪk ə kɔɹnɝd bædʒɝ.

"There is more, Master Cauthon," she announced, squaring her shoulders. The smile vanished from Nynaeve's face. "We also wish to apologize for delaying so long in giving you your much deserved thanks. And we apologize . . . humbly . . ." She stumbled a little on that. ". . . for the way we have treated you since." Nynaeve stretched out a beseeching hand that she ignored. "To show the depth of our regret, we undertake the following promises." Aviendha had said an apology was only a beginning. "We will not belittle or demean you in any way, nor shout at you for any reason, nor . . . nor attempt to give you orders." Nynaeve winced. Elayne's mouth tightened too, but she did not stop. "Recognizing your due concern for our safety, we will not leave the palace without telling you where we are going, and we will listen to your advice." Light, she had no wish to be Aiel, no wish to do any of this, but she wanted Aviendha's respect. "If you . . . if you decide that we are . . ." Not that she had any intention of becoming a sister-wife - the very idea was indecent! - but she did like her. ". . . are putting ourselves in needless danger . . ." It was not Aviendha's fault that Rand had caught both their hearts. And Min's as well. ". . . we will accept bodyguards of your choosing . . ." Fate or ta'veren or whatever, what was, was. She loved both women like sisters. ". . . and keep them with us as long as possible." Burn the man for doing this to her! It was not Mat Cauthon she meant. "This I swear by the Lion Throne of Andor." She breathed in as if she had run a mile. Nynaeve wore a face like a cornered badger.

hɪz hɛd swɪvəl təwɔɹɾ əm ɛvɝ soʊ sloʊli, ən i loʊɝd ðə klɔθ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə ɪkspoʊz wʌn ɹɛd-stʃɹikt aɪ. "ju saʊn laɪk juv ən aɪɝn ɹɑd daʊn jəɹ θɹoʊt, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd mɑkəŋli. "ju hæv maɪ pɝmɪʃən tə kɔl mi mæt." oʊɾiəs mæn! hi wəd nɑt noʊ səvɪləɾi ɪf ɪt bɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə noʊz! ðət sæŋɡwɪn aɪ slæntəd təwɔɹd hɝ. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, nɪneɪiv? aɪ hɝɾ ə lɑɾ ʌv 'wi' fɹəm hɝ, bʌt nɑɾ ə wɝd fɹəm ju."

His head swiveled toward them ever so slowly, and he lowered the cloth just enough to expose one red-streaked eye. "You sound like you have an iron rod down your throat, my Lady," he said mockingly. "You have my permission to call me Mat." Odious man! He would not know civility if it bit him on the nose! That sanguine eye slanted toward her. "What about you, Nynaeve? I heard a lot of 'we' from her, but not a word from you."

"aɪ woʊnt ʃaʊɾ ət ju," nɪneɪiv ʃaʊɾəd. "æn ɔl ðə ɹɛst, tu. aɪ pɹɑməs, jə . . . jə . . . !" ʃi ɡɑbəld ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə swɑloʊɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ əz ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi kəd nɑt kɔl ɪm wʌn ə ðə neɪmz i wɔɹəntɪd wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə pɹɑməs ɔlɹɛɾi. ən jɛt, ði ɪfɛkt ə hɝ ʃaʊt wɑz moʊst ɡɹæɾəfaɪɪŋ.

"I won't shout at you," Nynaeve shouted. "And all the rest, too. I promise, you . . . you . . . !" She gobbled on the edge of swallowing her tongue as she realized she could not call him one of the names he warranted without breaking the promise already. And yet, the effect of her shout was most gratifying.

wɪð ə kɹaɪ, hi ʃʌɾɝəd ən dʒɹɑp ðə klɔθ, klʌtʃt ɪz hɛd wɪð boʊθ hænz. hɪz aɪz bʌlʒd. "fleɪmɪŋ daɪs," hi wɪmpɝd, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk. ɪt sʌɾənli stʃɹʌk ɪleɪn ðəɾ i wəd bi ə vɛɹi ɡʊd sɔɹs ə pɪθi læŋɡwədʒ. steɪbəlmən ən ðə laɪk ɔlweɪz sim tə skɹeɪp ðɛɹ tʌŋz klin ðə moʊmən ðeɪ sɔ hɝ. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd pɹɑməs hɝsɛlf tə sɪvəlaɪz hɪm, tə meɪk ɪm jusfəl tə ɹænd, bʌt ðət nid nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ tu mʌtʃ wɪð ɪz læŋɡwədʒ. ɪn fækt, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡʊd dil ʃi hæd nɑt pɹɑməs nɑt tə du. pɔɪntɪŋ ðəɾ aʊt ʃəd sɛɾəl nɪneɪiv kənsɪɾɝəbli.

With a cry, he shuddered and dropped the cloth, clutched his head with both hands. His eyes bulged. "Flaming dice," he whimpered, or something very like. It suddenly struck Elayne that he would be a very good source of pithy language. Stablemen and the like always seemed to scrape their tongues clean the moment they saw her. Of course, she had promised herself to civilize him, to make him useful to Rand, but that need not interfere too much with his language. In fact, she realized there was a good deal she had not promised not to do. Pointing that out should settle Nynaeve considerably.

æftɝ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, hi spoʊk ɪn ə hɑloʊ vɔɪs. "θæŋk ju, nɪneɪiv." hi pɔz tə swɑloʊ hɑɹd. "aɪ θɔt jə tu mʌs bi sʌmbɑɾi ɛls ɪn dɪsɡaɪz, ðəɹ fəɹ ə bɪt. sɪns aɪ stɪl sim tə bi əlaɪv, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪt. aɪ sim tə ɹikɔl ðət bɝdʒɪt sɛd jə wɑntəd mi tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ju. wʌt?"

After a long moment, he spoke in a hollow voice. "Thank you, Nynaeve." He paused to swallow hard. "I thought you two must be somebody else in disguise, there for a bit. Since I still seem to be alive, we might as well take care of the rest of it. I seem to recall that Birgitte said you wanted me to find something for you. What?"

"ju woʊn faɪn ɪt," nɪneɪiv toʊld ɪm ɪn ə fɝm vɔɪs. wɛl, pɝhæps mɔɹ hɑɹd ðən fɝm, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə kɔlɪŋ əɹ daʊn. hi mɛɹɪɾɪd ɛvɹi wɪns. "ju wɪl əkʌmpəni ʌs, ən wɪl faɪn ɪt."

"You won't find it," Nynaeve told him in a firm voice. Well, perhaps more hard than firm, but Elayne did not think of calling her down. He merited every wince. "You will accompany us, and we will find it."

"bæktʃɹækɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi, nɪneɪiv?" sʌmhaʊ, hi mænədʒd ə dɝɪsɪv snɪɹ, ɪspɛʃli hɪɾiəs wɪð ɪz aɪz. "ju dʒʌs fɪnɪʃt pɹɑməsɪŋ tə də əz aɪ seɪ. ɪf jə wɑn ə teɪm tɑvɝən ɑn ə liʃ, ɡoʊ æsk ɹænd əɹ pɛɹɪn ən si wʌɾ ænsɝ jə ɡɛt."

"Backtracking already, Nynaeve?" Somehow, he managed a derisive sneer, especially hideous with his eyes. "You just finished promising to do as I say. If you want a tame ta'veren on a leash, go ask Rand or Perrin and see what answer you get."

"wi pɹɑməs noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən," nɪneɪiv snæpt, ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ɑn əɹ toʊz. "aɪ pɹɑməs noʊ sətʃ θɪŋ!" ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt tə flɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɾ ɪm əɡɛn. ivən əɹ bɹeɪd sim tə bɹɪsəl.

"We promised no such thing, Matrim Cauthon," Nynaeve snapped, going up on her toes. "I promised no such thing!" She looked about to fling herself at him again. Even her braid seemed to bristle.

ɪleɪn kɛpt ə bɛɾɝ ɹeɪn ɑn əɹ tɛmpɝ. ðeɪ wəd ɡɛt noʊwɛɹ blʌdʒoʊnɪŋ hɪm. "wi wɪl lɪsən tə jəɹ ædvaɪs, ən æksɛpt ɪɾ ɪf ɪts ɹizənəbəl, mæstɝ . . . mæt," ʃi tʃaɪɾɪd dʒɛnli. ʃʊɹli hi kəd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ðeɪ hæd pɹɑməs tə. . . . lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ðoʊ, ʃi sɔ ðəɾ i dɪd. oʊ, laɪt! nɪneɪiv wɑz ɹaɪt. hi wɑz gɑnə bi tʃɹʌbəl.

Elayne kept a better rein on her temper. They would get nowhere bludgeoning him. "We will listen to your advice, and accept it if it is reasonable, Master . . . Mat," she chided gently. Surely he could not really believe they had promised to. . . . Looking at him, though, she saw that he did. Oh, Light! Nynaeve was right. He was going to be trouble.

ʃi hɛl ðət ɹeɪn fɝmli. tʃænəlɪŋ əɡɛn, ʃi lɪftəɾ ɪz koʊt fɹəm ðə tʃɛɹ tə ə pɹɑpɝ pleɪs ɑn wʌn ə ðə pɛɡz ɑn ðə wɔl soʊ ʃi kəd sɪt, bæk stʃɹeɪt, ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ skɝts kɛɹfəli. kipɪŋ əɹ pɹɑməsəz tə mæstɝ kɔθən - mæt - ən tə hɝsɛlf wɑz gɑnə bi dɪfəkəlt, bʌt nʌθɪŋ i sɛɾ əɹ dɪd kəd tʌtʃ hɝ. nɪneɪiv aɪd ði oʊnli ʌðɝ pleɪs tə sɪt, ə loʊ kɑɹvd wʊɾən fʊtstul, ən ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ. wʌn hæn muv təwɔɹɾ əɹ bɹeɪd, bɪfɔɹ ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz. hɝ fʊt tæpt ɑmənəsli.

She held that rein firmly. Channeling again, she lifted his coat from the chair to a proper place on one of the pegs on the wall so she could sit, back straight, arranging her skirts carefully. Keeping her promises to Master Cauthon - Mat - and to herself was going to be difficult, but nothing he said or did could touch her. Nynaeve eyed the only other place to sit, a low carved wooden footstool, and remained standing. One hand moved toward her braid, before she folded her arms. Her foot tapped ominously.

"ði æθɑn maɪɹ kɔl ɪt ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, mæstɝ . . . mæt. ɪts ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. . . ."

"The Atha'an Miere call it the Bowl of the Winds, Master . . . Mat. It is a ter'angreal. . . ."

baɪ ði ɛnd, ə laɪɾ ʌv ɪksaɪtmənt ʃoʊn θɹu hɪz sɪklinəs. "naʊ, ðət wəd bi ə θɪŋ tə faɪnd," hi mɝmɝd. "ɪn ðə ɹæhəd." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən flɪntʃt. "aɪl tɛl jə ðɪs naʊ. niðɝ ə jə ɪz sɛɾɪŋ fʊɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪθaʊt fɔɹ əɹ faɪv ə maɪ ɹɛdʒɹmz itʃ. nɑɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə pæləs, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. dɪd bɝdʒɪt tɛl jə əbaʊt ðə noʊt ðət wɑz stʌft ɪn maɪ koʊt? aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ toʊl hɝ. ən ðɛɹz kæɹaɪɾɪn ən ɪz dɑɹkfɹɛnz; jə kæn tɛl mi hi ɪzən ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ."

By the end, a light of excitement shone through his sickliness. "Now, that would be a thing to find," he murmured. "In the Rahad." He shook his head, and flinched. "I'll tell you this now. Neither of you is setting foot on the other side of the river without four or five of my Redarms each. Not outside the palace, for that matter. Did Birgitte tell you about the note that was stuffed in my coat? I'm sure I told her. And there's Carridin and his Darkfriends; you can't tell me he isn't up to something."

"ɛni sɪstɝ u səpɔɹts ɛɡwin əz æmɪɝlɪn ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ." bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɛvɹiwɛɹ? laɪt! ə deɪnʒɝəs laɪt ʃoʊn ɪn nɪneɪivz aɪz, ən əɹ fʊt tæp fæstɝ. "wi kænɑt haɪd, mæst . . . mæt, ən wɪl nɑt. dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn wɪl bi teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv ɪn du kɔɹs." ðeɪ hæd nɑt pɹɑməs tə tɛl ɪm ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm bi daɪvɝɾɪd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz əfʊt."

"Any sister who supports Egwene as Amyrlin is in danger from the Tower." Bodyguards everywhere? Light! A dangerous light shone in Nynaeve's eyes, and her foot tapped faster. "We cannot hide, Mast . . . Mat, and we will not. Jaichim Carridin will be taken care of in due course." They had not promised to tell him everything, and they could not let him be diverted. "There are more important matters afoot."

"du kɔɹs?" hi bɪɡæn, vɔɪs ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn dɪsbɪlif, bʌt nɪneɪiv kʌɾ ɪm ʃɔɹt.

"Due course?" he began, voice rising in disbelief, but Nynaeve cut him short.

"fɔɹ əɹ faɪv itʃ?" ʃi sɛd saʊɝli. "ðæts ɹɪɾɪk - " hɝ aɪz ʃʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən əɹ toʊn bɪkeɪm maɪldɝ. slaɪtli maɪldɝ. "aɪ min tə seɪ, ɪɾ ɪzən sɛnsəbəl. ɪleɪn ən mi, bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə. jə doʊn əv ðət mɛni soʊlʒɝz. ɛniweɪ, ɔl wi ɹɪli niɾ ɪz ju." ðət læs keɪm aʊɾ əz ðoʊ dʒɹæɡd. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tu mʌtʃ ən ædmɪʃən.

"Four or five each?" she said sourly. "That's ridic - " Her eyes shut for a moment, and her tone became milder. Slightly milder. "I mean to say, it isn't sensible. Elayne and me, Birgitte and Aviendha. You don't have that many soldiers. Anyway, all we really need is you." That last came out as though dragged. It was much too much an admission.

"bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə doʊnt nid maɪndɝz," hi sɛɾ æbsənli. "aɪ səpoʊz ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən kæɹaɪɾɪn, bʌt. . . . ɪt dʌzn sim ɹaɪt, lɛɾɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɔk lus."

"Birgitte and Aviendha don't need minders," he said absently. "I suppose this Bowl of the Winds is more important than Carridin, but. . . . It doesn't seem right, letting Darkfriends walk loose."

sloʊli nɪneɪivz feɪs tɝn pɝpəl. ɪleɪn tʃɛkt əɹ oʊn ɪn ðə stænd-mɪɹɝ, ɹɪliv tə si ʃi wɑz meɪnteɪnɪŋ əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ. ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd, ɛniweɪ. ðə mæn wɑz ɹɛpɹɪhɛnsəbəl! maɪndɝz? ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ wəd bi wɝs: ðəɾ i hæd flʌŋ ðəɾ ɔfhæn ɪnsəlt ɑn pɝpəs, əɹ ðəɾ i hæd dʌn soʊ wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ. ʃi aɪd hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ əɡɛn ən loʊɝɾ əɹ tʃɪn ə tʃɹaɪfəl. maɪndɝz! ʃi wɑz pɔɪz ɪtsɛlf.

Slowly Nynaeve's face turned purple. Elayne checked her own in the stand-mirror, relieved to see she was maintaining her composure. On the outside, anyway. The man was reprehensible! Minders? She was not sure which would be worse: that he had flung that offhand insult on purpose, or that he had done so without realizing. She eyed herself in the mirror again and lowered her chin a trifle. Minders! She was poise itself.

hi stʌɾid əm wɪð ðoʊz blʌdʃɑɾ aɪz, bʌt sɔ nʌθɪŋ, əpɛɹənli. "wɑz ðəɾ ɔl bɝdʒɪt toʊl ju?" hi æskt, ən nɪneɪiv snæp bæk, "ðæt wɑz kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf, aɪd θɪŋk, ivən fəɹ ju." ɪnɪksplɪkəbli, hi lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, ən kwaɪt plizd.

He studied them with those bloodshot eyes, but saw nothing, apparently. "Was that all Birgitte told you?" he asked, and Nynaeve snapped back, "That was quite enough, I'd think, even for you." Inexplicably, he looked surprised, and quite pleased.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ðən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf taɪɾɝ. "sɪns jəɹ ɪn noʊ kəndɪʃən tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ wɪð əs naʊ - doʊn skaʊl ət mi, mæt kɔθən; ðəɾ ɪzən dɪminɪŋ, ɪts sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ! - jə kən spɛn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ muvɪŋ jɝsɛlf ɪndə ðə pæləs. ən jə nidn θɪŋk wɪl hɛlp kæɹi jəɹ θɪŋz. aɪ dɪdn pɹɑməs tə bi ə pækhɔɹs."

Nynaeve gave a start, then folded her arms around herself tighter. "Since you're in no condition to go anywhere with us now - don't scowl at me, Mat Cauthon; that isn't demeaning, it's simple truth! - you can spend the morning moving yourself into the palace. And you needn't think we'll help carry your things. I didn't promise to be a packhorse."

"ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən ɪz plɛnti ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf," hi bɪɡæn æŋɡɹəli, ðən stɑpt, ə wʌndɝɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃən spɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs. ə hɔɹəfaɪɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən, ɪleɪn wəɾ əv sɛd. ðət ʃəd titʃ ɪm tə ɡɹaʊl wən i hæɾ ə hɛd laɪk ə mɛlən. ət list, ðət wɑz wʌt hɝz hæd fɛlt laɪk, ðə taɪm ʃi dʒɹæŋk tu mʌtʃ. ʌv kɔɹs i wəd nɑt lɝn fɹəm ɪt. mɛn kɛp stɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz ɪn ðə faɪɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ðɪs taɪm ɪt wəd nɑt bɝn, soʊ lini ɔlweɪz sɛd.

"The Wandering Woman is plenty good enough," he began angrily, then stopped, a wondering expression spreading over his face. A horrified expression, Elayne would have said. That should teach him to growl when he had a head like a melon. At least, that was what hers had felt like, the time she drank too much. Of course he would not learn from it. Men kept sticking their hands in the fire thinking this time it would not burn, so Lini always said.

"ju kən hɑɹdli ɪkspɛkt wɪl faɪn ðə boʊl ðə fɝs taɪm wi tʃɹaɪ," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn, "tɑvɝən əɹ noʊ. ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ itʃ deɪ wɪl bi mʌtʃ sɪmpəlɝ ɪf jə doʊn əv tə kʌm əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ." ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv tə weɪt fəɹ ɪm ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ, wɑz wʌt ʃi mɛnt. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɝ, dʒɹʌŋkənnəs wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɪkskjus i kəd faɪn fəɹ laɪɪŋ ɪn bɛd tɪl ɔl aʊɝz, fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt.

"You can hardly expect we'll find the Bowl the first time we try," Nynaeve went on, "ta'veren or no. Going out each day will be much simpler if you don't have to come across the square." If they did not have to wait for him every morning, was what she meant. According to her, drunkenness was not the only excuse he could find for lying in bed till all hours, far from it.

"bɪsaɪdz," ɪleɪn æɾəd, "ðæt weɪ, jə kən kip ən aɪ ɑn ʌs." nɪneɪiv meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, vɛɹi kloʊs tə ə ɡɹoʊn. dɪd ʃi nɑt si ðəɾ i mʌs bi ɪntaɪst? ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd pɹɑməs tə æktʃəli  əlaʊ hɪm tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ðɛm.

"Besides," Elayne added, "that way, you can keep an eye on us." Nynaeve made a sound in her throat, very close to a groan. Did she not see that he must be enticed? It was not as if she had promised to actually allow him to keep an eye on them.

hi sim nɑt tə hæv hɝɾ əɹ əɹ nɪneɪiv. hæɡɝɾ aɪz stɛɹd ɹaɪt θɹu hɝ. "waɪ dɪd ðeɪ blʌɾi wɛl əv tə stɑp naʊ?" hi moʊnd, soʊ sɔfli ʃi bɛɹli hɝd. wʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt dɪɾ i min baɪ ðæt?

He seemed not to have heard her or Nynaeve. Haggard eyes stared right through her. "Why did they bloody well have to stop now?" he moaned, so softly she barely heard. What under the Light did he mean by that?

"ðə ɹumz ɑɹ fɪt fəɹ ə kɪŋ, mæstɝ . . . mæt. taɪlɪn hɝsɛlf tʃoʊz ðɛm, dʒʌs daʊn fɹəm əɹ oʊn. ʃiz teɪkən ə vɛɹi pɝsənəl ɪntʃɹəst. mæt, jə wʊdn əv əs əfɛn ðə kwin, wəd ju?"

"The rooms are fit for a king, Master . . . Mat. Tylin herself chose them, just down from her own. She has taken a very personal interest. Mat, you wouldn't have us offend the Queen, would you?"

wʌn lʊk əɾ ɪz feɪs, ən ɪleɪn hɝidli tʃænəl tə pʊʃ oʊpən ðə wɪndoʊ ən ɛmpti ðə wɑʃbeɪsən θɹu ɪt. ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ə mæn əbaʊt tə luz ðə kɑntɛns ə hɪz stʌmək, hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd-aɪɾ əɾ əɹ ɹaɪt ðət mɪnət.

One look at his face, and Elayne hurriedly channeled to push open the window and empty the washbasin through it. If she had ever seen a man about to lose the contents of his stomach, he was staring red-eyed at her right that minute.

"aɪ doʊn si waɪ jəɹ meɪkɪŋ sətʃ ə fʌs," ʃi sɛd. æktʃəli , ʃi səpoʊzd ʃi dɪd. səm ə ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən hɪɹ pɹɑbli lɛɾ ɪm pɔ ðɛm, bʌt ʃi daʊɾɪd mɛni ɪn ðə pæləs wʊd, ɪf ɛni. hi wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə dʒɹɪŋk ən ɡæmbəl ɪz naɪts əweɪ, iðɝ. taɪlɪn ʃʊɹli wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ə bæɾ ɪɡzæmpəl fəɹ bɛslən. "wi ɔl mʌs meɪk sækɹəfaɪsɪz." wɪð ən ɛfɝt ʃi stɑp ðɛɹ, nɑt tɛlɪŋ ɪm ðəɾ ɪz wɑz smɔl ən oʊnli ɹaɪt, ðɛɹz mɑnstʃɹəs ən əndʒʌst, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ eɪvinhə sɛd. nɪneɪiv hæd sɝɾənli ɹeɪld əɡɛnst ɛni sækɹəfaɪs.

"I don't see why you're making such a fuss," she said. Actually, she supposed she did. Some of the serving women here probably let him paw them, but she doubted many in the palace would, if any. He would not be able to drink and gamble his nights away, either. Tylin surely would not allow a bad example for Beslan. "We all must make sacrifices." With an effort she stopped there, not telling him that his was small and only right, theirs monstrous and unjust, no matter what Aviendha said. Nynaeve had certainly railed against any sacrifice.

hi pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ɪz hænz əɡɛn, meɪkɪŋ stʃɹæŋɡəl nɔɪzɪz waɪl ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk. hi wɑz læfɪŋ! ʃi hɛftəd ðə beɪsən ɑn ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ hɪɾɪŋ ɪm wɪð ɪt. wən i ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪz əɡɛn, ðoʊ, hi lʊkt aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ fəɹ səm ɹizən. "sækɹəfaɪsɪz?" hi snɑɹəld. "ɪf aɪ æsk jə tə meɪk ðə seɪm, jud bɑks ɛvɹi ɪɹ ɪn saɪɾ ən pʊl ðə ɹuf daʊn ɑn maɪ hɛd!" kəɾ i stɪl bi dʒɹʌŋk?

He put his head in his hands again, making strangled noises while his shoulders shook. He was laughing! She hefted the basin on a flow of Air, considering hitting him with it. When he raised his eyes again, though, he looked outraged for some reason. "Sacrifices?" he snarled. "If I asked you to make the same, you'd box every ear in sight and pull the roof down on my head!" Could he still be drunk?

ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪz fɹaɪtfəl ɡlɛɹ. "spikɪŋ ə jəɹ hɛd, ɪf jə wəd laɪk hilɪŋ, aɪm ʃʊɹ nɪneɪiv wəɾ əblaɪdʒ." ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə tʃænəl, ʃi wɑz naʊ.

She decided to ignore his frightful glare. "Speaking of your head, if you would like Healing, I'm sure Nynaeve would oblige." If she had ever been angry enough to channel, she was now.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə smɔl dʒɝk ən ɡlænst əɾ əɹ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ʌv wʌn aɪ. "ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi sɛd hɝidli. "ɪf jə wɑnt." ðə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks kənfɝmd ɔl ʌv ɪleɪnz səspɪʃənz əbaʊt ðət mɔɹnɪŋ.

Nynaeve gave a small jerk and glanced at her from the corner of one eye. "Of course," she said hurriedly. "If you want." The color in her cheeks confirmed all of Elayne's suspicions about that morning.

ɡɹeɪʃəs əz ɛvɝ, hi snɪɹd. "ju dʒʌs fɝɡɛt maɪ hɛd. aɪ də vɛɹi wɛl wɪθaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ən ðɛn, dʒʌs tə kənfjuz mæɾɝz ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ, hi æɾəd ɪn ə hɛzɪɾənt vɔɪs, "aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ æskɪŋ, ðoʊ." ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i mɛn ɪt!

Gracious as ever, he sneered. "You just forget my head. I do very well without Aes Sedai." And then, just to confuse matters she was sure, he added in a hesitant voice, "I thank you for asking, though." Almost as if he meant it!

ɪleɪn mænədʒ nɑt tə ɡeɪp. hɝ nɑlədʒ ə mɛn wɑz lɪməɾəd tə ɹænd ən wʌt lini ən əɹ mʌðɝ hæd toʊl hɝ. wɑz ɹænd gɑnə bi əz kənfjuzɪŋ əz mæt kɔθən?

Elayne managed not to gape. Her knowledge of men was limited to Rand and what Lini and her mother had told her. Was Rand going to be as confusing as Mat Cauthon?

læs θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə sɪkjʊɹ ə pɹɑməs ðəɾ i wəd stɑɹt muvɪŋ tə ðə pæləs ɪmiɾiətli. hi kɛpt ɪz wɝd wʌns ɡɪvən, soʊ nɪneɪiv hæd meɪd klɪɹ, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌt liv wʌn kɹæk, ən i kəd faɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd weɪz tə slɪp θɹu. ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ɔl tu iɡɝ tə ɛmfəsaɪz. hi ɡeɪv ɪz pɹɑməs wɪð ə blik, ɹɪzɛnfəl ɡɹɪmɑs; əɹ meɪbi ðət wɑz dʒʌst ɪz aɪz əɡɛn. wən ʃi sɛt ðə beɪsən daʊn əɾ ɪz fit, hi æktʃəli  lʊkt ɡɹeɪtfəl. ʃi wəd nɑt fil sɪmpəθi. ʃi wəd nɑt.

Last thing before going, she remembered to secure a promise that he would start moving to the palace immediately. He kept his word once given, so Nynaeve had made clear, however reluctantly, but leave one crack, and he could find a hundred ways to slip through. That she had been all too eager to emphasize. He gave his promise with a bleak, resentful grimace; or maybe that was just his eyes again. When she set the basin down at his feet, he actually looked grateful. She would not feel sympathy. She would not.

wʌns bæk ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, wɪð ðə dɔɹ tə mæts ɹum kloʊzd, nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ fɪst ət ðə silɪŋ. "ðæt mæn kəd tʃɹaɪ ðə peɪʃəns ʌv ə stoʊn! aɪm ɡlæɾ i wɑns tə kʌɾəl wɪð ɪz hɛd! dʒju hɪɹ mi? ɡlæd! hɪl meɪk tʃɹʌbəl. hi wɪl."

Once back in the corridor, with the door to Mat's room closed, Nynaeve shook her fist at the ceiling. "That man could try the patience of a stone! I'm glad he wants to cuddle with his head! Do you hear me? Glad! He will make trouble. He will."

"ju tu wɪl meɪk mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ ɪm ðən i ɛvɝ kʊd." ðə spikɝ stɔk daʊn ðə hɔl təwɔɹd ðɛm, ə wʊmən wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ə stʃɹɔŋ feɪs ən ə kəmændɪŋ vɔɪs. ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə fɹaʊn lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə skaʊl. dɪspaɪt ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf hæŋɪŋ ɪndə hɝ klivədʒ, ʃi wɑz tu fɛɹ fəɹ ən ɛbu dɑɹi. "aɪ kʊdn bɪliv ɪt wən kɛɹə toʊl mi. aɪ daʊɾ aɪv ɛvɝ sin soʊ mʌtʃ fulɪʃnəs pɔɹɾ ɪndə dʒʌs tu dʒɹɛsəz."

"You two will make more trouble for him than he ever could." The speaker stalked down the hall toward them, a woman with a touch of gray in her hair, a strong face and a commanding voice. She also wore a frown little short of a scowl. Despite the marriage knife hanging into her cleavage, she was too fair for an Ebou Dari. "I couldn't believe it when Caira told me. I doubt I've ever seen so much foolishness poured into just two dresses."

ɪleɪn aɪd ðə wʊmən ʌp ən daʊn. nɑɾ ivən əz ə nɑvəs hæd ʃi ɡɑɾən juz tə biɪŋ ədʒɹɛst ɪn ðət toʊn. "æn u maɪt jə bi, maɪ ɡʊd wʊmən?"

Elayne eyed the woman up and down. Not even as a novice had she gotten used to being addressed in that tone. "And who might you be, my good woman?"

"aɪ maɪt bi ən æm sɛɾəl ɑnən, ði oʊnɝ ə ðɪs ɪn, tʃaɪld" wɑz ðə dʒɹaɪ ɹɪplaɪ, ən wɪð ðæt, ðə wʊmən flʌŋ oʊpən ə dɔɹ əkɹɔs ðə hɔlweɪ, sizd əm itʃ baɪ ən ɑɹm, ən hʌsəld əm θɹu soʊ fæst ɪleɪn θɔɾ əɹ slɪpɝz hæd lɛf ðə flɔɹ.

"I might be and am Setalle Anan, the owner of this inn, child" was the dry reply, and with that, the woman flung open a door across the hallway, seized them each by an arm, and hustled them through so fast Elayne thought her slippers had left the floor.

"ju sim ʌndɝ səm mɪsæpɹihɛnʃən, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən," ʃi sɛd kuli əz ðə wʊmən ɹilist əm tə ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ.

"You seem under some misapprehension, Mistress Anan," she said coolly as the woman released them to shut the door.

nɪneɪiv wɑz ɪn noʊ mud fəɹ naɪsɪɾiz. hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hæn soʊ hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz pleɪn, ʃi sɛd hiɾɪdli, "naʊ, jə lʊk hɪɹ - "

Nynaeve was in no mood for niceties. Holding her hand so her Great Serpent ring was plain, she said heatedly, "Now, you look here - "

"vɛɹi pɹɪɾi," ðə wʊmən sɛd, ən pʊʃt itʃ ə ðɛm soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz sɪɾɪŋ saɪd-baɪ-saɪɾ ɑn ðə bɛd. ɪleɪnz aɪz pɑpt ɪn dɪsbɪlif. ðɪs ɑnən wʊmən kənfɹʌntəd ðɛm, ɡɹɪm-feɪst, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld laɪk ə mʌðɝ əbaʊt tə kæstəɡeɪɾ əɹ dɔɾɝz. "flɔntɪŋ ðət dʒʌst ʃoʊz haʊ sɪli jə ɑɹ. ðət jʌŋ mæn wɪl dændəl jə ɑn ɪz ni - wʌn ɑn itʃ, aɪ ʃʊdnt wʌndɝ, ɪf jə əlaʊ - hɪl teɪk ə fju kɪsəz ən əz mʌtʃ ɛls əz jəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv, bʌɾ i woʊn hɑɹm ju. jə kən hɑɹm hɪm, ðoʊ, ɪf jə kip ɑn wɪð ðɪs."

"Very pretty," the woman said, and pushed each of them so hard they found themselves sitting side-by-side on the bed. Elayne's eyes popped in disbelief. This Anan woman confronted them, grim-faced, fists on her hips, for all the world like a mother about to castigate her daughters. "Flaunting that just shows how silly you are. That young man will dandle you on his knee - one on each, I shouldn't wonder, if you allow - he'll take a few kisses and as much else as you're willing to give, but he won't harm you. You can harm him, though, if you keep on with this."

hɑɹm hɪm? ðə wʊmən θɔt ðeɪ - ʃi θɔɾ i hæd dændəld - ʃi θɔt - ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ, bʌt ʃi stʊɾ ʌp, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ skɝts. "æz aɪ sɛd, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, jə ɑɹ ʌndɝ ə mɪsæpɹihɛnʃən." hɝ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm smuðɝ əz ʃi wɛn ɑn, kənfjuʒən ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə kɑm. "aɪ æm ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə θɪŋk - " hɝ aɪz nɪɹli kɹɔst əz mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən pʊʃt ə fɪŋɡɝ tə ðə tɪp ə hɝ noʊz.

Harm him? The woman thought they - she thought he had dandled - she thought - Elayne did not know whether to laugh or cry, but she stood up, straightening her skirts. "As I said, Mistress Anan, you are under a misapprehension." Her voice became smoother as she went on, confusion giving way to calm. "I am Elayne Trakand, Daughter-Heir of Andor and Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah. I don't know what you think - " Her eyes nearly crossed as Mistress Anan pushed a finger to the tip of her nose.

"ɪleɪn, ɪf ðəɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm, ɔl ðət kips mi fɹəm dʒɹæɡɪŋ jə daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃən ən wɑʃɪŋ jəɹ maʊθ aʊt, jʊɹz ən ðəɾ ʌðɝ fulɪʃ ɡɝlz ðɛɹ, ɪz ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət jə æktʃəli  kən tʃænəl sʌmwʌt. əɹ ɑɹ jə sɪli ɪnʌf tə wɛɹ ðət ɹɪŋ wən jə kæn ivən də ðæt? aɪ wɔɹn ɪɾəl wɪl meɪk noʊ dɪfɝəns tə ðə sɪstɝz oʊvɝ ɪn ðə tɛɹə-sɪn dʒju jə ivən noʊ əbaʊt ðɛm? ɪf jə du, fɹæŋkli, jə ɑɹ nɑt fulɪʃ, jəɹ blaɪn stupəd."

"Elayne, if that is your name, all that keeps me from dragging you down to the kitchen and washing your mouth out, yours and that other foolish girl's there, is the possibility that you actually can channel somewhat. Or are you silly enough to wear that ring when you can't even do that? I warn you, it will make no difference to the sisters over in the Tara-sin Palace. Do you even know about them? If you do, frankly, you are not foolish, you're blind stupid."

ɪleɪnz tɛmpɝ ɡɹu baɪ ðə wɝd. fulɪʃ ɡɝl? blaɪn stupəd? ʃi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪt, ɪspɛʃli nɑt ɹaɪɾ æftɝ biɪŋ fɔɹs tə kɹɔl tə mæt kɔθən. dændəl? mæt kɔθən? ʃi meɪnteɪn əɹ aʊtwɝd kəmpoʊʒɝ, ðoʊ, bʌt nɑt soʊ nɪneɪiv.

Elayne's temper grew by the word. Foolish girl? Blind stupid? She would not put up with it, especially not right after being forced to crawl to Mat Cauthon. Dandle? Mat Cauthon? She maintained her outward composure, though, but not so Nynaeve.

ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ɪn ə fjʊɹi, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛnvɛləpt əɹ əz ʃi baʊndəd tə hɝ fit. floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ɹæp mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən fɹəm ʃoʊldɝz tə æŋkəlz, kɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən pɛɾikoʊts əɡɛnst əɹ lɛɡz, dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪɾ ɪnʌf tə tɑpəl hɝ. "aɪ hæpən tə bi wʌn ə ðoʊz sɪstɝz ɪn ðə pæləs. nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, tə bi ɪɡzækt. naʊ wəd jə laɪk mi tə kæɹi jə daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃənz? aɪ noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ə haʊ tə wɑʃ aʊɾ ə maʊθ." ɪleɪn stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪnkipɝz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ɑɹm.

She glared in a fury, and the glow of saidar enveloped her as she bounded to her feet. Flows of Air wrapped mistress Anan from shoulders to ankles, crushing her skirts and petticoats against her legs, just short of tight enough to topple her. "I happen to be one of those sisters in the palace. Nynaeve al'Meara of the Yellow Ajah, to be exact. Now would you like me to carry you down to the kitchens? I know something of how to wash out a mouth." Elayne stepped away from the innkeeper's outstretched arm.

ðə wʊmən hæd tə fil ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə ðə floʊz, ən ivən ə hæf-wɪt wʊɾə noʊn wʌt ðoʊz ɪnvɪzəbəl bɑnz mʌs bi, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt blɪŋk! hɝ ɡɹin-flɛkt aɪz nɛɹoʊd, noʊ mɔɹ. "soʊ wʌn ə jə kən tʃænəl, ət list," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "aɪ ʃəd lɛt jə dʒɹæɡ mi daʊnstɛɹz, tʃaɪld. wʌtɛvɝ jə də tə mi, jə wəd bi ɪn ðə hænz ə ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ baɪ nun; əl weɪdʒɝ ðæt."

The woman had to feel the pressure of the flows, and even a half-wit would have known what those invisible bonds must be, yet she did not blink! Her green-flecked eyes narrowed, no more. "So one of you can channel, at least," she said calmly. "I should let you drag me downstairs, child. Whatever you do to me, you would be in the hands of real Aes Sedai by noon; I'll wager that."

"dɪdn jə hɪɹ mi?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "aɪ - !"

"Didn't you hear me?" Nynaeve demanded. "I - !"

ði ɑnən wʊmən dɪd nɑɾ ivən pɔz. "jul nɑɾ oʊnli spɛn ðə nɛks jɪɹ blʌbɝɪŋ, jəl də pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛniwʌn jə toʊl ðət jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. bi ʃʊɹ, ðəl meɪk jə tɛl. ðəl tɝn jəɹ lɪvɝ tə wɔɾɝ. aɪ ʃəd lɛt jə ɡoʊ blʌndɝɪŋ ɑn jəɹ weɪ, əɹ ɛls ɹʌn əkɹɔs tə ðə pæləs əz sun əz jə lus mi. ði oʊnli ɹizən aɪ doʊn ɪz ðət ðəl meɪk ən ɪɡzæmpəl ə lɔɹd mæt nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ə ju, ɪf ðeɪ ivən səspɛk hiz hɛlp ju, ən əz aɪ sɛd, aɪ laɪk ðə jʌŋ mæn."

The Anan woman did not even pause. "You'll not only spend the next year blubbering, you will do part of it in front of anyone you told that you are Aes Sedai. Be sure, they'll make you tell. They will turn your liver to water. I should let you go blundering on your way, or else run across to the palace as soon as you loose me. The only reason I don't is that they'll make an example of Lord Mat nearly as much as of you, if they even suspect he's helped you, and as I said, I like the young man."

"aɪm tɛlɪŋ jə - " nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, bʌt stɪl ði ɪnkipɝ ɡeɪv əɹ noʊ tʃæns tə tɛl ɛniθɪŋ. taɪd laɪk ə bʌndəl, ðə wʊmən wɑz ə boʊldɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊnhɪl. ʃi wɑz ðə hoʊl hɪlsaɪd fɔlɪŋ, flæɾənɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ leɪ ɪn ɪts pæθ.

"I'm telling you - " Nynaeve tried again, but still the innkeeper gave her no chance to tell anything. Tied like a bundle, the woman was a boulder rolling downhill. She was the whole hillside falling, flattening whatever lay in its path.

"tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ʌp ðə laɪ dʌz noʊ ɡʊd, nɪneɪiv. jə lʊk tə bi, oʊ, twɛnti-wʌn ɡɪv əɹ teɪk ə jɪɹ, soʊ jə maɪt bi əz mʌtʃ əz tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ɪf juv ɔlɹɛɾi ɹitʃt ðə sloʊɪŋ. jə maɪɾ ivən əv wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl fɔɹ əɹ faɪv jɪɹz. ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ." hɝ hɛd, ði oʊnli pɑɹɾ ə hɝ ʃi kəd muv, swɪvəl təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪn. "ju, tʃaɪld, ɑɹən oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv sloʊd jɛt, ən noʊ wʊmən əz ɛvɝ wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl əz jʌŋ əz ju. nɛvɝ ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə taʊɝ. ɪf jə ɛvɝ wɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, əl weɪdʒɝ jə wɔɹ waɪɾ ən skwikt ɛvɹi taɪm ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ɡlæns jəɹ weɪ. jə hæd səm ɡoʊldsmɪθ meɪk ðət ɹɪŋ fəɹ jə - ðəɹ ɑɹ səm ful ɪnʌf, aɪ hɪɹ - əɹ meɪbi nɪneɪiv stoʊl ɪt fəɹ ju, ɪf ʃiz ɛni ɹaɪt tə hɝz. iðɝ weɪ, sɪns jə kæn bi ə sɪstɝ, niðɝ kən ʃi. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd tʃɹævəl wɪð ə wʊmən u wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ."

"Trying to keep up the lie does no good, Nynaeve. You look to be, oh, twenty-one give or take a year, so you might be as much as ten years older if you've already reached the slowing. You might even have worn the shawl four or five years. Except for one thing." Her head, the only part of her she could move, swiveled toward Elayne. "You, child, aren't old enough to have slowed yet, and no woman has ever worn the shawl as young as you. Never in the history of the Tower. If you ever were in the Tower, I'll wager you wore white and squeaked every time the Mistress of Novices glanced your way. You had some goldsmith make that ring for you - there are some fool enough, I hear - or maybe Nynaeve stole it for you, if she has any right to hers. Either way, since you can't be a sister, neither can she. No Aes Sedai would travel with a woman who was pretending."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd, nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz tʃuɪŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp. sloʊd. sloʊɪŋ. haʊ dɪɾ ən ɪnkipɝ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ noʊ ðoʊz wɝdz? meɪbi sɛɾəl ɑnən hæd ɡɔn tə ðə taʊɝ əz ə ɡɝl, ðoʊ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋ, sɪns ʃi klɪɹli kəd nɑt tʃænəl. ɪleɪn wʊɾə noʊn ivən ɪf əɹ əbɪləɾi hæd bɪn əz smɔl əz əɹ oʊn mʌðɝz, ən mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkən hæd hæɾ ən əbɪləɾi soʊ smɔl ʃi wʊɾə bɪn sɛn əweɪ ɪn ə mæɾɝ ʌv wiks pɹɑbli, hæd ʃi nɑt bɪn ɛɹ tə ə stʃɹɔŋ haʊs.

Elayne frowned, not noticing that she was chewing her lower lip. Slowed. Slowing. How did an innkeeper in Ebou Dar know those words? Maybe Setalle Anan had gone to the Tower as a girl, though she would not have remained long, since she clearly could not channel. Elayne would have known even if her ability had been as small as her own mother's, and Morgase Trakand had had an ability so small she would have been sent away in a matter of weeks probably, had she not been heir to a strong House.

"ɹilis hɝ, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ. ʃi tʃɹuli dɪd fil mɔɹ wɛl-dɪspoʊz təwɔɹd ðə wʊmən, naʊ. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn tɛɹəbəl tə meɪk ðət dʒɝni tə tɑɹ vəlɑn oʊnli tə bi tɝn əweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən ðə wʊmən hæd tə bɪliv əm - sʌmθɪŋ tɪkəld ət ðæt, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ wʌt - noʊ ɹizən əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd meɪd ðə tʃɹɪp tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, meɪbi ʃi wəd wɔk əkɹɔs ðə mɔl hɛɹə. mɛɝɪlɪl, əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, kəd sɛɾ əɹ stʃɹeɪt.

"Release her, Nynaeve," she said, smiling. She truly did feel more well-disposed toward the woman, now. It must have been terrible to make that journey to Tar Valon only to be turned away. There was no reason the woman had to believe them - something tickled at that, but she could not say what - no reason at all, but if she had made the trip to Tar Valon, maybe she would walk across the Mol Hara. Merilille, or any of the other sisters, could set her straight.

"ɹilis hɝ?" nɪneɪiv jɛlpt. "ɪleɪn?"

"Release her?" Nynaeve yelped. "Elayne?"

"ɹilis hɝ. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, aɪ si ði oʊnli weɪ tə kənvɪns jə ɪz - "

"Release her. Mistress Anan, I see the only way to convince you is - "

"ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ən θɹi sɪɾɝz kʊdn kənvɪns mi, tʃaɪld." laɪt, dɪd ʃi ɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛniwʌn fɪnɪʃ ə sɛntəns? "naʊ, aɪ doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ ɛni mɔɹ ɡeɪmz. aɪ kən hɛlp ðə pɛɹ ə ju. aɪ noʊ ðoʊz u kæn, ɛniweɪ, səm wɪmən u teɪk ɪn stʃɹeɪz. jə kən θæŋk lɔɹd mæt ðəɾ aɪm wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk jə tə ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ mʌs noʊ. wɝ jə ɛvɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, əɹ ɑɹ jə waɪldɝz? ɪf jə wɝ ðɛɹ, wɝ jə pʊɾ aʊt, əɹ dɪd jə ɹʌn əweɪ? ðə tʃɹuθ. ðeɪ hændəl itʃ ɪn ə dɪfɹənt weɪ."

"The Amyrlin Seat and three Sitters couldn't convince me, child." Light, did she ever let anyone finish a sentence? "Now, I don't have time for any more games. I can help the pair of you. I know those who can, anyway, some women who take in strays. You can thank Lord Mat that I'm willing to take you to them, but I must know. Were you ever in the Tower, or are you wilders? If you were there, were you put out, or did you run away? The truth. They handle each in a different way."

ɪleɪn ʃɹʌɡd. ðeɪ hæd dʌn wʌt ðeɪ keɪm fɔɹ; ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɹɛɾi tə stɑp weɪstɪŋ taɪm ən ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð wʌt niɾəd duɪŋ nɛkst. "ɪf jə woʊn bi kənvɪnst, ðən ðæts ɔl ðəɹ ɪz tə ɪt. nɪneɪiv? ɪts pæs taɪm wi wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ."

Elayne shrugged. They had done what they came for; she was more than ready to stop wasting time and get on with what needed doing next. "If you won't be convinced, then that's all there is to it. Nynaeve? It is past time we were on our way."

ðə floʊz ɝaʊn ði ɪnkipɝ vænɪʃt, ən ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv tu, bʌt nɪneɪiv stʊd ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊmən wɛɹəli, hoʊpfəli. ʃi wɛɾ əɹ lɪps. "ju noʊ ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən u kən hɛlp ʌs?"

The flows around the innkeeper vanished, and the glow around Nynaeve too, but Nynaeve stood there watching the woman warily, hopefully. She wet her lips. "You know a group of women who can help us?"

"nɪneɪiv?" ɪleɪn sɛd. "wi doʊnt niɾ ɛni hɛlp. wəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ?"

"Nynaeve?" Elayne said. "We don't need any help. We are Aes Sedai, remember?"

wɪð ə ɹaɪ ɡlæns ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɡeɪv əɹ skɝts ə ʃeɪk tə stʃɹeɪɾən əm ən bɛn tə smuð əɹ ɪkspoʊz pɛɾikoʊts. hɝ ɹil ətɛnʃən wɑz ɑn nɪneɪiv; ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ fɛl soʊ kəmplitli ʃʌntɪɾ əsaɪɾ ɪn əɹ laɪf. "aɪ noʊ ə fju wɪmən u teɪk ɪn ði əkeɪʒənəl waɪldɝ əɹ ɹʌnəweɪ əɹ wʊmən u feɪld əɹ tɛs fəɹ æksɛptɪɾ əɹ ðə ʃɔl. ðəɹ mʌs bi ət lis fɪfti ʌv ðɛm, ɔltəɡɛðɝ, ðoʊ ðə nʌmbɝ tʃeɪnʒəz. ðeɪ kən hɛlp jə faɪn ə laɪf wɪθaʊt ðə ɹɪsk ʌv ə ɹil sɪstɝ meɪkɪŋ jə wɪʃ ʃid dʒʌst skɪn jə ən bi dʌn. naʊ, doʊn laɪ tə mi. wɝ jə ɛvɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ? ɪf juv ɹʌn əweɪ, jə maɪɾ əz wɛl dɪsaɪd tə ɡoʊ bæk. ðə taʊɝ mænədʒ tə faɪn moʊst ɹʌnəweɪz ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, soʊ jə nidn θɪŋk ðɪs lɪɾəl bɑðɝ naʊ wɪl stɑp ðɛm. ɪn tʃɹuθ, maɪ sədʒɛstʃən ðən wəd bi tə ɡoʊ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ ən θɹoʊ jɝsɛlf ɑn ə sɪstɝz mɝsi. ɪɾəl bi ə smɔl mɝsi, aɪm əfɹeɪd, bʌt jə kən bɪliv mi, ɪts mɔɹ ðən jəl faɪn ɪf ðeɪv tə dʒɹæɡ jə bæk. jə woʊn ivən θɪŋk ə soʊ mʌtʃ əz livɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən æftɝ ðæt."

With a wry glance in her direction, Mistress Anan gave her skirts a shake to straighten them and bent to smooth her exposed petticoats. Her real attention was on Nynaeve; Elayne had never felt so completely shunted aside in her life. "I know a few women who take in the occasional wilder or runaway or woman who failed her test for Accepted or the shawl. There must be at least fifty of them, altogether, though the number changes. They can help you find a life without the risk of a real sister making you wish she'd just skin you and be done. Now, don't lie to me. Were you ever in the Tower? If you've run away, you might as well decide to go back. The Tower managed to find most runaways even during the War of the Hundred Years, so you needn't think this little bother now will stop them. In truth, my suggestion then would be to go across the square and throw yourself on a sister's mercy. It will be a small mercy, I'm afraid, but you can believe me, it's more than you'll find if they have to drag you back. You won't even think of so much as leaving the Tower grounds without permission after that."

nɪneɪiv dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "wi wɝ toʊl tə liv ðə taʊɝ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən. əl swɛɹ tə ðət haʊɛvɝ jə æsk."

Nynaeve drew a deep breath. "We were told to leave the Tower, Mistress Anan. I will swear to that however you ask."

ɪleɪn stɛɹɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "nɪneɪiv, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ? mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, wəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Elayne stared in disbelief. "Nynaeve, what are you saying? Mistress Anan, we are Aes Sedai."

ði ɑnən wʊmən læft. "tʃaɪld, lemi tɔk wɪð nɪneɪiv, hu ət list simz oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv sɛns. jə tɛl ðə sɝkəl ðæt, ən ðəl nɑt teɪk ɪt kaɪnli. ðeɪ woʊn kɛɹ jə kən tʃænəl; ðeɪ kæn, tu, ən ðəl smæk jəɹ bɑɾəm əɹ tɔs jə aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ ɑn jəɹ noʊz ɪf jə pleɪ ðə ful."

The Anan woman laughed. "Child, let me talk with Nynaeve, who at least seems old enough to have sense. You tell the Circle that, and they will not take it kindly. They won't care you can channel; they can, too, and they'll smack your bottom or toss you out in the street on your nose if you play the fool."

"hu ɪz ðɪs sɝkəl?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd. "wi ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə kʌm əkɹɔs tə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, ən jəl si."

"Who is this Circle?" Elayne demanded. "We are Aes Sedai. You come across to the Tarasin Palace, and you will see."

"aɪl kip əɹ ɪn hænd," nɪneɪiv hæd ðə ɡɔl tə seɪ, ɔl ðə waɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ ən ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ðə wʌn u hæd ɡɔn mæd.

"I'll keep her in hand," Nynaeve had the gall to say, all the while frowning and grimacing at Elayne as if she were the one who had gone mad.

ði ɑnən wʊmən mɪɹli nɑɾəd. "ɡʊd. naʊ teɪk ɔf ðoʊz ɹɪŋz ən pʊɾ əm əweɪ. ðə sɝkəl dʌzn əlaʊ ðət sɔɹɾ ə pɹitɛndɪŋ. ðəl əv əm mɛltəd daʊn tə ɡɪv jə ə stɑɹt. ðoʊ baɪ ðə lʊk ə jəɹ dʒɹɛsəz, juv kɔɪn. ɪf jə stoʊl ɪt, doʊn lɛt ɹin noʊ. wʌn ə ðə fɝst ɹulz jəl əv tə lɝn ɪz, doʊn stil ivən ɪf jə ɑɹ stɑɹvɪŋ. ðeɪ doʊnt wɑnə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən."

The Anan woman merely nodded. "Good. Now take off those rings and put them away. The Circle doesn't allow that sort of pretending. They'll have them melted down to give you a start. Though by the look of your dresses, you have coin. If you stole it, don't let Reanne know. One of the first rules you'll have to learn is, don't steal even if you are starving. They don't want to draw attention."

ɪleɪn meɪɾ ə fɪst ən θɹʌst ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ən wɑtʃt nɪneɪiv mikli slɪp əɹ ɹɪŋ ɔf ən tʌk ɪɾ ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ. nɪneɪiv, hu haʊld ɛvɹi taɪm mɛɝɪlɪl əɹ æɾɪliz əɹ ɛni ʌv əm fɝɡɑt ʃi wɑz ə fʊl sɪstɝ!

Elayne made a fist and thrust it behind her back. And watched Nynaeve meekly slip her ring off and tuck it into her belt pouch. Nynaeve, who howled every time Merilille or Adeleas or any of them forgot she was a full sister!

"tʃɹʌs mi, ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"Trust me, Elayne," Nynaeve said.

wɪtʃ ɪleɪn wʊɾə hæɾ ən iziɝ taɪm ʌv ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛni noʊʃən wʌt ðə wʊmən wɑz ʌp tə. stɪl, ʃi dɪd tʃɹʌs hɝ. moʊsli. "ə smɔl sækɹəfaɪs," ʃi mʌɾɝd. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ ɹɪŋz wən ðə niɾ ɝoʊz, ən ʃi hæd tu, waɪl pæsɪŋ fəɹ ə sɪstɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɝz baɪ ɹaɪt, naʊ. ɹimuvɪŋ ðət bæn ʌv ɡoʊld ɔlmoʊs hɝt fɪzɪkəli.

Which Elayne would have had an easier time of if she had any notion what the woman was up to. Still, she did trust her. Mostly. "A small sacrifice," she muttered. Aes Sedai did go without their rings when the need arose, and she had too, while passing for a sister, but it was hers by right, now. Removing that band of gold almost hurt physically.

"tɔk tə jəɹ fɹɛnd, tʃaɪld," ði ɑnən wʊmən toʊl nɪneɪiv ɪmpeɪʃənli. "ɹin kɔɹli woʊn pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɔl ðɪs sʌlki paʊɾɪŋ, ən ɪf jə meɪk mi weɪs maɪ mɔɹnɪŋ fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. . . . kʌm əlɔŋ, kʌm əlɔŋ. ɪts lʌki fəɹ jə aɪ laɪk lɔɹd mæt."

"Talk to your friend, child," the Anan woman told Nynaeve impatiently. "Reanne Corly won't put up with all this sulky pouting, and if you make me waste my morning for nothing. . . . Come along, come along. It's lucky for you I like Lord Mat."

ɪleɪn hɛld ɑn tə kul kəmpoʊʒɝ baɪ ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl. sʌlki paʊɾɪŋ? sʌlki paʊɾɪŋ? wən ʃi hæd ðə tʃæns, ʃi wɑz gɑnə kɪk nɪneɪiv wɛɹ ɪt hɝt!

Elayne held on to cool composure by a fingernail. Sulky pouting? Sulky pouting? When she had the chance, she was going to kick Nynaeve where it hurt!


tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi


CHAPTER 23

nɛks dɔɹ tə ə wivɝ


Next Door to a Weaver

nɪneɪiv dɪd wɑnə tɔk tə ɪleɪn, əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪnkipɝz ɪɹz, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt faɪn ðə tʃæns ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ðə wʊmən mɑɹtʃt əm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum duɪŋ ə faɪn ɪməteɪʃən ʌv ə ɡɑɹɾ ɑn pɹɪznɝz, hɝ stoʊni ɪmpeɪʃəns ʌndəntɪd baɪ ðə wɛɹi lʊk ʃi kæst ət mæts dɔɹ. ət ðə bæk ə ði ɪn ə sɛɾ ʌv ənɹeɪl stoʊn stɛps lɛd daʊn ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ hɑt kɪtʃən fʊl ə beɪkɪŋ smɛlz, wɛɹ ðə ɹaʊndəst wʊmən nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɛvɝ sin wɑz wildɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ wʊɾən spun laɪk ə sɛptɝ, dɝɛktɪŋ θɹi ʌðɝz ɪn slaɪɾɪŋ kɹʌsti bɹaʊn loʊvz fɹəm ði ʌvənz ən ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əm wɪð ɹoʊlz ə peɪl doʊ. ə lɑɹdʒ pɑɾ ə ðə kɔɹs waɪt pɔɹədʒ ðət wɑz iɾən fəɹ bɹɛkfəs hɪɹəbaʊt bʌbəl dʒɛnli ɑn wʌn ə ðə waɪt-taɪl stoʊvz.

Nynaeve did want to talk to Elayne, away from the innkeeper's ears, but she did not find the chance right away. The woman marched them out of the room doing a fine imitation of a guard on prisoners, her stony impatience undented by the wary look she cast at Mat's door. At the back of the inn a set of unrailed stone steps led down into a large hot kitchen full of baking smells, where the roundest woman Nynaeve had ever seen was wielding a large wooden spoon like a scepter, directing three others in sliding crusty brown loaves from the ovens and replacing them with rolls of pale dough. A large pot of the coarse white porridge that was eaten for breakfast hereabout bubbled gently on one of the white-tiled stoves.

"inɪd," mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ədʒɹɛs ðə ɹaʊnd wʊmən, "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl. aɪ nid tə teɪk ðiz tu tʃɪlʒɹən tə sʌmwʌn u hæz taɪm tə mʌðɝ əm pɹɑpɝli."

"Enid," Mistress Anan addressed the round woman, "I am going out for a little while. I need to take these two children to someone who has time to mother them properly."

waɪpɪŋ bɹɔd, flaʊɝi hænz ɑn ə pis ʌv waɪt taʊəlɪŋ, inɪd stʌɾid nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn dɪsəpɹuvɪŋli. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɑz ɹaʊnd, hɝ swɛɾi ɑləv-skɪn feɪs, hɝ dɑɹk aɪz, ɔl ə hɝ; ʃi simd meɪɾ ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ bɔlz stʌft ɪndə ə dʒɹɛs. ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf ʃi wɔɹ hæŋɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ snoʊi eɪpɹən spɑɹkəld wɪð ə fʊl dʌzən stoʊnz. "ɪz ðɪs ðə pɛɹ ə bɑɹkɝz kɛɹə wɑz tʃæɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt, mɪstʃɹəs? fænsi bɪts fəɹ ðə jʌŋ lɔɹdz teɪst, aɪɾ əv sɛd. hi laɪks əm wɪð ə bɪɾ ʌv wɪɡəl." ðəɾ əmjuz hɝ, baɪ hɝ toʊn. ði ɪnkipɝ ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn vɛkseɪʃən. "aɪ toʊl ðət ɡɝl tə hoʊld əɹ tʌŋ. aɪ woʊn lɛt ðət sɔɹɾ ə ɹumɝ tʌtʃ ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən. ɹimaɪn kɛɹə fəɹ mi, inɪd, ən juz jəɹ spun tə ɡɛɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən, ɪf nid bi." ðə ɡeɪz ʃi tɝn ɑn nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɑz soʊ dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ðət nɪneɪiv nɪɹli ɡæspt. "wʊɾ ɛniwʌn wɪð hæf ðɛɹ wɪts bɪliv ðiz tu wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ? spɛn ɔl ðɛɹ kɔɪn ɑn dʒɹɛsəz tə ɪmpɹɛs ðə mæn, ən naʊ ðeɪd stɑɹv ənlɛs ðeɪ smaɪl fəɹ hɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ!" ɡɪvɪŋ inɪd noʊ tʃæns tə ænsɝ, ʃi siz nɪneɪivz ɪɹ wɪð əɹ ɹaɪt hænd, ɪleɪnz wɪð əɹ lɛft, ən ɪn θɹi kwɪk stɛps hæɾ əm aʊɾ ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹd.

Wiping broad, floury hands on a piece of white toweling, Enid studied Nynaeve and Elayne disapprovingly. Everything about her was round, her sweaty olive-skinned face, her dark eyes, all of her; she seemed made of very large balls stuffed into a dress. The marriage knife she wore hanging outside her snowy apron sparkled with a full dozen stones. "Is this the pair of barkers Caira was chattering about, Mistress? Fancy bits for the young Lord's taste, I'd have said. He likes them with a bit of wiggle." That amused her, by her tone. The innkeeper shook her head in vexation. "I told that girl to hold her tongue. I won't let that sort of rumor touch The Wandering Woman. Remind Caira for me, Enid, and use your spoon to get her attention, if need be." The gaze she turned on Nynaeve and Elayne was so disparaging that Nynaeve nearly gasped. "Would anyone with half their wits believe these two were Aes Sedai? Spent all their coin on dresses to impress the man, and now they'd starve unless they smile for him. Aes Sedai!" Giving Enid no chance to answer, she seized Nynaeve's ear with her right hand, Elayne's with her left, and in three quick steps had them out into the stableyard.

ðət wɑz əz lɔŋ əz nɪneɪivz ʃɑk hɛld. ðən ʃi pʊl fɹi, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə, kəz ðə wʊmən lɛt ɡoʊ ət ðə seɪm ɪnstən ən ʃi stʌmbəl hæf ə dʌzən peɪsɪz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɪndɪɡnənli. ʃi hæd nɑt bɑɹɡən fəɹ biɪŋ dʒɹæɡd əbaʊt. ɪleɪnz tʃɪn ɹoʊz, hɝ blu aɪz soʊ koʊl nɪneɪiv wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə si fɹɔs fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn əɹ kɝlz.

That was as long as Nynaeve's shock held. Then she pulled free, or tried to, because the woman let go at the same instant and she stumbled half a dozen paces, glaring indignantly. She had not bargained for being dragged about. Elayne's chin rose, her blue eyes so cold Nynaeve would not have been surprised to see frost forming in her curls.

hænz ɑn hɪps, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs. əɹ pɝhæps ʃi sɪmpli dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. "aɪ kən hoʊp noʊ wʌn ɪn ðəɹ bɪlivz kɛɹə æftɝ ðæt," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "ɪf aɪ cʊɾə bɪn ʃʊɹ jə hæd ðə wɪts tə kip jəɹ maʊðz ʃʌt, aɪɾ əv sɛɾ ən dʌn mɔɹ, ən meɪd sɝɾən." ʃi wɑz kɑm, bʌt nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plɛzən əɹ sɑft; ðeɪ hæd tʃɹʌbəld əɹ mɔɹnɪŋ. "naʊ fɑloʊ mi ən doʊnt ɡɛt lɔst. əɹ ɪf jə du, də nɑt ʃoʊ jəɹ feɪsəz ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ maɪ ɪn əɡɛn, əɹ əl sɛn sʌmbɑɾi tə ðə pæləs tə tɛl mɛɝɪlɪl ən tɛslɪn. ðeɪ ɑɹ tu ʌv ðə ɹil sɪstɝz, ən ðəl pɹɑbli ɹɪp jə itʃ daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ən ʃɛɹ jə aʊt."

Hands on hips, Mistress Anan seemed not to notice. Or perhaps she simply did not care. "I can hope no one in there believes Caira after that," she said calmly. "If I could have been sure you had the wits to keep your mouths shut, I'd have said and done more, and made certain." She was calm, but not at all pleasant or soft; they had troubled her morning. "Now follow me and don't get lost. Or if you do, do not show your faces anywhere near my inn again, or I'll send somebody to the palace to tell Merilille and Teslyn. They are two of the real sisters, and they'll probably rip you each down the middle and share you out."

ɪleɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ɡeɪz fɹəm ði ɪnkipɝ tə nɪneɪiv. nɑɾ ə ɡlɛɹ, əɹ ə fɹaʊn, jɛɾ ə vɛɹi minɪŋ lʊk dʒʌs ðə seɪm. nɪneɪiv wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi eɪbəl tə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ðɪs. ðə θɔɾ ə mæt kənvɪns hɝ; ɛni tʃæns wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt.

Elayne shifted her gaze from the innkeeper to Nynaeve. Not a glare, or a frown, yet a very meaning look just the same. Nynaeve wondered whether she was going to be able to go through with this. The thought of Mat convinced her; any chance was better than that.

"wi woʊn luz aʊɝsɛlvz, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹaɪvɪŋ fəɹ miknəs. ʃi θɔt ʃi dɪd fɛɹli wɛl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ fɔɹən miknəs wɑz tə hɝ. "θæŋk jə fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ ʌs." smaɪlɪŋ ət ði ɪnkipɝ, ʃi dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪleɪn, huz stɛɹ bɪkeɪm mɔɹ minɪŋfəl, hɑɹɾ əz ðət wɑz tə kɹɛɾət. lʊks əɹ noʊ lʊks, ʃi hæd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə wʊmən kəntɪnjud tə θɪŋk əm wɝθ ðə tʃɹʌbəl. "wi ɑɹ tʃɹuli ɡɹeɪtfəl, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən."

"We won't lose ourselves, Mistress Anan," she said, striving for meekness. She thought she did fairly well, considering how foreign meekness was to her. "Thank you for helping us." Smiling at the innkeeper, she did her best to ignore Elayne, whose stare became more meaningful, hard as that was to credit. Looks or no looks, she had to make sure the woman continued to think them worth the trouble. "We are truly grateful, Mistress Anan."

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən aɪɾ əɹ əskæns, ðən snɪft ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. wən ðɪs wɑz dʌn, nɪneɪiv dɪsaɪɾɪd, ʃi wɑz gɑnə dʒɹæɡ ði ɪn-kipɝ tə ðə pæləs, ɪf nid bi, ən meɪk ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz æknɑlɪdʒ əɹ ɪn mɪstʃɹəs ɑnənz pɹɛzəns.

Mistress Anan eyed her askance, then sniffed and shook her head. When this was done, Nynaeve decided, she was going to drag the inn-keeper to the palace, if need be, and make the other sisters acknowledge her in Mistress Anan's presence.

ðɪs ɝli, ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɑz ɛmpti seɪv fəɹ ə loʊn bɔɪ ʌv tɛn əɹ twɛlv wɪð ə bʌkəɾ ən ə sɪv u spɹɪŋkəld wɔɾɝ tə dæmpən ðə hɑɹd-pækt ɡɹaʊn əɡɛns dʌst. ðə waɪt plæstɝd steɪbəlz dɔɹz wɝ waɪɾ oʊpən, ən ə bæɹoʊ sæɾ ɪn fɹʌnt wɪð ə dʌŋ-fɔɹk ɹɛstɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪt. saʊnz laɪk ə hjudʒ fɹɑɡ biɪŋ stɛpt ɑn floʊɾəd aʊt; nɪneɪiv dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz ə mæn sɪŋɪŋ. wəd ðeɪv tə ɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ðɛɹ dɛstəneɪʃən? ivən ə ʃɔɹt dʒɝni wəd nɑt bi plɛzənt; wɔkɪŋ oʊnli əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ ən minɪŋ tə bi bæk bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌn ɹoʊz vɛɹi haɪ, ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt niðɝ hæts nɔɹ pɛɹɑsəlz nɔɹ hʊɾɪd kloʊks.

This early, the stableyard was empty save for a lone boy of ten or twelve with a bucket and a sieve who sprinkled water to dampen the hard-packed ground against dust. The white plastered stable's doors were wide open, and a barrow sat in front with a dung-fork resting across it. Sounds like a huge frog being stepped on floated out; Nynaeve decided it was a man singing. Would they have to ride to reach their destination? Even a short journey would not be pleasant; walking only across the square and meaning to be back before the sun rose very high, they had brought neither hats nor parasols nor hooded cloaks.

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən lɛɾ əm θɹu ðə steɪbliɑɹd, haʊɛvɝ, daʊn ə nɛɹoʊ æliweɪ bɪtwin ðə steɪbəl ən ə haɪ wɔl ðət hæd dʒɹaʊt-bɪdʒɹæɡəl tʃɹiz poʊkɪŋ əbʌv ðə tɑp. sʌmwʌnz ɡɑɹɾən, noʊ daʊt. ə smɔl ɡeɪɾ ət ði ɛn lɛɾ ɪndə ə dʌsti æli soʊ kɹæmp dɔn hæd nɑt kəmplitli ɹitʃt ɪt jɛt.

Mistress Anan led them through the stableyard, however, down a narrow alleyway between the stable and a high wall that had drought-bedraggled trees poking above the top. Someone's garden, no doubt. A small gate at the end let into a dusty alley so cramped dawn had not completely reached it yet.

"ju tʃɪlʒɹən kip ʌp naʊ, maɪn ju," ði ɪnkipɝ toʊl ðɛm, stɑɹɾɪŋ əweɪ daʊn ðə dɪm æli. "ju luz jʊɹsɛlvz, ən aɪ vaʊ əl ɡoʊ tə ðə pæləs maɪsɛlf."

"You children keep up now, mind you," the innkeeper told them, starting away down the dim alley. "You lose yourselves, and I vow I'll go to the palace myself."

nɪneɪiv tʊk ə ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd wɪð boʊθ hænz əz ʃi fɑloʊd, tə kip əm fɹəm ði ɑnən wʊmənz θɹoʊt. haʊ ʃi jɝn fəɹ əɹ fɝst ɡɹeɪ hɛɹz. fɝs ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðən ðə si foʊk - laɪt, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðɛm! - ən naʊ ən ɪnkipɝ! noʊ wʌn tʊk jə sɪɹiəsli əntɪl jə hæɾ ət list ə lɪɾəl ɡɹeɪ; ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪz eɪdʒləs feɪs kəd nɑt pɑsəbli də əz wɛl ɪn əɹ ɛstəmeɪʃən.

Nynaeve took a grip on her braid with both hands as she followed, to keep them from the Anan woman's throat. How she yearned for her first gray hairs. First the other Aes Sedai, then the Sea Folk - Light, she did not want to think about them! - and now an innkeeper! No one took you seriously until you had at least a little gray; even an Aes Sedai's ageless face could not possibly do as well in her estimation.

ɪleɪn wɑz lɪftɪŋ əɹ skɝts aʊɾ ə ðə dʌst, ðoʊ ðɛɹ slɪpɝz stɪl kɪkt ʌp lɪɾəl pʌfs ðət sɛɾəld ɑn ðə hɛmz ə ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz. "lɛt mi si," ɪleɪn sɛd sɔfli, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. sɔfli, bʌt kuli. vɛɹi kuli, ɪn fækt. ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv slæʃɪŋ sʌmwʌn tə tæɾɝz wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ əɹ toʊn hit ðət nɪneɪiv ədmaɪɝd. juʒəwəli. naʊ, ɪt dʒʌs meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə bɑks ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɪɹz. "wi kəd bi bæk ɪn ðə pæləs dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ blubɛɹi ti ən ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə bɹizɪz waɪl wi weɪɾəd fəɹ mæstɝ kɔθən tə muv ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz. pɝhæps eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt maɪt ɹɪtɝn wɪð sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl. wi kəd faɪnəli bi sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪɡzækli wʌt tə də wɪð ðə mæn. də wi sɪmpli fɑloʊ hɪm əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹits ə ðə ɹæhəɾ ən si wʌt hæpənz, əɹ teɪk ɪm ɪndə bɪldɪŋz ðət lʊk laɪkli, əɹ lɛɾ ɪm tʃuz? ðəɹ mʌs bi ə hʌnʒɹəd wɝθwaɪl jusəz fəɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ ɪts seɪf tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ɛɡwin - ɛvɝ - æftɝ ðət bɑɹɡən ðə si foʊk ɹʌŋ aʊɾ ʌv ʌs. wɪv tə tɔk əbaʊt ðət sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ; ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪt woʊn hɛlp. ɪnstɛd, wəɹ ɔf ɑn ə wɔk ə hu noʊz wʌt lɛŋθ, skwɪntɪŋ ɪndə ðə sʌn ðə hoʊl weɪ ɪf wi kip ɑn əz wi ɑɹ, tə vɪzət wɪmən u fid ɹʌnəweɪz fɹəm ðə taʊɝ. maɪsɛlf, aɪ doʊn əv mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn kætʃɪŋ ɹʌnəweɪz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ əɹ ɛni mɔɹnɪŋ. bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ jə kən ɪkspleɪn ɪt soʊ əl ʌndɝstænd. aɪ də soʊ wɑnə ʌndɝstænd, nɪneɪiv. aɪ wəd heɪt tə θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə kɪk jə ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə mɔl hɛɹə fəɹ nʌθɪŋ."

Elayne was lifting her skirts out of the dust, though their slippers still kicked up little puffs that settled on the hems of their dresses. "Let me see," Elayne said softly, looking straight ahead. Softly, but coolly. Very coolly, in fact. She had a way of slashing someone to tatters without letting her tone heat that Nynaeve admired. Usually. Now, it just made her want to box the other woman's ears. "We could be back in the palace drinking blueberry tea and enjoying the breezes while we waited for Master Cauthon to move his belongings. Perhaps Aviendha and Birgitte might return with something useful. We could finally be settling exactly what to do with the man. Do we simply follow him along the streets of the Rahad and see what happens, or take him into buildings that look likely, or let him choose? There must be a hundred worthwhile uses for this morning, including deciding whether it's safe to go back to Egwene - ever - after that bargain the Sea Folk wrung out of us. We have to talk about that sooner or later; ignoring it won't help. Instead, we are off on a walk of who knows what length, squinting into the sun the whole way if we keep on as we are, to visit women who feed runaways from the Tower. Myself, I don't have much interest in catching runaways this morning or any morning. But I'm sure you can explain it so I will understand. I do so want to understand, Nynaeve. I would hate to think I'm going to kick you the length of the Mol Hara for nothing."

nɪneɪivz aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn. kɪk hɝ? ɪleɪn ɹɪli wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ vaɪələnt, spɛndɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð eɪvinhə. sʌmwʌn ɔt tə slæp səm sɛns ɪndə ðət pɛɹ. "ðə sʌn ɪzən haɪ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əs skwɪn jɛt," ʃi mʌɾɝd. ɪt wəd bi sun, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. "θɪŋk, ɪleɪn. fɪfti wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, hɛlpɪŋ waɪldɝz ən wɪmən pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ." ʃi fɛlt ɡɪlti səmtaɪmz, juzɪŋ ðə tɝm waɪldɝz; ɪn ðə maʊðz ə moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪt wɑz ən ɪnsəlt, bʌt ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə meɪk əm spik ɪɾ əz ə bædʒ ə pɹaɪd wʌn deɪ. "ænd ʃi kɔld əm 'ðə sɝkəl.' ðət dʌzn saʊn laɪk ə fju fɹɛnz tə mi. ɪt saʊnz ɔɹɡənaɪzd." ði æli miændɝd bɪtwin haɪ wɔlz ən ðə bæks ə bɪldɪŋz, mɛni ʃoʊɪŋ bɛɹ bɹɪk θɹu ðə plæstɝ, bɪtwin pæləs ɡɑɹɾənz ən ʃɑps wɛɹ ən oʊpən bæk dɔɹ ɹɪvil sɪlvɝsmɪθs əɹ teɪlɝz əɹ wʊdkɑɹvɝz ət wɝk. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ stɪl fɑloʊd. nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ smaɪlz ən nɑdz ʃi hoʊpt wəd kənveɪ iɡɝnəs.

Nynaeve's eyebrows drew down. Kick her? Elayne really was becoming violent, spending so much time with Aviendha. Someone ought to slap some sense into that pair. "The sun isn't high enough to make us squint yet," she muttered. It would be soon, unfortunately. "Think, Elayne. Fifty women who can channel, helping wilders and women put out of the Tower." She felt guilty sometimes, using the term wilders; in the mouths of most Aes Sedai, it was an insult, but she intended to make them speak it as a badge of pride one day. "And she called them 'the Circle.' That doesn't sound like a few friends to me. It sounds organized." The alley meandered between high walls and the backs of buildings, many showing bare brick through the plaster, between palace gardens and shops where an open back door revealed silversmiths or tailors or woodcarvers at work. Every so often Mistress Anan looked over her shoulder to make sure they still followed. Nynaeve gave her smiles and nods she hoped would convey eagerness.

"nɪneɪiv, ɪf tu wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl meɪɾ ə səsaɪəɾi, ðə taʊɝ wəd fɔl ɑn əm laɪk ə pæk ʌv wʊlvz. haʊ wəd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən noʊ wɛðɝ ðeɪ kən əɹ nɑt, ɛniweɪ? wɪmən u kən ən ɑɹən ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt ɡoʊ əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə ʃoʊ ʌv ðɛmsɛlvz, jə noʊ. nɑt fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ, ɛniweɪ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ kæn si ɪt meɪks ə dɪfɝəns. ɛɡwin maɪt wɑnə bɹɪŋ ɛvɹi wʊmən u kən tʃænəl ɪndə ðə taʊɝ sʌmhaʊ, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz nɑt wʌt wəɹ əbaʊt hɪɹ." ðə fɹɔsti peɪʃəns ɪn ɪleɪnz vɔɪs taɪɾənd nɪneɪivz hænz ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd. haʊ kəd ðə wʊmən bi soʊ dɛns? ʃi bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ əɡɛn fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, ən mænədʒ nɑt tə skaʊl ət ði ɪnkipɝz bæk wən əɹ hɛd tɝn fɔɹwɝd wʌns mɔɹ.

"Nynaeve, if two women who could channel made a society, the Tower would fall on them like a pack of wolves. How would Mistress Anan know whether they can or not, anyway? Women who can and aren't Aes Sedai do not go about making a show of themselves, you know. Not for very long, anyway. In any case, I can't see it makes a difference. Egwene might want to bring every woman who can channel into the Tower somehow, but that is not what we are about here." The frosty patience in Elayne's voice tightened Nynaeve's hands on her braid. How could the woman be so dense? She bared her teeth again for Mistress Anan, and managed not to scowl at the innkeeper's back when her head turned forward once more.

"fɪfti wɪmən ɪzən tu," nɪneɪiv wɪspɝd fɪɹsli. ðeɪ kəd tʃænəl; ðeɪ mʌs bi eɪbəl tə; ɛvɹiθɪŋ hɪnʒd ɑn ðæt. "ɪts bɪɑn ɹizən ðət ðɪs sɝkəl kən bi ɪn ðə seɪm sɪɾi wɪð ə stɔɹɹum pæk fʊl ʌv æŋɡɹil ən sətʃ wɪθaʊɾ ət lis noʊɪŋ ʌv ɪt. ən ɪf ðeɪ də . . ." ʃi kəd nɑt kip sæɾəsfækʃən fɹəm hʌniɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. ". . . wɪl əv faʊn ðə boʊl wɪθaʊt mæstɝ meɪtʃɹim kɔθən. wi kən fɝɡɛt ðoʊz əbsɝd pɹɑməsəz."

"Fifty women isn't two," Nynaeve whispered fiercely. They could channel; they must be able to; everything hinged on that. "It's beyond reason that this Circle can be in the same city with a storeroom packed full of angreal and such without at least knowing of it. And if they do . . ." She could not keep satisfaction from honeying her voice. ". . . we'll have found the Bowl without Master Matrim Cauthon. We can forget those absurd promises."

"ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ə bɹaɪb, nɪneɪiv," ɪleɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. "aɪ wɪl kip ðɛm, ən soʊ wɪl ju, ɪf juv ɛni ɑnɝ, ən aɪ noʊ jə du." ʃi wɑz spɛndɪŋ ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð eɪvinhə. nɪneɪiv wɪʃt ʃi nu waɪ ɪleɪn hæd bɪɡʌn θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ ɔl hæd tə fɑloʊ ðɪs pɹɪpɑstɝəs il dʒi-wʌtɛvɝ-ɪt-wɑz.

"They were not a bribe, Nynaeve," Elayne said absently. "I will keep them, and so will you, if you have any honor, and I know you do." She was spending entirely too much time with Aviendha. Nynaeve wished she knew why Elayne had begun thinking they all had to follow this preposterous Aiel ji-whatever-it-was.

ɪleɪn bɪɾ əɹ ʌndɝlɪp, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ɔl ðəɾ aɪsaɪnəs sim tə hæv vænɪʃt; ʃi wɑz hɝsɛlf əɡɛn, əpɛɹənli. faɪnəli ʃi sɛd, "wi wəd nɛvɝ əv ɡɔn tə ði ɪn wɪθaʊt mæstɝ kɔθən, soʊ wid nɛvɝ əv mɛt ðə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən əɹ bɪn teɪkən tə ðɪs sɝkəl. soʊ ɪf ðə sɝkəl dʌz lɛɾ əs tə ðə boʊl, wɪv tə seɪ hi wɑz ðə ɹut kɑz."

Elayne bit her underlip, frowning. All that iciness seemed to have vanished; she was herself again, apparently. Finally she said, "We would never have gone to the inn without Master Cauthon, so we'd never have met the remarkable Mistress Anan or been taken to this Circle. So if the Circle does lead us to the Bowl, we have to say he was the root cause."

mæt kɔθən; hɪz neɪm bɔɪld ɪn əɹ hɛd. nɪneɪiv stʌmbəld oʊvɝ əɹ oʊn fiɾ ən lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv əɹ bɹeɪd tə lɪft əɹ skɝts. ði æli wɑz hɑɹdli əz smuð əz ə peɪv skwɛɹ mʌtʃ lɛs ə pæləs flɔɹ. ət taɪmz, ɪleɪn ɪn ə teɪkɪŋ wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ɪleɪn θɪŋkɪŋ klɪɹli. "ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "aɪl 'ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl' hɝ tɪl əɹ aɪz kɹɔs. noʊ wʌn əz ɛvɝ tʃɹiɾəd əs ðɪs weɪ, ɪleɪn, nɑɾ ivən pipəl u daʊɾɪd, nɑɾ ivən ðə si foʊk. moʊs pipəl wəd stɛp wɛɹi ɪf ə tɛn-jɪɹ-oʊl sɛd ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Mat Cauthon; his name boiled in her head. Nynaeve stumbled over her own feet and let go of her braid to lift her skirts. The alley was hardly as smooth as a paved square much less a palace floor. At times, Elayne in a taking was better than Elayne thinking clearly. "Remarkable," she muttered. "I'll 'remarkable' her till her eyes cross. No one has ever treated us this way, Elayne, not even people who doubted, not even the Sea Folk. Most people would step wary if a ten-year-old said she was Aes Sedai."

"moʊs pipəl doʊn ɹɪli noʊ wʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs lʊks laɪk, nɪneɪiv. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wɛn tə ðə taʊɝ wʌns; ʃi noʊz θɪŋz ʃi kʊdnt, ʌðɝwaɪz."

"Most people don't really know what an Aes Sedai's face looks like, Nynaeve. I think she went to the Tower once; she knows things she couldn't, otherwise."

nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə ðə wʊmən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əhɛd. sɛɾəl ɑnən maɪɾ əv bɪn tə ðə taʊɝ tɛn taɪmz, ə hʌnʒɹəd, bʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə æknɑlɪdʒ nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə əz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən əpɑlədʒaɪz. ən lɝn wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk tə bi hɔld əbaʊt baɪ hɝ ɪɹ, tu! mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɡlæns bæk, ən nɪneɪiv flæʃt əɹ ə ɹɪdʒəd smaɪl, nɑɾəd əz ɪf əɹ nɛk wɑz ə hɪnʒ. "ɪleɪn? ɪf ðiz wɪmən də noʊ wɛɹ ðə boʊl ɪz. . . . wi doʊn əv tə tɛl mæt haʊ wi faʊn ɪt." ðət wɑz nɑt kwaɪɾ ə kwɛstʃən.

Nynaeve snorted, glowering at the back of the woman striding ahead. Setalle Anan might have been to the Tower ten times, a hundred, but she was going to acknowledge Nynaeve al'Meara as Aes Sedai. And apologize. And learn what it was like to be hauled about by her ear, too! Mistress Anan glanced back, and Nynaeve flashed her a rigid smile, nodded as if her neck was a hinge. "Elayne? If these women do know where the Bowl is. . . . We don't have to tell Mat how we found it." That was not quite a question.

"aɪ də nɑt si waɪ," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ðən dæʃt ɔl əɹ hoʊps baɪ æɾɪŋ, "bʌɾ əl əv tə æsk eɪvinhə tə bi ʃʊɹ."

"I do not see why," Elayne replied, then dashed all her hopes by adding, "But I'll have to ask Aviendha to be sure."

ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt ði ɑnən wʊmən maɪɾ əbændən əm ɑn ðə spɑt, nɪneɪiv wəɾ əv skɹimd.

If she had not thought the Anan woman might abandon them on the spot, Nynaeve would have screamed.

ðə wɑndɝɪŋ æli ɡeɪv weɪ tə ə stʃɹit, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɔkɪŋ ðən tə əmaʊn tə ɛniθɪŋ. ðə sʌnz θɪn ɹɪm ɡlɛɹd blaɪndɪŋli əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps əhɛd; ɪleɪn ʃeɪɾɪd əɹ aɪz wɪð wʌn hæn vɛɹi ɑstənteɪʃəsli. nɪneɪiv ɹəfjuz tə. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət bæd. ʃi bɛɹli hæd tə skwɪn əɾ ɔl, ɹɪli. ə klɪɹ blu skaɪ mɑkt əɹ wɛðɝ sɛns, ðət stɪl toʊld əɹ ə stɔɹm wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðə sɪɾi.

The wandering alley gave way to a street, and there was no talking then to amount to anything. The sun's thin rim glared blindingly above the rooftops ahead; Elayne shaded her eyes with one hand very ostentatiously. Nynaeve refused to. It was not that bad. She barely had to squint at all, really. A clear blue sky mocked her weather sense, that still told her a storm was right on top of the city.

ivən ðɪs ɝli ə fju bɹaɪtli lækɝd koʊtʃɪz wɝ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðə waɪndɪŋ stʃɹits, ən ə dʌbəl fɪsfəl ə bɹaɪɾɝ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz, tu əɹ səmtaɪmz fɔɹ bɛɹfʊt bɛɹɝz ɪn ɡɹin-ænd-ɹɛd stʃɹaɪp vɛsts tə itʃ, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ kəz ðeɪ kæɹid pæsənʒɝz hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɹɪld wʊɾən skɹinz. kɑɹts ən wæɡənz ɹʌmbəld oʊvɝ ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ən pipəl bɪɡæn tə fɪl ðə stʃɹits əz ʃɑp dɔɹz oʊpən ən ɔnɪŋz wɛn ʌp, vɛstəɾ əpɹɛntəsɪz hɝiɪŋ ɑn ɛɹənz ən mɛn wɪð ɡɹeɪt ɹoʊl kɑɹpəts bælənst ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, tʌmblɝz ən dʒʌɡəlɝz ən mjuzɪʃənz ɹɛɾiɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ət laɪkli kɔɹnɝz ən hɔkɝz wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz ə pɪnz əɹ ɹɪbənz əɹ ʃæbi fɹut. ði oʊpən-saɪɾəd fɪʃ-æn mit-mɑɹkəts hæd lɔŋ sɪns bɪn ɪn fʊl kɹaɪ; ɔl ðə fɪʃmɑŋɡɝz wɝ wɪmən, ən moʊst ə ðə bʊtʃɝz, tu, ɪksɛp ðoʊz dilɪŋ ɪn bif.

Even this early a few brightly lacquered coaches were about in the winding streets, and a double fistful of brighter sedan chairs, two or sometimes four barefoot bearers in green-and-red striped vests to each, trotting because they carried passengers hidden behind the grilled wooden screens. Carts and wagons rumbled over the paving stones, and people began to fill the streets as shop doors opened and awnings went up, vested apprentices hurrying on errands and men with great rolled carpets balanced on their shoulders, tumblers and jugglers and musicians readying themselves at likely corners and hawkers with their trays of pins or ribbons or shabby fruit. The open-sided fish-and meat-markets had long since been in full cry; all the fishmongers were women, and most of the butchers, too, except those dealing in beef.

dɑdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz, pæs ðə koʊtʃɪz ən sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən wæɡənz ðət sim tə θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɹizən tə sloʊ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən sɛɾ ə fæs peɪs tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ɪntɝʌpʃənz. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ðoʊz. ʃi sim tə bi ə wɛl-noʊn wʊmən, heɪl baɪ ʃɑpkipɝz ən kɹæfsmən ən ʌðɝ ɪnkipɝz stændɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ dɔɹweɪz. ðə ʃɑpkipɝz ən kɹæfsmən ɹəsivd ə fju wɝdz, ə plɛzənt nɑd, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz stɑp tə tʃæɾ ə moʊmənt wɪð ði ɪnkipɝz. æftɝ ðə fɝst, nɪneɪiv wɪʃt fɝvənli ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ əɡɛn; æftɝ ðə sɛkənd, ʃi pɹeɪd fəɹ ɪt. æftɝ ðə θɝd ʃi stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ən tʃɹaɪɾ ɪn veɪn nɑt tə hɪɹ. ɪleɪnz feɪs ɡɹu taɪɾɝ ən taɪɾɝ, koʊldɝ ən koʊldɝ; hɝ tʃɪn ɹoʊz tɪl ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ʃi kəd si tə wɔk.

Dodging through the crowds, past the coaches and sedan chairs and wagons that seemed to think they had no reason to slow, Mistress Anan set a fast pace to make up for interruptions. There were plenty of those. She seemed to be a well-known woman, hailed by shopkeepers and craftsmen and other innkeepers standing in their doorways. The shopkeepers and craftsmen received a few words, a pleasant nod, but she always stopped to chat a moment with the innkeepers. After the first, Nynaeve wished fervently that she would not again; after the second, she prayed for it. After the third she stared straight ahead and tried in vain not to hear. Elayne's face grew tighter and tighter, colder and colder; her chin rose till it was a wonder she could see to walk.

ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹizən, nɪneɪiv hæd tə ədmɪt ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, sʌmwʌn wɛɹɪŋ sɪlk maɪt stʃɹoʊl ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ə skwɛɹ, meɪbi, bʌt noʊ fɝðɝ. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls ɪn saɪt wɔɹ wʊl əɹ lɪnən, sɛldəm wɪð mʌtʃ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ɪksɛp fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl bɛɡɝ u hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə kæst-ɔf sɪlk ɡɑɹmənt, fɹeɪɾ ɑn ɛvɹi ɛdʒ ən mɔɹ hoʊl ðən klɔθ. ʃi dʒʌst wɪʃt mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən hæd tʃoʊzən səm ʌðɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən fəɹ waɪ ʃi wɑz liɾɪŋ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm θɹu ðə stʃɹits. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə lɪsən wʌn mɔɹ taɪm tə ə teɪl ə tu flaɪɾi ɡɝlz u hæd spɛn ɔl ðɛɹ mʌni ɑn faɪn kloʊðz tə ɪmpɹɛs ə mæn. mæt keɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt wɛl, bɝn hɪm. ə faɪn jʌŋ fɛloʊ, ɪf mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən hæd nɑt bɪn mɛɹid, ə bjuɾəfəl dænsɝ wɪð dʒʌst ə tʌtʃ ə ðə ɹoʊɡ. ɔl ə ðə wɪmən læft. nɑɾ əɹ əɹ ɪleɪn, ðoʊ. nɑt ðə bɹeɪnləs lɪɾəl hʌnikɪsɝz - ðət wɑz ðə wɝd ʃi juzd; nɪneɪiv kəd ɡɛs wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt! - hʌnikɪsɝz pɛniləs fɹəm tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ ə mæn ən ðɛɹ pɝsɪz fʊl ə bɹæs bɪts ən tɪn tə ful fulz, wɪtləs lubiz u wʊɾə bɪn ɹədus tə bɛɝi əɹ θɛf hæd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən nɑt noʊn sʌmwʌn u maɪt ɡɪv əm wɝk ɪn ðə kɪtʃən.

There was a reason, Nynaeve had to admit grudgingly. In Ebou Dar, someone wearing silk might stroll the length of a square, maybe, but no further. Everybody else in sight wore wool or linen, seldom with much embroidery, except for an occasional beggar who had acquired a cast-off silk garment, frayed on every edge and more hole than cloth. She just wished Mistress Anan had chosen some other explanation for why she was leading the pair of them through the streets. She wished she did not have to listen one more time to a tale of two flighty girls who had spent all their money on fine clothes to impress a man. Mat came out of it well, burn him. A fine young fellow, if Mistress Anan had not been married, a beautiful dancer with just a touch of the rogue. All of the women laughed. Not her or Elayne, though. Not the brainless little honeykissers - that was the word she used; Nynaeve could guess what it meant! - honeykissers penniless from chasing after a man and their purses full of brass bits and tin to fool fools, witless loobies who would have been reduced to beggary or theft had Mistress Anan not known someone who might give them work in the kitchen.

"ʃi dʌzn əv tə stɑp əɾ ɛvɹi ɪn ɪn ðə sɪɾi," nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld əz ʃi stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə stʃɹændəd ɡus, θɹi bɹɔd stɔɹiz wɪð ən ɪnkipɝ u wɔɹ lɑɹdʒ ɡɑɹnəts əɾ əɹ ɪɹz dɪspaɪt ðə hʌmbəl neɪm. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən hɑɹdli ivən ɡlæns bæk tə si ðeɪ fɑloʊd, naʊ. "du jə ɹilaɪz wɪl nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə ʃoʊ əɹ oʊn feɪsəz ɪn ɛni ʌv ðoʊz pleɪsəz!"

"She doesn't have to stop at every inn in the city," Nynaeve growled as she stalked away from The Stranded Goose, three broad stories with an innkeeper who wore large garnets at her ears despite the humble name. Mistress Anan hardly even glanced back to see they followed, now. "Do you realize we'll never be able to show our own faces in any of those places!"

"aɪ səspɛk ðəɾ ɪz ɪɡzækli ðə pɔɪnt." ɛvɹi wɝɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪleɪnz maʊθ wɑz tʃɪp fɹəm aɪs. "nɪneɪiv, ɪf juv sɛn əs ɹʌnɪŋ æftɝ ə waɪl pɪɡ. . . ." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə kəmplit ðə θɹɛt. wɪð bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə tə hɛlp, ən ðeɪ wʊd, ɪleɪn kəd meɪk əɹ laɪf mɪzɝəbəl əntɪl ʃi wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd.

"I suspect that is exactly the point." Every word out of Elayne's mouth was chipped from ice. "Nynaeve, if you've sent us running after a wild pig. . . ." There was no need to complete the threat. With Birgitte and Aviendha to help, and they would, Elayne could make her life miserable until she was satisfied.

"ðeɪ wɪl teɪk əs ɹaɪt tə ðə boʊl," ʃi ɪnsɪstəd, flæpɪŋ əɹ hænz tə ʃu ə bɛɡɝ wɪð ə hɔɹəbəl pɝpəl skɑɹ ðəɾ əblɪɾɝeɪtɪd wʌn aɪ; ʃi kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz flaʊɝ peɪs daɪd wɪð bluwɝt wən ʃi sɔ ɪt. "aɪ noʊ ðeɪ wɪl." ɪleɪn snɪft ɪn ən əfɛnsɪvli ɪkspɹɛsɪv mænɝ.

"They will take us right to the Bowl," she insisted, flapping her hands to shoo a beggar with a horrible purple scar that obliterated one eye; she could recognize flour paste dyed with bluewort when she saw it. "I know they will." Elayne sniffed in an offensively expressive manner.

nɪneɪiv lɔs kaʊn ə ðə nʌmbɝ ə bɹɪdʒəz ðeɪ kɹɔst, lɑɹdʒ ən smɔl, wɪð bɑɹdʒəz poʊlɪŋ bɪniθ. ðə sʌn klaɪmd ɪts oʊn haɪɾ əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps, ðən twaɪs. ði ɑnən wʊmən dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ ivən soʊ stʃɹeɪɾ ə laɪn əz ʃi maɪɾ əv - ʃi ɹɪli dɪd sim tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ tə faɪn ɪnz - bʌt ðeɪ kəntɪnjud dʒɛnɝəli ist, ən nɪneɪiv θɔt ðeɪ mʌs bi nɪɹɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ wən ðə heɪzəl-aɪd wʊmən sʌɾənli ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðɛm.

Nynaeve lost count of the number of bridges they crossed, large and small, with barges poling beneath. The sun climbed its own height above the rooftops, then twice. The Anan woman did not follow even so straight a line as she might have - she really did seem to be going out of her way to find inns - but they continued generally east, and Nynaeve thought they must be nearing the river when the hazel-eyed woman suddenly rounded on them.

"ju wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋz, naʊ. spik wən jəɹ spoʊkən tə ən nɑɾ ɛls. jə ɪmbɛɹəs mi, ænd. . . ." wɪð ə faɪnəl fɹaʊn ən ə mʌɾɝ hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ ðət ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli meɪkɪŋ ə mɪsteɪk, ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ hɛd fəɹ əm tə fɑloʊ əɡɛn, tə ə flæt-ɹuf haʊs ɹaɪɾ ɑpəzət.

"You watch your tongues, now. Speak when you're spoken to and not else. You embarrass me, and. . . ." With a final frown and a mutter half under her breath that she was probably making a mistake, she jerked her head for them to follow again, to a flat-roofed house right opposite.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə lɑɹdʒ haʊs, tu stɔɹiz wɪθaʊt wʌn bælkəni, kɹæk plæstɝ ən bɹɪk ʃoʊɪŋ ɪn sɛvɹəl pleɪsəz, ən hɑɹdli ɪn ən əɡɹiəbəl loʊkeɪʃən, wɪð ðə laʊd ɹætlɪŋ ʌv ə wivɝz lumz tə wʌn saɪɾ ən ði ækɹɪd stɪŋks ʌv ə daɪɝz ʃɑp tə ði ʌðɝ. ə meɪɾ ænsɝd ðə dɔɹ, ðoʊ, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən wɪð ə skwɛɹ dʒɔ, ʃoʊldɝz laɪk ə blæksmɪθ, ən ə stili aɪ ənsɑfən baɪ ðə swɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs. əz nɪneɪiv fɑloʊd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɪn, ʃi smaɪld. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðət haʊs, ə wʊmən wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ.

It was not a large house, two stories without one balcony, cracked plaster and brick showing in several places, and hardly in an agreeable location, with the loud rattling of a weaver's looms to one side and the acrid stinks of a dyer's shop to the other. A maid answered the door, though, a graying woman with a square jaw, shoulders like a blacksmith, and a steely eye unsoftened by the sweat on her face. As Nynaeve followed Mistress Anan in, she smiled. Somewhere in that house, a woman was channeling.

ðə skwɛɹ-dʒɔd meɪɾ ɑbviəsli nu sɛɾəl ɑnən ɑn saɪt, bʌɾ əɹ ɹiækʃən wɑz ɑd. ʃi kɝtsid wɪð ə vɛɹi ɹil ɹɪspɛkt, jɛt ʃi wɑz pleɪnli sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɝ, ən ɑbviəsli daʊtfəl əbaʊɾ əɹ biɪŋ ðɛɹ. ʃi ɔlmoʊs flʌɾɝd bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ əm ɪn. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ ɡɹiɾəd wɪð noʊ æmbɪvələns, ðoʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ʃoʊn tə ə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wʌn flaɪɾ ʌp, ən ðə meɪd toʊld əm fɝmli, "doʊn stɝ ə toʊ ən doʊn tʌtʃ ɛniθɪŋ, əɹ jəl kætʃ ði oʊld wʌt-fɔɹ," ðən vænɪʃt.

The square-jawed maid obviously knew Setalle Anan on sight, but her reaction was odd. She curtsied with a very real respect, yet she was plainly surprised to see her, and obviously doubtful about her being there. She almost fluttered before letting them in. Nynaeve and Elayne were greeted with no ambivalence, though. They were shown to a sitting room one flight up, and the maid told them firmly, "Don't stir a toe and don't touch anything, or you'll catch the old what-for," then vanished.

nɪneɪiv lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn.

Nynaeve looked at Elayne.

"nɪneɪiv, wʌn wʊmən tʃænəlɪŋ dʌzn min - " ðə fil tʃeɪnʒd, swɛlɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən səbsaɪɾɪŋ, loʊɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ. "ivən tu wɪmən dʌzn min ɛniθɪŋ," ɪleɪn pɹətɛstəd, bʌt ʃi saʊndəd daʊtfəl. "ðæt wɑz ðə moʊst ɪl-mænɝd meɪɾ aɪv ɛvɝ sin." ʃi tʊk ə tɔl-bækt ɹɛd tʃɛɹ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt nɪneɪiv sæt tu, bʌt ʃi pɝtʃt ɑn ði ɛdʒ. fɹəm iɡɝnəs, nɑt nɝvz. nɑt nɝvz əɾ ɔl.

"Nynaeve, one woman channeling doesn't mean - " The feel changed, swelling for a moment, then subsiding, lower than before.
