"Even two women doesn't mean anything," Elayne protested, but she sounded doubtful. "That was the most ill-mannered maid I've ever seen." She took a tall-backed red chair, and after a moment Nynaeve sat too, but she perched on the edge. From eagerness, not nerves. Not nerves at all.

ðə ɹum wɑz nɑt ɡɹænd, bʌt ðə blu-ænd-waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz ɡlɪsənd, ən ðə peɪl ɡɹin wɔlz lʊk fɹɛʃli peɪntəd. noʊ tʃɹeɪs ʌv ɡɪlt ʃoʊɾ ɛniwɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt faɪn kɑɹvɪŋ kʌvɝd ðə ɹɛd tʃɛɹz ɝeɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz ən sɛvɹəl smɔl teɪbəlz ʌv ə dɑɹkɝ blu ðən ðə taɪlz. ðə læmps hæŋɪŋ fɹəm skɑnsɪz wɝ klɪɹli bɹæs, pɑlɪʃt tɪl ðeɪ ʃoʊn. kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd ɛvɝɡɹin bɹæntʃəz fɪl ðə swɛp hɑɹθ, ən ðə lɪntəl əbʌv ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɑz kɑɹvd, nɑt pleɪn stoʊnwɝk. ðə kɑɹvɪŋ simd ən ɑd tʃɔɪs - wʌt pipəl ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ kɔl ðə θɝtin sɪnz; ə mæn wɪð aɪz ðət nɪɹli fɪld ɪz hoʊl feɪs fəɹ ɛnvi, ə fɛloʊ wɪð ɪz tʌŋ hæŋɪŋ tə hɪz æŋkəlz fəɹ ɡɑsəp, ə snɑɹlɪŋ, ʃɑɹp-tuθ mæn klʌtʃɪŋ kɔɪnz tə hɪz tʃɛs fəɹ ɡɹid, ən soʊ ɑn - bʌɾ ɔl ɪn ɔl, ɪt sæɾəsfaɪd əɹ vɛɹi mʌtʃ. huɛvɝ kəɾ əfɔɹd ðət ɹum kəɾ əfɔɹd fɹɛʃ plæstɝ aʊtsaɪd, ən ði oʊnli ɹizən nɑt tə pʊɾ ɪɾ ʌp wɑz tə kip loʊ, əvɔɪɾɪŋ noʊɾəs.

The room was not grand, but the blue-and-white floor tiles glistened, and the pale green walls looked freshly painted. No trace of gilt showed anywhere, of course, yet fine carving covered the red chairs arrayed along the walls and several small tables of a darker blue than the tiles. The lamps hanging from sconces were clearly brass, polished till they shone. Carefully arranged evergreen branches filled the swept hearth, and the lintel above the fireplace was carved, not plain stonework. The carving seemed an odd choice - what people around Ebou Dar called the Thirteen Sins; a man with eyes that nearly filled his whole face for Envy, a fellow with his tongue hanging to his ankles for Gossip, a snarling, sharp-toothed man clutching coins to his chest for Greed, and so on - but all in all, it satisfied her very much. Whoever could afford that room could afford fresh plaster outside, and the only reason not to put it up was to keep low, avoiding notice.

ðə meɪd hæd lɛf ðə dɔɹ oʊpən, ən sʌɾənli vɔɪsəz kʌmɪŋ ʌp ðə hɔl dʒɹɪftəd θɹu.

The maid had left the door open, and suddenly voices coming up the hall drifted through.

"aɪ kænɑt bɪliv jə bɹɔɾ əm hɪɹ." ðə spikɝz toʊn wɑz taɪt wɪð ɪnkɹədulɪɾi ən æŋɡɝ. "ju noʊ haʊ kɛɹfəl wi ɑɹ, sɛɾəl. jə noʊ mɔɹ ðən jə ʃʊd, ən jə ʃʊɹli noʊ ðæt."

"I cannot believe you brought them here." The speaker's tone was tight with incredulity and anger. "You know how careful we are, Setalle. You know more than you should, and you surely know that."

"aɪ æm vɛɹi sɑɹi, ɹin," mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ænsɝd stɪfli. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk. aɪ . . . səbmɪt maɪsɛlf, boʊθ tə stænd ʃʊɹəɾi fəɹ ðiz ɡɝlz' bɪheɪvjɝ ən tə jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt."

"I am very sorry, Reanne," Mistress Anan answered stiffly. "I suppose I didn't think. I . . . submit myself, both to stand surety for these girls' behavior and to your judgment."

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt!" ɹinz toʊn wɑz haɪ wɪð ʃɑk, naʊ. "ðæɾ ɪz tə seɪ. . . . aɪ min, jə ʃʊdn hæv, bʌt. . . . sɛɾəl, aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ maɪ vɔɪs. seɪ jə fɝɡɪv mi."

"Of course not!" Reanne's tone was high with shock, now. "That is to say. . . . I mean, you shouldn't have, but. . . . Setalle, I apologize for raising my voice. Say you forgive me."

"ju hæv noʊ ɹizən tə əpɑlədʒaɪz, ɹin." ði ɪnkipɝ mænədʒ tə saʊn ɹufəl ən ɹɪlʌktən ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "aɪ dɪd ɹɔŋ tə bɹɪŋ ðɛm."

"You have no reason to apologize, Reanne." The innkeeper managed to sound rueful and reluctant at the same time. "I did wrong to bring them."

"noʊ, noʊ, sɛɾəl. aɪ ʃʊdn əv spoʊkən tə jə soʊ. pliz, jə mʌs fɝɡɪv mi. pliz du."

"No, no, Setalle. I shouldn't have spoken to you so. Please, you must forgive me. Please do."

ði ɑnən wʊmən ən ɹin kɔɹli ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ən nɪneɪiv blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. fɹəm ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd sʌmwʌn jʌŋɡɝ ðən sɛɾəl ɑnən, bʌt ɹin hæd hɛɹ mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ ðən nɑɾ ən ə feɪs fʊl ʌv wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn smaɪl laɪnz, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ kɹist ɪn wɝi naʊ. waɪ wəd ði oʊldɝ wʊmən hʌmbəl hɝsɛlf soʊ tə ðə jʌŋɡɝ, ən waɪ wəd ðə jʌŋɡɝ əlaʊ ɪt, haʊɛvɝ hæfhɑɹɾɪdli? kʌstəmz wɝ dɪfɹən hɪɹ, ðə laɪt nu, səm mɔɹ dɪfɹən ðən ʃi laɪk tə θɪŋk əbaʊt, jɛt nɑt ðɪs mʌtʃ, ʃʊɹli. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɡɔn vɛɹi fɑɹ təwɔɹd biɪŋ hʌmbəl wɪð ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm, bʌt ðɪs. . . .

The Anan woman and Reanne Corly entered the sitting room, and Nynaeve blinked in surprise. From the exchange, she had expected someone younger than Setalle Anan, but Reanne had hair more gray than not and a face full of what might have been smile lines, though they were creased in worry now. Why would the older woman humble herself so to the younger, and why would the younger allow it, however halfheartedly? Customs were different here, the Light knew, some more different than she liked to think about, yet not this much, surely. Of course, she had never gone very far toward being humble with the Women's Circle back home, but this. . . .

ʌv kɔɹs, ɹin kəd tʃænəl - ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðæt; hoʊp fəɹ ɪt, ɛniweɪ - bʌt ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɹin wɑz nɑɾ əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪleɪn, əɹ ivən nɪkoʊlə - bɝn ðət ɹɛtʃɪd ɡɝl! - bʌt ʃi izəli ikwəld ʃɛɹiəm, seɪ, əɹ kweɪmɛsə əɹ kaɪɹunə. nɑt mɛni wɪmən pəzɛst soʊ mʌtʃ stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən fəɹ ɔl ʃi hɝsɛlf bɛɾɝd ɪt baɪ ə fɛɹ mɑɹdʒən, ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪt hɪɹ. ðə wʊmən mʌs bi wʌn ə ðə waɪldɝz; ðə taʊɝ wʊɾə faʊn ə weɪ tə kip ɪts hænz ɑn ə wʊmən laɪk ðɪs ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə hoʊld əɹ ɪn ə nɑvəs dʒɹɛs əɹ hoʊl laɪf.

Of course, Reanne could channel - she had expected that; hoped for it, anyway - but she had not expected the strength. Reanne was not as strong as Elayne, or even Nicola - burn that wretched girl! - but she easily equaled Sheriam, say, or Kwamesa or Kiruna. Not many women possessed so much strength, and for all she herself bettered it by a fair margin, she was surprised to find it here. The woman must be one of the wilders; the Tower would have found a way to keep its hands on a woman like this if they had to hold her in a novice dress her whole life.

nɪneɪiv ɹoʊz əz ðeɪ keɪm θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts. nɑt fɹəm nɝvəsnəs, sɝɾənli; sɝɾənli nɑt. oʊ, bʌɾ ɪf oʊnli ðɪs keɪm aʊt ɹaɪt. . . .

Nynaeve rose as they came through the doorway, smoothing her skirts. Not from nervousness, certainly; certainly not. Oh, but if only this came out right. . . .

ɹinz ʃɑɹp blu aɪz stʌɾid ðə tu ʌv əm wɪð ði ɛɹ ə sʌmwʌn u hæd dʒʌs faʊn ə pɛɹ ə pɪɡz ɪn əɹ kɪtʃən, fɹɛʃ fɹəm ðə staɪ ən dʒɹɪpɪŋ mʌd. ʃi dæbd əɾ əɹ feɪs wɪð ə taɪni hæŋkɝtʃɪf, ðoʊ ði ɪntɪɹiɝ ə ðə haʊs wɑz kulɝ ðən aʊtsaɪd. "aɪ səpoʊz wɪl əv tə də sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðɛm," ʃi mɝmɝd, "ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ wʌt ðeɪ kleɪm." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kwaɪt haɪ ivən naʊ, mjuzɪkəl ən ɔlmoʊs juθfəl. əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹt fəɹ səm ɹizən ən aɪd ði ɪn-kipɝ saɪdweɪz, wɪtʃ sɛɾ ɔf ənʌðɝ ɹaʊn ə mɪstʃɹəs ɑnənz ɹɪlʌktən əpɑlədʒiz ən mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹliz flʌstɝɾ ətɛmps tə dɪflɛk ðɛm. ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wən foʊk wɝ tʃɹuli biɪŋ pəlaɪt, əpɑlədʒiz bæk ən fɔɹθ kəd floʊ fəɹ ən aʊɝ.

Reanne's sharp blue eyes studied the two of them with the air of someone who had just found a pair of pigs in her kitchen, fresh from the sty and dripping mud. She dabbed at her face with a tiny handkerchief, though the interior of the house was cooler than outside. "I suppose we'll have to do something with them," she murmured, "if they are what they claim." Her voice was quite high even now, musical and almost youthful. As she finished speaking she gave a small start for some reason and eyed the inn-keeper sideways, which set off another round of Mistress Anan's reluctant apologies and Mistress Corly's flustered attempts to deflect them. In Ebou Dar, when folk were truly being polite, apologies back and forth could flow for an hour.

ɪleɪn hæd ɹɪzən tu, wɛɹɪŋ ə slaɪtli fɪkst smaɪl. ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət nɪneɪiv, kʌpt əɹ ɛlboʊ ɪn wʌn hæn ən leɪɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɡɛnst əɹ tʃik.

Elayne had risen too, wearing a slightly fixed smile. She raised an eyebrow at Nynaeve, cupped her elbow in one hand and laid a finger against her cheek.

nɪneɪiv klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. "mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli, maɪ neɪm ɪz nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə, ən ðɪs ɪz ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. wəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ - "

Nynaeve cleared her throat. "Mistress Corly, my name is Nynaeve al'Meara, and this is Elayne Trakand. We are looking for - "

"sɛɾəl əz toʊl mi ɔl əbaʊt ju," ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən kʌɾ ɪn ɑmənəsli. haʊɛvɝ mɛni ɡɹeɪ hɛɹz ɑn əɹ hɛd, nɪneɪiv səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ hɑɹɾ əz ə stoʊn fɛns. "əbaɪd wɪð peɪʃəns, ɡɝl, ən əl dil wɪð jə dɝɛkli." ʃi tɝn bæk tə sɛɾəl, blɑɾɪŋ əɹ tʃiks wɪð ðə hæŋkɝtʃɪf. bɛɹli səpɹɛs dɪfəɾəns wʌns mɔɹ tɪŋd əɹ vɔɪs. "sɛɾəl, ɪf jəl pliz ɪkskjuz mi, aɪ mʌs kwɛstʃən ðiz ɡɝlz, ən - "

"Setalle has told me all about you," the blue-eyed woman cut in ominously. However many gray hairs on her head, Nynaeve suspected she was also hard as a stone fence. "Abide with patience, girl, and I'll deal with you directly." She turned back to Setalle, blotting her cheeks with the handkerchief. Barely suppressed diffidence once more tinged her voice. "Setalle, if you will please excuse me, I must question these girls, and - "

"lʊk u ɪz ɹɪtɝn æftɝ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz," ə ʃɔɹt, staʊt wʊmən ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz blɝɾɪd əz ʃi bɑɹdʒd ɪndə ðə ɹum, nɑɾɪŋ əɾ əɹ kəmpænjən. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɹɛd-bɛltəɾ ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs ən ə tæn feɪs ðət ɡlɪsən dæmpli, hɝ æksɛns wɝ pjʊɹ kɛɹhinɪn. hɝ ikwəli swɛɾi kəmpænjən, ɪn ðə dɑɹk, pleɪnli kʌt wʊlənz ʌv ə mɝtʃənt, wɑz ə hɛd tɔlɝ, noʊ oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv, wɪð dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz, ə stʃɹɔŋli hʊk noʊz, ən ə waɪd maʊð. "ɪts ɡæɹiniə! ʃi - " ðə floʊ ʌv wɝdz tɝməneɪɾəd əbɹʌpli ɪn kənfjuʒən əz ðə staʊt wʊmən ɹilaɪzd ʌðɝz wɝ pɹɛzənt.

"Look who is returned after all these years," a short, stout woman in her middle years blurted as she barged into the room, nodding at her companion. Despite her red-belted Ebou Dari dress and a tanned face that glistened damply, her accents were pure Cairhienin. Her equally sweaty companion, in the dark, plainly cut woolens of a merchant, was a head taller, no older than Nynaeve, with dark tilted eyes, a strongly hooked nose, and a wide mouth. "It's Garenia! She - " The flow of words terminated abruptly in confusion as the stout woman realized others were present.

ɹin klæspt əɹ hænz əz ɪf ɪn pɹɛɹ, əɹ pɝhæps kəz ʃi wɑntəd tə hɪt sʌmwʌn. "bɛɹaʊɪn," ʃi sɛd wɪð ən ɛdʒ, "wʌn deɪ jəl ɹʌn ɹaɪɾ ɔf ə klɪf bɪfɔɹ jə si ɪɾ ʌndɝ jəɹ fit."

Reanne clasped her hands as if in prayer, or perhaps because she wanted to hit someone. "Berowin," she said with an edge, "one day you will run right off a cliff before you see it under your feet."

"aɪ æm sɑɹi, ɪld - " blʌʃɪŋ, ðə kɛɹhinɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ aɪz. ðə sɑldəiən bɪkeɪm ɪntɛn ɑn fɪdlɪŋ wɪð ə sɝkəl ə ɹɛd stoʊnz pɪn əɾ əɹ bɹɛst.

"I am sorry, Eld - " Blushing, the Cairhienin lowered her eyes. The Saldaean became intent on fiddling with a circle of red stones pinned at her breast.

fəɹ nɪneɪivz pɑɹt, ʃi ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə tʃɹaɪʌmfən lʊk. boʊθ nukʌmɝz kəd tʃænəl, ən seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz stɪl biɪŋ wildɪd sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə haʊs. tu mɔɹ, ən waɪl bɛɹaʊɪn wɑz nɑt vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ, ɡæɹiniə stʊɾ ivən əbʌv ɹin; ʃi kəd mætʃ ləleɪn əɹ ɹoʊmændə. nɑt ðət ðət mæɾɝd, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt ðɪs meɪɾ ət lis faɪv. ɪleɪnz tʃɪn sɛt stʌbɝnli, bʌt ðən ʃi saɪɾ ən ɡeɪv ə smɔl nɑd. səmtaɪmz ɪt tʊk ðə moʊst ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɛfɝt tə kənvɪns əɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ.

For Nynaeve's part, she gave Elayne a triumphant look. Both newcomers could channel, and saidar was still being wielded somewhere in the house. Two more, and while Berowin was not very strong, Garenia stood even above Reanne; she could match Lelaine or Romanda. Not that that mattered, of course, yet this made at least five. Elayne's chin set stubbornly, but then she sighed and gave a small nod. Sometimes it took the most incredible effort to convince her of anything.

"jɔɹ neɪm ɪz ɡæɹiniə?" mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən sɛd sloʊli, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə wʊmən ɪn kwɛstʃən. "ju lʊk vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk sʌmwʌn aɪ mɛt wʌns. zɛɹjə ælkeɪis."

"Your name is Garenia?" Mistress Anan said slowly, frowning at the woman in question. "You look very much like someone I met once. Zarya Alkaese."

dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. plʌkɪŋ ə leɪs-tʃɹɪm hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv, ðə sɑldəiən mɝtʃən tʌtʃt əɹ tʃiks. "ðæɾ ɪz maɪ ɡɹændmʌðɝz sɪstɝz neɪm," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "aɪm toʊld aɪ feɪvɝ əɹ stʃɹɔŋli. wɑz ʃi wɛl wən jə sɔ hɝ? ʃi fɝɡɑɾ əɹ fæmli kəmplitli æftɝ ʃi wɛn ɔf tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Dark tilted eyes blinked in surprise. Plucking a lace-trimmed handkerchief from her sleeve, the Saldaean merchant touched her cheeks. "That is my grandmother's sister's name," she said after a moment. "I'm told I favor her strongly. Was she well when you saw her? She forgot her family completely after she went off to become Aes Sedai."

"jɔɹ ɡɹændmʌðɝz sɪstɝ." ði ɪnkipɝ læf sɔfli. "ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wɑz wɛl wən aɪ sɔ hɝ, bʌt ðət wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ. aɪ wɑz jʌŋɡɝ ðən jə ɑɹ naʊ."

"Your grandmother's sister." The innkeeper laughed softly. "Of course. She was well when I saw her, but that was a long time ago. I was younger than you are now."

ɹin hæd bɪn hʌvɝɪŋ əɾ əɹ saɪd, ɔl bʌt ɡɹæbɪŋ əɹ ɛlboʊ, ən naʊ ʃi lɛpt ɪn. "sɛɾəl, aɪ tʃɹuli æm sɑɹi, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪli mʌst æsk jə tə ɪkskjuz ʌs. jəl fɝɡɪv mi nɑt ʃoʊɪŋ jə tə ðə dɔɹ?"

Reanne had been hovering at her side, all but grabbing her elbow, and now she leaped in. "Setalle, I truly am sorry, but I really must ask you to excuse us. You will forgive me not showing you to the door?"

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən meɪɾ əɹ oʊn əpɑlədʒiz, əz ɪf ʃi wɑz ət fɔl kəz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən kəd nɑɾ ɛskɔɹɾ əɹ daʊn, ən dɪpɑɹɾəd wɪð ə læst, vɛɹi dubiəs lʊk ət nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn.

Mistress Anan made her own apologies, as if she was at fault because the other woman could not escort her down, and departed with a last, very dubious look at Nynaeve and Elayne.

"sɛɾəl!" ɡæɹiniə ɪkskleɪmd əz sun əz ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ɡɔn. "ðæt wɑz sɛɾəl ɑnən? haʊ dɪd ʃi - ? laɪɾ ə hɛvən! ivən æftɝ sɛvənti jɪɹz, ðə taʊɝ wəd - "

"Setalle!" Garenia exclaimed as soon as the innkeeper was gone. "That was Setalle Anan? How did she - ? Light of Heaven! Even after seventy years, the Tower would - "

"ɡæɹiniə," mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli sɛɾ ɪn ən ɪkstʃɹimli ʃɑɹp toʊn. hɝ stɛɹ wɑz ʃɑɹpɝ stɪl, ən ðə sɑldəiənz feɪs ɹɛɾənd. "sɪns jə tu ɑɹ hɪɹ, wi kən meɪk ʌp ðə θɹi fəɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ. jə ɡɝlz steɪ wɛɹ jə ɑɹ ən kip saɪlənt." ðət læst wɑz fəɹ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. ði ʌðɝ wɪmən wɪθdʒɹu tə ə kɔɹnɝ ɪn ə hʌɾəl ən bɪɡæn kənvɝsɪŋ ɪn sɑf mɝmɝz.

"Garenia," Mistress Corly said in an extremely sharp tone. Her stare was sharper still, and the Saldaean's face reddened. "Since you two are here, we can make up the three for questioning. You girls stay where you are and keep silent." That last was for Nynaeve and Elayne. The other women withdrew to a corner in a huddle and began conversing in soft murmurs.

ɪleɪn muv nɪɹɝ nɪneɪiv. "aɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ tʃɹiɾəd əz ə nɑvəs wən aɪ wɑz ə nɑvəs. haʊ lɔŋ dʒju ɪntɛn tə kəntɪnju ðɪs fɑɹs?"

Elayne moved nearer Nynaeve. "I did not like being treated as a novice when I was a novice. How long do you intend to continue this farce?"

nɪneɪiv hɪst əɾ əɹ fəɹ kwaɪət. "aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪsən, ɪleɪn," ʃi wɪspɝd.

Nynaeve hissed at her for quiet. "I'm trying to listen, Elayne," she whispered.

juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə θɹi wʊɾə noʊn ɑn ði ɪnstənt. fɔɹtʃənətli, ðeɪ woʊv noʊ bæɹiɝz, pɝhæps nɑt noʊɪŋ haʊ, ən səmtaɪmz ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz dʒʌst ɪnʌf.

Using the Power was out of the question, of course. The three would have known on the instant. Fortunately, they wove no barriers, perhaps not knowing how, and sometimes their voices rose just enough.

". . . sɛd ðeɪ meɪ bi waɪldɝz," ɹin sɛd, ən ʃɑk ən ɹɪvʌlʃən blumd ɑn ði ʌðɝ wɪmənz feɪsəz.

". . . said they may be wilders," Reanne said, and shock and revulsion bloomed on the other women's faces.

"ðɛn wi ʃoʊ ðɛm ðə dɔɹ," bɛɹaʊɪn sɛd. "ðə bæk dɔɹ. waɪldɝz!"

"Then we show them the door," Berowin said. "The back door. Wilders!"

"aɪ stɪl wɑnə noʊ hu ðɪs sɛɾəl ɑnən ɪz," ɡæɹiniə pʊɾ ɪn.

"I still want to know who this Setalle Anan is," Garenia put in.

"If you can't keep your mind on the straight," Reanne told her, "perhaps you should spend this turn on the farm. Alise knows how to concentrate a mind wonderfully. Now. . . ." The words dropped back to a buzz.

ənʌðɝ meɪɾ əpɪɹd, ə slɛndɝ wʊmən, pɹɪɾi ɪksɛp fəɹ ə sʌlən ɪkspɹɛʃən, wɪð ə ɹʌf ɡɹeɪ wʊlən dʒɹɛs ən ə lɔŋ waɪɾ eɪpɹən. sɛɾɪŋ ə ɡɹin-lækɝd tʃɹeɪ ɑn wʌn ə ðə smɔl teɪbəlz, ʃi sɝəptɪʃəsli waɪpt əɹ tʃiks wɪð ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ eɪpɹən ən bɪɡæn fʌsɪŋ wɪð blu-ɡleɪz kʌps ən ə mætʃɪŋ tipɑt. nɪneɪivz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz. ðɪs wʊmən kəd tʃænəl, tu, ɪf nɑt tə ɛni haɪ dɪɡɹi. wʌt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ əz ə sɝvənt?

Another maid appeared, a slender woman, pretty except for a sullen expression, with a rough gray woolen dress and a long white apron. Setting a green-lacquered tray on one of the small tables, she surreptitiously wiped her cheeks with a corner of her apron and began fussing with blue-glazed cups and a matching teapot. Nynaeve's eyebrows rose. This woman could channel, too, if not to any high degree. What was she doing as a servant?

ɡæɹiniə ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt dɪd dɛɹiz də tə ɝn pɛnəns? aɪ θɔt fɪʃ wəd sɪŋ ðə deɪ ʃi kɹækt ə ɹul, mʌtʃ lɛs bɹoʊk wʌn."

Garenia glanced over her shoulder, and gave a start. "What did Derys do to earn penance? I thought fish would sing the day she cracked a rule, much less broke one."

bɛɹaʊɪn snɪf laʊdli, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɪplaɪ wɑz bɛɹli ɑɾəbəl. "ʃi wɑntəd tə mɛɹi. ʃɪl ədvæns ə tɝn ən ɡoʊ wɪð kɛɹeɪl ðə deɪ æftɝ ðə fist ə ðə hæf mun. ðət wɪl sɛɾəl fəɹ mæstɝ dɪnəl."

Berowin sniffed loudly, but her reply was barely audible. "She wanted to marry. She will advance a turn and go with Keraille the day after the Feast of the Half Moon. That will settle for Master Denal."

"pɝhæps jə boʊθ wɪʃ tə hoʊ ðə filz fəɹ æləz?" ɹin spoʊk dʒɹaɪli, ən ðə vɔɪsəz fɛl əɡɛn.

"Perhaps you both wish to hoe the fields for Alise?" Reanne spoke dryly, and the voices fell again.

nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə ɹʌʃ ʌv ɪɡzʌlteɪʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ mʌtʃ fəɹ ɹulz, ət lis fəɹ ʌðɝ pipəlz ɹulz - ʌðɝ pipəl ɹɛɹli sɔ ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən əz klɪɹli əz ʃi, ən ðʌs meɪd stupəd ɹulz; waɪ ʃəd ðət wʊmən, dɛɹiz, nɑt mɛɹi ɪf ʃi wɪʃt, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl? - bʌt ɹulz ən pɛnənsɪz spoʊk ʌv ə səsaɪəɾi. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt. ən ənʌðɝ θɪŋ. ʃi nʌdʒd ɪleɪn əntɪl ði ʌðɝ wʊmən bɛn əɹ hɛd.

Nynaeve felt a rush of exultation. She did not care much for rules, at least for other people's rules - other people rarely saw the situation as clearly as she, and thus made stupid rules; why should that woman, Derys, not marry if she wished, for example? - but rules and penances spoke of a society. She was right. And another thing. She nudged Elayne until the other woman bent her head.

"bɛɹaʊɪnz wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹɛd bɛlt," ʃi wɪspɝd. ðəɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə waɪz wʊmən, wʌn ʌv ɛbu dɑɹz feɪbəl hilɝz, ðɛɹ kɛɹ noʊn fɑɹ ən waɪɾ əz ðə nɛks bɛs tə biɪŋ hil baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, kjʊɹɪŋ dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ. səpoʊzədli ɪt wɑz ɔl dʌn wɪð ɝbz ən nɑlədʒ, bʌt. . . . "haʊ mɛni waɪz wɪmən əv wi sin, ɪleɪn? haʊ mɛni kəd tʃænəl? haʊ mɛni wɝ ɛbu dɑɹi, əɹ ivən ɔltɑɹən?"

"Berowin's wearing a red belt," she whispered. That indicated a Wise Woman, one of Ebou Dar's fabled healers, their care known far and wide as the next best to being Healed by an Aes Sedai, curing just about anything. Supposedly it was all done with herbs and knowledge, but. . . . "How many Wise Women have we seen, Elayne? How many could channel? How many were Ebou Dari, or even Altaran?"

"sɛvən, kaʊntɪŋ bɛɹaʊɪn" wɑz ðə sloʊ ænsɝ, "æn oʊnli wʌn aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz fɹəm hɪɹ." hɑ! ði ʌðɝz pleɪnli hæd nɑt bɪn. ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðoʊ ʃi wɛn ɑn sɔfli. "nʌn hæɾ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ðiz wɪmənz stʃɹɛŋkθ, ðoʊ." ət list ʃi hæd nɑt sədʒɛstəd ðeɪ wɝ mɪsteɪkən sʌmhaʊ; ɔl ə ðoʊz waɪz wɪmən hæd bɪn eɪbəl. "nɪneɪiv, ɑɹ jə ɹɪli sədʒɛstɪŋ ðət ðə waɪz wɪmən . . . ɔl ðə waɪz wɪmən . . . ɑɹ . . . ? ðət wəd bi bɪɑn ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl."

"Seven, counting Berowin" was the slow answer, "and only one I was sure was from here." Hah! The others plainly had not been. Elayne took a deep breath, though she went on softly. "None had anywhere near these women's strength, though." At least she had not suggested they were mistaken somehow; all of those Wise Women had been able. "Nynaeve, are you really suggesting that the Wise Women . . . all the Wise Women . . . are . . . ? That would be beyond incredible."

"ɪleɪn, ðɪs sɪɾi hæz ə ɡɪl fəɹ ðə mɛn u swip ðə skwɛɹz ɛvɹi naɪt! aɪ θɪŋk wiv dʒʌs faʊn ði eɪntʃən mʌkəɾi-mʌk sɪstɝhʊɾ ʌv waɪz wɪmən."

"Elayne, this city has a guild for the men who sweep the squares every night! I think we've just found the Ancient Muckety-muck Sisterhood of Wise Women."

ðə stʌbɝn wʊmən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ðə taʊɝ wʊɾə hæɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd sɪstɝz hɪɹ jɪɹz əɡoʊ, nɪneɪiv. tu hʌnʒɹəd. ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt wʊɾə bɪn skwɑʃt flæɾ ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ."

The stubborn woman shook her head. "The Tower would have had a hundred sisters here years ago, Nynaeve. Two hundred. Anything of the sort would have been squashed flat in short order."

"meɪbi ðə taʊɝ dʌznt noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "meɪbi ðə ɡɪl kips loʊ ɪnʌf ðət ðə taʊɝ nɛvɝ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ wɝθ tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ. ðɛɹz noʊ lɔ əɡɛns tʃænəlɪŋ ɪf jə ɑɹən ɛɛs sədaɪ, oʊnli əɡɛns kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ mɪsjuzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. əɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ dɪskɹɛɾət." ðət mɛn duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt pɑsəbli kæst ə bæd laɪɾ ɑn ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃəɾ ɛniwʌn hæpən tə θɪŋk jə wɝ wʌn, wɪtʃ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ pɹɪɾi fɑɹ, tə hɝ weɪ ʌv θɪŋkɪŋ. ðə ɹil tʃɹʌbəl, ðoʊ, wɑz ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ðə taʊɝ sim tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən ðeɪ pɹɑbli wəd bɹeɪk ʌp ə kwɪltɪŋ sɝkəl ɪf ðə wɪmən ɪn ɪt kəd tʃænəl. jɛt ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm ɛkspləneɪʃən fɔɹ. . . . oʊnli hæf-əwɛɹ, ʃi fɛl ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs biɪŋ ɛmbɹeɪst, bʌt sʌɾənli ʃi bɪkeɪm vɛɹi əwɛɹ. hɝ maʊθ fɛl oʊpən əz ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ snɛɹɾ əɹ bɹeɪd ɹaɪɾ ət ðə beɪs ə hɝ skʌl ən ɹæn əɹ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum ɑn əɹ toʊz. ɪleɪn ɹæn ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd hɝ, ɹɛd-feɪst wɪð fjʊɹi. ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ ʃildɪd.

"Maybe the Tower doesn't know," Nynaeve said. "Maybe the guild keeps low enough that the Tower never thought they were worth troubling. There's no law against channeling if you aren't Aes Sedai, only against claiming to be Aes Sedai, or misusing the Power. Or bringing discredit." That meant doing anything that might possibly cast a bad light on real Aes Sedai, should anyone happen to think you were one, which was going pretty far, to her way of thinking. The real trouble, though, was that she did not believe it. The Tower seemed to know everything, and they probably would break up a quilting circle if the women in it could channel. Yet there had to be some explanation for. . . . Only half-aware, she felt the True Source being embraced, but suddenly she became very aware. Her mouth fell open as a flow of Air snared her braid right at the base of her skull and ran her across the room on her toes. Elayne ran right beside her, red-faced with fury. The worst of it was, they were both shielded.

ðə ʃɔɹt ɹʌn ɛndəd wən ðeɪ wɝ əlaʊd tə sɛɾəl ðɛɹ hilz ɪn fɹʌn ə mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli ən ði ʌðɝ tu, ɔl θɹi siɾəd əɡɛns ðə wɔl ɪn ɹɛd tʃɛɹz, ɔl sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ.

The short run ended when they were allowed to settle their heels in front of Mistress Corly and the other two, all three seated against the wall in red chairs, all surrounded by the glow of saidar.

"ju wɝ toʊl tə bi kwaɪət," ɹin sɛd fɝmli. "ɪf wi dɪsaɪd tə hɛlp ju, jəl əv tə lɝn ðət wi ɪkspɛk stʃɹɪkt oʊbiɾiəns noʊ lɛs ðən ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf." ʃi ɪmbjud ðoʊz læst wɝdz wɪð ə toʊn ə ɹɛvɝəns. "aɪ wɪl tɛl jə ðət jə wʊɾə bɪn tʃɹiɾəd mɔɹ dʒɛnli ɪf jə hæd nɑt kʌm tə əs ɪn ðɪs ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ fæʃən." ðə floʊ ɡɹɪpɪŋ nɪneɪivz bɹeɪd vænɪʃt. ɪleɪn tɔst əɹ hɛɾ æŋɡɹəli əz ʃi wɑz ɹilist.

"You were told to be quiet," Reanne said firmly. "If we decide to help you, you will have to learn that we expect strict obedience no less than the White Tower itself." She imbued those last words with a tone of reverence. "I will tell you that you would have been treated more gently if you had not come to us in this irregular fashion." The flow gripping Nynaeve's braid vanished. Elayne tossed her head angrily as she was released.

əpɔld əstɑnɪʃmən bɪkeɪm faɪɝi aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ əz nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪz ðət bɛɹaʊɪn hɛld əɹ ʃild. moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi hæd mɛt stʊɾ əbʌv bɛɹaʊɪn; nɪɹli ɔl. ɡæðɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ʃi stʃɹeɪn tə ɹitʃ ðə sɔɹs, ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðə wivz tə ʃæɾɝ. ʃi wəɾ ət list ʃoʊ ðiz wɪmən ʃi wəd nɑt bi. . . . ðə wivz . . . stʃɹɛtʃt. ðə ɹaʊn kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən smaɪld, ən nɪneɪivz feɪs dɑɹkənd. ðə ʃil stʃɹɛtʃt fɝðɝ, fɝðɝ, bʌlʒɪŋ laɪk ə bɔl. ɪt wəd nɑt bɹeɪk. ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. ɛniwʌn kəd blɑk əɹ fɹəm ðə sɔɹs ɪf ðeɪ kɑɾ əɹ baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, ən sʌmwʌn wikɝ kəd hoʊl ðə ʃild wʌns woʊvən, bʌt nɑt ðɪs mʌtʃ wikɝ. ən ə ʃil dɪd nɑt bɛn ðət fɑɹ wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl!

Appalled astonishment became fiery outrage as Nynaeve realized that Berowin held her shield. Most Aes Sedai she had met stood above Berowin; nearly all. Gathering herself, she strained to reach the Source, expecting the weaves to shatter. She would at least show these women she would not be. . . . The weaves . . . stretched. The round Cairhienin woman smiled, and Nynaeve's face darkened. The shield stretched further, further, bulging like a ball. It would not break. That was impossible. Anyone could block her from the Source if they caught her by surprise, of course, and someone weaker could hold the shield once woven, but not this much weaker. And a shield did not bend that far without breaking. It was impossible!

"ju kəd bɝst ə blʌd vɛsəl ɪf jə kip ət ðæt," bɛɹaʊɪn sɛd, ɔlmoʊs kəmpænjənəbli. "wi də nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɹitʃ əbʌv əɹ steɪʃən, bʌt skɪlz ɑɹ hoʊnd wɪð taɪm, ən ðɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz nɪɹli ə tælənt wɪð mi. aɪ kəd hoʊld wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən."

"You could burst a blood vessel if you keep at that," Berowin said, almost companionably. "We do not try to reach above our station, but skills are honed with time, and this was always nearly a Talent with me. I could hold one of the Forsaken."

skaʊlɪŋ, nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv oʊvɝ. ʃi kəd weɪt. sɪns ʃi hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs, ʃi kʊd.

Scowling, Nynaeve gave over. She could wait. Since she had no choice, she could.

dɛɹiz keɪm bɛɹɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪ, dɪstʃɹɪbjuɾɪŋ kʌps ə dɑɹk ti. tə ðə θɹi siɾəd wɪmən. ʃi nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ə pɝfəkt kɝtsi ən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ teɪbəl.

Derys came bearing her tray, distributing cups of dark tea. To the three seated women. She never so much as glanced at Nynaeve or Elayne before making a perfect curtsy and returning to her table.

"wi cʊɾə bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ blubɛɹi ti, nɪneɪiv," ɪleɪn sɛd, ʃuɾɪŋ sətʃ ə lʊk əɾ əɹ ðət ʃi keɪm kloʊs tə stɛpɪŋ bæk. meɪbi ɪt wəd bi bɛs nɑt tə weɪt tu lɔŋ.

"We could have been drinking blueberry tea, Nynaeve," Elayne said, shooting such a look at her that she came close to stepping back. Maybe it would be best not to wait too long.

"bi kwaɪət, ɡɝl." mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹliz toʊn maɪt bi kɑm, bʌt ʃi pæɾəd əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf tə hɝ feɪs æŋɡɹəli. "aʊɝ ɹipɔɹɾ ə jə sɛz jə boʊθ ɑɹ fɹoʊwɝɾ ən kəntɛnʃəs, ðət jə tʃeɪs æftɝ mɛn ən laɪ. tə wɪtʃ aɪ æd ðət jə kænɑt fɑloʊ sɪmpəl ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ mʌs tʃeɪnʒ ɪf jə sik əɹ hɛlp. ɔl ʌv ɪt. ðɪs ɪz moʊst ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ. bi ɡɹeɪtfəl wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə spik tə ju."

"Be quiet, girl." Mistress Corly's tone might be calm, but she patted her handkerchief to her face angrily. "Our report of you says you both are froward and contentious, that you chase after men and lie. To which I add that you cannot follow simple instructions. All of which must change if you seek our help. All of it. This is most irregular. Be grateful we're willing to speak to you."

"wi də sik jəɹ hɛlp," nɪneɪiv sɛd. ʃi wɪʃt ɪleɪn wəd stɑp ɡlɛɹɪŋ soʊ. ɪt wɑz wɝs ðən ðə kɔɹli wʊmənz hɑɹd stɛɹ. wɛl, əz bæd, ɛniweɪ. "wi dɛspɝətli nid tə faɪn ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil - "

"We do seek your help," Nynaeve said. She wished Elayne would stop glaring so. It was worse than the Corly woman's hard stare. Well, as bad, anyway. "We desperately need to find a ter'angreal - "

ɹin kɔɹli bɹoʊk ɪn əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ðəɹ saɪlənt. "juʒəwəli, wi noʊ ðə ɡɝlz bɹɔt tə əs bɪfɔɹhænd, bʌt wi mʌs meɪk sɝɾən jə ɑɹ wʌt jə seɪ. haʊ mɛni dɔɹz tə ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi meɪ ə nɑvəs jus, ən wɪtʃ?" ʃi tʊk ə sɪp ə ti, weɪɾɪŋ.

Reanne Corly broke in as if she had been standing there silent. "Usually, we know the girls brought to us beforehand, but we must make certain you are what you say. How many doors to the Tower Library may a novice use, and which?" She took a sip of tea, waiting.

"tu." ðə wɝd dʒɹɪp vɛnəm fɹəm ɪleɪnz maʊð. "ðə meɪn dɔɹ tə ði ist, wən ə sɪstɝ sɛnz hɝ, əɹ ðə smɔl dɔɹ ət ðə saʊθwɛs kɔɹnɝ, kɔl ðə nɑvəs dɔɹ, wən ʃi ɡoʊz fəɹ hɝsɛlf. haʊ lɔŋ, nɪneɪiv?"

"Two." The word dripped venom from Elayne's mouth. "The main door to the east, when a sister sends her, or the small door at the southwest corner, called the Novice Door, when she goes for herself. How long, Nynaeve?"

ɡæɹiniə, hu hɛld ɪleɪnz ʃild, tʃænəld ənʌðɝ slɛndɝ floʊ ʌv ɛɹ, nɑt dʒɛnli. ɪleɪn kwɪvɝd, ðən əɡɛn, ən nɪneɪiv wɪnst, wʌndɝɪŋ ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɹæb ət ðə bæk ə hɝ skɝt. "ə sɪvəl tʌŋ ɪz ənʌðɝ ɹɪkwaɪɹmənt," ɡæɹiniə mɝmɝd ɹaɪli ɪndə hɝ kʌp.

Garenia, who held Elayne's shield, channeled another slender flow of Air, not gently. Elayne quivered, then again, and Nynaeve winced, wondering that she did not grab at the back of her skirt. "A civil tongue is another requirement," Garenia murmured wryly into her cup.

"ðæɾ ɪz ðə ɹaɪɾ ænsɝ," mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli sɛd, əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls hæd hæpənd. ɔlðoʊ ʃi dɪɾ aɪ ðə sɑldəiən wʊmən bɹifli oʊvɝ əɹ ti. "naʊ, haʊ mɛni bɹɪdʒəz ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ ɡɑɹɾən?"

"That is the right answer," Mistress Corly said, as if nothing else had happened. Although she did eye the Saldaean woman briefly over her tea. "Now, how many bridges in the Water Garden?"

"θɹi," nɪneɪiv snæpt, meɪnli kəz ʃi nu. ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn əbaʊt ðə laɪbɹɛɹi, hævɪŋ nɛvɝ bɪn ə nɑvəs. "wi nid tə noʊ - " bɛɹaʊɪn kəd nɑt spɛɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə tʃænəl ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ, bʌt mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli kʊd, ən dɪd. bɛɹli kipɪŋ əɹ feɪs smuð, nɪneɪiv nɑɾɪd əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ skɝts tə hoʊld əm stɪl. ɪleɪn hæd ðə ɡɔl tə ɡɪv əɹ ə smɔl, tʃɪli smaɪl. tʃɪli, bʌt sæɾəsfaɪd.

"Three," Nynaeve snapped, mainly because she knew. She had not known about the library, having never been a novice. "We need to know - " Berowin could not spare anything to channel a flow of Air, but Mistress Corly could, and did. Barely keeping her face smooth, Nynaeve knotted her hands in her skirts to hold them still. Elayne had the gall to give her a small, chilly smile. Chilly, but satisfied.

ə dʌzən mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz hæmɝɾ ət ðɛm, fɹəm haʊ mɛni flɔɹz ðə nɑvəs kɔɹɾɝz kənteɪnd - twɛlv - tə ʌndɝ wʌt sɝkəmstænsəz ə nɑvəs wɑz əlaʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ - tə kæɹi mɛsədʒəz əɹ tə bi ɪkspɛl fɹəm ðə taʊɝ fəɹ ə kɹaɪm; noʊ ʌðɝz - hæmɝd wɪθaʊt nɪneɪiv ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn mɔɹ ðən tu wɝdz, ən ðoʊz tu ænsɝd saɪlənli baɪ ðə hɔɹəbəl kɔɹli wʊmən. ʃi bɪɡæn tə fil laɪk ə nɑvəs ɪn ðə hɔl; ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə spik ə wɝɾ iðɝ. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju ænsɝz ʃi nu, bʌt lʌkəli ɪleɪn ɹɪspɑndɪd pɹɑmpli wən ʃi dɪd nɑt. nɪneɪiv maɪɾ əv dʌn bɛɾɝ hæd ðeɪ æskt əbaʊɾ æksɛptɪd, ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ət list, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wʌɾ ə nɑvəs ʃəd noʊ ðəɾ ɪntʃɹəstəd ðɛm. ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ɡlæɾ ɪleɪn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ɡoʊ əlɔŋ, ðoʊ baɪ hɝ peɪl tʃiks ən ɹeɪz tʃɪn, ðət kəd nɑt læs mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ.

A dozen more questions hammered at them, from how many floors the novice quarters contained - twelve - to under what circumstances a novice was allowed into the Hall of the Tower - to carry messages or to be expelled from the Tower for a crime; no others - hammered without Nynaeve getting in more than two words, and those two answered silently by the horrible Corly woman. She began to feel like a novice in the Hall; they were not allowed to speak a word either. That was one of the few answers she knew, but luckily Elayne responded promptly when she did not. Nynaeve might have done better had they asked about Accepted, a little better at least, but it was what a novice should know that interested them. She was just glad Elayne was willing to go along, though by her pale cheeks and raised chin, that could not last much longer.

"aɪ səpoʊz nɪneɪiv wɑz ɹɪli ðɛɹ," ɹin sɛd faɪnəli, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɡlænsɪz wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu. "ɪf ɪleɪn tɔɾ əɹ tə pæs, aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wʊɾə dʌn ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb. səm pipəl lɪv ɪn pɝpɛtʃuəl fɑɡ." ɡæɹiniə snɪft, ðən nɑɾəd sloʊli. bɛɹaʊɪnz nɑd keɪm ɪntaɪɝli tu pɹɑmpli fəɹ nɪneɪivz laɪkɪŋ.

"I suppose Nynaeve was really there," Reanne said finally, exchanging glances with the other two. "If Elayne taught her to pass, I think she would have done a better job. Some people live in perpetual fog." Garenia sniffed, then nodded slowly. Berowin's nod came entirely too promptly for Nynaeve's liking.

"pliz," ʃi sɛd pəlaɪtli. ʃi kəd bi pəlaɪt wən ðəɹ wɑz ɹizən, wʌtɛvɝ ɛniwʌn sɛd. "wi tʃɹuli nid tə faɪn ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðə si foʊk kɔl ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. ɪts ɪn ə dʌsti oʊl stɔɹɹum sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ən aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ɡɪld, jəɹ sɝkəl, mʌs noʊ wɛɹ. pliz hɛlp ʌs." θɹi sʌɾənli stoʊni feɪsəz stɛɹɾ ət hɝ.

"Please," she said politely. She could be polite when there was reason, whatever anyone said. "We truly need to find a ter'angreal the Sea Folk call the Bowl of the Winds. It's in a dusty old storeroom somewhere in the Rahad, and I think your guild, your Circle, must know where. Please help us." Three suddenly stony faces stared at her.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɡɪld," mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli sɛd kuli, "oʊnli ə fju fɹɛnz u faʊnd noʊ pleɪs ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ . . ." əɡɛn, ðət ɹɛvɝɛntʃəl toʊn. ". . . ən u ɑɹ fulɪʃ ɪnʌf əkeɪʒənəli tə ɹitʃ aʊɾ ə hænd wɛɹ ɪts niɾəd. wɪv noʊ tʃɹʌk wɪð tɛɹæŋɡɹil, əɹ æŋɡɹil, əɹ sɑŋɡɹil iðɝ. wəɹ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ." "ɛɛs sədaɪ" ɛkoʊd wɪð vɛnɝeɪʃən, əz wɛl. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, jə ɑɹ nɑt hɪɹ tə æsk kwɛstʃənz. wɪv mɔɹ fəɹ ju, tə si haʊ fɑɹ juv ɡɔn, æftɝ wɪtʃ jəl bi teɪkən tə ðə kʌntʃɹi ən ɡɪvən ɪndə ðə kɛɹ ʌv ə fɹɛnd. ʃɪl kip jə əntɪl wi dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də nɛkst. əntɪl wi kən bi ʃʊɹ ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹ nɑt lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju. juv ə nu laɪf əhɛɾ ə ju, ə nu tʃæns, ɪf jə kən oʊnli lɛt jɝsɛlf si ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ hɛl jə bæk ɪn ðə taʊɝ dʌz nɑɾ əplaɪ hɪɹ, wɛðɝ ə læk ə dɛkstɛɹəɾi əɹ fɪɹ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. noʊ wʌn wɪl pʊʃ jə tə lɝn əɹ də wʌt jə kænɑt. wʌt jə ɑɹ ɪz səfɪʃənt. naʊ."

"There is no guild," Mistress Corly said coolly, "only a few friends who found no place in the White Tower . . ." Again, that reverential tone. ". . . and who are foolish enough occasionally to reach out a hand where it's needed. We have no truck with ter'angreal, or angreal, or sa'angreal either. We are not Aes Sedai." "Aes Sedai" echoed with veneration, as well. "In any case, you are not here to ask questions. We have more for you, to see how far you've gone, after which you will be taken to the country and given into the care of a friend. She will keep you until we decide what to do next. Until we can be sure the sisters are not looking for you. You have a new life ahead of you, a new chance, if you can only let yourself see it. Whatever held you back in the Tower does not apply here, whether a lack of dexterity or fear or anything else. No one will push you to learn or do what you cannot. What you are is sufficient. Now."

"ɪnʌf," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə wɪntɝi vɔɪs. "lɔŋ ɪnʌf, nɪneɪiv. əɹ dʒju ɪntɛn tə weɪɾ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi fəɹ haʊɛvɝ lɔŋ? ðeɪ də nɑɾ əv ɪt, nɪneɪiv." ɹimuvɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ʃi θɹʌs ðə sɝkəl ʌv ɡoʊld ɑntu hɝ fɪŋɡɝ. fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt ət ðə siɾəd wɪmən, noʊ wʌn wəd bɪliv əɹ ʃildɪd. ʃi wɑz ə kwin aʊɾ ə peɪʃəns. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ hɛɹ wɑz wʌt ʃi wɑz. "aɪ æm ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. aɪm dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, ən aɪ dɪmæn jə ɹilis mi ɪmiɾiətli." nɪneɪiv ɡɹoʊnd.

"Enough," Elayne said in a wintery voice. "Long enough, Nynaeve. Or do you intend to wait in the country for however long? They do not have it, Nynaeve." Removing her Great Serpent ring from her belt pouch, she thrust the circle of gold onto her finger. From the way she looked at the seated women, no one would believe her shielded. She was a queen out of patience. She was Aes Sedai to her hair was what she was. "I am Elayne Trakand, High Seat of House Trakand. I am Daughter-Heir of Andor and Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah, and I demand you release me immediately." Nynaeve groaned.

ɡæɹiniə ɡɹɪməst wɪð dɪsɡʌst, ən bɛɹaʊɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn hɔɹɝ. ɹin kɔɹli ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli, bʌt wən ʃi spoʊk, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz aɪɝn. "aɪ hæd hoʊp sɛɾəl hæd tʃeɪnʒd jəɹ maɪn kənsɝnɪŋ ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ laɪ. aɪ noʊ haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪɾ ɪz, tə sɛɾ aʊt pɹaʊdli fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ðən faɪn jɝsɛlf feɪst wɪð ɹɪtɝnɪŋ hoʊm tə ədmɪt feɪljɝ. bʌt ðəɾ ɪz nɛvɝ sɛd, ivən ɪn dʒoʊk!"

Garenia grimaced with disgust, and Berowin's eyes widened in horror. Reanne Corly shook her head ruefully, but when she spoke, her voice was iron. "I had hoped Setalle had changed your mind concerning that particular lie. I know how hard it is, to set out proudly for the White Tower then find yourself faced with returning home to admit failure. But that is never said, even in joke!"

"aɪ meɪd noʊ dʒoʊk," ɪleɪn sɛd laɪtli. snoʊ wɑz laɪt.

"I made no joke," Elayne said lightly. Snow was light.

ɡæɹiniə lin fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə skaʊl, ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ ɔlɹɛɾi fɔɹmɪŋ əntɪl mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli ɹeɪzd əɹ hænd. "æn ju, nɪneɪiv? dʒju pɝsɪst ɪn ðɪs . . . mædnəs, tu?"

Garenia leaned forward with a scowl, a flow of Air already forming until Mistress Corly raised her hand. "And you, Nynaeve? Do you persist in this . . . madness, too?"

nɪneɪiv fɪld əɹ lʌŋz. ðiz wɪmən hæd tə noʊ wɛɹ ðə boʊl wɑz; ðeɪ dʒʌs hæd tə!

Nynaeve filled her lungs. These women had to know where the Bowl was; they just had to!

"nɪneɪiv!" ɪleɪn sɛd pivɪʃli. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə lɛɾ əɹ fɝɡɛt ðɪs ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪɾ əv tə ɪfɛkt ən ɪskeɪp. ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv hɑɹpɪŋ ɑn ɛvɹi lɪɾəl mɪsstɛp ɪn ə mænɝ ðət kʌt ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹaɪt fɹəm ʌndɝ jəɹ fit.

"Nynaeve!" Elayne said peevishly. She was not going to let her forget this even if they did have to effect an escape. She had a way of harping on every little misstep in a manner that cut the ground right from under your feet.

"aɪ æm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ," nɪneɪiv sɛd wɛɹəli. "ðə tʃɹu æmɪɝlɪn sit, ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ɹeɪzd əs tə ðə ʃɔl ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. ʃiz noʊ oʊldɝ ðən ɪleɪn; jə mʌst əv hɝd." nɑɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðoʊz θɹi hɑɹd feɪsəz. "ʃi sɛn əs tə faɪn ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. wɪð ɪt, wi kən mɛn ðə wɛðɝ." nɑɾ ə flɪkɝ ə tʃeɪnʒ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊld əɹ æŋɡɝ daʊn; ʃi tʃɹuli dɪd. ɪt dʒʌst uzd ʌp dɪspaɪt hɝ. "ju mʌst wɑn ðæt! lʊk ɝaʊn ju! ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ ðə wɝld! ɪf juv ivən ə hɪn ʌv wɛɹ ðə boʊl maɪt bi, tɛl ʌs!"

"I am an Aes Sedai of the Yellow Ajah," Nynaeve said wearily. "The true Amyrlin Seat, Egwene al'Vere, raised us to the shawl in Salidar. She's no older than Elayne; you must have heard." Not a glimmer of change in those three hard faces. "She sent us to find the Bowl of the Winds. With it, we can mend the weather." Not a flicker of change. She tried to hold her anger down; she truly did. It just oozed up despite her. "You must want that! Look around you! The Dark One is strangling the world! If you have even a hint of where the Bowl might be, tell us!"

mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli moʊʃən fəɹ dɛɹiz, hu keɪm ən tʊk ðə kʌps, kæstɪŋ fɪɹfəl, waɪd-aɪd lʊks ət nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. wən ʃi skɝiɾ əweɪ, aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum ɪn fækt, ðə θɹi wɪmən stʊd sloʊli, stændɪŋ laɪk ɡɹɪm mædʒɪstʃɹeɪts pɹənaʊnsɪŋ sɛntəns.

Mistress Corly motioned for Derys, who came and took the cups, casting fearful, wide-eyed looks at Nynaeve and Elayne. When she scurried away, out of the room in fact, the three women stood slowly, standing like grim magistrates pronouncing sentence.

"aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðət jəl nɑɾ æksɛpt əɹ hɛlp," mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli sɛd koʊldli. "aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðɪs hoʊl əfɛɹ." ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ, ʃi pɹɛs θɹi sɪlvɝ mɑɹks ɪndə nɪneɪivz hæn ən ənʌðɝ θɹi ɪndə ɪleɪnz. "ðiz wɪl teɪk jə ə lɪɾəl weɪ. jə kən ɔlsoʊ ɡɛt sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðoʊz dʒɹɛsəz, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk, ɪf nɑt wʌt jə peɪd. ðoʊz ɑɹ hɑɹdli suɾəbəl ɡɑɹməns fəɹ ə dʒɝni. baɪ təmɑɹoʊ sʌnɹaɪz, jəl bi ɡɔn fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ."

"I regret that you will not accept our help," Mistress Corly said coldly. "I regret this whole affair." Reaching into her pouch, she pressed three silver marks into Nynaeve's hand and another three into Elayne's. "These will take you a little way. You can also get something for those dresses, I should think, if not what you paid. Those are hardly suitable garments for a journey. By tomorrow sunrise, you will be gone from Ebou Dar."

"wi ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ," nɪneɪiv toʊl hɝ. "pliz, ɪf jə noʊ - " ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv kɛp saɪlənt. ðə mɛʒɝd floʊ ʌv wɝdz dɪd nɑt sloʊ.

"We aren't going anywhere," Nynaeve told her. "Please, if you know - " She might as well have kept silent. The measured flow of words did not slow.

"æt ðət taɪm wɪl bɪɡɪn sɝkjəleɪɾɪŋ jəɹ dɪskɹɪpʃənz, ən wɪl meɪk sɝɾən ðeɪ ɹitʃ ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. ɪf jə ɑɹ sin æftɝ sʌnɹaɪz, wɪl si ðət ðə sɪstɝz noʊ wɛɹ jə ɑɹ, ən ðə waɪt-kloʊks əz wɛl. jəɹ tʃɔɪs ðən wɪl bi tə ɹʌn, sɝɛndɝ tə ðə sɪstɝz, əɹ daɪ. ɡoʊ, də nɑt ɹɪtɝn, ən jə ʃəd lɪv lɔŋ ɪf jə ɡɪv oʊvɝ ðɪs ɹipʌlsɪv ən deɪnʒɝəs ɹuz. wəɹ dʌn wɪð ju. bɛɹaʊɪn, si tə ðɛm, pliz." bɹʌʃɪŋ bɪtwin ðɛm, ʃi wɛn fɹəm ðə ɹum wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk.

"At that time we will begin circulating your descriptions, and we will make certain they reach the sisters in the Tarasin Palace. If you are seen after sunrise, we will see that the sisters know where you are, and the White-cloaks as well. Your choice then will be to run, surrender to the sisters, or die. Go, do not return, and you should live long if you give over this repulsive and dangerous ruse. We are done with you. Berowin, see to them, please." Brushing between them, she went from the room without looking back.

sʌlənli, nɪneɪiv lɛt hɝsɛlf bi hɝɾɪd daʊn tə ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ. ə stʃɹʌɡəl wəd nɑɾ ətʃiv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp meɪbi biɪŋ θɹoʊn aʊt bɑɾəli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp. laɪt, ʃi dɪd nɑt! ɪleɪn mɑɹtʃt, fɹoʊzən dɪtɝməneɪʃən tə liv ən bi dʌn ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi laɪn ə hɝ.

Sullenly, Nynaeve let herself be herded down to the front door. A struggle would not achieve anything except maybe being thrown out bodily, but she did not like giving up. Light, she did not! Elayne marched, frozen determination to leave and be done shining in every line of her.

ɪn ðə smɔl ɛntʃɹi hɔl, nɪneɪiv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ wʌns mɔɹ. "pliz, ɡæɹiniə, bɛɹaʊɪn, ɪf juv ɛni hɪnt, tɛl ʌs. ɛni klu əɾ ɔl. jə mʌst si haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðɪs ɪz. jə mʌst!"

In the small entry hall, Nynaeve decided to try once more. "Please, Garenia, Berowin, if you have any hint, tell us. Any clue at all. You must see how important this is. You must!"

" 'ðə blaɪndəst ɑɹ ðoʊz u kip ðɛɹ aɪz ʃʌt,' " ɪleɪn kwoʊɾəd, nɑt kwaɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

" 'The blindest are those who keep their eyes shut,' " Elayne quoted, not quite under her breath.

bɛɹaʊɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt nɑt ɡæɹiniə. ʃi pʊɾ əɹ feɪs ɹaɪɾ ɪn nɪneɪivz. "du jə θɪŋk wɝ fulz, ɡɝl? əl tɛl jə ðɪs. ɪf aɪ hæd maɪ weɪ, wi wəd bʌndəl jə aʊt tə ðə fɑɹm noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt jə seɪ. ə fju mʌnθs ʌv æləzəz ətɛnʃənz, ən jud lɝn tə ɡɑɹd jəɹ tʌŋ ən bi ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə hɛlp jə spɪɾ ɑn." nɪneɪiv kənsɪɾɝd hɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɑn ðə noʊz; ʃi dɪd nɑt nid seɪaɪdɑɹ tə juz əɹ fɪst.

Berowin hesitated, but not Garenia. She put her face right in Nynaeve's. "Do you think we're fools, girl? I'll tell you this. If I had my way, we would bundle you out to the farm no matter what you say. A few months of Alise's attentions, and you'd learn to guard your tongue and be grateful for the help you spit on." Nynaeve considered hitting her on the nose; she did not need saidar to use her fist.

"ɡæɹiniə," bɛɹaʊɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "əpɑlədʒaɪz! wi də nɑt hoʊld ɛniwʌn əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl, ən jə noʊ ɪt wɛl. əpɑlədʒaɪz ɪmiɾiətli!"

"Garenia," Berowin said sharply. "Apologize! We do not hold anyone against her will, and you know it well. Apologize immediately!"

ən wʌndɝ ʌv wʌndɝz, ðə wʊmən u wʊɾə stʊd vɛɹi kloʊs tə ðə tɑp hæd ʃi bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊk saɪdweɪz ət ðə wʊmən u wʊɾə stʊd nɪɹ ðə bɑɾəm, ən blʌʃt kɹɪmzən. "aɪ æsk fɝɡɪvnəs," ɡæɹiniə mʌmbəld ət nɪneɪiv. "maɪ tɛmpɝ ɡɛts ðə bɛɾɝ ə mi səmtaɪmz, ən aɪ seɪ wʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə. aɪ hʌmbli æsk fɝɡɪvnəs." ənʌðɝ saɪd-lɔŋ ɡlæns ət bɛɹaʊɪn, hu nɑɾəd, pɹədusɪŋ ə saɪ ʌv oʊpən ɹɪlif.

And wonder of wonders, the woman who would have stood very close to the top had she been Aes Sedai looked sideways at the woman who would have stood near the bottom, and blushed crimson. "I ask forgiveness," Garenia mumbled at Nynaeve. "My temper gets the better of me sometimes, and I say what I have no right to. I humbly ask forgiveness." Another side-long glance at Berowin, who nodded, producing a sigh of open relief.

waɪl nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl ɡeɪpɪŋ, ðə ʃilz wɝ ɹilist, ən ʃi ən ɪleɪn wɝ pʊʃt ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, ðə dɔɹ slæmɪŋ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

While Nynaeve was still gaping, the shields were released, and she and Elayne were pushed into the street, the door slamming shut behind them.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ


CHAPTER 24

ðə kɪn


The Kin

ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl, ɹin θɔt, wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ əz ðə tu stʃɹeɪnʒ ɡɝlz vænɪʃt daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹeɪdzmən ən bɛɡɝz ən əkeɪʒənəl sɪdæn tʃɛɹz. ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə miɾɪŋ ɹum əz sun əz ðə pɛɹ wɑz ɛskɔɹɾɪd fɹəm ɪt. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə meɪk ə ðɛm, ən ðɛɹ pɝsɪstən kleɪmz ɪn ðə feɪs ʌv ɔl ɹizən wɝ oʊnli pɑɹɾ ə hɝ kənfjuʒən.

Incredible, Reanne thought, watching from a window as the two strange girls vanished down the street among the tradesmen and beggars and occasional sedan chairs. She had returned to the meeting room as soon as the pair was escorted from it. She did not know what to make of them, and their persistent claims in the face of all reason were only part of her confusion.

"ðeɪ dɪd nɑt pɝspaɪɹ," bɛɹaʊɪn wɪspɝɾ əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "jɛs?" ʃi wʊɾə ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ ðə nuz tə ɹitʃ ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs ɪn ðə nɛkst aʊɝ ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd. ən ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə deɪnʒɝ. fɪɹ bʌbəld ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl, ðə seɪm pænɪk ðət hæɾ oʊvɝteɪkən əɹ æftɝ wʌn pæsədʒ θɹu ðə sɪlvɝ ɑɹtʃəz wən ʃi wɛn tə tɛs fəɹ æksɛptɪd. dʒʌst əz ʃi hæɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ɪt hæd stɝɾ ɪn ðə jɪɹz sɪns, ʃi tʊk ə fɹɛʃ ɡɹɪp ɑn hɝsɛlf; ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət ðə fɪɹ ʃi maɪt ɹʌn skɹimɪŋ əɡɛn hæd lɔŋ sɪns kɑŋkɝɾ ɛni pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ʃi wʊd. ʃi pɹeɪd ðət ðoʊz ɡɝlz wəɾ əbændən ðɛɹ ɪnsænəɾi. ʃi pɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt, ðeɪ wɝ kɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ ən iðɝ kɛp saɪlən əɹ wɝ nɑt bɪlivd. pɹikɔʃənz wəɾ əv tə bi teɪkən, seɪfɡɑɹdz kæɹiɾ aʊt ðət hæd nɑt bɪn juzd ɪn jɪɹz. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ əz nɪɹ ɑmnɪpəɾənt əz meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns, ðoʊ. ðæt, ʃi nu ɪn əɹ boʊnz.

"They did not perspire," Berowin whispered at her shoulder. "Yes?" She would have arranged for the news to reach the Tarasin Palace in the next hour if she had not given her word. And if not for the danger. Fear bubbled in her middle, the same panic that had overtaken her after one passage through the silver arches when she went to test for Accepted. Just as she had every time it had stirred in the years since, she took a fresh grip on herself; in truth, she did not realize that the fear she might run screaming again had long since conquered any possibility that she would. She prayed that those girls would abandon their insanity. She prayed that if they did not, they were caught far from Ebou Dar and either kept silent or were not believed. Precautions would have to be taken, safeguards carried out that had not been used in years. Aes Sedai were as near omnipotent as made no difference, though. That, she knew in her bones.

"ɛldəst, kəɾ ɪt bi pɑsəbəl ðət ði oʊldɝ ə ðə tu ɹɪli ɪz . . . ? wi tʃænəld, ænd. . . ."

"Eldest, could it be possible that the older of the two really is . . . ? We channeled, and. . . ."

bɛɹaʊɪn tʃɹeɪld ɔf mɪzɝəbli, bʌt ɹin dɪd nɑt nid tə kənsɪɾɝ, nɑɾ ivən sɛɾɪŋ əsaɪd ðə jʌŋɡɝ ɡɝl. waɪ wəɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹitɛn tə bi lɛs, soʊ mʌtʃ lɛs? bɪsaɪdz, ɛni ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊɾə pʊɾ əm ɔl ɑn ðɛɹ niz bɛɡɪŋ mɝsi, nɑt stʊd ðəɹ soʊ səbmɪsɪvli.

Berowin trailed off miserably, but Reanne did not need to consider, not even setting aside the younger girl. Why would any Aes Sedai pretend to be less, so much less? Besides, any real Aes Sedai would have put them all on their knees begging mercy, not stood there so submissively.

"wi dɪd nɑt tʃænəl ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "wi bɹoʊk noʊ ɹul." ðoʊz ɹulz əplaɪd tə hɝ əz stʃɹɪkli əz ɛniwʌn ɛls; ðə vɛɹi fɝst wɑz ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɔl wʌn, ivən ðoʊz sɛɾ əbʌv fəɹ ə taɪm. haʊ kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn ʌðɝwaɪz, wən ðoʊz u wɝ əbʌv mʌst ɪvɛntʃəwəli stɛp daʊn? oʊnli θɹu muvmən ən tʃeɪnʒ kəd ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən.

"We did not channel in front of an Aes Sedai," she said firmly. "We broke no rule." Those rules applied to her as strictly as anyone else; the very first was that they were all one, even those set above for a time. How could it have been otherwise, when those who were above must eventually step down? Only through movement and change could they remain hidden.

"bʌt səm ə ðə ɹumɝz də mɛnʃən ə ɡɝl əz æmɪɝlɪn, ɛldəst. ən ʃi nu - "

"But some of the rumors do mention a girl as Amyrlin, Eldest. And she knew - "

"ɹɛbəlz." ɹin pʊɾ ɪndə ðəɾ ɔl ði aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ dɪsbɪlif ʃi fɛlt. ðəɾ ɛniwʌn ʃəd dɛɹ tə ɹəbɛl əɡɛns ðə waɪt taʊɝ! ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli stʃɹeɪnʒ fəɹ ʌnbəlivəbəl teɪlz tə ətætʃ tə ɛniwʌn laɪk ðæt.

"Rebels." Reanne put into that all the outraged disbelief she felt. That anyone should dare to rebel against the White Tower! It was hardly strange for unbelievable tales to attach to anyone like that.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt lɑɡən, ən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ?" ɡæɹiniə dɪmændəd, ən ɹeɪ-æn fɪkst əɹ wɪð ə stɛɹ. ðə wʊmən hæd ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf ənʌðɝ kʌp ə ti bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ bæk ʌp, ən ʃi mænədʒ tə sɪp dɪfaɪənli.

"What about Logain, and the Red Ajah?" Garenia demanded, and Re-anne fixed her with a stare. The woman had gotten herself another cup of tea before coming back up, and she managed to sip defiantly.

"wʌtɛvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ, ɡæɹiniə, ɪts nɑɾ əɹ pleɪs tə kɹɪɾɪsaɪz ɛniθɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt du." ɹinz maʊθ taɪɾənd. ðət hɑɹdli skwɛɹd wɪð wʌt ʃi fɛl təwɔɹd ðə ɹɛbəlz, bʌt haʊ kəɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ də sətʃ ə θɪŋ?

"Whatever the truth, Garenia, it is not our place to criticize anything Aes Sedai might do." Reanne's mouth tightened. That hardly squared with what she felt toward the rebels, but how could any Aes Sedai do such a thing?

ðə sɑldəiən bɛn əɹ nɛk ɪn ækwiɛsəns, ðoʊ, ən pɝhæps tə haɪd ðə sʌlən twɪst ə hɝ maʊθ. ɹin saɪd. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd ɡɪvən ʌp dʒɹimz ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ lɔŋ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz laɪk bɛɹaʊɪn u bɪlivd, sikɹɪtli ðeɪ θɔt, ðət sʌmhaʊ ðeɪ maɪt wʌn deɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, sʌmhaʊ jɛt bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ wɪmən laɪk ɡæɹiniə, ɔlmoʊst əz pʊɹ ət kipɪŋ ðɛɹ wɪʃɪz sikɹət, ðoʊ ðoʊz wɪʃɪz wɝ tɛn taɪmz əz fɔɹbɪɾən. ðeɪ æktʃəli wʊɾə əv æksɛptɪd waɪldɝz, ən ivən ɡɔn aʊt tə faɪnd ɡɝlz u kəd bi tɔt!

The Saldaean bent her neck in acquiescence, though, and perhaps to hide the sullen twist of her mouth. Reanne sighed. She herself had given up dreams of the Green Ajah long long ago, but there were those like Berowin who believed, secretly they thought, that somehow they might one day return to the White Tower, somehow yet become Aes Sedai. And then there were women like Garenia, almost as poor at keeping their wishes secret, though those wishes were ten times as forbidden. They actually would have accepted wilders, and even gone out to find girls who could be taught!

ɡæɹiniə wɑz nɑt dʌn; ʃi ɔlweɪz skɝɾɪd ði ɛdʒəz ə dɪsəplən, ən fɹikwənli stɛpt oʊvɝ. "wʌɾ ə ðɪs sɛɾəl ɑnən, ðɛn? ðoʊz ɡɝlz noʊ əbaʊt ðə sɝkəl. ði ɑnən wʊmən mʌst əv toʊl ðɛm, ðoʊ haʊ ʃi noʊz. . . ." ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd ɪn ə weɪ ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪntaɪɝli tu ɑstənteɪʃəs fəɹ moʊst ʌðɝz, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə kənsil əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz. ivən wən ʃi ʃʊd. "huɛvɝ bɪtʃɹeɪɾ əs tə hɝ mʌs bi faʊnd, ən əɹ bɪtʃɹeɪəl pʌnɪʃt tu. ʃiz ən ɪnkipɝ, ən ʃi mʌs bi tɔt tə ɡɑɹɾ əɹ tʌŋ!" bɛɹaʊɪn ɡæspt, waɪd-aɪd wɪð ʃɑk, ən dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ soʊ hɑɹd ʃi nɪɹli baʊnst.

Garenia was not done; she always skirted the edges of discipline, and frequently stepped over. "What of this Setalle Anan, then? Those girls know about the Circle. The Anan woman must have told them, though how she knows. . . ." She shuddered in a way that would have been entirely too ostentatious for most others, but she had never been able to conceal her emotions. Even when she should. "Whoever betrayed us to her must be found, and her betrayal punished too. She's an innkeeper, and she must be taught to guard her tongue!" Berowin gasped, wide-eyed with shock, and dropped into a chair so hard she nearly bounced.

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ u ʃi ɪz, ɡæɹiniə," ɹin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɪf sɛɾəl hæd bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ʌs, wi wəd bi kɹɔlɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, bɛɡɪŋ fɝɡɪvnəs ðə hoʊl weɪ." wən ʃi fɝs keɪm tə ɛbu dɑɹ, ʃi hæd bɪn toʊl ðə stɔɹi ʌv ə wʊmən meɪd tə kɹɔl tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən nʌθɪŋ ʃi hæd sin sɪns ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪɾ əɹ kwɛstʃən ɪɾ ɪn ðə list. "ʃi hæz kɛp ðə fju sikɹəts ʃi noʊz fɹəm ɡɹæɾətud, ən aɪ daʊt ðəɾ əz feɪɾəd. ʃi wʊɾə daɪɾ ɪn əɹ fɝs tʃaɪldbɝθ ɪf ðə kɪn hæd nɑt hɛlp hɝ. wʌt ʃi noʊz kʌmz fɹəm kɛɹləs tʌŋz, wən ɪt wɑz θɔt ʃi kəd nɑt hɪɹ, ən ði oʊnɝz ə ðoʊz tʌŋz wɝ pʌnɪʃt mɔɹ ðən twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ." stɪl, ʃi wɪʃt ðəɹ wɑz səm weɪ ʃi kəd bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə æsk sɛɾəl tə bi mɔɹ sɝkəmspɛkt. ʃi mʌst əv spoʊkən kɛɹləsli ɪn fɹʌn ə ðoʊz ɡɝlz.

"Remember who she is, Garenia," Reanne said sharply. "If Setalle had betrayed us, we would be crawling to Tar Valon, begging forgiveness the whole way." When she first came to Ebou Dar, she had been told the story of a woman made to crawl to the White Tower, and nothing she had seen since of Aes Sedai made her question it in the least. "She has kept the few secrets she knows from gratitude, and I doubt that has faded. She would have died in her first childbirth if the Kin had not helped her. What she knows comes from careless tongues, when it was thought she could not hear, and the owners of those tongues were punished more than twenty years ago." Still, she wished there was some way she could bring herself to ask Setalle to be more circumspect. She must have spoken carelessly in front of those girls.

ðə wʊmən baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛn, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ wɑz sɛt stʌbɝnli. ət lis pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs tɝn, ɹin dɪsaɪɾɪd, ɡæɹiniə wəd spɛn ət ðə ɹitʃɹit, ən ʃi wəɾ əv spɛʃəl ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ɹileɪ wɪð əɹ oʊn stʌbɝn maʊθ. æləz sɛldəm ɹikwaɪɝd mɔɹ ðən ə wik tə meɪk ə wʊmən dɪsaɪd stʌbɝnnəs dɪd nɑt peɪ.

The woman bowed her head again, but her mouth was set stubbornly. At least part of this turn, Reanne decided, Garenia would spend at the retreat, and she would have special instructions to relay with her own stubborn mouth. Alise seldom required more than a week to make a woman decide stubbornness did not pay.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ɪnfɔɹm ɡæɹiniə, ðoʊ, dɛɹiz wɑz kɝtsiɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ənaʊnsɪŋ sɹeɪnjə vɔstoʊvən. əz juʒəwəl, sɹeɪnjə swɛpt ɹaɪɾ ɪn bɪfɔɹ ɹin kəd seɪ tə ədmɪt hɝ. ɪn səm weɪz, ðə stʃɹaɪkɪŋli hænsəm wʊmən meɪd ɡæɹiniə əpɪɹ sʌpəl, dɪspaɪt kipɪŋ ðə fɔɹm ʌv ɛvɹi ɹul ɪɡzækli. ɹin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wʊɾə wɔɹn əɹ hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz ən bɛlz ɡɪvən ðə tʃɔɪs, ən nɛvɝ maɪn haʊ ðət wʊɾə lʊkt wɪð əɹ ɹɛd bɛlt. bʌt ðɛn, ɡɪvən ðə tʃɔɪs ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv sɝvd ivən wʌn tɝn wɪð ðə bɛlt.

Before she could inform Garenia, though, Derys was curtsying in the doorway, announcing Sarainya Vostovan. As usual, Sarainya swept right in before Reanne could say to admit her. In some ways, the strikingly handsome woman made Garenia appear supple, despite keeping the form of every rule exactly. Reanne was sure she would have worn her hair in braids and bells given the choice, and never mind how that would have looked with her red belt. But then, given the choice she would not have served even one turn with the belt.

sɹeɪnjə dɪd kɝtsi ət ðə dɔɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən nil bɪfɔɹ hɝ, hɛd loʊɝd, bʌt fɪfti jɪɹz hæd nɑt meɪɾ əɹ fɝɡɛt ðət ʃi wʊɾə bɪn ə wʊmən ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl paʊɝ hæd ʃi bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk hɝsɛlf ɹɪtɝn hoʊm tə ɝæfəl. kɝtsi ən ðə ɹɛst ɔl wɝ kənsɛʃənz. wən ʃi spoʊk, ɪn ðət hʌski, fɔɹsfəl vɔɪs, wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən wəɾ ɛvɝ ɹɛkənsaɪl hɝsɛlf ən ðə pɹɑbləm ʌv ɡæɹiniə lɛft ɹinz maɪnd!

Sarainya did curtsy at the door, of course, and kneel before her, head lowered, but fifty years had not made her forget that she would have been a woman of considerable power had she been able to make herself return home to Arafel. Curtsy and the rest all were concessions. When she spoke, in that husky, forceful voice, whether the woman would ever reconcile herself and the problem of Garenia left Reanne's mind!

"kɔli ɪz dɛd, ɛldəst sɪstɝ. hɝ θɹoʊt wɑz kʌɾ ən ʃi əpɛɹənli hæd bɪn ɹɑbd ivən ə hɝ stɑkɪŋz, bʌt sumeɪkoʊ sɛz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ðə wʌn paʊɝ kɪl hɝ."

"Callie is dead, Eldest Sister. Her throat was cut and she apparently had been robbed even of her stockings, but Sumeko says that it was the One Power killed her."

"ðæɾ ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl!" bɛɹaʊɪn bɝst aʊt. "noʊ kɪnswʊmən wəd də sətʃ ə θɪŋ!"

"That is impossible!" Berowin burst out. "No Kinswoman would do such a thing!"

"æn ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɡæɹiniə sɛd, hɛzɪɾənt fəɹ wʌns. "bʌt haʊ? ðə θɹi oʊðz. sumeɪkoʊ mʌs bi ɹɔŋ."

"An Aes Sedai?" Garenia said, hesitant for once. "But how? The Three Oaths. Sumeko must be wrong."

ɹin ɹeɪzd ə hæn fəɹ saɪləns. sumeɪkoʊ wɑz nɛvɝ ɹɔŋ, nɑɾ ɪn ðɪs ɛɹiə. ʃi wʊɾə bɪn jɛloʊ ədʒɑ hæd ʃi nɑt bɹoʊkən daʊn kəmplitli waɪl tɛstɪŋ fəɹ ðə ʃɔl, ən ɔlðoʊ ɪt wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən, dɪspaɪt kaʊnləs pɛnənsɪz, ʃi wɝk tə lɝn mɔɹ wɛnɛvɝ ʃi θɔt noʊ wʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ cʊɾə dʌn ðɪs, ɑbviəsli, ən noʊ kɪnz-wʊmən wəd hæv, bʌt. . . . ðoʊz ɡɝlz, soʊ ɪnsɪstənt, noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt. ðə sɝkəl hæd læstəd tu lɔŋ, ɔfɝd sʌkɝ tə tu mɛni wɪmən, tə bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd naʊ.

Reanne raised a hand for silence. Sumeko was never wrong, not in this area. She would have been Yellow Ajah had she not broken down completely while testing for the shawl, and although it was forbidden, despite countless penances, she worked to learn more whenever she thought no one was watching. No Aes Sedai could have done this, obviously, and no Kins-woman would have, but. . . . Those girls, so insistent, knowing what they should not. The Circle had lasted too long, offered succor to too many women, to be destroyed now.

"ðɪs ɪz wʌt mʌs bi dʌn," ʃi toʊl ðɛm. ðət flʌɾɝ ə fɪɹ bɪɡæn əɡɛn, bʌt fəɹ wʌns ʃi hɑɹdli noʊɾəst.

"This is what must be done," she told them. That flutter of fear began again, but for once she hardly noticed.

nɪneɪiv stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə smɔl haʊs ɪn aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ɪt wɑz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl! ðoʊz wɪmən dɪɾ əv ə ɡɪld; ʃi nu ðeɪ dɪd! wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ sɛd, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ nu wɛɹ ðə boʊl wɑz, tu. ʃi wʊɾə dʌn wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə bɹɪŋ əm tə tɛl hɝ. pɹitɛndɪŋ dɑsɪləɾi bɪfɔɹ əm fəɹ ə fju aʊɝz wʊɾə bɪn ə dil iziɝ ðən pʊɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð mæt kɔθən fəɹ ðə laɪt nu haʊ mɛni deɪz.

Nynaeve stalked away from the small house in outrage. It was incredible! Those women did have a guild; she knew they did! Whatever they said, she was sure they knew where the Bowl was, too. She would have done whatever was necessary to bring them to tell her. Pretending docility before them for a few hours would have been a deal easier than putting up with Mat Cauthon for the Light knew how many days.

aɪ cʊɾə bɪn əz əkwiɛsən əz ðeɪ wɑntəd, ʃi θɔɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ðeɪɾ əv θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ə plaɪəbəl oʊl slɪpɝ! aɪ kəd hæv. . . . ðət wɑz ə laɪ, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk ə faʊl, ɹɪmɛmbɝd teɪs tə kənvɪns hɝ. ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns, ʃi wʊɾə ʃeɪkən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən tɪl ðeɪ toʊld əɹ wʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ. ʃi wʊɾə ɡɪvən əm ɛɛs sədaɪ tɪl ðeɪ skwikt!

I could have been as acquiescent as they wanted, she thought irritably. They'd have thought I was a pliable old slipper! I could have. . . . That was a lie, and it did not take a foul, remembered taste to convince her. Given half a chance, she would have shaken every one of those women till they told her what she wanted to know. She would have given them Aes Sedai till they squeaked!

ʃi skaʊl saɪdweɪz əɾ ɪleɪn. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən sim lɔst ɪn θɔt. nɪneɪiv wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðə wʊmən wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt. ə weɪstəd mɔɹnɪŋ, ən nɑt fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə kəmplit hjumɪlieɪʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ. ʃi wɑz nɑt jɛt juz tə ædmɪɾɪŋ ʃi wɑz, ɹɪli. ən naʊ ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə əpɑlədʒaɪz tə ɪleɪn. ʃi tʃɹuli heɪɾəd əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ. wɛl, ɪt wəd bi bæɾ ɪnʌf bæk ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz. wɪð bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə stɪl aʊt, ɪt wɑz tə bi hoʊpt. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bɪɡɪn ɪn ðə stʃɹit, wɪð u nu hu stʃɹimɪŋ baɪ. ðə θɹɔŋ hæd θɪkənd, ðoʊ ðə sʌn hɑɹdli simd mʌtʃ haɪɝ θɹu ðə wilɪŋ klaʊdz ə sibɝdz ðət kɹaɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd.

She scowled sideways at Elayne. The other woman seemed lost in thought. Nynaeve wished she did not know what the woman was thinking about. A wasted morning, and not far short of complete humiliation. She did not like being in the wrong. She was not yet used to admitting she was, really. And now she was going to have to apologize to Elayne. She truly hated apologizing. Well, it would be bad enough back in their rooms. With Birgitte and Aviendha still out, it was to be hoped. She was not about to begin in the street, with who knew who streaming by. The throng had thickened, though the sun hardly seemed much higher through the wheeling clouds of seabirds that cried overhead.

faɪndɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ wɑz nɑɾ izi, æftɝ ɔl ðoʊz twɪsts ən tɝnz. nɪneɪiv hæd tə æsk dɝɛkʃənz hæf ə dʌzən taɪmz, waɪl ɪleɪn stɛɹɾ ɪn ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən, pɹitɛndɪŋ ɪndɪfɝəns. ʃi stɔkt əlɔŋ əkɹɔs bɹɪdʒəz, dʌkt ɝaʊnd wæɡənz ən kɑɹts, dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ɹeɪsɪŋ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ðət woʊv θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz, wɪʃt ɪleɪn wəd seɪ sʌmθɪŋ. nɪneɪiv nu haʊ tə nɝs ə ɡɹʌdʒ, ən ðə lɔŋɡɝ ʃi hɝsɛlf kɛp saɪlənt, ðə wɝs ɪt wɑz wən ʃi spoʊk, soʊ ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪleɪn wɔkt wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, ðə dɑɹkɝ bɪkeɪm ði ɪmədʒ ɪn əɹ maɪn ə haʊ ɪt wɑz gɑnə bi bæk ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz. ðət meɪɾ əɹ fjʊɹiəs. ʃi hæɾ ədmɪɾəd ʃi wɑz ɹɔŋ, ɪf oʊnli tə hɝsɛlf. ɪleɪn hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə meɪk əɹ sʌfɝ ðɪs weɪ. ʃi bɪɡæn wɛɹɪŋ sətʃ ə feɪs ðəɾ ivən pipəl u dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs ðɛɹ ɹɪŋz ɡeɪv əm ə klɪɹ pæθ. pipəl u dɪd noʊɾəs juʒəwəli sim tə faɪn ən ɝdʒənt nid tə bi ə stʃɹiɾ əweɪ. ivən səm sɪdæn-tʃɛɹ bɛɹɝz skɝɾɪd ɝaʊn hɝ.

Finding their way was not easy, after all those twists and turns. Nynaeve had to ask directions half a dozen times, while Elayne stared in another direction, pretending indifference. She stalked along across bridges, ducked around wagons and carts, jumped out of the way of racing sedan chairs that wove through the crowds, wished Elayne would say something. Nynaeve knew how to nurse a grudge, and the longer she herself kept silent, the worse it was when she spoke, so the longer Elayne walked without speaking, the darker became the image in her mind of how it was going to be back in their rooms. That made her furious. She had admitted she was wrong, if only to herself. Elayne had no right to make her suffer this way. She began wearing such a face that even people who did not notice their rings gave them a clear path. People who did notice usually seemed to find an urgent need to be a street away. Even some sedan-chair bearers skirted around her.

"haʊ oʊl dɪd ɹin lʊk tə ju?" ɪleɪn æsk sʌɾənli. nɪneɪiv nɪɹli dʒʌmpt. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊs bæk tə mɔl hɛɹə.

"How old did Reanne look to you?" Elayne asked suddenly. Nynaeve nearly jumped. They were almost back to Mol Hara.

"fɪfti jɪɹz. meɪbi sɪksti. aɪ doʊn si ɪt mæɾɝz." ʃi ɹæn əɹ aɪz oʊvɝ ðə kɹaʊd tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ. ə pæsɪŋ hɔkɝ, hɝ tʃɹeɪ dɪspleɪɪŋ ə bɪɾɝ lɪɾəl jɛloʊ fɹut kɔld ə lɛmən, tʃɹaɪd tə swɑloʊ hɝ kɹaɪ ɪn mɪdʃaʊt wən nɪneɪivz ɡeɪz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn əɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, wɪð ðə ɹɪzʌl ðət ʃi dʌbəld oʊvɝ əɹ tʃɹeɪ kɑfɪŋ ən tʃoʊkɪŋ. nɪneɪiv snɪft. ðə wʊmən pɹɑbli hæd bɪn ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, ɪf nɑt plænɪŋ tə kʌɾ ə pɝs. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ə ɡɪld, ɪleɪn, ən ðeɪ də noʊ wɛɹ ðə boʊl ɪz. aɪ dʒʌs noʊ ðeɪ du." ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ əɾ ɔl. ɪf ʃi əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪleɪn ɪndə ðɪs naʊ, meɪbi ɪt wəd nɑt bi soʊ bæd.

"Fifty years. Maybe sixty. I don't see it matters." She ran her eyes over the crowd to see if anyone was close enough to hear. A passing hawker, her tray displaying a bitter little yellow fruit called a lemon, tried to swallow her cry in midshout when Nynaeve's gaze rested on her for a moment, with the result that she doubled over her tray coughing and choking. Nynaeve sniffed. The woman probably had been eavesdropping, if not planning to cut a purse. "They are a guild, Elayne, and they do know where the Bowl is. I just know they do." That was not what she had intended to say at all. If she apologized for dragging Elayne into this now, maybe it would not be so bad.

"aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ ɑɹ," ɪleɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. "aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ maɪt. haʊ ɪz ɪt ðət ʃi kən əv eɪdʒ soʊ?"

"I suppose they are," Elayne said absently. "I suppose they might. How is it that she can have aged so?"

nɪneɪiv stɑp dɛɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl stʃɹit. æftɝ ɔl ðəɾ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, æftɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ əm θɹoʊn aʊt, ʃi səpoʊzd? "wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz ʃi eɪdʒ ðə seɪm weɪ əz ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, ə deɪ əɾ ə taɪm. ɪleɪn, ɪf jə bɪlivd, waɪ dɪd jə ənaʊns u jə wɝ laɪk ɹiænən ət ðə taʊɝ?" ʃi ɹæðɝ laɪk ðæt; əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə stɔɹi, wʌt kwin ɹiænən ɡɑt wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd wɑntəd.

Nynaeve stopped dead in the middle street. After all that arguing, after getting them thrown out, she supposed? "Well, I suppose she aged the same way as the rest of us, a day at a time. Elayne, if you believed, why did you announce who you were like Rhiannon at the Tower?" She rather liked that; according to the story, what Queen Rhiannon got was far from what she had wanted.

ðə kwɛstʃən dɪd nɑt sim tə ɹɛdʒɪstɝ wɪð ɪleɪn, fəɹ ɔl əɹ ɛdʒəkeɪʃən. ʃi pʊl nɪneɪiv tə wʌn saɪɾ əz ə kɝteɪnd ɡɹin kæɹɪdʒ ɹʌmbəl pæst - ðə stʃɹit wɑz nɑt vɛɹi waɪd ðəɹ - oʊvɝ tə ðə fɹʌn ʌv ə sim-stʃɹɛsəz ʃɑp wɪð ə waɪd dɔɹweɪ ʃoʊɪŋ sɛvɹəl dʒɹɛsmeɪkɝz fɔɹmz kloʊðd ɪn hæf-dʌn dʒɹɛsəz.

The question did not seem to register with Elayne, for all her education. She pulled Nynaeve to one side as a curtained green carriage rumbled past - the street was not very wide there - over to the front of a seam-stress's shop with a wide doorway showing several dressmaker's forms clothed in half-done dresses.

"ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə tɛl əs ɛniθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv, nɑɾ ɪf jə ɡɑt daʊn ɑn jəɹ niz ən bɛɡd." nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ɪndɪɡnənli, ðən snæpt ɪt ʃʌt. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt bɛɡɪŋ. ɛniweɪ, waɪ ʃəd ʃi hæv bɪn ði oʊnli wʌn? bɛɾɝ ɛni wʊmən əɾ ɔl ðən mæt kɔθən. ɪleɪn hæɾ ə flaɪ ʌp əɹ noʊz, ðoʊ, ən wɑz nɑt tə bi dɪstʃɹæktəd. "nɪneɪiv, ʃi mʌst əv sloʊd laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. haʊ oʊld ɪz ʃi, tə lʊk fɪfti əɹ sɪksti?"

"They were not going to tell us anything, Nynaeve, not if you got down on your knees and begged." Nynaeve opened her mouth indignantly, then snapped it shut. She had never said anything about begging. Anyway, why should she have been the only one? Better any woman at all than Mat Cauthon. Elayne had a fly up her nose, though, and was not to be distracted. "Nynaeve, she must have slowed like everyone else. How old is she, to look fifty or sixty?"

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ nɪneɪiv noʊɾəd ðə loʊkeɪʃən ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maɪnd; ðə simstʃɹɪsəz wɝk lʊkt kwaɪt ɡʊd, wɝθ kloʊsɝ ɪɡzæməneɪʃən. "ʃi pɹɑbli dʌzn tʃænəl ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi kən hɛlp, əfɹeɪɾ əz ʃiz ə biɪŋ mɪsteɪkən fəɹ ə sɪstɝ. ʃi wʊdn əv wɑntəɾ əɹ feɪs tu smuð, æftɝ ɔl."

"What are you talking about?" Without thinking Nynaeve noted the location in a corner of her mind; the seamstress's work looked quite good, worth closer examination. "She probably doesn't channel any more than she can help, afraid as she is of being mistaken for a sister. She wouldn't have wanted her face too smooth, after all."

"ju nɛvɝ lɪsən ɪn klæs, dɪd ju?" ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. ʃi sɔ ðə plʌmp simstʃɹɪs bimɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən dʒɹu nɪneɪiv təwɔɹd ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ði əmaʊn ə leɪs ðə simstʃɹɪs wɔɹ ɑn əɹ oʊn dʒɹɛs, ðə bɑɾəs bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɪɾ ən peɪsɪz ʌv ɪt dʒɹupɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ɪkspoʊz pɛɾikoʊts, ʃi wəd bɛɹ kloʊs wɑtʃɪŋ ɪf nɪneɪiv dɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ ɛniθɪŋ. "fɝɡɛt kloʊðz fəɹ wʌn moʊmənt, nɪneɪiv. hu ɪz ði oʊldəst æksɛptɪd jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ?"

"You never listened in class, did you?" Elayne murmured. She saw the plump seamstress beaming in the doorway, and drew Nynaeve toward the corner of the building. Considering the amount of lace the seamstress wore on her own dress, the bodice buried in it and paces of it drooping over her exposed petticoats, she would bear close watching if Nynaeve did order anything. "Forget clothes for one moment, Nynaeve. Who is the oldest Accepted you remember?"

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə vɛɹi lɛvəl lʊk. ðə wʊmən meɪɾ ɪt saʊn əz ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls! ən ʃi hæd tu lɪsənd. səmtaɪmz. "ɛlɪn wɔɹəl, aɪ θɪŋk. ʃiz ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən mi." ʌv kɔɹs, ðə simstʃɹɪsəz oʊn dʒɹɛs wəd lʊk faɪn wɪð ə mɔɹ mɑɾəst nɛklaɪn ən mʌtʃ lɛs leɪs. ɪn ɡɹin sɪlk. læn laɪkt ɡɹin, ðoʊ ʃi sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt gɑnə tʃuz əɹ dʒɹɛsəz fəɹ hɪm. hi laɪk blu, əz wɛl.

She gave Elayne a very level look. The woman made it sound as if she never thought of anything else! And she had too listened. Sometimes. "Elin Warrel, I think. She's a few years older than me." Of course, the seamstress's own dress would look fine with a more modest neckline and much less lace. In green silk. Lan liked green, though she certainly was not going to choose her dresses for him. He liked blue, as well.

ɪleɪn bɑɹk sətʃ ə læf ðət nɪneɪiv wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi hæd spoʊkən əlaʊd. kʌlɝɪŋ fɪɹsli, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪkspleɪn - ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kʊd; baɪ bɛl taɪn - bʌt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪv əɹ noʊ ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ ə wɝd. "ɛlɪnz sɪstɝ keɪm tə vɪzəɾ əɹ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ jə fɝst ɝaɪvd ət ðə taʊɝ, nɪneɪiv. hɝ jʌŋɡɝ sɪstɝ. ðə wʊmən hæd ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ. wɛl, səm ʌv ɪt wɑz. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn oʊvɝ fɔɹɾi, nɪneɪiv."

Elayne barked such a laugh that Nynaeve wondered whether she had spoken aloud. Coloring fiercely, she tried to explain - she was sure she could; by Bel Tine - but the other woman gave her no opportunity for a word. "Elin's sister came to visit her just before you first arrived at the Tower, Nynaeve. Her younger sister. The woman had gray hair. Well, some of it was. She must have been over forty, Nynaeve."

ɛlɪn wɔɹəl wɑz pæs fɔɹɾi? bʌt . . . ! "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ, ɪleɪn?"

Elin Warrel was past forty? But . . . ! "What are you saying, Elayne?"

noʊ wʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə lɪsən, ən noʊ wʌn sim tə bi ɡɪvɪŋ əm ə sɛkənd ɡlæns ɪksɛp ðə stɪl hoʊpfəl simstʃɹɪs, bʌɾ ɪleɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs tə ə wɪspɝ. "wi sloʊ, nɪneɪiv. sʌmwɛɹ bɪtwin twɛnti ən twɛnti-faɪv, wi bɪɡɪn eɪdʒɪŋ mɔɹ sloʊli. haʊ mʌtʃ dɪpɛnz ɑn haʊ stʃɹɔŋ wi ɑɹ, bʌt wən dʌznt. ɛni wʊmən u kən tʃænəl dʌz ɪt. tɑkimə sɛd ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ətʃivɪŋ ði eɪdʒləs lʊk, ðoʊ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɛniwʌn əz ɛvɝ ɹitʃt ðəɾ əntɪl ðeɪv wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl ət list ə jɪɹ əɹ tu, səmtaɪmz faɪv əɹ mɔɹ. θɪŋk. jə noʊ ɛni sɪstɝ wɪð ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɪz oʊld, ivən ɪf jə ɑɹən səpoʊz tə mɛnʃən ɪt. soʊ ɪf ɹin sloʊd, ən ʃi mʌs hæv, haʊ oʊld ɪz ʃi?"

No one was close enough to listen, and no one seemed to be giving them a second glance except the still hopeful seamstress, but Elayne lowered her voice to a whisper. "We slow, Nynaeve. Somewhere between twenty and twenty-five, we begin aging more slowly. How much depends on how strong we are, but when doesn't. Any woman who can channel does it. Takima said she thought it was the beginning of achieving the ageless look, though I don't think anyone has ever reached that until they've worn the shawl at least a year or two, sometimes five or more. Think. You know any sister with gray hair is old, even if you aren't supposed to mention it. So if Reanne slowed, and she must have, how old is she?"

nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt kɛɹ haʊ oʊld ɹin wɑz. ʃi wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. noʊ wʌndɝ ɛvɹiwʌn ɹəfjuz tə bɪliv əɹ eɪdʒ. ɪɾ ɪkspleɪnd waɪ ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm hæd lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd fʊli. ətʃivɪŋ ə sɪstɝz eɪdʒləs feɪs wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹz?

Nynaeve did not care how old Reanne was. She wanted to cry. No wonder everyone refused to believe her age. It explained why the Women's Circle back home had looked over her shoulder as if unsure she was old enough to be trusted fully. Achieving a sister's ageless face was all very well, but how long before she had her gray hairs?

blɪŋkɪŋ, ʃi tɝn əweɪ æŋɡɹəli. ən sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk əɹ ə ɡlænsɪŋ bloʊ ɑn ðə bæk ə ðə hɛd. stæɡɝɪŋ, ʃi ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ɪleɪn ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. waɪ hæd ðə wʊmən hɪt hɝ? oʊnli, ɪleɪn leɪ ɪn ə hip, aɪz kloʊzd ən ə næsti pɝpəl lʌmp ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn əɹ tɛmpəl. ɡɹɑdʒəli, nɪneɪiv fɛl tə hɝ niz ən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ fɹɛn ɪndə hɝ ɑɹmz.

Blinking, she turned away angrily. And something struck her a glancing blow on the back of the head. Staggering, she rounded on Elayne in astonishment. Why had the woman hit her? Only, Elayne lay in a heap, eyes closed and a nasty purple lump rising on her temple. Groggily, Nynaeve fell to her knees and gathered her friend into her arms.

"jɔɹ fɹɛn mʌs bi teɪkən ɪl," ə lɔŋ noʊzd wʊmən sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛm, kɛɹləs ʌv ə jɛloʊ dʒɹɛs ðət ʃoʊd fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ bʊzəm ivən baɪ ɛbu dɑɹi stændɝdz. "lɛt mi hɛlp."

"Your friend must be taken ill," a long nosed woman said, kneeling beside them, careless of a yellow dress that showed far too much bosom even by Ebou Dari standards. "Let me help."

ə tɔl fɛloʊ, hænsəm ɪn ɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlk vɛst ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɹæðɝ ɔɪli ɡɹɪn, bɛn tə teɪk nɪneɪivz ʃoʊldɝz. "hɪɹ, aɪ hæv ə kæɹɪdʒ. wɪl teɪk jə sʌmwɛɹ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ðən ə peɪvɪŋ stoʊn."

A tall fellow, handsome in his embroidered silk vest except for a rather oily grin, bent to take Nynaeve's shoulders. "Here, I have a carriage. We'll take you somewhere more comfortable than a paving stone."

"ɡoʊ əweɪ," nɪneɪiv toʊld əm pəlaɪtli. "wi doʊnt nid jəɹ hɛlp."

"Go away," Nynaeve told them politely. "We don't need your help."

ðə mæn kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪz əɹ tə hɝ fit, ðoʊ, tə ɡaɪɾ əɹ təwɔɹɾ ə ɹɛd kæɹɪdʒ, wɛɹ ə stɑɹɾəld-əpɪɹɪŋ wʊmən ɪn blu bɛkən vɪɡɝəsli. ðə lɔŋ-noʊzd wʊmən æktʃəli  tʃɹaɪd tə lɪft ɪleɪn, θæŋkɪŋ ðə mæn fəɹ ɪz hɛlp ən tʃæɾɝɪŋ haʊ hɪz kæɹɪdʒ saʊndəɾ ə faɪn aɪdiə. ə kɹaʊɾ ʌv ɔnlʊkɝz sim tə hæv ɡæðɝɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛɹ ɪn ə sɛmɪsɝkəl, wɪmən mɝmɝɪŋ sɪmpəθi əbaʊt feɪntɪŋ fɹəm ðə hit, mɛn ɔfɝɪŋ tə hɛlp kæɹi ðə leɪɾiz. ə skɹɔni fɛloʊ, boʊld əz jə pliz, ɹitʃt fəɹ nɪneɪivz pɝs ɔlmoʊst ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ noʊz.

The man kept trying to raise her to her feet, though, to guide her toward a red carriage, where a startled-appearing woman in blue beckoned vigorously. The long-nosed woman actually tried to lift Elayne, thanking the man for his help and chattering how his carriage sounded a fine idea. A crowd of onlookers seemed to have gathered out of air in a semicircle, women murmuring sympathy about fainting from the heat, men offering to help carry the ladies. A scrawny fellow, bold as you please, reached for Nynaeve's purse almost right under her nose.

hɝ hɛd stɪl swæm ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ dɪfəkəlt, bʌɾ ɪf ɔl ðoʊz næɾɝɪŋ foʊk hæd nɑt fjuəld əɹ tɛmpɝ, wʌt ʃi sɔ laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹit wəd hæv. ən æɹoʊ wɪð ə blʌn stoʊn hɛd. ðə wʌn ðət hæd ɡɹeɪzd əɹ əɹ ðə wʌn ðət hæd stʃɹʌk ɪleɪn. ʃi tʃænəld, ən ðə skɹɔni kʌtpɝs dʌbəld oʊvɝ, klʌtʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ən skwilɪŋ laɪk ə pɪɡ ɪn bɹaɪɹz. ənʌðɝ floʊ, ən ðə lɔŋ-noʊzd wʊmən fɛl oʊvɝ bækwɝd wɪð ə ʃɹik twaɪs əz haɪ. ðə mæn ɪn ðə sɪlk vɛst əpɛɹənli dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪz hɛlp æftɝ ɔl, kəz i tɝn ən ɹæn fəɹ ðə kæɹɪdʒ, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə doʊs ɛniweɪ. hi aʊt-bɛloʊɾ ɛni aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ bʊl əz ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə kæɹɪdʒ hɔld ɪm ɪn baɪ hɪz vɛst.

Her head still swam enough to make embracing saidar difficult, but if all those nattering folk had not fueled her temper, what she saw lying in the street would have. An arrow with a blunt stone head. The one that had grazed her or the one that had struck Elayne. She channeled, and the scrawny cutpurse doubled over, clutching himself and squealing like a pig in briars. Another flow, and the long-nosed woman fell over backward with a shriek twice as high. The man in the silk vest apparently decided they did not need his help after all, because he turned and ran for the carriage, but she gave him a dose anyway. He out-bellowed any outraged bull as the woman in the carriage hauled him in by his vest.

"θæŋk ju, bʌt wi doʊnt niɾ ɛni hɛlp," nɪneɪiv ʃaʊɾəd. pəlaɪtli.

"Thank you, but we don't need any help," Nynaeve shouted. Politely.

fju ɹɪmeɪn tə hɪɹ. wʌns ɪt bɪkeɪm klɪɹ ðət ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz biɪŋ juzd - ən foʊk sʌɾənli lipɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən jɛlɪŋ fəɹ noʊ vɪzəbəl kɑz meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ɪnʌf tə moʊst - ðeɪ hɝiɾ ɛlswɛɹ. ðə lɔŋ-noʊzd wʊmən ɡæðɝd hɝsɛlf ʌp ən æktʃəli  dʒʌmpt ɑntu ðə bæk ə ðə ɹɛd kæɹɪdʒ, klɪŋɪŋ pɹɪkɛɹiəsli əz ðə dɑɹk-vɛstəd dʒɹaɪvɝ wɪp ðə hɔɹsəz əweɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, pipəl lipɪŋ əsaɪd. ivən ðə kʌtpɝs hɑbəld ɔf əz fæst əz i kʊd.

Few remained to hear. Once it became clear that the One Power was being used - and folk suddenly leaping about and yelling for no visible cause made it clear enough to most - they hurried elsewhere. The long-nosed woman gathered herself up and actually jumped onto the back of the red carriage, clinging precariously as the dark-vested driver whipped the horses away through the crowd, people leaping aside. Even the cutpurse hobbled off as fast as he could.

nɪneɪiv kəd nɑɾ əv kɛɹd lɛs hæd ði ɝθ oʊpən ən swɑloʊd ðə hoʊl lɑt. tʃɛst eɪkɪŋ, ʃi ɹæn faɪn floʊz ʌv wɪn ən wɔɾɝ, ɝθ, faɪɝ ən spɪɹət mɪkst ən blɛndəd, θɹu ɪleɪn. ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl wiv, noʊ bɑðɝ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ feɪn dɪzinəs, ən ðə ɹɪzʌlt lɛɾ əɹ bɹið əɡɛn. ðə bɹuz wɑz nɑt sɪɹiəs; ðə boʊnz ʌv ɪleɪnz skʌl wɝ ənbɹoʊkən. nɔɹməli, ʃi wʊɾə ɹiɾɝɛktɪd ðoʊz seɪm floʊz ɪndə mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmplɛks wivz, ðə hilɪŋ ʃi hæd dɪskʌvɝd hɝsɛlf. ət ðə moʊmənt, sɪmpəlɝ wivz wɝ ɔl ʃi kəd mænədʒ, ðoʊ. wɪð dʒʌst spɪɹət, wɪn ən wɔɾɝ, ʃi woʊv ðə hilɪŋ ðət jɛloʊz hæd juz sɪns taɪm ɪməmɔɹiəl.

Nynaeve could not have cared less had the earth opened and swallowed the whole lot. Chest aching, she ran fine flows of Wind and Water, Earth, Fire and Spirit mixed and blended, through Elayne. It was a simple weave, no bother despite her faint dizziness, and the result let her breathe again. The bruise was not serious; the bones of Elayne's skull were unbroken. Normally, she would have redirected those same flows into much more complex weaves, the Healing she had discovered herself. At the moment, simpler weaves were all she could manage, though. With just Spirit, Wind and Water, she wove the Healing that Yellows had used since time immemorial.

ɪleɪnz aɪz ʃɑɾ oʊpən waɪd, ən wɪð ə ɡæsp ðət sim tə teɪk ɔl ði ɛɹ ɪn hɝ, ʃi kənvʌls laɪk ə nɛɾɪd tʃɹaʊt, slɪpɝd hilz dʒɹʌmɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvmənt. ðəɾ oʊnli læstəɾ ə moʊmənt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪn ðət moʊmən ðə bɹuz ʃɹæŋk ən vænɪʃt.

Elayne's eyes shot open wide, and with a gasp that seemed to take all the air in her, she convulsed like a netted trout, slippered heels drumming on the pavement. That only lasted a moment, of course, but in that moment the bruise shrank and vanished.

nɪneɪiv hɛlpt əɹ tə hɝ fit - ən ə wʊmənz hæn əpɪɹd, hoʊldɪŋ ə pjuɾɝ kʌp fʊl ʌv wɔɾɝ. "ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt bi θɝsti æftɝ ðæt," ðə simstʃɹɪs sɛd.

Nynaeve helped her to her feet - and a woman's hand appeared, holding a pewter cup full of water. "Even an Aes Sedai might be thirsty after that," the seamstress said.

ɪleɪn ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt, bʌt nɪneɪiv leɪd fɪŋɡɝz ɑn əɹ ɹɪst. "noʊ, θæŋk ju." ðə wʊmən ʃɹʌɡd, ən əz ʃi tɝn əweɪ, nɪneɪiv æɾəd ɪn ə dɪfɹən toʊn, "θæŋk ju." ɪt sim tə kʌm iziɝ ðə mɔɹ jə sɛɾ ɪt; ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi laɪk ðæt.

Elayne reached for it, but Nynaeve laid fingers on her wrist. "No, thank you." The woman shrugged, and as she turned away, Nynaeve added in a different tone, "Thank you." It seemed to come easier the more you said it; she was not sure she liked that.

ðəɾ oʊʃən ə leɪs hivd əz ðə simstʃɹɪs ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn. "aɪ meɪk dʒɹɛsəz fəɹ ɛniwʌn. aɪ kən də bɛɾɝ fəɹ jəɹ kʌlɝɪŋ ðən ðæt." ʃi vænɪʃt bæk ɪndə hɝ ʃɑp. nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn æftɝ hɝ.

That ocean of lace heaved as the seamstress shrugged again. "I make dresses for anyone. I can do better for your coloring than that." She vanished back into her shop. Nynaeve frowned after her.

"wʌt hæpənd?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd. "waɪ wʊdn jə lemi teɪk ə dʒɹɪŋk? aɪm θɝsti ən hʌŋɡɹi."

"What happened?" Elayne demanded. "Why wouldn't you let me take a drink? I'm thirsty and hungry."

wɪð ə læs fɹaʊn fəɹ ðə simstʃɹɪs, nɪneɪiv bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ði æɹoʊ.

With a last frown for the seamstress, Nynaeve bent to pick up the arrow.

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən niɾəd noʊ ɛkspləneɪʃənz. seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃoʊn ɝaʊn əɹ ɪn ə flæʃ. "tɛslɪn ən dʒoʊlin?"

The other woman needed no explanations. Saidar shone around her in a flash. "Teslyn and Joline?"

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ðə slaɪt wuzinəs sim tə bi feɪɾɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðoʊz tu wəd stup tə ðɪs. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ɹin?" ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. ðə simstʃɹɪs wɑz bæk ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, stɪl hoʊpfəl. "ʃi maɪt wɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ wi liv. əɹ wɝs, meɪbi ɡæɹiniə." ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tʃɪlɪŋ əz tɛslɪn ən dʒoʊlin. ən twaɪs əz ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ.

Nynaeve shook her head; the slight wooziness seemed to be fading. She did not think those two would stoop to this. She did not think so. "What about Reanne?" she said quietly. The seamstress was back in the doorway, still hopeful. "She might want to make sure we leave. Or worse, maybe Garenia." That was almost as chilling as Teslyn and Joline. And twice as infuriating.
