sʌmhaʊ ɪleɪn mænədʒ tə lʊk pɹɪɾi waɪl skaʊlɪŋ. "huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, wɪl sɛɾəl ðɛm. jəl si." ðə skaʊl feɪɾəd. "nɪneɪiv, ɪf ðə sɝkəl dʌz noʊ wɛɹ ðə boʊl ɪz, wi kən faɪn ɪt, bʌt. . . ." ʃi bɪɾ əɹ lɪp, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ. "aɪ oʊnli noʊ wʌn weɪ tə bi ʃʊɹ."

Somehow Elayne managed to look pretty while scowling. "Whoever it was, we will settle them. You'll see." The scowl faded. "Nynaeve, if the Circle does know where the Bowl is, we can find it, but. . . ." She bit her lip, hesitating. "I only know one way to be sure."

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd sloʊli, ðoʊ ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ əv iɾən ə hændfʊl ə dɝt. tədeɪ hæd sim soʊ bɹaɪt fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌt ðən ɪt hæd spaɪɹəld ɪndə dɑɹknəs, fɹəm ɹin tə. . . . oʊ, laɪt, haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ?

Nynaeve nodded slowly, though she would rather have eaten a handful of dirt. Today had seemed so bright for a time, but then it had spiraled into darkness, from Reanne to. . . . Oh, Light, how long before she had her gray hair?

"doʊn kɹaɪ, nɪneɪiv. mæt kæn pɑsəbli bi ðət bæd. hɪl faɪn ɪt fəɹ əs ɪn ə fju deɪz, aɪ noʊ."

"Don't cry, Nynaeve. Mat can't possibly be that bad. He'll find it for us in a few days, I know."

nɪneɪiv oʊnli kɹaɪd hɑɹɾɝ.

Nynaeve only cried harder.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

maɪntʃɹæp


Mindtrap

mɑɡiɾin dɪd nɑt wɑnə dʒɹim ðə dʒɹim əɡɛn, bʌt wɑntɪŋ tə weɪk, wɑntɪŋ tə skɹim, dɪd noʊ ɡʊd. slip hɛld əɹ fæstɝ ðən ɛni mænəkəlz. ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɛn baɪ kwɪkli, ə skɛtʃi blɝ. noʊ mɝsi; ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɹilɪv ðə ɹɛs ðət mʌtʃ sunɝ.

Moghedien did not want to dream the dream again, but wanting to wake, wanting to scream, did no good. Sleep held her faster than any manacles. The beginning went by quickly, a sketchy blur. No mercy; she would have to relive the rest that much sooner.

ʃi bɛɹli ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wʊmən u ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt wɛɹ ʃi wɑz hɛl pɹɪznɝ. hɑlimə, sɛkɹətɛɹi tə wʌn ə ðiz fulz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ. fulz, jɛt ðeɪ hɛld əɹ taɪtli ɪnʌf baɪ ðə bæn ə sɪlvɝ mɛɾəl ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, hɛld əɹ ən meɪɾ əɹ oʊbeɪ. fæs muvmənt, ðoʊ ʃi pɹeɪd fəɹ sloʊnəs. ðə wʊmən tʃænəl tə meɪk ə laɪt, ən mɑɡiɾin sɔ oʊnli ðə laɪt. ɪt hæd tə bi seɪɾɪn - əmʌŋ ðə lɪvɪŋ, oʊnli ðə tʃoʊzən nu haʊ tə tæp ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ - ðə paʊɝ ðət keɪm fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn - ən fju wɝ ful ɪnʌf tə ɪksɛpt ɪn daɪɹəs nid - bʌt ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl! blɝɪŋ kwɪknəs. ðə wʊmən neɪm hɝsɛlf ɝæŋɡɝ ən kɔl mɑɡiɾin baɪ neɪm, ʃi ɡeɪv sʌmənz tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum ən ɹimuv ði æɾəm nɛkləs, flɪntʃɪŋ ət peɪn noʊ wʊmən ʃəɾ əv fɛlt. əɡɛn - haʊ mɛni taɪmz hæd ʃi dʌn ðɪs? - əɡɛn mɑɡiɾin woʊv ə smɔl ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə tɛnt. ʃi skɪm tə ɡɪv hɝsɛlf taɪm tə θɪŋk ɪn ði ɛnləs dɑɹk, bʌt noʊ sunɝ dɪd ʃi stɛp ɑntu hɝ plætfɔɹm, laɪk ə smɔl ɛnkloʊz mɑɹbəl bælkəni kəmplit wɪð ə kʌmftəɹbəl tʃɛɹ, ðən ʃi ɝaɪvd ɑn ðə blæk sloʊps ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, fɝɛvɝ ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn twaɪlaɪt, wɛɹ vɛns ən tʌnəlz ɪmɪɾəd stim ən smoʊk ən hɑɹʃ veɪpɝz, ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl keɪm tə hɝ ɪn ɪts dɛd blæk ɡɑɹb, laɪk ə slʌɡ-waɪt, aɪləs mæn, bʌt tɔlɝ, mɔɹ mæsɪv ðən ɛni ʌðɝ hæfmən. ɪt ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ ɛɹəɡənli, ən ɡeɪv ɪts ɑd neɪm ənbɪddən, ən kəmændəɾ əɹ tə kʌm; ðiz wɝ nɑt θɪŋz mɹdʒɹɑl dɪd wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən. naʊ ʃi skɹimd ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə hɝ maɪn fəɹ ðə dʒɹim tə muv fæstɝ, tə blɝ bɪɑn siɪŋ, bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ, bʌt naʊ, əz ʃi fɑloʊd ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹənz bæk ɪndə ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum, naʊ ɔl floʊɾ əɾ ɪts nɔɹməl peɪs ən simd mɔɹ ɹil ðən tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ əɹ ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld.

She barely recognized the woman who entered the tent where she was held prisoner. Halima, secretary to one of these fools who called themselves Aes Sedai. Fools, yet they held her tightly enough by the band of silver metal around her neck, held her and made her obey. Fast movement, though she prayed for slowness. The woman channeled to make a light, and Moghedien saw only the light. It had to be saidin - among the living, only the Chosen knew how to tap the True Power - the Power that came from the Dark One - and few were fool enough to except in direst need - but that was impossible! Blurring quickness. The woman named herself Aran'gar and called Moghedien by name, she gave summons to the Pit of Doom and removed the a'dam necklace, flinching at pain no woman should have felt. Again - how many times had she done this? - again Moghedien wove a small gateway in the tent. She Skimmed to give herself time to think in the endless dark, but no sooner did she step onto her platform, like a small enclosed marble balcony complete with a comfortable chair, than she arrived on the black slopes of Shayol Ghul, forever shrouded in twilight, where vents and tunnels emitted steam and smoke and harsh vapors, and a Myrddraal came to her in its dead black garb, like a slug-white, eyeless man, but taller, more massive than any other Halfman. It regarded her arrogantly, and gave its odd name unbidden, and commanded her to come; these were not things Myrddraal did with the Chosen. Now she screamed in the depths of her mind for the dream to move faster, to blur beyond seeing, beyond knowing, but now, as she followed Shaidar Haran's back into the entrance to the Pit of Doom, now all flowed at its normal pace and seemed more real than Tel'aran'rhiod or the waking world.

tɪɹz lik fɹəm mɑɡiɾinz aɪz, daʊn tʃiks ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡlɪsənd. ʃi twɪtʃt ɑn əɹ hɑɹd pælət, ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz dʒɝkɪŋ əz ʃi fɔt dɛspɝətli, fjuɾɪlli, tə weɪk. ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əwɛɹ ðət ʃi dʒɹimd - ɔl simd ɹil - bʌt dip mɛmɹiz ɹɪmeɪnd, ən ɪn ðoʊz dɛpθs, ɪnstɪŋkt ʃɹikt ən klɔd fəɹ ɪskeɪp.

Tears leaked from Moghedien's eyes, down cheeks that already glistened. She twitched on her hard pallet, arms and legs jerking as she fought desperately, futilely, to wake. She was no longer aware that she dreamed - all seemed real - but deep memories remained, and in those depths, instinct shrieked and clawed for escape.

ʃi wɑz wɛl fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðə sloʊpɪŋ tʌnəl silɪŋɡd ɪn stoʊn dæɡɝz laɪk fæŋz, ðə wɔlz ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð peɪl laɪt. mɛni taɪmz ʃi hæd meɪd ðɪs daʊnwɝd dʒɝni sɪns ðə deɪ soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ wən ʃi fɝs keɪm tə meɪk oʊbaɪsəns tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ən plɛdʒ əɹ soʊl, bʌt nɛvɝ əz naʊ, nɛvɝ wɪð əɹ feɪljɝ noʊn ɪn ɔl ɪts mæɡnətud. ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə haɪd feɪljɝz ivən fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. mɛni taɪmz. θɪŋz kəd bi dʌn hɪɹ ðət kəd bi dʌn noʊwɛɹ ɛls. θɪŋz kəd hæpən hɪɹ ðət kəd hæpən noʊwɛɹ ɛls.

She was well familiar with the sloping tunnel ceilinged in stone daggers like fangs, the walls glowing with pale light. Many times she had made this downward journey since the day so long ago when she first came to make obeisance to the Great Lord and pledge her soul, but never as now, never with her failure known in all its magnitude. Always before she had managed to hide failures even from the Great Lord. Many times. Things could be done here that could be done nowhere else. Things could happen here that could happen nowhere else.

ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz wʌn ə ðə stoʊn fæŋz bɹʌʃt əɹ hɛɹ, ðən ɡæðɝd hɝsɛlf əz bɛst ʃi kʊd. ðoʊz spaɪks ən bleɪdz stɪl klɪɹd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ, tu-tɔl mɹdʒɹɑl izəli, bʌt ðoʊ ɪɾ oʊvɝtɑpt əɹ baɪ hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz ən mɔɹ, ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə muv əɹ hɛɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ pɔɪns naʊ. ɹiæləɾi wɑz kleɪ tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪɹ, ən i ɔfən meɪɾ ɪz dɪsplɛʒɝ noʊn soʊ. ə stoʊn tuθ stʃɹʌk əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən ʃi dʌk tə ɡoʊ ʌndɝ ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪnʌf haɪɾ ɪn ðə tʌnəl fəɹ əɹ tə stʃɹeɪɾən əz ʃi wɔkt. ʃi bɛn loʊɝ, skɝiɪŋ kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz weɪk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt kloʊsɝ. ɪts stʃɹaɪd nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ kwɪkli ʃi skʌɾəld, ði ɪntɝvəl bɪtwin əm dɪd nɑt lɛsən. ðə silɪŋ dɪsɛndəd, ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz fæŋz tə ɹɛn tʃɹeɪɾɝz ən fulz, ən mɑɡiɾin dʒɹɑp tə hænz ən niz, kɹɔlɪŋ, ðən flæɾənd tə ɛlboʊz ən niz. laɪt flɛɹɾ ən flɪkɝɾ ɪn ðə tʌnəl, kæs fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə pɪɾ ɪtsɛlf, dʒʌst əhɛd, ən mɑɡiɾin slaɪðɝɾ ɑn əɹ bɛli, pʊl hɝsɛlf əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ hænz, pʊʃt wɪð əɹ fit. stoʊn pɔɪns dʌɡ əɾ əɹ flɛʃ, kɑɾ əɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs. pæntɪŋ, ʃi ɹɪəl ðə læs dɪstəns tə ðə saʊn ə ɹɪpɪŋ wʊl.

She gave a start as one of the stone fangs brushed her hair, then gathered herself as best she could. Those spikes and blades still cleared the strange, too-tall Myrddraal easily, but though it overtopped her by head and shoulders and more, she was forced to move her head around their points now. Reality was clay to the Great Lord here, and he often made his displeasure known so. A stone tooth struck her shoulder, and she ducked to go under another. There was no longer enough height in the tunnel for her to straighten as she walked. She bent lower, scurrying crouched in the Myrddraal's wake, trying to get closer. Its stride never changed, but no matter how quickly she scuttled, the interval between them did not lessen. The ceiling descended, the Great Lord's fangs to rend traitors and fools, and Moghedien dropped to hands and knees, crawling, then flattened to elbows and knees. Light flared and flickered in the tunnel, cast from the entrance to the Pit itself, just ahead, and Moghedien slithered on her belly, pulled herself along with her hands, pushed with her feet. Stone points dug at her flesh, caught at her dress. Panting, she wriggled the last distance to the sound of ripping wool.

stɛɹɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ʃi ʃɪvɝd kənvʌlsɪvli. wɛɹ ðə tʌnəl maʊθ ʃʊɾə bɪn stʊɾ ə smuð stoʊn wɔl. pɝhæps ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd taɪmd ɪɾ ɔl ɪɡzækli, ən pɝhæps, hæd ʃi bɪn sloʊɝ. . . .

Staring back over her shoulder, she shivered convulsively. Where the tunnel mouth should have been stood a smooth stone wall. Perhaps the Great Lord had timed it all exactly, and perhaps, had she been slower. . . .

ðə lɛdʒ ɑn wɪtʃ ʃi leɪ pɹədʒɛktəɾ əbʌv ə blæk-mɑɾəld ɹɛd leɪk ə moʊltən ɹɑk wɛɹ fleɪmz ðə saɪz ə mɛn dænst ən daɪɾ ən ɹiəpɪɹd. oʊvɝhɛd, ðə kævɝn ɹoʊz ɹufləs θɹu ðə maʊntən tə ə skaɪ wɛɹ waɪl klaʊdz ɹeɪst, stʃɹieɪɾɪd ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ ən blæk, əz ɪf ɑn ðə wɪnz ə taɪm ðɛmsɛlvz. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə dɑɹk-klaʊɾəd skaɪ sin aʊtsaɪɾ ɑn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. nʌn ə ðəɾ ɝn ə sɛkənd ɡlæns, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ʃi hæd sin ɪt mɛni taɪmz. ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz pleɪs ʌv ɪmpɹɪzənmənt wɑz noʊ kloʊsɝ hɪɹ ðən ɛniwɛɹ ɛls ɪn ðə wɝld, bʌt hɪɹ ʃi kəd fil ɪt, hɪɹ ʃi kəd beɪð ɪn ðə ɹeɪɾiənt ɡlɔɹi ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wɑʃt ɝaʊn hɝ, soʊ stʃɹɔŋ hɪɹ ðəɾ ətɛmptɪŋ tə tʃænəl ɪt wəd fɹaɪ hɝ tə ə sɪndɝ. nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni dɪzaɪɝ tə peɪ ðə pɹaɪs ɛlswɛɹ iðɝ.

The ledge on which she lay projected above a black-mottled red lake of molten rock where flames the size of men danced and died and reappeared. Overhead, the cavern rose roofless through the mountain to a sky where wild clouds raced, striated red and yellow and black, as if on the winds of time themselves. It was not the dark-clouded sky seen outside on Shayol Ghul. None of that earned a second glance, and not just because she had seen it many times. The Bore into the Great Lord's place of imprisonment was no closer here than anywhere else in the world, but here she could feel it, here she could bathe in the radiant glory of the Great Lord. The True Power washed around her, so strong here that attempting to channel it would fry her to a cinder. Not that she had any desire to pay the price elsewhere either.

ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə pʊʃ ʌp tə hɝ niz, ən sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk əɹ bɪtwin ðə ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əɹ daʊn hɑɹɾ ɑntu ðə stoʊn lɛdʒ, kɹʌʃɪŋ ði ɛɹ fɹəm əɹ lʌŋz. stʌnd, ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ bɹɛθ, ðən stɛɹd bæk ʌp oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stʊd wɪð wʌn mæsɪv but plæntəd fɝmli ɑn əɹ bæk. ɔlmoʊst, ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðoʊ tʃænəlɪŋ hɪɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛs pɝmɪʃən wɑz ə ɡʊd weɪ tə daɪ. ði ɛɹəɡəns ɑn ðə sloʊps əbʌv wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs!

She started to push up to her knees, and something struck her between the shoulder blades, driving her down hard onto the stone ledge, crushing the air from her lungs. Stunned, she struggled for breath, then stared back up over her shoulder. The Myrddraal stood with one massive boot planted firmly on her back. Almost, she embraced saidar, though channeling here without express permission was a good way to die. The arrogance on the slopes above was one thing, but this!

"du jə noʊ hu aɪ æm?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "aɪ æm mɑɡiɾin!" ðəɾ aɪləs ɡeɪz wɑtʃt əɹ əz ɪt maɪɾ ən ɪnsɛkt; ʃi hæɾ ɔfən sin mɹdʒɹɑl lʊk əɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi hjumənz ðət weɪ.

"Do you know who I am?" she demanded. "I am Moghedien!" That eyeless gaze watched her as it might an insect; she had often seen Myrddraal look at ordinary humans that way.

mɑɡiɾin. ðət vɔɪs ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd flʌʃt əweɪ ɔl θɔɾ ə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl; ɪt nɪɹli flʌʃt əweɪ ɔl θɔt. bɪsaɪd ðɪs, ɛni hjumən lʌvɝz dipəst ɛmbɹeɪs wɑz ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ bɪsaɪd ði oʊʃən. haʊ dip ɪz jəɹ feɪljɝ, mɑɡiɾin? ðə tʃoʊzən ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst, bʌt jə lɛt jɝsɛlf bi kæptʃɝd. jə tɔt ðoʊz u wəɾ əpoʊz mi, mɑɡiɾin.

MOGHEDIEN. That voice inside her head flushed away all thought of the Myrddraal; it nearly flushed away all thought. Beside this, any human lover's deepest embrace was a drop of water beside the ocean. HOW DEEP IS YOUR FAILURE, MOGHEDIEN? THE CHOSEN ARE ALWAYS THE STRONGEST, BUT YOU LET YOURSELF BE CAPTURED. YOU TAUGHT THOSE WHO WOULD OPPOSE ME, MOGHEDIEN.

aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝɪŋ, ʃi fɔt fəɹ koʊhɪɹəns. "ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, aɪ tɔɾ əm oʊnli smɔl θɪŋz, ən aɪ fɔɾ əm əz aɪ kʊd. aɪ tɔɾ əm ə səpoʊzd weɪ tə dɪtɛkt ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ." ʃi mænədʒ tə læf. "pɹæktəsɪŋ ɪt ɡɪvz əm sətʃ hɛdeɪks ðeɪ kænɑt tʃænəl fəɹ aʊɝz." saɪləns. pɝhæps əz wɛl. ðeɪ hæd ɡɪvən ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn ðət lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɹɛskju, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd dɪd nɑt nid tə noʊ ðæt. "ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jə noʊ haʊ aɪ hæv sɝv ju. aɪ sɝv ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, ən jəɹ ɛnəmiz nɛvɝ fil maɪ baɪɾ əntɪl maɪ vɛnəm ɪz wɝkɪŋ." ʃi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt dɛɹ seɪ ʃi hæd dɪlɪbɝətli lɛt hɝsɛlf bi kæptʃɝd, tə wɝk fɹəm wɪðɪn, bʌt ʃi kəd sədʒɛst. "ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jə noʊ haʊ mɛni ʌv jəɹ ɛnəmiz aɪ bɹɔt daʊn ɪn ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ. fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz, ənsin, əɹ ɪf sin, ɪɡnɔɹd kəz aɪ kəd nɑt pɑsəbli bi ə θɹɛt." saɪləns. ən ðɛn. . . .

Eyelids fluttering, she fought for coherence. "Great Lord, I taught them only small things, and I fought them as I could. I taught them a supposed way to detect a man channeling." She managed to laugh. "Practicing it gives them such headaches they cannot channel for hours." Silence. Perhaps as well. They had given up trying to learn that long before her rescue, but the Great Lord did not need to know that. "Great Lord, you know how I have served you. I serve in the shadows, and your enemies never feel my bite until my venom is working." She did not quite dare say she had deliberately let herself be captured, to work from within, but she could suggest. "Great Lord, you know how many of your enemies I brought down in the War of Power. From the shadows, unseen, or if seen, ignored because I could not possibly be a threat." Silence. And then. . . .

maɪ tʃoʊzən ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst. maɪ hæn muvz.

MY CHOSEN ARE ALWAYS THE STRONGEST. MY HAND MOVES.

ðət vɔɪs ɹɪvɝbɝeɪɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ skʌl tɝn əɹ boʊnz tə bɔɪlɪŋ hʌni ən əɹ bɹeɪn tə faɪɝ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl hæɾ əɹ tʃɪn ɪn ɪts hænd, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ʌp bɪfɔɹ əɹ vɪʒən klɪɹɾ ɪnʌf tə si ðə naɪf ɪn ɪts ʌðɝ hænd. ɔl əɹ dʒɹimz wɝ tə ɛn hɪɹ ɪn ə slɪt θɹoʊt, hɝ bɑɾi gɑnə fid ðə tʃɹɑləks. pɝhæps ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wəd seɪv ə tʃɔɪs kʌt fəɹ ɪtsɛlf. pɝhæps. . . .

That voice reverberating in her skull turned her bones to boiling honey and her brain to fire. The Myrddraal had her chin in its hand, forcing her head up before her vision cleared enough to see the knife in its other hand. All her dreams were to end here in a slit throat, her body going to feed the Trollocs. Perhaps Shaidar Haran would save a choice cut for itself. Perhaps. . . .

noʊ. ʃi nu ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, bʌt ðɪs mɹdʒɹɑl wəd nɑɾ it wʌn ʃɹɛɾ ə hɝ! ʃi ɹitʃt tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ, ən əɹ aɪz bʌlʒd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðɛɹ. nʌθɪŋ! ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn sɛvɝd! ʃi nu ʃi hæd nɑt - ɪt wɑz sɛd ðət tɛɹɪŋ wɑz ðə dipəs peɪn ɛniwʌn kəd noʊ, bɪɑn ɛni paʊɝ tə dɛɾən - bʌt - !

No. She knew she was going to die, but this Myrddraal would not eat one shred of her! She reached to embrace saidar, and her eyes bulged. There was nothing there. Nothing! It was as if she had been severed! She knew she had not - it was said that tearing was the deepest pain anyone could know, beyond any power to deaden - but - !

ɪn ðoʊz stʌn moʊməns, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl fɔɹst əɹ maʊθ oʊpən, skɹeɪp ðə bleɪɾ əlɔŋ əɹ tʌŋ, ðən nɪkt əɹ ɪɹ. ən əz ɪt stʃɹeɪɾənd wɪð əɹ blʌɾ ən səlaɪvə, ʃi nu, ivən bɪfɔɹ ɪt pɹədust wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə taɪni, fɹædʒəl keɪdʒ ʌv ɡoʊld waɪɝ ən kɹɪstəl. səm θɪŋz kəɾ oʊnli bi dʌn hɪɹ, səm oʊnli tə ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl, ən ʃi hæd bɹɔɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ən wɪmən fəɹ ðɪs vɛɹi pɝpəs.

In those stunned moments, the Myrddraal forced her mouth open, scraped the blade along her tongue, then nicked her ear. And as it straightened with her blood and saliva, she knew, even before it produced what appeared to be a tiny, fragile cage of gold wire and crystal. Some things could only be done here, some only to those who could channel, and she had brought a number of men and women for this very purpose.

"noʊ," ʃi bɹiðd. hɝ aɪz kəd nɑt liv ðə kɔɹsvɹə. "noʊ, nɑt mi! nɑt meɪn!"

"No," she breathed. Her eyes could not leave the cour'souvra. "No, not me! NOT ME!"

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hɝ, ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən skɹeɪp ðə fluədz fɹəm ðə naɪf ɑntu ðə kɔɹsvɹə. ðə kɹɪstəl tɝn ə mɪlki pɪŋk, ðə fɝst sɛɾɪŋ. wɪð ə flɪk ʌv ɪts ɹɪst, ɪt tɔs ðə maɪnd-tʃɹæp aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə leɪk ə moʊltən stoʊn fəɹ ðə sɛkənd. ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-kɹɪstəl keɪdʒ ɑɹtʃt θɹu ði ɛɹ ən sʌɾənli stɑpt, floʊɾɪŋ ət ðə vɛɹi spɑt wɛɹ ɪt sim ðə bɔɹ wɑz, ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə pæɾɝn leɪ θɪnəst ʌv ɔl.

Ignoring her, Shaidar Haran scraped the fluids from the knife onto the cour'souvra. The crystal turned a milky pink, the first setting. With a flick of its wrist, it tossed the mind-trap out over the lake of molten stone for the second. The gold-and-crystal cage arched through the air and suddenly stopped, floating at the very spot where it seemed the Bore was, the place where the Pattern lay thinnest of all.

mɑɡiɾin fɝɡɑt ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. ʃi flʌŋ aʊɾ əɹ hænz təwɔɹd ðə bɔɹ. "mɝsi, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd!" ʃi hæd nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ðət ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk pəzɛst ɛni mɝsi, bʌt hæd ʃi bɪn baʊn ɪn ə sɛl wɪð ɹæbɪd wʊlvz əɹ wɪð ə dɑɹəθ ɪn moʊlt, ʃi wʊɾə bɛɡd ðə seɪm. ɪn ðə ɹaɪt sɝkəmstænsəz, jə bɛɡd ivən fəɹ ði ɪmpɑsəbəl. ðə kɔɹsvɹə hʌŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ, tɝnɪŋ sloʊli, ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə lipɪŋ faɪɝz bɪloʊ. "aɪ hæv sɝv jə wɪð ɔl maɪ hɑɹt, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪ bɛɡ mɝsi. aɪ bɛɡ! mɝsiiiiɪii!"

Moghedien forgot the Myrddraal. She flung out her hands toward the Bore. "Mercy, Great Lord!" She had never noticed that the Great Lord of the Dark possessed any mercy, but had she been bound in a cell with rabid wolves or with a darath in moult, she would have begged the same. In the right circumstances, you begged even for the impossible. The cour'souvra hung in midair, turning slowly, glittering in the light of leaping fires below. "I have served you with all my heart, Great Lord. I beg mercy. I beg! MERCYYYYYYY!"

jə meɪ sɝv mi stɪl.

YOU MAY SERVE ME STILL.

ðə vɔɪs flʌŋ əɹ ɪndə ɛkstəsi bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ, bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm ɪnstən ðə spɑɹklɪŋ maɪntʃɹæp sʌɾənli ɡloʊd laɪk ðə sʌn, ən ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ɹæptʃɝ, ʃi nu peɪn əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɪmɝst ɪn ðə faɪɝi leɪk. ðeɪ blɛndəd, ən ʃi haʊld, θɹæʃɪŋ laɪk ə mæd θɪŋ, θɹæʃɪŋ ɪn ɛnləs peɪn, ɛnləs, əntɪl æftɝ eɪdʒəz, æftɝ nʌθɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn bʌɾ æɡəni ən ðə mɛmɹi ʌv æɡəni, ðə taɪni mɝsi ʌv dɑɹknəs oʊvɝwɛlm hɝ.

The voice flung her into ecstasy beyond knowing, but at the same instant the sparkling mindtrap suddenly glowed like the sun, and in the midst of rapture, she knew pain as if she had been immersed in the fiery lake. They blended, and she howled, thrashing like a mad thing, thrashing in endless pain, endless, until after Ages, after nothing remained but agony and the memory of agony, the tiny mercy of darkness overwhelmed her.

mɑɡiɾin stɝɾ ɑn ðə pælət. nɑɾ əɡɛn. pliz.

Moghedien stirred on the pallet. Not again. Please.

ʃi bɛɹli ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wʊmən u ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt wɛɹ ʃi wɑz hɛl pɹɪznɝ.

She barely recognized the woman who entered the tent where she was held prisoner.

pliz, ʃi ʃɹikt ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə hɝ maɪnd.

Please, she shrieked in the depths of her mind.

ðə wʊmən tʃænəl tə meɪk ə laɪt, ən mɑɡiɾin sɔ oʊnli ðə laɪt.

The woman channeled to make a light, and Moghedien saw only the light.

dip ɪn slip, ʃi kwɪvɝd, vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ. pliz!

Deep in sleep, she quivered, vibrating from head to toe. Please!

ðə wʊmən neɪm hɝsɛlf ɝæŋɡɝ ən kɔl mɑɡiɾin baɪ neɪm, ʃi ɡeɪv sʌmənz tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum ən -  "weɪk, wʊmən," sɛɾ ə vɔɪs laɪk ɹɑɾɪd boʊn kɹʌmbəlɪŋ, ən mɑɡiɾinz aɪz pɑpt oʊpən. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt fəɹ ðə dʒɹim bæk.

The woman named herself Aran'gar and called Moghedien by name, she gave summons to the Pit of Doom and -  "Wake, woman," said a voice like rotted bone crumbling, and Moghedien's eyes popped open. She almost wished for the dream back.

noʊ dɔɹ əɹ wɪndoʊ bɹoʊk ðə fitʃɝləs stoʊn wɔlz ə hɝ smɔl pɹɪzən, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɡloʊbəlbz əɹ ivən læmps, bʌt laɪt keɪm fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni deɪz ʃi hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, oʊnli ðət teɪsləs fuɾ əpɪɹɾ əɾ ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪntɝvəlz, ðət ðə sɪŋɡəl bʌkət sɝvɪŋ fəɹ sænəteɪʃən wɑz ɛmptiɾ əɾ ivən mɔɹ ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ taɪmz, ən soʊp ən ə bʌkəɾ ə pɝfjumd wɔɾɝ wɝ sʌmhaʊ lɛft fəɹ əɹ tə klin hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ðət wɑz ə mɝsi əɹ nɑt; ðə ɡlæd θɹɪl ət siɪŋ ə bʌkəɾ ʌv wɔɾɝ ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ haʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd fɔlən. ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wɑz ɪn ðə sɛl wɪð əɹ naʊ.

No door or window broke the featureless stone walls of her small prison, and there were no glowbulbs or even lamps, but light came from somewhere. She did not know how many days she had been there, only that tasteless food appeared at irregular intervals, that the single bucket serving for sanitation was emptied at even more irregular times, and soap and a bucket of perfumed water were somehow left for her to clean herself. She was not sure whether that was a mercy or not; the glad thrill at seeing a bucket of water reminded her how far she had fallen. Shaidar Haran was in the cell with her now.

hɝidli ɹoʊlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ pælət, ʃi nɛlt ən pʊɾ əɹ feɪs tə ðə bɛɹ stoʊn flɔɹ. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz dʌn wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi fəɹ sɝvaɪvəl, ən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl hæd bɪn ɔl tu ɡlæd tə titʃ əɹ wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. "aɪ ɡɹit jə iɡɝli, miɑkoʊvə." ðə læʃt-təɡɛðɝ taɪɾəl bɝn ɑn əɹ tʌŋ. "wʌn u oʊnz meɪn," ɪt mɛnt, əɹ sɪmpli, "maɪ oʊnɝ." ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ ʃild ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən hæd juzd ɑn əɹ - mɹdʒɹɑl kəd nɑt, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd - ðə ʃild wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ɛvəɾəns, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt kənsɪɾɝ tʃænəlɪŋ. ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wɑz dɪnaɪd hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs - ðət kəd bi dʒɹɔn oʊnli wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz blɛsɪŋ - bʌt ðə sɔɹs tæntəlaɪzd, ðoʊ ðə ɡloʊ dʒʌs bɪɑn saɪt sim sʌmhaʊ ɑd. ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt kənsɪɾɝ ɪt. ɛvɹi taɪm ðə mɹdʒɹɑl vɪzəɾəd, ɪt dɪspleɪɾ əɹ maɪntʃɹæp. tʃænəlɪŋ tu nɪɹ jəɹ oʊn kɔɹsvɹə wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli peɪnfəl, ðə nɪɹɝ, ðə mɔɹ ðə peɪn; ðɪs kloʊs, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəd sɝvaɪv ə sɪmpəl tʌtʃ ɑn ðə sɔɹs. ən ðət wɑz ðə list ə ðə maɪntʃɹæps deɪnʒɝz.

Hurriedly rolling from her pallet, she knelt and put her face to the bare stone floor. She had always done whatever was necessary for survival, and the Myrddraal had been all too glad to teach her what was necessary. "I greet you eagerly, Mia'cova." The lashed-together title burned on her tongue. "One Who Owns Me," it meant, or simply, "My Owner." The strange shield Shaidar Haran had used on her - Myrddraal could not, but it did - the shield was not in evidence, yet she did not consider channeling. The True Power was denied her, of course - that could be drawn only with the Great Lord's blessing - but the Source tantalized, though the glow just beyond sight seemed somehow odd. She still did not consider it. Every time the Myrddraal visited, it displayed her mindtrap. Channeling too near your own cour'souvra was extremely painful, the nearer, the more the pain; this close, she did not think she would survive a simple touch on the Source. And that was the least of the mindtrap's dangers.

ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən tʃʌkəld, ə ɹæsp ə dʒɹaɪd, kɹæk lɛðɝ. ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ dɪfɝəns əbaʊt ðɪs mɹdʒɹɑl. fɑɹ mɔɹ kɹuəl ðən tʃɹɑləks, hu wɝ mɪɹli blʌdθɝsti, mɹdʒɹɑl wɝ koʊld ən dɪspæʃənəɾ ɪn ɪt. ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən ɔfən ʃoʊɾ əmjuzmənt, ðoʊ. soʊ fɑɹ ʃi fɛlt lʌki tə hæv oʊnli bɹuzəz. moʊst wɪmən wʊɾə bɪn ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə mædnəs baɪ naʊ, ɪf nɑt bɪɑnd.

Shaidar Haran chuckled, a rasp of dried, cracked leather. That was another difference about this Myrddraal. Far more cruel than Trollocs, who were merely bloodthirsty, Myrddraal were cold and dispassionate in it. Shaidar Haran often showed amusement, though. So far she felt lucky to have only bruises. Most women would have been on the brink of madness by now, if not beyond.

"æn ɑɹ jə iɡɝ tə oʊbeɪ?" ðət ɹʌslɪŋ, ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ vɔɪs æskt.

"And are you eager to obey?" that rustling, grating voice asked.

"jɛs, aɪm iɡɝ tə oʊbeɪ, miɑkoʊvə." wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə sɝvaɪv. bʌt ʃi stɪl ɡæspt wən koʊl fɪŋɡɝz sʌɾənli tæŋɡəld ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. ʃi skɹæmbəl tə hɝ fiɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, bʌt stɪl wɑz hɔld ʌp. ət lis ðɪs taɪm əɹ fit ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stʌɾid hɝ, ɪkspɹɛʃənləs. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ pæs vɪzəts, ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə flɪntʃ, əɹ skɹim, əɹ sɪmpli ɹitʃ fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ ən meɪk ən ɛnd.

"Yes, I am eager to obey, Mia'cova." Whatever was necessary to survive. But she still gasped when cold fingers suddenly tangled in her hair. She scrambled to her feet on her own as much as possible, but still was hauled up. At least this time her feet remained on the floor. The Myrddraal studied her, expressionless. Remembering past visits, it required an effort not to flinch, or scream, or simply reach for saidar and make an end.

"kloʊs jəɹ aɪz," ɪt toʊl hɝ, "æn kip əm kloʊzd əntɪl jə ɑɹ kəmændəd tə oʊpən ðɛm."

"Close your eyes," it told her, "and keep them closed until you are commanded to open them."

mɑɡiɾinz aɪz snæpt ʃʌt. wʌn ə ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹənz lɛsənz hæd bɪn ɪnstən oʊbiɾiəns. bɪsaɪdz, wɪð əɹ aɪz kloʊzd, ʃi kəd tʃɹaɪ tə pɹitɛn ðət ʃi wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi.

Moghedien's eyes snapped shut. One of Shaidar Haran's lessons had been instant obedience. Besides, with her eyes closed, she could try to pretend that she was somewhere else. Whatever was necessary.

əbɹʌpli ðə hæn ɪn əɹ hɛɹ ɹʌʃt əɹ fɔɹwɝd, ən ʃi skɹimd ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl mɛn tə ɹʌn əɹ ɪndə ðə wɔl. hɝ hænz wɛn ʌp fəɹ pɹətɛkʃən, ən ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən ɹilis hɝ. ʃi stæɡɝɾ ət lis tɛn stɛps - bʌɾ əɹ sɛl wɑz nɑt tɛn peɪsɪz kɔɹnɝ tə kɔɹnɝ. wʊd smoʊk; ʃi smɛld ə feɪn tʌtʃ ʌv wʊd smoʊk. ʃi kɛpt əɹ aɪlɪdz fɝmli kloʊzd, ðoʊ. ʃi mɛn tə kəntɪnju wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən bɹuzəz, ən əz fju bɹuzəz əz pɑsəbəl, fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ.

Abruptly the hand in her hair rushed her forward, and she screamed in spite of herself. The Myrddraal meant to run her into the wall. Her hands went up for protection, and Shaidar Haran released her. She staggered at least ten steps - but her cell was not ten paces corner to corner. Wood smoke; she smelled a faint touch of wood smoke. She kept her eyelids firmly closed, though. She meant to continue with no more than bruises, and as few bruises as possible, for as long as she could manage.

"ju kən lʊk naʊ," ə dip vɔɪs sɛd.

"You can look now," a deep voice said.

ʃi dɪd, kɔʃəsli. ðə spikɝ wɑz ə tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd jʌŋ mæn ɪn blæk buts ən bɹitʃɪz ən ə floʊɪŋ waɪt ʃɝɾ ənleɪst ət ðə tɑp, hu wɑtʃt əɹ wɪð stɑɹtlɪŋli blu aɪz fɹəm ə dip, kʊʃən ɑɹmtʃɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs wɛɹ fleɪmz dænst əlɔŋ lɔŋ lɔɡz. ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ə wʊd-pænəld ɹum ðət maɪɾ əv bɪlɔŋ tə ə wɛlθi mɝtʃən əɹ noʊbəl ə mɑɾɝət ɹæŋk ɪn ðɪs taɪm, ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ laɪtli kɑɹvd ən tʌtʃt wɪð ɡɪlt, ðə ɹʌɡz woʊvən ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊld ɹæbɛsks. ʃi dɪd nɑt daʊɾ ɪt wɑz sʌmwɛɹ kloʊz baɪ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, ðoʊ; ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə fil ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ði oʊnli ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾi. swɪvəlɪŋ əɹ hɛd heɪstəli, ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin. taɪt bænz ə kuɑn sim tə vænɪʃ fɹəm ɝaʊn əɹ tʃɛst.

She did, cautiously. The speaker was a tall, broad-shouldered young man in black boots and breeches and a flowing white shirt unlaced at the top, who watched her with startlingly blue eyes from a deep, cushioned armchair in front of a marble fireplace where flames danced along long logs. She stood in a wood-paneled room that might have belonged to a wealthy merchant or noble of moderate rank in this time, the furniture lightly carved and touched with gilt, the rugs woven in red-and-gold arabesques. She did not doubt it was somewhere close by Shayol Ghul, though; it did not have the feel of Tel'aran'rhiod, the only other possibility. Swiveling her head hastily, she drew a deep breath. The Myrddraal was nowhere to be seen. Tight bands of cuande seemed to vanish from around her chest.

"dɪd jə ɛndʒɔɪ jəɹ taɪm ɪn ðə vækwoʊl?"

"Did you enjoy your time in the vacuole?"

mɑɡiɾin fɛlt aɪsi fɪŋɡɝz dɪɡ ɪndə hɝ skælp. ʃi wɑz noʊ ɹisɝtʃɝ əɹ meɪkɝ, bʌt ʃi nu ðət wɝd. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən θɪŋk tə æsk haʊ ə jʌŋ mæn ə ðɪs taɪm dɪd, tu. səmtaɪmz ðəɹ wɝ bʌbəlz ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, ðoʊ sʌmwʌn laɪk mɛsænə wəd seɪ ðət wɑz tu sɪmpəl ən ɛkspləneɪʃən. vækwoʊlz kəd bi ɛntɝd, ɪf jə nu haʊ, ən mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd mʌtʃ laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wɝld - ɹisɝtʃɝz hæɾ ɔfən dʌn ɡɹeɪɾ ɪkspɛɹəməns ɪn vækwoʊlz, soʊ ʃi veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪɹɪŋ - bʌt ðeɪ wɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə pæɾɝn ɹɪli, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪ kloʊzd ʌp, əɹ pɝhæps bɹoʊk ɔf ən dʒɹɪftəɾ əweɪ. ivən mɛsænə kəd nɑt seɪ wʌt hæpənd - ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn əm ət ðə taɪm wɑz ɡɔn fɝɛvɝ.

Moghedien felt icy fingers dig into her scalp. She was no researcher or maker, but she knew that word. She did not even think to ask how a young man of this time did, too. Sometimes there were bubbles in the Pattern, though someone like Mesaana would say that was too simple an explanation. Vacuoles could be entered, if you knew how, and manipulated much like the rest of the world - researchers had often done great experiments in vacuoles, so she vaguely remembered hearing - but they were outside the Pattern really, and sometimes they closed up, or perhaps broke off and drifted away. Even Mesaana could not say what happened - except that anything in them at the time was gone forever.

"haʊ lɔŋ?" ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ vɔɪs wɑz soʊ stɛɾi. ʃi ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðə jʌŋ mæn, hu sæt ðəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ waɪt tiθ. "aɪ sɛd, haʊ lɔŋ? əɹ doʊn jə noʊ?"

"How long?" She was surprised her voice was so steady. She rounded on the young man, who sat there showing her white teeth. "I said, how long? Or don't you know?"

"aɪ sɔ jə ɝaɪv. . . ." hi pɔzd, lɪftɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ ɡɑblət fɹəm ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ, aɪz smaɪlɪŋ əɾ əɹ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm əz i dʒɹæŋk. ". . . ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ læst."

"I saw you arrive. . . ." He paused, lifting a silver goblet from the table beside his chair, eyes smiling at her over the rim as he drank. ". . . the night before last."

ʃi kəd nɑt haɪɾ ə ɹɪlivd ɡæsp. ði oʊnli ɹizən ɛniwʌn wəd wɑnə ɛntɝ ə vækwoʊl wɑz ðət taɪm floʊd dɪfɹənli ðɛɹ, səmtaɪmz sloʊɝ, səmtaɪmz fæstɝ. səmtaɪmz mʌtʃ fæstɝ. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ɪntaɪɝli sɝpɹaɪz tə lɝn ðət ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd ɹɪli ɪmpɹɪzən əɹ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, əɹ ə θaʊzənd, tə ɪmɝdʒ ɪndə ə wɝld ɔlɹɛɾi hɪz, tə meɪk əɹ weɪ fiɾɪŋ əmʌŋ kɛɹiən waɪl ði ʌðɝ tʃoʊzən stʊɾ ət ðə pɪnəkəl. ʃi wɑz stɪl wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ɪn əɹ oʊn maɪnd, ət list. əntɪl ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪmsɛlf sɛd ʃi wɑz nɑt. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn biɪŋ ɹilist wʌns ə maɪntʃɹæp wɑz sɛt, bʌt ʃi wəd faɪn ə weɪ. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə weɪ fəɹ ðoʊz u wɝ kɔʃəs, waɪl ðoʊz fɛl u kɔl kɑʃən kaʊɝɾəs. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd kæɹiɾ ə fju ʌv ðət soʊ-kɔl bɹeɪv sɔɹt tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl tə bi fɪɾəd wɪð kɔɹsvɹə.

She could not hide a relieved gasp. The only reason anyone would want to enter a vacuole was that time flowed differently there, sometimes slower, sometimes faster. Sometimes much faster. She would not have been entirely surprised to learn that the Great Lord had really imprisoned her for a hundred years, or a thousand, to emerge into a world already his, to make her way feeding among carrion while the other Chosen stood at the pinnacle. She was still one of the Chosen, in her own mind, at least. Until the Great Lord himself said she was not. She had never heard of anyone being released once a mindtrap was set, but she would find a way. There was always a way for those who were cautious, while those fell who called caution cowardice. She herself had carried a few of that so-called brave sort to Shayol Ghul to be fitted with cour'souvra.

sʌɾənli, ɪɾ əkɝd tə hɝ ðət ðɪs fɛloʊ nu ə ɡɹeɪt dil fəɹ ə fɹɛn ə ðə dɑɹk, ɪspɛʃli wʌn nɑt mɛni jɪɹz pæs twɛnti. hi swʌŋ wʌn lɛɡ oʊvɝ ən ɑɹm ə ðə tʃɛɹ, laʊnʒɪŋ ɪnsələnli ʌndɝ əɹ skɹuɾəni. ɡɹeɪndəl maɪɾ əv snætʃt hɪm, ɪf i hæɾ ɛni pəzɪʃən əɹ paʊɝ; oʊnli tu stʃɹɔŋ ə tʃɪn kɛpt ɪm fɹəm biɪŋ pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin aɪz soʊ blu. wɪð ɪz ɪnsələns ɪn əɹ vɛɹi feɪs ən wʌt ʃi hæd hæd tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ət ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹənz hænz soʊ fɹɛʃ, wɪð ðə sɔɹs kɔlɪŋ əɹ ən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɡɔn, ʃi kənsɪɾɝd titʃɪŋ ðɪs jʌŋ fɹɛn ə ðə dɑɹk ə ʃɑɹp lɛsən. ðə fæk ðəɾ əɹ kloʊðz wɝ ɡɹaɪmi æɾəd ðɛɹ pɑɹt; ʃi hɝsɛlf smɛl feɪnli ʌv ðə pɝfjum ɪn ðə wɑʃ wɔɾɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd hæd noʊ weɪ tə klin ðə ɹʌf wʊlən dʒɹɛs ɪn wɪtʃ ʃi flɛɾ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, wɪð ɪts ɹɪps fɹəm əɹ dʒɝni daʊn tə ðə pɪt. pɹuɾəns pɹɪveɪld - ðɪs ɹum mʌs bi kloʊs tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl - bʌt bɛɹli.

Suddenly, it occurred to her that this fellow knew a great deal for a Friend of the Dark, especially one not many years past twenty. He swung one leg over an arm of the chair, lounging insolently under her scrutiny. Graendal might have snatched him, if he had any position or power; only too strong a chin kept him from being pretty enough. She did not think she had ever seen eyes so blue. With his insolence in her very face and what she had had to endure at Shaidar Haran's hands so fresh, with the Source calling her and the Myrddraal gone, she considered teaching this young Friend of the Dark a sharp lesson. The fact that her clothes were grimy added their part; she herself smelled faintly of the perfume in the wash water, but she had had no way to clean the rough woolen dress in which she fled Egwene al'Vere, with its rips from her journey down to the Pit. Prudence prevailed - this room must be close to Shayol Ghul - but barely.

"wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "du juv ɛni aɪdiə hu jə ɑɹ spikɪŋ tə?"

"What is your name?" she demanded. "Do you have any idea who you are speaking to?"

"jɛs, aɪ du, mɑɡiɾin. jə meɪ kɔl mi mɔɹaɪɾɪn."

"Yes, I do, Moghedien. You may call me Moridin."

mɑɡiɾin ɡæspt. nɑt fəɹ ðə neɪm; ɛni ful kəd kɔl hɪmsɛlf dɛθ. bʌɾ ə taɪni blæk flɛk, dʒʌs lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə si, floʊɾəd stʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs wʌn ə ðoʊz blu aɪz ən ðən əkɹɔs ði ʌðɝ ɪn ðə seɪm laɪn. ðɪs mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd tæpt ɪndə ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ, ən mɔɹ ðən wʌns. mʌtʃ mɔɹ. ʃi nu ðət səm mɛn u kəd tʃænəl sɝvaɪvd ɪn ðɪs taɪm əsaɪd fɹəm ælθɹ - ðɪs fɛloʊ wɑz mʌtʃ ʌv ə saɪz wɪð ælθɹ - bʌt ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd tə əlaʊ wʌn ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɑnɝ. ən ɑnɝ wɪð ə baɪt, əz ɛni ʌv ðə tʃoʊzən nu. ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn, ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ədɪktɪv ðən ðə wʌn paʊɝ; ə stʃɹɔŋ wɪl kəd hoʊl daʊn ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə dʒɹɔ mɔɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ əɹ seɪɾɪn, bʌt ʃi hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðə wɪl ɪɡzɪstəd stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪzɪs ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ, nɑt wʌns ðə sæɑ əpɪɹɾ ɪn jəɹ aɪz. ðə faɪnəl pɹaɪs wɑz dɪfɹənt, bʌt noʊ lɛs tɛɹəbəl.

Moghedien gasped. Not for the name; any fool could call himself Death. But a tiny black fleck, just large enough to see, floated straight across one of those blue eyes and then across the other in the same line. This Moridin had tapped into the True Power, and more than once. Much more. She knew that some men who could channel survived in this time aside from al'Thor - this fellow was much of a size with al'Thor - but she had not expected the Great Lord to allow one that particular honor. An honor with a bite, as any of the Chosen knew. In the long run, the True Power was far more addictive than the One Power; a strong will could hold down the desire to draw more saidar or saidin, but she herself did not believe the will existed strong enough to resist the True Power, not once the saa appeared in your eyes. The final price was different, but no less terrible.

"ju hæv bɪn ɡɪvən dɪstɪŋkʃən ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən jə noʊ," ʃi toʊl hɪm. əz ðoʊ hɝ fɪlθi dʒɹɛs wɑz ðə faɪnəst stʃɹaɪθ, ʃi tʊk ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ ɑpəzət hɪm. "bɹɪŋ mi səm ə ðət waɪn, ən əl tɛl ju. oʊnli twɛnti-naɪn ʌðɝz əv ɛvɝ bɪn ɡɹæntəd - "

"You have been given distinction greater than you know," she told him. As though her filthy dress was the finest streith, she took the armchair opposite him. "Bring me some of that wine, and I will tell you. Only twenty-nine others have ever been granted - "

tə hɝ ʃɑk, hi læft. "ju mɪsəpɹɪhɛnd, mɑɡiɾin. jə stɪl sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, bʌt nɑt kwaɪɾ əz jə wʌns dɪd. ðə taɪm fəɹ pleɪɪŋ jəɹ oʊn ɡeɪmz əz pæst. ɪf jə hæd nɑt mænədʒ tə də səm ɡʊd baɪ æksəɾənt, jə wəd bi dɛd naʊ."

To her shock, he laughed. "You misapprehend, Moghedien. You still serve the Great Lord, but not quite as you once did. The time for playing your own games has passed. If you had not managed to do some good by accident, you would be dead now."

"aɪ æm wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, bɔɪ," ʃi sɛd, fjʊɹi bɝnɪŋ θɹu kɑʃən. ʃi sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, feɪsɪŋ ɪm wɪð ɔl ðə nɑlədʒ ʌv ən eɪdʒ ðət meɪɾ ɪz lɪɾəl dɪfɹən fɹəm taɪmz ə mʌd hʌts. əz mʌtʃ ə ðət nɑlədʒ əz ʃi hæd, ɛniweɪ, ən ɪn səm ɛɹiəz, kənsɝnɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, noʊ wʌn aʊtstʃɹɪp hɝ. ʃi ɔlmoʊst ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ kloʊs ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl leɪ. "jɔɹ mʌðɝ pɹɑbli juz maɪ neɪm tə fɹaɪɾən jə nɑt soʊ mɛni jɪɹz ɡɔn, bʌt noʊ ðət ɡɹoʊn mɛn u kəd kɹʌmpəl jə laɪk ə ɹæɡ swɛɾɪd wən ðeɪ hɝɾ ɪt. jəl wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ wɪð mi!"

"I am one of the Chosen, boy," she said, fury burning through caution. She sat up straight, facing him with all the knowledge of an Age that made his little different from times of mud huts. As much of that knowledge as she had, anyway, and in some areas, concerning the One Power, no one outstripped her. She almost embraced the Source no matter how close Shayol Ghul lay. "Your mother probably used my name to frighten you not so many years gone, but know that grown men who could crumple you like a rag sweated when they heard it. You will watch your tongue with me!"

hi ɹitʃt ɪndə ði oʊpən nɛk ə hɪz ʃɝt, ən əɹ oʊn tʌŋ kloʊv tə ðə ɹuf ə hɝ maʊð. hɝ aɪz fɪkst ɑn ðə smɔl keɪdʒ ʌv ɡoʊld waɪɝ ən blʌd-ɹɛd kɹɪstəl ðəɾ i dʒɹu aʊt dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑn ə kɔɹd. ʃi θɔt veɪɡli ðəɾ i tʌkt ənʌðɝ dʒʌs laɪk ɪt bæk ɪn, bʌt ʃi hæɾ aɪz oʊnli fəɹ əɹ oʊn. ɪt dɛfənətli wɑz hɝz. hɪz θʌm stʃɹoʊkt, ən ʃi fɛl ðət kɝɛs əkɹɔs əɹ maɪnd, hɝ soʊl. bɹeɪkɪŋ ə maɪntʃɹæp dɪd nɑt ɹikwaɪɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ pɹɛʃɝ ðən i wɑz juzɪŋ. ʃi kəd bi ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɝld əɹ fɑɹðɝ, ən ɪt wəd nɑt mæɾɝ ə hɛɹ. ðə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ ðət wɑz əɹ wəd bi sɛpɝeɪɾəd; ʃi wəd stɪl si wɪð əɹ aɪz ən hɪɹ wɪð əɹ ɪɹz, teɪst wʌt kɹɔst əɹ tʌŋ ən fil wʌt tʌtʃt hɝ, bʌt hɛlpləs wɪðɪn ən ɔtɑmətɑn ðət wɑz ʌɾɝli oʊbiɾiənt tə huɛvɝ hɛl ðə kɔɹsvɹə. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ tə ɡɛt fɹi ʌv ɪt, ə maɪntʃɹæp wɑz dʒʌst wʌɾ ɪts neɪm ɪmplaɪd. ʃi kəd fil ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪnɪŋ fɹəm əɹ feɪs.

He reached into the open neck of his shirt, and her own tongue clove to the roof of her mouth. Her eyes fixed on the small cage of gold wire and blood-red crystal that he drew out dangling on a cord. She thought vaguely that he tucked another just like it back in, but she had eyes only for her own. It definitely was hers. His thumb stroked, and she felt that caress across her mind, her soul. Breaking a mindtrap did not require much more pressure than he was using. She could be on the other side of the world or farther, and it would not matter a hair. The part of her that was her would be separated; she would still see with her eyes and hear with her ears, taste what crossed her tongue and feel what touched her, but helpless within an automaton that was utterly obedient to whoever held the cour'souvra. Whether or not there was any way to get free of it, a mindtrap was just what its name implied. She could feel the blood draining from her face.

"ju ʌndɝstænd naʊ?" hi sɛd. "ju stɪl sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, bʌt naʊ ɪɾəl bi baɪ duɪŋ əz aɪ seɪ."

"You understand now?" he said. "You still serve the Great Lord, but now it will be by doing as I say."

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd, miɑkoʊvə," ʃi sɛɾ ɔɾəmætɪkli.

"I understand, Mia'cova," she said automatically.

əɡɛn i læft, ə dip ɹɪtʃ saʊn ðət mɑkt əɹ əz i pʊt ðə maɪntʃɹæp əweɪ bɪniθ ɪz ʃɝt. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt, naʊ juv hæd jəɹ lɛsən. əl kɔl jə mɑɡiɾin, ən jəl kɔl mi mɔɹaɪɾɪn. jə ɑɹ stɪl wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. hu ɪz ðəɹ tə ɹipleɪs ju?"

Again he laughed, a deep rich sound that mocked her as he put the mindtrap away beneath his shirt. "There is no need for that, now you've had your lesson. I will call you Moghedien, and you will call me Moridin. You are still one of the Chosen. Who is there to replace you?"

"jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, mɔɹaɪɾɪn," ʃi sɛd toʊnləsli. wʌtɛvɝ i sɛd, ʃi nu ðət ʃi wɑz oʊnd.

"Yes, of course, Moridin," she said tonelessly. Whatever he said, she knew that she was owned.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks


CHAPTER 26

ði ɪɹɛvəkəbəl wɝdz


The Irrevocable Words

mɔɹɡeɪs leɪ əweɪk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ θɹu ðə munlɪt dɑɹknəs, ən tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ə hɝ dɔɾɝ. ə sɪŋɡəl peɪl lɪnən ʃit kʌvɝd hɝ, bʌt dɪspaɪt ðə hit ʃi swɛɾɪd ɪn ə θɪk wʊlən slipɪŋ ɡaʊn, leɪs taɪtli tə ðə nɛk. swɛt hɑɹdli mæɾɝd; noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni taɪmz ʃi beɪðd, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑt ðə wɔɾɝ, ʃi dɪd nɑt fil klin. ɪleɪn mʌs bi seɪf ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ət taɪmz ɪt sim jɪɹz sɪns ʃi kəd meɪk hɝsɛlf tʃɹʌst ɛɛs sədaɪ, jɛt wʌtɛvɝ ðə pɛɹədɑks, ðə taʊɝ wɑz ʃʊɹli ðə seɪfəs pleɪs fəɹ ɪleɪn. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ʌv ɡɔɪn - hi wəd bi ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð ɪz sɪstɝ, fʊl ə hɪz pɹaɪd fəɹ hɝ, soʊ ɝnɪst ɪn ɪz dɪzaɪɝ tə bi hɝ ʃild wən ʃi niɾəd wʌn - ən ʌv ɡɑləd - waɪ wəd ðeɪ nɑt lɛɾ əɹ si hɪm? ʃi lʌvd ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz ɪf i hæd kʌm aʊɾ ə hɝ oʊn bɑɾi, ən ɪn soʊ mɛni weɪz i niɾəd ɪt mɔɹ ðən ði ʌðɝ tu. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ə ðɛm. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛpt. . . . waɪɾ aɪz stɛɹɾ ʌp ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs, ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɪð ənʃt tɪɹz.

Morgase lay awake, staring at the ceiling through the moonlit darkness, and tried to think of her daughter. A single pale linen sheet covered her, but despite the heat she sweated in a thick woolen sleeping gown, laced tightly to the neck. Sweat hardly mattered; no matter how many times she bathed, no matter how hot the water, she did not feel clean. Elayne must be safe in the White Tower. At times it seemed years since she could make herself trust Aes Sedai, yet whatever the paradox, the Tower was surely the safest place for Elayne. She tried to think of Gawyn - he would be in Tar Valon with his sister, full of his pride for her, so earnest in his desire to be her shield when she needed one - and of Galad - why would they not let her see him? She loved him as much as if he had come out of her own body, and in so many ways he needed it more than the other two. She tried to think of them. It was difficult to think of anything except. . . . Wide eyes stared up into the darkness, glistening with unshed tears.

ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz θɔt ʃi wɑz bɹeɪv ɪnʌf tə də wʌtɛvɝ niɾəd duɪŋ, tə feɪs wʌtɛvɝ keɪm; ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪlivd ʃi kəd pɪk hɝsɛlf ʌp ən kəntɪnju tə faɪt. ɪn wʌn ɛnləs aʊɝ, wɪθaʊt livɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fju bɹuzəz ðət wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi feɪɾɪŋ, ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə hæd bɪɡʌn titʃɪŋ əɹ dɪfɹənli. imən vɑldə hæd kəmpliɾəd əɹ ɛdʒəkeɪʃən wɪð wʌn kwɛstʃən. ðə bɹuz əɹ ænsɝ hæd lɛft ɑn əɹ hɑɹt hæd nɑt feɪɾəd. ʃi ʃʊɾə ɡɔn bæk tə əsunɑwə hɝsɛlf ən toʊld ɪm tə də hɪz wɝst. ʃi ʃəd hæv. . . . ʃi pɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz seɪf. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz nɑt fɛɹ tə hoʊp mɔɹ fəɹ ɪleɪn ðən fəɹ ɡɑləɾ əɹ ɡɔɪn, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wəd bi ðə nɛks kwin ʌv ændɝ. ðə taʊɝ wəd nɑt mɪs ðə tʃæns tə pʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd si ɪleɪn, si ɔl əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən wʌns mɔɹ.

She had always thought she was brave enough to do whatever needed doing, to face whatever came; she had always believed she could pick herself up and continue to fight. In one endless hour, without leaving more than a few bruises that were already fading, Rhadam Asunawa had begun teaching her differently. Eamon Valda had completed her education with one question. The bruise her answer had left on her heart had not faded. She should have gone back to Asunawa herself and told him to do his worst. She should have. . . . She prayed that Elayne was safe. Perhaps it was not fair to hope more for Elayne than for Galad or Gawyn, but Elayne would be the next Queen of Andor. The Tower would not miss the chance to put an Aes Sedai on the Lion Throne. If only she could see Elayne, see all her children once more.

sʌmθɪŋ ɹʌsəld ɪn ðə dɑɹk bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ən ʃi hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ, fɔɾ əɡɛns tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. ðə feɪn munlaɪt bɛɹli lɛɾ əɹ meɪk aʊt ðə bɪdpoʊsts. vɑldə hæd ɹɪɾən nɔɹθ fɹəm æmədɔɹ jɛstɝdeɪ, hɪm ən əsunɑwə, wɪð θaʊzənz ʌv waɪtkloʊks tə feɪs ðə pɹɑfət, bʌɾ ɪf i hæd kʌm bæk, ɪf hi. . . . ə ʃeɪp ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ə wʊmən, tu ʃɔɹt fəɹ lini. "aɪ θɔt jə maɪt stɪl bi əweɪk," bɹinz vɔɪs sɛd sɔfli. "dʒɹɪŋk ðɪs; ɪɾəl hɛlp." ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ə sɪlvɝi kʌp ɪndə mɔɹɡeɪsəz hænd. ɪt ɡeɪv ɔf ə slaɪtli saʊɝ smɛl.

Something rustled in the dark bedchamber, and she held her breath, fought against trembling. The faint moonlight barely let her make out the bedposts. Valda had ridden north from Amador yesterday, him and Asunawa, with thousands of Whitecloaks to face the Prophet, but if he had come back, if he. . . . A shape in the darkness resolved into a woman, too short for Lini. "I thought you might still be awake," Breane's voice said softly. "Drink this; it will help." The Cairhienin woman tried to put a silvery cup into Morgase's hand. It gave off a slightly sour smell.

"weɪɾ əntɪl jəɹ sʌmən tə bɹɪŋ mi dʒɹɪŋk," ʃi snæpt, pʊʃɪŋ ðə kʌp əweɪ. wɔɹm lɪkwəd spɪld ɑntu hɝ hænd, ɑntu ðə lɪnən ʃit. "aɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊst əslip wən jə keɪm stæmpɪŋ ɪn," ʃi laɪd. "liv mi!"

"Wait until you're summoned to bring me drink," she snapped, pushing the cup away. Warm liquid spilled onto her hand, onto the linen sheet. "I was almost asleep when you came stamping in," she lied. "Leave me!"

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊbeɪɪŋ, ðə wʊmən stʊd lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ, feɪs ʃæɾoʊd. mɔɹɡeɪs dɪd nɑt laɪk bɹin tæbɔɹwɪn. wɛðɝ bɹin tʃɹuli wɑz nɑbli bɔɹn ən kʌm daʊn ɪn ðə wɝld, əz ʃi səmtaɪmz kleɪmd, əɹ mɪɹli ə sɝvən u hæd lɝn tə kaʊntɝfɪɾ əɹ bɛɾɝz, ʃi oʊbeɪd wən ən əz ʃi tʃoʊz ən lɛɾ əɹ tʌŋ ɹʌn ɪntaɪɝli tu fɹi. əz ʃi pɹuv naʊ.

Instead of obeying, the woman stood looking down at her, face shadowed. Morgase did not like Breane Taborwin. Whether Breane truly was nobly born and come down in the world, as she sometimes claimed, or merely a servant who had learned to counterfeit her betters, she obeyed when and as she chose and let her tongue run entirely too free. As she proved now.

"ju moʊn laɪk ə ʃip, mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd." ivən kɛp loʊ, hɝ vɔɪs siðd ɪn æŋɡɝ. ʃi sɛt ðə kʌp ɑn ðə smɔl bɛdsaɪd teɪbəl wɪð ə θʌmp; mɔɹ ə ðə kɑntɛns splæʃt ɑntu ðə teɪbəltɑp. "bɑ! mɛni ʌðɝz əv sin fɑɹ wɝs. jə ɑɹ əlaɪv. nʌn ə jəɹ boʊnz ɑɹ bɹoʊkən; jəɹ wɪts ɑɹ hoʊl. ɛndʒjʊɹ; lɛt ðə pæs pæs, ən ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð jəɹ laɪf. juv bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ ɑn ɛdʒ ðət ðə mɛn wɔk ɑn ðɛɹ toʊz, ivən mæstɝ ɡɪl. læmɡwɪn əz hɑɹdli slɛpt ə wɪŋk ðiz θɹi naɪts."

"You moan like a sheep, Morgase Trakand." Even kept low, her voice seethed in anger. She set the cup on the small bedside table with a thump; more of the contents splashed onto the tabletop. "Bah! Many others have seen far worse. You are alive. None of your bones are broken; your wits are whole. Endure; let the past pass, and go on with your life. You have been so much on edge that the men walk on their toes, even Master Gill. Lamgwin has hardly slept a wink these three nights."

mɔɹɡeɪs flʌʃt wɪð ənɔɪəns; ivən ɪn ændɝ, sɝvəns dɪd nɑt spik soʊ. ʃi kɑt ðə wʊmənz ɑɹm ɪn ə taɪt ɡɹɪp, bʌɾ æŋzaɪəɾi wɔɹd wɪð dɪsplɛʒɝ. "ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ, də ðeɪ?" ɪf ðeɪ dɪd, ðeɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ tə əvɛnʒ hɝ, ɹɛskju hɝ. ðeɪ wəd daɪ. tɑlænvɝ wəd daɪ.

Morgase flushed with annoyance; even in Andor, servants did not speak so. She caught the woman's arm in a tight grip, but anxiety warred with displeasure. "They don't know, do they?" If they did, they would try to avenge her, rescue her. They would die. Tallanvor would die.

"lini ən aɪ dʒɹeɪp lɪnən oʊvɝ ðɛɹ aɪz fəɹ ju," bɹin snɪɹd, pʊlɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ ən flɪŋɪŋ ɪt bæk ət hɝ. "ɪf aɪ kəd seɪv læmɡwɪn, aɪ wəd lɛɾ əm noʊ jə fəɹ ðə bliɾɪŋ ʃip jə ɑɹ. hi siz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ ɪn ju; aɪ si ə wʊmən wɪθaʊt kɝədʒ tə æksɛp ðə deɪ. əl nɑt lɛt jə dɪstʃɹɔɪ hɪm wɪð jəɹ kaʊɝɾəs."

"Lini and I drape linen over their eyes for you," Breane sneered, pulling her hand away and flinging it back at her. "If I could save Lamgwin, I would let them know you for the bleating sheep you are. He sees the Light made flesh in you; I see a woman without courage to accept the day. I will not let you destroy him with your cowardice."

kaʊɝɾəs. aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ wɛld ʌp ɪn mɔɹɡeɪs, jɛt noʊ wɝdz keɪm. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz nɑɾɪd ɪn ðə ʃit. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi cʊɾə dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪn koʊl blʌd tə laɪ wɪð vɑldə, bʌt hæd ʃi, ʃi cʊɾə lɪvd wɪð ɪt. ʃi θɔt ʃi kʊd. ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ ɪntaɪɝli tə seɪ jɛs kəz ʃi fɪɹd feɪsɪŋ əsunɑwəz nɑɾɪd kɔɹdz ən niɾəlz əɡɛn, fɪɹd wɝs wʌɾ i wʊɾə ɡɑɾən tə ɪvɛntʃəwəli. haʊɛvɝ ʃi hæd skɹimd ʌndɝ əsunɑwəz mɪnəstʃɹeɪʃənz, vɑldə wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd ʃoʊɾ əɹ ðə tʃɹu bɔɹɾɝz ə hɝ kɝədʒ, soʊ fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪlivd. vɑldəz tʌtʃ, hɪz bɛd, kəd bi fɝɡɑɾən, wɪð taɪm, bʌt ʃi wəd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə wɑʃ ðə ʃeɪm ə ðət "jɛs" fɹəm əɹ lɪps. bɹin hɝl ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn əɹ feɪs, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə ɹɪplaɪ.

Cowardice. Outrage welled up in Morgase, yet no words came. Her fingers knotted in the sheet. She did not think she could have decided in cold blood to lie with Valda, but had she, she could have lived with it. She thought she could. Another matter entirely to say yes because she feared facing Asunawa's knotted cords and needles again, feared worse what he would have gotten to eventually. However she had screamed under Asunawa's ministrations, Valda was the one who had showed her the true borders of her courage, so far short of where she had believed. Valda's touch, his bed, could be forgotten, with time, but she would never be able to wash the shame of that "yes" from her lips. Breane hurled the truth in her face, and she did not know how to reply.

ʃi wɑz spɛɹd ðə nid baɪ ə ɹʌʃ ə buts ɪn ði aʊɾɝ ɹum. ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ dɔɹ flʌŋ oʊpən, ən ə ɹʌnɪŋ mæn stɑpt ə peɪs ɪnsaɪd.

She was spared the need by a rush of boots in the outer room. The bedchamber door flung open, and a running man stopped a pace inside.

"soʊ jəɹ əweɪk; ɡʊd," tɑlænvɝz vɔɪs sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. wɪtʃ əlaʊɾ əɹ hɑɹt tə stɑɹt biɾɪŋ əɡɛn, əlaʊɾ əɹ tə bɹið. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹilis bɹinz hænd - ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ klæspɪŋ ɪt - bʌt tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə wʊmən skwizd wʌns bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ.

"So you're awake; good," Tallanvor's voice said after a moment. Which allowed her heart to start beating again, allowed her to breathe. She tried to release Breane's hand - she did not remember clasping it - but to her surprise, the woman squeezed once before letting go.

"sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ," tɑlænvɝ wɛn ɑn, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə loʊn wɪndoʊ. stændɪŋ tə wʌn saɪɾ əz ɪf tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ sin, hi pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt. munlaɪɾ aʊtlaɪn ɪz tɔl fɔɹm. "mæstɝ ɡɪl, kʌm ən tɛl wʌt jə sɔ."

"Something is happening," Tallanvor went on, striding to the lone window. Standing to one side as if to avoid being seen, he peered into the night. Moonlight outlined his tall form. "Master Gill, come and tell what you saw."

ə hɛɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, bɔl tɑp ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. bɪhaɪnd, ɪn ði ʌðɝ ɹum, ə hʌlkɪŋ ʃædoʊ muvd; læmɡwɪn dɔɹn. wən bɑzəl ɡɪl ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz stɪl ɪn bɛd, ðət feɪnt ʃaɪnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz skælp dʒɝkt əz i dɝɛktəɾ ɪz aɪz ɛlswɛɹ, ðoʊ hi pɹɑbli hæd dɪfəkəlti meɪkɪŋ aʊt mɔɹ ðən ðə bɛɾ ɪtsɛlf. mæstɝ ɡɪl wɑz ivən waɪɾɝ ðən læmɡwɪn, bʌt nɑt nɪɹli əz tɔl. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ kwin. aɪ dɪdn min tə. . . ." hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt vaɪələnli, ən ɪz buts skɹeɪpt ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ʃɪftɪŋ. hæɾ i hæɾ ə kæp, hi wʊɾə bɪn tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz, əɹ wɑɾɪŋ ɪt nɝvəsli. "aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə lɔŋ kɔɹəɾɝ, ɑn maɪ weɪ tə . . . tə. . . ." tə ðə dʒeɪks, wɑz wʌɾ i kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə seɪ tə hɝ. "ɛniweɪ, aɪ ɡlænst aʊt wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz, ən aɪ sɔ ə . . . ə bɪɡ bɝd, aɪ θɪŋk . . . læn ɑn tɑp ə ðə saʊθ bæɹəks."

A head appeared in the doorway, bald top shining in the darkness. Behind, in the other room, a hulking shadow moved; Lamgwin Dorn. When Basel Gill realized she was still in bed, that faint shining from his scalp jerked as he directed his eyes elsewhere, though he probably had difficulty making out more than the bed itself. Master Gill was even wider than Lamgwin, but not nearly as tall. "Forgive me, my Queen. I didn't mean to. . . ." He cleared his throat violently, and his boots scraped on the floor, shifting. Had he had a cap, he would have been turning it in his hands, or wadding it nervously. "I was in the Long Corridor, on my way to . . . to. . . ." To the jakes, was what he could not bring himself to say to her. "Anyway, I glanced out one of the windows, and I saw a . . . a big bird, I think . . . land on top of the South Barracks."

"ə bɝd!" liniz θɪn vɔɪs dʒɹoʊv mæstɝ ɡɪl tə lip ɪndə ðə ɹum, klɪɹɪŋ ðə dɔɹweɪ. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ə ʃɑɹp poʊk ɪn ɪz staʊt ɹɪbz. lini juʒəwəli tʊk ɛvɹi ædvæntɪdʒ əɹ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɔfɝd. ʃi stɔk baɪ hɪm stɪl bɛltɪŋ əɹ naɪtʃɹoʊb. "fulz! ɑks-bɹeɪn lʌmɑksɪz! jə woʊk maɪ tʃ - !" ʃi stɑpt wɪð ə fɪɹs kɑf; lini nɛvɝ fɝɡɑt ðət ʃi hæd bɪn mɔɹɡeɪsəz nɝs, ən əɹ mʌðɝz əz wɛl, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ slɪpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌðɝz. ʃi wəd bi kɹɔs ðət ʃi hæd naʊ, ən ɪt ʃoʊɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "ju woʊk jəɹ kwin fəɹ ə bɝd!" pæɾɪŋ əɹ hɛɹnɛt, ʃi ɔɾəmætɪkli tʌkt ɪn ə fju stʃɹænz ðət hæɾ ɪskeɪpt ɪn əɹ slip. "hæv jə bɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, bɑzəl ɡɪl?" mɔɹɡeɪs wʌndɝd ðət hɝsɛlf.

"A bird!" Lini's thin voice drove Master Gill to leap into the room, clearing the doorway. Or maybe it was a sharp poke in his stout ribs. Lini usually took every advantage her gray hair offered. She stalked by him still belting her nightrobe. "Fools! Ox-brained lummoxes! You woke my ch - !" She stopped with a fierce cough; Lini never forgot that she had been Morgase's nurse, and her mother's as well, but she never slipped in front of others. She would be cross that she had now, and it showed in her voice. "You woke your Queen for a bird!" Patting her hairnet, she automatically tucked in a few strands that had escaped in her sleep. "Have you been drinking, Basel Gill?" Morgase wondered that herself.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪt wɑz ə bɝd," mæstɝ ɡɪl pɹətɛstəd. "ɪt dɪdn lʊk laɪk ɛni bɝd, bʌt wʌɾ ɛls flaɪz, ɪksɛp bæts? ɪt wɑz bɪɡ. mɛn klaɪmd ɔf ɪts bæk, ən ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ stɪl ɑn ɪts nɛk wən ɪt tʊk ɔf əɡɛn. waɪl aɪ wɑz slæpɪŋ maɪ feɪs tə weɪk ʌp, ənʌðɝ ə ðə . . . θɪŋz . . . lændəd, ən mɔɹ mɛn klaɪm daʊn, ən ðən ənʌðɝ keɪm, ən aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz taɪm tə tɛl lɔɹd tɑlænvɝ." lini dɪd nɑt snɪf, bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil əɹ stɛɹ, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt dɝɛktəɾ ət hɝ. ðə mæn u hæɾ əbændən ɪz ɪn tə fɑloʊ hɝ sɝɾənli fɛlt ɪt. "ðə laɪts oʊn tʃɹuθ, maɪ kwin," hi ɪnsɪstəd.

"I don't know it was a bird," Master Gill protested. "It didn't look like any bird, but what else flies, except bats? It was big. Men climbed off its back, and there was another still on its neck when it took off again. While I was slapping my face to wake up, another of the . . . things . . . landed, and more men climbed down, and then another came, and I decided it was time to tell Lord Tallanvor." Lini did not sniff, but Morgase could almost feel her stare, and it was not directed at her. The man who had abandoned his inn to follow her certainly felt it. "The Light's own truth, my Queen," he insisted.

"laɪt!" tɑlænvɝ ənaʊns laɪk ən ɛkoʊ. "sʌmθɪŋ. . . . sʌmθɪŋ dʒʌs lændəɾ ətɑp ðə nɔɹθ bæɹəks." mɔɹɡeɪs hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪm saʊnd ʃeɪkən bɪfɔɹ. ɔl ʃi wɑntəd wɑz tə meɪk əm ɔl ɡoʊ əweɪ ən liv əɹ əloʊn ɪn əɹ mɪzɝi, bʌt ðəɹ sim noʊ hoʊp. tɑlænvɝ wɑz wɝs ðən bɹin ɪn mɛni weɪz. mʌtʃ wɝs.

"Light!" Tallanvor announced like an echo. "Something. . . . Something just landed atop the North Barracks." Morgase had never heard him sound shaken before. All she wanted was to make them all go away and leave her alone in her misery, but there seemed no hope. Tallanvor was worse than Breane in many ways. Much worse.

"maɪ ɹoʊb," ʃi sɛd, ən fəɹ wʌns bɹin wɑz kwɪk tə hæn əɹ wʌn. mæstɝ ɡɪl heɪstəli tɝn ɪz feɪs tə ðə wɔl waɪl ʃi klaɪm fɹəm ðə bɛɾ ən pʊɾ ɑn ðə sɪlk ɹoʊb.

"My robe," she said, and for once Breane was quick to hand her one. Master Gill hastily turned his face to the wall while she climbed from the bed and put on the silk robe.

ʃi stʃɹoʊd tə ðə wɪndoʊ, taɪɪŋ ðə sæʃ. ðə lɔŋ nɔɹθ bæɹəks lumd əkɹɔs ðə waɪd kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, fɔɹ hʌlkɪŋ flɔɹz ə flæt-ɹuf dɑɹk stoʊn. nɑɾ ə laɪt ʃoʊd, ðəɹ əɹ ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. ɔl wɑz stɪlnəs ən saɪləns. "aɪ si nʌθɪŋ, tɑlænvɝ."

She strode to the window, tying the sash. The long North Barracks loomed across the wide courtyard, four hulking floors of flat-roofed dark stone. Not a light showed, there or anywhere in the Fortress. All was stillness and silence. "I see nothing, Tallanvor."

hi dʒɹu hɝ bæk. "dʒʌst wɑtʃ," hi sɛd.

He drew her back. "Just watch," he said.

ənʌðɝ taɪm ʃi wʊɾə ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ɪz hæn livɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ən bɪn ɪɹəteɪɾəd əɾ əɹ oʊn ɹəɡɹɛɾ əz wɛl əz ɪz toʊn. naʊ, æftɝ vɑldə, ʃi fɛlt ɹɪlif. ən ɪɹɪteɪʃən ət ðə ɹɪlif əz wɛl əz ɪz toʊn. hi wɑz tu dɪsɹɪspɛkfəl baɪ maɪlz, fɑɹ tu stʌbɝn, tu jʌŋ. nɑt mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən ɡɑləd.

Another time she would have regretted his hand leaving her shoulder, and been irritated at her own regret as well as his tone. Now, after Valda, she felt relief. And irritation at the relief as well as his tone. He was too disrespectful by miles, far too stubborn, too young. Not much older than Galad.

ʃædoʊz muvd əz ðə mun dɪd, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɛls stɝd. ɔf ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv æmədɔɹ, ə dɔɡ beɪd, ænsɝd baɪ mɔɹ. ðɛn, əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə dɪsmɪs tɑlænvɝ ən ɔl ə ðɛm, dɑɹknəs ətɑp ðə mæsɪv bæɹəks hʌmpt ʌp ən hɝld ɪtsɛlf ɔf ðə ɹuf.

Shadows moved as the moon did, but nothing else stirred. Off in the city of Amador, a dog bayed, answered by more. Then, as she opened her mouth to dismiss Tallanvor and all of them, darkness atop the massive barracks humped up and hurled itself off the roof.

sʌmθɪŋ, tɑlænvɝ hæd kɔld ɪt, ən ʃi hæd noʊ bɛɾɝ neɪm. ən ɪmpɹɛʃən ʌv ə lɔŋ bɑɾi ðət sim θɪkɝ ðən ə mæn wɑz tɔl; ɡɹeɪt ɹɪbd wɪŋz laɪk ə bæts swipɪŋ daʊn əz ðə kɹitʃɝ fɛl təwɔɹd ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd; ə fɪɡjɝ, ə mæn, sɪɾɪŋ dʒʌs bɪhaɪn ə sɪnwəs nɛk. ən ðən ðə wɪŋz kɑɾ ɛɹ, ən ðə . . . sʌmθɪŋ . . . sɔɹɾ ʌp, blɑkɪŋ ðə munlaɪɾ əz ɪt swɛpt oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ə lɔŋ, θɪn teɪl.

Something, Tallanvor had called it, and she had no better name. An impression of a long body that seemed thicker than a man was tall; great ribbed wings like a bat's sweeping down as the creature fell toward the courtyard; a figure, a man, sitting just behind a sinuous neck. And then the wings caught air, and the . . . something . . . soared up, blocking the moonlight as it swept over her head trailing a long, thin tail.

mɔɹɡeɪs kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ sloʊli. ði oʊnli θɔt ðət keɪm tə hɝ wɑz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ʃædoʊ-twɪstəd kɹitʃɝz ɪn ðə blaɪt. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tɔɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, bʌɾ əɹ tuɾɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ sɛd ðət θɪŋz lɪv ðəɹ noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin klɪɹli ən lɪv tə dɪskɹaɪb. haʊ kəɾ ɪt bi soʊ fɑɹ saʊθ, ðoʊ?

Morgase closed her mouth slowly. The only thought that came to her was Shadowspawn. Trollocs and Myrddraal were not the only Shadow-twisted creatures in the Blight. She had never been taught of anything like this, but her tutors in the Tower said that things lived there no one had ever seen clearly and lived to describe. How could it be so far south, though?

əbɹʌpli ə flæʃ ə laɪt flɛɹd wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt bum ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə meɪn ɡeɪts, ən ðən əɡɛn, ət tu mɔɹ pleɪsəz əlɔŋ ðə ɡɹeɪɾ aʊɾɝ wɔl. ðoʊz wɝ ɡeɪts tu, ʃi bɪlivd.

Abruptly a flash of light flared with a great boom in the direction of the main gates, and then again, at two more places along the great outer wall. Those were gates too, she believed.

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə dum wɑz ðæt?" tɑlænvɝ mʌɾɝd ɪn ə moʊmən ə saɪləns bɪfɔɹ əlɑɹm ɡɔŋz bɪɡæn ɹisaʊndɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ʃaʊts ɹoʊz, ən skɹimz, ən hɔɹs kɹaɪz laɪk səm sɔɹɾ ə hɔɹn. faɪɝ lɛpt wɪð ə kɹæʃ ə θʌndɝ, ðən əɡɛn ɛlswɛɹ.

"What in the Pit of Doom was that?" Tallanvor muttered in a moment of silence before alarm gongs began resounding in the darkness. Shouts rose, and screams, and hoarse cries like some sort of horn. Fire leaped with a crash of thunder, then again elsewhere.

"ðə wʌn paʊɝ," mɔɹɡeɪs bɹiðd. ʃi maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, əɹ əz wɛl əz nɑt, bʌt ʃi kəd tɛl ðæt. noʊʃənz ə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn flɛd. "ɪt . . . ɪt mʌs bi ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi hɝd sʌmwʌnz bɹɛθ kætʃ bɪhaɪn hɝ; lini əɹ bɹin. bɑzəl ɡɪl ɪksaɪɾədli mɝmɝd "ɛɛs sədaɪ," ən læmɡwɪn mɝmɝd bæk tu loʊ fəɹ əɹ tə ʌndɝstænd. ɔf ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, mɛɾəl klæʃt ɑn mɛɾəl; faɪɝ bɛloʊd, ən laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹik fɹəm ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ. feɪnli θɹu ðə dɪn keɪm əlɑɹm bɛlz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ət læst, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli fju.

"The One Power," Morgase breathed. She might not be able to channel, or as well as not, but she could tell that. Notions of Shadowspawn fled. "It . . . it must be Aes Sedai." She heard someone's breath catch behind her; Lini or Breane. Basel Gill excitedly murmured "Aes Sedai," and Lamgwin murmured back too low for her to understand. Off in the darkness, metal clashed on metal; fire bellowed, and lightning streaked from the cloudless sky. Faintly through the din came alarm bells from the city at last, but strangely few.

"ɛɛs sədaɪ." tɑlænvɝ saʊndəd daʊtfəl. "waɪ naʊ? tə ɹɛskju ju, mɔɹɡeɪs? aɪ θɔt ðeɪ kʊdn juz ðə paʊɝ əɡɛns mɛn, oʊnli ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf ðət wɪŋ kɹitʃɝ wɑznt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əl nɛvɝ si wʌn."

"Aes Sedai." Tallanvor sounded doubtful. "Why now? To rescue you, Morgase? I thought they couldn't use the power against men, only Shadowspawn. Besides, if that winged creature wasn't Shadowspawn, I will never see one."

"ju doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt!" ʃi sɛd, kənfɹʌntɪŋ ɪm hiɾɪdli. "ju - !" ə kɹɔsboʊ boʊl klæʃt əɡɛns ðə wɪndoʊfɹeɪm ɪn ə spɹeɪ ʌv stoʊn tʃɪps; ɛɹ stɝɾ əɡɛnst əɹ feɪs əz ɪt ɹɪkəʃeɪd bɪtwin əm ən plæntəɾ ɪtsɛlf ɪn wʌn ə ðə bɪdpoʊsts wɪð ə sɑləd tʃʌŋk. ə fju ɪntʃəz tə ðə ɹaɪt, ən ɔl əɹ tʃɹʌbəlz wʊɾə bɪn ɛndəd.

"You don't know what you are talking about!" she said, confronting him heatedly. "You - !" A crossbow bolt clashed against the windowframe in a spray of stone chips; air stirred against her face as it ricocheted between them and planted itself in one of the bedposts with a solid tchunk. A few inches to the right, and all her troubles would have been ended.

ʃi dɪd nɑt muv, bʌt tɑlænvɝ pʊld əɹ əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ wɪð ən oʊθ. ivən baɪ munlaɪt, ʃi kəd si hɪz fɹaʊn əz i stʌɾid hɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi θɔɾ i maɪt tʌtʃ əɹ feɪs; ɪf i dɪd, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ʃi wəd wip əɹ skɹim əɹ ɔɹɾɝ ɪm tə liv əɹ fɝɛvɝ ɔɹ. . . . ɪnstɛd, hi sɛd, "mɔɹ laɪkli ɪts səm ə ðoʊz mɛn, ðoʊz ʃeɪmən əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz." hi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn æksɛptɪŋ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɪmpɑsəbəl teɪlz ðət hæd sipt ivən ɪndə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən ɡɛt jə aʊt, ɹaɪt naʊ; ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪl bi kənfjuʒən. kʌm wɪð mi."

She did not move, but Tallanvor pulled her away from the window with an oath. Even by moonlight, she could see his frown as he studied her. For a moment she thought he might touch her face; if he did, she did not know whether she would weep or scream or order him to leave her forever or. . . . Instead, he said, "More likely it's some of those men, those Shamin or whatever they call themselves." He insisted on accepting the strange, impossible tales that had seeped even into the Fortress. "I think I can get you out, right now; everything will be confusion. Come with me."

ʃi dɪd nɑt kɝɛk hɪm; fju pipəl nu ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wʌn paʊɝ, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə dɪfɝənsɪz bɪtwin seɪaɪdɑɹ ən seɪɾɪn. hɪz aɪdiə hæɾ ɪts ətʃɹækʃənz. ðeɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp ɪn ðə bɛdləm ʌv ə bæɾəl.

She did not correct him; few people knew anything about the One Power, much less the differences between saidar and saidin. His idea had its attractions. They might be able to escape in the bedlam of a battle.

"teɪk əɹ aʊɾ ɪndə ðæt!" lini skɹitʃt. flɛɹɪŋ laɪts dʒɹaʊn ðə mun ət ðə wɪndoʊ; kɹæʃɪz ən θʌndɝz dʒɹaʊn ðə dɪn ə mɛn ən sɔɹdz. "aɪ θɔt jə hæd mɔɹ wɪts, mɑɹɾɪn tɑlænvɝ. 'oʊnli fulz kɪs hɔɹnəts əɹ baɪt faɪɝ.' jə hɝɾ əɹ seɪ ɪts ɛɛs sədaɪ. dʒju θɪŋk ʃi dʌznt noʊ? də ju?"

"Take her out into that!" Lini screeched. Flaring lights drowned the moon at the window; crashes and thunders drowned the din of men and swords. "I thought you had more wits, Martyn Tallanvor. 'Only fools kiss hornets or bite fire.' You heard her say it's Aes Sedai. Do you think she doesn't know? Do you?"

"maɪ lɔɹd, ɪf ɪts ɛɛs sədaɪ. . . ." mæstɝ ɡɪl tʃɹeɪld ɔf.

"My Lord, if it is Aes Sedai. . . ." Master Gill trailed off.

tɑlænvɝz hænz fɛl əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, ən i ɡɹʌmbəld ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, wɪʃɪŋ i hæɾ ə sɔɹd. peɪdʒɹən naɪl hæɾ əlaʊɾ ɪm tə kip ɪz bleɪd; imən vɑldə wɑz nɑt soʊ tʃɹʌstɪŋ.

Tallanvor's hands fell away from her, and he grumbled under his breath, wishing he had a sword. Pedron Niall had allowed him to keep his blade; Eamon Valda was not so trusting.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, dɪsəpɔɪnmənt swɛld ɪn əɹ bɹɛst. ɪf oʊnli hi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd, hæd dʒɹæɡd hɝ. . . . wʌt wɑz ðə mæɾɝ wɪð hɝ? hæɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə dʒɹæɡ hɝ ɛniwɛɹ fəɹ ɛni ɹizən, ʃi wʊɾə hæɾ ɪz haɪd. ʃi niɾəd tə teɪk hoʊld ə hɝsɛlf. vɑldə hæd dɛntɪɾ əɹ kɑnfəɾəns - noʊ, hi hæd kæʒəwəli ɹɪpt ɪt tə ʃɹɛdz - bʌt ʃi mʌs klɪŋ tə ðoʊz ʃɹɛdz ən nɪɾ əm ʌp əɡɛn. sʌmhaʊ. ɪf ðə tæɾɝz wɝ wɝθ nɪɾɪŋ ʌp əɡɛn.

For an instant, disappointment swelled in her breast. If only he had insisted, had dragged her. . . . What was the matter with her? Had he tried to drag her anywhere for any reason, she would have had his hide. She needed to take hold of herself. Valda had dented her confidence - no, he had casually ripped it to shreds - but she must cling to those shreds and knit them up again. Somehow. If the tatters were worth knitting up again.

"æt list aɪ kən faɪn aʊt wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ," tɑlænvɝ ɡɹaʊld, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. "ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ - "

"At least I can find out what is happening," Tallanvor growled, striding for the door. "If it isn't your Aes Sedai - "

"noʊ! jəl ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ. pliz." ʃi wɑz vɛɹi ɡlæɾ ə ðə peɪl dɑɹknəs, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ fjʊɹiəsli flʌʃɪŋ feɪs. ʃi wʊɾə bɪɾən əɹ tʌŋ ɔf bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ ðət læst wɝd, bʌɾ ɪt hæd slɪpt aʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu. ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn fɝmɝ toʊnz. "ju wɪl ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ jəɹ kwin əz jə ʃʊd."

"No! You will remain here. Please." She was very glad of the pale darkness, hiding her furiously flushing face. She would have bitten her tongue off before saying that last word, but it had slipped out before she knew. She went on in firmer tones. "You will remain here, guarding your Queen as you should."

ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt, ʃi kəd si hɪz feɪs, ən ɪz baʊ sim kwaɪt pɹɑpɝ, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə weɪdʒɝɾ əɹ læs kɑpɝ boʊθ wɝ æŋɡɹi. "aɪ wɪl bi ɪn jəɹ æntəɹum." wɛl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz vɔɪs. fəɹ wʌns, ðoʊ, ʃi kɛɹd niðɝ haʊ æŋɡɹi hi wɑz nɔɹ haʊ lɪɾəl i hɪɾ ɪt. vɛɹi pɑsəbli ʃi maɪt kɪl ði ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ mæn wɪð əɹ oʊn hænz, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt gɑnə daɪ tənaɪt, kʌt daʊn baɪ soʊlʒɝz wɪð noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɪtʃ saɪɾ i wɑz ɑn.

In the dim light, she could see his face, and his bow seemed quite proper, but she would have wagered her last copper both were angry. "I will be in your anteroom." Well, there was no doubt about his voice. For once, though, she cared neither how angry he was nor how little he hid it. Very possibly she might kill the infuriating man with her own hands, but he was not going to die tonight, cut down by soldiers with no way to tell which side he was on.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hoʊp ə slip naʊ ivən hæd ʃi bɪn eɪbəl. wɪθaʊt laɪɾɪŋ ɛni læmps, ʃi wɑʃt əɹ feɪs ən tiθ. bɹin ən lini hɛlpt əɹ dʒɹɛs, ɪn blu sɪlk slæʃt wɪð ɡɹin, wɪð spɪlz ə snoʊi leɪs əɾ əɹ ɹɪsts ən bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn. ɪt wəd də vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ ɹəsivɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. seɪaɪdɑɹ ɹeɪdʒd ɪn ðə naɪt. ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. hu ɛls kəɾ ɪt bi?

There was no hope of sleep now even had she been able. Without lighting any lamps, she washed her face and teeth. Breane and Lini helped her dress, in blue silk slashed with green, with spills of snowy lace at her wrists and beneath her chin. It would do very well for receiving Aes Sedai. Saidar raged in the night. They had to be Aes Sedai. Who else could it be?

wən ʃi dʒɔɪn ðə mɛn ɪn ði æntəɹum, ðeɪ wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɪn dɑɹknəs ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə munlaɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz, ən ði əkeɪʒənəl flæʃ ə paʊɝ-ɹɔt faɪɝ. ivən ə kændəl maɪɾ ətʃɹækt ənwɔntɪɾ ətɛnʃən. læmɡwɪn ən mæstɝ ɡɪl spɹæŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz ɹɪspɛkfəli; tɑlænvɝ stʊd mɔɹ sloʊli, ən ʃi niɾəd noʊ laɪt tə noʊ hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ wɪð ə sʌlən fɹaʊn. fjʊɹiəs ðət ʃi hæd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪm - ʃi wɑz ɪz kwin! - fjʊɹiəs ən bɛɹli eɪbəl tə kip ɪt fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs, ʃi ɔɹɾɝd læmɡwɪn tə bɹɪŋ mɔɹ ə ðə tɔl wʊɾən tʃɛɹz fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊz. ɪn saɪləns, ðeɪ sæɾ ən weɪɾəd. ət list, saɪləns ɑn ðɛɹ pɑɹt. aʊtsaɪd θʌndɝəs kɹæʃɪz ən ɹɔɹz stɪl ɛkoʊd, hɔɹnz kɹaɪɾ ən mɛn ʃaʊɾəd, ən θɹu ɪt ʃi fɛl seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝdʒ ən fɔl ən sɝdʒ əɡɛn.

When she joined the men in the anteroom, they were sitting in darkness except for the moonlight through the windows, and the occasional flash of Power-wrought fire. Even a candle might attract unwanted attention. Lamgwin and Master Gill sprang from their chairs respectfully; Tallanvor stood more slowly, and she needed no light to know he regarded her with a sullen frown. Furious that she had to ignore him - she was his Queen! - furious and barely able to keep it from her voice, she ordered Lamgwin to bring more of the tall wooden chairs further from the windows. In silence, they sat and waited. At least, silence on their part. Outside thunderous crashes and roars still echoed, horns cried and men shouted, and through it she felt saidar surge and fall and surge again.

sloʊli, æftɝ ət list ən aʊɝ, ðə bæɾəl dwɪndəld ən daɪd. vɔɪsəz stɪl ʃaʊɾəd ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl ɔɹɾɝz, wundəd skɹimd, ən səmtaɪmz ðoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒ hɔɹs hɔɹnz ɡeɪv vɔɪs, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ dɪd stil ɹɪŋ ɑn stil. seɪaɪdɑɹ feɪɾəd; ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ wɪmən stɪl hɛld ɪɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛni tʃænəl naʊ. ɔl sim kloʊs tə pisfəl æftɝ ðə klæmɝ ən kəmoʊʃən.

Slowly, after at least an hour, the battle dwindled and died. Voices still shouted incomprehensible orders, wounded screamed, and sometimes those strange hoarse horns gave voice, but no more did steel ring on steel. Saidar faded; she was sure women still held it inside the Fortress, but she did not think any channeled now. All seemed close to peaceful after the clamor and commotion.

tɑlænvɝ stɝd, bʌt ʃi weɪvd ɪm bæk bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹaɪz; fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi θɔɾ i wəd nɑɾ oʊbeɪ. naɪt wikənd, ən sʌnlaɪt kɹɛpt ɪn θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz, ʃaɪnɪŋ ɑn tɑlænvɝz ɡlaʊɝ. ʃi hɛld əɹ hænz stɪl ɪn əɹ læp. peɪʃəns wɑz bʌt wʌn ə ðə vɝtʃuz ðət jʌŋ mæn niɾəd tə lɝn. peɪʃəns stʊd sɛkən oʊnli tə kɝədʒ əz ə noʊbəl vɝtʃu. ðə sʌn ɹoʊz haɪɝ. lini ən bɹin bɪɡæn wɪspɝɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɪn ɪnkɹisɪŋli wɝid toʊnz, ʃuɾɪŋ ɡlænsɪz ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. tɑlænvɝ skaʊld, dɑɹk aɪz smoʊldɝɪŋ, sɪɾɪŋ ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðət dɑɹk blu koʊt ðət fɪɾ ɪm soʊ wɛl. mæstɝ ɡɪl fɪdʒəɾɪd, ɹʌnɪŋ fɝst wʌn hæn ðən ði ʌðɝ əkɹɔs ɪz ɡɹeɪ-fɹɪn hɛd, mɑpɪŋ ɪz pɪŋk tʃiks wɪð ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf. læmɡwɪn slaʊtʃt ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, ðə wʌntaɪm stʃɹit tʌfs hɛvi-lɪɾɪd aɪz meɪkɪŋ ɪm sim hæf əslip, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ i ɡlænst ət bɹin ə smaɪl flɪkɝɾ ɑn ɪz skɑɹd, bɹoʊkən-noʊz feɪs. mɔɹɡeɪs foʊkəst ɑn əɹ bɹiðɪŋ, ɔlmoʊs laɪk ði ɛksɝsaɪzəz ʃi hæd dʌn dʊɹɪŋ əɹ mʌnθs ɪn ðə taʊɝ. peɪʃəns. ɪf sʌmwʌn dɪd nɑt kʌm sun, ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv ʃɑɹp wɝdz tə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ nɑt!

Tallanvor stirred, but she waved him back before he could rise; for a moment she thought he would not obey. Night weakened, and sunlight crept in through the windows, shining on Tallanvor's glower. She held her hands still in her lap. Patience was but one of the virtues that young man needed to learn. Patience stood second only to courage as a noble virtue. The sun rose higher. Lini and Breane began whispering together in increasingly worried tones, shooting glances in her direction. Tallanvor scowled, dark eyes smoldering, sitting rigid in that dark blue coat that fit him so well. Master Gill fidgeted, running first one hand then the other across his gray-fringed head, mopping his pink cheeks with a handkerchief. Lamgwin slouched in his chair, the onetime street tough's heavy-lidded eyes making him seem half asleep, but whenever he glanced at Breane a smile flickered on his scarred, broken-nosed face. Morgase focused on her breathing, almost like the exercises she had done during her months in the Tower. Patience. If someone did not come soon, she was going to have sharp words to say, Aes Sedai or not!

dɪspaɪt hɝsɛlf, ʃi dʒʌmpt əɾ ən əbɹʌpt paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔlweɪ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd tɛl bɹin tə si hu wɑz ðɛɹ, ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən, bæŋɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl. mɔɹɡeɪs stɛɹɾ əɾ u ɛntɝd.

Despite herself, she jumped at an abrupt pounding on the door to the hallway. Before she could tell Breane to see who was there, the door swung open, banging against the wall. Morgase stared at who entered.

ə tɔl, dɑɹk, hʊk-noʊz mæn stɛɹd bæk əɾ əɹ koʊldli, ðə lɔŋ hɪlt ʌv ə sɔɹd ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒ ɑɹmɝ kʌvɝɾ ɪz tʃɛst, oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts lækɝd ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɡoʊld ən blæk, ən i hɛld ə hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp ðət lʊk laɪk ən ɪnsɛks hɛd, blæk ən ɡoʊld ən ɡɹin, wɪð θɹi lɔŋ, θɪn ɡɹin plumz. tu mɔɹ ɑɹmɝd laɪk ɪm keɪm əɾ ɪz hilz wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛlməts, ðoʊ wɪθaʊt plumz; ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ sim peɪntəd ɹæðɝ ðən lækɝd, ən ðeɪ kæɹid kɹɔsboʊz ɹɛɾi. stɪl mɔɹ stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl aʊtsaɪd, wɪð ɡoʊld-ænd-blæk tæsɛl spɪɹz.

A tall, dark, hook-nosed man stared back at her coldly, the long hilt of a sword rising above his shoulder. Strange armor covered his chest, overlapping plates lacquered glistening gold and black, and he held a helmet on his hip that looked like an insect's head, black and gold and green, with three long, thin green plumes. Two more armored like him came at his heels wearing their helmets, though without plumes; their armor seemed painted rather than lacquered, and they carried crossbows ready. Still more stood in the hall outside, with gold-and-black tasseled spears.

tɑlænvɝ ən læmɡwɪn ən ivən staʊt mæstɝ ɡɪl skɹæmbəl tə ðɛɹ fit, pleɪsɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bɪtwin əɹ ən əɹ pəkjuljɝ vɪzəɾɝz. ʃi hæd tə pʊʃ ə weɪ θɹu.

Tallanvor and Lamgwin and even stout Master Gill scrambled to their feet, placing themselves between her and her peculiar visitors. She had to push a way through.

ðə hʊk-noʊz mænz aɪz wɛn stʃɹeɪt tə hɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd dɪmæn ən ɛkspləneɪʃən. "ju ɑɹ mɔɹɡeɪs, kwin ʌv ændɝ?" hɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɑɹʃ, ən i dʒɹɔld ɪz wɝdz soʊ bædli ʃi bɛɹli ʌndɝstʊd.

The hook-nosed man's eyes went straight to her before she could demand an explanation. "You are Morgase, Queen of Andor?" His voice was harsh, and he drawled his words so badly she barely understood.

hi stɛpt ɑn əɹ ɹɪplaɪ. "ju wɪl kʌm wɪð mi. əloʊn," hi æɾəd əz tɑlænvɝ, ən læmɡwɪn, ən mæstɝ ɡɪl, ɔl muv fɔɹwɝd. ðə kɹɔs-boʊmən pɹizɛntəd ðɛɹ wɛpənz; ðə hɛvi kwɔɹəlz lʊk meɪd tə pʌntʃ hoʊlz ɪn ɑɹmɝ; ə mæn wəd hɑɹdli sloʊ wʌn daʊn.

He stepped on her reply. "You will come with me. Alone," he added as Tallanvor, and Lamgwin, and Master Gill, all moved forward. The cross-bowmen presented their weapons; the heavy quarrels looked made to punch holes in armor; a man would hardly slow one down.

"aɪ hæv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən tə maɪ pipəl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɪɹ əntɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn," ʃi sɛɾ ə ɡʊd mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt. hu wɝ ðiz pipəl? ʃi wɑz fəmɪljɝ wɪð ði æksɛns ʌv ɛvɹi neɪʃən, fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ jəl si tə maɪ seɪfti vɛɹi wɛl, kæptən . . . ?"

"I have no objection to my people remaining here until I return," she said a good more calmly than she felt. Who were these people? She was familiar with the accents of every nation, familiar with their armor. "I am sure you will see to my safety very well, Captain . . . ?"

hi dɪd nɑt səplaɪ ə neɪm, oʊnli moʊʃən kɝtli fəɹ əɹ tə fɑloʊ. tə hɝ væst ɹɪlif, tɑlænvɝ meɪd noʊ fʌs dɪspaɪɾ ɪz hɑt ɡeɪz. tə hɝ væst ɪɹɪteɪʃən, mæstɝ ɡɪl ən læmɡwɪn lʊk tə hɪm bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ bæk.

He did not supply a name, only motioned curtly for her to follow. To her vast relief, Tallanvor made no fuss despite his hot gaze. To her vast irritation, Master Gill and Lamgwin looked to him before stepping back.

ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, ðə soʊlʒɝz fɔɹmd ɝaʊn hɝ, ðə hʊk-noʊzd ɔfəsɝ ən ðə tu kɹɔsboʊmən ɪn ðə lɛd. ə ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ɑnɝ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɝsɛlf. ðɪs sun æftɝ ə bæɾəl, wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊn ʌnpɹətɛktɪd wɑz wɝs ðən fulɪʃ; ðəɹ maɪt bi hoʊldaʊts u wəd siz ə hɑstɪdʒ, əɹ kɪl ɛni hu sɔ ðɛm. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi bɪliv ðæt.

In the hallway, the soldiers formed around her, the hook-nosed officer and the two crossbowmen in the lead. A guard of honor, she tried to tell herself. This soon after a battle, wandering around unprotected was worse than foolish; there might be holdouts who would seize a hostage, or kill any who saw them. She wished she believed that.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd kwɛstʃənɪŋ ði ɔfəsɝ, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ spoʊk ə wɝd, nɛvɝ slækən ɪz stʃɹaɪɾ əɹ tɝn ɪz hɛd, ən ʃi stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ. nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət hɝ; ðeɪ wɝ hɑɹd-aɪd mɛn ə ðə kaɪnd ʃi nu fɹəm əɹ oʊn kwinz ɡɑɹdz, mɛn u hæd sin faɪɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ, mɔɹ ðən wʌns. bʌɾ u wɝ ðeɪ? ðɛɹ buts stʃɹʌk ðə flɔɹ-stoʊnz əz wʌn ɪn ən ɑmənəs dʒɹʌmbiɾ ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ ðə stɑɹk fɔɹtʃɹəs kɔɹɪɾɝz. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl kʌlɝ, nʌθɪŋ fəɹ bjuɾi ɪksɛp skæɾɝd tæpəstʃɹiz ʃoʊɪŋ waɪtkloʊks ɪn blʌɾi bæɾəl.

She tried questioning the officer, but he never spoke a word, never slackened his stride or turned his head, and she stopped trying. None of the soldiers so much as glanced at her; they were hard-eyed men of the kind she knew from her own Queen's Guards, men who had seen fighting before, more than once. But who were they? Their boots struck the floor-stones as one in an ominous drumbeat emphasized by the stark Fortress corridors. There was little color, nothing for beauty except scattered tapestries showing Whitecloaks in bloody battle.

ʃi ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ təwɔɹd ðə lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝz kɔɹɾɝz, ən ə kwizinəs sɛɾəld ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə hɝ stʌmək. ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ɔlmoʊs plɛzənli əkʌstəm tə ðə weɪ waɪl peɪdʒɹən naɪl lɪvd; ʃi hæd kʌm tə dʒɹɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə fju deɪz sɪns i daɪd - bʌɾ əz ðeɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ, ʃi stɑɹɾəd ət ðə saɪɾ ə səm tu dʌzən ɑɹtʃɝz mɑɹtʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ɔfəsɝ, mɛn ɪn bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz ən bɔɪld lɛðɝ bɹɛstpleɪts peɪntəɾ ɪn hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps ə blu ən blæk. itʃ mæn wɔɹ ə kɑnɪkəl stil kæp, wɪð ə veɪl ʌv ɡɹeɪ stil meɪl kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz feɪs tə ði aɪz; hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ði ɛnz ə mʌstæʃɪz dæŋɡəl bɪloʊ ðə veɪlz. ði ɑɹtʃɝz' ɔfəsɝ baʊd tə ðə wʌn liɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɑɹd, hu mɪɹli ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn ɪn ɹɪplaɪ.

She realized they were taking her toward the Lord Captain Commander's quarters, and a queasiness settled in the pit of her stomach. She had grown almost pleasantly accustomed to the way while Pedron Niall lived; she had come to dread it in the few days since he died - but as they rounded a corner, she started at the sight of some two dozen archers marching behind their own officer, men in baggy trousers and boiled leather breastplates painted in horizontal stripes of blue and black. Each man wore a conical steel cap, with a veil of gray steel mail covering his face to the eyes; here and there the ends of mustaches dangled below the veils. The archers' officer bowed to the one leading her guard, who merely raised his hand in reply.

tæɹɑbənɝz. ʃi hæd nɑt sin ə tæɹɑbənɝ soʊlʒɝ ɪn ə ɡʊd mɛni jɪɹz, bʌt ðoʊz mɛn wɝ tæɹɑbənɝz ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðoʊz stʃɹaɪps, əɹ ʃi wəɾ iɾ əɹ slɪpɝz. jɛt ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns. tæɹɑbən wɑz keɪɑs kʌm tə laɪf, ə hʌnʒɹəd-saɪdəd sɪvəl wɔɹ bɪtwin pɹitɛndɝz tə ðə θɹoʊn ən dʒɹæɡən-swɔɹn. tæɹɑbən kəd nɛvɝ əv lɔntʃt ðɪs ətæk ɑn æmədɔɹ ɪtsɛlf. ənlɛs, ɪnkɹɛɾəbli, wʌn kleɪmən hæd wʌn aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɛst, ən oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, ænd. . . . ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl, ən ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn ðiz stʃɹeɪnʒli ɑɹmɝd soʊlʒɝz, əɹ ðət wɪŋ bist, ɔɹ. . . . ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd sin stʃɹeɪnʒnəs. ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd noʊn kwizinəs. ðən ʃi ən əɹ ɡɑɹd tɝn ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ ən ɪnkaʊntɝd tu wɪmən.

Taraboners. She had not seen a Taraboner soldier in a good many years, but those men were Taraboners in spite of those stripes, or she would eat her slippers. Yet that made no sense. Tarabon was chaos come to life, a hundred-sided civil war between pretenders to the throne and Dragon-sworn. Tarabon could never have launched this attack on Amador itself. Unless, incredibly, one claimant had won out over the rest, and over the Dragonsworn, and. . . . It was impossible, and it did not explain these strangely armored soldiers, or that winged beast, or. . . . She thought she had seen strangeness. She thought she had known queasiness. Then she and her guard turned another corner and encountered two women.

wʌn wɑz slɛndɝ, ʃɔɹɾ əz ɛni kɛɹhinɪn ən dɑɹkɝ ðən ɛni tɛɹən, ɪn ə blu dʒɹɛs ðət stɑpt wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ æŋkəlz; sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ fɔɹkt əkɹɔs ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn əɹ bɹɛst ən ðə saɪdz ə hɝ waɪd, dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, ɪn dʒɹæb dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ, stʊd tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, wɪð ɡoʊldən hɛɹ tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ðət hæd bɪn bɹʌʃt tɪl ɪt ɡlɪsən ən fɹaɪɾənd ɡɹin aɪz. ə sɪlvɝ liʃ kənɛktəɾ ə sɪlvɝ bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ wʊmənz ɹɪs tə ə nɛkləs wɔɹn baɪ ðə tɔlɝ.

One was slender, short as any Cairhienin and darker than any Tairen, in a blue dress that stopped well short of her ankles; silver lightning forked across red panels on her breast and the sides of her wide, divided skirts.
