The other woman, in drab dark gray, stood taller than most men, with golden hair to her shoulders that had been brushed till it glistened and frightened green eyes. A silver leash connected a silver bracelet on the shorter woman's wrist to a necklace worn by the taller.

ðeɪ stʊɾ əsaɪd fəɹ mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɡɑɹd, ən wən ðə hʊk-noʊzd ɔfəsɝ mɝmɝd "dɝsʌldəm" - mɔɹɡeɪs θɔt ðət wɑz ɪt; hɪz slɝɾ æksɛn meɪɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ dɪfəkəlt - wən i mɝmɝɾ ɪn toʊnz nɪɹli bʌt nɑt kwaɪt tə ən ikwəl, ðə dɑɹk wʊmən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, twɪtʃt ət ðə liʃ, ən ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən sæŋk tə ðə flɔɹ, foʊldɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð əɹ hɛɾ ɑn əɹ niz ən əɹ pɑmz flæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹstoʊnz. əz mɔɹɡeɪs ən əɹ ɡɑɹdz pæs baɪ, ðə dɑɹk wʊmən bɛn tə pæt ði ʌðɝ fɑnli ɑn ðə hɛd, əz ʃi maɪɾ ə dɔɡ, ən wɝs, ðə nilɪŋ wʊmən lʊkt ʌp wɪð plɛʒɝ ən ɡɹæɾətud.

They stood aside for Morgase's guard, and when the hook-nosed officer murmured "Der'sul'dam" - Morgase thought that was it; his slurred accent made understanding difficult - when he murmured in tones nearly but not quite to an equal, the dark woman bowed her head slightly, twitched at the leash, and the golden-haired woman sank to the floor, folding herself with her head on her knees and her palms flat on the floorstones. As Morgase and her guards passed by, the dark woman bent to pat the other fondly on the head, as she might a dog, and worse, the kneeling woman looked up with pleasure and gratitude.

mɔɹɡeɪs meɪd ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɛfɝt tə kip wɔkɪŋ, tə kip əɹ niz fɹəm foʊldɪŋ, tə kip əɹ stʌmək fɹəm ɛmptiɪŋ ɪtsɛlf. ðə ʃɪɹ sɝvɪləɾi wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf, bʌt ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ðə wʊmən biɪŋ pæɾəd ɑn ðə hɛd kəd tʃænəl. ɪmpɑsəbəl! ʃi wɔkt ɪn ə deɪz, wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðɪs kəd bi ə dʒɹim, ə naɪtmɛɹ. pɹeɪɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz. ʃi hæɾ ə veɪɡ əwɛɹnəs ə stɑpɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz, ðiz ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-blæk ɑɹmɝ, ðɛn. . . . peɪdʒɹən naɪlz ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝ - vɑldəz naʊ, əɹ ɹæðɝ huɛvɝ hæd teɪkən ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs - wɑz tʃeɪnʒd. ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɹɪmeɪnd, sɛɾ ɪn ðə flɔɹ, bʌɾ ɔl naɪlz kæptʃɝd bænɝz, wɪtʃ vɑldə hæd kɛpt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hɪz, wɝ ɡɔn, ən soʊ wɝ ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə pleɪnli kɑɹv haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ naɪl ən ðən vɑldə hæd juzd, flæŋk naʊ baɪ tu tɔl, lʊɹɪdli peɪntəd skɹinz. wʌn ʃoʊɾ ə waɪt-kɹɛstəd blæk bɝɾ ə pɹeɪ wɪð ə kɹuəl bik, ɪts waɪt-tɪpt wɪŋz spɹɛd waɪd, ði ʌðɝ ə blæk-spɑɾəd jɛloʊ kæt wɪð wʌn pɔ ɑn ə dɛd, dɪɝlaɪk kɹitʃɝ hæf ɪts saɪz, wɪð lɔŋ, stʃɹeɪt hɔɹnz ən waɪt stʃɹaɪps.

Morgase made the necessary effort to keep walking, to keep her knees from folding, to keep her stomach from emptying itself. The sheer servility was bad enough, but she was certain the woman being patted on the head could channel. Impossible! She walked in a daze, wondering whether this could be a dream, a nightmare. Praying that it was. She had a vague awareness of stopping for more soldiers, these in red-and-black armor, then. . . . Pedron Niall's audience chamber - Valda's now, or rather whoever had taken the fortress - was changed. The great golden sunburst remained, set in the floor, but all Niall's captured banners, which Valda had kept as if they were his, were gone, and so were the furnishings, except for the plainly carved high-backed chair Niall and then Valda had used, flanked now by two tall, luridly painted screens. One showed a white-crested black bird of prey with a cruel beak, its white-tipped wings spread wide, the other a black-spotted yellow cat with one paw on a dead, deerlike creature half its size, with long, straight horns and white stripes.

ðəɹ wɝ ə nʌmbɝ ə pipəl ɪn ðə ɹum, bʌt ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi hæd taɪm tə noʊɾəs bɪfɔɹ ə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən ɪn blu ɹoʊbz stɛp fɔɹwɝd, wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd ʃeɪvd ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɛɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ bɹaʊn bɹeɪd ðət hʌŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ. hɝ blu aɪz, fʊl ə kəntɛmpt, cʊɾə dʌn fəɹ ði iɡəlz əɹ ðə kæts. "ju ɑɹ ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ, hu lidz ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ, ən səkɹz ðə ɹɪtɝn," ʃi ɪntoʊn ɪn ðət seɪm slɝɪŋ æksɛnt.

There were a number of people in the room, but that was all she had time to notice before a sharp-faced woman in blue robes stepped forward, one side of her head shaved and the remaining hair in a long brown braid that hung in front of her right shoulder. Her blue eyes, full of contempt, could have done for the eagle's or the cat's. "You are in the presence of the High Lady Suroth, who leads Those Who Come Before, and succors The Return," she intoned in that same slurring accent.

wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, ðə hʊk-noʊzd ɔfəsɝ siz ðə bæk ə mɔɹɡeɪsəz nɛk ən bɔɹ əɹ daʊn pɹɑstʃɹeɪt bɪsaɪd hɪm. stʌnd, nɑt lis kəz ðə bɹɛθ wɑz nɑkt aʊɾ ə hɝ, ʃi sɔ hɪm kɪs ðə flɔɹ.

Without warning, the hook-nosed officer seized the back of Morgase's neck and bore her down prostrate beside him. Stunned, not least because the breath was knocked out of her, she saw him kiss the floor.

"ɹilis hɝ, ɛlbɑɹ," ənʌðɝ wʊmən dʒɹɔld æŋɡɹəli. "ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ ɪz nɑt tə bi tʃɹiɾəd soʊ."

"Release her, Elbar," another woman drawled angrily. "The Queen of Andor is not to be treated so."

ðə mæn, ɛlbɑɹ, ɹoʊz əz fɑɹ əz ɪz niz, hɛd bɛnt. "aɪ əbeɪs maɪsɛlf, haɪ leɪɾi. aɪ bɛɡ fɝɡɪvnəs." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz əz koʊld ən flæɾ əz ðəɾ æksɛn əlaʊd.

The man, Elbar, rose as far as his knees, head bent. "I abase myself, High Lady. I beg forgiveness." His voice was as cold and flat as that accent allowed.

"aɪ hæv smɔl fɝɡɪvnəs fəɹ ðɪs, ɛlbɑɹ." mɔɹɡeɪs lʊkt ʌp. sjuɹɔθ tʊk əɹ əbæk. ðə saɪdz ə hɝ hɛd wɝ ʃeɪvd, livɪŋ ə ɡlɔsi blæk kɹɛst əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛɾ ən ə meɪn ðət floʊd daʊn əɹ bæk. "pɝhæps wən jə ɑɹ pʌnɪʃt. ɹipɔɹt jɝsɛlf naʊ. liv mi! ɡoʊ!" ə swipɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ flæʃt fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ət list ən ɪntʃ lɔŋ, ðə fɝs tu ɑn itʃ hæn ə ɡlɪsnɪŋ blu.

"I have small forgiveness for this, Elbar." Morgase looked up. Suroth took her aback. The sides of her head were shaved, leaving a glossy black crest across the top of her head and a mane that flowed down her back. "Perhaps when you are punished. Report yourself now. Leave me! Go!" A sweeping gesture flashed fingernails at least an inch long, the first two on each hand a glistening blue.

ɛlbɑɹ baʊɾ ɑn ɪz niz, ðən ɹoʊz smuðli, bækɪŋ əweɪ θɹu ðə dɔɹ. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm mɔɹɡeɪs ɹilaɪz nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ soʊlʒɝz hæd fɑloʊɾ əm ɪn. ʃi ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, əz wɛl. hi ɡeɪv əɹ wʌn faɪnəl ɡlæns bɪfɔɹ i vænɪʃt, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə flɪkɝɪŋ ɹɪzɛnmənt fəɹ ðə wʌn u hæd kɑzd ɪz pʌnɪʃmənt, hi . . . kənsɪɾɝd. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ pʌnɪʃmənt; ði ɪntaɪɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd bɪfɔɹhænd.

Elbar bowed on his knees, then rose smoothly, backing away through the door. For the first time Morgase realized none of the other soldiers had followed them in. She realized something else, as well. He gave her one final glance before he vanished, and instead of flickering resentment for the one who had caused his punishment, he . . . considered. There would be no punishment; the entire exchange had been arranged beforehand.

sjuɹɔθ swɛp təwɔɹd mɔɹɡeɪs, kɛɹfəli hoʊldɪŋ əɹ peɪl blu ɹoʊb tə kip əɹ skɝts ɪkspoʊzd, snoʊ-waɪt, wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ə taɪni plits. ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd vaɪnz ən lʌʃ ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ flaʊɝz spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹoʊb. fəɹ ɔl əɹ swipɪŋ, mɔɹɡeɪs noʊɾəst ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ əɹ əntɪl ʃi hæd ɹiɡeɪn əɹ fiɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn.

Suroth swept toward Morgase, carefully holding her pale blue robe to keep her skirts exposed, snow-white, with hundreds of tiny pleats. Embroidered vines and lush red and yellow flowers spread across the robe. For all her sweeping, Morgase noticed the woman did not reach her until she had regained her feet on her own.

"ju ɑɹ ənhɑɹmd?" sjuɹɔθ æskt. "ɪf jə ɑɹ hɑɹmd, əl dʌbəl ɪz pʌnɪʃmənt."

"You are unharmed?" Suroth asked. "If you are harmed, I will double his punishment."

mɔɹɡeɪs bɹʌʃt əɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs soʊ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə lʊk ət ðə fɔls smaɪl ðət nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ðə wʊmənz aɪz. ʃi tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə lʊk ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. fɔɹ mɛn ən fɔɹ wɪmən nɛlt əɡɛnst wʌn wɔl, ɔl jʌŋ ən mɔɹ ðən ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ, ɔl wɛɹɪŋ. . . . ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ aɪz əweɪ. ðoʊz lɔŋ waɪt ɹoʊbz wɝ vɛɹi nɪɹli tʃɹænspɛɹənt! ət ðə fɑɹ saɪdz ə ðə skɹinz tu mɔɹ pɛɹz ʌv wɪmən nɛlt, wʌn ʌv itʃ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs, wʌn ɪn ðə blu ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð laɪtnɪŋ, baʊn baɪ ðə sɪlvɝi liʃ fɹəm ɹɪs tə nɛk. mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə seɪ fəɹ ʃʊɹ, bʌt ʃi hæd ðə sɪk-meɪkɪŋ sɝɾənti ðət ðə ɡɹeɪ-klæd wɪmən kəd tʃænəl. "aɪ æm kwaɪɾ ɔl ɹaɪt, θæŋk - " ə hjudʒ ɹɛɾɪʃ bɹaʊn ʃeɪp leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ðə flɔɹ - ə hip ə tæn kɔfskɪnz, pɝhæps. ðən ɪt hivd. "wʌɾ ɪz ðæt?" ʃi mænədʒ nɑt tə ɡeɪp, bʌt ðə kwɛstʃən pɑp fɹəm əɹ tʌŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp ɪt.

Morgase brushed at her dress so she would not have to look at the false smile that never touched the woman's eyes. She took the opportunity to look around the room. Four men and four women knelt against one wall, all young and more than good-looking, all wearing. . . . She jerked her eyes away. Those long white robes were very nearly transparent! At the far sides of the screens two more pairs of women knelt, one of each in the gray dress, one in the blue embroidered with lightning, bound by the silvery leash from wrist to neck. Morgase was not close enough to say for sure, but she had the sick-making certainty that the gray-clad women could channel. "I am quite all right, thank - " A huge reddish brown shape lay sprawled on the floor - a heap of tanned cowskins, perhaps. Then it heaved. "What is that?" She managed not to gape, but the question popped from her tongue before she could stop it.

"ju ædmaɪɹ maɪ loʊpɝ?" sjuɹɔθ swɛpt əweɪ ə ɡʊd dil kwɪkɝ ðən ʃi hæd kʌm. ði ɪnɔɹməs ʃeɪp ɹeɪzd ə ɡɹeɪt ɹaʊn hɛd fəɹ əɹ tə stʃɹoʊk ɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə tʃɪn wɪð ə nʌkəl. ðə kɹitʃɝ pʊt mɔɹɡeɪs ɪn maɪn ʌv ə bɛɹ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz izəli hæf əɡɛn əz bɪɡ əz ðə lɑɹdʒəs bɛɹ ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd tɛl ʌv, ən hɛɹləs tə but, wɪð noʊ mʌzəl tə spik ʌv ən hɛvi ɹɪdʒəz sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪts aɪz. "ælmændɑɹəɡəl wɑz ɡɪvən tə mi əz ə pʌp, fəɹ maɪ fɝs tʃɹu-neɪm deɪ; hi fɔɪl ðə fɝst ətɛmp tə kɪl mi ðət seɪm jɪɹ, wən i wɑz oʊnli ə kɔɹɾɝ ɡɹoʊn." ðəɹ wɑz ɹil əfɛkʃən ɪn ðə wʊmənz vɔɪs. ðə . . . loʊpɝz . . . lɪps pil bæk tə ɹɪvil θɪk pɔɪntəd tiθ əz ʃi stʃɹoʊkt; ɪts fɹpɔz flɛkst, klɔz ʃiðɪŋ ən ənʃiðɪŋ fɹəm sɪks lɔŋ toʊz ɑn itʃ. ən ɪt bɪɡæn tə pɝ, ə bæs ɹʌmbəl fɪt fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd kæts.

"You admire my lopar?" Suroth swept away a good deal quicker than she had come. The enormous shape raised a great round head for her to stroke it under the chin with a knuckle. The creature put Morgase in mind of a bear, though it was easily half again as big as the largest bear she had ever heard tell of, and hairless to boot, with no muzzle to speak of and heavy ridges surrounding its eyes. "Almandaragal was given to me as a pup, for my first true-name day; he foiled the first attempt to kill me that same year, when he was only a quarter grown." There was real affection in the woman's voice. The . . . lopar's . . . lips peeled back to reveal thick pointed teeth as she stroked; its forepaws flexed, claws sheathing and unsheathing from six long toes on each. And it began to purr, a bass rumble fit for a hundred cats.

"ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl," mɔɹɡeɪs sɛd feɪnli. tʃɹu-neɪm deɪ? haʊ mɛni ətɛmps hæd ðəɹ bɪn tə kɪl ðɪs wʊmən ðət ʃi kəd spik ʌv "ðə fɝst" soʊ kæʒəwəli?

"Remarkable," Morgase said faintly. True-name day? How many attempts had there been to kill this woman that she could speak of "the first" so casually?

ðə loʊpɝ waɪn bɹifli wən sjuɹɔθ lɛft ɪt, bʌt kwɪkli sɛɾəld wɪð ɪts hɛɾ ɑn ɪts pɔz. dɪskənsɝɾɪŋli, ɪts aɪz dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ hɝ, bʌt sɛɾəld meɪnli ɑn mɔɹɡeɪs, naʊ ən ðən flɪkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ əɹ ðə nɛɹoʊ, æɹoʊ-slɪt wɪndoʊz.

The lopar whined briefly when Suroth left it, but quickly settled with its head on its paws. Disconcertingly, its eyes did not follow her, but settled mainly on Morgase, now and then flicking toward the door or the narrow, arrow-slit windows.

"ʌv kɔɹs, haʊɛvɝ lɔɪəl ə loʊpɝ, ɪt kænɑt mætʃ deɪmeɪn." noʊ əfɛkʃən tʌtʃt sjuɹɔθs vɔɪs naʊ. "pʊɹə ən dʒɪnʒɪn kəd sleɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd əsæsənz bɪfɔɹ ælmændɑɹəɡəl blɪŋkt ɪz aɪ." ət ðə mɛnʃən ʌv itʃ neɪm, wʌn ə ðə blu-klæd wɪmən twɪtʃt əɹ sɪlvɝi liʃ, ən ðə wʊmən ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn dʌbəl hɝsɛlf əz ðə wʌn ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ hæd. "wi hæv mɛni mɔɹ deɪmeɪn sɪns ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðən bɪfɔɹ. ðɪs ɪz ə ɹɪtʃ hʌntɪŋ ɡɹaʊn fəɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. pʊɹə," ʃi æɾəd kæʒəwəli, "wɑz wʌns ə . . . wʊmən ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"Of course, however loyal a lopar, it cannot match damane." No affection touched Suroth's voice now. "Pura and Jinjin could slay a hundred assassins before Almandaragal blinked his eye." At the mention of each name, one of the blue-clad women twitched her silvery leash, and the woman at the other end doubled herself as the one in the corridor had. "We have many more damane since returning than before. This is a rich hunting ground for marath'damane. Pura," she added casually, "was once a . . . woman of the White Tower."

mɔɹɡeɪsəz niz wɑbəld. ɛɛs sədaɪ? ʃi stʌɾid ðə bɛn bæk ə ðə wʊmən kɔl pʊɹə, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bɪliv. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd bi meɪd tə kɹɪnʒ laɪk ðæt. bʌɾ ɛni wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl, nɑt dʒʌst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə teɪk ðət liʃ ən stʃɹæŋɡəl əɹ tɔɹmɛntɝ. ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə. noʊ, ðɪs pʊɹə kəd nɑt bi. mɔɹɡeɪs wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi dɛɹɾ æsk fəɹ ə tʃɛɹ. "ðæɾ ɪz vɛɹi . . . ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ." ət list əɹ vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi. "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk jə æsk mi hɪɹ tə spik ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn æskt. sjuɹɔθ stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, nɑɾ ə mʌsəl muvɪŋ ɪksɛp ðət ðə lɔŋ-neɪl fɪŋɡɝz ə hɝ lɛf hæn twɪtʃt.

Morgase's knees wobbled. Aes Sedai? She studied the bent back of the woman called Pura, refusing to believe. No Aes Sedai could be made to cringe like that. But any woman who could channel, not just an Aes Sedai, should be able to take that leash and strangle her tormentor. Anyone at all should be able to. No, this Pura could not be. Morgase wondered if she dared ask for a chair. "That is very . . . interesting." At least her voice was steady. "But I do not think you asked me here to speak of Aes Sedai." Of course, she had not been asked. Suroth stared at her, not a muscle moving except that the long-nailed fingers of her left hand twitched.

"θɛɹə!" ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən wɪð hæf əɹ hɛd ʃeɪv bɑɹk sʌɾənli. "kæf fəɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi ən əɹ ɡɛst!"

"Thera!" the sharp-faced woman with half her head shaved barked suddenly. "Kaf for the High Lady and her guest!"

wʌn ə ðə wɪmən ɪn daɪəfənəs ɹoʊbz, ði ɛldəs bʌt stɪl jʌŋ, lɛpt ɡɹeɪsfəli tə hɝ fit. hɝ ɹoʊzbʌd maʊθ hæɾ ə pɛtʃələn lʊk tə ɪt, bʌt ʃi dɑɹɾɪd bɪhaɪn ðə tɔl skɹin peɪntəd wɪð ði iɡəl, ən ɪn moʊməns ɹiəpɪɹd bɛɹɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ wɪð tu smɔl waɪt kʌps. nilɪŋ sɪnjuəsli bɪfɔɹ sjuɹɔθ, ʃi baʊɾ əɹ dɑɹk hɛɾ əz ʃi ɹeɪz ðə tʃɹeɪ, soʊ hɝ ɔfɝɪŋ stʊd haɪɝ ðən ʃi. mɔɹɡeɪs ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ɛni sɝvən ɪn ændɝ æsk tə də ðət - əɹ wɛɹ ðət ɹoʊb! - wʊɾə stɔɹmd ɔf ɪn ə dʌdʒən.

One of the women in diaphanous robes, the eldest but still young, leaped gracefully to her feet. Her rosebud mouth had a petulant look to it, but she darted behind the tall screen painted with the eagle, and in moments reappeared bearing a silver tray with two small white cups. Kneeling sinuously before Suroth, she bowed her dark head as she raised the tray, so her offering stood higher than she. Morgase shook her head; any servant in Andor asked to do that - or wear that robe! - would have stormed off in a dudgeon.

"hu ɑɹ ju? wɛɹ dʒju kʌm fɹʌm?"

"Who are you? Where do you come from?"

sjuɹɔθ ɹeɪzd wʌn ə ðə kʌps ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps, ɪnheɪlɪŋ ðə stim ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪt. hɝ nɑd wɑz ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ pɝmɪʃən fəɹ mɔɹɡeɪsəz laɪkɪŋ, bʌt ʃi tʊk ə kʌp ɛniweɪ. wʌn sɪp, ən ʃi stɛɹɾ ɪndə hɝ dʒɹɪŋk ɪn əmeɪzmənt. blækɝ ðən ɛni ti, ðə lɪkwəd wɑz ɔlsoʊ mɔɹ bɪɾɝ. noʊ əmaʊn ə hʌni wəd meɪk ɪt dʒɹɪŋkəbəl. sjuɹɔθ pʊɾ əɹ oʊn kʌp tə hɝ lɪps ən saɪd wɪð ɛndʒɔɪmənt.

Suroth raised one of the cups on her fingertips, inhaling the steam rising from it. Her nod was entirely too much permission for Morgase's liking, but she took a cup anyway. One sip, and she stared into her drink in amazement. Blacker than any tea, the liquid was also more bitter. No amount of honey would make it drinkable. Suroth put her own cup to her lips and sighed with enjoyment.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɪŋz wi mʌst spik ʌv, mɔɹɡeɪs, jɛɾ əl bi bɹif ət ðɪs fɝs tɔk. wi sintʃæn ɹɪtɝn tə ɹikleɪm wʌt wɑz stoʊlən fɹəm ði ɛɹz ə ðə haɪ kɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ tænɹəl." plɛʒɝ oʊvɝ ðə kæf bɪkeɪm ə dɪfɹən plɛʒɝ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, boʊθ ɛkspɛkteɪʃən ən sɝɾənti, ən ʃi wɑtʃt mɔɹɡeɪsəz feɪs kloʊsli. mɔɹɡeɪs kəd nɑt teɪk əɹ aɪz əweɪ. "wʌt wɑz aʊɝz, wɪl bi aʊɝz əɡɛn. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪɾ ɔlweɪz əz bɪn; ə θif ɡeɪnz noʊ oʊnɝʃɪp. aɪ hæv bɪɡʌn ðə ɹəkʌvɝi ɪn tæɹɑbən. mɛni noʊbəlz ə ðət læn əv ɔlɹɛɾi swɔɹn tə oʊbeɪ, əweɪɾ ən sɝv; ɪɾəl nɑt bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɔl hæv. ðɛɹ kɪŋ - aɪ kænɑt ɹikɔl ɪz neɪm - daɪɾ əpoʊzɪŋ mi. hæɾ i lɪvd, ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn ən nɑɾ ivən ə ðə blʌd, hi wʊɾə bɪn ɪmpeɪld. hɪz fæmli kəd nɑt bi faʊn tə bi meɪd pɹɑpɝɾi, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ə nu kɪŋ ən ə nu pɑnɑɹtʃ u hæv swɔɹn ðɛɹ fiəlti tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ən ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn. ðə bændəts wɪl bi ɪɹæɾəkeɪtɪd; noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɪl ðəɹ bi stʃɹaɪf əɹ hʌŋɡɝ ɪn tæɹɑbən, bʌt ðə pipəl wɪl ʃɛltɝ bɪniθ ðə wɪŋz ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. naʊ ðəfɝs bɪɡɪn ɪn ðɪs ɑmɑdɪʃiə. sun ɔl wɪl nil tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ðə dɝɛk dɪsɛndən ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔk-wɪŋ."

"There are many things we must speak of, Morgase, yet I will be brief at this first talk. We Seanchan return to reclaim what was stolen from the heirs of the High King, Artur Paendrag Tanreall." Pleasure over the kaf became a different pleasure in her voice, both expectation and certainty, and she watched Morgase's face closely. Morgase could not take her eyes away. "What was ours, will be ours again. In truth, it always has been; a thief gains no ownership. I have begun the recovery in Tarabon. Many nobles of that land have already sworn to obey, await and serve; it will not be long before all have. Their king - I cannot recall his name - died opposing me. Had he lived, in rebellion against the Crystal Throne and not even of the Blood, he would have been impaled. His family could not be found to be made property, but there is a new King and a new Panarch who have sworn their fealty to the Empress, may she live forever, and the Crystal Throne. The bandits will be eradicated; no longer will there be strife or hunger in Tarabon, but the people will shelter beneath the wings of the Empress. Now I begin in this Amadicia. Soon all will kneel to the Empress, may she live forever, the direct descendant of the great Artur Hawk-wing."

ɪf ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən hæd nɑt ɡɔn wɪð ðə tʃɹeɪ, mɔɹɡeɪs wʊɾə pʊɾ əɹ kʌp bæk. noʊ tʃɹɛmɝ dɪstɝb ðə dɑɹk sɝfəs ə ðə kæf, bʌt mʌtʃ ʌv wʌt ðə wʊmən spaʊɾəd wɑz minɪŋləs tə hɝ. ɛmpɹɛs? ʃɔn-tʃæn? ðəɹ hæd bɪn waɪld ɹumɝz ə jɪɹ əɹ mɔɹ əɡoʊ əbaʊɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔk-wɪŋz ɑɹmiz kʌm bæk fɹəm əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə moʊs kɹɛdʒjələs kəɾ əv bɪlivd, ən ʃi daʊɾɪd ðət ðə wɝst ɡɑsɪpmɑŋɡɝ ɪn ðə mɑɹkəts stɪl toʊl ðə teɪl. kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn tʃɹuθ? ɪn ɛni keɪs, wʌt ʃi dɪɾ ʌndɝstænd wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf.

If the serving woman had not gone with the tray, Morgase would have put her cup back. No tremor disturbed the dark surface of the kaf, but much of what the woman spouted was meaningless to her. Empress? Sean-chan? There had been wild rumors a year or more ago about Artur Hawk-wing's armies come back from across the Aryth Ocean, but only the most credulous could have believed, and she doubted that the worst gossipmonger in the markets still told the tale. Could it have been truth? In any case, what she did understand was more than enough.

"ɔl ɑnɝ ðə neɪm ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, sjuɹɔθ. . . ." ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, səbsaɪɾɪŋ ət ðə muv ʌv ə blu-neɪl fɪŋɡɝ baɪ ðə haɪ leɪɾi. ". . . bʌɾ ɪz taɪm ɪz lɔŋ pæst. ɛvɹi neɪʃən hɪɹ əz ən eɪntʃən lɪniədʒ. noʊ lænd wɪl sɝɛndɝ tə jə əɹ jəɹ ɛmpɹɛs. ɪf juv teɪkən səm pɑɹɾ ə tæɹɑbən . . ." sjuɹɔθs ɪndʒɹɔn bɹɛθ hɪst, ən əɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd, ". . . ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɪts ə tʃɹʌbəld lænd, dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf. ɑmɑdɪʃiə wɪl nɑt fɔl izəli, ən mɛni neɪʃənz wɪl ɹaɪd tə hɝ eɪd wən ðeɪ lɝn ə ju." kəɾ ɪt bi tʃɹu? "haʊɛvɝ mɛni jə ɑɹ, jəl faɪnd noʊ izi ɡeɪm fəɹ jəɹ spɪt. wɪv feɪst ɡɹeɪt θɹɛts bɪfɔɹ, ən oʊvɝkʌm ðɛm. aɪ ædvaɪz jə tə meɪk pis bɪfɔɹ jə ɑɹ kɹʌʃt." mɔɹɡeɪs ɹɪmɛmbɝd seɪaɪdɑɹ ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt, ən əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə - deɪmeɪn, hæd ʃi kɔl ðɛm? baɪ stʃɹɔŋ ɛfɝt, ʃi mænədʒ nɑt tə wɛɾ əɹ lɪps.

"All honor the name of Artur Hawkwing, Suroth. . . ." The sharp-faced woman opened her mouth angrily, subsiding at the move of a blue-nailed finger by the High Lady. ". . . but his time is long past. Every nation here has an ancient lineage. No land will surrender to you or your Empress. If you have taken some part of Tarabon . . ." Suroth's indrawn breath hissed, and her eyes glittered, ". . . remember that it is a troubled land, divided against itself. Amadicia will not fall easily, and many nations will ride to her aid when they learn of you." Could it be true? "However many you are, you will find no easy game for your spit. We have faced great threats before, and overcome them. I advise you to make peace before you are crushed." Morgase remembered saidar raging in the night, and avoided looking at the - damane, had she called them? By strong effort, she managed not to wet her lips.

sjuɹɔθ smaɪl ðət mæsks smaɪl əɡɛn, aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk pɑlɪʃt stoʊnz. "ɔl mʌs meɪk tʃɔɪsəz. səm wɪl tʃuz tə oʊbeɪ, əweɪɾ ən sɝv, ən wɪl ɹul ðɛɹ lænz ɪn ðə neɪm ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ."

Suroth smiled that mask's smile again, eyes shining like polished stones. "All must make choices. Some will choose to obey, await and serve, and will rule their lands in the name of the Empress, may she live forever."

ʃi tʊk ə hæn fɹəm əɹ kʌp tə dʒɛstʃɝ, ə slaɪt muvmən ə lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz, ən ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən bɑɹkt, "θɛɹə! poʊzəz ə ðə swɑn!"

She took a hand from her cup to gesture, a slight movement of long fingernails, and the sharp-faced woman barked, "Thera! Poses of the Swan!"

fəɹ səm ɹizən, sjuɹɔθs maʊθ taɪɾənd. "nɑt ðə swɑn, ælwɪn, jə blaɪn ful!" ʃi hɪst, hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ðoʊ hɝ æksɛn meɪɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ dɪfəkəlt. ðə fɹoʊzən smaɪl ɹɪtɝn ɪn ən ɪnstənt.

For some reason, Suroth's mouth tightened. "Not the Swan, Alwhin, you blind fool!" she hissed, half under her breath, though her accent made understanding difficult. The frozen smile returned in an instant.

ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən ɹoʊz fɹəm əɹ pleɪs ət ðə wɔl əɡɛn, ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt tə ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flɔɹ ɪn ən ɑd weɪ, ɑn tɪptoʊ, wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz swɛp bæk. sloʊli, ətɑp ðə flɛɹɪŋ ɡoʊldən sʌn, sɪmbəl ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, ʃi bɪɡæn ə sɔɹɾ ə staɪlaɪz dæns. hɝ ɑɹmz ənfoʊldəd tə ðə saɪdz laɪk wɪŋz, ðən foʊldəd bæk. twɪstɪŋ, ʃi slɪɾ əɹ lɛft fʊɾ aʊt, loʊɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf oʊvɝ ðə bɛndɪŋ ni, boʊθ ɑɹmz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt əz ɪf əpilɪŋ, əntɪl ɑɹmz ən bɑɾi ən ɹaɪt lɛɡ meɪɾ ə stʃɹeɪt, slæntəd laɪn. hɝ ʃɪɹ waɪt ɹoʊb meɪd ðə hoʊl θɪŋ skændələs. mɔɹɡeɪs fɛlt əɹ tʃiks ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɾ əz ðə dæns, ɪf ɪt kəd bi kɔl ðæt, kəntɪnjud.

The serving woman rose from her place at the wall again, running out to the middle of the floor in an odd way, on tiptoe, with her arms swept back. Slowly, atop the flaring golden sun, symbol of the Children of the Light, she began a sort of stylized dance. Her arms unfolded to the sides like wings, then folded back. Twisting, she slid her left foot out, lowering herself over the bending knee, both arms outstretched as if appealing, until arms and body and right leg made a straight, slanted line. Her sheer white robe made the whole thing scandalous. Morgase felt her cheeks growing hot as the dance, if it could be called that, continued.

"θɛɹə ɪz nu ən nɑt wɛl tʃɹeɪn jɛt," sjuɹɔθ mɝmɝd. "ðə poʊzəz ɑɹ moʊst ɔfən dʌn wɪð tɛn əɹ twɛnti dækoʊvæl təɡɛðɝ, mɛn ən wɪmən tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðə klin bjuɾi ʌv ðɛɹ laɪnz, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪts plɛzən tə vju oʊnli wʌn. ɪts vɛɹi plɛzən tə oʊn bjuɾəfəl θɪŋz, ɪz ɪt nɑt?"

"Thera is new and not well trained yet," Suroth murmured. "The Poses are most often done with ten or twenty da'covale together, men and women chosen for the clean beauty of their lines, but sometimes it is pleasant to view only one. It is very pleasant to own beautiful things, is it not?"

mɔɹɡeɪs fɹaʊnd. haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn oʊn ə pɝsən? sjuɹɔθ hæd spoʊkən ɝliɝ əbaʊt "meɪkɪŋ sʌmwʌn pɹɑpɝɾi." ʃi nu ði oʊl tʌŋ, ən ðə wɝd dækoʊvæl wɑz nɑt fəmɪljɝ tə hɝ, bʌt θɪŋkɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt ʃi keɪm ʌp wɪð "pɝsən u ɪz oʊnd." ɪt wɑz dɪsɡʌstɪŋ. hɔɹɛndəs! "ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd liv jə tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðə . . . dæns."

Morgase frowned. How could anyone own a person? Suroth had spoken earlier about "making someone property." She knew the Old Tongue, and the word da'covale was not familiar to her, but thinking it out she came up with "Person Who Is Owned." It was disgusting. Horrendous! "Incredible," she said dryly. "Perhaps I should leave you to enjoy the . . . dance."

"ɪn wʌn moʊmənt," sjuɹɔθ sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ ət ðə pɑstʃɝɪŋ θɛɹə. mɔɹɡeɪs əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ. "ɔl əv tʃɔɪsəz tə meɪk, əz aɪ sɛd. ði oʊl kɪŋ ə tæɹɑbən tʃoʊz tə ɹəbɛl, ən daɪd. ði oʊl pɑnɑɹtʃ wɑz kæptʃɝd, jɛt ɹəfjuz ði oʊθ. itʃ ʌv əs əz ə pleɪs wɛɹ wi bɪlɔŋ, ənlɛs ɹeɪz baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛs, bʌt ðoʊz u ɹɪdʒɛk ðɛɹ pɹɑpɝ pleɪs kən ɔlsoʊ bi kæs daʊn, ivən tə ðə dɛpθs. θɛɹə hæz ə sɝɾən ɡɹeɪs. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ælwɪn ʃoʊz ɡɹeɪt pɹɑməs ɪn titʃɪŋ, soʊ aɪ ɪkspɛk ðət bɪfɔɹ mɛni jɪɹz, θɛɹə wɪl lɝn ðə skɪl ɪn ðə poʊzəz tə ɡoʊ wɪð əɹ ɡɹeɪs." ðət smaɪl swɪvəl təwɔɹd mɔɹɡeɪs, ðət ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɡeɪz.

"In one moment," Suroth said, smiling at the posturing Thera. Morgase avoided looking. "All have choices to make, as I said. The old King of Tarabon chose to rebel, and died. The old Panarch was captured, yet refused the Oath. Each of us has a place where we belong, unless raised by the Empress, but those who reject their proper place can also be cast down, even to the depths. Thera has a certain grace. Strangely, Alwhin shows great promise in teaching, so I expect that before many years, Thera will learn the skill in the Poses to go with her grace." That smile swiveled toward Morgase, that glittering gaze.

ə vɛɹi səɡnɪfɪkənt ɡeɪz, bʌt waɪ? sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə dænsɝ? hɝ neɪm, mɛnʃən soʊ ɔfən, əz ɪf tə haɪlaɪɾ ɪt. bʌt wʌt . . . ? mɔɹɡeɪsəz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊnd, ən ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə wʊmən, ʌp ɑn əɹ toʊz ən sloʊli pɪvoʊɾɪŋ ɪn wʌn spɑt wɪð əɹ hænz flæt təɡɛðɝ ən ɑɹmz stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp əz haɪ əz ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ. "aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪt," ʃi ɡæspt. "aɪ woʊnt!"

A very significant gaze, but why? Something to do with the dancer? Her name, mentioned so often, as if to highlight it. But what . . . ? Morgase's head whipped around, and she stared at the woman, up on her toes and slowly pivoting in one spot with her hands flat together and arms stretched up as high as they would go. "I don't believe it," she gasped. "I won't!"

"θɛɹə," sjuɹɔθ sɛd, "wʌt wɑz jəɹ neɪm bɪfɔɹ jə bɪkeɪm maɪ pɹɑpɝɾi? wʌt taɪɾəl dɪd jə hoʊld?"

"Thera," Suroth said, "what was your name before you became my property? What title did you hold?"

θɛɹə fɹoʊz ɪn əɹ ʌp-stʃɹɛtʃt pɑstʃɝ, kwɪvɝɪŋ, ʃuɾɪŋ ə lʊk hæf pænɪk, hæf tɛɹɝ ət ʃɑɹp-feɪst ælwɪn, ə lʊk ə pjʊɹ tɛɹɝ ət sjuɹɔθ. "θɛɹə wɑz kɔld æməðɛɹə, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθəli. "θɛɹə wɑz ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə haɪ leɪɾi."

Thera froze in her up-stretched posture, quivering, shooting a look half panic, half terror at sharp-faced Alwhin, a look of pure terror at Suroth. "Thera was called Amathera, if it pleases the High Lady," she said breathily. "Thera was the Panarch of Tarabon, if it pleases the High Lady."

ðə kʌp dʒɹɑp fɹəm mɔɹɡeɪsəz hænd, smæʃɪŋ tə bɪts ɑn ðə flɔɹ, spɹeɪɪŋ ðə blæk kæf. ɪt hæd tə bi ə laɪ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ mɛɾ æməðɛɹə, bʌt ʃi hæd hɝɾ ə dɪskɹɪpʃən, wʌns. noʊ. mɛni wɪmən ə ðə ɹaɪɾ eɪdʒ kəɾ əv lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz ən ə pɛtʃələn maʊθ. pʊɹə hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðɪs wʊmən. . . . "poʊz!" ælwɪn snæpt, ən θɛɹə floʊɾ ɑn wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz wʌn mɔɹ ɡlæns ət sjuɹɔθ əɹ ɛniwʌn. huɛvɝ ʃi wɑz, klɪɹli ðə fɔɹmoʊs θɔɾ ɪn əɹ hɛd naʊ wɑz ən ɝdʒən dɪzaɪɝ nɑt tə meɪk ə mɪsteɪk. mɔɹɡeɪs kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn nɑt vɑməɾɪŋ.

The cup dropped from Morgase's hand, smashing to bits on the floor, spraying the black kaf. It had to be a lie. She had never met Amathera, but she had heard a description, once. No. Many women of the right age could have large dark eyes and a petulant mouth. Pura had never been Aes Sedai, and this woman. . . . "Pose!" Alwhin snapped, and Thera flowed on without so much as one more glance at Suroth or anyone. Whoever she was, clearly the foremost thought in her head now was an urgent desire not to make a mistake. Morgase concentrated on not vomiting.

sjuɹɔθ stɛp vɛɹi kloʊs, feɪs koʊld əz mɪdwɪntɝ. "ɔl kənfɹʌn tʃɔɪsəz," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. hɝ vɔɪs cʊɾə mɑɹk stil. "sʌm ə maɪ pɹɪznɝz seɪ ðət jə spɛn taɪm ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. baɪ lɔ, noʊ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn meɪ ɪskeɪp ðə liʃ, bʌɾ aɪ plɛdʒ tə jə ðət ju, hu neɪmd mi tə maɪ aɪz ən kɔld laɪ ɑn maɪ wɝd, jəl nɑt feɪs ðət feɪt." ði ɛmfəsəs meɪd kwaɪt klɪɹ ðəɾ əɹ plɛdʒ kʌvɝd noʊ ʌðɝ pɑsəbəl feɪt. ðə smaɪl ðət nɛvɝ ɹitʃt əɹ aɪz ɹɪtɝnd. "aɪ hoʊp ðət jəl tʃuz tə swɛɹ ði oʊθ, mɔɹɡeɪs, ən ɹul ændɝ ɪn ðə neɪm ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ." fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz æbsəlutli sɝɾən ðə wʊmən laɪd. "aɪ wɪl spik tə jə əɡɛn təmɑɹoʊ, əɹ pɝhæps ðə nɛks deɪ, ɪf aɪ hæv taɪm."

Suroth stepped very close, face cold as midwinter. "All confront choices," she said quietly. Her voice could have marked steel. "Some of my prisoners say that you spent time in the White Tower. By law, no marath'damane may escape the leash, but I pledge to you that you, who named me to my eyes and called lie on my word, you will not face that fate." The emphasis made quite clear that her pledge covered no other possible fate. The smile that never reached her eyes returned. "I hope that you will choose to swear the oath, Morgase, and rule Andor in the name of the Empress, may she live forever." For the first time, Morgase was absolutely certain the woman lied. "I will speak to you again tomorrow, or perhaps the next day, if I have time."

tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, sjuɹɔθ ɡlaɪɾɪd pæs ðə loʊn dænsɝ tə ðə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ. əz ʃi sæt, spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊb ɡɹeɪsfəli, ælwɪn bɑɹkt əɡɛn. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə hæv ɛni ʌðɝ vɔɪs. "ɔl! poʊzəz ə ðə swɑn!" ðə jʌŋ mɛn ən wɪmən nilɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl lɛp fɔɹwɝd tə dʒɔɪn θɛɹə, dʒɔɪnɪŋ əɹ muvməns ɪɡzækli ɪn ə laɪn bɪfɔɹ sjuɹɔθs tʃɛɹ. oʊnli ðə loʊpɝz ɡeɪz stɪl æknɑlɪdʒ mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɛɡzɪstəns. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn dɪsmɪst soʊ θɝoʊli ɪn əɹ laɪf. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ dɪɡnəɾi wɪð əɹ skɝts, ʃi lɛft.

Turning away, Suroth glided past the lone dancer to the high-backed chair. As she sat, spreading her robe gracefully, Alwhin barked again. She did not seem to have any other voice. "All! Poses of the Swan!" The young men and women kneeling against the wall leaped forward to join Thera, joining her movements exactly in a line before Suroth's chair. Only the lopar's gaze still acknowledged Morgase's existence. She did not believe she had ever been dismissed so thoroughly in her life. Gathering her dignity with her skirts, she left.

ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ fɑɹ əloʊn ə kɔɹs. ðoʊz ɹɛd-ænd-blæk ɑɹmɝd soʊlʒɝz stʊɾ ɪn ði æntəɹum laɪk stætʃuz wɪð ɹɛd-ænd-blæk tæsɛl spɪɹz, feɪsəz ɪmpæsɪv ɪn ðɛɹ lækɝd hɛlməts, hɑɹɾ aɪz simɪŋ tə stɛɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə mændəbəlz ə mɑnstʃɹəs ɪnsɛks. wʌn, nɑt mʌtʃ tɔlɝ ðən ʃi, fɛl ɪn əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ ən ɛskɔɹɾɪd əɹ bæk tə hɝ ɹumz, wɛɹ tu tæɹɑbənɝz wɪð sɔɹdz flæŋkt əɹ dɔɹ, ðiz ɪn stil bɹɛst-pleɪts, bʌt stɪl peɪntəɾ ɪn hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps. ðeɪ baʊd loʊ, hænz ɑn ðɛɹ niz, ən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz fəɹ əɹ əntɪl əɹ ɛskɔɹt spoʊk fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm.

She did not go far alone of course. Those red-and-black armored soldiers stood in the anteroom like statues with red-and-black tasseled spears, faces impassive in their lacquered helmets, hard eyes seeming to stare from behind the mandibles of monstrous insects. One, not much taller than she, fell in at her shoulder without a word and escorted her back to her rooms, where two Taraboners with swords flanked her door, these in steel breast-plates, but still painted in horizontal stripes. They bowed low, hands on their knees, and she thought it was for her until her escort spoke for the first time.

"ɑnɝ mɛt," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə hɑɹʃ, dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs, ən ðə tæɹɑbənɝz stʃɹeɪɾənd, nɛvɝ ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ əɹ əntɪl i sɛd, "wɑtʃ əɹ wɛl. ʃiz nɑt ɡɪvən ði oʊθ." dɑɹk aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹɾ əɹ əbʌv stil veɪlz, bʌt ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt baʊz ʌv əsɛnt wɝ fəɹ ðə sintʃæn.

"Honor met," he said in a harsh, dry voice, and the Taraboners straightened, never glancing at her until he said, "Watch her well. She has not given the Oath." Dark eyes flickered toward her above steel veils, but their short bows of assent were for the Seanchan.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə hɝi ɪnsaɪd, bʌt wʌns ðə dɔɹ wɑz kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ, ʃi lin əɡɛnst ɪɾ ətɛmptɪŋ tə sɛɾəl əɹ wɝlɪŋ θɔts. sintʃæn ən deɪmeɪn, ɛmpɹɛsəz ən oʊðz ən pipəl oʊnd. lini ən bɹin stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ.

She tried not to hurry inside, but once the door was closed behind her, she leaned against it attempting to settle her whirling thoughts. Seanchan and damane, Empresses and oaths and people owned. Lini and Breane stood in the middle of the room looking at her.

"wʌt dɪd jə lɝn?" lini æsk peɪʃənli, ɪn mʌtʃ ðə toʊn ɪn wɪtʃ ʃi hæd kwɛstʃən ðə tʃaɪl mɔɹɡeɪs əbaʊɾ ə bʊk ɹɛd.

"What did you learn?" Lini asked patiently, in much the tone in which she had questioned the child Morgase about a book read.

"naɪtmɛɹz ən mædnəs," mɔɹɡeɪs saɪd. sʌɾənli ʃi stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum æŋkʃəsli. "wɛɹ ɪz - ? wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə mɛn?"

"Nightmares and madness," Morgase sighed. Suddenly she stood up straight, looking around the room anxiously. "Where is - ? Where are the men?"

bɹin ænsɝd ði ʌnəskt kwɛstʃən ɪn ə dʒɹaɪli mɑkɪŋ toʊn. "tɑlænvɝ wɛn tə si wʌɾ i kəd faɪn aʊt." hɝ fɪsts plæntəd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn əɹ hɪps, ən əɹ feɪs bɪkeɪm dɛdli sɪɹiəs. "læmɡwɪn wɛnt wɪð hɪm, ən mæstɝ ɡɪl. wʌd jə faɪn aʊt? hu ɑɹ ðiz . . . sintʃæn?" ʃi sɛd ðə neɪm ɔkwɝdli, fɹaʊnɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪt. "wi hɝd ðət mʌtʃ fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz." ʃi əfɛktəd nɑt tə noʊɾəs liniz baɪɾɪŋ stɛɹ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tə də naʊ, mɔɹɡeɪs?"

Breane answered the unasked question in a dryly mocking tone. "Tallanvor went to see what he could find out." Her fists planted themselves on her hips, and her face became deadly serious. "Lamgwin went with him, and Master Gill. What did you find out? Who are these . . . Seanchan?" She said the name awkwardly, frowning around it. "We heard that much for ourselves." She affected not to notice Lini's biting stare. "What are we to do now, Morgase?"

mɔɹɡeɪs bɹʌʃt bɪtwin ðə wɪmən, kɹɔsɪŋ tə ðə nɪɹəst wɪndoʊ. nɑɾ əz nɛɹoʊ əz ðoʊz ɪn ði ɑɾiəns tʃeɪmbɝ, ɪt lʊk daʊn twɛnti fiɾ əɹ mɔɹ tə ðə stoʊn peɪvɪŋ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ə dɪspɪɹəɾɪd kɑləm ə bæɹhɛɾɪd, dɪʃɛvəl mɛn, səm wɪð blʌd-steɪn bændədʒəz, ʃæmbəld əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl ɡeɪz ə tæɹɑbənɝz kæɹiɪŋ spɪɹz. sɛvɹəl sintʃæn stʊɾ ətɑp ə nɪɹbaɪ taʊɝ, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɪstəns bɪtwin ðə kɹɛnɛleɪʃənz. wʌn wɔɹ ə hɛlmət dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð θɹi slɛndɝ plumz. ə wʊmən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ə wɪndoʊ əkɹɔs ðə kɔɹt, ðə laɪtnɪŋ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd pænəl pleɪn ɑn əɹ bɹɛst, fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət ðə waɪt-kloʊk pɹɪznɝz. ðoʊz stʌmbəlɪŋ mɛn lʊk stʌnd, əneɪbəl tə bɪliv wʌt hæd hæpənd.

Morgase brushed between the women, crossing to the nearest window. Not as narrow as those in the audience chamber, it looked down twenty feet or more to the stone paving of the courtyard. A dispirited column of bareheaded, disheveled men, some with blood-stained bandages, shambled across the courtyard under the watchful gaze of Taraboners carrying spears. Several Seanchan stood atop a nearby tower, peering into the distance between the crenellations. One wore a helmet decorated with three slender plumes. A woman appeared in a window across the court, the lightning-embroidered red panel plain on her breast, frowning down at the White-cloak prisoners. Those stumbling men looked stunned, unable to believe what had happened.

wʌt wɝ ðeɪ tə du? ə dɪsɪʒən mɔɹɡeɪs dʒɹɛɾɪd. ɪt sim ðət ʃi hæd nɑt meɪd soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə dɪsɪʒən ɑn fɹut fəɹ bɹɛkfəst ɪn mʌnθs wɪθaʊɾ ɪt liɾɪŋ tə dɪzæstɝ. ə tʃɔɪs, sjuɹɔθ hæd sɛd. eɪd ðiz sintʃæn ɪn teɪkɪŋ ændɝ, ɔɹ. . . . wʌn læst sɝvəs ʃi kəd də fəɹ ændɝ. ðə teɪl ɛn ə ðə kɑləm əpɪɹd, fɑloʊd baɪ mɔɹ tæɹɑbənɝz, hu wɝ dʒɔɪn baɪ ðɛɹ kʌntʃɹimɪn ðeɪ pæst. ə twɛnti-fʊt fɔl, ən sjuɹɔθ lɔst əɹ lɛvɝ. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðə kaʊɝdz weɪ aʊt, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pɹuv hɝsɛlf ðæt. stɪl, ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ ʃəd nɑt daɪ soʊ.

What were they to do? A decision Morgase dreaded. It seemed that she had not made so much as a decision on fruit for breakfast in months without it leading to disaster. A choice, Suroth had said. Aid these Seanchan in taking Andor, or. . . . One last service she could do for Andor. The tail end of the column appeared, followed by more Taraboners, who were joined by their countrymen they passed. A twenty-foot fall, and Suroth lost her lever. Maybe it was the coward's way out, but she had already proved herself that. Still, the Queen of Andor should not die so.

ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi spoʊk ði ɪɹɛvəkəbəl wɝdz ðət hæd bɪn juzd oʊnli twaɪs bɪfɔɹ ɪn ðə θaʊzənd-jɪɹ hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃ ðə haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkən tə ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ ɹɪnaʊns ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ən æbdəkeɪt ðə laɪən θɹoʊn tə ɪleɪn, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ səbmɪt maɪsɛlf tə ðə wɪl ʌv ɪleɪn ʌv ændɝ, hɝ oʊbiɾiənt sʌbʒɪkt." nʌn ə ðət meɪɾ ɪleɪn kwin, tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪt klɪɹd ðə weɪ.

Under her breath, she spoke the irrevocable words that had been used only twice before in the thousand-year history of Andor. "Under the Light, I relinquish the High Seat of House Trakand to Elayne Trakand. Under the Light, I renounce the Rose Crown and abdicate the Lion Throne to Elayne, High Seat of House Trakand. Under the Light, I submit myself to the will of Elayne of Andor, her obedient subject." None of that made Elayne Queen, true, but it cleared the way.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə smaɪlɪŋ æt?" lini æskt.

"What are you smiling at?" Lini asked.

mɔɹɡeɪs tɝn sloʊli. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪleɪn." ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əɹ oʊl nɝs hæd bɪn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ wʌt noʊ wʌn ɹɪli niɾəd tə.

Morgase turned slowly. "I was thinking of Elayne." She did not think her old nurse had been close enough to hear what no one really needed to.

liniz aɪz waɪɾənd, ðoʊ, ən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt. "ju kʌm əweɪ fɹəm ðəɹ naʊ!" ʃi snæpt, ən suɾɪŋ ækʃənz tə wɝdz, sizd əɹ ɑɹm ən fɪzɪkəli pʊld əɹ fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ.

Lini's eyes widened, though, and her breath caught. "You come away from there now!" she snapped, and suiting actions to words, seized her arm and physically pulled her from the window.

"lini, jə fɝɡɛt jɝsɛlf! jə stɑp biɪŋ maɪ nɝs ə lɔŋ - !" mɔɹɡeɪs dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən sɔfən əɹ toʊn. miɾɪŋ ðoʊz fɹaɪɾənd aɪz wɑz nɑɾ izi; nʌθɪŋ fɹaɪɾənd lini. "wʌɾ aɪ də ɪz fəɹ ðə bɛst, bɪliv mi," ʃi toʊld əɹ dʒɛnli. "ðɛɹz noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ - "

"Lini, you forget yourself! You stopped being my nurse a long - !" Morgase drew a deep breath and softened her tone. Meeting those frightened eyes was not easy; nothing frightened Lini. "What I do is for the best, believe me," she told her gently. "There's no other way - "

"noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ?" bɹin bɹoʊk ɪn æŋɡɹəli, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ skɝts tɪl əɹ hænz ʃʊk. klɪɹli ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ əv hæɾ əm ɹæpt ɝaʊn mɔɹɡeɪsəz θɹoʊt. "wʌt ful nɑnsɛns ɑɹ jə spaʊɾɪŋ naʊ? wʌɾ ɪf ðiz sintʃæn θɪŋk wi kɪl ju?" mɔɹɡeɪs kəmpɹɛst əɹ lɪps; hæd ʃi bɪkʌm soʊ tʃɹænspɛɹənt?

"No other way?" Breane broke in angrily, gripping her skirts till her hands shook. Clearly she would rather have had them wrapped around Morgase's throat. "What fool nonsense are you spouting now? What if these Seanchan think we killed you?" Morgase compressed her lips; had she become so transparent?

"ʃʌɾ ʌp, wʊmən!" lini nɛvɝ ɡɑɾ æŋɡɹi, iðɝ, əɹ ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi dɪd boʊθ naʊ, hɝ wɪðɝd tʃiks ɹɛd. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə boʊni hænd. "ju hoʊl jəɹ maʊθ, əɹ əl slæp jə sɪliɝ ðən jə ɑɹ!"

"Shut up, woman!" Lini never got angry, either, or raised her voice, but she did both now, her withered cheeks red. She raised a bony hand. "You hold your mouth, or I'll slap you sillier than you are!"

"slæp əɹ ɪf jə wɑnə slæp sʌmwʌn!" bɹin ʃaʊɾəd bæk soʊ fɪɹsli ðət spɪɾəl flu. "kwin mɔɹɡeɪs! ʃɪl sɛn jə ən mi ən maɪ læmɡwɪn tə ðə ɡæloʊz, ən əɹ pɹɛʃəs tɑlænvɝ tu, kəz ʃi læks ðə bɛli ʌv ə maʊs!"

"Slap her if you want to slap someone!" Breane shouted back so fiercely that spittle flew. "Queen Morgase! She will send you and me and my Lamgwin to the gallows, and her precious Tallanvor too, because she lacks the belly of a mouse!"

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən tə ədmɪt tɑlænvɝ ən pʊɾ ən əbɹʌpt ɛn tə ɪt. noʊ wʌn wɑz əbaʊt tə ʃaʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. lini pɹitɛndəd tə ɪɡzæmɪn mɔɹɡeɪsəz sliv əz ðoʊ ɪt maɪt nid mɛndɪŋ əz mæstɝ ɡɪl ən læmɡwɪn fɑloʊd tɑlænvɝ ɪn. bɹin pʊɾ ɑn ə bɹaɪt smaɪl ən smuðd əɹ skɝts. ðə mɛn noʊɾəst nʌθɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs.

The door opened to admit Tallanvor and put an abrupt end to it. No one was about to shout in front of him. Lini pretended to examine Morgase's sleeve as though it might need mending as Master Gill and Lamgwin followed Tallanvor in. Breane put on a bright smile and smoothed her skirts. The men noticed nothing, of course.

mɔɹɡeɪs noʊɾəst ə ɡɹeɪt dil. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, tɑlænvɝ hæɾ ə sɔɹd bɛltəɾ ɑn, ən soʊ dɪd mæstɝ ɡɪl, ən ivən læmɡwɪn, ðoʊ hɪz wɑz ə ʃɔɹt-sɔɹd. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz hæd ðə filɪŋ i wɑz mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ɪz fɪsts ðən ɛni ʌðɝ wɛpənz. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ æsk haʊ, ðə skɪni lɪɾəl mæn u bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ kloʊz ðə dɔɹ kɛɹfəli bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Morgase noticed a great deal. For one thing, Tallanvor had a sword belted on, and so did Master Gill, and even Lamgwin, though his was a short-sword. She had always had the feeling he was more comfortable with his fists than any other weapons. Before she could ask how, the skinny little man who brought up the rear closed the door carefully behind him.

"mædʒəsti," sɛbæn beɪlwɝ sɛd, "fɝɡɪv ði ɪntʃɹuʒən." ivən ɪz baʊ ən ɪz smaɪl sim dʒɹaɪ ən pɹɪsaɪs, bʌɾ əz ɪz aɪz flɪk fɹəm əɹ tə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, mɔɹɡeɪs dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət wɛðɝ ði ʌðɝ mɛn noʊɾəst ði ætməsfɪɹ ɪn ðə ɹum əɹ nɑt, peɪdʒɹən naɪlz wʌntaɪm sɛkɹətɛɹi dɪd.

"Majesty," Sebban Balwer said, "forgive the intrusion." Even his bow and his smile seemed dry and precise, but as his eyes flicked from her to the other women, Morgase decided that whether the other men noticed the atmosphere in the room or not, Pedron Niall's onetime secretary did.

"aɪ æm sɝpɹaɪz tə si ju, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hɝd ðəɹ wɑz səm ənplɛzəntnəs wɪð imən vɑldə." wʌt ʃi hæd hɝd wɑz ðət vɑldə hæd sɛɾ ɪf i leɪɾ aɪz ɑn beɪlwɝ, hi wəd kɪk ɪm oʊvɝ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs wɔlz. beɪlwɝz smaɪl taɪɾənd; hi nu wʌt vɑldə hæd sɛd.

"I am surprised to see you, Master Balwer," she said. "I heard there was some unpleasantness with Eamon Valda." What she had heard was that Valda had said if he laid eyes on Balwer, he would kick him over one of the Fortress walls. Balwer's smile tightened; he knew what Valda had said.

"hi hæz ə plæn tə teɪk əs ɔl aʊɾ ə hɪɹ," tɑlænvɝ bɹoʊk ɪn. "tədeɪ. naʊ." hi ɡeɪv əɹ ə lʊk nɑt ðəɾ ə sʌbʒɪkt tə kwin. "wi ɑɹ æksɛptɪŋ ɪz ɔfɝ."

"He has a plan to take us all out of here," Tallanvor broke in. "Today. Now." He gave her a look not that of subject to queen. "We are accepting his offer."

"haʊ?" ʃi sɛd sloʊli, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz tə ɹɪmeɪn stʃɹeɪt. wʌt hɛlp kəd ðɪs pɹɪsi lɪɾəl stɪk ʌv ə mæn ɔfɝ? ɪskeɪp. ʃi wɑntəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə sɪt daʊn, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə, nɑt wɪð tɑlænvɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɪn ðət fæʃən. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪz kwin, naʊ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ ðæt. ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən əkɝd. "waɪ? mæstɝ beɪlwɝ, əl nɑt ʃʌn ɛni tʃɹu ɔfɝ ə hɛlp, bʌt waɪ wəd jə ɹɪsk jɝsɛlf? ðiz sintʃæn wɪl meɪk jə ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt, ʃəd ðeɪ faɪn aʊt."

"How?" she said slowly, forcing her legs to remain straight. What help could this prissy little stick of a man offer? Escape. She wanted very much to sit down, but she was not going to, not with Tallanvor looking at her in that fashion. Of course, she was not his Queen, now, but he did not know that. Another question occurred. "Why? Master Balwer, I'll not shun any true offer of help, but why would you risk yourself? These Seanchan will make you regret it, should they find out."

"aɪ leɪd maɪ plænz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ keɪm," hi sɛd kɛɹfəli. "ɪt simd . . . ɪmpɹuɾənt . . . tə liv ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ ɪn vɑldəz hænz. kənsɪɾɝ ɪt maɪ weɪ ʌv ɹipeɪɪŋ hɪm. aɪ noʊ aɪm nɑt mʌtʃ tə lʊk æt, mædʒəsti . . ." hi hɪɾ ə sɛlf-dɛpɹəkeɪɾɪŋ kɑf bɪhaɪn ɪz hænd. ". . . bʌt ðə plæn wɪl wɝk. ðiz sintʃæn æktʃəli  meɪk ɪɾ iziɝ; aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ɹɛɾi fəɹ deɪz jɛt wɪθaʊt ðɛm. fəɹ ə nuli kɑŋkɝd sɪɾi, ðeɪ əlaʊ ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl fɹiɾəm tə ɛniwʌn wɪlɪŋ tə seɪ ðɛɹ oʊθ. nɑɾ ən aʊɝ æftɝ sʌnɹaɪz, aɪ əbteɪn ə pæs əlaʊɪŋ maɪsɛlf ən ʌp tə tɛn mɔɹ u hæv teɪkən ði oʊθ tə dɪpɑɹɾ æmədɔɹ. ðeɪ bɪliv aɪ ɪntɛn tə baɪ waɪn, ən wæɡənz tə kæɹi ɪt, ɪn ði ist."

"I laid my plans before they came," he said carefully. "It seemed . . . imprudent . . . to leave the Queen of Andor in Valda's hands. Consider it my way of repaying him. I know I am not much to look at, Majesty . . ." He hid a self-deprecating cough behind his hand. ". . . but the plan will work. These Seanchan actually make it easier; I would not have been ready for days yet without them. For a newly conquered city, they allow remarkable freedom to anyone willing to say their Oath. Not an hour after sunrise, I obtained a pass allowing myself and up to ten more who have taken the Oath to depart Amador. They believe I intend to buy wine, and wagons to carry it, in the east."

"ɪt mʌs bi ə tʃɹæp." ðə wɝdz teɪstəd bɪɾɝ. bɛɾɝ ðə wɪndoʊ ðən fɔlɪŋ ɪndə səm snɛɹ. "ðeɪ woʊn əlaʊ jə tə kæɹi wɝɾ ə ðɛm əhɛɾ ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmi."

"It must be a trap." The words tasted bitter. Better the window than falling into some snare. "They won't allow you to carry word of them ahead of their army."

beɪlwɝz hɛd tɪltəd tə wʌn saɪd, ən i bɪɡæn dʒɹaɪ-wɑʃɪŋ ɪz hænz, ðən stɑpt əbɹʌpli. "ɪn tʃɹuθ, mædʒəsti, aɪ kənsɪɾɝd ðæt. ði ɔfəsɝ u ɡeɪv mi ðə pæs sɛɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hɪz ɪɡzækt wɝdz: 'tɛl u jəl wʌt juv sin, ən lɛɾ əm noʊ ðeɪ kænɑt stæn əɡɛnst ʌs. jəɹ lænz wɪl noʊ sun ɪnʌf ɛniweɪ.' aɪ hæv sin sɛvɹəl mɝtʃəns teɪk ði oʊθ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ən dɪpɑɹt wɪð ðɛɹ wæɡənz."

Balwer's head tilted to one side, and he began dry-washing his hands, then stopped abruptly. "In truth, Majesty, I considered that. The officer who gave me the pass said it did not matter. His exact words: 'Tell who you will what you have seen, and let them know they cannot stand against us. Your lands will know soon enough anyway.' I have seen several merchants take the Oath this morning and depart with their wagons."

tɑlænvɝ muv kloʊs tə hɝ. tu kloʊs. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ɪz bɹɛθ. ʃi kəd fil ɪz aɪz. "wi ɑɹ æksɛptɪŋ ɪz ɔfɝ," hi sɛd fəɹ əɹ ɪɹz əloʊn. "ɪf aɪ mʌs baɪn ən ɡæɡ ju, aɪ θɪŋk i kən faɪn ə weɪ ivən soʊ. hi simz ə vɛɹi ɹisɔɹsfəl lɪɾəl fɛloʊ."

Tallanvor moved close to her. Too close. She could almost feel his breath. She could feel his eyes. "We are accepting his offer," he said for her ears alone. "If I must bind and gag you, I think he can find a way even so. He seems a very resourceful little fellow."

ʃi mɛɾ ɪm stɛɹ fəɹ stɛɹ. ðə wɪndoʊ əɹ . . . ə tʃæns. ɪf tɑlænvɝ hæɾ oʊnli hɛld ɪz tʌŋ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn mʌtʃ iziɝ tə seɪ, "aɪ æksɛpt wɪð ɡɹæɾətud, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ," bʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪt. ʃi stɛpt əweɪ əz ɪf tə si beɪlwɝ wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə kɹeɪn pæs tɑlænvɝ. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz dɪstɝbɪŋ biɪŋ soʊ nɪɹ tə hɪm. hi wɑz tu jʌŋ. "wʌɾ ɪz tə də fɝst? aɪ daʊt ðoʊz ɡɑɹdz ət ðə dɔɹ wɪl æksɛp jəɹ pæs fəɹ ʌs."

She met him stare for stare. The window or . . . a chance. If Tallanvor had only held his tongue it would have been much easier to say, "I accept with gratitude, Master Balwer," but she said it. She stepped away as if to see Balwer without having to crane past Tallanvor. It was always disturbing being so near to him. He was too young. "What is to do first? I doubt those guards at the door will accept your pass for us."

beɪlwɝ baʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ əɹ fɔɹsaɪt. "aɪ fɪɹ ðeɪ mʌs mit wɪð æksəɾənts, mædʒəsti." tɑlænvɝ izd ɪz dæɡɝ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd, ən læmɡwɪn flɛkst ɪz hænz laɪk ðə loʊpɝ flɛksɪŋ ɪts klɔz.

Balwer bowed his head as if acknowledging her foresight. "I fear they must meet with accidents, Majesty." Tallanvor eased his dagger in its scabbard, and Lamgwin flexed his hands like the lopar flexing its claws.

ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt kəd bi soʊ izi, ivən æftɝ ðeɪ hæd pækt ʌp wʌt ðeɪ kəd kæɹi ən ðə tu tæɹɑbənɝz hæd bɪn stʌf bɪniθ əɹ bɛd. ət ðə meɪn ɡeɪts, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ lɪnən dʌst-kloʊk kloʊs ɔkwɝdli kəz ə ðə bʌndəl ɑn əɹ bæk, ʃi baʊd, hænz ɑn əɹ niz ðə weɪ beɪlwɝ hæd ʃoʊn hɝ, waɪl i toʊl ðə ɡɑɹdz ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl swɔɹn tə oʊbeɪ, əweɪɾ ən sɝv. ʃi θɔɾ ə haʊ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz nɑt teɪkən əlaɪv. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ æktʃəli  ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv æmədɔɹ, pæs ðə læst ɡɑɹdz, ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz beɪlwɝ hæd hæd weɪɾɪŋ, ðət ʃi bɪɡæn tə bɪliv. ʌv kɔɹs, beɪlwɝ pɹɑbli ɪkspɛktəd səm faɪn ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ ɹɛskjuɪŋ ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt toʊld ɛniwʌn ðət ðət wɑz dʌn wɪð bɪɑnd ɡoʊɪŋ bæk; ʃi nu ʃi hæd spoʊkən ðə wɝdz, ən noʊ wʌn ɛls niɾəd tə noʊ. ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ əm wɑz jusləs. naʊ ʃi wəd si wʌt sɔɹɾ ə laɪf ʃi kəd faɪnd wɪθaʊɾ ə θɹoʊn. ə laɪf fɑɹ fɹəm ə mæn u wɑz mʌtʃ tu jʌŋ ən mʌtʃ tu dɪstɝbɪŋ.

She did not believe it could be so easy, even after they had packed up what they could carry and the two Taraboners had been stuffed beneath her bed. At the main gates, holding her linen dust-cloak close awkwardly because of the bundle on her back, she bowed, hands on her knees the way Balwer had shown her, while he told the guards that they had all sworn to obey, await and serve. She thought of how to make sure she was not taken alive. It was not until they were actually riding out of Amador, past the last guards, on the horses Balwer had had waiting, that she began to believe. Of course, Balwer probably expected some fine reward for rescuing the Queen of Andor. She had not told anyone that that was done with beyond going back; she knew she had spoken the words, and no one else needed to know. Regretting them was useless. Now she would see what sort of life she could find without a throne. A life far from a man who was much too young and much too disturbing.

"waɪ ɪz jəɹ smaɪl soʊ sæd?" lini æskt, ɹeɪnɪŋ əɹ slæb-saɪɾəd bɹaʊn mɛɹ kloʊsɝ. ði ænəməl lʊk mʌðiəɾən. mɔɹɡeɪsəz beɪ wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ; nʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ. ðə sintʃæn maɪɾ əv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə lɛt beɪlwɝ ɡoʊ wɪð ɪz pæs, bʌt nɑt wɪð disən maʊns.

"Why is your smile so sad?" Lini asked, reining her slab-sided brown mare closer. The animal looked motheaten. Morgase's bay was no better; none of the horses were. The Seanchan might have been willing to let Balwer go with his pass, but not with decent mounts.

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə lɔŋ ɹoʊɾ əhɛd, jɛt," mɔɹɡeɪs toʊl hɝ, ən θʌmpt əɹ mɛɹ ɪndə səm sɛmbləns ʌv ə tʃɹɑɾ æftɝ tɑlænvɝ.

"There is a long road ahead, yet," Morgase told her, and thumped her mare into some semblance of a trot after Tallanvor.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

tə bi əloʊn


To Be Alone

slɪpɪŋ ðə hæft ə hɪz æks θɹu ðə lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt ɑpəzəɾ ɪz kwɪvɝ, pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ lɔŋboʊ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ, slʌŋ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən lɛf ðə ɹumz i hæd ʃɛɹd wɪð feɪl wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝd lʊk. ðeɪ hæd bɪn hæpi ðəɹ - moʊst ə ðə taɪm. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəɾ ɛvɝ bi bæk. səmtaɪmz i wʌndɝd wɛðɝ biɪŋ hæpi sʌmwɛɹ wɪð feɪl mɛn i wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ. hi hoʊp nɑt.

Slipping the haft of his axe through the loop on his belt opposite his quiver, Perrin took his unstrung longbow from the corner, slung his saddlebags over his shoulder and left the rooms he had shared with Faile without a backward look. They had been happy there - most of the time. He did not think he would ever be back. Sometimes he wondered whether being happy somewhere with Faile meant he would never return there. He hoped not.

ðə sɝvəns i sɔ ɪn ðə pæləs kɔɹɪɾɝz wɔɹ ʌnɹiliv blæk lɪvɝi; pɝhæps ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪt, ən pɝhæps ðə sɝvəns ðɛmsɛlvz hæd sɪmpli ədɑptəɾ ɪt. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ənizi wɪθaʊt lɪvɝi, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋd, ən blæk sim seɪf əz ɹændz kʌlɝ kəz ə ði æʃəmən. ðoʊz u sɔ pɛɹɪn skæmpɝɾ əweɪ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd, nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛni baʊz əɹ kɝtsiz. fɪɹ sɛn dʒɹɪftəd bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

The servants he saw in the palace corridors wore unrelieved black livery; perhaps Rand had ordered it, and perhaps the servants themselves had simply adopted it. They had been uneasy without livery, as though they did not know where they belonged, and black seemed safe as Rand's color because of the Asha'man. Those who saw Perrin scampered away as fast as they could, not waiting for any bows or curtsies. Fear scent drifted behind them.

fəɹ wʌns ɪz jɛloʊ aɪz hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɛniwʌn biɪŋ əfɹeɪd. ɪt maɪt nɑt bi seɪf tə lɔɪɾɝ nɪɹ ə mæn ət hum ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæɾ ənliʃt ɪz ɹeɪdʒ soʊ pʌblɪkli ðɪs vɛɹi mɔɹnɪŋ. pɛɹɪn iz ðə ʃoʊldɝ ʌndɝ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. ə lɔŋ waɪl hæd pæst sɪns ɛniwʌn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə pɪk ɪm ʌp ən θɹoʊ hɪm. ʌv kɔɹs, noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ juz ðə paʊɝ tə tʃɹaɪ, bɪfɔɹ. wʌn moʊmən ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ stʌk wɪð hɪm.

For once his yellow eyes had nothing to do with anyone being afraid. It might not be safe to loiter near a man at whom the Dragon Reborn had unleashed his rage so publicly this very morning. Perrin eased the shoulder under his saddlebags. A long while had passed since anyone had been able to pick him up and throw him. Of course, no one had ever used the Power to try, before. One moment in particular stuck with him.

hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, slaɪɾɪŋ ɪz bæk ʌp ðə skwɛɹ kɑləm ðət hæd stɑpt ɪz flaɪt. hi θɔɾ ə fju ɹɪbz maɪɾ əv kɹækt. ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹæn hɔl ə ðə sʌn, ə skæɾɝɪŋ ə noʊbəlz u hæd kʌm tə əpil wʌn θɪŋ əɹ ənʌðɝ tə ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ wɝ ɛniwɛɹ ɛls. oʊnli dɑbɹeɪn wɑtʃt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz ɡɹeɪ hɛd, əz ɹænd stɔkt əkɹɔs ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. "aɪ wɪl dil wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz aɪ tʃuz!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. "du jə hɪɹ mi, pɛɹɪn? əz aɪ tʃuz!"

He pushed himself up holding his shoulder, sliding his back up the square column that had stopped his flight. He thought a few ribs might have cracked. Around the Grand Hall of the Sun, a scattering of nobles who had come to appeal one thing or another to Rand tried to look anywhere else, tried to pretend they were anywhere else. Only Dobraine watched, shaking his gray head, as Rand stalked across the throne room. "I will deal with the Aes Sedai as I choose!" Rand shouted. "Do you hear me, Perrin? As I choose!"

"juv dʒʌs hændəɾ əm oʊvɝ tə ðə waɪz wʌnz," hi ɡɹaʊl bæk, ʃʌvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kɑləm. "ju doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ðəɹ slipɪŋ ɑn sɪlk əɹ hæd ðɛɹ θɹoʊts kʌt! jə ɑɹ nɑt ðə kɹieɪɾɝ!"

"You've just handed them over to the Wise Ones," he growled back, shoving away from the column. "You don't know whether they're sleeping on silk or had their throats cut! You are not the Creator!"

wɪð ə snɑɹl ə ɹeɪdʒ, ɹænd θɹu hɪz hɛd bæk. "aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" hi kɹaɪd. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ ðəɹ tʃɹiɾəd! ðeɪ dɪzɝv ə dʌnʒən!" pɛɹɪnz hækəlz stɝɾ əz ɹændz aɪz loʊɝd fɹəm ðə vɔltəd silɪŋ. blu aɪs wʊɾə bɪn wɔɹm ən sɑf bɪsaɪd ðɛm, ðə mɔɹ soʊ kəz ðeɪ stɛɹd fɹəm ə feɪs twɪstəd wɪð peɪn. "ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt, pɛɹɪn. dʒju hɪɹ mi? ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin! tədeɪ! naʊ! aɪ nɛvɝ wɑnə si jə əɡɛn!" pɪvoʊɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz hil, hi stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ wɪð noʊbəlz ɔl bʌt θɹoʊɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðə flɔɹ əz i pæst.

With a snarl of rage, Rand threw his head back. "I am the Dragon Reborn!" he cried. "I don't care how they're treated! They deserve a dungeon!" Perrin's hackles stirred as Rand's eyes lowered from the vaulted ceiling. Blue ice would have been warm and soft beside them, the more so because they stared from a face twisted with pain. "Get out of my sight, Perrin. Do you hear me? Get out of Cairhien! Today! Now! I never want to see you again!" Pivoting on his heel, he strode away with nobles all but throwing themselves to the floor as he passed.

pɛɹɪn θʌmd ə tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maʊθ. fəɹ wʌn moʊmən ðɛɹ, hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɹænd wɑz gɑnə kɪl hɪm.

Perrin thumbed a trickle of blood from the corner of his mouth. For one moment there, he had been sure Rand was going to kill him.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə ɹɪd hɪmsɛlf ə ðə θɔt, hi ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ən nɪɹli ɹæn ɪndə lɔɪəl. wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ bʌndəl stʃɹæp tə hɪz bæk ən ə skɹɪp bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ə ʃip slʌŋ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz juzɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ-hændəld æks əz ə wɔkɪŋ stæf. ðə kəpeɪʃəs pɑkəts ə hɪz koʊt bʌlʒd wɪð ðə ʃeɪps ə bʊks.

Shaking his head to rid himself of the thought, he rounded a corner and nearly ran into Loial. With a large bundle strapped to his back and a scrip big enough to hold a sheep slung on his shoulder, the Ogier was using his long-handled axe as a walking staff. The capacious pockets of his coat bulged with the shapes of books.

lɔɪəlz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz pɝkt ʌp ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ðən sʌɾənli dʒɹupt. hɪz hoʊl feɪs dʒɹupt, aɪbɹaʊz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ɪz tʃiks. "aɪ hɝd, pɛɹɪn," hi bum sædli. "ɹænd ʃəd nɑɾ əv dʌn ðæt. kwɪk wɝdz meɪk lɔŋ tʃɹʌbəlz. aɪ noʊ hɪl ɹikənsɪɾɝ. təmɑɹoʊ, meɪbi."

Loial's tufted ears perked up at the sight of him, then suddenly drooped. His whole face drooped, eyebrows hanging on his cheeks. "I heard, Perrin," he boomed sadly. "Rand should not have done that. Quick words make long troubles. I know he'll reconsider. Tomorrow, maybe."

"ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "kɛɹhin ɪz tu . . . pɑlɪʃt . . . fəɹ mi, ɛniweɪ. ɪm ə blæksmɪθ, nɑɾ ə kɔɹɾiɝ. baɪ təmɑɹoʊ, əl bi ə lɔŋ weɪ ɡɔn."

"It's all right," Perrin told him. "Cairhien is too . . . polished . . . for me, anyway. I'm a blacksmith, not a courtier. By tomorrow, I'll be a long way gone."

"ju ən feɪl kəd kʌm wɪð mi. kɑɹldɪn ən aɪ ɑɹ gɑnə vɪzət ðə stɛɾɪŋ, pɛɹɪn. ɔl ə ðɛm, əbaʊt ðə weɪɡeɪts." ə nɛɹoʊ-feɪst, peɪl-hɛɹd jʌŋ fɛloʊ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn lɔɪəl stɑp fɹaʊnɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn tə fɹaʊn ət ði oʊɡiɝ. hi hæɾ ə skɹɪp ən ə bʌndəl, tu, ən ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp. dɪspaɪt ðə blu koʊt, pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌn ə ði æʃəmən. kɑɹldɪn dɪd nɑt lʊk pliz tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz pɛɹɪn; bɪsaɪdz, hɪz smɛl wɑz koʊld ən æŋɡɹi. lɔɪəl pɪɹd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn. "wɛɹ ɪz feɪl?"

"You and Faile could come with me. Karldin and I are going to visit the stedding, Perrin. All of them, about the Waygates." A narrow-faced, pale-haired young fellow standing behind Loial stopped frowning at Perrin to frown at the Ogier. He had a scrip and a bundle, too, and a sword on his hip. Despite the blue coat, Perrin recognized one of the Asha'man. Karldin did not look pleased to recognize Perrin; besides, his smell was cold and angry. Loial peered down the hallway behind Perrin. "Where is Faile?"

"ʃiz . . . miɾɪŋ mi ɪn ðə steɪbəlz. wi hæd wɝdz." ðət wɑz sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ; feɪl sim tə laɪk ʃaʊɾɪŋ, səmtaɪmz. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "lɔɪəl, aɪ wʊdn tɔk əbaʊt ðət wɛɹ ɛniwʌn kəd hɪɹ. ðə weɪɡeɪts, aɪ min."

"She's . . . meeting me in the stables. We had words." That was simple truth; Faile seemed to like shouting, sometimes. He lowered his voice. "Loial, I wouldn't talk about that where anyone could hear. The Waygates, I mean."

lɔɪəl snɔɹɾɪd hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə bʊl dʒʌmp, bʌɾ i dɪd dʒɹɑp ɪz toʊn. "aɪ doʊn si ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ʌs," hi ɹʌmbəld. noʊ wʌn mɔɹ ðən tu əɹ θɹi peɪsɪz bɪɑn kɑɹldɪn cʊɾə hɝd klɪɹli. hɪz ɪɹz . . . læʃt wɑz ði oʊnli wɝd . . . ən leɪd bæk æŋɡɹəli. "ɛvɹiwʌnz əfɹeɪd tə bi sin nɪɹ ju. æftɝ ɔl juv dʌn fəɹ ɹænd."

Loial snorted hard enough to make a bull jump, but he did drop his tone. "I don't see anyone but us," he rumbled. No one more than two or three paces beyond Karldin could have heard clearly. His ears . . . lashed was the only word . . . and laid back angrily. "Everyone's afraid to be seen near you. After all you've done for Rand."

kɑɹldɪn tʌɡd ət lɔɪəlz sliv. "wi hæv tə ɡoʊ," hi sɛd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn. ɛniwʌn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ʃaʊɾəd ət wɑz aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts soʊ fɑɹ əz i wɑz kənsɝnd. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɹaɪt ðɛn.

Karldin tugged at Loial's sleeve. "We have to go," he said, glaring at Perrin. Anyone the Dragon Reborn shouted at was outside the gates so far as he was concerned. Perrin wondered whether he was holding the Power right then.

"jɛs, jɛs," lɔɪəl mɝmɝd, weɪvɪŋ ə hæm-saɪz hænd, bʌɾ i lin ɑn ɪz æks, fɹaʊnɪŋ pɛnsɪvli. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs, pɛɹɪn. ɹænd tʃeɪsəz jə əweɪ. hi sɛnz mi ɔf. haʊ aɪm tə fɪnɪʃ maɪ bʊk. . . ." hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt, ən i kɔft. "wɛl, ðæts niðɝ hɪɹ nɔɹ ðɛɹ. bʌt ju, mi, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz wɛɹ mæt ɪz. hɪl sɛn mɪn əweɪ nɛkst. hi hɪd fɹəm hɝ, ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. hi sɛn mi aʊt tə tɛl əɹ i wɑzn ðɛɹ. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi nu aɪ wɑz laɪɪŋ. hɪl bi əloʊn, ðɛn, pɛɹɪn. 'ɪts tɛɹəbəl tə bi əloʊn.' ðæts wʌɾ i sɛd tə mi. hiz plænɪŋ tə sɛn ɔl ə hɪz fɹɛnz əweɪ."

"Yes, yes," Loial murmured, waving a ham-sized hand, but he leaned on his axe, frowning pensively. "I don't like this, Perrin. Rand chases you away. He sends me off. How I'm to finish my book. . . ." His ears twitched, and he coughed. "Well, that's neither here nor there. But you, me, and the Light only knows where Mat is. He'll send Min away next. He hid from her, this morning. He sent me out to tell her he wasn't there. I think she knew I was lying. He'll be alone, then, Perrin. 'It's terrible to be alone.' That's what he said to me. He is planning to send all of his friends away."

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. lɔɪəl blɪŋkt ət ðəɾ ɛkoʊ ʌv mɔɪɹeɪn. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ ə lɑt ɹisənli; ʃi hæd bɪn ə ɹistʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪnfluəns ɑn ɹænd. "fɛɹwɛl, lɔɪəl. kip seɪf, ən doʊn tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn jə doʊn əv tə." hi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt lʊk ət kɑɹldɪn.

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Perrin said. Loial blinked at that echo of Moiraine. Perrin had been thinking of her a lot recently; she had been a restraining influence on Rand. "Farewell, Loial. Keep safe, and don't trust anyone you don't have to." He did not quite look at Karldin.

"ju doʊn min ðæt, pɛɹɪn." lɔɪəl saʊndəd ʃɑkt; hi sim tə tʃɹʌst ɛvɹiwʌn. "ju kænɑt. kʌm wɪð mi, jə ən feɪl."

"You don't mean that, Perrin." Loial sounded shocked; he seemed to trust everyone. "You cannot. Come with me, you and Faile."

"wil miɾ əɡɛn, wʌn deɪ," pɛɹɪn toʊld ɪm dʒɛnli, ən hɝid pæs bɪfɔɹ i hæd tə seɪ mɔɹ. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk laɪɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli nɑt tə ə fɹɛnd.

"We'll meet again, one day," Perrin told him gently, and hurried past before he had to say more. He did not like lying, especially not to a friend.

ɪn ðə nɔɹθ steɪbəl θɪŋz wɝ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm əz ɪnsaɪd ðə pæləs. ɡɹumz sɔ hɪm wɔk ɪn, ən dʒɹɑp dʌŋ fɔɹks ən kʌɹi koʊmz, kɹaʊɾɪŋ aʊt θɹu smɔl dɔɹz ət ðə bæk. ɹʌsəlz ɪn ðə lɔf haɪ əbʌv ðət maɪɾ əv ɪskeɪpt ənʌðɝz ɪɹz toʊld ə foʊk haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ; hi kəd hɪɹ æŋkʃəs, fɪɹfəl bɹɛθs. hi bɹɔt stɛpɝ aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡɹin-stʃɹik mɑɹbəl stɔl, slɪpt ɑn ɪz bɹaɪɾəl ən taɪd ðə dʌn stæljən tə ə ɡɪldɪd hɪtʃɪŋ ɹɪŋ. hi wɛn tə fɛtʃ blæŋkəɾ ən sæɾəl fɹəm ə mɑɹbəl tæk ɹum wɛɹ hæf ðə sæɾəlz wɝ maʊntəd wɪð sɪlvɝ əɹ ɡoʊld. ðə steɪbəl fɪt vɛɹi wɛl ɪn ə pæləs, wɪð tɔl skwɛɹ mɑɹbəl kɑləmz ən ə mɑɹbəl flɔɹ, ivən ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn ðə stɔlz. hi ɹoʊɾ aʊt ɡlæd tə si ðə bæk ʌv ɡɹænduɹ.

In the north stable things were much the same as inside the palace. Grooms saw him walk in, and dropped dung forks and curry combs, crowding out through small doors at the back. Rustles in the loft high above that might have escaped another's ears told of folk hiding there; he could hear anxious, fearful breaths. He brought Stepper out of a green-streaked marble stall, slipped on his bridle and tied the dun stallion to a gilded hitching ring. He went to fetch blanket and saddle from a marble tack room where half the saddles were mounted with silver or gold. The stable fit very well in a palace, with tall square marble columns and a marble floor, even under the straw in the stalls. He rode out glad to see the back of grandeur.

nɔɹθ ə ðə sɪɾi hi fɑloʊd ðə ɹoʊɾ i hæd kʌm daʊn soʊ dɛspɝətli wɪð ɹænd dʒʌst ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ, ɹoʊɾ əntɪl foʊlz ɪn ðə læn hɪd kɛɹhin. ðən i tɝn ɔf tə ði ist, wɛɹ ə fɛɹ pætʃ ə fɔɹəst ɹɪmeɪnd, ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn wʌn tɔl hɪl ən oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst, tɔlɝ wʌn. dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə tʃɹiz, feɪl buɾɪd swɑloʊ tə mit hɪm, ɛɹæm hilɪŋ əɹ laɪk ə haʊn ɑn ɪz oʊn hɔɹs. ɛɹæmz feɪs bɹaɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑt seɪɪŋ mʌtʃ; hi mɪɹli dɪvaɪɾəd ɪz feɪθfəl haʊn lʊks bɪtwin ɪm ən feɪl.

North of the city he followed the road he had come down so desperately with Rand just a few days before, rode until folds in the land hid Cairhien. Then he turned off to the east, where a fair patch of forest remained, running down one tall hill and over the next, taller one. Just inside the trees, Faile booted Swallow to meet him, Aram heeling her like a hound on his own horse. Aram's face brightened at the sight of him, though that was not saying much; he merely divided his faithful hound looks between him and Faile.

"hʌzbənd," ʃi sɛd. nɑt tu kuli, bʌt ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp æŋɡɝ ən spaɪki dʒɛləsi stɪl θɹɛɾəd θɹu ðə klin sɛn ə hɝ ən əɹ ɝbəl soʊp. ʃi wɑz ɡɑɹb fəɹ tʃɹævəl, wɪð ə θɪn dʌst-kloʊk hæŋɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk ən ɹɛd ɡlʌvz ðət mætʃt ðə buts pikɪŋ aʊt bɪniθ ðə dɑɹk nɛɹoʊ ɹaɪɾɪŋ skɝts ʃi feɪvɝd. noʊ fjuɝ ðən fɔɹ ʃið dæɡɝz wɝ tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt.

"Husband," she said. Not too coolly, but razor-sharp anger and spiky jealousy still threaded through the clean scent of her and her herbal soap. She was garbed for travel, with a thin dust-cloak hanging down her back and red gloves that matched the boots peeking out beneath the dark narrow riding skirts she favored. No fewer than four sheathed daggers were tucked behind her belt.

muvmən bɪhaɪn əɹ tɝn ɪndə beɪn ən kiæd. ən səlɪn, wɪð ə dʌzən mɔɹ meɪɾənz. pɛɹɪnz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz. hi wʌndɝd wʌt ɡɔl θɔɾ ə ðæt; ði il mæn hæd sɛɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə ɡɛɾɪŋ beɪn ən kiæɾ əloʊn. ivən mɔɹ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ wɝ feɪlz ʌðɝ kəmpænjənz.

Movement behind her turned into Bain and Chiad. And Sulin, with a dozen more Maidens. Perrin's eyebrows rose. He wondered what Gaul thought of that; the Aiel man had said he was looking forward to getting Bain and Chiad alone. Even more surprising were Faile's other companions.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ duɪŋ hɪɹ?" hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ə smɔl klʌstɝ u hɛl ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bæk. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz sɛlən ən kɑmɛl ən ðə tɔl tɛɹən wʊmən, ɔl stɪl ɪn mɛnz kloʊðz ən wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz. ðə blɑki fɛloʊ ɪn ə fæt-sliv koʊɾ u hæd kɛpt ɪz bɪɹɾ ɔɪld ən tʃɹɪm tə ə pɔɪn dɪspaɪt wɛɹɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ taɪd bæk wɪð ə ɹɪbən ɔlsoʊ lʊk fəmɪljɝ. ði ʌðɝ tu mɛn, boʊθ kɛɹhinɪn, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ, bʌɾ i kəd ɡɛs, baɪ ðɛɹ juθ ən ðə ɹɪbən taɪɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛɹ ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls, ðət ðeɪ wɝ pɑɹɾ ə sɛlənz "səsaɪəɾi."

"What are they doing here?" He nodded toward a small cluster who held their horses back. He recognized Selande and Camaille and the tall Tairen woman, all still in men's clothes and wearing swords. The blocky fellow in a fat-sleeved coat who had kept his beard oiled and trimmed to a point despite wearing his hair tied back with a ribbon also looked familiar. The other two men, both Cairhienin, he did not know, but he could guess, by their youth and the ribbon tying their hair if nothing else, that they were part of Selande's "society."

"aɪ tʊk sɛlən ən ə fju ʌv əɹ fɹɛnz ɪndə maɪ sɝvəs." feɪl spoʊk laɪtli, bʌt sʌɾənli ʃi ɡeɪv ɔf fɑɡi weɪvz ə kɑʃən. "ðeɪ wʊɾə ɡɑɾən ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. ðeɪ nid sʌmwʌn tə ɡɪv əm dɝɛkʃən. θɪŋk ə ðɛm əz tʃɛɹɪɾi. aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm ɡɛɾ ʌndɝ jəɹ fit."

"I took Selande and a few of her friends into my service." Faile spoke lightly, but suddenly she gave off foggy waves of caution. "They would have gotten themselves into trouble in the city, sooner or later. They need someone to give them direction. Think of them as charity. I won't let them get under your feet."

pɛɹɪn saɪɾ ən skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹd. ə waɪz mæn dɪd nɑt tɛl ɪz waɪf tə hɝ feɪs ðət ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ θɪŋz. ɪspɛʃli wən ðət waɪf wɑz feɪl; ʃi wɑz gɑnə bi əz fɔɹməɾəbəl əz əɹ mʌðɝ. ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ʌndɝ ɪz fit? haʊ mɛni ʌv ðiz . . . pʌpiz . . . hæd ʃi teɪkən ɑn? "ɪz ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹɛɾi? pɹɪɾi sun səm ɪɾiət bæk ðəɹ wɪl dɪsaɪɾ i kən kʌɹi feɪvɝ baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ ɹænd maɪ hɛd. aɪd laɪk tə bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ðæt." ɛɹæm ɡɹaʊld ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

Perrin sighed and scratched his beard. A wise man did not tell his wife to her face that she was hiding things. Especially when that wife was Faile; she was going to be as formidable as her mother. If she was not already. Under his feet? How many of these . . . puppies . . . had she taken on? "Is everything ready? Pretty soon some idiot back there will decide he can curry favor by bringing Rand my head. I'd like to be gone before that." Aram growled in his throat.

"noʊ wʌn ɪz gɑnə teɪk jəɹ hɛd, hʌzbənd." feɪl ʃoʊd waɪt tiθ, ən wɛn ɑn ɪn ə wɪspɝ ʃi nu hi wəd kætʃ. "ɪksɛpt pɝhæps mi." ɪn ə nɔɹməl vɔɪs, ʃi sɛd, "ɔl ɪz ɹɛɾi."

"No one is going to take your head, husband." Faile showed white teeth, and went on in a whisper she knew he would catch. "Except perhaps me." In a normal voice, she said, "All is ready."

ɪn ə klɪɹ, fɛɹli flæt hɑloʊ bɪɑn ðə tʃɹiz, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stʊd bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ə kɑləm ə tuz ðət waʊn aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl. pɛɹɪn saɪɾ əɡɛn. ðə ɹɛd wʊlfhɛd bænɝ ən ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə meɪnɛðɝən stɝd slaɪtli ɪn ə hɑt bɹiz ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm. meɪbi ənʌðɝ dʌzən meɪɾənz skwɑɾɪd ɑn ðɛɹ hilz nɪɹ ðə bænɝz; ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ɡɔl wɔɹ əz kloʊs tə ə sʌlən ɪkspɹɛʃən əz pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɑn ən il.

In a clear, fairly flat hollow beyond the trees, the Two Rivers men stood beside their horses, a column of twos that wound out of sight around the side of the hill. Perrin sighed again. The red wolfhead banner and the Red Eagle of Manetheren stirred slightly in a hot breeze at the head of the column. Maybe another dozen Maidens squatted on their heels near the banners; on the other side, Gaul wore as close to a sullen expression as Perrin had ever seen on an Aiel.

əz i dɪsmaʊntɪd, tu blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn keɪm tə hɪm, səluɾɪŋ wɪð fɪs pɹɛs tə hɑɹt. "lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," dʒɝ ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd. "wiv bɪn hɪɹ sɪns læs naɪt. wəɹ ɹɛɾi."

As he dismounted, two black-coated men came to him, saluting with fist pressed to heart. "Lord Perrin," Jur Grady said. "We've been here since last night. We are ready."

ɡɹeɪɾiz wɛðɝd fɑɹmɝz feɪs meɪd pɛɹɪn ɔlmoʊs kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð hɪm, bʌt feɪɡɝ nild wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. meɪbi tɛn jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən ɡɹeɪɾi, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə fɑɹmɝ tu fəɹ ɔl pɛɹɪn nu, bʌɾ i əfɛktəɾ ɛɹz ən ɡɹeɪsɪz, ən wɔɹ ɪz pɪɾəfəl mʌstæʃ wæks tə ə sɛmbləns ə pɔɪns. wɛɹ ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz wʌn ə ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd, hi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, wɪθaʊt ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd pɪn tə hɪz kɑlɝ, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt hoʊld ɪm bæk fɹəm spikɪŋ. "lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, ɪz ɪt ɹɪli nɛsəsɛɹi tə teɪk ðoʊz wɪmən wɪð ʌs? ðəl bi nʌθɪŋ bʌt tʃɹʌbəl, ðeɪ wɪl, ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm, ən jə noʊ ɪt wɛl."

Grady's weathered farmer's face made Perrin almost comfortable with him, but Fager Neald was another matter. Maybe ten years younger than Grady, he might have been a farmer too for all Perrin knew, but he affected airs and graces, and wore his pitiful mustache waxed to a semblance of points. Where Grady was one of the Dedicated, he was a Soldier, without the silver sword pinned to his collar, but that did not hold him back from speaking. "Lord Perrin, is it really necessary to take those women with us? They'll be nothing but trouble, they will, the whole lot of them, and you know it well."

səm ə ðə wɪmən i wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt stʊd nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, ʃɔlz lupt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz. ɛdʒɹə əpɪɹd ði ɛldəst ə ðə sɪks waɪz wʌnz ɪmpæsɪvli wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tu wɪmən nil hæd nɑɾəd tə. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðət pɛɹ wɝid pɛɹɪn əz wɛl. siɑnɪd tʃɹeɪɡən, ɔl kulnəs ən ɹɪzɝv ɪn ɡɹin sɪlk, hæd bɪn hɔɾəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ði ilwɪmən - moʊs kɛɹhinɪn u wɝ nɑt pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi il dɪspaɪzd əm - bʌt wən ʃi sɔ pɛɹɪn, ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ beɪz ɹeɪnz tə ði ʌðɝ hæn ən ɡeɪv mɑsʊɝi soʊkɑwə ə nʌdʒ ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. mɑsʊɝi stɑɹɾəd - bɹaʊnz sim tə ɡoʊ ɔf ɪn deɪdʒɹimz fɛɹli ɔfən - stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ blæŋkli, ðən dɝɛktəɾ əɹ stɛɹ ət pɛɹɪn. ðɪs wʌn wɑz mɔɹ ðə sɔɹt ʃi maɪɾ əv ɡɪvən səm pəkjuljɝ ən pɝhæps deɪnʒɝəs ænəməl, wʌn ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə bi ʃʊɹ ə bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz dʌn. ðeɪ hæd swɔɹn tə oʊbeɪ ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌt haʊ wəd ðeɪ də oʊbeɪɪŋ pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə? ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ simd ənnætʃɹəl. bʌt bɛɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd, ət list.

Some of the women he was talking about stood not far from the Two Rivers men, shawls looped over their arms. Edarra appeared the eldest of the six Wise Ones impassively watching the two women Neald had nodded to. In truth, that pair worried Perrin as well. Seonid Traighan, all coolness and reserve in green silk, had been haughtily trying to ignore the Aielwomen - most Cairhienin who were not pretending to be Aiel despised them - but when she saw Perrin, she shifted her bay's reins to the other hand and gave Masuri Sokawa a nudge in the ribs. Masuri started - Browns seemed to go off in daydreams fairly often - stared at the Green sister blankly, then directed her stare at Perrin. This one was more the sort she might have given some peculiar and perhaps dangerous animal, one she intended to be sure of before she was done. They had sworn to obey Rand al'Thor, but how would they do obeying Perrin Aybara? Giving orders to Aes Sedai seemed unnatural. But better than the other way around, at least.

"ɛvɹibɑɾi kʌmz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "lɛts bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ wəɹ sin." feɪl snɪft.

"Everybody comes," Perrin said. "Let's be gone before we are seen." Faile sniffed.

ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil səluɾəd əɡɛn ən stʃɹoʊɾ aʊt tə ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə tʃɹiləs ɛɹiə. pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ aɪdiə wɪtʃ ə ðɛm dɪd wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, bʌt sʌɾənli ðə naʊ-fəmɪljɝ sɪlvɝi vɝɾɪkəl flæʃ ɪn ði ɛɹ ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ɪndə ə ɡeɪtweɪ nɑt kwaɪt tɔl ɪnʌf tə ɹaɪd θɹu. tʃɹiz ʃoʊd bɪɑn ði oʊpənɪŋ, nɑt ðət mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðoʊz ɑn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪlz. ɡɹeɪɾi stʃɹoʊd θɹu ɪmiɾiətli, bʌɾ ivən soʊ hi wɑz nɪɹli nɑk daʊn baɪ səlɪn ən ə smɔl hɔɹɾ ə veɪl meɪɾənz. ðeɪ sim tə hæv teɪkən ði ɑnɝ ə biɪŋ fɝs θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən wɝ nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛɾ ɛniwʌn jusɝp ɪt.

Grady and Neald saluted again and strode out to the middle of the treeless area. Perrin had no idea which of them did what was necessary, but suddenly the now-familiar silvery vertical flash in the air rotated into a gateway not quite tall enough to ride through. Trees showed beyond the opening, not that much different from those on the surrounding hills. Grady strode through immediately, but even so he was nearly knocked down by Sulin and a small horde of veiled Maidens. They seemed to have taken the honor of being first through a gateway for themselves, and were not about to let anyone usurp it.

fɔɹsiɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd pɹɑbləmz i hæd nɑt θɔɾ ʌv, pɛɹɪn lɛd stɛpɝ θɹu ɪndə ə lænd nɑt soʊ hɪli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ klɪɹɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ θɪkli tʃɹiɾ əz ðə hɑloʊ bæk ɪn kɛɹhin, iðɝ. ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz wɝ tɔlɝ, bʌt dʒʌst əz sɪɹ, ivən ðə paɪnz. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mʌtʃ ɛls ɪksɛp fəɹ oʊk ən lɛðɝlif. ði ɛɹ simd ə lɪɾəl hɑɾɝ.

Foreseeing a hundred problems he had not thought of, Perrin led Stepper through into a land not so hilly. There was no clearing, but it was not so thickly treed as the hollow back in Cairhien, either. The scattered trees were taller, but just as sere, even the pines. He did not recognize much else except for oak and leatherleaf. The air seemed a little hotter.

feɪl fɑloʊd hɪm, bʌt wən i tɝn tə ðə lɛft, ʃi tʊk swɑloʊ ɹaɪt. ɛɹæmz hɛd swʌŋ wɝidli bɪtwin əm əntɪl pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ɪz waɪf. ðə wʌntaɪm tɪŋkɝ hɔld ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ æftɝ hɝ, bʌt kwɪk əz i wɑz, hi wɑz nɑt bɪfɔɹ beɪn ən kiæd, stɪl veɪld, ænd, fəɹ ɔl pɛɹɪnz ɔɹɾɝz ðət ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ tə bi nɛkst, sɛlən ən ə ɡʊd tu dʌzən jʌŋ kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ dʒɹɔɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əlɔŋ. tu dʌzən! ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, pɛɹɪn stɑp bɪsaɪd ɡɹeɪɾi, hu tɝn ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə spɑɹs wʊdlænd.

Faile followed him, but when he turned to the left, she took Swallow right. Aram's head swung worriedly between them until Perrin nodded toward his wife. The onetime Tinker hauled his gelding after her, but quick as he was, he was not before Bain and Chiad, still veiled, and, for all Perrin's orders that the Two Rivers men were to be next, Selande and a good two dozen young Cairhienin and Tairens poured out of the gateway drawing their horses along. Two dozen! Shaking his head, Perrin stopped beside Grady, who turned this way and that, studying the sparse woodland.

ɡɔl keɪm stɔkɪŋ ʌp əz dænɪl faɪnəli bɪɡæn liɾɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn aʊɾ əɾ ə ɹʌn, pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ðoʊz blʌɾi bænɝz əpɪɹd ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn dænɪl, ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ klɪɹ. ðə mæn ɔt tə ʃeɪv ðoʊz ful mʌstæʃɪz.

Gaul came stalking up as Dannil finally began leading the Two Rivers men out at a run, pulling their horses. Those bloody banners appeared right behind Dannil, going up as soon as they were clear. The man ought to shave those fool mustaches.

"wɪmən ɑɹ bɪɑn ɛni bɪlif," ɡɔl mʌɾɝd.

"Women are beyond any belief," Gaul muttered.

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə dɪfɛn feɪl bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd ɪt mʌs bi beɪn ən kiæd ðə mæn wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ æt. tə kʌvɝ, hi sɛd, "du juv ə waɪf, ɡɹeɪɾi?"

Perrin opened his mouth to defend Faile before he realized it must be Bain and Chiad the man was glaring at. To cover, he said, "Do you have a wife, Grady?"

"sɔɹə," ɡɹeɪɾi ænsɝɾ æbsənli, hɪz ətɛnʃən stɪl ɑn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn wʊɾə weɪdʒɝɾ i hɛl ðə paʊɝ naʊ, fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ɛniwʌn kəd si ə lɔŋ weɪ ɪn ðɪs, kəmpɛɹd tə ɛni wʊdz bæk hoʊm, bʌt sʌmwʌn kəd stɪl snik ʌp ɑn ju. "ʃiz mɪsɪŋ mi," ɡɹeɪɾi wɛn ɑn, ɔlmoʊs tə hɪmsɛlf. "ju lɝn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət wʌn ɹaɪɾ ɔf. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu waɪ hɝ ni hɝts, ðoʊ."

"Sora," Grady answered absently, his attention still on the surrounding trees. Perrin would have wagered he held the Power now, for sure. Anyone could see a long way in this, compared to any woods back home, but someone could still sneak up on you. "She's missing me," Grady went on, almost to himself. "You learn to recognize that one right off. I wish I knew why her knee hurts, though."

"hɝ ni hɝts," pɛɹɪn sɛd flætli. "ɹaɪt ðɪs mɪnət, ɪt hɝts."

"Her knee hurts," Perrin said flatly. "Right this minute, it hurts."

ɡɹeɪɾi sim tə ɹilaɪz i wɑz stɛɹɪŋ, ən ɡɔl wɑz tu. hi blɪŋkt, bʌt wɛn ɹaɪt bæk tə hɪz stʌɾi. "fɝɡɪv mi, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. aɪ nid tə kip ə wɑtʃ." fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən i sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ðən bɪɡæn sloʊli, "ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ə fɛloʊ neɪm kænlɝ wɝkt aʊt. ðə l dʌzn laɪk əs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt θɪŋz ɑn əɹ oʊn, bʌt wʌns ɪt wɑz dʌn. . . ." hɪz slaɪt ɡɹɪmɑs sɛd pɝhæps teɪm hæd nɑt bɪn ɔl ðəɾ izi əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ivən ðɛn. "wi θɪŋk meɪbi ɪts sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðə bɑn bɪtwin wɔɹɾɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. meɪbi wʌn ɪn θɹi ʌv əs ɪz mɛɹid; ɛniweɪ, ðæts haʊ mɛni waɪvz steɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf wən ðeɪ lɝnd wʌt ðɛɹ hʌzbənz wɝ. ðɪs weɪ, wən jəɹ əpɑɹt fɹəm hɝ, jə noʊ ʃiz ɔl ɹaɪt, ən ʃi noʊz jə ɑɹ. ə mæn laɪks tə noʊ hɪz waɪfs seɪf."

Grady seemed to realize he was staring, and Gaul was too. He blinked, but went right back to his study. "Forgive me, Lord Perrin. I need to keep a watch." For a long moment he said nothing, then began slowly, "It's something a fellow named Canler worked out. The M'Hael doesn't like us trying to figure out things on our own, but once it was done. . . ." His slight grimace said perhaps Taim had not been all that easy about it even then. "We think maybe it's something like the bond between Warders and Aes Sedai. Maybe one in three of us is married; anyway, that's how many wives stayed instead of running off when they learned what their husbands were. This way, when you're apart from her, you know she's all right, and she knows you are. A man likes to know his wife's safe."

"ðæɾ i dʌz," pɛɹɪn sɛd. wʌt wɑz feɪl ʌp tə wɪð ðoʊz fulz? ʃi wɑz maʊntəɾ ɑn swɑloʊ naʊ, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stændɪŋ kloʊs ɝaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət hɝ. hi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst əɹ tə lip ɪndə ðɪs dʒiɾoʊ nɑnsɛns hɝsɛlf.

"That he does," Perrin said. What was Faile up to with those fools? She was mounted on Swallow now, and they were all standing close around, looking up at her. He would not put it past her to leap into this ji'e'toh nonsense herself.

siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi ɡlaɪɾɪd bɪhaɪn ðə læst ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɪð ðə θɹi wɔɹɾɝz ðeɪ hæd bɪtwin ðɛm, ən ðə waɪz wʌnz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm, wɪtʃ wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz. ðeɪ wɝ əlɔŋ tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. siɑnɪd ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz əz ɪf tə maʊnt, bʌɾ ɛdʒɹə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə fæt lɑpsaɪɾɪd oʊk, ən ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊkt ət hɝ, hɛdz swɪvəlɪŋ əz wʌn, ðən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz ən lɛd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tə ðə tʃɹi. mæɾɝz wəd ɡoʊ ə dil smuðɝ ɪf ðət pɛɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz soʊ mik - wɛl, nɑt mik ɪɡzækli; siɑnɪdz nɛk wɑz stɪf əz ə ɹɑd.

Seonid and Masuri glided behind the last of the Two Rivers men with the three Warders they had between them, and the Wise Ones right behind them, which was no surprise. They were along to keep an eye on the Aes Sedai. Seonid gathered her reins as if to mount, but Edarra said something in a low voice, pointing to a fat lopsided oak, and the two Aes Sedai looked at her, heads swiveling as one, then exchanged glances and led their horses to the tree. Matters would go a deal smoother if that pair was always so meek - well, not meek exactly; Seonid's neck was stiff as a rod.

æftɝ ðət keɪm ðə ɹimaʊns, ə hɝɾ ə spɛɹ hɔɹsəz taɪd tɛn tə ə lɛd, ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ə foʊk fɹəm dɑbɹeɪnz ɪsteɪts u səpoʊzədli nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊt. pɛɹɪn ɔɾəmætɪkli pɪkt aʊt steɪɝ, ɑn ə lɛd baɪ hɪmsɛlf; ðə wʊmən teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə hɪm bɛɾɝ noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni haɪ-wil səplaɪ kɑɹts keɪm θɹu, dʒɹaɪvɝz tʌɡɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ fɪɹd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ maɪt kloʊz ɑn əm - ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni kəz kɑɹts kəd nɑt kæɹi əz mʌtʃ əz wæɡənz, ən kɑɹts kəz ə wæɡən ən tim wəd nɑt fɪt θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪt sim niðɝ nil nɔɹ ɡɹeɪɾi kəd meɪk wʌn əz bɪɡ əz ɹænd kʊd, əɹ dæʃivə.
