After that came the remounts, a herd of spare horses tied ten to a lead, under the watchful eyes of folk from Dobraine's estates who supposedly knew what they were about. Perrin automatically picked out Stayer, on a lead by himself; the woman taking care of him better know what she was doing. A great many high-wheeled supply carts came through, drivers tugging the horses and shouting as if they feared the gateway might close on them - a great many because carts could not carry as much as wagons, and carts because a wagon and team would not fit through the gateway. It seemed neither Neald nor Grady could make one as big as Rand could, or Dashiva.

wən ðə læs kɑɹt faɪnəli tʃɹʌndəld aʊɾ ɑn ə skwilɪŋ æksəl, pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝd ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊzd ɹaɪt ðɛn, bʌt nild wɑz ðə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ðə θɪŋ oʊpən, ən ɪm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ɪt bæk ɪn kɛɹhin. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

When the last cart finally trundled out on a squealing axle, Perrin considered ordering the gateway closed right then, but Neald was the man holding the thing open, and him on the other side of it back in Cairhien. A moment later, it was too late.

bɹəleɪn stʃɹoʊd θɹu liɾɪŋ ə mɛɹ əz waɪɾ əz swɑloʊ wɑz blæk, ən i ɔfɝɾ ʌp smɔl θæŋks ðəɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs hæɾ ə nɛk ɹaɪt tə hɝ tʃɪn. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, fɹəm ðə weɪst ʌp, ɪt fɪɾ əz snʌɡli əz ɛni tæɹɑbənɝ dʒɹɛs. pɛɹɪn ɡɹoʊnd. wɪð əɹ keɪm nɹɛl ən bɝteɪn ɡælɛn, ðə lɔɹd kæptən ə hɝ wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd fɛloʊ hu wɔɹ ɪz ɹɛɾ aɪpætʃ əz ənʌðɝ mæn maɪɾ ə plum ɪn ɪz hæt, ən ðən ðə ɹɛd-ɑɹmɝd wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz ðɛmsɛlvz, mɔɹ ðən naɪn hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm. nɹɛl ən ðə ɹɛst u hæd bɪn ət dəməaɪz wɛlz wɔɹ ə jɛloʊ kɔɹd taɪd haɪ ɑn ðə lɛft ɑɹm.

Berelain strode through leading a mare as white as Swallow was black, and he offered up small thanks that her gray riding dress had a neck right to her chin. On the other hand, from the waist up, it fit as snugly as any Taraboner dress. Perrin groaned. With her came Nurelle and Bertain Gallenne, the Lord Captain of her Winged Guards, a gray-haired fellow who wore his red eyepatch as another man might a plume in his hat, and then the red-armored Winged Guards themselves, more than nine hundred of them. Nurelle and the rest who had been at Dumai's Wells wore a yellow cord tied high on the left arm.

klaɪmɪŋ ɑntu hɝ mɛɹ, bɹəleɪn ɹoʊɾ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd wɪð ɡælɛn waɪl nɹɛl fɔɹm ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn fɪfti peɪsɪz bɪtwin əɹ ən feɪl, ən dʌzənz ə tʃɹiz, bʌt ʃi pleɪs hɝsɛlf wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd stɛɹ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. stɛɹ wɪð soʊ lɪɾəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ðət pɛɹɪnz skɪn kɹɔld. pʊɾɪŋ bɹəleɪn ət ðə ɹɪɹ, əz fɑɹ fɹəm feɪl əz i kəd mænədʒ, hæd simd ə ɡʊd noʊʃən, bʌɾ i wɑz gɑnə feɪs ðɪs ɛvɹi blʌɾi ivnɪŋ. bɝn ɹænd!

Climbing onto her mare, Berelain rode off to one side with Gallenne while Nurelle formed the Winged Guards among the trees. There must have been fifty paces between her and Faile, and dozens of trees, but she placed herself where they could stare at each other. Stare with so little expression that Perrin's skin crawled. Putting Berelain at the rear, as far from Faile as he could manage, had seemed a good notion, but he was going to face this every bloody evening. Burn Rand!

naʊ nil pɑpt aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs mʌstæʃ ən pɹinɪŋ fəɹ ɛniwʌn u maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ əz ði oʊpənɪŋ vænɪʃt. noʊ wʌn wɑz, ən i klaɪmd ɑntu hɪz hɔɹs wɪð ə dɪsɡɹʌntəld ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Now Neald popped out of the gateway, stroking his ridiculous mustache and preening for anyone who might be watching as the opening vanished. No one was, and he climbed onto his horse with a disgruntled expression.

maʊntɪŋ stɛpɝ, pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd tə ə slaɪt ɹaɪz. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd si hɪm kəz ə ðə tʃɹiz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf ðeɪ kəd hɪɹ. ə stɝ ɹæn θɹu ði əsɛmblədʒ əz i ɹeɪn ɪn, pipəl ʃɪftɪŋ fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ lʊk.

Mounting Stepper, Perrin rode to a slight rise. Not everyone could see him because of the trees, but it was enough they could hear. A stir ran through the assemblage as he reined in, people shifting for a better look.

"æz fɑɹ əz ɛniwʌnz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz bæk ɪn kɛɹhin noʊ," hi sɛd laʊdli, "aɪv bɪn bænɪʃt, ðə fɝst ə min ɪz ɑn əɹ weɪ bæk hoʊm, ən ðə ɹɛst ə juv dʒʌs dɪsəpɪɹd laɪk fɑɡ ɪn ðə sʌn."

"As far as anyone's eyes-and-ears back in Cairhien know," he said loudly, "I've been banished, the First of Mayene is on her way back home, and the rest of you have just disappeared like fog in the sun."

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ðeɪ læft. ə kɹaɪ ʌv "pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldən-aɪz" wɛn ʌp, ən nɑt dʒʌs fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk. hi weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪt tə kwaɪət; ðət tʊk ə waɪl. feɪl niðɝ læf nɔɹ ʃaʊɾəd, nɔɹ dɪd bɹəleɪn. itʃ wʊmən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; niðɝ bɪlivd i ʃəd tɛl əz mʌtʃ əz i ɪntɛndəd tə. ðən ðeɪ sɔ itʃ ʌðɝ, ən ðoʊz ʃeɪkɪŋ hɛdz fɹoʊz əz ɪf tʃɹæpt ɪn æmbɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk əɡɹiɪŋ. ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz wən ðɛɹ aɪz swʌŋ tə hɪm wɪð aɪdɛntɪkəl ɪkspɹɛʃənz. ðəɹ wɑz ən oʊl seɪɪŋ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðoʊ haʊ jə sɛɾ ɪɾ ən wʌt jə mɛn dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn sɝkəmstæns ən u jə wɝ. "ɪts ɔlweɪz ə mænz fɔlt." wʌn θɪŋ, hi hæd lɝnd, wɪmən wɝ bɛɾɝ ət ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls: titʃɪŋ ə mæn tə saɪ.

To his surprise, they laughed. A cry of "Perrin Golden-eyes" went up, and not just from the Two Rivers folk. He waited for it to quiet; that took a while. Faile neither laughed nor shouted, nor did Berelain. Each woman shook her head; neither believed he should tell as much as he intended to. Then they saw each other, and those shaking heads froze as if trapped in amber. They did not like agreeing. It was no surprise when their eyes swung to him with identical expressions. There was an old saying in the Two Rivers, though how you said it and what you meant depended on circumstance and who you were. "It's always a man's fault." One thing, he had learned, women were better at than anything else: teaching a man to sigh.

"sʌm ə jə meɪ bi wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ wi ɑɹ, ən waɪ," hi wɛn ɑn wən saɪləns fɛl ət læst. ə smɔlɝ ɹɪpəl ə læftɝ. "ðɪs ɪz ɡildən." mɝmɝz ʌv ɑ, ən meɪbi dɪsbɪlif, ət hævɪŋ kɹɔs fɪftin hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əɹ mɔɹ ɪn ə stɛp. "ðə fɝs θɪŋ wɪv tə də ɪz kənvɪns kwin æliændɝ wi ɑɹən hɪɹ tə ɪnveɪd." bɹəleɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə tɔk tə æli-ɑndʒɹeɪ, ən feɪl wɑz gɑnə ɡɪv ɪm fɪts fəɹ ɪt. "ðɛn wɝ gɑnə faɪn ə fɛloʊ hu kɔlz hɪmsɛlf ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." ðət wəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ plɛʒɝ, iðɝ; mæsimə hæd bɪn noʊ dʒɔɪ bɪfɔɹ i tɪpt oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. "ðɪs pɹɑfəɾ əz bɪn kɑzɪŋ səm pɹɑbləmz, bʌt wɝ gɑnə lɛɾ ɪm noʊ ɹænd ælθɹ dʌznt wɑn ɛnibəɾi fɹaɪɾənd ɪndə fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm, ən wɪl teɪk ɪm ən ɛni ʌv ɪz pipəl u wɑnə kʌm bæk tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." ən wɪl fɹaɪɾən ðə bɹitʃɪz ɔf mæsimə tə də ɪɾ ɪf nid bi, hi ðoʊ ɹaɪli.

"Some of you may be wondering where we are, and why," he went on when silence fell at last. A smaller ripple of laughter. "This is Ghealdan." Murmurs of awe, and maybe disbelief, at having crossed fifteen hundred miles or more in a step. "The first thing we have to do is convince Queen Alliandre we aren't here to invade." Berelain was supposed to talk to Alli-andre, and Faile was going to give him fits for it. "Then we're going to find a fellow who calls himself the Prophet of the Lord Dragon." That would not be much pleasure, either; Masema had been no joy before he tipped over the edge. "This Prophet has been causing some problems, but we're going to let him know Rand al'Thor doesn't want anybody frightened into following him, and we'll take him and any of his people who want to come back to the Lord Dragon." And we'll frighten the breeches off Masema to do it if need be, he though wryly.

ðeɪ tʃɪɹd. ðeɪ wupt ən ʃaʊɾəd ðət ðeɪ wəd mɑɹtʃ ðɪs pɹɑfət bæk tə kɛɹhin fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən tɪl pɛɹɪn hoʊp ðɪs spɑt wɑz ivən fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ɛni vɪlədʒ ðən ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə bi. ivən ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz ən hɔɹs hænlɝz dʒɔɪn ɪn. mɔɹ ðən ðæt, hi pɹeɪd ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛn smuðli, ən kwɪkli. ðə sunɝ i kəd pʊɾ əz mʌtʃ dɪstəns əz pɑsəbəl bɪtwin bɹəleɪn ən hɪmsɛlf ən feɪl, ðə bɛɾɝ. noʊ sɝpɹaɪzəz, ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wɑntəd wʌns ðeɪ ɹoʊd saʊθ. ɪt wɑz əbaʊt taɪm ɪz biɪŋ tɑvɝən ʃoʊɾ ɪtsɛlf ɡʊd fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ.

They cheered. They whooped and shouted that they would march this Prophet back to Cairhien for the Lord Dragon till Perrin hoped this spot was even farther from any village than it was supposed to be. Even the cart drivers and horse handlers joined in. More than that, he prayed that everything went smoothly, and quickly. The sooner he could put as much distance as possible between Berelain and himself and Faile, the better. No surprises, that was what he wanted once they rode south. It was about time his being ta'veren showed itself good for something.


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz


Bread and Cheese

mæt nu hi wɑz ɪn tʃɹʌbəl fɹəm ðə deɪ hi muvd ɪndə ðə tɛɹə-sɪn pæləs. hi kəɾ əv ɹəfjuzd. dʒʌs kəz ðə fleɪmɪŋ daɪs stɑɹɾəd əɹ stɑp dɪd nɑt min i hæd tə də ɛniθɪŋ; juʒəwəli wən ðeɪ stɑp spɪnɪŋ, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt nɑt tə də sʌmθɪŋ. ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz, hi wɑntəd tə noʊ waɪ. bɪfɔɹ vɛɹi mɛni deɪz, hi wɪʃt i hæd teɪkən ɪz kjʊɹiɑsəɾi baɪ ðə θɹoʊɾ ən θɹɑɾəld ɪt.

Mat knew he was in trouble from the day he moved into the Tara-sin Palace. He could have refused. Just because the flaming dice started or stopped did not mean he had to do anything; usually when they stopped spinning, it was too late not to do something. The problem was, he wanted to know why. Before very many days, he wished he had taken his curiosity by the throat and throttled it.

æftɝ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn lɛft ɪz ɹum, wʌns i kəd mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ ɪz fit wɪθaʊɾ ɪz hɛd fɔlɪŋ ɔf, hi spɹɛd ðə wɝɾ əmʌŋ ɪz mɛn. noʊbɑdi sim tə si ðə dɪsədvæntɪdʒɪz. hi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə pɹipɛɹ ðɛm, bʌt noʊbɑdi lɪsənd.

After Nynaeve and Elayne left his room, once he could manage to reach his feet without his head falling off, he spread the word among his men. Nobody seemed to see the disadvantages. He just wanted to prepare them, but nobody listened.

"vɛɹi ɡʊd, maɪ lɔɹd," nɹɪm mɝmɝd, tʌɡɪŋ mæts buɾ ɑntu hɪz fʊt. "maɪ lɔɹd wɪl faɪnəli hæv disən ɹumz. oʊ, vɛɹi ɡʊd." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi sim tə luz ɪz mɔɹnfəl ɪkspɹɛʃən. fəɹ dʒʌst ə moʊmənt. "aɪ wɪl bɹʌʃ ðə ɹɛd sɪlk koʊt fəɹ maɪ lɔɹd; maɪ lɔɹɾ əz steɪn ðə blu ɹæðɝ bædli wɪð waɪn." mæt weɪɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli, pʊɾ ɑn ðə koʊt, ən hɛɾəd daʊn ðə hɔl.

"Very good, my Lord," Nerim murmured, tugging Mat's boot onto his foot. "My Lord will finally have decent rooms. Oh, very good." For a moment, he seemed to lose his mournful expression. For just a moment. "I will brush the red silk coat for my Lord; my Lord has stained the blue rather badly with wine." Mat waited impatiently, put on the coat, and headed down the hall.

"ɛɛs sədaɪ?" neɪlzin mʌɾɝd əz ɪz hɛd pɑpt aʊɾ ət ðə tɑp ʌv ə klin ʃɝt. hɪz ɹaʊnd-bɛlid mænsɝvənt, ləpɪn, wɑz hʌvɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. "bɝn maɪ soʊl, aɪ doʊn mʌtʃ laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt. . . . ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, mæt." mæt wɪnst; bæɾ ɪnʌf ðə mæn kəd dʒɹɪŋk ə bæɹəl ə bɹændi wɪð noʊ ɪfɛk ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌt dɪɾ i hæv tə ɡɹɪn soʊ? "ɑ, mæt, naʊ wi kən fɝɡɛt daɪs, ən pleɪ kɑɹdz wɪð əɹ oʊn kaɪnd." hi mɛnt noʊbəlz, ði oʊnli wʌnz u kəɾ əfɔɹd tə pleɪ ɪksɛp fəɹ wɛl-tə-du mɝtʃəns u wəd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn wɛl-tə-du lɔŋ ɪf ðeɪ bɪɡæn bɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə steɪks noʊbəlz dɪd. neɪlzin ɹʌbd ɪz hænz bɹɪskli waɪl ləpɪn tʃɹaɪd tə sɛɾəl ɪz leɪsəz; ivən ɪz bɪɹd simd iɡɝ. "sɪlk ʃits," hi mɝmɝd. huɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sɪlk ʃits? ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz nʌdʒd, bʌt mæt ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən.

"Aes Sedai?" Nalesean muttered as his head popped out at the top of a clean shirt. His round-bellied manservant, Lopin, was hovering behind him. "Burn my soul, I don't much like Aes Sedai, but. . . . The Tarasin Palace, Mat." Mat winced; bad enough the man could drink a barrel of brandy with no effect the next morning, but did he have to grin so? "Ah, Mat, now we can forget dice, and play cards with our own kind." He meant nobles, the only ones who could afford to play except for well-to-do merchants who would not remain well-to-do long if they began betting for the stakes nobles did. Nalesean rubbed his hands briskly while Lopin tried to settle his laces; even his beard seemed eager. "Silk sheets," he murmured. Whoever heard of silk sheets? Those old memories nudged, but Mat refused to listen.

"fʊl ə noʊbəlz," veɪnɪn ɡɹaʊl daʊnstɛɹz, pɝsɪŋ ɪz lɪps tə spɪt. hɪz ɡlæns sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɑz ɔɾəmætɪk naʊ; hi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪnstɛd tə swɑloʊ fɹəm ðə mʌɡ ʌv ɹʌf waɪn ðət wɑz ɪz bɹɛkfəst. "bi ɡʊd tə si ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn əɡɛn, ðoʊ," hi mjuzd. hɪz fɹi hæn ɹoʊz əz ɪf tə nʌkəl ɪz fɔɹhɛd; hi dɪd nɑt sim əwɛɹ ə ðə dʒɛstʃɝ. mæt ɡɹoʊnd. ðət wʊmən hæd ɹuən ə ɡʊd mæn. "ju wɑn mi tə lʊk ɪn ɑn kæɹaɪɾɪn əɡɛn?" veɪnɪn wɛn ɑn əz ɪf ðə ɹɛst wɑz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. "hɪz stʃɹits soʊ fʊl ə bɛɡɝz, ɪts hɑɹd tə si ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt hiz ən ɑfəl lɑɾ ə foʊk kʌm tə kɔl." mæt toʊld ɪm ðət wəd bi faɪn. noʊ wʌndɝ veɪnɪn dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ðə pæləs wɑz fʊl ə noʊbəlz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ; hi wəd spɛn ðə deɪ swɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn ən dʒɑsəl baɪ ðə kɹaʊdz. mʌtʃ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl.

"Full of nobles," Vanin growled downstairs, pursing his lips to spit. His glance searching for Mistress Anan was automatic now; he decided instead to swallow from the mug of rough wine that was his breakfast. "Be good to see the Lady Elayne again, though," he mused. His free hand rose as if to knuckle his forehead; he did not seem aware of the gesture. Mat groaned. That woman had ruined a good man. "You want me to look in on Carridin again?" Vanin went on as if the rest was unimportant. "His street's so full of beggars, it's hard to see anything, but he has an awful lot of folk come to call." Mat told him that would be fine. No wonder Vanin did not care whether the palace was full of nobles and Aes Sedai; he would spend the day sweating in the sun and jostled by the crowds. Much more comfortable.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɔɹn hɑɹnən ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, ɔl ʃʌvlɪŋ daʊn waɪt pɔɹədʒ ən taɪni blæk sɔsɪdʒɪz waɪl ðeɪ nʌdʒd wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə ɹɪbz ən læft əbaʊt ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɪn ðə pæləs, hu, ðeɪ hæd hɝd, wɝ ɔl tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðɛɹ bjuɾi ən ɹɪmɑɹkəbli fɹi wɪð ðɛɹ feɪvɝz. ə tʃɹu fækt, ðeɪ kɛpt əʃʊɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

There was no point trying to warn Harnan and the rest of the Redarms, all shoveling down white porridge and tiny black sausages while they nudged one another in the ribs and laughed about the serving women in the palace, who, they had heard, were all chosen for their beauty and remarkably free with their favors. A true fact, they kept assuring themselves.

θɪŋz dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ɛni bɛɾɝ wən i wɛn ɪndə ðə kɪtʃənz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən tə sɛɾəl ðə bɪl. kɛɹə wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌt wɪð ɔl əɹ bæd tɛmpɝ ə ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ dʌbəld; ʃi stʌk aʊɾ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ət hɪm, ən stɔkt aʊt ðə dɔɹ tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd ɹʌbɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɝ skɝt. meɪbi ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf ɪndə səm mɪzɝi əɹ ʌðɝ, bʌt haʊ ʃi kəd bleɪm mæt kɔθən wɑz bɪɑn hɪm.

Things did not get any better when he went into the kitchens searching for Mistress Anan to settle the bill. Caira was there, but with all her bad temper of the night before doubled; she stuck out her lower lip, glowering at him, and stalked out the door to the stableyard rubbing the back of her skirt. Maybe she had gotten herself into some misery or other, but how she could blame Mat Cauthon was beyond him.

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɑz aʊt, ɪt simd - ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ sup kɪtʃənz fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒiz əɹ lipɪŋ ɪndə səm ʌðɝ ɡʊd wɝk - bʌɾ inɪd wɑz weɪvɪŋ ə lɔŋ wʊɾən spun əɾ əɹ skɝiɪŋ hɛlpɝz ən ɹɛɾi tə teɪk ɪz kɔɪn ɪn əɹ staʊt hænd. "ju skwiz tu mɛni mɛlənz, maɪ jʌŋ lɔɹd, ən jə ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd wən ə ɹɑɾən wʌn bɹeɪks ɪn jəɹ hænd," ʃi sɛd dɑɹkli fəɹ səm ɹizən. "ɔɹ tu," ʃi æɾəd æftɝ ə moʊmənt, nɑɾɪŋ. ʃi lin kloʊs, tɪltɪŋ ʌp əɹ swɛɾɪŋ ɹaʊn feɪs wɪð ən ɪntɛn stɛɹ. "jul oʊnli meɪk tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ jɝsɛlf ɪf jə seɪ ə wɝd. jə woʊnt." ðət dɪd nɑt saʊn laɪk ə kwɛstʃən.

Mistress Anan was out, it seemed - she was always organizing soup kitchens for refugees or leaping into some other good work - but Enid was waving a long wooden spoon at her scurrying helpers and ready to take his coin in her stout hand. "You squeeze too many melons, my young Lord, and you shouldn't be surprised when a rotten one breaks in your hand," she said darkly for some reason. "Or two," she added after a moment, nodding. She leaned close, tilting up her sweating round face with an intent stare. "You'll only make trouble for yourself if you say a word. You won't." That did not sound like a question.

"nɑɾ ə wɝd," mæt sɛd. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz ʃi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt? ɪt sim ðə ɹaɪt ɹɪspɑns, ðoʊ, kəz ʃi nɑɾəd ən wɑɾəld əweɪ weɪvɪŋ ðət spun twaɪs əz vɪɡɝəsli əz bɪfɔɹ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi hæd θɔt ʃi mɛn tə θʌmp ɪm wɪð ɪt. ðə pjʊɹ tʃɹuθ wɑz, wɪmən ɔl hæɾ ə vaɪələn stʃɹik, nɑt dʒʌst səm ə ðɛm.

"Not a word," Mat said. What in the Light was she talking about? It seemed the right response, though, because she nodded and waddled away waving that spoon twice as vigorously as before. For a moment, he had thought she meant to thump him with it. The pure truth was, women all had a violent streak, not just some of them.

wʌn θɪŋ ən ənʌðɝ, ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif wən nɹɪm ən ləpɪn ɡɑɾ ɪndə ə ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ oʊvɝ huz mæstɝz bæɡədʒ wəd bi kæɹiɾ oʊvɝ fɝst. smuðɪŋ ðɛɹ fɛðɝz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə ɡʊd hæf ən aʊɝ fɹəm ɪm ən neɪlzin boʊθ. ə mænsɝvənt wɪð ɪz dændɝ ɹʌfəl kəd meɪk jəɹ laɪf mɪzɝəbəl. ðən i hæd tə sɛɾəl wɪtʃ ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wɝ tə hæv ði ɑnɝ ə lʌɡɪŋ ðə tʃɛst ʌv ɡoʊld əkɹɔs ən wɪtʃ wɝ tə teɪk ðə hɔɹsəz. ɛniweɪ, ɪt wɑz ðət mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə blʌɾi tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs.

One thing and another, it was a relief when Nerim and Lopin got into a shouting match over whose master's baggage would be carried over first. Smoothing their feathers required a good half an hour from him and Nalesean both. A manservant with his dander ruffled could make your life miserable. Then he had to settle which of the Redarms were to have the honor of lugging the chest of gold across and which were to take the horses. Anyway, it was that much longer outside the bloody Tarasin Palace.

wʌns i wɑz ɪnskɑnst ɪn ɪz nu ɹumz, ðoʊ, hi ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑt tʃɹʌbəlz ət fɝst. hi hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ən ə smɔl, wʌt ðeɪ kɔld ə sʌlkɪŋ ɹum hɪɹəbaʊts, ən ən ɪmɛns bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ðə bɪɡəs bɛɾ i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ðə mæsɪv bɪdpoʊsts kɑɹvd wɪð ɛntwaɪn flaʊɝz ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ən peɪntəd ɹɛd. moʊst ə ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ wɑz bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ əɹ bɹaɪt blu, wɛɹ ɪt wɑz nɑt leɪɝd wɪð ɡɪlt. ə smɔl dɔɹ nɪɹ ðə bɛd lɛd tə ə kɹæmpt ɹum fəɹ nɹɪm, wɪtʃ ðə fɛloʊ sim tə θɪŋk wɑz ɛksələn dɪspaɪɾ ə nɛɹoʊ bɛɾ ən noʊ wɪndoʊ. mæts ɹumz ɔl hæd tɔl ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz lɛɾɪŋ ɑntu waɪt ɹɔt-aɪɝn bælkəniz ðəɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðə mɔl hɛɹə. ðə stænd-læmps wɝ ɡɪldɪd, ən soʊ wɝ ðə mɪɹɝ fɹeɪmz; ðəɹ wɝ tu mɪɹɝz ɪn ðə sʌlkɪŋ ɹum, θɹi ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ən fɔɹ ɪn ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ðə klɑk - ə klɑk! - ɑn ðə mɑɹbəl mæntəl əbʌv ðə faɪɝpleɪs ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum spɑɹkəld wɪð ɡɪlt, əz wɛl. ðə wɑʃbeɪsən ən pɪtʃɝ wɝ ɹɛd si foʊk pɔɹsələn. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs dɪsəpɔɪntɪd tə dɪskʌvɝ ðət ðə tʃeɪmbɝ pɑɾ ʌndɝ ðə bɛd wɑz oʊnli pleɪn waɪt pɑɾɝi. ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə ʃɛlf ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɪð ə fʊl dʌzən bʊks. nɑt ðəɾ i ɹɛd mʌtʃ.

Once he was ensconced in his new rooms, though, he almost forgot troubles at first. He had a large sitting room and a small, what they called a sulking room hereabouts, and an immense bedchamber with the biggest bed he had ever seen, the massive bedposts carved with entwined flowers of all things, and painted red. Most of the furniture was bright red or bright blue, where it was not layered with gilt. A small door near the bed led to a cramped room for Nerim, which the fellow seemed to think was excellent despite a narrow bed and no window. Mat's rooms all had tall arched windows letting onto white wrought-iron balconies that overlooked the Mol Hara. The stand-lamps were gilded, and so were the mirror frames; there were two mirrors in the sulking room, three in the sitting room, and four in the bedchamber. The clock - a clock! - on the marble mantel above the fireplace in the sitting room sparkled with gilt, as well. The washbasin and pitcher were red Sea Folk porcelain. He was almost disappointed to discover that the chamber pot under the bed was only plain white pottery. There was even a shelf in the large sitting room with a full dozen books. Not that he read much.

ivən ɡɪvən ðə dʒɑɹɪŋ kʌlɝz ʌv wɔlz ən silɪŋz ən flɔɹ taɪlz, ðə ɹumz ʃaʊɾəd ɹɪtʃ. ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, hi wʊɾə dænst ə dʒɪɡ. ɛni taɪm wən i wɑz nɑɾ əwɛɹ ðəɾ ə wʊmən wɪð tʃeɪmbɝz ɹaɪt daʊn ðə hɔl wɑntəd tə stɪk ɪm ɪn hɑt wɔɾɝ ən pʊɾ ə bɛloʊz tə ðə faɪɝ. ɪf tɛslɪn əɹ mɛɝɪlɪl əɹ wʌn ə ðət lɑt dɪd nɑt mænədʒ ɪt fɝs dɪspaɪɾ ɪz mədæljən. waɪ hæd ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd stɑp tʌmbəlɪŋ əz sun əz ɪleɪn mɛnʃən ðiz blʌɾi ɹumz? kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. hi hæd hɝɾ ə seɪɪŋ ɑn sɛvɹəl wɪmənz lɪps bæk hoʊm, juʒəwəli wən i hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ ðət lʊk fʌn ət ðə taɪm. "mɛn titʃ kæts kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, bʌt kæts kip sɛns fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz."

Even given the jarring colors of walls and ceilings and floor tiles, the rooms shouted rich. Any other time, he would have danced a jig. Any time when he was not aware that a woman with chambers right down the hall wanted to stick him in hot water and put a bellows to the fire. If Teslyn or Merilille or one of that lot did not manage it first despite his medallion. Why had the dice in his head stopped tumbling as soon as Elayne mentioned these bloody rooms? Curiosity. He had heard a saying on several women's lips back home, usually when he had done something that looked fun at the time. "Men teach cats curiosity, but cats keep sense for themselves."

"ɪm noʊ blʌɾi kæt," hi mʌɾɝd, stɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. hi dʒʌs hæd tə noʊ; ðət wɑz ɔl.

"I'm no bloody cat," he muttered, stalking out of the bedchamber into the sitting room. He just had to know; that was all.

"ʌv kɔɹs jəɹ nɑɾ ə kæt," taɪlɪn sɛd. "jɔɹ ə sʌkjəlɪn lɪɾəl dʌklɪŋ, ɪz wʌt jə ɑɹ."

"Of course you're not a cat," Tylin said. "You're a succulent little duckling, is what you are."

mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən stɛɹd. dʌklɪŋ? ən ə lɪɾəl dʌklɪŋ, ət ðæt! ðə wʊmən stʊd wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɪndɪɡneɪʃən əɹ noʊ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, hi mænədʒd ən ɛləɡən baʊ ɛniweɪ. ʃi wɑz ðə kwin; hi hæd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. "mædʒəsti, θæŋk jə fəɹ ðiz wʌndɝfəl əpɑɹtməns. aɪd lʌv tə tɔk wɪð ju, bʌɾ aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ aʊɾ ən - "

Mat gave a start and stared. Duckling? And a little duckling, at that! The woman stood well short of his shoulder. Indignation or no indignation, he managed an elegant bow anyway. She was the Queen; he had to remember that. "Majesty, thank you for these wonderful apartments. I'd love to talk with you, but I have to go out and - "

smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi ədvænst əkɹɔs ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin flɔɹ taɪlz, leɪɝd blu ən waɪt sɪlk pɛɾikoʊts swɪʃɪŋ, lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪm. hi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ əɾ ɔl tə lʊk ət ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf nɛsəld ɪn əɹ dʒɛnɝəs klivədʒ. əɹ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, dʒɛm-stʌɾɪd dæɡɝ θɹʌs bɪhaɪn ən ikwəli dʒɛm-stʌɾɪd bɛlt. hi bækt əweɪ.

Smiling, she advanced across the red-and-green floor tiles, layered blue and white silk petticoats swishing, large dark eyes fixed on him. He had no desire at all to look at the marriage knife nestled in her generous cleavage. Or the larger, gem-studded dagger thrust behind an equally gem-studded belt. He backed away.

"mædʒəsti, aɪ hæv ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt - "

"Majesty, I have an important - "

ʃi stɑɹɾəd hʌmɪŋ. hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə tun; hi hæd hʌmd ɪt tə ə fju ɡɝlz leɪtli. hi wɑz waɪz ɪnʌf nɑt tə tʃɹaɪ æktʃəli  sɪŋɪŋ wɪð ɪz vɔɪs, ən bɪsaɪdz, ðə wɝdz ðeɪ juzd ɪn ɛbu wʊɾə əv sɪŋʒd ɪz ɪɹz. ɝaʊn hɪɹ, ðeɪ kɔld ɪt "aɪ wɪl stil jəɹ bɹɛθ wɪð kɪsəz."

She started humming. He recognized the tune; he had hummed it to a few girls lately. He was wise enough not to try actually singing with his voice, and besides, the words they used in Ebou Dar would have singed his ears. Around here, they called it "I Will Steal Your Breath with Kisses."

læfɪŋ nɝvəsli, hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ə læpəs-ɪnleɪd teɪbəl bɪtwin ðɛm, bʌt ʃi sʌmhaʊ ɡɑɾ ɝaʊn ɪt fɝst wɪθaʊt simɪŋ tə ɪnkɹis əɹ spid. "mædʒəsti, aɪ - "

Laughing nervously, he tried to put a lapis-inlaid table between them, but she somehow got around it first without seeming to increase her speed. "Majesty, I - "

ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn flæɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, bæk-hild ɪm ɪndə ə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ, ən plʌmp hɝsɛlf daʊn ɑn ɪz læp. bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə tʃɛɹ ɑɹmz, hi wɑz tʃɹæpt. oʊ, hi cʊɾə pɪkt əɹ ʌp ən sɛɾ əɹ ɑn əɹ fit kwaɪɾ izəli. ɪksɛp ðət ʃi dɪɾ əv ðət blʌɾi bɪɡ dæɡɝ ɪn əɹ bɛlt, ən i daʊɾɪd ɪz mænhænlɪŋ əɹ wəd bi əz æksɛptəbəl tə hɝ əz əɹ mænhænlɪŋ ɪm sim tə bi. ðɪs wɑz ɛbu dɑɹ, æftɝ ɔl, wɛɹ ə wʊmən kɪlɪŋ ə mæn wɑz dʒʌstəfaɪɾ əntɪl pɹuvən ʌðɝwaɪz. hi cʊɾə pɪkt əɹ ʌp izəli, ɪksɛpt. . . .

She laid a hand flat on his chest, back-heeled him into a high-backed chair, and plumped herself down on his lap. Between her and the chair arms, he was trapped. Oh, he could have picked her up and set her on her feet quite easily. Except that she did have that bloody big dagger in her belt, and he doubted his manhandling her would be as acceptable to her as her manhandling him seemed to be. This was Ebou Dar, after all, where a woman killing a man was justified until proven otherwise. He could have picked her up easily, except. . . .

hi hæd sin fɪʃmɑŋɡɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi sɛlɪŋ pəkjuljɝ kɹitʃɝz kɔl skwɪɾ ən ɑktəpʊs - ɛbu dɑɹi æktʃəli  eɪt ðə θɪŋz! - bʌt ðeɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ ɑn taɪlɪn. ðə wʊmən pəzɛs tɛn hænz. hi θɹæʃt əbaʊt, veɪnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɛn əɹ ɔf, ən ʃi læf sɔfli. bɪtwin kɪsəz, hi bɹɛθləsli pɹətɛstəd ðət sʌmwʌn maɪt wɔk ɪn, ən ʃi dʒʌs tʃʌkəld. hi bæbəld ɪz ɹɪspɛk fəɹ əɹ kɹaʊn, ən ʃi tʃɔɹɾəld. hi kleɪm bɪtʃɹɑθɔl tə ə ɡɝl bæk hoʊm u hɛld ɪz hɑɹɾ ɪn əɹ hænz. ʃi ɹɪli læft ət ðæt.

He had seen fishmongers in the city selling peculiar creatures called squid and octopus - Ebou Dari actually ate the things! - but they had nothing on Tylin. The woman possessed ten hands. He thrashed about, vainly trying to fend her off, and she laughed softly. Between kisses, he breathlessly protested that someone might walk in, and she just chuckled. He babbled his respect for her crown, and she chortled. He claimed betrothal to a girl back home who held his heart in her hands. She really laughed at that.

"wʌt ʃi dʌz nɑt noʊ kænɑt hɑɹm hɝ," ʃi mɝmɝd, hɝ twɛnti hænz nɑt sloʊɪŋ fəɹ ən ɪnstənt.

"What she does not know cannot harm her," she murmured, her twenty hands not slowing for an instant.

sʌmwʌn nɑkt ət ðə dɔɹ.

Someone knocked at the door.

pɹaɪɪŋ ɪz maʊθ fɹi, hi ʃaʊɾəd, "hu ɪz ɪt?" wɛl, ɪt wɑz ə ʃaʊt. ə haɪ-pɪtʃt ʃaʊt. hi wɑz aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ, æftɝ ɔl.

Prying his mouth free, he shouted, "Who is it?" Well, it was a shout. A high-pitched shout. He was out of breath, after all.

taɪlɪn wɑz ɔf ɪz læp ən θɹi peɪsɪz əweɪ soʊ fæst ɪt simd ʃi wɑz dʒʌs hɪɹ ðən ðɛɹ. ðə wʊmən hæd ðə nɝv tə ɡɪv ɪm ə ɹipɹoʊtʃfəl lʊk! ən ðən ʃi meɪɾ ə kɪs ət hɪm.

Tylin was off his lap and three paces away so fast it seemed she was just here then there. The woman had the nerve to give him a reproachful look! And then she made a kiss at him.

ðət bɛɹli lɛft əɹ lɪps bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən tɑm stʌk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn. "mæt? aɪ wɑznt ʃʊɹ ðət wɑz ju. oʊ! mædʒəsti." fəɹ ə skɹɔni oʊld ɡlimən wɪð pɹətɛnʃənz, tɑm kəd flɝɪʃ ə baʊ wɪð ðə bɛst ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪz lɪmp. dʒulɪn kəd nɑt, bʌɾ i snætʃt ɔf ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs ɹɛd hæɾ ən dɪd wʌɾ i kʊd. "fɝɡɪv ʌs. wi woʊn dɪstɝb - " tɑm bɪɡæn, bʌt mæt bɹoʊk ɪn hɝidli.

That barely left her lips before the door opened, and Thom stuck his head in. "Mat? I wasn't sure that was you. Oh! Majesty." For a scrawny old gleeman with pretensions, Thom could flourish a bow with the best in spite of his limp. Juilin could not, but he snatched off his ridiculous red hat and did what he could. "Forgive us. We won't disturb - " Thom began, but Mat broke in hurriedly.

"kʌm ɪn, tɑm!" snætʃɪŋ ɪz koʊt bæk ɔl ðə weɪ ɑn, hi stɑɹɾəd tə stænd, ðən ɹilaɪz ðət sʌmhaʊ ðə blʌɾi wʊmən hæɾ əntaɪd ðə weɪst ə hɪz bɹitʃɪz wɪθaʊɾ ɪm noʊɾɪsɪŋ. ðiz tu maɪt mɪs ðəɾ ɪz ʃɝt wɑz əndʌn tə hɪz bɛli, bʌt ðeɪ wəd nɑt mɪs ɪz bɹitʃɪz fɔlɪŋ ɔf. taɪlɪnz blu dʒɹɛs wɑz nɑt mʌst əɾ ɔl! "dʒulɪn, kʌm ɪn!"

"Come in, Thom!" Snatching his coat back all the way on, he started to stand, then realized that somehow the bloody woman had untied the waist of his breeches without him noticing. These two might miss that his shirt was undone to his belly, but they would not miss his breeches falling off. Tylin's blue dress was not mussed at all! "Juilin, come in!"

"aɪ æm ɡlæd jə faɪn ðə ɹumz æksɛptəbəl, mæstɝ kɔθən," taɪlɪn sɛd, dɪɡnəɾi ɪnkɑɹnət. ɪksɛp fəɹ əɹ aɪz, ɛniweɪ, wən ʃi stʊd soʊ tɑm ən dʒulɪn kəd nɑt si ðɛm. hɝ aɪz leɪst ɪnɑkjuəs wɝdz wɪð æɾəd minɪŋ. "aɪ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə hævɪŋ jəɹ kʌmpəni wɪð plɛʒɝ; aɪ ʃæl faɪn ɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, hævɪŋ ə tɑvɝən wɛɹ aɪ kən ɹitʃ aʊɾ ən tʌtʃ ɪm ət wɪl. bʌɾ aɪ mʌs liv jə tə jəɹ fɹɛnz, naʊ. noʊ, də nɑt stænd; pliz." ðət wɪð dʒʌs ðə hɪn ʌv ə mɑkɪŋ smaɪl.

"I am glad you find the rooms acceptable, Master Cauthon," Tylin said, dignity incarnate. Except for her eyes, anyway, when she stood so Thom and Juilin could not see them. Her eyes laced innocuous words with added meaning. "I look forward to having your company with pleasure; I shall find it interesting, having a ta'veren where I can reach out and touch him at will. But I must leave you to your friends, now. No, do not stand; please." That with just the hint of a mocking smile.

"wɛl, bɔɪ," tɑm sɛd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz wən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, "ðɛɹz lʌk fəɹ ju, biɪŋ wɛlkəmd wɪð oʊpən ɑɹmz baɪ ðə kwin hɝsɛlf." dʒulɪn bɪkeɪm vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɪz kæp.

"Well, boy," Thom said, knuckling his mustaches when she was gone, "there's luck for you, being welcomed with open arms by the Queen herself." Juilin became very interested in his cap.

mæt aɪɾ əm wɛɹəli, mɛntəli dɛɹɪŋ əm tə seɪ ə wɝd mɔɹ - dʒʌst wʌn wɝd! - bʌt wʌns i æskt æftɝ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, hi kwɪt wɝiɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ səspɛktəd. ðə wɪmən wɝ nɑt bæk. hi ɔlmoʊs lɛpt ʌp, bɹitʃɪz əɹ noʊ. ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɪɡəl aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ əɡɹimən ɔlɹɛɾi; hi hæd tə ɪkspleɪn wʌɾ i mɛn ɪn bɪtwin ðɛɹ aʊtbɝsts ʌv ɪnkɹədulɪɾi, ɪn bɪtwin ɪkspɹɛsɪŋ ɪz əpɪnjənz ə nɪneɪiv blʌɾi ɑlmɹə ən ɪleɪn blʌɾi dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. nɑt mʌtʃ tʃæns ðeɪ wʊɾə ɡɔn ɔf tə ðə ɹæhəd wɪθaʊt hɪm, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst əm tə tʃɹaɪ ðɛɹ hæn spaɪɪŋ ɑn kæɹaɪɾɪn. ɪleɪn wəd dɪmæn ə kənfɛʃən ən ɪkspɛk ðə mæn tə bɹeɪk daʊn; nɪneɪiv wəd tʃɹaɪ tə bit wʌn aʊɾ ə hɪm.

Mat eyed them warily, mentally daring them to say a word more - just one word! - but once he asked after Nynaeve and Elayne, he quit worrying what they suspected. The women were not back. He almost leaped up, breeches or no. They were trying to wiggle out of their agreement already; he had to explain what he meant in between their outbursts of incredulity, in between expressing his opinions of Nynaeve bloody al'Meara and Elayne bloody Daughter-Heir. Not much chance they would have gone off to the Rahad without him, but he would not put it past them to try their hand spying on Carridin. Elayne would demand a confession and expect the man to break down; Nynaeve would try to beat one out of him.

"aɪ daʊt ðeɪ ɑɹ bɑðɝɪŋ kæɹaɪɾɪn," dʒulɪn sɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹ. "aɪ bɪliv eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪɾ ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ ə lʊk ət hɪm, fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ hɝd. wi dɪdn si ðɛm ɡoʊ. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk jə nid tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪm noʊɪŋ wʌt hiz siɪŋ ivən ɪf i wɔks ɹaɪt baɪ ðɛm." tɑm, pɔɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə ɡoʊldən ɡɑbləɾ ə ðə waɪn pʌntʃ ðət mæt hæd faʊnd weɪɾɪŋ, tʊk ʌp ði ɛkspləneɪʃən.

"I doubt they are bothering Carridin," Juilin said, scratching behind his ear. "I believe Aviendha and Birgitte are taking a look at him, from what I heard. We didn't see them go. I do not think you need to worry about him knowing what he's seeing even if he walks right by them." Thom, pouring himself a golden goblet of the wine punch that Mat had found waiting, took up the explanation.

mæt pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz. dɪsɡaɪzɪz meɪd wɪð ðə paʊɝ; noʊ wʌndɝ ðeɪ hæd slɪpt əweɪ laɪk sneɪks wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɑntəd. ðoʊz wɪmən wɝ gɑnə meɪk tʃɹʌbəl. ðət wɑz wʌt wɪmən dɪd bɛst. ɪt hɑɹdli sɝpɹaɪzd ɪm tə lɝn ðət tɑm ən dʒulɪn nu lɛs əbaʊt ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ðən i dɪd.

Mat put a hand over his eyes. Disguises made with the Power; no wonder they had slipped away like snakes whenever they wanted. Those women were going to make trouble. That was what women did best. It hardly surprised him to learn that Thom and Juilin knew less about this Bowl of the Winds than he did.

æftɝ ðeɪ lɛf tə ɹɛɾi ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ ə tʃɹɪp tə ðə ɹæhəd, hi hæd taɪm tə sɛɾ ɪz kloʊðz tə ɹaɪts bɪfɔɹ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn keɪm bæk. hi hæd taɪm tə tʃɛk ɑn oʊlvɝ, ɪn ɪz ɹum wʌn flɔɹ daʊn. ðə bɔɪz skɪni fɹeɪm hæd flɛʃt aʊt sʌmwʌt, wɪð inɪɾ ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kʊks ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən stʌfɪŋ hɪm, bʌɾ i wəɾ ɔlweɪz bi ʃɔɹɾ ivən fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, ən ɪf ɪz ɪɹz ʃɹæŋk tə hæf ðɛɹ saɪz ən ɪz maʊθ tə hæf ɪts wɪdθ, hɪz noʊz wəd stɪl stɑp ɪm wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə hænsəm. noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi sɝvɪŋ wɪmən fʌst oʊvɝ ɪm waɪl i sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ɪz bɛd.

After they left to ready themselves for a trip to the Rahad, he had time to set his clothes to rights before Nynaeve and Elayne came back. He had time to check on Olver, in his room one floor down. The boy's skinny frame had fleshed out somewhat, with Enid and the rest of the cooks at The Wandering Woman stuffing him, but he would always be short even for a Cairhienin, and if his ears shrank to half their size and his mouth to half its width, his nose would still stop him well short of handsome. No fewer than three serving women fussed over him while he sat cross-legged on his bed.

"mæt, dʌzn hɛsəl əv ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl aɪz?" oʊlvɝ sɛd, bimɪŋ ət ðə bɪɡ-aɪd jʌŋ wʊmən mæt hæd mɛt ðə læs taɪm i keɪm tə ðə pæləs. ʃi bim bæk ən ɹʌfəl ðə bɔɪz hɛɹ. "oʊ, bʌɾ æləs ən lɔɪə ɑɹ soʊ swit, aɪ kəd nɛvɝ tʃuz." ə plʌmp wʊmən dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ənpækɪŋ oʊlvɝz sæɾəlbæɡz tə ɡɪv ɪm ə bɹɔd ɡɹɪn, ən ə slɛndɝ ɡɝl wɪð bi-stʌŋ lɪps pæɾəd ðə taʊəl ʃi hæd dʒʌs pʊɾ ɑn ɪz wɑʃstænd, ðən flʌŋ hɝsɛlf ɑntu ðə bɛd tə tɪkəl oʊlvɝz ɹɪbz tɪl i fɛl oʊvɝ læfɪŋ hɛlpləsli.

"Mat, doesn't Haesel have the most beautiful eyes?" Olver said, beaming at the big-eyed young woman Mat had met the last time he came to the palace. She beamed back and ruffled the boy's hair. "Oh, but Alis and Loya are so sweet, I could never choose." A plump woman just short of her middle years looked up from unpacking Olver's saddlebags to give him a broad grin, and a slender girl with bee-stung lips patted the towel she had just put on his washstand, then flung herself onto the bed to tickle Olver's ribs till he fell over laughing helplessly.

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. hɑɹnən ən ðət lɑt wɝ bæɾ ɪnʌf, bʌt naʊ ðiz wɪmən wɝ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ðə bɔɪ! haʊ wɑz i ɛvɝ gɑnə lɝn tə bɪheɪv ɪf wɪmən dɪd ðæt? oʊlvɝ ɔt tə bi pleɪɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ tɛn-jɪɹ-oʊld. hi hæd hæd noʊ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən fɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪm ɪn ɪz ɹumz. taɪlɪn hæd sin tə ðæt, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ.

Mat snorted. Harnan and that lot were bad enough, but now these women were encouraging the boy! How was he ever going to learn to behave if women did that? Olver ought to be playing in the streets like any other ten-year-old. He had had no serving women falling over him in his rooms. Tylin had seen to that, he was sure.

hi hæd taɪm tə tʃɛk ɑn oʊlvɝ, ən tə lʊk ɪn ɑn hɑɹnən ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, ʃɛɹɪŋ ə lɔŋ ɹum laɪnd wɪð bɛdz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə steɪbəlz, ən tə sɔntɝ daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃənz fəɹ səm bɹɛɾ ən bif - hi hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə feɪs ðət pɔɹədʒ bæk ət ði ɪn. stɪl nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn hæd nɑt ɹɪtɝnd. hi faɪnəli lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə bʊks ɪn ɪz sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ən bɪɡæn ɹiɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, ðoʊ hi bɛɹli meɪɾ aʊɾ ə wɝd fəɹ wɝiɪŋ. tɑm ən dʒulɪn keɪm ɪn dʒʌst əz ðə wɪmən faɪnəli bʌsəld ɪn ɪkskleɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ faɪndɪŋ ɪm ðɛɹ, əz ɪf ðeɪ θɔɾ i wəd nɑt kip ɪz wɝd.

He had time to check on Olver, and to look in on Harnan and the rest of the Redarms, sharing a long room lined with beds not far from the stables, and to saunter down to the kitchens for some bread and beef - he had not been able to face that porridge back at the inn. Still Nynaeve and Elayne had not returned. He finally looked over the books in his sitting room and began reading The Travels of Jain Farstrider, though he barely made out a word for worrying. Thom and Juilin came in just as the women finally bustled in exclaiming over finding him there, as if they thought he would not keep his word.

hi kloʊz ðə bʊk dʒɛnli, sɛɾ ɪt dʒɛnli ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ. "wɛɹ əv jə bɪn?"

He closed the book gently, set it gently on the table beside his chair. "Where have you been?"

"waɪ, wi wɛn fəɹ ə wɔk," ɪleɪn sɛd bɹaɪtli, blu aɪz waɪɾɝ ðən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd siɪŋ bɪfɔɹ. tɑm fɹaʊn ən pɹədust ə naɪf fɹəm ɪz sliv, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪt bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu hɪz fɪŋɡɝz. hi vɛɹi mɑɹkədli dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns əɾ ɪleɪn.

"Why, we went for a walk," Elayne said brightly, blue eyes wider than he remembered seeing before. Thom frowned and produced a knife from his sleeve, rolling it back and forth through his fingers. He very markedly did not so much as glance at Elayne.

"wi hæd ti wɪð səm wɪmən jəɹ ɪnkipɝ noʊz," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "aɪ woʊn bɔɹ jə wɪð tɔk əbaʊt niɾəlwɝk." dʒulɪn stɑɹɾəd tə ʃeɪk ɪz hɛd, ðən stɑp bɪfɔɹ ʃi noʊɾəst.

"We had tea with some women your innkeeper knows," Nynaeve said. "I won't bore you with talk about needlework." Juilin started to shake his head, then stopped before she noticed.

"pliz, doʊn bɔɹ mi," mæt sɛd dʒɹaɪli. hi səpoʊzd ʃi nu wʌn ɛn ʌv ə niɾəl fɹəm ði ʌðɝ, bʌɾ i səspɛktəd ʃi wəɾ əz sun stɪk wʌn θɹu hɝ tʌŋ əz tɔk əbaʊt niɾəlwɝk. niðɝ wʊmən kɹækt əɹ tiθ əbaʊt səvɪləɾi, kənfɝmɪŋ ɪz wɝs səspɪʃənz. "aɪv toʊld ɔf tu fɛloʊz tə wɔk aʊt wɪð itʃ ə jə ðɪs æftɝnun, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi tu mɔɹ təmɑɹoʊ ən ɛvɹi deɪ. ɪf jəɹ nɑɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə pæləs əɹ ʌndɝ maɪ noʊz, jəl əv bɑɾiɡɑɹdz. ðeɪ noʊ ðɛɹ tɝnz ɔlɹɛɾi. ðəl steɪ wɪð jə əɾ ɔl taɪmz - ɔl taɪmz - ən jəl lemi noʊ wɛɹ jəɹ hɛɾəd. noʊ mɔɹ meɪkɪŋ mi wɝi tɪl maɪ hɛɹ fɔlz aʊt."

"Please, don't bore me," Mat said dryly. He supposed she knew one end of a needle from the other, but he suspected she would as soon stick one through her tongue as talk about needlework. Neither woman cracked her teeth about civility, confirming his worse suspicions. "I've told off two fellows to walk out with each of you this afternoon, and there will be two more tomorrow and every day. If you're not inside the palace or under my nose, you'll have bodyguards. They know their turns already. They'll stay with you at all times - all times - and you will let me know where you're headed. No more making me worry till my hair falls out."

hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən ən ɑɹɡjəmənt. hi ɪkspɛktəd wizəlɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ əɹ hæd nɑt pɹɑməst. hi ɪkspɛktəd ðət dɪmændɪŋ ðɪs hoʊl loʊf maɪt ɡɛɾ ɪm ə slaɪs ət ði ɛnd; ə bʌt slaɪs, ɪf ɪz lʌk wɑz ɪn. nɪneɪiv lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn; ɪleɪn lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv.

He expected indignation and argument. He expected weaseling over what they had or had not promised. He expected that demanding this whole loaf might get him a slice at the end; a butt slice, if his luck was in. Nynaeve looked at Elayne; Elayne looked at Nynaeve.

"waɪ, bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɑɹ ə wʌndɝfəl aɪdiə, mæt," ɪleɪn ɪkskleɪmd, hɝ tʃik dɪmplɪŋ ɪn ə smaɪl. "aɪ səpoʊz jə wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðæt. ɪts vɛɹi smɑɹɾ ə jə tə hæv jəɹ mɛn ɔlɹɛɾi tə ə skɛdʒʊl."

"Why, bodyguards are a wonderful idea, Mat," Elayne exclaimed, her cheek dimpling in a smile. "I suppose you were right about that. It's very smart of you to have your men already to a schedule."

"ɪɾ ɪz ə wʌndɝfəl noʊʃən," nɪneɪiv sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ ɪnθuziæstɪkli. "vɛɹi smɑɹɾ ə ju, mæt."

"It is a wonderful notion," Nynaeve said, nodding enthusiastically. "Very smart of you, Mat."

tɑm dʒɹɑp ðə naɪf wɪð ə mʌfəl kɝs ən sæt sʌkɪŋ ɑn ə nɪk fɪŋɡɝ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɪmən.

Thom dropped the knife with a muffled curse and sat sucking on a nicked finger, staring at the women.

mæt saɪd. tʃɹʌbəl; hi hæd noʊn ɪt. ən ðət wɑz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ toʊld ɪm tə fɝɡɛt ðə ɹæhəd fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ.

Mat sighed. Trouble; he had known it. And that was before they told him to forget the Rahad for the time being.

wɪtʃ wɑz haʊ hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn ə bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə tʃip tævɝn nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝfɹʌn kɔl ðə ɹoʊz ə ði ɪldɑɹ, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ə ðə dɛntɪd tɪn kʌps tʃeɪn tə ðə bɛntʃ. ət lis ðeɪ wɑʃt ðə kʌps aʊt fəɹ itʃ nu peɪtʃɹən. ðə stɪŋk fɹəm ə daɪɝz ʃɑp əkɹɔs ðə weɪ oʊnli ɹeɪz ðə staɪl ə ðə ɹoʊz. nɑt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə ʃæbi neɪbɝhʊd ɹɪli, ðoʊ ðə stʃɹit wɑz tu nɛɹoʊ fəɹ kæɹɪdʒɪz. ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə bɹaɪtli lækɝd sɪdæn tʃɛɹz sweɪd θɹu ðə kɹaʊd. ɪf fɑɹ mɔɹ pæsɝzbi wɔɹ wʊl ən pɝhæps ə ɡɪl vɛs ðən sɪlk, ðə wʊl wɑz əz ɔfən wɛl kʌɾ əz fɹeɪd. ðə haʊsəz ən ʃɑps wɝ ðə juʒəwəl ɝeɪ ʌv waɪt plæstɝ, ən ɪf moʊst wɝ smɔl ən ivən ɹʌn-daʊn, ðə tɔl haʊs ʌv ə wɛlθi mɝtʃən stʊɾ ɑn ə kɔɹnɝ tə hɪz ɹaɪɾ ən ɑn ðə lɛft ə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv pæləs - smɔlɝ ðən ðə mɝtʃəns haʊs, ət list - wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl ɡɹin-bændɪd doʊm ən noʊ spaɪɹ. ə pɛɹ ə tævɝnz ən ən ɪn ɪn pleɪn saɪt lʊkt kul ən ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə ɹoʊz wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn wɛɹ ə mæn kəd sɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, ði oʊnli wʌn ɪn dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt spɑt. ənfɔɹtʃənətli.

Which was how he found himself on a bench in front of a cheap tavern not far from the riverfront called The Rose of the Eldar, drinking from one of the dented tin cups chained to the bench. At least they washed the cups out for each new patron. The stink from a dyer's shop across the way only raised the style of the Rose. Not that it was a shabby neighborhood really, though the street was too narrow for carriages. A fair number of brightly lacquered sedan chairs swayed through the crowd. If far more passersby wore wool and perhaps a guild vest than silk, the wool was as often well cut as frayed. The houses and shops were the usual array of white plaster, and if most were small and even run-down, the tall house of a wealthy merchant stood on a corner to his right and on the left a diminutive palace - smaller than the merchant's house, at least - with a single green-banded dome and no spire. A pair of taverns and an inn in plain sight looked cool and inviting. Unfortunately, the Rose was the only one where a man could sit outside, the only one in just the right spot. Unfortunately.

"aɪ daʊɾ aɪv ɛvɝ sin sətʃ splɛndəd flaɪz," neɪlzin ɡɹʌmbəld, weɪvɪŋ əweɪ sɛvɹəl tʃɔɪs spɛsəmənz fɹəm ɪz kʌp. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt wɝ duɪŋ əɡɛn?"

"I doubt I've ever seen such splendid flies," Nalesean grumbled, waving away several choice specimens from his cup. "What is it we're doing again?"

"ju ɑɹ swɪlɪŋ ðət faʊl ɪkskjus fəɹ waɪn ən swɛɾɪŋ laɪk ə ɡoʊt," mæt mʌɾɝd, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz hæt tə ʃeɪɾ ɪz aɪz bɛɾɝ. "aɪm biɪŋ tɑvɝən." hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə dəlæpədeɪɾɪd haʊs, bɪtwin ðə daɪɝz ən ə nɔɪzi wivɝz ɪstæblɪʃmənt, ðəɾ i hæd bɪn toʊl tə wɑtʃ. nɑɾ æskt - toʊld - ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt keɪm tə, haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ fɹeɪzd ɪt, skwɝmɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ plɛdʒɪz. oʊ, ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪt saʊn laɪk æskɪŋ, meɪɾ ɪt saʊn laɪk pliɾɪŋ ət ði ɛnd, wɪtʃ i wəd bɪliv wən dɑɡz dænst, bʌɾ i nu wən i hæd bɪn bʊlid. "dʒʌs bi tɑvɝən, mæt," hi mɪmɪkt. "aɪ noʊ jəl dʒʌs noʊ wʌt tə du. bɑ!" meɪbi ɪleɪn blʌɾi dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ən əɹ blʌɾi dɪmpəl nu, əɹ nɪneɪiv wɪð əɹ blʌɾi hænz twɪtʃɪŋ tə jæŋk əɹ blʌɾi bɹeɪd, bʌɾ i wəd bi bɝn ɪf i dɪd. "ɪf ðə pɪɡ-kɪsɪŋ boʊl ɪz ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, haʊ æm aɪ səpoʊz tə faɪn ɪɾ ɑn ðɪs fleɪmɪŋ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ?"

"You are swilling that foul excuse for wine and sweating like a goat," Mat muttered, tugging his hat to shade his eyes better. "I'm being ta'veren." He glared at the dilapidated house, between the dyer's and a noisy weaver's establishment, that he had been told to watch. Not asked - told - that was what it came to, however they phrased it, squirming around their pledges. Oh, they made it sound like asking, made it sound like pleading at the end, which he would believe when dogs danced, but he knew when he had been bullied. "Just be ta'veren, Mat," he mimicked. "I know you'll just know what to do. Bah!" Maybe Elayne bloody Daughter-Heir and her bloody dimple knew, or Nynaeve with her bloody hands twitching to yank her bloody braid, but he would be burned if he did. "If the pig-kissing Bowl is in the Rahad, how am I supposed to find it on this flaming side of the river?"

"aɪ də nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ əm seɪɪŋ," dʒulɪn sɛd ɹaɪli, ən tʊk ə lɔŋ swɑloʊ ʌv səm dʒɹɪŋk meɪd fɹəm ə jɛloʊ fɹut ɡɹoʊn ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. "juv æsk ðət fɪfti taɪmz, ət list." hi kleɪm ðə peɪl dʒɹɪŋk wɑz ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ ɪn ðə hit, bʌt mæt hæd teɪkən ə baɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðoʊz lɛmənz, ən i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə swɑloʊ ɛniθɪŋ meɪd fɹəm ðɛm. wɪð ɪz hɛd stɪl θɹɑbɪŋ feɪnli, hi hɪmsɛlf dʒɹæŋk ti. ɪt teɪstəɾ əz ɪf ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ, ə skɹɔni fɛloʊ wɪð biɾi səspɪʃəs aɪz, hæd bɪn dʌmpɪŋ nu livz ən wɔɾɝ ɪn jɛstɝdeɪz livɪŋz sɪns ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə sɪɾi. ðə teɪst suɾəd ɪz mud.

"I do not remember them saying," Juilin said wryly, and took a long swallow of some drink made from a yellow fruit grown in the countryside. "You've asked that fifty times, at least." He claimed the pale drink was refreshing in the heat, but Mat had taken a bite of one of those lemons, and he was not about to swallow anything made from them. With his head still throbbing faintly, he himself drank tea. It tasted as if the tavernkeeper, a scrawny fellow with beady suspicious eyes, had been dumping new leaves and water in yesterday's leavings since the founding of the city. The taste suited his mood.

"wʌɾ ɪntʃɹəsts mi," tɑm mɝmɝɾ oʊvɝ stipəl fɪŋɡɝz, "ɪz waɪ ðeɪ æsk soʊ mɛni kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt jəɹ ɪnkipɝ." hi dɪd nɑt sim vɛɹi əpsɛɾ ət ðə wɪmən stɪl kipɪŋ sikɹəts; səmtaɪmz, hi wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd. "wʌt də sɛɾəl ɑnən ən ðiz wɪmən əv tə də wɪð ðə boʊl?"

"What interests me," Thom murmured over steepled fingers, "is why they asked so many questions about your innkeeper." He did not seem very upset at the women still keeping secrets; sometimes, he was decidedly odd. "What do Setalle Anan and these women have to do with the Bowl?"

wɪmən dɪd pæs ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə dəlæpədeɪɾɪd haʊs. ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ʌv wɪmən, dʒʌst əbaʊt, səm wɛl dʒɹɛst ɪf nʌn ɪn sɪlks, ən nɑt wʌn mæn. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt ʌv ə waɪz wʊmən. mæt hæd kənsɪɾɝd fɑloʊɪŋ səm ə ðɛm wən ðeɪ lɛft, bʌɾ ɪt fɛl tu plænd. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tɑvɝən wɝkt - hi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli sin ɛni saɪn ʌv ɪɾ ɪn hɪmsɛlf - bʌɾ ɪz lʌk wɑz ɔlweɪz bɛst wən ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɹændəm. laɪk wɪð daɪs. moʊst ə ðoʊz lɪɾəl aɪɝn tævɝn pʌzəlz ɪluɾɪd hɪm, haʊɛvɝ lʌki hi fɛlt.

Women did pass in and out of the dilapidated house. A steady stream of women, just about, some well dressed if none in silks, and not one man. Three or four wore the red belt of a Wise Woman. Mat had considered following some of them when they left, but it felt too planned. He did not know how ta'veren worked - he had never really seen any sign of it in himself - but his luck was always best when everything was random. Like with dice. Most of those little iron tavern puzzles eluded him, however lucky he felt.

hi ɪɡnɔɹd tɑmz kwɛstʃən; tɑm hæɾ æskt ɪɾ ət list əz ɔfən əz mæt hæɾ æsk haʊ hi wɑz tə faɪn ðə boʊl hɪɹ. nɪneɪiv hæd toʊld ɪm tə hɪz feɪs ʃi hæd nɑt pɹɑməs tə tɛl ɪm ɛvɹi læs θɪŋ ʃi nu; ʃi sɛd ʃi wəd tɛl ɪm wʌtɛvɝ i niɾəd tə noʊ; ʃi sɛd. . . . wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ nɪɹli tʃoʊk fɹəm nɑt kɔlɪŋ ɪm neɪmz wɑz nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf vɛnʒəns.

He ignored Thom's question; Thom had asked it at least as often as Mat had asked how he was to find the Bowl here. Nynaeve had told him to his face she had not promised to tell him every last thing she knew; she said she would tell him whatever he needed to know; she said. . . . Watching her nearly choke from not calling him names was not nearly enough vengeance.

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃəd teɪk ə wɔk daʊn ði æli," neɪlzin saɪd. "ɪn keɪs wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən dɪsaɪdz tə klaɪm oʊvɝ ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɔl." ðə nɛɹoʊ ɡæp bɪtwin ðə haʊs ən ðə daɪɝ leɪ ɪn fʊl vju fəɹ ɪts hoʊl lɛŋθ, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ æliweɪ ɹæn əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn ðə ʃɑps ən haʊsəz. "mæt, tɛl mi əɡɛn waɪ wɝ duɪŋ ðɪs ɪnstɛɾ ə pleɪɪŋ kɑɹdz."

"I suppose I should take a walk down the alley," Nalesean sighed. "In case one of those women decides to climb over the garden wall." The narrow gap between the house and the dyer lay in full view for its whole length, but another alleyway ran along behind the shops and houses. "Mat, tell me again why we're doing this instead of playing cards."

"aɪl də ɪt," mæt sɛd. meɪbi hi wəd faɪn aʊt haʊ tɑvɝən wɝk bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɔl. hi wɛnt, ən faʊn aʊt nʌθɪŋ.

"I'll do it," Mat said. Maybe he would find out how ta'veren worked behind the garden wall. He went, and found out nothing.

baɪ ðə taɪm twaɪlaɪt bɪɡæn kɹipɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə stʃɹiɾ ən hɑɹnən keɪm wɪð ə bɔld-hɛɾəd, nɛɹoʊ-aɪɾ ændɔɝən neɪmd wɔt, ði oʊnli pɑsəbəl ɪfɛkt ə biɪŋ tɑvɝən i hæd sin wɑz ðət ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ bɹuɾ ə fɹɛʃ pɑɾ ə ti. ɪt teɪstəɾ ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ði oʊld.

By the time twilight began creeping over the street and Harnan came with a bald-headed, narrow-eyed Andoran named Wat, the only possible effect of being ta'veren he had seen was that the tavernkeeper brewed a fresh pot of tea. It tasted almost as bad as the old.

bæk ɪn ɪz ɹumz ɪn ðə pæləs, hi faʊn ə noʊt, ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən ə sɔɹts, ɛlɪɡənli lɛɾɝd ɑn θɪk waɪt peɪpɝ ðət smɛld laɪk ə ɡɑɹɾən ə flaʊɝz.

Back in his rooms in the palace, he found a note, an invitation of sorts, elegantly lettered on thick white paper that smelled like a garden of flowers.

maɪ lɪɾəl ɹæbət, aɪ ɪkspɛk tə hæv jə fəɹ dɪnɝ tənaɪɾ ɪn maɪ əpɑɹtməns.

My little rabbit, I expect to have you for dinner tonight in my apartments.

noʊ sɪɡnətʃɝ, bʌɾ i hɑɹdli niɾəd wʌn. laɪt! ðə wʊmən hæd noʊ ʃeɪm əɾ ɔl! ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɛd-peɪntəɾ aɪɝn lɑk ɑn ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ; hi faʊn ðə ki ən lɑkt ɪt. ðɛn, fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ, hi dʒæmd ə tʃɛɹ ʌndɝ ðə lætʃ ɑn ðə dɔɹ tə nɹɪmz ɹum. hi kəd də wɛl ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt dɪnɝ. dʒʌst əz i wɑz əbaʊt tə klaɪm ɪndə bɛd, ðə lɑk ɹæɾəld; aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl, ə wʊmən læft ət faɪndɪŋ ðə dɔɹ sɪkjʊɹd.

No signature, but he hardly needed one. Light! The woman had no shame at all! There was a red-painted iron lock on the door to the corridor; he found the key and locked it. Then, for good measure, he jammed a chair under the latch on the door to Nerim's room. He could do well enough without dinner. Just as he was about to climb into bed, the lock rattled; out in the hall, a woman laughed at finding the door secured.

hi ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə slip saʊnli ðɛn, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən i leɪ ðəɹ lɪsnɪŋ tə hɪz bɛli ɡɹʌmbəl. waɪ wɑz ʃi duɪŋ ðɪs? wɛl, hi nu waɪ, bʌt waɪ hɪm? ʃʊɹli ʃi hæd nɑt dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tɔs ɔl disənsi oʊvɝ ðə bɑɹn dʒʌs tə bɛɾ ə tɑvɝən. hi wɑz seɪf naʊ, ɛniweɪ. taɪlɪn wəd nɑt bæɾɝ daʊn ðə dɔɹ, æftɝ ɔl. wəd ʃi? nɑɾ ivən moʊs bɝdz kəd ɡɛɾ ɪn θɹu ðə ɹɔt-aɪɝn ɹæbɛsks skɹinɪŋ ðə bælkəniz. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wəd niɾ ə lɔŋ læɾɝ tə ɹitʃ ðət haɪ. ən mɛn tə kæɹi ɪt. ənlɛs ʃi klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ðə ɹuf ɑn ə ɹoʊp. əɹ ʃi kʊd. . . . ðə naɪt pæst, hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld, ðə sʌn ɹoʊz, ən i nɛvɝ kloʊzd ɪz aɪz əɹ hæɾ ə disən θɔt. ɪksɛp ðəɾ i dɪd meɪk ə dɪsɪʒən. hi θɔɾ ʌv ə jus fəɹ ðə sʌlkɪŋ ɹum. hi sɝɾənli nɛvɝ sʌlkt.

He should have been able to sleep soundly then, but for some reason he lay there listening to his belly grumble. Why was she doing this? Well, he knew why, but why him? Surely she had not decided to toss all decency over the barn just to bed a ta'veren. He was safe now, anyway. Tylin would not batter down the door, after all. Would she? Not even most birds could get in through the wrought-iron arabesques screening the balconies. Besides, she would need a long ladder to reach that high. And men to carry it. Unless she climbed down from the roof on a rope. Or she could. . . . The night passed, his stomach rumbled, the sun rose, and he never closed his eyes or had a decent thought. Except that he did make a decision. He thought of a use for the sulking room. He certainly never sulked.

ət fɝs laɪt, hi snikt aʊɾ ə hɪz ɹumz ən faʊn ənʌðɝ ə ðə pæləs sɝvəns i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ə bɔldɪŋ fɛloʊ neɪmd mæɾɪk, wɪð ə smʌɡ, sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd ɛɹ ən ə ʃaɪ twɪs tə hɪz maʊθ ðət sɛɾ i wɑz nɑt sæɾəsfaɪd əɾ ɔl. ə mæn u kəd bi bɑt. ðoʊ ðə stɑɹɾəld lʊk ðət flæʃt əkɹɔs ɪz skwɛɹ feɪs, ən ðə smɝk i bɛɹli bɑðɝd tə haɪd, sɛɾ i nu ɪɡzækli waɪ mæt wɑz slɪpɪŋ ɡoʊld ɪndə hɪz hænd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! haʊ mɛni pipəl nu wʌt taɪlɪn wɑz ʌp tə?

At first light, he sneaked out of his rooms and found another of the palace servants he remembered, a balding fellow named Madic, with a smug, self-satisfied air and a shy twist to his mouth that said he was not satisfied at all. A man who could be bought. Though the startled look that flashed across his square face, and the smirk he barely bothered to hide, said he knew exactly why Mat was slipping gold into his hand. Blood and ashes! How many people knew what Tylin was up to?

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ðoʊ ðət dɪd min ðeɪ tʃaɪɾɪd ɪm əbaʊt mɪsɪŋ dɪnɝ wɪð ðə kwin, wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæd lɝn əbaʊt wən taɪlɪn ɪnkwaɪɝd wɛðɝ i wɑz ɪl. ən wɝs. . . . "pliz," ɪleɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðə wɝd dɪd nɑt peɪn hɝ, "ju mʌs pʊt jəɹ bɛs fʊt fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə kwin. doʊn bi nɝvəs. jəl ɛndʒɔɪ ən ivnɪŋ wɪð hɝ."

Nynaeve and Elayne did not seem to, thank the Light. Though that did mean they chided him about missing dinner with the Queen, which they had learned about when Tylin inquired whether he was ill. And worse. . . . "Please," Elayne said, smiling almost as if the word did not pain her, "you must put your best foot forward with the Queen. Don't be nervous. You'll enjoy an evening with her."

"dʒʌs doʊn də ɛniθɪŋ tə əfɛn hɝ," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊt wɪð əɹ ðət biɪŋ sɪvəl hɝt; hɝ bɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn ɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən, hɝ dʒɔ taɪɾənd, ən əɹ hænz tʃɹɛmbəl tə pʊl əɹ bɹeɪd. "bi əkɑmədeɪɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌns ɪn jəɹ - aɪ min tə seɪ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ʃiz ə disənt wʊmən, ən doʊn tʃɹaɪ ɛni ʌv jəɹ - laɪt, jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min."

"Just don't do anything to offend her," Nynaeve muttered. There was no doubt with her that being civil hurt; her brows drew down in concentration, her jaw tightened, and her hands trembled to pull her braid. "Be accommodating for once in your - I mean to say, remember she's a decent woman, and don't try any of your - Light, you know what I mean."

nɝvəs. hɑ! disənt wʊmən. hɑ!

Nervous. Ha! Decent woman. Ha!

niðɝ sim ðə lis kənsɝn ðəɾ i hæd weɪstəɾ ə hoʊl æftɝnun. ɪleɪn pæɾəd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ sɪmpəθɛɾɪkəli ən æskt ɪm pliz tə tʃɹaɪ ənʌðɝ deɪ əɹ tu; ɪt sɝɾənli wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən tʃɹæmpɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹæhəɾ ɪn ðɪs hit. nɪneɪiv sɛd ði ɪɡzæk seɪm θɪŋ, ðə weɪ wɪmən dɪd, bʌt wɪθaʊt ðə ʃoʊldɝ pæt. ðeɪ ədmɪɾəd ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðət ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə spɛn ðə deɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə spaɪ ɑn kæɹaɪɾɪn wɪð eɪvinhə, ðoʊ ðeɪ ɪveɪɾɪd ɪz kwɛstʃən ə hu ɪt wɑz ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ maɪt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. nɪneɪiv lɛt ðət slɪp, ən ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əɹ sətʃ ə lʊk i θɔɾ i maɪt si nɪneɪivz ɪɹz bɑks fəɹ wʌns. ðeɪ mikli æksɛptɪɾ ɪz stʃɹɪktʃɝ nɑt tə luz saɪɾ ə ðɛɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, ən mikli lɛɾ ɪm si ðə dɪsɡaɪzɪz ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə wɛɹ. ivən æftɝ tɑmz dɪskɹɪpʃən, siɪŋ ðə pɛɹ sʌɾənli tɝn ɪndə ɛbu dɑɹi wɪmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bɪɡ ə ʃɑk əz ðɛɹ miknəs. wɛl, nɪneɪiv meɪɾ ə sɪkli stæb ət miknəs, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd i hæd mɛnt wʌɾ i sɛɾ əbaʊt ði ilwʊmən niɾɪŋ noʊ bɑɾiɡɑɹd, bʌt ʃi keɪm kloʊs. iðɝ wʌn ə ðiz wɪmən foʊldɪŋ əɹ hænz ən ænsɝɪŋ səbmɪsɪvli meɪɾ ɪm nɝvəs. boʊθ ə ðɛm təɡɛðɝ - wɪð eɪvinhə nɑɾɪŋ əpɹuvɪŋli! - ən i wɑz hæpi tə sɛn əm ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ. dʒʌs tə bi ʃʊɹ, ðoʊ, hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛɹ sʌɾənli flæt maʊðz ən meɪɾ əm dɛmənstʃɹeɪt ðɛɹ dɪsɡaɪzɪz fəɹ ðə mɛn i wɑz sɛndɪŋ əlɔŋ fɝst. veɪnɪn lɛpt ət ðə tʃæns tə bi wʌn ʌv ɪleɪnz ɡɑɹdz, nʌklɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛd ɹaɪɾ ən lɛf laɪk ə ful.

Neither seemed the least concerned that he had wasted a whole afternoon. Elayne patted his shoulder sympathetically and asked him please to try another day or two; it certainly was better than tramping through the Rahad in this heat. Nynaeve said the exact same thing, the way women did, but without the shoulder pat. They admitted right out that they intended to spend the day trying to spy on Carridin with Aviendha, though they evaded his question of who it was they thought they might recognize. Nynaeve let that slip, and Elayne gave her such a look he thought he might see Nynaeve's ears boxed for once. They meekly accepted his stricture not to lose sight of their bodyguards, and meekly let him see the disguises they intended to wear. Even after Thom's description, seeing the pair suddenly turn into Ebou Dari women in front of his eyes was almost as big a shock as their meekness. Well, Nynaeve made a sickly stab at meekness, growling when she realized he had meant what he said about the Aielwoman needing no bodyguard, but she came close. Either one of these women folding her hands and answering submissively made him nervous. Both of them together - with Aviendha nodding approvingly! - and he was happy to send them on their way. Just to be sure, though, he ignored their suddenly flat mouths and made them demonstrate their disguises for the men he was sending along first. Vanin leaped at the chance to be one of Elayne's guards, knuckling his forehead right and left like a fool.

ðə fæt mæn hæd nɑt lɝn mʌtʃ wɑtʃɪŋ ɑn ɪz oʊn. dʒʌst əz ɑn ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə pipəl hæd kʌm tə kɔl ɑn kæɹaɪɾɪn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm ɪn sɪlk, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt pɹuf ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɔl sɛɾ ən dʌn, ðə mæn wɑz ðə waɪtkloʊk æmbæsəɾɝ; mɔɹ foʊk u wɑntəd tə tʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə ɑmɑdɪʃiə pɹɑbli wɛn tə hɪm ðən tə ði ɑmɑdɪʃən æmbæsəɾɝ, huɛvɝ i əɹ ʃi wɑz. veɪnɪn dɪd seɪ tu wɪmən hæd dɛfənətli bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ kæɹaɪɾɪnz pæləs, tu - ðə lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs wən eɪvinhə sʌɾənli tɝn ɪndə ə θɝɾ ɛbu dɑɹi wʊmən wɑz ə wʌndɝ - ən ɔlsoʊ ən oʊl mæn, hi θɔt, ðoʊ ðə fɛloʊ pɹuv sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli spɹaɪ. veɪnɪn hæd nɑt mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ə ɡʊd lʊk əɾ ɪm dɪspaɪt spɑɾɪŋ ɪm θɹi taɪmz. wʌns veɪnɪn ən ðə wɪmən lɛft, mæt sɛn ɔf tɑm ən dʒulɪn tə si wʌt ðeɪ kəɾ ənkʌvɝ kənsɝnɪŋ dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn ən ə bɛnt, waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl mæn wɪð ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪf ðə θif-kætʃɝ kəd nɑt dɪskʌvɝ ə weɪ tə tʃɹɪp kæɹaɪɾɪn ɑn ɪz feɪs, ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst, ən tɑm sim tə hæv ə weɪ ʌv pʊɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɔl ðə ɡɑsəp ən ɹumɝ ɪn ə pleɪs ən fɪltɝɪŋ aʊt ðə tʃɹuθ. ɔl ðət wɑz ði izi pɑɹt, ʌv kɔɹs.

The fat man had not learned much watching on his own. Just as on the day before, a surprising number of people had come to call on Carridin, including some in silk, but that was not proof they were all Darkfriends. All said and done, the man was the Whitecloak ambassador; more folk who wanted to trade into Amadicia probably went to him than to the Amadician ambassador, whoever he or she was. Vanin did say two women had definitely been watching Carridin's palace, too - the look on his face when Aviendha suddenly turned into a third Ebou Dari woman was a wonder - and also an old man, he thought, though the fellow proved surprisingly spry. Vanin had not managed to get a good look at him despite spotting him three times. Once Vanin and the women left, Mat sent off Thom and Juilin to see what they could uncover concerning Jaichim Carridin and a bent, white-haired old man with an interest in Darkfriends. If the thief-catcher could not discover a way to trip Carridin on his face, it did not exist, and Thom seemed to have a way of putting together all the gossip and rumor in a place and filtering out the truth. All that was the easy part, of course.

fəɹ tu deɪz i swɛɾɪd ɑn ðət bɛntʃ, wɪð ən əkeɪʒənəl stʃɹoʊl daʊn ði æli bɪsaɪd ðə daɪɝz, ən ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət tʃeɪnʒd wɑz ðət ðə ti ɡɑt wɝs əɡɛn. ðə waɪn wɑz soʊ bæd, neɪlzin bɪɡæn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ eɪl. ðə fɝs deɪ, ðə tɑvɝŋkipɝ ɔfɝd fɪʃ fəɹ ə mɪddeɪ mil, bʌt baɪ ðə smɛl ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɑt læst wik. ðə sɛkən deɪ, hi ɔfɝɾ ə stu ʌv ɔɪstɝz; mæt eɪt faɪv boʊlz ə ðət dɪspaɪt ðə bɪts ə ʃɛl. bɝdʒɪt dɪklaɪn boʊθ.

For two days he sweated on that bench, with an occasional stroll down the alley beside the dyer's, and the only thing that changed was that the tea got worse again. The wine was so bad, Nalesean began drinking ale. The first day, the tavernkeeper offered fish for a midday meal, but by the smell they had been caught last week. The second day, he offered a stew of oysters; Mat ate five bowls of that despite the bits of shell. Birgitte declined both.

hi hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd wən ʃi kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm ən neɪlzin hɝiɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə mɔl hɛɹə ðət fɝs mɔɹnɪŋ. ðə sʌn bɛɹli meɪɾ ə ɹɪm əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pipəl ən kɑɹts dɑɾəd ðə skwɛɹ. "aɪ mʌst əv blɪŋkt," ʃi læft. "aɪ wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ðə weɪ aɪ θɔt jud kʌm aʊt. ɪf jə doʊn maɪn kʌmpəni."

He had been surprised when she caught up to him and Nalesean hurrying across the Mol Hara that first morning. The sun barely made a rim above the rooftops, but already people and carts dotted the square. "I must have blinked," she laughed. "I was waiting the way I thought you'd come out. If you don't mind company."

"wi muv fæst səmtaɪmz," hi sɛɾ ɪvæsɪvli. neɪlzin lʊkt əɾ ɪm saɪdweɪz; ʌv kɔɹs, hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə waɪ ðeɪ hæd kɹɛpt aʊt θɹu ə taɪni saɪd dɔɹ nɪɹ ðə steɪbəlz. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət mæt θɔt taɪlɪn wəɾ æktʃəli  lip ɑn ɪm ɪn ðə hɔlz ɪn bɹɔd deɪlaɪt, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, ɪt nɛvɝ hɝt tə bi kɛɹfəl. "jɔɹ kʌmpəni ɪz wɛlkəm ɛni taɪm. ʌ. θæŋks." ʃi dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡd ən mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ i dɪd nɑt kætʃ ən fɛl ɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm.

"We move fast sometimes," he said evasively. Nalesean looked at him sideways; of course, he had no idea why they had crept out through a tiny side door near the stables. It was not that Mat thought Tylin would actually leap on him in the halls in broad daylight, but then again, it never hurt to be careful. "Your company is welcome any time. Uh. Thanks." She just shrugged and murmured something he did not catch and fell in on the other side of him.

ðət wɑz ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð hɝ. ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən i hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn wʊɾə dɪmændəd tə noʊ θæŋks fəɹ wʌt, ən ðən ɪkspleɪnd waɪ nʌn wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi ət sətʃ lɛŋθ ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə kʌvɝ ɪz ɪɹz, əɹ əpbɹeɪɾɪd ɪm əɾ ikwəl lɛŋθ fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ, əɹ səmtaɪmz meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ʃi ɪkspɛktəd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ səbstæntʃəl ðən wɝdz. bɝdʒɪt dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡd, ən oʊvɝ ðə nɛks tu deɪz, sʌmθɪŋ stɑɹtlɪŋ əkɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

That was the beginning with her. Any other woman he had ever known would have demanded to know thanks for what, and then explained why none were necessary at such length that he wanted to cover his ears, or upbraided him at equal length for thinking they were, or sometimes made it clear she expected something more substantial than words. Birgitte just shrugged, and over the next two days, something startling occurred in his head.

nɔɹməli, tə hɪm, wɪmən wɝ tə ædmaɪɹ ən smaɪl æt, tə dæns wɪð ən kɪs ɪf ðeɪ wəɾ əlaʊ, tə snʌɡəl wɪð ɪf i wɑz lʌki. dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɪtʃ wɪmən tə tʃeɪs wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ fʌn əz tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɛm, ɪf nɑt nɪɹli soʊ mʌtʃ əz kætʃɪŋ ðɛm. səm wɪmən wɝ dʒʌs fɹɛnz, ʌv kɔɹs. ə fju. ɛɡwin, fəɹ wʌn, ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ ðət fɹɛndʃɪp wəd sɝvaɪv əɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn. nɪneɪiv wɑz sɔɹɾ ʌv ə fɹɛnd, ɪn ə weɪ; ɪf ʃi kəd fɝɡɛt fəɹ wʌn aʊɝ ðət ʃi hæd swɪtʃt ɪz bɑɾəm mɔɹ ðən wʌns ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ i wɑz nɑɾ ə bɔɪ ɛnimɔɹ. bʌɾ ə wʊmən fɹɛnd wɑz dɪfɹən fɹəm ə mæn; jə ɔlweɪz nu hɝ maɪn ɹæn əlɔŋ ʌðɝ pæðz ðən jʊɹz, ðət ʃi sɔ ðə wɝld wɪð dɪfɹən aɪz.

Normally, to him, women were to admire and smile at, to dance with and kiss if they would allow, to snuggle with if he was lucky. Deciding which women to chase was almost as much fun as chasing them, if not nearly so much as catching them. Some women were just friends, of course. A few. Egwene, for one, though he was not sure how that friendship would survive her becoming Amyrlin. Nynaeve was sort of a friend, in a way; if she could forget for one hour that she had switched his bottom more than once and remember he was not a boy anymore. But a woman friend was different from a man; you always knew her mind ran along other paths than yours, that she saw the world with different eyes.

bɝdʒɪt lin təwɔɹɾ ɪm ɑn ðə bɛntʃ. "bɛs bi wɛɹi," ʃi mɝmɝd. "ðæt wɪɾoʊ ɪz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə nu hʌzbənd; ðə ʃiθ ɑn əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf ɪz blu. bɪsaɪdz, ðə haʊs ɪz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ."

Birgitte leaned toward him on the bench. "Best be wary," she murmured. "That widow is looking for a new husband; the sheath on her marriage knife is blue. Besides, the house is over there."

hi blɪŋkt, luzɪŋ saɪɾ ə ðə switli plʌmp wʊmən u ɹoʊld əɹ hɪps soʊ ɛkstʃɹævəɡənli əz ʃi wɔkt, ən bɝdʒɪɾ ænsɝɾ ɪz ʃipɪʃ ɡɹɪn wɪð ə læf. nɪneɪiv wʊɾə fleɪɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ tʌŋ fəɹ lʊkɪŋ, ən ivən ɛɡwin wʊɾə bɪn kuli dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ. baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə sɛkən deɪ ɑn ðət bɛntʃ, hi ɹilaɪzd i hæd sæɾ ɔl ðət taɪm wɪð ɪz hɪp pɹɛst əɡɛns bɝdʒɪts ən nɛvɝ wʌns θɔɾ ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪs hɝ. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi kɪs baɪ hɪm - fɹæŋkli, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə dɔɡ-ʌɡli mɛn ʃi sim tə ɛndʒɔɪ lʊkɪŋ æt, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪnsʌltɪɾ ɪf ʃi hæd - ən ʃi wɑz ə hɪɹoʊ aʊɾ ə lɛdʒən hum i stɪl hæf-ɪkspɛktəd tə lip oʊvɝ ə haʊs ən ɡɹæb ə kʌpəl ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən baɪ ðə nɛk ɑn ðə weɪ. bʌt ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪt: hi wəɾ əz sun əv θɔɾ ə kɪsɪŋ neɪlzin. ðə seɪm əz ðə tɛɹən, dʒʌst ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm æz, hi laɪk bɝdʒɪt.

He blinked, losing sight of the sweetly plump woman who rolled her hips so extravagantly as she walked, and Birgitte answered his sheepish grin with a laugh. Nynaeve would have flayed him with her tongue for looking, and even Egwene would have been coolly disapproving. By the end of the second day on that bench, he realized he had sat all that time with his hip pressed against Birgitte's and never once thought of trying to kiss her. He was sure she did not want to be kissed by him - frankly, considering the dog-ugly men she seemed to enjoy looking at, he might have been insulted if she had - and she was a hero out of legend whom he still half-expected to leap over a house and grab a couple of the Forsaken by the neck on the way. But that was not it: He would as soon have thought of kissing Nalesean. The same as the Tairen, just exactly the same as, he liked Birgitte.

tu deɪz ɑn ðət bɛntʃ, ʌp ən daʊn tə tʃɹɑt daʊn ði æli bɪsaɪd ðə daɪɝ ən stɛɹ ət ðə tɔl wɔl ə bɛɹ bɹɪk ət ðə bæk ə ðə haʊsəz ɡɑɹɾən. bɝdʒɪt cʊɾə klaɪmd ɪt, bʌɾ ivən ʃi maɪɾ əv bɹoʊkən əɹ nɛk ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs. θɹi taɪmz i dɪsaɪɾɪd ɑn ðə spɝ ə ðə moʊmən tə fɑloʊ ə wʊmən kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə haʊs, tu wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt ʌv ə waɪz wʊmən. ɹændəm tʃæns dɪd sim tə ɪnvoʊk ɪz lʌk.

Two days on that bench, up and down to trot down the alley beside the dyer and stare at the tall wall of bare brick at the back of the house's garden. Birgitte could have climbed it, but even she might have broken her neck if she tried wearing a dress. Three times he decided on the spur of the moment to follow a woman coming out of the house, two wearing the red belt of a Wise Woman. Random chance did seem to invoke his luck.

wʌn ə ðə waɪz wɪmən wɛn ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ən bɑɾ ə bʌntʃ ə ʃɹɪvəl tɝnəps bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk; ði ʌðɝ wɔk tu stʃɹits oʊvɝ tə baɪ ə pɛɹ ə bɪɡ, ɡɹin-stʃɹaɪp fɪʃ. ðə θɝd wʊmən, tɔl ən dɑɹk ɪn nit ɡɹeɪ wʊl, meɪbi ə tɛɹən, kɹɔs tu bɹɪdʒəz bɪfɔɹ ɛntɝɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ ʃɑp wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡɹiɾəd wɪð smaɪlz baɪ ə skɪni boʊɪŋ fɛloʊ ən bɪɡæn supɝvaɪzɪŋ ðə loʊɾɪŋ ə lækɝd bɑksəz ən tʃɹeɪz ɪndə sɔdʌst-fɪl bæskəts ðət wɝ ðən loʊɾəd ɪndə ə wæɡən. baɪ wʌɾ i hɝd, ʃi hoʊp tə fɛtʃ ə pɹɪɾi pis ə sɪlvɝ wɪð əm ɪn ændɝ. mæt bɛɹli mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp wɪθaʊt baɪɪŋ ə bɑks. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ɹændəm lʌk. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæɾ ɛni iðɝ. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə meɪd ðɛɹ pɪlɡɹəmɪdʒɪz tə ðə stʃɹits ɝaʊn kæɹaɪɾɪnz smɔl pæləs wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɛniwʌn ðeɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd, wɪtʃ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd əm noʊ ɛnd. ðeɪ stɪl ɹəfjuz tə seɪ hu; ɪt hɑɹdli mæɾɝd, sɪns ðə pipəl wɝ nɑt tə bi sin. ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ sɛd, ʃoʊɪŋ ɪm ɪnʌf tiθ fəɹ sɪks wɪmən. ðə ɡɹɪməsɪz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi smaɪlz, hi θɔt. ɪt wɑz ə ʃeɪm eɪvinhə sim tə hæv fɔlən ɪn wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu soʊ θɝoʊli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə moʊmənt wən i wɑz pɹɛsɪŋ əm fəɹ ən ænsɝ, ən ɪleɪn snæpt ət hɪm, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn əɹ noʊz, ən ði il wʊmən wɪspɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɪɹ.

One of the Wise Women went around the corner and bought a bunch of shriveled turnips before going back; the other walked two streets over to buy a pair of big, green-striped fish. The third woman, tall and dark in neat gray wool, maybe a Tairen, crossed two bridges before entering a large shop where she was greeted with smiles by a skinny bowing fellow and began supervising the loading of lacquered boxes and trays into sawdust-filled baskets that were then loaded into a wagon. By what he heard, she hoped to fetch a pretty piece of silver with them in Andor. Mat barely managed to escape without buying a box. So much for random luck. No one else had any either. Nynaeve and Elayne and Aviendha made their pilgrimages to the streets around Carridin's small palace without seeing anyone they recognized, which frustrated them no end. They still refused to say who; it hardly mattered, since the people were not to be seen. That was what they said, showing him enough teeth for six women. The grimaces were supposed to be smiles, he thought. It was a shame Aviendha seemed to have fallen in with the other two so thoroughly, but there was a moment when he was pressing them for an answer, and Elayne snapped at him, staring down her nose, and the Aiel woman whispered something in her ear.

"fɝɡɪv mi, mæt," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɝnəsli, hɝ feɪs ɡoʊɪŋ soʊ ɹɛɾ əɹ hɛɹ sim tə peɪl. "aɪ hʌmbli bɛɡ pɑɹɾən fəɹ spikɪŋ soʊ. aɪ . . . wɪl bɛɡ ɑn maɪ niz, ɪf jə wɪʃ." noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ əɹ vɔɪs fɔltɝɾ ət ði ɛnd.

"Forgive me, Mat," Elayne said earnestly, her face going so red her hair seemed to pale. "I humbly beg pardon for speaking so. I . . . will beg on my knees, if you wish." No surprise that her voice faltered at the end.

"noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt," hi sɛd feɪnli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə ɡɑɡəl. "jɔɹ fɝɡɪvən; ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ." ði ɑɾəst θɪŋ, ðoʊ; ɪleɪn lʊkt əɾ eɪvinhə ðə hoʊl taɪm ʃi spoʊk tə hɪm ən dɪd nɑt twɪtʃ ən aɪləd wən i ɹɪplaɪd, bʌt ʃi hivd ə ɡɹeɪt saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif wən eɪvinhə nɑɾəd. wɪmən wɝ dʒʌst stʃɹeɪnʒ.

"No need for that," he said faintly, trying not to goggle. "You're forgiven; it was nothing." The oddest thing, though; Elayne looked at Aviendha the whole time she spoke to him and did not twitch an eyelid when he replied, but she heaved a great sigh of relief when Aviendha nodded. Women were just strange.

tɑm ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət kæɹaɪɾɪn ɡeɪv tə bɛɡɝz fɹikwənli, ən əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, ɛvɹi skɹæp ʌv wɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɪm ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz ðə kaɪn tə bi ɪkspɛktəd, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn wɛðɝ ðə spikɝ θɔt waɪtkloʊks wɝ mɝɾɝəs mɑnstɝz əɹ ðə tʃɹu seɪvjɝz ə ðə wɝld. dʒulɪn lɝn ðət kæɹaɪɾɪn hæd pɝtʃəst ə plæn ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, wɪtʃ maɪɾ ɪndəkeɪt səm waɪtkloʊk ɪntɛntʃən təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ ən maɪɾ ɪndəkeɪt ðət peɪdʒɹən naɪl wɑntəɾ ə pæləs fəɹ hɪmsɛlf ən ɪntɛndəd tə kɑpi ðə tɑɹɑsɪn. ɪf i stɪl lɪvd; ɹumɝz hæd spɹʌŋ ʌp ɪn ðə sɪɾi ðəɾ i wɑz dɛd, bʌt ðɛn, hæf sɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd kɪld ɪm ən hæf sɛd ɹænd hæd, wɪtʃ ʃoʊd ðɛɹ wɝθ. niðɝ dʒulɪn əɹ tɑm hæd skʌft ʌp ə pɛbəl kənsɝnɪŋ ə waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl mæn wɪð ə mʌtʃ-wɔɹn feɪs.

Thom reported that Carridin gave to beggars frequently, and aside from that, every scrap of word about him in Ebou Dar was the kind to be expected, depending on whether the speaker thought Whitecloaks were murderous monsters or the true saviors of the world. Juilin learned that Carridin had purchased a plan of the Tarasin Palace, which might indicate some Whitecloak intention toward Ebou Dar and might indicate that Pedron Niall wanted a palace for himself and intended to copy the Tarasin. If he still lived; rumors had sprung up in the city that he was dead, but then, half said Aes Sedai had killed him and half said Rand had, which showed their worth. Neither Juilin or Thom had scuffed up a pebble concerning a white-haired old man with a much-worn face.

fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wɪð kæɹaɪɾɪn, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wɪð wɑtʃɪŋ ðə blʌɾi haʊs, ən əz fɑɹ əz ðə pæləs wɛnt. . . .

Frustration with Carridin, frustration with watching the bloody house, and as far as the palace went. . . .

mæt faʊn aʊt haʊ θɪŋz wɝ tə ɡoʊ ðət fɝs naɪt wən i faɪnəli ɡɑt bæk tə hɪz ɹumz. oʊlvɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, ɔlɹɛɾi fɛɾ ən kɝld ʌp ɪn ə tʃɛɹ wɪð ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə stænd-læmps, ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əpsɛɾ oʊvɝ biɪŋ muvd aʊɾ ə hɪz oʊn ɹum. mæɾɪk hæd bɪn əz ɡʊɾ əz ɪz wɝd; əz ɡʊɾ əz ðə ɡoʊld i stʌft ɪn ɪz paʊtʃ, ɛniweɪ. ðə sʌlkɪŋ ɹum naʊ hɛld oʊlvɝz bɛd. dʒʌs lɛt taɪlɪn tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ wɪð ə tʃaɪld wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ! ðə kwin hæd nɑt bɪn aɪɾəl iðɝ, ðoʊ. hi snik daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃənz laɪk ə fɑks, slɪpɪŋ fɹəm kɔɹnɝ tə kɔɹnɝ, flæʃɪŋ daʊn stɛɹz - ən faʊn ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fud tə bi hæd.

Mat found out how things were to go that first night when he finally got back to his rooms. Olver was there, already fed and curled up in a chair with The Travels of Jain Farstrider by the light of the stand-lamps, and not at all upset over being moved out of his own room. Madic had been as good as his word; as good as the gold he stuffed in his pouch, anyway. The sulking room now held Olver's bed. Just let Tylin try anything with a child watching her! The Queen had not been idle either, though. He sneaked down to the kitchens like a fox, slipping from corner to corner, flashing down stairs - and found there was no food to be had.

oʊ, ðə smɛl ə kʊkɪŋ pɝmieɪɾɪd ði ɛɹ, ɹoʊsts tɝnɪŋ ɑn spɪts ɪn ðə bɪɡ faɪɝpleɪsəz, pɑts bʌbəlɪŋ ətɑp ðə waɪt-taɪl stoʊvz, ən kʊks kɛpt pɑpɪŋ oʊpən ʌvənz tə pɹɑd ðɪs əɹ ðæt. ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌs noʊ fud fəɹ mæt kɔθən. smaɪlɪŋ wɪmən ɪn pɹɪstin waɪɾ eɪpɹənz ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz oʊn smaɪlz ən pʊt ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ɪz weɪ soʊ hi kəd nɑt ɡɛt nɪɹ ðə sɔɹsəz ə ðoʊz wʌndɝfəl smɛlz. ðeɪ smaɪld ən ɹæpt ɪz nʌkəlz wən i tʃɹaɪd tə snætʃ ə loʊf ə bɹɛɾ əɹ dʒʌst ə bɪɾ ə hʌni-ɡleɪz tɝnəp. ðeɪ smaɪld ən toʊld ɪm i mʌs nɑt spɔɪl ɪz æpətaɪɾ ɪf i wɑz tə it wɪð ðə kwin. ðeɪ nu. ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðɛm nu! hɪz oʊn blʌʃəz əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls dʒɹoʊv ɪm bæk tə hɪz ɹumz, bɪɾɝli ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðəɾ oʊɾɝəs fɪʃ ət mɪddeɪ. hi lɑk ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ə wʊmən u wəd stɑɹv ə mæn maɪt tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ.

Oh, the smell of cooking permeated the air, roasts turning on spits in the big fireplaces, pots bubbling atop the white-tiled stoves, and cooks kept popping open ovens to prod this or that. There was just no food for Mat Cauthon. Smiling women in pristine white aprons ignored his own smiles and put themselves in his way so he could not get near the sources of those wonderful smells. They smiled and rapped his knuckles when he tried to snatch a loaf of bread or just a bit of honey-glazed turnip. They smiled and told him he must not spoil his appetite if he was to eat with the Queen. They knew. Every last one of them knew! His own blushes as much as anything else drove him back to his rooms, bitterly regretting that odorous fish at midday. He locked the door behind him. A woman who would starve a man might try anything.

hi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ə ɡɹin sɪlk kɑɹpət pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪð oʊlvɝ wən ðə sɛkənd noʊt wɑz slɪpt ʌndɝ ɪz dɔɹ.

He was lying on a green silk carpet playing Snakes and Foxes with Olver when the second note was slipped under his door.

aɪ hæv bɪn toʊld ɪts mɔɹ spɔɹɾɪŋ tə teɪk ə pɪdʒən ɑn ðə wɪŋ, tə wɑtʃ ɪt flʌɾɝ, bʌt sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ə hʌŋɡɹi bɝd wɪl flaɪ tə ðə hænd.

I have been told it is more sporting to take a pigeon on the wing, to watch it flutter, but sooner or later, a hungry bird will fly to the hand.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, mæt?" oʊlvɝ æskt.

"What is it, Mat?" Olver asked.

"nʌθɪŋ." mæt kɹʌmpəl ðə noʊt. "ənʌðɝ ɡeɪm?"

"Nothing." Mat crumpled the note. "Another game?"

"oʊ, jɛs." ðə bɔɪ wəd pleɪ ðə ful ɡeɪm ɔl deɪ, ɡɪvən ə tʃæns. "mæt, dɪd jə tʃɹaɪ ɛni ʌv ðət hæm ðeɪ kʊk tənaɪt? aɪ nɛvɝ teɪstəɾ ɛniθɪŋ - "

"Oh, yes." The boy would play the fool game all day, given a chance. "Mat, did you try any of that ham they cooked tonight? I never tasted anything - "

"dʒʌs θɹoʊ ðə daɪs, oʊlvɝ. dʒʌs θɹoʊ ðə blʌɾi daɪs."

"Just throw the dice, Olver. Just throw the bloody dice."

kʌmɪŋ bæk fəɹ ɪz θɝd naɪɾ ɪn ðə pæləs, hi bɑt bɹɛɾ ən ɑlɪvz ən uz mɪlk tʃiz ɑn ðə weɪ, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl. ðə kɪtʃən stɪl hæɾ ɪts ɔɹɾɝz. ðə blʌɾi wɪmən æktʃəli  læft aʊt laʊd waɪl ðeɪ wɑftɪd stimɪŋ plæɾɝz ə mits ən fɪʃəz dʒʌs bɪɑn ɪz ɹitʃ ən toʊld ɪm nɑt tə spɔɪl ɪz blʌɾi æpətaɪt.

Coming back for his third night in the palace, he bought bread and olives and ewe's milk cheese on the way, which was just as well. The kitchen still had its orders. The bloody women actually laughed out loud while they wafted steaming platters of meats and fishes just beyond his reach and told him not to spoil his bloody appetite.

hi meɪnteɪn ɪz dɪɡnəɾi. hi dɪd nɑt ɡɹæb ə plæɾɝ ən ɹʌn. hi meɪɾ ɪz faɪnəs lɛɡ, flɝɪʃɪŋ ən ɪmædʒənɛɹi kloʊk. "ɡɹeɪʃəs leɪɾiz, jəɹ wɔɹmθ ən hɑspətæləɾi oʊvɝwɛlm mi."

He maintained his dignity. He did not grab a platter and run. He made his finest leg, flourishing an imaginary cloak. "Gracious ladies, your warmth and hospitality overwhelm me."

hɪz wɪðdʒɹɔəl wʊɾə ɡɔn ə dil bɛɾɝ ɪf wʌn ə ðə kʊks hæd nɑt kækəld əɾ ɪz bæk, "ðə kwin wɪl fist ɑn ɹoʊs dʌklɪŋ sun ɪnʌf, læd." vɛɹi dʒɹoʊl. ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɹɔɹd soʊ hɑɹd, ðeɪ mʌst əv bɪn ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. vɛɹi blʌɾi dʒɹoʊl.

His withdrawal would have gone a deal better if one of the cooks had not cackled at his back, "The Queen will feast on roast duckling soon enough, lad." Very droll. The other women roared so hard, they must have been rolling on the floor. Very bloody droll.

bɹɛɾ ən ɑlɪvz ən sɔlti tʃiz meɪɾ ə faɪn mil, wɪð ə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ fɹəm ɪz wɑʃstæn tə wɑʃ ɪt daʊn. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ɛni waɪn pʌntʃ ɪn ɪz ɹum sɪns ðət fɝs deɪ. oʊlvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl ɪm əbaʊt səm sɔɹɾ ə ɹoʊstəd fɪʃ wɪð mʌstɝd sɔs ən ɹeɪzənz; mæt toʊld ɪm tə pɹæktəs ɪz ɹɛɾɪŋ.

Bread and olives and salty cheese made a fine meal, with a little water from his washstand to wash it down. There had not been any wine punch in his room since that first day. Olver tried to tell him about some sort of roasted fish with mustard sauce and raisins; Mat told him to practice his reading.

noʊbɑdi slɪpt ə noʊɾ ʌndɝ ɪz dɔɹ ðət naɪt. noʊbɑdi ɹæɾəld ðə lɑk. hi bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk θɪŋz maɪt tɝn fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ. təmɑɹoʊ wɑz ðə fɛstəvəl ə bɝdz. fɹəm wʌɾ i hæd hɝɾ ə ðə kɑstumz səm pipəl wɔɹ, mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ, ɪt maɪt bi pɑsəbəl taɪlɪn wəd faɪn hɝsɛlf ə nu dʌklɪŋ tə tʃeɪs æftɝ. sʌmbɑɾi maɪt kʌm aʊɾ ə ðət blʌɾi haʊs əkɹɔs fɹəm ðə ɹoʊz ə ði ɪldɑɹ ən hæn ɪm ðə blʌɾi boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. θɪŋz dʒʌs hæd tə tɝn fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ.

Nobody slipped a note under his door that night. Nobody rattled the lock. He began to think things might turn for the better. Tomorrow was the Festival of Birds. From what he had heard of the costumes some people wore, men and women both, it might be possible Tylin would find herself a new duckling to chase after. Somebody might come out of that bloody house across from The Rose of the Eldar and hand him the bloody Bowl of the Winds. Things just had to turn for the better.

wən i woʊk fəɹ ɪz θɝd mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, ðə daɪs wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd.

When he woke for his third morning in the Tarasin Palace, the dice were rolling in his head.


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

ðə fɛstəvəl ə bɝdz


The Festival of Birds

weɪkɪŋ tə ðə daɪs, mæt kənsɪɾɝd ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə slip əntɪl ðeɪ wɛn əweɪ, bʌɾ ət læst i ɡɑɾ ʌp filɪŋ ɡɹʌmpi. əz ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ əv mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ɑn ɪz pleɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. hi tʃeɪs nɹɪm əweɪ ən dʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf, iɾɪŋ ðə læst ə ðə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz fɹəm ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ waɪl i dɪd, ðən wɛn tə tʃɛk ɑn oʊlvɝ. ðə bɔɪ flæʃt bɪtwin bɝsts ə jæŋkɪŋ ɑn ɪz kloʊðz ɪn ə hɝi tə bi aʊɾ ən stɑpɪŋ ɪntaɪɝli wɪð buɾ əɹ ʃɝɾ ɪn hæn tə spaʊt dʌzənz ə kwɛstʃənz ðət mæt ænsɝd wɪð hæf ə maɪnd. noʊ, ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɡoʊ ɹeɪsɪŋ tədeɪ, ən nɛvɝ maɪn ðə ɹɪtʃ ɹeɪsəz ət ðə sɝkəɾ ə hɛvən, nɔɹθ ə ðə sɪɾi. meɪbi ðeɪ kəd ɡoʊ si ðə mənædʒɝi. jɛs, mæt wəd baɪ hɪm ə fɛðɝd mæsk fəɹ ðə fɛstəvəl. ɪf i ɛvɝ ɡɑt dʒɹɛst. ðət sɛn ɪm ɪndə ə flɝi.

Waking to the dice, Mat considered going back to sleep until they went away, but at last he got up feeling grumpy. As if he did not have more than enough on his plate already. He chased Nerim away and dressed himself, eating the last of the bread and cheese from the night before while he did, then went to check on Olver. The boy flashed between bursts of yanking on his clothes in a hurry to be out and stopping entirely with boot or shirt in hand to spout dozens of questions that Mat answered with half a mind. No, they would not go racing today, and never mind the rich races at the Circuit of Heaven, north of the city. Maybe they could go see the menagerie. Yes, Mat would buy him a feathered mask for the festival. If he ever got dressed. That sent him into a flurry.

wʌt ɹɪli ɑkjəpaɪd mæts θɔts wɝ ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs. waɪ hæd ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ʌp əɡɛn? hi stɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ ðeɪ hæd bɪfɔɹ!

What really occupied Mat's thoughts were those bloody dice. Why had they started up again? He still did not know why they had before!

wən oʊlvɝ wɑz faɪnəli kloʊðd, hi fɑloʊd mæt ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum bʌbəlɪŋ wɪð hæf-hɝd kwɛstʃənz - ən bʌmpt ɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd wən i stɑp dɛd. taɪlɪn ɹipleɪs ðə bʊk oʊlvɝ hæd bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

When Olver was finally clothed, he followed Mat into the sitting room bubbling with half-heard questions - and bumped him from behind when he stopped dead. Tylin replaced the book Olver had been reading the night before on the table.

"mædʒəsti!" mæts aɪz dɑɹɾɪd tə ðə dɔɹ i hæd lɑk læs naɪt, naʊ stændɪŋ waɪɾ oʊpən. "wʌɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz." hi pʊld oʊlvɝ ɝaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə wʊmənz mɑkɪŋ smaɪl. wɛl, meɪbi ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹɪli mɑkɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt ʃʊɹli sim soʊ ɹaɪt ðɛn. ʃi wɑz sɝɾənli plizd wɪð hɝsɛlf. "aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə teɪk oʊlvɝ aʊt. tə si ðə fɛstəvəl. ən səm tʃɹævlɪŋ mənædʒɝi. hi wɑns ə fɛðɝd mæsk." hi snæpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt tə stɑp bæbəlɪŋ ən stɑɹɾəd ɛdʒɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ, juzɪŋ ðə bɔɪ əz ə ʃild.
