"Majesty!" Mat's eyes darted to the door he had locked last night, now standing wide open. "What a surprise." He pulled Olver around in front of him, between him and the woman's mocking smile. Well, maybe it was not really mocking, but it surely seemed so right then. She was certainly pleased with herself. "I was about to take Olver out. To see the festival. And some traveling menagerie. He wants a feathered mask." He snapped his mouth shut to stop babbling and started edging toward the door, using the boy as a shield.

"jɛs," taɪlɪn mɝmɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ θɹu hɝ aɪlæʃɪz. ʃi meɪd noʊ muv tə ɪntɝvin, bʌɾ əɹ smaɪl dipənd, əz ɪf ʃi wɑz dʒʌst weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz fʊt tə læn ɪn ðə snɛɹ. "mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ɪf hiz ə kəmpænjən, ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð ði ɝtʃənz, əz aɪ hɪɹ i dʌz. wʌn hɪɹz ə ɡʊd dil əbaʊt jəɹ læd. ɹaɪzɛl?"

"Yes," Tylin murmured, watching through her eyelashes. She made no move to intervene, but her smile deepened, as if she was just waiting for his foot to land in the snare. "Much better if he has a companion, instead of running with the urchins, as I hear he does. One hears a good deal about your lad. Riselle?"

ə wʊmən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ə fænsɪfəl mæsk ə swɝlɪŋ blu ən ɡoʊldən fɛðɝz hɪd moʊst ə ɹaɪzɛlz feɪs, bʌt ðə fɛðɝz ɑn ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ kɑstum dɪd nɑt haɪd vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɛls. ʃi pəzɛs ðə moʊst spɛktækjəlɝ bʊzəm i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin.

A woman appeared in the doorway, and Mat gave a start. A fanciful mask of swirling blue and golden feathers hid most of Riselle's face, but the feathers on the rest of her costume did not hide very much else. She possessed the most spectacular bosom he had ever seen.

"oʊlvɝ," ʃi sɛd, sɪŋkɪŋ tə hɝ niz, "wʊd jə laɪk tə wɔk aʊt wɪð mi ət fɛstəvəl?" ʃi hɛld ʌp ə mæsk laɪk ə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin hɔk, dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt saɪz fəɹ ə bɔɪ.

"Olver," she said, sinking to her knees, "would you like to walk out with me at festival?" She held up a mask like a red-and-green hawk, just the right size for a boy.

bɪfɔɹ mæt kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, oʊlvɝ bɹoʊk fɹi ən ɹʌʃt tə hɝ. "oʊ, jɛs, pliz. θæŋk ju." ði ənɡɹeɪtfəl lɪɾəl laʊt læft əz ʃi taɪd ðə hɔk mæsk ɑn ɪz feɪs ən hʌɡd ɪm tə hɝ bʊzəm. hæn ɪn hænd, ðeɪ ɹæn aʊt, livɪŋ mæt ɡeɪpɪŋ.

Before Mat could open his mouth, Olver broke free and rushed to her. "Oh, yes, please. Thank you." The ungrateful little lout laughed as she tied the hawk mask on his face and hugged him to her bosom. Hand in hand, they ran out, leaving Mat gaping.

hi ɹəkʌvɝd hɪmsɛlf kwɪkli ɪnʌf wən taɪlɪn sɛd, "wɛl fəɹ jə aɪm nɑɾ ə dʒɛləs wʊmən, maɪ swit." ʃi pɹədus ðə lɔŋ aɪɝn ki tə hɪz dɔɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪn əɹ ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ bɛlt, ən ðən ənʌðɝ dʒʌs laɪk ɪt, wæɡəlɪŋ ðə pɛɹ ət hɪm. "pipəl ɔlweɪz kip kiz ɪn ə bɑks nɪɹ ðə dɔɹ." ðət wɑz wɛɹ i hæd lɛf hɪz. "ænd noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ θɪŋks ðəɹ maɪt bi ə sɛkən ki." wʌn ki wɛn bæk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt; ði ʌðɝ wɑz tɝn ɪn ðə lɑk wɪð ə laʊd klɪk bɪfɔɹ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪts fɛloʊ. "naʊ, læmbkɪn." ʃi smaɪld.

He recovered himself quickly enough when Tylin said, "Well for you I am not a jealous woman, my sweet." She produced the long iron key to his door from behind her gold-and-silver belt, and then another just like it, waggling the pair at him. "People always keep keys in a box near the door." That was where he had left his. "And no one ever thinks there might be a second key." One key went back behind her belt; the other was turned in the lock with a loud click before joining its fellow. "Now, lambkin." She smiled.

ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ. ðə wʊmən haʊndɪd hɪm, tʃɹaɪd tə stɑɹv hɪm; naʊ ʃi lɑkt əm ɪn təɡɛðɝ laɪk . . . laɪk i dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt. læmbkɪn! ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs wɝ baʊnsɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn ɪz skʌl. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt bɪznəs tə si tə. ðə daɪs hæd nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð faɪndɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt. . . . hi ɹitʃt əɹ ɪn tu lɔŋ stʃɹaɪdz, sizd əɹ ɑɹm, ən bɪɡæn fʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn əɹ bɛl fəɹ ðə kiz. "aɪ doʊn əv blʌɾi taɪm fəɹ - " hɪz bɹɛθ fɹoʊz əz ðə ʃɑɹp pɔɪn ə hɝ dæɡɝ bɪniθ ɪz tʃɪn ʃʌɾ ɪz maʊθ ən dʒɹoʊv ɪm ɹaɪɾ ʌp ɑntu hɪz toʊz.

It was too much. The woman hounded him, tried to starve him; now she locked them in together like . . . like he did not know what. Lambkin! Those bloody dice were bouncing around in his skull. Besides, he had important business to see to. The dice had never had anything to do with finding something, but. . . . He reached her in two long strides, seized her arm, and began fumbling in her belt for the keys. "I don't have bloody time for - " His breath froze as the sharp point of her dagger beneath his chin shut his mouth and drove him right up onto his toes.

"ɹimuv jəɹ hænd," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. hi mænədʒ tə lʊk daʊn ɪz noʊz əɾ əɹ feɪs. ʃi wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ naʊ. hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv əɹ ɑɹm kɛɹfəli. ʃi dɪd nɑt lɛsən ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɝ bleɪd, ðoʊ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "sk, tsk. aɪ də tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk əlaʊənsɪz fəɹ jə biɪŋ ən aʊtləndɝ, ɡɑsəlɪŋ, bʌt sɪns jə wɪʃ tə pleɪ ɹʌfli. . . . hænz ət jəɹ saɪdz. muv." ðə naɪfpɔɪnt ɡeɪv ə dɝɛkʃən. hi ʃʌfəl bækwɝɾ ɑn tɪptoʊ ɹæðɝ ðən əv ɪz nɛk slaɪst.

"Remove your hand," she said coldly. He managed to look down his nose at her face. She was not smiling now. He let go of her arm carefully. She did not lessen the pressure of her blade, though. She shook her head. "Tsk, tsk. I do try to make allowances for you being an outlander, gosling, but since you wish to play roughly. . . . Hands at your sides. Move." The knifepoint gave a direction. He shuffled backward on tiptoe rather than have his neck sliced.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" hi mʌmbəl θɹu hɪz tiθ. ə stʃɹɛtʃt nɛk pʊɾ ə stʃɹeɪn ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. ə stʃɹɛtʃt nɛk əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. "wɛl?" hi kəd tʃɹaɪ ɡɹæbɪŋ əɹ ɹɪst; hi wɑz kwɪk wɪð ɪz hænz. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" kwɪk ɪnʌf, wɪð ðə naɪf ɔlɹɛɾi əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt? ðət wɑz ðə kwɛstʃən. ðæt, ən ðə wʌn i æsk hɝ. ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə kɪl hɪm, ə ʃʌv ə hɝ ɹɪst ɹaɪt ðəɹ wəd dʒɹaɪv ðə dæɡɝ stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp ɪndə hɪz bɹeɪn. "wɪl jə ænsɝ mi!" ðət wɑz nɑt pænɪk ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. hi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ə pænɪk. "mædʒəsti? taɪlɪn?" wɛl, meɪbi hi wɑz ɪn ə bɪɾ ʌv ə pænɪk, tə juz əɹ neɪm. jə kəd kɔl ɛni wʊmən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ "dʌklɪŋ" əɹ "pʊɾɪŋ" ɔl deɪ, ən ʃi wəd smaɪl, bʌt juz əɹ neɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɛd jə kʊd, ən jə faʊn ə hɑɾɝ ɹɪsɛpʃən ðən jə wəd fəɹ ɡuzɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ wʊmən ɑn ðə stʃɹiɾ ɛniwɛɹ ɛls. ə fju kɪsəz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝ nɛvɝ ɪnʌf fəɹ pɝmɪʃən, iðɝ.

"What are you going to do?" he mumbled through his teeth. A stretched neck put a strain in his voice. A stretched neck among other things. "Well?" He could try grabbing her wrist; he was quick with his hands. "What are you going to do?" Quick enough, with the knife already at his throat? That was the question. That, and the one he asked her. If she intended to kill him, a shove of her wrist right there would drive the dagger straight up into his brain. "Will you answer me!" That was not panic in his voice. He was not in a panic. "Majesty? Tylin?" Well, maybe he was in a bit of a panic, to use her name. You could call any woman in Ebou Dar "duckling" or "pudding" all day, and she would smile, but use her name before she said you could, and you found a hotter reception than you would for goosing a strange woman on the street anywhere else. A few kisses exchanged were never enough for permission, either.

taɪlɪn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, oʊnli kɛpt ɪm tɪptoʊɪŋ bækwɝd, əntɪl sʌɾənli hɪz ʃoʊldɝz bʌmpt əɡɛnst sʌmθɪŋ ðət stɑp hɪm. wɪð ðət fleɪmɪŋ dæɡɝ nɛvɝ izɪŋ ə hɛɹ, hi kəd nɑt muv ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ aɪz ðət hæd bɪn foʊkəst ɑn əɹ feɪs dɑɹɾɪd. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ə flaʊɝ-kɑɹvd ɹɛd bɪdpoʊs hɑɹd bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. waɪ wəd ʃi bɹɪŋ ɪm . . . ? hɪz feɪs wɑz sʌɾənli əz kɹɪmzən əz ðə bɪdpoʊst. noʊ. ʃi kəd nɑt min tə. . . . ɪt wɑz nɑt disənt! ɪt wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl!

Tylin did not answer, only kept him tiptoeing backward, until suddenly his shoulders bumped against something that stopped him. With that flaming dagger never easing a hair, he could not move his head, but eyes that had been focused on her face darted. They were in the bedchamber, a flower-carved red bedpost hard between his shoulder blades. Why would she bring him . . . ? His face was suddenly as crimson as the bedpost. No. She could not mean to. . . . It was not decent! It was not possible!

"ju kæn də ðɪs tə mi," hi mʌmbəld ət hɝ, ən ɪf ɪz vɔɪs wɑz ə tʌtʃ bɹɛθi ən ʃɹɪl, hi ʃʊɹli hæd kɑz.

"You can't do this to me," he mumbled at her, and if his voice was a touch breathy and shrill, he surely had cause.

"wɑtʃ ən lɝn, maɪ kɪɾən," taɪlɪn sɛd, ən dʒɹu hɝ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf.

"Watch and learn, my kitten," Tylin said, and drew her marriage knife.

æftɝwɝd, ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl taɪm leɪɾɝ, hi ɪɹɪɾəbli pʊl ðə ʃiɾ ʌp tə hɪz tʃɛst. ə sɪlk ʃit; neɪlzin hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ðə kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə hʌm hæpəli bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd, ɑɹmz twɪstəd bɪhaɪn əɹ tə də ʌp ðə bʌɾənz ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. ɔl i hæɾ ɑn wɑz ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən ɑn ɪts kɔɹd - mʌtʃ ɡʊd ðət hæd dʌn - ən ðə blæk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. ə ɹɪbən ɑn əɹ pɹizɛnt, ðə blʌɾi wʊmən kɔld ɪt. hi ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ən snætʃt ɪz sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd paɪp ən təbæk paʊtʃ fɹəm ðə smɔl teɪbəl ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd fɹəm hɝ. ɡoʊldən tɑŋz ən ə hɑt koʊl ɪn ə ɡoʊldən boʊl ə sæn pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə minz fəɹ laɪɾɪŋ. foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz, hi pʌft əweɪ əz fɪɹsli əz i fɹaʊnd.

Afterward, a considerable time later, he irritably pulled the sheet up to his chest. A silk sheet; Nalesean had been right. The Queen of Altara hummed happily beside the bed, arms twisted behind her to do up the buttons of her dress. All he had on was the foxhead medallion on its cord - much good that had done - and the black scarf tied around his neck. A ribbon on her present, the bloody woman called it. He rolled over and snatched his silver-mounted pipe and tabac pouch from the small table on the other side from her. Golden tongs and a hot coal in a golden bowl of sand provided the means for lighting. Folding his arms, he puffed away as fiercely as he frowned.

"ju ʃəd nɑt flaʊns, dʌklɪŋ, ən jə ʃʊdn paʊt." ʃi jæŋkt əɹ dæɡɝ fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt wɑz dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ə bɪdpoʊs bɪsaɪɾ əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə pɔɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃiðɪŋ ɪt. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ? jə noʊ jə ɛndʒɔɪd jɝsɛlf əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ dɪd, ən aɪ. . . ." ʃi læf sʌɾənli, ən oʊ soʊ ɹɪtʃli, ɹiʃiðɪŋ ðə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf əz wɛl. "ɪf ðəɾ ɪz pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt biɪŋ tɑvɝən minz, jə mʌs bi vɛɹi pɑpjəlɝ." mæt flʌʃt laɪk faɪɝ.

"You should not flounce, duckling, and you shouldn't pout." She yanked her dagger from where it was driven into a bedpost beside her marriage knife, examining the point before sheathing it. "What is the matter? You know you enjoyed yourself as much as I did, and I. . . ." She laughed suddenly, and oh so richly, resheathing the marriage knife as well. "If that is part of what being ta'veren means, you must be very popular." Mat flushed like fire.

"ɪɾ ɪzənt nætʃɹəl," hi bɝst aʊt, jæŋkɪŋ ðə paɪpɛstəm fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. "ɪm ðə wʌn huz səpoʊz tə də ðə tʃeɪsɪŋ!" hɝ əstɑnɪʃt aɪz ʃʊɹli mɪɹɝɾ ɪz oʊn. hæd taɪlɪn bɪn ə tævɝn meɪɾ u smaɪl ðə ɹaɪt weɪ, hi maɪɾ əv tʃɹaɪɾ ɪz lʌk - wɛl, ɪf ðə tævɝn meɪd lækt ə sʌn u laɪk poʊkɪŋ hoʊlz ɪn pipəl - bʌɾ i wɑz ðə wʌn u tʃeɪst. hi hæd dʒʌs nɛvɝ θɔɾ ʌv ɪt ðət weɪ bɪfɔɹ. hi hæd nɛvɝ hæd ðə nid tə, bɪfɔɹ.

"It isn't natural," he burst out, yanking the pipestem from between his teeth. "I'm the one who's supposed to do the chasing!" Her astonished eyes surely mirrored his own. Had Tylin been a tavern maid who smiled the right way, he might have tried his luck - well, if the tavern maid lacked a son who liked poking holes in people - but he was the one who chased. He had just never thought of it that way before. He had never had the need to, before.

taɪlɪn bɪɡæn læfɪŋ, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ən waɪpɪŋ əɾ əɹ aɪz wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. "oʊ, pɪdʒən. aɪ də kip fɝɡɛɾɪŋ. jə ɑɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, naʊ. aɪ lɛft ə lɪɾəl pɹɛzən fəɹ jə ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum." ʃi pæɾəd ɪz fʊt θɹu ðə ʃit. "it wɛl tədeɪ. jə ɑɹ gɑnə nid jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ."

Tylin began laughing, shaking her head and wiping at her eyes with her fingers. "Oh, pigeon. I do keep forgetting. You are in Ebou Dar, now. I left a little present for you in the sitting room." She patted his foot through the sheet. "Eat well today. You are going to need your strength."

mæt pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz ən tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə wip. wən i ənkʌvɝd ðɛm, ʃi wɑz ɡɔn.

Mat put a hand over his eyes and tried very hard not to weep. When he uncovered them, she was gone.

klaɪmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə bɛd, hi tʌk ðə ʃiɾ ɝaʊn hɪm; fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə noʊʃən ʌv wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn bɛɹ fɛlt ənkʌmftəɹbəl. ðə blʌɾi wʊmən maɪt lip aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. ðə ɡɑɹməns i hæd bɪn wɛɹɪŋ leɪ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. waɪ bɑðɝ wɪð leɪsəz, hi θɔt saʊɝli, wən jə kən dʒʌs kʌt sʌmbɑɾiz kloʊðz ɔf! ʃi hæd noʊ kɔl tə slaɪs ʌp ɪz ɹɛd koʊt ðət weɪ, ðoʊ. ʃi hæd dʒʌst ɛndʒɔɪd pilɪŋ ɪm wɪð əɹ naɪf.

Climbing out of the bed, he tucked the sheet around him; for some reason, the notion of walking around bare felt uncomfortable. The bloody woman might leap out of the wardrobe. The garments he had been wearing lay on the floor. Why bother with laces, he thought sourly, when you can just cut somebody's clothes off! She had no call to slice up his red coat that way, though. She had just enjoyed peeling him with her knife.

nɑt kwaɪt hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ, hi pʊld oʊpən ðə tɔl ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɪlt wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. ʃi wɑz nɑt haɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. hɪz tʃɔɪsəz wɝ lɪməɾəd; nɹɪm hæd moʊst ə hɪz koʊts fəɹ klinɪŋ əɹ mɛndɪŋ. dʒɹɛsɪŋ kwɪkli, hi tʃoʊz ə pleɪn koʊɾ ə dɑɹk bɹɑnz sɪlk, ðən stʌf ðə slaɪst ɹæɡz əz fɑɹ ʌndɝ ðə bɛɾ əz i kəd ɹitʃ əntɪl i kəd dɪspoʊz ə ðɛm wɪθaʊt nɹɪm siɪŋ. əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. tu mɛni pipəl ɔlɹɛɾi nu ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ ʌv wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪtwin ɪm ən taɪlɪn; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ hi kəd feɪs ɛnibəɾi noʊɪŋ ðɪs.

Not quite holding his breath, he pulled open the tall red-and-gilt wardrobe. She was not hiding inside. His choices were limited; Nerim had most of his coats for cleaning or mending. Dressing quickly, he chose a plain coat of dark bronze silk, then stuffed the sliced rags as far under the bed as he could reach until he could dispose of them without Nerim seeing. Or anyone else, for that matter. Too many people already knew entirely too much of what was going on between him and Tylin; there was no way he could face anybody knowing this.

ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, hi lɪftəd ðə lɪɾ ə ðə lækɹwɛɹ bɑks baɪ ðə dɔɹ, ðən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl wɪð ə saɪ; hi hæd nɑt ɹɪli ɪkspɛktəd taɪlɪn tə ɹipleɪs ðə ki. hi lin əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ. ði ənlɑk dɔɹ. laɪt, wʌt wɑz i ɡoʊɪŋ tə du? muv bæk tə ði ɪn? bɝn waɪ ðə daɪs hæd stɑp bɪfɔɹ. oʊnli, hi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæs taɪlɪn tə bɹaɪb mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ən inɪd, əɹ ði ɪnkipɝ wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt. hi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæs nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn tə kleɪm i hæd bɹoʊkən səm əɡɹimən ən pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ðɛɹ pɹɑməsəz. bɝn ɔl wɪmən!

In the sitting room, he lifted the lid of the lacquerware box by the door, then let it fall with a sigh; he had not really expected Tylin to replace the key. He leaned against the door. The unlocked door. Light, what was he going to do? Move back to the inn? Burn why the dice had stopped before. Only, he would not put it past Tylin to bribe Mistress Anan and Enid, or the innkeeper wherever he went. He would not put it past Nynaeve and Elayne to claim he had broken some agreement and put an end to their promises. Burn all women!

ə lɑɹdʒ pɑɹsəl ɪlæbɹətli ɹæpt ɪn ɡɹin peɪpɝ sæɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz. ɪt kənteɪn ən iɡəl mæsk ɪn blæk ən ɡoʊld ən ə koʊt kʌvɝd wɪð fɛðɝz tə mætʃ. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ ə ɹɛd sɪlk pɝs hoʊldɪŋ twɛnti ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz ən ə noʊt ðət smɛld ə flaʊɝz.

A large parcel elaborately wrapped in green paper sat on one of the tables. It contained an eagle mask in black and gold and a coat covered with feathers to match. There was also a red silk purse holding twenty gold crowns and a note that smelled of flowers.

aɪ wʊɾə bɑt jə ən ɪɹɪŋ, paɪɡlɛt, bʌɾ aɪ noʊɾəst jəɹ ɪɹ ɪz nɑt pɪɹst. hæv ɪt dʌn, ən baɪ jɝsɛlf sʌmθɪŋ naɪs.

I would have bought you an earring, piglet, but I noticed your ear is not pierced. Have it done, and buy yourself something nice.

hi nɪɹli wɛpt əɡɛn. hi ɡeɪv wɪmən pɹizɛns. ðə wɝld wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn ɪts hɛd! paɪɡlɛt? oʊ, laɪt! æftɝ ə mɪnət, hi dɪd teɪk ðə mæsk; ʃi oʊɾ ɪm ðət mʌtʃ, fəɹ ɪz koʊɾ əloʊn.

He nearly wept again. He gave women presents. The world was standing on its head! Piglet? Oh, Light! After a minute, he did take the mask; she owed him that much, for his coat alone.

wən i faɪnəli ɹitʃt ðə smɔl, ʃeɪɾɪd kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn miɾɪŋ itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə taɪni ɹaʊn pul ə lɪli pædz ən bɹaɪtli spɑɾəd waɪt fɪʃ, hi faʊnd neɪlzin ən bɝdʒɪt ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðə fɛstəvəl ə bɝdz, tu. ðə tɛɹən hæd kəntɛntəd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə pleɪn ɡɹin mæsk, bʌt bɝdʒɪts wɑz ə spɹeɪ ʌv jɛloʊ-ænd-ɹɛd wɪð ə kɹɛst ə plumz, hɝ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ hʌŋ lus, wɪð fɛðɝz taɪɾ ɔl daʊn ɪts lɛŋθ, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə dʒɹɛs wɪð ə waɪd jɛloʊ bɛlt, daɪəfənəs bɪniθ mɔɹ ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ fɛðɝz. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪvil nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ɹaɪzɛlz, jɛɾ ɪt simd əbaʊt tə ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi muvd. hi hæd nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə hɝ wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs laɪk ʌðɝ wɪmən.

When he finally reached the small, shaded courtyard where they had been meeting each morning beside a tiny round pool of lily pads and brightly spotted white fish, he found Nalesean and Birgitte ready for the Festival of Birds, too. The Tairen had contented himself with a plain green mask, but Birgitte's was a spray of yellow-and-red with a crest of plumes, her golden hair hung loose, with feathers tied all down its length, and she wore a dress with a wide yellow belt, diaphanous beneath more red and yellow feathers. It did not reveal nearly as much as Riselle's, yet it seemed about to every time she moved. He had never thought of her wearing a dress like other women.

"səmtaɪmz ɪts fʌn tə bi lʊkt æt," ʃi sɛd, poʊkɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz, wən i kɑmɛntəd. hɝ ɡɹɪn wʊɾə dʌn fəɹ neɪlzin seɪɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ fʌn ɪt wɑz tə pɪntʃ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz. "ðɛɹz ə lɑt mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən fɛðɝ dænsɝz wɔɹ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɪt tə sloʊ mi daʊn, ən ɛniweɪ, aɪ kænɑt si wɪl əv tə muv kwɪkli ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ." ðə daɪs ɹæɾəld ɪn ɪz hɛd. "wʌt kɛp ju?" ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ju dɪdn meɪk əs weɪt soʊ jə kəd tɪkəl ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl, aɪ hoʊp." hi hoʊpt i wɑz nɑt blʌʃɪŋ.

"Sometimes it's fun to be looked at," she said, poking him in the ribs, when he commented. Her grin would have done for Nalesean saying how much fun it was to pinch serving girls. "There's a lot more to it than feather dancers wore, but not enough to it to slow me down, and anyway, I cannot see we'll have to move quickly on this side of the river." The dice rattled in his head. "What kept you?" she went on. "You didn't make us wait so you could tickle a pretty girl, I hope." He hoped he was not blushing.

"aɪ - " hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən wʌɾ ɪkskjus i wəɾ əv meɪd, bʌt dʒʌs ðən hæf ə dʌzən mɛn wɛɹɪŋ fɛðɝd koʊts stʃɹoʊld ɪndə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ɔl wɪð ðoʊz nɛɹoʊ sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ hɪps, ɔl bʌt wʌn wɛɹɪŋ ən ɪlæbɹət mæsk wɪð kʌlɝfəl kɹɛst ən bik ðət ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd noʊ bɝɾ ɛvɝ sin baɪ hjumən aɪz. ði ɪksɛpʃən wɑz bɛslən, twɝlɪŋ ɪz mæsk baɪ ɪts ɹɪbən. "oʊ, blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, wʌts i duɪŋ hɪɹ?"

"I - " He was not certain what excuse he would have made, but just then half a dozen men wearing feathered coats strolled into the courtyard, all with those narrow swords on their hips, all but one wearing an elaborate mask with colorful crest and beak that represented no bird ever seen by human eyes. The exception was Beslan, twirling his mask by its ribbon. "Oh, blood and bloody ashes, what's he doing here?"

"bɛslən?" neɪlzin foʊldəɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sɔɹɾ ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "waɪ, bɝn maɪ soʊl, hi sɛz i ɪntɛnz tə spɛn ðə fɛstəvəl ɪn jəɹ kʌmpəni. səm pɹɑməs jə tu meɪd, hi sɛz. aɪ toʊld ɪm ɪt wəd bi dɛdli bɔɹɪŋ, bʌɾ i wʊdn bɪliv mi."

"Beslan?" Nalesean folded his hands on the pommel of his sword and shook his head in disbelief. "Why, burn my soul, he says he intends to spend the festival in your company. Some promise you two made, he says. I told him it would be deadly boring, but he wouldn't believe me."

"aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ɪts ɛvɝ bɔɹɪŋ ɝaʊn mæt," taɪlɪnz sʌn sɛd; hɪz baʊ tʊk əm ɔl ɪn, bʌɾ ɪz dɑɹk aɪz ɪspɛʃli lɪŋɡɝɾ ɑn bɝdʒɪt. "aɪv nɛvɝ hæd soʊ mʌtʃ fʌn əz aɪ dɪd dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɪð ɪm ən ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪnz wɔɹɾɝ ɑn swʊvən naɪt, ðoʊ tʃɹuθ, aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ lɪɾəl." hi dɪd nɑt sim tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət wɔɹɾɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə teɪst ʃi hæd ʃoʊn ɪn mɛn - bɛslən wɑz faɪn-lʊkɪŋ, meɪbi ə lɪɾəl tu faɪn, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əɹ sɔɹt - stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi smaɪl slaɪtli, ən pɹin ʌndɝ ɪz skɹuɾəni.

"I cannot think it is ever boring around Mat," Tylin's son said; his bow took them all in, but his dark eyes especially lingered on Birgitte. "I've never had so much fun as I did drinking with him and the Lady Elayne's Warder on Swovan Night, though truth, I remember little." He did not seem to recognize that Warder. Strangely, considering the taste she had shown in men - Beslan was fine-looking, maybe a little too fine, not at all her sort - strangely, she smiled slightly, and preened under his scrutiny.

ɹaɪt ðɛn, mæt dɪd nɑt kɛɹ haʊ aʊɾ ə kɛɹɪktɝ ʃi bɪheɪvd. ɑbviəsli bɛslən səspɛktəd nʌθɪŋ, əɹ ðət sɔɹɾ ə hɪz laɪkli wəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi aʊt, bʌt ðə læs θɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt mæt wɑntəd wɑz ə deɪ ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ðə mæn. ɪt wəd bi ɪkskɹuʃieɪɾɪŋ. hi hæd səm sɛns ə disənsi, ivən ɪf bɛslənz mʌðɝ dɪd nɑt.

Right then, Mat did not care how out of character she behaved. Obviously Beslan suspected nothing, or that sword of his likely would already be out, but the last thing under the Light Mat wanted was a day in company with the man. It would be excruciating. He had some sense of decency, even if Beslan's mother did not.

ði oʊnli pɹɑbləm wɑz bɛslən, hu tʊk ðət blʌɾi pɹɑməs tə ətɛn ɔl ðə fɛstəvəlz ən fistdeɪz təɡɛðɝ vɛɹi sɪɹiəsli. ðə mɔɹ mæt əɡɹid wɪð neɪlzin ðət ðə deɪ ðeɪ hæd plænd wəd bi dʌl bɪɑn bɪlif, ðə mɔɹ dɪtɝmən bɛslən ɡɹu. æftɝ ə bɪt, hɪz feɪs bɪɡæn tə dɑɹkən, ən mæt bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðət sɔɹd maɪt bi ənʃið jɛt. wɛl, ə pɹɑməs wɑz ə pɹɑməs. wən i ən neɪlzin ən bɝdʒɪt lɛf ðə pæləs, hæf ə dʌzən fɛðɝd fulz stʃɹʌɾɪd əlɔŋ. mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv hæpən hæd bɝdʒɪt bɪn wɛɹɪŋ əɹ pɹɑpɝ kloʊðz. ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm kɛpt aɪɪŋ əɹ ən smaɪlɪŋ.

The only problem was Beslan, who took that bloody promise to attend all the festivals and feastdays together very seriously. The more Mat agreed with Nalesean that the day they had planned would be dull beyond belief, the more determined Beslan grew. After a bit, his face began to darken, and Mat began to think that sword might be unsheathed yet. Well, a promise was a promise. When he and Nalesean and Birgitte left the palace, half a dozen feathered fools strutted along. Mat was sure it would not have happened had Birgitte been wearing her proper clothes. The whole lot of them kept eyeing her and smiling.

"wʌt wɑz ɔl ðət twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊnd waɪl i wɑz spɪlɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔl oʊvɝ ju?" hi mʌɾɝd əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə mɔl hɛɹə. hi tʌɡd ðə ɹɪbən hoʊldɪŋ ði iɡəl mæsk taɪɾɝ.

"What was all that twisting around while he was spilling his eyes all over you?" he muttered as they crossed the Mol Hara. He tugged the ribbon holding the eagle mask tighter.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt twɪst, aɪ muvd." hɝ pɹɪmnəs wɑz soʊ bleɪɾəntli fɔls, hi wʊɾə læf səm ʌðɝ taɪm. "slaɪtli." əbɹʌpli hɝ ɡɹɪn wɑz bæk, ən ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs fəɹ ɪz ɪɹ əloʊn. "aɪ toʊl jə səmtaɪmz ɪts fʌn tə bi lʊkt æt; dʒʌs kəz ðəɹ ɔl tu pɹɪɾi dʌzn min aɪ kænɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ðɛm lʊkɪŋ. oʊ, jəl wɑnə lʊk ət hɝ," ʃi æɾəd, pɔɪntɪŋ tə ə slɛndɝ wʊmən u wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ baɪ ɪn ə blu aʊl mæsk ən ɹæðɝ fjuɝ fɛðɝz ðən ɹaɪzɛl hæd wɔɹn.

"I did not twist, I moved." Her primness was so blatantly false, he would have laughed some other time. "Slightly." Abruptly her grin was back, and she lowered her voice for his ear alone. "I told you sometimes it's fun to be looked at; just because they're all too pretty doesn't mean I cannot enjoy them looking. Oh, you'll want to look at her," she added, pointing to a slender woman who went running by in a blue owl mask and rather fewer feathers than Riselle had worn.

ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz əbaʊt bɝdʒɪt; ʃi wəd nʌdʒ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz ən pɔɪn aʊɾ ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl fəɹ ɪz aɪ əz ɹɛɾəli əz ɛni mæn i hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn, ən ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə pɔɪn aʊɾ ɪn tɝn wʌt ʃi laɪk tə si, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒɛnɝəli ði ʌɡliəs mæn ɪn saɪt. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi tʃoʊz tə ɡoʊ hæf-neɪkəd tədeɪ - ə kɔɹɾɝ, ɛniweɪ - ʃi wɑz . . . wɛl, ə fɹɛnd. ə stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝld, ɪt wɑz tɝnɪŋ aʊt tə bi. wʌn wʊmən i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv əz ə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ kəmpænjən, ən ənʌðɝ æftɝ ɪm əz ɪntɛnli əz i hæɾ ɛvɝ pɝsuɾ ɛni pɹɪɾi wʊmən, ɪn ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz əɹ ɪz oʊn. mɔɹ ɪntɛnli; hi hæd nɛvɝ tʃeɪst ɛni wʊmən u lɛɾ ɪm noʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi tʃeɪst. ə vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝld.

That was one of the things about Birgitte; she would nudge him in the ribs and point out a pretty girl for his eye as readily as any man he had ever known, and expect him to point out in turn what she liked to see, which was generally the ugliest man in sight. Whether or not she chose to go half-naked today - a quarter, anyway - she was . . . well, a friend. A strange world, it was turning out to be. One woman he was beginning to think of as a drinking companion, and another after him as intently as he had ever pursued any pretty woman, in those old memories or his own. More intently; he had never chased any woman who let him know she did not want to be chased. A very strange world.

ðə sʌn stʊd lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ tə ɪts pik, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sɛləbɹəns fɪl ðə stʃɹits ən skwɛɹz ən bɹɪdʒəz. tʌmblɝz ən dʒʌɡəlɝz ən mjuzɪʃənz wɪð fɛðɝz soʊn əbaʊt ðɛɹ kloʊðz pɝfɔɹmd əɾ ɛvɹi stʃɹit kɔɹnɝ, ðə mjuzɪk ɔfən dʒɹaʊn ɪn læftɝ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ. fəɹ ðə pʊɹɝ foʊk ə fju fɛðɝz leɪst ɪndə ðɛɹ hɛɹ səfaɪst, pɪdʒən fɛðɝz ɡæðɝd fɹəm ðə peɪvmən fəɹ ðə stʃɹit tʃɪlʒɹən dɑdʒɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən ðə bɛɡɝz, bʌt mæsks ən kɑstumz ɡɹu mɔɹ ɪlæbɹəɾ əz pɝsɪz ɡɹu hɛviɝ. mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət, ən fɹikwənli mɔɹ skændələs. mɛn ən wɪmən əlaɪk wɝ ɔfən dɛkt ɪn fɛðɝz ðət ɹɪvil mɔɹ skɪn ðən ɹaɪzɛl əɹ ðət wʊmən bæk ɪn ðə mɔl hɛɹə. noʊ kɑmɝs muvd ɪn ðə stʃɹits əɹ kənælz tədeɪ, ðoʊ ə nʌmbɝ ə ʃɑps sim tə bi oʊpən - əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹi tævɝn ən ɪn, ʌv kɔɹs - bʌt hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə wæɡən meɪɾ ɪts weɪ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ əɹ ə bɑɹdʒ wɑz poʊld əlɔŋ səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə plætfɔɹm wɛɹ jʌŋ mɛn ən wɪmən poʊzd ɪn bɹaɪt bɝd mæsks ðət kʌvɝd ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝ hɛdz, wɪð spɹɛɾɪŋ kɹɛsts səmtaɪmz ɹaɪzɪŋ ə fʊl peɪs, muvɪŋ lɔŋ kʌlɝfəl wɪŋz ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛɹ kɑstumz wɝ ɪkspoʊzd oʊnli ɪn flæʃɪz. wɪtʃ wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ.

The sun stood little more than halfway to its peak, but already celebrants filled the streets and squares and bridges. Tumblers and jugglers and musicians with feathers sewn about their clothes performed at every street corner, the music often drowned in laughter and shouting. For the poorer folk a few feathers laced into their hair sufficed, pigeon feathers gathered from the pavement for the street children dodging about and the beggars, but masks and costumes grew more elaborate as purses grew heavier. More elaborate, and frequently more scandalous. Men and women alike were often decked in feathers that revealed more skin than Riselle or that woman back in the Mol Hara. No commerce moved in the streets or canals today, though a number of shops seemed to be open - along with every tavern and inn, of course - but here and there a wagon made its way through the throng or a barge was poled along supporting a platform where young men and women posed in bright bird masks that covered their entire heads, with spreading crests sometimes rising a full pace, moving long colorful wings in such a way that the rest of their costumes were exposed only in flashes. Which was just as well, considering.

əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə bɛslən, ðiz sɛɾɪŋz, əz ðeɪ wɝ kɔld, wɝ juʒəwəli pɹizɛntəɾ ɪn ɡɪl hɔlz ən pɹaɪvət pæləsəz ən haʊzɪz. ði ɪntaɪɝ fɛstəvəl nɔɹməli tʊk pleɪs ɪndɔɹz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. ɪt dɪd nɑt snoʊ pɹɑpɝli ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ivən wən ðə wɛðɝ wɑz əz ɪt ʃəd bi - bɛslən sɛɾ i wəd laɪk tə si ðɪs snoʊ, wʌn deɪ - bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ɔɹɾənɛɹi wɪntɝ wɑz koʊld ɪnʌf tə kip pipəl fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ ɝaʊn aʊtdɔɹz ɔl bʌɾ ʌn-kloʊðd. wɪð ðə hit, ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz spɪlɪŋ ɪndə ðə stʃɹits. weɪɾ əntɪl naɪt fɛl, bɛslən sɛd; ðən mæt wəd ɹɪli si sʌmθɪŋ. əz sʌnlaɪt feɪɾəd, soʊ dɪɾ ɪnhəbɪʃənz.

According to Beslan, these settings, as they were called, were usually presented in guild halls and private palaces and houses. The entire festival normally took place indoors for the most part. It did not snow properly in Ebou Dar even when the weather was as it should be - Beslan said he would like to see this snow, one day - but apparently ordinary winter was cold enough to keep people from running around outdoors all but un-clothed. With the heat, everything was spilling into the streets. Wait until night fell, Beslan said; then Mat would really see something. As sunlight faded, so did inhibitions.

stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə tɔl slɛndɝ wʊmən ɡlaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn mæsk ən fɛðɝd kloʊk ən bɪɑn ðæt, sɪks əɹ sɛvən fɛðɝz, mæt wʌndɝd wʌɾ ɪnhəbɪʃənz səm ə ðiz foʊk hæd lɛf tə ʃɛd. hi ɔlmoʊst ʃaʊɾəd əɾ əɹ tə kʌvɝ hɝsɛlf wɪð ðət kloʊk. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit, bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪɾ ən ɛvɹibɑɾi?

Staring at a tall slender woman gliding along through the crowd in mask and feathered cloak and beyond that, six or seven feathers, Mat wondered what inhibitions some of these folk had left to shed. He almost shouted at her to cover herself with that cloak. She was pretty, but out in the street, before the Light and everybody?

ðoʊz wæɡənz kæɹiɪŋ ðə sɛɾɪŋz ətʃɹæktəd fɑloʊɝz, ʌv kɔɹs, θɪk nɑts ə mɛn ən wɪmən u ʃaʊɾəd ən læft əz ðeɪ tɔs kɔɪnz, ən səmtaɪmz foʊldəd noʊts, ɑntu ðə wæɡənz ən skwizd ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ əsaɪd. hi bɪkeɪm juz tə fliɪŋ əhɛɾ əntɪl ðeɪ kəd dʌk daʊn ə kɹɔsɪŋ stʃɹit, əɹ weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ðə sɛɾɪŋ wɛn baɪ tə kɹɔs ən ɪntɝsɛkʃən əɹ bɹɪdʒ. waɪl weɪɾɪŋ, bɝdʒɪɾ ən neɪlzin tɔs kɔɪnz tə fɪlθi ɝtʃənz ən dɝɾiɝ bɛɡɝz. wɛl, neɪlzin tɔst; bɝdʒɪt kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ən pɹɛst itʃ kɔɪn ɪndə ə ɡɹʌbi hæn laɪk ə ɡɪft.

Those wagons carrying the settings attracted followers, of course, thick knots of men and women who shouted and laughed as they tossed coins, and sometimes folded notes, onto the wagons and squeezed everyone else in the street aside. He became used to fleeing ahead until they could duck down a crossing street, or waiting until the setting went by to cross an intersection or bridge. While waiting, Birgitte and Nalesean tossed coins to filthy urchins and dirtier beggars. Well, Nalesean tossed; Birgitte concentrated on the children, and pressed each coin into a grubby hand like a gift.

ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz weɪts, bɛslən sʌɾənli pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn neɪlzinz ɑɹm, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əbʌv ðə kɹaʊɾ ən ə kækɑfəni ʌv mjuzɪk kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ət list sɪks dɪfɹən pleɪsəz. "fɝɡɪv mi, tɛɹən, bʌt nɑt hɪm." ə ɹæɡəd mæn ɛdʒ bæk ɪndə ðə θɹɔŋ, wɛɹəli; ɡɔnt-tʃikt ən boʊni, hi sim tə hæv lɔst wʌtɛvɝ pɪɾəfəl fɛðɝz i maɪɾ əv faʊn fəɹ ɪz hɛɹ.

In one of those waits, Beslan suddenly put a hand on Nalesean's arm, raising his voice above the crowd and a cacophony of music coming from at least six different places. "Forgive me, Tairen, but not him." A ragged man edged back into the throng, warily; gaunt-cheeked and bony, he seemed to have lost whatever pitiful feathers he might have found for his hair.

"waɪ nɑt?" neɪlzin dɪmændəd.

"Why not?" Nalesean demanded.

"noʊ bɹæs ɹɪŋ ɑn ɪz lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ," bɛslən ɹɪplaɪd. "hiz nɑɾ ɪn ðə ɡɪld."

"No brass ring on his little finger," Beslan replied. "He's not in the guild."

"laɪt," mæt sɛd, "ə mæn kæn ivən bɛɡ ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi wɪθaʊt bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ə ɡɪld?" meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɪz toʊn. ðə bɛɡɝ lɛp fəɹ ɪz θɹoʊt, ə naɪf əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɡɹaɪmi fɪst.

"Light," Mat said, "a man can't even beg in this city without belonging to a guild?" Maybe it was his tone. The beggar leaped for his throat, a knife appearing in his grimy fist.

wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, mæt ɡɹæb ðə mænz ɑɹm ən spʌn, slɪŋɪŋ ɪm əweɪ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd; səm pipəl kɝst ət mæt, səm ət ðə spɹɔlɪŋ bɛɡɝ. səm tɔs ðə fɛloʊ ə kɔɪn.

Without thinking, Mat grabbed the man's arm and spun, slinging him away into the crowd; some people cursed at Mat, some at the sprawling beggar. Some tossed the fellow a coin.

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, mæt sɔ ə sɛkən skɪni mæn ɪn ɹæɡz tʃɹaɪ tə pʊʃ bɝdʒɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ tə ɹitʃ ɪm wɪð ə lɔŋ naɪf. ɪt wɑz ə fulɪʃ mɪsteɪk tə ʌndɝɛstəmeɪt ðə wʊmən kəz ə hɝ kɑstum; fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ əmʌŋ ðoʊz fɛðɝz ʃi pɹədust ə naɪf ən stæbd ɪm bɪniθ ði ɑɹm.

From the corner of his eye, Mat saw a second skinny man in rags try to push Birgitte out of the way to reach him with a long knife. It was a foolish mistake to underestimate the woman because of her costume; from somewhere among those feathers she produced a knife and stabbed him beneath the arm.

"lʊk aʊt!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd ət hɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ wɔɹnɪŋz; ivən əz i ʃaʊɾəd, hi dʒɹu fɹəm ɪz koʊt-sliv ən θɹu saɪdɪɹmd. ðə bleɪd stʃɹik pæst əɹ feɪs tə sɪŋk ɪndə ðə θɹoʊɾ ə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ bɛɡɝ flɔntɪŋ stil bɪfɔɹ i kəd plæn ɪɾ ɪn əɹ ɹɪbz.

"Look out!" Mat shouted at her, but there was no time for warnings; even as he shouted, he drew from his coat-sleeve and threw sidearmed. The blade streaked past her face to sink into the throat of yet another beggar flaunting steel before he could plant it in her ribs.

sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɝ bɛɡɝz ɛvɹiwɛɹ wɪð naɪvz, ən klʌbz stʌɾɪd wɪð spaɪks; skɹimz ən ʃaʊts ɹoʊz əz pipəl ɪn mæsks ən kɑstumz skɹæmbəl tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. neɪlzin slæʃt ə mæn ɪn ɹæɡz əkɹɔs ðə feɪs, sɛndɪŋ ɪm ɹilɪŋ; bɛslən ɹæn ənʌðɝ θɹu ðə mɪɾəl, waɪl ɪz kɔstum kɹoʊniz fɔt stɪl ʌðɝz.

Suddenly there were beggars everywhere with knives, and clubs studded with spikes; screams and shouts rose as people in masks and costumes scrambled to get out of the way. Nalesean slashed a man in rags across the face, sending him reeling; Beslan ran another through the middle, while his costumed cronies fought still others.

mæt hæd noʊ taɪm tə si mɔɹ; hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf bæk-tə-bæk wɪð bɝdʒɪɾ ən feɪsɪŋ ɪz oʊn ædvɝsɛɹiz. hi kəd fil əɹ ʃɪftɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm, hɪɹ əɹ mʌɾɝ kɝsɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz bɛɹli kɑnʃəs ʌv ɪt; bɝdʒɪt kəd teɪk kɛɹ ə hɝsɛlf, ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tu mɛn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd də ðə seɪm. ðə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ wɪð ðə tuθləs snɪɹ hæɾ oʊnli wʌn ɑɹm ən ə pʌkɝd sɑkət wɛɹ ɪz lɛft aɪ hæd bɪn, bʌɾ ɪz fɪs hɛld ə klʌb tu fit lɔŋ, ɪnsɝkəl baɪ aɪɝn bænz ðət spɹaʊɾəd spaɪks laɪk stil θɔɹnz. hɪz ɹæt-feɪs lɪɾəl kəmpænjən stɪl hæd boʊθ aɪz ən sɛvɹəl tiθ, ən dɪspaɪt sʌŋkən tʃiks ən ɑɹmz ðət simd ɔl boʊn ən sɪnu, hi muv laɪk ə sneɪk, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps ən flɪkɪŋ ə ɹʌsti dæɡɝ fɹəm hæn tə hænd. mæt eɪm ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ naɪf ɪn ɪz oʊn hæn fɝst ət wʌn, ðən ði ʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz stɪl lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ə mænz vaɪɾəlz, ən ðeɪ dænst ən ʃʌfəld, itʃ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝ tə lip əɾ ɪm fɝst.

Mat had no time to see more; he found himself back-to-back with Birgitte and facing his own adversaries. He could feel her shifting against him, hear her mutter curses, but he was barely conscious of it; Birgitte could take care of herself, and watching the two men in front of him, he was not sure he could do the same. The hulking fellow with the toothless sneer had only one arm and a puckered socket where his left eye had been, but his fist held a club two feet long, encircled by iron bands that sprouted spikes like steel thorns. His rat-faced little companion still had both eyes and several teeth, and despite sunken cheeks and arms that seemed all bone and sinew, he moved like a snake, licking his lips and flicking a rusty dagger from hand to hand. Mat aimed the shorter knife in his own hand first at one, then the other. It was still long enough to reach a man's vitals, and they danced and shuffled, each waiting for the other to leap at him first.

"oʊl kʌli woʊn laɪk ðɪs, spɑɹ," ðə bɪɡɝ mæn ɡɹaʊld, ən ɹæt-feɪs dɑɹɾɪd fɔɹwɝd, ɹʌsti bleɪd flæʃɪŋ fɹəm hæn tə hænd.

"Old Cully won't like this, Spar," the bigger man growled, and rat-face darted forward, rusty blade flashing from hand to hand.

hi dɪd nɑt kaʊn ɑn ðə naɪf ðət sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ɪn mæts lɛf hæn ən slaɪst əkɹɔs ɪz ɹɪst. ðə dæɡɝ klæɾɝd tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, bʌt ðə fɛloʊ flʌŋ hɪmsɛlf ət mæt ɛniweɪ. əz mæts ʌðɝ bleɪd stæbd ɪndə hɪz tʃɛst, hi skwild, aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ waɪd, ɑɹmz ɹæpɪŋ ɝaʊn mæt kənvʌlsɪvli. ðə bɔl fɛloʊz snɪɹ waɪɾənd, hɪz klʌb ɹaɪzɪŋ əz i stɛpt ɪn.

He did not count on the knife that suddenly appeared in Mat's left hand and sliced across his wrist. The dagger clattered to the paving stones, but the fellow flung himself at Mat anyway. As Mat's other blade stabbed into his chest, he squealed, eyes going wide, arms wrapping around Mat convulsively. The bald fellow's sneer widened, his club rising as he stepped in.

ðə ɡɹɪn vænɪʃt əz tu bɛɡɝz swɔɹmd oʊvɝ hɪm, snɑɹlɪŋ ən stæbɪŋ.

The grin vanished as two beggars swarmed over him, snarling and stabbing.

stɛɹɪŋ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, mæt ʃʌvd ɹæt-feɪsəz kɔɹps əweɪ. ðə stʃɹit wɑz klɪɹ fəɹ fɪfti peɪsɪz ɪksɛp fəɹ kəmbæɾənts, ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ bɛɡɝz ɹoʊld ɑn ðə peɪvmənt, tu əɹ θɹi əɹ səmtaɪmz fɔɹ stæbɪŋ ət wʌn, biɾɪŋ ɪm wɪð klʌbz əɹ ɹɑks.

Staring incredulously, Mat shoved rat-face's corpse away. The street was clear for fifty paces except for combatants, and everywhere beggars rolled on the pavement, two or three or sometimes four stabbing at one, beating him with clubs or rocks.

bɛslən kɑt mæts ɑɹm. ðəɹ wɑz blʌɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, bʌɾ i wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ. "lɛts ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ ən lɛt ðə fɛloʊʃɪp ʌv ɑlmz fɪnɪʃ ɪts bɪznəs. ðɛɹz noʊ ɑnɝ ɪn faɪɾɪŋ bɛɡɝz, ən bɪsaɪdz, ðə ɡɪld woʊn liv ɛni ʌv ðiz ɪntɝloʊpɝz əlaɪv. fɑloʊ mi." neɪlzin wɑz skaʊlɪŋ - daʊtləs i sɔ noʊ ɑnɝ ɪn faɪɾɪŋ bɛɡɝz iðɝ - ən bɛslənz fɹɛnz, sɛvɹəl wɪð ðɛɹ kɑstumz ɝaɪ ən wʌn wɪð ɪz mæsk ɔf soʊ ənʌðɝ kəd dæb əɾ ə kʌɾ əkɹɔs ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ðə mæn wɪð ðə kʌt wɑz ɡɹɪnɪŋ, tu. bɝdʒɪt bɔɹ nɑɾ ə skɹætʃ ðət mæt kəd si, ən əɹ kɑstum lʊkt əz niɾ əz ɪt hæd bæk ɪn ðə pæləs. ʃi meɪɾ əɹ naɪf dɪsəpɪɹ; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ʃi kəd haɪɾ ə bleɪɾ ʌndɝ ðoʊz fɛðɝz, bʌt ʃi dɪd.

Beslan caught Mat's arm. There was blood on his face, but he was grinning. "Let's get out of here and let the Fellowship of Alms finish its business. There's no honor in fighting beggars, and besides, the guild won't leave any of these interlopers alive. Follow me." Nalesean was scowling - doubtless he saw no honor in fighting beggars either - and Beslan's friends, several with their costumes awry and one with his mask off so another could dab at a cut across his forehead. The man with the cut was grinning, too. Birgitte bore not a scratch that Mat could see, and her costume looked as neat as it had back in the palace. She made her knife disappear; there was no way she could hide a blade under those feathers, but she did.

mæt meɪd noʊ pɹoʊɾɛst ət biɪŋ dʒɹɔn əweɪ, bʌɾ i dɪd ɡɹaʊl, "du bɛɡɝz ɔlweɪz ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ətækɪŋ pipəl ɪn ðɪs . . . ðɪs sɪɾi?" bɛslən maɪt nɑɾ əpɹiʃieɪt hɪɹɪŋ ɪt kɔld ə blʌɾi sɪɾi.

Mat made no protest at being drawn away, but he did growl, "Do beggars always go around attacking people in this . . . this city?" Beslan might not appreciate hearing it called a bloody city.

ðə mæn læft. "ju ɑɹ tɑvɝən, mæt. ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz ɪksaɪtmən ɝaʊn tɑvɝən."

The man laughed. "You are ta'veren, Mat. There's always excitement around ta'veren."

mæt smaɪl bæk wɪð ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ. blʌɾi ful, blʌɾi sɪɾi, ən blʌɾi tɑvɝən. wɛl, ɪf ə bɛɡɝ slɪɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, hi wəd nɑɾ əv tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə pæləs ən lɛt taɪlɪn pil ɪm laɪk ə ɹaɪp pɛɹ. kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, ʃi hæd kɔld ɪm əɹ lɪɾəl pɛɹ. blʌɾi ɛvɹiθɪŋ! ðə stʃɹit bɪtwin ðə daɪɝz ʃɑp ən ðə ɹoʊz ə ði ɪldɑɹ hæɾ ɪts ʃɛɹ ə ɹɛvəlɝz, ðoʊ nɑt mɛni skæntəli klæd. əpɛɹənli jə hæd tə hæv kɔɪn tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ neɪkəd. ðoʊ ði ækɹəbæts ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə mɝtʃəns haʊs ɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ keɪm kloʊz, ðə mɛn bɛɹfʊɾ ən bɛɹ-tʃɛstəɾ ɪn taɪt, bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd bɹitʃɪz, ðə wɪmən ɪn ivən taɪɾɝ bɹitʃɪz ən θɪn blaʊsəz. ðeɪ ɔl hæɾ ə fju fɛðɝz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ, əz dɪd ðə keɪpɝɪŋ mjuzɪʃənz pleɪɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə smɔl pæləs ət ðə fɑɹ kɔɹnɝ, ə wʊmən wɪð ə flut, ənʌðɝ bloʊɪŋ ɑn ə tɔl, twɪstəd blæk tub kʌvɝd wɪð lɛvɝz, ən ə fɛloʊ biɾɪŋ ə tæmbɝ fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ. ðə haʊs ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə wɑtʃ lʊkt ʃʌɾ ʌp taɪt.

Mat smiled back with gritted teeth. Bloody fool, bloody city, and bloody ta'veren. Well, if a beggar slit his throat, he would not have to go back to the palace and let Tylin peel him like a ripe pear. Come to think of it, she had called him her little pear. Bloody everything! The street between the dyer's shop and The Rose of the Eldar had its share of revelers, though not many scantily clad. Apparently you had to have coin to go near naked. Though the acrobats in front of the merchant's house on the corner came close, the men barefoot and bare-chested in tight, brightly colored breeches, the women in even tighter breeches and thin blouses. They all had a few feathers in their hair, as did the capering musicians playing in front of the small palace at the far corner, a woman with a flute, another blowing on a tall, twisted black tube covered with levers, and a fellow beating a tambour for all he was worth. The house they had come to watch looked shut up tight.

ðə ti ət ðə ɹoʊz wɑz əz bæɾ əz ɛvɝ, wɪtʃ mɛn ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən ðə waɪn. neɪlzin stʌk tə ðə saʊɝ loʊkəl eɪl. bɝdʒɪt sɛd θæŋks wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ fəɹ wʌt, ən mæt ʃɹʌɡd ɪɾ ɔf saɪlənli; ðeɪ ɡɹɪn əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ən tæp kʌps. ðə sʌn ɹoʊz, ən bɛslən sæt bælənsɪŋ fɝst wʌn buɾ ɑn ðə toʊ ʌv ði ʌðɝ, ðən ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪz kəmpænjənz bɪɡæn ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹɛstɪv, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən i pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət mæt wɑz tɑvɝən. ə skʌfəl wɪð bɛɡɝz wɑz hɑɹdli pɹɑpɝ ɪksaɪtmənt, ðə stʃɹit wɑz tu nɛɹoʊ fəɹ ɛni sɛɾɪŋz tə pæs, ðə wɪmən wɝ nɑɾ əz pɹɪɾi əz ɛlswɛɹ, ən ivən lʊkɪŋ ət bɝdʒɪt sim tə pɑl wʌns ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə kɪs ivən wʌn ə ðɛm. wɪð pɹoʊtɛsteɪʃənz ə ɹəɡɹɛt ðət bɛslən wəd nɑt kʌm, ðeɪ hɝiɾ ɔf tə faɪn sʌmwɛɹ mɔɹ ɪɡzɪlɝeɪɾɪŋ. neɪlzin tʊk ə stʃɹoʊl daʊn ði æli bɪsaɪd ðə daɪɝz, ən bɝdʒɪt vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə ɹoʊzəz mɝki ɪntɪɹiɝ tə faɪnd, ʃi sɛd, wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl fɪt tə dʒɹɪŋk hɪɾən ɪn səm fɝɡɑɾən kɔɹnɝ.

The tea at The Rose was as bad as ever, which meant it was much better than the wine. Nalesean stuck to the sour local ale. Birgitte said thanks without saying for what, and Mat shrugged it off silently; they grinned at each other and tapped cups. The sun rose, and Beslan sat balancing first one boot on the toe of the other, then the other way around, but his companions began growing restive, no matter how often he pointed out that Mat was ta'veren. A scuffle with beggars was hardly proper excitement, the street was too narrow for any settings to pass, the women were not as pretty as elsewhere, and even looking at Birgitte seemed to pall once they realized that she did not intend to kiss even one of them. With protestations of regret that Beslan would not come, they hurried off to find somewhere more exhilarating. Nalesean took a stroll down the alley beside the dyer's, and Birgitte vanished into The Rose's murky interior to find, she said, whether there was anything at all fit to drink hidden in some forgotten corner.

"aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə si ə wɔɹɾɝ ɡɑɹb laɪk ðæt," bɛslən sɛd, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz buts ɝaʊnd.

"I never expected to see a Warder garbed like that," Beslan said, changing his boots around.

mæt blɪŋkt. ðə fɛloʊ hæd ʃɑɹp aɪz. ʃi hæd nɑt ɹimuvd əɹ mæsk wʌns. wɛl, əz lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt noʊ əbaʊt -  "aɪ θɪŋk jəl bi ɡʊd fəɹ maɪ mʌðɝ, mæt."

Mat blinked. The fellow had sharp eyes. She had not removed her mask once. Well, as long as he did not know about -  "I think you will be good for my Mother, Mat."

tʃoʊkɪŋ, mæt spɹeɪd ti ɪndə ðə pæsɝzbi. sɛvɹəl ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm æŋɡɹəli, ən wʌn slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð ə naɪs lɪɾəl bʊzəm ɡeɪv ɪm ə kɔɪ smaɪl fɹəm bɪniθ ə blu mæsk i θɔt wɑz mɛn tə bi ə ɹɛn. ʃi stæmpt ə fʊɾ ən stɔkt ɔf wən i dɪd nɑt smaɪl bæk. lʌkəli, noʊ wʌn wɑz æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə teɪk ɪt bɪɑnd ɡlɛɹz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tu wɛn ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ. əɹ meɪbi ənlʌkəli. hi wəd nɑɾ əv maɪndəɾ ɪf sɪks əɹ eɪt paɪld ɑn ɪm ɹaɪt ðɛn.

Choking, Mat sprayed tea into the passersby. Several glared at him angrily, and one slender woman with a nice little bosom gave him a coy smile from beneath a blue mask he thought was meant to be a wren. She stamped a foot and stalked off when he did not smile back. Luckily, no one was angry enough to take it beyond glares before they too went on their way. Or maybe unluckily. He would not have minded if six or eight piled on him right then.

"wʌt dʒju min?" hi sɛd hɔɹsli.

"What do you mean?" he said hoarsely.

bɛslənz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊn ɪn waɪd-aɪd sɝpɹaɪz. "waɪ, hɝ tʃuzɪŋ jə fəɹ əɹ pɹɪɾi, ʌv kɔɹs. waɪ ɪz jəɹ feɪs soʊ ɹɛd? ɑɹ jə æŋɡɹi? waɪ - ?" sʌɾənli hi slæpt ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən læft. "ju θɪŋk əl bi æŋɡɹi. fɝɡɪv mi, aɪ fɝɡɛt jəɹ ən aʊtləndɝ. mæt, ʃiz maɪ mʌðɝ, nɑt maɪ waɪf. fɑðɝ daɪd tɛn jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ən ʃiz ɔlweɪz kleɪm tə bi tu bɪzi. aɪm dʒʌst ɡlæd ʃi tʃoʊz sʌmwʌn aɪ laɪk. wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?"

Beslan's head whipped around in wide-eyed surprise. "Why, her choosing you for her pretty, of course. Why is your face so red? Are you angry? Why - ?" Suddenly he slapped his forehead and laughed. "You think I will be angry. Forgive me, I forget you're an outlander. Mat, she's my mother, not my wife. Father died ten years ago, and she has always claimed to be too busy. I am just glad she chose someone I like. Where are you going?"

hi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz i wɑz ɑn ɪz fiɾ əntɪl bɛslən spoʊk. "aɪ dʒʌst . . . nid tə klɪɹ maɪ hɛd."

He did not realize he was on his feet until Beslan spoke. "I just . . . need to clear my head."

"bʌt jəɹ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ti, mæt."

"But you're drinking tea, Mat."

dɑdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn ə ɡɹin sɪdæn tʃɛɹ, hi hæf sɔ ðə dɔɹ ə ðə haʊs oʊpən ən ə wʊmən wɪð ə blu-fɛðɝd kloʊk oʊvɝ əɹ dʒɹɛs slɪp aʊt. ənθɪŋkɪŋli - hɪz hɛd wɑz spɪnɪŋ tu mʌtʃ tə θɪŋk klɪɹli - hi fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn hɝ. bɛslən nu! hi əpɹuvd! hɪz oʊn mʌðɝ, ən hi. . . .

Dodging around a green sedan chair, he half saw the door of the house open and a woman with a blue-feathered cloak over her dress slip out. Unthinkingly - his head was spinning too much to think clearly - he fell in behind her. Beslan knew! He approved! His own mother, and he. . . .

"mæt?" neɪlzin ʃaʊɾəd bɪhaɪn hɪm. "wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"Mat?" Nalesean shouted behind him. "Where are you going?"

"ɪf aɪm nɑt bæk baɪ təmɑɹoʊ," mæt ʃaʊɾəd bæk æbsənli oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "tɛl əm ðəl əv tə faɪn ɪt fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz!" hi wɔkt ɑn æftɝ ðə wʊmən ɪn ə deɪz, nɑt hɪɹɪŋ ɪf neɪlzin əɹ bɛslən ʃaʊɾəd əɡɛn. ðə mæn nu! hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌns θɪŋkɪŋ ðət bɛslən ən ɪz mʌðɝ wɝ boʊθ mæd. ðeɪ wɝ wɝs! ɔl ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz mæd! hi wɑz hɑɹdli əwɛɹ ə ðə daɪs stɪl spɪnɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl.

"If I'm not back by tomorrow," Mat shouted back absently over his shoulder, "tell them they'll have to find it for themselves!" He walked on after the woman in a daze, not hearing if Nalesean or Beslan shouted again. The man knew! He remembered once thinking that Beslan and his mother were both mad. They were worse! All of Ebou Dar was mad! He was hardly aware of the dice still spinning inside his skull.

fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ ʌv ðə miɾɪŋ ɹum, ɹin wɑtʃt soʊlən dɪsəpɪɹ daʊn ðə stʃɹit təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ. səm fɛloʊ ɪn ə bɹɑnz koʊt fɑloʊɾ ɪn əɹ weɪk, bʌɾ ɪf i tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmpid hɝ, hi wəd faɪn aʊt sun ɪnʌf ðət soʊlən hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ mɛn, ən noʊ peɪʃəns wɪð ðɛm.

From a window of the meeting room, Reanne watched Solain disappear down the street toward the river. Some fellow in a bronze coat followed in her wake, but if he tried to impede her, he would find out soon enough that Solain had no time for men, and no patience with them.

ɹin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ ði ɝdʒ hæd ɡɹoʊn soʊ stʃɹɔŋ tədeɪ. fəɹ deɪz ɪt hæd kʌm ɑn ɔlmoʊst wɪð ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ən feɪɾəd wɪð ðə sʌn, ən fəɹ deɪz ʃi hæd fɔt - baɪ ðə stʃɹɪkt ɹulz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kwaɪt dɛɹ kɔl lɔz, ðəɾ ɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɡɪvən ət ðə hæf mun, stɪl faɪv naɪts ɔf - bʌt tədeɪ. . . . ʃi hæd spoʊkən ði ɔɹɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi θɔɾ ən bɪn əneɪbəl tə meɪk hɝsɛlf ɹitʃɹækt əntɪl ðə pɹɑpɝ taɪm. ɪt wəd bi wɛl. noʊ wʌn hæd sin ɛni saɪn ə ðoʊz tu jʌŋ fulz kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi; θæŋk ðə laɪt, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ nid tə teɪk deɪnʒɝəs tʃænsəz.

Reanne was not sure why the urge had grown so strong today. For days it had come on almost with the morning and faded with the sun, and for days she had fought - by the strict rules they did not quite dare call laws, that order was given at the half moon, still five nights off - but today. . . . She had spoken the order before she thought and been unable to make herself retract until the proper time. It would be well. No one had seen any sign of those two young fools calling themselves Elayne and Nynaeve anywhere in the city; thank the Light, there had been no need to take dangerous chances.

saɪɪŋ, ʃi tɝn tə ði ʌðɝz, hu weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi tʊk əɹ tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ siɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ɪt wəd bi wɛl, əz ɪɾ ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn. sikɹəts wəd bi kɛpt, əz ðeɪ ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn. bʌt, stɪl. . . . ʃi hæd noʊ tʌtʃ ə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ə ðət sɔɹt, jɛt pɝhæps ðəɾ oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ ɝdʒ hæd bɪn tɛlɪŋ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ. twɛlv wɪmən wɑtʃt əɹ ɪkspɛktənli. "aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd kənsɪɾɝ muvɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn u dʌz nɑt wɛɹ ðə bɛl tə ðə fɑɹm fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl." ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl dɪskʌʃən; ðeɪ wɝ ði ɛldɝz, bʌt ʃi wɑz ði ɛldəst. ɪn ðæt, ət list, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɑɹm ɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd.

Sighing, she turned to the others, who waited until she took her chair before seating themselves. It would be well, as it always had been. Secrets would be kept, as they always had been. But, still. . . . She had no touch of Foretelling or anything of that sort, yet perhaps that overwhelming urge had been telling her something. Twelve women watched her expectantly. "I think we should consider moving everyone who does not wear the belt to the farm for a little while." There was little discussion; they were the Elders, but she was the Eldest. In that, at least, there was no harm in behaving as Aes Sedai did.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi

ðə fɝs kʌp


The First Cup

aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɪs," ɪleɪn pɹətɛstəd. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɔfɝɾ ə tʃɛɹ; ɪn fækt, wən ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə sɪt, ʃi hæd bɪn toʊl kɝtli tə ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ. faɪv sɛts ʌv aɪz wɝ foʊkəst ɑn hɝ, faɪv wɪmən wɪð sɛt, ɡɹɪm feɪsəz. "ju ɑɹ bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ɪf wiv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ tɛɹəbəl wən wʌt wɪv dʌn ɪz faɪn ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz!" ət lis ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ʌv ɪt, ʃi hoʊpt; ðə mɛsədʒ neɪlzin hæd kʌm ɹʌnɪŋ bæk wɪð wɑz nʌn tu klɪɹ. mæt hæd ɡɔn ɔf ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd faʊn ɪt. əɹ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk, neɪlzin əlaʊd; ðə lɔŋɡɝ i tɔkt, ðə mɔɹ i baʊns bɪtwin æbsəlut sɝɾənti ən daʊt. bɝdʒɪt hæd ɹɪmeɪnd wɑtʃɪŋ ɹinz haʊs; ʃi sim tə bi swɛɾi ən bɔɹd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, mæɾɝz wɝ ɪn moʊʃən. ɪleɪn wʌndɝd haʊ nɪneɪiv wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn. bɛɾɝ ðən hɝsɛlf, ʃi hoʊpt. ʃi hæd sɝɾənli nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs wən ʃi ɹɪvil ðɛɹ səksɛs.

I do not understand this," Elayne protested. She had not been offered a chair; in fact, when she started to sit, she had been told curtly to remain standing. Five sets of eyes were focused on her, five women with set, grim faces. "You are behaving as if we've done something terrible when what we have done is find the Bowl of the Winds!" At least they were on the brink of it, she hoped; the message Nalesean had come running back with was none too clear. Mat had gone off shouting that he had found it. Or something very like, Nalesean allowed; the longer he talked, the more he bounced between absolute certainty and doubt. Birgitte had remained watching Reanne's house; she seemed to be sweaty and bored. In any case, matters were in motion. Elayne wondered how Nynaeve was getting on. Better than herself, she hoped. She had certainly never expected this when she revealed their success.

"ju hæv ɛndeɪnʒɝd ə sikɹət kɛp kloʊs baɪ ɛvɹi wʊmən tə wɛɹ ðə ʃɔl fəɹ oʊvɝ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz." mɛɝɪlɪl sæt stɪf-bækt, sɝɛnəɾi ɔlmoʊst əbændən ɑn ðə taɪt-lɪp bɹɪŋk ʌv æpəplɛksi. "ju mʌst əv bɪn ɪnseɪn! oʊnli mædnəs kəɾ ɪkskjuz ðɪs!"

"You have endangered a secret kept close by every woman to wear the shawl for over two thousand years." Merilille sat stiff-backed, serenity almost abandoned on the tight-lipped brink of apoplexy. "You must have been insane! Only madness could excuse this!"

"wʌt sikɹət?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd.

"What secret?" Elayne demanded.

vændin, flæŋkɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪl wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ, ədʒʌstəd peɪl ɡɹin sɪlk skɝts ɪɹɪɾəbli ən sɛd, "taɪm ɪnʌf fəɹ ðət wən juv bɪn pɹɑpɝli ɹeɪzd, tʃaɪld. aɪ θɔt jə hæd səm sɛns." æɾɪliz, ɪn ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wʊl wɪð dip bɹaʊn tʃɹɪm, nɑɾəd, mɪɹɝɪŋ vændinz dɪsəpɹuvəl.

Vandene, flanking Merilille with her sister, adjusted pale green silk skirts irritably and said, "Time enough for that when you've been properly raised, child. I thought you had some sense." Adeleas, in a dark gray wool with deep brown trim, nodded, mirroring Vandene's disapproval.

"ðə tʃaɪl kænɑt bi fɔltɪd fəɹ ɹɪvilɪŋ ə sikɹət ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ," kɛɝin fɹænzi sɛd fɹəm ɪleɪnz lɛft, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ bʌlk ɪn əɹ ɡɹin-ænd-ɡɪlt ɑɹmtʃɛɹ. ʃi wɑz nɑt staʊt, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst, wɪð ʃoʊldɝz əz waɪɾ ən ɑɹmz əz θɪk əz moʊs mɛn.

"The child cannot be faulted for revealing a secret she did not know," Careane Fransi said from Elayne's left, shifting her bulk in her green-and-gilt armchair. She was not stout, but almost, with shoulders as wide and arms as thick as most men.

"taʊɝ lɔ dʌz nɑɾ əlaʊ fəɹ ɪkskjusɪz," sɝaɪðə pʊɾ ɪn kwɪkli, ɪn sʌmwʌt sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾənt toʊnz, hɝ nɔɹməli ɪnkwɪzɪɾɪv bɹaʊn aɪz stɝn. "wʌns mɪɹ ɪkskjusɪz ɑɹ əlaʊd, ɪnɛvəɾəbli lɛsɝ ən lɛsɝ ɪkskjusɪz wɪl bɪkʌm æksɛptəbəl, əntɪl lɔ ɪtsɛlf ɪz ɡɔn." hɝ haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ stʊd tə ðə ɹaɪt. oʊnli ʃi wɔɹ əɹ ʃɔl, bʌt mɛɝɪlɪlz sɪɾɪŋ ɹum hæd bɪn ɝeɪnʒd əz ə kɔɹt, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn kɔld ɪt ðæt. soʊ fɑɹ, noʊ wʌn hæd. mɛɝɪlɪl, æɾɪliz ən vændin kənfɹʌntəɾ ɪleɪn laɪk dʒʌdʒɪz, sɝaɪðəz tʃɛɹ wɑz pleɪst wɛɹ ðə siɾ ə ɹibjuk wəd bi, ən kɛɝinz ðə siɾ ə pɑɹɾən, bʌt ðə dəmɑni ɡɹin u wʊɾə bɪn əɹ dɪfɛndɝ nɑɾəd θɔtfəli əz ðə tɛɹən bɹaʊn u wʊɾə bɪn əɹ pɹɑsɪkjuɾɝ kəntɪnjud. "ʃi hæz ədmɪɾəd ɡɪl fɹəm əɹ oʊn maʊθ. aɪ ɹɛkəmɛn ðət ðə tʃaɪl bi kənfaɪn tə ðə pæləs əntɪl wi liv, wɪð səm ɡʊd hɑɹd wɝk tə ɑkjəpaɪ hɝ maɪn ən əɹ hænz. aɪ ɔlsoʊ ɹɛkəmɛn ə fɝm doʊs ə ðə slɪpɝ ət ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪntɝvəlz tə ɹimaɪn əɹ nɑt tə ɡoʊ bɪhaɪn sɪstɝz' bæks. ən ðə seɪm fəɹ nɪneɪiv, əz sun əz ʃi kən bi faʊnd."

"Tower law does not allow for excuses," Sareitha put in quickly, in somewhat self-important tones, her normally inquisitive brown eyes stern. "Once mere excuses are allowed, inevitably lesser and lesser excuses will become acceptable, until law itself is gone." Her high-backed chair stood to the right. Only she wore her shawl, but Merilille's sitting room had been arranged as a court, though no one called it that. So far, no one had. Merilille, Adeleas and Vandene confronted Elayne like judges, Sareitha's chair was placed where the Seat of Rebuke would be, and Careane's the Seat of Pardon, but the Domani Green who would have been her defender nodded thoughtfully as the Tairen Brown who would have been her prosecutor continued. "She has admitted guilt from her own mouth. I recommend that the child be confined to the palace until we leave, with some good hard work to occupy her mind and her hands. I also recommend a firm dose of the slipper at regular intervals to remind her not to go behind sisters' backs. And the same for Nynaeve, as soon as she can be found."

ɪleɪn swɑloʊd. kənfaɪnd? pɝhæps ðeɪ dɪd nɑt nid tə neɪm ðɪs ə tʃɹaɪəl fəɹ ɪt tə bi wʌn. sɝaɪðə maɪt nɑt jɛɾ əv ətʃiv ði eɪdʒləs feɪs, bʌt ðə weɪɾ ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmənz jɪɹz pɹɛst əɾ ɪleɪn. æɾɪliz ən vændin wɪð ðɛɹ hɛɹ nɪɹli ɔl waɪt, ivən ðɛɹ eɪdʒləs feɪsəz ɛkoʊɪŋ jɪɹz. mɛɝɪlɪlz hɛɹ wɑz ɡlɔsi blæk, jɛɾ ɪleɪn wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə lɝn ʃi hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl əz lɔŋ əɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən moʊst wɪmən nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪvd. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, kɛɝin maɪt hæv, əz wɛl. nɑt wʌn ə ðɛm əpɹoʊtʃt əɹ oʊn stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, bʌt. . . . ɔl ðəɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔl ðət nɑlədʒ. ɔl ðət . . . əθɔɹəɾi. ə hɛvi ɹimaɪndɝ ðət ʃi wɑz oʊnli eɪtin ən hæd bɪn ɪn nɑvəs waɪɾ ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ.

Elayne swallowed. Confined? Perhaps they did not need to name this a trial for it to be one. Sareitha might not yet have achieved the ageless face, but the weight of the other women's years pressed at Elayne. Adeleas and Vandene with their hair nearly all white, even their ageless faces echoing years. Merilille's hair was glossy black, yet Elayne would not have been surprised to learn she had worn the shawl as long or longer than most women not Aes Sedai lived. For that matter, Careane might have, as well. Not one of them approached her own strength in the Power, but. . . . All that experience as Aes Sedai, all that knowledge. All that . . . authority. A heavy reminder that she was only eighteen and had been in novice white a year ago.

kɛɝin meɪd noʊ muv tə ɹɪbʌt sɝaɪðəz sədʒɛstʃənz. pɝhæps ʃi bɛst ɡoʊ ɑn dɪfɛndɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "pleɪnli ðɪs sikɹət jə spik ə hæz sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə sɝkəl, bʌt - "

vændin weɪvd əɹ hæn dɪsmɪsɪvli. "aɪ kənkɝ ən dɪfɝ. bʌɾ aɪ əɡɹi wɪð ðə siɾ ə ɹibjuk." kɛɝinz lʊk maɪɾ əv kənteɪn ə slɪvɝ ə sɪmpəθi. meɪbi ə slɪvɝ.

mɛɝɪlɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ.

Merilille opened her mouth.

ðə tɪmɪd nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ saʊndəd kwaɪt laʊɾ ɪn ðə moʊməntɛɹi, θʌndɝəs saɪləns.

nɑt ðə jʌŋɡəst, bʌt ðə loʊəst ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ, kɛɝin stʊɾ ən ɡlaɪɾɪd tə ðə dɔɹ. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ hɛft, ʃi ɔlweɪz muv laɪk ə swɑn.

Not the youngest, but the lowest in strength, Careane stood and glided to the door. Despite her heft, she always moved like a swan.

ɪt wɑz pɔl hɝsɛlf, mɛɝɪlɪlz meɪd, hu pɑpt ɪn kɝtsiɪŋ lɛft ən ɹaɪt. ə slɛndɝ, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən juʒəwəli pəzɛst ʌv ə dɪɡnəɾi tə ɹaɪvəl ðəɾ ə hɝ mɪstʃɹəs, ʃi wɔɹ ən æŋkʃəs fɹaʊn naʊ, əz wɛl ʃi maɪt, bɑɹdʒɪŋ ɪn æftɝ mɛɝɪlɪlz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ɪleɪn hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ ɡlæd tə si ɛniwʌn sɪns . . . sɪns mæt kɔθən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ə hɔɹɛndəs θɔt. ɪf eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt seɪ ʃi hæd mɛt toʊ səfɪʃənli sun, ʃi maɪt dʒʌst si ɪf æskɪŋ ðə mæn tə biɾ əɹ æftɝ ɔl kəɾ ɛn ði æɡəni.

It was Pol herself, Merilille's maid, who popped in curtsying left and right. Elayne had not been so glad to see anyone since . . . since Mat Cauthon appeared in the Stone of Tear. A horrendous thought. If Aviendha did not say she had met toh sufficiently soon, she might just see if asking the man to beat her after all could end the agony.

"ðə kwin bɹɔt ðɪs hɝsɛlf," pɔl ənaʊns bɹɛθəli, pɹɑfɝɪŋ ə lɛɾɝ sild wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd lʌmp ʌv wæks. "ʃi sɛɾ ɪf aɪ dɪdnt ɡɪv ɪt tə ɪleɪn ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, ʃid bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn hɝsɛlf. ʃi sɛɾ ɪts əbaʊt ðə tʃaɪlz mʌðɝ." ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊst ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ. ðə sɪstɝz' sɝvɪŋ wɪmən hæɾ ɔl pɪkt ʌp ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz' weɪ ʌv tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt nɪneɪiv ən hɝ, ɪf sɛldəm wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd hɪɹ.

"The Queen brought this herself," Pol announced breathily, proffering a letter sealed with a large red lump of wax. "She said if I didn't give it to Elayne right away, she'd bring it in herself. Elayne frowned; Mistress Anan had said the Kin took in wilders, too, but Reanne's biggest anxiety had seemed to be making her and Nynaeve prove they were not.

"nʌn ɛvɝ ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋ," æɾɪliz æɾəd. "faɪv jɪɹz, pɝhæps tɛn; ðɛn, aɪ səpoʊz, əz naʊ. wʌns ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðət ðɛɹ lɪɾəl ɡɹup ɪz noʊ ɹɪpleɪsmən fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðeɪ ɡoʊ ɔf ən bɪkʌm vɪlədʒ hilɝz əɹ wɪsdəmz əɹ ðə laɪk, əɹ səmtaɪmz sɪmpli fɝɡɛt ðə paʊɝ, stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ, ən teɪk ʌp ə kɹæft əɹ tʃɹeɪd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðeɪ vænɪʃ, soʊ tə spik." ɪleɪn wʌndɝd haʊ ɛniwʌn kəd fɝɡɛt ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðət weɪ; ði ɝdʒ tə tʃænəl, ðə tɛmteɪʃən ə ðə sɔɹs, wɑz ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, wʌns jə lɝn haʊ. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd sim tə bɪliv səm wɪmən kəd dʒʌs pʊɾ ɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ðoʊ, wʌns ðeɪ faʊn aʊt ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"None ever remained long," Adeleas added. "Five years, perhaps ten; then, I suppose, as now. Once they realize that their little group is no replacement for the White Tower, they go off and become village Healers or Wisdoms or the like, or sometimes simply forget the Power, stop channeling, and take up a craft or trade. In any case, they vanish, so to speak." Elayne wondered how anyone could forget the One Power that way; the urge to channel, the temptation of the Source, was always there, once you learned how. Aes Sedai did seem to believe some women could just put it behind them, though, once they found out they would not be Aes Sedai.

vændin tʊk ʌp ði ɛkspləneɪʃən əɡɛn; ðə sɪstɝz fɹikwənli spoʊk ɔlmoʊst ɪn ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ sɛntənsəz, itʃ kæɹiɪŋ ɑn smuðli wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ lɛft ɔf. "ðə taʊɝ əz noʊn ə ðə kɪn fɹəm nɪɹli ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, pɝhæps fɹəm ðə vɛɹi bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ət fɝst, noʊ daʊt, ðə wɔɹz tʊk pɹɛsəɾəns. ən dɪspaɪt kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ðə kɪn, ðeɪv dʌn dʒʌst wʌt wi wɑn sətʃ wɪmən tə du. ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən, ivən ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ kən tʃænəl, dʒɹɔ noʊ ətɛnʃən wʌtsoʊɛvɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz. oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, ðeɪv ivən pæst əlɔŋ wɝd - sikɹɪtli, ʌv kɔɹs; kɛɹfəli - wən wʌn ə ðɛm faʊn ə wʊmən fɔlsli kleɪmɪŋ ðə ʃɔl. jə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ?"

Vandene took up the explanation again; the sisters frequently spoke almost in alternating sentences, each carrying on smoothly where the other left off. "The Tower has known of the Kin from nearly the beginning, perhaps from the very beginning. At first, no doubt, the Wars took precedence. And despite calling themselves the Kin, they have done just what we want such women to do. They remain hidden, even the fact that they can channel, draw no attention whatsoever to themselves. Over the years, they have even passed along word - secretly, of course; carefully - when one of them found a woman falsely claiming the shawl. You said something?"

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "kɛɝin, ɪz ðəɹ ɛni ti ɪn ðət pɑt?" kɛɝin ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹt. "aɪ θɪŋk æɾɪliz ən vændin maɪt laɪk tə wɛt ðɛɹ θɹoʊts." ðə dəmɑni wʊmən dɪd nɑt kwaɪt lʊk əɾ ə stɪl-stɛɹɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪl bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə teɪbəl wɛɹ ðə sɪlvɝ tipɑɾ ən kʌps wɝ. "ðæt dʌzn ɪkspleɪn waɪ," ɪleɪn wɛn ɑn. "waɪ ɪz nɑlədʒ ə ðɛm sətʃ ə dip sikɹət? waɪ hævən ðeɪ bɪn skæɾɝd lɔŋ əɡoʊ?"

Elayne shook her head. "Careane, is there any tea in that pot?" Careane gave a small start. "I think Adeleas and Vandene might like to wet their throats." The Domani woman did not quite look at a still-staring Merilille before going to the table where the silver teapot and cups were. "That doesn't explain why," Elayne went on. "Why is knowledge of them such a deep secret? Why haven't they been scattered long ago?"

"waɪ, ðə ɹʌnəweɪz, ʌv kɔɹs." æɾɪliz meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ðə moʊst ɑbviəs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. "ɪɾ ɪz ə fæk ðəɾ ʌðɝ ɡæðɝɪŋz əv bɪn bɹoʊkən ʌp əz sun əz faʊnd - ðə læst əbaʊt tu hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ - bʌt ðə kɪn də kip ðɛmsɛlvz smɔl, ən kwaɪət. ðət læst ɡɹup kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə dɔɾɝz ə saɪləns, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ hɑɹdli saɪlənt. oʊnli twɛnti-θɹi ʌv əm ɔltəɡɛðɝ, waɪldɝz ɡæðɝɾ ən tʃɹeɪn æftɝ ə fæʃən baɪ ə pɛɹ ə fɔɹmɝ æksɛptɪd, bʌt ðeɪ - "

"Why, the runaways, of course." Adeleas made it sound the most obvious thing in the world. "It is a fact that other gatherings have been broken up as soon as found - the last about two hundred years ago - but the Kin do keep themselves small, and quiet. That last group called themselves the Daughters of Silence, yet they were hardly silent. Only twenty-three of them altogether, wilders gathered and trained after a fashion by a pair of former Accepted, but they - "

"ɹʌnəweɪz," ɪleɪn pɹɑmptəd, teɪkɪŋ ə kʌp fɹəm kɛɝin wɪð ə smaɪl ə θæŋks. ʃi hæd nɑɾ æskt wʌn fəɹ hɝsɛlf, bʌt ʃi ɹilaɪzd æbsənli ðət ðə wʊmən hæɾ ɔfɝɾ əɹ ðə fɝst. vændin ən əɹ sɪstɝ hæd tɔkt kwaɪɾ ə bɪɾ əbaʊt ɹʌnəweɪz ɑn ðə weɪ tə ɛbu dɑɹ.

"Runaways," Elayne prompted, taking a cup from Careane with a smile of thanks. She had not asked one for herself, but she realized absently that the woman had offered her the first. Vandene and her sister had talked quite a bit about runaways on the way to Ebou Dar.

æɾɪliz blɪŋkt, ən pʊl hɝsɛlf bæk tə ðə tɑpɪk. "ðə kɪn hɛlp ɹʌnəweɪz. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz əv tu əɹ θɹi wɪmən ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn kipɪŋ wɑtʃ. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi wʊmən pʊɾ aʊt, ɪn ə vɛɹi sɝkəmspɛkt weɪ, ən fəɹ ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ mænədʒ tə faɪn ɛvɹi ɹʌnəweɪ, wɛðɝ nɑvəs əɹ æksɛptɪd. ət list, nʌn əz meɪɾ ɪɾ ɔf ði aɪlənd wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ hɛlp sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz."

Adeleas blinked, and pulled herself back to the topic. "The Kin help runaways. They always have two or three women in Tar Valon keeping watch. For one thing, they approach almost every woman put out, in a very circumspect way, and for another, they manage to find every runaway, whether novice or Accepted. At least, none has made it off the island without their help since the Trolloc Wars."

"oʊ, jɛs," vændin sɛɾ əz æɾɪliz pɔz tə teɪk ə kʌp fɹəm kɛɝin. ɪt hæd bɪn ɔfɝd tə mɛɝɪlɪl fɝst, bʌt mɛɝɪlɪl sæt slʌmpt ən stɛɹɪŋ blikli ət nʌθɪŋ. "ɪf ɛniwʌn dʌz mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp, waɪ, wi noʊ ɹaɪt wɛɹ tə lʊk, ən ʃi nɪɹli ɔlweɪz ɛnz ʌp bæk ɪn ðə taʊɝ wɪʃɪŋ əɹ fit hæd nɛvɝ ɪtʃt. əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɪn doʊnt noʊ wi noʊ, ɛniweɪ. wʌns ðət hæpənz, ɪɾəl bi bæk tə ðə deɪz bɪfɔɹ ðə kɪn, wən ə wʊmən ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ maɪt ɡoʊ ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən. ðə nʌmbɝz wɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən - ɛɛs sədaɪ, æksɛptɪd, nɑvəsɪz ən ɹʌnəweɪz - ən səm jɪɹz tu aʊɾ ə θɹi ɪskeɪp klin, ʌðɝz θɹi aʊɾ ə fɔɹ. juzɪŋ ðə kɪn, wi ɹiteɪk ət lis naɪn ə tɛn. jə kən si waɪ ðə taʊɝ əz pɹəzɝv ðə kɪn ən ðɛɹ sikɹət laɪk pɹɛʃəs dʒuəlz."

"Oh, yes," Vandene said as Adeleas paused to take a cup from Careane. It had been offered to Merilille first, but Merilille sat slumped and staring bleakly at nothing. "If anyone does manage to escape, why, we know right where to look, and she nearly always ends up back in the Tower wishing her feet had never itched. As long as the Kin don't know we know, anyway. Once that happens, it will be back to the days before the Kin, when a woman running from the Tower might go in any direction. The numbers were larger then - Aes Sedai, Accepted, novices and runaways - and some years two out of three escaped clean, others three out of four. Using the Kin, we retake at least nine of ten. You can see why the Tower has preserved the Kin and their secret like precious jewels."

ɪleɪn kʊd. ə wʊmən wɑz nɑt dʌn wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ əntɪl ɪt wɑz dʌn wɪð hɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ɪt kəd nɑt hɝt ðə taʊɝz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ ɪnfælɪbɪlɪɾi ðəɾ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz kɑt ɹʌnəweɪz. ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz. wɛl, naʊ ʃi nu.

Elayne could. A woman was not done with the White Tower until it was done with her. Besides, it could not hurt the Tower's reputation for infallibility that it always caught runaways. Almost always. Well, now she knew.

ʃi stʊd, ən tə hɝ əstɑnɪʃmənt, æɾɪliz dɪɾ ɔlsoʊ, ən vændin, weɪvɪŋ əweɪ kɛɝinz ɔfɝd ti, ən sɝaɪðə. ivən mɛɝɪlɪl, æftɝ ə moʊmənt. ðeɪ ɔl lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɪkspɛktənli, ivən mɛɝɪlɪl.

She stood, and to her astonishment, Adeleas did also, and Vandene, waving away Careane's offered tea, and Sareitha. Even Merilille, after a moment. They all looked at her expectantly, even Merilille.

vændin noʊɾəst əɹ sɝpɹaɪz, ən smaɪld. "ənʌðɝ θɪŋ jə maɪt nɑt noʊ. wəɹ ə kəntɛnʃəs lɑɾ ɪn mɛni weɪz, wi ɛɛs sədaɪ, itʃ dʒɛləs ə hɝ pleɪs ən pɹɪɹɑɡəɾɪvz, bʌt wən sʌmwʌn ɪz pleɪst əbʌv əs əɹ stænz əbʌv ʌs, wi tɛn tə fɑloʊ hɝ fɛɹli mikli fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. haʊɛvɝ wi maɪt ɡɹʌmbəl əbaʊɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒənz ɪn pɹaɪvət."

Vandene noticed her surprise, and smiled. "Another thing you might not know. We are a contentious lot in many ways, we Aes Sedai, each jealous of her place and prerogatives, but when someone is placed above us or stands above us, we tend to follow her fairly meekly for the most part. However we might grumble about her decisions in private."

"waɪ, soʊ wi du," æɾɪliz mɝmɝd hæpəli, əz ɪf ʃi hæd dʒʌs dɪskʌvɝd sʌmθɪŋ.

"Why, so we do," Adeleas murmured happily, as if she had just discovered something.

mɛɝɪlɪl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, əbzɔɹbɪŋ hɝsɛlf fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪn stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ skɝts. "vændin ɪz ɹaɪt," ʃi sɛd. "ju stæn əbʌv əs ɪn jɝsɛlf, ən aɪ mʌst ədmɪt, jə əpɛɹənli hæv bɪn pleɪst əbʌv ʌs. ɪf əɹ bɪheɪvjɝ kɔlz fəɹ pɛnəns. . . . wɛl, jəl tɛl əs ɪf ɪt dʌz. wɛɹ ɑɹ wi tə fɑloʊ ju? ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk?" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɑɹkæzəm ɪn ɛni ʌv ðæt; ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, hɝ toʊn wɑz mɔɹ pəlaɪt ðən ɪleɪn hæd hɝɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ bɪfɔɹ.

Merilille took a deep breath, absorbing herself for a moment in straightening her skirts. "Vandene is right," she said. "You stand above us in yourself, and I must admit, you apparently have been placed above us. If our behavior calls for penance. . . . Well, you will tell us if it does. Where are we to follow you? If I may ask?" There was no sarcasm in any of that; if anything, her tone was more polite than Elayne had heard out of her before.

ʃi θɔɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɛvɝ lɪvd wʊɾə bɪn pɹaʊd tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ fitʃɝz əz wɛl əz ʃi dɪd ɹaɪt ðɛn. ɔl ʃi hæd wɑntəd wɑz fəɹ əm tə ədmɪt ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi fɔɾ ə moʊməntɛɹi ɝdʒ tə pɹoʊtɛs ðət ʃi wɑz tu jʌŋ, tu ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst. "ju kən nɛvɝ pʊt hʌni bæk ɪn ðə koʊm," soʊ lini juz tə seɪ wən ʃi wɑz ə ɡɝl. ɛɡwin wɑz noʊ oʊldɝ.

She thought any Aes Sedai who ever lived would have been proud to control her features as well as she did right then. All she had wanted was for them to admit she really was Aes Sedai. She fought a momentary urge to protest that she was too young, too inexperienced. "You can never put honey back in the comb," so Lini used to say when she was a girl. Egwene was no older.

dʒɹɔɪŋ bɹɛθ, ʃi smaɪld wɔɹmli. "ðə fɝs θɪŋ tə ɹikɔl ɪz ðət wəɹ ɔl sɪstɝz, ɪn ɛvɹi minɪŋ ə ðə wɝd. wi mʌst wɝk təɡɛðɝ; ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ɪz tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ lɛs." ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl nɑd soʊ ɪnθuziæstɪkli wən ʃi toʊld əm wʌɾ ɛɡwin ɪntɛndəd. "pɝhæps wi ʃəd sɪɾ əɡɛn." ðeɪ weɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ bɪfɔɹ foʊldɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bæk ɪndə ðɛɹ sits. ʃi hoʊp nɪneɪiv wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn ə tɛnθ soʊ wɛl. wən ʃi faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊt ðɪs, nɪneɪiv wɑz gɑnə feɪn fɹəm ʃɑk. "aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ ə maɪ oʊn tə tɛl jə əbaʊt ðə kɪn."

Drawing breath, she smiled warmly. "The first thing to recall is that we are all sisters, in every meaning of the word. We must work together; the Bowl of the Winds is too important for anything less." She hoped they would all nod so enthusiastically when she told them what Egwene intended. "Perhaps we should sit again." They waited for her before folding themselves back into their seats. She hoped Nynaeve was getting on a tenth so well. When she found out about this, Nynaeve was going to faint from shock. "I have something of my own to tell you about the Kin."

fɛɹli sun ɪt wɑz mɛɝɪlɪl u lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə feɪn fɹəm ʃɑk, ən ivən æɾɪliz ən vændin wɝ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. bʌt ðeɪ wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn seɪɪŋ, "jɛs, ɪleɪn," ən "ɪf jə seɪ soʊ, ɪleɪn." pɝhæps ɪt wəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ smuðli fɹəm naʊ ɑn.

Fairly soon it was Merilille who looked ready to faint from shock, and even Adeleas and Vandene were not far from it. But they went right on saying, "Yes, Elayne," and "If you say so, Elayne." Perhaps it would all go smoothly from now on.

ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹ wɑz ɹɑkɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz ə ɹɛvəlɝz əlɔŋ ðə ki wən mɑɡiɾin spɑɾəd ðə wʊmən. ʃi wɑz biɪŋ hændəd daʊn fɹəm ə koʊtʃ ət wʌn ə ðə boʊt lændɪŋz baɪ ə fʊtmən ɪn ɡɹin ən waɪt. ə waɪd fɛðɝd mæsk kʌvɝɾ əɹ feɪs mɔɹ kəmplitli ðən mɑɡiɾinz dɪd, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə noʊn ðət dɪtɝmən stʃɹaɪd, noʊn ðət wʊmən, fɹəm ɛni æŋɡəl ɪn ɛni laɪt. ðə kɑɹv skɹinz ðət sɝvd əz wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə kloʊz tʃɛɹ wɝ sɝɾənli noʊ hɪnʒɹəns. tu fɛloʊz wɪð sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ hɪps skɹæmbəl fɹəm ðə koʊtʃ ɹuf tə fɑloʊ ðə mæskt wʊmən.

The sedan chair was rocking through the crowds of revelers along the quay when Moghedien spotted the woman. She was being handed down from a coach at one of the boat landings by a footman in green and white. A wide feathered mask covered her face more completely than Moghedien's did, but she would have known that determined stride, known that woman, from any angle in any light. The carved screens that served as windows in the closed chair were certainly no hindrance. Two fellows with swords on their hips scrambled from the coach roof to follow the masked woman.

mɑɡiɾin θʌmpt ə fɪst əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ, ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "stɑp!" ðə bɛɹɝz hɔltəd soʊ kwɪkli ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊs flʌŋ fɔɹwɝd.

Moghedien thumped a fist against the side of the chair, shouting, "Stop!" The bearers halted so quickly she was almost flung forward.

ðə kɹaʊd dʒɑsəl pæst, səm ʃaʊɾɪŋ kɝsɪz əɾ əɹ bɛɹɝz fəɹ blɑkɪŋ ðə weɪ, səm ʃaʊɾɪŋ mɔɹ ɡʊd neɪtʃɝdli. daʊn hɪɹ baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðə θɹɔŋ ɹæn θɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə wɑtʃ θɹu ðə ɡæps. ðə boʊt ðət pʊld əweɪ fɹəm ðə lændɪŋ sim kwaɪt dɪstɪŋktɪv; ðə ɹuf ə ðə loʊ kæbən ɪn ðə ɹɪɹ wɑz peɪntəd ɹɛd; ʃi dɪd nɑt si ðəɾ æfɛkteɪʃən ɑn ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə lɔŋ stoʊn dɑk.

The crowd jostled past, some shouting curses at her bearers for blocking the way, some shouting more good naturedly. Down here by the river, the throng ran thin enough for her to watch through the gaps. The boat that pulled away from the landing seemed quite distinctive; the roof of the low cabin in the rear was painted red; she did not see that affectation on any of the others waiting at the long stone dock.

ʃi wɛɾ əɹ lɪps, ʃɪvɝɪŋ. mɔɹaɪɾɪnz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz hæd bɪn ɪksplɪsət, ðə pɹaɪs ə dɪsəbiɾiəns meɪɾ ɛkskɹusieɪɾɪŋli klɪɹ. bʌɾ ə slaɪt dɪleɪ wəd nɑt hɝt. nɑɾ ɪf i nɛvɝ lɝn ʌv ɪt, ɛniweɪ.

She wet her lips, shivering. Moridin's instructions had been explicit, the price of disobedience made excruciatingly clear. But a slight delay would not hurt. Not if he never learned of it, anyway.

flɪŋɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, ʃi klaɪmd aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹiɾ ən lʊkt əbaʊt heɪstəli. ðɛɹ; ðəɾ ɪn, ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə dɑks. ən ðə ɹɪvɝ. lɪftɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ʃi hɝiɾ əweɪ wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst fɪɹ ɛniwʌn maɪt haɪɝ əɹ tʃɛɹ; əntɪl ʃi əntaɪd ðə wɛbz ə kəmpʌlʃən ɑn ðɛm, ðə bɛɹɝz wəd tɛl ɛniwʌn u æsk ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɛnɡeɪdʒd, ən stæn ðəɹ əntɪl ðeɪ daɪɾ ə hʌŋɡɝ. ə pæθ oʊpən əhɛɾ ə hɝ, mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn fɛðɝd mæsks lipɪŋ əsaɪd bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ðɛm, lipɪŋ wɪð skwilz ən kɹaɪz əz ðeɪ klʌtʃt wɛɹ ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ hæd bɪn stæbd. əz ðeɪ hæd; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə spɪn sʌɾəl wɛbz ɑn soʊ mɛni maɪnz, bʌɾ ə flɝi ʌv niɾəlz woʊvən ʌv ɛɹ dɪɾ əz wɛl hɪɹ.

Flinging open the door, she climbed out into the street and looked about hastily. There; that inn, right overlooking the docks. And the river. Lifting her skirts, she hurried away without the slightest fear anyone might hire her chair; until she untied the webs of Compulsion on them, the bearers would tell anyone who asked that they were engaged, and stand there until they died of hunger. A path opened ahead of her, men and women in feathered masks leaping aside before she reached them, leaping with squeals and cries as they clutched where they thought they had been stabbed. As they had; there was no time to spin subtle webs on so many minds, but a flurry of needles woven of Air did as well here.

ðə staʊɾ ɪnkipɝ ət ði ɔɹzmənz pɹaɪd nɪɹli lɛpt, tu, ət ðə saɪɾ ə mɑɡiɾin stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə hɝ kɑmən ɹum ɪn ɡlɔɹiəsli skɑɹlət sɪlk wɝkt wɪð θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld ən blæk sɪlk ðət ɡlɪsən əz ɹɪtʃli əz ðə ɡoʊld. hɝ mæsk wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt spɹeɪ ʌv pɪtʃ blæk fɛðɝz wɪð ə ʃɑɹp blæk bik; ə ɹeɪvən. ðət wɑz mɔɹaɪɾɪnz dʒoʊk, hɪz kəmænd, əz wɑz ðə dʒɹɛs, ɪn fækt. hɪz kʌlɝz wɝ blæk ən ɹɛd, hi sɛd, ən ʃi wəd wɛɹ əm waɪl ʃi sɝv hɪm. ʃi wɑz ɪn lɪvɝi, haʊɛvɝ ɛləɡənt, ən ʃi cʊɾə kɪld ɛvɹiwʌn u sɔ hɝ.

The stout innkeeper at The Oarsman's Pride nearly leaped, too, at the sight of Moghedien striding into her common room in gloriously scarlet silk worked with thread-of-gold and black silk that glistened as richly as the gold. Her mask was a great spray of pitch black feathers with a sharp black beak; a raven. That was Moridin's joke, his command, as was the dress, in fact. His colors were black and red, he said, and she would wear them while she served him. She was in livery, however elegant, and she could have killed everyone who saw her.

ɪnstɛd, ʃi spʌn ə heɪsti wɛb ɑn ðə ɹaʊnd-tʃikt ɪnkipɝ ðət dʒɝkt əɹ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ən meɪɾ əɹ aɪz pɑp. noʊ taɪm fəɹ sʌɾəlti. ət mɑɡiɾinz kəmæn tə ʃoʊ hɝ ðə ɹuf, ðə wʊmən ɹæn ʌp ðə ɹeɪləs stɛɹz ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ɛni ʌv ðə fɛðɝ-dʒɹeɪp dʒɹɪŋkɝz sɔ ɛniθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl ɪn ði ɪnkipɝz bɪheɪvjɝ, mɑɡiɾin θɔt wɪð ə smɔl læf. ði ɔɹzmənz pɹaɪd pɹɑbli hæd nɛvɝ sin ə peɪtʃɹən ə hɝ kwɑləɾi bɪfɔɹ.

Instead, she spun a hasty web on the round-cheeked innkeeper that jerked her up straight and made her eyes pop. No time for subtlety. At Moghedien's command to show her the roof, the woman ran up the railless stairs at the side of the room. It was unlikely any of the feather-draped drinkers saw anything unusual in the innkeeper's behavior, Moghedien thought with a small laugh. The Oarsman's Pride probably had never seen a patron of her quality before.

ɑn ðə flæt ɹuf, ʃi kwɪkli weɪd ðə deɪnʒɝz ə lɛɾɪŋ ði ɪn-kipɝ lɪv vɝsəs ðoʊz ə kɪlɪŋ hɝ. kɔɹpsəz hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv pɔɪntɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ɪf jə wɪʃt tə ɹɪmeɪn kwaɪətli hɪɾən ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, jə dɪd nɑt kɪl ənlɛs jə æbsəlutli hæd tə. heɪstəli, ʃi ədʒʌstəd ðə wɛb ə kəmpʌlʃən, toʊl ðə wʊmən tə ɡoʊ daʊn tə hɝ ɹum, tə ɡoʊ tə slip ən fɝɡɛɾ ɛvɝ hævɪŋ sin hɝ. wɪð ðə heɪst, ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl ði ɪnkipɝ maɪt luz ðə hoʊl deɪ, əɹ weɪk sʌmwʌt sloʊɝ ʌv wɪts ðən ʃi hæd bɪn - soʊ mʌtʃ ɪn mɑɡiɾinz laɪf wʊɾə bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ hæd ʃi pəzɛst ə bɛɾɝ tælən fəɹ kəmpʌlʃən - bʌɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə wʊmən skɝiɾ əweɪ, iɡɝ tə oʊbeɪ, ən lɛft əɹ əloʊn.

On the flat roof, she quickly weighed the dangers of letting the inn-keeper live versus those of killing her. Corpses had a way of pointing a finger, eventually. If you wished to remain quietly hidden in the shadows, you did not kill unless you absolutely had to. Hastily, she adjusted the web of Compulsion, told the woman to go down to her room, to go to sleep and forget ever having seen her. With the haste, it was possible the innkeeper might lose the whole day, or wake somewhat slower of wits than she had been - so much in Moghedien's life would have been so much easier had she possessed a better Talent for Compulsion - but in any case, the woman scurried away, eager to obey, and left her alone.

əz ðə dɔɹ θʌmp daʊn flæɾ ɪndə ðə dɝɾi waɪt-taɪld ɹuf, mɑɡiɾin ɡæspt ət ðə sʌɾən fil ə fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ maɪnd, pælpɪŋ əɹ soʊl. mɔɹaɪɾɪn dɪd ðət səmtaɪmz; ə ɹimaɪndɝ, hi sɛd, əz ɪf ʃi niɾəd ɛni mɔɹ. ʃi ɔlmoʊs lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ hɪm; hɝ skɪn pɛbəld əz ðoʊ əɾ ə sʌɾən aɪsi bɹiz. ðə tʌtʃ vænɪʃt, ən ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn. kʌmɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ɪt dɪd ɹimaɪn hɝ. mɔɹaɪɾɪn hɪmsɛlf kəɾ əpɪɹ ɛniwɛɹ əɾ ɛni taɪm. heɪst.

As the door thumped down flat into the dirty white-tiled roof, Moghedien gasped at the sudden feel of fingers stroking her mind, palping her soul. Moridin did that sometimes; a reminder, he said, as if she needed any more. She almost looked around for him; her skin pebbled as though at a sudden icy breeze. The touch vanished, and she shivered again. Coming or going, it did remind her. Moridin himself could appear anywhere at any time. Haste.

spiɾɪŋ tə ðə loʊ wɔl ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə ɹuf, ʃi sɝtʃt ðə ɹɪvɝ spɹɛɾ aʊt bɪloʊ. skɔɹz ə boʊts ʌv ɛvɹi saɪz swɛpt əlɔŋ ɑn ðɛɹ ɔɹz bɪtwin lɑɹdʒɝ vɛsəlz, æŋkɝɾ əɹ ʌndɝ seɪl. moʊst ə ðə kæbənz ə ðə sɔɹt ʃi sɔt wɝ pleɪn wʊd, bʌt ðəɹ ʃi sɔ ə jɛloʊ ɹuf, ən ðəɹ ə blu, ən ðɛɹ, ɪn mɪdʒɹaɪvɝ ən hɛɾɪŋ saʊθwɝd fæst. . . . ɹɛd. ɪt hæd tə bi ðə ɹaɪt wʌn; ʃi kəd nɑt teɪk ɛni mɔɹ taɪm hɪɹ.

Speeding to the low wall that surrounded the roof, she searched the river spread out below. Scores of boats of every size swept along on their oars between larger vessels, anchored or under sail. Most of the cabins of the sort she sought were plain wood, but there she saw a yellow roof, and there a blue, and there, in midriver and heading southward fast. . . . Red. It had to be the right one; she could not take any more time here.

ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hænz, bʌɾ əz bɑlfaɪɝ lɔntʃt ɪtsɛlf, sʌmθɪŋ flæʃt ɝaʊn əɹ ən ʃi dʒɝkt. mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd kʌm; hi wɑz ðɛɹ, ən i wʊd. . . . ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə pɪdʒənz flʌɾɝɪŋ əweɪ. pɪdʒənz! ʃi nɪɹli spjud ðə kɑntɛns ə hɝ stʌmək əkɹɔs ðə ɹuf. ə ɡlæns ət ðə ɹɪvɝ, meɪɾ əɹ snɑɹl.

She raised her hands, but as balefire launched itself, something flashed around her and she jerked. Moridin had come; he was there, and he would. . . . She stared at the pigeons fluttering away. Pigeons! She nearly spewed the contents of her stomach across the roof. A glance at the river, made her snarl.

kəz ʃi hæd dʒɝkt, ðə bɑlfaɪɝ ʃi mɛn tə slaɪs θɹu kæbən ən pæsənʒɝ ɪnstɛd hæd slaɪs daɪæɡənəli θɹu ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə boʊt, əbaʊt wɛɹ ði ɔɹsmɪn hæd stʊd, ən ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹdz. kəz ðə ɹoʊɝz hæd bɪn bɝn aʊɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn bɪfɔɹ ðə bɑlfaɪɝ stʃɹʌk, ðə tu hævz ə ðə kɹæft wɝ naʊ ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bæk ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðən əɡɛn, pɝhæps ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kəmplit dɪzæstɝ. kəz ðət slaɪs fɹəm ðə boʊts sɛntɝ hæd ɡɔn ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðə boʊtmən ɹɪli daɪd, ðə ɹɪvɝ hæd hæd mɪnəts tə ɹʌʃ ɪn. ðə tu pɑɹts ə ðə boʊt sæŋk aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt fɹɔθ ə bʌbəlz ivən əz əɹ aɪz ʃɪftəd tə ðɛm, kæɹiɪŋ ðɛɹ pæsənʒɝ tə ðə dɛpθs.

Because she had jerked, the balefire she meant to slice through cabin and passenger instead had sliced diagonally through the middle of the boat, about where the oarsmen had stood, and the bodyguards. Because the rowers had been burned out of the Pattern before the balefire struck, the two halves of the craft were now a good hundred paces back up the river. Then again, perhaps it was not a complete disaster. Because that slice from the boat's center had gone at the same time the boatmen really died, the river had had minutes to rush in. The two parts of the boat sank out of sight in a great froth of bubbles even as her eyes shifted to them, carrying their passenger to the depths.

sʌɾənli, wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn stʃɹʌk hɝ. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz muvd ɪn ðə dɪm pleɪsəz, ɔlweɪz kɛp hɝsɛlf hɪɾən, ɔlweɪz. . . . ɛni wʊmən ɪn ðə sɪɾi hu kəd tʃænəl wəd noʊ sʌmwʌn hæd dʒɹɔn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɪf nɑt fəɹ wʌt, ən ɛni aɪ wɑtʃɪŋ hæd sin ðət bɑɹ ə lɪkwəd waɪt faɪɝ sɪɹ əkɹɔs ði æftɝnun. fɪɹ ɡeɪv əɹ wɪŋz. nɑt fɪɹ. tɛɹɝ.

Suddenly, what she had done struck her. She had always moved in the dim places, always kept herself hidden, always. . . .
