Any woman in the city who could channel would know someone had drawn a great deal of saidar, if not for what, and any eye watching had seen that bar of liquid white fire sear across the afternoon. Fear gave her wings. Not fear. Terror.

ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ʃi ɹæn bæk daʊn ðə stɛɹz, ɹæn θɹu ðə kɑmən ɹum bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə teɪbəlz ən kɝɪɹɪŋ ɔf pipəl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ əɹ weɪ, ɹæn ɪndə ðə stʃɹit tu fɹaɪɾənd tə θɪŋk, bæɾɝɪŋ ə pæθ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɪð əɹ hænz.

Gathering her skirts, she ran back down the stairs, ran through the common room bumping into tables and careering off people trying to get out her way, ran into the street too frightened to think, battering a path through the crowd with her hands.

"ɹʌn!" ʃi ʃɹikt, hɝlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪndə ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹ. hɝ skɝts kɑɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹ; ʃi ɹɪpt əm fɹi. "ɹʌn!"

"Run!" she shrieked, hurling herself into the sedan chair. Her skirts caught in the door; she ripped them free. "Run!"

ðə bɛɹɝz flʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə moʊʃən, tɔsɪŋ əɹ əbaʊt, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ʃi bɹeɪs hɝsɛlf wɪð fɪŋɡɝz leɪs θɹu ðə kɑɹvd wɪndoʊ skɹinz, ən ʃʊk ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli. hi hæd nɑt fɔɹbɪɾən ðɪs. hi maɪt fɝɡɪv, əɹ ivən ɪɡnɔɹ əɹ ɪndɪpɛndən ækʃən hɪɹ, ɪf ʃi kæɹiɾ aʊɾ ɪz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz swɪfli, ɪfɪʃənli. ðət wɑz əɹ oʊnli hoʊp. ʃi wɑz gɑnə meɪk fæljən ən ɪspæn kɹɔl!

The bearers flung themselves into motion, tossing her about, but she did not care. She braced herself with fingers laced through the carved window screens, and shook uncontrollably. He had not forbidden this. He might forgive, or even ignore her independent action here, if she carried out his instructions swiftly, efficiently. That was her only hope. She was going to make Falion and Ispan crawl!


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

mæʃiɑɹə


Mashiara

əz ðə boʊt swɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə lændɪŋ, nɪneɪiv tɔst əɹ mæsk daʊn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə kʊʃən bɛntʃ ən slʌmp bæk wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ən bɹeɪd ɡɹɪp fɝmli, skaʊlɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. skaʊlɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪn stɪl toʊld əɹ ə fɪɹs stɔɹm wɑz ɑn ðə weɪ, ðə kaɪn ðət tɔɹ ɔf ɹufs ən flæɾənd bɑɹnz, ən ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ðə ɹɪvɝ wəd bɪɡɪn tə kɪk ʌp ɪn weɪvz ɹaɪt ðət mɪnət.

As the boat swept away from the landing, Nynaeve tossed her mask down beside her on the cushioned bench and slumped back with arms folded and braid gripped firmly, scowling at nothing. Scowling at everything. Listening to the Wind still told her a fierce storm was on the way, the kind that tore off roofs and flattened barns, and she almost wished the river would begin to kick up in waves right that minute.

"ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən ðə wɛðɝ, nɪneɪiv," ʃi mɪmɪkt, "ðɛn jə ʃəd bi ðə wʌn tə ɡoʊ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps maɪt bi ɪnsʌltɪɾ ɪf wi dɪdn sɛn ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ʌv ʌs. ðeɪ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ pʊt ɡɹeɪt stɔɹ ɪn ðæt. bɑ!" ðət hæd bɪn ɪleɪn. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə "bɑ." ɪleɪn dʒʌs θɔt pʊɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð ɛni əmaʊn ə nɑnsɛns fɹəm mɛɝɪlɪl wəd bi pɹɛfɝəbəl tə feɪsɪŋ nɛstə əɡɛn. wʌns jə bɪɡæn bædli wɪð sʌmwʌn, ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə ɹɪkʌvɝ - mæt kɔθən wɑz pɹuf ɪnʌf ə ðæt! - ən ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɡɑɾən ɔf ɛni wɝs wɪð nɛstə dɪn ɹiz tu munz, ʃi wəd bi sɛndɪŋ ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm tə fɛtʃ ən kæɹi.

"If it isn't the weather, Nynaeve," she mimicked, "then you should be the one to go. The Mistress of the Ships might be insulted if we didn't send the strongest of us. They know Aes Sedai put great store in that. Bah!" That had been Elayne. Except for the "bah." Elayne just thought putting up with any amount of nonsense from Merilille would be preferable to facing Nesta again. Once you began badly with someone, it was hard to recover - Mat Cauthon was proof enough of that! - and if they had gotten off any worse with Nesta din Reas Two Moons, she would be sending the lot of them to fetch and carry.

"hɔɹəbəl wʊmən!" ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld, ʃɪftɪŋ ɝaʊn ɑn ðə sit kʊʃənz. eɪvinhə hæd bɪn noʊ bɛɾɝ wən nɪneɪiv sədʒɛstəd ʃi ɡoʊ tə ðə si foʊk; ðoʊz pipəl hæd bɪn fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ hɝ. ʃi pɪtʃt əɹ vɔɪs haɪ ən fɪnəki, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk eɪvinhəz, bʌt ðə mud fɪt. "wi wɪl lɝn ə ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl wən wi lɝn, nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə. pɝhæps əl lɝn sʌmθɪŋ wɑtʃɪŋ dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn tədeɪ." ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə fæk ðət nʌθɪŋ wʌtsoʊɛvɝ fɹaɪɾənd ði il wʊmən, ʃi wʊɾə θɔɾ eɪvinhə fɪɹfəl fɹəm əɹ iɡɝnəs tə spaɪ ɑn kæɹaɪɾɪn. ə deɪ stændɪŋ ɪn ə hɑt stʃɹit dʒɑsəl baɪ kɹaʊdz wɑz nɑɾ əmjuzɪŋ, ən tədeɪ wəd bi wɝs, wɪð ðə fɛstəvəl. nɪneɪiv wʊɾə θɔt ðə wʊmən wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ə naɪs ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ boʊt ɹaɪd.

"Horrible woman!" she grumbled, shifting around on the seat cushions. Aviendha had been no better when Nynaeve suggested she go to the Sea Folk; those people had been fascinated by her. She pitched her voice high and finicky, not at all like Aviendha's, but the mood fit. "We will learn of this trouble when we learn, Nynaeve al'Meara. Perhaps I will learn something watching Jaichim Carridin today." If not for the fact that nothing whatsoever frightened the Aiel woman, she would have thought Aviendha fearful from her eagerness to spy on Carridin. A day standing in a hot street jostled by crowds was not amusing, and today would be worse, with the festival. Nynaeve would have thought the woman would enjoy a nice refreshing boat ride.

ðə boʊt lɝtʃt. ə naɪs ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ boʊt ɹaɪd, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. naɪs kul bɹizɪz ɑn ðə beɪ. mɔɪs bɹizɪz, nɑt dʒɹaɪ. ðə boʊt ɹoʊld. "oʊ, blʌɾ ən æʃəz!" ʃi moʊnd. əpɔld, ʃi klæpt ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ ən dʒɹʌmd əɹ hilz əɡɛns ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɛntʃ ɪn ɹaɪtʃəs aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ɪf ʃi hæd tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ðoʊz si foʊk fəɹ lɔŋ, ʃi wəɾ əv əz mʌtʃ fɪlθ kʌmɪŋ ɔf ə hɝ tʌŋ əz mæt dɪd. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt hɪm. wʌn mɔɹ deɪ foʊldɪŋ əɹ hænz fəɹ ðət . . . ðət mæn . . . ən ʃi wəd jæŋk ɛvɹi hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd! nɑt ðəɾ i hæd dɪmændəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ənɹiznəbəl soʊ fɑɹ, bʌt ʃi kɛpt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə, ən ɪz mænɝ . . . !

The boat lurched. A nice refreshing boat ride, she told herself. Nice cool breezes on the bay. Moist breezes, not dry. The boat rolled. "Oh, blood and ashes!" she moaned. Appalled, she clapped a hand over her mouth and drummed her heels against the front of the bench in righteous outrage. If she had to endure those Sea Folk for long, she would have as much filth coming off of her tongue as Mat did. She did not want to think about him. One more day folding her hands for that . . . that man . . . and she would yank every hair out of her head! Not that he had demanded anything unreasonable so far, but she kept waiting for him to, and his manner . . . !

"noʊ!" ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ wɑnə sɛɾəl maɪ stʌmək, nɑt ɹaɪl ɪt." ðə boʊt hæd bɪɡʌn ə sloʊ ɹɑkɪŋ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn əɹ kloʊðz. ʃi wɑz nɑt fɪkseɪɾɪd ɑn kloʊðz ðə weɪ ɪleɪn səmtaɪmz sim tə bi, bʌt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt sɪlks ən leɪsəz wɑz suðɪŋ.

"No!" she said firmly. "I want to settle my stomach, not rile it." The boat had begun a slow rocking. She tried to concentrate on her clothes. She was not fixated on clothes the way Elayne sometimes seemed to be, but thinking about silks and laces was soothing.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən tə ɪmpɹɛs ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, tə tʃɹaɪ ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ ə lɪɾəl lɔst ɡɹaʊnd, fəɹ ɔl ðə ɡʊɾ ɪt maɪt du. ɡɹin sɪlk slæʃt wɪð jɛloʊ ɪn ðə skɝts, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊl daʊn ðə slivz ən əkɹɔs ðə bɑɾəs, wɪð ɡoʊldən leɪs əlɔŋ ðə hɛm, ən əɾ əɹ ɹɪsts, ən dʒʌs bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə nɛklaɪn. pɝhæps ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn haɪɝ, tə bi teɪkən sɪɹiəsli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ oʊn ɛniθɪŋ haɪɝ. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ si foʊk kʌstəmz, ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən mɑɾəst. nɛstə wəɾ əv tə teɪk əɹ əz ʃi wɑz; nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ hɝsɛlf fəɹ ɛniwʌn.

Everything had been chosen to impress the Mistress of the Ships, to try regaining a little lost ground, for all the good it might do. Green silk slashed with yellow in the skirts, embroidered in gold down the sleeves and across the bodice, with golden lace along the hem, and at her wrists, and just bordering the neckline. Perhaps that should have been higher, to be taken seriously, but she did not own anything higher. Considering Sea Folk customs, it was more than modest. Nesta would have to take her as she was; Nynaeve al'Meara did not go changing herself for anyone.

ðə jɛloʊ oʊpəl pɪnz stʌk ɪn əɹ bɹeɪd wɝ əɹ oʊn - ə pɹɛzən fɹəm ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən, noʊ lɛs - bʌt taɪlɪn hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə ɡoʊl nɛkləs ðət fæn ɛmɹəlz ən pɝlz daʊn tə hɝ bʊzəm. ə ɹɪtʃɝ pis ðən ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv oʊnɪŋ; ə ɡɪft fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ mæt, taɪlɪn hæd kɔld ɪt, wɪtʃ meɪd noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl, bʌt meɪbi ðə kwin θɔt ʃi niɾəd səm ɪkskjus fəɹ sətʃ ə væljəbəl pɹizɛnt. boʊθ ɡoʊld-ænd-aɪvɝi bɹeɪslɪts keɪm fɹəm eɪvinhə, hu hæɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ lɪɾəl stɑk ə dʒuəlɹi fəɹ ə wʊmən u soʊ sɛldəm wɔɹ mɔɹ ðən ðət wʌn sɪlvɝ nɛkləs. nɪneɪiv hæɾ æsk tə bɑɹoʊ ðət pɹɪɾi ɹoʊzɪz-ænd-θɔɹnz aɪvɝi bɹeɪslət ðət ði il wʊmən nɛvɝ wɔɹ; sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, eɪvinhə hæd snætʃt ɪt tə hɝ bʊzəm əz ɪf ɪt wɑz əɹ moʊs pɹɛʃəs pəzɛʃən, ən ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn kʌmfɝɾɪŋ hɝ. nɪneɪiv wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðə pɛɹ fɔl wipɪŋ ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝ.

The yellow opal pins stuck in her braid were her own - a present from the Panarch of Tarabon, no less - but Tylin had provided the gold necklace that fanned emeralds and pearls down to her bosom. A richer piece than she had ever dreamed of owning; a gift for bringing Mat, Tylin had called it, which made no sense at all, but maybe the Queen thought she needed some excuse for such a valuable present. Both gold-and-ivory bracelets came from Aviendha, who had a surprising little stock of jewelry for a woman who so seldom wore more than that one silver necklace. Nynaeve had asked to borrow that pretty roses-and-thorns ivory bracelet that the Aiel woman never wore; surprisingly, Aviendha had snatched it to her bosom as if it was her most precious possession, and of all things, Elayne began comforting her. Nynaeve would not have been surprised to see the pair fall weeping on one another's shoulder.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɑd ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ, ən ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn ðoʊz tu wɝ tu sɛnsəbəl fəɹ sətʃ nɑnsɛns, ʃi wʊɾə səspɛktəɾ ə mæn ət ðə ɹuɾ ʌv ɪt. wɛl, eɪvinhə wɑz tu sɛnsəbəl; ɪleɪn dɪd stɪl jɝn fəɹ ɹænd, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv kəd hɑɹdli fɔlt əɹ fəɹ -  sʌɾənli ʃi fɛlt wivz ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɔlmoʊst ətɑp əɹ ɪn hjudʒ əmaʊns, ən . . .

There was something odd going on there, and if she had not known those two were too sensible for such nonsense, she would have suspected a man at the root of it. Well, Aviendha was too sensible; Elayne did still yearn for Rand, though Nynaeve could hardly fault her for -  Suddenly she felt weaves of saidar almost atop her in huge amounts, and . . .

. . . ʃi flaʊndɝɾ ɪn sɔlti wɔɾɝ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd, fleɪlɪŋ ʌpwɝd tə faɪn ɛɹ, tæŋɡəld ɪn əɹ skɝts, fleɪlɪŋ. hɝ hɛd bɹoʊk sɝfəs, ən ʃi ɡæsp fəɹ bɹɛθ əmɪd floʊɾɪŋ kʊʃənz, stɛɹɪŋ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə slæntɪŋ ʃeɪp əbʌv əɹ əz wʌn ə ðə kæbən sits, ən ə bɪɾ ə ðə kæbən wɔl. ʃi wɑz ɪnsaɪɾ ə tʃɹæpt pɑkəɾ ʌv ɛɹ. nɑt lɑɹdʒ; ʃi cʊɾə tʌtʃt boʊθ saɪdz wɪθaʊt stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz aʊt fʊli. bʌt haʊ . . . ? ən ɑɾəbəl θʌɾ ənaʊns ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə ɹɪvɝ; ði ʌpsaɪd-daʊn kæbən, lɝtʃt, tɪltəd. ʃi θɔt ði ɛɹ pɑkət ʃɹæŋk ə lɪɾəl.

. . . she floundered in salty water over her head, flailing upward to find air, tangled in her skirts, flailing. Her head broke surface, and she gasped for breath amid floating cushions, staring in astonishment. After a moment, she recognized the slanting shape above her as one of the cabin seats, and a bit of the cabin wall. She was inside a trapped pocket of air. Not large; she could have touched both sides without stretching her arms out fully. But how . . . ? An audible thud announced the bottom of the river; the upside-down cabin, lurched, tilted. She thought the air pocket shrank a little.

ðə fɝst ɔɹɾɝ ə bɪznəs, bɪfɔɹ wʌndɝɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ, wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃi juzd ʌp ði ɛɹ. ʃi nu haʊ tə swɪm - ʃi hæd splæʃt ɪn ðə wɔɾɝwʊd pɑnz ɔfən ɪnʌf bæk hoʊm - ɪt wɑz dʒʌst wən ðə wɔɾɝ stɑɹɾəd ɹɑkɪŋ əɹ əbaʊt ðət ʃi maɪndəd. fɪlɪŋ əɹ lʌŋz, ʃi dʌbəld oʊvɝ ən swæm daʊn təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə dɔɹ mʌs bi, kɪkɪŋ ɔkwɝdli kəz ə hɝ skɝts. ɪt maɪt hɛlp tə ʃɛd ðə dʒɹɛs, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bɑb tə ðə sɝfəs ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪn nʌθɪŋ bʌt ʃɪft ən stɑkɪŋz ən dʒuəlz. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə liv ðoʊz bɪhaɪnd, iðɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹɛs wɪθaʊt lusɪŋ əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ən ʃi wəd dʒɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ luzɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ.

The first order of business, before wondering about anything, was getting out before she used up the air. She knew how to swim - she had splashed in the Waterwood ponds often enough back home - it was just when the water started rocking her about that she minded. Filling her lungs, she doubled over and swam down toward where the door must be, kicking awkwardly because of her skirts. It might help to shed the dress, but she was not about to bob to the surface of the river in nothing but shift and stockings and jewels. She was not about to leave those behind, either. Besides, she could not get out of the dress without loosing her belt pouch, and she would drown before losing what was in there.

ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz blæk, laɪtləs. hɝ aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹʌk wʊd, ən ʃi fɛlt əkɹɔs ðə pɪɹswɝk kɑɹvɪŋ əntɪl ʃi faʊn ðə dɔɹ, skɹæb-blɛd daʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðət - ən faʊn ə hɪnʒ. mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪmpɹəkeɪʃənz ɪn əɹ hɛd, ʃi kɔʃəsli fɛlt əɹ weɪ tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd. jɛs! ðə lætʃ hændəl! ʃi lɪftəɾ ɪt, pʊʃt aʊtwɝd. ðə dɔɹ muv meɪbi tu ɪntʃəz - ən stɑpt.

The water was black, lightless. Her outstretched fingers struck wood, and she felt across the piercework carving until she found the door, scrab-bled down the edge of that - and found a hinge. Muttering imprecations in her head, she cautiously felt her way to the other side. Yes! The latch handle! She lifted it, pushed outward. The door moved maybe two inches - and stopped.

lʌŋz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ʃi swæm bæk ʌp tə ðə pɑkət, bʌɾ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə fɪl əm əɡɛn. ðɪs taɪm, faɪndɪŋ ðə dɔɹ keɪm fæstɝ. ʃi stʌk əɹ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu ðə kɹæk tə faɪnd wʌt hɛl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt. ðeɪ sæŋk ɪndə mʌd. meɪbi ʃi kəd dɪɡ əweɪ ə lɪɾəl hɪlək, ɔɹ. . . . ʃi fɛl haɪɝ. mɔɹ mʌd. ɪnkɹisɪŋli fɹæntɪk, ʃi wɝkt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə kɹæk tə ðə tɑp, ən ðɛn, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bɪliv, fɹəm ðə tɑp tə ðə bɑɾəm. mʌd, sɑləd ɡui mʌd, ɔl ðə weɪ.

Lungs straining, she swam back up to the pocket, but only long enough to fill them again. This time, finding the door came faster. She stuck her fingers through the crack to find what held the door shut. They sank into mud. Maybe she could dig away a little hillock, or. . . . She felt higher. More mud. Increasingly frantic, she worked her fingers from the bottom of the crack to the top, and then, refusing to believe, from the top to the bottom. Mud, solid gooey mud, all the way.

ðɪs taɪm wən ʃi swæm bæk ʌp tə ðə pɑkət, ʃi ɡɹæb hoʊld ə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə siɾ əbʌv əɹ ən hʌŋ fɹəm ɪt, pæntɪŋ, hɑɹt biɾɪŋ waɪldli. ði ɛɹ fɛlt . . . θɪkɝ.

This time when she swam back up to the pocket, she grabbed hold of the edge of the seat above her and hung from it, panting, heart beating wildly. The air felt . . . thicker.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt daɪ hɪɹ," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "aɪ wɪl nɑt daɪ hɪɹ!"

"I will not die here," she muttered. "I will not die here!"

ʃi hæmɝɾ ə fɪst əɡɛns ðə siɾ əntɪl ʃi fɛlt ɪt bɹuz, faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði æŋɡɝ ðət wəɾ əlaʊ hɝ tə tʃænəl. ʃi wəd nɑt daɪ. nɑt hɪɹ. əloʊn. noʊ wʌn wəd noʊ wɛɹ ʃi hæd daɪd. noʊ ɡɹeɪv, dʒʌst ə kɔɹps ɹɑɾɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. hɝ ɑɹm fɛl wɪð ə splæʃ. ʃi leɪbɝd fəɹ bɹɛθ. flɛks ə blæk ən sɪlvɝ dænst ɪn əɹ aɪz; ʃi sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ daʊn ə tub. noʊ æŋɡɝ, ʃi ɹilaɪz dɪmli. ʃi kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ fəɹ seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni bɪlif ðət ʃi wəd tʌtʃ ɪt, naʊ. ʃi wɑz gɑnə daɪ hɪɹ æftɝ ɔl. noʊ hoʊp. noʊ læn. ən wɪð hoʊp ɡɔn, flɪkɝɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə kɑnʃəsnəs laɪk ə ɡʌɾɝɪŋ kændəl fleɪm, ʃi dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ dʌn bɪfɔɹ ɪn əɹ laɪf. ʃi sɝɛndɝd kəmplitli.

She hammered a fist against the seat until she felt it bruise, fighting for the anger that would allow her to channel. She would not die. Not here. Alone. No one would know where she had died. No grave, just a corpse rotting at the bottom of the river. Her arm fell with a splash. She labored for breath. Flecks of black and silver danced in her eyes; she seemed to be looking down a tube. No anger, she realized dimly. She kept trying to reach for saidar, but without any belief that she would touch it, now. She was going to die here after all. No hope. No Lan. And with hope gone, flickering on the edge of consciousness like a guttering candle flame, she did something she had never done before in her life. She surrendered completely.

seɪaɪdɑɹ floʊɾ ɪndə hɝ, fɪl hɝ.

Saidar flowed into her, filled her.

ʃi wɑz oʊnli hæf-əwɛɹ ə ðə wʊɾ əbʌv əɹ sʌɾənli bʌlʒɪŋ aʊtwɝd, bɝstɪŋ. ɪn ɹʌʃɪŋ bʌbəlz ʌv ɛɹ ʃi dʒɹɪftəɾ ʌp, aʊt θɹu ðə hoʊl ɪn ðə hʌl ɪndə dɑɹknəs. veɪɡli, ʃi nu ʃi ʃəd də sʌmθɪŋ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt. jɛs. hɝ fit kɪkt wikli; ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə muv əɹ ɑɹmz tə swɪm. ðeɪ sim tə dʒʌs floʊt.

She was only half-aware of the wood above her suddenly bulging outward, bursting. In rushing bubbles of air she drifted up, out through the hole in the hull into darkness. Vaguely, she knew she should do something. She could almost remember what. Yes. Her feet kicked weakly; she tried to move her arms to swim. They seemed to just float.

sʌmθɪŋ sizd əɹ dʒɹɛs, ən pænɪk ɹaʊzd əɹ ɪn θɔts ə ʃɑɹks, ən laɪənfɪʃ, ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɛls ðət maɪɾ ɪnhæbət ðiz blæk dɛpθs. ə spɑɹk ə kɑnʃəsnəs spoʊk ə ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ʃi fleɪl dɛspɝətli wɪð fɪsts ən fit, fɛlt əɹ nʌkəlz læn sɑlədli. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi ɔlsoʊ skɹimd, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə. ə ɡɹeɪt kwɑntəɾi ʌv wɔɾɝ ɹʌʃɪŋ daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt wɑʃt əweɪ skɹim, seɪaɪdɑɹ, ən vɛɹi nɪɹli hɝ faɪnəl skɹæps ʌv əwɛɹnəs.

Something seized her dress, and panic roused her in thoughts of sharks, and lionfish, and the Light alone knew what else that might inhabit these black depths. A spark of consciousness spoke of the Power, but she flailed desperately with fists and feet, felt her knuckles land solidly. Unfortunately, she also screamed, or tried to. A great quantity of water rushing down her throat washed away scream, saidar, and very nearly her final scraps of awareness.

sʌmθɪŋ tʌɡd ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd, ðən əɡɛn, ən ʃi wɑz biɪŋ toʊd . . . sʌmwɛɹ. ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kɑnʃəs ɪnʌf tə stʃɹʌɡəl, əɹ ivən tə bi vɛɹi mʌtʃ əfɹeɪɾ ə biɪŋ iɾən.

Something tugged on her braid, then again, and she was being towed . . . somewhere. She was no longer conscious enough to struggle, or even to be very much afraid of being eaten.

əbɹʌpli hɝ hɛd bɹoʊk sɝfəs. hænz ɪnsɝkəld əɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd - hænz; nɑɾ ə ʃɑɹk, æftɝ ɔl - skwiz hɑɹɾ əɡɛnst əɹ ɹɪbz ɪn ə moʊs fəmɪljɝ weɪ. ʃi kɔft - wɔɾɝ spjud fɹəm əɹ noʊz - kɔft əɡɛn, peɪnfəli. ən dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ teɪstəɾ ɛniθɪŋ soʊ swiɾ ɪn əɹ laɪf.

Abruptly her head broke surface. Hands encircled her from behind - hands; not a shark, after all - squeezed hard against her ribs in a most familiar way. She coughed - water spewed from her nose - coughed again, painfully. And drew a shuddering breath. She had never tasted anything so sweet in her life.

ə hæn kʌpt əɹ tʃɪn, ən sʌɾənli ʃi wɑz biɪŋ toʊɾ əɡɛn. læsətud wɑʃt θɹu hɝ. ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz floʊɾ ɑn əɹ bæk, ən bɹið, ən stɛɹ ʌp ət ðə skaɪ. soʊ blu. soʊ bjuɾəfəl. ðə stɪŋɪŋ ɪn əɹ aɪz wɑz nɑɾ ɔl fɹəm ðə sɔlti ɹɪvɝ.

A hand cupped her chin, and suddenly she was being towed again. Lassitude washed through her. All she could do was float on her back, and breathe, and stare up at the sky. So blue. So beautiful. The stinging in her eyes was not all from the salty river.

ən ðən ʃi wɑz biɪŋ pʊʃt ʌpwɝɾ əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə boʊt, ə ɹud hæn bɪniθ əɹ bɑɾəm ʃʌvɪŋ əɹ haɪɝ, əntɪl tu læŋki fɛloʊz wɪð bɹæs ɹɪŋz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪɹz kəd ɹitʃ daʊn ən hɔl əɹ əbɔɹd. ðeɪ hɛlpt əɹ wɔk ə stɛp əɹ tu, bʌɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ lɛt ɡoʊ tə hɛlp əɹ ɹɛskjuɝ, hɝ lɛɡz kəlæps laɪk taʊɝz ə sɑɡi mʌʃ.

And then she was being pushed upward against the side of a boat, a rude hand beneath her bottom shoving her higher, until two lanky fellows with brass rings in their ears could reach down and haul her aboard. They helped her walk a step or two, but as soon as they let go to help her rescuer, her legs collapsed like towers of soggy mush.

ɑn ənstɛɾi hænz ən niz, ʃi stɛɹd blæŋkli əɾ ə sɔɹɾ ən buts ən ɡɹin koʊt sʌmwʌn hæd θɹoʊn daʊn ɑn ðə dɛk. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ - ən ɛmptid hɝsɛlf ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪldɑɹ. ði ɪntaɪɝ ɹɪvɝ, ɪt simd, plʌs əɹ mɪddeɪ mil, ən əɹ bɹɛkfəst; ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ əɾ ɔl tə si ə fju fɪʃ, əɹ əɹ slɪpɝz. ʃi wɑz waɪpɪŋ əɹ lɪps wɪð ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd wən ʃi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə vɔɪsəz.

On unsteady hands and knees, she stared blankly at a sword and boots and green coat someone had thrown down on the deck. She opened her mouth - and emptied herself of the River Eldar. The entire river, it seemed, plus her midday meal, and her breakfast; it would not have surprised her at all to see a few fish, or her slippers. She was wiping her lips with the back of her hand when she became aware of voices.

"maɪ lɔɹɾ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt? maɪ lɔɹd wɑz daʊn fəɹ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm."

"My Lord is all right? My Lord was down for a very long time."

"fɝɡɛt mi, mæn," sɛɾ ə dip vɔɪs. "ɡɛt sʌmθɪŋ tə ɹæp ɝaʊn ðə leɪɾi." lænz vɔɪs, ðət ʃi dʒɹimd ɛvɹi naɪɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ.

"Forget me, man," said a deep voice. "Get something to wrap around the lady." Lan's voice, that she dreamed every night of hearing.

waɪd-aɪd, nɪneɪiv bɛɹli bɪt bæk ə weɪl; ðə hɔɹɝ ʃi hæd fɛlt wən ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz gɑnə daɪ wɑz nʌθɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd wʌt flæʃt θɹu hɝ naʊ. nʌθɪŋ! ðɪs wɑz ə naɪtmɛɹ. nɑt naʊ! nɑt laɪk ðɪs! nɑt wən ʃi wɑz ə dʒɹaʊn ɹæt, nilɪŋ wɪð ðə kɑntɛns ə hɝ stʌmək spɹɛɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ hɝ!

Wide-eyed, Nynaeve barely bit back a wail; the horror she had felt when she thought she was going to die was nothing alongside what flashed through her now. Nothing! This was a nightmare. Not now! Not like this! Not when she was a drowned rat, kneeling with the contents of her stomach spread out before her!

wɪθaʊt θɔt ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ ən tʃænəld. wɔɾɝ fɛl əweɪ fɹəm əɹ kloʊðz, hɝ hɛɹ, ɪn ə ɹʌʃ ən wɑʃt ɔl ɛvəɾəns ə hɝ lɪɾəl mɪshæp aʊt θɹu ə skʌpɝ hoʊl. skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə hɝ fit, ʃi hɝidli pʊld əɹ nɛkləs æɹaɪɾ ən dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə stʃɹeɪɾən əɹ dʒɹɛs ən hɛɹ, bʌt ðə soʊkɪŋ ɪn sɔlt wɔɾɝ ən ðən ðə ɹæpəd dʒɹaɪɪŋ hæd lɛf sɛvɹəl steɪnz ɑn ðə sɪlk ən ə nʌmbɝ ə kɹisɪz ðət wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ə nɑlədʒəbəl hænd wɪð ə hɑɾ aɪɝn tə ɹimuv. wɪsps ə hɛɹ wɑntəd tə flaɪ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ skælp, ən ði oʊpəlz ɪn əɹ bɹeɪd sim tə dɑt ðə bɹɪsəlɪŋ teɪl ʌv ən æŋɡɹi kæt.

Without thought she embraced saidar and channeled. Water fell away from her clothes, her hair, in a rush and washed all evidence of her little mishap out through a scupper hole. Scrambling to her feet, she hurriedly pulled her necklace aright and did her best to straighten her dress and hair, but the soaking in salt water and then the rapid drying had left several stains on the silk and a number of creases that would require a knowledgeable hand with a hot iron to remove. Wisps of hair wanted to fly away from her scalp, and the opals in her braid seemed to dot the bristling tail of an angry cat.

ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. ʃi wɑz kɑmnəs ɪtsɛlf, kul əz ən ɝli spɹɪŋ bɹiz, sɛlf-pəzɛst æz. . . . ʃi spʌn ɝaʊn bɪfɔɹ i kəd kʌm ɑn əɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ən stɑɹɾəl əɹ ɪndə dɪsɡɹeɪsɪŋ hɝsɛlf kəmplitli.

It did not matter. She was calmness itself, cool as an early spring breeze, self-possessed as. . . . She spun around before he could come on her from behind and startle her into disgracing herself completely.

ʃi oʊnli ɹilaɪz haʊ kwɪkli ʃi hæd muvd wən ʃi sɔ ðət læn wɑz dʒʌs ðən teɪkɪŋ ɪz sɛkən stɛp fɹəm ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ. hi wɑz ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl mæn ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. soʊkɪŋ wɛɾ ɪn ʃɝɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ən stɑkɪŋz, hi wɑz ɡɔɹdʒəs, wɪð ɪz dʒɹɪpɪŋ hɛɹ klɪŋɪŋ tə ði æŋɡəlz ə hɪz feɪs, ænd. . . . ə splɪt pɝpəl bɹuz wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs, əz fɹəm ə bloʊ. ʃi klæpt ə hæn tə hɝ maʊθ, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ əɹ fɪs kənɛktɪŋ.

She only realized how quickly she had moved when she saw that Lan was just then taking his second step from the railing. He was the most beautiful man she had ever seen. Soaking wet in shirt and breeches and stockings, he was gorgeous, with his dripping hair clinging to the angles of his face, and. . . . A split purple bruise was rising on his face, as from a blow. She clapped a hand to her mouth, remembering her fist connecting.

"oʊ, noʊ! oʊ, læn, aɪm soʊ sɑɹi! aɪ dɪdn min tə!" ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹɪli əwɛɹ ə kɹɔsɪŋ ðə speɪs bɪtwin ðɛm; ʃi wɑz dʒʌs ðɛɹ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ʌp ɑn toʊɾəps tə leɪ fɪŋɡɝz dʒɛnli ɑn ɪz ɪnʒɝi. ə dɛft wiv ʌv ɔl faɪv paʊɝz, ən ɪz tæn tʃik wɑz ənblɛmɪʃt. bʌɾ i maɪɾ əv bɪn hɝɾ ɛlswɛɹ. ʃi spʌn ðə wivz tə dɛlv hɪm; nu skɑɹz meɪɾ əɹ wɪns ɪnsaɪd, ən ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɑd, bʌɾ i sim hɛlθi əz ə pɹaɪm bʊl. hi wɑz ɔlsoʊ vɛɹi wɛt, fɹəm seɪvɪŋ hɝ. ʃi dʒɹaɪɾ ɪm əz ʃi hæd hɝsɛlf; wɔɾɝ splæʃt ɝaʊn ɪz fit. ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp tʌtʃɪŋ hɪm. boʊθ hænz tʃɹeɪst ɪz hɑɹd tʃiks, hɪz wʌndɝfəl blu aɪz, hɪz stʃɹɔŋ noʊz, hɪz fɝm lɪps, hɪz ɪɹz. ʃi koʊm ðət sɪlki blæk hɛɹ ɪndə pleɪs wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ədʒʌstəd ðə bɹeɪɾɪd lɛðɝ bæn ðət hɛld ɪt. hɝ tʌŋ sim tə hæv ə laɪf ʌv ɪts oʊn, tu. "oʊ, læn," ʃi mɝmɝd. "ju ɹɪli ɑɹ hɪɹ." sʌmbɑɾi ɡɪɡəld. nɑɾ əɹ - nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə dɪd nɑt ɡɪɡəl - bʌt sʌmbɑɾi dɪd. "ɪɾ ɪzən ə dʒɹim. oʊ, laɪt, jəɹ hɪɹ. haʊ?"

"Oh, no! Oh, Lan, I'm so sorry! I didn't mean to!" She was not really aware of crossing the space between them; she was just there, stretching up on toetips to lay fingers gently on his injury. A deft weave of all Five Powers, and his tanned cheek was unblemished. But he might have been hurt elsewhere. She spun the weaves to Delve him; new scars made her wince inside, and there was something odd, but he seemed healthy as a prime bull. He was also very wet, from saving her. She dried him as she had herself; water splashed around his feet. She could not stop touching him. Both hands traced his hard cheeks, his wonderful blue eyes, his strong nose, his firm lips, his ears. She combed that silky black hair into place with her fingers, adjusted the braided leather band that held it. Her tongue seemed to have a life of its own, too. "Oh, Lan," she murmured. "You really are here." Somebody giggled. Not her - Nynaeve al'Meara did not giggle - but somebody did. "It isn't a dream. Oh, Light, you're here. How?"

"ə sɝvən ət ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs toʊl mi jud ɡɔn tə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən ə fɛloʊ ət ðə lændɪŋ sɛd wʌt boʊt jə hæd teɪkən. ɪf mændɑɹb hædn lɔst ə ʃu, aɪ wʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ jɛstɝdeɪ."

"A servant at the Tarasin Palace told me you'd gone to the river, and a fellow at the landing said what boat you had taken. If Mandarb hadn't lost a shoe, I would have been here yesterday."

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ. jəɹ hɪɹ naʊ. jəɹ hɪɹ." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪɡəl.

"I don't care. You're here now. You're here." She did not giggle.

"meɪbi ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ," wʌn ə ðə boʊtmən mɝmɝd, nɑt kwaɪt loʊ ɪnʌf, "bʌɾ aɪ stɪl seɪ ʃiz wʌn dʌklɪŋ u minz tə stʌf hɝsɛlf ɪn ðət wʊlfs dʒɔz."

"Maybe she is Aes Sedai," one of the boatmen murmured, not quite low enough, "but I still say she's one duckling who means to stuff herself in that wolf's jaws."

nɪneɪivz feɪs flæʃt pjʊɹ skɑɹlət, ən ʃi snætʃt əɹ hænz tə hɝ saɪdz, hɝ hilz θʌmpɪŋ tə ðə dɛk. ənʌðɝ taɪm, ʃi wʊɾə ɡɪvən ðə fɛloʊ wʌt fɔɹ, ən noʊ mɪsteɪk. ənʌðɝ taɪm, wən ʃi kəd θɪŋk. læn kɹaʊɾəd ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ʃi sizd ɪz ɑɹm. "wi kən tɔk mɔɹ pɹaɪvətli ɪn ðə kæbən." hæd wʌn ə ði ɔɹsmɪn snɪkɝd?

Nynaeve's face flashed pure scarlet, and she snatched her hands to her sides, her heels thumping to the deck. Another time, she would have given the fellow what for, and no mistake. Another time, when she could think. Lan crowded everything else out of her head. She seized his arm. "We can talk more privately in the cabin." Had one of the oarsmen snickered?

"maɪ sɔɹɾ ən - "

"My sword and - "

"aɪl bɹɪŋ ɪt," ʃi sɛd, snætʃɪŋ ʌp ɪz θɪŋz fɹəm ðə dɛk ɑn floʊz ʌv ɛɹ. wʌn ə ðoʊz laʊts hæd snɪkɝd. ənʌðɝ floʊ ʌv ɛɹ pʊld oʊpən ðə kæbən dɔɹ, ən ʃi hʌsəld læn ən ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ðə ɹɛst ɪnsaɪɾ ən slæmd ɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

"I'll bring it," she said, snatching up his things from the deck on flows of Air. One of those louts had snickered. Another flow of Air pulled open the cabin door, and she hustled Lan and his sword and the rest inside and slammed it behind them.

laɪt, ʃi daʊɾɪd ɪf ivən keɪl kɑplɪn bæk hoʊm hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn əz boʊld əz ðɪs, ən əz mɛni mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz nu keɪlz bɝθmɑɹk əz nu hɝ feɪs. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əɾ ɔl. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl! stɪl, noʊ hɑɹm ɪn biɪŋ dʒʌst ə tæd lɛs . . . iɡɝ. hɝ hænz wɛn bæk tə hɪz feɪs - oʊnli tə stʃɹeɪɾən ɪz hɛɹ səm mɔɹ; dʒʌs ðət - ən i kɑɾ əɹ ɹɪsts dʒɛnli ɪn ɪz bɪɡ hænz.

Light, she doubted if even Calle Coplin back home had ever been as bold as this, and as many merchants' guards knew Calle's birthmark as knew her face. But it was not the same at all. Not at all! Still, no harm in being just a tad less . . . eager. Her hands went back to his face - only to straighten his hair some more; just that - and he caught her wrists gently in his big hands.

"maɪɹɛl hoʊlz maɪ bɑnd, naʊ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ʃi ɪz lɛndɪŋ mi tə jə əntɪl jə faɪn ə wɔɹɾɝ ə jəɹ oʊn."

"Myrelle holds my bond, now," he said quietly. "She is lending me to you until you find a Warder of your own."

kɑmli pʊlɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪt hæn fɹi, ʃi slæpt ɪz feɪs əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kəd swɪŋ. hɪz hɛd hɑɹdli muvd, soʊ ʃi fɹid ði ʌðɝ hæn ən slæpt ɪm hɑɹɾɝ wɪð ðæt. "haʊ kəd ju?" fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ, ʃi pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪd ðə kwɛstʃən wɪð ənʌðɝ slæp. "ju nu aɪ wɑz weɪɾɪŋ!" wʌn mɔɹ sim kɔl fɔɹ, dʒʌs tə dʒɹaɪv ðə pɔɪn hoʊm. "haʊ kəd jə də sətʃ ə θɪŋ? haʊ kəd jə lɛt hɝ?" ənʌðɝ slæp. "bɝn ju, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən! bɝn ju! bɝn ju! bɝn jə tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum! bɝn ju!"

Calmly pulling her right hand free, she slapped his face as hard as she could swing. His head hardly moved, so she freed the other hand and slapped him harder with that. "How could you?" For good measure, she punctuated the question with another slap. "You knew I was waiting!" One more seemed called for, just to drive the point home. "How could you do such a thing? How could you let her?" Another slap. "Burn you, Lan Mandragoran! Burn you! Burn you! Burn you to the Pit of Doom! Burn you!"

ðə mæn - ðə blʌɾi mæn! - dɪd nɑt seɪ wʌn wɝd. nɑt ðəɾ i kʊd, ʌv kɔɹs; wʌt dɪfɛns kəɾ i ɔfɝ? hi dʒʌst stʊd ðəɹ waɪl ʃi ɹeɪn bloʊz ət hɪm, meɪkɪŋ noʊ muv, ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪz lʊkɪŋ pəkjuljɝ, əz wɛl ðeɪ maɪt wɪð ðə weɪ ʃi ɹɛɾənd ɪz tʃiks fəɹ hɪm. ɪf əɹ slæps meɪd lɪɾəl ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn hɪm, ðoʊ, ðə pɑmz ə hɝ hænz bɪɡæn tə stɪŋ laɪk fjʊɹi.

The man - the bloody man! - did not say one word. Not that he could, of course; what defense could he offer? He just stood there while she rained blows at him, making no move, unblinking eyes looking peculiar, as well they might with the way she reddened his cheeks for him. If her slaps made little impression on him, though, the palms of her hands began to sting like fury.

ɡɹɪmli, ʃi klɛntʃt ə fɪst ən pʌntʃt ɪm ɪn ðə bɛli wɪð ɔl əɹ maɪt. hi ɡɹʌntɪd. slaɪtli.

Grimly, she clenched a fist and punched him in the belly with all her might. He grunted. Slightly.

"wi wɪl tɔk ðɪs oʊvɝ kɑmli ən ɹæʃənəli," ʃi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ bæk fɹəm hɪm. "æz ədʌls." læn dʒʌs nɑɾəd ən sæt daʊn ən pʊld ɪz buts oʊvɝ tə hɪm! pʊʃɪŋ bɪts ə hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ feɪs wɪð əɹ lɛf hænd, ʃi stʌk ðə ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ soʊ ʃi kəd flɛks əɹ sɔɹ fɪŋɡɝz wɪθaʊɾ ɪm siɪŋ. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt biɪŋ ðət hɑɹd, nɑt wən ʃi wɑntəd tə hɪt hɪm. tu mʌtʃ tə hoʊp ʃi hæd kɹækt ə ɹɪb ɪn hɪm.

"We will talk this over calmly and rationally," she said, stepping back from him. "As adults." Lan just nodded and sat down and pulled his boots over to him! Pushing bits of hair out of her face with her left hand, she stuck the right behind her so she could flex her sore fingers without him seeing. He had no right being that hard, not when she wanted to hit him. Too much to hope she had cracked a rib in him.

"ju ʃəd θæŋk hɝ, nɪneɪiv." haʊ kəd ðə mæn saʊn soʊ kɑm! stæmpɪŋ ɪz fʊt fɝmli ɪndə wʌn but, hi bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ði ʌðɝ, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. "ju wʊdnt wɑn mi bɑndəd tə ju."

"You should thank her, Nynaeve." How could the man sound so calm! Stamping his foot firmly into one boot, he bent to pick up the other, not looking at her. "You wouldn't want me bonded to you."

ðə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ sizd ə hændfʊl ə hɪz hɛɹ ən bɛn ɪz hɛɾ ʌp peɪnfəli. "ɪf jə dɛɹ - ɪf jə ivən dɛɹ - tə spaʊt ðət dʒɹɪvəl əbaʊt nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə ɡɪmi ə wɪɾoʊz widz, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, əl . . . aɪl. . . ." ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. kɪkɪŋ ɪm wɑz nɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf. maɪɹɛl. maɪɹɛl ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz. bɝn hɪm! ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz haɪɾ ɪn stʃɹɪps wəd nɑt bi ɪnʌf!

The flow of Air seized a handful of his hair and bent his head up painfully. "If you dare - if you even dare - to spout that drivel about not wanting to give me a widow's weeds, Lan Mandragoran, I'll . . . I'll. . . ." She could not think of anything strong enough. Kicking him was not near enough. Myrelle. Myrelle and her Warders. Burn him! Removing his hide in strips would not be enough!

hi maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv bɪn bɛn oʊvɝ wɪð ɪz nɛk kɹeɪnd. hi dʒʌst ɹɛstəɾ ɪz fɹɑɹmz əkɹɔs ɪz niz, ən wɑtʃt əɹ wɪð ðəɾ ɑd lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz, ən sɛd, "aɪ θɔɾ əbaʊt nɑt tɛlɪŋ ju, bʌt juv ə ɹaɪt tə noʊ." ivən soʊ, hɪz toʊn bɪkeɪm hɛzɪɾənt; læn wɑz nɛvɝ hɛzɪɾənt. "wɛn mɔɪɹeɪn daɪd - wən ə wɔɹɾɝz bɑn tə hɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz snæpt - ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃeɪnʒəz. . . ."

He might as well not have been bent over with his neck craned. He just rested his forearms across his knees, and watched her with that odd look in his eyes, and said, "I thought about not telling you, but you have a right to know." Even so, his tone became hesitant; Lan was never hesitant. "When Moiraine died - when a Warder's bond to his Aes Sedai is snapped - there are changes. . . ."

əz i kəntɪnjud, hɝ ɑɹmz sneɪkt ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, hʌɡɪŋ taɪtli tə kip əɹ fɹəm ʃɪvɝɪŋ. hɝ dʒɔ ætʃt, fəɹ ʃi kɛpt ɪt klæmpt ʃʌt. ʃi ɹilis ðə floʊ hoʊldɪŋ ɪm əz ɪf ə hæn spɹɪŋɪŋ əweɪ, ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌɾ i oʊnli stʃɹeɪɾənd ən wɛn ɑn ɹɪleɪɾɪŋ ðɪs hɔɹɝ wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə flɪntʃ, wɛn ɑn wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. sʌɾənli ʃi ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪz aɪz, koʊldɝ ðən wɪntɝz hɑɹt. ði aɪz ʌv ə mæn u nu hi wɑz dɛɾ ən kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf kɛɹ, ə mæn weɪɾɪŋ, ɔlmoʊst iɡɝ, fəɹ ðət lɔŋ slip. hɝ oʊn aɪz stʌŋ wɪð nɑt wipɪŋ.

As he continued, her arms snaked around herself, hugging tightly to keep her from shivering. Her jaw ached, for she kept it clamped shut. She released the flow holding him as if a hand springing away, released saidar, but he only straightened and went on relating this horror without so much as a flinch, went on watching her. Suddenly she understood his eyes, colder than winter's heart. The eyes of a man who knew he was dead and could not make himself care, a man waiting, almost eager, for that long sleep. Her own eyes stung with not weeping.

"soʊ jə si," hi kənkluɾəd wɪð ə smaɪl ðət tʌtʃt oʊnli hɪz maʊð; ən æksɛptɪŋ smaɪl, "wɛn ɪts dʌn, ʃɪl əv ə jɪɹ əɹ mɔɹ ə peɪn, ən əl stɪl bi dɛd. jə ɑɹ spɛɹd ðæt. maɪ læst ɡɪf tə ju, mæʃiɑɹə." mæʃiɑɹə. hɪz lɔs lʌv.

"So you see," he concluded with a smile that touched only his mouth; an accepting smile, "when it's done, she will have a year or more of pain, and I will still be dead. You are spared that. My last gift to you, Mashiara." Mashiara. His lost love.

"ju ɑɹ tə bi maɪ wɔɹɾɝ əntɪl aɪ faɪnd wʌn?" hɝ vɔɪs stɑɹɾəld əɹ wɪð ɪts lɛvlnəs. ʃi kəd nɑt bɹeɪk daʊn ɪn tɪɹz naʊ. ʃi wəd nɑt. naʊ, mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ, ʃi hæd tə ɡæðɝ ɔl əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ.

"You are to be my Warder until I find one?" Her voice startled her with its levelness. She could not break down in tears now. She would not. Now, more than ever before, she had to gather all her strength.

"jɛs," hi sɛd kɔʃəsli, tʌɡɪŋ ɑn ɪz ʌðɝ but. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz sim sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə hæf-teɪm wʊlf, ən ɪz aɪz meɪɾ ɪm sim mʌtʃ lɛs ðən hæf teɪm naʊ.

"Yes," he said cautiously, tugging on his other boot. He had always seemed something of a half-tame wolf, and his eyes made him seem much less than half tame now.

"ɡʊd." ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd ði ɝdʒ tə kɹɔs ðə kæbən tə hɪm. ʃi kəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm si hɝ fɪɹ. "bɪkɔz aɪ hæv faʊn hɪm. ju. aɪ weɪɾəd ən wɪʃt wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn; aɪ woʊnt wɪð maɪɹɛl. ʃiz gɑnə ɡɪmi jəɹ bɑnd." maɪɹɛl wʊd, ɪf ʃi hæd tə dʒɹæɡ ðə wʊmən tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən bæk baɪ hɝ hɛɹ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi maɪt dʒɹæɡ hɝ dʒʌs fəɹ ðə pɹɪnsəpəl ʌv ɪt. "doʊn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli wən i oʊpən ɪz maʊð. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, wɛɹ ɪz hɛvi ɡoʊl sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ leɪ ɹæpt ɪn ə sɪlk hæŋkɝtʃɪf. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi mɑɾɝeɪtɪd əɹ toʊn; hi wɑz ɪl, ən hɑɹʃ wɝdz nɛvɝ hɛlp sɪknəs. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt, ðoʊ; ʃi wɑntəd tə bɪɹeɪɾ ɪm ʌp wʌn saɪɾ ən daʊn ði ʌðɝ, wɑntəd tə pʊl əɹ bɹeɪɾ aʊt baɪ ðə ɹuts ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi θɔɾ ə hɪm ən ðət wʊmən. faɪɾɪŋ tə kip əɹ vɔɪs kɑm, ʃi wɛn ɑn.

"Good." Adjusting her skirts, she resisted the urge to cross the cabin to him. She could not let him see her fear. "Because I have found him. You. I waited and wished with Moiraine; I won't with Myrelle. She is going to give me your bond." Myrelle would, if she had to drag the woman to Tar Valon and back by her hair. For that matter, she might drag her just for the principle of it. "Don't say anything," she said sharply when he opened his mouth. Her fingers brushed her belt pouch, where his heavy gold signet ring lay wrapped in a silk handkerchief. With an effort, she moderated her tone; he was ill, and harsh words never helped sickness. It was an effort, though; she wanted to berate him up one side and down the other, wanted to pull her braid out by the roots every time she thought of him and that woman. Fighting to keep her voice calm, she went on.

"ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, læn, wən sʌmbɑɾi ɡɪvz ənʌðɝ ə ɹɪŋ, ðeɪ ɑɹ bɪtʃɹɑθd." ðət wɑz ə laɪ, ən ʃi hæf-ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə dʒʌmp tə hɪz fiɾ ɪn aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, bʌɾ i oʊnli blɪŋkt wɛɹəli. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi hæd ɹɛɾ əbaʊt ðə noʊʃən ɪn ə stɔɹi. "wi hæv bɪn bɪtʃɹɑθ lɔŋ ɪnʌf. wəɹ gɑnə bi mɛɹid tədeɪ."

"In the Two Rivers, Lan, when somebody gives another a ring, they are betrothed." That was a lie, and she half-expected him to jump to his feet in outrage, but he only blinked warily. Besides, she had read about the notion in a story. "We have been betrothed long enough. We are going to be married today."

"aɪ juz tə pɹeɪ fəɹ ðæt," hi sɛd sɔfli, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ju noʊ waɪ ɪt kæn bi, nɪneɪiv. ən ivən ɪf ɪt kʊd, maɪɹɛl - "

"I used to pray for that," he said softly, then shook his head. "You know why it can't be, Nynaeve. And even if it could, Myrelle - "

dɪspaɪɾ ɔl əɹ pɹɑməsəz tə kip əɹ tɛmpɝ, tə bi dʒɛntəl, ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ ən stʌft ə ɡæɡ ʌv ɛɹ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i kəd kənfɛs wʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ. soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt kənfɛs, ʃi kəd pɹitɛnd nʌθɪŋ hæd hæpənd. wən ʃi ɡɑt hoʊld ə maɪɹɛl, ðoʊ! oʊpəlz pɹɛs hɑɹɾ ɪndə hɝ pɑm, ən əɹ hæn lɛp fɹəm əɹ bɹeɪɾ əz ɪf bɝnd. ʃi ɑkjəpaɪɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz wɪð bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ əɡɛn waɪl i ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ɪndɪɡnənli əbʌv ɪz ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊð. "ə smɔl lɛsən fəɹ jə ɪn ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin waɪvz ən ʌðɝ wɪmən," ʃi sɛd laɪtli. sətʃ ə stʃɹʌɡəl. "aɪ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪf jə dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən maɪɹɛlz neɪm əɡɛn ɪn maɪ pɹɛzəns. dʒju ʌndɝstænd?"

Despite all her promises to keep her temper, to be gentle, she embraced saidar and stuffed a gag of Air into his mouth before he could confess what she did not want to hear. So long as he did not confess, she could pretend nothing had happened. When she got hold of Myrelle, though! Opals pressed hard into her palm, and her hand leaped from her braid as if burned. She occupied her fingers with brushing his hair again while he glared at her indignantly above his gaping mouth. "A small lesson for you in the difference between wives and other women," she said lightly. Such a struggle. "I would appreciate it very much if you did not mention Myrelle's name again in my presence. Do you understand?"

hi nɑɾəd, ən ʃi ɹilis ðə floʊ, bʌɾ əz sun əz i hæd wɝkt ɪz dʒɔ ə moʊmənt, hi sɛd, "neɪmɪŋ noʊ neɪmz, nɪneɪiv, jə noʊ ʃiz əwɛɹ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ fil, θɹu ðə bɑnd. ɪf wi wɝ mæn ən waɪf. . . ."

He nodded, and she released the flow, but as soon as he had worked his jaw a moment, he said, "Naming no names, Nynaeve, you know she's aware of everything I feel, through the bond. If we were man and wife. . . ."

ʃi θɔɾ əɹ feɪs maɪt bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə ðæt! blʌɾi maɪɹɛl! "ɪz ðəɹ ɛni weɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi noʊz ɪts mi?" ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, ən əɹ tʃiks nɪɹli dɪd flæʃ tə faɪɝ. ɪspɛʃli wən i fɛl bæk əɡɛns ðə kæbən wɔl læfɪŋ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt.

She thought her face might burst into flame. She had never thought of that! Bloody Myrelle! "Is there any way to make sure she knows it is me?" she said finally, and her cheeks nearly did flash to fire. Especially when he fell back against the cabin wall laughing in astonishment.

"laɪt, nɪneɪiv, jə ɑɹ ə hɔk! laɪt! aɪ hævən læf sɪns. . . ." hɪz mɝθ feɪɾəd, ðə koʊlnəs ðət hæd dɪmd ɪn ɪz aɪz fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. "aɪ də wɪʃ ɪt kəd bi, nɪneɪiv, bʌt - "

"Light, Nynaeve, you are a hawk! Light! I haven't laughed since. . . ." His mirth faded, the coldness that had dimmed in his eyes for an instant returning. "I do wish it could be, Nynaeve, but - "

"ɪt kən ən wɪl," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn. mɛn ɔlweɪz sim tə ɡɛt ði ʌpɝ hæn ɪf jə lɛɾ əm tɔk tu lɔŋ. ʃi plʌmp hɝsɛlf daʊn ɑn ɪz niz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt mɛɹid jɛt, tʃɹu, bʌɾ i wɑz sɑftɝ ðən ði ənpəɾəd bɛntʃɪz ɑn ðɪs boʊt. ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ə bɪt tə meɪk hɝsɛlf mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl. wɛl, noʊ hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðə bɛntʃɪz, ɛniweɪ. "ju maɪɾ əz wɛl ɹɛkənsaɪl jɝsɛlf, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən. maɪ hɑɹt bɪlɔŋz tə ju, ən juv ədmɪɾəd jʊɹz bɪlɔŋz tə mi. jə bɪlɔŋ tə mi, ən əl nɑt lɛt jə ɡoʊ. jəl bi maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, ən maɪ hʌzbənd, ən fəɹ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm. əl nɑt lɛt jə daɪ. dʒju ʌndɝstæn ðæt? aɪ kən bi əz stʌbɝn əz aɪ hæv tə bi."

"It can and will," she broke in. Men always seemed to get the upper hand if you let them talk too long. She plumped herself down on his knees. They were not married yet, true, but he was softer than the unpadded benches on this boat. She shifted a bit to make herself more comfortable. Well, no harder than the benches, anyway. "You might as well reconcile yourself, Lan Mandragoran. My heart belongs to you, and you've admitted yours belongs to me. You belong to me, and I will not let you go. You will be my Warder, and my husband, and for a very long time. I will not let you die. Do you understand that? I can be as stubborn as I have to be."

"aɪ hædnt noʊɾəst," hi sɛd, ən əɹ aɪz nɛɹoʊd. hɪz toʊn saʊndəɾ ɑfli . . . dʒɹaɪ.

"I hadn't noticed," he said, and her eyes narrowed. His tone sounded awfully . . . dry.

"æz lɔŋ əz jə də naʊ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. twɪstɪŋ əɹ nɛk, ʃi pɪɹd θɹu ðə pɪɹswɝk ɪn ðə hʌl bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðən kɹeɪn ɝaʊn tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə kɑɹvɪŋ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kæbən. lɔŋ stoʊn dɑks θɹʌstɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə stoʊn ki pæs baɪ; ɔl ʃi kəd si əhɛd wɝ mɔɹ dɑks, ən ðə sɪɾi ɡlimɪŋ waɪɾ ɪn ði æftɝnun sʌn. "wɛɹ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ?" ʃi mʌɾɝd.

"As long as you do now," she said firmly. Twisting her neck, she peered through the piercework in the hull behind him, then craned around to peer through the carving at the front of the cabin. Long stone docks thrusting out from the stone quay passed by; all she could see ahead were more docks, and the city gleaming white in the afternoon sun. "Where are we going?" she muttered.

"aɪ toʊld əm tə pʊɾ əs əʃɔɹ əz sun əz aɪ hæd jə əbɔɹd," læn sɛd. "ɪt sim bɛs tə ɡɛɾ ɔf ðə ɹɪvɝ əz fæst əz pɑsəbəl."

"I told them to put us ashore as soon as I had you aboard," Lan said. "It seemed best to get off the river as fast as possible."

"ju . . . ?" ʃi klæmpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌt. hi hæd nɑt noʊn wɛɹ ʃi wɑz hɛɾəd əɹ waɪ; hi hæd dʌn ðə bɛst i kəd wɪð wʌɾ i dɪd noʊ. ən i hæd seɪvd əɹ laɪf. "aɪ kænt ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə sɪɾi jɛt, læn." klɪɹɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊt, ʃi tʃeɪnʒd əɹ toʊn. haʊɛvɝ dʒɛntəl ʃi hæd tə bi wɪð hɪm, ðət mʌtʃ sɝəp wəd meɪk əɹ sɪk ʌp ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn. "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ tə ðə si foʊk ʃɪps, tə wɪndʒɹʌnɝ" mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ; laɪt, bʌt nɑt tu laɪt, ən fɝm.

"You . . . ?" She clamped her teeth shut. He had not known where she was headed or why; he had done the best he could with what he did know. And he had saved her life. "I can't go back to the city yet, Lan." Clearing her throat, she changed her tone. However gentle she had to be with him, that much syrup would make her sick up all over again. "I have to go to the Sea Folk ships, to Windrunner" Much better; light, but not too light, and firm.

"nɪneɪiv, aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn jəɹ boʊt. aɪ sɔ wʌt hæpənd. jə wɝ fɪfti peɪsɪz əhɛɾ ə mi, ən ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz bɪhaɪnd, sɪŋkɪŋ. ɪt hæd tə bi bɑlfaɪɝ." hi dɪd nɑt nid tə seɪ mɔɹ; ʃi sɛɾ ɪt fəɹ hɪm, ən wɪð mɔɹ nɑlədʒ ðən i hæd.

"Nynaeve, I was right behind your boat. I saw what happened. You were fifty paces ahead of me, and then fifty paces behind, sinking. It had to be balefire." He did not need to say more; she said it for him, and with more knowledge than he had.

"mɑɡiɾin," ʃi bɹiðd. oʊ, ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ənʌðɝ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, əɹ wʌn ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ pɝhæps, bʌt ʃi nu. wɛl, ʃi hæd biɾən mɑɡiɾin nɑt wʌns, bʌt twaɪs. ʃi kəd də soʊ ə θɝd taɪm, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi. hɝ feɪs mʌs nɑɾ əv ʃɛɹɾ əɹ kɑnfəɾəns.

"Moghedien," she breathed. Oh, it could have been another of the Forsaken, or one of the Black Ajah perhaps, but she knew. Well, she had beaten Moghedien not once, but twice. She could do so a third time, if necessary. Her face must not have shared her confidence.

"doʊn bi əfɹeɪd," læn sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ tʃik. "doʊn ɛvɝ bi əfɹeɪd waɪl aɪm nɪɹ. ɪf juv tə feɪs mɑɡiɾin, əl meɪk ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə tʃænəl. aɪ sim tə hæv səm tælən ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən."

"Don't be afraid," Lan said, touching her cheek. "Don't ever be afraid while I'm near. If you have to face Moghedien, I'll make sure you are angry enough to channel. I seem to have some talent in that direction."

"jul nɛvɝ meɪk mi æŋɡɹi əɡɛn," ʃi bɪɡæn, ən stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm waɪd-aɪd. "aɪm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi," ʃi sɛd sloʊli.

"You'll never make me angry again," she began, and stopped, staring at him wide-eyed. "I'm not angry," she said slowly.

"nɑt naʊ, bʌt wən jə nid tə bi - "

"Not now, but when you need to be - "

"aɪm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi," ʃi læft. ʃi kɪkt əɹ fiɾ ɪn dɪlaɪt, ən paʊndɪɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, læfɪŋ, seɪaɪdɑɹ fɪl hɝ, nɑt dʒʌst wɪð laɪf ən dʒɔɪ, bʌt ðɪs taɪm, wɪð ɑ. wɪð fɛðɝi floʊz ʌv ɛɹ, ʃi stʃɹoʊkt ɪz tʃiks. "aɪ æm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi, læn," ʃi wɪspɝd.

"I'm not angry," she laughed. She kicked her feet in delight, and pounded her fists on his chest, laughing, Saidar filled her, not just with life and joy, but this time, with awe. With feathery flows of Air, she stroked his cheeks. "I am not angry, Lan," she whispered.

"jɔɹ blɑk ɪz ɡɔn." hi ɡɹɪnd, ʃɛɹɪŋ əɹ dɪlaɪt, bʌt ðə ɡɹɪn pʊt noʊ wɔɹmθ ɪndə hɪz aɪz.

"Your block is gone." He grinned, sharing her delight, but the grin put no warmth into his eyes.

əl teɪk kɛɹ ə ju, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, ʃi pɹɑməst saɪlənli. əl nɑt lɛt jə daɪ. linɪŋ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ʃi θɔɾ ə kɪsɪŋ hɪm, ən ivən. . . . jə ɑɹ nɑt keɪl kɑplɪn, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf fɝmli.

I will take care of you, Lan Mandragoran, she promised silently. I will not let you die. Leaning on his chest, she thought of kissing him, and even. . . . You are not Calle Coplin, she told herself firmly.

ə sʌɾən, hɔɹəbəl θɔt stʃɹʌk hɝ. ɔl ðə mɔɹ hɔɹəbəl kəz ɪt hæd nɑt kʌm ɝliɝ. "ðə boʊtmən?" ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "maɪ bɑɾiɡɑɹdz?" wɝdləsli, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən ʃi saɪd. bɑɾiɡɑɹdz. laɪt, ðeɪ hæd niɾəd əɹ pɹətɛkʃən, nɑt ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd. fɔɹ mɔɹ dɛθs tə leɪ ət mɑɡiɾinz fit. fɔɹ ɑn tɑp ə θaʊzənz, bʌt ðiz wɝ pɝsənəl, əz fɑɹ ʃi wɑz kənsɝnd. wɛl, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə sɛɾəl mɑɡiɾin ðɪs moʊmənt.

A sudden, horrible thought struck her. All the more horrible because it had not come earlier. "The boatmen?" she said quietly. "My bodyguards?" Wordlessly, he shook his head, and she sighed. Bodyguards. Light, they had needed her protection, not the other way around. Four more deaths to lay at Moghedien's feet. Four on top of thousands, but these were personal, as far she was concerned. Well, she was not about to settle Moghedien this moment.

ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɝ fit, ʃi bɪɡæn siɪŋ wʌt ʃi kəd də əbaʊɾ əɹ kloʊðz. "læn, wɪl jə tɝn ðə boʊtmən ɝaʊnd? tɛl əm tə ɹoʊ fəɹ ɔl ðeɪ hæv." əz ɪt wɑz, ʃi wəd nɑt si ðə pæləs əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl. "æn faɪn aʊɾ ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm əz sətʃ ə θɪŋ əz ə koʊm." ʃi kəd nɑt feɪs nɛstə laɪk ðɪs.

Getting to her feet, she began seeing what she could do about her clothes. "Lan, will you turn the boatmen around? Tell them to row for all they have." As it was, she would not see the palace again before nightfall. "And find out if one of them has such a thing as a comb." She could not face Nesta like this.

hi pɪkt ʌp ɪz koʊɾ ən sɔɹɾ ən ɡeɪv əɹ ə baʊ. "æz jə kəmænd, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

He picked up his coat and sword and gave her a bow. "As you command, Aes Sedai."

pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps, ʃi wɑtʃt ðə dɔɹ kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɪm. læfɪŋ ət hɝ, wɑz hi? ʃi wəd weɪdʒɝ sʌmwʌn ɑn wɪndʒɹʌnɝ kəd pɝfɔɹm ə mɛɹɪdʒ. ən fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd sin ə ðə si foʊk, ʃi wəd weɪdʒɝ læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən wəd faɪn hɪmsɛlf pɹɑməsɪŋ tə də əz i wɑz toʊld. ðeɪ wəd si hu læf ðɛn.

Pursing her lips, she watched the door close behind him. Laughing at her, was he? She would wager someone on Windrunner could perform a marriage. And from what she had seen of the Sea Folk, she would wager Lan Mandragoran would find himself promising to do as he was told. They would see who laughed then.

lɝtʃɪŋ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ, ðə boʊt bɪɡæn tə swɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ən əɹ stʌmək lɝtʃt wɪð ɪt.

Lurching and rolling, the boat began to swing around, and her stomach lurched with it.

"oʊ, laɪt!" ʃi ɡɹoʊnd, sɪŋkɪŋ ɑntu ðə bɛntʃ. waɪ kəd ʃi nɑɾ əv lɔs ðəɾ əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ blɑk? hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, əwɛɹ ʌv ɛvɹi tʌtʃ ə ði ɛɹ ɑn əɹ skɪn, oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt wɝs. lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ dɪd nɑt hɛlp. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə sɪk ʌp əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz gɑnə meɪk læn hɝz wʌns ən fəɹ ɔl. ðɪs wɑz gɑnə bi ə wʌndɝfəl deɪ jɛt. ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd stɑp filɪŋ ðət stɔɹm ɑn ðə weɪ.

"Oh, Light!" she groaned, sinking onto the bench. Why could she not have lost that along with her block? Holding saidar, aware of every touch of the air on her skin, only made it worse. Letting go did not help. She was not going to sick up again. She was going to make Lan hers once and for all. This was going to be a wonderful day yet. If only she could stop feeling that storm on the way.

ðə sʌn sæt lʊɹɪdli dʒʌst əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps baɪ ðə taɪm ɪleɪn ɹæpt ɑn ðə dɔɹ wɪð əɹ nʌkəlz. ɹɛvəlɝz dænst ən kəvɔɹɾɪd ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪhaɪn hɝ, fɪlɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð læftɝ ən sɔŋ ən ðə sɛn ə pɝfjum. aɪdli, ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd hæɾ ə tʃæns ɹɪli tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðə fɛstəvəl. ə kɑstum laɪk bɝdʒɪts maɪɾ əv bɪn fʌn. əɹ ivən wʌn laɪk ðət ʃi hæd sin ɑn ðə leɪɾi ɹaɪzɛl, wʌn ə taɪlɪnz ətɛndəns, fɝs θɪŋ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. əz lɔŋ əz ʃi cʊɾə kɛpt əɹ mæsk ɑn. ʃi ɹæpt əɡɛn, hɑɹɾɝ.

The sun sat luridly just above the rooftops by the time Elayne rapped on the door with her knuckles. Revelers danced and cavorted in the street behind her, filling the air with laughter and song and the scent of perfume. Idly, she wished she had had a chance really to enjoy the festival. A costume like Birgitte's might have been fun. Or even one like that she had seen on the Lady Riselle, one of Tylin's attendants, first thing this morning. As long as she could have kept her mask on. She rapped again, harder.

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd, skwɛɹ-dʒɔd meɪɾ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, fjʊɹi sʌɾənli peɪntɪŋ əɹ feɪs wən ɪleɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ ɡɹin mæsk. "ju! wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ bæk - ?" fjʊɹi tɝn tə ɡæsli pælnəs əz mɛɝɪlɪl ɹimuvd əɹ mæsk, ən æɾɪliz ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd ðə seɪm. ðə wʊmən dʒɝkt wɪð itʃ eɪdʒləs feɪs ɹɪvild, ən ivən wɪð sɝaɪðəz. baɪ ðət taɪm, meɪbi ʃi sɔ wʌt ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə si.

The gray-haired, square-jawed maid opened the door, fury suddenly painting her face when Elayne lowered her green mask. "You! What are you doing back - ?" Fury turned to ghastly paleness as Merilille removed her mask, and Adeleas and the others did the same. The woman jerked with each ageless face revealed, and even with Sareitha's. By that time, maybe she saw what she expected to see.

wɪð ə sʌɾən kɹaɪ, ðə meɪd tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt, bʌt bɝdʒɪt dɑɹɾɪd pæst ɪleɪn, hɝ fɛðɝd ʃoʊldɝ nɑkɪŋ ɪt bæk oʊpən. ðə sɝvən stæɡɝɾ ə fju stɛps, ðən ɡæðɝd hɝsɛlf, bʌt wɛðɝ tə ɹʌn əɹ ʃaʊt, bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðəɹ bɪfɹtaɪm, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə ʃoʊldɝ.

With a sudden cry, the maid tried to push the door shut, but Birgitte darted past Elayne, her feathered shoulder knocking it back open. The servant staggered a few steps, then gathered herself, but whether to run or shout, Birgitte was there beforetime, gripping her arm just below the shoulder.

"izi," bɝdʒɪt sɛd fɝmli. "wi doʊnt wɑn ɛni fʌs əɹ ʃaʊɾɪŋ, naʊ də wi?" ɪt dɪd sim ʃi wɑz oʊnli hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʊmənz ɑɹm, ɔlmoʊst səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ, bʌt ðə meɪd stʊd vɛɹi stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndiɾ ən vɛɹi stɪl. stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ əɾ əɹ kæptɝz plum-kɹɛstəd mæsk, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli.

"Easy," Birgitte said firmly. "We don't want any fuss or shouting, now do we?" It did seem she was only holding the woman's arm, almost supporting her, but the maid stood very straight indeed and very still. Staring wide-eyed at her captor's plume-crested mask, she shook her head slowly.

"wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?" ɪleɪn æskt, əz ɛvɹiwʌn kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə kloʊzɪŋ dɔɹ mjuɾɪd ðə nɔɪz fɹəm aʊtsaɪd. ðə meɪdz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm wʌn feɪs tə ðə nɛkst əz ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt bɛɹ tə ɡeɪz əɾ ɛni wʌn fəɹ lɔŋ.

"What is your name?" Elayne asked, as everyone crowded into the entry hall behind her. The closing door muted the noise from outside. The maid's eyes darted from one face to the next as if she could not bear to gaze at any one for long.

"si-si-sidɔɹə."

"C-c-cedora."

"ju wɪl teɪk əs tə ɹin, sidɔɹə." ðɪs taɪm, sidɔɹə nɑɾəd; ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt tə kɹaɪ.

"You will take us to Reanne, Cedora." This time, Cedora nodded; she looked about to cry.

sidɔɹə stɪfli lɛd ðə weɪ əpstɛɹz wɪð bɝdʒɪt stɪl hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm. ɪleɪn kənsɪɾɝd tɛlɪŋ əɹ tə ɹilis ðə wʊmən, bʌt ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd wɑz ə ʃaʊɾəd əlɑɹm ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə haʊs fliɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz. ðət wɑz waɪ bɝdʒɪt juz mʌsəl ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf tʃænəlɪŋ. ʃi θɔt sidɔɹə wɑz mɔɹ fɹaɪɾənd ðən hɝt, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz tə bi ət list ə lɪɾəl fɹaɪɾənd ðɪs ivnɪŋ.

Cedora stiffly led the way upstairs with Birgitte still holding her arm. Elayne considered telling her to release the woman, but the last thing she wanted was a shouted alarm and everyone in the house fleeing in all directions. That was why Birgitte used muscle instead of Elayne herself channeling. She thought Cedora was more frightened than hurt, and everybody was to be at least a little frightened this evening.

"ɪn tieɪtʃ-ðɛɹ," sidɔɹə sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ tə ə ɹɛd dɔɹ. ðə dɔɹ tə ðə ɹum wɛɹ nɪneɪiv ən ʃi hæd hæd ðəɾ ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪntɝvju. ʃi oʊpən ɪɾ ən wɛn ɪn.

"In th-there," Cedora said, nodding to a red door. The door to the room where Nynaeve and she had had that unfortunate interview. She opened it and went in.

ɹin wɑz ðɛɹ, siɾəd wɪð ðə faɪɝpleɪs kɑɹvd wɪð ðə θɝtin sɪnz əɾ əɹ bæk, ən soʊ wɝ ənʌðɝ dʌzən wɪmən ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ ɔl ə ðə tʃɛɹz əɡɛns ðə peɪl ɡɹin wɔlz, swɛɾɪŋ wɪð ðə wɪndoʊz taɪɾ ən kɝɾənz dʒɹɔn. moʊst wɔɹ ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛsəz, ðoʊ oʊnli wʌn pəzɛs ði ɑləv skɪn; moʊs hæd laɪnz ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ən ət list ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ; ən ɛvɹi læst wʊmən ə ðɛm kəd tʃænəl tə wʌn dɪɡɹi əɹ ənʌðɝ. sɛvən wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt. ʃi saɪɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. wən nɪneɪiv wɑz ɹaɪt, ʃi lɛt jə noʊ ɪɾ əntɪl jə wɑntəd tə skɹim.

Reanne was there, seated with the fireplace carved with the Thirteen Sins at her back, and so were another dozen women Elayne had never seen before, occupying all of the chairs against the pale green walls, sweating with the windows tight and curtains drawn. Most wore Ebou Dari dresses, though only one possessed the olive skin; most had lines on their faces and at least a touch of gray; and every last woman of them could channel to one degree or another. Seven wore the red belt. She sighed in spite of herself. When Nynaeve was right, she let you know it until you wanted to scream.

ɹin baʊndəd tə hɝ fiɾ ɪn ðə seɪm ɹɛd-feɪs fjʊɹi sidɔɹə hæd ʃoʊn, ən əɹ fɝst wɝdz wɝ ɔlmoʊst aɪdɛntɪkəl əz wɛl. "ju! haʊ dɛɹ jə ʃoʊ jəɹ feɪs . . . ?" wɝdz ən fjʊɹi dʒɹeɪn əweɪ təɡɛðɝ fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən, tu, əz mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɛntɝɾ ɑn ɪleɪnz hilz. ə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ɹɛd bɛlt ən plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklaɪn meɪɾ ə feɪn saʊn əz əɹ aɪz ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn əɹ hɛɾ ən ʃi slɪd boʊnləsli fɹəm əɹ ɹɛd tʃɛɹ. noʊ wʌn muv tə hɛlp hɝ. noʊ wʌn ivən ɡlænst ət bɝdʒɪɾ əz ʃi ɛskɔɹɾɪd sidɔɹə tə ə kɔɹnɝ ən plæntəɾ əɹ ðɛɹ. noʊ wʌn sim tə bɹið. ɪleɪn fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪt dɪzaɪɝ tə ʃaʊt "bu" dʒʌs tə si wʌt wəd hæpən.

Reanne bounded to her feet in the same red-faced fury Cedora had shown, and her first words were almost identical as well. "You! How dare you show your face . . . ?" Words and fury drained away together for the same reason, too, as Merilille and the others entered on Elayne's heels. A yellow-haired woman in red belt and plunging neckline made a faint sound as her eyes rolled up in her head and she slid bonelessly from her red chair. No one moved to help her. No one even glanced at Birgitte as she escorted Cedora to a corner and planted her there. No one seemed to breathe. Elayne felt a great desire to shout "boo" just to see what would happen.

ɹin sweɪd, waɪt-feɪst, ən vɪzəbli tʃɹaɪd tə ɡæðɝ hɝsɛlf wɪð slaɪt səksɛs. ɪt tʊk əɹ oʊnli ə moʊmən tə skæn ðə faɪv kul-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪn ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ ən dɪsaɪɾ u mʌs bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. ʃi wɑbəld əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹtaɪlz tə mɛɝɪlɪl ən sæŋk tə hɝ niz, hɛd baʊd. "fɝɡɪv ʌs, ɛɛs sədaɪ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz wɝʃəpfəl, ən oʊnli ə lɪɾəl stɛɾiɝ ðən əɹ niz hæd bɪn. ʃi bæbəld, ɪn fækt. "wi ɑɹ oʊnli ə fju fɹɛnz. wɪv dʌn nʌθɪŋ, sɝɾənli nʌθɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ dɪskɹɛɾət tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ swɛɹ ðæt, wʌtɛvɝ ðɪs ɡɝl əz toʊl ju. wi wʊɾə toʊl jə ʌv hɝ, bʌt wi wɝ əfɹeɪd. wi oʊnli mit tə tɔk. ʃiz ə fɹɛnd, ɛɛs sədaɪ. dɪd jə kætʃ hɝ, tu? aɪ kən dɪskɹaɪb əɹ fəɹ ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ. wʌtɛvɝ jə wɪʃ, wɪl du. aɪ swɛɹ, wi - "

Reanne swayed, white-faced, and visibly tried to gather herself with slight success. It took her only a moment to scan the five cool-faced Aes Sedai lined up before the door and decide who must be in charge. She wobbled across the floortiles to Merilille and sank to her knees, head bowed. "Forgive us, Aes Sedai." Her voice was worshipful, and only a little steadier than her knees had been. She babbled, in fact. "We are only a few friends. We have done nothing, certainly nothing to bring discredit to Aes Sedai. I swear that, whatever this girl has told you. We would have told you of her, but we were afraid. We only meet to talk. She has a friend, Aes Sedai. Did you catch her, too? I can describe her for you, Aes Sedai. Whatever you wish, we will do. I swear, we - "

mɛɝɪlɪl klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt laʊdli. "jɔɹ neɪm ɪz ɹin kɔɹli, aɪ bɪliv?" ɹin flɪntʃt ən wɪspɝd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz, stɪl piɹɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹ ət ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝz fit. "aɪ fɪɹ jə mʌst ædʒɹɛs jɝsɛlf tə ɪleɪn sədaɪ, ɹin."

Merilille cleared her throat loudly. "Your name is Reanne Corly, I believe?" Reanne flinched and whispered that it was, still peering at the floor at the Gray sister's feet. "I fear you must address yourself to Elayne Sedai, Reanne."

ɹinz hɛd dʒɝkt ʌp ɪn ə moʊst sæɾəsfæktʃɹi weɪ. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət mɛɝɪlɪl, ðən baɪ sloʊ ɪŋkɹəməns tɝn aɪz əz bɪɡ əz əɹ feɪs tə ɪleɪn. ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps. ʃi dʒɹu ə dip, lɔŋ bɹɛθ. twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊn ɑn əɹ niz tə feɪs ɪleɪn, ʃi baʊɾ əɹ hɛd wʌns mɔɹ. "aɪ bɛɡ jəɹ fɝɡɪvnəs, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd liɾənli. "aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ. aɪ kəd nɑt - " ənʌðɝ lɔŋ, hoʊpləs bɹɛθ. "wʌtɛvɝ pʌnɪʃmən jə dɪkɹi, wi æksɛp hʌmbli, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt pliz, aɪ bɛɡ jə tə bɪliv ðət - "

Reanne's head jerked up in a most satisfactory way. She stared at Merilille, then by slow increments turned eyes as big as her face to Elayne. She licked her lips. She drew a deep, long breath. Twisting around on her knees to face Elayne, she bowed her head once more. "I beg your forgiveness, Aes Sedai," she said leadenly. "I did not know. I could not - " Another long, hopeless breath. "Whatever punishment you decree, we accept humbly, of course, but please, I beg you to believe that - "

"oʊ, stæn ʌp," ɪleɪn bɹoʊk ɪn ɪmpeɪʃənli. ʃi hæd wɑntəd tə meɪk ðɪs wʊmən æknɑlɪdʒ əɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi hæd mɛɝɪlɪl əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, bʌt ðə ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ sɪkən hɝ. "ðæts ɹaɪt. stæn ɑn jəɹ fit." ʃi weɪɾəd əntɪl ɹin kəmplaɪd, ðən wɔkt oʊvɝ ən sæɾ ɪn ðə wʊmənz tʃɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ kɹɪŋɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd noʊ daʊts u wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. "du jə stɪl dɪnaɪ nɑlədʒ ə ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, ɹin?"

"Oh, stand up," Elayne broke in impatiently. She had wanted to make this woman acknowledge her as much as she had Merilille or any of the others, but the groveling sickened her. "That's right. Stand on your feet." She waited until Reanne complied, then walked over and sat in the woman's chair. There was no need for cringing, but she wanted no doubts who was in charge. "Do you still deny knowledge of the Bowl of the Winds, Reanne?"

ɹin spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz. "ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd ɡaɪlləsli, "nʌn ʌv əs wəɾ ɛvɝ juz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, mʌtʃ lɛs ən æŋɡɹil əɹ sɑŋɡɹil." ɡaɪlləs, ən wɛɹi əz ə fɑks ɪn ə sɪɾi. "aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, wi meɪk noʊ pɹitɛns ə biɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ivən nɪɹ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. wəɹ dʒʌs ðiz fju fɹɛnz jə si, taɪd təɡɛðɝ baɪ wʌns hævɪŋ bɪn əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl."

Reanne spread her hands. "Aes Sedai," she said guilelessly, "none of us would ever use a ter'angreal, much less an angreal or sa'angreal." Guileless, and wary as a fox in a city. "I assure you, we make no pretense of being anything even near to Aes Sedai. We are just these few friends you see, tied together by once having been allowed to enter the White Tower. That is all."

"dʒʌs ðiz fju fɹɛnz," ɪleɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli oʊvɝ stipəl fɪŋɡɝz. "ænd ɡæɹiniə, ʌv kɔɹs. ən bɛɹaʊɪn, ən dɛɹiz, ən æləz."

"Just these few friends," Elayne said dryly over steepled fingers. "And Garenia, of course. And Berowin, and Derys, and Alise."

"jɛs," ɹin sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "æn ðɛm."

"Yes," Reanne said reluctantly. "And them."

ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd vɛɹi sloʊli. "ɹin, ðə waɪt taʊɝ noʊz əbaʊt jəɹ kɪn. ðə taʊɝ əz ɔlweɪz noʊn." ə dɑɹk wʊmən wɪð ə tɛɹən lʊk tə hɝ, ðoʊ wɛɹɪŋ ə blu-ænd-waɪt sɪlk vɛst wɪð ðə sɪdʒəl ə ðə ɡoʊldsmɪθs ɡɪld, ɡeɪv ə stʃɹæŋɡəl skɹim ən pɹɛs boʊθ plʌmp hænz tə hɝ maʊð. ə lin, ɡɹeɪɪŋ sɑldəiən wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛd bɛl kɹʌmpəld wɪð ə saɪ tə dʒɔɪn ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ən tu mɔɹ sweɪɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt.

Elayne shook her head very slowly. "Reanne, the White Tower knows about your Kin. The Tower has always known." A dark woman with a Tairen look to her, though wearing a blue-and-white silk vest with the sigil of the goldsmith's guild, gave a strangled scream and pressed both plump hands to her mouth. A lean, graying Saldaean wearing the red belt crumpled with a sigh to join the yellow-haired woman on the floor, and two more swayed as if they might.

fəɹ əɹ pɑɹt, ɹin lʊk tə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ fəɹ kɑnfɝmeɪʃən, ən sɔ ɪt, əz ʃi θɔt. mɛɝɪlɪlz feɪs wɑz mɔɹ aɪsi ðən sɝin, ən sɝaɪðə ɡɹɪməs bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp hɝsɛlf. vændin ən kɛɝin wɝ boʊθ taɪt-lɪpt, ən ivən æɾɪliz simd ɪnkluɾəd, tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɛd ðɪs weɪ ən ðət tə stʌɾi ðə wɪmən əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz əz ʃi maɪɾ əv ɪnsɛks pɹiviəsli ənnoʊn tə hɝ. ʌv kɔɹs, wʌt ɹin sɔ ən wʌt wɑz wɝ nɑt ðə seɪm. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl æksɛptɪɾ ɪleɪnz dɪsɪʒən, bʌt noʊ əmaʊn ʌv "jɛs, ɪleɪn . . ." kəd meɪk əm laɪk ɪt. ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ tu aʊɝz əɡoʊ ɪf nɑt fəɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv "bʌt, ɪleɪn . . ." tɔst ɪn. səmtaɪmz liɾɪŋ mɛn hɝɾɪŋ.

For her part, Reanne looked to the sisters in front of the door for confirmation, and saw it, as she thought. Merilille's face was more icy than serene, and Sareitha grimaced before she could stop herself. Vandene and Careane were both tight-lipped, and even Adeleas seemed included, turning her head this way and that to study the women along the walls as she might have insects previously unknown to her. Of course, what Reanne saw and what was were not the same. They had all accepted Elayne's decision, but no amount of "Yes, Elayne . . ." could make them like it. They would have been here two hours ago if not for a great deal of "But, Elayne . . ." tossed in. Sometimes leading meant herding.

ɹin dɪd nɑt feɪnt, bʌt fɪɹ fɪld əɹ feɪs, ən ʃi ɹeɪz pliɾɪŋ hænz. "du jə min tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə kɪn? waɪ naʊ, æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ? wʌɾ əv wi dʌn ðət jə ʃəd kʌm daʊn ɑn əs naʊ?"

Reanne did not faint, but fear filled her face, and she raised pleading hands. "Do you mean to destroy the Kin? Why now, after so long? What have we done that you should come down on us now?"

"noʊ wʌn wɪl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ju," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. "kɛɝin, sɪns noʊbɑdi ɛls ɪz gɑnə hɛlp ðoʊz tu, wəd ju, pliz?" dʒʌmps ən blʌʃəz ɹæn ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, ən bɪfɔɹ kɛɝin kəd muv, tu wɪmən wɝ kɹaʊtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ itʃ wʌn u hæd feɪntɪd, lɪftɪŋ əɹ ʌp ən weɪvɪŋ smɛlɪŋ sɔls ʌndɝ əɹ noʊz. "ði æmɪɝlɪn sit dɪzaɪɝz ɛvɹi wʊmən u kən tʃænəl tə bi kənɛktəd tə ðə taʊɝ," ɪleɪn wɛn ɑn. "ði ɔfɝ ɪz oʊpən tə ɛni ʌv ðə kɪn u wɪʃ tə æksɛpt."

"No one will destroy you," Elayne told her. "Careane, since nobody else is going to help those two, would you, please?" Jumps and blushes ran around the room, and before Careane could move, two women were crouching over each one who had fainted, lifting her up and waving smelling salts under her nose. "The Amyrlin Seat desires every woman who can channel to be connected to the Tower," Elayne went on. "The offer is open to any of the Kin who wish to accept."

hæd ʃi woʊvən floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv fɹoʊzən əm mɔɹ stɪl. hæd ʃi skwiz ðoʊz floʊz taɪt, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv pɹədus mɔɹ bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən u hæd feɪntɪd sʌɾənli ɡæspt ən kɔft, pʊʃɪŋ əweɪ ðə taɪni vaɪəl ə sɔls ðət hæd bɪn hɛl stɪl tu lɔŋ. ðət bɹoʊk ɛvɹiwʌn fɹi ɪn ə dɛljudʒ ə vɔɪsəz.

Had she woven flows of Air around every one of those women, she could not have frozen them more still. Had she squeezed those flows tight, she could not have produced more bulging eyes. One of the women who had fainted suddenly gasped and coughed, pushing away the tiny vial of salts that had been held still too long. That broke everyone free in a deluge of voices.

"wi kən bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ æftɝ ɔl?" ðə tɛɹən ɪn ðə ɡoʊldsmɪθs vɛst æskt ɪksaɪɾədli, ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðəɾ ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən wɪð ə ɹɛd bɛlt ət lis twaɪs əz lɔŋ əz ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz bɝst aʊt wɪð, "ðeɪ wɪl lɛɾ əs lɝn? ðəl titʃ əs əɡɛn?" ə dɛljudʒ ə peɪnfəli iɡɝ vɔɪsəz. "wi kən ɹɪli . . . ?" ən "ðeɪ wɪl lɛɾ əs . . . ?" fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd.

"We can become Aes Sedai after all?" the Tairen in the goldsmith's vest asked excitedly, at the same time that a round-faced woman with a red belt at least twice as long as anyone else's burst out with, "They will let us learn? They will teach us again?" A deluge of painfully eager voices. "We can really . . . ?" and "They will let us . . . ?" from every side.

ɹin ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn əm fɪɹsli. "ɪvɑɹə, sumeɪkoʊ, ɔl ə ju, jə fɝɡɛt jʊɹsɛlvz! jə spik ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ! jə spik ɪn - fɹʌn ʌv - ɛɛs sədaɪ." ʃi pæst ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ feɪs, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. ən ɪmbɛɹəst saɪləns dɪsɛndəd. aɪz fɛl ən blʌʃəz ɹoʊz. wɪð ɔl ðoʊz laɪn feɪsəz, ɔl ðət ɡɹeɪ ən waɪt hɛɹ, ɪleɪn stɪl wɑz maɪndəɾ ə nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz hævɪŋ ə pɪloʊ-faɪɾ æftɝ læs hæd tɑld wən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz wɔkt ɪn.

Reanne rounded on them fiercely. "Ivara, Sumeko, all of you, you forget yourselves! You speak in front of Aes Sedai! You speak in - front of - Aes Sedai." She passed a hand over her face, trembling. An embarrassed silence descended. Eyes fell and blushes rose. With all those lined faces, all that gray and white hair, Elayne still was minded of nothing so much as a group of novices having a pillow-fight after Last had tolled when the Mistress of Novices walked in.

hɛzɪɾəntli, ɹin lʊkt əɾ əɹ əkɹɔs əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. "wi tʃɹuli wɪl bi əlaʊd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ?" ʃi mʌmbəld ɪndə hɝ hænd.

Hesitantly, Reanne looked at her across her fingertips. "We truly will be allowed to return to the Tower?" she mumbled into her hand.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. "ðoʊz u kən lɝn tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl əv ðə tʃæns, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi ə pleɪs fəɹ ɔl. fəɹ ɛni wʊmən u tʃænəlz."

Elayne nodded. "Those who can learn to become Aes Sedai will have the chance, and there will be a place for all. For any woman who channels."

ənʃt tɪɹz ʃoʊn ɪn ɹinz aɪz. ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ, bʌt ʃi θɔt ðə wʊmən wɪspɝd, "aɪ kən bi ɡɹin." ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə ɹʌʃ oʊvɝ ən θɹoʊ hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ.

Unshed tears shone in Reanne's eyes. Elayne was not sure, but she thought the woman whispered, "I can be Green." It was hard not to rush over and throw her arms around her.

nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃoʊɾ ɛni saɪnz ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə ɪmoʊʃən, ən mɛɝɪlɪl sɝɾənli wɑz ə stɝnɝ stʌf. "ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk ə kwɛstʃən, ɪleɪn? ɹin, haʊ mɛni . . . ʌv jəl wi bi teɪkɪŋ ɪn?" daʊtləs ðət pɔz kʌvɝɾ ə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm "haʊ mɛni waɪldɝz ən feɪljɝz."

None of the other Aes Sedai showed any signs of giving way to emotion, and Merilille certainly was of sterner stuff. "If I may ask a question, Elayne? Reanne, how many . . . of you will we be taking in?" Doubtless that pause covered a change from "how many wilders and failures."

ɪf ɹin noʊɾəst əɹ səspɛktəd, ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪɾ əɹ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. "aɪ kænɑt bɪliv ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛni hu wəd ɹəfjuz ði ɔfɝ," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "ɪt meɪ teɪk səm taɪm tə sɛnd wɝd tə ɛvɹiwʌn. wi ɹɪmeɪn spɹɛɾ aʊt, jə si, soʊ. . . ." ʃi læft, ə tʌtʃ nɝvəsli ən stɪl nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm tɪɹz. ". . . soʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt noʊɾəs ʌs. ət pɹɛzən ðəɹ ɑɹ wʌn θaʊzən sɛvən hʌnʒɹəd ən eɪɾi-θɹi neɪmz ɑn ðə ɹoʊl."

If Reanne noticed or suspected, she ignored it or did not care. "I cannot believe there are any who would refuse the offer," she said breathlessly. "It may take some time to send word to everyone. We remain spread out, you see, so. . . ." She laughed, a touch nervously and still not far from tears. ". . . so Aes Sedai would not notice us. At present there are one thousand seven hundred and eighty-three names on the roll."

moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ lɝn tə kʌvɝ ʃɑk wɪð ən aʊtwɝd ʃoʊ ʌv kɑm, ən oʊnli sɝaɪðə əlaʊɾ əɹ aɪz tə waɪɾən. ʃi ɔlsoʊ maʊð saɪlənt wɝdz, bʌɾ ɪleɪn nu hɝ wɛl ɪnʌf tə ɹiɾ əɹ lɪps. tu θaʊzənd waɪldɝz! laɪt hɛlp ʌs! ɪleɪn meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ skɝts əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ əɹ oʊn feɪs wɑz ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. laɪt hɛlp ðɛm, ɪndid.

Most Aes Sedai learned to cover shock with an outward show of calm, and only Sareitha allowed her eyes to widen. She also mouthed silent words, but Elayne knew her well enough to read her lips. Two thousand wilders! Light help us! Elayne made a great show of adjusting her skirts until she was sure her own face was under control. Light help them, indeed.

ɹin mɪsəndɝstʊd ðə saɪləns. "ju ɪkspɛktəd mɔɹ? æksəɾənts də teɪk səm ɛvɹi jɪɹ, əɹ nætʃɹəl dɛθs, əz wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ən aɪ fɪɹ ðə kɪn əv ɡɹoʊn fjuɝ ɪn ðə læs θaʊzən jɪɹz. pɝhæps wɪv bɪn tu kɔʃəs ɪn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ wɪmən wən ðeɪ liv ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt ðəɹ əz ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə fɪɹ ðət wʌn ə ðɛm maɪt ɹipɔɹt biɪŋ kwɛstʃənd, ən . . . ænd. . . ."

Reanne misunderstood the silence. "You expected more? Accidents do take some every year, or natural deaths, as with everyone else, and I fear the Kin have grown fewer in the last thousand years. Perhaps we have been too cautious in approaching women when they leave the White Tower, but there has always been the fear that one of them might report being questioned, and . . . and. . . ."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə list," ɪleɪn əʃʊɹd hɝ, meɪkɪŋ suðɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝz. dɪsəpɔɪntɪd? ʃi vɛɹi nɪɹli ɡɪɡəl hɪstɛɹɪkli. ðəɹ wɝ nɪɹli twaɪs əz mɛni kɪnswɪmən əz ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ! ɛɡwin kəd nɛvɝ seɪ ʃi hæd nɑt dʌn əɹ pɑɹt tə bɹɪŋ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl tə ðə taʊɝ. bʌɾ ɪf ðə kɪn ɹəfjuzd waɪldɝz. . . . ʃi mʌst stɪk tə ðə pɔɪnt; kɑnskɹɪptɪŋ ðə kɪn hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ɪnsɪdɛntəl. "ɹin," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli, "du jə θɪŋk pɝhæps jə maɪt hæpən tə ɹikɔl wɛɹ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ɪz, naʊ?"

"We are not disappointed in the least," Elayne assured her, making soothing gestures. Disappointed? She very nearly giggled hysterically. There were nearly twice as many Kinswomen as there were Aes Sedai! Egwene could never say she had not done her part to bring women who could channel to the Tower. But if the Kin refused wilders. . . . She must stick to the point; conscripting the Kin had only been incidental. "Reanne," she said gently, "do you think perhaps you might happen to recall where the Bowl of the Winds is, now?"

ɹin blʌʃt ə sʌnsɛt. "wiv nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ðɛm, ɪleɪn sədaɪ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ ðeɪ wɝ ɡæðɝd. aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ə stɔɹɹum sətʃ əz jə dɪskɹaɪb oʊvɝ - "

Reanne blushed a sunset. "We've never touched them, Elayne Sedai. I don't know why they were gathered. I've never heard of this Bowl of the Winds, but there is a storeroom such as you describe over - "

bɛləstɛɹz, ə wʊmən tʃænəl bɹifli. sʌmwʌn skɹimd ɪn pjʊɹəs tɛɹɝ.

Belowstairs, a woman channeled briefly. Someone screamed in purest terror.

ɪleɪn wɑz ɑn əɹ fiɾ ɪn ə flæʃ, əz wɝ ðeɪ ɔl. fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðət fɛðɝd dʒɹɛs, bɝdʒɪt pɹədust ə dæɡɝ.

Elayne was on her feet in a flash, as were they all. From somewhere in that feathered dress, Birgitte produced a dagger.

"ðæt mʌst əv bɪn dɛɹiz," ɹin sɛd. "ʃiz ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wʌn hɪɹ."

"That must have been Derys," Reanne said. "She's the only other one here."

ɪleɪn dɑɹɾɪd fɔɹwɝɾ ən kɑɾ əɹ ɑɹm əz ʃi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. "ju ɑɹənt ɡɹin jɛt," ʃi mɝmɝd, ən wɑz ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd wɪð ə lʌvli dɪmpəl smaɪl, sɝpɹaɪzd ən plizd ən dɪfəɾənt ɔl ət wʌns. "wi wɪl hændəl ðɪs, ɹin."

Elayne darted forward and caught her arm as she started for the door. "You aren't Green yet," she murmured, and was rewarded with a lovely dimpled smile, surprised and pleased and diffident all at once. "We will handle this, Reanne."

mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɝeɪd ðɛmsɛlvz tə iðɝ saɪd, ɹɛɾi tə fɑloʊ ɪleɪn aʊt, bʌt bɝdʒɪt wɑz ət ðə dɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm, ɡɹɪnɪŋ əz ʃi pʊt hæn tə lætʃ. ɪleɪn swɑloʊɾ ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ðət wɑz ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɑnɝ, soʊ ðə ɡeɪɾɪn sɛd; fɝs tə ɡoʊ ɪn, læs tə kʌm aʊt. bʌt ʃi stɪl fɪl hɝsɛlf wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɹɛɾi tə kɹʌʃ ɛniθɪŋ ðət θɹɛɾənd əɹ wɔɹɾɝ.

Merilille and the others arrayed themselves to either side, ready to follow Elayne out, but Birgitte was at the door before any of them, grinning as she put hand to latch. Elayne swallowed and said nothing. That was the Warder's honor, so the Gaidin said; first to go in, last to come out. But she still filled herself with saidar, ready to crush anything that threatened her Warder.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən bɪfɔɹ bɝdʒɪt kəd lɪf ðə lætʃ.

The door opened before Birgitte could lift the latch.

mæt sɔntɝɾ ɪn, pʊʃɪŋ ðə slɛndɝ meɪɾ ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm. "aɪ θɔt jə maɪt bi hɪɹ." hi ɡɹɪn ɪnsələnli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ dɛɹiz' ɡlɛɹz, ən wɛn ɑn, "wɛn aɪ faʊn ə blʌɾi ɡɹeɪt lɑɾ ʌv wɔɹɾɝz dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ət maɪ lis feɪvɹɪt tævɝn. aɪv dʒʌs kʌm bæk fɹəm fɑloʊɪŋ ə wʊmən tə ðə ɹæhəd. tə ðə tɑp flɔɹ ʌv ə haʊs wɪð noʊbɑdi lɪvɪŋ ɑn ɪt, tə bi pɹɪsaɪs. æftɝ ʃi lɛft, ðə flɔɹ wɑz soʊ dʌsti, aɪ kəd si ɹaɪɾ əweɪ wɪtʃ ɹum ʃid ɡɔn tə. ðɛɹz ə fleɪmɪŋ bɪɡ ɹʌstəd lɑk ɑn ðə dɔɹ, bʌɾ əl bɛɾ ə θaʊzən kɹaʊnz tə ə kɪk ɪn ðə bɑɾəm, jəɹ boʊl ɪz bɪhaɪn ɪt." dɛɹiz eɪmd ə kɪk ət hɪm, ən i pʊʃt əɹ əweɪ, pʊlɪŋ ə smɔl naɪf fɹəm ɪz bɛl tə baʊns ɑn ɪz pɑm. "wɪl wʌn ə jə tɛl ðɪs waɪldkæt wɑtʃdɔɡ huz saɪɾ aɪm ɑn? wɪmən wɪð naɪvz meɪk mi ənizi, ðiz deɪz."

Mat sauntered in, pushing the slender maid Elayne remembered ahead of him. "I thought you might be here." He grinned insolently, ignoring Derys' glares, and went on, "When I found a bloody great lot of Warders drinking at my least favorite tavern. I've just come back from following a woman to the Rahad. To the top floor of a house with nobody living on it, to be precise. After she left, the floor was so dusty, I could see right away which room she'd gone to. There's a flaming big rusted lock on the door, but I'll bet a thousand crowns to a kick in the bottom, your Bowl is behind it." Derys aimed a kick at him, and he pushed her away, pulling a small knife from his belt to bounce on his palm. "Will one of you tell this wildcat watchdog whose side I'm on? Women with knives make me uneasy, these days."

"wi ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ɔl əbaʊt ðæt, mæt," ɪleɪn sɛd. wɛl, ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒʌst əbaʊt tə lɝn ɔl əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən ðə stʌn lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs wɑz pɹaɪsləs. ʃi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm bɝdʒɪt. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪzd əɾ əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən, bʌt ðət lɪɾəl nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃən ɪn ðə bæk ʌv ɪleɪnz hɛd ɹeɪɾieɪtəd dɪsəpɹuvəl. eɪvinhə pɹɑbli wəd nɑt θɪŋk mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt, iðɝ. oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ wɑz wʌn ə ðə moʊs dɪfəkəl θɪŋz ɪleɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ dʌn. "aɪ mʌs θæŋk ju, ðoʊ, mæt. ɪts ɪntaɪɝli du tə jə ðət wɪv faʊnd wʌt wi wɝ lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ." hɪz ɡeɪpɪŋ əstɑnɪʃmənt wɑz ɔlmoʊst wɝθ ði æɡəni.

"We already know all about that, Mat," Elayne said. Well, they had been just about to learn all about it, and the stunned look on his face was priceless. She felt something from Birgitte. The other woman gazed at her without any particular expression, but that little knot of emotion in the back of Elayne's head radiated disapproval. Aviendha probably would not think much of it, either. Opening her mouth was one of the most difficult things Elayne had ever done. "I must thank you, though, Mat. It is entirely due to you that we have found what we were looking for." His gaping astonishment was almost worth the agony.

hi kloʊzd ɪz maʊθ kwɪkli, ðoʊ oʊpənɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛn tə seɪ, "ðɛn lɛts haɪɝ ə boʊɾ ən fɛtʃ ðɪs blʌɾi boʊl. wɪð ɛni lʌk, wi kən liv ɛbu dɑɹ tənaɪt."

He closed his mouth quickly, though opening it again to say, "Then let's hire a boat and fetch this bloody Bowl. With any luck, we can leave Ebou Dar tonight."

"ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs, mæt. ən doʊn tɛl mi aɪm dɪminɪŋ ju. wəɹ nɑt kɹɔlɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹæhəɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən wəɹ nɑt livɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ əntɪl wɪv juz ðə boʊl."

"That is ridiculous, Mat. And don't tell me I'm demeaning you. We are not crawling about the Rahad in the dark, and we are not leaving Ebou Dar until we have used the Bowl."

hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɑɹɡju, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt dɛɹiz tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi ʌv ɪz ətɛnʃən biɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ tə tʃɹaɪ kɪkɪŋ ɪm əɡɛn. hi dɑdʒd ɝaʊn bɝdʒɪt, jɛlpɪŋ fəɹ sʌmbɑɾi tə hɛlp hɪm, waɪl ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən dɑɹɾɪd æftɝ hɪm.

He tried to argue, of course, but Derys took the opportunity of his attention being elsewhere to try kicking him again. He dodged around Birgitte, yelping for somebody to help him, while the slender woman darted after him.

"hi ɪz jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ, ɪleɪn sədaɪ?" ɹin æsk daʊtfəli.

"He is your Warder, Elayne Sedai?" Reanne asked doubtfully.

"laɪt, noʊ! bɝdʒɪɾ ɪz." ɹinz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. hævɪŋ ænsɝɾ ə kwɛstʃən, ɪleɪn æskt wʌn, ə kwɛstʃən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv bɹɔt hɝsɛlf tə æsk ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ. "ɹin, ɪf jə doʊn maɪn tɛlɪŋ mi, haʊ oʊld ɑɹ ju?"

"Light, no! Birgitte is." Reanne's mouth fell open. Having answered a question, Elayne asked one, a question she could not have brought herself to ask another sister. "Reanne, if you don't mind telling me, how old are you?"

ðə wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət mæt, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl dɑdʒɪŋ tə kip ə ɡɹɪnɪŋ bɝdʒɪt bɪtwin ɪm ən dɛɹiz. "maɪ nɛks neɪmɪŋ deɪ," ɹin sɛɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɑz ðə moʊst ɔɹɾənɛɹi θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld, "wɪl bi maɪ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd ən twɛlfθ."

The woman hesitated, glancing at Mat, but he was still dodging to keep a grinning Birgitte between him and Derys. "My next naming day," Reanne said as if it was the most ordinary thing in the world, "will be my four hundred and twelfth."

mɛɝɪlɪl feɪntɪd dɛɾ əweɪ.

Merilille fainted dead away.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

sil tə ðə fleɪm


Sealed to the Flame

ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən sæt ɹiɡəli ɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðə tɔl vɪnkɑɹv tʃɛɹ peɪntəd naʊ ɪn oʊnli sɪks kʌlɝz ɪnstɛɾ ə sɛvən, ə sɪks-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən ɹæn əɹ ɡeɪz ɝaʊn ðə sɝkjəlɝ hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ðə sɪɾɝz' peɪntəd tʃɛɹz hæd bɪn ɹiɝeɪnʒd əlɔŋ ðə stɛɹ-fɹʌntɪd deɪz ðəɾ ɪnsɝkəl ðə tʃeɪmbɝ bɪniθ ðə ɡɹeɪt doʊm, speɪst aʊt tə əkaʊn fəɹ oʊnli sɪks ədʒəz ɪnstɛɾ ə sɛvən naʊ, ən eɪtin sɪɾɝz stʊɾ oʊbiɾiəntli. jʌŋ ælθɹ nɛl kwaɪətli bɪsaɪd ði æmɪɝlɪn sit; hi wəd nɑt spik ənlɛs ɡɪvən liv, wɪtʃ i wəd nɑt ɹəsiv tədeɪ. tədeɪ, hi wɑz mɪɹli ənʌðɝ sɪmbəl ə hɝ paʊɝ, ən ðə twɛlv moʊs feɪvɝd sɪɾɝz ɡloʊd wɪð ðə lɪŋk ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf kəntʃɹoʊl tə kip ɪm seɪf.

Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan sat regally in the Amyrlin Seat, the tall vinecarved chair painted now in only six colors instead of seven, a six-striped stole on her shoulders, and ran her gaze around the circular Hall of the Tower. The Sitters' painted chairs had been rearranged along the stair-fronted dais that encircled the chamber beneath the great dome, spaced out to account for only six Ajahs instead of seven now, and eighteen Sitters stood obediently. Young al'Thor knelt quietly beside the Amyrlin Seat; he would not speak unless given leave, which he would not receive today. Today, he was merely another symbol of her power, and the twelve most favored Sitters glowed with the link that she herself controlled to keep him safe.

"ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs ɪz ətʃivd, mʌðɝ," ɑlviɛɝɪn sɛd mikli əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, boʊɪŋ hʌmbli əɡɛns ðə fleɪm-tɑp stæf.

"The greater consensus is achieved, Mother," Alviarin said meekly at her shoulder, bowing humbly against the Flame-topped staff.
