daʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ, bɪloʊ ðə deɪz, ʃɛɹiəm skɹimd waɪldli ən hæd tə bi ɹistʃɹeɪn baɪ ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ əɾ əɹ saɪd. ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ ʃildɪŋ əɹ snɪɹɾ ɪn kəntɛmpt. ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn klʌŋ tə ə koʊld aʊtwɝd dɪɡnəɾi, bʌt moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz ʃildɪɾ ən ɡɑɹɾəd ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɛp kwaɪətli, pɝhæps ɪn ɹɪlif ðəɾ oʊnli fɔɹ wɪmən hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ði ʌltəmət pɛnəlti, pɝhæps ɪn fɪɹ ʌv wʌɾ ɛls wɑz tə kʌm. ðə moʊst æʃən feɪsəz bɪlɔŋ tə ðə θɹi hu hæd dɛɹd sɪɾ ɪn ə ɹɛbəl hɔl fəɹ ðə naʊ-dɪzɑlv blu. ɛvɹi ɹɛbəl hæd bɪn kæst aʊt fɹəm əɹ ədʒɑ əntɪl ɪleɪɾə ɡɹæntəd pɝmɪʃən tə ɹɪkwɛst ɹiksɛptəns, bʌt ðə wʌntaɪm bluz nu ðeɪ kənfɹʌntəd dɪfəkəl jɪɹz wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə hɝ ɡʊd ɡɹeɪsɪz, jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wəd bi əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ɛni ədʒɑ əɾ ɔl. əntɪl ðɛn, ðeɪ leɪ ɪn ðə pɑm ə hɝ hænd.

Down on the floor, below the dais, Sheriam screamed wildly and had to be restrained by the Tower Guard at her side. The Red sister shielding her sneered in contempt. Romanda and Lelaine clung to a cold outward dignity, but most of the others shielded and guarded on the floor wept quietly, perhaps in relief that only four women had been given the ultimate penalty, perhaps in fear of what else was to come. The most ashen faces belonged to the three who had dared sit in a rebel Hall for the now-dissolved Blue. Every rebel had been cast out from her Ajah until Elaida granted permission to request reacceptance, but the onetime Blues knew they confronted difficult years working their way into her good graces, years before they would be allowed to enter any Ajah at all. Until then, they lay in the palm of her hand.

ʃi stʊd, ən ɪt sim ðə wʌn paʊɝ floʊɪŋ θɹu hɝ fɹəm ðə sɝkəl wɑz ə mænəfɛsteɪʃən ə hɝ paʊɝ. "ðə hɔl kənkɝz wɪð ðə wɪl ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. lɛt ɹoʊmændə bi ðə fɝs tə bi bɝtʃt." ɹoʊmændəz hɛd dʒɝkt; lɛɾ əɹ si haʊ mʌtʃ dɪɡnəɾi ʃi kəd ɹɪteɪn əntɪl əɹ stɪlɪŋ. ɪleɪɾə dʒɛstʃɝd kɝtli. "teɪk ðə pɹɪznɝz əweɪ, ən bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə fɝst ə ðə pʊɹ dɪluɾɪd sɪstɝz u fɑloʊd ðɛm. əl æksɛp ðɛɹ səbmɪʃən."

She stood, and it seemed the One Power flowing through her from the circle was a manifestation of her power. "The Hall concurs with the will of the Amyrlin Seat. Let Romanda be the first to be birched." Romanda's head jerked; let her see how much dignity she could retain until her stilling. Elaida gestured curtly. "Take the prisoners away, and bring in the first of the poor deluded sisters who followed them. I will accept their submission."

ðəɹ wɑz ə kɹaɪ əmʌŋ ðə pɹɪznɝz, ən wʌn tɔɹ fɹi fɹəm ðə ɡɑɹd ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm. ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ θɹu hɝsɛlf ɑntu ðə stɛps əɾ ɪleɪɾəz fit, hænz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt, tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks.

There was a cry among the prisoners, and one tore free from the guard gripping her arm. Egwene al'Vere threw herself onto the steps at Elaida's feet, hands outstretched, tears streaming down her cheeks.

"fɝɡɪv mi, mʌðɝ!" ðə ɡɝl wɛpt. "aɪ ɹɪpɛnt! əl səbmɪt; aɪ də səbmɪt. pliz, də nɑt stɪl mi!" bɹoʊkənli, ʃi sæɡd feɪsdaʊn, ʃoʊldɝz ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð sɑbz. "pliz, mʌðɝ! aɪ ɹɪpɛnt! aɪ du!"

"Forgive me, Mother!" the girl wept. "I repent! I will submit; I do submit. Please, do not still me!" Brokenly, she sagged facedown, shoulders shaking with sobs. "Please, Mother! I repent! I do!"

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit kən ʃoʊ mɝsi," ɪleɪɾə sɛɾ ɪɡzʌltənli. ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd tə luz ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə ən ʃɛɹiəm əz ɪɡzæmpəlz, bʌt ʃi kəd kip ðɪs ɡɝlz stʃɹɛŋkθ. ʃi wɑz ðə waɪt taʊɝ. "ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, juv ɹɪbɛld əɡɛns jəɹ æmɪɝlɪn, bʌɾ əl ʃoʊ mɝsi. jəl bi dʒɹɛst ɪn nɑvəs waɪɾ əɡɛn, əntɪl aɪ maɪsɛlf dʒʌdʒ jə ɹɛɾi tə bi ɹeɪz fɝðɝ, bʌt ðɪs vɛɹi deɪ jə ʃæl bi ðə fɝs tə teɪk ə fɔɹθ oʊθ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ʌv fiəlti ən oʊbiɾiəns tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"The Amyrlin Seat can show mercy," Elaida said exultantly. The White Tower had to lose Lelaine and Romanda and Sheriam as examples, but she could keep this girl's strength. She was the White Tower. "Egwene al'Vere, you have rebelled against your Amyrlin, but I will show mercy. You will be dressed in novice white again, until I myself judge you ready to be raised further, but this very day you shall be the first to take a Fourth Oath on the Oath Rod, of fealty and obedience to the Amyrlin Seat."

ðə pɹɪznɝz bɪɡæn fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ niz, kɹaɪɪŋ aʊt tə bi əlaʊd tə teɪk ðəɾ oʊθ, tə pɹuv ðɛɹ tʃɹu səbmɪʃən. ləleɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðə fɝst, ən niðɝ ɹoʊmændə nɔɹ ʃɛɹiəm ðə læst. ɛɡwin kɹɔld ʌp ðə stɛps tə kɪs ðə hɛm ʌv ɪleɪɾəz dʒɹɛs.

The prisoners began falling on their knees, crying out to be allowed to take that oath, to prove their true submission. Lelaine was one of the first, and neither Romanda nor Sheriam the last. Egwene crawled up the steps to kiss the hem of Elaida's dress.

"aɪ jil maɪsɛlf tə jəɹ wɪl, mʌðɝ," ʃi mɝmɝd θɹu hɝ tɪɹz. "θæŋk ju. oʊ, θæŋk ju!"

"I yield myself to your will, Mother," she murmured through her tears. "Thank you. Oh, thank you!"

ɑlviɛɝɪn sizd ɪleɪɾəz ʃoʊldɝ, ʃʊk hɝ. "weɪk ʌp, jə ful wʊmən!" ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

Alviarin seized Elaida's shoulder, shook her. "Wake up, you fool woman!" she growled.

ɪleɪɾəz aɪz pɑpt oʊpən tə ðə dɪm laɪɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl læmp hɛl baɪ ɑlviɛɝɪn, bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ bɛd wɪð ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. stɪl oʊnli hæf-əweɪk, ʃi mʌmbəld, "wʌt dɪd jə seɪ?"

Elaida's eyes popped open to the dim light of a single lamp held by Alviarin, bending over her bed with a hand on her shoulder. Still only half-awake, she mumbled, "What did you say?"

"aɪ sɛd, 'pliz weɪk ʌp, mʌðɝ,' " ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹɪplaɪd kuli. "koʊvɑɹlə bɑldin əz ɹɪtɝn fɹəm kɛɹhin."

"I said, 'Please wake up, Mother,' " Alviarin replied coolly. "Covarla Baldene has returned from Cairhien."

ɪleɪɾə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klɪɹ əweɪ ðə tæɡ ɛn ə ðə dʒɹim. "soʊ sun? aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt əm fəɹ ənʌðɝ wik ət list. koʊvɑɹlə, jə seɪ? wɛɹ ɪz ɡəlinə?" fulɪʃ kwɛstʃənz; ɑlviɛɝɪn wəd nɑt noʊ wʌt ʃi mɛnt.

Elaida shook her head, trying to clear away the tag end of the dream. "So soon? I did not expect them for another week at least. Covarla, you say? Where is Galina?" Foolish questions; Alviarin would not know what she meant.

bʌɾ ɪn ðət kul kɹɪstəlaɪn toʊn, ðə wʊmən sɛd, "ʃi bɪlivz ɡəlinə dɛɾ əɹ ə pɹɪznɝ. aɪ fɪɹ ðə nuz ɪz . . . nɑt ɡʊd."

But in that cool crystalline tone, the woman said, "She believes Galina dead or a prisoner. I fear the news is . . . not good."

wʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn ʃəɾ əɹ ʃəd nɑt noʊ ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ʌv ɪleɪɾəz hɛd. "tɛl mi," ʃi dɪmændəd, θɹoʊɪŋ ɔf ðə sɪlk ʃit, bʌɾ əz ʃi ɹoʊz ən bɛltəɾ ə sɪlk ɹoʊb oʊvɝ əɹ naɪtdʒɹɛs, ʃi hɝɾ oʊnli snætʃɪz. ə bæɾəl. hɔɹdz ʌv il wɪmən tʃænəlɪŋ. ælθɹ ɡɔn. dɪzæstɝ. dɪstʃɹæktɪdli, ʃi noʊɾəst ðəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz nitli ɡɑɹbd ɪn ə sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd waɪt dʒɹɛs, wɪð ðə kipɝz stoʊl ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ðə wʊmən hæd weɪɾəd tɪl ʃi kloʊð hɝsɛlf tə bɹɪŋ əɹ ðɪs!

What Alviarin should or should not know rushed out of Elaida's head. "Tell me," she demanded, throwing off the silk sheet, but as she rose and belted a silk robe over her nightdress, she heard only snatches. A battle. Hordes of Aiel women channeling. Al'Thor gone. Disaster. Distractedly, she noticed that Alviarin was neatly garbed in a silver-embroidered white dress, with the Keeper's stole around her neck. The woman had waited till she clothed herself to bring her this!

ðə keɪs klɑk ɪn əɹ stʌɾi sɔfli tʃaɪm sɛkən loʊ əz ʃi ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ðə smɔl aʊɝz ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ; ðə wɝs taɪm tə ɹəsiv daɪɹ nuz. koʊvɑɹlə ɹoʊz heɪstəli fɹəm wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd-kʊʃən ɑɹmtʃɛɹz, hɝ ɪmplækəbəl feɪs sæɡɪŋ wɪð wɪɹinəs ən wɝi, ən nɛl tə kɪs ɪleɪɾəz ɹɪŋ. hɝ dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs stɪl bɔɹ ðə dʌst ə tʃɹævəl, ən əɹ peɪl hɛɹ niɾəd ə bɹʌʃ, bʌt ʃi hæd dɑn ðə ʃɔl ʃi hæd wɔɹn əz lɔŋ əz ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪn əlaɪv.

The case clock in her study softly chimed Second Low as she entered the sitting room. The small hours of the morning; the worst time to receive dire news. Covarla rose hastily from one of the red-cushioned armchairs, her implacable face sagging with weariness and worry, and knelt to kiss Elaida's ring. Her dark riding dress still bore the dust of travel, and her pale hair needed a brush, but she had donned the shawl she had worn as long as Elaida had been alive.

ɪleɪɾə bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə wʊmənz lɪps tə tʌtʃ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən bɪfɔɹ pʊlɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ. "waɪ wɝ jə sɛnt?" ʃi sɛd kɝtli. snætʃɪŋ ʌp əɹ nɪɾɪŋ fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi hæd lɛft ɪɾ ɪn ə tʃɛɹ, ʃi sæɾ ən bɪɡæn tə wɝk ðə lɔŋ aɪvɝi niɾəlz. nɪɾɪŋ sɝv mɛni ʌv ðə seɪm pɝpəsəz əz fɑndəlɪŋ əɹ kɑɹvd aɪvɝi mɪniətʃɝz, ən ʃi ʃʊɹli niɾəd suðɪŋ naʊ. nɪɾɪŋ hɛlpt əɹ θɪŋk, tu. ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk. "wɛɹ ɪz keɪɾɝin?" ɪf ɡəlinə wɑz dɛd, keɪɾɝin ʃʊɾə teɪkən tʃɑɹdʒ əhɛɾ ə kɔɪɹən; ɪleɪɾə hæd meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ðət wʌns ælθɹ wɑz teɪkən, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ.

Elaida barely waited for the woman's lips to touch the Great Serpent before pulling her hand away. "Why were you sent?" she said curtly. Snatching up her knitting from where she had left it in a chair, she sat and began to work the long ivory needles. Knitting served many of the same purposes as fondling her carved ivory miniatures, and she surely needed soothing now. Knitting helped her think, too. She had to think. "Where is Katerine?" If Galina was dead, Katerine should have taken charge ahead of Coiren; Elaida had made it clear that once al'Thor was taken, the Red Ajah was in charge.

koʊvɑɹlə stʊd sloʊli, əz ɪf ənsɝɾən ʃi ʃʊd. hɝ hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl lupt oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹmz. "keɪɾɝin ɪz əmʌŋ ðə mɪsɪŋ, mʌðɝ. aɪ stæn haɪəst əmʌŋ ðoʊz hu. . . ." hɝ wɝdz tʃɹeɪld ɔf əz ɪleɪɾə stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, fɪŋɡɝz fɹoʊzən ɪn ði ækt ə pæsɪŋ wʊl oʊvɝ wʌn ə ðə niɾəlz. koʊvɑɹlə swɑloʊɾ ən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fit.

Covarla stood slowly, as if uncertain she should. Her hands tightened on the red-fringed shawl looped over her arms. "Katerine is among the missing, Mother. I stand highest among those who. . . ." Her words trailed off as Elaida stared at her, fingers frozen in the act of passing wool over one of the needles. Covarla swallowed and shifted her feet.

"haʊ mɛni, dɔɾɝ?" ɪleɪɾə æsk faɪnəli. ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv əɹ vɔɪs wɑz soʊ kɑm.

"How many, daughter?" Elaida asked finally. She could not believe her voice was so calm.

"aɪ kænɑt seɪ haʊ mɛni ɪskeɪpt, mʌðɝ," koʊvɑɹlə sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli. "wi dɛɹd nɑt weɪt tə meɪk ə θɝoʊ sɝtʃ, ən - "

"I cannot say how many escaped, Mother," Covarla said hesitantly. "We dared not wait to make a thorough search, and - "

"haʊ mɛni?" ɪleɪɾə ʃaʊɾəd. wɪð ə ʃʌɾɝ, ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn əɹ nɪɾɪŋ; ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə æŋɡɝ wɑz wiknəs. lup ðə jɑɹn, pʊl θɹu ən pʊʃ daʊn. suðɪŋ moʊʃənz.

"How many?" Elaida shouted. With a shudder, she made herself concentrate on her knitting; giving way to anger was weakness. Loop the yarn, pull through and push down. Soothing motions.

"aɪ - aɪ bɹɔɾ ɪlɛvən ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɪð mi, mʌðɝ." ðə wʊmən pɔzd, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, ən ðɛn, wən ɪleɪɾə sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ɹʌʃt ɑn. "ʌðɝz meɪ bi meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ bæk, mʌðɝ. ɡɔɪn ɹəfjuz tə weɪt lɔŋɡɝ, ən wi dɛɹd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn wɪθaʊɾ ɪm ən ɪz jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, nɑt wɪð soʊ mɛni il əbaʊt, ən ðə. . . ."

"I - I brought eleven other sisters with me, Mother." The woman paused, breathing hard, and then, when Elaida said nothing, rushed on. "Others may be making their way back, Mother. Gawyn refused to wait longer, and we dared not remain without him and his Younglings, not with so many Aiel about, and the. . . ."

ɪleɪɾə dɪd nɑt hɪɹ. twɛlv ɹɪtɝnd. hæɾ ɛni mɔɹ ɪskeɪpt, ðeɪ wʊɾə spɛd bæk tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, wʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ əz sun əz koʊvɑɹlə, ʃʊɹli. ivən ɪf wʌn əɹ tu wɝ ɪnʒɝd, tʃɹævlɪŋ sloʊli. . . . twɛlv aʊɾ ə θɝɾi-naɪn. ðə taʊɝ hæd nɑt sʌfɝɾ ə dɪzæstɝ ə ðɪs mæɡnətuɾ ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Elaida did not hear. Twelve returned. Had any more escaped, they would have sped back to Tar Valon, would have been here as soon as Covarla, surely. Even if one or two were injured, traveling slowly. . . . Twelve out of thirty-nine. The Tower had not suffered a disaster of this magnitude even during the Trolloc Wars.

"ðiz il waɪldɝz mʌs bi tɔɾ ə lɛsən," ʃi sɛd, tʃɹæmplɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌtɛvɝ koʊvɑɹlə wɑz bæbəlɪŋ. ɡəlinə hæd θɔt ʃi kəd juz il tə daɪvɝɾ il; wʌɾ ə ful ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn! "wi wɪl ɹɛskju ðə sɪstɝz ðeɪ hoʊl pɹɪznɝ, ən titʃ əm wʌɾ ɪt minz tə dɪfaɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ! ən wɪl teɪk ælθɹ əɡɛn." ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm ɡɛɾ əweɪ, nɑɾ ɪf ʃi hæd tə pɝsənəli lɛd ði ɪntaɪɝ waɪt taʊɝ tə teɪk hɪm! ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ hæd bɪn sɝɾən. ʃi wəd tʃɹaɪəmf!

"These Aiel wilders must be taught a lesson," she said, trampling over whatever Covarla was babbling. Galina had thought she could use Aiel to divert Aiel; what a fool the woman had been! "We will rescue the sisters they hold prisoner, and teach them what it means to defy Aes Sedai! And we will take al'Thor again." She would not let him get away, not if she had to personally lead the entire White Tower to take him! The Foretelling had been certain. She would triumph!

kæstɪŋ ən ənizi ɡlæns əɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn, koʊvɑɹlə ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fiɾ əɡɛn. "mʌðɝ, ðoʊz mɛn - aɪ θɪŋk - "

Casting an uneasy glance at Alviarin, Covarla shifted her feet again. "Mother, those men - I think - "

"du nɑt θɪŋk!" ɪleɪɾə snæpt. hɝ hænz klæsp ðə nɪɾɪŋ niɾəlz kənvʌlsɪvli, ən ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd soʊ fɪɹsli ðət koʊvɑɹlə æktʃəli  ɹeɪzd ə hæn əz ðoʊ tə fɛn ɔf ən ətæk. ɑlviɛɝɪnz pɹɛzəns hæd slɪp fɹəm ɪleɪɾəz maɪnd. wɛl, ðə wʊmən nu wʌt ʃi nu, naʊ; ðət kəd bi dɛlt wɪð leɪɾɝ. "ju hæv meɪnteɪn sikɹəsi, koʊvɑɹlə? əsaɪd fɹəm ɪnfɔɹmɪŋ ðə kipɝ?"

"Do not think!" Elaida snapped. Her hands clasped the knitting needles convulsively, and she leaned forward so fiercely that Covarla actually raised a hand as though to fend off an attack. Alviarin's presence had slipped from Elaida's mind. Well, the woman knew what she knew, now; that could be dealt with later. "You have maintained secrecy, Covarla? Aside from informing the Keeper?"

"oʊ, jɛs, mʌðɝ," koʊvɑɹlə sɛd heɪstəli. hɝ hɛd bɑbd wɪð iɡɝnəs, ɡlæd ðət ʃi hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ ɹaɪt. "aɪ ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi əloʊn, ən hɪd maɪ feɪs əntɪl aɪ ɹitʃt ɑlviɛɝɪn. ɡɔɪn mɛn tə əkʌmpəni mi, bʌt ðə bɹɪdʒ ɡɑɹdz ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ ɛni mɛmbɝ ə ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz pæs."

"Oh, yes, Mother," Covarla said hastily. Her head bobbed with eagerness, glad that she had done something right. "I entered the city alone, and hid my face until I reached Alviarin. Gawyn meant to accompany me, but the bridge guards refused to let any member of the Younglings pass."

"fɝɡɛt ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd," ɪleɪɾə ɔɹɾɝd saʊɝli. ðət jʌŋ mæn ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv tə tʃɹʌbəl əɹ plænz, ɪt simd. ɪf ɡəlinə dɪd tɝn aʊt tə bi əlaɪv stɪl, ʃi wəd peɪ fəɹ feɪlɪŋ ɪn ðæt, ɑn tɑp ə lɛɾɪŋ ælθɹ ɪskeɪp. "ju wɪl liv ðə sɪɾi əz sɝkəmspɛkli əz jə ɛntɝd, dɔɾɝ, ən kip jɝsɛlf ən ði ʌðɝz wɛl hɪɾən ɪn wʌn ə ðə vɪlədʒəz bɪɑn ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊnz əntɪl aɪ sɛn fəɹ ju. dɔɹlən wɪl də naɪsli." ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə slip ɪn bɑɹnz ɪn ðət taɪni hæmlət, wɪtʃ hæd noʊ ɪn; ðə lis ðɛɹ bʌŋɡəlɪŋ dɪzɝvd. "ɡoʊ, naʊ. ən pɹeɪ ðət sʌmwʌn əbʌv jə dʌz ɝaɪv sun. ðə hɔl wɪl dɪmæn əmɛnz fəɹ ðɪs ənpɛɹəlɛl kətæstʃɹəfi, ən ət ðə moʊmənt, ɪt simz jə stæn haɪəst əmʌŋ ðoʊz ət fɔlt. ɡoʊ!"

"Forget Gawyn Trakand," Elaida ordered sourly. That young man remained alive to trouble her plans, it seemed. If Galina did turn out to be alive still, she would pay for failing in that, on top of letting al'Thor escape. "You will leave the city as circumspectly as you entered, daughter, and keep yourself and the others well hidden in one of the villages beyond the bridge towns until I send for you. Dorlan will do nicely." They would have to sleep in barns in that tiny hamlet, which had no inn; the least their bungling deserved. "Go, now. And pray that someone above you does arrive soon. The Hall will demand amends for this unparalleled catastrophe, and at the moment, it seems you stand highest among those at fault. Go!"

koʊvɑɹləz feɪs wɛnt waɪt. ʃi tɑɾɝd soʊ meɪkɪŋ əɹ kɝtsi tə liv, ɪleɪɾə θɔt ʃi maɪt fɔl. bʌŋɡlɝz! ʃi wɑz sɝaʊndəd baɪ fulz, tʃɹeɪɾɝz ən bʌŋɡlɝz!

Covarla's face went white. She tottered so making her curtsy to leave, Elaida thought she might fall. Bunglers! She was surrounded by fools, traitors and bunglers!

əz sun əz ɪleɪɾə hɝd ði aʊɾɝ dɔɹ kloʊs, ʃi hɝl daʊn əɹ nɪɾɪŋ ən spɹæŋ tə hɝ fit, ɹaʊndɪŋ ɑn ɑlviɛɝɪn. "waɪ hæv aɪ nɑt hɝɾ ə ðɪs bɪfɔɹ? ɪf ælθɹ ɪskeɪpt - wʌt wɑz ɪt jə sɛd? sɛvən deɪz əɡoʊ? - ɪf i ɪskeɪp sɛvən deɪz əɡoʊ, sʌmwʌnz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz mʌst əv sin hɪm. waɪ wɑz aɪ nɑɾ ɪnfɔɹmd?"

As soon as Elaida heard the outer door close, she hurled down her knitting and sprang to her feet, rounding on Alviarin. "Why have I not heard of this before? If al'Thor escaped - what was it you said? seven days ago? - if he escaped seven days ago, someone's eyes-and-ears must have seen him. Why was I not informed?"

"aɪ kən oʊnli pæs ɑn tə jə wʌt ði ədʒəz pæs tə mi, mʌðɝ." ɑlviɛɝɪn ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ stoʊl kɑmli, nɑɾ ə wɪt ɹʌfəld. "du jə ɹɪli min tə kɔɹɾ ə θɝd dəbɑkəl baɪ ətɛmptɪŋ tə ɹɛskju ðə kæptɪvz?"

"I can only pass on to you what the Ajahs pass to me, Mother." Alviarin adjusted her stole calmly, not a whit ruffled. "Do you really mean to court a third debacle by attempting to rescue the captives?"

ɪleɪɾə snɪf dɪsmɪsɪvli. "du jə ɹɪli bɪliv waɪldɝz kən stæn bɪfɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɡəlinə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi sɝpɹaɪzd; ʃi mʌs hæv." ʃi fɹaʊnd. "wʌt dʒju min, ə θɝd dəbɑkəl?"

Elaida sniffed dismissively. "Do you really believe wilders can stand before Aes Sedai? Galina let herself be surprised; she must have." She frowned. "What do you mean, a third debacle?"

"ju dɪdn lɪsən, mʌðɝ." ʃɑkɪŋli, ɑlviɛɝɪn sæt wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ɡɪvən pɝmɪʃən, kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ niz ən sɝinəli ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ skɝts. "koʊvɑɹlə θɔt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv hɛld aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə waɪldɝz - ðoʊ aɪ bɪliv ʃiz noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ əz sɝɾən əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛnd - bʌt ðə mɛn wɝ ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm ɪn blæk koʊts, ɔl tʃænəlɪŋ. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi sɝɾən ə ðæt, ən soʊ ɑɹ ði ʌðɝz, əpɛɹənli. lɪvɪŋ wɛpənz, ʃi kɔl ðɛm. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi nɪɹli sɔɪl hɝsɛlf dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ."

"You didn't listen, Mother." Shockingly, Alviarin sat without being given permission, crossing her knees and serenely arranging her skirts. "Covarla thought they might have held out against the wilders - though I believe she is nowhere near as certain as she tried to pretend - but the men were another matter. Several hundred of them in black coats, all channeling. She was very certain of that, and so are the others, apparently. Living weapons, she called them. I think she nearly soiled herself just remembering."

ɪleɪɾə stʊɾ əz ɪf pɑliækst. sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd? "ɪmpɑsəbəl. ðəɹ kæn bi mɔɹ ðən - " ʃi wɔk tə ə teɪbəl ðət simd ɔl aɪvɝi ən ɡɪlt, ən pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə ɡɑbləɾ ʌv waɪn pʌntʃ. ðə lɪp ə ðə kɹɪstəl pɪtʃɝ ɹæɾəld əɡɛns ðə kɹɪstəl ɡɑblət, ən ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ pʌntʃ wɛn ɑntu ðə ɡoʊldən tʃɹeɪ.

Elaida stood as if poleaxed. Several hundred? "Impossible. There can't be more than - " She walked to a table that seemed all ivory and gilt, and poured herself a goblet of wine punch. The lip of the crystal pitcher rattled against the crystal goblet, and almost as much punch went onto the golden tray.

"sɪns ælθɹ kən tʃɹævəl," ɑlviɛɝɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, "ɪt simz lɑdʒɪkəl ət lis ðət səm ə ðiz mɛn kæn, tu. koʊvɑɹlə ɪz kwaɪt ʃʊɹ ðət wɑz haʊ ðeɪ ɝaɪvd. aɪ səpoʊz hiz ɹæðɝ əpsɛɾ əɾ ɪz tʃɹitmənt. koʊvɑɹlə sim sʌmwʌɾ ənizi əbaʊɾ ɪt; ʃi ɪmplaɪd ðəɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə sɪstɝz wɝ. hi maɪt fil i oʊz jə sʌmθɪŋ. ɪt wəd nɑt bi plɛzən tə hæv ðoʊz mɛn sʌɾənli stɛpɪŋ aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, wəɾ ɪt?"

"Since al'Thor can Travel," Alviarin said suddenly, "it seems logical at least that some of these men can, too. Covarla is quite sure that was how they arrived. I suppose he is rather upset at his treatment. Covarla seemed somewhat uneasy about it; she implied that a number of the sisters were. He might feel he owes you something. It would not be pleasant to have those men suddenly stepping out of thin air right here in the Tower, would it?"

ɪleɪɾə pɹæktəkli tɔs ðə pʌntʃ daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. ɡəlinə hæd bɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə bɪɡɪn meɪkɪŋ ælθɹ sʌpəl. ɪf i keɪm fəɹ ɹivɛnʒ. . . . ɪf ðəɹ ɹɪli wɝ hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, əɹ ivən wʌn hʌnʒɹəd. . . . ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk!

Elaida practically tossed the punch down her throat. Galina had been instructed to begin making al'Thor supple. If he came for revenge. . . . If there really were hundreds of men who could channel, or even one hundred. . . . She had to think!

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ, aɪ bɪliv ðeɪ wəɾ əv baɪ naʊ. ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv weɪstəd sɝpɹaɪz. pɝhæps ivən ælθɹ dʌznt wɪʃ tə kənfɹʌn ðə fʊl taʊɝ. aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪv ɔl ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn, tə ðɛɹ blæk taʊɝ. wɪtʃ minz, aɪ fɪɹ, ðət tʌvaɪn əz ə moʊst ənplɛzənt ʃɑk əweɪɾɪŋ hɝ."

"Of course, if they were coming, I believe they would have by now. They would not have wasted surprise. Perhaps even al'Thor doesn't wish to confront the full Tower. I suppose they have all returned to Caemlyn, to their Black Tower. Which means, I fear, that Toveine has a most unpleasant shock awaiting her."

"pɛn ən ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ əɹ tə ɹɪtɝn ɪmiɾiətli," ɪleɪɾə sɛd hɔɹsli. ðə pʌntʃ dɪd nɑt sim tə hɛlp. ʃi tɝnd, ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt tə faɪn ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. meɪbi ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ivən wʌn hʌnʒɹəd - nɑɾ ivən wʌn hʌnʒɹəd? ət sʌnsɛt, tɛn wʊɾə simd mædnəs - bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt teɪk ðə tʃæns. "ɹaɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt jɝsɛlf, ɑlviɛɝɪn. naʊ; ɹaɪt naʊ."

"Pen an order for her to return immediately," Elaida said hoarsely. The punch did not seem to help. She turned, and gave a start to find Alviarin right in front of her. Maybe there were not even one hundred - not even one hundred? at sunset, ten would have seemed madness - but she could not take the chance. "Write it out yourself, Alviarin. Now; right now."

"æn haʊ ɪz ɪt tə bi ɡɑɾən tə hɝ?" ɑlviɛɝɪn tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, aɪsɪli kjʊɹiəs. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi wɔɹ ə feɪn smaɪl. "nʌn ʌv əs kən tʃɹævəl. ðə ʃɪps wɪl pʊt tʌvaɪn ən əɹ pɑɹɾi əʃɔɹ ɪn ændɝ ɛni deɪ naʊ, ɪf ðeɪv nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. jə toʊld əɹ tə dɪvaɪɾ ɪndə smɔl ɡɹups ən əvɔɪd vɪlədʒəz, soʊ əz tə ɡɪv noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ. noʊ, ɪleɪɾə, aɪm əfɹeɪd tʌvaɪn wɪl ɹiɡɑðɝ əɹ fɔɹsɪz nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn ən ətæk ðə blæk taʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni wɝd fɹəm əs ɹitʃɪŋ hɝ."

"And how is it to be gotten to her?" Alviarin tilted her head, icily curious. For some reason, she wore a faint smile. "None of us can Travel. The ships will put Toveine and her party ashore in Andor any day now, if they have not already. You told her to divide into small groups and avoid villages, so as to give no warning. No, Elaida, I am afraid Toveine will regather her forces near Caemlyn and attack the Black Tower without any word from us reaching her."

ɪleɪɾə ɡæspt. ðə wʊmən hæd dʒʌs kɔld əɹ baɪ neɪm! ən bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bɪɡɪn tə spləɾɝ wɪð aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, wɝs keɪm.

Elaida gasped. The woman had just called her by name! And before she could begin to splutter with outrage, worse came.

"aɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ ɪn ɡɹeɪt tʃɹʌbəl, ɪleɪɾə." koʊld aɪz stɛɹɾ ɪndə ɪleɪɾəz ən koʊld wɝdz slɪd smuðli fɹəm ɑlviɛɝɪnz smaɪlɪŋ lɪps. "sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðə hɔl wɪl lɝn ə ðə dɪzæstɝ wɪð ælθɹ. ɡəlinə maɪɾ əv sæɾəsfaɪd ðə hɔl, pɑsəbli, bʌɾ aɪ daʊt koʊvɑɹlə wɪl; ðəl wɑn sʌmwʌn . . . haɪɝ . . . tə peɪ. ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, wɪl ɔl lɝn tʌvaɪnz feɪt. ɪɾəl bi dɪfəkəl tə kip ðɪs ɑn jəɹ ʃoʊldɝz ðɛn." kæʒəwəli, ʃi ədʒʌstəd ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl ɝaʊn ɪleɪɾəz nɛk. "ɪn fækt, ɪɾəl bi ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪf ðeɪ lɝn ɛni taɪm sun. jəl bi stɪld, meɪɾ ən ɪɡzæmpəl, ðə weɪ jə wɑntəd tə meɪk sɪuən sɑntʃ. bʌt ðəɹ maɪt bi taɪm tə ɹɪkʌvɝ, ɪf jə lɪsən tə jəɹ kipɝ. jə mʌs teɪk ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs."

"I think you are in great trouble, Elaida." Cold eyes stared into Elaida's and cold words slid smoothly from Alviarin's smiling lips. "Sooner or later, the Hall will learn of the disaster with al'Thor. Galina might have satisfied the Hall, possibly, but I doubt Covarla will; they will want someone . . . higher . . . to pay. And sooner or later, we will all learn Toveine's fate. It will be difficult to keep this on your shoulders then." Casually, she adjusted the Amyrlin's stole around Elaida's neck. "In fact, it will be impossible if they learn any time soon. You will be stilled, made an example, the way you wanted to make Siuan Sanche. But there might be time to recover, if you listen to your Keeper. You must take good advice."

ɪleɪɾəz tʌŋ fɛl fɹoʊzən. ðə θɹɛt kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn klɪɹɝ. "wʌt juv hɝd tənaɪɾ ɪz sil tə ðə fleɪm," ʃi sɛd θɪkli, bʌt ʃi nu ðət ðə wɝdz wɝ jusləs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ.

Elaida's tongue felt frozen. The threat could not have been clearer. "What you have heard tonight is Sealed to the Flame," she said thickly, but she knew that the words were useless before they were out of her mouth.

"ɪf jə min tə ɹɪdʒɛk maɪ ædvaɪs. . . ." ɑlviɛɝɪn pɔzd, ðən bɪɡæn tə tɝn əweɪ.

"If you mean to reject my advice. . . ." Alviarin paused, then began to turn away.

"weɪt!" ɪleɪɾə pʊl daʊn ðə hænd ʃi hæd stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ʌnəwɛɹ. stʃɹɪpt ə ðə stoʊl. stɪld. ivən æftɝ ðæt, ðeɪ wəd meɪk əɹ haʊl. "wʌt - ?" ʃi hæd tə stɑp ən swɑloʊ. "wʌɾ ædvaɪs dʌz maɪ kipɝ ɔfɝ?" ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə stɑp ðɪs.

"Wait!" Elaida pulled down the hand she had stretched out unaware. Stripped of the stole. Stilled. Even after that, they would make her howl. "What - ?" She had to stop and swallow. "What advice does my Keeper offer?" There had to be some way to stop this.

saɪɪŋ, ɑlviɛɝɪn keɪm kloʊs əɡɛn. kloʊsɝ, ɪn fækt; mʌtʃ tu nɪɹ fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə stæn tə ði æmɪɝlɪn, ðɛɹ skɝts ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃɪŋ. "fɝst, aɪ fɪɹ jə mʌst əbændən tʌvaɪn tə wʌtɛvɝ kʌmz, fəɹ ðə moʊmən ət list. ən ɔlsoʊ ɡəlinə ən huɛvɝ ɛls wɑz teɪkən pɹɪznɝ, wɛðɝ baɪ ði il əɹ ði æʃəmən. ɛni ətɛmptəd ɹɛskju naʊ mʌs min dɪskʌvɝi."

Sighing, Alviarin came close again. Closer, in fact; much too near for anyone to stand to the Amyrlin, their skirts almost touching. "First, I fear you must abandon Toveine to whatever comes, for the moment at least. And also Galina and whoever else was taken prisoner, whether by the Aiel or the Asha'man. Any attempted rescue now must mean discovery."

ɪleɪɾə nɑɾəd sloʊli. "jɛs. aɪ kən si ðæt." ʃi kəd nɑt teɪk əɹ hɔɹəfaɪɾ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz dɪmændɪŋ ɡeɪz. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ! ðɪs kəd nɑt bi hæpənɪŋ!

Elaida nodded slowly. "Yes. I can see that." She could not take her horrified eyes away from the other woman's demanding gaze. There had to be a way! This could not be happening!

"æn aɪ θɪŋk ɪts taɪm tə ɹikənsɪɾɝ jəɹ dɪsɪʒən əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd. doʊn jə ɹɪli θɪŋk ðə ɡɑɹd ʃəd bi ɪnkɹist æftɝ ɔl?"

"And I think it is time to reconsider your decision about the Tower Guard. Don't you really think the Guard should be increased after all?"

"aɪ - kən si maɪ weɪ klɪɹ tə də ðæt." laɪt, ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk!

"I - can see my way clear to do that." Light, she had to think!

"soʊ ɡʊd," ɑlviɛɝɪn mɝmɝd, ən ɪleɪɾə flʌʃt wɪð hɛlpləs ɹeɪdʒ. "təmɑɹoʊ, jəl pɝsənəli sɝtʃ dʒoʊseɪnz ɹumz, ən ædlɔɹnəz."

"So good," Alviarin murmured, and Elaida flushed with helpless rage. "Tomorrow, you will personally search Josaine's rooms, and Adelorna's."

"waɪ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt wəɾ aɪ - ?"

"Why under the Light would I - ?"

ðə wʊmən tʌɡd əɹ stʃɹaɪp stoʊl əɡɛn, ɹʌfli ðɪs taɪm, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf tə jæŋk ɪɾ ɔf əɹ sɔ θɹu hɝ nɛk wɪð ɪt. "ɪt simz ðət dʒoʊseɪn faʊn ən æŋɡɹil səm jɪɹz əɡoʊ ən nɛvɝ tɝn ɪɾ ɪn. ædlɔɹnə dɪd wɝs, aɪ fɪɹ. ʃi ɹimuvd ən æŋɡɹil fɹəm wʌn ə ðə stɔɹɹumz wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. wən juv faʊn ðɛm, jəl ənaʊns ðɛɹ pʌnɪʃmən ɪmiɾiətli. sʌmθɪŋ kwaɪt stɪf. ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm jəl hoʊld ʌp dɝeɪz, kɪjoʊʃi ən fɑɹɛliən əz mɑɾəlz ə pɹəzɝvɪŋ ðə lɔ. jəl ɡɪv itʃ ə pɹɛzənt; ə faɪn nu hɔɹs wɪl du."

The woman tugged her striped stole again, roughly this time, almost as if to yank it off or saw through her neck with it. "It seems that Josaine found an angreal some years ago and never turned it in. Adelorna did worse, I fear. She removed an angreal from one of the storerooms without permission. When you have found them, you will announce their punishment immediately. Something quite stiff. And at the same time you will hold up Doraise, Kiyoshi and Farellien as models of preserving the law. You will give each a present; a fine new horse will do."

ɪleɪɾə wʌndɝd wɛðɝ əɹ aɪz wɝ gɑnə pɑp ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ feɪs. "waɪ?" fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm ə sɪstɝ kɛpt ən æŋɡɹil tə hɝsɛlf ɪn dɪfaɪəns ə ðə lɔ, bʌt ðə pɛnəns wɑz sɛldəm mɔɹ ðən ə stɝn slæp ɑn ðə nʌkəlz. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ nu ðə tɛmteɪʃən. ən ðə ɹɛst! ði ɪfɛkt wɑz ɑbviəs. ɛvɹiwʌn wəd bɪliv dɝeɪz ən kɪjoʊʃi ən fɑɹɛliən hæɾ ɪkspoʊz ði ʌðɝ tu. dʒoʊseɪn ən ædlɔɹnə wɝ ɡɹin, ði ʌðɝz bɹaʊn, ɡɹeɪ ən jɛloʊ ɹɪspɛktɪvli. ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ wəd bi fjʊɹiəs. ðeɪ maɪɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛt bæk ət ði ʌðɝz, wɪtʃ wəɾ ɪnsaɪt ðoʊz ədʒəz, ænd. . . . "waɪ dʒju wɑnə də ðɪs, ɑlviɛɝɪn?"

Elaida wondered whether her eyes were going to pop right out of her face. "Why?" From time to time a sister kept an angreal to herself in defiance of the law, but the penance was seldom more than a stern slap on the knuckles. Every sister knew the temptation. And the rest! The effect was obvious. Everyone would believe Doraise and Kiyoshi and Farellien had exposed the other two. Josaine and Adelorna were Green, the others Brown, Gray and Yellow respectively. The Green Ajah would be furious. They might even try to get back at the others, which would incite those Ajahs, and. . . . "Why do you want to do this, Alviarin?"

"ɪleɪɾə, ɪt ʃəd bi ɪnʌf fəɹ jə ðəɾ ɪts maɪ ædvaɪs." mɑkɪŋ, hʌniɾ aɪs sʌɾənli tɝn tə koʊld aɪɝn. "aɪ wɑnə hɪɹ jə seɪ ðət jəl də əz jə ɑɹ toʊld. ðɛɹz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn mi wɝkɪŋ tə kip ðə stoʊl ɑn jəɹ nɛk, ʌðɝwaɪz. seɪ ɪt!"

"Elaida, it should be enough for you that it is my advice." Mocking, honeyed ice suddenly turned to cold iron. "I want to hear you say that you will do as you are told. There's no point in me working to keep the stole on your neck, otherwise. Say it!"

"aɪ - " ɪleɪɾə tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk əweɪ. oʊ, laɪt, ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk! hɝ bɛli wɑz klɛntʃt ɪn ə nɑt. "aɪ wɪl - də - əz aɪ - æm toʊld."

"I - " Elaida tried to look away. Oh, Light, she had to think! Her belly was clenched in a knot. "I will - do - as I - am told."

ɑlviɛɝɪn smaɪl ðət tʃɪli smaɪl. "ju si, ðət dɪd nɑt hɝt vɛɹi mʌtʃ." sʌɾənli ʃi stɛp bæk, spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɪn ə mɑɾɝət kɝtsi. "wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən, əl wɪðdʒɹɔ ən lɛt jə faɪn səm slip ɪn wʌt ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə naɪt. juv ən ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ əhɛd, wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə ɪʃu fəɹ haɪ kæptən tʃʌbn ən əpɑɹtməns tə sɝtʃ. wɪv tə dɪsaɪd wən tə lɛt ðə taʊɝ noʊ əbaʊt ði æʃəmən, tu." hɝ toʊn meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ðət ʃi wəd dɪsaɪd. "æn pɝhæps wi ʃəd bɪɡɪn plænɪŋ əɹ nɛks muv əɡɛnst ælθɹ. ɪts əbaʊt taɪm ðə taʊɝ stʊɾ oʊpənli ən kɔld ɪm tə hil, doʊn jə θɪŋk? θɪŋk wɛl. aɪ ɡɪv jə ɡʊd naɪt, ɪleɪɾə."

Alviarin smiled that chilly smile. "You see, that did not hurt very much." Suddenly she stepped back, spreading her skirts in a moderate curtsy. "With your permission, I will withdraw and let you find some sleep in what remains of the night. You have an early morning ahead, with orders to issue for High Captain Chubain and apartments to search. We have to decide when to let the Tower know about the Asha'man, too." Her tone made it clear that she would decide. "And perhaps we should begin planning our next move against al'Thor. It is about time the Tower stood openly and called him to heel, don't you think? Think well. I give you good night, Elaida."

deɪzd, wɑntɪŋ tə sɪk ʌp, ɪleɪɾə wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ. stæn oʊpənli? ðət wəɾ ɪnvaɪɾ ətæk baɪ ðiz - wʌt hæd ðə wʊmən kɔl ðɛm? - ðiz æʃəmən. ðɪs kəd nɑt bi hæpənɪŋ tə hɝ. nɑt tə hɝ! bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ʃi hɝl ðə ɡɑbləɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum tə ʃæɾɝ əɡɛnst ə tæpəstʃɹi ʌv flaʊɝz. sizɪŋ ðə pɪtʃɝ wɪð boʊθ hænz, ʃi ɹeɪzd ɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd wɪð ə ʃɹik ə fjʊɹi ən flʌŋ ðət tu, ɪn ə spɹeɪ ʌv pʌntʃ. ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ hæd bɪn soʊ sɝɾən! ʃi wəd . . . !

Dazed, wanting to sick up, Elaida watched her go. Stand openly? That would invite attack by these - what had the woman called them? - these Asha'man. This could not be happening to her. Not to her! Before she realized what she was doing, she hurled the goblet across the room to shatter against a tapestry of flowers. Seizing the pitcher with both hands, she raised it overhead with a shriek of fury and flung that too, in a spray of punch. The Foretelling had been so certain! She would . . . !

əbɹʌpli ʃi stɑpt, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə taɪni ʃɑɹdz ə kɹɪstəlz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə tæpəstʃɹi, ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pisəz skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. ʃʊɹli ðət hæd spoʊkən ə hɝ tʃɹaɪəmf. hɝ tʃɹaɪəmf! ɑlviɛɝɪn maɪɾ əv əɹ maɪnɝ vɪktɝi, bʌt ðə fjutʃɝ bɪlɔŋ tə ɪleɪɾə. əz lɔŋ əz ɑlviɛɝɪn kəd bi ɡɑɾən ɹɪɾ ʌv. bʌɾ ɪt hæd tə bi dʌn kwaɪətli, ɪn səm weɪ soʊ ðəɾ ivən ðə hɔl wəd wɑn saɪləns. ə weɪ ðət wəd nɑt pɔɪn tə ɪleɪɾə əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt, ʃəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪnz seɪlz ɡeɪn wɪnd. ən sʌɾənli ðə waɪ keɪm tə hɝ. ɑlviɛɝɪn wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪf ʃi wɑz toʊld. noʊ wʌn wʊd.

Abruptly she stopped, frowning at the tiny shards of crystals clinging to the tapestry, the larger pieces scattered across the floor. The Foretelling. Surely that had spoken of her triumph. Her triumph! Alviarin might have her minor victory, but the future belonged to Elaida. As long as Alviarin could be gotten rid of. But it had to be done quietly, in some way so that even the Hall would want silence. A way that would not point to Elaida until it was too late, should Alviarin's sails gain wind. And suddenly the why came to her. Alviarin would not believe if she was told. No one would.

kəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn əv sin əɹ smaɪl ðɛn, ðə wʊmənz niz wʊɾə tɝn tə dʒɛli. bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz dʌn, ɑlviɛɝɪn wəɾ ɛnvi ɡəlinə, əlaɪv əɹ dɛd.

Could Alviarin have seen her smile then, the woman's knees would have turned to jelly. Before she was done, Alviarin would envy Galina, alive or dead.

pɔzɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪleɪɾəz əpɑɹtməns, ɑlviɛɝɪn stʌɾid əɹ hænz baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə stænd-læmps. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ʃeɪk, wɪtʃ sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə wʊmən tə faɪt hɑɹɾɝ, tə ɹɪzɪs lɔŋɡɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɪɡʌn, ən ʃi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ. ənlɛs ɪleɪɾə lɝn ðət noʊ fjuɝ ðən faɪv ədʒəz hæd pæs mɛnʃən ʌv ælθɹ tə hɝ ɪn ðə læs fju deɪz; ðə dəpoʊzɪŋ ə koʊləveɪɪɹ hæd sɛn ɛvɹi ədʒɑz eɪdʒən ɪn kɛɹhin flaɪɪŋ fəɹ ə pɛn. noʊ, ɪf ɪleɪɾə dɪd lɝn, ʃi wɑz seɪf ɪnʌf, wɪð ðə hoʊld ʃi hæɾ ɑn ðə wʊmən naʊ. ən wɪð mɛsænə əz peɪtʃɹən. ɪleɪɾə, ðoʊ, wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɛðɝ ʃi ɹilaɪzd əɹ nɑt. ivən ɪf ði æʃəmən feɪl tə tʃɹʌmpət ðɛɹ kɹʌʃɪŋ ə tʌvaɪnz ɛkspədɪʃən - ən ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd kɹʌʃ ɪt, æftɝ wʌt mɛsænə hæd toʊld əɹ ʌv ɪvɛns ə dəməaɪz wɛlz - ɔl ði aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn tʃɹuli wəd ɡeɪn wɪŋz wʌns ðeɪ lɝnd. lækɪŋ ə mɪɹəkəl, sətʃ əz ðə ɹɛbəlz əpɪɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡeɪts, ɪleɪɾə wəd sʌfɝ sɪuən sɑntʃəz feɪɾ ɪn ə mæɾɝ ʌv wiks. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn, ən ɪf ʃi wɪʃt ʃi nu wʌt "ɪt" wɑz, ɔl ʃi ɹɪli hæd tə də wɑz oʊbeɪ. ən wɑtʃ. ən lɝn. pɝhæps ʃi wəd wɛɹ ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl hɝsɛlf wən ɔl wɑz dʌn.

Pausing in the hallway outside Elaida's apartments, Alviarin studied her hands by the light of the stand-lamps. They did not shake, which surprised her. She had expected the woman to fight harder, to resist longer. But it was begun, and she had nothing to fear. Unless Elaida learned that no fewer than five Ajahs had passed mention of al'Thor to her in the last few days; the deposing of Colavaere had sent every Ajah's agent in Cairhien flying for a pen. No, if Elaida did learn, she was safe enough, with the hold she had on the woman now. And with Mesaana as patron. Elaida, though, was finished whether she realized or not. Even if the Asha'man failed to trumpet their crushing of Toveine's expedition - and she was sure they would crush it, after what Mesaana had told her of events of Dumai's Wells - all the eyes-and-ears in Caemlyn truly would gain wings once they learned. Lacking a miracle, such as the rebels appearing at the gates, Elaida would suffer Siuan Sanche's fate in a matter of weeks. In any case, it had begun, and if she wished she knew what "it" was, all she really had to do was obey. And watch. And learn. Perhaps she would wear the seven-striped stole herself when all was done.

ɪn ði ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimɪŋ θɹu hɝ wɪndoʊz, sin dɪp ðə pɛn, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɹaɪt ðə nɛkst wɝd, ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl oʊpən ən ði æmɪɝlɪn swɛpt ɪn. sinz θɪk blæk aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz; ʃi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls əɾ ɔl bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪɾə, pɝhæps nɑɾ ɪkskluɾɪŋ ɹænd ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf. stɪl, ʃi sɛt ðə pɛn daʊn ən ɹoʊz smuðli, pʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə sɪlvɝ-waɪt slivz ʃi hæd pʊʃt ʌp tə kip klɪɹ ə ði ɪŋk. ʃi meɪd ðə dɪɡɹi ʌv kɝtsi pɹɑpɝ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit fɹəm ə sɪɾɝ ɪn əɹ oʊn əpɑɹtməns.

In the early morning sunlight streaming through her windows, Seaine dipped the pen, but before she could write the next word, the door to the hall opened and the Amyrlin swept in. Seaine's thick black eyebrows rose; she would have expected anyone else at all before Elaida, perhaps not excluding Rand al'Thor himself. Still, she set the pen down and rose smoothly, pulling down the silver-white sleeves she had pushed up to keep clear of the ink. She made the degree of curtsy proper to the Amyrlin Seat from a Sitter in her own apartments.

"aɪ də hoʊp jə hævən faʊn ɛni waɪt sɪstɝz haɪɾɪŋ əweɪ æŋɡɹil, mʌðɝ." ʃi dɪd hoʊp ɪt, kwaɪt fɝvənli. ɪleɪɾəz dɪsɛn ɑn ðə ɡɹinz ə fju aʊɝz əɡoʊ, waɪl moʊst ə ðɛm slɛpt, wɑz pɹɑbli stɪl pɹədusɪŋ weɪlz ən næʃɪŋ ə tiθ. ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi noʊ wʌn hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd bɝtʃt fəɹ kipɪŋ bæk ən æŋɡɹil, ən naʊ ðəɹ wɝ tə bi tu. ði æmɪɝlɪn mʌst əv bɪn ɪn wʌn ə hɝ ɪnfəməs koʊl fʊɹiz.

"I do hope you haven't found any White sisters hiding away angreal, Mother." She did hope it, quite fervently. Elaida's descent on the Greens a few hours ago, while most of them slept, was probably still producing wails and gnashing of teeth. In living memory no one had been ordered birched for keeping back an angreal, and now there were to be two. The Amyrlin must have been in one of her infamous cold furies.

bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ðɛn, noʊ saɪn ʌv ɪt ɹɪmeɪnd naʊ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd sin saɪlənli, kul əz ə wɪntɝ pɑn ɪn əɹ ɹɛd-slæʃt sɪlks, ðən ɡlaɪɾɪd tə ðə kɑɹv saɪdbɔɹd wɛɹ peɪntəɾ aɪvɝi mɪniətʃɝz ə sinz fæmli stʊd. ɔl jɪɹz dɛd, bʌt ʃi stɪl lʌvd ɛvɹi wʌn.

But if she had been then, no sign of it remained now. For a moment she regarded Seaine silently, cool as a winter pond in her red-slashed silks, then glided to the carved sideboard where painted ivory miniatures of Seaine's family stood. All years dead, but she still loved every one.

"ju dɪd nɑt stæn tə ɹeɪz mi æmɪɝlɪn," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə pɪktʃɝ ə sinz fɑðɝ. ʃi sɛɾ ɪt daʊn heɪstəli ən tʊk ʌp əɹ mʌðɝ ɪnstɛd.

"You did not stand to raise me Amyrlin," Elaida said, picking up the picture of Seaine's father. She set it down hastily and took up her mother instead.

sinz aɪbɹaʊz ɔlmoʊst ɹoʊz əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪɾ ə ɹul nɑt tə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi sɝpɹaɪz mɔɹ ðən wʌns ɪn ə deɪ. "aɪ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnfɔɹm ðət ðə hɔl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ əntɪl æftɝwɝd, mʌðɝ." æftɝ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz, ə tʌtʃ ə luɡɹd stɪl klʌŋ tə hɝ vɔɪs.

Seaine's eyebrows almost rose again, but she tried to make it a rule not to let herself be surprised more than once in a day. "I was not informed that the Hall was sitting until afterward, Mother." After all these years, a touch of Lugard still clung to her voice.

"jɛs, jɛs." əbændənɪŋ ðə peɪntɪŋz, ɪleɪɾə ɡlaɪɾɪd tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. sin hæɾ ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə fɑndnəs fəɹ kæts, ən kɑɹvd wʊɾən kæts ʌv ɛvɹi sɔɹt kɹaʊɾəd ðə mæntəlpis, səm ɪn əmjuzɪŋ poʊzəz. ði æmɪɝlɪn fɹaʊn ət ðə dɪspleɪ, ðən skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌɾ ən ɡeɪv əɹ hɛɾ ə taɪni ʃeɪk. "bʌt jə ɹɪmeɪnd," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ kwɪkli. "ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ u wɑz nɑɾ ɪnfɔɹm flɛd ðə taʊɝ ən dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛbəlz. ɪksɛp ju. waɪ?"

"Yes, yes." Abandoning the paintings, Elaida glided to the fireplace. Seaine had always had a fondness for cats, and carved wooden cats of every sort crowded the mantelpiece, some in amusing poses. The Amyrlin frowned at the display, then squeezed her eyes shut and gave her head a tiny shake. "But you remained," she said, turning quickly. "Every Sitter who was not informed fled the Tower and joined the rebels. Except you. Why?"

sin spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz. "wʌɾ ɛls kəɾ aɪ də bʌt steɪ, mʌðɝ? ðə taʊɝ mʌs bi hoʊl." huɛvɝ ði æmɪɝlɪn, ʃi æɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. ən wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð maɪ kæts, ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk? nɑt ðət ʃi ɛvɝ wəɾ əlaʊd, ʌv kɔɹs. sɛɝl beɪɡən hæd bɪn ə fɪɹs mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ ɹeɪzd æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðə vɛɹi jɪɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf ɝn ðə ʃɔl, ən ə fɪɹsɝ æmɪɝlɪn ðən ɪleɪɾə kəd bi wɪð ə sɔɹ tuθ. sin hæd hæd ðə pɹəpɹaɪəɾiz dʒɹɪvən ɪndə hɝ tu hɑɹɾ ən dip fəɹ mɪɹ jɪɹz tə ʃɪft, əɹ ɛni dɪslaɪk fəɹ ðə wʊmən u wɔɹ ðə stoʊl. wʌn dɪd nɑɾ əv tə laɪk ən æmɪɝlɪn.

Seaine spread her hands. "What else could I do but stay, Mother? The Tower must be whole." Whoever the Amyrlin, she added to herself. And what's wrong with my cats, if I may ask? Not that she ever would aloud, of course. Sereille Bagand had been a fierce Mistress of Novices before being raised Amyrlin Seat, the very year she herself earned the shawl, and a fiercer Amyrlin than Elaida could be with a sore tooth. Seaine had had the proprieties driven into her too hard and deep for mere years to shift, or any dislike for the woman who wore the stole. One did not have to like an Amyrlin.

"ðə taʊɝ mʌs bi hoʊl," ɪleɪɾə əɡɹid, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ. "ɪt mʌs bi hoʊl." naʊ, waɪ wɑz ʃi nɝvəs? ʃi hæd naɪnti-naɪn kaɪnz ə tɛmpɝ, ɔl hɑɹɾ əz ə naɪf ən twaɪs əz ʃɑɹp, bʌt nɝvəs ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt. "wʌɾ aɪ seɪ tə jə naʊ ɪz sil tə ðə fleɪm, sin." hɝ maʊθ twɪstəd ɹaɪli, ən ʃi ʃɹʌɡd, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ stoʊl ən ɪɹəɾəbəl twɪtʃ. "ɪf aɪ nu haʊ tə meɪk ðə sil stʃɹɔŋɝ, aɪ wʊd," ʃi sɛd, dʒɹaɪ əz jɛstɝdeɪz dʌst.

"The Tower must be whole," Elaida agreed, rubbing her hands together. "It must be whole." Now, why was she nervous? She had ninety-nine kinds of temper, all hard as a knife and twice as sharp, but nervous the woman was not. "What I say to you now is Sealed to the Flame, Seaine." Her mouth twisted wryly, and she shrugged, giving her stole an irritable twitch. "If I knew how to make the seal stronger, I would," she said, dry as yesterday's dust.

"aɪ wɪl hoʊl jəɹ wɝdz ɪn maɪ hɑɹt, mʌðɝ."

"I will hold your words in my heart, Mother."

"aɪ wɑn jə - aɪ kəmæn jə - tə ʌndɝteɪk ən ɪnkwaɪɹi. ən jə mʌst ɪndid hoʊld ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ hɑɹt. ðə ɹɔŋ ɪɹ hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ɪt maɪt min dɛθ, ən dɪzæstɝ fəɹ ðə hoʊl taʊɝ."

"I want you - I command you - to undertake an inquiry. And you must indeed hold it in your heart. The wrong ear hearing of it might mean death, and disaster for the whole Tower."

sinz aɪbɹaʊz twɪtʃt. dɛθ ən dɪzæstɝ fəɹ ðə hoʊl taʊɝ? "ɪn maɪ hɑɹt," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛn. "wɪl jə sɪt jɝsɛlf, mʌðɝ?" ðət wɑz pɹɑpɝ, ɪn əɹ oʊn əpɑɹtməns. "meɪ aɪ pɔɹ jə səm mɪn ti? əɹ plʌm pʌntʃ?"

Seaine's eyebrows twitched. Death and disaster for the whole Tower? "In my heart," she said again. "Will you sit yourself, Mother?" That was proper, in her own apartments. "May I pour you some mint tea? Or plum punch?"

weɪvɪŋ əweɪ ði ɔfɝ ə ɹəfɹɛʃmənt, ɪleɪɾə tʊk ðə moʊs kʌmftəɹbəl tʃɛɹ, kɑɹv baɪ sinz fɑðɝ əz ə ɡɪft wən ʃi ɹəsiv ðə ʃɔl, ðoʊ ʌv kɔɹs ðə kʊʃənz hæd bɪn ɹipleɪs mɛni taɪmz sɪns. ði æmɪɝlɪn meɪd ðə kʌntʃɹi tʃɛɹ sim ə θɹoʊn, ɔl stɪf bæk ən aɪɝn kaʊntənəns. moʊst ənɡɹeɪʃəsli, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv pɝmɪʃən fəɹ sin tə sɪt, tu, soʊ sin foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ən ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ.

Waving away the offer of refreshment, Elaida took the most comfortable chair, carved by Seaine's father as a gift when she received the shawl, though of course the cushions had been replaced many times since. The Amyrlin made the country chair seem a throne, all stiff back and iron countenance. Most ungraciously, she did not give permission for Seaine to sit, too, so Seaine folded her hands and remained standing.

"aɪ hæv θɔt lɔŋ ən hɑɹɾ ɑn tʃɹizən, sin, sɪns maɪ pɹɛɾəsɛsɝ ən əɹ kipɝ wɝ əlaʊd tə ɪskeɪp. hɛlp tə ɪskeɪp. tʃɹizən mʌst əv bɪn ət ðə kɔɹ ə ðæt, ən aɪ fɪɹ oʊnli ə sɪstɝ, əɹ sɪstɝz, cʊɾə ɪfɛktəɾ ɪt."

"I have thought long and hard on treason, Seaine, since my predecessor and her Keeper were allowed to escape. Helped to escape. Treason must have been at the core of that, and I fear only a sister, or sisters, could have effected it."

"ðæt wəd sɝɾənli bi ə pɑsəbɪləɾi, mʌðɝ."

"That would certainly be a possibility, Mother."

ɪleɪɾə fɹaʊn ət ði ɪntɝʌpʃən. "wi kən nɛvɝ bi ʃʊɹ u hæz ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv tʃɹizən ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, sin. waɪ, aɪ səspɛk ðət sʌmwʌn ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ ən ɔɹɾɝ ə maɪn tə bi kaʊntɝmændɪd. ən aɪ hæv ɹizən tə bɪliv ðət sʌmwʌn əz kəmjunəkeɪɾɪd pɹaɪvətli wɪð ɹænd ælθɹ; tə wʌɾ ɛnd, aɪ kænɑt seɪ, bʌt ðət ʃʊɹli ɪz tʃɹizən əɡɛns mi, ən əɡɛns ðə taʊɝ."

Elaida frowned at the interruption. "We can never be sure who has the shadow of treason in her heart, Seaine. Why, I suspect that someone arranged for an order of mine to be countermanded. And I have reason to believe that someone has communicated privately with Rand al'Thor; to what end, I cannot say, but that surely is treason against me, and against the Tower."

sin weɪɾəd fəɹ mɔɹ, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn oʊnli lʊk bæk ət hɝ, sloʊli smuðɪŋ əɹ ɹɛd-slæʃt skɝts. "ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ɪnkwaɪɹi dʒju wɪʃ mi tə meɪk, mʌðɝ?" ʃi æskt kɔʃəsli.

Seaine waited for more, but the Amyrlin only looked back at her, slowly smoothing her red-slashed skirts. "Exactly what inquiry do you wish me to make, Mother?" she asked cautiously.

ɪleɪɾə baʊndəd tə hɝ fit. "aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ jə tə fɑloʊ ðə stɛntʃ ə tʃɹizən, noʊ mæɾɝ wɛɹ ɪt lidz əɹ haʊ haɪ, ivən tə ðə kipɝ hɝsɛlf. jɛs, ivən tə hɝ. wʌt jə faɪnd, huɛvɝ ɪt lidz tə, jəl bɹɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əloʊn, sin. noʊ wʌn ɛls mʌs noʊ. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?"

Elaida bounded to her feet. "I charge you to follow the stench of treason, no matter where it leads or how high, even to the Keeper herself. Yes, even to her. What you find, whoever it leads to, you will bring before the Amyrlin Seat alone, Seaine. No one else must know. Do you understand me?"

"aɪ ʌndɝstæn jəɹ kəmænz, mʌðɝ."

"I understand your commands, Mother."

wɪtʃ, ʃi θɔt, wʌns ɪleɪɾə hæd dɪpɑɹɾəd ivən mɔɹ swɪfli ðən ʃi hæd kʌm, wɑz əbaʊɾ ɔl ʃi dɪɾ ʌndɝstænd. ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə θɪŋk ʃi tʊk ðə tʃɛɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd veɪkeɪɾəd, fɪsts pɹɛs bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn ɪn dʒʌs ðə weɪ hɝ fɑðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz sæt θɪŋkɪŋ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɛl tə lɑdʒɪk, ɪvɛntʃəwəli.

Which, she thought, once Elaida had departed even more swiftly than she had come, was about all she did understand. In order to think she took the chair the Amyrlin had vacated, fists pressed beneath her chin in just the way her father had always sat thinking. Everything fell to logic, eventually.

ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv stʊɾ əɡɛnst sɪuən sɑntʃ - ʃi hæd pɹəpoʊz ðə ɡɝl əz æmɪɝlɪn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs! - bʌt wʌns ɪt wɑz dʌn ən ɔl ðə fɔɹmz wɝ fɑloʊd, haʊɛvɝ spɑɹli, eɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɪskeɪp sɝɾənli hæd bɪn tʃɹizən, ən dɪlɪbɝətli kaʊntɝməndɪŋ ən æmɪɝlɪnz ɔɹɾɝ dʒʌst əz mʌtʃ. pɑsəbli kəmjunəkeɪɾɪŋ wɪð ælθɹ wɑz, tu; ðət dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn wʌt wɑz kəmjunəkeɪɾɪd, wɪð wʌɾ ɪntɛnt. faɪndɪŋ u hæd tʃeɪnʒd ði æmɪɝlɪnz kəmænd wəd bi dɪfəkəlt wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt kəmænd. ət ðɪs leɪt deɪt lɝnɪŋ u maɪɾ əv hɛlp sɪuən ɪskeɪp stʊɾ əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ tʃæns ə səksɛs əz lɝnɪŋ u maɪt bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ælθɹ. soʊ mɛni pɪdʒənz flu ɪndə ən aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ koʊts ɛvɹi deɪ ðəɾ ət taɪmz ðə skaɪ sim tə bi ɹeɪnɪŋ fɛðɝz. ɪf ɪleɪɾə nu mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæd sɛd, ʃi hæd sɝɾənli ɡɔn ɝaʊn ðə bɑɹn. ðɪs ɔl meɪd vɛɹi lɪɾəl sɛns. tʃɹizən ɔt tə meɪk ɪleɪɾə bɔɪl wɪð ɹeɪdʒ, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn æŋɡɹi. ʃi hæd bɪn nɝvəs. ən æŋkʃəs tə bi ɡɔn. ən sikɹəɾɪv, əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɛl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu əɹ səspɛktəd. ɔlmoʊst əz ðoʊ ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə. wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹizən wəd meɪk ɪleɪɾə nɝvəs əɹ əfɹeɪd? dɛθ ən dɪzæstɝ fəɹ ðə hoʊl taʊɝ.

She would not have stood against Siuan Sanche - she had proposed the girl as Amyrlin in the first place! - but once it was done and all the forms were followed, however sparely, aiding her escape certainly had been treason, and deliberately countermanding an Amyrlin's order just as much. Possibly communicating with al'Thor was, too; that depended on what was communicated, with what intent. Finding who had changed the Amyrlin's command would be difficult without knowing what command. At this late date learning who might have helped Siuan escape stood about as much chance of success as learning who might be writing to al'Thor. So many pigeons flew into and out of the Tower cotes every day that at times the sky seemed to be raining feathers. If Elaida knew more than she had said, she had certainly gone around the barn. This all made very little sense. Treason ought to make Elaida boil with rage, but she had not been angry. She had been nervous. And anxious to be gone. And secretive, as if she did not want to tell everything she knew or suspected. Almost as though she was afraid to. What kind of treason would make Elaida nervous or afraid? Death and disaster for the whole Tower.

laɪk ðə pisəz ʌv ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl, ɔl fɛl ɪndə pleɪs, ən sinz aɪbɹaʊz tʃɹaɪd tə klaɪm ɑntu hɝ skælp. ɪt fɪt; ɪɾ ɔl fɪt. ʃi fɛl ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪnɪŋ fɹəm əɹ feɪs; hɝ hænz ən fit wɝ sʌɾənli aɪsi. sil tə ðə fleɪm. ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi wəd kip ðɪs ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd sɪns ʃi spoʊk ðoʊz wɝdz. ʃi oʊnli lɛt hɝsɛlf bi əfɹeɪd wən ɪt wɑz lɑdʒɪkəl tə bi, ən ɹaɪt ðɛn, ʃi wɑz tɛɹəfaɪd. ʃi kəd nɑt feɪs ðɪs əloʊn. bʌt hu? ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, hu? ðɪs ænsɝ keɪm mʌtʃ mɔɹ izəli. ɡæðɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf tʊk ə lɪɾəl taɪm, bʌt ʃi hɝid fɹəm əɹ ɹumz ən aʊɾ ə ðə waɪt kɔɹɾɝz wɔkɪŋ ə ɡʊd dil fæstɝ ðən ʃi juʒəwəli dɪd.

Like the pieces of a blacksmith's puzzle, all fell into place, and Seaine's eyebrows tried to climb onto her scalp. It fit; it all fit. She felt the blood draining from her face; her hands and feet were suddenly icy. Sealed to the Flame. She had said she would keep this in her heart, but everything had changed since she spoke those words. She only let herself be afraid when it was logical to be, and right then, she was terrified. She could not face this alone. But who? Under the circumstances, who? This answer came much more easily. Gathering herself took a little time, but she hurried from her rooms and out of the White quarters walking a good deal faster than she usually did.

sɝvəns skɝid θɹu ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz əz ɔlweɪz, ðoʊ ʃi wɔk soʊ kwɪkli ðət ʃi wɑz pæs moʊs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd bɪɡɪn baʊ əɹ kɝtsi, bʌt ðəɹ sim fjuɝ sɪstɝz əbaʊt ðən ði ɝli aʊɝ kəɾ əkaʊn fɔɹ. mɛni fjuɝ. jɛɾ ɪf moʊst wɝ steɪɪŋ kloʊz tə ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə fju ʃi sɔ meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɪɾ ɪn wʌn weɪ. sɪstɝz swɑn əlɔŋ ðə tæpəstʃɹi-hʌŋ hɔlweɪz, feɪsəz ɔl sɝɛnəɾi, ən ðɛɹ aɪz sim tə hæv stim bɪhaɪn ðɛm. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ tu əɹ θɹi wɪmən spoʊk təɡɛðɝ, wɪð ʃɑɹp aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ tə si hu maɪt bi lɪsnɪŋ. ɔlweɪz tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ðə seɪm ədʒɑ. ivən jɛstɝdeɪ, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd stɪl sin wɪmən ʃɛɹɪŋ fɹɛndʃɪp bɪtwin ədʒəz. waɪts wɝ səpoʊz tə pʊɾ ɪmoʊʃən əweɪ ɪntaɪɝli, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ðə ɹizən fəɹ blaɪndɪŋ hɝsɛlf, əz səm dɪd. səspɪʃən meɪd ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ laɪk hɑt dʒɛli. nɑɾ ə nu θɪŋ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli - ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd bɪɡʌn ɪt wɪð əɹ hɑɹʃ mɛʒɝz, ən ðə ɹumɝz əbaʊt lɑɡən hæɾ oʊnli ɪɡzæsɝbeɪɾəd ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən - bʌt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ simd wɝs ðən ɛvɝ.

Servants scurried through the corridors as always, though she walked so quickly that she was past most before they could begin bow or curtsy, but there seemed fewer sisters about than the early hour could account for. Many fewer. Yet if most were staying close to their quarters for some reason, the few she saw made up for it in one way. Sisters swanned along the tapestry-hung hallways, faces all serenity, and their eyes seemed to have steam behind them. Here and there two or three women spoke together, with sharp eyes darting to see who might be listening. Always two or three of the same Ajah. Even yesterday, she was sure she had still seen women sharing friendship between Ajahs. Whites were supposed to put emotion away entirely, but she had never seen the reason for blinding herself, as some did. Suspicion made the air in the Tower like hot jelly. Not a new thing, unfortunately - the Amyrlin had begun it with her harsh measures, and the rumors about Logain had only exacerbated the situation - but this morning seemed worse than ever.

tælin mɪnli keɪm ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ əhɛɾ ə hɝ, hɝ ʃɔl nɑt dʒʌst əkɹɔs əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt spɹɛd daʊn əɹ ɑɹmz əz ðoʊ tə dɪspleɪ ðə ɡɹin fɹɪnʒ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛvɹi ɡɹin ʃi hæd sin ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ wɔɹ əɹ ʃɔl. tælin, ɡoʊldən-hɛɹɾ ən stætʃuɛsk ən lʌvli, hæd stʊd tə dɪpoʊz sɪuən, bʌt ʃi hæd kʌm tə ðə taʊɝ waɪl sin wɑz æksɛptɪd, ən ðət dɪsɪʒən hæd nɑt dɛntɪd ðɛɹ lɔŋ fɹɛndʃɪp. tælin hæd hæd ɹizənz sin æksɛptɪɾ ɪf nɑɾ əɡɹid wɪð. tədeɪ, hɝ fɹɛn stɑpt, wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ wɛɹəli. soʊ mɛni sɪstɝz sim tə wɑtʃ wʌn ənʌðɝ ðət weɪ ʌv leɪt. ənʌðɝ taɪm, ʃi wəɾ əv stɑpt, bʌt nɑt wɪð wʌt meɪɾ əɹ hɛd wɑnə bɝst oʊpən laɪk ə spɔɪl mɛlən. tælin wɑz ə fɹɛnd, ən ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd bi ʃʊɹ ə hɝ, bʌt θɪŋkɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ðɪs. leɪɾɝ, ɪf pɑsəbəl, ʃi wəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ tælin. hoʊpɪŋ ɪt wəd bi pɑsəbəl, ʃi hɝid pæst wɪð oʊnli ə nɑd.

Talene Minly came around a corner ahead of her, her shawl not just across her shoulders, but spread down her arms as though to display the green fringe. For that matter, she realized that every Green she had seen this morning wore her shawl. Talene, golden-haired and statuesque and lovely, had stood to depose Siuan, but she had come to the Tower while Seaine was Accepted, and that decision had not dented their long friendship. Talene had had reasons Seaine accepted if not agreed with. Today, her friend stopped, watching her warily. So many sisters seemed to watch one another that way of late. Another time, she would have stopped, but not with what made her head want to burst open like a spoiled melon. Talene was a friend, and she thought she could be sure of her, but thinking was not enough for this. Later, if possible, she would approach Talene. Hoping it would be possible, she hurried past with only a nod.

ɪn ðə ɹɛd kɔɹɾɝz, ðə mud wɑz ivən wɝs, ði ɛɹ θɪkɝ. əz wɪð ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz, ðəɹ wɝ mɛni mɔɹ ɹumz ðən ðəɹ wɝ sɪstɝz tə fɪl əm naʊ - ðət hæd bɪn soʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst ɹɛbəl flɛd - bʌt ðə ɹɛd wɑz ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ði ədʒəz, ən sɪstɝz fɪl ðə lɛvəlz stɪl ɪn jus. ɹɛdz fɹikwənli wɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz wən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid, bʌt naʊ ɛvɹi læst wʊmən spɔɹɾɪd əɹ ɹɛd fɹɪnʒ laɪk ə bænɝ. kɑnvɝseɪʃənz stɑpt əz sin əpɹoʊtʃt, ən koʊld aɪz fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪn ə bʌbəl ʌv aɪsi saɪləns. ʃi fɛlt ən ɪnveɪɾɝ dip ɪn ɛnəmi kʌntʃɹi əz ʃi kɹɔs ðoʊz pəkjuljɝ flɔɹ taɪlz, waɪt wɪð ðə tɪɹdʒɹɑp fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪn ɹɛd. bʌt ðɛn, ɛni pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊɝ maɪt bi ɛnəmi kʌntʃɹi. lʊkɪŋ ənʌðɝ weɪ, ðoʊz skɑɹlət fleɪmz maɪt bi teɪkən fəɹ ɹɛd dʒɹæɡənz fæŋz. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪliv ðoʊz ɪɹæʃənəl teɪlz əbaʊt ðə ɹɛdz ən fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, bʌt. . . . waɪ wəd nʌn ə ðɛm dɪnaɪ ɪt?

In the Red quarters, the mood was even worse, the air thicker. As with the other Ajahs, there were many more rooms than there were sisters to fill them now - that had been so long before the first rebel fled - but the Red was the largest of the Ajahs, and sisters filled the levels still in use. Reds frequently wore their shawls when there was no need, but now every last woman sported her red fringe like a banner. Conversations stopped as Seaine approached, and cold eyes followed her in a bubble of icy silence. She felt an invader deep in enemy country as she crossed those peculiar floor tiles, white with the teardrop Flame of Tar Valon in red. But then, any part of the Tower might be enemy country. Looking another way, those scarlet flames might be taken for red Dragon's Fangs. She had never believed those irrational tales about the Reds and false Dragons, but. . . . Why would none of them deny it?

ʃi hæd tə æsk dɝɛkʃənz. "aɪ wɪl nɑt dɪstɝb əɹ ɪf ʃiz bɪzi," ʃi sɛd. "wi wɝ kloʊs fɹɛnz, wʌns, ən aɪ wəd laɪk əs tə bi əɡɛn. naʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ, ði ədʒəz kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə dʒɹɪft əpɑɹt." ɔl tʃɹu, ðoʊ ði ədʒəz sim tə splɪɾɪŋ əpɑɹt ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɹɪftɪŋ, bʌt ðə dəmɑni wʊmən lɪsənd wɪð ə feɪs ðət cʊɾə bɪn kæst ɪn kɑpɝ. ðəɹ wɝ nɑt mɛni dəmɑni ɹɛdz, ən ðoʊz fju juʒəwəli minɝ ðən sneɪks kɑɾ ɪn ə fɛns.

She had to ask directions. "I will not disturb her if she is busy," she said. "We were close friends, once, and I would like us to be again. Now more than ever, the Ajahs cannot afford to drift apart." All true, though the Ajahs seemed to splitting apart rather than drifting, but the Domani woman listened with a face that could have been cast in copper. There were not many Domani Reds, and those few usually meaner than snakes caught in a fence.

"aɪ wɪl ʃoʊ ju, sɪɾɝ," ðə wʊmən sɛɾ ət læst, ən nɑt vɛɹi ɹɪspɛkfəli. ʃi lɛd ðə weɪ, ðən wɑtʃt waɪl sin nɑkt ɑn ðə dɔɹ, əz ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd hɪɹ əloʊn. ðə dɔɹ pænəlz wɝ kɑɹvd wɪð ðə fleɪm, tu, lækɝd ðə kʌlɝ ə fɹɛʃ blʌd.

"I will show you, Sitter," the woman said at last, and not very respectfully. She led the way, then watched while Seaine knocked on the door, as though she could not be trusted here alone. The door panels were carved with the Flame, too, lacquered the color of fresh blood.

"kʌm!" ə bɹɪsk vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm wɪðɪn. sin oʊpən ðə dɔɹ hoʊpɪŋ ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt.

"Come!" a brisk voice called from within. Seaine opened the door hoping she was right.

"sin!" pɛvɑɹə ɪkskleɪm tʃɪɹfəli. "wʌt bɹɪŋz jə hɪɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ? kʌm! ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ ən sɪt!" ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɔl ðə jɪɹz sɪns ðeɪ wɝ nɑvəs ən æksɛptɪd təɡɛðɝ hæd mɛltəɾ əweɪ. kwaɪt plʌmp ən nɑt tɔl - ɪn tʃɹuθ, fəɹ ə kændɔɹi, ʃi wɑz ʃɔɹt - pɛvɑɹə wɑz ɔlsoʊ kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, wɪð ə mɛɹi twɪŋkəl ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz ən ə ɹɛɾi smaɪl. ɪt wɑz sæd ðət ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən ɹɛd, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɡʊɾ əɹ ɹizənz, kəz ʃi stɪl laɪk mɛn. ðə ɹɛd dɪɾ ətʃɹækt wɪmən u wɝ nætʃɹəli səspɪʃəs ə mɛn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ʌðɝz tʃoʊz ɪt kəz ðə tæsk ə faɪndɪŋ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. wɛðɝ ðeɪ laɪk mɛn, əɹ dɪslaɪk ðɛm, əɹ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ði ʌðɝ ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ, nɑt mɛni wɪmən kəd bɪlɔŋ tə ðə ɹɛd fəɹ lɔŋ wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ə dʒɔndɪs vju ʌv ɔl mɛn. sin hæd ɹizən tə bɪliv pɛvɑɹə hæd sɝvd ə pɛnəns ʃɔɹtli æftɝ əteɪnɪŋ ðə ʃɔl fəɹ seɪɪŋ ðət ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ; sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ ðə seɪfɝ haɪts ə ðə hɔl, ʃi hæɾ oʊpənli sɛd wɔɹɾɝz wəd meɪk ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑz wɝk iziɝ. nɑt ðət ðət hæɾ ɛni pɑɹɾ ɪn sin tʃɹʌstɪŋ hɝ. ʌv ɔl ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ðoʊ, pɛvɑɹə wɑz ðə wʌn ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst wɪð ðɪs.

"Seaine!" Pevara exclaimed cheerfully. "What brings you here this morning? Come! Shut the door and sit!" It was as if all the years since they were novice and Accepted together had melted away. Quite plump and not tall - in truth, for a Kandori, she was short - Pevara was also quite pretty, with a merry twinkle in her dark eyes and a ready smile. It was sad that she had chosen Red, no matter how good her reasons, because she still liked men. The Red did attract women who were naturally suspicious of men, of course, but others chose it because the task of finding men who could channel was important. Whether they liked men, or disliked them, or did not care one way or the other in the beginning, however, not many women could belong to the Red for long without taking a jaundiced view of all men. Seaine had reason to believe Pevara had served a penance shortly after attaining the shawl for saying that she wished she had a Warder; since reaching the safer heights of the Hall, she had openly said Warders would make the Red Ajah's work easier. Not that that had any part in Seaine trusting her. Of all the sisters in the Tower, though, Pevara was the one she was sure she could trust with this.

"aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə haʊ hæpi aɪm tə si ju," pɛvɑɹə sɛd wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɪnskɑnst ɪn ɑɹmtʃɛɹz kɑɹvd ɪn ðə spaɪɹəlz pɑpjəlɝ ɪn kændɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wɪð dɛləkət, bʌɾɝflaɪ-peɪntəd kʌps ə blubɛɹi ti ɪn hænd. "aɪv ɔfən θɔt haʊ aɪ ʃəd ɡoʊ tə ju, bʌɾ aɪ ədmɪt tə fɪɹɪŋ wʌt jə wəd seɪ æftɝ aɪ ɡeɪv jə ðə kʌt dɝɛk soʊ mɛni jɪɹz əɡoʊ. swɔɹn ɑn ðə bleɪd, sin, aɪd nɑɾ əv dʌn ɪt, ɪksɛp tɛsin dʒɔɹhəl pɹæktəkli hæd mi baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə maɪ nɛk, ən aɪ wɑz tu nu tə ðə ʃɔl tə hæv mʌtʃ bækboʊn jɛt. kən jə fɝɡɪv mi?"

"I cannot tell you how happy I am to see you," Pevara said once they were ensconced in armchairs carved in the spirals popular in Kandor a hundred years ago, with delicate, butterfly-painted cups of blueberry tea in hand. "I've often thought how I should go to you, but I admit to fearing what you would say after I gave you the cut direct so many years ago. Sworn on the blade, Seaine, I'd not have done it, except Tesien Jorhald practically had me by the scruff of my neck, and I was too new to the shawl to have much backbone yet. Can you forgive me?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ kæn," sin ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ ʌndɝstʊd." ðə ɹɛd fɝmli dɪskɝədʒ fɹɛndʃɪps aʊtsaɪd ði ədʒɑ. kwaɪt fɝmli, ən kwaɪɾ ɪfɪʃənli. "wi kænɑt ɡoʊ əɡɛnst əɹ ədʒəz wən wəɹ jʌŋ, ən leɪɾɝ, ɪt simz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə ɹitʃɹeɪs əɹ stɛps. ə θaʊzən taɪmz aɪv ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əs wɪspɝɪŋ təɡɛðɝ æftɝ læst - oʊ, ən ðə pɹæŋks! dʒju ɹikɔl wən wi dʌstɪd sɹæntʃəz ʃɪft wɪð paʊɾɝd ɪtʃhoʊk? - bʌɾ aɪm ʃeɪm tə seɪ ɪt tʊk biɪŋ tɛɹəfaɪɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ wɪts tə stɝ maɪ fit. aɪ də wɑn əs tə bi fɹɛnz əɡɛn, bʌɾ aɪ nid jəɹ hɛlp, tu. jə ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʌn aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ kən tʃɹʌst."

"Of course, I can," Seaine replied. "I understood." The Red firmly discouraged friendships outside the Ajah. Quite firmly, and quite efficiently. "We cannot go against our Ajahs when we are young, and later, it seems impossible to retrace our steps. A thousand times I've remembered us whispering together after Last - oh, and the pranks! do you recall when we dusted Serancha's shift with powdered itchoak? - but I'm shamed to say it took being terrified out of my wits to stir my feet. I do want us to be friends again, but I need your help, too. You are the only one I'm sure I can trust."

"sɹæntʃə wɑz ə pɹɪɡ ðɛn, ən stɪl ɪz." pɛvɑɹə læft. "ðə ɡɹeɪ ɪz ə ɡʊd pleɪs fəɹ hɝ. bʌɾ aɪ kæn bɪliv jə tɛɹəfaɪɾ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ. waɪ, jə nɛvɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz lɑdʒɪkəl tə bi əfɹeɪɾ əntɪl wi wɝ bæk ɪn əɹ bɛdz. ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə pɹɑməs tə stæn ɪn ðə hɔl wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt fɔɹ, wʌtɛvɝ hɛlp aɪ kən ɡɪv ɪz jʊɹz, sin. wʌt dʒju nid?"

"Serancha was a prig then, and still is." Pevara laughed. "The Gray is a good place for her. But I can't believe you terrified at anything. Why, you never decided it was logical to be afraid until we were back in our beds. Short of a promise to stand in the Hall without knowing what for, whatever help I can give is yours, Seaine. What do you need?"

bɹɔt tə ðə pɔɪnt, sin hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti. nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni daʊts əbaʊt pɛvɑɹə, bʌt pʊʃɪŋ ðə wɝdz aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ wɑz . . . dɪfəkəlt. "ði æmɪɝlɪn keɪm tə si mi ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ʃi ɪnstʃɹʌktəd mi tə meɪk ən ɪnkwaɪɹi, sil tə ðə fleɪm." pɛvɑɹə fɹaʊn slaɪtli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ ðəɾ ɪn ðət keɪs sin ʃəd nɑt bi spikɪŋ ʌv ɪt. sin maɪɾ əv plæn haʊ tə kæɹi aʊt moʊst ə ðɛɹ pɹæŋks əz ɡɝlz, bʌt pɛvɑɹə hæd bɪn ðə wʌn wɪð ði ɑdæsəɾi tə θɪŋk moʊst ə ðɛm ʌp, ən ʃi hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd moʊst ə ðə nɝv tə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ðɛm. "ʃi wɑz vɛɹi sɝkəmspɛkt, bʌɾ æftɝ ə lɪɾəl θɔt, ɪt wɑz klɪɹ tə mi wʌt ʃi wɑntəd. aɪm tə hʌn aʊt . . ." ət ðə læst, kɝədʒ feɪld əɹ tʌŋ. ". . . dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə taʊɝ."

Brought to the point, Seaine hesitated, sipping her tea. Not that she had any doubts about Pevara, but pushing the words out of her mouth was . . . difficult. "The Amyrlin came to see me this morning," she said finally. "She instructed me to make an inquiry, Sealed to the Flame." Pevara frowned slightly, but she did not say that in that case Seaine should not be speaking of it. Seaine might have planned how to carry out most of their pranks as girls, but Pevara had been the one with the audacity to think most of them up, and she had provided most of the nerve to go through with them. "She was very circumspect, but after a little thought, it was clear to me what she wanted. I am to hunt out . . ." At the last, courage failed her tongue. ". . . Darkfriends in the Tower."

pɛvɑɹəz aɪz, əz dɑɹk əz əɹ oʊn wɝ blu, bɪkeɪm stoʊn, ən swɛp tə ðə mæntəl əbʌv əɹ faɪɝpleɪs, wɛɹ mɪniətʃɝz ə hɝ oʊn fæmli meɪɾ ə pɹɪsaɪs laɪn. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl daɪd waɪl ʃi wɑz ə nɑvəs, pɛɹəns, bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz, æns, ʌŋkəlz ən ɔl, mɝɾɝd ɪn ə kwɪkli səpɹɛst əpɹaɪzɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz u hæd bɪkʌm kənvɪns ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz əbaʊt tə bɹeɪk fɹi. ðət wɑz waɪ sin hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd tʃɹʌs hɝ. ðət wɑz waɪ pɛvɑɹə hæd tʃoʊzən ɹɛd - ðoʊ sin stɪl θɔt ʃi cʊɾə dʌn əz wɛl ən bɪn hæpiɝ əz ə ɡɹin - kəz ʃi bɪlivd ə ɹɛd hʌntɪŋ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl hæd ðə bɛs tʃæns ə faɪndɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ʃi hæd bɪn vɛɹi ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪt; ðət plʌmp ɪkstɪɹiɝ kʌvɝɾ ə kɔɹ ə stil. ən ʃi pəzɛs ðə kɝədʒ tə seɪ kɑmli wʌt sin hæd bɪn əneɪbəl tə bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ʌɾɝ.

Pevara's eyes, as dark as her own were blue, became stone, and swept to the mantel above her fireplace, where miniatures of her own family made a precise line. They had all died while she was a novice, parents, brothers and sisters, aunts, uncles and all, murdered in a quickly suppressed uprising of Darkfriends who had become convinced the Dark One was about to break free. That was why Seaine had been sure she could trust her. That was why Pevara had chosen Red - though Seaine still thought she could have done as well and been happier as a Green - because she believed a Red hunting men who could channel had the best chance of finding Darkfriends. She had been very good at it; that plump exterior covered a core of steel. And she possessed the courage to say calmly what Seaine had been unable to bring herself to utter.

"ðə blæk ədʒɑ. wɛl. noʊ wʌndɝ ɪleɪɾə wəd bi sɝkəmspɛkt."

"The Black Ajah. Well. No wonder Elaida would be circumspect."

"pɛvɑɹə, aɪ noʊ ʃiz ɔlweɪz dɪnaɪɾ ɪts ɛɡzɪstəns hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛni θɹi ʌðɝ sɪstɝz kəmbaɪnd, bʌɾ aɪm sɝɾən ʃʊɹ ðæts wʌt ʃi mɛnt, ən ɪf ʃiz kənvɪnst. . . ."

"Pevara, I know she's always denied its existence harder than any three other sisters combined, but I'm certain sure that's what she meant, and if she is convinced. . . ."

hɝ fɹɛnd weɪvd əɹ ɔf. "ju hæv noʊ nid tə kənvɪns mi, sin. aɪ hæv bɪn ʃʊɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪɡzɪsts fɔɹ. . . ." stʃɹeɪnʒli, pɛvɑɹə bɪkeɪm hɛzɪɾənt, piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ tikʌp laɪk ə fɔɹtʃən-tɛlɝ əɾ ə fɛɹ. "wʌt dʒju noʊ ʌv ɪvɛns ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ði il wɔɹ?"

Her friend waved her off. "You have no need to convince me, Seaine. I have been sure the Black Ajah exists for. . . ." Strangely, Pevara became hesitant, peering into her teacup like a fortune-teller at a fair. "What do you know of events right after the Aiel War?"

"tu æmɪɝlənz daɪɪŋ sʌɾənli ɪn ðə speɪs ə faɪv jɪɹz," sin sɛd kɛɹfəli. ʃi əsum ði ʌðɝ wʊmən mɛn ɪvɛns ɪn ðə taʊɝ. tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, əntɪl biɪŋ ɹeɪzd ə sɪɾɝ nɪɹli fɪftin jɪɹz əɡoʊ, dʒʌst ə jɪɹ æftɝ pɛvɑɹə, ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən tə ɛniθɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ. ən nɑt ðət mʌtʃ ɪnsaɪd, ɹɪli. "ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni sɪstɝz daɪɾ ɪn ðoʊz jɪɹz, əz aɪ ɹikɔl. dʒju min tə seɪ jə θɪŋk ðə . . . ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæɾ ə hæn ɪn ðæt?" ðɛɹ; ʃi hæd sɛɾ ɪt, ən ðə neɪm hæd nɑt bɝn əɹ tʌŋ.

"Two Amyrlins dying suddenly in the space of five years," Seaine said carefully. She assumed the other woman meant events in the Tower. Truth to tell, until being raised a Sitter nearly fifteen years ago, just a year after Pevara, she had not given much attention to anything outside the Tower. And not that much inside, really. "A great many sisters died in those years, as I recall. Do you mean to say you think the . . . the Black Ajah had a hand in that?" There; she had said it, and the name had not burned her tongue.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," pɛvɑɹə sɛd sɔfli, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "juv dʌn wɛl tə ɹæp jɝsɛlf dip ɪn fəlɑsəfi. ðəɹ wɝ . . . θɪŋz . . . dʌn ðɛn, ən sil tə ðə fleɪm." ʃi dʒɹu ə tʃɹʌbəl bɹɛθ.

"I don't know," Pevara said softly, shaking her head. "You've done well to wrap yourself deep in philosophy. There were . . . things . . . done then, and Sealed to the Flame." She drew a troubled breath.

sin dɪd nɑt pɹɛs hɝ; ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd kəmɪɾəd sʌmθɪŋ əkɪn tə tʃɹizən baɪ bɹeɪkɪŋ ðət seɪm sil, ən pɛvɑɹə wəɾ əv tə dɪsaɪɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn. "lʊkɪŋ ət ɹɪpɔɹts wɪl bi seɪfɝ ðən æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz wɪð noʊ aɪdiə hu wɝ ɹɪli æskɪŋ. lɑdʒɪkli, ə blæk sɪstɝ mʌs bi eɪbəl tə laɪ dɪspaɪt ði oʊðz." ʌðɝwaɪz, ðə blæk ədʒɑ wʊɾə bɪn ɹɪvild lɔŋ sɪns. ðət neɪm sim tə bi kʌmɪŋ mɔɹ izəli wɪð jus. "ɪf ɛni sɪstɝ ɹoʊt ðət ʃi dɪd wʌn θɪŋ wən wi kən pɹuv ʃi dɪɾ ənʌðɝ, ðən wɪv faʊn ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

Seaine did not press her; she herself had committed something akin to treason by breaking that same seal, and Pevara would have to decide on her own. "Looking at reports will be safer than asking questions with no idea who we're really asking. Logically, a Black sister must be able to lie despite the Oaths." Otherwise, the Black Ajah would have been revealed long since. That name seemed to be coming more easily with use. "If any sister wrote that she did one thing when we can prove she did another, then we have found a Darkfriend."

pɛvɑɹə nɑɾəd. "jɛs. pɝhæps ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæz noʊ hæn ɪn ðə ɹɪbɛljən, bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd lɛt ðɪs tɝmɔɪl pæs wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ædvæntɪdʒ. wi mʌs lʊk kloʊsli ət ðɪs læs jɪɹ, aɪ θɪŋk."

Pevara nodded. "Yes. Perhaps the Black Ajah has no hand in the rebellion, but I cannot think they would let this turmoil pass without taking advantage. We must look closely at this last year, I think."

tə ðæt, sin əɡɹid ɹɪlʌktənli. ðəɹ wəd bi fjuɝ pisəz ə peɪpɝ tə ɹiɾ ən mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz tə æsk kənsɝnɪŋ ɹisən mʌnθs. dəsaɪɾɪŋ u ɛls tə meɪk pɑɹɾ ə ði ɪnkwaɪɹi wɑz ivən hɑɹɾɝ. ɪspɛʃli æftɝ pɛvɑɹə sɛd, "ju wɝ vɛɹi bɹeɪv kʌmɪŋ tə mi, sin. aɪv noʊn dɑɹk-fɹɛnz tə kɪl bɹʌðɝz, sɪstɝz, pɛɹəns, tə tʃɹaɪ haɪɾɪŋ u ðeɪ ɑɹ ən wʌt ðeɪv dʌn. aɪ lʌv jə fəɹ ɪt, bʌt jə wɝ vɛɹi bɹeɪv ɪndid."

To that, Seaine agreed reluctantly. There would be fewer pieces of paper to read and more questions to ask concerning recent months. Deciding who else to make part of the inquiry was even harder. Especially after Pevara said, "You were very brave coming to me, Seaine. I've known Dark-friends to kill brothers, sisters, parents, to try hiding who they are and what they've done. I love you for it, but you were very brave indeed."

sin ʃɪvɝɾ əz ɪf ə ɡus hæd wɔkt ɑn əɹ ɡɹeɪv. hæd ʃi wɑntəd tə bi bɹeɪv, ʃi wʊɾə tʃoʊzən ɡɹin. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ɪleɪɾə hæd ɡɔn tə sʌmwʌn ɛls. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɝnɪŋ bæk naʊ, ðoʊ.

Seaine shivered as if a goose had walked on her grave. Had she wanted to be brave, she would have chosen Green. She almost wished Elaida had gone to someone else. There was no turning back now, though.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 33

eɪ bæθ


A Bath

ðə deɪz æftɝ sɛndɪŋ pɛɹɪn əweɪ simd ɛnləs tə ɹænd, ən ðə naɪts lɔŋɡɝ. hi ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə hɪz ɹumz ən steɪd ðɛɹ, tɛlɪŋ ðə meɪɾənz tə əlaʊ noʊ wʌn tə ɛntɝ. oʊnli nændɛɹə wɑz əlaʊd pæs ðə dɔɹz wɪð ðə ɡɪldɪd sʌnz, bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪz milz. ðə sɪnjui meɪɾən wəd sɛt daʊn ə kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ ən lɪs ðoʊz u hæɾ æsk tə si hɪm, ðən ɡɪv ɪm ə lʊk ə ɹibjuk wən i ɹɪpiɾɪd ðəɾ i wəd si noʊ wʌn. ɔfən i hɝd dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ kɑmɛns fɹəm ðə meɪɾənz aʊtsaɪd bɪfɔɹ ʃi pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ; hi wɑz ɪntɛndəd tə hɪɹ, ɛls ðeɪ wʊɾə juz hæntɔk. bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ θɔt tə tʃɪvi hɪm aʊt baɪ kleɪmɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz sʌlkɪŋ. . . . ðə meɪɾənz dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, ən maɪt nɑɾ ɪf i ɪkspleɪnd. ɪf i cʊɾə bɹɔt hɪmsɛlf tə.

The days after sending Perrin away seemed endless to Rand, and the nights longer. He retreated to his rooms and stayed there, telling the Maidens to allow no one to enter. Only Nandera was allowed past the doors with the gilded suns, bringing his meals. The sinewy Maiden would set down a covered tray and list those who had asked to see him, then give him a look of rebuke when he repeated that he would see no one. Often he heard disapproving comments from the Maidens outside before she pulled the door shut behind her; he was intended to hear, else they would have used handtalk. But if they thought to chivy him out by claiming that he was sulking. . . . The Maidens did not understand, and might not if he explained. If he could have brought himself to.

hi pɪkt ət ðə milz wɪθaʊɾ æpətaɪt, ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹid, bʌɾ ɪz feɪvɹɪt bʊks kəd daɪvɝɾ ɪm fəɹ oʊnli ə fju peɪdʒəz ivən ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ət list wʌns ɛvɹi deɪ, ðoʊ hi hæd pɹɑməs hɪmsɛlf i wəd nɑt, hi lɪftəd ðə mæsɪv wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ə pɑlɪʃt blækwʊɾ ən aɪvɝi ɪn ɪz bɛd-tʃeɪmbɝ, floʊɾəd ɪɾ əsaɪɾ ɑn floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ən kɛɹfəli ənɹævəl ðə tʃɹæps i hæd sɛɾ ən ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts ðət meɪd ðə wɔl sim smuð, ɔl ɪnvɝɾɪd soʊ noʊ ʌðɝ aɪz bʌɾ ɪz kəd si. ðɛɹ, ɪn ə nɪtʃ hɑloʊɾ aʊt wɪð ðə paʊɝ, stʊd tu smɔl stætʃuz ʌv waɪt stoʊn əbaʊɾ ə fʊt tɔl, ə wʊmən ən ə mæn, itʃ ɪn floʊɪŋ ɹoʊbz ən hoʊldɪŋ ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ oʊvɝhɛɾ ɪn wʌn hænd. ðə naɪɾ i sɛt ði ɑɹmi ɪn moʊʃən təwɔɹɾ ɪljən i hæd ɡɔn tə ɹɪɾiən əloʊn tə fɛtʃ ðiz tɛɹæŋɡɹil: ɪf i niɾəd ðɛm, hi maɪt nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ taɪm. ðət wɑz wʌɾ i hæd toʊl hɪmsɛlf. hɪz hænd wəd stʃɹɛtʃ təwɔɹd ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn, ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðə pɛɹ ə mæn kəd juz, stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɾ ən stɑp, ʃeɪkɪŋ. wʌn fɪŋɡɝ tʌtʃɪŋ, ən mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən i kəɾ ɪmædʒən kəd bi hɪz. wɪð ðæt, noʊ wʌn kəd dɪfit hɪm, noʊ wʌn stæn əɡɛns hɪm. wɪð ðæt, lænfɝ hæd sɛd wʌns, hi kəd tʃælənʒ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ.

He picked at the meals without appetite, and tried to read, but his favorite books could divert him for only a few pages even in the beginning. At least once every day, though he had promised himself he would not, he lifted the massive wardrobe of polished blackwood and ivory in his bed-chamber, floated it aside on flows of Air and carefully unraveled the traps he had set and the Mirror of Mists that made the wall seem smooth, all inverted so no other eyes but his could see. There, in a niche hollowed out with the Power, stood two small statues of white stone about a foot tall, a woman and a man, each in flowing robes and holding a clear crystal sphere overhead in one hand. The night he set the army in motion toward Illian he had gone to Rhuidean alone to fetch these ter'angreal: if he needed them, he might not have much time. That was what he had told himself. His hand would stretch toward the bearded man, the only one of the pair a man could use, stretch out and stop, shaking. One finger touching, and more of the One Power than he could imagine could be his. With that, no one could defeat him, no one stand against him. With that, Lanfear had said once, he could challenge the Creator.

"ɪɾ ɪz maɪn baɪ ɹaɪt," hi mʌɾɝd itʃ taɪm, wɪð ɪz hæn tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə fɪɡjɝ. "maɪn! aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!"

"It is mine by right," he muttered each time, with his hand trembling just short of the figure. "Mine! I am the Dragon Reborn!"

ən itʃ taɪm i meɪd hɪmsɛlf dʒɹɔ bæk, ɹiivɪŋ ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts, ɹiivɪŋ ði ɪnvɪzəbəl tʃɹæps ðət wəd bɝn ɛniwʌn tə ə sɪndɝ u tʃɹaɪd tə pæs əm wɪθaʊt ðə ki. ðə hjudʒ wɔɹdʒɹoʊb wɑftɪd bæk ɪndə pleɪs laɪk ə fɛðɝ. hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bʌt wɑz ðəɾ ɪnʌf? ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi.

And each time he made himself draw back, reweaving the Mirror of Mists, reweaving the invisible traps that would burn anyone to a cinder who tried to pass them without the key. The huge wardrobe wafted back into place like a feather. He was the Dragon Reborn. But was that enough? It would have to be.

"aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi wɪspɝɾ ət ðə wɔlz səmtaɪmz, ən səmtaɪmz ʃaʊɾəd ət ðɛm. "aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" saɪlənli ən əlaʊɾ i ɹeɪdʒd ət ðoʊz u əpoʊz hɪm, ðə blaɪn fulz u kəd nɑt si ən ðoʊz u ɹəfjuz tə si, fəɹ æmbɪʃən əɹ ævɝəs əɹ fɪɹ. hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ði oʊnli hoʊp ə ðə wɝld əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ən ðə laɪt hɛlp ðə wɝl fəɹ ɪt.

"I am the Dragon Reborn," he whispered at the walls sometimes, and sometimes shouted at them. "I am the Dragon Reborn!" Silently and aloud he raged at those who opposed him, the blind fools who could not see and those who refused to see, for ambition or avarice or fear. He was the Dragon Reborn, the only hope of the world against the Dark One. And the Light help the world for it.

bʌɾ ɪz ɹeɪdʒɪz ən θɔts ə juzɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝ oʊnli ətɛmps tə ɪskeɪp ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ən i nu ɪt. əloʊn, hi pɪkt əɾ ɪz milz, ðoʊ lɛs ɛvɹi deɪ, ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹid, ðoʊ sɛldəm, ən ətɛmptəd tə faɪn slip. ðəɾ i tʃɹaɪd mɔɹ ɔfən əz ðə deɪz pæst, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wɛðɝ ðə sʌn wɑz daʊn əɹ haɪ. slip keɪm ɪn fɪtfəl snætʃɪz, ən wʌt hɛɹɹoʊɾ ɪz weɪkɪŋ θɔts ɔlsoʊ stɔkt ɪz dʒɹimz ən tʃeɪst ɪm əweɪk tu sun fəɹ ɛni ɹɛst. noʊ əmaʊn ə ʃildɪŋ kəd kip aʊt wʌt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪnsaɪd. hi hæd ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə feɪs, ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf. hi hæd fulz u fɔɾ ɪm əɹ ɹæn əweɪ wən ðɛɹ oʊnli hoʊp wɑz tə stæn bɪhaɪn hɪm. waɪ wəɾ ɪz dʒɹimz nɑt lɛɾ ɪm bi? fɹəm wʌn dʒɹim i ɔlweɪz spɹæŋ əweɪk bɪfɔɹ ɪt mɔɹ ðən bɪɡæn, tə laɪ ðəɹ fɪld wɪð sɛlf-loʊθɪŋ ən mʌɾəld wɪð læk ə slip, bʌt ði ʌðɝz. . . . hi dɪzɝvd əm ɔl, hi nu.

But his rages and thoughts of using the ter'angreal were only attempts to escape other things, and he knew it. Alone, he picked at his meals, though less every day, and tried to read, though seldom, and attempted to find sleep. That he tried more often as the days passed, not caring whether the sun was down or high. Sleep came in fitful snatches, and what harrowed his waking thoughts also stalked his dreams and chased him awake too soon for any rest. No amount of shielding could keep out what was already inside. He had the Forsaken to face, and sooner or later the Dark One himself. He had fools who fought him or ran away when their only hope was to stand behind him. Why would his dreams not let him be? From one dream he always sprang awake before it more than began, to lie there filled with self-loathing and muddled with lack of sleep, but the others. . . . He deserved them all, he knew.

koʊləveɪɪɹ kənfɹʌntəɾ ɪm slipɪŋ, hɝ feɪs blæk ən ðə skɑɹf ʃi hæd juz tə hæŋ hɝsɛlf stɪl bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə swoʊlən flɛʃ ə hɝ nɛk. koʊləveɪɪɹ, saɪlən ən əkjuzɪŋ, wɪð ɔl ðə meɪɾənz u hæd daɪd fəɹ ɪm ɝeɪd bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn saɪlən stɛɹɪŋ ɹæŋks, ɔl ðə wɪmən u daɪd kəz ə hɪm. hi nu ɛvɹi feɪs əz wɛl əz ɪz oʊn, ən ɛvɹi neɪm bʌt wʌn. fɹəm ðoʊz dʒɹimz, hi woʊk wipɪŋ.

Colavaere confronted him sleeping, her face black and the scarf she had used to hang herself still buried in the swollen flesh of her neck. Colavaere, silent and accusing, with all the Maidens who had died for him arrayed behind her in silent staring ranks, all the women who died because of him. He knew every face as well as his own, and every name but one. From those dreams, he woke weeping.

ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz i hɝl pɛɹɪn əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹæn hɔl ə ðə sʌn, ən ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz i wɑz oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ bleɪzɪŋ fɪɹ ən ɹeɪdʒ. ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz, hi kɪl pɛɹɪn ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz ən woʊk tə hɪz oʊn skɹimz. waɪ hæd ðə mæn tʃoʊzən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹɪznɝz tə juz fəɹ ðɛɹ ɑɹɡjəmənt? ɹænd tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðɛm; hi hæd dʌn ɪz bɛs tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ tu deɪnʒɝəs tə kip lɔŋ əz kæptɪvz, ən i hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt tə də wɪð ðɛm. ðeɪ fɹaɪɾənd hɪm. səmtaɪmz i dʒɹimd ə biɪŋ baʊn ɪnsaɪd ðə bɑks əɡɛn, ʌv ɡəlinə ən ɛɹiən ən keɪɾɝin ən ðə ɹɛs teɪkɪŋ ɪm aʊt tə bit hɪm, dʒɹimd ən woʊk wɪmpɝɪŋ ivən æftɝ i kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ɪz aɪz wɝ oʊpən ən i wɑz aʊtsaɪd. ðeɪ fɹaɪɾənd ɪm kəz i fɪɹɾ i maɪt ɡɪv weɪ tə ðə fɪɹ ən ði æŋɡɝ, ən ðɛn. . . . hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌɾ i maɪt də ðɛn, bʌt səmtaɪmz i dʒɹimd ɪt, ən woʊk ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪn ə koʊl swɛt. hi wəd nɑt də ðæt. wʌtɛvɝ i hæd dʌn, hi wəd nɑt də ðæt.

A hundred times he hurled Perrin across the Grand Hall of the Sun, and a hundred times he was overwhelmed by blazing fear and rage. A hundred times, he killed Perrin in his dreams and woke to his own screams. Why had the man chosen the Aes Sedai prisoners to use for their argument? Rand tried not to think about them; he had done his best to ignore their existence from the beginning. They were too dangerous to keep long as captives, and he had no idea what to do with them. They frightened him. Sometimes he dreamed of being bound inside the box again, of Galina and Erian and Katerine and the rest taking him out to beat him, dreamed and woke whimpering even after he convinced himself his eyes were open and he was outside. They frightened him because he feared he might give way to the fear and the anger, and then. . . . He tried not to think of what he might do then, but sometimes he dreamed it, and woke shaking in a cold sweat. He would not do that. Whatever he had done, he would not do that.

ɪn dʒɹimz i ɡæðɝd ði æʃəmən tə ətæk ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən pʌnɪʃ ɪleɪɾə; hi lɛp fɹəm ə ɡeɪtweɪ fɪld wɪð ɹaɪtʃəs æŋɡɝ ən seɪɾɪn - ən lɝn ðəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪnz lɛɾɝ hæd bɪn ə laɪ, sɔ hɝ stæn əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪleɪɾə, sɔ ɛɡwin bɪsaɪd hɝ, tu, ən nɪneɪiv, ən ivən ɪleɪn, ɔl wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz, kəz i wɑz tu deɪnʒɝəs tə lɛt ɹʌn fɹi. hi wɑtʃt ði æʃəmən dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ wɪmən u hæd jɪɹz ə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, nɑt dʒʌst ə fju mʌnθs ə hɑɹʃ tuɾɝɪŋ, ən fɹəm ðoʊz dʒɹimz, hi kəd nɛvɝ weɪk əntɪl ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt wɑz dɛd, ən i stʊɾ əloʊn tə feɪs ðə maɪɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. əloʊn.

In dreams he gathered the Asha'man to attack the White Tower and punish Elaida; he leaped from a gateway filled with righteous anger and saidin - and learned that Alviarin's letter had been a lie, saw her stand alongside Elaida, saw Egwene beside her, too, and Nynaeve, and even Elayne, all with Aes Sedai faces, because he was too dangerous to let run free. He watched the Asha'man destroyed by women who had years of studying the One Power behind them, not just a few months of harsh tutoring, and from those dreams, he could never wake until every man in a black coat was dead, and he stood alone to face the might of the Aes Sedai. Alone.

əɡɛn ən əɡɛn kædzueɪn spoʊk ðoʊz wɝdz əbaʊt mædmən hɪɹɪŋ vɔɪsəz, tɪl i flɪntʃt əɾ əm əz ət bloʊz ʌv ə wɪp, flɪntʃt ɪn ɪz slip wən ʃi əpɪɹd. ɪn dʒɹimz ən weɪkɪŋ, hi kɔl tə luz θɝɪn, ʃaʊɾəd ət hɪm, skɹim fəɹ hɪm, ən oʊnli saɪləns ænsɝd. əloʊn. ðət smɔl bʌndəl ə sɛnseɪʃənz ən ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd, ðə sɛns ʌv ɑlɑnəz ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃ, sloʊli bɪkeɪm ə kʌmfɝt. ɪn mɛni weɪz, ðət fɹaɪɾənd ɪm moʊst ʌv ɔl.

Again and again Cadsuane spoke those words about madmen hearing voices, till he flinched at them as at blows of a whip, flinched in his sleep when she appeared.
