In dreams and waking, he called to Lews Therin, shouted at him, screamed for him, and only silence answered. Alone. That small bundle of sensations and emotions in the back of his head, the sense of Alanna's almost touch, slowly became a comfort. In many ways, that frightened him most of all.

ɑn ðə fɔɹθ mɔɹnɪŋ, hi woʊk ɡɹɑdʒəli fɹəm ə dʒɹim ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, flɪŋɪŋ ʌp ə hæn tə ʃild ɡɹeɪni aɪz fɹəm wʌɾ i θɔt wɑz ə flɛɹ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ-ɹɔt faɪɝ. dʌs moʊts spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ tə ɹitʃ ɪz bɛd, wɪð ɪts ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ blækwʊd bɪdpoʊsts ɪnleɪd wɪð aɪvɝi wɛdʒəz. ɛvɹi pis ə fɝnɪʃɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz pɑlɪʃt blækwʊɾ ən aɪvɝi, skwɛɹ ən stɑɹk ən hɛvi ɪnʌf tə suɾ ɪz mud. fəɹ ə moʊmən i leɪ ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪf slip ɹɪtɝnd, ɪt wəɾ oʊnli bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ dʒɹim.

On the fourth morning, he woke groggily from a dream of the White Tower, flinging up a hand to shield grainy eyes from what he thought was a flare of saidar-wrought fire. Dust motes sparkled in the sunlight streaming through the window to reach his bed, with its great square blackwood bedposts inlaid with ivory wedges. Every piece of furnishing in the room was polished blackwood and ivory, square and stark and heavy enough to suit his mood. For a moment he lay there, but if sleep returned, it would only bring another dream.

ɑɹ jə ðɛɹ, luz θɝɪn? hi θɔt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni hoʊp ʌv ænsɝ, ən wɛɹəli pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz ɹɪŋkəl koʊt stʃɹeɪt. hi hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ɪz kloʊðz sɪns fɝst ʃʌɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əweɪ.

Are you there, Lews Therin? he thought without any hope of answer, and wearily pushed himself to his feet, tugging his wrinkled coat straight. He had not changed his clothes since first shutting himself away.

wən i stæɡɝɾ ɪndə ði æntəɹum, ət fɝst i θɔɾ i wɑz dʒɹimɪŋ əɡɛn, ðə dʒɹim ðəɾ ɔlweɪz woʊk ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ɔf ɪn ʃeɪm ən ɡɪlt ən loʊθɪŋ, bʌt mɪn lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tɔl ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹz, ə lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊk ɑn əɹ niz, ən i dɪd nɑt weɪk. dɑɹk ɹɪŋləts fɹeɪmd əɹ feɪs, bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz soʊ ɪntɛn i ɔlmoʊs fɛlt əɹ tʌtʃ. hɝ bɹitʃɪz ə bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɡɹin sɪlk fɪɾ əɹ laɪk ə sɛkən skɪn, ən əɹ koʊɾ ə mætʃɪŋ sɪlk hʌŋ oʊpən, ə kɹim-kʌlɝd blaʊs ɹaɪzɪŋ ən fɔlɪŋ wɪð əɹ bɹɛθ. hi pɹeɪd tə weɪk. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn fɪɹ, əɹ æŋɡɝ, əɹ ɡɪlt oʊvɝ koʊləveɪɪɹ, əɹ luz θɝɪnz dɪsəpɪɹəns ðət dʒɹoʊv ɪm tə ʃʌt hɪmsɛlf əweɪ.

When he staggered into the anteroom, at first he thought he was dreaming again, the dream that always woke him straight off in shame and guilt and loathing, but Min looked up at him from one of the tall gilded chairs, a leather-bound book on her knees, and he did not wake. Dark ringlets framed her face, big dark eyes so intent he almost felt her touch. Her breeches of brocaded green silk fit her like a second skin, and her coat of matching silk hung open, a cream-colored blouse rising and falling with her breath. He prayed to wake. It had not been fear, or anger, or guilt over Colavaere, or Lews Therin's disappearance that drove him to shut himself away.

"ðɛɹz ə fist ə sɔɹts ɪn fɔɹ deɪz," ʃi sɛd bɹaɪtli, "æt ðə hæf mun. ðə deɪ ʌv ɹɪpɛntəns, ðeɪ kɔl ɪt fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt ðəɹ wɪl bi dænsɪŋ ðət naɪt. sɪdeɪt dænsɪŋ, aɪ hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɛni dænsɪŋ ɪz bɛɾɝ ðən nʌn." kɛɹfəli tʌkɪŋ ə θɪn stʃɹɪp ə lɛðɝ ɪndə ðə bʊk, ʃi pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪd hɝ. "ðæts dʒʌs taɪm tə hæv ə dʒɹɛs meɪd, ɪf aɪ sɛt ðə simstʃɹɪs tə wɝk tədeɪ. ðəɾ ɪz, ɪf jə min tə dæns wɪð mi."

"There's a feast of sorts in four days," she said brightly, "at the half moon. The Day of Repentance, they call it for some reason, but there will be dancing that night. Sedate dancing, I hear, but any dancing is better than none." Carefully tucking a thin strip of leather into the book, she placed it on the floor beside her. "That's just time to have a dress made, if I set the seamstress to work today. That is, if you mean to dance with me."

hi pʊld ɪz ɡeɪz əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, ən ɪt fɛl ɑn ə klɔθ-kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ bɪsaɪd ðə tɔl dɔɹz. dʒʌs ðə θɔɾ ə fud meɪɾ ɪm kwizi. nændɛɹə wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɪn, bɝn hɝ! list ʌv ɔl mɪn. hi hæd nɑt mɛnʃən əɹ baɪ neɪm, bʌɾ i hæd sɛd noʊ wʌn! "mɪn, aɪ - aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ. aɪ - "

He pulled his gaze away from her, and it fell on a cloth-covered tray beside the tall doors. Just the thought of food made him queasy. Nandera was not supposed to let anyone in, burn her! Least of all Min. He had not mentioned her by name, but he had said no one! "Min, I - I don't know what to say. I - "

"ʃifɝɾɝ, jə lʊk laɪk wʌt ðə dɑɡz fɔɾ oʊvɝ. naʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ɑlɑnə wɑz soʊ fɹæntɪk, ivən ɪf aɪ doʊn si haʊ ʃi nu. ʃi pɹæktəkli bɛɡd mi tə spik tə ju, æftɝ ðə meɪɾənz tɝn əɹ əweɪ fəɹ əbaʊt ðə fɪfθ taɪm. nændɛɹə wʊdn əv lemi ɪn ɪf ʃi wɑzn ɪn ə læðɝ əbaʊt jə nɑɾ iɾɪŋ, ən ivən soʊ, aɪ hæd tə də ə lɪɾəl bɛɡɪŋ maɪsɛlf. jə oʊ mi, kʌntʃɹi bɔɪ."

"Sheepherder, you look like what the dogs fought over. Now I understand why Alanna was so frantic, even if I don't see how she knew. She practically begged me to speak to you, after the Maidens turned her away for about the fifth time. Nandera wouldn't have let me in if she wasn't in a lather about you not eating, and even so, I had to do a little begging myself. You owe me, country boy."

ɹænd flɪntʃt. ɪmədʒəz ə hɪmsɛlf flæʃt ɪn ɪz hɛd; hɪm tɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ kloʊðz, fɔɹsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn əɹ laɪk ə maɪnləs bist. hi oʊɾ əɹ mɔɹ ðən i kəɾ ɛvɝ peɪ. ɹeɪkɪŋ ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf tɝn tə feɪs hɝ. ʃi hæd tʌkt əɹ fiɾ ʌp soʊ ʃi sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, linɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ niz. haʊ kəd ʃi lʊk əɾ ɪm soʊ kɑmli? "mɪn, ðɛɹz noʊ ɪkskjus fəɹ wʌɾ aɪ dɪd. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni dʒʌstəs, aɪd ɡoʊ tə ðə ɡæloʊz. ɪf aɪ kʊd, aɪd pʊt ðə ɹoʊp ɝaʊn maɪ nɛk maɪsɛlf. ɑn oʊθ, aɪ wʊd." ðə wɝdz teɪstəd bɪɾɝ. hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ʃi wəɾ əv tə weɪɾ ɑn dʒʌstəs əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl. wʌɾ ə ful i hæd bɪn tə wɑnə lɪv pæs tɑɹmən ɡdən. hi dɪd nɑt dɪzɝv tə.

Rand flinched. Images of himself flashed in his head; him tearing at her clothes, forcing himself on her like a mindless beast. He owed her more than he could ever pay. Raking a hand through his hair, he made himself turn to face her. She had tucked her feet up so she sat cross-legged in the chair, leaning her fists on her knees. How could she look at him so calmly? "Min, there's no excuse for what I did. If there was any justice, I'd go to the gallows. If I could, I'd put the rope around my neck myself. On oath, I would." The words tasted bitter. He was the Dragon Reborn, and she would have to wait on justice until the Last Battle. What a fool he had been to want to live past Tarmon Gai'don. He did not deserve to.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, ʃifɝɾɝ?" ʃi sɛd sloʊli.

"What are you talking about, sheepherder?" she said slowly.

"aɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌɾ aɪ dɪd tə ju," hi ɡɹoʊnd. haʊ kəɾ i hæv dʌn ðæt, tə ɛniwʌn, bʌt moʊst ʌv ɔl tə hɝ? "mɪn, aɪ noʊ haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪts fəɹ jə tə bi ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum wɪð mi." haʊ kəɾ i ɹikɔl ðə sɑft fil ə hɝ soʊ, ðə sɪlkənəs ə hɝ skɪn? æftɝ i hæd tɔɹn əɹ kloʊðz ɔf. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ən ænəməl, ə mɑnstɝ." bʌɾ i wɑz. hi loʊð hɪmsɛlf fəɹ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. ən loʊð hɪmsɛlf wɝs kəz i wɑntəd tə də ɪɾ əɡɛn. "ði oʊnli ɪkskjus aɪ hæv ɪz mædnəs. kædzueɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. aɪ dɪd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz. luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs, aɪ θɔt. kən jə - ? noʊ. noʊ, aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə æsk jə tə fɝɡɪv mi. bʌt juv tə noʊ haʊ sɑɹi aɪ æm, mɪn." hi wɑz sɑɹi. ən ɪz hænz ætʃt tə ɹʌn daʊn əɹ bɛɹ bæk, oʊvɝ əɹ hɪps. hi wɑz ə mɑnstɝ. "bɪɾɝli sɑɹi. ət lis noʊ ðæt."

"I'm talking about what I did to you," he groaned. How could he have done that, to anyone, but most of all to her? "Min, I know how hard it is for you to be in the same room with me." How could he recall the soft feel of her so, the silkiness of her skin? After he had torn her clothes off. "I never thought I was an animal, a monster." But he was. He loathed himself for what he had done. And loathed himself worse because he wanted to do it again. "The only excuse I have is madness. Cadsuane was right. I did hear voices. Lews Therin's voice, I thought. Can you - ? No. No, I have no right to ask you to forgive me. But you have to know how sorry I am, Min." He was sorry. And his hands ached to run down her bare back, over her hips. He was a monster. "Bitterly sorry. At least know that."

ʃi sæt ðəɹ moʊʃənləs, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hæd sin ɪz laɪk. naʊ, ʃi kəd stɑp pɹitɛndɪŋ. naʊ, ʃi kəd seɪ wʌt ʃi ɹɪli θɔɾ ə hɪm, ən haʊɛvɝ vaɪl ɪt wɑz, ɪt wəd nɑt bi hæf vaɪl ɪnʌf.

She sat there motionless, staring at him as if she never before had seen his like. Now, she could stop pretending. Now, she could say what she really thought of him, and however vile it was, it would not be half vile enough.

"soʊ ðæts waɪ juv bɪn kipɪŋ mi əweɪ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ju lɪsən tə mi, jə wʊɾən-hɛdəd nʌmskʌl. aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə kɹaɪ maɪsɛlf tə dʌs kəz aɪd sin wʌn dɛθ tu mɛni, ən ju, jə wɝ əbaʊt tə də ðə seɪm fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən. wʌt wi dɪd, maɪ ɪnəsən læm, wɑz kʌmfɝt wʌn ənʌðɝ. fɹɛnz kʌmfɝt wʌn ənʌðɝ ət taɪmz laɪk ðæt. kloʊs jəɹ maʊθ, jə tu ɹɪvɝz heɪ-hɛɹ."

"So that's why you've been keeping me away," she said finally. "You listen to me, you wooden-headed numbskull. I was ready to cry myself to dust because I'd seen one death too many, and you, you were about to do the same for the same reason. What we did, my innocent lamb, was comfort one another. Friends comfort one another at times like that. Close your mouth, you Two Rivers hay-hair."

hi dɪd, bʌɾ oʊnli tə swɑloʊ. hi θɔɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ gɑnə fɔl ɑntu ðə flɔɹstoʊnz. hi nɪɹli spləɾɝd ɡɛɾɪŋ wɝdz aʊt. "kʌmfɝɾɪd? mɪn, ɪf ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm hɝd wʌt wi dɪd kɔl kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, ðeɪd bi laɪnɪŋ ʌp tə pil əɹ haɪdz ɪf wi wɝ fɪfti!"

He did, but only to swallow. He thought his eyes were going to fall onto the floorstones. He nearly spluttered getting words out. "Comforted? Min, if the Women's Circle back home heard what we did called comforting, they'd be lining up to peel our hides if we were fifty!"

"æt list ɪts 'wi,' naʊ, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv 'aɪ,' " ʃi sɛd ɡɹɪmli. ɹaɪzɪŋ smuðli, ʃi ədvæns təwɔɹɾ ɪm ʃeɪkɪŋ ə fjʊɹiəs fɪŋɡɝ. "du jə θɪŋk ɪm ə dɑl, fɑɹmbɔɪ? dʒju θɪŋk aɪm tu dɪmwɪɾɪd tə lɛt jə noʊ ɪf aɪ dɪdnt wɑn jəɹ tʌtʃ? dʒju θɪŋk aɪ kʊdn lɛt jə noʊ ɪn noʊ ənsɝɾən tɝmz?" hɝ fɹi hæn pɹədust ə naɪf fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ koʊt, ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə flɝɪʃ ən tʌkt ɪt bæk wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ ðə tɔɹənt. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɹɪpɪŋ jəɹ ʃɝɾ ɔf jəɹ bæk kəz jə kʊdn pʊl ɪɾ oʊvɝ jəɹ hɛd fæst ɪnʌf tə sut mi. ðæts haʊ lɪɾəl aɪ wɑntəd jəɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn mi! aɪ dɪd wɪð jə wʌɾ aɪv nɛvɝ dʌn wɪð ɛni mæn - ən doʊn jə θɪŋk aɪ wɑz nɛvɝ tɛmptəd! - ən jə seɪ ɪt wɑz ɔl ju! əz ɪf aɪ wɑzn ivən ðɛɹ!"

"At least it's 'we,' now, instead of 'I,' " she said grimly. Rising smoothly, she advanced toward him shaking a furious finger. "Do you think I'm a doll, farmboy? Do you think I am too dimwitted to let you know if I didn't want your touch? Do you think I couldn't let you know in no uncertain terms?" Her free hand produced a knife from under her coat, gave it a flourish and tucked it back without slowing the torrent. "I remember ripping your shirt off your back because you couldn't pull it over your head fast enough to suit me. That's how little I wanted your arms around me! I did with you what I've never done with any man - and don't you think I was never tempted! - and you say it was all you! As if I wasn't even there!"

ðə bæk ə hɪz lɛɡz hɪɾ ə tʃɛɹ, ən i ɹilaɪzd i hæd bɪn bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. fɹaʊnɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm, ʃi mʌɾɝd, "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ laɪk jə lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət mi ɹaɪt naʊ." əbɹʌpli ʃi kɪkt ɪm hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə ʃɪn, plæntəd boʊθ hænz ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ən ʃʌvd. hi tɑpəld ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪt nɪɹli wɛn oʊvɝ bækwɝd. ɹɪŋləts sweɪɾ əz ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ hɛɾ ə tɔs ən ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd koʊt.

The back of his legs hit a chair, and he realized he had been backing away from her. Frowning up at him, she muttered, "I don't think I like you looking down at me right now." Abruptly she kicked him hard on the shin, planted both hands on his chest, and shoved. He toppled into the chair so hard it nearly went over backward. Ringlets swayed as she gave her head a toss and adjusted her brocaded coat.

"ðæts əz meɪ bi, mɪn, bʌt - "

"That's as may be, Min, but - "

"ðæts əz ɪz, ʃifɝɾɝ," ʃi kʌɾ ɪn fɝmli, "æn ɪf jə seɪ dɪfɹən əɡɛn, jə hæd bɛst ʃaʊt fəɹ ðə meɪɾənz ən tʃænəl fəɹ ɔl jəɹ wɝθ, kəz əl θʌmp jə ɝaʊn ðɪs ɹum tɪl jə skwil fəɹ mɝsi. jə niɾ ə ʃeɪv. ən ə bæθ."

"That's as is, sheepherder," she cut in firmly, "and if you say different again, you had best shout for the Maidens and channel for all you're worth, because I'll thump you around this room till you squeal for mercy. You need a shave. And a bath."

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. pɛɹɪn hæd sətʃ ə sɝin mɛɹɪdʒ, wɪð ə smaɪlɪŋ, dʒɛntəl waɪf. waɪ wɑz ɪt ðəɾ i ɔlweɪz sim dʒɹɔn tə wɪmən u spʌn ɪz hɛd laɪk ə tɑp? ɪf oʊnli hi nu ðə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt mæt dɪɾ əbaʊt wɪmən, hi wʊɾə noʊn wʌt tə seɪ tə ɔl ðæt, bʌɾ əz ɪt wɑz, ɔl i kəd də wɑz blʌndɝ ɑn. "ɪn ɛni keɪs," hi sɛd kɔʃəsli, "ðɛɹz oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ aɪ kən du."

Rand took a deep breath. Perrin had such a serene marriage, with a smiling, gentle wife. Why was it that he always seemed drawn to women who spun his head like a top? If only he knew the tenth part of what Mat did about women, he would have known what to say to all that, but as it was, all he could do was blunder on. "In any case," he said cautiously, "there's only one thing I can do."

"ænd wʌt maɪt ðət bi?" ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz taɪt bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən əɹ fʊt bɪɡæn tæpɪŋ ɑmənəsli, bʌɾ i nu ðɪs wɑz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du.

"And what might that be?" She folded her arms tight beneath her breasts, and her foot began tapping ominously, but he knew this was the right thing to do.

"sɛn jə əweɪ." dʒʌst əz i hæɾ ɪleɪn, ən eɪvinhə. "ɪf aɪ hæɾ ɛni sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl, aɪ wʊdn əv - " ðət fʊt stɑɹɾəd tæpɪŋ fæstɝ. meɪbi bɛɾɝ tə liv ðəɾ əloʊn. kʌmfɝɾɪd? laɪt! "mɪn, ɛniwʌn kloʊs tə mi ɪz ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹən ði oʊnli wʌnz u wəd hɑɹm sʌmbɑɾi nɪɹ mi dʒʌst ɑn ðə tʃæns ɪt maɪt hɑɹm mi, tu. ən naʊ ðɛɹz mi, əz wɛl. aɪ kæn kəntʃɹoʊl maɪ tɛmpɝ ɛnimɔɹ. mɪn, aɪ nɪɹli kɪl pɛɹɪn! kædzueɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. ɪm ɡoʊɪŋ mæd, əɹ ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi. aɪ hæv tə sɛn jə əweɪ soʊ jəl bi seɪf."

"Send you away." Just as he had Elayne, and Aviendha. "If I had any self-control, I wouldn't have - " That foot started tapping faster. Maybe better to leave that alone. Comforted? Light! "Min, anyone close to me is in danger. The Forsaken aren't the only ones who would harm somebody near me just on the chance it might harm me, too. And now there's me, as well. I can't control my temper anymore. Min, I nearly killed Perrin! Cadsuane was right. I'm going mad, or there already. I have to send you away so you'll be safe."

"hu ɪz ðɪs kædzueɪn?" ʃi sɛd, soʊ kɑmli ðəɾ i ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðəɾ əɹ fʊt wɑz stɪl tæpɪŋ. "ɑlɑnə mɛnʃən ðət neɪm əz ɪf ʃi wɑz ðə kɹieɪɾɝz sɪstɝ. noʊ, doʊn tɛl mi; aɪ doʊn kɛɹ." nɑt ðət ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm wʌn hɛɹ ʌv ə ɡæp tə tɛl ɛniθɪŋ. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊt pɛɹɪn, iðɝ. jə wəd hɝt mi əz sun əz hɪm. aɪ θɪŋk ðət ɡɹeɪt pʌblɪk faɪɾ ə jʊɹz wɑz ə feɪk, ɪz wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊt jəɹ tɛmpɝ, ən aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wɛðɝ jəɹ mæd. jə kæn bi vɛɹi mæd, əɹ jud nɑt bi wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt soʊ. wʌɾ aɪ də kɛɹ əbaʊt. . . ."

"Who is this Cadsuane?" she said, so calmly that he gave a start at noticing that her foot was still tapping. "Alanna mentioned that name as if she was the Creator's sister. No, don't tell me; I don't care." Not that she gave him one hair of a gap to tell anything. "I don't care about Perrin, either. You would hurt me as soon as him. I think that great public fight of yours was a fake, is what I think. I don't care about your temper, and I don't care whether you're mad. You can't be very mad, or you'd not be worrying about it so. What I do care about. . . ."

ʃi bɛn əntɪl ðoʊz vɛɹi bɪɡ, vɛɹi dɑɹk aɪz wɝ lɛvəl wɪð hɪz, nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dɪstəns əweɪ, ən sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ə laɪt ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɪn əm ðəɾ i siz seɪɾɪn, ɹɛɾi tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf. "sɛn mi əweɪ tə bi seɪf?" ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "haʊ dɛɹ ju? wʌt ɹaɪt dʒju θɪŋk juv tə sɛn mi ɛniwɛɹ? jə nid mi, ɹænd ælθɹ! ɪf aɪ toʊl jə hæf ðə vjuɪŋz aɪv hæɾ əbaʊt ju, hæf jəɹ hɛɹ wəd kɝl ən ðə ɹɛs fɔl aʊt! jə dɛɹ! jə lɛt ðə meɪɾənz feɪs ɛni ɹɪsk ðeɪ wɑnt, ən jə wɑnə sɛn mi əweɪ laɪk ə tʃaɪld?"

She bent until those very big, very dark eyes were level with his, not a great distance away, and suddenly there was such a light glaring in them that he seized saidin, ready to defend himself. "Send me away to be safe?" she growled. "How dare you? What right do you think you have to send me anywhere? You need me, Rand al'Thor! If I told you half the viewings I've had about you, half your hair would curl and the rest fall out! You dare! You let the Maidens face any risk they want, and you want to send me away like a child?"

"aɪ doʊn lʌv ðə meɪɾənz." floʊɾɪŋ dip ɪn ði ɪmoʊʃənləs vɔɪd, hi hɝd ðoʊz wɝdz spɹɪŋ fɹəm ɪz tʌŋ, ən ʃɑk ʃæɾɝd ði ɛmptinəs ən sɛn seɪɾɪn flaɪɪŋ.

"I don't love the Maidens." Floating deep in the emotionless Void, he heard those words spring from his tongue, and shock shattered the emptiness and sent saidin flying.

"wɛl," mɪn sɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ. ə smɔl smaɪl æɾəd mɔɹ kɝv tə hɝ lɪps. "ðæts aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ." ən ʃi sæt daʊn ɑn ɪz læp.

"Well," Min said, straightening. A small smile added more curve to her lips. "That's out of the way." And she sat down on his lap.

ʃi hæd sɛɾ i wəd nɑt hɝt pɛɹɪn ɛni mɔɹ ðən i wəd hɝ, bʌɾ i hæd tə hɝɾ əɹ naʊ. hi hæd tə, fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɡʊd. "aɪ lʌv ɪleɪn, tu," hi sɛd bɹuɾəli. "æn eɪvinhə. jə si wʌɾ aɪ æm?" fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə feɪz əɹ əɾ ɔl.

She had said he would not hurt Perrin any more than he would her, but he had to hurt her now. He had to, for her own good. "I love Elayne, too," he said brutally. "And Aviendha. You see what I am?" For some reason, that did not seem to faze her at all.

"ɹəɑɹk lʌvz mɔɹ ðən wʌn wʊmən," ʃi sɛd. hɝ smaɪl simd ɔlmoʊst ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. "soʊ dʌz beɪl, ən aɪ nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ɛni tʃɹɑlɑks hɔɹnz ɑn iðɝ. noʊ, ɹænd, jə lʌv mi, ən jə kæn bæk aʊɾ ə ðæt. aɪ ɔt tə stʃɹɪŋ jə ʌp ɑn tɛntɝhʊks fəɹ wʌt juv pʊt mi θɹu, bʌt. . . . dʒʌst soʊ jəl noʊ, aɪ lʌv ju, tu." ðə smaɪl feɪɾəd ɪn ə fɹaʊn ʌv ɪntɝnəl stʃɹʌɡəl, ən faɪnəli ʃi saɪd. "laɪf wəd bi ə dil iziɝ səmtaɪmz ɪf maɪ æns hædn bɹɔt mi ʌp tə bi fɛɹ," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "æn tə bi fɛɹ, ɹænd, aɪ hæv tə tɛl jə ðəɾ ɪleɪn lʌvz ju, tu. soʊ dʌz eɪvinhə. ɪf boʊθ ə mændələnz waɪvz kən lʌv hɪm, aɪ səpoʊz θɹi wɪmən kən mænədʒ tə lʌv ju. bʌɾ aɪm hɪɹ, ən ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə sɛn mi əweɪ, əl taɪ maɪsɛlf tə jəɹ lɛɡ." hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋkəld. "wʌns jə stɑɹt beɪðɪŋ əɡɛn, ɛniweɪ. bʌɾ aɪ woʊnt ɡoʊ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt."

"Rhuarc loves more than one woman," she said. Her smile seemed almost of Aes Sedai serenity. "So does Bael, and I never noticed any Trolloc's horns on either. No, Rand, you love me, and you can't back out of that. I ought to string you up on tenterhooks for what you've put me through, but. . . . Just so you'll know, I love you, too." The smile faded in a frown of internal struggle, and finally she sighed. "Life would be a deal easier sometimes if my aunts hadn't brought me up to be fair," she muttered. "And to be fair, Rand, I have to tell you that Elayne loves you, too. So does Aviendha. If both of Mandelain's wives can love him, I suppose three women can manage to love you. But I'm here, and if you try to send me away, I'll tie myself to your leg." Her nose wrinkled. "Once you start bathing again, anyway. But I won't go, no matter what."

dʒʌst ɪɡzækli laɪk ə tɑp, hɪz hɛd spʌn. "ju - lʌv mi?" hi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "haʊ dʒju noʊ wʌɾ ɪleɪn filz? haʊ jə noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ eɪvinhə? laɪt! mændələn kən də wʌɾ i laɪks, mɪn; aɪm nɑɾ il." hi fɹaʊnd. "wʌt wɑz ðət jə sɛɾ əbaʊt tɛlɪŋ mi hæf ʌv wʌt jə si? aɪ θɔt jə toʊl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ən aɪm tu sɛndɪŋ jə sʌmwɛɹ seɪf. ən stɑp duɪŋ jəɹ noʊz laɪk ðæt! aɪ doʊn smɛl!" hi dʒɝk ðə hæn i hæd bɪn skɹætʃɪŋ wɪð fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt.

Just exactly like a top, his head spun. "You - love me?" he said incredulously. "How do you know what Elayne feels? How you know anything about Aviendha? Light! Mandelain can do what he likes, Min; I'm not Aiel." He frowned. "What was that you said about telling me half of what you see? I thought you told me everything. And I am too sending you somewhere safe. And stop doing your nose like that! I don't smell!" He jerked the hand he had been scratching with from under his coat.

hɝ ɑɹtʃt aɪbɹaʊ spoʊk vɑljumz, bʌɾ ə kɔɹs əɹ tʌŋ hæd tə hæv ɪts bɪt, tu. "ju dɛɹ teɪk ðət toʊn? laɪk jə doʊn bɪliv ɪt?" sʌɾənli hɝ vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz baɪ ðə wɝd, ən ʃi ɔɡjɝɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst əz ðoʊ ʃi mɛn tə dʒɹaɪv ɪt θɹu hɪm. "du jə θɪŋk aɪd ɡoʊ tə bɛd wɪð ə mæn aɪ dɪd nɑt lʌv? də ju? əɹ meɪbi jə θɪŋk jə ɑɹənt wɝθ lʌvɪŋ? ɪz ðəɾ ɪt?" ʃi meɪɾ ə saʊn laɪk ə stɛpt-ɑn kæt. "soʊ ɪm səm lɪɾəl bɪɾ ə flʌf wɪθaʊɾ ə bɹeɪn ɪn əɹ hɛd, fɔlɪŋ ɪn lʌv wɪð ə wɝθləs laʊt, æm aɪ? jə sɪt ðəɹ ɡeɪpɪŋ laɪk ə sɪk ɑks ən slændɝ maɪ wɪts, maɪ teɪst, maɪ - "

Her arched eyebrow spoke volumes, but of course her tongue had to have its bit, too. "You dare take that tone? Like you don't believe it?" Suddenly her voice began to rise by the word, and she augured a finger against his chest as though she meant to drive it through him. "Do you think I'd go to bed with a man I did not love? Do you? Or maybe you think you aren't worth loving? Is that it?" She made a sound like a stepped-on cat. "So I'm some little bit of fluff without a brain in her head, falling in love with a worthless lout, am I? You sit there gaping like a sick ox and slander my wits, my taste, my - "

"ɪf jə doʊn kwaɪət daʊn ən tɔk sɛns," hi ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ swɛɹ, əl smæk jəɹ bɑɾəm!" ðət lɛpt aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ, aʊɾ ə slipləs naɪts ən kənfjuʒən, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd bɪɡɪn tə fɔɹm ən əpɑlədʒi, ʃi smaɪld. ðə wʊmən smaɪld!

"If you don't quiet down and talk sense," he growled, "I swear, I'll smack your bottom!" That leaped out of nowhere, out of sleepless nights and confusion, but before he could begin to form an apology, she smiled. The woman smiled!

"æt lis jəɹ nɑt sʌlkɪŋ ɛnimɔɹ," ʃi sɛd. "doʊn ɛvɝ waɪn, ɹænd; jə ɑɹ noʊ ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪt. naʊ, ðɛn. jə wɑn sɛns? aɪ lʌv ju, ən əl nɑt ɡoʊ. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə sɛn mi əweɪ, əl tɛl ðə meɪɾənz jə ɹuən mi ən kæs mi əsaɪd. əl tɛl ɛvɹibɑɾi hu wɪl lɪsən. əl - "

"At least you're not sulking anymore," she said. "Don't ever whine, Rand; you are no good at it. Now, then. You want sense? I love you, and I will not go. If you try to send me away, I'll tell the Maidens you ruined me and cast me aside. I'll tell everybody who will listen. I will - "

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz ɹaɪt hæn ən stʌɾid ðə flæɾ ə hɪz pɑm, wɛɹ ðə bɹændɪd hɛɹən stʊd klɪɹ, ðən lʊkt ət hɝ. ʃi aɪɾ ɪz hænd wɛɹəli ən ʃɪftəd hɝsɛlf ɑn ɪz niz, ðən kənspɪkjuəsli ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɪz feɪs.

He raised his right hand and studied the flat of his palm, where the branded heron stood clear, then looked at her. She eyed his hand warily and shifted herself on his knees, then conspicuously ignored everything except his face.

"aɪ woʊnt ɡoʊ, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ju nid mi."

"I won't go, Rand," she said quietly. "You need me."

"haʊ dʒju də ɪt?" hi saɪd, slʌmpɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ. "ivən wən jə stæn mi ɑn maɪ hɛd, jə meɪk ɔl maɪ tʃɹʌbəlz ʃɹɪŋk."

"How do you do it?" he sighed, slumping back in the chair. "Even when you stand me on my head, you make all my troubles shrink."

mɪn snɪft. "ju nid tə bi stʊɾ ɑn jəɹ hɛd mɔɹ ɔfən. tɛl mi. ðɪs eɪvinhə. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðəɹ ɪz ɛni tʃæns ʃiz boʊni ən skɑɹd, laɪk nændɛɹə."

Min sniffed. "You need to be stood on your head more often. Tell me. This Aviendha. I don't suppose there is any chance she's bony and scarred, like Nandera."

hi læft ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. laɪt, haʊ lɔŋ sɪns i hæd læft wɪð plɛʒɝ? "mɪn, aɪd seɪ ʃiz əz pɹɪɾi əz ju, bʌt haʊ kən jə kəmpɛɹ tu sʌnɹaɪsəz?"

He laughed in spite of himself. Light, how long since he had laughed with pleasure? "Min, I'd say she is as pretty as you, but how can you compare two sunrises?"

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm wɪð ə smɔl smaɪl, əz ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə bi sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ dɪlaɪɾəd. "ju ɑɹ ə vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs mæn, ɹænd ælθɹ," ʃi mɝmɝd, linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪm sloʊli. hi θɔɾ i maɪt fɔl ɪndə hɝ aɪz ən bi lɔst. ɔl ðoʊz taɪmz bɪfɔɹ wən ʃi sæɾ ɑn ɪz læp ən kɪs hɪm, ɔl ðoʊz taɪmz i hæd θɔt ʃi wɑz oʊnli tizɪŋ ə kʌntʃɹi bɔɪ, hi hæd nɪɹli kɹɔld aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn wɑntɪŋ tə kɪs əɹ fɝɛvɝ. naʊ, ɪf ʃi kɪst ɪm əɡɛn naʊ. . . .

For a moment she stared at him with a small smile, as if she could not decide whether to be surprised or delighted. "You are a very dangerous man, Rand al'Thor," she murmured, leaning toward him slowly. He thought he might fall into her eyes and be lost. All those times before when she sat on his lap and kissed him, all those times he had thought she was only teasing a country boy, he had nearly crawled out of his skin wanting to kiss her forever. Now, if she kissed him again now. . . .

teɪkɪŋ əɹ fɝmli baɪ ði ɑɹmz, hi stʊɾ ən sɛɾ əɹ ɑn əɹ fit. hi lʌv hɝ, ən ʃi lʌv hɪm, bʌɾ i hæd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə kɪs ɪleɪn fɝɛvɝ wən i θɔɾ əbaʊt hɝ, ən eɪvinhə. wʌtɛvɝ mɪn sɛɾ əbaʊt ɹəɑɹk əɹ ɛni il mæn, ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə pʊɹ bɑɹɡən ðə deɪ ʃi fɛl ɪn lʌv wɪð hɪm. "ju sɛd hæf, mɪn," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "wʌt vjuɪŋz hævən jə toʊl mi?"

Taking her firmly by the arms, he stood and set her on her feet. He loved her, and she loved him, but he had to remember that he wanted to kiss Elayne forever when he thought about her, and Aviendha. Whatever Min said about Rhuarc or any Aiel man, she had made a poor bargain the day she fell in love with him. "You said half, Min," he said quietly. "What viewings haven't you told me?"

ʃi lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð wʌɾ ɔlmoʊs maɪɾ əv bɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ɪksɛpt ə kɔɹs ðəɾ ɪt kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn. "jɔɹ ɪn lʌv wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, mɪn fɑɹʃɔ," ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld, "æn bɛs jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt. bɛs jə dɪd, tu, ɹænd," ʃi æɾəd, pʊlɪŋ əweɪ. hi lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɹɪlʌktənli, iɡɝli; hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ. "juv bɪn bæk ɪn kɛɹhin hæf ə wik, ən jə stɪl əv dʌn nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk. bɹəleɪn θɔt jə maɪt dʒɹæɡ jəɹ fiɾ əɡɛn. ʃi lɛf mi ə lɛɾɝ, æskɪŋ mi tə kip ɹimaɪndɪŋ ju, oʊnli jə wʊdn lemi - wɛl, nɛvɝ maɪn ðæt. bɹəleɪn θɪŋks ðəɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə jə sʌmhaʊ; ʃi sɛz jəɹ ðə fʊlfɪlmən ə səm pɹɑfəsi ʌv ðɛɹz."

She looked up at him with what almost might have been frustration, except of course that it could not have been. "You're in love with the Dragon Reborn, Min Farshaw," she grumbled, "and best you remember it. Best you did, too, Rand," she added, pulling away. He let her go reluctantly, eagerly; he did not know which. "You've been back in Cairhien half a week, and you still have done nothing about the Sea Folk. Berelain thought you might drag your feet again. She left me a letter, asking me to keep reminding you, only you wouldn't let me - Well, never mind that. Berelain thinks they're important to you somehow; she says you're the fulfillment of some prophecy of theirs."

"aɪ noʊ ɔl əbaʊt ðæt, mɪn. aɪ - " hi hæd θɔt tə liv ðə si foʊk aʊɾ ə biɪŋ tæŋɡəld wɪð hɪm; ðeɪ wɝ nɑt mɛnʃən ɪn ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ðəɾ i kəd faɪnd. bʌɾ ɪf i wɑz gɑnə lɛt mɪn steɪ nɪɹ hɪm, lɛɾ əɹ ɹɪsk ðə deɪnʒɝz. . . . ʃi hæd wʌn, hi ɹilaɪzd. hi hæd wɑtʃt ɪleɪn wɔk əweɪ wɪð ɪz hɑɹt sɪŋkɪŋ, wɑtʃt eɪvinhə ɡoʊ wɪð ɪz stʌmək ɪn nɑts. hi kəd nɑt də ɪɾ əɡɛn. mɪn stʊd ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ. "aɪl ɡoʊ tə ðɛɹ ʃɪp. əl ɡoʊ tədeɪ. ðə si foʊk kən nil tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn ɔl ɪz splɛndɝ. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðəɹ wɑz ɛvɝ ɛni hoʊp fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. iðɝ ðəɹ maɪn, əɹ ðəɹ maɪ ɛnəmiz. ðəɾ ɪz haʊ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz simz tə bi. wɪl jə tɛl mi əbaʊt ðoʊz vjuɪŋz, naʊ?"

"I know all about that, Min. I - " He had thought to leave the Sea Folk out of being tangled with him; they were not mentioned in the Prophecies of the Dragon that he could find. But if he was going to let Min stay near him, let her risk the dangers. . . . She had won, he realized. He had watched Elayne walk away with his heart sinking, watched Aviendha go with his stomach in knots. He could not do it again. Min stood there waiting. "I'll go to their ship. I'll go today. The Sea Folk can kneel to the Dragon Reborn in all his splendor. I don't suppose there was ever any hope for anything else. Either they're mine, or they're my enemies. That is how it always seems to be. Will you tell me about those viewings, now?"

"ɹænd, jə ʃəd stʌɾi wʌt ðəɹ laɪk bɪfɔɹ jə - "

"Rand, you should study what they're like before you - "

"ðə vjuɪŋz?"

"The viewings?"

ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ən fɹaʊn ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ læʃɪz. ʃi tʃuɾ əɹ lɪp ən fɹaʊn ət ðə dɔɹ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. ət læst ʃi sɛd, "ðɛɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn, ɹɪli. aɪ wɑz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾɪŋ. aɪ sɔ jə ən ənʌðɝ mæn. aɪ kʊdn meɪk aʊɾ iðɝ feɪs, bʌɾ aɪ nu wʌn wɑz ju. jə tʌtʃt, ən sim tə mɝdʒ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ, ænd. . . ." hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd wɝidli, ən ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə vɛɹi smɔl vɔɪs. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz, ɹænd, ɪksɛp ðət wʌn ə jə daɪz, ən wʌn dʌznt. aɪ - waɪ ɑɹ jə ɡɹɪnɪŋ? ðɪs ɪzən ə dʒoʊk, ɹænd. aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ ə jə daɪz."

She folded her arms and frowned up at him through her lashes. She chewed her lip and frowned at the door. She shook her head and muttered under her breath. At last she said, "There is only one, really. I was exaggerating. I saw you and another man. I couldn't make out either face, but I knew one was you. You touched, and seemed to merge into one another, and. . . ." Her mouth tightened worriedly, and she went on in a very small voice. "I don't know what it means, Rand, except that one of you dies, and one doesn't. I - Why are you grinning? This isn't a joke, Rand. I do not know which of you dies."

"aɪm ɡɹɪnɪŋ kəz juv ɡɪvən mi vɛɹi ɡʊd nuz," hi sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ tʃik. ði ʌðɝ mæn hæd tə bi luz θɝɪn. aɪm nɑt dʒʌst ɪnseɪn ən hɪɹɪŋ vɔɪsəz, hi θɔt, dʒubələnt. wʌn lɪvd ən wʌn daɪd, bʌɾ i hæd noʊn fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm ðəɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. ət list i wɑz nɑt mæd. əɹ nɑɾ əz fɑɹ mæɾ əz i hæd fɪɹd. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ðə tɛmpɝ i kəd bɛɹli kəntʃɹoʊl. "ju si, aɪ - "

"I'm grinning because you've given me very good news," he said, touching her cheek. The other man had to be Lews Therin. I'm not just insane and hearing voices, he thought, jubilant. One lived and one died, but he had known for a long time that he was going to die. At least he was not mad. Or not as far mad as he had feared. There was still the temper he could barely control. "You see, I - "

sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd ɡɔn fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ tʃik tə kʌpɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɪn boʊθ hænz. hi pʊld əm əweɪ əz ɪf bɝnd. mɪn pɝst əɹ lɪps ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɹipɹoʊvɪŋ lʊk, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt gɑnə teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ə hɝ. ɪt wəd nɑt bi fɛɹ tə hɝ. lʌkəli, hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld laʊdli.

Suddenly he realized that he had gone from touching her cheek to cupping her face in both hands. He pulled them away as if burned. Min pursed her lips and gave him a reproving look, but he was not going to take advantage of her. It would not be fair to her. Luckily, his stomach rumbled loudly.

"aɪ nid sʌmθɪŋ tə it, ɪf aɪm gɑnə si ðə si foʊk. aɪ sɔ ə tʃɹeɪ. . . ."

"I need something to eat, if I'm going to see the Sea Folk. I saw a tray. . . ."

mɪn meɪɾ ə saʊn mɔɹ snɔɹt ðən snɪf əz i tɝn əweɪ, bʌt ðə nɛks moʊmənt ʃi wɑz seɪlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə tɔl dɔɹz. "ju niɾ ə bæθ, ɪf wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə si foʊk."

Min made a sound more snort than sniff as he turned away, but the next moment she was sailing toward the tall doors. "You need a bath, if we're going to the Sea Folk."

nændɛɹə wɑz dɪlaɪɾəd, nɑɾɪŋ ɪnθuziæstɪkli ən sɛndɪŋ meɪɾənz ɹʌnɪŋ. ðoʊ ʃi dɪd lin kloʊs tə mɪn ən seɪ, "aɪ ʃəɾ əv lɛt jə ɪn ðə fɝs deɪ. aɪ wɑntəd tə kɪk hɪm, bʌɾ ɪts nɑt dʌn, kɪkɪŋ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn." baɪ hɝ toʊn, ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn dʌn. ʃi spoʊk sɔfli, jɛt nɑt soʊ sɔfli hi kəd nɑt hɪɹ. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət wɑz dɪlɪbɝɪt; ʃi dɝɛktəd tu ʃɑɹp ə ɡlɛɹ əɾ ɪm fəɹ ɪt nɑt tə bi.

Nandera was delighted, nodding enthusiastically and sending Maidens running. Though she did lean close to Min and say, "I should have let you in the first day. I wanted to kick him, but it is not done, kicking the Car'a'carn." By her tone, it should have been done. She spoke softly, yet not so softly he could not hear. He was sure that was deliberate; she directed too sharp a glare at him for it not to be.

meɪɾənz lʌɡd ɪn ðə bɪɡ kɑpɝ tʌb ðɛmsɛlvz, flæʃɪŋ hæntɔk wʌns ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪt daʊn, læfɪŋ ən tu ɪksaɪɾəd tə lɛt ðə sʌn pæləs sɝvəns də ðə wɝk, əɹ bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹim ə bʌkəts fɪld wɪð hɑt wɔɾɝ, iðɝ. ɹænd hæɾ ə hɑɹd taɪm teɪkɪŋ ɪz oʊn kloʊðz ɔf. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hi hæɾ ə hɑɹd taɪm wɑʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ən i kəd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp nændɛɹə læðɝɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ. fleɪksən-hɛɹd soʊmɑɹə ən faɪɝi-hɛɹɾ ɪneɪlə ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ʃeɪvɪŋ ɪm əz i sæt tʃɛst-dip ɪn ðə tʌb, kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ soʊ ɪntɛnli ðeɪ simd əfɹeɪd ðeɪ maɪt kʌɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. hi wɑz juz tə ðət fɹəm ʌðɝ taɪmz ðeɪ hæd ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ ɪm hændəl bɹʌʃ ən ɹeɪzɝ hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑz juz tə ðə meɪɾənz u stʊɾ ɝaʊnd wɑtʃɪŋ, ɔfɝɪŋ tə skɹʌb ɪz bæk əɹ ɪz fit, hænz flɪkɝɪŋ ɪn saɪlən tʃæɾɝ ən stɪl mɔɹ ðən hæf-skændəlaɪzd ət ðə saɪɾ ə sʌmwʌn sɪɾɪŋ ɪn wɔɾɝ. bɪsaɪdz, hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə sʌm, ət list, baɪ sɛndɪŋ əm ɔf kæɹiɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz.

Maidens lugged in the big copper tub themselves, flashing handtalk once they set it down, laughing and too excited to let the Sun Palace servants do the work, or bring in the stream of buckets filled with hot water, either. Rand had a hard time taking his own clothes off. For that matter, he had a hard time washing himself, and he could not escape Nandera lathering his hair. Flaxen-haired Somara and fiery-haired Enaila insisted on shaving him as he sat chest-deep in the tub, concentrating so intently they seemed afraid they might cut his throat. He was used to that from other times they had refused to let him handle brush and razor himself. He was used to the Maidens who stood around watching, offering to scrub his back or his feet, hands flickering in silent chatter and still more than half-scandalized at the sight of someone sitting in water. Besides, he managed to get rid of some, at least, by sending them off carrying orders.

wʌɾ i wɑz nɑt juz tə wɑz mɪn, sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð əɹ tʃɪn ɑn əɹ hænz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə hoʊl θɪŋ ɪn vɛɹi ɛvəɾənt fæsəneɪʃən. ɪn ɔl ðə kɹaʊɾ ə meɪɾənz, hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz ðəɹ əntɪl i wɑz neɪkəd, ən ɔl ðəɹ wɑz tə də ðən wɑz sɪt daʊn əz fæst əz i kʊd, splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ oʊvɝ ðə saɪdz ə ðə tʌb. ðə wʊmən wʊɾə dʌn vɛɹi wɛl əz ə meɪɾən hɝsɛlf. ʃi dɪskʌst ɪm wɪð ðə meɪɾənz kwaɪɾ oʊpənli, wɪð nɛvɝ ə blʌʃ! hi wɑz ðə wʌn u blʌʃt.

What he was not used to was Min, sitting cross-legged on the bed with her chin on her hands, watching the whole thing in very evident fascination. In all the crowd of Maidens, he had not realized she was there until he was naked, and all there was to do then was sit down as fast as he could, splashing water over the sides of the tub. The woman would have done very well as a Maiden herself. She discussed him with the Maidens quite openly, with never a blush! He was the one who blushed.

"jɛs, hiz vɛɹi mɑɾəst," ʃi sɛd, əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð mɑlindɛɹ, ə wʊmən mɔɹ ɹaʊndəd ðən moʊs meɪɾənz, wɪð ðə dɑɹkəs hɛɹ ɹænd hæd sin ɑn ɛni il. "mɑɾəsti ɪz ə mænz kɹaʊnɪŋ ɡlɔɹi." mɑlindɛɹ nɑɾəd soʊbɝli, bʌt mɪn wɔɹ ə ɡɹɪn ðət nɪɹli splɪɾ əɹ tʃiks.

"Yes, he is very modest," she said, agreeing with Malindare, a woman more rounded than most Maidens, with the darkest hair Rand had seen on any Aiel. "Modesty is a man's crowning glory." Malindare nodded soberly, but Min wore a grin that nearly split her cheeks.

ænd, "oʊ, noʊ, doʊmil; ɪt wəd bi ə ʃeɪm tə spɔɪl sətʃ ə pɹɪɾi feɪs wɪð ə skɑɹ." doʊmil, ɡɹeɪɝ ðən nændɛɹə, linɝ, ən wɪð ə θɹʌstɪŋ tʃɪn, ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf tə də wɪθaʊɾ ə skɑɹ tə sɛɾ ɔf wʌt bjuɾi hi hæd. hɝ wɝdz. ðə ɹɛst wɑz wɝs. ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə ɛndʒɔɪ meɪkɪŋ ɪz feɪs ɹɛd. mɪn sɝɾənli dɪd.

And, "Oh, no, Domeille; it would be a shame to spoil such a pretty face with a scar." Domeille, grayer than Nandera, leaner, and with a thrusting chin, insisted that he was not pretty enough to do without a scar to set off what beauty he had. Her words. The rest was worse. The Maidens had always seemed to enjoy making his face red. Min certainly did.

"ju hæv tə dʒɹaɪ ɔf sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ə lɔŋ pis ʌv waɪt taʊəlɪŋ wɪð boʊθ hænz. ʃi stʊɾ ə ɡʊd θɹi peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə tʌb, ən ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ ɔl bækt ɪndə ə wɑtʃɪŋ ɹɪŋ. mɪnz smaɪl wɑz soʊ ɪnəsən ɛni mædʒəstʃɹeɪt wʊɾə faʊn əɹ ɡɪlti ɑn ðəɾ əloʊn. "kʌm ən ɡɛt dʒɹaɪ, ɹænd."

"You have to dry off sooner or later, Rand," she said, holding up a long piece of white toweling with both hands. She stood a good three paces from the tub, and the Maidens had all backed into a watching ring. Min's smile was so innocent any magistrate would have found her guilty on that alone. "Come and get dry, Rand."

hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ ɹɪliv tə pʊl ɑn kloʊðz ɪn ɪz laɪf.

He had never been so relieved to pull on clothes in his life.

baɪ ðət taɪm, ɔl ɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn kæɹiɾ aʊt, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɪn ɹɛɾinəs. ɹænd ælθɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn ɹuɾəd ɪn ə bæθtəb, bʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə si foʊk ɪn ə staɪl ðət wəd sɛn əm plʌməɾɪŋ tə ðɛɹ niz wɪð ɑ.

By that time, all his orders had been carried out, and everything was in readiness. Rand al'Thor might have been routed in a bathtub, but the Dragon Reborn was going to the Sea Folk in a style that would send them plummeting to their knees with awe.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 34

tɑvɝən


Ta'veren

ɔl wɑz ɹɛɾi əz ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə sʌn pæləs. əɹ ɔlmoʊst ɔl. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn slæntəd ʃædoʊz fɹəm ðə stɛp taʊɝz, soʊ oʊnli tɛn peɪsɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɔl bɹɑnz ɡeɪts leɪ ɪn fʊl laɪt. dæʃivə ən flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə, ðə θɹi æʃəmən i hæd ɹɪteɪnd, weɪɾəd bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ivən dæʃivə ɹisplɛndənt wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ən ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz blæk kɑlɝ, ðoʊ hi stɪl tʌtʃt ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp əz ɪf kɑnstənli sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪt ðɛɹ. ə hʌnʒɹəd ə dɑbɹeɪnz ɑɹmmɪn sæt ðɛɹ maʊns bɪhaɪn dɑbɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf wɪð tu lɔŋ bænɝz ðət hʌŋ daʊn ɪn ðə stɪl ɛɹ, ðɛɹ dɑɹk ɑɹmɝ nuli lækɝd soʊ ɪt ɡlɪsən ɪn ðə sʌn, ən sɪlk stʃɹimɝz ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪɾ ən blæk taɪd bɪloʊ ðə hɛdz ə ðɛɹ lænsɪz. ðeɪ ɹeɪzd ə tʃɪɹ wən ɹænd əpɪɹd, hɪz sɔɹd bɛlt wɪð ɪts ɡɪldɪd dʒɹæɡən bʌkəl stʃɹæpt oʊvɝ ə ɹɛd koʊt hɛvi wɪð ɡoʊld.

All was ready as Rand had ordered in the courtyard at the front of the Sun Palace. Or almost all. The morning sun slanted shadows from the stepped towers, so only ten paces in front of the tall bronze gates lay in full light. Dashiva and Flinn and Narishma, the three Asha'man he had retained, waited beside their horses, even Dashiva resplendent with the silver sword and red-and-gold Dragon on his black collar, though he still touched the sword at his hip as if constantly surprised to find it there. A hundred of Dobraine's armsmen sat their mounts behind Dobraine himself with two long banners that hung down in the still air, their dark armor newly lacquered so it glistened in the sun, and silk streamers of red and white and black tied below the heads of their lances. They raised a cheer when Rand appeared, his sword belt with its gilded Dragon buckle strapped over a red coat heavy with gold.

"ælθɹ! ælθɹ! ælθɹ!" fɪl ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. pipəl kɹaʊɾɪŋ ði ɑɹtʃɝz' bælkəniz dʒɔɪn ɪn, tɛɹən ən kɛɹhinɪn ɪn ðɛɹ sɪlks ən leɪsəz u dʒʌst ə wik bɪfɔɹ hæd noʊ daʊt tʃɪɹd koʊləveɪɪɹ əz laʊdli. mɛn ən wɪmən u wəɾ əz sun i hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹhin, səm ə ðɛm, weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən ɡɪvɪŋ vɔɪs. hi ɹeɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ tə æknɑlɪdʒ ðɛm, ən ðeɪ ɹɔɹd laʊɾɝ.

"Al'Thor! Al'Thor! Al'Thor!" filled the courtyard. People crowding the archers' balconies joined in, Tairen and Cairhienin in their silks and laces who just a week before had no doubt cheered Colavaere as loudly. Men and women who would as soon he had never returned to Cairhien, some of them, waving their arms and giving voice. He raised the Dragon Scepter to acknowledge them, and they roared louder.

ə θʌndɝəs ɹoʊl ə dʒɹʌmz ən ə blɛɹ ə tʃɹʌmpəts ɹoʊz θɹu ðə tʃɪɹz, pɹədus baɪ ə dʌzən mɔɹ ə dɑbɹeɪnz mɛn u wɔɹ kɹɪmzən tɑbɝdz wɪð ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk ɑn ðə tʃɛst, hæf kæɹiɪŋ lɔŋ tʃɹʌmpəts dʒɹeɪpt ɪn aɪdɛntɪkəl klɔθs, ði ʌðɝ hæf wɪð kɛɾəl dʒɹʌmz ɔlsoʊ dɛkɝeɪɾəd slʌŋ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔɹsəz. faɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɔlz keɪm tə miɾ ɪm əz i dɪsɛndəd ðə bɹɔd stɛɹz. ət list, ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹd hɪm. ɑlɑnə ɡeɪv ɪm wʌn sɝtʃɪŋ lʊk wɪð ðoʊz bɪɡ dɑɹk pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ aɪz; ðə taɪni nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ɪz skʌl sɛd ʃi wɑz kɑmɝ, mɔɹ ɹɪlækst, ðən i ɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðən ʃi meɪɾ ə smɔl moʊʃən, ən mɪn tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm ən wɛn əsaɪd wɪð hɝ. bɛɹə ən ði ʌðɝz meɪd smɔl kɝtsiz, ɪnklaɪnɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz slaɪtli, əz il stʃɹimd aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs bɪhaɪn hɪm. nændɛɹə lɛd tu hʌnʒɹəd meɪɾənz - ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bi aʊtʃoʊn baɪ ði "oʊθbɹeɪkɝz" - ən kɑmɑɹ, ə ɹeɪnʒi bɛn pik dɛɹn ɡɹeɪɝ ðən nændɛɹə ən hæf ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən ɹænd, lɛd tu hʌnʒɹəd siə dun u wəd nɑt bi aʊtʃoʊn baɪ fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, lɛɾ əloʊn kɛɹhinɪn. ðeɪ swʌŋ pæst ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɹɪŋ ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. bɛɹə laɪk ə pɹaʊd fɑɹmwaɪf ən ɑlɑnə laɪk səm dɑɹkli bjuɾəfəl kwin, ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔlz, ən plʌmp ɹæfɛlə, ivən dɑɹkɝ ɹæpt ɪn əɹ blu, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm æŋkʃəsli, ən kul-aɪd feɪlʒɹɪn, jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɡɹin, hɝ θɪn bɹeɪdz wɝkt wɪð kʌlɝd bidz, ən slɪm mɛɹænə ɪn əɹ ɡɹeɪ, huz fɹaʊn meɪd ɹæfɛlə sim ə pɪktʃɝ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. faɪv.

A thunderous roll of drums and a blare of trumpets rose through the cheers, produced by a dozen more of Dobraine's men who wore crimson tabards with the black-and-white disc on the chest, half carrying long trumpets draped in identical cloths, the other half with kettle drums also decorated slung on either side of the horses. Five Aes Sedai in their shawls came to meet him as he descended the broad stairs. At least, they glided toward him. Alanna gave him one searching look with those big dark penetrating eyes; the tiny knot of emotions in his skull said she was calmer, more relaxed, than he ever remembered. Then she made a small motion, and Min touched his arm and went aside with her. Bera and the others made small curtsies, inclining their heads slightly, as Aiel streamed out of the palace behind him. Nandera led two hundred Maidens - they were not about to be outshone by the "oathbreakers" - and Camar, a rangy Bent Peak Daryne grayer than Nandera and half a head taller than Rand, led two hundred Seia Doon who would not be outshone by Far Dareis Mai, let alone Cairhienin. They swung past on either side of him and the Aes Sedai to ring the courtyard. Bera like a proud farmwife and Alanna like some darkly beautiful queen, in their green-fringed shawls, and plump Rafela, even darker wrapped in her blue, watching him anxiously, and cool-eyed Faeldrin, yet another Green, her thin braids worked with colored beads, and slim Merana in her gray, whose frown made Rafela seem a picture of Aes Sedai serenity. Five.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ kaɪɹunə ən vɛɹɪn?" hi dɪmændəd. "aɪ kɔl fəɹ ɔl ə ju."

"Where are Kiruna and Verin?" he demanded. "I called for all of you."

"soʊ jə dɪd, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," bɛɹə ænsɝd smuðli. ʃi meɪɾ ənʌðɝ kɝtsi, tu; oʊnli ðə slaɪɾəst dɪp, bʌɾ ɪt tʊk ɪm əbæk. "wi kəd nɑt faɪn vɛɹɪn; ʃiz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ði il tɛns. kwɛstʃənɪŋ ðə . . ." hɝ smuð toʊn fɔltɝd fəɹ wʌn ɪnstənt. ". . . ðə pɹɪznɝz, aɪ bɪliv, ɪn ən ətɛmp tə lɝn wʌt wɑz plænd wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt tɑɹ vəlɑn." wʌns i ɹitʃt tɑɹ vəlɑn; ʃi nu ɪnʌf nɑt tə blɝt ðət wɛɹ ɛniwʌn kəd hɪɹ. "æn kaɪɹunə ɪz . . . kənsʌltɪŋ wɪð sɔɹɪliə ɑn ə mæɾɝ ə pɹoʊɾəkɑl. bʌɾ aɪm kwaɪt sɝɾən ʃɪl bi mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə dʒɔɪn əs ɪf jə sɛn ə pɝsənəl sʌmənz tə sɔɹɪliə. aɪ kəd ɡoʊ maɪsɛlf, ɪf jə - "

"So you did, my Lord Dragon," Bera answered smoothly. She made another curtsy, too; only the slightest dip, but it took him aback. "We could not find Verin; she is somewhere in the Aiel tents. Questioning the . . ." Her smooth tone faltered for one instant. ". . . the prisoners, I believe, in an attempt to learn what was planned once they reached Tar Valon." Once he reached Tar Valon; she knew enough not to blurt that where anyone could hear. "And Kiruna is . . . consulting with Sorilea on a matter of protocol. But I'm quite certain she will be more than happy to join us if you send a personal summons to Sorilea. I could go myself, if you - "

hi weɪv ðəɾ əweɪ. faɪv ʃəd bi ɪnʌf. pɝhæps vɛɹɪn kəd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ. dɪɾ i wɑnə noʊ? ən kaɪɹunə. ə mæɾɝ ə pɹoʊɾəkɑl? "aɪm ɡlæd jə ɑɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz." bɛɹə stɑɹɾəd tə spik, ðən kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ fɝmli. wʌtɛvɝ ɑlɑnə wɑz seɪɪŋ tə mɪn, skɑɹlət spɑts hæd flɛɹɾ ɪn mɪnz tʃiks ən ʃi hæd ɹeɪzd əɹ tʃɪn, ðoʊ ɑdli, ʃi sim tə bi ɹɪplaɪɪŋ kɑmli ɪnʌf. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wəd tɛl hɪm. wʌn θɪŋ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv əbaʊt wɪmən wɑz ðəɾ ɛvɹi læst wʌn hæd sikɹət pleɪsəz ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, səmtaɪmz ʃɛɹd wɪð ənʌðɝ wʊmən bʌt nɛvɝ wɪð ə mæn. ði oʊnli θɪŋ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv əbaʊt wɪmən.

He waved that away. Five should be enough. Perhaps Verin could learn something. Did he want to know? And Kiruna. A matter of protocol? "I'm glad you are getting on with the Wise Ones." Bera started to speak, then closed her mouth firmly. Whatever Alanna was saying to Min, scarlet spots had flared in Min's cheeks and she had raised her chin, though oddly, she seemed to be replying calmly enough. He wondered whether she would tell him. One thing he was sure of about women was that every last one had secret places in her heart, sometimes shared with another woman but never with a man. The only thing he was sure of about women.

"aɪ dɪdn kʌm aʊt hɪɹ tə stæn ɔl deɪ," hi sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð bɛɹə ɪn ðə lɛd, ði ʌðɝz hæf ə stɛp bæk. ɪf ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn hɝ, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn kaɪɹunə. ðɛɹ oʊn ɝeɪnʒmənts, nɑt hɪz. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli kɛɹ soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hɛl tə ðɛɹ oʊðz, ən i maɪɾ əv lɛft ɪɾ əloʊn ɪf nɑt fəɹ mɪn ən ɑlɑnə. "mɛɹænə wɪl spik fəɹ jə fɹəm naʊ ɑn; jəl teɪk jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm hɝ."

"I didn't come out here to stand all day," he said irritably. The Aes Sedai had arranged themselves with Bera in the lead, the others half a step back. If it had not been her, it would have been Kiruna. Their own arrangements, not his. He did not really care so long as they held to their oaths, and he might have left it alone if not for Min and Alanna. "Merana will speak for you from now on; you will take your orders from her."

baɪ ðə sʌɾənli waɪɾənd aɪz, jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæd slæpt ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm. ɪnkluɾɪŋ mɛɹænə. ivən ɑlɑnəz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊnd. waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ bi stɑɹɾəld? tʃɹu, bɛɹə əɹ kaɪɹunə hæd dʌn ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ sɪns dəməaɪz wɛlz, bʌt mɛɹænə hæd bɪn ði æmbæsəɾɝ sɛn tə hɪm ət keɪɛmlɪn.

By the suddenly widened eyes, you would have thought he had slapped every one of them. Including Merana. Even Alanna's head whipped around. Why should they be startled? True, Bera or Kiruna had done almost all the talking since Dumai's Wells, but Merana had been the ambassador sent to him at Caemlyn.

"ɪf jə ɑɹ ɹɛɾi, mɪn?" hi sɛd, ən wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə ɹɪplaɪ stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ðə bɪɡ, faɪɝi-aɪd blæk ɡɛldɪŋ i hæd ɹɪɾən bæk fɹəm dəməaɪz wɛlz hæd bɪn bɹɔɾ aʊt fəɹ hɪm, wɪð ə haɪ-kæntəl sæɾəl ɔl wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊld ən ə kɹɪmzən sæɾələklɔθ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ðə dɪsk ə blæk-ænd-waɪɾ əɾ itʃ kɔɹnɝ. ðə tʃɹæpɪŋz suɾəd ði ænəməl, ən ɪz neɪm. teɪdeɪʃɝ; ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, lɔɹɾ ʌv ɡlɔɹi. hɔɹs ən tʃɹæpɪŋz boʊθ suɾəd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

"If you are ready, Min?" he said, and without waiting for a reply strode out into the courtyard. The big, fiery-eyed black gelding he had ridden back from Dumai's Wells had been brought out for him, with a high-cantled saddle all worked in gold and a crimson saddlecloth embroidered with the disc of black-and-white at each corner. The trappings suited the animal, and his name. Tai'daishar; in the Old Tongue, Lord of Glory. Horse and trappings both suited the Dragon Reborn.

əz i maʊntəd, mɪn lɛɾ ʌp ðə maʊs-kʌlɝd mɛɹ ʃi hæd ɹɪɾən bæk, snʌɡɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz bɪfɔɹ swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. "saɪɹəz ə faɪn ænəməl," ʃi sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ðə mɛɹz ɑɹtʃt nɛk. "aɪ wɪʃ ʃi wɑz maɪn. aɪ laɪk əɹ neɪm, tu. wi kɔl ðə flaʊɝ ə blu-aɪ ɝaʊn bɛɹlən, ən ðeɪ ɡɹoʊ ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ."

As he mounted, Min led up the mouse-colored mare she had ridden back, snugging on her riding gloves before swinging into the saddle. "Seiera's a fine animal," she said, patting the mare's arched neck. "I wish she was mine. I like her name, too. We call the flower a blue-eye around Baerlon, and they grow everywhere in the spring."

"ʃiz jʊɹz," ɹænd sɛd. wɪtʃɛvɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðə mɛɹ bɪlɔŋ tə wəd nɑt ɹəfjuz tə sɛl tə hɪm. hi wəd ɡɪv kaɪɹunə ə θaʊzən kɹaʊnz fəɹ teɪdeɪʃɝ; ʃi kəd nɑt kəmpleɪn ðɛn; ðə faɪnəst stæljən ə tɛɹən blʌd stɑk nɛvɝ kɑst ə tɛnθ ə ðæt. "dɪd juv ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ɑlɑnə?"

"She's yours," Rand said. Whichever Aes Sedai the mare belonged to would not refuse to sell to him. He would give Kiruna a thousand crowns for Tai'daishar; she could not complain then; the finest stallion of Tairen blood stock never cost a tenth of that. "Did you have an interesting conversation with Alanna?"

"nʌθɪŋ ðət wəɾ ɪntʃɹəs ju," ʃi sɛɾ ɑfhændɪdli. bʌɾ ə feɪn tʌtʃ ə ɹɛd steɪn əɹ tʃiks.

"Nothing that would interest you," she said offhandedly. But a faint touch of red stained her cheeks.

hi snɔɹɾɪd sɔfli, ðən ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn, aɪv kɛp ðə si foʊk weɪɾɪŋ lɔŋ ɪnʌf, aɪ θɪŋk."

He snorted softly, then raised his voice. "Lord Dobraine, I've kept the Sea Folk waiting long enough, I think."

ðə pɹəsɛʃən dʒɹu kɹaʊdz əlɔŋ ðə bɹɔɾ ævənuz ən fɪl ðə wɪndoʊz ən ɹuftɑps əz wɝd ɹeɪst əhɛd. twɛnti ʌv dɑbɹeɪnz lænsɝz lɛd, tə klɪɹ ðə weɪ, əlɔŋ wɪð θɝɾi meɪɾənz ən əz mɛni blæk aɪz, ðən dʒɹʌmɝz, bumɪŋ əweɪ - dʒɹum, dʒɹum, dʒɹum, dʒɹum-dʒɹum - ən ðə tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪŋ ðət wɪð flɝɪʃəz. ʃaʊts fɹəm ði ɔnlʊkɝz nɪɹli dʒɹaʊn dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts əlaɪk, ə wɝdləs ɹɔɹ ðət cʊɾə bɪn ɹeɪdʒ əz izəli əz æpɹəbeɪʃən. ðə bænɝz stʃɹimd aʊt, dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə dɑbɹeɪn ən bɪhaɪn ɹænd, ðə waɪt dʒɹæɡən bænɝ ən ðə skɑɹlət bænɝ ə ðə laɪt, ən veɪld il tʃɹɑɾəd əlɔŋsaɪd ðə lænsɝz, huz stʃɹimɝz ɔlsoʊ floʊɾəd ɪn ði ɛɹ. naʊ ən ðən ə fju flaʊɝz wɝ hɝld ət hɪm. meɪbi ðeɪ dɪd nɑt heɪt hɪm. meɪbi ðeɪ oʊnli fɪɹd. ɪt hæd tə du.

The procession drew crowds along the broad avenues and filled the windows and rooftops as word raced ahead. Twenty of Dobraine's lancers led, to clear the way, along with thirty Maidens and as many Black Eyes, then drummers, booming away - droom, droom, droom, DROOM-DROOM - and the trumpeters punctuating that with flourishes. Shouts from the onlookers nearly drowned drums and trumpets alike, a wordless roar that could have been rage as easily as approbation. The banners streamed out, just ahead of Dobraine and behind Rand, the white Dragon Banner and the scarlet Banner of the Light, and veiled Aiel trotted alongside the lancers, whose streamers also floated in the air. Now and then a few flowers were hurled at him. Maybe they did not hate him. Maybe they only feared. It had to do.

"ə tʃɹeɪn wɝði ʌv ɛni kɪŋ," mɛɹænə sɛd laʊdli, tə bi hɝd.

"A train worthy of any king," Merana said loudly, to be heard.

"ðɛn ɪts ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi ɹɪplaɪd ʃɑɹpli. "wɪl jə steɪ bæk? ən ju, tu, mɪn." ʌðɝ ɹuftɑps hæd hɛld əsæsənz. ði æɹoʊ əɹ kɹɔsboʊ boʊl mɛn fəɹ ɪm wəd nɑt faɪn ɪts tɑɹɡəɾ ɪn ə wʊmən tədeɪ.

"Then it's enough for the Dragon Reborn," he replied sharply. "Will you stay back? And you, too, Min." Other rooftops had held assassins. The arrow or crossbow bolt meant for him would not find its target in a woman today.

ðeɪ dɪd fɔl bɪhaɪn ɪz bɪɡ blæk, fəɹ ɔl ə θɹi peɪsɪz, ən ðən ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əɡɛn, mɪn tɛlɪŋ ɪm wʌt bɹəleɪn hæd ɹɪɾən əbaʊt ðə si foʊk ɑn ðə ʃɪps, əbaʊt ðə dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi ən ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ən mɛɹænə æɾɪŋ wʌt ʃi nu ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsi, ðoʊ ʃi ədmɪɾəd ðət wɑz nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən mɪn.

They did fall behind his big black, for all of three paces, and then they were right beside him again, Min telling him what Berelain had written about the Sea Folk on the ships, about the Jendai Prophecy and the Coramoor, and Merana adding what she knew of the prophecy, though she admitted that was not very much, little more than Min.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɹuftɑps, hi lɪsənd wɪð hæf ən ɪɹ. hi dɪd nɑt hoʊl seɪɾɪn, bʌɾ i kəd fil ɪɾ ɪn dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝ tu, ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt fil ðə tɪŋɡəl ðət wəɾ ənaʊns ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs, bʌɾ i hæd toʊld əm nɑt tə, wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən. pɝhæps i ʃəd tʃeɪnʒ ðæt. ðeɪ dɪd sim tə bi kipɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊθ. haʊ kəd ðeɪ nɑt? ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə faɪn θɪŋ ɪf i tʊk ən əsæsənz bleɪd waɪl wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz tʃɹaɪd tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ sɝvɪŋ mɛn seɪvɪŋ ɪm əɹ oʊbeɪɪŋ mɛnt nɑt tʃænəlɪŋ.

Watching the rooftops, he listened with half an ear. He did not hold saidin, but he could feel it in Dashiva and the other two, right behind him. He did not feel the tingle that would announce the Aes Sedai embracing the Source, but he had told them not to, without permission. Perhaps he should change that. They did seem to be keeping their oath. How could they not? They were Aes Sedai. A fine thing if he took an assassin's blade while one of the sisters tried to decide whether serving meant saving him or obeying meant not channeling.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə læfɪŋ?" mɪn wɑntəd tə noʊ. saɪɹə pɹæns kloʊsɝ, ən ʃi smaɪld ʌp ət hɪm.

"Why are you laughing?" Min wanted to know. Seiera pranced closer, and she smiled up at him.

"ðɪs ɪz noʊ læfɪŋ mæɾɝ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," mɛɹænə sɛɾ æsədli ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. "ði æθɑn maɪɹ kən bi vɛɹi pɝtɪkjəlɝ. ɛni pipəl ɡɹoʊ fæstɪɾiəs wən ɪt kʌmz tə ðɛɹ pɹɑfəsiz."

"This is no laughing matter, my Lord Dragon," Merana said acidly on the other side. "The Atha'an Miere can be very particular. Any people grow fastidious when it comes to their prophecies."

"ðə wɝld ɪz ə læfɪŋ mæɾɝ," hi toʊl hɝ. mɪn læft əlɔŋ wɪð hɪm, bʌt mɛɹænə snɪft ən wɛn ɹaɪt bæk tə ðə si foʊk əz sun əz i stɑpt.

"The world is a laughing matter," he told her. Min laughed along with him, but Merana sniffed and went right back to the Sea Folk as soon as he stopped.

ət ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðə haɪ sɪɾi wɔlz ɹæn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ, flæŋkɪŋ lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ stoʊn dɑks ðət stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt fɹəm ðə ki. ɹɪvɝʃɪps ən boʊts ən bɑɹdʒəz ʌv ɛvɹi kaɪn ən saɪz wɝ taɪɾ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ðə kɹuz ɑn dɛk tə si ðə kəmoʊʃən, bʌt ðə vɛsəl ɹænd sɔt stʊd ɹɛɾi ən weɪɾɪŋ, læʃt ɛnd-ɑn tə ði ɛn ʌv ə dɑk wɛɹ ɔl ðə leɪbɝɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn klɪɹɾ ɔf. ə lɔŋboʊt, ɪt wɑz kɔld, ə loʊ nɛɹoʊ splɪntɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni mæsts, dʒʌst wʌn stæf ɪn ðə baʊ, fɔɹ peɪsɪz tɔl, tɑp baɪ ə læntɝn, ən ənʌðɝ ət ðə stɝn. nɪɹli θɝɾi peɪsɪz ɪn lɛŋθ ən laɪnd wɪð əz mɛni lɔŋ ɔɹz, ɪt kəd nɑt kæɹi ðə kɑɹɡoʊ ə seɪlɪŋ vɛsəl ðə seɪm saɪz wʊd, bʌɾ ɪt hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðə wɪnd, iðɝ, ən wɪð ə ʃæloʊ dʒɹæft, ɪt kəd tʃɹævəl deɪ ən naɪt, juzɪŋ ɹoʊɝz ɪn ʃɪfs. lɔŋboʊts ɹæn ðə ɹɪvɝz wɪð kɑɹɡoʊz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns ən ɝdʒənsi. ɪt hæd simd əpɹoʊpɹiət.

At the river, the high city walls ran out into the water, flanking long gray stone docks that stretched out from the quay. Riverships and boats and barges of every kind and size were tied everywhere, the crews on deck to see the commotion, but the vessel Rand sought stood ready and waiting, lashed end-on to the end of a dock where all the laborers had already been cleared off. A longboat, it was called, a low narrow splinter without any masts, just one staff in the bow, four paces tall, topped by a lantern, and another at the stern. Nearly thirty paces in length and lined with as many long oars, it could not carry the cargo a sailing vessel the same size would, but it had no need of the wind, either, and with a shallow draft, it could travel day and night, using rowers in shifts. Longboats ran the rivers with cargoes of importance and urgency. It had seemed appropriate.

ðə kæptən baʊd ɹɪpiɾɪdli əz ɹænd keɪm daʊn ðə bɔɹɾɪŋ ɹæmp wɪð mɪn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən əɾ ɪz hilz. ɛlvɝ ʃeɪin wɑz ivən skɪniɝ ðən ɪz kɹæft ɪn ə jɛloʊ koʊɾ ə mʊɹændiən kʌt ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz niz. "ɪts ən ɑnɝ tə bi kæɹiɪŋ ju, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi mɝmɝd, mɑpɪŋ ɪz bɔl hɛd wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf. "æn ɑnɝ, ɪɾ ɪz. ən ɑnɝ, ɪndid. ən ɑnɝ."

The captain bowed repeatedly as Rand came down the boarding ramp with Min on his arm and the Aes Sedai and Asha'man at his heels. Elver Shaene was even skinnier than his craft in a yellow coat of Murandian cut that hung to his knees. "It's an honor to be carrying you, my Lord Dragon," he murmured, mopping his bald head with a large handkerchief. "An honor, it is. An honor, indeed. An honor."

pleɪnli ðə mæn wəd ɹæðɝ əv hæɾ ɪz ʃɪp bɹɪm fʊl ə laɪv vaɪpɝz. hi blɪŋkt ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ʃɔlz ən stɛɹɾ ət ðɛɹ eɪdʒləs feɪsəz ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps, aɪz flɪkɝɪŋ bæk tə ɹænd ənizəli. ði æʃəmən dʒɹɑpt ɪz maʊθ oʊpən wʌns i pʊt ðɛɹ blæk koʊts təɡɛðɝ wɪð ɹumɝ, ən ðɛɹæftɝ i əvɔɪɾəd soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən. ʃeɪin wɑtʃt dɑbɹeɪn lɛd ðə mɛn wɪð ðə bænɝz əbɔɹd, ən ðə tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz, ən ðə dʒɹʌmɝz lʌɡɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒɹʌmz, ðən aɪd ðə hɔɹsmən laɪnɪŋ ðə dɑk əz ɪf i səspɛktəd ðeɪ maɪt wɑnə bɔɹd, tu. nændɛɹə, wɪð twɛnti meɪɾənz, ən kɑmɑɹ wɪð twɛnti blæk aɪz, ɔl wɪð ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ðoʊ ənveɪld, meɪd ðə kæptən stɛp heɪstəli tə pʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪtwin ɪm ən ðɛm. ði il wɔɹ skaʊlz, fəɹ ðə hɑɹtbit ðət niɾɪŋ tə veɪl maɪt sloʊ ðɛm, bʌt ðə si foʊk maɪt wɛl noʊ wʌɾ ə veɪl mɛnt, ən ɪt wəd hɑɹdli də fəɹ əm tə θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ ʌndɝ ətæk. ɹænd θɔt ʃeɪinz hæŋkɝtʃɪf maɪt jɛt ɹʌb əweɪ wʌt θɪn ɡɹeɪ fɹɪnʒ ə hɛɹ i hæd lɛft.

Plainly the man would rather have had his ship brim full of live vipers. He blinked at the Aes Sedai's shawls and stared at their ageless faces and licked his lips, eyes flickering back to Rand uneasily. The Asha'man dropped his mouth open once he put their black coats together with rumor, and thereafter he avoided so much as a glance in their direction. Shaene watched Dobraine lead the men with the banners aboard, and the trumpeters, and the drummers lugging their drums, then eyed the horsemen lining the dock as if he suspected they might want to board, too. Nandera, with twenty Maidens, and Camar with twenty Black Eyes, all with shoufa wrapped around their heads though unveiled, made the captain step hastily to put the Aes Sedai between him and them. The Aiel wore scowls, for the heartbeat that needing to veil might slow them, but the Sea Folk might well know what a veil meant, and it would hardly do for them to think they were under attack. Rand thought Shaene's handkerchief might yet rub away what thin gray fringe of hair he had left.

ðə lɔŋboʊt swɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɑk ɑn ɪts lɔŋ ɔɹz, ðə tu bænɝz ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ðə baʊz, ən ðə dʒɹʌmz paʊndɪŋ, ən ðə tʃɹʌmpəts blɛɹɪŋ. aʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, pipəl əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə dɛks ə ʃɪps tə wɑtʃ, ivən klaɪmd ɪndə ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ. ɑn ðə si foʊk ʃɪp ðeɪ keɪm aʊt, tu, mɛni ɪn bɹaɪt kʌlɝz ənlaɪk ðə dʒɹæb kloʊðɪŋ ɑn kɹuz ə ði ʌðɝ vɛsəlz. ðə waɪt spɹeɪ wɑz ə lɑɹdʒɝ kɹæf ðən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst, jɛt sʌmhaʊ slikɝ əz wɛl, wɪð tu tɔl mæsts ɹeɪk bæk ʃɑɹpli ən spɑɹz leɪɾ əkɹɔs əm skwɛɹli wɛɹ nɪɹli ɔl ði ʌðɝ ʃɪps hæd slæntɪŋ spɑɹz lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə mæsts tə hoʊl moʊst ə ðɛɹ seɪlz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt spoʊk ə dɪfɝəns, bʌɾ ɪn wʌn θɪŋ, ɹænd nu, ði æθɑn maɪɹ hæd tə bi laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. ðeɪ kəɾ iðɝ əɡɹi tə fɑloʊ hɪm ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn əɹ bi fɔɹs tə ɪt; ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛɾ i wəd baɪn təɡɛðɝ ðə pipəl ʌv ɛvɹi lænd - "ðə nɔɹθ ʃæl i taɪ tə ði ist, ən ðə wɛst ʃæl bi baʊn tə ðə saʊθ," ɪt sɛd - ən noʊ wʌn kəd bi əlaʊd tə stæn əsaɪd. hi nu ðæt, naʊ.

The longboat swept away from the dock on its long oars, the two banners rippling in the bows, and the drums pounding, and the trumpets blaring. Out in the river, people appeared on the decks of ships to watch, even climbed into the rigging. On the Sea Folk ship they came out, too, many in bright colors unlike the drab clothing on crews of the other vessels. The White Spray was a larger craft than most of the rest, yet somehow sleeker as well, with two tall masts raked back sharply and spars laid across them squarely where nearly all the other ships had slanting spars longer than the masts to hold most of their sails. Everything about it spoke of difference, but in one thing, Rand knew, the Atha'an Miere had to be like everyone else. They could either agree to follow him on their own or be forced to it; the Prophecies said he would bind together the people of every land - "The north shall he tie to the east, and the west shall be bound to the south," it said - and no one could be allowed to stand aside. He knew that, now.

sɛndɪŋ aʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm ɪz bæθ, hi hæd nɑt hæɾ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ɡɪv dɪteɪlz ʌv wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəɾ ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ waɪt spɹeɪ, soʊ hi ənaʊnst əm naʊ. ðə dɪteɪlz pɹədust ɡɹɪnz əmʌŋ ði æʃəmən, əz ɪkspɛktəd - wɛl, flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə ɡɹɪnd; dæʃivə blɪŋkt æbsənli - ən fɹaʊnz əmʌŋ ði il, ɔlsoʊ əz ɪkspɛktəd. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ lɛf bɪhaɪnd. dɑbɹeɪn mɪɹli nɑɾəd; hi nu hi wɑz oʊnli hɪɹ fəɹ ʃoʊ tədeɪ. wʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt wɑz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹiækʃən.

Sending out orders from his bath, he had not had an opportunity to give details of what he intended on reaching White Spray, so he announced them now. The details produced grins among the Asha'man, as expected - well, Flinn and Narishma grinned; Dashiva blinked absently - and frowns among the Aiel, also as expected. They did not like being left behind. Dobraine merely nodded; he knew he was only here for show today. What Rand did not expect was the Aes Sedai reaction.

"ɪt ʃæl bi əz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," mɛɹænə sɛd, meɪkɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz smɔl kɝtsiz. ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kɝtsiɪŋ ən mɝmɝɪŋ "æz jə kəmænd" ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ. nɑt wʌn pɹoʊɾɛst, nɑt wʌn fɹaʊn, nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl hɔɾi stɛɹ əɹ ɹəsaɪɾəl ʌv waɪ ɪt ʃəd bi dʌn ɛni weɪ bʌt wʌɾ i wɑntəd. kəɾ i bɪɡɪn tə tʃɹʌs ðɛm? əɹ wəd ðeɪ faɪn səm ɛɛs sədaɪ weɪ tə ɹɪɡəl ɝaʊn ðɛɹ oʊθ əz sun əz ɪz bæk wɑz tɝnd?

"It shall be as you command, my Lord Dragon," Merana said, making one of those small curtsies. The other four exchanged glances, but they were curtsying and murmuring "as you command" right behind her. Not one protest, not one frown, not a single haughty stare or recital of why it should be done any way but what he wanted. Could he begin to trust them? Or would they find some Aes Sedai way to wriggle around their oath as soon as his back was turned?

"ðeɪ wɪl kip ðɛɹ wɝd," mɪn mɝmɝɾ əbɹʌpli, dʒʌst əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹɛɾ ɪz θɔts. wɪð ən ɑɹm ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz ən boʊθ hænz hoʊldɪŋ ɪz sliv, ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs fəɹ ɪz ɪɹz əloʊn. "aɪ dʒʌst sɔ ðiz faɪv ɪn jəɹ hænd," ʃi æɾəd ɪn keɪs i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd fɪks ɪz maɪn ɝaʊn ðæt, ivən ɪf ʃi hæd sin ɪɾ ɪn ə vjuɪŋ.

"They will keep their word," Min murmured abruptly, just as if she had read his thoughts. With an arm wrapped around his and both hands holding his sleeve, she kept her voice for his ears alone. "I just saw these five in your hand," she added in case he did not understand. He was not sure he could fix his mind around that, even if she had seen it in a viewing.

hi dɪd nɑɾ əv lɔŋ tə tʃɹaɪ. ðə lɔŋboʊt flu θɹu ðə wɔɾɝ, ən ɪn noʊ taɪm əɾ ɔl wɑz bækɪŋ ɔɹz səm twɛnti peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə mʌtʃ tɔlɝ waɪt spɹeɪ. dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts fɛl saɪlənt, ən ɹænd tʃænəld, meɪkɪŋ ə bɹɪdʒ ʌv ɛɹ leɪst wɪð faɪɝ ðət kənɛktəd ðə lɔŋboʊts ɹeɪlɪŋ tə ðəɾ ə ðə si foʊk ʃɪp. wɪð mɪn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, hi stɑɹɾəd əkɹɔs, tə ɛvɹi aɪ bʌt ðəɾ ʌv ən æʃəmən, wɔkɪŋ ʌpwɝɾ ɑn nʌθɪŋ.

He did not have long to try. The longboat flew through the water, and in no time at all was backing oars some twenty paces from the much taller White Spray. Drums and trumpets fell silent, and Rand channeled, making a bridge of Air laced with Fire that connected the longboat's railing to that of the Sea Folk ship. With Min on his arm, he started across, to every eye but that of an Asha'man, walking upward on nothing.

hi hæf ɪkspɛktəd mɪn tə fɔltɝ, ət list ət fɝst, bʌt ʃi sɪmpli wɔkt əɾ ɪz saɪɾ əz ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ stoʊn bɪniθ əɹ ɡɹin-hil buts.

He half expected Min to falter, at least at first, but she simply walked at his side as though there were stone beneath her green-heeled boots.

"aɪ tʃɹʌs ju," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. ʃi smaɪld, tu, pɑɹtli ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ smaɪl, ən pɑɹtli, hi θɔt, kəz ʃi wɑz əmjuzd ət ɹiɾɪŋ ɪz maɪnd wʌns mɔɹ.

"I trust you," she said quietly. She smiled, too, partly a comforting smile, and partly, he thought, because she was amused at reading his mind once more.

hi wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi wəd tʃɹʌst ɪf ʃi nu ðət ðɪs wɑz əz fɑɹ əz i kəd wiv ə bɹɪdʒ laɪk ðɪs. wʌn peɪs fɑɹðɝ, wʌn fʊt, ən ðə hoʊl θɪŋ wʊɾə ɡɪvən weɪ ət ðə fɝst stɛp. ət ðət pɔɪn ɪt bɪkeɪm laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪf jɝsɛlf wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ən ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi; ivən ðə fɔɹseɪkən dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ nu waɪ ə wʊmən kəd meɪk ə lɔŋɡɝ bɹɪdʒ ðən ə mæn ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əz stʃɹɔŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə mæɾɝ ʌv weɪt; ɛni əmaʊn ʌv weɪt kəd kɹɔs ɛni bɹɪdʒ.

He wondered how much she would trust if she knew that this was as far as he could weave a bridge like this. One pace farther, one foot, and the whole thing would have given way at the first step. At that point it became like trying to lift yourself with the Power, an impossibility; even the Forsaken did not know why, any more than they knew why a woman could make a longer bridge than a man even if she was not as strong. It was not a matter of weight; any amount of weight could cross any bridge.

dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv waɪt spɹeɪz ɹeɪlɪŋ, hi stɑpt, stændɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ. fəɹ ɔl mɛɹænəz dɪskɹɪpʃənz, ðə pipəl stɛɹɪŋ bæk əɾ ɪm wɝ ə ʃɑk. dɑɹk wɪmən ən bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn wɪð kʌlɝfəl sæʃɪz ðət dæŋɡəl tə ðə ni, ən ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ tʃeɪnz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks ən ɹɪŋz ɪn ðɛɹ ɪɹz, ɪn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz ɑn səm ə ðə wɪmən, hu wɔɹ ə ɹeɪnboʊ ʌv blaʊsəz əbʌv ðɛɹ dɑɹk, bæɡi bɹitʃɪz. nʌn hæɾ ɛni mɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd. fɔɹ ə ðə wɪmən, dɪspaɪt biɪŋ bɛɹfʊt laɪk ðə ɹɛst, wɔɹ bɹaɪt sɪlks, tu ʌv əm bɹoʊkeɪdz, ən ðeɪ hæd mɔɹ nɛkləsɪz ən ɪɹɪŋz ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls əz wɛl, wɪð ə tʃeɪn stʃɹʌŋ wɪð ɡoʊl mədæljənz ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ən ɪɹɪŋ tə ə ɹɪŋ ɪn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə noʊz. ðeɪ sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli stʊd təɡɛðɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, snɪfɪŋ ət smɔl, leɪsi ɡoʊldən bɑksəz ðət hʌŋ fɹəm tʃeɪnz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks. hi ədʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf tə ðɛm.

Just short of White Spray's railing, he stopped, standing in midair. For all Merana's descriptions, the people staring back at him were a shock. Dark women and bare-chested men with colorful sashes that dangled to the knee, and gold or silver chains around their necks and rings in their ears, in their noses of all places on some of the women, who wore a rainbow of blouses above their dark, baggy breeches. None had any more expression than an Aes Sedai who was trying hard. Four of the women, despite being barefoot like the rest, wore bright silks, two of them brocades, and they had more necklaces and earrings than anyone else as well, with a chain strung with gold medallions running from an earring to a ring in the side of the nose. They said nothing, only stood together watching him, sniffing at small, lacy golden boxes that hung from chains around their necks. He addressed himself to them.

"aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. aɪm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ."

"I am the Dragon Reborn. I am the Coramoor."

ə kəlɛktɪv saɪ ɹæn θɹu ðə kɹu. nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðə fɔɹ wɪmən, ðoʊ.

A collective sigh ran through the crew. Not among the four women, though.

"aɪ æm hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə tu wɪnz, weɪvməstʃɹəs tə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn," ənaʊns ðə wʌn wɪð ðə moʊst ɪɹɪŋz, ə hænsəm, fʊl-maʊðd wʊmən ɪn ɹɛd bɹoʊkeɪd wɛɹɪŋ faɪv fæt lɪɾəl ɡoʊld ɹɪŋz ɪn itʃ ɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ waɪt stʃɹiks θɹu hɝ stʃɹeɪt blæk hɛɹ, ən faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. ʃi hæɾ ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv dɪɡnəɾi. "aɪ spik hɪɹ fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt, ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ meɪ kʌm əbɔɹd." fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən soʊ dɪd ðə θɹi wɪð hɝ, bʌt ðət saʊndəɾ ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ laɪk pɝmɪʃən. ɹænd stɛpt ɑntu ðə dɛk wɪð mɪn wɪʃɪŋ i hæd nɑt weɪɾəd.

"I am Harine din Togara Two Winds, Wavemistress to Clan Shodein," announced the one with the most earrings, a handsome, full-mouthed woman in red brocade wearing five fat little gold rings in each ear. There were white streaks through her straight black hair, and fine lines at the corners of her eyes. She had an impressive dignity. "I speak here for the Mistress of the Ships. If it pleases the Light, the Coramoor may come aboard." For some reason she gave a start, and so did the three with her, but that sounded entirely too much like permission. Rand stepped onto the deck with Min wishing he had not waited.

hi lɛt ðə bɹɪdʒ ɡoʊ, ən seɪɾɪn, bʌɾ ɪmiɾiətli fɛlt ənʌðɝ bɹɪdʒ ɹipleɪs ɪt. ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ ði æʃəmən ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ wɪð hɪm, ðə sɪstɝz noʊ mɔɹ flʌstɝd ðən mɪn hæd bɪn, ðoʊ pɝhæps wʌn əɹ tu dɪd stʃɹeɪɾən əɹ skɝts ə bɪt mɔɹ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl nɑt soʊ izi ɝaʊn ði æʃəmən əz ðeɪ pɹitɛndəd.

He let the bridge go, and saidin, but immediately felt another bridge replace it. In short order the Asha'man and the Aes Sedai were with him, the sisters no more flustered than Min had been, though perhaps one or two did straighten her skirts a bit more than necessary. They were still not so easy around the Asha'man as they pretended.

ðə fɔɹ si foʊk wɪmən tʊk wʌn lʊk ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɪmiɾiətli ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ə kloʊs hʌɾəl, wɪspɝɪŋ. hɑɹɪn dɪɾ ə lɑɾ ə ðə tɔkɪŋ, ən soʊ dɪɾ ə jʌŋ, pɹɪɾi wʊmən ɪn ɡɹin bɹoʊkeɪd wɪð eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz ɔltəɡɛðɝ, bʌt ðə pɛɹ ɪn pleɪn sɪlk pʊɾ ɪn əkeɪʒənəl kɑmɛns.

The four Sea Folk women took one look at the Aes Sedai and immediately gathered in a close huddle, whispering. Harine did a lot of the talking, and so did a young, pretty woman in green brocade with eight earrings altogether, but the pair in plain silk put in occasional comments.

mɛɹænə kɔf dɛləkətli, ən spoʊk sɔfli ɪndə ðə hænd ʃi juz tə kʌvɝ ɪt. "aɪ hɝɾ əɹ neɪm jə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ. ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɑɹ ɡɹeɪt bɑɹɡɪnɝz, aɪv hɝd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃi ɡeɪv əweɪ sʌmθɪŋ, ðɛn." nɑɾɪŋ, ɹænd ɡlæns daʊn ət mɪn. ʃi wɑz skwɪntɪŋ ət ðə si foʊk wɪmən, bʌɾ əz sun əz ʃi noʊɾəst ɪz lʊk, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli; ʃi sɔ nʌθɪŋ jɛt ðət maɪt hɛlp hɪm.

Merana coughed delicately, and spoke softly into the hand she used to cover it. "I heard her name you the Coramoor. The Atha'an Miere are great bargainers, I've heard, but I think she gave away something, then." Nodding, Rand glanced down at Min. She was squinting at the Sea Folk women, but as soon as she noticed his look, she shook her head ruefully; she saw nothing yet that might help him.

hɑɹɪn tɝn soʊ kɑmli ðəɹ maɪt nɛvɝ əv bɪn ɛni heɪsti kɑnfɝəns. "ðɪs ɪz ʃələn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə mɔɹnɪŋ taɪd, wɪndfɪndɝ tə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə smɔl baʊ təwɔɹd ðə wʊmən ɪn ɡɹin bɹoʊkeɪd, "æn ðɪs ɪz dɪɹə dɪn sɛlɑn ɹaɪzɪŋ weɪv, seɪlməstʃɹəs ʌv waɪt spɹeɪ." itʃ wʊmən baʊd slaɪtli əz ʃi wɑz neɪmd, ən tʌtʃt fɪŋɡɝz tə hɝ lɪps.

Harine turned so calmly there might never have been any hasty conference. "This is Shalon din Togara Morning Tide, Windfinder to Clan Shodein," she said with a small bow toward the woman in green brocade, "and this is Derah din Selaan Rising Wave, Sailmistress of White Spray." Each woman bowed slightly as she was named, and touched fingers to her lips.

dɪɹə, ə hænsəm wʊmən ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɔɹ pleɪn blu ən ɔlsoʊ eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz, ðoʊ hɝ ɪɹɪŋz, noʊz ɹɪŋ, ən ðə tʃeɪn ðət ɹæn bɪtwin wɑz faɪnɝ ðən hɑɹɪnz əɹ ʃələnz. "ðə wɛlkəm ə maɪ ʃɪp tə ju," dɪɹə sɛd, "æn ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn jə əntɪl jə liv ɪz dɛks." ʃi meɪɾ ə smɔl baʊ təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹθ wʊmən, ɪn jɛloʊ. "ðɪs ɪz tɑvəl dɪn tʃənɑi naɪn ɡʌlz, wɪndfɪndɝ ʌv waɪt spɹeɪ." oʊnli θɹi ɹɪŋz hʌŋ fɹəm itʃ ə tɑvəlz ɪɹz, faɪn laɪk ðoʊz ə ðə seɪl-mɪstʃɹəs. ʃi lʊk jʌŋɡɝ ðən ʃələn, noʊ oʊldɝ ðən hɪmsɛlf.

Derah, a handsome woman a little short of her middle years, wore plain blue and also eight earrings, though her earrings, nose ring, and the chain that ran between was finer than Harine's or Shalon's. "The welcome of my ship to you," Derah said, "and the grace of the Light be upon you until you leave his decks." She made a small bow toward the fourth woman, in yellow. "This is Taval din Chanai Nine Gulls, Windfinder of White Spray." Only three rings hung from each of Taval's ears, fine like those of the Sail-mistress. She looked younger than Shalon, no older than himself.

hɑɹɪn tʊk ɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹeɪz stɝn ə ðə ʃɪp. "wi wɪl spik ɪn maɪ kæbən, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju. ə sɔɹɝ ɪz nɑɾ ə lɑɹdʒ vɛsəl, ɹænd ælθɹ, ən ðə kæbən ɪz smɔl. ɪf ɪt plizɪz jə tə kʌm əloʊn, ɔl hɪɹ stænd ʃʊɹəɾi fəɹ jəɹ seɪfti." soʊ. fɹəm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ tə pleɪn ɹænd ælθɹ. ʃi wəd teɪk bæk wʌt ʃi hæd ɡɪvən, ɪf ʃi kʊd.

Harine took it up again, gesturing toward the raised stern of the ship. "We will speak in my cabin, if it pleases you. A soarer is not a large vessel, Rand al'Thor, and the cabin is small. If it pleases you to come alone, all here stand surety for your safety." So. From the Coramoor to plain Rand al'Thor. She would take back what she had given, if she could.

hi wɑz əbaʊt tə oʊpən ɪz maʊθ ən əɡɹi - ɛniθɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðɪs dʌn; hɑɹɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi muvɪŋ ðət weɪ, stɪl dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə fɑloʊ, ði ʌðɝ wɪmən wɪð əɹ - wən mɛɹænə ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ taɪni kɑf.

He was about to open his mouth and agree - anything to get this done; Harine was already moving that way, still gesturing for him to follow, the other women with her - when Merana gave another tiny cough.

"ðə wɪndfɪndɝz kən tʃænəl," ʃi mɝmɝd heɪstəli ɪndə hɝ hænd. "ju ʃəd teɪk tu sɪstɝz wɪð ju, əɹ ðəl fil ðeɪv ɡeɪn ði ʌpɝ hænd."

"The Windfinders can channel," she murmured hastily into her hand. "You should take two sisters with you, or they'll feel they've gained the upper hand."

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. ði ʌpɝ hænd? hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, æftɝ ɔl. stɪl. . . . "aɪ wɪl bi pliz tə kʌm, weɪvməstʃɹəs, bʌt mɪn hɪɹ ɡoʊz ɛvɹiwɛɹ wɪð mi." hi pæɾəd mɪnz hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm - ʃi hæd nɑt lɛt ɡoʊ ən ɪnstənt - ən hɑɹɪn nɑɾəd. tɑvəl wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɔɹ oʊpən; dɪɹə meɪd wʌn ə ðoʊz smɔl baʊz, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɪm təwɔɹɾ ɪt.

Rand frowned. The upper hand? He was the Dragon Reborn, after all. Still. . . . "I will be pleased to come, Wavemistress, but Min here goes everywhere with me." He patted Min's hand on his arm - she had not let go an instant - and Harine nodded. Taval was already holding the door open; Derah made one of those small bows, gesturing him toward it.

"æn dæʃivə, ʌv kɔɹs." ðə mæn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əɾ ɪz neɪm, əz ɪf i hæd bɪn əslip. ət list i wɑz nɑt stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə dɛk laɪk flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə. stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɪmən. stɔɹiz spoʊk ə ði əlʊɹɪŋ bjuɾi ən ɡɹeɪs ə si foʊk wɪmən, ən ɹænd kəd sɝɾənli si ðət - ðeɪ wɔkt əz ɪf ðeɪ wəd bɪɡɪn dænsɪŋ ɑn ðə nɛkst stɛp, sweɪɪŋ sɪnjuəsli - bʌɾ i hæd nɑt bɹɔt ðə mɛn hɪɹ tə oʊɡəl. "kip jəɹ aɪz oʊpən!" hi toʊld əm hɑɹʃli. nɛɹɪʃmə kʌlɝd, dʒɝkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf stɪfli ɪɹɛkt, ən pɹɛs fɪs tə tʃɛst. flɪn sɪmpli səluɾəd, bʌt boʊθ simd mɔɹ əlɝt. fəɹ səm ɹizən, mɪn lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð ðə taɪniəst ɹaɪ smaɪl.

"And Dashiva, of course." The man gave a start at his name, as if he had been asleep. At least he was not staring wide-eyed around the deck like Flinn and Narishma. Staring at the women. Stories spoke of the alluring beauty and grace of Sea Folk women, and Rand could certainly see that - they walked as if they would begin dancing on the next step, swaying sinuously - but he had not brought the men here to ogle. "Keep your eyes open!" he told them harshly. Narishma colored, jerking himself stiffly erect, and pressed fist to chest. Flinn simply saluted, but both seemed more alert. For some reason, Min looked up at him with the tiniest wry smile.

hɑɹɪn nɑɾəd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪmpeɪʃənli. ə mæn stɛpt aʊt fɹəm ðə kɹu, ɪn bæɡi ɡɹin sɪlk bɹitʃɪz ən wɪð ən aɪvɝi-hɪltɪd sɔɹɾ ən dæɡɝ θɹʌs bɪhaɪn ɪz sæʃ. mɔɹ waɪt-hɛɹd ðən ʃi, hi ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ faɪv fæt lɪɾəl ɹɪŋz ɪn itʃ ɪɹ. ʃi weɪvd ɪm əweɪ ivən mɔɹ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "æz ɪt pliz ju, ɹænd ælθɹ," ʃi sɛd.

Harine nodded a little more impatiently. A man stepped out from the crew, in baggy green silk breeches and with an ivory-hilted sword and dagger thrust behind his sash. More white-haired than she, he also wore five fat little rings in each ear. She waved him away even more impatiently. "As it please you, Rand al'Thor," she said.

"æn ə kɔɹs," ɹænd æɾəd, əz ðoʊ ən æftɝθɑt, "aɪ mʌst əv mɛɹænə, ən ɹæfɛlə." hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən waɪ hi tʃoʊz ðə sɛkənd neɪm - pɝhæps kəz ðə plʌmp tɛɹən sɪstɝ wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn nɑt ɡɹin ɪksɛp mɛɹænə - bʌt tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, mɛɹænə smaɪld ɪn əpɹuvəl. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, bɛɹə nɑɾəd, ən soʊ dɪd feɪlʒɹɪn, ən ɑlɑnə.

"And of course," Rand added, as though an afterthought, "I must have Merana, and Rafela." He was not certain why he chose the second name - perhaps because the plump Tairen sister was the only one not Green except Merana - but to his surprise, Merana smiled in approval. For that matter, Bera nodded, and so did Faeldrin, and Alanna.

hɑɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpɹuv. hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. "æz ɪt plizɪz ju," ʃi sɛd, nɑt kwaɪt soʊ plɛzənli əz bɪfɔɹ.

Harine did not approve. Her mouth tightened before she could control it. "As it pleases you," she said, not quite so pleasantly as before.

wʌns i wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə stɝn kæbən, wɛɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ə fju bɹæs-baʊn tʃɛsts sim bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔlz, ɹænd wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt ɡeɪnd wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑntəd dʒʌs bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm ðɛɹ. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, hi wɑz fɔɹs tə stæn hʌntʃt oʊvɝ, ivən bɪtwin ðə ɹuf bimz, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ kɔld ɑn ə ʃɪp. hi hæd ɹɛd sɛvɹəl bʊks əbaʊt ʃɪps, bʌt nʌn mɛnʃən ðæt. ðə tʃɛɹ i wɑz ɔfɝɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə nɛɹoʊ teɪbəl wəd nɑt pʊl aʊt, biɪŋ fæsən tə ðə dɛk, ən wʌns mɪn ʃoʊɾ ɪm haʊ tə ənlætʃ ðə tʃɛɹ ɑɹm ən swɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt soʊ hi kəd sɪt, hɪz niz hɪt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə teɪbəl. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli eɪt tʃɛɹz. hɑɹɪn sæɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛnd, hɝ bæk tə ðə stɝnz ɹɛd-ʃʌɾɝd wɪndoʊz, wɪð əɹ wɪndfɪndɝ tə hɝ lɛft ən ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs tə hɝ ɹaɪɾ ən tɑvəl bɪloʊ hɝ. mɛɹænə ən ɹæfɛlə tʊk ðə tʃɛɹz bɪloʊ ʃələn, waɪl mɪn sæt tə ɹændz lɛft. dæʃivə, wɪð noʊ tʃɛɹ, tʊk ə pleɪs bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, stændɪŋ əpɹaɪt kwaɪɾ izəli, ðoʊ ðə ɹuf bimz ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃt ɪz hɛd, tu. ə jʌŋ wʊmən ɪn ə bɹaɪt blu blaʊs, wɪð wʌn θɪn ɪɹɪŋ ɪn itʃ ɪɹ, bɹɔt θɪk kʌps ə ti, bɹud blæk ən bɪɾɝ.

Once he was inside the stern cabin, where everything except a few brass-bound chests seemed built into the walls, Rand was not so sure the woman had not gained whatever she wanted just bringing him there. For one thing, he was forced to stand hunched over, even between the roof beams, or whatever they were called on a ship. He had read several books about ships, but none mentioned that. The chair he was offered at the foot of the narrow table would not pull out, being fastened to the deck, and once Min showed him how to unlatch the chair arm and swing it out so he could sit, his knees hit the bottom of the table. There were only eight chairs. Harine sat at the far end, her back to the stern's red-shuttered windows, with her Windfinder to her left and the Sailmistress to her right and Taval below her. Merana and Rafela took the chairs below Shalon, while Min sat to Rand's left. Dashiva, with no chair, took a place beside the door, standing upright quite easily, though the roof beams almost brushed his head, too. A young woman in a bright blue blouse, with one thin earring in each ear, brought thick cups of tea, brewed black and bitter.

"lɛts bi dʌn wɪð ðɪs," ɹænd sɛd tɛstəli əz sun əz ðə wʊmən lɛft wɪð əɹ tʃɹeɪ. hi lɛft ɪz kʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl æftɝ wʌn sɪp. hi kəd nɑt stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɾ ɪz lɛɡz. hi heɪɾəd biɪŋ kənfaɪnd. θɔts ə biɪŋ dʌbəld ɪnsaɪd ðə tʃɛs flæʃt ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə ɹeɪn ɪz tɛmpɝ. "ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ əz fɔlən, ði il əv kʌm oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ɔl ðə pɑɹts ə jəɹ dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi hæv kʌm tə pæs. aɪm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ."

"Let's be done with this," Rand said testily as soon as the woman left with her tray. He left his cup on the table after one sip. He could not stretch out his legs. He hated being confined. Thoughts of being doubled inside the chest flashed in his head, and it was all he could do to rein his temper. "The Stone of Tear has fallen, the Aiel have come over the Dragonwall, all the parts of your Jendai Prophecy have come to pass. I am the Coramoor."

hɑɹɪn smaɪld əkɹɔs əɹ kʌp, ə kul smaɪl wɪð noʊ əmjuzmən ɪn ɪt. "ðæt meɪ bi soʊ, əz ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt, bʌt - "

Harine smiled across her cup, a cool smile with no amusement in it. "That may be so, as it pleases the Light, but - "

"ɪɾ ɪz soʊ," ɹænd snæp dɪspaɪɾ ə wɔɹnɪŋ ɡlæns fɹəm mɛɹænə. ʃi wɛn soʊ fɑɹ tə nʌdʒ ɪz lɛɡ wɪð əɹ fʊt. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðæt, tu. ðə kæbən wɔlz sim kloʊsɝ, sʌmhaʊ. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðət jə doʊn bɪliv, weɪv-mɪstʃɹəs? ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝv mi? ɹæfɛlə, mɛɹænə." hi dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli.

"It is so," Rand snapped despite a warning glance from Merana. She went so far to nudge his leg with her foot. He ignored that, too. The cabin walls seemed closer, somehow. "What is it that you don't believe, Wave-mistress? That Aes Sedai serve me? Rafela, Merana." He gestured sharply.

ɔl i wɑntəd wɑz fəɹ əm tə kʌm tə hɪm ən bi sin tə kʌm, bʌt ðeɪ sɛt daʊn ðɛɹ kʌps ən ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli, ɡlaɪɾɪd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm - ən nɛlt. itʃ tʊk wʌn ə hɪz hænz ɪn boʊθ ə hɝz ən pɹɛst əɹ lɪps tə ðə bæk ʌv ɪt, ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ ɡoʊldən-meɪn hɛɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ðət waʊn ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹɑɹm. hi dʒʌs mænədʒ tə kənsil ɪz ʃɑk, nɑt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm hɑɹɪn. hɝ feɪs wɛn ə lɪɾəl ɡɹeɪ.

All he wanted was for them to come to him and be seen to come, but they set down their cups and rose gracefully, glided to either side of him - and knelt. Each took one of his hands in both of hers and pressed her lips to the back of it, right on the shining golden-maned head of the Dragon that wound around his forearm.
