He just managed to conceal his shock, not taking his eyes from Harine. Her face went a little gray.

"ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝv mi, ən soʊ wɪl ðə si foʊk." hi moʊʃən ðə sɪstɝz bæk tə ðɛɹ sits. ɑdli, ðeɪ lʊkt ə tʌtʃ sɝpɹaɪzd. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌt ðə dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi sɛz. ðə si foʊk wɪl sɝv ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ. aɪm ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ."

"Aes Sedai serve me, and so will the Sea Folk." He motioned the sisters back to their seats. Oddly, they looked a touch surprised. "That is what the Jendai Prophecy says. The Sea Folk will serve the Coramoor. I am the Coramoor."

"jɛs, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ ə ðə bɑɹɡən." ðət wɝd wɑz pleɪnli kæpɪɾəlaɪzd ɪn hɑɹɪnz toʊn. "ðə dʒɛndaɪ pɹɑfəsi sɛz jəl bɹɪŋ əs tə ɡlɔɹi, ən ɔl ðə siz ə ðə wɝld wɪl bi aʊɝz. əz wi ɡɪv tə ju, jə mʌst ɡɪv tə ʌs. ɪf aɪ də nɑt meɪk ðə bɑɹɡən wɛl, nɛstə wɪl hæŋ mi neɪkəɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ baɪ maɪ æŋkəlz ən kɔl ðə fɝs twɛlv ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn tə neɪm ə nu weɪvməstʃɹəs." ə lʊk ʌv ʌɾɝ hɔɹɝ stoʊl əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs əz ðoʊz wɝdz keɪm aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ, ən əɹ blæk aɪz wɛnt waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ baɪ ðə wɝd wɪð dɪsbɪlif. hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ ɡɑɡəld ət hɝ, ən dɪɹə ən tɑvəl tʃɹaɪd soʊ hɑɹd nɑt tə, ðɛɹ aɪz fæsən tə ðə teɪbəl, ðəɾ ɪt sim ðɛɹ feɪsəz maɪt bɹeɪk.

"Yes, but there is the matter of the Bargain." That word was plainly capitalized in Harine's tone. "The Jendai Prophecy says you will bring us to glory, and all the seas of the world will be ours. As we give to you, you must give to us. If I do not make the Bargain well, Nesta will hang me naked in the rigging by my ankles and call the First Twelve of Clan Shodein to name a new Wavemistress." A look of utter horror stole across her face as those words came out of her mouth, and her black eyes went wider and wider by the word with disbelief. Her Windfinder goggled at her, and Derah and Taval tried so hard not to, their eyes fastened to the table, that it seemed their faces might break.

ən sʌɾənli, ɹænd ʌndɝstʊd. tɑvɝən. hi hæd sin ði ɪfɛks, ðə sʌɾən moʊməns wən ðə lis laɪkli θɪŋ hæpən kəz i wɑz nɪɹ, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ noʊn wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪfɔɹ əntɪl ɪt wɑz fɪnɪʃt. izɪŋ ɪz lɛɡz əz bɛst i kʊd, hi lin ɪz ɑɹmz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪl sɝv mi, hɑɹɪn. ðəɾ ɪz ɡɪvən."

And suddenly, Rand understood. Ta'veren. He had seen the effects, the sudden moments when the least likely thing happened because he was near, but he had never known what was going on before until it was finished. Easing his legs as best he could, he leaned his arms on the table. "The Atha'an Miere will serve me, Harine. That is given."

"jɛs, wɪl sɝv ju, bʌt - " hɑɹɪn hæf-ɹɪɹɾ aʊɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ, spɪlɪŋ əɹ ti. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ tə mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ʃi kɹaɪd, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. "ðɪs ɪz nɑt fɛɹ bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ!"

"Yes, we will serve you, but - " Harine half-reared out her chair, spilling her tea. "What are you doing to me, Aes Sedai?" she cried, trembling. "This is not fair bargaining!"

"wi də nʌθɪŋ," mɛɹænə sɛd kɑmli. ʃi æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə dʒɹɪŋk ə swɑloʊ ʌv ðət ti wɪθaʊt wɪnsɪŋ.

"We do nothing," Merana said calmly. She actually managed to drink a swallow of that tea without wincing.

"ju ɑɹ ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ɹæfɛlə æɾəd. "ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ jəɹ pɹɑfəsi kɔlz jə tə sɝv, əz aɪ bɪliv." ʃi leɪɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ tə wʌn ɹaʊn tʃik. "ju sɛd jə spik fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. dʌz ðət min jəɹ wɝɾ ɪz baɪndɪŋ ɑn ði æθɑn maɪɹ?"

"You are in the presence of the Dragon Reborn," Rafela added. "The Coramoor your prophecy calls you to serve, as I believe." She laid a finger to one round cheek. "You said you speak for the Mistress of the Ships. Does that mean your word is binding on the Atha'an Miere?"

"jɛs," hɑɹɪn wɪspɝd hɔɹsli, fɔlɪŋ bæk ɪn əɹ sit. "wʌɾ aɪ seɪ baɪnz ɛvɹi ʃɪp, ən ɔl tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps hɝsɛlf." ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl fəɹ wʌn ə ðə si foʊk tə ɡoʊ waɪɾ ɪn ðə feɪs, jɛt stɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd, ʃi keɪm əz nɪɹ əz ʃi kʊd.

"Yes," Harine whispered hoarsely, falling back in her seat. "What I say binds every ship, and all to the Mistress of the Ships herself." It was impossible for one of the Sea Folk to go white in the face, yet staring at Rand, she came as near as she could.

hi smaɪld ət mɪn, tə ʃɛɹ ðə moʊmənt. ət læst ə pipəl wəd kʌm tə hɪm wɪθaʊt faɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹi stɛp ə ðə weɪ, əɹ splɪɾɪŋ əpɑɹt laɪk ði il. meɪbi mɪn θɔɾ i wɑntəɾ əɹ hɛlp tə klɪntʃ mæɾɝz, əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz tɑvɝən. ʃi lin təwɔɹd ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs. "ju wɪl bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ wʌt hæpənz hɪɹ tədeɪ, hɑɹɪn, bʌt nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz jə fɪɹ, aɪ θɪŋk. ət list, wʌn deɪ jəl bi ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps."

He smiled at Min, to share the moment. At last a people would come to him without fighting every step of the way, or splitting apart like the Aiel. Maybe Min thought he wanted her help to clinch matters, or maybe it was ta'veren. She leaned toward the Wavemistress. "You will be punished for what happens here today, Harine, but not so much as you fear, I think. At least, one day you will be the Mistress of the Ships."

hɑɹɪn fɹaʊn ət hɝ, ðən ɡlæns tə hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ.

Harine frowned at her, then glanced to her Windfinder.

"ʃi ɪz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃələn sɛd, ən hɑɹɪn sim kɑt bɪtwin ɹɪlif ən dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. əntɪl ɹæfɛlə spoʊk.

"She is not Aes Sedai," Shalon said, and Harine seemed caught between relief and disappointment. Until Rafela spoke.

"sɛvɹəl jɪɹz əɡoʊ, aɪ hɝd ɹɪpɔɹts ʌv ə ɡɝl wɪð ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl əbɪləɾi tə si θɪŋz. ɑɹ jə ʃi, mɪn?"

"Several years ago, I heard reports of a girl with a remarkable ability to see things. Are you she, Min?"

mɪn ɡɹɪməst ɪndə hɝ kʌp, ðən nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli; ʃi ɔlweɪz sɛd ðət ðə mɔɹ pipəl nu wʌt ʃi kəd du, ðə lɛs ɡʊd keɪm ʌv ɪt. ɡlænsɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi saɪd. ɹæfɛlə oʊnli nɑɾəd, bʌt mɛɹænə wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ, heɪzəl aɪz ævəɾ ɪn ə mæsk ə sɝɛnəɾi. noʊ daʊt ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə kɔɹnɝ mɪn əz sun əz pɑsəbəl ən faɪn aʊt wʌt ðɪs tælənt wɑz ən haʊ ɪt wɝkt, ən noʊ daʊt mɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt tu. ɹænd fɛlt ə pɹɪkəl ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən; ʃi ʃʊɾə noʊn i wəd pɹətɛkt əɹ fɹəm biɪŋ bɑðɝd. ə pɹɪkəl ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən, ən ə wɔɹmθ ðəɾ i kəd pɹətɛkt əɹ fɹəm ðæt, ət list.

Min grimaced into her cup, then nodded reluctantly; she always said that the more people knew what she could do, the less good came of it. Glancing across the table at the Aes Sedai, she sighed. Rafela only nodded, but Merana was staring at her, hazel eyes avid in a mask of serenity. No doubt she expected to corner Min as soon as possible and find out what this talent was and how it worked, and no doubt Min expected it too. Rand felt a prickle of irritation; she should have known he would protect her from being bothered. A prickle of irritation, and a warmth that he could protect her from that, at least.

"ju meɪ tʃɹʌst wʌt mɪn sɛz, hɑɹɪn," ɹæfɛlə sɛd. "ðə ɹɪpɔɹts aɪ hɝd seɪ ðət wʌt ʃi siz ɔlweɪz simz tə kʌm tʃɹu. ən ivən ɪf ʃi dʌz nɑt ɹilaɪz ɪt, ʃiz sin sʌmθɪŋ ɛls." hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs tɪltəd tə wʌn saɪd, ən ə smaɪl kɝvd əɹ maʊθ. "ɪf jəl bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ wʌt hæpənz hɪɹ, ðən ɪt mʌs min jəl əɡɹi tə wʌtɛvɝ jəɹ kɔɹəmʊɹ wɑns."

"You may trust what Min says, Harine," Rafela said. "The reports I heard say that what she sees always seems to come true. And even if she does not realize it, she has seen something else." Her round face tilted to one side, and a smile curved her mouth. "If you will be punished for what happens here, then it must mean you will agree to whatever your Coramoor wants."

"ənlɛs aɪ əɡɹi tə nʌθɪŋ," hɑɹɪn blʌstɝd. "ɪf aɪ meɪk noʊ bɑɹɡən. . . ." hɝ fɪsts klɛntʃt ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp. ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ədmɪɾəd ʃi hæd tə meɪk ðə bɑɹɡən. ʃi hæɾ ədmɪɾəd ðə si foʊk wəd sɝv.

"Unless I agree to nothing," Harine blustered. "If I make no Bargain. . . ." Her fists clenched on the tabletop. She had already admitted she had to make the Bargain. She had admitted the Sea Folk would serve.

"wʌɾ aɪ ɹikwaɪɝ ə jə ɪz nɑɾ oʊnɝəs," ɹænd sɛd. hi hæd θɔɾ əbaʊt ðɪs sɪns dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə kʌm. "wɛn aɪ wɑnt ʃɪps tə kæɹi mɛn əɹ səplaɪz, ðə si foʊk wɪl ɡɪv ðɛm. aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ ɪn tæɹɑbən ən ɑɹæd dumən, ən ɪn ðə lænz bɪtwin. jəɹ ʃɪps kən lɝn - wɪl lɝn - wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ; ðeɪ kɔl ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ən bændɑɹ ɛbən ən ə hʌnʒɹəd fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒəz ən taʊnz bɪtwin. jəɹ ʃɪps kən tʃɹævəl fɑɹðɝ aʊt tə si ðən ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz. ðə si foʊk wɪl kip wɑtʃ əz fɑɹ wɛst ɪn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən əz ðeɪ kən seɪl. ðəɹ ɪz ə pipəl, ðə ʃɔn-tʃæn, hu lɪv bɪɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, ən wʌn deɪ, ðəl kʌm tə tʃɹaɪ tə kɑŋkɝ ʌs. ðə si foʊk wɪl lemi noʊ wən ðeɪ kʌm."

"What I require of you is not onerous," Rand said. He had thought about this since deciding to come. "When I want ships to carry men or supplies, the Sea Folk will give them. I want to know what is happening in Tarabon and Arad Doman, and in the lands between. Your ships can learn - will learn - what I want to know; they call in Tanchico and Bandar Eban and a hundred fishing villages and towns between. Your ships can travel farther out to sea than anyone else's. The Sea Folk will keep watch as far west in the Aryth Ocean as they can sail. There is a people, the Sean-chan, who live beyond the Aryth Ocean, and one day, they will come to try to conquer us. The Sea Folk will let me know when they come."

"ju ɹikwaɪɝ mʌtʃ," hɑɹɪn mʌɾɝd bɪɾɝli. "wi noʊ ʌv ðiz sintʃæn, hu kʌm fɹəm ði aɪlənz ə ðə dɛd, ɪt simz, fɹəm wɪtʃ noʊ ʃɪp ɹɪtɝnz. səm ʌv əɹ ʃɪps əv ɪnkaʊntɝd ðɛɹz; ðeɪ juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. jə ɹikwaɪɝ mɔɹ ðən jə noʊ, kɔɹəmʊɹ." fəɹ wʌns, ʃi dɪd nɑt pɔz ət ðə taɪɾəl. "sʌm dɑɹk ivəl əz dɪsɛndəɾ əpɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. noʊ ʃɪp ʌv aʊɝz əz kʌm fɹəm ðəɹ ɪn mɛni mʌnθs. ʃɪps ðət seɪl wɛst, vænɪʃ."

"You require much," Harine muttered bitterly. "We know of these Seanchan, who come from the Islands of the Dead, it seems, from which no ship returns. Some of our ships have encountered theirs; they use the One Power as a weapon. You require more than you know, Coramoor." For once, she did not pause at the title. "Some dark evil has descended upon the Aryth Ocean. No ship of ours has come from there in many months. Ships that sail west, vanish."

ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hi tɝn ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ, meɪd fɹəm pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sintʃæn spɪɹ, ɪn ɪz hænz. kəd ðeɪv ɹɪtɝn ɔlɹɛɾi? ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒɹɪvən bæk wʌns, ət fɑlm. hi kæɹid ðə spɪɹhɛd tə ɹimaɪn ɪm ðət ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɛnəmiz ɪn ðə wɝl ðən ðoʊz i kəd si, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd teɪk ðə sintʃæn jɪɹz tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm ðɛɹ dɪfit, dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə si baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ðə dɛd hɪɹoʊz kɔl bæk baɪ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ. wɑz ðə hɔɹn stɪl ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ? hi nu ɪt hæd bɪn teɪkən ðɛɹ.

Rand felt a chill. He turned the Dragon Scepter, made from part of a Seanchan spear, in his hands. Could they have returned already? They had been driven back once, at Falme. He carried the spearhead to remind him that there were more enemies in the world than those he could see, but he had been sure it would take the Seanchan years to recover from their defeat, driven into the sea by the Dragon Reborn and the dead heroes called back by the Horn of Valere. Was the Horn still in the White Tower? He knew it had been taken there.

sʌɾənli hi kəd nɑt bɛɹ ðə kɑnfaɪnz ə ðə kæbən ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. hi fʌmbəld wɪð ðə lætʃ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ ɑɹm. ɪt wəd nɑɾ oʊpən. ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə smuð wʊd, hi tɔɹ ði ɑɹm ɔf ɪn splɪntɝz wɪð wʌn kənvʌlsɪv hiv. "wiv əɡɹid ðə si foʊk wɪl sɝv mi," hi sɛd, pʊʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp. ðə loʊ silɪŋ meɪɾ ɪm hʌntʃ oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl θɹɛɾənɪŋli. ðə kæbən dɪd fil smɔlɝ. "ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛni mɔɹ tə jəɹ bɑɹɡən, mɛɹænə ən ɹæfɛlə hɪɹ wɪl si tə ɪt wɪð ju." wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ, hi spʌn fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, wɛɹ dæʃivə əpɪɹd tə bi mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn.

Suddenly he could not bear the confines of the cabin any longer. He fumbled with the latch on the chair arm. It would not open. Gripping the smooth wood, he tore the arm off in splinters with one convulsive heave. "We've agreed the Sea Folk will serve me," he said, pushing himself up. The low ceiling made him hunch over the table threateningly. The cabin did feel smaller. "If there is any more to your Bargain, Merana and Rafela here will see to it with you." Without waiting for an answer, he spun for the door, where Dashiva appeared to be muttering to himself again.

mɛɹænə kɑɾ ɪm ðɛɹ, kɑɾ ɪz sliv ən spoʊk swɪfli ən loʊ. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ɪt wəd bi fəɹ ðə bɛst ɪf jə ɹɪmeɪnd. juv sin wʌt jəɹ biɪŋ tɑvɝən əz dʌn ɔlɹɛɾi. wɪð jə hɪɹ, aɪ bɪliv ʃɪl kəntɪnju tə ɹɪvil wʌt ʃi wɑns tə haɪɾ ən ɡɪv əɡɹimən bɪfɔɹ wi ɡɪv ɛniθɪŋ."

Merana caught him there, caught his sleeve and spoke swiftly and low. "My Lord Dragon, it would be for the best if you remained. You have seen what your being ta'veren has done already. With you here, I believe she will continue to reveal what she wants to hide and give agreement before we give anything."

"ju ɑɹ ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ," hi toʊld əɹ hɑɹʃli. "nəɡoʊʃieɪt! dæʃivə, kʌm wɪð mi."

"You are Gray Ajah," he told her harshly. "Negotiate! Dashiva, come with me."

ɑn dɛk, hi dʒɹu dip bɹɛθs. ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ wɑz oʊpən oʊvɝhɛd. oʊpən.

On deck, he drew deep breaths. The cloudless sky was open overhead. Open.

ɪt tʊk ɪm ə moʊmən tə noʊɾəs bɛɹə ən ði ʌðɝ tu sɪstɝz, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɪkspɛktənli. flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə kɛp tə wʌt ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə du, ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ən aɪ ɑn ðə ʃɪp ən ðə ɹɛst ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbɑŋks, ðə sɪɾi ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən ðə hæf-ɹibɪlt ɡɹænɛɝiz ɑn ði ʌðɝ. ə ʃɪp ɪn mɪd-ɹɪvɝ wɑz ə vʌlnɝəbəl pleɪs tə bi ɪf wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stʃɹaɪk. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɛniwɛɹ wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs ðɛn. ɹænd kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ wʌn ə ðɛm hæd nɑɾ ət lis tʃɹaɪd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə sʌn pæləs ɝaʊn ɪz ɪɹz.

It took him a moment to notice Bera and the other two sisters, watching him expectantly. Flinn and Narishma kept to what they were supposed to do, a quarter of an eye on the ship and the rest on the riverbanks, the city on one side and the half-rebuilt granaries on the other. A ship in mid-river was a vulnerable place to be if one of the Forsaken decided to strike. For that matter, anywhere was a dangerous place then. Rand could not understand why one of them had not at least tried to destroy the Sun Palace around his ears.

mɪn tʊk ɪz ɑɹm, ən i ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt.

Min took his arm, and he gave a start.

"aɪm sɑɹi," hi sɛd. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv lɛf ju."

"I'm sorry," he said. "I shouldn't have left you."

"ðæts ɔl ɹaɪt," ʃi læft. "mɛɹænə ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi sɛɾɪŋ tə wɝk. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi minz tə ɡɛt jə hɑɹɪnz bɛs blaʊs, ən meɪbi hɝ sɛkən bɛst əz wɛl. ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs lʊk laɪk ə ɹæbət kɑt bɪtwin tu fɛɹəts."

"That's all right," she laughed. "Merana is already setting to work. I think she means to get you Harine's best blouse, and maybe her second best as well. The Wavemistress looked like a rabbit caught between two ferrets."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. ðə si foʊk wɝ hɪz, əɹ əz ɡʊɾ æz. wʌt mæɾɝ wɛðɝ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ wɑz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ? hi wɑz tɑvɝən. hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ. ðə ɡoʊldən sʌn stɪl bɝnd wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪts nun pik. "ðə deɪ ɪz jʌŋ jɛt, mɪn." hi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ. "wʊd jə laɪk tə si mi sɛɾəl ðə ɹɛbəlz? ə θaʊzən kɹaʊnz tə ə kɪs, ðəɹ maɪn bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt."

Rand nodded. The Sea Folk were his, or as good as. What matter whether the Horn of Valere was in the White Tower? He was ta'veren. He was the Dragon Reborn, and the Coramoor. The golden sun still burned well short of its noon peak. "The day is young yet, Min." He could do anything. "Would you like to see me settle the rebels? A thousand crowns to a kiss, they're mine before sunset."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 35

ɪndə ðə wʊdz


Into the Woods

sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ɹændz bɛd, mɪn wɑtʃt hɪm, ɪn ɪz ʃɝt-slivz, ɹuɾɪŋ θɹu ðə koʊts ɪn ðə hjudʒ aɪvɝi-ɪnleɪd wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. haʊ kəɾ i slip ɪn ðɪs ɹum, wɪð ɔl ɪts blæk, hɛvi fɝnɪtʃɝ? ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ θɔɾ æbsənli əbaʊt muvɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aʊt, ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ɪt wɪð səm kɑɹv pisəz ʃi hæd sin ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, laɪtli tʌtʃt wɪð ɡɪldɪŋ, ən peɪl dʒɹeɪpɝiz ən lɪnənz ðəɾ i wəd faɪn lɛs əpɹɛsɪv. ɑd; ʃi hæd nɛvɝ kɛɹd wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ əbaʊt fɝnɪtʃɝ, əɹ lɪnənz. bʌt ðət wʌn tæpəstʃɹi ʌv ə bæɾəl, ʌv ə loʊn sɔɝdzmən sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɛnəmiz ən əbaʊt tə bi oʊvɝwɛlmd - ðət dɛfənətli hæd tə ɡoʊ. moʊsli, ðoʊ, ʃi dʒʌst wɑtʃt hɪm.

Sitting cross-legged on Rand's bed, Min watched him, in his shirt-sleeves, rooting through the coats in the huge ivory-inlaid wardrobe. How could he sleep in this room, with all its black, heavy furniture? A part of her thought absently about moving everything out, replacing it with some carved pieces she had seen in Caemlyn, lightly touched with gilding, and pale draperies and linens that he would find less oppressive. Odd; she had never cared one way or another about furniture, or linens. But that one tapestry of a battle, of a lone swordsman surrounded by enemies and about to be overwhelmed - that definitely had to go. Mostly, though, she just watched him.

ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ən ɪntɛn lʊk ɪn ɪz mɔɹnɪŋ-blu aɪz, ən ðə snoʊi ʃɝt taɪɾənd əkɹɔs ðə bɹɔɾ ə hɪz bæk wən i tɝn tə ɹitʃ dip ɪndə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz ɪntɪɹiɝ. hi hæd vɛɹi ɡʊd lɛɡz, ən mɑɹvələs kævz, ʃoʊn ɔf wɛl ɪn dɑɹk kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ bɹitʃɪz, wɪð ɪz buts tɝn daʊn. səmtaɪmz i fɹaʊnd, koʊmɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu dɑɹk ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ; noʊ əmaʊn ə bɹʌʃɪŋ kəd meɪk ɪt ɹuli; ɪɾ ɔlweɪz kɝl slaɪtli ɝaʊn ɪz ɪɹz ən ɑn ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk. ʃi wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz ful wɪmən u tɔs ðɛɹ bɹeɪnz əɾ ə mænz fiɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðɛɹ hɑɹts. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət səmtaɪmz, nɪɹ hɪm, θɪŋkɪŋ klɪɹli bɪkeɪm ə tʃɹaɪfəl dɪfəkəlt. ðət wɑz ɔl.

There was such an intent look in his morning-blue eyes, and the snowy shirt tightened across the broad of his back when he turned to reach deep into the wardrobe's interior. He had very good legs, and marvelous calves, shown off well in dark close-fitting breeches, with his boots turned down. Sometimes he frowned, combing fingers through dark reddish hair; no amount of brushing could make it ruly; it always curled slightly around his ears and on the nape of his neck. She was not one of those fool women who tossed their brains at a man's feet along with their hearts. It was just that sometimes, near him, thinking clearly became a trifle difficult. That was all.

koʊɾ æftɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlk koʊt keɪm aʊɾ ən wɑz tɔs tə ðə flɔɹ ətɑp ðə wʌn i hæd wɔɹn tə ðə si foʊk ʃɪp. kəd ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz stɪl bi ɡoʊɪŋ hæf soʊ wɛl wɪθaʊɾ ɪz tɑvɝən pɹɛzəns? ɪf oʊnli ʃi hæɾ ə ɹɪli jusfəl vjuɪŋ ə ðə si foʊk. əz ɔlweɪz tə hɝ aɪz, ɪmədʒəz ən kʌlɝfəl ɔʊɹəz flɪkɝɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, moʊst ɡɔn tu kwɪkli tə meɪk aʊt, ɔl bʌt wʌn minɪŋləs tə hɝ ət ðə moʊmənt. ðət wʌn vjuɪŋ keɪm ən wɛn ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz ə deɪ, ən wɛnɛvɝ mæt əɹ pɛɹɪn wɝ pɹɛzənt, ɪɾ ɛnkʌmpəs ðɛm, tu, ən səmtaɪmz ʌðɝz. ə væst ʃædoʊ lɝkt oʊvɝ hɪm, swɑloʊɪŋ ʌp θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ə taɪni laɪts laɪk faɪɝəfliz ðət hɝl ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə ɪɾ ɪn ən ətɛmp tə fɪl ʌp ðə dɑɹknəs. tədeɪ, ðəɹ sim tə bi kaʊnləs tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ə faɪɝəfliz, bʌt ðə ʃædoʊ sim lɑɹdʒɝ, tu. sʌmhaʊ ðət vjuɪŋ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ ɪz bæɾəl wɪð ðə ʃædoʊ, bʌɾ i ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə noʊ haʊ ɪt stʊd. nɑt ðət ʃi kəd ɹɪli seɪ, ɪksɛp ðət ðə ʃædoʊ ɔlweɪz sim tə bi wɪnɪŋ, tə wʌn dɪɡɹi əɹ ənʌðɝ. ʃi saɪd wɪð ɹɪlif tə si ði ɪmədʒ ɡoʊ.

Coat after embroidered silk coat came out and was tossed to the floor atop the one he had worn to the Sea Folk ship. Could the negotiations still be going half so well without his ta'veren presence? If only she had a really useful viewing of the Sea Folk. As always to her eyes, images and colorful auras flickered around him, most gone too quickly to make out, all but one meaningless to her at the moment. That one viewing came and went a hundred times a day, and whenever Mat or Perrin were present, it encompassed them, too, and sometimes others. A vast shadow lurked over him, swallowing up thousands upon thousands of tiny lights like fireflies that hurled themselves into it in an attempt to fill up the darkness. Today, there seemed to be countless tens of thousands of fireflies, but the shadow seemed larger, too. Somehow that viewing represented his battle with the Shadow, but he almost never wanted to know how it stood. Not that she could really say, except that the shadow always seemed to be winning, to one degree or another. She sighed with relief to see the image go.

ə taɪni stæb ʌv ɡɪl meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪft əɹ siɾ ɑn ðə kʌvɝlət. ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪli laɪd wən i æskt wʌt vjuɪŋz ʃi hæd kɛp bæk. nɑt ɹɪli. wʌt ɡʊd tə tɛl ɪm i wəɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli feɪl wɪθaʊɾ ə wʊmən u wɑz dɛɾ ən ɡɔn? hi bɪkeɪm blik tu izəli əz ɪt wɑz. ʃi hæd tə kip ɪz spɪɹəts ʌp, meɪk ɪm ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə læf. ɪksɛpt. . . .

A tiny stab of guilt made her shift her seat on the coverlet. She had not really lied when he asked what viewings she had kept back. Not really. What good to tell him he would almost certainly fail without a woman who was dead and gone? He became bleak too easily as it was. She had to keep his spirits up, make him remember to laugh. Except. . . .

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, ɹænd." seɪɪŋ ðət maɪt bi ə mɪsteɪk. mɛn wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz ɪn soʊ mɛni weɪz; wʌn mɪnət ðeɪ tʊk ɹizənəbəl ædvaɪs, ən ðə nɛks dɪd dʒʌs ði ɑpəzət. dɪlɪbɝətli dɪd ði ɑpəzət, ɪt simd. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðoʊ, ʃi fɛlt . . . pɹətɛktɪv . . . təwɔɹd ðɪs taʊɝɪŋ mæn u kəd pɹɑbli lɪft əɹ wɪð iðɝ hænd. ən ðət wɪθaʊɾ ɪz tʃænəlɪŋ.

"I don't think this is a good idea, Rand." Saying that might be a mistake. Men were strange creatures in so many ways; one minute they took reasonable advice, and the next did just the opposite. Deliberately did the opposite, it seemed. For some reason, though, she felt . . . protective . . . toward this towering man who could probably lift her with either hand. And that without his channeling.

"ɪɾ ɪz ə wʌndɝfəl aɪdiə," hi sɛd, tɔsɪŋ daʊn ə blu koʊt wɪð sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. "aɪm tɑvɝən, ən tədeɪ ɪt simz tə bi wɝkɪŋ ɪn maɪ feɪvɝ fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ." ə ɡɹin koʊt wɪð ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi wɛn tə ðə flɔɹ.

"It is a wonderful idea," he said, tossing down a blue coat with silver embroidery. "I'm ta'veren, and today it seems to be working in my favor for a change." A green coat with gold embroidery went to the floor.

"wʊdn jə ɹæðɝ kʌmfɝt mi əɡɛn?"

"Wouldn't you rather comfort me again?"

hi stɑp dɛd, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɪð ə sɪlvɝ-wɝkt ɹɛd koʊt hæŋɪŋ fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ɪz hænz. ʃi hoʊpt ʃi wɑz nɑt blʌʃɪŋ. kʌmfɝɾɪŋ. wɛɹ dɪd ðəɾ aɪdiə ɛvɝ kʌm fɹʌm? ʃi wʌndɝd saɪlənli. ði æns u hæd ɹeɪzd əɹ wɝ dʒɛntəl, kaɪnd wɪmən, bʌt ðeɪ hæd stʃɹɔŋ noʊʃənz ə pɹɑpɝ bɪheɪvjɝ. ðeɪ hæd dɪsəpɹuvd ə hɝ wɛɹɪŋ bɹitʃɪz, dɪsəpɹuvd ə hɝ wɝkɪŋ ɪn steɪbəlz, ðə dʒɑb ʃi lʌv bɛst, sɪns ɪt bɹɔɾ əɹ ɪndə kɑntækt wɪð hɔɹsəz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɛstʃən wʌt ðeɪ wəd θɪŋk ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, wɪð ə mæn ʃi wɑz nɑt mɛɹid tə. ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ faʊn aʊt, ðeɪ wəd ɹaɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm bɛɹlən dʒʌs tə skɪn hɝ. ən hɪm, tu, ʌv kɔɹs.

He stopped dead, staring at her with a silver-worked red coat hanging forgotten in his hands. She hoped she was not blushing. Comforting. Where did that idea ever come from? she wondered silently. The aunts who had raised her were gentle, kind women, but they had strong notions of proper behavior. They had disapproved of her wearing breeches, disapproved of her working in stables, the job she loved best, since it brought her into contact with horses. There was no question what they would think of comforting, with a man she was not married to. If they ever found out, they would ride all the way from Baerlon just to skin her. And him, too, of course.

"aɪ . . . nid tə kip muvɪŋ waɪl aɪm ʃʊɹ ɪts stɪl wɝkɪŋ," hi sɛd sloʊli, ðən tɝn kwaɪt kwɪkli bæk tə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. "ðɪs wɪl du," hi ɪkskleɪmd, pʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ə pleɪn koʊɾ ʌv ɡɹin wʊl. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ðɪs wɑz ɪn ðɛɹ."

"I . . . need to keep moving while I'm sure it is still working," he said slowly, then turned quite quickly back to the wardrobe. "This will do," he exclaimed, pulling out a plain coat of green wool. "I didn't know this was in there."

ɪt wɑz ðə koʊɾ i hæd wɔɹn kʌmɪŋ bæk fɹəm dəməaɪz wɛlz, ən ʃi kəd si hɪz hænz tʃɹɛmbəl əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi kæʒəwəl, ʃi ɡɑɾ ʌp ən wɛn tə pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm, kɹʌʃɪŋ ðə koʊt bɪtwin əm əz ʃi leɪɾ əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst.

It was the coat he had worn coming back from Dumai's Wells, and she could see his hands tremble as he remembered. Trying to be casual, she got up and went to put her arms around him, crushing the coat between them as she laid her head against his chest.

"aɪ lʌv ju" wɑz ɔl ʃi sɛd. θɹu hɪz ʃɝt ʃi kəd fil ðə ɹaʊnd, hæf-hil skɑɹ ɑn ɪz lɛf saɪd. ʃi kəd ɹikɔl wən i ɡɑɾ ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ jɛstɝdeɪ. ðət hæd bɪn ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi ɛvɝ hɛld ɪm ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz, waɪl i leɪ ʌnkɑnʃəs ən nɪɹ dɛθ.

"I love you" was all she said. Through his shirt she could feel the round, half-healed scar on his left side. She could recall when he got it as if it were yesterday. That had been the first time she ever held him in her arms, while he lay unconscious and near death.

hɪz hænz pɹɛst əɡɛnst əɹ bæk, skwizɪŋ əɹ taɪt, skwizɪŋ ðə bɹɛθ aʊɾ ə hɝ, bʌt ðɛn, dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋli, ðeɪ fɛl əweɪ. ʃi θɔɾ i mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt "nɑt fɛɹ" ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. wɑz i θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk waɪl ʃi hʌɡd hɪm? hi ʃəd bi, ɹɪli. mɛɹænə wɑz ə ɡɹeɪ, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz sɛd ðə si foʊk kəd meɪk ə dəmɑni swɛt. hi ʃəd bi, bʌt. . . . ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt kɪkɪŋ ɪz æŋkəl. dʒɛnli hi muvd əɹ əweɪ ən bɪɡæn pʊlɪŋ ɑn ðə koʊt.

His hands pressed against her back, squeezing her tight, squeezing the breath out of her, but then, disappointingly, they fell away. She thought he muttered something about "not fair" under his breath. Was he thinking about the Sea Folk while she hugged him? He should be, really. Merana was a Gray, yet it was said the Sea Folk could make a Domani sweat. He should be, but. . . . She thought about kicking his ankle. Gently he moved her away and began pulling on the coat.

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, "ju kæn bi ʃʊɹ ɪɾəl əv ɛni ɪfɛkt, dʒʌs kəz ɪt dɪɾ ɑn hɑɹɪn. ɪf jə biɪŋ tɑvɝən ɔlweɪz əfɛktəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, juɾ əv ɛvɹi ɹulɝ nilɪŋ ət jəɹ fit baɪ naʊ, ən ðə waɪtkloʊks, tu."

"Rand," she said firmly, "you can't be sure it will have any effect, just because it did on Harine. If you being ta'veren always affected everything, you'd have every ruler kneeling at your feet by now, and the Whitecloaks, too."

"ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi ɹɪplaɪd hɔɾəli, "æn tədeɪ aɪ kən də ɛniθɪŋ." skupɪŋ ʌp ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt, hi fæsən ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. ɪt bɔɹ ə pleɪn bɹæs bʌkəl, naʊ. ðə ɡɪldɪd dʒɹæɡən leɪ ətɑp ðə kʌvɝləɾ ɑn ðə bɛd. ɡlʌvz ə θɪn blæk lɛðɝ wɛn ɑn tə kʌvɝ ðə ɡoʊldən-meɪn hɛdz ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz ən ðə hɛɹənz bɹændɪɾ ɑn ɪz pɑmz. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn lʊk laɪk hɪm, də aɪ?" hi spɹɛɾ ɪz ɑɹmz, smaɪlɪŋ. "ðeɪ woʊnt noʊ əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt."

"I'm the Dragon Reborn," he replied haughtily, "and today I can do anything." Scooping up his sword belt, he fastened it around his waist. It bore a plain brass buckle, now. The gilded Dragon lay atop the coverlet on the bed. Gloves of thin black leather went on to cover the golden-maned heads on the backs of his hands and the herons branded on his palms. "But I don't look like him, do I?" He spread his arms, smiling. "They won't know until it's too late."

ʃi ɔlmoʊs θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz. "ju doʊn lʊk mʌtʃ laɪk ə ful, iðɝ." ən lɛɾ ɪm teɪk ðət haʊ hi wʊd. ði ɪɾiət aɪɾ əɹ əskæns, əz ɪf i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. "ɹænd, əz sun əz ðeɪ si ði il, ðəl iðɝ ɹʌn əɹ stɑɹt faɪɾɪŋ. ɪf jə woʊn teɪk ɛni ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ət lis teɪk ðoʊz æʃəmən. wʌn æɹoʊ, ən jəɹ dɛd, wɛðɝ jəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ ə ɡoʊðɝd!"

She almost threw up her hands. "You don't look much like a fool, either." And let him take that how he would. The idiot eyed her askance, as if he was not sure. "Rand, as soon as they see the Aiel, they will either run or start fighting. If you won't take any of the Aes Sedai, at least take those Asha'man. One arrow, and you're dead, whether you're the Dragon Reborn or a goatherd!"

"bʌɾ aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, mɪn," hi sɛd sɪɹiəsli. "æn tɑvɝən. wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ əloʊn; dʒʌs jə ən mi. ðəɾ ɪz, ɪf jə stɪl wɑnə kʌm."

"But I am the Dragon Reborn, Min," he said seriously. "And ta'veren. We are going alone; just you and me. That is, if you still want to come."

"jɔɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ wɪθaʊt mi, ɹænd ælθɹ." ʃi stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm seɪɪŋ i wəd tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn fiɾ ɪf i dɪd. ðɪs jufɔɹiə wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ðə dɑɹk bliknəs. "nændɛɹə woʊn laɪk ðɪs." ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪɡzækli wʌt wɛn ɑn bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə meɪɾənz - sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi pəkjuljɝ ɪndid, baɪ ðə θɪŋz ʃi hæd sin - bʌɾ ɛni hoʊp ðət ðət maɪt stɑp ɪm ɡʌɾɝd aʊt wən i ɡɹɪn laɪk ə smɔl bɔɪ ɪveɪɾɪŋ ɪz mʌðɝ.

"You're not going anywhere without me, Rand al'Thor." She stopped herself from saying he would trip over his own feet if he did. This euphoria was almost as bad as the dark bleakness. "Nandera won't like this." She did not know exactly what went on between him and the Maidens - something very peculiar indeed, by the things she had seen - but any hope that that might stop him guttered out when he grinned like a small boy evading his mother.

"ʃi woʊnt noʊ, mɪn." hi ivən hæɾ ə twɪŋkəl ɪn ɪz aɪ! "aɪ də ðɪs ɔl ðə taɪm, ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ noʊ." hi hɛld aʊɾ ə ɡlʌv hænd, ɪkspɛktɪŋ əɹ tə dʒʌmp wən i kɔld.

"She won't know, Min." He even had a twinkle in his eye! "I do this all the time, and they never know." He held out a gloved hand, expecting her to jump when he called.

ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt stʃɹeɪɾən əɹ ɡɹin koʊt, ɡlæns ɪndə ðə stænd-mɪɹɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ə hɝ hɛɹ - ən teɪk ɪz hænd. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə lip ɪf i kɹʊkəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ; ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i nɛvɝ faʊn aʊt.

There really was nothing to do but straighten her green coat, glance into the stand-mirror to make sure of her hair - and take his hand. The trouble was, she was ready to leap if he crooked a finger; she just wanted to make sure he never found out.

ɪn ði æntəɹum, hi meɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ ətɑp ðə ɡoʊldən ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn sɛɾ ɪn ðə flɔɹ, ən ʃi lɛɾ ɪm lɛɾ əɹ θɹu ɑntu ə hɪli fɔɹəs flɔɹ kɑɹpəɾɪd wɪð dɛd livz. ə bɝd flæʃt əweɪ, flɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd wɪŋz. ə skwɝəl əpɪɹɾ ɑn ə bɹæntʃ ən tʃɪɾɝd ət ðɛm, læʃɪŋ ə fɝi waɪt-tɪp teɪl.

In the anteroom, he made a gateway atop the golden Rising Sun set in the floor, and she let him lead her through onto a hilly forest floor carpeted with dead leaves. A bird flashed away, flaring red wings. A squirrel appeared on a branch and chittered at them, lashing a furry white-tipped tail.

ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊdz ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm nɪɹ bɛɹlən; ðəɹ wɝ nɑt mɛni ɹil fɔɹəsts ɛniwɛɹ kloʊs tə ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin. moʊst ə ðə tʃɹiz stʊd fɔɹ əɹ faɪv əɹ ivən tɛn peɪsɪz əpɑɹt, tɔl lɛðɝlifs ən paɪnz, tɔlɝ oʊks ən tʃɹiz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ, ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flæt ʃi ən ɹænd stʊɾ ɑn ən ʌp ə sloʊp ðət bɪɡæn oʊnli ə fju spænz ɔf. ivən ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ sim θɪnɝ ðən bæk hoʊm, ðə bʊʃəz ən vaɪnz ən bɹaɪɹz spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn pætʃəz, ðoʊ səm ə ðoʊz wɝ nɑt smɔl. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz bɹaʊn ən dʒɹaɪ. ʃi plʌkt ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv ən dæbd ət ðə swɛt ðət sʌɾənli sim tə pɑp aʊɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs.

It was hardly the sort of woods she remembered from near Baerlon; there were not many real forests anywhere close to the city of Cairhien. Most of the trees stood four or five or even ten paces apart, tall leatherleafs and pines, taller oaks and trees she did not know, running across the flat she and Rand stood on and up a slope that began only a few spans off. Even the undergrowth seemed thinner than back home, the bushes and vines and briars spread out in patches, though some of those were not small. Everything was brown and dry. She plucked a lace-edged handkerchief from her sleeve and dabbed at the sweat that suddenly seemed to pop out on her face.

"wɪtʃ weɪ də wi ɡoʊ?" ʃi æskt. baɪ ðə sʌn, nɔɹθ leɪ oʊvɝ ðə sloʊp, ðə dɝɛkʃən ʃi wəd tʃuz. ðə sɪɾi ʃəd laɪ əbaʊt sɛvən əɹ eɪt maɪlz ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən. wɪð lʌk, ðeɪ kəd wɔk ɔl ðə weɪ bæk wɪθaʊɾ ɛnkaʊntɝɪŋ ɛniwʌn. əɹ bɛɾɝ, ɡɪvən əɹ hil buts ən ðə tɝeɪn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə hit, ɹænd kəd dɪsaɪd tə ɡɪv ʌp ən meɪk ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ bæk tə ðə sʌn pæləs. ðə pæləs ɹumz wɝ kul kəmpɛɹd tə ðɪs.

"Which way do we go?" she asked. By the sun, north lay over the slope, the direction she would choose. The city should lie about seven or eight miles in that direction. With luck, they could walk all the way back without encountering anyone. Or better, given her heeled boots and the terrain, not to mention the heat, Rand could decide to give up and make another gateway back to the Sun Palace. The palace rooms were cool compared to this.

bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ ænsɝ, kɹæklɪŋ bɹʌʃ ən livz ənaʊnst sʌmwʌn kʌmɪŋ. ðə ɹaɪɾɝ u əpɪɹɾ ɑn ə lɔŋ-lɛɡəd ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð bɹaɪt-fɹɪn bɹaɪɾəl ən ɹeɪnz wɑz ə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, ʃɔɹɾ ən slɛndɝ ɪn ə dɑɹk blu, nɪɹli blæk, sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, hɔɹəzɑntəl slæʃɪz ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin ən waɪt ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm əɹ nɛk tə bɪloʊ hɝ niz. ðə swɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs kəd nɑt dɪmɪnɪʃ əɹ peɪl bjuɾi, əɹ meɪk əɹ aɪz lɛs ðən lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk pulz. ə smɔl klɪɹ ɡɹin stoʊn hʌŋ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd fɹəm ə faɪn ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn fæsən ɪn blæk hɛɹ ðət fɛl ɪn weɪvz tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz.

Before he could answer, crackling brush and leaves announced someone coming. The rider who appeared on a long-legged gray gelding with bright-fringed bridle and reins was a Cairhienin woman, short and slender in a dark blue, nearly black, silk riding dress, horizontal slashes of red and green and white running from her neck to below her knees. The sweat on her face could not diminish her pale beauty, or make her eyes less than large dark pools. A small clear green stone hung on her forehead from a fine golden chain fastened in black hair that fell in waves to her shoulders.

mɪn ɡæspt, ən nɑt fəɹ ðə hʌntɪŋ kɹɔsboʊ ðə wʊmən kæɹid kæʒəwəli ɹeɪzd ɪn wʌn ɡɹin-ɡlʌv hænd. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn. bʌt. . . .

Min gasped, and not for the hunting crossbow the woman carried casually raised in one green-gloved hand. For a moment, she was sure it was Moiraine. But. . . .

"aɪ də nɑt ɹikɔl siɪŋ iðɝ ə jə ɪn ðə kæmp," ðə wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn ə θɹoʊɾi, ɔlmoʊst sʌltʃɹi, vɔɪs. mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs hæd bɪn kɹɪstəl. ðə kɹɔs-baʊ loʊɝd, stɪl kwaɪt kæʒəwəli, əntɪl ɪt pɔɪntəd ɹɑk-stɛɾi ət ɹændz tʃɛst.

"I do not recall seeing either of you in the camp," the woman said in a throaty, almost sultry, voice. Moiraine's voice had been crystal. The cross-bow lowered, still quite casually, until it pointed rock-steady at Rand's chest.

hi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt laɪk tə teɪk ə lʊk ət jəɹ kæmp," hi sɛd wɪð ə slaɪt baʊ. "aɪ bɪliv jə ɑɹ ðə leɪɾi kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹd?" ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd, æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə neɪm.

He ignored it. "I thought I might like to take a look at your camp," he said with a slight bow. "I believe you are the Lady Caraline Damodred?" The slender woman inclined her head, acknowledging the name.

mɪn saɪd ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹɪli ɪkspɛktəd mɔɪɹeɪn tə tɝn ʌp əlaɪv. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ði oʊnli vjuɪŋ ə hɝz ðət hæɾ ɛvɝ feɪld. bʌt kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹd hɝsɛlf, wʌn ə ðə liɾɝz ə ðə ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ɹænd hɪɹ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən ə kleɪmən tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. . . . hi ɹɪli wɑz pʊlɪŋ ɔl ðə θɹɛdz ə ðə pæɾɝn ɝaʊn hɪm, tə hæv əɹ əpɪɹ.

Min sighed regretfully, but it was not as if she had really expected Moiraine to turn up alive. Moiraine was the only viewing of hers that had ever failed. But Caraline Damodred herself, one of the leaders of the rebellion against Rand here in Cairhien, and a claimant to the Sun Throne. . . . He really was pulling all the threads of the Pattern around him, to have her appear.

leɪɾi kæɹɑlin sloʊli ɹeɪz ðə kɹɔsboʊ tə wʌn saɪd; ðə kɔɹd meɪɾ ə laʊd snæp, lɔntʃɪŋ ðə bɹɔdhɛd boʊlt ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

Lady Caraline slowly raised the crossbow to one side; the cord made a loud snap, launching the broadhead bolt into the air.

"aɪ daʊt wʌn wəd də ɛni ɡʊɾ əɡɛns ju," ʃi sɛd, wɔkɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ sloʊli təwɔɹd ðɛm, "æn aɪ wəd nɑt laɪk jə tə θɪŋk aɪ wɑz θɹɛɾənɪŋ ju." ʃi lʊkt wʌns ət mɪn - dʒʌst ə ɡlæns ðət ɹæn hɛd tə toʊ, ðoʊ mɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɑz faɪld əweɪ - bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, leɪɾi kæɹɑlin kɛpt əɹ aɪz ɑn ɹænd. ʃi dʒɹu ɹeɪn θɹi peɪsɪz əweɪ, dʒʌs fɑɹ ɪnʌf soʊ hi kəd nɑt ɹitʃ əɹ əfʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd dɪɡ ɪn əɹ hilz. "aɪ kən oʊnli θɪŋk ʌv wʌn ɡɹeɪ-aɪd mæn wɪð jəɹ haɪɾ u maɪt sʌɾənli əpɪɹ aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ, ənlɛs pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ən il ɪn dɪsɡaɪz, bʌt pɝhæps jəl bi soʊ kaɪn əz tə səplaɪ ə neɪm?"

"I doubt one would do any good against you," she said, walking her gelding slowly toward them, "and I would not like you to think I was threatening you." She looked once at Min - just a glance that ran head to toe, though Min was sure everything about her was filed away - but aside from that, Lady Caraline kept her eyes on Rand. She drew rein three paces away, just far enough so he could not reach her afoot before she could dig in her heels. "I can only think of one gray-eyed man with your height who might suddenly appear out of nowhere, unless perhaps you are an Aiel in disguise, but perhaps you will be so kind as to supply a name?"

"aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ɹænd sɛd, ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ɛɹəɡən əz i hæd bɪn wɪð ðə si foʊk, jɛɾ ɪf ɛni tɑvɝən swɝlɪŋ ə ðə pæɾɝn wɑz ət wɝk, ðə wʊmən ɑn ðə hɔɹs ɡeɪv noʊ ɛvəɾəns.

"I am the Dragon Reborn," Rand said, every bit as arrogant as he had been with the Sea Folk, yet if any ta'veren swirling of the Pattern was at work, the woman on the horse gave no evidence.

ɹæðɝ ðən lipɪŋ daʊn tə fɔl tə hɝ niz, ʃi mɪɹli nɑɾəd, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps. "aɪ hæv hɝd soʊ vɛɹi mʌtʃ əbaʊt ju. aɪ hæv hɝd jə wɛn tə ðə taʊɝ tə səbmɪt tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. aɪ hæv hɝd jə min tə ɡɪv ðə sʌn θɹoʊn tə ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. aɪ hæv ɔlsoʊ hɝd ðət jə kɪld ɪleɪn, ən əɹ mʌðɝ."

Rather than leaping down to fall to her knees, she merely nodded, pursing her lips. "I have heard so very much about you. I have heard you went to the Tower to submit to the Amyrlin Seat. I have heard you mean to give the Sun Throne to Elayne Trakand. I have also heard that you killed Elayne, and her mother."

"aɪ səbmɪt tə noʊ wʌn," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd ʃɑɹpli. hi stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ əɹ wɪð aɪz fɪɹs ɪnʌf tə snætʃ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. "ɪleɪn ɪz ɑn əɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn əz wi spik, tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. æftɝ wɪtʃ, ʃɪl əv ðə θɹoʊn ə kɛɹhin əz wɛl." mɪn wɪnst. dɪɾ i hæv tə saʊn laɪk ə pɪloʊ stʌft fʊl ə hɔɾi? ʃi hæd hoʊpt i hæd kɑm daʊn ə bɪɾ æftɝ ðə si foʊk.

"I submit to no one," Rand replied sharply. He stared up at her with eyes fierce enough to snatch her out of the saddle by themselves. "Elayne is on her way to Caemlyn as we speak, to take the throne of Andor. After which, she will have the throne of Cairhien as well." Min winced. Did he have to sound like a pillow stuffed full of haughty? She had hoped he had calmed down a bit after the Sea Folk.

leɪɾi kæɹɑlin leɪɾ əɹ kɹɔsboʊ əkɹɔs ðə sæɾəl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ɹʌnɪŋ ə ɡlʌv hæn əlɔŋ ɪt. pɝhæps ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðət lus boʊlt? "aɪ kəɾ æksɛp maɪ jʌŋ kʌzən ɑn ðə θɹoʊn - bɛɾɝ ʃi ðən sʌm, ət list - bʌt. . . ." ðoʊz bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz ðət hæd sim soʊ lɪkwəd sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm stoʊn. "bʌɾ aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ aɪ kæn, æksɛp jə ɪn kɛɹhin, ən aɪ də nɑt min oʊnli jəɹ tʃeɪnʒəz tə lɔz ən kʌstəmz. jə . . . tʃeɪnʒ feɪt baɪ jəɹ vɛɹi pɹɛzəns. ɛvɹi deɪ sɪns jə keɪm, pipəl daɪ ɪn æksəɾənts soʊ bəzɑɹ noʊ wʌn kən bɪliv ðɛm. soʊ mɛni hʌzbənz əbændən ðɛɹ waɪvz, ən waɪvz ðɛɹ hʌzbənz, ðət noʊ wʌn ivən kɑmɛns əpɑn ɪt naʊ. jəl tɛɹ kɛɹhin əpɑɹt dʒʌs baɪ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɪɹ."

Lady Caraline laid her crossbow across the saddle in front of her, running a gloved hand along it. Perhaps regretting that loosed bolt? "I could accept my young cousin on the throne - better she than some, at least - but. . . ." Those big dark eyes that had seemed so liquid suddenly became stone. "But I am not sure I can, accept you in Cairhien, and I do not mean only your changes to laws and customs. You . . . change fate by your very presence. Every day since you came, people die in accidents so bizarre no one can believe them. So many husbands abandon their wives, and wives their husbands, that no one even comments upon it now. You will tear Cairhien apart just by remaining here."

"bæləns," mɪn bɹoʊk ɪn heɪstəli. ɹændz feɪs wɑz soʊ dɑɹk, hi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə bɝst. meɪbi hi hæd bɪn ɹaɪt tə kʌm æftɝ ɔl. sɝɾənli ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn lɛɾɪŋ ɪm θɹoʊ ðɪs miɾɪŋ əweɪ ɪn ə tæntʃɹəm. ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ wʌn ə tʃæns tə spik. "ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə bæləns ʌv ɡʊɾ əɡɛns bæd. ðæts haʊ ðə pæɾɝn wɝks. ivən i dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ ðæt. əz naɪt bælənsəz deɪ, ɡʊd bælənsəz hɑɹm. sɪns i keɪm, ðəɹ hæzən bɪn ə sɪŋɡəl stɪlbɝθ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, nɑt wʌn tʃaɪl bɔɹn dɪfɔɹmd. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ mɛɹɪdʒɪz səm deɪz ðən juz tə bi ɪn ə wik, ən fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn u tʃoʊks tə dɛθ ɑn ə fɛðɝ, ə wʊmən tʌmbəlz hɛɾ oʊvɝ hilz daʊn θɹi flaɪts ə stɛɹz ænd, ɪnstɛɾ ə bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ nɛk, stænz ʌp wɪθaʊɾ ə bɹuz. neɪm ði ivəl, ən jə kən pɔɪn tə ðə ɡʊd. ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ɹikwaɪɝz bæləns, ən i oʊnli ɪnkɹisəz ðə tʃænsəz ʌv wʌt maɪɾ əv hæpən ɛniweɪ ɪn neɪtʃɝ." sʌɾənli ʃi kʌlɝd, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. stɛɹɪŋ, mɔɹ laɪk.

"Balance," Min broke in hastily. Rand's face was so dark, he looked ready to burst. Maybe he had been right to come after all. Certainly there was no point letting him throw this meeting away in a tantrum. She gave no one a chance to speak. "There is always a balance of good against bad. That's how the Pattern works. Even he doesn't change that. As night balances day, good balances harm. Since he came, there hasn't been a single stillbirth in the city, not one child born deformed. There are more marriages some days than used to be in a week, and for every man who chokes to death on a feather, a woman tumbles head over heels down three flights of stairs and, instead of breaking her neck, stands up without a bruise. Name the evil, and you can point to the good. The turning of the Wheel requires balance, and he only increases the chances of what might have happened anyway in nature." Suddenly she colored, realizing they were both looking at her. Staring, more like.

"bæləns?" ɹænd mɝmɝd, aɪbɹaʊz lɪftɪŋ.

"Balance?" Rand murmured, eyebrows lifting.

"aɪv bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ səm ə mæstɝ fɛlz bʊks," ʃi sɛd feɪnli. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk ʃi wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə fəlɑsəfɝ. leɪɾi kæɹɑlin smaɪld əɾ əɹ tɔl sæɾəlboʊ ən tɔɪd wɪð əɹ ɹeɪnz. ðə wʊmən wɑz læfɪŋ ət hɝ. ʃi wəd ʃoʊ ðɪs wʊmən wʌt ʃi kəd læf æt!

"I've been reading some of Master Fel's books," she said faintly. She did not want anyone to think she was pretending to be a philosopher. Lady Caraline smiled at her tall saddlebow and toyed with her reins. The woman was laughing at her. She would show this woman what she could laugh at!

əbɹʌpli ə tɔl blæk ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð ðə lʊk ʌv ə wɔɹhɔɹs keɪm kɹæʃɪŋ θɹu ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ, ɹɪɾən baɪ ə mæn wɛl ɪndə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð kloʊs-kɹɑp hɛɹ ən ə pɔɪntəd bɪɹd. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz jɛloʊ tɛɹən koʊt, ðə fæt slivz stʃɹaɪpt wɪð ɡɹin sæɾən, aɪz ʌv ə stɑɹtlɪŋ pɹɪɾi blu lʊkt aʊɾ ə hɪz dæmp, dɑɹk feɪs, laɪk peɪl pɑlɪʃt sæfaɪɝz. nɑɾ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pɹɪɾi mæn, bʌt ðoʊz aɪz meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ə tu-lɔŋ noʊz. hi kæɹiɾ ə kɹɔsboʊ ɪn wʌn lɛðɝ-ɡɔntələɾəd hænd, ən bɹændɪʃt ə bɹɔd-hɛd boʊlt ɪn ði ʌðɝ.

Abruptly a tall black gelding with the look of a warhorse came crashing through the undergrowth, ridden by a man well into his middle years, with close-cropped hair and a pointed beard. Despite his yellow Tairen coat, the fat sleeves striped with green satin, eyes of a startling pretty blue looked out of his damp, dark face, like pale polished sapphires. Not a particularly pretty man, but those eyes made up for a too-long nose. He carried a crossbow in one leather-gauntleted hand, and brandished a broad-head bolt in the other.

"ðɪs keɪm daʊn ɪntʃəz fɹəm maɪ feɪs, kæɹɑlin, ən ɪts jəɹ mɑɹkɪŋz! dʒʌs kəz ðɛɹz noʊ ɡeɪm ɪz noʊ ɹizən - " hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ɹænd ən mɪn dʒʌs ðɛn, ən ɪz dʒɹɔn kɹɔsboʊ loʊɝd təwɔɹd ðɛm. "ɑɹ ðiz stʃɹeɪz, kæɹɑlin, əɹ dɪd jə faɪn spaɪz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi? aɪv nɛvɝ bɪlivd ælθɹ wəd kəntɪnju tə lɛɾ əs sɪt hɪɹ ənhɪndɝd."

"This came down inches from my face, Caraline, and it has your markings! Just because there's no game is no reason - " He became aware of Rand and Min just then, and his drawn crossbow lowered toward them. "Are these strays, Caraline, or did you find spies from the city? I've never believed al'Thor would continue to let us sit here unhindered."

hæf ə dʌzən mɔɹ ɹaɪɾɝz əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm, swɛɾɪŋ mɛn ɪn fæt-sliv koʊts wɪð sæɾən stʃɹaɪps ən pɝspaɪɹɪŋ wɪmən ɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz wɪð waɪd, θɪk leɪs kɑlɝz. ɔl kæɹiɪŋ kɹɔsboʊz. ðə læst ə ðoʊz ɹaɪɾɝz hæd nɑt hɔltəd, hɔɹsəz stæmpɪŋ ən tɔsɪŋ hɛdz, bɪfɔɹ twaɪs əz mɛni keɪm stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ θɹu ðə bɹʌʃ fɹəm ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən ən pʊld ʌp nɪɹ kæɹɑlin, slaɪt, peɪl mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn dɑɹk kloʊðz wɪð stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ səmtaɪmz tə bɪloʊ ðə weɪst. ɔl wɪð kɹɔsboʊz. sɝvəns əfʊt keɪm æftɝ, leɪbɝɪŋ ən pæntɪŋ wɪð ðə hit, ðə mɛn u wəd dʒɹɛs ən kæɹi ɛni daʊnd ɡeɪm. ɪt hɑɹdli sim tə mæɾɝ ðət nʌn hæd mɔɹ ðən ə skɪnɪŋ naɪf əɾ ɪz bɛlt. mɪn swɑloʊd, ən ʌnkɑnʃəsli bɪɡæn pæɾɪŋ əɹ tʃiks wɪð əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ vɪɡɝəsli. ɪf ivən wʌn pɝsən ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɹænd bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt. . . .

Half a dozen more riders appeared behind him, sweating men in fat-sleeved coats with satin stripes and perspiring women in riding dresses with wide, thick lace collars. All carrying crossbows. The last of those riders had not halted, horses stamping and tossing heads, before twice as many came struggling through the brush from another direction and pulled up near Caraline, slight, pale men and women in dark clothes with stripes of color sometimes to below the waist. All with crossbows. Servants afoot came after, laboring and panting with the heat, the men who would dress and carry any downed game. It hardly seemed to matter that none had more than a skinning knife at his belt. Min swallowed, and unconsciously began patting her cheeks with her handkerchief a little more vigorously. If even one person recognized Rand before he knew it. . . .

leɪɾi kæɹɑlin dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt. "nɑt spaɪz, dɑɹlɪn," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs tə feɪs ðə tɛɹən nukʌmɝz. ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə! ɔl ðət wɑz niɾəd naʊ wɑz lɔɹd tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən. mɪn wɪʃt ɹændz tɑvɝən tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə pæɾɝn kəd bi dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl lɛs kəmplit. "ə kʌzən ən ɪz waɪf," kæɹɑlin wɛn ɑn, "kʌm fɹəm ændɝ tə si mi. meɪ aɪ pɹɛzən toʊmɑs tʃɹəkənd - fɹəm ə maɪnɝ bɹæntʃ ə ðə haʊs - ən ɪz waɪf dʒeɪɪzi." mɪn ɔlmoʊst ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ; ði oʊnli dʒeɪɪzi ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn hæd bɪn ə dʌsti pɹun bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz twɛnti, ən saʊɝ ən bæd-tɛmpɝd tə but.

Lady Caraline did not hesitate. "Not spies, Darlin," she said, turning her horse to face the Tairen newcomers. The High Lord Darlin Sisnera! All that was needed now was Lord Toram Riatin. Min wished Rand's ta'veren tugging at the Pattern could be just a little less complete. "A cousin and his wife," Caraline went on, "come from Andor to see me. May I present Tomas Trakand - from a minor branch of the House - and his wife Jaisi." Min almost glared at her; the only Jaisi she had ever known had been a dusty prune before she was twenty, and sour and bad-tempered to boot.

dɑɹlɪnz ɡeɪz swɛpt oʊvɝ ɹænd əɡɛn, lɪŋɡɝɾ ə moʊmən ɑn mɪn. hi loʊɝɾ ɪz kɹɔsboʊ ən baʊɾ ɪz hɛd dʒʌst ə hɛɹ, ə haɪ lɔɹɾ ə tiɹ tə ə maɪnɝ noʊbəl. "ju ɑɹ wɛlkəm, lɔɹd toʊmɑs. ɪt teɪks ə bɹeɪv mæn tə dʒɔɪn əs ɪn əɹ pɹɛzən sɝkəmstænsəz. ælθɹ meɪ lus ðə sævədʒəz ɑn əs ɛni deɪ." ðə leɪɾi kæɹɑlin ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk ðəɾ i meɪɾ ə ʃoʊ ʌv nɑt siɪŋ.

Darlin's gaze swept over Rand again, lingered a moment on Min. He lowered his crossbow and bowed his head just a hair, a High Lord of Tear to a minor noble. "You are welcome, Lord Tomas. It takes a brave man to join us in our present circumstances. Al'Thor may loose the savages on us any day." The Lady Caraline gave him an exasperated look that he made a show of not seeing.

hi noʊɾəd ðət ɹændz ɹɪtɝn baʊ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən hɪz, haʊɛvɝ; noʊɾəd, ən fɹaʊnd. ə dɑɹkli hænsəm wʊmən ɪn ɪz ɹɛɾənu mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ - ʃi hæɾ ə lɔŋ hɑɹd feɪs, wɛl-pɹæktəst ɪn æŋɡɝ - ən ə staʊt fɛloʊ, skaʊlɪŋ ən swɛɾɪŋ ɪn ə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊɾ ə peɪl ɡɹin, hild ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝɾ ə fju stɛps əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ tə ɹaɪd ɹænd daʊn.

He noted that Rand's return bow was no more than his, however; noted, and frowned. A darkly handsome woman in his retinue muttered angrily under her breath - she had a long hard face, well-practiced in anger - and a stout fellow, scowling and sweating in a red-striped coat of pale green, heeled his horse forward a few steps as if thinking to ride Rand down.

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," ɹænd sɛd kuli, əz ðoʊ hi noʊɾəst nʌθɪŋ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə. . . . ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛnibəɾi, wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ɛɹəɡəns ɑn ə maʊntəntɑp. "nɑt mʌtʃ hæpənz əz wi ɪkspɛkt. fəɹ ɪnstəns, aɪ hɝd jə wɝ ɪn tiɹ, ɪn hæɾən mɝk."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Rand said coolly, as though he noticed nothing. The Dragon Reborn to. . . . The Dragon Reborn to just about anybody, was what it was. Arrogance on a mountaintop. "Not much happens as we expect. For instance, I heard you were in Tear, in Haddon Mirk."

mɪn wɪʃt ʃi dɛɹd spik ʌp, dɛɹd seɪ sʌmθɪŋ tə suð hɪm. ʃi sɛɾəld fəɹ stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm. kæʒəwəli. ə waɪf - naʊ ðəɹ wɑz ə wɝd ðət sʌɾənli saʊndəd faɪn - ə waɪf aɪdli pæɾɪŋ əɹ hʌzbənd. ənʌðɝ faɪn wɝd. laɪt, ɪt wɑz hɑɹd biɪŋ fɛɹ! ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli fɛɹ, hævɪŋ tə bi fɛɹ.

Min wished she dared speak up, dared say something to soothe him. She settled for stroking his arm. Casually. A wife - now there was a word that suddenly sounded fine - a wife idly patting her husband. Another fine word. Light, it was hard being fair! It was hardly fair, having to be fair.

"ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɪz bʌt leɪtli kʌm baɪ lɔŋboʊt wɪð ə fju ʌv ɪz kloʊs fɹɛnz, toʊmɑs." kæɹɑlinz θɹoʊɾi toʊn nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌɾ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ sʌɾənli pɹænst, noʊ daʊɾ əɾ ə ʃɑɹp hil, ən ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ə ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ʃi tɝn əɹ bæk tə dɑɹlɪn ən ʃɑt ɹænd ə bɹif wɔɹnɪŋ fɹaʊn. "du nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ðə haɪ lɔɹd, toʊmɑs."

"The High Lord Darlin is but lately come by longboat with a few of his close friends, Tomas." Caraline's throaty tone never changed, but her gelding suddenly pranced, no doubt at a sharp heel, and under cover of regaining control she turned her back to Darlin and shot Rand a brief warning frown. "Do not trouble the High Lord, Tomas."

"aɪ də nɑt maɪnd, kæɹɑlin," dɑɹlɪn sɛd, slɪŋɪŋ ɪz kɹɔsboʊ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl baɪ ə lup. hi ɹoʊɾ ə lɪɾəl kloʊsɝ ən ɹɛstəɾ ən ɑɹm ɑn ɪz tɔl sæɾəl-baʊ. "ə mæn ʃəd noʊ wʌt hiz stɛpɪŋ ɪntu. jə meɪ hæv hɝd ðə teɪlz əbaʊɾ ælθɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ, toʊmɑs. aɪ keɪm kəz ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɹoʊtʃt mi mʌnθs əɡoʊ wɪð sədʒɛstʃənz ðət maɪt hæpən, ən jəɹ kʌzən ɪnfɔɹmd mi ʃi hæd ɹəsiv ðə seɪm. wi θɔt wi maɪt pʊɾ əɹ ɑn ðə sʌn θɹoʊn bɪfɔɹ koʊləveɪɪɹ kəd teɪk ɪt. wɛl, ælθɹ ɪz noʊ ful; nɛvɝ bɪliv i ɪz. maɪsɛlf, aɪ θɪŋk i pleɪd ðə taʊɝ laɪk ə hɑɹp. koʊləveɪɪɹ ɪz hæŋd, hi sɪts sɪkjʊɹ bɪhaɪn kɛɹhinz wɔlz - wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hɔltɝ, əl weɪdʒɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ɹumɝ sɛz - ən əntɪl wi faɪn səm weɪ tə ɛkstʃɹəkeɪɾ aʊɝsɛlvz, wi sɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænd, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk ə fɪst."

"I do not mind, Caraline," Darlin said, slinging his crossbow from his saddle by a loop. He rode a little closer and rested an arm on his tall saddle-bow. "A man should know what he is stepping into. You may have heard the tales about al'Thor going to the Tower, Tomas. I came because Aes Sedai approached me months ago with suggestions that might happen, and your cousin informed me she had received the same. We thought we might put her on the Sun Throne before Colavaere could take it. Well, al'Thor is no fool; never believe he is. Myself, I think he played the Tower like a harp. Colavaere is hanged, he sits secure behind Cairhien's walls - without an Aes Sedai halter, I'll wager, no matter what rumor says - and until we find some way to extricate ourselves, we sit in his hand, waiting for him to make a fist."

"ə ʃɪp bɹɔt ju," ɹænd sɛd sɪmpli. "ə ʃɪp kəd teɪk jə əweɪ." əbɹʌpli mɪn ɹilaɪzd i wɑz dʒɛnli pæɾɪŋ əɹ hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə suð hɝ!

"A ship brought you," Rand said simply. "A ship could take you away." Abruptly Min realized he was gently patting her hand on his arm. Trying to soothe her!

stɑɹtlɪŋli, dɑɹlɪn θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni wɪmən wəd fɝɡɛɾ ɪz noʊz fəɹ ðoʊz aɪz ən ðət læf. "soʊ ɪt wʊd, toʊmɑs, bʌɾ aɪv æsk jəɹ kʌzən tə mɛɹi mi. ʃɪl nɑt seɪ jɛs əɹ noʊ, bʌɾ ə mæn kænɑɾ əbændən ivən ə pɑsəbəl waɪf tə ðə mɝsiz ə ði il, ən ʃɪl nɑt liv."

Startlingly, Darlin threw back his head and laughed. A great many women would forget his nose for those eyes and that laugh. "So it would, Tomas, but I've asked your cousin to marry me. She will not say yes or no, but a man cannot abandon even a possible wife to the mercies of the Aiel, and she will not leave."

kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹd dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp ɑn əɹ sæɾəl, feɪs koʊld ɪnʌf tə ʃeɪm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt sʌɾənli ɔʊɹəz ə ɹɛɾ ən waɪt flæʃt ɝaʊn əɹ ən dɑɹlɪn, ən mɪn nu. ðə kʌlɝz nɛvɝ sim tə mæɾɝ, bʌt ʃi nu ðət ðeɪ wəd mɛɹi - æftɝ kæɹɑlin hæd lɛɾ ɪm ə mɛɹi tʃeɪs. mɔɹ, tə hɝ aɪz ə kɹaʊn sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ ɑn dɑɹlɪnz hɛd, ə sɪmpəl ɡoʊldən sɝklət wɪð ə slaɪtli kɝv sɔɹd laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪts saɪɾ əbʌv ɪz bɹaʊz. ðə kɪŋz kɹaʊn i wəd wɛɹ wʌn deɪ, ðoʊ ʌv wʌt kʌntʃɹi, ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ. tiɹ hæd haɪ lɔɹdz ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə kɪŋ.

Caraline Damodred drew herself up on her saddle, face cold enough to shame an Aes Sedai, but suddenly auras of red and white flashed around her and Darlin, and Min knew. The colors never seemed to matter, but she knew that they would marry - after Caraline had led him a merry chase. More, to her eyes a crown suddenly appeared on Darlin's head, a simple golden circlet with a slightly curved sword lying on its side above his brows. The king's crown he would wear one day, though of what country, she could not say. Tear had High Lords instead of a king.

ɪmədʒ ən ɔʊɹəz vænɪʃt əz dɑɹlɪn pʊld ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊn tə feɪs kæɹɑlin. "ðɛɹz noʊ ɡeɪm tə bi faʊn tədeɪ. tɔɹæm əz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹɪtɝn tə kæmp. aɪ sədʒɛst wi də ðə seɪm." ðoʊz blu aɪz skæn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz kwɪkli. "ɪt simz jəɹ kʌzən ən ɪz waɪf əv lɔs ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ðəl wɑndɝ, ɪn ə kɛɹləs moʊmənt," hi æɾəd tə ɹænd, ɪn ə kaɪnli toʊn. hi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðeɪ hæd noʊ hɔɹsəz. "bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ ɹoʊvɛɹ ən ɪnɪs wɪl ɡɪv ʌp ðɛɹ maʊns. ə wɔk ɪn ði ɛɹ wɪl də ðɛm ɡʊd."

Image and auras vanished as Darlin pulled his horse around to face Caraline. "There's no game to be found today. Toram has already returned to camp. I suggest we do the same." Those blue eyes scanned the surrounding trees quickly. "It seems your cousin and his wife have lost their horses. They will wander, in a careless moment," he added to Rand, in a kindly tone. He knew very well they had no horses. "But I'm sure Rovair and Ines will give up their mounts. A walk in the air will do them good."

ðə staʊt mæn ɪn ðə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz tɔl beɪ ɪmiɾiətli, wɪð ə toʊɾiɪŋ smaɪl fəɹ dɑɹlɪn ən wʌn mɑɹkədli lɛs wɔɹm ɪf dʒʌst əz ɡɹisi fəɹ ɹænd. ði æŋɡɹi-feɪst wʊmən wɑz ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ ɪn klaɪmɪŋ stɪfli fɹəm əɹ sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk plizd.

The stout man in the red-striped coat swung down from his tall bay immediately, with a toadying smile for Darlin and one markedly less warm if just as greasy for Rand. The angry-faced woman was a moment later in climbing stiffly from her silver-gray mare. She did not look pleased.

niðɝ wɑz mɪn. "ju min tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ðɛɹ kæmp?" ʃi wɪspɝɾ əz ɹænd lɛɾ əɹ tə ðə hɔɹsəz. "ɑɹ jə mæd?" ʃi æɾəd bɪfɔɹ θɪŋkɪŋ.

Neither was Min. "You mean to go into their camp?" she whispered as Rand led her to the horses. "Are you mad?" she added before thinking.

"nɑt jɛt," hi sɛd sɔfli, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ noʊz wɪð ðə tɪp ʌv wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. "θæŋks tə ju, aɪ noʊ ðæt." ən i bustɪɾ əɹ ɑntu ðə mɛɹ, ðən klaɪmd ɪndə ðə beɪz sæɾəl ən hil ði ænəməl ʌp bɪsaɪd dɑɹlɪn.

"Not yet," he said softly, touching her nose with the tip of one finger. "Thanks to you, I know that." And he boosted her onto the mare, then climbed into the bay's saddle and heeled the animal up beside Darlin.

hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ ən ə lɪɾəl təwɔɹd ðə wɛst, əkɹɔs ðə sloʊp, ðeɪ lɛft ɹoʊvɛɹ ən ɪnɪs stændɪŋ bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ saʊɝli. əz ðeɪ fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪnd wɪð ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ði ʌðɝ tɛɹənz ʃaʊɾəd læfɪŋ wɪʃɪz ðət ðə pɛɹ wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ðə wɔk.

Heading north and a little toward the west, across the slope, they left Rovair and Ines standing beneath the trees frowning at one another sourly. As they fell in behind with the Cairhienin, the other Tairens shouted laughing wishes that the pair would enjoy the walk.

mɪn wʊɾə ɹɪɾən əlɔŋsaɪd ɹænd, bʌt kæɹɑlin pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm, dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ ɪn bæk ə ðə tu mɛn. "aɪ wɑnə si wʌɾ i dʌz," kæɹɑlin sɛd kwaɪətli. wɪtʃ wʌn, mɪn wʌndɝd. "ju ɑɹ ɪz lʌvɝ?" kɛɹə-laɪn æskt.

Min would have ridden alongside Rand, but Caraline put a hand on her arm, drawing her in back of the two men. "I want to see what he does," Caraline said quietly. Which one, Min wondered. "You are his lover?" Cara-line asked.

"jɛs," mɪn toʊld əɹ dɪfaɪənli, wʌns ʃi kəd kætʃ ə bɹɛθ. hɝ tʃiks fɛlt laɪk faɪɝ. bʌt ðə wʊmən oʊnli nɑɾəd, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə moʊs nætʃɹəl θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. meɪbi ɪt wɑz, ɪn kɛɹhin. səmtaɪmz ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɔl ðə səfɪstəkeɪʃən ʃi hæd pɪkt ʌp tɔkɪŋ tə wɝldli pipəl wɑz əbaʊɾ əz θɪk əz əɹ blaʊs.

"Yes," Min told her defiantly, once she could catch a breath. Her cheeks felt like fire. But the woman only nodded, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. Maybe it was, in Cairhien. Sometimes she realized that all the sophistication she had picked up talking to worldly people was about as thick as her blouse.

ɹænd ən dɑɹlɪn ɹoʊd ni tə ni dʒʌst əhɛd, ðə jʌŋɡɝ mæn hæf ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən ði oʊldɝ, itʃ ɹæpt ɪn pɹaɪd laɪk ə kloʊk. bʌt tɔkɪŋ, dʒʌs ðə seɪm. lɪsnɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ izi. ðeɪ spoʊk kwaɪətli, ən ðə dɛd livz ɹʌslɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz, fɔlən bɹæntʃəz kɹækɪŋ, ɔfən wɑz ɪnʌf tə mʌfəl ðɛɹ wɝdz. ðə kɹaɪ ʌv ə hɔk oʊvɝhɛɾ əɹ ðə tʃæɾɝɪŋ ʌv ə skwɝəl ɪn ə tʃɹi dʒɹaʊn ðɛm. stɪl, ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə oʊvɝhɪɹ snætʃɪz.

Rand and Darlin rode knee to knee just ahead, the younger man half a head taller than the older, each wrapped in pride like a cloak. But talking, just the same. Listening was not easy. They spoke quietly, and the dead leaves rustling under the horses' hooves, fallen branches cracking, often was enough to muffle their words. The cry of a hawk overhead or the chattering of a squirrel in a tree drowned them. Still, it was possible to overhear snatches.

"ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ, toʊmɑs," dɑɹlɪn sɛɾ ət wʌn pɔɪnt, əz ðeɪ hɛɾəd daʊn æftɝ ðə fɝst ɹaɪz, "æn ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ aɪ ɔfɝ noʊ dɪsɹɪspɛkt, jə ɑɹ fɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪn hævɪŋ ə bjuɾəfəl waɪf. ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, əl əv wʌn əz bjuɾəfəl maɪsɛlf."

"If I may say so, Tomas," Darlin said at one point, as they headed down after the first rise, "and under the Light I offer no disrespect, you are fortunate in having a beautiful wife. The Light willing, I will have one as beautiful myself."

"waɪ də ðeɪ nɑt spik ə sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt?" kæɹɑlin mʌɾɝd.

"Why do they not speak of something important?" Caraline muttered.

mɪn tɝn əɹ hɛd tə haɪɾ ə smɔl smaɪl. ðə leɪɾi kæɹɑlin dɪd nɑt lʊk hæf əz dɪsplizd əz ʃi saʊndəd. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɛvɝ kɛɹd wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn θɔɾ əɹ pɹɪɾi əɹ nɑt. wɛl, əntɪl ʃi mɛt ɹænd, ɛniweɪ. meɪbi dɑɹlɪnz noʊz wɑz nɑɾ ɔl ðət lɔŋ.

Min turned her head to hide a small smile. The Lady Caraline did not look half as displeased as she sounded. She herself had never cared whether anyone thought her pretty or not. Well, until she met Rand, anyway. Maybe Darlin's nose was not all that long.

"aɪ wʊɾə lɛɾ ɪm teɪk kælændɝ fɹəm ðə stoʊn," dɑɹlɪn sɛd səm taɪm leɪɾɝ, əz ðeɪ klaɪmd ə spɑɹsli tʃɹid sloʊp, "bʌɾ aɪ kəd nɑt stæn əsaɪd wən i bɹɔɾ il ɪnveɪɾɝz ɪndə tiɹ."

"I would have let him take Callandor from the Stone," Darlin said some time later, as they climbed a sparsely treed slope, "but I could not stand aside when he brought Aiel invaders into Tear."

"aɪv ɹɛd ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən," ɹænd sɛd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ðə beɪz nɛk ən ɝdʒɪŋ ði ænəməl ɑn. ə faɪn ɡlɔsi əpɪɹəns ðə hɔɹs hæd, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ bɑɾəm ðən ɪz oʊnɝ, mɪn səspɛktəd. "ðə stoʊn hæd tə fɔl bɪfɔɹ i kəd teɪk kælændɝ," ɹænd kəntɪnjud. "ʌðɝ tɛɹən lɔɹdz fɑloʊ hɪm, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ."

"I've read the Prophecies of the Dragon," Rand said, leaning forward on the bay's neck and urging the animal on. A fine glossy appearance the horse had, but no more bottom than his owner, Min suspected. "The Stone had to fall before he could take Callandor," Rand continued. "Other Tairen lords follow him, so I hear."

dɑɹlɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "ðeɪ kɹɪnʒ ən lɪk ɪz buts! aɪ kəɾ əv fɑloʊd, ɪf ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wɑntəd, ɪf. . . ." wɪð ə saɪ, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "tu mɛni ɪfs, toʊmɑs. ðəɹ ɪz ə seɪɪŋ ɪn tɛɹ. 'ɛni kwɔɹəl kən bi fɝɡɪvən, bʌt kɪŋz nɛvɝ fɝɡɛt.' tiɹ əz nɑt bɪn ʌndɝ ə kɪŋ sɪns ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz vɛɹi laɪk ə kɪŋ. noʊ, hiz əɾəntɪd mi wɪð tʃɹizən, əz i kɔlz ɪt, ən aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn əz aɪ bɪɡæn. ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, aɪ meɪ si tɛɹ sɑvɹən ɑn ɪts oʊn lænd wʌns mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ aɪ daɪ."

Darlin snorted. "They cringe and lick his boots! I could have followed, if that was what he wanted, if. . . ." With a sigh, he shook his head. "Too many ifs, Tomas. There is a saying in Tear. 'Any quarrel can be forgiven, but kings never forget.' Tear has not been under a king since Artur Hawkwing, but I think the Dragon Reborn is very like a king. No, he has attainted me with treason, as he calls it, and I must go on as I began. The Light willing, I may see Tear sovereign on its own land once more before I die."

ɪt hæd tə bi tɑvɝən wɝk, mɪn nu. ðə mæn wəd nɛvɝ əv spoʊkən ðɪs weɪ tə sʌmwʌn kæʒəwəli mɛt, kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹdz səpoʊz kʌzən əɹ nɑt. bʌt wʌd ɹænd θɪŋk? ʃi kəd hɑɹdli weɪt tə tɛl ɪm əbaʊt ðə kɹaʊn.

It had to be ta'veren work, Min knew. The man would never have spoken this way to someone casually met, Caraline Damodred's supposed cousin or not. But what did Rand think? She could hardly wait to tell him about the crown.

tɑpɪŋ ðət hɪl, ðeɪ sʌɾənli keɪm ɑn ə nɑɾ ə spɹmən, səm wɪð ə dɛntɪd bɹɛstpleɪɾ əɹ hɛlmət, moʊst wɪθaʊɾ iðɝ, hu baʊɾ əz sun ðeɪ sɔ ðə pɑɹɾi. tə lɛft ən ɹaɪt θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, mɪn kəd si ʌðɝ ɡɹups ə sɛntʃɹiz. bɪloʊ, ðə kæmp leɪ spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn wʌt simd ə pɝmənən heɪz ə dʌst, daʊn ə nɪɹli tʃɹiləs sloʊp ən əkɹɔs ðə hɪlvəli ən ʌp ðə nɛks hɪl. itʃ ə ðə fju tɛns wɑz lɑɹdʒ, wɪð səm noʊbəlz bænɝ hæŋɪŋ lɪmpli ɑn ə stæf əbʌv ðə pik. ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni hɔɹsəz stʊd taɪd tə pɪkət laɪnz əz ðəɹ wɝ pipəl, ən θaʊzənz ə mɛn ən ə hændfʊl ʌv wɪmən wɑndɝɾ əmʌŋ ðə kʊkfaɪɝz ən wæɡənz. nʌn ɹeɪzd ə tʃɪɹ əz ðɛɹ liɾɝz ɹoʊɾ ɪn.

Topping that hill, they suddenly came on a knot of spearmen, some with a dented breastplate or helmet, most without either, who bowed as soon they saw the party. To left and right through the trees, Min could see other groups of sentries. Below, the camp lay spread out in what seemed a permanent haze of dust, down a nearly treeless slope and across the hillvalley and up the next hill. Each of the few tents was large, with some noble's banner hanging limply on a staff above the peak. Almost as many horses stood tied to picket lines as there were people, and thousands of men and a handful of women wandered among the cookfires and wagons. None raised a cheer as their leaders rode in.

mɪn stʌɾid əm oʊvɝ ðə hæŋkɝtʃɪf ʃi pɹɛs tə hɝ noʊz əɡɛns ðə dʌst, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wɛðɝ kæɹɑlin sɔ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. dɪspɪɹəɾɪd feɪsəz wɑtʃt əm pæs, ən ɡɹɪm feɪsəz, pipəl u nu ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ə tʃɹæp. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə haʊsəz kɑn stʊd stɪfli əbʌv səm mænz hɛd, jɛt moʊst sim tə bi wɛɹɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd, bɪts ən pisəz ʌv ɑɹmɝ ðəɾ ɔfən niðɝ mætʃt nɔɹ fɪɾəd vɛɹi wɛl. ə ɡʊd mɛni, ðoʊ, mɛn tu tɔl fəɹ kɛɹhin, wɔɹ ɹɛd koʊts ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bæɾɝd bɹɛstpleɪts. mɪn aɪɾ ə nɪɹli əbskjʊɹd waɪt laɪən wɝkt ɑn ə fɪlθi ɹɛd sliv. dɑɹlɪn kəɾ oʊnli hæv bɹɔɾ ə fju pipəl wɪð ɪm ɑn ə lɔŋboʊt, pɝhæps noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɪz hʌntɪŋ pɑɹɾi. kæɹɑlin lʊk tə niðɝ saɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu ðə kæmp, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ keɪm nɪɹ ðoʊz mɛn ɪn ɹɛd koʊts, hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd.

Min studied them over the handkerchief she pressed to her nose against the dust, not caring whether Caraline saw what she was doing. Dispirited faces watched them pass, and grim faces, people who knew they were in a trap. Here and there a House's con stood stiffly above some man's head, yet most seemed to be wearing whatever they could find, bits and pieces of armor that often neither matched nor fitted very well. A good many, though, men too tall for Cairhien, wore red coats under their battered breastplates. Min eyed a nearly obscured white lion worked on a filthy red sleeve. Darlin could only have brought a few people with him on a longboat, perhaps no more than his hunting party. Caraline looked to neither side as they rode through the camp, but whenever they came near those men in red coats, her mouth tightened.

dɑɹlɪn dɪsmaʊntɪd bɪfɔɹ ə tʃɹəmɛndəs tɛnt, ðə lɑɹdʒəs mɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɛni ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ ɪmædʒənd, ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪpt oʊvəl, ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt laɪk sɪlk, wɪð noʊ fjuɝ ðən fɔɹ haɪ kɑnɪkəl piks, itʃ wɪð ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ə kɛɹhin stɝɪŋ əbʌv ɪn ə leɪzi bɹiz, ɡoʊld ɑn blu. ðə stʃɹʌmɪŋ ə hɑɹps dʒɹɪftəɾ aʊɾ əmɪd ðə mɝmɝ ə vɔɪsəz, laɪk ðə saʊnz ʌv ɡis. əz sɝvəns tʊk əweɪ ðə hɔɹsəz, dɑɹlɪn ɔfɝɾ ɪz ɑɹm tə kæɹɑlin. æftɝ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ pɔz, ʃi leɪɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz laɪtli ɑn ɪz ɹɪst wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən wʌtsoʊɛvɝ, lɛɾɪŋ ɪm ɛskɔɹɾ əɹ ɪnsaɪd.

Darlin dismounted before a tremendous tent, the largest Min had ever seen, larger than any she had ever imagined, a great red-striped oval, shining in the sunlight like silk, with no fewer than four high conical peaks, each with the Rising Sun of Cairhien stirring above in a lazy breeze, gold on blue. The strumming of harps drifted out amid the murmur of voices, like the sounds of geese. As servants took away the horses, Darlin offered his arm to Caraline. After a very long pause, she laid her fingers lightly on his wrist with no expression whatsoever, letting him escort her inside.

"maɪ leɪɾi waɪf?" ɹænd mɝmɝd wɪð ə smaɪl, ɪkstɛndɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm.

"My Lady wife?" Rand murmured with a smile, extending his arm.

mɪn snɪft ən pʊɾ əɹ hæn ətɑp hɪz. ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ əv hɪt hɪm. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə meɪk ə dʒoʊk ə ðæt. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə bɹɪŋ əɹ hɪɹ, tɑvɝən əɹ noʊ tɑvɝən. hi kəd bi kɪl hɪɹ, bɝn hɪm! bʌt dɪɾ i kɛɹ ɪf ʃi spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf wipɪŋ? ʃi tʌtʃt wʌn ə ðə stʃɹaɪp dɔɹ-flæps əz ðeɪ wɛn ɪn, ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. ɪt wɑz sɪlk. ə sɪlk tɛnt!

Min sniffed and put her hand atop his. She would rather have hit him. He had no right to make a joke of that. He had no right to bring her here, ta'veren or no ta'veren. He could be killed here, burn him! But did he care if she spent the rest of her life weeping? She touched one of the striped door-flaps as they went in, and shook her head in wonder. It was silk. A silk tent!

noʊ sunɝ wɝ ðeɪ ɪnsaɪd ðən ʃi fɛlt ɹænd stɪfən. dɑɹlɪnz ʃɹʌŋkən ɹɛɾənu, ən kæɹɑlinz, dʒɑsəld ɝaʊn əm wɪð ɪnsɪnsɪɹ mɝmɝz ʌv əpɑlədʒi. bɪtwin ðə fɔɹ meɪn tɛntpoʊlz, lɔŋ tʃɹɛsəl teɪbəlz ɡɹoʊnɪŋ wɪð fuɾ ən dʒɹɪŋk stʊɾ əbaʊt ðə kʌlɝfəl kɑɹpəts ðət hæd bɪn leɪd fəɹ ə flɔɹ, ən ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɛvɹiwɛɹ, kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz ɪn ðɛɹ faɪnɝi, ə fju soʊlʒɝz wɪð ðə fɹʌns ə ðə hɛdz ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd, pleɪnli mɛn ə haɪ ɹæŋk baɪ ðə faɪn kʌɾ ə ðɛɹ koʊts. ə hændfʊl ə bɑɹdz stʃɹoʊl pleɪɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, pɪkt aʊɾ əz mʌtʃ baɪ ə lɔftiɝ ɛɹ ðən ɛni noʊbəl əz baɪ ðə kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd hɑɹps ðeɪ kæɹid. jɛt mɪnz aɪz flu əz ɪf pʊl tə ðə ʃʊɹ sɔɹs ə ɹændz wɝi, θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ tɔkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɪn ʃɔlz fɹɪnd ɡɹin ən jɛloʊ ən ɡɹeɪ. ɪmədʒəz ən kʌlɝz flæʃt ɝaʊn ðɛm, bʌt nɑɾ ə θɪŋ ʃi kəd meɪk sɛns ʌv. ə swɝl ɪn ðə kɹaʊd ɹɪvild ənʌðɝ, ə kʌmfɝɾəbli ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən. mɔɹ ɪmədʒəz, mɔɹ flɛɹɪŋ kʌlɝz, bʌɾ ɔl mɪn niɾəd wɑz ðə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl lupt oʊvɝ əɹ plʌmp ɑɹmz.

No sooner were they inside than she felt Rand stiffen. Darlin's shrunken retinue, and Caraline's, jostled around them with insincere murmurs of apology. Between the four main tentpoles, long trestle tables groaning with food and drink stood about the colorful carpets that had been laid for a floor, and there were people everywhere, Cairhienin nobles in their finery, a few soldiers with the fronts of the heads shaved and powdered, plainly men of high rank by the fine cut of their coats. A handful of bards strolled playing through the crowd, picked out as much by a loftier air than any noble as by the carved and gilded harps they carried. Yet Min's eyes flew as if pulled to the sure source of Rand's worry, three Aes Sedai talking together in shawls fringed green and yellow and gray. Images and colors flashed around them, but not a thing she could make sense of. A swirl in the crowd revealed another, a comfortably round-faced woman. More images, more flaring colors, but all Min needed was the red-fringed shawl looped over her plump arms.

ɹænd tʌkt əɹ hæn ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm ən pæɾəd ɪt. "doʊnt wɝi," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz ɡoʊɪŋ wɛl." ʃi wʊɾə æskt ɪm wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ ðɛɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪɾ i wəd tɛl hɝ.

Rand tucked her hand under his arm and patted it. "Don't worry," he said softly. "Everything is going well." She would have asked him what they were doing there, but she was afraid he would tell her.

dɑɹlɪn ən kæɹɑlin hæd vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðɛɹ fɑloʊɝz, jɛɾ əz ə boʊɪŋ sɝvɪŋ mæn wɪð stʃɹaɪps ə ɹɛd, ɡɹin ən waɪɾ ɑn ɪz dɑɹk kʌfs ɔfɝɾ ə tʃɹeɪ ʌv sɪlvɝ ɡoʊbləts tə ɹænd ən mɪn, ʃi ɹiəpɪɹd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ði ɪmpɹtunɪŋz ʌv ə hætʃət-feɪs fɛloʊ ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹɛd koʊts. hi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ bæk əz ʃi tʊk ə ɡɑbləɾ ə pʌntʃ ən weɪv ðə sɝvən əweɪ, ən mɪnz bɹɛθ kɑɾ ət ði ɔɹə ðət sʌɾənli flæʃt ɝaʊn hɪm, bɹuz hjuz soʊ dɑɹk ðeɪ sim nɪɹli blæk.

Darlin and Caraline had vanished into the crowd along with their followers, yet as a bowing serving man with stripes of red, green and white on his dark cuffs offered a tray of silver goblets to Rand and Min, she reappeared, shaking off the importunings of a hatchet-faced fellow in one of those red coats. He glared at her back as she took a goblet of punch and waved the servant away, and Min's breath caught at the aura that suddenly flashed around him, bruised hues so dark they seemed nearly black.

"doʊn tʃɹʌs ðət mæn, leɪɾi kæɹɑlin." ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp hɝsɛlf. "hi wɪl mɝɾɝ ɛniwʌn i θɪŋks ɪz ɪn ɪz weɪ; hɪl kɪl fəɹ ə wɪm, kɪl ɛnibəɾi." ʃi klæmpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌt bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ mɔɹ.

"Don't trust that man, Lady Caraline." She could not stop herself. "He will murder anyone he thinks is in his way; he'll kill for a whim, kill anybody." She clamped her teeth shut before saying more.

kæɹɑlin ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əz ðə hætʃət-feɪs mæn tɝn əweɪ əbɹʌpli. "aɪ kəd bɪliv ɪɾ izəli ʌv dɑv hænlən," ʃi sɛd ɹaɪli. "hɪz waɪt laɪənz faɪt fəɹ ɡoʊld, nɑt kɛɹhin, ən lut wɝs ðən ði il. ændɝ bɪkeɪm tu hɑt fəɹ ðɛm, ɪt simz." ðət wɪð ən ɑɹtʃ ɡlæns ət ɹænd. "tɔɹæm əz pɹɑməst ɪm ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɡoʊld, aɪ θɪŋk, ən ɪsteɪts aɪ noʊ." ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ aɪz ʌp tə mɪn. "du jə noʊ ðə mæn, dʒeɪɪzi?"

Caraline glanced over her shoulder as the hatchet-faced man turned away abruptly. "I could believe it easily of Daved Hanlon," she said wryly. "His White Lions fight for gold, not Cairhien, and loot worse than the Aiel. Andor became too hot for them, it seems." That with an arch glance at Rand. "Toram has promised him a great deal of gold, I think, and estates I know." She tilted her eyes up to Min. "Do you know the man, Jaisi?"

mɪn kəɾ oʊnli ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd. haʊ tə ɪkspleɪn wʌt ʃi dɪd noʊ əbaʊt hænlən naʊ, ðəɾ ɪz hænz wəd bi ɹɛd wɪð mɔɹ ɹeɪps ən mɝɾɝz bɪfɔɹ i daɪd? ɪf ʃi hæd noʊn wən əɹ hu. . . . bʌɾ ɔl ʃi nu wɑz ðəɾ i wʊd. ɛniweɪ, tɛlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə vjuɪŋ nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd ɪt; wʌt ʃi sɔ hæpənd, noʊ mæɾɝ u ʃi wɔɹnd. səmtaɪmz, bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd lɝn bɛɾɝ, ɪt hæd hæpən kəz ʃi wɔɹnd.

Min could only shake her head. How to explain what she did know about Hanlon now, that his hands would be red with more rapes and murders before he died? If she had known when or who. . . . But all she knew was that he would. Anyway, telling about a viewing never changed it; what she saw happened, no matter who she warned. Sometimes, before she had learned better, it had happened because she warned.

"aɪv hɝɾ ə ðə waɪt laɪənz," ɹænd sɛd koʊldli. "lʊk əmʌŋ əm fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən jə woʊn bi dɪsəpɔɪntɪd." ðeɪ hæd bɪn səm ʌv ɡeɪbɹəlz soʊlʒɝz; mɪn nu ðət mʌtʃ, ən lɪɾəl mɔɹ, ɪksɛp ðət lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl hæd ɹɪli bɪn ɹɑvɪn. ɪt stʊd tə ɹizən ðət soʊlʒɝz sɝvɪŋ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wəɾ ɪnklud dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

"I've heard of the White Lions," Rand said coldly. "Look among them for Darkfriends, and you won't be disappointed." They had been some of Gaebril's soldiers; Min knew that much, and little more, except that Lord Gaebril had really been Rahvin. It stood to reason that soldiers serving one of the Forsaken would include Darkfriends.

"wʌɾ ə hɪm?" ɹænd nɑɾəd təwɔɹɾ ə mæn əkɹɔs ðə tɛn huz lɔŋ dɑɹk koʊt hæɾ əz mɛni stʃɹaɪps əz kæɹɑlinz dʒɹɛs. vɛɹi tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, pɝhæps lɛs ðən ə fʊl hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd, hi wɑz slɛndɝ ɪksɛp fəɹ bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz, ən stʃɹaɪkɪŋli ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ, wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ tʃɪn ən dʒʌst ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ əɾ ɪz dɑɹk tɛmpəlz. fəɹ səm ɹizən, mɪnz aɪz wɝ dʒɹɔn tə hɪz kəmpænjən, ə skɪni lɪɾəl fɛloʊ wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ noʊz ən waɪɾ ɪɹz, ɪn ə ɹɛd sɪlk koʊt ðət dɪd nɑt fɪɾ ɪm vɛɹi wɛl. hi kɛp fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ə kɝv dæɡɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ə fænsi pis wɪð ə ɡoʊldən ʃiθ ən ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd stoʊn kæpɪŋ ðə hɪl ðət sim tə kætʃ ðə laɪt dɑɹkli. ʃi sɔ noʊ ɔʊɹəz ɝaʊn hɪm. hi sim veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ən ɹænd.

"What of him?" Rand nodded toward a man across the tent whose long dark coat had as many stripes as Caraline's dress. Very tall for a Cairhienin, perhaps less than a full head shorter than Rand, he was slender except for broad shoulders, and strikingly good-looking, with a strong chin and just a touch of gray at his dark temples. For some reason, Min's eyes were drawn to his companion, a skinny little fellow with a large nose and wide ears, in a red silk coat that did not fit him very well. He kept fingering a curved dagger at his belt, a fancy piece with a golden sheath and a large red stone capping the hilt that seemed to catch the light darkly. She saw no auras around him. He seemed vaguely familiar. They were both looking at her and Rand.

"ðæt," kæɹɑlin bɹiðd ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, "ɪz lɔɹd tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən hɪmsɛlf. ən ɪz kɑnstən kəmpænjən ðiz pæs deɪz, mæstɝ dʒɛɹɑl mɔɹɾɪθ. oʊɾiəs lɪɾəl mæn. hɪz aɪz meɪk mi wɑnə teɪk ə bæθ. ðeɪ boʊθ meɪk mi fil ənklin." ʃi blɪŋkt, sɝpɹaɪzd ət wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd, bʌt ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli. mɪn hæd ðə filɪŋ lɪɾəl pʊt kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹɾ ɔf əɹ stʃɹaɪd fəɹ lɔŋ. ɪn ðæt, ʃi wɑz vɛɹi laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn. "aɪ wəd bi kɛɹfəl wɝ aɪ ju, kʌzən toʊmɑs," ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ju meɪ hæv ɹɔt səm mɪɹəkəl əɹ tɑvɝən-wɝk ɑn mi - ən pɝhæps ivən ɑn dɑɹlɪn - ðoʊ aɪ kænɑt seɪ wʌɾ ɪt maɪt kʌm tə - aɪ meɪk noʊ pɹɑməsəz - bʌt tɔɹæm heɪts jə wɪð ə pæʃən. ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ bæd bɪfɔɹ mɔɹɾɪθ dʒɔɪn hɪm, jɛt sɪns. . . . tɔɹæm wəɾ əv əs ətæk ðə sɪɾi ɪmiɾiətli, ɪn ðə naɪt. wɪð jə dɛd, hi sɛz, ði il wəd ɡoʊ, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɪts jə dɛɾ i siks naʊ ivən mɔɹ ðən i dʌz ðə θɹoʊn."

"That," Caraline breathed in a tight voice, "is Lord Toram Riatin himself. And his constant companion these past days, Master Jeraal Mordeth. Odious little man. His eyes make me want to take a bath. They both make me feel unclean." She blinked, surprised at what she had said, but recovered quickly. Min had the feeling little put Caraline Damodred off her stride for long. In that, she was very like Moiraine. "I would be careful were I you, Cousin Tomas," she went on. "You may have wrought some miracle or ta'veren-work on me - and perhaps even on Darlin - though I cannot say what it might come to - I make no promises - but Toram hates you with a passion. It was not so bad before Mordeth joined him, yet since. . . . Toram would have us attack the city immediately, in the night. With you dead, he says, the Aiel would go, but I think it is you dead he seeks now even more than he does the throne."

"mɔɹɾɪθ," ɹænd sɛd. hɪz aɪz wɝ lɑk tə tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən ən ðə skɪni fɛloʊ. "hɪz neɪm ɪz pdən feɪn, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ wʌn hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd ɡoʊldən kɹaʊnz ɑn ɪz hɛd."

"Mordeth," Rand said. His eyes were locked to Toram Riatin and the skinny fellow. "His name is Padan Fain, and there are one hundred thousand golden crowns on his head."

kæɹɑlin nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt əɹ ɡɑblət. "kwinz əv bɪn ɹænsəm fəɹ lɛs. wʌɾ i du?"

Caraline nearly dropped her goblet. "Queens have been ransomed for less. What did he do?"

"hi ɹævɪdʒ maɪ hoʊm kəz ɪt wɑz maɪ hoʊm." ɹændz feɪs wɑz fɹoʊzən, hɪz vɔɪs aɪs. "hi bɹɔt tʃɹɑləks tə kɪl maɪ fɹɛnz kəz ðeɪ wɝ maɪ fɹɛnz. hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ə dɛd mæn." ðoʊz læst wɝdz keɪm θɹu klɛntʃt tiθ. pʌntʃ splæʃt tə ðə kɑɹpəɾ əz ðə sɪlvɝ ɡɑblət bɛn ɪn ɪz ɡlʌv fɪst.

"He ravaged my home because it was my home." Rand's face was frozen, his voice ice. "He brought Trollocs to kill my friends because they were my friends. He is a Darkfriend, and a dead man." Those last words came through clenched teeth. Punch splashed to the carpet as the silver goblet bent in his gloved fist.

mɪn fɛl sɪk fəɹ hɪm, fəɹ ɪz peɪn - ʃi hæd hɝd wʌt feɪn hæd dʌn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz - bʌt ʃi pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɹændz tʃɛst ɪn nɪɹ pænɪk. ɪf i ɡeɪv weɪ naʊ, tʃænəld wɪð u nu haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝaʊnd. . . . "fɔɹ ðə laɪts seɪk, teɪk hoʊld ə jɝsɛlf," ʃi bɪɡæn, ən ə wʊmənz vɔɪs spoʊk plɛzənli bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Min felt sick for him, for his pain - she had heard what Fain had done in the Two Rivers - but she put a hand on Rand's chest in near panic. If he gave way now, channeled with who knew how many Aes Sedai around. . . . "For the Light's sake, take hold of yourself," she began, and a woman's voice spoke pleasantly behind her.

"wɪl jə pɹɛzən mi tə jəɹ tɔl jʌŋ fɹɛnd, kæɹɑlin?"

"Will you present me to your tall young friend, Caraline?"

mɪn lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ən eɪdʒləs feɪs, kul-aɪd bɪniθ aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ pʊld ʌp ɪndə ə bʌn fɹəm wɪtʃ dæŋɡəl smɔl ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns. swɑloʊɪŋ ə skwik, mɪn kɔft. ʃi hæd θɔt kæɹɑlin hæd teɪkən əɹ ɪn ɪn wʌn ɡlæns, bʌt ðiz kul aɪz sim tə noʊ θɪŋz əbaʊɾ əɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd fɝɡɑɾən. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz smaɪl, əz ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, wɑz nɑt nɪɹli soʊ plɛzən əz əɹ vɔɪs.

Min looked over her shoulder, right into an ageless face, cool-eyed beneath iron-gray hair pulled up into a bun from which dangled small golden ornaments. Swallowing a squeak, Min coughed. She had thought Caraline had taken her in in one glance, but these cool eyes seemed to know things about her she herself had forgotten. The Aes Sedai's smile, as she adjusted her green-fringed shawl, was not nearly so pleasant as her voice.

"ʌv kɔɹs, kædzueɪn sədaɪ." kæɹɑlin saʊndəd ʃeɪkən, bʌt ʃi smuðd əɹ toʊn wɛl bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɪntʃɹədusɪŋ əɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ "kʌzən" ən ɪz "waɪf." "bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ kɛɹhin ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ əm ət pɹɛzənt," ʃi sɛd, ɔl sɛlf-pəzɛʃən wʌns mɔɹ, smaɪlɪŋ ɹəɡɹɛt ðət ʃi kəd nɑt kip ɹænd ən mɪn lɔŋɡɝ. "ðeɪ hæv əɡɹid tə teɪk maɪ ædvaɪs ən ɹɪtɝn tə ændɝ."

"Of course, Cadsuane Sedai." Caraline sounded shaken, but she smoothed her tone well before she finished introducing her visiting "cousin" and his "wife." "But I fear Cairhien is no place for them at present," she said, all self-possession once more, smiling regret that she could not keep Rand and Min longer. "They have agreed to take my advice and return to Andor."

"hæv ðeɪ?" kædzueɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. mɪnz hɑɹt sæŋk. ivən ɪf ɹænd hæd nɑt spoʊkən ə hɝ, ɪt wɑz klɪɹ fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm ðət ʃi nu hɪm. taɪni ɡoʊldən bɝdz ən munz ən stɑɹz sweɪɾ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "moʊs bɔɪz lɝn nɑt tə stɪk ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪndə ðə pɹɪɾi faɪɝ ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪ ɑɹ bɝnd, toʊmɑs. ʌðɝz nid tə bi spæŋkt, tə lɝn. bɛɾɝ ə tɛndɝ bɑɾəm ðən ə sɪɹd hænd."

"Have they?" Cadsuane said dryly. Min's heart sank. Even if Rand had not spoken of her, it was clear from the way she looked at him that she knew him. Tiny golden birds and moons and stars swayed as she shook her head. "Most boys learn not to stick their fingers into the pretty fire the first time they are burned, Tomas. Others need to be spanked, to learn. Better a tender bottom than a seared hand."

"ju noʊ ɪm noʊ tʃaɪld," ɹænd toʊld əɹ ʃɑɹpli.

"You know I'm no child," Rand told her sharply.

"du aɪ?" ʃi aɪɾ ɪm fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ, ən meɪɾ ɪt sim noʊ vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dɪstəns. "wɛl, ɪt simz aɪ ʃæl sun si wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt jə nid spæŋkɪŋ." ðoʊz kul aɪz dʒɹɪftəd tə mɪn, tə kæɹɑlin, ən wɪð ə faɪnəl hɪtʃ tə hɝ ʃɔl, kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf dʒɹɪftəɾ əweɪ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd.

"Do I?" She eyed him from head to toe, and made it seem no very great distance. "Well, it seems I shall soon see whether or not you need spanking." Those cool eyes drifted to Min, to Caraline, and with a final hitch to her shawl, Cadsuane herself drifted away into the crowd.

mɪn swɑloʊd ðə lʌmp ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən wɑz pliz tə si kæɹɑlin də ðə seɪm, sɛlf-pəzɛʃən əɹ noʊ. ɹænd - ðə blaɪn ful! - stɛɹɾ æftɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ðoʊ ɪntɛndɪŋ tə ɡoʊ æftɝ hɝ. ðɪs taɪm ɪt wɑz kæɹɑlin u leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɹændz tʃɛst.

Min swallowed the lump in her throat, and was pleased to see Caraline do the same, self-possession or no. Rand - the blind fool! - stared after the Aes Sedai as though intending to go after her. This time it was Caraline who laid a hand on Rand's chest.

"aɪ teɪk ɪt jə noʊ kædzueɪn," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθəli. "bi kɛɹfəl ə hɝ; ivən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz stæn ɪn ɑ ʌv hɝ." hɝ θɹoʊɾi toʊnz tʊk ɑn ə noʊɾ ʌv ɡɹævəɾi. "aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə wʌt wɪl kʌm ə tədeɪ, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, aɪ θɪŋk ɪts taɪm jə wɝ ɡɔn, 'kʌzən toʊmɑs.' pæs taɪm. əl əv hɔɹsəz - "

"I take it you know Cadsuane," she said breathily. "Be careful of her; even the other sisters stand in awe of her." Her throaty tones took on a note of gravity. "I have no idea what will come of today, but whatever it is, I think it is time you were gone, 'Cousin Tomas.' Past time. I will have horses - "

"ðɪs ɪz jəɹ kʌzən, kæɹɑlin?" sɛɾ ə dip, ɹɪtʃ mænz vɔɪs, ən mɪn dʒʌmpt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf.

"This is your cousin, Caraline?" said a deep, rich man's voice, and Min jumped in spite of herself.
