dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, flɪn lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɾ æmɪz. wən i kɑt saɪɾ ə mɪn, hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən ɪz lɛðɝi feɪs ɹɛɾənd. heɪstəli hi ɹiɝeɪnʒd ðə ʃit tə kʌvɝ ɹænd tə hɪz nɛk, livɪŋ oʊnli ði oʊld waʊn ən ðə nu ɪkspoʊzd.

Drawing a deep breath, Flinn looked around the room, at the Aes Sedai, at Amys. When he caught sight of Min, he gave a start, and his leathery face reddened. Hastily he rearranged the sheet to cover Rand to his neck, leaving only the old wound and the new exposed.

"aɪ hoʊp noʊbɑdi maɪnz ɪf aɪ tɔk," hi sɛd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə muv kælʌz hænz əbʌv ɹændz saɪd. "tɔkɪŋ simz tə hɛlp ə maɪt." hi skwɪntɪd, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ði ɪnʒɝiz, ən ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɹɪθ sloʊli. vɛɹi mʌtʃ əz ðoʊ hi wɑz wivɪŋ θɹɛdz, mɪn ɹilaɪzd. hɪz toʊn wɑz ɔlmoʊst əbsɛnt, oʊnli pɑɹɾ ə hɪz maɪn ɑn ðə wɝdz. "ɪt wɑz hilɪŋ meɪd mi ɡoʊ tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, jə maɪt seɪ. aɪ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, tɪl aɪ tʊk ə læns ɪn maɪ θaɪ; kʊdnt ɡɹɪp ə sæɾəl pɹɑpɝ æftɝ ðæt, əɹ ivən wɔk fɑɹ. ðət wɑz ðə fɪftinθ waʊn aɪ tʊk ɪn nɪɹ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz ɪn ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. fɪftin ðət kaʊntəd, ɛniweɪ; ɪt doʊn ɪf jə kən wɔk əɹ ɹaɪd, æftɝ. aɪ sin ə lɑɾ ə fɹɛnz daɪ ɪn əm fɔɹɾi jɪɹz. soʊ aɪ wɛnt, ən ðə l tɔt mi hilɪŋ. ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ə ɹʌf sɔɹɾ ə hilɪŋ; aɪ wɑz hil baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wʌns - oʊ, naɪ ɑn θɝɾi jɪɹz bæk naʊ - ən ðɪs hɝts, kəmpɛɹd tə ðæt. wɝks əz wɛl, ðoʊ. ðən wʌn deɪ, dæʃivə hɪɹ - pɑɹɾən; æʃəmən dæʃivə - sɛz i wʌndɝz waɪ ɪts ɔl ðə seɪm, noʊ mæɾɝ ɪf ə mænz ɡɑɾ ə bɹoʊk lɛɡ əɹ ə koʊld, ən wi ɡɑt tə tɔkɪŋ, ænd. . . . wɛl, hiz ɡɑt noʊ fil fəɹ ɪt, hɪmsɛlf, bʌt mi, simz aɪ ɡɑt ðə næk jə maɪt seɪ. ðə tælənt. soʊ aɪ stɑɹɾəd θɪŋkɪŋ, wʌɾ ɪf aɪ . . . ? ðɛɹ. bɛst aɪ kən du."

"I hope nobody minds if I talk," he said, beginning to move callused hands above Rand's side. "Talking seems to help a mite." He squinted, focusing on the injuries, and his fingers writhed slowly. Very much as though he was weaving threads, Min realized. His tone was almost absent, only part of his mind on the words. "It was Healing made me go to the Black Tower, you might say. I was a soldier, till I took a lance in my thigh; couldn't grip a saddle proper after that, or even walk far. That was the fifteenth wound I took in near forty years in the Queen's Guards. Fifteen that counted, anyway; it don't if you can walk or ride, after. I seen a lot of friends die in them forty years. So I went, and the M'Hael taught me Healing. And other things. A rough sort of Healing; I was Healed by an Aes Sedai once - oh, nigh on thirty years back now - and this hurts, compared to that. Works as well, though. Then one day, Dashiva here - pardon; Asha'man Dashiva - says he wonders why it's all the same, no matter if a man's got a broke leg or a cold, and we got to talking, and. . . . Well, he's got no feel for it, himself, but me, seems I got the knack you might say. The Talent. So I started thinking, what if I . . . ? There. Best I can do."

dæʃivə ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz flɪn əbɹʌpli sæt bæk ɑn ɪz hilz ən waɪp ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn əkɹɔs ɪz fɔɹhɛd. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz feɪs, ðə fɝs taɪm mɪn hæd sin ən æʃəmən pɝspaɪɹ. ðə slæʃ ɪn ɹændz saɪd wɑz nɑt ɡɔn, jɛɾ ɪt simd ə lɪɾəl smɔlɝ, lɛs ɹɛɾ ən æŋɡɹi. hi stɪl slɛpt, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs sim lɛs peɪl.

Dashiva grunted as Flinn abruptly sat back on his heels and wiped the back of his hand across his forehead. Sweat beaded on his face, the first time Min had seen an Asha'man perspire. The slash in Rand's side was not gone, yet it seemed a little smaller, less red and angry. He still slept, but his face seemed less pale.

sæmɪtsu dɑɹɾɪd pæs nɛɹɪʃmə soʊ kwɪkli hi hæd noʊ tʃæns tə ɪntɝvin. "wʌt dɪd jə du?" ʃi dɪmændəd, leɪɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɹændz fɔɹhɛd. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi faʊnd wɪð ðə paʊɝ, hɝ aɪbɹaʊz klaɪm hæfweɪ tə hɝ hɛɹ, ən əɹ toʊn lɛp fɹəm ɪmpɪɹiəs tə ɪnkɹɛdʒələs. "wʌt dɪd jə du?"

Samitsu darted past Narishma so quickly he had no chance to intervene. "What did you do?" she demanded, laying fingers on Rand's forehead. Whatever she found with the Power, her eyebrows climbed halfway to her hair, and her tone leaped from imperious to incredulous. "What did you do?"

flɪn ʃɹʌɡd ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. "nɑt mʌtʃ. aɪ kʊdn ɹɪli tʌtʃ wʌts ɹɔŋ. aɪ sɔɹɾ ə sild əm əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, fəɹ ə taɪm, ɛnihaʊ. ɪt woʊn læst. ðəɹ faɪɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, naʊ. meɪbi ðəl kɪl ɔf itʃ ʌðɝ, waɪl i hilz hɪmsɛlf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ." saɪɪŋ, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, aɪ kæn seɪ ðət ðeɪ woʊn kɪl hɪm. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk hiz ə bɛɾɝ tʃæns ðən i dɪd."

Flinn shrugged his shoulders regretfully. "Not much. I couldn't really touch what's wrong. I sort of sealed them away from him, for a time, anyhow. It won't last. They're fighting each other, now. Maybe they'll kill off each other, while he heals himself the rest of the way." Sighing, he shook his head. "On the other hand, I can't say that they won't kill him. But I think he has a better chance than he did."

dæʃivə nɑɾəd sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾəntli. "jɛs; hiz ə tʃæns, naʊ." jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæd dʌn ðə hilɪŋ hɪmsɛlf.

Dashiva nodded self-importantly. "Yes; he has a chance, now." You would have thought he had done the Healing himself.

tə flɪnz ɛvəɾənt sɝpɹaɪz, sæmɪtsu ɹaʊndəd ðə bɛd tə hɛlp ɪm ɹaɪz. "ju wɪl tɛl mi wʌt jə dɪd," ʃi sɛd, ɹiɡəl toʊn ət stʃɹɔŋ ɑdz wɪð ðə weɪ hɝ kwɪk fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹeɪɾənd ði oʊl mænz kɑlɝ ən smuðd ɪz ləpɛlz. "ɪf oʊnli ðəɹ wɑz səm weɪ jə kəd ʃoʊ mi! bʌt jəl dɪskɹaɪb ɪt. jə mʌst! əl ɡɪv jə ɔl ðə ɡoʊld aɪ pəzɛs, bɛɹ jəɹ tʃaɪld, wʌtɛvɝ jə wɪʃ, bʌt jəl tɛl mi ɔl ðət jə kæn." əpɛɹənli nɑt ʃʊɹ hɝsɛlf wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz kəmændɪŋ əɹ bɛɡɪŋ, ʃi lɛɾ ə vɛɹi bi-mjuz flɪn oʊvɝ baɪ ðə wɪndoʊz. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ mɔɹ ðən wʌns, bʌt ʃi wɑz tu bɪzi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪm tɔk tə si ɪt.

To Flinn's evident surprise, Samitsu rounded the bed to help him rise. "You will tell me what you did," she said, regal tone at strong odds with the way her quick fingers straightened the old man's collar and smoothed his lapels. "If only there was some way you could show me! But you will describe it. You must! I will give you all the gold I possess, bear your child, whatever you wish, but you will tell me all that you can." Apparently not sure herself whether she was commanding or begging, she led a very be-mused Flinn over by the windows. He opened his mouth more than once, but she was too busy trying to make him talk to see it.

nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wʌɾ ɛniwʌn θɔt, mɪn klaɪmd ɑntu ðə bɛɾ ən leɪ soʊ ʃi kəd tʌk ɹændz hɛɾ ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn ən ɹæp əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm. ə tʃæns. fɝɾɪvli ʃi stʌɾid ðə θɹi pipəl ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɛd. kædzueɪn ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ, æmɪz stændɪŋ ɑpəzət, dæʃivə linɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə skwɛɹ bɪdpoʊsts ət ðə fʊt, ɔl wɪð ənɹiɾəbəl ɔʊɹəz ən ɪmədʒəz dænsɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɔl wɪð ðɛɹ aɪz ɪntɛn ɑn ɹænd. noʊ daʊɾ æmɪz sɔ səm dɪzæstɝ fəɹ ði il ɪf ɹænd daɪd, ən dæʃivə, ði oʊnli wʌn wɪð ɛni ɪkspɹɛʃən, ə dɑɹk jɛt wɝid skaʊl, dɪzæstɝ fəɹ ði æʃəmən. ən kædzueɪn. . . . kædzueɪn, hu wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli noʊn tə bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə, bʌt meɪɾ əm dʒʌmp laɪk ɡɝlz fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ oʊðz tə ɹænd. kædzueɪn, hu wəd nɑt hɝt ɹænd "ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæd tə."

Not caring what anyone thought, Min climbed onto the bed and lay so she could tuck Rand's head under her chin and wrap her arms around him. A chance. Furtively she studied the three people gathered around the bed. Cadsuane in her chair, Amys standing opposite, Dashiva leaning against one of the square bedposts at the foot, all with unreadable auras and images dancing around them. All with their eyes intent on Rand. No doubt Amys saw some disaster for the Aiel if Rand died, and Dashiva, the only one with any expression, a dark yet worried scowl, disaster for the Asha'man. And Cadsuane. . . . Cadsuane, who was not only known to Bera and Kiruna, but made them jump like girls for all their oaths to Rand. Cadsuane, who would not hurt Rand "any more than she had to."

kædzueɪnz ɡeɪz mɛt mɪnz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən mɪn ʃɪvɝd. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi wəd pɹətɛkt ɪm waɪl i kəd nɑt pɹətɛk hɪmsɛlf, fɹəm æmɪz, ən dæʃivə, ən kædzueɪn. sʌmhaʊ. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, ʃi bɪɡæn tə hʌm ə lʌləbaɪ, ɹɑkɪŋ ɹænd dʒɛnli. sʌmhaʊ.

Cadsuane's gaze met Min's for a moment, and Min shivered. Somehow, she would protect him while he could not protect himself, from Amys, and Dashiva, and Cadsuane. Somehow. Unconsciously, she began to hum a lullaby, rocking Rand gently. Somehow.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 37

eɪ noʊt fɹəm ðə pæləs


A Note from the Palace

ðə deɪ æftɝ ðə fɛstəvəl ə bɝdz dɔn tə stʃɹɔŋ wɪnz ɔf ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz ðəɾ æktʃəli  kʌt ðə hiɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ə skaɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə klaʊɾ ən ðə ɹɛd-ɡoʊl doʊm ə ðə sʌn ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən ɡeɪv pɹɑməsəz fəɹ wʌns ðə wɪn daɪd, ðoʊ. mæt hɝid daʊn θɹu ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs wɪð ɪz ɡɹin koʊɾ əndʌn ən ɪz ʃɝɾ oʊnli hæf-leɪst ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən. hi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt dʒʌmp əɾ ɛvɹi saʊnd, bʌɾ i dɪd ɡɪv ə stɑɹt, kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ waɪd-aɪd ðən i laɪkt, wɛnɛvɝ wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən pæst, swɪʃɪŋ əɹ pɛɾikoʊts ən smaɪlɪŋ ət hɪm. ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðɛm smaɪld, ɪn ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli . . . noʊɪŋ . . . weɪ. ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də nɑt tə ɹʌn.

The day after the Festival of Birds dawned to strong winds off the Sea of Storms that actually cut the heat in Ebou Dar. A sky without a cloud and the red-gold dome of the sun on the horizon gave promises for once the wind died, though. Mat hurried down through the Tarasin Palace with his green coat undone and his shirt only half-laced in anticipation. He did not quite jump at every sound, but he did give a start, considerably more wide-eyed than he liked, whenever one of the serving women passed, swishing her petticoats and smiling at him. Every last one of them smiled, in a particularly . . . knowing . . . way. It was all he could do not to run.

ət ðə læst, hi sloʊd, izɪŋ ɑntu ðə ʃeɪɾɪd wɔk bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ɔlmoʊst ɑn tɪptoʊ. bɪtwin ðə fluɾəd kɑləmz ə ðə wɔk, jɛloʊɪʃ ɹiɾi plæns ɪn bɪɡ ɹɛd pɑɾɝi boʊlz ən vaɪnz wɪð waɪd, ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp livz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm mɛɾəl bæskəts ɑn tʃeɪnz fɔɹmd ə θɪn skɹin. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hi tʌɡd ɪz hæt loʊɝ tə əbskjʊɹ ɪz feɪs. hɪz hænz ɹæn əlɔŋ ɪz spɪɹ - ən æʃhændʒɹeɪ, bɝdʒɪt kɔld ɪt - ənθɪŋkɪŋli fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə hæft əz ɪf i maɪt nid tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf. ðə daɪs tʌmbəld ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd fɪɹsli, jɛt ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz ʌnizinəs. ðə sɔɹs ə ðət wɑz taɪlɪn.

At the last, he slowed, easing onto the shaded walk bordering the stableyard almost on tiptoe. Between the fluted columns of the walk, yellowish reedy plants in big red pottery bowls and vines with wide, red-striped leaves dangling from metal baskets on chains formed a thin screen. Unconsciously, he tugged his hat lower to obscure his face. His hands ran along his spear - an ashandarei, Birgitte called it - unthinkingly fingering the haft as if he might need to defend himself. The dice tumbled inside his head fiercely, yet that had nothing to do with his uneasiness. The source of that was Tylin.

sɪks kloʊz koʊtʃɪz wɪð ðə ɡɹin æŋkɝ ən sɔɹɾ ə haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ lækɝɾ ɑn ðə dɔɹz ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾəd ɪn laɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt aʊɾɝ ɡeɪts wɪð timz hɪtʃt ən lɪvɹid dʒɹaɪvɝz maʊntəd. hi kəd si neɪlzin jɔnɪŋ ɪn ə jɛloʊ-stʃɹaɪp koʊɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðɛm, ən veɪnɪn sæt slʌmpt ətɑp ən ʌpɛndəd bæɹəl nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə steɪbəl dɔɹz, əpɛɹənli əslip. moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ peɪʃənli ɑn ðə steɪbliɑɹd flæɡstoʊnz; ə fju tɔs daɪs ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə hjudʒ waɪt steɪbəlz. ɪleɪn stʊd bɪtwin mæt ən ðə koʊtʃɪz, dʒʌs ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə skɹin ə plæns. ɹin kɔɹli wɑz wɪð hɝ, ən kloʊs baɪ, sɛvən mɔɹ ə ðə wɪmən u wɝ ət ðət pəkjuljɝ miɾɪŋ i hæd bɝst ɪndə ði ivnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ; ɹin wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt ʌv ə waɪz wʊmən. hi hæd hæf-ɪkspɛktəɾ əm nɑt tə əpɪɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd ðə fitʃɝz ʌv wɪmən juz tə ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn laɪvz ən ʌðɝz, ən moʊs hæɾ ət list ə bɪɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ, jɛt ðeɪ wɑtʃt fɹɛʃ-feɪst ɪleɪn wɪð ən ɛɹ ʌv ɛkspɛkteɪʃən, simɪŋli ɑn ðɛɹ toʊz, əz ðoʊ ɹɛɾi tə dʒʌmp əɾ əɹ kəmænd. ðə hoʊl lɑt kɑt lɛs ðən hæf ɪz ətɛnʃən, ðoʊ; nʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ðə wʊmən u hæɾ ɪm ɹɛɾi tə dʒʌmp aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn. taɪlɪn meɪɾ ɪm fil . . . wɛl . . . hɛlpləs wɑz ði oʊnli wɝd ðət sim tə fɪt, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪdɪkjələs ɪt simd.

Six closed coaches with the green Anchor and Sword of House Mitsobar lacquered on the doors already waited in line before the tall arched outer gates with teams hitched and liveried drivers mounted. He could see Nalesean yawning in a yellow-striped coat on the far side of them, and Vanin sat slumped atop an upended barrel not far from the stable doors, apparently asleep. Most of the other Redarms were squatting patiently on the stableyard flagstones; a few tossed dice in the shadow of the huge white stables. Elayne stood between Mat and the coaches, just the other side of the screen of plants. Reanne Corly was with her, and close by, seven more of the women who were at that peculiar meeting he had burst into the evening before; Reanne was the only one not wearing the red belt of a Wise Woman. He had half-expected them not to appear this morning. They had the features of women used to ordering their own lives and other's, and most had at least a bit of gray in their hair, yet they watched fresh-faced Elayne with an air of expectation, seemingly on their toes, as though ready to jump at her command. The whole lot caught less than half his attention, though; none of them was the woman who had him ready to jump out of his skin. Tylin made him feel . . . well . . . helpless was the only word that seemed to fit, however ridiculous it seemed.

"wi də nɑt nid ðɛm, mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli," ɪleɪn sɛd. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ saʊndəd laɪk ə wʊmən pæɾɪŋ ə tʃaɪld ɑn ðə hɛd. "aɪv toʊld əm tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ əntɪl wi ɹɪtɝn. wɪl ətʃɹæk lɛs ətɛnʃən, ɪspɛʃli əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbli ɛɛs sədaɪ." hɝ noʊʃən ʌv wʌt tə wɛɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ ðə ɹʌfəs pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊɾ ətʃɹæktɪŋ ətɛnʃən wɑz ə waɪd ɡɹin hæt wɪð ɡɹin-daɪd plumz, ə laɪt dʌstkloʊk ʌv ɡɹin lɪnən wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊldən skɹoʊlz hæŋɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk, ən ə haɪ-nɛkt ɡɹin sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɪð ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi klaɪmɪŋ ðə dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən θɪkli ɛmfəsaɪzɪŋ ði oʊvəl ðəɾ ɪkspoʊz hæf əɹ bʊzəm. ʃi ivən wɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz nɛkləsɪz fəɹ ə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf. ðət bɹɔd bæn ʌv woʊvən ɡoʊld wəd meɪk ɛvɹi θifs hæn ɪn ðə ɹæhəɾ ɪtʃ. ʃi kæɹid noʊ wɛpən bɪɑn ə smɔl bɛl naɪf. bʌɾ əz tə ðæt, wʌt wɛpən dɪɾ ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl nid? ʌv kɔɹs, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹɛd bɛls hæɾ ə kɝv dæɡɝ tʌk bɪhaɪn ɪt. soʊ dɪd ɹinz bɛlt ə pleɪn wɝk lɛðɝ.

"We do not need them, Mistress Corly," Elayne said. The Daughter-Heir sounded like a woman patting a child on the head. "I've told them to remain here until we return. We will attract less attention, especially across the river, without anyone recognizably Aes Sedai." Her notion of what to wear visiting the roughest part of the city without attracting attention was a wide green hat with green-dyed plumes, a light dustcloak of green linen worked in golden scrolls hanging down her back, and a high-necked green silk riding dress with gold embroidery climbing the divided skirts and thickly emphasizing the oval that exposed half her bosom. She even wore one of those necklaces for a marriage knife. That broad band of woven gold would make every thief's hand in the Rahad itch. She carried no weapon beyond a small belt knife. But as to that, what weapon did a woman who could channel need? Of course, every one of those red belts had a curved dagger tucked behind it. So did Reane's belt of plain worked leather.

ɹin ɹimuvd ə lɑɹdʒ blu stʃɹɔ hæt, fɹaʊn əɾ ɪt, ðən pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɑn ən ɹɛtaɪd ðə ɹɪbənz. ɪleɪnz toʊn dɪd nɑt sim tə bi wʌt wɑz bɑðɝɪŋ hɝ. ʃi pʊɾ ɑn ə dɪfəɾənt smaɪl wɪð ðə hæt, ən ə tɪmɪd toʊn. "bʌt waɪ dʌz mɛɝɪlɪl sədaɪ θɪŋk wəɹ laɪɪŋ, ɪleɪn sədaɪ?"

Reanne removed a large blue straw hat, frowned at it, then put it back on and retied the ribbons. Elayne's tone did not seem to be what was bothering her. She put on a diffident smile with the hat, and a timid tone. "But why does Merilille Sedai think we are lying, Elayne Sedai?"

"ðeɪ ɔl du," wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd-bɛls sɛd bɹɛθləsli. ɔl ə ðɛm wɔɹ ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛsəz ɪn soʊbɝ kʌlɝz, wɪð nɛɹoʊ plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklinz ən skɝts soʊn ʌp ɑn wʌn saɪd tə ɪkspoʊz leɪɝd pɛɾikoʊts, bʌɾ oʊnli ðɪs wʌn, boʊn-lin ən wɪð mɔɹ waɪt ðən blæk ɪn əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ, hæd ði ɑləv skɪn ən dɑɹk aɪz ʌv ən ɛbu dɑɹi. "sɝaɪðə sədaɪ kɔl mi laɪɝ tə maɪ feɪs, əbaʊɾ əɹ nʌmbɝz, əbaʊt - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf ʃɔɹɾ əɾ ə fɹaʊn ən ə "bi kwaɪət, tæmɑɹlə" fɹəm ɹin; mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli maɪt bi ɹɛɾi tə kɝtsi ən sɪmpɝ fəɹ ə tʃaɪld ɪf ðə tʃaɪld wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ʃi kɛpt ə taɪt ɹeɪn ɑn əɹ kəmpænjənz.

"They all do," one of the red-belts said breathlessly. All of them wore Ebou Dari dresses in sober colors, with narrow plunging necklines and skirts sewn up on one side to expose layered petticoats, but only this one, bone-lean and with more white than black in her long hair, had the olive skin and dark eyes of an Ebou Dari. "Sareitha Sedai called me liar to my face, about our numbers, about - " She cut off short at a frown and a "Be quiet, Tamarla" from Reanne; Mistress Corly might be ready to curtsy and simper for a child if the child was Aes Sedai, but she kept a tight rein on her companions.

mæt fɹaʊn ʌp ət ðə wɪndoʊz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ðoʊz i kəd si fɹəm wɛɹ i stʊd. ɪlæbɹət waɪt ɹɔt-aɪɝn skɹinz kʌvɝd sʌm, waɪt wʊɾən skɹinz ʌv ɪntʃɹəkətli kɑɹv pɪɹswɝk ʌðɝz. nɑt laɪkli taɪlɪn wɑz ʌp ðɛɹ; nɑt laɪkli ʃi wəɾ əpɪɹ ɪn ðə steɪbəl-jɑɹd. hi hæd bɪn vɛɹi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə weɪk əɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹɛst. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ hɪɹ. ət list, hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wʊd. ðən əɡɛn, wɑz ɛniθɪŋ pæs ðə wʊmən u hæd hæd hæf ə dʌzən sɝvɪŋ wɪmən siz ɪm ɪn ðə hɔlz læs naɪɾ ən dʒɹæɡ hɪm ɪndə hɝ əpɑɹtməns? ðə blʌɾi wʊmən tʃɹiɾəd ɪm laɪk ə tɔɪ! hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ. hi wɑz nɑt. laɪt, hu wɑz i tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ful? ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡɹæb ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, taɪlɪn wəd bi pɪntʃɪŋ ɪz bɑɾəm ən kɔlɪŋ ɪm əɹ lɪɾəl pɪdʒən əɡɛn tənaɪt.

Mat frowned up at the windows overlooking the stableyard, those he could see from where he stood. Elaborate white wrought-iron screens covered some, white wooden screens of intricately carved piercework others. Not likely Tylin was up there; not likely she would appear in the stable-yard. He had been very careful not to wake her getting dressed. Besides, she would not try anything here. At least, he did not think she would. Then again, was anything past the woman who had had half a dozen serving women seize him in the halls last night and drag him into her apartments? The bloody woman treated him like a toy! He was not going to put up with it anymore. He was not. Light, who was he trying to fool? If they did not grab this Bowl of the Winds and get out of Ebou Dar, Tylin would be pinching his bottom and calling him her little pigeon again tonight.

"ɪts jəɹ eɪdʒəz, ɹin." ɪleɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzækli saʊn hɛzɪɾənt - ʃi nɛvɝ dɪd ðət - bʌɾ əɹ toʊn bɪkeɪm vɛɹi kɛɹfəl. "ɪɾ ɪz kənsɪɾɝd ɹuɾ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə spik ʌv eɪdʒ, bʌt. . . . ɹin, əpɛɹənli noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ əz lɪvd əz lɔŋ əz ɛni ʌv jə ɪn ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl kleɪm." ðət wɑz ði ɑd neɪm ðiz kɪn ɡeɪv ðɛɹ ɹulɪŋ kaʊnsəl. "ɪn jəɹ oʊn keɪs, nɑt baɪ oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz." ðə ɹɛd-bɛls ɡæspt, ɡoʊɪŋ waɪd-aɪd. ə slɛndɝ bɹaʊn-aɪd wʊmən wɪð peɪl hʌni hɛɹ ɡeɪv ə nɝvəs ɡɪɡəl ən ɪnstənli kʌvɝɾ əɹ maʊθ ət ɹinz wɪp-kwɪk "feɪmɛl!"

"It's your ages, Reanne." Elayne did not exactly sound hesitant - she never did that - but her tone became very careful. "It is considered rude among Aes Sedai to speak of age, but. . . . Reanne, apparently no Aes Sedai since the Breaking has lived as long as any of you in the Knitting Circle claim." That was the odd name these Kin gave their ruling council. "In your own case, not by over a hundred years." The red-belts gasped, going wide-eyed. A slender brown-eyed woman with pale honey hair gave a nervous giggle and instantly covered her mouth at Reanne's whip-quick "Famelle!"

"ðæt kæn bi pɑsəbəl," ɹin sɛd feɪnli tə ɪleɪn. "ʃʊɹli, ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌst - "

"That can't be possible," Reanne said faintly to Elayne. "Surely, Aes Sedai must - "

"ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ," mæt sɛd, stɛpɪŋ pæs ðə skɹin ə plæns. ðə hoʊl dɪskʌʃən wɑz ɪɾiɑtɪk; ɛvɹiwʌn nu ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪv lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛnibəɾi ɛls. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv weɪstɪŋ taɪm, ðeɪ ʃəd bi ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə ɹæhəd. "wɛɹ ɑɹ tɑm ən dʒulɪn? ən nɪneɪiv." ʃi hæd tə hæv kʌm bæk læs naɪt, əɹ ɪleɪn wʊɾə bɪn ɪn ə swɪvət. "blʌɾ ən æʃəz, aɪ doʊn si bɝdʒɪɾ iðɝ. wi nid tə bi ɑn əɹ weɪ, ɪleɪn, nɑt stændɪŋ ɝaʊnd. ɪz eɪvinhə kʌmɪŋ?"

"Good morning," Mat said, stepping past the screen of plants. The whole discussion was idiotic; everyone knew Aes Sedai lived longer than anybody else. Instead of wasting time, they should be on their way to the Rahad. "Where are Thom and Juilin? And Nynaeve." She had to have come back last night, or Elayne would have been in a swivet. "Blood and ashes, I don't see Birgitte either. We need to be on our way, Elayne, not standing around. Is Aviendha coming?"

ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm slaɪtli, wɪð dʒʌst ə flɪkɝ ə hɝ aɪz təwɔɹd ɹin, ən i nu ʃi wɑz dəsaɪɾɪŋ wʌt pɝfɔɹməns tə ɡɪv hɪm. waɪd-aɪɾ ɪnəsəns maɪt dæmədʒ əɹ stændɪŋ wɪð ðiz wɪmən əz mʌtʃ əz flæʃɪŋ əɹ dɪmpəl əɾ ɪm wʊd; ɪleɪn ɔlweɪz ɪkspɛktəd ðət dɪmpəl tə wɝk wɛɹ ɔl ɛls feɪld. hɝ tʃɪn ɹoʊz slaɪtli. "tɑm ən dʒulɪn ɑɹ hɛlpɪŋ eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt wɑtʃ kæɹaɪɾɪnz pæləs, mæt." ɪt wɑz tə bi ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɪn nɪɹ fʊl-blum. nɑt ðə hoʊl flaʊɝɪŋ, sɪns ʃi ʃʊɹli nu haʊ hi wəd ɹiæk tə ðæt, bʌɾ ə vɔɪs fʊl ə sɝɾənti, kul blu aɪz dɪmændɪŋ, ən ðət pɹɪɾi feɪs tʃɪl ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli fɹoʊzən wɪð ɛɹəɡəns. wɑz ðəɹ ɛni wʊmən ɪn ðə wɝld u wɑz dʒʌst wʌn pɝsən? "nɪneɪiv wɪl bi daʊn ʃɔɹtli, aɪm ʃʊɹ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ jə tə kʌm, jə noʊ, mæt. neɪlzin ən jəɹ soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ ə mɔɹ ðən æɾəkwət bɑɾiɡɑɹd. jə kəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ jɝsɛlf ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs əntɪl wi ɹɪtɝn."

She frowned at him slightly, with just a flicker of her eyes toward Reanne, and he knew she was deciding what performance to give him. Wide-eyed innocence might damage her standing with these women as much as flashing her dimple at him would; Elayne always expected that dimple to work where all else failed. Her chin rose slightly. "Thom and Juilin are helping Aviendha and Birgitte watch Carridin's palace, Mat." It was to be the Daughter-Heir in near full-bloom. Not the whole flowering, since she surely knew how he would react to that, but a voice full of certainty, cool blue eyes demanding, and that pretty face chill if not exactly frozen with arrogance. Was there any woman in the world who was just one person? "Nynaeve will be down shortly, I'm sure. There is no reason for you to come, you know, Mat. Nalesean and your soldiers are a more than adequate bodyguard. You could enjoy yourself right here in the palace until we return."

"kæɹaɪɾɪn!" hi kɹaɪd. "ɪleɪn, wi ɑɹən steɪɪŋ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ tə sɛɾəl dʒeɪitʃɪm kæɹaɪɾɪn. wəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə boʊl, ðən jə əɹ nɪneɪiv ɪz gɑnə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən wəɹ livɪŋ. ɪz ðət klɪɹ? ən aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð jə tə ðə ɹæhəd." ɛndʒɔɪ hɪmsɛlf! ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt taɪlɪn wəd ɡɛɾ ʌp tə ɪf i ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə pæləs ɔl deɪ. ðə vɛɹi θɔt meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə læf hɪstɛɹɪkli.

"Carridin!" he cried. "Elayne, we aren't staying in Ebou Dar to settle Jaichim Carridin. We are getting the Bowl, then you or Nynaeve is going to make a gateway, and we are leaving. Is that clear? And I'm going with you to the Rahad." Enjoy himself! The Light only knew what Tylin would get up to if he remained in the palace all day. The very thought made him want to laugh hysterically.

aɪsi stɛɹz stæbd əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə waɪz wɪmən; staʊt sumeɪkoʊ pɝst əɹ lɪps æŋɡɹəli, ən məlɹ, ə plʌmp dəmɑni ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz huz bʊzəm i hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪɾ aɪɪŋ jɛstɝdeɪ, plæntəd fɪsts ɑn hɪps wɪð ə feɪs laɪk ə θʌndɝhɛd. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn fɹəm jɛstɝdeɪ ðəɾ i wɑz nɑɾ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, jɛɾ ivən ɹin ɡeɪv ɪm sətʃ ə skaʊl i hæf θɔt ʃi maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə bɑks ɪz ɪɹz. əpɛɹənli, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə fɔl ɔl oʊvɝ ðɛmsɛlvz ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls hæd tə əz wɛl.

Icy stares stabbed at him from the Wise Women; stout Sumeko pursed her lips angrily, and Melore, a plump Domani in her middle years whose bosom he had enjoyed eyeing yesterday, planted fists on hips with a face like a thunderhead. They should have known from yesterday that he was not intimidated by Aes Sedai, yet even Reanne gave him such a scowl he half thought she might try to box his ears. Apparently, if they were going to fall all over themselves around Aes Sedai, then everybody else had to as well.

ɪleɪn stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð hɝsɛlf vɪzəbli. hɝ lɪps kəmpɹɛst, bʌt wʌn θɪŋ i hæd tə ɡɪv hɝ; ʃi wɑz tu smɑɹt tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð wʌɾ ɑbviəsli wəd nɑt wɝk. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ʃi wɑz snuɾi tə ðə boʊn haʊɛvɝ ʃi tʃɹaɪd. ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ. "mæt, jə noʊ wi kænɑt liv əntɪl wɪv juz ðə boʊl." ðət hɔɾi tʃɪn ɹɪmeɪn haɪ, ən əɹ toʊn wɑz ət bɛs hæfweɪ bɪtwin ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ən tɛlɪŋ. "ɪt maɪt ɹikwaɪɝ deɪz fəɹ əs tə bi ʃʊɹ ə haʊ tə juz ɪt, pɝhæps ivən hæf ə wik əɹ mɔɹ, ən wi maɪɾ əz wɛl fɪnɪʃ kæɹaɪɾɪn ɪf wi kən ɪn ðət taɪm." sətʃ ə kɹækəl ɛntɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs ɑn ðə waɪtkloʊks neɪm ðət jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ʃi bɔɹ ðə mæn ə pɝsənəl ɡɹʌdʒ, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls lɛpt aʊɾ ən klæmpt ə fɪst ɑn ɪz θɔts.

Elayne struggled with herself visibly. Her lips compressed, but one thing he had to give her; she was too smart to go on with what obviously would not work. On the other hand, she was snooty to the bone however she tried. And the other women were watching. "Mat, you know we cannot leave until we have used the Bowl." That haughty chin remained high, and her tone was at best halfway between explaining and telling. "It might require days for us to be sure of how to use it, perhaps even half a week or more, and we might as well finish Carridin if we can in that time." Such a crackle entered her voice on the Whitecloak's name that you might have thought she bore the man a personal grudge, but something else leaped out and clamped a fist on his thoughts.

"hæf ə wik!" filɪŋ stʃɹæŋɡəld, hi pʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ bɪhaɪn ðə skɑɹf nɑɾɪd ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk ən tʌɡd tə iz ɪt. taɪlɪn hæd juz ðət lɛŋθ ə blæk sɪlk tə taɪ hɪz hænz læs naɪt bɪfɔɹ i nu wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. hæf ə wik. əɹ mɔɹ! dɪspaɪɾ ɪz bɛst ɛfɝts, hɪz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm ə tʌtʃ fɹæntɪk. "ɪleɪn, ʃʊɹli jə kən juz ðə boʊl ɛniwɛɹ. ɪt dʌzn əv tə bi hɪɹ. ɛɡwin mʌst wɑn jə bæk əz sun əz pɑsəbəl; ʃi kən juz ə fɹɛn əɹ tu, əl weɪdʒɝ." baɪ ðə læst i hæd sin, ʃi kəd juz ə fju hʌnʒɹəd. meɪbi wʌns i ɡɑt ðiz wɪmən bæk, ɛɡwin wəd bi ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv ʌp ðət nɑnsɛns əbaʊt biɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn ən lɛɾ ɪm teɪk əɹ tə ɹænd əlɔŋ wɪð ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ən eɪvinhə. "ænd wʌɾ əbaʊt ɹænd, ɪleɪn? keɪɛmlɪn. ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, jə noʊ jə wɑnə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn kwɪk əz jə kən soʊ ɹænd kən ɡɪv jə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn." fəɹ səm ɹizən, hɝ feɪs ɡɹu dɑɹkɝ ɔlmoʊs baɪ ðə wɝd, ən əɹ aɪz flæʃt. hi wʊɾə sɛd ʃi wɑz ɪndɪɡnənt, ɪksɛpt ə kɔɹs ðət ʃi hæd noʊ kɑz.

"Half a week!" Feeling strangled, he put a finger behind the scarf knotted around his neck and tugged to ease it. Tylin had used that length of black silk to tie his hands last night before he knew what she was doing. Half a week. Or more! Despite his best efforts, his voice became a touch frantic. "Elayne, surely you can use the Bowl anywhere. It doesn't have to be here. Egwene must want you back as soon as possible; she can use a friend or two, I'll wager." By the last he had seen, she could use a few hundred. Maybe once he got these women back, Egwene would be ready to give up that nonsense about being Amyrlin and let him take her to Rand along with Elayne and Nynaeve and Aviendha. "And what about Rand, Elayne? Caemlyn. The Lion Throne. Blood and ashes, you know you want to reach Caemlyn quick as you can so Rand can give you the Lion Throne." For some reason, her face grew darker almost by the word, and her eyes flashed. He would have said she was indignant, except of course that she had no cause.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli tə ɑɹɡju əz sun əz i fɪnɪʃt, ən i sɛt hɪmsɛlf, ɹɛɾi tə lɪst əɹ pɹɑməsəz ən tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum wɪð wʌt ðət dɪd tə hɝ ɪn ði aɪz ə ɹin ən ðə ɹɛst. baɪ ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ðeɪ wʊɾə snʌbd ɪm ʃɔɹɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn əɹ pleɪs.

She opened her mouth angrily to argue as soon as he finished, and he set himself, ready to list her promises and to the Pit of Doom with what that did to her in the eyes of Reanne and the rest. By their faces, they would have snubbed him short already in her place.

bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ðoʊ, ə ɹaʊnd ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən ɪn haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ lɪvɝi wɑz kɝtsiɪŋ, fɝs tə ɪleɪn, ðən tə ðə wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd bɛls, ən faɪnəli tə hɪm. "kwin taɪlɪn sɛnz ðɪs, mæstɝ kɔθən," lɹən sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə bæskət wɪð ə stʃɹaɪp klɔθ oʊvɝ ðə kɑntɛns ən smɔl ɹɛd flaʊɝz woʊvən ɝaʊn ðə hændəl. "ju dɪd nɑt bɹɛkfəst, ən jə mʌs meɪnteɪn jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ."

Before anyone could say anything, though, a round graying woman in House Mitsobar livery was curtsying, first to Elayne, then to the women wearing red belts, and finally to him. "Queen Tylin sends this, Master Cauthon," Laren said, holding out a basket with a striped cloth over the contents and small red flowers woven around the handle. "You did not breakfast, and you must maintain your strength."

mæts tʃiks wɔɹmd. ðə wʊmən mɪɹli lʊkt ət hɪm, bʌt ʃi hæd sin kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ ə hɪm ðən wən ʃi fɝst ʃoʊɾ ɪm ɪndə taɪlɪnz pɹɛzəns. kənsɪɾɝəbli mɔɹ. ʃi hæd bɹɔt sʌpɝ ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ læs naɪt, waɪl i tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə sɪlk bɛdʃit. hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt. ðiz wɪmən hæɾ ɪm dʒʌmpɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən blʌʃɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɝl. hi dʒʌs kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd.

Mat's cheeks warmed. The woman merely looked at him, but she had seen considerably more of him than when she first showed him into Tylin's presence. Considerably more. She had brought supper on a tray last night, while he tried to hide under the silk bedsheet. He did not understand it. These women had him jumping about and blushing like a girl. He just could not understand.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə wʊdn ɹæðɝ ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ?" ɪleɪn æskt. "aɪm ʃʊɹ taɪlɪn wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ jəɹ kʌmpəni fəɹ bɹɛkfəst. ðə kwin sɛd ʃi faɪnz jə wʌndɝfəli ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ən kɔɝɾiəsli kəmplaɪənt," ʃi æɾəd ɪn ə daʊtfəl toʊn.

"Are you sure you wouldn't rather remain here?" Elayne asked. "I'm sure Tylin would enjoy your company for breakfast. The Queen said she finds you wonderfully entertaining and courteously compliant," she added in a doubtful tone.

mæt flɛd fəɹ ðə koʊtʃɪz wɪð ðə bæskəɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ði ʌðɝ.

Mat fled for the coaches with the basket in one hand and his ashandarei in the other.

"ɑɹ ɔl nɔɹðɝn mɛn soʊ ʃaɪ?" lɹən sɛd.

"Are all northern men so shy?" Laren said.

hi ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ, ən hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts, tɝnɪŋ tə wɔk ðoʊ ðə skɹin ə plæns, ən ɪleɪn wɑz moʊʃənɪŋ ɹin ən ðə waɪz wɪmən ɪndə ə sɝkəl kloʊs ɝaʊn hɝ. ivən soʊ, hi ʃɪvɝd. wɪmən wɝ gɑnə bi ðə dɛθ ə hɪm jɛt.

He risked a glance over his shoulder without stopping, and heaved a sigh of relief. The serving woman was already gathering her skirts, turning to walk though the screen of plants, and Elayne was motioning Reanne and the Wise Women into a circle close around her. Even so, he shivered. Women were going to be the death of him yet.

ɹaʊndɪŋ ðə nɪɹəs koʊtʃ, hi nɪɹli dʒɹɑp ðə bæskəɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə bɛslən siɾəd ɑn ðə koʊtʃ stɛp, sʌnlaɪt ɡlimɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ bleɪɾ ə hɪz sɔɹɾ əz i ɪɡzæmən ði ɛdʒ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ?" mæt ɪkskleɪmd.

Rounding the nearest coach, he nearly dropped the basket at the sight of Beslan seated on the coach step, sunlight gleaming along the narrow blade of his sword as he examined the edge. "What are you doing here?" Mat exclaimed.

bɛslən slɪd ðə sɔɹɾ ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ, ə ɡɹɪn splɪɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs. "kʌmɪŋ wɪð jə tə ðə ɹæhəd. aɪ səspɛk jəl faɪn mɔɹ fʌn fəɹ ʌs."

Beslan slid the sword into its sheath, a grin splitting his face. "Coming with you to the Rahad. I suspect you'll find more fun for us."

"ðɛɹ hæd bɛɾɝ bi səm fʌn," neɪlzin jɔn ɪndə hɪz hænd. "aɪ dɪdnt ɡɛt vɛɹi mʌtʃ slip læs naɪt, ən naʊ jə dʒɹæɡ mi ɔf wən ðəɹ ɑɹ si foʊk wɪmən əbaʊt." veɪnɪn sæɾ ʌp ɑn ɪz bæɹəl, lʊkt ɝaʊnd, faʊnd nʌθɪŋ muvɪŋ, ən sɛɾəld hɪmsɛlf bæk əɡɛn wɪð ɪz aɪz ʃʌt.

"There had better be some fun," Nalesean yawned into his hand. "I didn't get very much sleep last night, and now you drag me off when there are Sea Folk women about." Vanin sat up on his barrel, looked around, found nothing moving, and settled himself back again with his eyes shut.

"ðɛɹəl bi noʊ fʌn ɪf aɪ kən hɛlp ɪt," mæt mʌɾɝd. neɪlzin hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən mʌtʃ slip? hɑ! ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm hæd bɪn aʊɾ ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ət ðə fɛstəvəl. nɑt ðəɾ i hæd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪd hɪmsɛlf ɪn pætʃəz, bʌɾ oʊnli wən i kəd fɝɡɛɾ i wɑz wɪð ə wʊmən u θɔɾ i wɑz səm sɔɹɾ ə blʌɾi dɑl. "wʌt si foʊk wɪmən?"

"There'll be no fun if I can help it," Mat muttered. Nalesean had not gotten much sleep? Hah! The whole lot of them had been out enjoying themselves at the festival. Not that he had not enjoyed himself in patches, but only when he could forget he was with a woman who thought he was some sort of bloody doll. "What Sea Folk women?"

"wɛn nɪneɪiv sədaɪ ɹɪtɝn læs naɪt, ʃi bɹɔɾ ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ, mæt." bɛslən blu aʊɾ ɪz bɹɛθ, ən ɪz hænz meɪd sweɪɪŋ moʊʃənz. "ðə weɪ ðeɪ muv, mæt. . . ."

"When Nynaeve Sedai returned last night, she brought a dozen or more, Mat." Beslan blew out his breath, and his hands made swaying motions. "The way they move, Mat. . . ."

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi wɑz nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ klɪɹli; taɪlɪn wɑz skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɪz bɹeɪnz. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn hæd toʊld ɪm əbaʊt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ɹɪlʌktənli ən ɪn swɔɹn sikɹəsi, æftɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊl bæk ivən wɛɹ nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ, mʌtʃ lɛs waɪ. ən nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl blʌʃ ət ði ɛfɝt, iðɝ. "wɪmən kip pɹɑməsəz ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ," soʊ ðə seɪɪŋ wɛnt. kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, lɔɾɪn ən bɛlvɪn wɝ nɑt wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹɛd-ɑɹmz. meɪbi nɪneɪiv θɔt tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ði ʌðɝ baɪ kipɪŋ əm wɪð əɹ naʊ. ". . . ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ." bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə pæləs, ʃʊɹli ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk hæf ə wik tə juz ðə boʊl. laɪt, pliz nɑt!

Mat shook his head. He was not thinking clearly; Tylin was scrambling his brains. Nynaeve and Elayne had told him about the Windfinders, reluctantly and in sworn secrecy, after trying to hold back even where Nynaeve wanted to go, much less why. And not a single blush at the effort, either. "Women keep promises in their own way," so the saying went. Come to think of it, Lawtin and Belvyn were not with the rest of the Red-arms. Maybe Nynaeve thought to make up for the other by keeping them with her now. ". . . In their own way." But if she had the Windfinders already in the palace, surely it would not take half a week to use the Bowl. Light, please not!

əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ hæd bɪn ə sʌmənz, nɪneɪiv keɪm stʃɹoʊlɪŋ θɹu ðə skɹin ə plæns ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. mæts dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt. ðə tɔl mæn ɪn ə dɑɹk ɡɹin koʊɾ ɑn əɹ ɑɹm wɑz læn! əɹ ɹæðɝ, ʃi wɑz ɑn hɪz, klɪŋɪŋ tə ɪt wɪð boʊθ hænz, smaɪlɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm. wɪð ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən, mæt wʊɾə sɛd ʃi wɑz mun-aɪɾ ən dʒɹimɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz nɪneɪiv.

As if thinking of her had been a summons, Nynaeve came strolling through the screen of plants into the stableyard. Mat's jaw dropped. The tall man in a dark green coat on her arm was Lan! Or rather, she was on his, clinging to it with both hands, smiling up at him. With any other woman, Mat would have said she was moon-eyed and dreaming, but this was Nynaeve.

ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wʌns ʃi ɹilaɪzd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, ən tʊk ə heɪsti stɛp tə wʌn saɪd, ðoʊ ʃi stɪl hɛld ɑn tə lænz hæn fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hɝ tʃɔɪs ə dʒɹɛsəz wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɪleɪnz, ɔl blu sɪlk ən ɡɹin ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, kʌt loʊ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ə hɛvi ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ ðət wʊɾə ɹæɾəld ɑn əɹ tu θʌmz təɡɛðɝ, dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪndə hɝ klivədʒ ɑn ə θɪn ɡoʊl tʃeɪn. ðə waɪd hæt ʃi kæɹid baɪ ɪts ɹɪbənz wɑz tʃɹɪmd wɪð blu plumz, hɝ dʌstkloʊk ɡɹin lɪnən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn blu. ʃi ən ɪleɪn meɪd ði ʌðɝ wɪmən dʒɹæb baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən ɪn ðɛɹ wʊlənz.

She gave a start once she realized where she was, and took a hasty step to one side, though she still held on to Lan's hand for a moment. Her choice of dresses was no better than Elayne's, all blue silk and green embroidery, cut low enough to show a heavy gold ring that would have rattled on her two thumbs together, dangling into her cleavage on a thin gold chain. The wide hat she carried by its ribbons was trimmed with blue plumes, her dustcloak green linen embroidered in blue. She and Elayne made the other women drab by comparison in their woolens.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi hæd bɪn kæf-aɪz ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ, ʃi wɑz ɔl hɝsɛlf naʊ, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ɝaʊnd. "dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝ mɛn naʊ, læn," ʃi sɛd pɝɛmptɔɹəli, "ænd wi kən ɡoʊ. ðə læs fɔɹ koʊtʃɪz ɑɹ fəɹ ðə mɛn."

In any case, whether or not she had been calf-eyes a moment before, she was all herself now, shifting her braid around. "Join the other men now, Lan," she said peremptorily, "and we can go. The last four coaches are for the men."

"æz jə seɪ," læn ɹɪplaɪd, boʊɪŋ wɪð ə hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt.

"As you say," Lan replied, bowing with a hand on his sword hilt.

ʃi wɑtʃt ɪm stʃɹaɪd təwɔɹd mæt wɪð ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ʌv wʌndɝ, pɹɑbli əneɪbəl tə bɪliv i wɑz oʊbeɪɪŋ soʊ mikli, ðən ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən ɹəkʌvɝɾ əɹ bɹɪsli sɛlf əɡɛn. ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp ɪleɪn ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, ʃi hɝɾɪd əm təwɔɹd ðə fɝs tu koʊtʃɪz laɪk ə wʊmən ʃuɪŋ ɡis. baɪ ðə weɪ ʃi ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə oʊpən ðə steɪbliɑɹd ɡeɪts, noʊ wʌn wʊɾə noʊn ʃi hæd bɪn ðə wʌn dɪleɪɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. ʃi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz, tu, sɛɾɪŋ əm tə snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz ən flɝɪʃɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ wɪps; ɪt wɑz ə mɑɹvəl ðeɪ weɪɾəd fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə klaɪm əbɔɹd.

She watched him stride toward Mat with an expression of wonder, probably unable to believe he was obeying so meekly, then gave herself a shake and recovered her bristly self again. Gathering up Elayne and the other women, she herded them toward the first two coaches like a woman shooing geese. By the way she shouted for someone to open the stableyard gates, no one would have known she had been the one delaying their departure. She shouted at the drivers, too, setting them to snatching up their reins and flourishing their long whips; it was a marvel they waited for anyone to climb aboard.

skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɔkwɝdli æftɝ læn ən neɪlzin ən bɛslən ɪndə ðə θɝd koʊtʃ, mæt pɹɑpt ɪz spɪɹ əkɹɔs ðə dɔɹ ən sæt daʊn hɑɹd wɪð ðə bæskəɾ ɑn ɪz læp əz ðə koʊtʃ lɝtʃt fɔɹwɝd. "wɛɹ dɪd jə kʌm fɹʌm, læn?" hi bɝst aʊɾ əz sun əz ɪntʃɹədʌkʃənz wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. "jɔɹ ðə læs mæn aɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə si. wɛɹ əv jə bɪn? laɪt, aɪ θɔt jə wɝ dɛd. aɪ noʊ ɹændz əfɹeɪd jə ɑɹ. ən lɛɾɪŋ nɪneɪiv ɔɹɾɝ jə ɝaʊnd. waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt wəd jə də ðæt?"

Scrambling awkwardly after Lan and Nalesean and Beslan into the third coach, Mat propped his spear across the door and sat down hard with the basket on his lap as the coach lurched forward. "Where did you come from, Lan?" he burst out as soon as introductions were out of the way. "You're the last man I expected to see. Where have you been? Light, I thought you were dead. I know Rand's afraid you are. And letting Nynaeve order you around. Why in the Light would you do that?"

ðə stoʊn-feɪst wɔɹɾɝ sim tə kənsɪɾɝ wɪtʃ kwɛstʃən tə ænsɝ. "nɪneɪiv ən aɪ wɝ mɛɹid læs naɪt baɪ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "ði æθɑn maɪɹ əv sɛvɹəl . . . ənjuʒəwəl . . . mɛɹɪdʒ kʌstəmz. ðəɹ wɝ sɝpɹaɪzəz fəɹ boʊθ ʌv ʌs." ə smɔl smaɪl tʌtʃt ɪz maʊθ, ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls. hi ʃɹʌɡd slaɪtli; simɪŋli ðət wɑz ɔl ði ænsɝ i ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɪv.

The stone-faced Warder seemed to consider which question to answer. "Nynaeve and I were married last night by the Mistress of the Ships," he said finally. "The Atha'an Miere have several . . . unusual . . . marriage customs. There were surprises for both of us." A small smile touched his mouth, if nothing else. He shrugged slightly; seemingly that was all the answer he intended to give.

"ðə blɛsɪŋ ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn jə ən jəɹ bɹaɪd," bɛslən mɝmɝd pəlaɪtli wɪð əz mʌtʃ ʌv ə baʊ əz ðə kɑnfaɪnz ə ðə koʊtʃ wəɾ əlaʊ, ən neɪlzin mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz pleɪn fɹəm ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ðəɾ i θɔt læn mʌs bi mæd. neɪlzin hæd hæɾ ə ɡʊd bɪɾ ə nɪneɪivz kʌmpəni.

"The blessing of the Light be upon you and your bride," Beslan murmured politely with as much of a bow as the confines of the coach would allow, and Nalesean mumbled something, though it was plain from his expression that he thought Lan must be mad. Nalesean had had a good bit of Nynaeve's company.

mæt dʒʌst sæt ðəɹ sweɪɪŋ wɪð ðə koʊtʃəz moʊʃən ən stɛɹɪŋ. nɪneɪiv mɛɹid? læn mɛɹid tə nɪneɪiv? ðə mæn wɑz mæd. noʊ wʌndɝ ɪz aɪz lʊk soʊ blik. mæt wəɾ əz sun əv stʌft ə ɹæbɪd fɑks daʊn ɪz oʊn ʃɝt. oʊnli ə ful mɛɹid, ən oʊnli ə mædmæn wəd mɛɹi nɪneɪiv.

Mat just sat there swaying with the coach's motion and staring. Nynaeve married? Lan married to Nynaeve? The man was mad. No wonder his eyes looked so bleak. Mat would as soon have stuffed a rabid fox down his own shirt. Only a fool married, and only a madman would marry Nynaeve.

ɪf læn noʊɾəst ðət nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz oʊvɝdʒɔɪd, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz aɪz, hi lʊk noʊ dɪfɹən ðən mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd. meɪbi ə lɪɾəl hɑɹɾɝ, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. "ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt," læn sɛd. "nɪneɪiv dʌznt wɑn jə tə noʊ, mæt, bʌt jə nid tə hɪɹ ɪt. jəɹ tu mɛn ɑɹ dɛd, kɪl baɪ mɑɡiɾin. aɪm sɑɹi, bʌɾ ɪf ɪts ɛni kɑnsəleɪʃən, ðeɪ tʃɹuli wɝ dɛd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ nu. nɪneɪiv θɪŋks mɑɡiɾin mʌs bi ɡɔn, əɹ ʃiɾ əv tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt soʊ sɝɾən. ɪt simz ʃiz ə pɝsənəl ɛnməɾi təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv, ɔlðoʊ nɪneɪiv mænədʒ tə əvɔɪd tɛlɪŋ mi waɪ." əɡɛn ðə smaɪl; læn simd ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv ɪt. "nɑɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt, ət list, ən ɪt dʌz nɑt mæɾɝ. bɛs jə noʊ wʌt maɪt bi feɪsɪŋ əs bɪɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðoʊ."

If Lan noticed that not everyone was overjoyed, he gave no sign. Except for his eyes, he looked no different than Mat remembered. Maybe a little harder, if that was possible. "There is something more important," Lan said. "Nynaeve doesn't want you to know, Mat, but you need to hear it. Your two men are dead, killed by Moghedien. I am sorry, but if it is any consolation, they truly were dead before they knew. Nynaeve thinks Moghedien must be gone, or she'd have tried again, but I am not so certain. It seems she has a personal enmity toward Nynaeve, although Nynaeve managed to avoid telling me why." Again the smile; Lan seemed unaware of it. "Not all of it, at least, and it does not matter. Best you know what might be facing us beyond the river, though."

"mɑɡiɾin," bɛslən bɹiðd, aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ. ðə mæn wɑz pɹɑbli siɪŋ fʌn.

"Moghedien," Beslan breathed, eyes shining. The man was probably seeing fun.

"mɑɡiɾin," neɪlzin bɹiðd, bʌɾ ɪn ɪz keɪs, ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ʌv ə ɡɹoʊn, ən i ɡeɪv ɪz pɔɪntəd bɪɹɾ ə fɪtfəl dʒɝk.

"Moghedien," Nalesean breathed, but in his case, it was more of a groan, and he gave his pointed beard a fitful jerk.

"ðoʊz blʌɾi fleɪmɪŋ wɪmən," mæt mʌɾɝd.

"Those bloody flaming women," Mat muttered.

"aɪ hoʊp jə doʊn ɪnklud maɪ waɪf," læn sɛd koʊldli, wʌn hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, ən mæt kwɪkli ɹeɪzd ɪz oʊn hænz.

"I hope you don't include my wife," Lan said coldly, one hand gripping the hilt of his sword, and Mat quickly raised his own hands.

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. dʒʌst ɪleɪn ən . . . ən ðə kɪn."

"Of course not. Just Elayne and . . . and the Kin."

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, læn nɑɾəd, ən mæt bɹiðd ə smɔl saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ɪt wəd bi dʒʌs laɪk nɪneɪiv tə ɡɛɾ ɪm kɪl baɪ hɝ hʌzbənd - hɝ hʌzbənd! - wən ʃʊɹ əz bɹɛd wɑz bɹaʊn, ʃi wʊɾə hɪɾən ðə fæk ðət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən maɪt bi ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ivən mɑɡiɾin dɪd nɑt ɹɪli fɹaɪɾən hɪm, nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz i hæd ðə fɑkshɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, bʌt ðə mədæljən kəd nɑt pɹətɛk neɪlzin əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə ɹɛst. noʊ daʊt nɪneɪiv θɔt ʃi ən ɪleɪn wəd də ðæt. ðeɪ lɛɾ ɪm bɹɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, ɔl ðə waɪl læfɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ slivz əɾ ɪm waɪl ðeɪ -  "ɑɹən jə gɑnə ɹid maɪ mʌðɝz noʊt, mæt?"

After a moment, Lan nodded, and Mat breathed a small sigh of relief. It would be just like Nynaeve to get him killed by her husband - her husband! - when sure as bread was brown, she would have hidden the fact that one of the Forsaken might be in the city. Even Moghedien did not really frighten him, not so long as he had the foxhead around his neck, but the medallion could not protect Nalesean or any of the rest. No doubt Nynaeve thought she and Elayne would do that. They let him bring along the Redarms, all the while laughing up their sleeves at him while they -  "Aren't you going to read my mother's note, Mat?"

əntɪl bɛslən mɛnʃən ɪt, hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ, foʊldəd smɔl, tʌkt ɪn bɪtwin ðə bæskəɾ ən ðə stʃɹaɪp klɔθ. dʒʌst ɪnʌf ʃoʊd tə ɹɪvil ðə ɡɹin sil ɪmpɹɛst wɪð ði æŋkɝ ən sɔɹd.

Until Beslan mentioned it, he had not realized there was a sheet of paper, folded small, tucked in between the basket and the striped cloth. Just enough showed to reveal the green seal impressed with the Anchor and Sword.

hi bɹoʊk ðə wæks wɪð ɪz θʌm ən ənfoʊldəd ðə peɪdʒ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪt soʊ bɛslən kəd nɑt si wʌt wɑz ɹɪɾən. əz wɛl i dɪd; əɹ ðən əɡɛn, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ haʊ ði ʌðɝ mæn sɔ θɪŋz, meɪbi ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. iðɝ weɪ, mæt wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæd noʊ aɪz bʌɾ ɪz sɔ ðoʊz wɝdz. hɪz hɑɹt sæŋk dipɝ baɪ ðə laɪn.

He broke the wax with his thumb and unfolded the page, holding it so Beslan could not see what was written. As well he did; or then again, considering how the other man saw things, maybe it did not matter. Either way, Mat was just as glad no eyes but his saw those words. His heart sank deeper by the line.

mæt, maɪ swit, aɪm hævɪŋ jəɹ θɪŋz muv tə maɪ əpɑɹtməns. soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kənvinjənt. baɪ ðə taɪm jə ɹɪtɝn, ɹaɪzɛl wɪl bi ɪn jəɹ oʊld ɹumz tə lʊk æftɝ jʌŋ oʊlvɝ. hi simz tə ɛndʒɔɪ hɝ kʌmpəni.

Mat, my sweet, I am having your things moved to my apartments. So much more convenient. By the time you return, Riselle will be in your old rooms to look after young Olver. He seems to enjoy her company.

aɪ hæv simstʃɹəsəz kʌmɪŋ tə mɛʒɝ ju. əl ɛndʒɔɪ wɑtʃɪŋ ðæt. jə mʌst wɛɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ koʊts. ən nu bɹitʃɪz, ʌv kɔɹs. juv ə dɪlaɪtfəl bɑɾəm. dʌklɪŋ, hu ɪz ðɪs dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz aɪ meɪd jə θɪŋk ʌv? aɪ hæv θɔɾ ə sɛvɹəl dɪlɪʃəs weɪz tə meɪk jə tɛl mi.

I have seamstresses coming to measure you. I will enjoy watching that. You must wear shorter coats. And new breeches, of course. You have a delightful bottom. Duckling, who is this Daughter of the Nine Moons I made you think of? I have thought of several delicious ways to make you tell me.

taɪlɪn ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪkspɛktənli. wɛl, læn wɑz sɪmpli lʊkɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz ɡeɪz wɑz mɔɹ ənɝvɪŋ ðən ðə ɹɛst; ðət stɛɹ simd ɔlmoʊst . . . dɛd.

Tylin The others were all looking at him expectantly. Well, Lan was simply looking, but his gaze was more unnerving than the rest; that stare seemed almost . . . dead.

"ðə kwin θɪŋks ðəfɝs nid nu kloʊðz," mæt sɛd, stʌfɪŋ ðə noʊɾ ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. "aɪ θɪŋk əl teɪk ə næp." hi pʊl ðə bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt daʊn oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kloʊs ðɛm, stɛɹɪŋ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ, wɛɹ ðə taɪd-bæk kɝɾən lɛɾ ɪn əkeɪʒənəl ɛɾiz ə dʌst. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ lɛɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, ðoʊ, wɪtʃ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbli bɛɾɝ ðən ðə hiɾ ʌv ə kloʊz koʊtʃ.

"The Queen thinks I need new clothes," Mat said, stuffing the note into his coat pocket. "I think I'll take a nap." He pulled the brim of his hat down over his eyes, but he did not close them, staring out the window, where the tied-back curtain let in occasional eddies of dust. It also let in the wind, though, which was considerably better than the heat of a closed coach.

mɑɡiɾin ən taɪlɪn. ʌv ðə tu, hi wəd ɹæðɝ kənfɹʌn mɑɡiɾin. hi tʌtʃt ðə fɑkshɛd hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpən nɛk ə hɪz ʃɝt. ət list i hæd səm pɹətɛkʃən əɡɛns mɑɡiɾin. əɡɛns taɪlɪn, hi hæd noʊ mɔɹ ðən i dɪɾ əɡɛns ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə blʌɾi naɪn munz, huɛvɝ ʃi wɑz. ənlɛs i kəd faɪn səm weɪ tə meɪk nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn liv ɛbu dɑɹ bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt, ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə noʊ. sʌlənli, hi tʌɡd ɪz hæt loʊɝ. ðiz fleɪmɪŋ wɪmən ɹɪli wɝ meɪkɪŋ ɪm æk laɪk ə ɡɝl. ɪn ənʌðɝ mɪnət, hi wɑz əfɹeɪd, hi maɪt dʒʌst stɑɹt kɹaɪɪŋ.

Moghedien and Tylin. Of the two, he would rather confront Moghedien. He touched the foxhead hanging in the open neck of his shirt. At least he had some protection against Moghedien. Against Tylin, he had no more than he did against the Daughter of the bloody Nine Moons, whoever she was. Unless he could find some way to make Nynaeve and Elayne leave Ebou Dar before tonight, everybody was going to know. Sullenly, he tugged his hat lower. These flaming women really were making him act like a girl. In another minute, he was afraid, he might just start crying.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾieɪt


CHAPTER 38

sɪks stɔɹiz


Six Stories

mæt wʊɾə ɡɑɾən aʊɾ ən pʊl ðə koʊtʃ hɪmsɛlf, ɪf i kʊd. hi θɔt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv muv fæstɝ. ðə stʃɹits wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi fʊl wɪð ðə sʌn nɑɾ ɔl ðə weɪ ʌp, wæɡənz ən kɑɹts wɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ nɑsəli θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz ən wɪnbloʊn dʌs tə ʃaʊts ən kɝsɪz boʊθ fɹəm dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ðoʊz fɔɹs tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. soʊ mɛni bɑɹdʒəz slɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə kənælz ɑn ðə bɑɹɡmənz poʊlz ðəɾ ə mæn ɔlmoʊst cʊɾə wɔk ðə kənælz laɪk stʃɹits, stɛpɪŋ fɹəm wʌn bɑɹdʒ tə ðə nɛkst. ə nɔɪzi hʌm hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɡlimɪŋ waɪt sɪɾi. ɛbu dɑɹ sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ taɪm lɔs jɛstɝdeɪ, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ət haɪ tʃeɪsəlin ən ðə fist ə laɪts, ən wɛl ɪt maɪt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðət təmɑɹoʊ naɪt wɑz ðə fist ʌv ɛmbɝz, wɪð mæɾɪnz deɪ, sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə faʊndɝ ʌv ɔltɑɹə, tu deɪz æftɝ ðæt, ən ðə fist ə ðə hæf mun ðə fɑloʊɪŋ naɪt. sʌðɝnɝz hæɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ ɪndəstʃɹi, bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz kəz ðeɪ hæd tə wɝk soʊ hɑɹd tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ɔl ðə fɛstəvəlz ən fistdeɪz. ðə wʌndɝ wɑz ðət ðeɪ hæd ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ fəɹ ɪt.

Mat would have gotten out and pulled the coach himself, if he could. He thought they might have moved faster. The streets were already full with the sun not all the way up, wagons and carts wending their way nosily through the crowds and windblown dust to shouts and curses both from drivers and those forced to get out of the way. So many barges slid along the canals on the bargemen's poles that a man almost could have walked the canals like streets, stepping from one barge to the next. A noisy hum hung over the gleaming white city. Ebou Dar seemed to be trying to make up for time lost yesterday, not to mention at High Chasaline and the Feast of Lights, and well it might, considering that tomorrow night was the Feast of Embers, with Maddin's Day, celebrating the founder of Altara, two days after that, and the Feast of the Half Moon the following night. Southerners had a reputation for industry, but he thought it was because they had to work so hard to make up for all the festivals and feastdays. The wonder was that they had the strength for it.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə koʊtʃɪz dɪd ɹitʃ ðə ɹɪvɝ, dʒɹɔɪŋ ʌp ət wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ stoʊn lændɪŋz ðət dʒʌɾɪd aʊɾ ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ, ɔl laɪnd wɪð stɛps fəɹ bɔɹɾɪŋ ðə boʊts taɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd. stɪkɪŋ ə wɛdʒ ə dɑɹk jɛloʊ tʃiz ən ə bʌɾ ɛn ə bɹɛɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət, hi stʌf ðə bæskət wɛl ʌndɝ ðə sit. hi wɑz hʌŋɡɹi, bʌt sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz hæd bɪn ɪn tu mʌtʃ ʌv ə hɝi; moʊst ə ðə bæskət wɑz fɪl baɪ ə kleɪ pɑt fʊl ʌv ɔɪstɝz, bʌt ðə kɪtʃənz hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə kʊk ðɛm.

Eventually the coaches did reach the river, drawing up at one of the long stone landings that jutted out into the water, all lined with steps for boarding the boats tied alongside. Sticking a wedge of dark yellow cheese and a butt end of bread into his pocket, he stuffed the basket well under the seat. He was hungry, but someone in the kitchens had been in too much of a hurry; most of the basket was filled by a clay pot full of oysters, but the kitchens had forgotten to cook them.

skɹæmbəlɪŋ daʊn bɪhaɪn læn, hi lɛf neɪlzin ən bɛslən tə hɛlp veɪnɪn ən ði ʌðɝz daʊn fɹəm ðə læs koʊtʃɪz. nɪɹli ə dʌzən mɛn, ən nɑɾ ivən ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɹɪli smɔl, ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒæmd ɪn laɪk æpəlz ɪn ə bæɹəl ən klæmbɝɾ aʊt stɪfli. mæt stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ təwɔɹd ðə lɛd koʊtʃ, ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ boʊθ gɑnə ɡɛɾ ə pis ə hɪz maɪnd noʊ mæɾɝ u wɑz lɪsnɪŋ. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip mɑɡiɾin hɪɾən! nɑt tə mɛnʃən tu ʌv ɪz mɛn dɛd! hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə - ! sʌɾənli vɛɹi kɑnʃəs ə læn taʊɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪm laɪk ə stoʊn stætʃu wɪð ðət sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, hi əmɛndəɾ ɪz θɔts. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ət list wɑz gɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊt kipɪŋ ðət sɔɹɾ ə sikɹət.

Scrambling down behind Lan, he left Nalesean and Beslan to help Vanin and the others down from the last coaches. Nearly a dozen men, and not even the Cairhienin really small, they had been jammed in like apples in a barrel and clambered out stiffly. Mat strode ahead of the Warder toward the lead coach, the ashandarei slanted across his shoulder. Nynaeve and Elayne were both going to get a piece of his mind no matter who was listening. Trying to keep Moghedien hidden! Not to mention two of his men dead! He was going to - ! Suddenly very conscious of Lan towering behind him like a stone statue with that sword on his hip, he amended his thoughts. The Daughter-Heir at least was going to hear about keeping that sort of secret.

nɪneɪiv wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn ðə lændɪŋ, taɪɪŋ ɑn əɹ blu-plum hæɾ ən tɔkɪŋ bæk ʌp ɪndə ðə koʊtʃ wən i ɹitʃt ɪt. ". . . wɪl wɝk aʊt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ u wəd θɪŋk ðə si foʊk, ʌv ɔl pipəl, wəd dɪmæn sətʃ ə θɪŋ, ivən dʒʌst ɪn pɹaɪvət?"

Nynaeve was standing on the landing, tying on her blue-plumed hat and talking back up into the coach when he reached it. ". . . Will work out, of course, but who would think the Sea Folk, of all people, would demand such a thing, even just in private?"

"bʌt, nɪneɪiv," ɪleɪn sɛɾ əz ʃi stɛp daʊn wɪð əɹ ɡɹin-plum hæɾ ɪn əɹ hænd, "ɪf læs naɪt wɑz əz ɡlɔɹiəs əz jə seɪ, haʊ kən jə kəmpleɪn əbaʊt - ?"

"But, Nynaeve," Elayne said as she stepped down with her green-plumed hat in her hand, "if last night was as glorious as you say, how can you complain about - ?"

ðət wɑz wən ðeɪ bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə hɪm ən læn. ʌv læn, ɹɪli. nɪneɪivz aɪz oʊpənd waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ, fɪlɪŋ əɹ feɪs əz ɪt ɹɛɾənd tə ʃeɪm tu sʌnsɛts. meɪbi θɹi. ɪleɪn fɹoʊz wɪð wʌn fʊt stɪl ɑn ðə koʊtʃ stɛp, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ sətʃ ə fɹaʊn jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæd snikt ʌp ɑn ðɛm. læn ɡeɪz daʊn ət nɪneɪiv, ðoʊ, wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən ə fɛns poʊst, ən fəɹ ɔl nɪneɪiv əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə kɹɔl ʌndɝ ðə koʊtʃ ən haɪd, ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət læn əz ɪf noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪɡzɪstəɾ ɪn ðə wɝld. ɹilaɪzɪŋ əɹ fɹaʊn wɑz weɪstəd ðɛɹ, ɪleɪn tʊk əɹ fʊɾ ɔf ðə stɛp ən muvd aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ɹin ən ðə tu waɪz wɪmən u hæd ʃɛɹd ðə koʊtʃ, tæmɑɹlə ən ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ sɑldəiən wʊmən neɪm dʒənɪɹə, bʌt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp; oʊ, noʊ. ʃi tʃɹænsfɝd ðət skaʊl tə mæt kɔθən, ən ɪf ɪɾ ɔltɝɾ ə wɪt, ɪt wɑz tə dipən. hi snɔɹɾɪd ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. juʒəwəli wən ə wʊmən wɑz ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ, ʃi kəd faɪn soʊ mɛni θɪŋz tə bleɪm ɑn ðə nɪɹəs mæn ðəɾ i waʊn ʌp θɪŋkɪŋ meɪbi hi ɹɪli wɑz ət fɔlt. ɪn ɪz ɪkspɪɹiəns, oʊl mɛmɹiz əɹ nu, ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tu taɪmz ə wʊmən ədmɪɾəd ʃi wɑz ɹɔŋ: wən ʃi wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ, ən wən ɪt snoʊɾ ət mɪdsʌmɝ.

That was when they became aware of him and Lan. Of Lan, really. Nynaeve's eyes opened wider and wider, filling her face as it reddened to shame two sunsets. Maybe three. Elayne froze with one foot still on the coach step, giving the Warder such a frown you would have thought he had sneaked up on them. Lan gazed down at Nynaeve, though, with no more expression than a fence post, and for all Nynaeve appeared ready to crawl under the coach and hide, she stared up at Lan as if no one else existed in the world. Realizing her frown was wasted there, Elayne took her foot off the step and moved out of the way of Reanne and the two Wise Women who had shared the coach, Tamarla and a graying Saldaean woman named Janira, but the Daughter-Heir did not give up; oh, no. She transferred that scowl to Mat Cauthon, and if it altered a whit, it was to deepen. He snorted and shook his head. Usually when a woman was in the wrong, she could find so many things to blame on the nearest man that he wound up thinking maybe he really was at fault. In his experience, old memories or new, there were only two times a woman admitted she was wrong: when she wanted something, and when it snowed at midsummer.

nɪneɪiv sizd əɾ əɹ bɹeɪd, bʌt nɑɾ əz ɪf əɹ hɑɹt wɑz ɪn ɪt. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz fʌmbəld ən fɛl əweɪ, ən ʃi stɑɹɾəd ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz ɪnstɛd. "læn," ʃi bɪɡæn ənstɛɾəli, "ju mʌsnt θɪŋk aɪ wəd tɔk əbaʊt - "

Nynaeve seized at her braid, but not as if her heart was in it. Her fingers fumbled and fell away, and she started wringing her hands instead. "Lan," she began unsteadily, "you mustn't think I would talk about - "

ðə wɔɹɾɝ kʌɾ ɪn smuðli, boʊɪŋ ən ɔfɝɪŋ əɹ ɪz ɑɹm. "wi ɑɹ ɪn pʌblɪk, nɪneɪiv. wʌtɛvɝ jə wɑnə seɪ ɪn pʌblɪk, jə meɪ. meɪ aɪ ɛskɔɹt jə tə ðə boʊt?"

The Warder cut in smoothly, bowing and offering her his arm. "We are in public, Nynaeve. Whatever you want to say in public, you may. May I escort you to the boat?"

"jɛs," ʃi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ soʊ vɪɡɝəsli ðəɾ əɹ hæt nɪɹli fɛl ɔf. ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪt hɝidli wɪð boʊθ hænz. "jɛs. ɪn pʌblɪk. jəl ɛskɔɹt mi." teɪkɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm, ʃi ɹiɡeɪn səm mɛʒɝ ə kəmpoʊʒɝ, ət list ɪnsəfɑɹ əz əɹ feɪs wɛnt. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ dʌst-kloʊk ɪn əɹ fɹi hænd, ʃi pɹæktəkli dʒɹæɡd ɪm əkɹɔs ðə ki təwɔɹd ðə lændɪŋ.

"Yes," she said, nodding so vigorously that her hat nearly fell off. She straightened it hurriedly with both hands. "Yes. In public. You will escort me." Taking his arm, she regained some measure of composure, at least insofar as her face went. Gathering her dust-cloak in her free hand, she practically dragged him across the quay toward the landing.

mæt wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi maɪt bi ɪl. hi ɹæðɝ ɛndʒɔɪd siɪŋ nɪneɪiv dʒɹɑpt ə pɛɡ əɹ sɪks, bʌt ʃi hɑɹdli ɛvɝ lɛɾ ɪt læs tu bɹɛθs. ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt hil ðɛmsɛlvz. meɪbi hi ʃəd sədʒɛs tə ɪleɪn ðət ʃi dil wɪð wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɹɔŋ wɪð nɪneɪiv. hi əvɔɪɾəd hilɪŋ laɪk dɛθ əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfɹən fəɹ ʌðɝ pipəl əz i sɔ ɪt. fɝst, ðoʊ, hi hæɾ ə fju tʃɔɪs wɝdz tə seɪ əbaʊt sikɹəts.

Mat wondered whether she might be ill. He rather enjoyed seeing Nynaeve dropped a peg or six, but she hardly ever let it last two breaths. Aes Sedai could not Heal themselves. Maybe he should suggest to Elayne that she deal with whatever was wrong with Nynaeve. He avoided Healing like death or marriage himself, but it was different for other people as he saw it. First, though, he had a few choice words to say about secrets.

oʊpənɪŋ ɪz maʊθ, hi ɹeɪzd ən ædmənətɔɹi fɪŋɡɝ . . . .

Opening his mouth, he raised an admonitory finger . . . .

. . . ən ɪleɪn poʊkt ɪm ɪn ðə tʃɛst wɪð hɝz, hɝ skaʊl bɪniθ ðət plum hæt soʊ koʊld ɪt meɪɾ ɪz toʊz hɝt. "mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ði aɪsi vɔɪs ʌv ə kwin pɹənaʊnsɪŋ dʒʌdʒmənt, "ɪkspleɪn tə nɪneɪiv ən mi ðə səɡnɪfɪkəns ə ðoʊz ɹɛd flaʊɝz ɑn ðə bæskət, wɪtʃ aɪ si jə ət list əv ʃeɪm ɪnʌf tə hæv hɪɾən."

. . . and Elayne poked him in the chest with hers, her scowl beneath that plumed hat so cold it made his toes hurt. "Mistress Corly," she said in the icy voice of a queen pronouncing judgment, "explained to Nynaeve and me the significance of those red flowers on the basket, which I see you at least have shame enough to have hidden."

hɪz feɪs wɛn ɹɛɾɝ ðən nɪneɪivz hæd θɔɾ ʌv. ə fju peɪsɪz əweɪ, ɹin kɔɹli ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ taɪɪŋ ɑn hæts ən ədʒʌstɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz ðə weɪ wɪmən dɪɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ stʊɾ ʌp, sæt daʊn əɹ muv θɹi stɛps. jɛt dɪspaɪt ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən tə ðɛɹ kloʊðz, ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnʌf lɛft oʊvɝ fəɹ ɡlænsɪz ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, ən fəɹ wʌns ðeɪ wɝ niðɝ dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ nɔɹ stɑɹɾəld. hi hæd nɑt noʊn ðə blʌɾi flaʊɝz mɛn ɛniθɪŋ! tɛn sʌnsɛts wəd nɑɾ əv dʌn fəɹ ɪz feɪs.

His face went redder than Nynaeve's had thought of. A few paces away, Reanne Corly and the other two were tying on hats and adjusting dresses the way women did every time they stood up, sat down or moved three steps. Yet despite giving their attention to their clothes, they had enough left over for glances in his direction, and for once they were neither disapproving nor startled. He had not known the bloody flowers meant anything! Ten sunsets would not have done for his face.

"soʊ!" ɪleɪnz vɔɪs wɑz loʊ, fəɹ ɪz ɪɹz əloʊn, bʌɾ ɪt dʒɹɪp dɪsɡʌst ən kəntɛmpt. ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ kloʊk ə twɪtʃ, tə kip ɪt fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ hɪm. "ɪts tʃɹu! aɪ kəd nɑt bɪliv ɪɾ ə ju, nɑɾ ivən ju! aɪm ʃʊɹ nɪneɪiv kʊdnt. ɛni pɹɑməs aɪ meɪd tə jə ɪz əbɑlɪʃt! əl nɑt kip ɛni pɹɑməs tə ə mæn u kəd fɔɹs ɪz ətɛnʃənz ɑn ə wʊmən, ɑn ɛni wʊmən, bʌɾ ɪspɛʃli ɑn ə kwin u hæz ɔfɝɾ ɪm - "

"So!" Elayne's voice was low, for his ears alone, but it dripped disgust and contempt. She gave her cloak a twitch, to keep it from touching him. "It's true! I could not believe it of you, not even you! I'm sure Nynaeve couldn't. Any promise I made to you is abolished! I will not keep any promise to a man who could force his attentions on a woman, on any woman, but especially on a Queen who has offered him - "

"mi fɔɹs maɪ ətɛnʃənz ɑn hɝ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. əɹ ɹæðɝ, hi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃaʊt; tʃoʊkɪŋ meɪɾ ɪt kʌm aʊɾ ɪn ə wiz.

"Me force my attentions on her!" he shouted. Or rather, he tried to shout; choking made it come out in a wheeze.

sizɪŋ ɪleɪnz ʃoʊldɝz, hi pʊld əɹ əweɪ fɹəm ðə kæɹɪdʒɪz ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns. ʃɝtləs dɑkmən ɪn steɪnd ɡɹin lɛðɝ vɛsts hɝid baɪ, kæɹiɪŋ sæks ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz əɹ ɹoʊlɪŋ bæɹəlz əlɔŋ ðə ki, səm pʊʃɪŋ loʊ bæɹoʊz loʊɾəd wɪð kɹeɪts, ɔl ɡɪvɪŋ ðə koʊtʃɪz ə waɪd bɝθ. ðə kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə maɪt nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ paʊɝ, bʌɾ əɹ sɪdʒəl ɑn ə koʊtʃ dɔɹ ɛnʃʊɹd ðət kɑmənɝz wəd ɡɪv ɪt ɹum. neɪlzin ən bɛslən wɝ tʃæɾɪŋ əz ðeɪ lɛd ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz ɑntu ðə lændɪŋ, veɪnɪn bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ ən stɛɹɪŋ ɡluməli ət ðə tʃɑpi ɹɪvɝ; hi kleɪm tə hæv ə tɛndɝ bɛli wən ɪt keɪm tə boʊts. ðə waɪz wɪmən fɹəm boʊθ koʊtʃɪz hæd ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ɹin, wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. hi wɪspɝd hɔɹsli dʒʌs ðə seɪm.

Seizing Elayne's shoulders, he pulled her away from the carriages a little distance. Shirtless dockmen in stained green leather vests hurried by, carrying sacks on their shoulders or rolling barrels along the quay, some pushing low barrows loaded with crates, all giving the coaches a wide berth. The Queen of Altara might not have much power, but her sigil on a coach door ensured that commoners would give it room. Nalesean and Beslan were chatting as they led the Redarms onto the landing, Vanin bringing up the rear and staring gloomily at the choppy river; he claimed to have a tender belly when it came to boats. The Wise Women from both coaches had gathered around Reanne, watching, but they were not close enough to overhear. He whispered hoarsely just the same.

"ju lɪsən tə mi! ðət wʊmən woʊn teɪk noʊ fəɹ ən ænsɝ; aɪ seɪ noʊ, ən ʃi læfs ət mi. ʃiz stɑɹv mi, bʊlid mi, tʃeɪs mi daʊn laɪk ə stæɡ! ʃiz mɔɹ hænz ðən ɛni sɪks wɪmən aɪ ɛvɝ mɛt. ʃi θɹɛɾənd tə hæv ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən əndʒɹɛs mi ɪf aɪ dɪdn lɛɾ əɹ - " əbɹʌpli, wʌɾ i wɑz seɪɪŋ hɪt hɪm. ən u hi wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪt tə. hi mænədʒ tə kloʊz ɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i swɑloʊɾ ə flaɪ. hi bɪkeɪm vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə dɑɹk mɛɾəl ɹeɪvənz ɪnleɪɾ ɪn ðə hæft ə ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, soʊ hi wəd nɑɾ əv tə miɾ əɹ aɪz. "wʌɾ aɪ min tə seɪ ɪz, jə doʊn ʌndɝstænd," hi mʌɾɝd. "ju hæv ɪɾ ɔl bækwɝdz." hi ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns əɾ əɹ ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz hætbɹəm.

"You listen to me! That woman won't take no for an answer; I say no, and she laughs at me. She's starved me, bullied me, chased me down like a stag! She has more hands than any six women I ever met. She threatened to have the serving women undress me if I didn't let her - " Abruptly, what he was saying hit him. And who he was saying it to. He managed to close his mouth before he swallowed a fly. He became very interested in one of the dark metal ravens inlaid in the haft of the ashandarei, so he would not have to meet her eyes. "What I mean to say is, you don't understand," he muttered. "You have it all backwards." He risked a glance at her under the edge of his hatbrim.

ə feɪn blʌʃ kɹɛpt ɪndə hɝ tʃiks, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs bɪkeɪm sɑləm əz ə mɑɹbəl bʌst. "ɪt . . . əpɪɹz ðəɾ aɪ meɪ hæv mɪsəndɝstʊd," ʃi sɛd soʊbɝli. "ðæɾ ɪz . . . vɛɹi bæɾ ə taɪlɪn." hi θɔɾ əɹ lɪps twɪtʃt. "hæv jə kənsɪɾɝd pɹæktəsɪŋ dɪfɹən smaɪlz ɪn ə mɪɹɝ, mæt?"

A faint blush crept into her cheeks, but her face became solemn as a marble bust. "It . . . appears that I may have misunderstood," she said soberly. "That is . . . very bad of Tylin." He thought her lips twitched. "Have you considered practicing different smiles in a mirror, Mat?"

stɑɹɾəld, hi blɪŋkt. "wʌt?"

Startled, he blinked. "What?"

"aɪ hæv hɝd ɹɪlaɪəbli ðət ðəɾ ɪz wʌt jʌŋ wɪmən də hu ətʃɹæk ði aɪz ə kɪŋz." sʌmθɪŋ kɹæk ðə səbɹaɪəɾi ʌv əɹ vɔɪs, ən ðɪs taɪm əɹ lɪps dɛfənətli twɪtʃt. "ju maɪt tʃɹaɪ bæɾɪŋ jəɹ aɪlæʃɪz, tu." kætʃɪŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp wɪð əɹ tiθ, ʃi tɝn əweɪ, ʃoʊldɝz ʃeɪkɪŋ, dʌst-kloʊk stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪn əz ʃi hɝid təwɔɹd ðə lændɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi dɑɹɾɪd bɪɑn hɪɹɪŋ, hi hɝɾ əɹ kɔɹɾəl sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt "ə teɪst ə hɪz oʊn mɛɾəsən." ɹin ən ðə waɪz wɪmən skɝiɾ ɪn əɹ weɪk, ə flɑk ə hɛnz fɑloʊɪŋ ə tʃɪk ɪnstɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd. ðə fju bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd boʊtmən ʌp aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ boʊts stɑp kɔɪlɪŋ laɪnz əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ ən baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz ɹɪspɛkfəli əz ðə pɹəsɛʃən wɛn baɪ.

"I have heard reliably that that is what young women do who attract the eyes of kings." Something cracked the sobriety of her voice, and this time her lips definitely twitched. "You might try batting your eyelashes, too." Catching her lower lip with her teeth, she turned away, shoulders shaking, dust-cloak streaming behind as she hurried toward the landing. Before she darted beyond hearing, he heard her chortle something about "a taste of his own medicine." Reanne and the Wise Women scurried in her wake, a flock of hens following a chick instead of the other way around. The few bare-chested boatmen up out of their boats stopped coiling lines or whatever they were doing and bowed their heads respectfully as the procession went by.

snætʃɪŋ ɔf ɪz hæt, mæt kənsɪɾɝd θɹoʊɪŋ ɪt daʊn ən dʒʌmpɪŋ ɑn ɪt. wɪmən! hi ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ ðən tə ɪkspɛk sɪmpəθi. hi wəd laɪk tə θɹɑɾəl ðə blʌɾi dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. ən nɪneɪiv, tu, ɑn dʒɛnɝəl pɹɪnsəpəl. ɪksɛpt, ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɾ i kəd nɑt. hi hæd meɪd pɹɑməsəz. ən ðoʊz daɪs wɝ stɪl juzɪŋ ɪz skʌl fəɹ ə daɪs kʌp. ən wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən maɪt bi ɝaʊn sʌmwɛɹ. sɛɾəlɪŋ ðə hæt skwɛɹli bæk ɑn ɪz hɛd, hi mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə lændɪŋ, bɹʌʃt pæs ðə waɪz wɪmən ən kɑɾ ʌp tə ɪleɪn. ʃi wɑz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪt daʊn ɡɪɡəlz, bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi kʌɾ əɹ aɪz ɪz weɪ, ðə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks ɹɪnuɾ ɪtsɛlf ən soʊ dɪd ðə ɡɪɡəlz.

Snatching off his hat, Mat considered throwing it down and jumping on it. Women! He should have known better than to expect sympathy. He would like to throttle the bloody Daughter-Heir. And Nynaeve, too, on general principle. Except, of course, that he could not. He had made promises. And those dice were still using his skull for a dice cup. And one of the Forsaken might be around somewhere. Settling the hat squarely back on his head, he marched down the landing, brushed past the Wise Women and caught up to Elayne. She was still trying to fight down giggles, but every time she cut her eyes his way, the color in her cheeks renewed itself and so did the giggles.

hi stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. blʌɾi wɪmən! blʌɾi pɹɑməsəz. ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz hæt lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pʊl ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹd fɹəm ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, hi ɹɪlʌktənli ʃʌvd ɪɾ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd dæŋɡəl bɪniθ ɪz fɪst. "ju ən nɪneɪiv wɪl əv tə dɪsaɪd wɪtʃ ə jə wɛɹz ðɪs. bʌɾ aɪ wɑn ɪt bæk wən wi liv ɛbu dɑɹ. jə ʌndɝstænd? ðə moʊmənt wi liv - "

He stared straight ahead. Bloody women! Bloody promises. Removing his hat long enough to pull the leather cord from around his neck, he reluctantly shoved it in her direction. The silver foxhead dangled beneath his fist. "You and Nynaeve will have to decide which of you wears this. But I want it back when we leave Ebou Dar. You understand? The moment we leave - "

sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz wɔkɪŋ əloʊn. tɝnɪŋ, hi faʊn ɪleɪn stændɪŋ stɑk stɪl tu peɪsɪz bæk, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð ɹin ən ðə ɹɛs klʌstɝd bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Suddenly he realized he was walking alone. Turning, he found Elayne standing stock still two paces back, staring at him with Reanne and the rest clustered behind her.

"wʌts ðə mæɾɝ naʊ?" hi dɪmændəd. "oʊ. jɛs, aɪ noʊ ɔl əbaʊt mɑɡiɾin." ə skɪni fɛloʊ wɪð ɹɛd stoʊnz ɑn ɪz bɹæs-hup ɪɹɪŋz, bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ ə mʊɹɪŋ laɪn, dʒɝkt ɝaʊn soʊ fæst ət ðət neɪm ðəɾ i pɪtʃt oʊvɝ ðə saɪd wɪð ə laʊd jɛl ən ə laʊɾɝ splæʃ. mæt dɪd nɑt kɛɹ u hɝd.
