"What's the matter now?" he demanded. "Oh. Yes, I know all about Moghedien." A skinny fellow with red stones on his brass-hoop earrings, bending over a mooring line, jerked around so fast at that name that he pitched over the side with a loud yell and a louder splash. Mat did not care who heard. "Trying to keep her secret - and two of my men dead! - after you promised. Well, we'll talk about that later. I made a promise, too; I promised to keep the pair of you alive. If Moghedien shows up, she'll go after you two. Now, here." He pushed the medallion at her again.

ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli ɪn pʌzəlmənt, ðən tɝn tə mɝmɝ tə ɹin. oʊnli æftɝ ði oʊldɝ wɪmən wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ təwɔɹd wɛɹ nɪneɪiv stʊd bɛkənɪŋ əm ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə flaɪɾ ə boʊt stɛɹz dɪɾ ɪleɪn teɪk ðə fɑkshɛd, tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

She shook her head slowly in puzzlement, then turned to murmur to Reanne. Only after the older women were on their way toward where Nynaeve stood beckoning them at the head of a flight of boat stairs did Elayne take the foxhead, turning it over in her fingers.

"du juv ɛni noʊʃən wʌɾ aɪ wʊɾə dʌn tə hæv ðɪs fəɹ stʌɾi?" ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɛni noʊʃən əɾ ɔl?" ʃi wɑz tɔl fəɹ ə wʊmən, bʌt ʃi stɪl hæd tə lʊk ʌp ət hɪm. ʃi maɪt nɛvɝ əv sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ. "ju ɑɹ ə tʃɹʌbəlsəm mæn, mæt kɔθən. lini wəd seɪ aɪ wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪŋ maɪsɛlf, bʌt jə . . . !" ɪkspɛlɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ, ɪleɪn ɹitʃt ʌp tə pʊl ɪz hæɾ ɔf ən slɪp ðə kɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ʃi æktʃəli  tʌk ðə fɑkshɛɾ ɪndə hɪz ʃɝɾ ən pæɾəd ɪt bɪfɔɹ hændɪŋ ɪm ɪz hæt. "aɪ woʊnt wɛɹ ðət waɪl nɪneɪiv dʌzn əv wʌn, əɹ eɪvinhə, ən aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ fil ðə seɪm. jə wɛɹ ɪt. æftɝ ɔl, jə kən hɑɹdli kip jəɹ pɹɑməs ɪf mɑɡiɾin kɪlz ju. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz stɪl hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi bɪlivz ʃi kɪl nɪneɪiv, ən aɪ wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi keɪm fɔɹ. jə mʌs bi kɛɹfəl, ðoʊ. nɪneɪiv sɛz ðɛɹz ə stɔɹm kʌmɪŋ, ən ʃi dʌzn min ðɪs wɪnd. aɪ. . . ." ðət feɪn blʌʃ ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ tʃiks. "aɪ æm sɑɹi aɪ læft ət ju." ʃi klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt, lʊkɪŋ əweɪ. "səmtaɪmz aɪ fɝɡɛt maɪ duɾi tə maɪ sʌbʒɪkts. jə ɑɹ ə wɝði sʌbʒɪkt, meɪtʃɹim əl wɪl si ðət nɪneɪiv ʌndɝstænz ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv . . . ʌv jə ən taɪlɪn. pɝhæps wi kən hɛlp."

"Do you have any notion what I would have done to have this for study?" she said quietly. "Any notion at all?" She was tall for a woman, but she still had to look up at him. She might never have seen him before. "You are a troublesome man, Mat Cauthon. Lini would say I was repeating myself, but you . . . !" Expelling her breath, Elayne reached up to pull his hat off and slip the cord over his head. She actually tucked the foxhead into his shirt and patted it before handing him his hat. "I won't wear that while Nynaeve doesn't have one, or Aviendha, and I think they feel the same. You wear it. After all, you can hardly keep your promise if Moghedien kills you. Not that I think she's still here. I think she believes she killed Nynaeve, and I would not be surprised if that was all she came for. You must be careful, though. Nynaeve says there's a storm coming, and she doesn't mean this wind. I. . . ." That faint blush returned to her cheeks. "I am sorry I laughed at you." She cleared her throat, looking away. "Sometimes I forget my duty to my subjects. You are a worthy subject, Matrim Cauthon. I will see that Nynaeve understands the right of . . . of you and Tylin. Perhaps we can help."

"noʊ," hi spləɾɝd. "aɪ min, jɛs. aɪ min. . . . ðəɾ ɪz. . . . oʊ, kɪs ə fleɪmɪŋ ɡoʊɾ ɪf aɪ noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min. aɪ ɔlmoʊst wɪʃ jə dɪdnt noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ." nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn sɪɾɪŋ daʊn tə dɪskʌs ɪm wɪð taɪlɪn oʊvɝ ti. kəɾ i ɛvɝ lɪv ðət daʊn? kəɾ i ɛvɝ əɡɛn lʊk ɛni ʌv əm ɪn ði aɪ æftɝwɝd? bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt. . . . hi wɑz bɪtwin ðə wʊlf ən ðə bɛɹ wɪð noʊwɛɹ tə ɹʌn. "oʊ, ʃip swɑləp! ʃip swɑləp ən blʌɾi bʌɾɝd ʌnjənz!" hi nɪɹli wɪʃt ʃi wəd kɔl ɪm daʊn fəɹ ɪz læŋɡwədʒ ðə weɪ nɪneɪiv wʊd, dʒʌs tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə sʌbʒɪkt.

"No," he spluttered. "I mean, yes. I mean. . . . That is. . . . Oh, kiss a flaming goat if I know what I mean. I almost wish you didn't know the truth." Nynaeve and Elayne sitting down to discuss him with Tylin over tea. Could he ever live that down? Could he ever again look any of them in the eye afterward? But if they did not. . . . He was between the wolf and the bear with nowhere to run. "Oh, sheep swallop! Sheep swallop and bloody buttered onions!" He nearly wished she would call him down for his language the way Nynaeve would, just to change the subject.

hɝ lɪps muv saɪlənli, ən fəɹ ən ɪnstən i hæd ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət ʃi wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd dʒʌst sɛd. ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. hi wɑz siɪŋ θɪŋz; ðət wɑz ɔl. əlaʊd, ʃi sɛd, "aɪ ʌndɝstænd." saʊndɪŋ dʒʌst əz ɪf ʃi dɪd. "kʌm əlɔŋ, naʊ, mæt. wi kænt weɪs taɪm stændɪŋ ɪn wʌn spɑt."

Her lips moved silently, and for an instant he had the strange impression that she was repeating what he had just said. Of course not. He was seeing things; that was all. Aloud, she said, "I understand." Sounding just as if she did. "Come along, now, Mat. We can't waste time standing in one spot."

ɡeɪpɪŋ, hi wɑtʃt əɹ lɪf skɝts ən kloʊk tə meɪk əɹ weɪ əlɔŋ ðə lændɪŋ. ʃi ʌndɝstʊd? ʃi ʌndɝstʊd, ən nɑt wʌn æsəd lɪɾəl kɑmɛnt, nɑt wʌn kʌɾɪŋ ɹɪmɑɹk? ən i wɑz əɹ səbdʒɛkt. hɝ wɝði sʌbʒɪkt. fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə mədæljən, hi fɑloʊd. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðə faɪt wəd bi tə ɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɪt bæk. ɪf i lɪvd əz lɔŋ əz tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi stɪl wəd nɛvɝ ʌndɝstænd wɪmən, ən noʊbəlwɪmən wɝ pjʊɹli ðə wɝst.

Gaping, he watched her lift skirts and cloak to make her way along the landing. She understood? She understood, and not one acid little comment, not one cutting remark? And he was her subject. Her worthy subject. Fingering the medallion, he followed. He had been sure the fight would be to ever get it back. If he lived as long as two Aes Sedai, he still would never understand women, and noblewomen were purely the worst.

wən i ɹitʃt ðə stɛps ɪleɪn hæd ɡɔn daʊn, ðə boʊts tu bɹæs-ɪɹɪn ɔɹsmɪn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi juzɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ swips tə pʊʃ ðə vɛsəl əweɪ. ɪleɪn wɑz hɝɾɪŋ ɹin ən ðə læst ə ðə waɪz wɪmən ɪndə ðə kæbən, ən læn stʊɾ ʌp ɪn ðə baʊz wɪð nɪneɪiv. ə ʃaʊt fɹəm bɛslən kɔld ɪm ɑn tə ðə nɛks boʊt, wɪtʃ hɛld ɔl ə ðə mɛn ɪksɛp ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

When he reached the steps Elayne had gone down, the boat's two brass-earringed oarsmen were already using their long sweeps to push the vessel away. Elayne was herding Reanne and the last of the Wise Women into the cabin, and Lan stood up in the bows with Nynaeve. A shout from Beslan called him on to the next boat, which held all of the men except the Warder.

"nɪneɪiv sɛd ðəɹ wɑzn ɹum fəɹ ɛni ʌv ʌs," neɪlzin sɛɾ əz ðə boʊt ɹɑkt ɪts weɪ aʊɾ ɪndə ði ɪldɑɹ. "ʃi sɛd wid kɹaʊd ðɛm." bɛslən læft, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ oʊn boʊt. veɪnɪn sæt bɪsaɪd ðə kæbən dɔɹ wɪð ɪz aɪz kloʊzd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn i wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. hɑɹnən ən tæd kændəl, ən ændɔɝən dɪspaɪt biɪŋ əz dɑɹk əz iðɝ ə ðə boʊtmən, hæd klaɪmd ətɑp ðə kæbən; ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz hʌŋkɝɾ əbaʊt ðə dɛk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə ɹoʊɝz. noʊbɑdi wɛn ɪndə ðə kæbən, ɔl əpɛɹənli weɪɾɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ mæt ən neɪlzin ən bɛslən wɑntəɾ ɪt.

"Nynaeve said there wasn't room for any of us," Nalesean said as the boat rocked its way out into the Eldar. "She said we'd crowd them." Beslan laughed, looking around their own boat. Vanin sat beside the cabin door with his eyes closed, trying to pretend he was somewhere else. Harnan and Tad Kandel, an Andoran despite being as dark as either of the boatmen, had climbed atop the cabin; the rest of the Redarms hunkered about the deck, trying to keep out of the way of the rowers. Nobody went into the cabin, all apparently waiting to see whether Mat and Nalesean and Beslan wanted it.

mæt pʊt hɪmsɛlf bɪsaɪd ðə tɔl boʊpoʊst, piɹɪŋ æftɝ ði ʌðɝ boʊt, kɹɔlɪŋ ɑn ɪts swips dʒʌst əhɛd. ðə wɪnd wɪp ðə dɑɹk tʃɑpi wɔɾɝz, ən ɪz skɑɹf əz wɛl, ən i hæd tə hoʊld ɑn tə hɪz hæt. wʌt wɑz nɪneɪiv ʌp tə? ði ʌðɝ naɪn wɪmən ɑn ðə sɛkən boʊt wɝ ɔl ɪn ðə kæbən, livɪŋ ðə dɛk tə hɝ ən læn. ðeɪ stʊɾ ʌp ɪn ðə baʊz, læn wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd, nɪneɪiv dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ əz ðoʊ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ. ɪksɛp ðət nɪneɪiv sɛldəm ɪkspleɪn ɛniθɪŋ. bɛɾɝ seɪ nɛvɝ ðən sɛldəm.

Mat put himself beside the tall bowpost, peering after the other boat, crawling on its sweeps just ahead. The wind whipped the dark choppy waters, and his scarf as well, and he had to hold on to his hat. What was Nynaeve up to? The other nine women on the second boat were all in the cabin, leaving the deck to her and Lan. They stood up in the bows, Lan with his arms folded, Nynaeve gesturing as though explaining. Except that Nynaeve seldom explained anything. Better say never than seldom.

wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ɪt dɪd nɑt læs lɔŋ. ðəɹ wɝ waɪtkæps aʊɾ ɪn ðə beɪ, wɛɹ si foʊk ɹeɪkɝz ən skɪmɝz ən sɔɹɝz hivd ət ðɛɹ æŋkɝz. ðə ɹɪvɝ wɑz nɑt soʊ bæd, bʌt ðə boʊt stɪl wɑloʊd mɔɹ ðən mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm ɛni pɹiviəs tʃɹɪp. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, nɪneɪiv wɑz dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, luzɪŋ əɹ bɹɛkfəst waɪl læn hɛl hɝ. ðət ɹimaɪndəd mæt ə hɪz oʊn bɛli; tʌkɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm soʊ ɪt kəd nɑt bloʊ əweɪ, hi pʊld aʊt ðə wɛdʒ ə tʃiz.

whatever she was doing, it did not last long. There were whitecaps out in the bay, where Sea Folk rakers and skimmers and soarers heaved at their anchors. The river was not so bad, but the boat still wallowed more than Mat remembered from any previous trip. Before long, Nynaeve was draped over the railing, losing her breakfast while Lan held her. That reminded Mat of his own belly; tucking his hat under his arm so it could not blow away, he pulled out the wedge of cheese.

"bɛslən, ɪz ðɪs stɔɹm laɪkli tə bɹeɪk bɪfɔɹ wi kən kʌm bæk fɹəm ðə ɹæhəd?" hi tʊk ə baɪɾ ə ðə ʃɑɹp-teɪstɪŋ tʃiz; ðeɪ hæd fɪfti dɪfɹən sɔɹts ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ɔl ɡʊd. nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd. haʊ mʌtʃ hæd ðə wʊmən iɾən ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ? "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ wɪl ʃɛltɝ ɪf wɝ kɑt." hi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl ɪn i hæd sin ɪn ðə ɹæhəd ðəɾ i wəd teɪk ðə wɪmən ɪntu.

"Beslan, is this storm likely to break before we can come back from the Rahad?" He took a bite of the sharp-tasting cheese; they had fifty different sorts in Ebou Dar, all good. Nynaeve was still hanging over the side. How much had the woman eaten this morning? "I don't know where we'll shelter if we're caught." He could not think of a single inn he had seen in the Rahad that he would take the women into.

"noʊ stɔɹm," bɛslən sɛd, siɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ. "ðiz ɑɹ ðə wɪntɝ tʃɹeɪd wɪnz. ðə tʃɹeɪdz kʌm twaɪs ə jɪɹ, ɪn leɪt wɪntɝ ən leɪt sʌmɝ, bʌt ðeɪv tə bloʊ mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ɪt kʌmz tə stɔɹm." hi dɝɛktəɾ ə saʊɝ lʊk aʊt təwɔɹd ðə beɪ. "ɛvɹi jɪɹ ðoʊz wɪnz bɹɪŋ - bɹɔt - ʃɪps fɹəm tæɹɑbən, ən ɑɹæd dumən. aɪ wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɛvɝ wɪl əɡɛn."

"No storm," Beslan said, seating himself on the railing. "These are the winter trade winds. The trades come twice a year, in late winter and late summer, but they have to blow much harder before it comes to storm." He directed a sour look out toward the bay. "Every year those winds bring - brought - ships from Tarabon, and Arad Doman. I wonder whether they ever will again."

"ðə wil wivz," mæt bɪɡæn, ən tʃoʊkt ɑn ə kɹʌm ə tʃiz. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, hi wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə saʊn laɪk səm ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹ ɹɛstɪŋ ɪz eɪkɪŋ dʒɔɪns ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ ðə wɪmən ɪndə ə ɹʌf ɪn. ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ, hæf ə jɪɹ, hi wʊɾə teɪkən ðɛm, ən læft wən ðɛɹ aɪz pɑpt, læft əɾ ɛvɹi pɹɪm snɪf. "wɛl, meɪbi wɪl faɪn jə səm fʌn ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ɛniweɪ. ət ðə list, sʌmbɑɾi wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə kʌɾ ə pɝs, əɹ pʊl ɪleɪnz nɛkləs ɔf." meɪbi ðət wɑz wʌɾ i niɾəd tə klin ðə teɪst ə səbɹaɪəɾi fɹəm ɪz tʌŋ. səbɹaɪəɾi. laɪt, wʌɾ ə wɝd tə əplaɪ tə mæt kɔθən! taɪlɪn mʌs bi skɛɹɪŋ ɪm mɔɹ ðən i θɔt, ɪf i wɑz ʃɹɪvəlɪŋ ʌp ðɪs weɪ. meɪbi hi niɾəd səm ə bɛslənz sɔɹɾ ə fʌn. ðət wɑz kɹeɪzi - hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ðə faɪɾ i wəd nɑt ɹæðɝ wɔk ɝaʊnd - bʌt meɪbi. . . .

"The Wheel weaves," Mat began, and choked on a crumb of cheese. Blood and ashes, he was starting to sound like some gray-hair resting his aching joints in front of the fireplace. Worrying about taking the women into a rough inn. A year ago, half a year, he would have taken them, and laughed when their eyes popped, laughed at every prim sniff. "Well, maybe we'll find you some fun in the Rahad, anyway. At the least, somebody will try to cut a purse, or pull Elayne's necklace off." Maybe that was what he needed to clean the taste of sobriety from his tongue. Sobriety. Light, what a word to apply to Mat Cauthon! Tylin must be scaring him more than he thought, if he was shriveling up this way. Maybe he needed some of Beslan's sort of fun. That was crazy - he had never seen the fight he would not rather walk around - but maybe. . . .

bɛslən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪf ɛniwʌn kən faɪn ɪt, jə kæn, bʌt. . . . wɪl bi wɪð sɛvən waɪz wɪmən, mæt. sɛvən. wɪð dʒʌst wʌn ət jəɹ saɪd, jə kəd slæp ə mæn, ivən ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ən i wəd swɑloʊ hɪz tʌŋ ən wɔk əweɪ. ən ðə wɪmən. wʌts ðə fʌn ə kɪsɪŋ ə wʊmən wɪθaʊt ðə ɹɪsk ʃɪl dɪsaɪd tə stɪk ə naɪf ɪn ju?"

Beslan shook his head. "If anyone can find it, you can, but. . . . We'll be with seven Wise Women, Mat. Seven. With just one at your side, you could slap a man, even in the Rahad, and he would swallow his tongue and walk away. And the women. What's the fun of kissing a woman without the risk she'll decide to stick a knife in you?"

"bɝn maɪ soʊl," neɪlzin mʌɾɝd ɪndə hɪz bɪɹd. "ɪt saʊnz əz ðoʊ aɪv dʒɹæɡd maɪsɛlf fɹəm bɛd fəɹ ə dʌl mɔɹnɪŋ."

"Burn my soul," Nalesean muttered into his beard. "It sounds as though I've dragged myself from bed for a dull morning."

bɛslən nɑɾəd ɪn kəməzɝeɪʃən. "ɪf wɝ lʌki, ðoʊ. . . . ðə sɪvəl ɡɑɹd dʌz sɛn pətʃɹoʊlz tə ðə ɹæhəɾ əkeɪʒənəli, ən ɪf ðəɹ æftɝ smʌɡəlɝz, ðeɪ ɔlweɪz dʒɹɛs laɪk ɛniwʌn ɛls. ðeɪ sim tə θɪŋk noʊbɑdi wɪl noʊɾəs ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ mɛn təɡɛðɝ kæɹiɪŋ sɔɹdz, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɛɹ, ən ðəɹ ɔlweɪz sɝpɹaɪzd wən ðə smʌɡəlɝz æmbʊʃ ðɛm, wɪtʃ ɪz wʌt nɪɹli ɔlweɪz hæpənz. ɪf mæts tɑvɝən lʌk wɝks fəɹ ʌs, wi maɪt bi teɪkən fəɹ ðə sɪvəl ɡɑɹd, ən səm smʌɡəlɝz maɪɾ ətæk əs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ si ðə ɹɛd bɛls." neɪlzin bɹaɪɾənd ən bɪɡæn ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ.

Beslan nodded in commiseration. "If we're lucky, though. . . . The Civil Guard does send patrols to the Rahad occasionally, and if they're after smugglers, they always dress like anyone else. They seem to think nobody will notice a dozen or so men together carrying swords, whatever they wear, and they're always surprised when the smugglers ambush them, which is what nearly always happens. If Mat's ta'veren luck works for us, we might be taken for the Civil Guard, and some smugglers might attack us before they see the red belts." Nalesean brightened and began rubbing his hands together.

mæt ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðɛm. meɪbi bɛslənz sɔɹɾ ə fʌn wɑz nɑt wʌɾ i niɾəd. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, hi hæd mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ʌv wɪmən wɪð naɪvz. nɪneɪiv stɪl hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə boʊɾ əhɛd; ðət wəd titʃ əɹ tə ɡɔɹdʒ hɝsɛlf. wʊlfɪŋ daʊn ðə læst ə ðə tʃiz, hi bɪɡæn ɑn ðə bɹɛɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd. ən izi tʃɹɪp wɪð noʊ tʃɹʌbəl dɪd nɑt saʊn bæɾ əɾ ɔl. ə kwɪk tʃɹɪp, wɪð ə kwɪk dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ.

Mat glared at them. Maybe Beslan's sort of fun was not what he needed. For one thing, he had more than enough of women with knives. Nynaeve still hung over the side of the boat ahead; that would teach her to gorge herself. Wolfing down the last of the cheese, he began on the bread and tried to ignore the dice in his head. An easy trip with no trouble did not sound bad at all. A quick trip, with a quick departure from Ebou Dar.

ðə ɹæhəd wɑz ɛvɹiθɪŋ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɛslən fɪɹd. ðə wɪn meɪd klaɪmɪŋ ðə kɹækt ɡɹeɪ stoʊn stɛps ət ðə boʊt lændɪŋ ɪndə ə pɛɹələs fit, ən æftɝ ðæt, ɪt ɡɹu wɝs. kənælz ɹæn ɛvɹiwɛɹ, dʒʌst əz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt hɪɹ ðə bɹɪdʒəz wɝ pleɪn, ðə ɡɹaɪmi stoʊn pɛɹəpəts bɹoʊkən ən kɹʌmbəlɪŋ; hæf ðə kənælz wɝ soʊ sɪltɪd ðət bɔɪz weɪɾɪd weɪst-dip ɪn ðɛm, ən hɑɹdli ə bɑɹdʒ wɑz tə bi sin. tɔl bɪldɪŋz stʊd kɹaʊɾəd təɡɛðɝ, blɑki stʃɹʌktʃɝz wɪð skəbɹəs wʌns-waɪt plæstɝ ɡɔn ɪn hjudʒ pætʃəz tə ɹɪvil ɹɑɾɪŋ ɹɛd bɹɪk, bɔɹɾɝɪŋ nɛɹoʊ stʃɹits wɪð bɹoʊkən peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ɪn ðoʊz stʃɹits wɛɹ ivən ðə fɹæɡməns hæd nɑt bɪn ɹɪpt ʌp. mɔɹnɪŋ dɪd nɑt ɹɪli ɹitʃ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz ə ðə bɪldɪŋz. dɪnʒi lɔnʒɹi hʌŋ dʒɹaɪɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi θɝd wɪndoʊ, ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ə stʃɹʌktʃɝ stʊɾ ɛmpti. səm dɪd, ən ðoʊz wɪndoʊz ɡeɪp laɪkt aɪ sɑkəts ɪn ə skʌl. ə saʊɝ-swit smɛl ə dəkeɪ pɝmieɪɾɪd ði ɛɹ, læs mʌnθs tʃeɪmbɝ pɑts ən eɪntʃən ɹɛfjus moʊldɝɪŋ wɛɹɛvɝ ɪt hæd bɪn flʌŋ, ən fəɹ ɛvɹi flaɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɪldɑɹ, ə hʌnʒɹəd bʌz hɪɹ ɪn klaʊdz ʌv ɡɹin ən blu. hi spɑɾəd ðə pilɪŋ blu dɔɹ ə ðə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn ə hɛvən ən ʃʌɾɝəd ət ðə θɔɾ ə teɪkɪŋ ðə wɪmən ɪn ðəɹ ɪf ðə stɔɹm bɹoʊk, dɪspaɪt wʌt bɛslən sɛd. ðən i ʃʌɾɝəd əɡɛn fəɹ hævɪŋ ʃʌɾɝəd. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə hɪm, ən i dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt.

The Rahad was everything he remembered, and everything Beslan feared. The wind made climbing the cracked gray stone steps at the boat landing into a perilous feat, and after that, it grew worse. Canals ran everywhere, just as across the river, but here the bridges were plain, the grimy stone parapets broken and crumbling; half the canals were so silted that boys waded waist-deep in them, and hardly a barge was to be seen. Tall buildings stood crowded together, blocky structures with scabrous once-white plaster gone in huge patches to reveal rotting red brick, bordering narrow streets with broken paving stones. In those streets where even the fragments had not been ripped up. Morning did not really reach into the shadows of the buildings. Dingy laundry hung drying from every third window, except where a structure stood empty. Some did, and those windows gaped liked eye sockets in a skull. A sour-sweet smell of decay permeated the air, last month's chamber pots and ancient refuse moldering wherever it had been flung, and for every fly on the other side of the Eldar, a hundred buzzed here in clouds of green and blue. He spotted the peeling blue door of The Golden Crown of Heaven and shuddered at the thought of taking the women in there if the storm broke, despite what Beslan said. Then he shuddered again for having shuddered. Something was happening to him, and he did not like it.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn teɪkɪŋ ðə lɛd, wɪð ɹin bɪtwin əm ən ðə waɪz wɪmən kloʊs bɪhaɪnd. læn steɪɾ ət nɪneɪivz ʃoʊldɝ laɪk ə wʊlfhnd, hæn ɑn sɔɹd hɪlt, aɪz kɑnstənli sɝtʃɪŋ, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ mɛnəs. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz pɹɑbli ɪnʌf pɹətɛkʃən fəɹ tu dʌzən pɹɪɾi sɪkstin-jɪɹ-oʊld ɡɝlz kæɹiɪŋ sæks ʌv ɡoʊld, ivən hɪɹ, bʌt mæt ɪnsɪstəd ðət veɪnɪn ən ðə ɹɛs kip ðɛɹ aɪz oʊpən. ɪn fækt, ðə fɔɹmɝ hɔɹsɛθif ən poʊtʃɝ kɛp soʊ kloʊs tə ɪleɪn ðəɾ ɛniwʌn cʊɾə bɪn fɝɡɪvən fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ i wɑz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, ɪf ə ɹæðɝ fæɾ ən ɹʌmpəld wʌn. bɛslən ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz ɪkspɹɛsɪvli ət mæts ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, ən neɪlzin ɪɹɪɾəbli stʃɹoʊkt ɪz bɪɹɾ ən mʌɾɝd ðəɾ i kəd stɪl bi ɪn bɛd.

Nynaeve and Elayne insisted on taking the lead, with Reanne between them and the Wise Women close behind. Lan stayed at Nynaeve's shoulder like a wolfhound, hand on sword hilt, eyes constantly searching, radiating menace. In truth, he was probably enough protection for two dozen pretty sixteen-year-old girls carrying sacks of gold, even here, but Mat insisted that Vanin and the rest keep their eyes open. In fact, the former horsethief and poacher kept so close to Elayne that anyone could have been forgiven for thinking he was her Warder, if a rather fat and rumpled one. Beslan rolled his eyes expressively at Mat's instructions, and Nalesean irritably stroked his beard and muttered that he could still be in bed.

mɛn stʃɹʌɾɪd ɛɹəɡənli əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹits wɪð ɔfən ɹæɡəd vɛsts ən noʊ ʃɝts, wɛɹɪŋ ɡɹeɪt bɹæs hups ɪn ðɛɹ ɪɹz ən bɹæs fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz sɛt wɪð kʌlɝd ɡlæs, wʌn naɪf əɹ səmtaɪmz tu stʌk bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ bɛls. hænz hʌvɝɪŋ nɪɹ ðoʊz naɪvz, ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əz ðoʊ dɛɹɪŋ sʌmwʌn tə ɡɪv ðə ɹɔŋ twɪs tə ə lʊk. ʌðɝz skʌlk fɹəm kɔɹnɝ tə kɔɹnɝ, dɔɹweɪ tə dɔɹweɪ wɪð hʊɾɪd aɪz, ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ðə slæt-ɹɪb dɑɡz ðət səmtaɪmz snɑɹəl fɹəm ə dɑɹk æliweɪ bɛɹli waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə mæn tə skwiz ɪntu. ðoʊz mɛn hʌntʃt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ naɪvz, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɪtʃ wəd ɹʌn ən wɪtʃ stæb. baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, ðə wɪmən meɪɾ ɛni ʌv ðə mɛn əpɪɹ hʌmbəl, pɝeɪɾɪŋ ɪn wɔɹn dʒɹɛsəz ən twaɪs əz mʌtʃ bɹæs dʒuəlɹi əz ðə mɛn. ðeɪ kæɹid naɪvz tu, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðɛɹ boʊl dɑɹk aɪz sɛn tɛn sɔɹts ə tʃælənʒ ɪn ɛvɹi ɡlæns. ɪn ʃɔɹt, ðə ɹæhəd wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə pleɪs wɛɹ ɛniwʌn wɛɹɪŋ sɪlk kəd hɑɹdli hoʊp tə wɔk tɛn stɛps wɪθaʊt biɪŋ kɹækt oʊvɝ ðə hɛd. æftɝ wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæd bɛs hoʊp tə weɪk stʃɹɪp tə ðə skɪn ən tɔst ɑntu ə paɪl ə ɹʌbɪʃ ɪn ən æli, sɪns ði ɔltɝnəɾɪv wɑz nɑt tə weɪk əɾ ɔl. bʌt. . . .

Men strutted arrogantly along the streets with often ragged vests and no shirts, wearing great brass hoops in their ears and brass finger rings set with colored glass, one knife or sometimes two stuck behind their belts. Hands hovering near those knives, they stared as though daring someone to give the wrong twist to a look. Others skulked from corner to corner, doorway to doorway with hooded eyes, imitating the slat-ribbed dogs that sometimes snarled from a dark alleyway barely wide enough for a man to squeeze into. Those men hunched over their knives, and there was no way to tell which would run and which stab. By and large, the women made any of the men appear humble, parading in worn dresses and twice as much brass jewelry as the men. They carried knives too, of course, and their bold dark eyes sent ten sorts of challenge in every glance. In short, the Rahad was the sort of place where anyone wearing silk could hardly hope to walk ten steps without being cracked over the head. After which they had best hope to wake stripped to the skin and tossed onto a pile of rubbish in an alley, since the alternative was not to wake at all. But. . . .

tʃɪlʒɹən dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm ɛvɹi sɛkən dɔɹ wɪð tʃɪpt pɑɾɝi kʌps ʌv wɔɾɝ, sɛn baɪ ðɛɹ mʌðɝz ɪn keɪs ðə waɪz wɪmən wɪʃt ə dʒɹɪŋk. mɛn wɪð skɑɹd feɪsəz ən mɝɾɝ ɛtʃt ɪndə ðɛɹ aɪz stɛɹɾ oʊpənməðd ət sɛvən waɪz wɪmən təɡɛðɝ, ðən bɑb dʒɝki baʊz ən ɪnkwaɪɝd pəlaɪtli ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi ʌv əsɪstəns, wɑz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət ɹikwaɪɝd kæɹiɪŋ? wɪmən, səmtaɪmz wɪð əz mɛni skɑɹz ən ɔlweɪz aɪz tə meɪk taɪlɪn flɪntʃ, kɝtsiɾ ɔkwɝdli ən bɹɛθləsli æskt wɛðɝ ðeɪ maɪt səplaɪ dɝɛkʃənz, hæɾ ɛniwʌn meɪɾ ə bɑðɝ ə ðɛmsɛlvz tə bɹɪŋ soʊ mɛni waɪz wɪmən? ɪf soʊ, ðə stʃɹɔŋ ɪmpləkeɪʃən wɑz, tæmɑɹlə ən ðə ɹɛs hæd noʊ niɾ ə tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪf ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst səplaɪ ðə neɪm.

Children darted from every second door with chipped pottery cups of water, sent by their mothers in case the Wise Women wished a drink. Men with scarred faces and murder etched into their eyes stared openmouthed at seven Wise Women together, then bobbed jerky bows and inquired politely if they could be of assistance, was there anything that required carrying? Women, sometimes with as many scars and always eyes to make Tylin flinch, curtsied awkwardly and breathlessly asked whether they might supply directions, had anyone made a bother of themselves to bring so many Wise Women? If so, the strong implication was, Tamarla and the rest had no need of troubling themselves if they would just supply the name.

oʊ, ðeɪ ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə soʊlʒɝz əz hɑtli əz ɛvɝ, ðoʊ ivən ðə hɑɹɾəst flɪntʃt əweɪ fɹəm læn æftɝ ə sɪŋɡəl lʊk. ænd, ɑdli ɪnʌf, fɹəm veɪnɪn. ə fju ʌv ðə mɛn ɡɹaʊld ət bɛslən ən neɪlzin wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ ɡeɪz tu lɔŋ əɾ ə wʊmənz dip nɛklaɪn. səm ɡɹaʊld ət mæt, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ; ənlaɪk ðoʊz tu, hi wɑz nɛvɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə hɪz aɪbɔlz fɔlɪŋ daʊn ðə fɹʌn ʌv ə wʊmənz dʒɹɛs. hi nu haʊ tə lʊk dɪskɹitli. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɝ ɪɡnɔɹd, fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ faɪnɝi, ən soʊ wɑz ɹin ɪn əɹ ɹɛd wʊl dʒɹɛs; ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə ɹɛd bɛlt. bʌt ðeɪ dɪɾ əv ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðoʊz bɛls. mæt ɹilaɪz ðət bɛslən hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. hi kəɾ ɛmpti hɪz pɝs ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən noʊ wʌn wəd pɪk ʌp ə kɑpɝ, ət list soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə waɪz wɪmən ɹɪmeɪnd. hi kəd pɪntʃ ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn saɪt, ən ivən ɪf ʃi hæɾ æpəplɛksi, ʃi wəd wɔk əweɪ.

Oh, they glared at the soldiers as hotly as ever, though even the hardest flinched away from Lan after a single look. And, oddly enough, from Vanin. A few of the men growled at Beslan and Nalesean whenever they gazed too long at a woman's deep neckline. Some growled at Mat, though he could not understand why; unlike those two, he was never in danger of his eyeballs falling down the front of a woman's dress. He knew how to look discreetly. Nynaeve and Elayne were ignored, for all their finery, and so was Reanne in her red wool dress; they did not have the red belt. But they did have the protection of those belts. Mat realized that Beslan had been right. He could empty his purse on the ground, and no one would pick up a copper, at least so long as the Wise Women remained. He could pinch the bottom of every woman in sight, and even if she had apoplexy, she would walk away.

"wʌɾ ə plɛzənt wɔk," neɪlzin sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "wɪð sətʃ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ saɪts ən smɛlz. dɪɾ aɪ tɛl jə aɪ dɪdnt ɡɛt mʌtʃ slip læs naɪt, mæt?"

"What a pleasant walk," Nalesean said dryly, "with such interesting sights and smells. Did I tell you I didn't get much sleep last night, Mat?"

"du jə wɑnə daɪ ɪn bɛd?" mæt ɡɹʌmbəld. ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl ɔl əv steɪɾ ɪn bɛd; ðeɪ wɝ blʌɾi jusləs hɪɹ, ðət wɑz fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ðə tɛɹən snɔɹɾɪd ɪndɪɡnənli. bɛslən læft, bʌɾ i pɹɑbli θɔt mæt mɛn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls.

"Do you want to die in bed?" Mat grumbled. They might as well all have stayed in bed; they were bloody useless here, that was for sure. The Tairen snorted indignantly. Beslan laughed, but he probably thought Mat meant something else.

əkɹɔs ðə ɹæhəd ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt, əntɪl ɹin faɪnəli stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə bɪldɪŋ ɪɡzækli laɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ, ɔl fleɪkɪŋ plæstɝ ən kɹʌmbəlɪŋ bɹɪk, ðə seɪm mæt hæd fɑloʊɾ ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə jɛstɝdeɪ. noʊ lɔnʒɹi hʌŋ fɹəm ðiz wɪndoʊz; oʊnli ɹæts lɪvd ɪn ðɛɹ. "ɪn hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd.

Across the Rahad they marched, until Reanne finally stopped in front of a building exactly like every other, all flaking plaster and crumbling brick, the same Mat had followed another woman to yesterday. No laundry hung from these windows; only rats lived in there. "In here," she said.

ɪleɪnz aɪz klaɪm sloʊli tə ðə flæt ɹuf. "sɪks," ʃi mɝmɝɾ ɪn toʊnz ʌv ɡɹeɪt sæɾəsfækʃən.

Elayne's eyes climbed slowly to the flat roof. "Six," she murmured in tones of great satisfaction.

"sɪks," nɪneɪiv saɪd, ən ɪleɪn pæɾəd əɹ ɑɹm əz ðoʊ sɪmpəθaɪzɪŋ wɪð hɝ.

"Six," Nynaeve sighed, and Elayne patted her arm as though sympathizing with her.

"aɪ wɑzn ɹɪli ʃʊɹ," ʃi sɛd. soʊ nɪneɪiv smaɪld ən pæɾəd hɝ. mæt dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ə wɝɾ ʌv ɪt. soʊ ðə bɪldɪŋ hæd sɪks flɔɹz. wɪmən bɪheɪvd vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒli səmtaɪmz. wɛl, moʊst ə ðə taɪm.

"I wasn't really sure," she said. So Nynaeve smiled and patted her. Mat did not understand a word of it. So the building had six floors. Women behaved very strangely sometimes. Well, most of the time.

ɪnsaɪd, ə lɔŋ hɔlweɪ kɑɹpəɾɪd wɪð dʌst ɹæn dɪmli tə ðə bæk, ðə fɑɹ ɛn lɔst ɪn ʃædoʊz. fju ʌv ðə dɔɹweɪz hɛl dɔɹz, ən ðoʊz wɝ ɹʌf plæŋks. wʌn oʊpənɪŋ, ɔlmoʊst ə θɝɾ ə ðə weɪ daʊn ðə hɔl, lɛd tə ə nɛɹoʊ flaɪɾ ə stip stoʊn-feɪst stɛps klaɪmɪŋ ʌpwɝd. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ hi hæd ɡɔn ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, fɑloʊɪŋ fʊtpɹɪns ɪn ðə dʌst, bʌɾ i θɔt səm ə ðoʊz ʌðɝ oʊpənɪŋz mʌs bi kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz. hi hæd nɑt teɪkən taɪm tə lʊk ɝaʊn ðɛn, bʌt ðə bɪldɪŋ wɑz tu dip ən tu waɪd fəɹ ðɪs flɔɹ tə bi sɝv baɪ oʊnli ðə wʌn ðeɪ sɔ. ɪt wɑz tu bɪɡ fəɹ oʊnli wʌn weɪ ɪn.

Inside, a long hallway carpeted with dust ran dimly to the back, the far end lost in shadows. Few of the doorways held doors, and those were rough planks. One opening, almost a third of the way down the hall, led to a narrow flight of steep stone-faced steps climbing upward. That was the way he had gone the day before, following footprints in the dust, but he thought some of those other openings must be crossing corridors. He had not taken time to look around then, but the building was too deep and too wide for this floor to be served by only the one they saw. It was too big for only one way in.

"ɹɪli, mæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd wən i toʊld ɔf hɑɹnən ən hæf ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz tə faɪn ɛni bæk weɪ ɪn ən ɡɑɹɾ ɪt. læn kɛp soʊ kloʊs tə hɝ saɪd, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɡlud ðɛɹ. "doʊn jə si baɪ naʊ ðɛɹz noʊ nid?"

"Really, Mat," Nynaeve said when he told off Harnan and half the Redarms to find any back way in and guard it. Lan kept so close to her side, he might have been glued there. "Don't you see by now there's no need?"

hɝ toʊn wɑz soʊ maɪl ðəɾ ɪleɪn mʌst əv pæst ɑn ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt taɪlɪn, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðəɾ oʊnli saʊɝɾ ɪz mud fɝðɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə noʊ. blʌɾi jusləs! bʌt ðoʊz daɪs wɝ stɪl ɹætlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn ɪz hɛd. "meɪbi mɑɡiɾin laɪks bæk dɔɹz," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. sʌmθɪŋ tʃɪɾɝd ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɛn ə ðə hɔl, ən wʌn ə ðə mɛn wɪð hɑɹnən kɝs laʊdli əbaʊt ɹæts.

Her tone was so mild that Elayne must have passed on the truth about Tylin, but if anything, that only soured his mood further. He did not want anyone to know. Bloody useless! But those dice were still rattling around in his head. "Maybe Moghedien likes back doors," he said dryly. Something chittered in the dark end of the hall, and one of the men with Harnan cursed loudly about rats.

"ju toʊl hɪm," nɪneɪiv bɹið fjʊɹiəsli ət læn, wʌn hæn snæpɪŋ ʃʌɾ ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd.

"You told him," Nynaeve breathed furiously at Lan, one hand snapping shut on her braid.

ɪleɪn meɪɾ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saʊnd. "ðɪs ɪz noʊ taɪm tə stɑp fəɹ ən ɑɹɡjəmənt, nɪneɪiv. ðə boʊl ɪz əpstɛɹz! ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz!" ə smɔl bɔl ə laɪt sʌɾənli əpɪɹd, floʊɾɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt nɪneɪiv wɑz kʌmɪŋ, ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts ən dɑɹɾɪd ʌp ðə stɛɹz. veɪnɪn dæʃt æftɝ əɹ wɪð ə stɑɹtlɪŋ tɝn ə spid fəɹ ɪz bʌlk, fɑloʊd baɪ ɹin ən moʊst ə ðə waɪz wɪmən. ɹaʊnd-feɪst sumeɪkoʊ ən iin, tɔl ən dɑɹk ən pɹɪɾi dɪspaɪt ðə laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð nɪneɪiv.

Elayne made an exasperated sound. "This is no time to stop for an argument, Nynaeve. The Bowl is upstairs! The Bowl of the Winds!" A small ball of light suddenly appeared, floating in front of her, and without waiting to see whether or not Nynaeve was coming, she gathered her skirts and darted up the stairs. Vanin dashed after her with a startling turn of speed for his bulk, followed by Reanne and most of the Wise Women. Round-faced Sumeko and Ieine, tall and dark and pretty despite the lines at the corners of her eyes, hesitated, then remained with Nynaeve.

mæt wəɾ əv ɡɔn, tu, ɪf nɪneɪiv ən læn hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn ɪz weɪ. "wʊd jə lemi baɪ, nɪneɪiv?" hi æskt. hi dɪzɝv tə bi ðɛɹ, ət list, wən ðɪs fæbjələs blʌɾi boʊl wɑz ənkʌvɝd. "nɪneɪiv?" ʃi wɑz soʊ foʊkəst ɑn læn ʃi sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən ɛniwʌn ɛls. mæt ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð bɛslən, hu ɡɹɪn ən skwɑɾɪd izəli wɪð kɔɹɪvən ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɹɛdʒɹmz. neɪlzin lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl ən jɔn ɑstənteɪʃəsli. wɪtʃ wɑz ə mɪsteɪk wɪð ɔl ðət dʌst əbaʊt; ðə jɔn tɝn ɪndə ə kɑfɪŋ fɪt ðət dɑɹkən ɪz feɪs ən dʌbəld ɪm oʊvɝ.

Mat would have gone, too, if Nynaeve and Lan had not been in his way. "Would you let me by, Nynaeve?" he asked. He deserved to be there, at least, when this fabulous bloody Bowl was uncovered. "Nynaeve?" She was so focused on Lan she seemed to have forgotten anyone else. Mat exchanged glances with Beslan, who grinned and squatted easily with Corevin and the remaining Redarms. Nalesean leaned against the wall and yawned ostentatiously. Which was a mistake with all that dust about; the yawn turned into a coughing fit that darkened his face and doubled him over.

ivən ðət dɪd nɑt dɪstʃɹæk nɪneɪiv. kɛɹfəli, ʃi tʊk əɹ hæn əweɪ fɹəm əɹ bɹeɪd. "aɪ æm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi, læn," ʃi sɛd.

Even that did not distract Nynaeve. Carefully, she took her hand away from her braid. "I am not angry, Lan," she said.

"jɛs, jə ɑɹ," hi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. "bʌɾ i hæd tə bi toʊld."

"Yes, you are," he replied calmly. "But he had to be told."

"nɪneɪiv?" mæt sɛd. "læn?" niðɝ wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz flɪkɝɾ ən aɪ hɪz weɪ.

"Nynaeve?" Mat said. "Lan?" Neither one so much as flickered an eye his way.

"aɪ wʊɾə toʊld ɪm wən aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən!" hɝ maʊθ klæmpt ʃʌt, bʌɾ əɹ lɪps ɹɪθd əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi æŋɡɹi wɪð ju," ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə mʌtʃ maɪldɝ toʊn, ən ðət saʊndəɾ ədʒɹɛs tə hɝsɛlf əz wɛl. vɛɹi dɪlɪbɝətli ʃi tɔst əɹ bɹeɪd bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, dʒɝk ðət blu-plum hæt stʃɹeɪt, ən klæspt əɹ hænz əɾ əɹ weɪst.

"I would have told him when I was ready, Lan Mandragoran!" Her mouth clamped shut, but her lips writhed as though she were talking to herself. "I will not be angry with you," she went on in a much milder tone, and that sounded addressed to herself as well. Very deliberately she tossed her braid back over her shoulder, jerked that blue-plumed hat straight, and clasped her hands at her waist.

"ɪf jə seɪ soʊ," læn sɛd maɪldli.

"If you say so," Lan said mildly.

nɪneɪiv kwɪvɝd. "doʊn jə teɪk ðət toʊn wɪð mi!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd. "aɪ tɛl ju, aɪm nɑɾ æŋɡɹi! dʒju hɪɹ mi?"

Nynaeve quivered. "Don't you take that tone with me!" she shouted. "I tell you, I'm not angry! Do you hear me?"

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz, nɪneɪiv," mæt ɡɹaʊld. "hi dʌzn θɪŋk jəɹ æŋɡɹi. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk jəɹ æŋɡɹi." ə ɡʊd θɪŋ wɪmən hæd tɔɾ ɪm tə laɪ wɪð ə stʃɹeɪt feɪs. "naʊ kəd wi ɡoʊ əpstɛɹz ən fɛtʃ ðɪs blʌɾi boʊl ə ðə wɪnz?"

"Blood and ashes, Nynaeve," Mat growled. "He doesn't think you're angry. I don't think you're angry." A good thing women had taught him to lie with a straight face. "Now could we go upstairs and fetch this bloody Bowl of the Winds?"

"ə mɑɹvələs aɪdiə," sɛɾ ə wʊmənz vɔɪs fɹəm ðə dɔɹ tə ðə stʃɹit. "ʃæl wi ɡoʊ ʌp təɡɛðɝ ən sɝpɹaɪz ɪleɪn?" mæt hæd nɛvɝ sin ðə tu wɪmən u wɔkt ɪndə ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz. ðə spikɝz wɑz lɔŋ ən koʊld əz əɹ vɔɪs, hɝ kəmpænjənz fɹeɪm baɪ skɔɹz ə θɪn dɑɹk bɹeɪdz wɝkt wɪð kʌlɝd bidz. nɪɹli tu dʌzən mɛn kɹaʊɾəd ɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm, bʌlki fɛloʊz wɪð hɛvi ʃoʊldɝz, klʌbz ən naɪvz ɪn hænd. mæt ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ; hi nu tʃɹʌbəl wən i sɔ ɪt, ən ðə fɑkshɛɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst wɑz kul, ɔlmoʊs koʊld əɡɛnst ɪz skɪn. sʌmbɑɾi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

"A marvelous idea," said a woman's voice from the door to the street. "Shall we go up together and surprise Elayne?" Mat had never seen the two women who walked into the hall before, but their faces were Aes Sedai faces. The speaker's was long and cold as her voice, her companion's framed by scores of thin dark braids worked with colored beads. Nearly two dozen men crowded in behind them, bulky fellows with heavy shoulders, clubs and knives in hand. Mat shifted his grip on the ashandarei; he knew trouble when he saw it, and the foxhead on his chest was cool, almost cold against his skin. Somebody was holding the One Power.

ðə tu waɪz wɪmən nɪɹli fɛl oʊvɝ dʒɹɑpɪŋ kɝtsiz əz sun əz ðeɪ sɔ ðoʊz eɪdʒləs fitʃɝz, bʌt nɪneɪiv sɝɾənli nu tʃɹʌbəl, tu. hɝ maʊθ wɝk saʊnləsli əz ðə pɛɹ keɪm daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ, hɝ feɪs ɔl kɑnstɝneɪʃən ən sɛlf-ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃən. bɪhaɪn hɪm, mæt hɝɾ ə sɔɹd livɪŋ ɪts skæbɝd, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lʊk bæk tə si huz. læn dʒʌst stʊd ðɛɹ, wɪtʃ mɛn ə kɔɹs ðəɾ i lʊk laɪk ə lɛpɝd ɹɛɾi tə paʊns.

The two Wise Women nearly fell over dropping curtsies as soon as they saw those ageless features, but Nynaeve certainly knew trouble, too. Her mouth worked soundlessly as the pair came down the hallway, her face all consternation and self-recrimination. Behind him, Mat heard a sword leaving its scabbard, but he was not about to look back to see whose. Lan just stood there, which meant of course that he looked like a leopard ready to pounce.

"ðeɪɹ blæk ədʒɑ," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ət læst. hɝ vɔɪs stɑɹɾəd feɪn ən ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ əz ʃi wɛn ɑn. "fæljən boʊɾə ən ɪspæn ʃɛfɹ. ðeɪ kəmɪɾəd mɝɾɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən wɝs sɪns. ðəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən . . ." hɝ vɔɪs fɔltɝd fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. ". . . ðeɪv mi ʃildɪd."

"They're Black Ajah," Nynaeve said at last. Her voice started faint and gained strength as she went on. "Falion Bhoda and Ispan Shefar. They committed murder in the Tower, and worse since. They're Darkfriends, and . . ." Her voice faltered for an instant. ". . . they have me shielded."

ðə nukʌmɝz kəntɪnjud tə ədvæns sɝinəli. "hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝd sətʃ nɑnsɛns, ɪspæn?" ðə lɔŋ-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ æskt əɹ kəmpænjən, hu stɑpt ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət ðə dʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə smɝk ət nɪneɪiv. "ɪspæn ən aɪ kʌm fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ, waɪl nɪneɪiv ən əɹ fɹɛnz ɑɹ ɹɛbəlz əɡɛns ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðəl bi pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli fəɹ ðæt, ən soʊ wɪl ɛniwʌn u hɛlps ðɛm." wɪð ə ʃɑk, mæt ɹilaɪz ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt noʊ; ʃi θɔt ðəɾ i ən læn ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ dʒʌs haɪɝd stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz. fæljən dɝɛktəɾ ə smaɪl ət nɪneɪiv; ɪt meɪɾ ə blɪzɝd wɔɹm baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. "ðɛɹz sʌmwʌn u wɪl bi oʊvɝdʒɔɪd tə si jə wən wi teɪk jə bæk, nɪneɪiv. ʃi θɪŋks jə ɑɹ dɛd. bɛɾɝ ðə ɹɛst ə jə ɡoʊ naʊ. jə doʊnt wɑnə mɛɾəl ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ əfɛɹz. maɪ mɛn wɪl si jə tə ðə ɹɪvɝ." wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm nɪneɪiv, fæljən moʊʃən fəɹ ðə mɛn bɪhaɪn əɹ tə kʌm fɔɹwɝd.

The newcomers continued to advance serenely. "Have you ever heard such nonsense, Ispan?" the long-faced Aes Sedai asked her companion, who stopped grimacing at the dust long enough to smirk at Nynaeve. "Ispan and I come from the White Tower, while Nynaeve and her friends are rebels against the Amyrlin Seat. They'll be punished severely for that, and so will anyone who helps them." With a shock, Mat realized the woman did not know; she thought that he and Lan and the others were just hired strongarms. Falion directed a smile at Nynaeve; it made a blizzard warm by comparison. "There's someone who will be overjoyed to see you when we take you back, Nynaeve. She thinks you are dead. Better the rest of you go now. You don't want to meddle in Aes Sedai affairs. My men will see you to the river." Without taking her eyes from Nynaeve, Falion motioned for the men behind her to come forward.

læn muvd. hi dɪd nɑt dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹd, ən əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ hi ʃʊɾə hæd noʊ tʃæns ɪf i hæd, noʊ tʃæns ɪn ɛni keɪs, bʌt wʌn moʊmən i wɑz stændɪŋ stɪl ən ðə nɛkst i hæd θɹoʊn hɪmsɛlf ət ðə pɛɹ. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ i stʃɹʌk, hi ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz ðoʊ hɪt hɑɹd, bʌɾ i kɹæʃt ɪndə ðɛm, kæɹiɪŋ boʊθ blæk sɪstɝz tə ðə dʌsti flɔɹ. ðəɾ oʊpən ðə sluətʃəɡeɪts waɪd.

Lan moved. He did not draw his sword, and against Aes Sedai he should have had no chance if he had, no chance in any case, but one moment he was standing still and the next he had thrown himself at the pair. Just before he struck, he grunted as though hit hard, but he crashed into them, carrying both Black sisters to the dusty floor. That opened the sluicegates wide.

læn pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf tə hænz ən niz, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd ɡɹɑdʒəli, ən wʌn ə ðə bʌlki fɛloʊz ɹeɪzd ən aɪɝn-stʃɹæp klʌb tə smæʃ ɪz skʌl. mæt stæb ðə fɛloʊ ɪn ðə bɛli wɪð ɪz spɪɹ əz bɛslən ən neɪlzin ən ðə faɪv ɹɛdʒɹmz ɹʌʃt tə mit ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz' ʃaʊɾɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ. læn stæɡɝd tə hɪz fit, sɔɹd swipɪŋ aʊt tə oʊpən ə dɑɹkfɹɛn fɹəm kɹɑtʃ tə nɛk. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ ɹum tə wɝk sɔɹɾ əɹ æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, bʌt ðə taɪt kɔɹɾɝz wɝ wʌɾ əlaʊɾ əm tə feɪs ɑdz ə tu tə wʌn əɹ wɝs wɪθaʊt biɪŋ oʊvɝkʌm ɪn ðə fɝs moʊmənt. ɡɹʌntɪŋ mɛn stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð əm feɪs-tə-feɪs, ɛlboʊɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ fəɹ ɹum tə stæb əɹ swɪŋ ə klʌb ət ðɛm.

Lan pushed himself to hands and knees, shaking his head groggily, and one of the bulky fellows raised an iron-strapped club to smash his skull. Mat stabbed the fellow in the belly with his spear as Beslan and Nalesean and the five Redarms rushed to meet the Darkfriends' shouting charge. Lan staggered to his feet, sword sweeping out to open a Darkfriend from crotch to neck. There was not much room to work sword or ashandarei in the corridor, but the tight quarters were what allowed them to face odds of two to one or worse without being overcome in the first moment. Grunting men struggled with them face-to-face, elbowing each other for room to stab or swing a club at them.

smɔl speɪsəz ɹɪmeɪn klɪɹ ɝaʊn ðə blæk sɪstɝz, ən ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv; ðeɪ sɔ tə ðət ðɛmsɛlvz. ə wɪɹi ændɔɝən ɹɛdɑɹm ɔlmoʊs bʌmpt ɪndə fæljən, bʌɾ ət ðə læst ɪnstən i dʒɝkt ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən flu əkɹɔs ðə hɔlweɪ, nɑkɪŋ daʊn tu ʌv ðə hɛvi-ʃoʊldɝd dɑɹk-fɹɛnz ɪn ɪz flaɪt bɪfɔɹ smækɪŋ ɪndə ðə wɔl ən slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn, ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd livɪŋ ə blʌɾi smɪɹ ɑn ðə kɹækt, dʌsti plæstɝ. ə bɔld-hɛɾəd dɑɹkfɹɛn skwiz θɹu ðə laɪn ə dɪfɛndɝz ən ɹʌʃt ət nɪneɪiv wɪð aʊt-stʃɹɛtʃt naɪf; hi jɛld əz ɪz fit wɝ sʌɾənli dʒɝk bæk fɹəm hɪm, ə jɛl ðət kʌɾ ɔf wən ɪz feɪs hɪt ðə flɔɹ soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz hɛd baʊnst.

Small spaces remained clear around the Black sisters, and around Nynaeve; they saw to that themselves. A wiry Andoran Redarm almost bumped into Falion, but at the last instant he jerked into the air and flew across the hallway, knocking down two of the heavy-shouldered Dark-friends in his flight before smacking into the wall and sliding down, the back of his head leaving a bloody smear on the cracked, dusty plaster. A bald-headed Darkfriend squeezed through the line of defenders and rushed at Nynaeve with out-stretched knife; he yelled as his feet were suddenly jerked back from him, a yell that cut off when his face hit the floor so hard that his head bounced.

ɑbviəsli nɪneɪiv wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʃildɪd, ən ɪf ðə tʃɪli sɪlvɝ fɑks-hɛd slaɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn mæts tʃɛst əz i fɔt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf ɪndəkeɪʃən ðət ʃi ən ðə blæk sɪstɝz wɝ ɪn səm sɔɹɾ ə stʃɹʌɡəl, ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ən ʃi ət ðɛm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə bæɾəl ɝaʊn ðɛm, ʃaʊɾəd ðə fækt. ðə tu waɪz wɪmən lʊkt ɑn ɪn hɔɹɝ; ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ kɝv naɪvz ɪn ðɛɹ fɪsts, bʌt ðeɪ hʌɾəld əɡɛns ðə wɔl, stɛɹɪŋ fɹəm nɪneɪiv tə ði ʌðɝ tu wɪð aɪz waɪɾ ən maʊðz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

Obviously Nynaeve was no longer shielded, and if the chilly silver fox-head sliding around Mat's chest as he fought was not enough indication that she and the Black sisters were in some sort of struggle, the way they glared at her and she at them, ignoring the battle around them, shouted the fact. The two Wise Women looked on in horror; they had their curved knives in their fists, but they huddled against the wall, staring from Nynaeve to the other two with eyes wide and mouths hanging open.

"faɪt," nɪneɪiv snæpt ət ðɛm. ʃi tɝn əɹ hɛd dʒʌst ə fɹækʃən, soʊ ʃi kəd si ðɛm əz wɛl əz fæljən ən ɪspæn. "aɪ kænɑt də ɪɾ əloʊn; ðəɹ lɪŋkt. ɪf jə doʊn faɪt ðɛm, ðəl kɪl ju. jə noʊ əbaʊt ðɛm, naʊ!" ðə waɪz wɪmən ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd sədʒɛstəd spɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kwinz feɪs. ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ʃaʊts ən ɡɹʌns, ɪspæn læf mɛloʊɾiəsli. ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ʃaʊts ən ɡɹʌns, ə ʃɹɪl skɹim ɛkoʊd daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

"Fight," Nynaeve snapped at them. She turned her head just a fraction, so she could see them as well as Falion and Ispan. "I cannot do it alone; they're linked. If you don't fight them, they will kill you. You know about them, now!" The Wise Women gaped at her as though she had suggested spitting in the Queen's face. In the midst of shouts and grunts, Ispan laughed melodiously. In the midst of shouts and grunts, a shrill scream echoed down the stairs.

nɪneɪivz hɛd swʌŋ ðət weɪ. sʌɾənli ʃi stæɡɝd, ən əɹ hɛd swʌŋ bæk laɪk ə wundəd bædʒɝz, wɪð ə skaʊl ðət ʃʊɾə meɪd fæljən ən ɪspæn liv ɹaɪt ðən ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɛni sɛns. nɪneɪiv spɛɹɾ ən æɡənaɪzd ɡlæns fəɹ mæt, ðoʊ. "ðɛɹ wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ əpstɛɹz," ʃi sɛd θɹu hɝ tiθ. "ðɛɹz tʃɹʌbəl."

Nynaeve's head swung that way. Suddenly she staggered, and her head swung back like a wounded badger's, with a scowl that should have made Falion and Ispan leave right then if they had any sense. Nynaeve spared an agonized glance for Mat, though. "There was channeling upstairs," she said through her teeth. "There's trouble."

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. mɔɹ laɪkli, ɪleɪn hæd sin ə ɹæt. mɔɹ laɪkli. . . . hi mænədʒ tə nɑk əsaɪɾ ə dæɡɝ θɹʌst əɾ ɪz ɹɪbz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹum tə stæb bæk wɪð ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ əɹ juz ðə hæf laɪk ə kɔɹɾɝstæf. bɛslən stæb pæst ɪm ən tʊk ɪz ətækɝ θɹu ðə hɑɹt.

Mat hesitated. More likely, Elayne had seen a rat. More likely. . . . He managed to knock aside a dagger thrust at his ribs, but there was no room to stab back with the ashandarei or use the haft like a quarterstaff. Beslan stabbed past him and took his attacker through the heart.

"pliz, mæt," nɪneɪiv sɛd taɪtli. ʃi nɛvɝ bɛɡd. ʃi wəd kʌɾ əɹ oʊn θɹoʊt fɝst. "pliz."

"Please, Mat," Nynaeve said tightly. She never begged. She would cut her own throat first. "Please."

wɪð ə kɝs, mæt pʊl hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə faɪɾ ən dæʃt ʌp ðə stip, nɛɹoʊ stɛɹz, teɪkɪŋ ɔl sɪks flaɪts ɪn ðə dɑɹk stɛɹwɛl əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn. ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ tə ɡɪv laɪt. ɪf ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə ɹæt, hi wɑz gɑnə ʃeɪk ɪleɪn tɪl əɹ tiθ. . . . hi bɝst aʊɾ ɑntu ðə tɑp flɔɹ, nɑt mʌtʃ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ðə stɛɹwɛl wɪð oʊnli wʌn wɪndoʊ ət ðə stʃɹiɾ ɛnd, bɝst ɪndə ə sin fɹəm naɪtmɛɹ.

With a curse, Mat pulled himself out of the fight and dashed up the steep, narrow stairs, taking all six flights in the dark stairwell at a dead run. There was not a single window to give light. If it was just a rat, he was going to shake Elayne till her teeth. . . . He burst out onto the top floor, not much brighter than the stairwell with only one window at the street end, burst into a scene from nightmare.

wɪmən leɪ spɹɔld ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ɪleɪn wɑz wʌn, hæf ɑn əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, aɪz kloʊzd. veɪnɪn kɹaʊtʃt ɑn ɪz niz, blʌd stʃɹimɪŋ fɹəm noʊz ən ɪɹz, fibli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ðə læst wʊmən ɑn əɹ fit, dʒənɪɹə, flɛd təwɔɹd mæt əz sun əz ʃi sɔ hɪm. hi hæd θɔɾ ə hɝ əz ə hɔk, wɪð əɹ hʊk bik ʌv ə noʊz ən ʃɑɹp tʃikboʊnz, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz pjʊɹ tɛɹɝ naʊ, ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz waɪɾ ən stɑɹk.

Women lay sprawled everywhere. Elayne was one, half on her back against the wall, eyes closed. Vanin crouched on his knees, blood streaming from nose and ears, feebly trying to pull himself up against the wall. The last woman on her feet, Janira, fled toward Mat as soon as she saw him. He had thought of her as a hawk, with her hooked beak of a nose and sharp cheekbones, but her face was pure terror now, those dark eyes wide and stark.

"hɛlp mi!" ʃi skɹimd ət hɪm, ən ə mæn kɑɾ əɹ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. hi wɑz ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi-lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊ, meɪbi ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən mæt, ʌv ðə seɪm haɪɾ ən slɛndɝ ɪn ə pleɪn ɡɹeɪ koʊt. smaɪlɪŋ, hi tʊk dʒənɪɹəz hɛd bɪtwin ɪz hænz ən twɪstəd ʃɑɹpli. ðə saʊn ə hɝ nɛk bɹeɪkɪŋ wɑz laɪk ə dʒɹaɪ bɹæntʃ snæpɪŋ. hi lɛɾ əɹ dʒɹɑp ɪn ə boʊnləs hip ən ɡeɪz daʊn ət hɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɪz smaɪl lʊkt . . . ɹæptʃɝəs.

"Help me!" she screamed at him, and a man caught her from behind. He was an ordinary-looking fellow, maybe a little older than Mat, of the same height and slender in a plain gray coat. Smiling, he took Janira's head between his hands and twisted sharply. The sound of her neck breaking was like a dry branch snapping. He let her drop in a boneless heap and gazed down at her. For a moment, his smile looked . . . rapturous.

baɪ ðə laɪɾ ʌv ə pɛɹ ə læntɝnz, ə smɔl nɑɾ ə mɛn dʒʌs bɪɑn veɪnɪn wɝ pɹaɪɪŋ oʊpən ə dɔɹ tə ðə skwil ə ɹʌstəd hɪnʒɪz, bʌt mæt hɑɹdli noʊɾəst. hɪz aɪz wɛn fɹəm dʒənɪɹəz kɹʌmpəl kɔɹps tə ɪleɪn. hi hæd pɹɑməs tə kip əɹ seɪf fəɹ ɹænd. hi hæd pɹɑməst. wɪð ə kɹaɪ, hi lɔntʃt hɪmsɛlf ət ðə kɪlɝ, æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪkstɛndəd.

By the light of a pair of lanterns, a small knot of men just beyond Vanin were prying open a door to the squeal of rusted hinges, but Mat hardly noticed. His eyes went from Janira's crumpled corpse to Elayne. He had promised to keep her safe for Rand. He had promised. With a cry, he launched himself at the killer, ashandarei extended.

mæt hæd sin mɹdʒɹɑl muv, bʌt ðɪs fɛloʊ wɑz kwɪkɝ, hɑɹɾ əz ðət wɑz tə bɪliv. hi dʒʌst sim tə floʊ fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə spɪɹ, ən sizɪŋ ðə hæft, hi pɪvəɾəd, flɪŋɪŋ mæt pæst ɪm faɪv peɪsɪz daʊn ðə hɔl.

Mat had seen Myrddraal move, but this fellow was quicker, hard as that was to believe. He just seemed to flow from in front of the spear, and seizing the haft, he pivoted, flinging Mat past him five paces down the hall.

bɹɛθ lɛft wən i hɪt ðə flɔɹ ɪn ə smɔl klaʊɾ ə dʌst. soʊ dɪd ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ. stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ ɛɹ, hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp, fɑkshɛd dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz oʊpən ʃɝt. dʒɹæɡɪŋ ə naɪf fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, hi flʌŋ hɪmsɛlf ət ðə mæn əɡɛn dʒʌst əz neɪlzin əpɪɹɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz, sɔɹɾ ɪn hænd. naʊ ðeɪ hæd hɪm, haʊɛvɝ kwɪk hi. . . .

Breath left when he hit the floor in a small cloud of dust. So did the ashandarei. Struggling for air, he pushed himself up, foxhead dangling from his open shirt. Dragging a knife from under his coat, he flung himself at the man again just as Nalesean appeared at the head of the stairs, sword in hand. Now they had him, however quick he. . . .

ðə mæn meɪɾ ə mɹdʒɹɑl sim stɪf. hi slɪɾ ɝaʊnd neɪlzinz θɹʌst əz ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə boʊn ɪn ɪz bɑɾi, ɹaɪt hænd ʃuɾɪŋ aʊt tə siz neɪlzinz θɹoʊt. hɪz hæn keɪm əweɪ wɪð ə lɪkwəd, ɹɪpɪŋ saʊnd. blʌd faʊnteɪn pæs neɪlzinz bɪɹd. hɪz sɔɹd dʒɹɑpt, ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn ðə dʌsti stoʊn flɔɹ, ən i klʌtʃt boʊθ hænz tə hɪz ɹuənd nɛk, ɹɛd ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu hɪz fɪŋɡɝz əz i fɛl.

The man made a Myrddraal seem stiff. He slid around Nalesean's thrust as though there was not a bone in his body, right hand shooting out to seize Nalesean's throat. His hand came away with a liquid, ripping sound. Blood fountained past Nalesean's beard. His sword dropped, ringing on the dusty stone floor, and he clutched both hands to his ruined neck, red running through his fingers as he fell.

mæt kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə kɪlɝz bæk, ən ðeɪ ɔl θɹi hɪt ðə flɔɹ təɡɛðɝ. hi hæd noʊ kəmpjuŋkʃənz əɡɛnst stæbɪŋ ə mæn ɪn ðə bæk wən ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, ɪspɛʃli ə mæn u kəd tɛɹ sʌmbɑɾiz θɹoʊɾ aʊt. hi ʃʊɾə lɛt neɪlzin steɪ ɪn bɛd. ðə θɔt keɪm sædli əz i dʒɹoʊv ðə bleɪd hoʊm hɑɹd, ðən ə sɛkən taɪm, ə θɝd.

Mat crashed into the killer's back, and they all three hit the floor together. He had no compunctions against stabbing a man in the back when it was necessary, especially a man who could tear somebody's throat out. He should have let Nalesean stay in bed. The thought came sadly as he drove the blade home hard, then a second time, a third.

ðə mæn twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz ɡɹɪp. ɪt ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn pɑsəbəl, bʌt sʌmhaʊ ðə fɛloʊ ɹoʊld oʊvɝ bɪniθ hɪm, pʊlɪŋ ðə naɪf hɪlt aʊɾ ə hɪz hænd. neɪlzinz stɛɹɪŋ aɪz ən blʌɾi θɹoʊt wɝ ə ɹimaɪndɝ ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪz aɪz. dɛspɝətli hi ɡɹæb ðə mænz ɹɪsts, wʌn hæn slɪpɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɪn ðə blʌd ðət ɹæn daʊn ðə fɛloʊz hænd.

The man twisted in his grip. It should not have been possible, but somehow the fellow rolled over beneath him, pulling the knife hilt out of his hand. Nalesean's staring eyes and bloody throat were a reminder right before his eyes. Desperately he grabbed the man's wrists, one hand slipping a little in the blood that ran down the fellow's hand.

ðə mæn smaɪld ət hɪm. wɪð ə naɪf stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪd, hi smaɪld! "hi wɑns jə dɛɾ əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑns hɝ," hi sɛd sɔfli. ən əz ɪf mæt wɑz nɑt hoʊldɪŋ ɪm əɾ ɔl, hɪz hænz muv təwɔɹd mæts hɛd, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ mæts ɑɹmz bæk.

The man smiled at him. With a knife sticking out of his side, he smiled! "He wants you dead as much as he wants her," he said softly. And as if Mat was not holding him at all, his hands moved toward Mat's head, driving Mat's arms back.

mæt pʊʃt fɹæntəkəli, θɹu ɔl ə hɪz weɪɾ əɡɛns ðə fɛloʊz ɑɹmz tə noʊ əveɪl. laɪt, hi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə tʃaɪl faɪɾɪŋ ə ɡɹoʊn mæn. ðə fɛloʊ wɑz meɪkɪŋ ə ɡeɪm ʌv ɪt, teɪkɪŋ ɪz blʌɾi taɪm. hænz tʌtʃt ɪz hɛd. wɛɹ wɑz ɪz fleɪmɪŋ lʌk? hi ɡeɪv ə hiv wɪð wʌt simd ɪz læst stʃɹɛŋkθ - ən ðə mədæljən fɛl əɡɛns ðə mænz tʃik. ðə mæn skɹimd. smoʊk ɹoʊz ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə fɑkshɛd, ən ə sɪzəl laɪk beɪkən fɹaɪɪŋ. kənvʌlsɪvli, hi hɝl mæt əweɪ wɪð hænz ən fit boʊθ. ðɪs taɪm, mæt flu tɛn peɪsɪz ən slɪd.

Mat pushed frantically, threw all of his weight against the fellow's arms to no avail. Light, he might as well have been a child fighting a grown man. The fellow was making a game of it, taking his bloody time. Hands touched his head. Where was his flaming luck? He gave a heave with what seemed his last strength - and the medallion fell against the man's cheek. The man screamed. Smoke rose around the edges of the foxhead, and a sizzle like bacon frying. Convulsively, he hurled Mat away with hands and feet both. This time, Mat flew ten paces and slid.

wən i skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, hæf-deɪzd, ðə mæn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ʌp, hænz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ əɾ ɪz feɪs. ə ɹɔ ɹɛd bɹæn mɑɹkt wɛɹ ðə fɑkshɛd hæd fɔlən. dʒɪnʒɝli, mæt fɪŋɡɝd ðə mədæljən. ɪt wɑz kul. nɑt ðə kul ə sʌmwʌn tʃænəlɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ - meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ stɪl əɾ ɪt bɪloʊ, bʌt ðət wɑz tu fɑɹ ɔf - dʒʌs ðə kul ə sɪlvɝ. hi hæd noʊ noʊʃən wʌt ðɪs fɛloʊ wɑz, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt hjumən, bʌt bɪtwin ðət bɝn ən θɹi stæb wunz, wɪð ðə naɪf hɪl stɪl dʒʌɾɪŋ aʊt bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹm, hi hæd tə bi sloʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mæt tə ɡɛt pæst ɪm tə ðə stɛɹz. əvɛnʒɪŋ ɪleɪn wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, ən neɪlzin tu, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt gɑnə hæpən tədeɪ, əpɛɹənli, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɔl tə səplaɪ ə ɹizən fəɹ əvɛnʒɪŋ mæt kɔθən.

When he scrambled to his feet, half-dazed, the man was already up, hands trembling at his face. A raw red brand marked where the foxhead had fallen. Gingerly, Mat fingered the medallion. It was cool. Not the cool of someone channeling nearby - maybe they were still at it below, but that was too far off - just the cool of silver. He had no notion what this fellow was, except that he certainly was not human, but between that burn and three stab wounds, with the knife hilt still jutting out beneath his arm, he had to be slowed enough for Mat to get past him to the stairs. Avenging Elayne was all very well, and Nalesean too, but it was not going to happen today, apparently, and there was no call to supply a reason for avenging Mat Cauthon.

dʒɝkɪŋ ðə naɪf aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪd, ðə mæn hɝld ɪɾ ət hɪm. mæt snæɡd ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ. tɑm hæd tɔɾ ɪm tə dʒʌɡəl, ən tɑm sɛɾ i hæd ðə kwɪkɪs hænz i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. flɪpɪŋ ðə naɪf ɝaʊn soʊ hi hɛld ɪt pɹɑpɝli, pɔɪntəd slæntəɾ ʌp, hi noʊɾəst ðə ɡlimɪŋ bleɪd, ən ɪz hɑɹt sæŋk. noʊ blʌd. ðəɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn ət list ə smɪɹ ə ɹɛd, bʌt ðə stil ʃoʊn, bɹaɪɾ ən klin. meɪbi ivən θɹi stæb wunz wɝ nɑt gɑnə sloʊ ðɪs - wʌtɛvɝ i wɑz.

Jerking the knife out of his side, the man hurled it at him. Mat snagged it out of the air without thinking. Thom had taught him to juggle, and Thom said he had the quickest hands he had ever seen. Flipping the knife around so he held it properly, pointed slanted up, he noticed the gleaming blade, and his heart sank. No blood. There should have been at least a smear of red, but the steel shone, bright and clean. Maybe even three stab wounds were not going to slow this - whatever he was.

hi ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ði ʌðɝ mɛn wɝ stʃɹimɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðət dɔɹ ðeɪ hæd pɹaɪɾ oʊpən, ðə dɔɹ ðoʊz fʊtpɹɪns hæd lɛɾ ɪm tə jɛstɝdeɪ, bʌt ðɛɹ ɑɹmz sim fʊl ə ɹʌbɪʃ, smɔl hæf-ɹɑɾɪd tʃɛsts, ə kæsk wɪð klɔθ-ɹæpt ɑbʒɛkts bʌlʒɪŋ θɹu mɪsɪŋ steɪvz, ivən ə bɹoʊkən tʃɛɹ ən ə kɹæk mɪɹɝ. ðeɪ mʌst əv hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz tə teɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ. peɪɪŋ noʊ ətɛnʃən wʌtɛvɝ tə mæt, ðeɪ hɝid təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə hɔl ən vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə stɛɹz bæk ðɛɹ. meɪbi hi kəd fɑloʊ ðɛm daʊn əɾ ə dɪstəns. meɪbi. . . . dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹweɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm aʊɾ ʌv, veɪnɪn meɪɾ ənʌðɝ ɛfɝt tə stænd, ən fɛl bæk. mæt bɪt bæk ə kɝs. lʌɡɪŋ veɪnɪn wɑz gɑnə sloʊ hɪm, bʌɾ ɪf ɪz lʌk wɑz ɪn. . . . ɪt hæd nɑt seɪvd ɪleɪn, bʌt meɪbi. . . . fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, hi sɔ hɝ muv, lɪftɪŋ ə hæn tə hɝ hɛd.

He risked a glance over his shoulder. The other men were streaming out of that door they had pried open, the door those footprints had led him to yesterday, but their arms seemed full of rubbish, small half-rotted chests, a cask with cloth-wrapped objects bulging through missing staves, even a broken chair and a cracked mirror. They must have had orders to take everything. Paying no attention whatever to Mat, they hurried toward the far end of the hall and vanished around a corner. There had to be another set of stairs back there. Maybe he could follow them down at a distance. Maybe. . . . Just before the doorway they had come out of, Vanin made another effort to stand, and fell back. Mat bit back a curse. Lugging Vanin was going to slow him, but if his luck was in. . . . It had not saved Elayne, but maybe. . . . From the corner of his eye, he saw her move, lifting a hand to her head.

ðə mæn ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ koʊt sɔ ɪt, tu. wɪð ə smaɪl, hi tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ.

The man in the gray coat saw it, too. With a smile, he turned toward her.

saɪɪŋ, mæt tʌk ðə jusləs naɪf ɪndə ɪts skæbɝd. "ju kæn əv hɝ," hi sɛd laʊdli. pɹɑməsəz. wʌn dʒɝk bɹoʊk ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk; ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd dæŋɡəld ə fʊt bɪloʊ hɪz fɪst. ɪt meɪɾ ə loʊ hʌm əz i wɝld ɪɾ ɪn ə dʌbəl lup. "ju kæn blʌɾi hæv hɝ." hi stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd, kipɪŋ ðə mədæljən spɪnɪŋ. ðə fɝst stɛp wɑz ðə hɑɹɾəst, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə pɹɑməs tə kip.

Sighing, Mat tucked the useless knife into its scabbard. "You can't have her," he said loudly. Promises. One jerk broke the leather cord around his neck; the silver foxhead dangled a foot below his fist. It made a low hum as he whirled it in a double loop. "You can't bloody have her." He started forward, keeping the medallion spinning. The first step was the hardest, but he had a promise to keep.

ðə fɛloʊz smaɪl feɪɾəd. wɑtʃɪŋ ðə flæʃɪŋ fɑkshɛd wɛɹəli, hi bækt əweɪ ɑn ɪz toʊz. ðə seɪm laɪt ðət ɡlɪɾɝd ɑn ðə wɝlɪŋ sɪlvɝ, fɹəm ðə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ, meɪɾ ə heɪloʊ ɝaʊn hɪm. ɪf mæt kəd dʒɹaɪv ɪm ðət fɑɹ, meɪbi hi kəd si wɛðɝ ə sɪks-stɔɹi dʒɹɑp wəd də wʌɾ ə naɪf kəd nɑt.

The fellow's smile faded. Watching the flashing foxhead warily, he backed away on his toes. The same light that glittered on the whirling silver, from the single window, made a halo around him. If Mat could drive him that far, maybe he could see whether a six-story drop would do what a knife could not.

bɹæn lɪvɪɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, ðə fɛloʊ bækt əweɪ, səmtaɪmz hæf-ɹitʃɪŋ əz ɪf tə tʃɹaɪ ɡɹæbɪŋ pæs ðə mədæljən. ən sʌɾənli, hi dɑɹɾɪd tə wʌn saɪd, ɪndə wʌn ə ðə ɹumz. ðɪs wʌn hæɾ ə dɔɹ ðəɾ i pʊld ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɪm. mæt hɝd ðə bɑɹ dʒɹɑp.

Brand livid on his face, the fellow backed away, sometimes half-reaching as if to try grabbing past the medallion. And suddenly, he darted to one side, into one of the rooms. This one had a door that he pulled shut behind him. Mat heard the bar drop.

meɪbi hi ʃʊɾə lɛft ɪt ðɛɹ, bʌt wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi ɹeɪzd ə fʊɾ ən slæm ðə hil ə hɪz buɾ əɡɛns ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə dɔɹ. dʌs lɛpt ɔf ðə ɹʌf wʊd. ə sɛkən kɪk, ən ɹɑɾən bɑɹ-kætʃəz ɡeɪv weɪ, əlɔŋ wɪð ə ɹʌstəd hɪnʒ. ðə dɔɹ fɛl ɪn, hæŋɪŋ əɾ ə slæntəɾ æŋɡəl.

Maybe he should have left it there, but without thinking, he raised a foot and slammed the heel of his boot against the center of the door. Dust leaped off the rough wood. A second kick, and rotten bar-catches gave way, along with a rusted hinge. The door fell in, hanging at a slanted angle.

ðə ɹum wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli dɑɹk. ə lɪɾəl laɪt ɹitʃt ɪt fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔl, dʒʌst wʌn dɔɹ əweɪ, ən ə bɹoʊkən tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ə mɪɹɝ linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl spɹɛɾ ə feɪn ɪluməneɪʃən. ðət mɪɹɝ lɛɾ ɪm si ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn. əsaɪd fɹəm ðəɾ ən ə pis ʌv ə tʃɛɹ, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə si. ði oʊnli oʊpənɪŋz wɝ ðə dɔɹweɪ ən ə ɹæθhoʊl bɪsaɪd ðə mɪɹɝ, bʌt ðə mæn ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ koʊt wɑz ɡɔn.

The room was not entirely dark. A little light reached it from the window at the end of the hall, just one door away, and a broken triangle of mirror leaning against the far wall spread a faint illumination. That mirror let him see everything without going in. Aside from that and a piece of a chair, there was nothing else to see. The only openings were the doorway and a rathole beside the mirror, but the man in the gray coat was gone.

"mæt," ɪleɪn kɔl feɪnli. hi hɝiɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹum əz mʌtʃ əz təwɔɹd hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ bɪloʊ, bʌt nɪneɪiv ən ðə ɹɛst wəɾ əv tə teɪk kɛɹ ə ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

"Mat," Elayne called faintly. He hurried away from the room as much as toward her. There was shouting somewhere below, but Nynaeve and the rest would have to take care of themselves for the moment.

ɪleɪn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ʌp, wɝkɪŋ əɹ dʒɔ ən wɪnsɪŋ, wən i nɛl bɪsaɪd hɝ. dʌs kʌvɝɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs, hɝ hæt hʌŋ əskju, səm ə ðə plumz bɹoʊkən, ən əɹ ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡd baɪ ɪt. "hi hɪt mi soʊ hɑɹd," ʃi sɛd peɪnfəli. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɛniθɪŋ ɪz bɹoʊkən, bʌt. . . ." hɝ aɪz lætʃt ɑn tə hɪz, ən ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ θɔt ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, hi sɔ ɪt fəɹ tʃɹu naʊ. "aɪ sɔ wʌt jə dɪd, mæt. wɪð hɪm. wi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn tʃɪkənz ɪn ə bɑks wɪð ə wizəl. tʃænəlɪŋ wʊdn tʌtʃ hɪm; ðə floʊz mɛltəd ðə weɪ ðeɪ də wɪð jɔɹ. . . ." ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə mədæljən stɪl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz fɪst, ʃi dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ ðət dɪɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ θɪŋz tə ðəɾ oʊvəl kʌt-aʊt. "θæŋk ju, mæt. aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ ɛvɝ dɪɾ əɹ θɔt." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi ɹɪli mɛn ɪt. "aɪ kip bɪldɪŋ ʌp toʊ təwɔɹd ju," ʃi smaɪld ɹufəli, "bʌɾ aɪm nɑt gɑnə lɛt jə bit mi. jə ɑɹ gɑnə hæv tə lemi seɪv jə ət list wʌns tə bæləns mæɾɝz."

Elayne was sitting up, working her jaw and wincing, when he knelt beside her. Dust covered her dress, her hat hung askew, some of the plumes broken, and her red-gold hair looked as if she had been dragged by it. "He hit me so hard," she said painfully. "I don't think anything is broken, but. . . ." Her eyes latched on to his, and if he had ever thought she looked at him as if he were a stranger, he saw it for true now. "I saw what you did, Mat. With him. We might as well have been chickens in a box with a weasel. Channeling wouldn't touch him; the flows melted the way they do with your. . . ." Glancing at the medallion still hanging from his fist, she drew a breath that did interesting things to that oval cut-out. "Thank you, Mat. I apologize for everything I ever did or thought." She sounded as though she really meant it. "I keep building up toh toward you," she smiled ruefully, "but I am not going to let you beat me. You are going to have to let me save you at least once to balance matters."

"aɪl si wʌɾ aɪ kən ɝeɪnʒ," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, stʌfɪŋ ðə mədæljən ɪndə ə koʊt pɑkət. toʊ? bit hɝ? laɪt! ðə wʊmən wɑz dɛfənətli spɛndɪŋ tu mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð eɪvinhə.

"I'll see what I can arrange," he said dryly, stuffing the medallion into a coat pocket. Toh? Beat her? Light! The woman was definitely spending too much time with Aviendha.

wʌns i hɛlpt əɹ tə hɝ fit, ʃi lʊkt ət ðə hɔlweɪ, ət veɪnɪn wɪð ɪz blʌd-smɪɹd feɪs, ən ðə wɪmən laɪɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd fɔlən, ən ʃi ɡɹɪməst. "oʊ, laɪt!" ʃi bɹiðd. "oʊ, blʌɾ ən blʌɾi fleɪmɪŋ æʃəz!" dɪspaɪt ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ðəɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə hɪɹ ðoʊz wɝdz aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ; ðeɪ sim pəkjuljɝ, əz ɪf ʃi nu ðə saʊnz bʌt nɑt ðə minɪŋz. sʌmhaʊ, ðeɪ meɪɾ əɹ saʊn jʌŋɡɝ ðən ʃi lʊkt.

Once he helped her to her feet, she looked at the hallway, at Vanin with his blood-smeared face, and the women lying where they had fallen, and she grimaced. "Oh, Light!" she breathed. "Oh, blood and bloody flaming ashes!" Despite the situation, he gave a start. It was not just that he had never expected to hear those words out of her mouth; they seemed peculiar, as if she knew the sounds but not the meanings. Somehow, they made her sound younger than she looked.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz ɑɹm, ʃi dɪskɑɹɾɪd əɹ hæt, dʒʌs tɔsɪŋ ɪɾ əsaɪd, ən hɝid tə nil bɪsaɪd ðə nɪɹəst waɪz wʊmən, ɹin, ən teɪk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz. ðə wʊmən leɪ lɪmp, feɪs daʊn ən ɑɹmz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɹɪpt ʌp ɹʌnɪŋ. təwɔɹd ðə ɹum ɛvɹiwʌn hæd bɪn æftɝ, təwɔɹɾ əɹ ətækɝ, nɑɾ əweɪ.

Shaking off his arm, she discarded her hat, just tossing it aside, and hurried to kneel beside the nearest Wise Woman, Reanne, and take her head in both hands. The woman lay limp, face down and arms stretched out as though she had been tripped up running. Toward the room everyone had been after, toward her attacker, not away.

"ðɪs ɪz bɪɑn mi," ɪleɪn mʌɾɝd. "wɛɹ ɪz nɪneɪiv? waɪ dɪdnt ʃi kʌm ʌp wɪð ju, mæt? nɪneɪiv!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz.

"This is beyond me," Elayne muttered. "Where is Nynaeve? Why didn't she come up with you, Mat? Nynaeve!" she shouted toward the stairs.

"noʊ nid tə ʃɹik laɪk ə kæt," nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld, əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə stɛɹwɛl. ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ daʊn ðə stɛɹz, ðoʊ. "ju hoʊld əɹ taɪt, jə hɪɹ mi?" ʃi ʃɹik laɪk ə kæt. ʃi kæɹiɾ əɹ hæt, ən ʃʊk ɪɾ ət huɛvɝ ʃi wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ æt. "ju lɛɾ əɹ ɡɛɾ əweɪ, tu, ən əl bɑks jəɹ ɪɹz tɪl jə hɪɹ bɛlz nɛks jɪɹ!"

"No need to shriek like a cat," Nynaeve growled, appearing in the stairwell. She was looking back over her shoulder down the stairs, though. "You hold her tight, you hear me?" she shrieked like a cat. She carried her hat, and shook it at whoever she was shouting at. "You let her get away, too, and I'll box your ears till you hear bells next year!"

ʃi tɝnd, ðɛn, ən əɹ aɪz nɪɹli bʌlʒd aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ʌs," ʃi bɹiðd, hɝiɪŋ tə bɛn oʊvɝ dʒənɪɹə. wʌn tʌtʃ, ən ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd, wɪnsɪŋ peɪnfəli. hi cʊɾə toʊld əɹ ðə wʊmən wɑz dɛd. nɪneɪiv sim tə teɪk dɛθ pɝsənəli. ɡɪvɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ʃi wɛn ɑn tə ðə nɛkst, tæmɑɹlə, ən ðɪs taɪm ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʃi kəd hil. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ əpɪɹd tæmɑɹləz ɪnʒɝiz wɝ nɑt sɪmpəl, kəz ʃi nɛlt oʊvɝ hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "wʌt hæpən hɪɹ, mæt?" ʃi dɪmændəd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ət hɪm. hɝ toʊn meɪɾ ɪm saɪ; hi maɪɾ əv noʊn ʃi wəd dɪsaɪɾ ɪt wɑz ɪz fɔlt. "wɛl, mæt? wʌt hæpənd? wɪl jə spik ʌp, mæn, əɹ də aɪ hæv tə - " hi nɛvɝ lɝnd wʌt θɹɛt ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɔfɝ.

She turned, then, and her eyes nearly bulged out of her head. "The Light shine on us," she breathed, hurrying to bend over Janira. One touch, and she straightened, wincing painfully. He could have told her the woman was dead. Nynaeve seemed to take death personally. Giving herself a shake, she went on to the next, Tamarla, and this time it appeared there was something she could Heal. It also appeared Tamarla's injuries were not simple, because she knelt over her, frowning. "What happened here, Mat?" she demanded without looking around at him. Her tone made him sigh; he might have known she would decide it was his fault. "Well, Mat? What happened? Will you speak up, man, or do I have to - " He never learned what threat she intended to offer.

læn hæd fɑloʊd nɪneɪiv aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹwɛl, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪð sumeɪkoʊ ɹaɪɾ əɾ ɪz hilz. ðə staʊt waɪz wʊmən tʊk wʌn lʊk ət ðə hɔl ən ɪmiɾiətli lɪftəɾ əɹ skɝts ən ɹæn tə ɹin. ʃi dɪd ɡɪv ɪleɪn wʌn wɝid ɡlæns bɪfɔɹ loʊɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə hɝ niz ən bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə muv əɹ hænz oʊvɝ ɹin ɪn ən ɑd weɪ. ðət wɑz wʌt pʊl nɪneɪiv ʌp ʃɔɹt.

Lan had followed Nynaeve out of the stairwell, of course, with Sumeko right at his heels. The stout Wise Woman took one look at the hall and immediately lifted her skirts and ran to Reanne. She did give Elayne one worried glance before lowering herself to her knees and beginning to move her hands over Reanne in an odd way. That was what pulled Nynaeve up short.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. nɑt hɔltɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ tə tæmɑɹlə, ʃi spɛɹd ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən oʊnli ʃɔɹt ɡlænsɪz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ əz pɪɹsɪŋ əz əɹ vɔɪs. "wɛɹ dɪd jə lɝn ðæt?"

"What are you doing?" she said sharply. Not halting what she was doing to Tamarla, she spared the round-faced woman only short glances, but they were as piercing as her voice. "Where did you learn that?"

sumeɪkoʊ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, bʌɾ əɹ hænz dɪd nɑt stɑp. "fɝɡɪv mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə bɹɛθləs, dɪsdʒɔɪntɪd ɹʌʃ. "aɪ noʊ aɪm nɑt səpoʊz tə. . . . ʃɪl daɪ ɪf aɪ doʊnt. . . . aɪ noʊ aɪ wɑzn səpoʊz tə kip tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə. . . . aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə lɝn, ɛɛs sədaɪ. pliz."

Sumeko gave a start, but her hands did not stop. "Forgive me, Aes Sedai," she said in a breathless, disjointed rush. "I know I'm not supposed to. . . . She'll die if I don't. . . . I know I wasn't supposed to keep trying to. . . . I just wanted to learn, Aes Sedai. Please."

"noʊ, noʊ, ɡoʊ ɑn," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ æbsənli. moʊst ə hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz fɪkst ɑn ðə wʊmən ʌndɝ əɹ hænz, bʌt nɑɾ ɔl. "ju sim tə noʊ ə fju θɪŋz ivən aɪ - ðəɾ ɪz tə seɪ, juv ə vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ weɪ wɪð ðə floʊz. aɪ səspɛk jəl faɪn ðəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni sɪstɝz wɑnə lɝn fɹəm ju." hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi æɾəd, "meɪbi naʊ ðəl liv mi əloʊn." sumeɪkoʊ kəd nɑɾ əv hɝd ðət læst, bʌt wʌt ʃi dɪd hɪɹ dʒɹɑpt əɹ tʃɪn tə hɝ kənsɪɾɝəbəl tʃɛst. hɝ hænz bɛɹli pɔzd, ðoʊ.

"No, no, go on," Nynaeve said absently. Most of her attention was fixed on the woman under her hands, but not all. "You seem to know a few things even I - That is to say, you have a very interesting way with the flows. I suspect you'll find that a great many sisters want to learn from you." Half under her breath, she added, "Maybe now they'll leave me alone." Sumeko could not have heard that last, but what she did hear dropped her chin to her considerable chest. Her hands barely paused, though.

"ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn, "wʊd jə lʊk fəɹ ðə boʊl, pliz? aɪ səspɛk ðət dɔɹ ɪz ðə wʌn." ʃi nɑɾəd tə ðə kɝɛk dɔɹ, stændɪŋ oʊpən laɪk hæf ə dʌzən ʌðɝz. ðət meɪd mæt blɪŋk əntɪl i sɔ tu taɪni klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəlz laɪɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt wɛɹ ðə luɾɝz mʌst əv dʒɹɑp ðɛm.

"Elayne," Nynaeve went on, "would you look for the Bowl, please? I suspect that door is the one." She nodded to the correct door, standing open like half a dozen others. That made Mat blink until he saw two tiny cloth-wrapped bundles lying in front of it where the looters must have dropped them.

"jɛs," ɪleɪn mʌɾɝd. "jɛs, aɪ kən də ðət mʌtʃ, ət list." hæf-ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn təwɔɹd veɪnɪn, stɪl ɑn ɪz niz, ʃi lɛɾ ɪt fɔl wɪð ə saɪ ən stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, wɪtʃ ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli ɪmɪɾəd ə klaʊɾ ə dʌst ən ðə saʊn ə kɑfɪŋ.

"Yes," Elayne muttered. "Yes, I can do that much, at least." Half-raising a hand toward Vanin, still on his knees, she let it fall with a sigh and strode through the doorway, which almost immediately emitted a cloud of dust and the sound of coughing.

ðə mɔɹ-ðæn-plʌmp waɪz wʊmən hæd nɑt bɪn ði oʊnli wʌn fɑloʊɪŋ nɪneɪiv ən læn. iin stɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹwɛl, fɔɹsɪŋ ðə tæɹɑbənɝ dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ baɪ minz ʌv ən ɑɹm twɪstəɾ ʌp ɪndə hɝ bæk ən ə fɪs klʌtʃɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk. iinz dʒɔ wɑz sɛt, hɝ maʊθ taɪt; hɝ feɪs wɑz hæf fɹaɪɾənd sɝɾənti ðət ʃi wəd bi skɪn əlaɪv fəɹ mænhænlɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən hæf dɪtɝməneɪʃən tə hoʊld ɑn noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. nɪneɪiv hæd ðəɾ ɪfɛkt ɑn pipəl, səmtaɪmz. ðə blæk sɪstɝ wɑz waɪd-aɪd wɪð tɛɹɝ, sæɡɪŋ soʊ ʃi ʃʊɹli wʊɾə fɔlən ɪksɛp fəɹ iinz ɡɹɪp. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn ʃildɪd, sɝɾənli, ən wɪð ikwəl ʃʊɹəɾi ʃi pɹɑbli wʊɾə tʃoʊzən biɪŋ skɪn tə wʌtɛvɝ wɑz gɑnə hæpən tə hɝ. tɪɹz bɪɡæn likɪŋ fɹəm əɹ aɪz, ən əɹ maʊθ sæɡd ɪn saɪlən sɑbz.

The more-than-plump Wise Woman had not been the only one following Nynaeve and Lan. Ieine stalked out of the stairwell, forcing the Taraboner Darkfriend in front of her by means of an arm twisted up into her back and a fist clutching the back of her neck. Ieine's jaw was set, her mouth tight; her face was half frightened certainty that she would be skinned alive for manhandling an Aes Sedai, and half determination to hold on no matter what. Nynaeve had that effect on people, sometimes. The Black sister was wide-eyed with terror, sagging so she surely would have fallen except for Ieine's grip. She must have been shielded, certainly, and with equal surety she probably would have chosen being skinned to whatever was going to happen to her. Tears began leaking from her eyes, and her mouth sagged in silent sobs.

bɪhaɪn əm keɪm bɛslən, hu ɡeɪv ə sæd saɪ ət ðə saɪɾ ə neɪlzin ən ə sæɾɝ fəɹ ðə wɪmən, ən ðən hɑɹnən ən θɹi ʌv ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, fɝdʒɪn ən ɡɔɹɾɝən ən mɛtwɪn. θɹi hu hæd bɪn ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ. hɑɹnən ən tu ʌv ði ʌðɝz hæd blʌɾi ɡæʃəz ɪn ðɛɹ koʊts, bʌt nɪneɪiv mʌst əv hild əm bɪloʊ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt muv əz ɪf ðeɪ stɪl hæɾ ɪnʒɝiz. ðeɪ lʊk vɛɹi səbdud, ðoʊ.

Behind them came Beslan, who gave a sad sigh at the sight of Nalesean and a sadder for the women, and then Harnan and three of the Redarms, Fergin and Gorderan and Metwyn. Three who had been at the front of the building. Harnan and two of the others had bloody gashes in their coats, but Nynaeve must have Healed them below. They did not move as if they still had injuries. They looked very subdued, though.

"wʌt hæpən ət ðə bæk?" mæt æskt kwaɪətli.

"What happened at the back?" Mat asked quietly.

"bɝn mi ɪf aɪ noʊ," hɑɹnən ɹɪplaɪd. "wi wɔkt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ə nɑɾ ə ʃoʊldɝθʌmpɝz wɪð naɪvz ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn, muv laɪk ə sneɪk. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə blʌdsteɪn hoʊl ɪn ɪz koʊɾ æbsəntmaɪndɪdli. "wʌn ə ðɛm ɡɑɾ ə naɪf ɪndə mi, ən ðə nɛkst aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz oʊpənɪŋ maɪ aɪz wɪð nɪneɪiv sədaɪ bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ mi ən mɛndɛɹ ən ði ʌðɝz dɛɾ əz jɛstɝdeɪz mʌɾən."

"Burn me if I know," Harnan replied. "We walked right into a knot of shoulderthumpers with knives in the dark. There was one, moved like a snake. . . ." He shrugged, touching the bloodstained hole in his coat absentmindedly. "One of them got a knife into me, and the next I remember is opening my eyes with Nynaeve Sedai bending over me and Mendair and the others dead as yesterday's mutton."

mæt nɑɾəd. wʌn u muv laɪk ə sneɪk. ən ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə ɹumz laɪk wʌn, tu. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. ɹin ən tæmɑɹlə wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fit - stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz, ʌv kɔɹs - ən veɪnɪn, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum wɛɹ ɪleɪn wɑz əpɛɹənli tʃɹaɪɪŋ aʊt səm mɔɹ kɝsɪz, simɪŋli wɪð noʊ mɔɹ səksɛs ðən ɝliɝ. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl kəz ə ðə kɑfɪŋ. nɪneɪiv stʊd, hɛlpɪŋ ʌp sɪbɛlə, ə skɹɔni jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən, ən sumeɪkoʊ wɑz stɪl wɝkɪŋ ɑn feɪmɛl, wɪð əɹ peɪl-hʌni hɛɹ ən bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz. bʌɾ i wɑz nɛvɝ gɑnə ædmaɪɹ məlɹz bʊzəm əɡɛn; ɹin nɛl tə stʃɹeɪɾən əɹ lɪmz ən kloʊs əɹ aɪz, waɪl tæmɑɹlə pɝfɔɹm ðə seɪm sɝvəs fəɹ dʒənɪɹə. tu waɪz wɪmən dɛd, ən sɪks ə hɪz ɹɛdʒɹmz. kɪl baɪ ə . . . mæn . . . ðə paʊɝ wəd nɑt tʌtʃ.

Mat nodded. One who moved like a snake. And got out of rooms like one, too. He looked around the hallway. Reanne and Tamarla were on their feet - straightening their dresses, of course - and Vanin, peering into the room where Elayne was apparently trying out some more curses, seemingly with no more success than earlier. It was hard to tell because of the coughing. Nynaeve stood, helping up Sibella, a scrawny yellow-haired woman, and Sumeko was still working on Famelle, with her pale-honey hair and big brown eyes. But he was never going to admire Melore's bosom again; Reanne knelt to straighten her limbs and close her eyes, while Tamarla performed the same service for Janira. Two Wise Women dead, and six of his Redarms. Killed by a . . . man . . . the Power would not touch.

"aɪv faʊn ɪt!" ɪleɪn ʃaʊɾəd ɪksaɪɾədli. ʃi stʃɹoʊd bæk aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl hoʊldɪŋ ə waɪd ɹaʊn bʌndəl ə ɹɑɾɪd klɔθ ʃi wəd nɑt lɛt veɪnɪn teɪk fɹəm hɝ. koʊɾəd ɪn ɡɹeɪ fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ, ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd leɪn daʊn ən ɹoʊld ɪn ðə dʌst. "wi hæv ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, nɪneɪiv!"

"I've found it!" Elayne shouted excitedly. She strode back out into the hall holding a wide round bundle of rotted cloth she would not let Vanin take from her. Coated in gray from head to toe, she looked as if she had lain down and rolled in the dust. "We have the Bowl of the Winds, Nynaeve!"

"ɪn ðət keɪs," mæt ənaʊnst, "wi ɑɹ blʌɾi wɛl ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ naʊ." noʊbɑdi ɑɹɡjud. oʊ, nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɔl ðə mɛn meɪkɪŋ sæks aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ dʒækɪts fəɹ θɪŋz ðeɪ ɹuɾəd aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum - ðeɪ ivən loʊɾəd ðə waɪz wɪmən daʊn, ən ðɛmsɛlvz - ən ɹin hæd tə ɡoʊ daʊn ən ɹəkɹut mɛn tə kæɹi ðɛɹ dɛd daʊn ðə boʊt lændɪŋ, bʌt noʊbɑdi ɑɹɡjud. hi daʊɾɪd ɪf ðə ɹæhəd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin əz ɑɾ ə pɹəsɛʃən əz meɪɾ ɪts weɪ tə ðə ɹɪvɝ, əɹ wʌn ðət muv mɔɹ kwɪkli.

"In that case," Mat announced, "we are bloody well getting out of here now." Nobody argued. Oh, Nynaeve and Elayne insisted on all the men making sacks out of their jackets for things they rooted out of the room - they even loaded the Wise Women down, and themselves - and Reanne had to go down and recruit men to carry their dead down the boat landing, but nobody argued. He doubted if the Rahad had ever seen as odd a procession as made its way to the river, or one that moved more quickly.

pɹɑməsəz tə kip


Promises to Keep

wəɹ blʌɾi wɛl ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ naʊ," mæt sɛɾ əɡɛn leɪɾɝ, ən ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmənt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɑɹɡjəmən fəɹ ðə pæs hæf-aʊɝ, nɪɹ ɪnʌf. aʊtsaɪd, ðə sʌn wɑz pæst ɪts nun pik. ðə tʃɹeɪd wɪnz kʌt ðə hiɾ ə lɪɾəl; stɪf jɛloʊ kɝɾənz fæsən oʊvɝ ðə tɔl wɪndoʊz bʌlʒd ən snæpt ət ɡʌsts. θɹi aʊɝz bæk ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, ðə daɪs stɪl baʊnsɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən i wɑntəd tə kɪk sʌmθɪŋ. əɹ sʌmbɑɾi. hi tʌɡd ət ðə skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk; ɪt fɛlt əz ðoʊ ðə ɹoʊp ðət hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðə skɑɹ ʌndɝ ðət skɑɹf wɑz bæk ən taɪɾənɪŋ sloʊli. "lʌv ə ðə laɪt, ɑɹ jə ɔl blaɪnd? əɹ dʒʌs dɛf?"

We are bloody well getting out of here now," Mat said again later, and this time there was argument. There had been argument for the past half-hour, near enough. Outside, the sun was past its noon peak. The trade winds cut the heat a little; stiff yellow curtains fastened over the tall windows bulged and snapped at gusts. Three hours back in the Tarasin Palace, the dice still bouncing in his head, and he wanted to kick something. Or somebody. He tugged at the scarf tied around his neck; it felt as though the rope that had given him the scar under that scarf was back and tightening slowly. "Love of the Light, are you all blind? Or just deaf?"

ðə ɹum taɪlɪn hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd wɑz lɑɹdʒ, wɪð ɡɹin wɔlz ən haɪ blu silɪŋ, ən noʊ fɝnɪʃɪŋz bʌt ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹz ən smɔl teɪbəlz sɛt wɪð pɝlʃɛl, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz kɹaʊɾəd ivən soʊ. ɪt sim soʊ, ɛniweɪ. taɪlɪn hɝsɛlf sæt bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðə θɹi mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪsəz wɪð əɹ niz kɹɔst, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪð ðoʊz dɑɹk iɡəlz aɪz ən ə smɔl smaɪl, aɪdli kɪkɪŋ əɹ leɪɝd blu ən jɛloʊ pɛɾikoʊts, aɪdli tɔɪɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒuəl hɪlt ə hɝ kɝv naɪf. hi səspɛktəɾ ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv hæd spoʊkən tə hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, tu, siɾəd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kwin, sʌmhaʊ ɪn klin dʒɹɛsəz ən əpɛɹənli ivən beɪðd, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli bɪn aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt fəɹ mɪnəts əɾ ə stʃɹɛtʃ sɪns ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə pæləs. ðeɪ ɔlmoʊs mætʃt taɪlɪn fəɹ ɹiɡəl dɪɡnəɾi ɪn ðɛɹ bɹaɪt sɪlks; hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ u ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɪmpɹɛs, wɪð ɔl ðət leɪs ən ɪlæbɹəɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ðeɪ lʊkt ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə ɹɔɪəl bɔl, nɑɾ ə dʒɝni. hi hɪmsɛlf wɑz stɪl ɪn ɪz mʌk, wɪð ɪz dʌsti ɡɹin koʊt hæŋɪŋ oʊpən ən ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd kɑɾ ɪn ðə nɛk ə hɪz hæf-əndʌn ʃɝt. nɑɾɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹd hæd ʃɔɹɾənd ɪt, bʌɾ i wɑntəd ðə mədæljən tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz skɪn. hi wɑz ɝaʊnd wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl, æftɝ ɔl.

The room Tylin had provided was large, with green walls and high blue ceiling, and no furnishings but gilded chairs and small tables set with pearlshell, yet it was crowded even so. It seemed so, anyway. Tylin herself sat before one of the three marble fireplaces with her knees crossed, watching him with those dark eagle's eyes and a small smile, idly kicking her layered blue and yellow petticoats, idly toying with the jeweled hilt of her curved knife. He suspected Elayne or Nynaeve had spoken to her. They were there, too, seated to either side of the Queen, somehow in clean dresses and apparently even bathed, though they had only been out of his sight for minutes at a stretch since returning to the palace. They almost matched Tylin for regal dignity in their bright silks; he was not sure who they wanted to impress, with all that lace and elaborate embroidery. They looked ready for a royal ball, not a journey. He himself was still in his muck, with his dusty green coat hanging open and the silver foxhead caught in the neck of his half-undone shirt. Knotting the leather cord had shortened it, but he wanted the medallion touching his skin. He was around women who could channel, after all.

tʃɹuθ, ðoʊz θɹi wɪmən kəd pɹɑbli hæv kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹum baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. taɪlɪn cʊɾə dʌn ɪt baɪ hɝsɛlf, soʊ fɑɹ əz i wɑz kənsɝnd; ɪf nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn hæd spoʊkən tə hɝ, ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd θɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ. ðeɪ θɹi cʊɾə dʌn ɪɾ əloʊn, bʌt. . . .

Truth, those three women could probably have crowded the room by themselves. Tylin could have done it by herself, so far as he was concerned; if Nynaeve or Elayne had spoken to her, it was a very good thing that he was going. They three could have done it alone, but. . . .

"ðɪs ɪz pɹɪpɑstɝəs," mɛɝɪlɪl ənaʊnst. "aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni ʃæɾoʊzpɔn kɔld ə ɡoʊləm. hæv ɛni ʌv ju?" ðət wɑz dɝɛktəd tə æɾɪliz ən vændin, sɝaɪðə ən kɛɝin. feɪsɪŋ taɪlɪn, ðə kul-aɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi ʌv ɔl faɪv meɪɾ ə fɛɹ dʒɑb ə tɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ haɪ-bækt ɑɹmtʃɛɹz ɪndə θɹoʊnz. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn dʒʌst sæt laɪk lʌmps, kuli sɝin tu, bʌɾ æbsəlutli saɪlənt. ðeɪ nu, ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd, ən fəɹ səm ɹizən, mɛɝɪlɪl ən ðət lɑt slæðɝd ðɛɹ tʌŋz wɪð miknəs fəɹ ðɛm, naʊ. mæt kɔθən, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, wɑz ə hɛɹi-ɪɹd laʊɾ u niɾəd tə bi kɪkt, ən fɹəm mɛɝɪlɪl ɑn daʊn, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɹɛɾi tə də ðə kɪkɪŋ.

"This is preposterous," Merilille announced. "I've never heard of any Shadowspawn called a gholam. Have any of you?" That was directed to Adeleas and Vandene, Sareitha and Careane. Facing Tylin, the cool-eyed Aes Sedai serenity of all five made a fair job of turning their high-backed armchairs into thrones. He could not understand why Nynaeve and Elayne just sat like lumps, coolly serene too, but absolutely silent. They knew, they understood, and for some reason, Merilille and that lot slathered their tongues with meekness for them, now. Mat Cauthon, on the other hand, was a hairy-eared lout who needed to be kicked, and from Merilille on down, they were all ready to do the kicking.

"aɪ sɔ ðə θɪŋ," hi snæpt, "ɪleɪn sɔ ðə θɪŋ, ɹin ən ðə waɪz wɪmən sɔ ɪt. æsk ɛni ʌv ðɛm!"

"I saw the thing," he snapped, "Elayne saw the thing, Reanne and the Wise Women saw it. Ask any of them!"
