ɡæðɝɾ ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə ɹum, ɹin ən ðə faɪv sɝvaɪvɪŋ waɪz wɪmən ʃɹæŋk bæk laɪk hʌɾəlɪŋ hɛnz, əfɹeɪɾ ʌv æktʃəwəl kwɛstʃənz. ɔl bʌt sumeɪkoʊ, ɛniweɪ; θʌmz tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ lɔŋ ɹɛd bɛlt, ðə ɹaʊnd wʊmən kɛp fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðən ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ðən ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. nɪneɪiv hæd hæɾ ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl tɔk wɪð əɹ ɪn ðə pɹaɪvəsi ʌv ðə kæbən ɑn ðə boʊt kʌmɪŋ bæk, ən mæt θɔt ðət hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð əɹ nufaʊn æɾətud. hi hæd kɑt mɛnʃən ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ mɔɹ ðən wʌns; nɑt ðəɾ i hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ivzdʒɹɑp. ðə ɹɛst sim tə bi wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ ʃəɾ ɔfɝ tə fɛtʃ ti. oʊnli sumeɪkoʊ hæɾ ivən əpɪɹd tə kənsɪɾɝ ði ɔfɝ ʌv ə tʃɛɹ. sɪbɛlə, flæpɪŋ boʊni ɑɹmz ɪn ʃɑk, hæd nɪɹli feɪntɪd.

Gathered at one end of the room, Reanne and the five surviving Wise Women shrank back like huddling hens, afraid of actual questions. All but Sumeko, anyway; thumbs tucked behind her long red belt, the round woman kept frowning at the Aes Sedai, then shaking her head, frowning, then shaking her head. Nynaeve had had a considerable talk with her in the privacy of the cabin on the boat coming back, and Mat thought that had something to do with her newfound attitude. He had caught mention of Aes Sedai more than once; not that he had been trying to eavesdrop. The rest seemed to be wondering whether they should offer to fetch tea. Only Sumeko had even appeared to consider the offer of a chair. Sibella, flapping bony arms in shock, had nearly fainted.

"noʊ wʌn dɪnaɪz ðə wɝɾ ʌv ɪleɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, mæstɝ kɔθən," sɛd ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn blu stɑɹ ɪn ə kul dip vɔɪs. ivən hæd ðə dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən ɪn sɪlks tə mætʃ ðə ɹɛd-ænd-jɛloʊ flɔɹ taɪlz nɑt bɪn neɪm tə hɪm ɝliɝ, ði oʊl mɛmɹiz mɛʃt ɪndə hɪz oʊn wʊɾə aɪdɛntəfaɪɾ əɹ əz wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps baɪ ðə tɛn fæt ɡoʊld ɹɪŋz ɪn əɹ ɝloʊbz, ðoʊz ɪn itʃ ɪɹ kənɛktəd baɪ ə ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn ən hæf-hɪɾən baɪ ðə nɛɹoʊ wɪŋz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əɹ stʃɹeɪt blæk hɛɹ. ðə mədæljənz klʌstɝɾ əlɔŋ ðə faɪnɝ tʃeɪn ðət ɹæn tə hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋ wəd tɛl ɪm wʌt klæn ʃi keɪm fɹəm əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. soʊ wəd ðə tætuz ɑn əɹ slɪm dɑɹk hænz. "wʌt wi kwɛstʃən ɪz ðə deɪnʒɝ," ʃi kəntɪnjud. "wi də nɑt laɪk livɪŋ ðə wɔɾɝ wɪθaʊt ɡʊd kɑz."

"No one denies the word of Elayne Aes Sedai, Master Cauthon," said Renaile din Calon Blue Star in a cool deep voice. Even had the dignified woman in silks to match the red-and-yellow floor tiles not been named to him earlier, the old memories meshed into his own would have identified her as Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships by the ten fat gold rings in her earlobes, those in each ear connected by a golden chain and half-hidden by the narrow wings of white in her straight black hair. The medallions clustered along the finer chain that ran to her nose ring would tell him what clan she came from among other things. So would the tattoos on her slim dark hands. "What we question is the danger," she continued. "We do not like leaving the water without good cause."

nɪɹli twɛnti si foʊk wɪmən stʊd ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ, ə ɹaɪəɾ ə kʌlɝfəl sɪlks ən ɪɹɪŋz ən mədæljənz ɑn tʃeɪnz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. ðə fɝst ɑd θɪŋ i hæd noʊɾəst əbaʊɾ əm wɑz ðɛɹ æɾətud təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ pɝfəkli ɹɪspɛkfəl, ɑn ðə sɝfəs əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ sin ɛniwʌn lʊk əɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ smʌɡli. ðə sɛkən ɑd θɪŋ keɪm fɹəm ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz; hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊt ðə si foʊk fɹəm ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪnʌf. ɛvɹi æθɑn maɪɹ, mæn əɹ wʊmən, bɪɡæn əz ðə loʊəs dɛkhænd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ dɛstɪnd wʌn deɪ tə bɪkʌm ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz əɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps hɝsɛlf, ən ɛvɹi stɛp ə ðə weɪ bɪtwin, ðə si foʊk wɝ stɪklɝz fəɹ ɹæŋk tə meɪk ɛni kɪŋ əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊk ə sloʊvən. ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn ɹɪneɪl wɝ ə pəkjuljɝ lɑt baɪ ɛni mɛʒɝ - wɪndfɪndɝz tə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz ɹʌbɪŋ ʃoʊldɝz wɪð wɪndfɪndɝz fɹəm sɔɹɝz, baɪ ðɛɹ mədæljənz - bʌt tu wɔɹ bɹaɪt blaʊsəz ə pleɪn wʊl əbʌv ðə dɑɹk ɔɪli bɹitʃɪz ə dɛk-hænz, itʃ wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl θɪn ɹɪŋ ɪn əɹ lɛft ɪɹ. ə sɛkən ən θɝd ɹɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹaɪɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ tʃɹeɪn əz wɪndfɪndɝz, bʌt wɪð tu mɔɹ tə ɝn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə noʊz ɹɪŋ, ɪt wəd bi ə lɔŋ waɪl jɛt ðəɾ iðɝ wəd faɪn hɝsɛlf kɔl tə hɔl seɪl wɛnɛvɝ ðə dɛkmæstɝ niɾəd hɝ, ən faɪn ðə dɛkmæstɝz fleɪl əkɹɔs əɹ ɹʌmp ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt muv kwɪkli ɪnʌf. ðoʊz tu dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ ɪn ðɪs ɡæðɝɪŋ baɪ ɛni mɛmɹi hi hæd; nɔɹməli, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps wəd nɑɾ ivən əv spoʊkən tə wʌn ə ðɛm.

Nearly twenty Sea Folk women stood gathered behind her chair, a riot of colorful silks and earrings and medallions on chains for the most part. The first odd thing he had noticed about them was their attitude toward the Aes Sedai. They were perfectly respectful, on the surface at any rate, but he had never before seen anyone look at Aes Sedai smugly. The second odd thing came from those other men's memories; he did not know a great deal about the Sea Folk from them, but enough. Every Atha'an Miere, man or woman, began as the lowest deckhand whether they were destined one day to become the Master of the Blades or the Mistress of the Ships herself, and every step of the way between, the Sea Folk were sticklers for rank to make any king or Aes Sedai look a sloven. The women behind Renaile were a peculiar lot by any measure - Windfinders to Wavemistresses rubbing shoulders with Windfinders from soarers, by their medallions - but two wore bright blouses of plain wool above the dark oily breeches of deck-hands, each with a single thin ring in her left ear. A second and third ring in the right indicated they were being trained as Windfinders, but with two more to earn, not to mention the nose ring, it would be a long while yet that either would find herself called to haul sail whenever the deckmaster needed her, and find the deckmaster's flail across her rump if she did not move quickly enough. Those two did not belong in this gathering by any memory he had; normally, the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships would not even have spoken to one of them.

"vɛɹi mʌtʃ əz aɪ sɛd, ɹɪneɪl," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛd, aɪsɪli kɑndɪsɛndɪŋ. ʃi hæd sɝɾənli noʊɾəst ðoʊz smʌɡ ɡlænsɪz. ðət toʊn dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ əz ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən tə hɪm. "du nɑt ɡɹoʊ pɛtʃələnt, mæstɝ kɔθən. wəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə lɪsən tə ɹizən. ɪf juv ɛni."

"Very much as I said, Renaile," Merilille said, icily condescending. She had certainly noticed those smug glances. That tone did not change as she shifted her attention to him. "Do not grow petulant, Master Cauthon. We are willing to listen to reason. If you have any."

mæt ɡæðɝd peɪʃəns; hi hoʊpt i kəd faɪn ɪnʌf. meɪbi ɪf i juz boʊθ hænz ən boʊθ fit. "ɡoʊləm wɝ kɹieɪɾəd ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ, dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz," hi bɪɡæn fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv wʌt bɝdʒɪt hæd toʊl hɪm. hi tɝnd, feɪsɪŋ itʃ ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən əz i spoʊk. bɝn ɪm ɪf i wɑz gɑnə lɛt wʌn bʌntʃ θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. əɹ ðəɾ i wɑz blʌɾi pliɾɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. ɪspɛʃli sɪns i wɑz. "ðeɪ wɝ meɪd tə əsæsəneɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən. tə kɪl pipəl u kəd tʃænəl. ðə wʌn paʊɝ woʊn hɛlp ju; ðə paʊɝ woʊn tʌtʃ ə ɡoʊləm. ɪn fækt, ðeɪ kən sɛns ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl, ɪf ðəɹ wɪðɪn, seɪ, fɪfti peɪsɪz ə ju. ðeɪ kən fil ðə paʊɝ ɪn ju, tu. jə woʊnt noʊ ðə ɡoʊləm əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt. ðeɪ lʊk dʒʌs laɪk ɛnibəɾi ɛls. ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd. ɪnsaɪd. . . . ɡoʊləm əv noʊ boʊnz; ðeɪ kən skwiz ðɛmsɛlvz ʌndɝ ə dɔɹ. ən ðəɹ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪp ə dɔɹ ɔf stil hɪnʒɪz wɪð wʌn hænd." əɹ ɹɪp aʊɾ ə θɹoʊt. laɪt, hi ʃʊɾə lɛt neɪlzin steɪ ɪn bɛd.

Mat gathered patience; he hoped he could find enough. Maybe if he used both hands and both feet. "Gholam were created in the middle of the War of the Power, during the Age of Legends," he began from the beginning. Almost from the beginning of what Birgitte had told him. He turned, facing each group of women as he spoke. Burn him if he was going to let one bunch think they were more important. Or that he was bloody pleading with them. Especially since he was. "They were made to assassinate Aes Sedai. No other reason. To kill people who could channel. The One Power won't help you; the Power won't touch a gholam. In fact, they can sense the ability to channel, if they're within, say, fifty paces of you. They can feel the power in you, too. You won't know the gholam until it's too late. They look just like anybody else. On the outside. Inside. . . . Gholam have no bones; they can squeeze themselves under a door. And they're strong enough to rip a door off steel hinges with one hand." Or rip out a throat. Light, he should have let Nalesean stay in bed.

səpɹɛsɪŋ ə ʃɪvɝ, hi pɹɛst ɑn. ðə wɪmən, ɔl ə ðɛm, wɑtʃt hɪm, ɔlmoʊs nɑɾ əpɪɹɪŋ tə blɪŋk. hi wəd nɑt lɛɾ əm si hɪm ʃɪvɝ. "ðɛɹ wɝ oʊnli sɪks ɡoʊləm meɪd - θɹi meɪl ən θɹi fimeɪl; ət list, ðæts wʌt ðeɪ lʊk laɪk. əpɛɹənli ivən ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ ə lɪɾəl ənizi əbaʊt ðɛm. əɹ meɪbi ðeɪ dʒʌs dɪsaɪɾɪd sɪks wɑz ɪnʌf. iðɝ weɪ, wi noʊ wʌn ɪz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, pɹɑbli kɛpt əlaɪv sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪn ə stəsəs-bɑks. wi doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɛni ʌðɝz wɝ pʊɾ ɪndə ðət bɑks, bʌt wʌn ɪz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf. huɛvɝ sɛn ɪm - ən ɪt hæd tə bi wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən - nu tə fɑloʊ əs əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. hi hæd tə hæv bɪn sɛn æftɝ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, ən baɪ wʌɾ i sɛd tə mi, tə kɪl nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn, meɪbi boʊθ." hi spɛɹɾ əm ə kwɪk lʊk, suðɪŋ ən sɪmpəθɛɾɪk; noʊbɑdi kəd fil izi noʊɪŋ ðət θɪŋ wɑz æftɝ ðɛm. ɪn ɹɪtɝn i ɹəsivd ə pʌzəl fɹaʊn fɹəm ɪleɪn, dʒʌs ðə smɔləst ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd, ən fɹəm nɪneɪiv ə slaɪt weɪv ə ðə hænd, ən ɪmpeɪʃənt weɪv, tə ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt.

Suppressing a shiver, he pressed on. The women, all of them, watched him, almost not appearing to blink. He would not let them see him shiver. "There were only six gholam made - three male and three female; at least, that's what they look like. Apparently even the Forsaken were a little uneasy about them. Or maybe they just decided six was enough. Either way, we know one is in Ebou Dar, probably kept alive since the Breaking in a stasis-box. We don't know if any others were put into that box, but one is more than enough. Whoever sent him - and it had to be one of the Forsaken - knew to follow us across the river. He had to have been sent after the Bowl of the Winds, and by what he said to me, to kill Nynaeve or Elayne, maybe both." He spared them a quick look, soothing and sympathetic; nobody could feel easy knowing that thing was after them. In return he received a puzzled frown from Elayne, just the smallest wrinkling of her forehead, and from Nynaeve a slight wave of the hand, an impatient wave, to get on with it.

"tə kəntɪnju," hi sɛd, ʃuɾɪŋ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm ə ɡlɛɹ. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə saɪ, dilɪŋ wɪð wɪmən. "huɛvɝ sɛn ðə ɡoʊləm əz tə noʊ ðə boʊl ɪz hɪɹ ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, naʊ. ɪf hi, əɹ ʃi, sɛnz ðə ɡoʊləm hɪɹ, səm ə jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. meɪbi ə lɑɾ ə ju. aɪ kæn pɹətɛkt ɔl ə jə ət wʌns. meɪbi hɪl ɡɛt ðə boʊl, tu. ən ðæts ɑn tɑp ə fæljən boʊɾə; smɔl tʃæns ʃiz əloʊn, ivən wɪð ɪspæn ə pɹɪznɝ, soʊ ðət minz wɪv ðə blæk ədʒɑ tə wɝi əbaʊt, əz wɛl. dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðə fɔɹseɪkən ən ɡoʊləm ɑɹən ɪnʌf fəɹ ju." ɹin ən ðə waɪz wɪmən dʒɹu ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp ivən mɔɹ ɪndɪɡnənli ðən mɛɝɪlɪl ən əɹ fɹɛnz ət mɛnʃən ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, stɪfənɪŋ ən ɡæðɝɪŋ skɝts, lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə stɔk aʊɾ ɪn ə hʌf. pɹɛs ɑn; ðət wɑz ɔl i kəd du. "naʊ. naʊ dʒju si waɪ jə ɔl əv tə liv ðə pæləs ən teɪk ðə boʊl sʌmwɛɹ ðə ɡoʊləm dʌznt noʊ əbaʊt? sʌmwɛɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ dʌznt noʊ? dʒju si waɪ ɪts tə bi dʌn naʊ?"

"To continue," he said, shooting the pair of them a glare. It was very hard not to sigh, dealing with women. "Whoever sent the gholam has to know the Bowl is here in the Tarasin Palace, now. If he, or she, sends the gholam here, some of you are going to die. Maybe a lot of you. I can't protect all of you at once. Maybe he'll get the Bowl, too. And that's on top of Falion Bhoda; small chance she's alone, even with Ispan a prisoner, so that means we have the Black Ajah to worry about, as well. Just in case the Forsaken and gholam aren't enough for you." Reanne and the Wise Women drew themselves up even more indignantly than Merilille and her friends at mention of the Black Ajah, and the Aes Sedai, stiffening and gathering skirts, looked ready to stalk out in a huff. Press on; that was all he could do. "Now. Now do you see why you all have to leave the palace and take the Bowl somewhere the gholam doesn't know about? Somewhere the Black Ajah doesn't know? Do you see why it has to be done now?"

ɹɪneɪlz snɪf wʊɾə stɑɹɾəld ɡis ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum. "ju mɪɹli ɹɪpit jɝsɛlf, mæstɝ kɔθən. mɛɝɪlɪl sədaɪ sɛz ʃiz nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɪs ɡoʊləm. ɪleɪn sədaɪ sɛz ðəɹ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ mæn, ə kɹitʃɝ, bʌt lɪɾəl ɛls. wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs . . . stəsəs-bɑks? juv nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn ðæt. haʊ dʒju noʊ wʌt jə kleɪm tə noʊ? waɪ ʃəd wi ɡoʊ ɛni fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝ ðən wəɹ ɑn ðə wɝɾ ʌv ə mæn u kɹieɪts feɪbəlz fɹəm ɛɹ?"

Renaile's sniff would have startled geese in the next room. "You merely repeat yourself, Master Cauthon. Merilille Sedai says she has never heard of this gholam. Elayne Sedai says there was a strange man, a creature, but little else. What is this . . . stasis-box? You have not explained that. How do you know what you claim to know? Why should we go any further from the water than we are on the word of a man who creates fables from air?"

mæt lʊk tə nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, ðoʊ wɪð lɪɾəl hoʊp. ɪf ðeɪ wəɾ oʊnli oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz, ðɪs kəd bɪn əv bɪn fɪnɪʃt lɔŋ sɪns, bʌt ðeɪ ɡeɪz bæk ət hɪm, pɹæktəsɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃənləs ɛɛs sədaɪ mæsks tɪl ðɛɹ dʒɔz mʌs bi kɹikɪŋ. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðɛɹ saɪləns. ə bɛɹ-boʊnz əkaʊn ʌv ɪvɛns ɪn ðə ɹæhəd hæd bɪn ɔl ðeɪ ɡeɪv, ən i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə bɛt ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv mɛnʃən ðə blæk ədʒɑ əɾ ɔl hæd ðəɹ bɪn ɛni ʌðɝ weɪ tə ɪkspleɪn ʃoʊɪŋ ʌp ɪn ðə pæləs wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ baʊn ən ʃildɪd. ɪspæn wɑz biɪŋ hɛld ɪn ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæləs, hɝ pɹɛzəns noʊn oʊnli tə ə hændfʊl. nɪneɪiv hæd fɔɹst səm kənkɑkʃən daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt, ə faʊl-smɛlɪŋ mɪks ə ɝbz ðət bʌlʒd ðə wʊmənz aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn ən hæɾ əɹ ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ən stʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ɑkjəpaɪd ðə ɹum wɪð əɹ fəɹ ɡɑɹdz. ənwɪlɪŋ ɡɑɹdz, bʌt vɛɹi əsɪdwəs; nɪneɪiv hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪkstʃɹimli klɪɹ ðət ʃəd ðeɪ lɛɾ ɪspæn ɡɛɾ əweɪ, ðeɪ hæd bɛst stɑɹt ɹʌnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi leɪd hænz ɑn əm əɡɛn.

Mat looked to Nynaeve and Elayne, though with little hope. If they would only open their mouths, this could been have been finished long since, but they gazed back at him, practicing expressionless Aes Sedai masks till their jaws must be creaking. He could not understand their silence. A bare-bones account of events in the Rahad had been all they gave, and he was willing to bet they would not have mentioned the Black Ajah at all had there been any other way to explain showing up in the palace with an Aes Sedai bound and shielded. Ispan was being held in another part of the palace, her presence known only to a handful. Nynaeve had forced some concoction down her throat, a foul-smelling mix of herbs that bulged the woman's eyes going down and had her giggling and stumbling in short order, and the rest of the Knitting Circle occupied the room with her for guards. Unwilling guards, but very assiduous; Nynaeve had made it extremely clear that should they let Ispan get away, they had best start running before she laid hands on them again.

hi vɛɹi kɛɹfəli dɪd nɑt lʊk təwɔɹd bɝdʒɪt, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ wɪð eɪvinhə. ði il wʊmən wɔɹ ən ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs; nɑt ðə pleɪn wʊl ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝn ɪn, bʌɾ ə sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ðət dʒɑɹd wɪð əɹ pleɪn-ʃið hɔɹn-hændəl bɛl naɪf. bɝdʒɪt hæd bɪn kwɪk tə ʃɛɾ əɹ oʊn dʒɹɛs fəɹ əɹ juʒəwəl ʃɔɹt koʊɾ ən waɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz, ðiz dɑɹk blu ən dɑɹk ɡɹin. ə kwɪvɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hʌŋ əɾ əɹ hɪp. ʃi wɑz ðə sɔɹs ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ i nu əbaʊt ɡoʊləm - ən stəsəs-bɑksəz - ɪksɛpt wʌɾ ɪz aɪz hæd sin ɪn ðə ɹæhəd. ən i wəd nɑɾ əv ɹɪvil ðəɾ ɑn ə hɑt ɡɹɪl.

He very carefully did not look toward Birgitte, standing beside the door with Aviendha. The Aiel woman wore an Ebou Dari dress; not the plain wool she had returned in, but a silver-gray silk riding dress that jarred with her plain-sheathed horn-handled belt knife. Birgitte had been quick to shed her own dress for her usual short coat and wide trousers, these dark blue and dark green. A quiver already hung at her hip. She was the source of everything he knew about gholam - and stasis-boxes - except what his eyes had seen in the Rahad. And he would not have revealed that on a hot grill.

"aɪ ɹɛɾ ə bʊk wʌns ðət tɔkt əbaʊt - " hi bɪɡæn, ən ɹɪneɪl kʌɾ ɪm ɔf.

"I read a book once that talked about - " he began, and Renaile cut him off.

"ə bʊk," ʃi snɪɹd. "aɪ wɪl nɑɾ əbændən ðə sɔl fəɹ ə bʊk ɛɛs sədaɪ də nɑt noʊ."

"A book," she sneered. "I will not abandon the salt for a book Aes Sedai do not know."

sʌɾənli ɪt stʃɹʌk mæt ðəɾ i wɑz ði oʊnli mæn pɹɛzənt. læn hæd ɡɔn ɔf ət nɪneɪivz kəmænd, ɡɔn əz teɪmli əz bɛslən hæɾ əɾ ɪz mʌðɝz. tɑm ən dʒulɪn wɝ pækɪŋ tə liv. hæd pɹɑbli fɪnɪʃt pækɪŋ baɪ naʊ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni jus tə ɪt; ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ dɪd liv. ði oʊnli mæn, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə wɔl ʌv wɪmən u əpɛɹənli ɪntɛndəd tə lɛɾ ɪm biɾ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛns ðət wɔl tɪl ɪz bɹeɪnz wɝ skɹæmbəld. ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns. nʌn. ðeɪ lʊkt ət hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ.

Suddenly it struck Mat that he was the only man present. Lan had gone off at Nynaeve's command, gone as tamely as Beslan had at his mother's. Thom and Juilin were packing to leave. Had probably finished packing by now. If there was any use to it; if they ever did leave. The only man, surrounded by a wall of women who apparently intended to let him beat his head against that wall till his brains were scrambled. It made no sense. None. They looked at him, waiting.

nɪneɪiv, ɪn jɛloʊ-slæʃt leɪs-tʃɹɪm blu, hæd pʊld əɹ bɹeɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ soʊ ɪt hʌŋ daʊn bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts, bʌt ðət hɛvi ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ - lænz ɹɪŋ, hi hæd lɝnd - wɑz kɛɹfəli pəzɪʃən tə ʃoʊ ɛniweɪ. hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð, ən əɹ hænz ɹɛstəɾ ɪn əɹ læp, jɛt səmtaɪmz əɹ fɪŋɡɝz twɪtʃt. ɪleɪn, ɪn ɡɹin ɛbu dɑɹi sɪlk ðət meɪd nɪneɪiv sim kʌvɝɾ ʌp dɪspaɪt ðə smoʊki leɪs kɑlɝ ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn, ɡeɪz bæk əɾ ɪm wɪð aɪz laɪk kul pulz ə dip blu wɔɾɝ. hɝ hænz leɪ ɪn əɹ læp tu, bʌt naʊ ən əɡɛn ʃi wəd bɪɡɪn tə tʃɹeɪs ðə θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ðət kʌvɝɾ əɹ skɝts, ðən ɪmiɾiətli stɑp. waɪ dɪd ðeɪ nɑt seɪ sʌmθɪŋ? wɝ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt bæk ət hɪm? wɑz ɪt dʒʌst ə keɪs ʌv "mæt wɑns tə bi ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ soʊ mʌtʃ, lɛɾ ɪm si haʊ wɛl i kən də wɪθaʊɾ ʌs"? hi maɪɾ əv bɪlivd ɪɾ ə nɪneɪiv, ɛni taɪm bʌt ðɪs ɛniweɪ, bʌt nɑɾ ʌv ɪleɪn, nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ. soʊ waɪ?

Nynaeve, in yellow-slashed lace-trimmed blue, had pulled her braid over her shoulder so it hung down between her breasts, but that heavy gold ring - Lan's ring, he had learned - was carefully positioned to show anyway. Her face was smooth, and her hands rested in her lap, yet sometimes her fingers twitched. Elayne, in green Ebou Dari silk that made Nynaeve seem covered up despite the smoky lace collar under her chin, gazed back at him with eyes like cool pools of deep blue water. Her hands lay in her lap too, but now and again she would begin to trace the thread-of-gold embroidery that covered her skirts, then immediately stop. Why did they not say something? Were they trying to get back at him? Was it just a case of "Mat wants to be in charge so much, let him see how well he can do without us"? He might have believed it of Nynaeve, any time but this anyway, but not of Elayne, not anymore. So why?

ɹin ən ðə waɪz wɪmən dɪd nɑt hʌɾəl əweɪ fɹəm ɪm əz ðeɪ dɪd fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðɛɹ mænɝ təwɔɹɾ ɪm hæd tʃeɪnʒd. tæmɑɹlə ɡeɪv ɪm ə disənli ɹɪspɛkfəl nɑd. hʌni-hɛɹd feɪmɛl wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz ə fɹɛnli smaɪl. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɹin blʌʃt, ə peɪl steɪn. bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kaʊn əz ɑpəzɪʃən, ɹɪli. ðə sɪks wɪmən hæd nɑt sɛɾ ə dʌzən ʌnpɹmptəd wɝdz bɪtwin əm sɪns ɛntɝɪŋ ðɪs ɹum. ɛvɹi wʌn wəd dʒʌmp ɪf nɪneɪiv əɹ ɪleɪn snæpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ən kip dʒʌmpɪŋ əntɪl toʊl tə stɑp.

Reanne and the Wise Women did not huddle away from him as they did from the Aes Sedai, but their manner toward him had changed. Tamarla gave him a decently respectful nod. Honey-haired Famelle went so far as a friendly smile. Strangely, Reanne blushed, a pale stain. But they did not count as opposition, really. The six women had not said a dozen unprompted words between them since entering this room. Every one would jump if Nynaeve or Elayne snapped her fingers, and keep jumping until told to stop.

hi tɝn tə ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. feɪsəz ɪnfənətli kɑm, ɪnfənətli peɪʃənt. ɪksɛpt. . . . mɛɝɪlɪlz aɪz flɪkɝd pæst ɪm təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn fəɹ wʌn ɪnstənt. sɝaɪðə bɪɡæn sloʊli smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts ʌndɝ ɪz ɡeɪz, simɪŋli ʌnəwɛɹ ə duɪŋ soʊ. ə dɑɹk səspɪʃən blumd ɪn ɪz maɪnd. hænz muvɪŋ ɑn skɝts. ɹinz blʌʃ. bɝdʒɪts ɹɛɾi kwɪvɝ. ə mɝki səspɪʃən. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli noʊ ʌv wʌt. dʒʌs ðəɾ i hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ. hi ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə stɝn lʊk, ən ɪleɪn ə stɝnɝ. bʌɾɝ wəd nɑɾ əv mɛltəɾ ɑn ðɛɹ blʌɾi tʌŋz.

He turned to the rest of the Aes Sedai. Faces infinitely calm, infinitely patient. Except. . . . Merilille's eyes flickered past him toward Nynaeve and Elayne for one instant. Sareitha began slowly smoothing her skirts under his gaze, seemingly unaware of doing so. A dark suspicion bloomed in his mind. Hands moving on skirts. Reanne's blush. Birgitte's ready quiver. A murky suspicion. He did not really know of what. Just that he had been going about this the wrong way. He gave Nynaeve a stern look, and Elayne a sterner. Butter would not have melted on their bloody tongues.

sloʊli hi wɔk təwɔɹd ðə si foʊk. hi dʒʌst wɔkt, bʌɾ i hɝd sʌmwʌn wɪð mɛɝɪlɪl snɪf, ən sɝaɪðə mʌɾɝd, "sʌtʃ ɪnsələns!" wɛl, hi wɑz əbaʊt tə ʃoʊ ðɛm ɪnsələns. ɪf nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt, ðeɪ ʃʊɾə teɪkən ɪm ɪndə ðɛɹ kɑnfəɾəns. laɪt, bʌɾ i heɪɾəd biɪŋ juzd. ɪspɛʃli wən i dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ, əɹ waɪ.

Slowly he walked toward the Sea Folk. He just walked, but he heard someone with Merilille sniff, and Sareitha muttered, "Such insolence!" Well, he was about to show them insolence. If Nynaeve and Elayne did not like it, they should have taken him into their confidence. Light, but he hated being used. Especially when he did not know how, or why.

stɑpɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹɪneɪlz tʃɛɹ, hi stʌɾid ðə dɑɹk feɪsəz ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪmən bɪhaɪn ɪt bɪfɔɹ lʊkɪŋ daʊn tə hɝ. ʃi fɹaʊnd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ə naɪf sɛt wɪð munstoʊnz θɹʌs bɪhaɪn əɹ sæʃ. ʃi wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən ɹæðɝ ðən pɹɪɾi, sʌmwɛɹ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, ən ʌndɝ dɪfɹən sɝkəmstænsəz i maɪɾ əv ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ aɪz. ðeɪ wɝ lɑɹdʒ blæk pulz ə mæn kəd spɛn ən ivnɪŋ dʒʌst ɡeɪzɪŋ ɪntu. ʌndɝ dɪfɹən sɝkəmstænsəz. sʌmhaʊ, ðə si foʊk wɝ ðə flaɪ ɪn ðə kɹim pɪtʃɝ, ən i hæd nɑɾ ə klu haʊ tə plʌk ɪɾ aʊt. hi mænədʒ tə kip ɪz ɪɹɪteɪʃən ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. bɛɹli. wʌt tə blʌɾi du?

Stopping in front of Renaile's chair, he studied the dark faces of the Atha'an Miere women behind it before looking down to her. She frowned, stroking a knife set with moonstones thrust behind her sash. She was a handsome woman rather than pretty, somewhere in her middle years, and under different circumstances he might have enjoyed looking at her eyes. They were large black pools a man could spend an evening just gazing into. Under different circumstances. Somehow, the Sea Folk were the fly in the cream pitcher, and he had not a clue how to pluck it out. He managed to keep his irritation under control. Barely. What to bloody do?

"ju kən ɔl tʃænəl, aɪ ʌndɝstænd," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, "bʌt ðət dʌzn min mʌtʃ tə mi." əz wɛl bi stʃɹeɪt fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. "ju kən æsk æɾɪliz əɹ vændin haʊ mʌtʃ aɪ kɛɹ wɛðɝ ə wʊmən kən tʃænəl."

"You can all channel, I understand," he said quietly, "but that doesn't mean much to me." As well be straight from the start. "You can ask Adeleas or Vandene how much I care whether a woman can channel."

ɹɪneɪl lʊk pæst ɪm təwɔɹd taɪlɪn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt tə ðə kwin ʃi spoʊk. "nɪneɪiv sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "aɪ bɪliv ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɛnʃən ɪn jəɹ bɑɹɡən ə maɪ hævɪŋ tə lɪsən tə ðɪs jʌŋ oʊkəm pɪkɝ. aɪ - "

Renaile looked past him toward Tylin, but it was not to the Queen she spoke. "Nynaeve Sedai," she said dryly, "I believe there was no mention in your bargain of my having to listen to this young oakum picker. I - "

"aɪ doʊn blʌɾi kɛɹ əbaʊt jəɹ bɑɹɡənz wɪð ɛnibəɾi ɛls, jə dɔɾɝ ə ðə sænz," mæt snæpt. soʊ hɪz ɪɹɪteɪʃən wɑz nɑt ðət wɛl ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. ə mæn kəɾ oʊnli teɪk soʊ mʌtʃ.

"I don't bloody care about your bargains with anybody else, you daughter of the sands," Mat snapped. So his irritation was not that well under control. A man could only take so much.

ɡæsps ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn hɝ. sʌmθɪŋ oʊvɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ ə si foʊk wʊmən hæd kɔld ə ʃiəɾən soʊlʒɝ ə sʌn ə ðə sænz dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə plæn ə bleɪɾ ɪn ɪz ɹɪbz; ðə mɛmɹi leɪ tʌkt ɪnsaɪd mæt kɔθənz hɛd, naʊ. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə wɝst ɪnsəlt əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm kloʊs. ɹɪneɪlz feɪs ɡɔɹdʒd wɪð blʌd; hɪsɪŋ, aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ ɪn fjʊɹi, ʃi lɛp tə hɝ fit, ðət munstoʊn-stʌɾɪd dæɡɝ flæʃɪŋ ɪn əɹ fɪst.

Gasps rose among the women behind her. Something over a thousand years ago a Sea Folk woman had called a Shiotan soldier a son of the sands just before trying to plant a blade in his ribs; the memory lay tucked inside Mat Cauthon's head, now. It was not the worst insult among the Atha'an Miere, but it came close. Renaile's face gorged with blood; hissing, eyes bulging in fury, she leaped to her feet, that moonstone-studded dagger flashing in her fist.

mæt snætʃt ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hæn bɪfɔɹ ðə bleɪd kəd ɹitʃ ɪz tʃɛst ən ʃʌvd əɹ bæk ɪndə hɝ tʃɛɹ. hi dɪɾ əv kwɪk hænz. hi kəd stɪl hoʊld ɑn tə hɪz tɛmpɝ, tu. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni wɪmən θɔt ðeɪ kəd dæns ɪm fəɹ ə pʌpət, hi kəd - "ju lɪsən tə mi, jə bɪlʒ stoʊn." ɔl ɹaɪt; meɪbi hi kəd nɑt hoʊld ɪt. "nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn nid ju, əɹ aɪd liv jə fəɹ ðə ɡoʊləm tə kɹæk jəɹ boʊnz ən ðə blæk ədʒɑ tə pɪk oʊvɝ wʌts lɛft. wɛl, əz fɑɹ əz jəɹ kənsɝnd, ɪm ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz, ən maɪ bleɪdz ɑɹ bɛɹ." wʌt ðət mɛn ɪɡzækli, hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə, ɪksɛp fəɹ hævɪŋ wʌns hɝd, "wɛn ðə bleɪdz ɑɹ bɛɹ, ivən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps baʊz tə ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz." "ðɪs ɪz ðə bɑɹɡən bɪtwin jə ən mi. jə ɡoʊ wɛɹ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɑnt, ən ɪn ɹɪtɝn, aɪ woʊn taɪ ðə lɑɾ ə jə əkɹɔs hɔɹsəz laɪk pæksæɾəlz ən hɔl jə ðɛɹ!"

Mat snatched it out of her hand before the blade could reach his chest and shoved her back into her chair. He did have quick hands. He could still hold on to his temper, too. No matter how many women thought they could dance him for a puppet, he could - "You listen to me, you bilge stone." All right; maybe he could not hold it. "Nynaeve and Elayne need you, or I'd leave you for the gholam to crack your bones and the Black Ajah to pick over what's left. Well, as far as you're concerned, I'm the Master of the Blades, and my blades are bare." What that meant exactly, he had no idea, except for having once heard, "When the blades are bare, even the Mistress of the Ships bows to the Master of the Blades." "This is the bargain between you and me. You go where Nynaeve and Elayne want, and in return, I won't tie the lot of you across horses like packsaddles and haul you there!"

ðət wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɡoʊ ɑn, nɑt wɪð ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. nɑt wɪð ə bɪlʒəbɔɪ ɔf ə bɹoʊkən-bæk dɑɹɾɝ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɹɪneɪl kwɪvɝd wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ɪm wɪð əɹ bɛɹ hænz, ən nɛvɝ maɪn əɹ dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz hænd. "ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid, ʌndɝ ðə laɪt!" ʃi ɡɹaʊld. hɝ aɪz nɪɹli stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. hɝ maʊθ wɝkt, kənfjuʒən ən dɪsbɪlif sʌɾənli tʃeɪsɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs. ðɪs taɪm, ðə ɡæsps saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðə wɪn hæd ɹɪp ðə kɝɾənz daʊn.

That was no way to go on, not with the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships. Not with a bilgeboy off a broken-backed darter, for that matter. Renaile quivered with the effort of not going for him with her bare hands, and never mind her dagger in his hand. "It is agreed, under the Light!" she growled. Her eyes nearly started out of her head. Her mouth worked, confusion and disbelief suddenly chasing one another across her face. This time, the gasps sounded as if the wind had ripped the curtains down.

"ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid," mæt sɛd kwɪkli, ən tʌtʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz tə hɪz lɪps, hi pɹɛst əm tə hɝz.

"It is agreed," Mat said quickly, and touching fingers to his lips, he pressed them to hers.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi dɪd ðə seɪm, fɪŋɡɝz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz maʊθ. hi hɛld aʊt ðə dæɡɝ, ən ʃi stɛɹd dʌli əɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪt fɹəm hɪm. ðə bleɪd wɛn bæk ɪndə ɪts dʒuəld ʃiθ. ɪt wɑz nɑt pəlaɪt tə kɪl sʌmwʌn jə hæd sild ə bɑɹɡən wɪð. ət list, nɑɾ əntɪl ðə tɝmz wɝ fʊlfɪld. mɝmɝz bɪɡæn əmʌŋ ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ, ɹaɪzɪŋ, ən ɹɪneɪl stɝd hɝsɛlf tə klæp əɹ hænz wʌns. ðət saɪlənst wɪndfɪndɝz tə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz əz kwɪkli əz ðə tu dɛkhənz ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ.

After a moment, she did the same, fingers trembling against his mouth. He held out the dagger, and she stared dully at it before taking it from him. The blade went back into its jeweled sheath. It was not polite to kill someone you had sealed a bargain with. At least, not until the terms were fulfilled. Murmurs began among the women behind her chair, rising, and Renaile stirred herself to clap her hands once. That silenced Windfinders to Wavemistresses as quickly as the two deckhands in training.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hæv dʒʌs meɪɾ ə bɑɹɡən wɪð ə tɑvɝən," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət kul, dip vɔɪs. ðə wʊmən kəd titʃ ɛɛs sədaɪ haʊ tə pʊl ðɛmsɛlvz təɡɛðɝ kwɪkli. "bʌt wʌn deɪ, mæstɝ kɔθən, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt, aɪ θɪŋk jəl wɔk ə ɹoʊp fəɹ mi."

"I think I have just made a bargain with a ta'veren," she said in that cool, deep voice. The woman could teach Aes Sedai how to pull themselves together quickly. "But one day, Master Cauthon, if it pleases the Light, I think you will walk a rope for me."

hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðət mɛnt, ɪksɛp ðət ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ənplɛzənt. hi meɪɾ ɪz bɛs lɛɡ. "ɔl θɪŋz ɑɹ pɑsəbəl, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt," hi mɝmɝd. kɝɾəsi peɪd, æftɝ ɔl. bʌɾ əɹ smaɪl wɑz dɪstɝbɪŋli hoʊpfəl.

He did not know what that meant, except that she made it sound unpleasant. He made his best leg. "All things are possible, if it pleases the Light," he murmured. Courtesy paid, after all. But her smile was disturbingly hopeful.

wən i tɝn bæk tə ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹum, jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæd hɔɹnz ən wɪŋz, fəɹ ðə stɛɹz. "ɪz ðəɹ ɛni fɝðɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt?" hi æskt ɪn ə ɹaɪ toʊn, ən dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ænsɝz. "aɪ θɔt nɑt. ɪn ðət keɪs, aɪ sədʒɛs jə pɪk aʊt səm spɑt wɛl əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ, ən wi kən bi ɑn əɹ weɪ əz sun əz jə bʌndəl ʌp jəɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz."

When he turned back to the rest of the room, you would have thought he had horns and wings, for the stares. "Is there any further argument?" he asked in a wry tone, and did not wait for answers. "I thought not. In that case, I suggest you pick out some spot well away from here, and we can be on our way as soon as you bundle up your belongings."

ðeɪ meɪɾ ə ʃoʊ ʌv dɪskʌʃən. ɪleɪn mɛnʃən keɪɛmlɪn, saʊndɪŋ ət lis hæf-sɪɹiəs, ən kɛɝin sədʒɛstəd sɛvɹəl ɹɪmoʊt vɪlədʒəz ɪn ðə blæk hɪlz, ɔl izəli ɹitʃt baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ. laɪt, ɛniwɛɹ wɑz izəli ɹitʃt baɪ ɡeɪtweɪ. vændin spoʊk ə ɝæfəl, ən eɪvinhə sədʒɛstəd ɹɪɾiən, ɪn ði il weɪst, wɪð ðə si foʊk wɪmən ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɡlʌmɝ ðə fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə si wɝ ðə pleɪsəz neɪmd. ɔl ə ʃoʊ. tə mæt, ət list, ðət wɑz klɪɹ baɪ nɪneɪivz ɪmpeɪʃən fɪdlɪŋ wɪð əɹ bɹeɪd dɪspaɪt ðə sədʒɛstʃənz kʌmɪŋ hɑɾ ən fæst.

They made a show of discussion. Elayne mentioned Caemlyn, sounding at least half-serious, and Careane suggested several remote villages in the Black Hills, all easily reached by gateway. Light, anywhere was easily reached by gateway. Vandene spoke of Arafel, and Aviendha suggested Rhuidean, in the Aiel Waste, with the Sea Folk women growing glummer the farther from the sea were the places named. All a show. To Mat, at least, that was clear by Nynaeve's impatient fiddling with her braid despite the suggestions coming hot and fast.

"ɪf aɪ meɪ spik, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɹin sɛd tɪmədli ət læst. ʃi ivən ɹeɪzd əɹ hænd. "ðə kɪn meɪnteɪn ə fɑɹm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ə fju maɪlz nɔɹθ. ɛvɹiwʌn noʊz ɪts ə ɹitʃɹit fəɹ wɪmən u nid kɑntəmpleɪʃən ən kwaɪət, bʌt noʊ wʌn kənɛks ɪt tə ʌs. ðə bɪldɪŋz ɑɹ lɑɹdʒ ən kwaɪt kʌmftəɹbəl, ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni nid tə steɪ lɔŋ, ən - "

"If I may speak, Aes Sedai?" Reanne said timidly at last. She even raised her hand. "The Kin maintain a farm on the other side of the river, a few miles north. Everyone knows it is a retreat for women who need contemplation and quiet, but no one connects it to us. The buildings are large and quite comfortable, if there's any need to stay long, and - "

"jɛs," nɪneɪiv bɹoʊk ɪn. "jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk ðət saʊnz dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ. wʌt dʒju seɪ, ɪleɪn?"

"Yes," Nynaeve broke in. "Yes, I think that sounds just the thing. What do you say, Elayne?"

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪt saʊnz wʌndɝfəl, nɪneɪiv. aɪ noʊ ɹɪneɪl wɪl əpɹiʃieɪt steɪɪŋ kloʊs tə ðə si." ði ʌðɝ faɪv sɪstɝz pɹæktəkli paɪld ɑn tɑp ə hɝ seɪɪŋ haʊ əɡɹiəbəl ɪt saʊndəd, haʊ supɪɹiɝ tə ɛni ʌðɝ sədʒɛstʃən.

"I think it sounds wonderful, Nynaeve. I know Renaile will appreciate staying close to the sea." The other five sisters practically piled on top of her saying how agreeable it sounded, how superior to any other suggestion.

mæt ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz tə ðə hɛvənz. taɪlɪn wɑz ə stʌɾi ɪn nɑt siɪŋ wʌt leɪ ʌndɝ əɹ noʊz, bʌt ɹɪneɪl snæpt əɾ ɪt laɪk ə tʃɹaʊt teɪkɪŋ ə leɪsɪŋ. wɪtʃ wɑz ðə pɔɪnt, ʌv kɔɹs. fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃi wɑz nɑt tə noʊ ðət nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn hæd hæɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝeɪnʒd bɪfɔɹhænd. ʃi lɛd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə si foʊk wɪmən aʊt tə ɡæðɝ wʌtɛvɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt bɪfɔɹ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn kəd tʃeɪnʒ ðɛɹ maɪnz.

Mat rolled his eyes to the heavens. Tylin was a study in not seeing what lay under her nose, but Renaile snapped at it like a trout taking a lacewing. Which was the point, of course. For some reason she was not to know that Nynaeve and Elayne had had everything arranged beforehand. She led the rest of the Sea Folk women out to gather whatever belongings they had brought before Nynaeve and Elayne could change their minds.

ðoʊz tu wʊɾə fɑloʊd mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ i kɹʊkəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət ðɛm. ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz - hi wʊɾə hæd tə tɔk ən aʊɝ tə seɪ əz mʌtʃ əz pæst ɪn ðoʊz lʊks - ðɛn, sʌmwʌt tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, keɪm tə hɪm. eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt wɑtʃt fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, taɪlɪn fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ.

Those two would have followed Merilille and the other Aes Sedai, but he crooked a finger at them. They exchanged glances - he would have had to talk an hour to say as much as passed in those looks - then, somewhat to his surprise, came to him. Aviendha and Birgitte watched from the door, Tylin from her chair.

"aɪ æm vɛɹi sɑɹi tə hæv juz ju," ɪleɪn sɛd bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ ə wɝɾ aʊt. hɝ smaɪl flæʃt ðət dɪmpəl ət hɪm. "wi dɪɾ əv ɹizənz, mæt; jə mʌs bɪliv ðæt."

"I am very sorry to have used you," Elayne said before he could get a word out. Her smile flashed that dimple at him. "We did have reasons, Mat; you must believe that."

"wɪtʃ jə də nɑt nid tə noʊ," nɪneɪiv pʊɾ ɪn fɝmli, flɪpɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə pɹæktəs tɔs ə hɝ hɛd ðət meɪd ðə ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ baʊns ɑn əɹ bʊzəm. læn mʌs bi ɪnseɪn. "aɪ mʌst seɪ, aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd jə tə də wʌt jə dɪd. wʌtɛvɝ ɪn ðə wɝl meɪd jə θɪŋk ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bʊli ðɛm? jə cʊɾə ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

"Which you do not need to know," Nynaeve put in firmly, flipping her braid back over her shoulder with a practiced toss of her head that made the gold ring bounce on her bosom. Lan must be insane. "I must say, I never expected you to do what you did. Whatever in the world made you think of trying to bully them? You could have ruined everything."

"wʌts laɪf ɪf jə doʊn teɪk ə tʃæns naʊ ən ðɛn?" hi sɛd blaɪθli. əz wɛl baɪ hɪm ɪf ðeɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz plæn ɪnstɛɾ ə tɛmpɝ. bʌt ðeɪ hæd juzd ɪm əɡɛn wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ hɪm, ən i wɑntəɾ ə bɪt bæk fəɹ ðæt. "nɛks taɪm juv tə meɪk ə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə si foʊk, lemi meɪk ɪt fəɹ ju. meɪbi ðət weɪ, ɪt woʊn tɝn aʊɾ əz bædli əz ðə læst wʌn." spɑts ə kʌlɝ blumɪŋ ɪn nɪneɪivz tʃiks toʊld ɪm i hæd hɪt ðə mɑɹk skwɛɹli. nɑt bæd ʃuɾɪŋ blaɪndfoʊldɪd.

"What's life if you don't take a chance now and then?" he said blithely. As well by him if they thought it was planned instead of temper. But they had used him again without telling him, and he wanted a bit back for that. "Next time you have to make a bargain with the Sea Folk, let me make it for you. Maybe that way, it won't turn out as badly as the last one." Spots of color blooming in Nynaeve's cheeks told him he had hit the mark squarely. Not bad shooting blindfolded.

ɪleɪn, ðoʊ, dʒʌs mɝmɝd "ə moʊst əbzɝvən sʌbʒɪkt" ɪn toʊnz ə ɹufəl əmjuzmənt. biɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɡʊd bʊks maɪt tɝn aʊt lɛs kʌmftəɹbəl ðən biɪŋ ɪn əɹ bæd.

Elayne, though, just murmured "A most observant subject" in tones of rueful amusement. Being in her good books might turn out less comfortable than being in her bad.

ðeɪ swɛp təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ɪm seɪ mɔɹ. wɛl, hi hæd nɑt ɹɪli θɔt ðeɪ wəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɛniθɪŋ. boʊθ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðə boʊn. ə mæn lɝn tə lɪv wɪð wʌɾ i hæd tə.

They swept toward the door without letting him say more. Well, he had not really thought they would explain anything. Both were Aes Sedai to the bone. A man learned to live with what he had to.

taɪlɪn hæɾ ɔl bʌt slɪp fɹəm ɪz maɪnd, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt fɹəm hɝz. ʃi kɑɾ ɪm ʌp bɪfɔɹ i tʊk tu stɛps. nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn pɔzd ət ðə dɔɹ wɪð eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt, wɑtʃɪŋ. soʊ ðeɪ sɔ wən taɪlɪn pɪntʃt ɪz bɑɾəm. səm θɪŋz, noʊbɑdi kəd lɝn tə lɪv wɪð. ɪleɪn pʊɾ ɑn ə feɪs ə kəməzɝeɪʃən, nɪneɪiv ʌv ɡlaʊɝɪŋ dɪsəpɹuvəl. eɪvinhə fɔt læftɝ nʌn tu səksɛsfəli, waɪl bɝdʒɪt wɔɹ əɹ ɡɹɪn oʊpənli. ðeɪ ɔl blʌɾi nu.

Tylin had all but slipped from his mind, but he had not from hers. She caught him up before he took two steps. Nynaeve and Elayne paused at the door with Aviendha and Birgitte, watching. So they saw when Tylin pinched his bottom. Some things, nobody could learn to live with. Elayne put on a face of commiseration, Nynaeve of glowering disapproval. Aviendha fought laughter none too successfully, while Birgitte wore her grin openly. They all bloody knew.

"nɪneɪiv θɪŋks jə ɑɹ ə lɪɾəl bɔɪ niɾɪŋ pɹətɛkʃən," taɪlɪn bɹiðd ʌp ət hɪm. "aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ ə ɡɹoʊn mæn." hɝ smoʊki tʃʌkəl meɪd ðət ðə dɝɾiəst kɑmɛn i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd. ðə fɔɹ wɪmən baɪ ðə dɔɹ ɡɑt tə wɑtʃ ɪz feɪs tɝn bit ɹɛd. "aɪ wɪl mɪs ju, pɪdʒən. wʌt jə dɪd wɪð ɹɪneɪl wɑz mæɡnɪfəsənt. aɪ də soʊ ædmaɪɹ mæstɝfəl mɛn."

"Nynaeve thinks you are a little boy needing protection," Tylin breathed up at him. "I know you are a grown man." Her smoky chuckle made that the dirtiest comment he had ever heard. The four women by the door got to watch his face turn beet red. "I will miss you, pigeon. What you did with Renaile was magnificent. I do so admire masterful men."

"aɪl mɪs ju, tu," hi mʌɾɝd. tə hɪz ʃɑk, ðət wɑz sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ. hi wɑz livɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ dʒʌst ɪn taɪm. "bʌɾ ɪf wi miɾ əɡɛn, əl də ðə tʃeɪsɪŋ."

"I'll miss you, too," he muttered. To his shock, that was simple truth. He was leaving Ebou Dar just in time. "But if we meet again, I'll do the chasing."

ʃi tʃɔɹɾəld ət hɪm, ən ðoʊz dɑɹk iɡəlz aɪz ɔlmoʊst ɡloʊd. "aɪ ædmaɪɹ mæstɝfəl mɛn, dʌklɪŋ. bʌt nɑt wən ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ biɪŋ mæstɝfəl wɪð mi." sizɪŋ ɪz ɪɹz, ʃi pʊld ɪz hɛd daʊn wɛɹ ʃi kəd kɪs hɪm.

She chortled at him, and those dark eagle's eyes almost glowed. "I admire masterful men, duckling. But not when they try being masterful with me." Seizing his ears, she pulled his head down where she could kiss him.

hi nɛvɝ sɔ nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝz ɡoʊ, ən i wɔkt aʊɾ ɑn ənstɛɾi lɛɡz, tʌkɪŋ ɪz ʃɝt bæk ɪn. hi hæd tə ɹɪtɝn tə fɛtʃ ɪz spɪɹ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ, ən ɪz hæt. ðə wʊmən hæd noʊ ʃeɪm. nɑɾ ə skɹæp ʌv ɪt.

He never saw Nynaeve and the others go, and he walked out on unsteady legs, tucking his shirt back in. He had to return to fetch his spear from the corner, and his hat. The woman had no shame. Not a scrap of it.

hi faʊn tɑm ən dʒulɪn, kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, fɑloʊd baɪ nɹɪm ən ləpɪn, neɪlzinz staʊt mæn, hu itʃ lʌɡd ə lɑɹdʒ wɪkɝ pæniɝ meɪd fəɹ ə pæksæɾəl. loʊɾəd wɪð ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz, hi ɹilaɪzd. dʒulɪn kæɹid mæts ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ ən hæɾ ɪz kwɪvɝ slʌŋ ɑn wʌn ʃoʊldɝ. wɛl, ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi wɑz muvɪŋ hɪm.

He found Thom and Juilin, coming out of Tylin's apartments, followed by Nerim and Lopin, Nalesean's stout man, who each lugged a large wicker pannier made for a packsaddle. Loaded with his belongings, he realized. Juilin carried Mat's unstrung bow and had his quiver slung on one shoulder. Well, she had said she was moving him.

"aɪ faʊn ðɪs ɑn jəɹ pɪloʊ," tɑm sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ɪm ðə ɹɪŋ i hæd bɑt wʌt simd ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ. "ə pɑɹɾɪŋ ɡɪft, ɪt simz; ðəɹ wɝ lʌvɝz-nɑts ən səm ʌðɝ flaʊɝz stʃɹun oʊvɝ boʊθ pɪloʊz."

"I found this on your pillow," Thom said, tossing him the ring he had bought what seemed a year ago. "A parting gift, it seems; there were lovers-knots and some other flowers strewn over both pillows."

mæt dʒæm ðə ɹɪŋ ɑntu hɪz fɪŋɡɝ. "ɪts maɪn, bɝn ju. aɪ peɪd fəɹ ɪt maɪsɛlf."

Mat jammed the ring onto his finger. "It's mine, burn you. I paid for it myself."

ði oʊld ɡlimən nʌkəld ɪz mʌstæʃɪz ən kɔft ɪn ə feɪld ɛfɝt tə staɪfəl ə sʌɾən waɪd ɡɹɪn. dʒulɪn snætʃt ɔf ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs tæɹɑbənɝ hæɾ ən bɪkeɪm ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn stʌɾiɪŋ ði ɪnsaɪɾ ʌv ɪt.

The old gleeman knuckled his mustaches and coughed in a failed effort to stifle a sudden wide grin. Juilin snatched off that ridiculous Taraboner hat and became engrossed in studying the inside of it.

"blʌɾ ən fleɪmɪŋ - !" mæt dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ hoʊp jə tu spɛɹɾ ə moʊmən fəɹ jəɹ oʊn bɪlɔŋɪŋz," hi sɛd lɛvəli, "bɪkɔz əz sun əz aɪ ɡɹæb oʊlvɝ, wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ, ivən ɪf wi hæpən tə liv ə moʊldi hɑɹp əɹ ə ɹʌsti sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ bɪhaɪnd." dʒulɪn tʌɡd ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min, bʌt tɑm æktʃəli  fɹaʊnd. ɪnsʌls tə tɑmz fluɾ əɹ ɪz hɑɹp wɝ ɪnsʌls tə hɪmsɛlf.

"Blood and flaming - !" Mat drew a deep breath. "I hope you two spared a moment for your own belongings," he said levelly, "because as soon as I grab Olver, we're on our way, even if we happen to leave a moldy harp or a rusty sword-breaker behind." Juilin tugged at the corner of his eye with one finger, whatever that was supposed to mean, but Thom actually frowned. Insults to Thom's flute or his harp were insults to himself.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ləpɪn sɛd mɔɹnfəli. hi wɑz ə dɑɹk, bɔldɪŋ mæn, ɹaʊndɝ ðən sumeɪkoʊ, ən ɪz blæk tɛɹən kɑmənɝz koʊt, taɪt tə ðə weɪs ðən flɛɹɪŋ, laɪk dʒulɪnz, fɪt vɛɹi taɪtli ɪndid. nɔɹməli ɔlmoʊst əz sɑləm əz nɹɪm, naʊ hi hæd ɹɛɾənd aɪz, əz ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn wipɪŋ. "maɪ lɔɹd, ɪz ðəɹ ɛni tʃæns aɪ maɪt ɹɪmeɪn tə si lɔɹd neɪlzin bɛɹid? hi wɑz ə ɡʊd mæstɝ."

"My Lord," Lopin said mournfully. He was a dark, balding man, rounder than Sumeko, and his black Tairen commoner's coat, tight to the waist then flaring, like Juilin's, fit very tightly indeed. Normally almost as solemn as Nerim, now he had reddened eyes, as though he had been weeping. "My Lord, is there any chance I might remain to see Lord Nalesean buried? He was a good master."

mæt heɪɾəd seɪɪŋ noʊ. "ɛnibəɾi lɛf bɪhaɪn maɪt bi lɛft fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ləpɪn," hi sɛd dʒɛnli. "lɪsən, əl nid sʌmwʌn tə hɛlp lʊk æftɝ oʊlvɝ. nɹɪm əz ɪz hænz fʊl wɪð mi. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, nɹɪm wɪl ɡoʊ bæk tə tælmɑnz, jə noʊ. ɪf jud laɪk, əl teɪk jə ɑn maɪsɛlf." hi hæd ɡɹoʊn juz tə hævɪŋ ə mænsɝvənt, ən ðiz wɝ hɑɹd taɪmz fəɹ ə mæn hʌntɪŋ wɝk.

Mat hated saying no. "Anybody left behind might be left for a long time, Lopin," he said gently. "Listen, I'll need someone to help look after Olver. Nerim has his hands full with me. For that matter, Nerim will go back to Talmanes, you know. If you'd like, I will take you on myself." He had grown used to having a manservant, and these were hard times for a man hunting work.

"aɪ wəd laɪk ðət vɛɹi mʌtʃ, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə fɛloʊ sɛd luɡʌbɹiəsli. "jʌŋ oʊlvɝ ɹimaɪnz mi mʌtʃ ə maɪ jʌŋɡəst sɪstɝz sʌn."

"I would like that very much, my Lord," the fellow said lugubriously. "Young Olver reminds me much of my youngest sister's son."

oʊnli, wən ðeɪ ɛntɝd mæts fɔɹmɝ ɹumz, ðə leɪɾi ɹaɪzɛl wɑz ðɛɹ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ disənli kloʊðd ðən wən i hæd læst sin hɝ, ən kwaɪɾ əloʊn.

Only, when they entered Mat's former rooms, the Lady Riselle was there, much more decently clothed than when he had last seen her, and quite alone.

"waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ hæv kɛpt ɪm taɪd tə mi?" ʃi sɛd, ðət tʃɹuli mɑɹvələs bʊzəm hivɪŋ wɪð ɪmoʊʃən əz ʃi plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. ðə kwinz dʌklɪŋ, ɪt simd, wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə teɪk ə snæpɪʃ toʊn wɪð ðə kwinz ətɛndəns. "klɪp ə bɔɪz wɪŋz tu fɑɹ, ən hɪl nɛvɝ ɡɹoʊ tə ə pɹɑpɝ mæn. hi ɹɛɾ ɪz peɪdʒəz əlaʊd sɪɾɪŋ ɑn maɪ ni - hi maɪɾ əv ɹɛɾ ɔl deɪ, hæɾ aɪ əlaʊɾ ɪt - ən dɪɾ ɪz nʌmbɝz, soʊ aɪ lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ. waɪ ɑɹ jə ɪn sətʃ ə bɑðɝ? hi pɹɑməs tə ɹɪtɝn baɪ sʌnsɛt, ən i simz tə sɛɾ ə ɡɹeɪt stɔɹ baɪ hɪz pɹɑməsəz."

"Why should I have kept him tied to me?" she said, that truly marvelous bosom heaving with emotion as she planted her fists on her hips. The Queen's duckling, it seemed, was not supposed to take a snappish tone with the Queen's attendants. "Clip a boy's wings too far, and he will never grow to a proper man. He read his pages aloud sitting on my knee - he might have read all day, had I allowed it - and did his numbers, so I let him go. Why are you in such a bother? He promised to return by sunset, and he seems to set a great store by his promises."

pɹɑpɪŋ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ɪn ɪts oʊl kɔɹnɝ, mæt toʊl ði ʌðɝ mɛn tə dʒɹɑp ðɛɹ bɝɾənz ən ɡoʊ faɪn veɪnɪn ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɹɛdʒɹmz. ðən i lɛft ɹaɪzɛlz spɛktækjəlɝ bʊzəm ən ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə ɹumz nɪneɪiv ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ʃɛɹd. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ən soʊ wɑz læn, wɪð ɪz wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹeɪp daʊn ɪz bæk ən sæɾəlbæɡz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, ən nɪneɪivz, ɪt simd. ə ɡʊd mɛni bʌndəlz ə dʒɹɛsəz ən nɑt-soʊ-smɔl tʃɛsts stʊɾ əbaʊt ðə flɔɹ. mæt wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ wəd meɪk læn kæɹi ðoʊz, tu.

Propping the ashandarei in its old corner, Mat told the other men to drop their burdens and go find Vanin and the remaining Redarms. Then he left Riselle's spectacular bosom and ran all the way to the rooms Nynaeve and the other women shared. They were all there, in the sitting room, and so was Lan, with his Warder's cloak already draped down his back and saddlebags on his shoulders. His saddlebags, and Nynaeve's, it seemed. A good many bundles of dresses and not-so-small chests stood about the floor. Mat wondered if they would make Lan carry those, too.

"ʌv kɔɹs juv tə ɡoʊ faɪn hɪm, mæt kɔθən," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "du jə θɪŋk wi wəd dʒʌst əbændən ðə tʃaɪld?" tə hɪɹ hɝ, jə wʊɾə θɔt ðət wɑz ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i hæɾ ɪntɛndəd.

"Of course you have to go find him, Mat Cauthon," Nynaeve said. "Do you think we would just abandon the child?" To hear her, you would have thought that was exactly what he had intended.

sʌɾənli hi wɑz dɛljudʒd wɪð ɔfɝz ə hɛlp, nɑt dʒʌs nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn pɹəpoʊzɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɔf ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə fɑɹm, bʌt læn ən bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə ɔfɝɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðə sɝtʃ. læn wɑz stoʊn koʊld əbaʊɾ ɪt, ɡɹɪm əz ɛvɝ, bʌt bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə. . . .

Suddenly he was deluged with offers of help, not just Nynaeve and Elayne proposing to put off going to the farm, but Lan and Birgitte and Aviendha offering to join the search. Lan was stone cold about it, grim as ever, but Birgitte and Aviendha. . . .

"maɪ hɑɹt wəd bɹeɪk ɪf ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə ðət bɔɪ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd, ən eɪvinhə æɾəd, dʒʌst əz wɔɹmli, "aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz sɛd jə də nɑt kɛɹ fəɹ ɪm pɹɑpɝli." mæt ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ. ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə ðə sɪɾi, oʊlvɝ maɪt wɛl ɪluɾ eɪt mɛn əntɪl i əpɪɹd bæk ət ðə pæləs ət sʌnsɛt. hi dɪd kip ɪz pɹɑməsəz, bʌt smɔl tʃæns i wəd ɡɪv ʌp wʌn moʊmən ə fɹiɾəm i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə. mɔɹ aɪz wəd min ə kwɪkɝ sɝtʃ, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ɔl ə ðə waɪz wɪmən wɝ bɹɔɾ ɪndə ɪt. fəɹ ðə speɪs ə θɹi hɑɹtbits i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi hæɾ ɪz oʊn pɹɑməsəz tə kip, ðoʊ hi wɑz waɪz ɪnʌf nɑt tə pʊɾ ɪt ðət weɪ.

"My heart would break if anything happened to that boy," Birgitte said, and Aviendha added, just as warmly, "I have always said you do not care for him properly." Mat ground his teeth. In the streets of the city, Olver might well elude eight men until he appeared back at the palace at sunset. He did keep his promises, but small chance he would give up one moment of freedom he did not have to. More eyes would mean a quicker search, especially if all of the Wise Women were brought into it. For the space of three heartbeats he hesitated. He had his own promises to keep, though he was wise enough not to put it that way.

"ðə boʊl ɪz tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt," hi toʊl ðɛm. "ðæt ɡoʊləm ɪz stɪl aʊt ðɛɹ, ən meɪbi mɑɡiɾin, ən ðə blæk ədʒɑ fəɹ ʃʊɹ." ðə daɪs θʌndɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. eɪvinhə wəd nɑɾ əpɹiʃieɪt biɪŋ lʌmpt ɪn wɪð nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ ɹaɪt ðɛn. hi ədʒɹɛs læn ən bɝdʒɪt. "kip əm seɪf əntɪl aɪ kən ɹitʃ ju. kip ɔl ə ðɛm seɪf."

"The Bowl is too important," he told them. "That gholam is still out there, and maybe Moghedien, and the Black Ajah for sure." The dice thundered in his head. Aviendha would not appreciate being lumped in with Nynaeve and Elayne, but he did not care right then. He addressed Lan and Birgitte. "Keep them safe until I can reach you. Keep all of them safe."

stɑɹtlɪŋli, eɪvinhə sɛd, "wi wɪl. aɪ pɹɑməs." ʃi fɪŋɡɝd ðə hɪlt ə hɝ naɪf. əpɛɹənli ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz tə bi kɛp seɪf.

Startlingly, Aviendha said, "We will. I promise." She fingered the hilt of her knife. Apparently she did not understand she was one of those to be kept safe.

nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn dɪd. nɪneɪivz sʌɾən ɡlɛɹ tʃɹaɪd tə bɔɹ ə hoʊl θɹu hɪz skʌl; hi ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə jæŋk ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd, bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli, hɝ hæn oʊnli flʌɾɝd təwɔɹɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ pʊt fɝmli tə hɝ saɪd. ɪleɪn kəntɛntəd hɝsɛlf wɪð ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn, ðoʊz bɪɡ blu aɪz fɹɔsti. noʊ dɪmpəl hɪɹ.

Nynaeve and Elayne did. Nynaeve's sudden glare tried to bore a hole through his skull; he expected her to yank on her braid, but strangely, her hand only fluttered toward it before being put firmly to her side. Elayne contented herself with raising her chin, those big blue eyes frosty. No dimple here.

læn ən bɝdʒɪɾ ʌndɝstʊd, tu.

Lan and Birgitte understood, too.

"nɪneɪiv ɪz maɪ laɪf," læn sɛd sɪmpli, pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ði ɑd θɪŋ wɑz, ʃi sʌɾənli lʊk vɛɹi sæd, ən ðən dʒʌst əz sʌɾənli, hɝ dʒɔ sɛɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɑz pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə wɔk θɹu ə stoʊn wɔl ən meɪk ə lɑɹdʒ hoʊl.

"Nynaeve is my life," Lan said simply, putting a hand on her shoulder. The odd thing was, she suddenly looked very sad, and then just as suddenly, her jaw set as though she was preparing to walk through a stone wall and make a large hole.

bɝdʒɪt ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə fɑn lʊk, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə mæt ʃi spoʊk. "aɪ wɪl," ʃi sɛd. "ɑnɝz tʃɹuθ."

Birgitte gave Elayne a fond look, but it was to Mat she spoke. "I will," she said. "Honor's truth."

mæt tʌɡd əɾ ɪz koʊɾ ənkʌmftəbli. hi stɪl wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ i hæd toʊld əɹ waɪl dʒɹʌŋk. laɪt, bʌt ðə wʊmən kəd soʊk ɪɾ ʌp laɪk dʒɹaɪ sænd. ivən soʊ, hi ɡeɪv ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɑns fəɹ ə bɑɹɑʃhændən lɔɹd, æksɛptɪŋ əɹ plɛdʒ. "ði ɑnɝ ə blʌd; ðə tʃɹuθ ə blʌd." bɝdʒɪt nɑɾəd, ən fɹəm ðə stɑɹɾəld lʊks i ɹəsiv fɹəm nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, ʃi stɪl kɛpt ɪz sikɹəts kloʊs. laɪt, ɪf ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛvɝ faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊt ðoʊz mɛmɹiz, ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl noʊ hi hæd bloʊn ðə hɔɹn əz wɛl; fɑkshɛɾ əɹ noʊ fɑkshɛd, ðeɪ wəd stʃɹɛtʃ ɪm aʊt tɪl ðeɪ dʌɡ aʊɾ ɛvɹi læst waɪ ən haʊ.

Mat tugged at his coat uncomfortably. He still was not sure how much he had told her while drunk. Light, but the woman could soak it up like dry sand. Even so, he gave the proper response for a Barashandan lord, accepting her pledge. "The honor of blood; the truth of blood." Birgitte nodded, and from the startled looks he received from Nynaeve and Elayne, she still kept his secrets close. Light, if any Aes Sedai ever found out about those memories, they might as well know he had blown the Horn as well; foxhead or no foxhead, they would stretch him out till they dug out every last why and how.

əz i wɑz tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ, nɪneɪiv kɑɾ ɪz sliv. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə stɔɹm, mæt. ɪts gɑnə bɹeɪk sun; aɪ noʊ ɪt. jə teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf, mæt kɔθən. dʒju hɪɹ mi? taɪlɪn əz dɝɛkʃənz fəɹ ðə fɑɹm, wən jə ɡɛt bæk wɪð oʊlvɝ."

As he was turning to go, Nynaeve caught his sleeve. "Remember the storm, Mat. It's going to break soon; I know it. You take care of yourself, Mat Cauthon. Do you hear me? Tylin has directions for the farm, when you get back with Olver."

nɑɾɪŋ, hi meɪɾ ɪz ɪskeɪp, ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd laɪk ɛkoʊz ə hɪz ɹʌnɪŋ buts. wɑz ɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə sɝtʃ ðəɾ i wɑz səpoʊz tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪmsɛlf, əɹ waɪl ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə dɝɛkʃənz fɹəm taɪlɪn? nɪneɪiv ən əɹ lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪnd. dɪd ʃi θɪŋk ə lɪɾəl ɹeɪn wɑz gɑnə mɛl hɪm? kʌm tə θɪŋk, wʌns ðeɪ juz ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, ɪt wəd ɹeɪn əɡɛn. ɪt sim jɪɹz sɪns ɹeɪn læs fɛl. sʌmθɪŋ tʌɡd əɾ ɪz θɔts, sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ, ən ɪleɪn, wɪtʃ meɪd noʊ sɛns, bʌɾ i ʃɹʌɡd ɪɾ ɔf. wʌn θɪŋ əɾ ə taɪm, ən ðə wʌn θɪŋ ɹaɪt naʊ wɑz oʊlvɝ.

Nodding, he made his escape, the dice in his head like echoes of his running boots. Was it during the search that he was supposed to take care of himself, or while getting the directions from Tylin? Nynaeve and her Listening to the Wind. Did she think a little rain was going to melt him? Come to think, once they used the Bowl of the Winds, it would rain again. It seemed years since rain last fell. Something tugged at his thoughts, something about the weather, and Elayne, which made no sense, but he shrugged it off. One thing at a time, and the one thing right now was Olver.

ðə mɛn wɝ ɔl weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz' lɔŋ ɹum nɪɹ ðə steɪbəlz, ɛvɹiwʌn ɑn ðɛɹ fiɾ ɪksɛp veɪnɪn, hu leɪ spɹɔld ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɛdz wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz leɪst oʊvɝ ɪz bɛli. veɪnɪn sɛɾ ə mæn hæd tə teɪk ɹɛst wən i kʊd. hi swʌŋ ɪz buts oʊvɝ ən sæɾ ʌp wən mæt ɛntɝd, ðoʊ. hi kɛɹɾ əbaʊɾ oʊlvɝ əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz; mæt wɑz dʒʌst əfɹeɪd ðə mæn wɑz gɑnə stɑɹt titʃɪŋ ɪm haʊ tə stil hɔɹsəz ən poʊtʃ fɛzəns. sɛvən sɛts ʌv aɪz foʊkəst ɑn mæt ɪntɛnli.

The men were all waiting in the Redarms' long room near the stables, everyone on their feet except Vanin, who lay sprawled on one of the beds with his fingers laced over his belly. Vanin said a man had to take rest when he could. He swung his boots over and sat up when Mat entered, though. He cared about Olver as much as any of the others; Mat was just afraid the man was going to start teaching him how to steal horses and poach pheasants. Seven sets of eyes focused on Mat intently.

"ɹaɪzɛl sɛɾ oʊlvɝz wɛɹɪŋ ɪz ɹɛd koʊt," hi toʊl ðɛm. "hi ɡɪvz əm əweɪ, səmtaɪmz, bʌɾ ɛni ɝtʃən jə si ɪn ə ɡʊd ɹɛd koʊt pɹɑbli noʊz wɛɹ oʊlvɝ læst wɑz. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɡoʊz ɪn ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən. meɪk lups aʊt fɹəm ðə mɔl hɛɹə, ən tʃɹaɪ tə bi bæk æftɝ əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ. weɪt tɪl ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪz bæk bɪfɔɹ jə ɡoʊ aʊɾ əɡɛn. ðət weɪ, ɪf sʌmbɑɾi faɪnz hɪm, ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs woʊn stɪl bi lʊkɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ. dʌz ɛvɹibɑɾi ʌndɝstænd?" ðeɪ nɑɾəd.

"Riselle said Olver's wearing his red coat," he told them. "He gives them away, sometimes, but any urchin you see in a good red coat probably knows where Olver last was. Everybody goes in a different direction. Make loops out from the Mol Hara, and try to be back after about an hour. Wait till everybody is back before you go out again. That way, if somebody finds him, the rest of us won't still be looking tomorrow. Does everybody understand?" They nodded.

səmtaɪmz ɪɾ əmeɪz hɪm. læŋki tɑm wɪð ɪz waɪt hɛɹ ən mʌstæʃɪz, hu hæd bɪn ə kwinz lʌvɝ wʌns, ən mɔɹ wɪlɪŋli ðən hɪmsɛlf, nɑt tə mɛnʃən mɔɹ ðən ə lʌvɝ, ɪf jə bɪliv hæf i sɛd. skwɛɹ-dʒɔd hɑɹnən wɪð ðət tætu ɑn ɪz tʃik ən mɔɹ ɛlswɛɹ, hu hæd bɪn ə soʊlʒɝ ɔl ɪz laɪf. dʒulɪn wɪð ɪz bæmbu stæf ən ɪz sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ ɑn ɪz hɪp, hu θɔt hɪmsɛlf əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛni lɔɹɾ ivən ɪf ði aɪdiə ʌv kæɹiɪŋ ə sɔɹd hɪmsɛlf stɪl meɪɾ ɪm ənizi, ən fæt veɪnɪn, hu meɪd dʒulɪn lʊk ə butlɪkɝ baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. skɪni fɝdʒɪn, ən ɡɔɹɾɝən, nɪɹli əz waɪɾ ɪn ðə ʃoʊldɝz əz pɛɹɪn, ən mɛtwɪn, huz peɪl kɛɹhinɪn feɪs stɪl lʊk laɪk ə bɔɪz dɪspaɪt biɪŋ jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən mæt. səm ə ðɛm fɑloʊd mæt kɔθən kəz ðeɪ θɔɾ i wɑz lʌki, kəz ɪz lʌk maɪt kip əm əlaɪv wən ðə sɔɹdz wɝ aʊt, ən səm fəɹ ɹizənz i wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ʃʊɹ ʌv, bʌt ðeɪ fɑloʊd. nɑɾ ivən tɑm hæɾ ɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən pɹətɛstəɾ ən ɔɹɾɝ ə hɪz. meɪbi ɹɪneɪl hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən lʌk. meɪbi hɪz biɪŋ tɑvɝən dɪd mɔɹ ðən dʌmp ɪm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə tʃɹʌbəl. sʌɾənli hi fɛlt . . . ɹispɑnsəbəl . . . fəɹ ðiz mɛn. ɪt wɑz ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl filɪŋ. mæt kɔθən ən ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ. ɪt wɑz ənnætʃɹəl.

Sometimes it amazed him. Lanky Thom with his white hair and mustaches, who had been a Queen's lover once, and more willingly than himself, not to mention more than a lover, if you believed half he said. Square-jawed Harnan with that tattoo on his cheek and more elsewhere, who had been a soldier all his life. Juilin with his bamboo staff and his sword-breaker on his hip, who thought himself as good as any lord even if the idea of carrying a sword himself still made him uneasy, and fat Vanin, who made Juilin look a bootlicker by comparison. Skinny Fergin, and Gorderan, nearly as wide in the shoulders as Perrin, and Metwyn, whose pale Cairhienin face still looked like a boy's despite being years older than Mat. Some of them followed Mat Cauthon because they thought he was lucky, because his luck might keep them alive when the swords were out, and some for reasons he was not really sure of, but they followed. Not even Thom had ever more than protested an order of his. Maybe Renaile had been more than luck. Maybe his being ta'veren did more than dump him in the middle of trouble. Suddenly he felt . . . responsible . . . for these men. It was an uncomfortable feeling. Mat Cauthon and responsibility did not go together. It was unnatural.

"teɪk kɛɹ ə jʊɹsɛlvz, ən lʊk ʃɑɹp," hi sɛd. "ju noʊ wʌts aʊt ðɛɹ. ðɛɹz ə stɔɹm kʌmɪŋ." naʊ waɪ hæɾ i sɛd ðæt? "muv. wɝ weɪstɪŋ laɪt."

"Take care of yourselves, and look sharp," he said. "You know what's out there. There's a storm coming." Now why had he said that? "Move. We're wasting light."

ðə wɪn stɪl blu stʃɹɔŋli, swipɪŋ dʌst əkɹɔs ðə mɔl hɛɹə skwɛɹ wɪð ɪts stætʃu ʌv ə lɔŋ-dɛd kwin poʊzɪŋ əbʌv ðə faʊntən, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ saɪn ʌv ə stɔɹm. nɑɹaɪn hæd bɪn noʊɾəd fəɹ əɹ ɑnəsti, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə hæv bɪn dɪpɪktəd kəmplitli bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd. ði æftɝnun sʌn bɝn haɪ ɪn ə skaɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə klaʊd, bʌt pipəl ɹʌʃt θɹu ðə skwɛɹ əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ kul. ðət wɑz ɡɔn, wɪn əɹ noʊ, daʊn hɪɹ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz simd ə ɡɹɪɾəl ʌndɝ ɪz buts.

The wind still blew strongly, sweeping dust across the Mol Hara Square with its statue of a long-dead queen posing above the fountain, but there was no other sign of a storm. Nariene had been noted for her honesty, but not enough to have been depicted completely bare-chested. The afternoon sun burned high in a sky without a cloud, but people rushed through the square as quickly as they had in the morning cool. That was gone, wind or no, down here on the ground. The paving stones seemed a griddle under his boots.

ɡlɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, mæt hɛɾəd təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ. oʊlvɝ hæd nɑt ɡɔn ɔf wɪð ðə stʃɹiɾ ɝtʃənz hæf əz ɔfən waɪl ðeɪ wɝ steɪɪŋ ət ði ɪn; hi hæd bɪn tu kɑntɛn ɑɡəlɪŋ ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ən sɛɾəl ɑnənz dɔɾɝz. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ðə daɪs tɛlɪŋ ɪm i hæd tə muv ɪndə ðə pæləs. ɛniθɪŋ i hæd dʌn sɪns livɪŋ - ɛniθɪŋ i wɑntəd tə du, hi əmɛndəd, θɪŋkɪŋ ə taɪlɪn ən əɹ aɪz; ən əɹ hænz - ɛni ʌv ɪt cʊɾə bɪn dʌn dʒʌst əz wɛl fɹəm ðɛɹ. ðoʊz daɪs spʌn naʊ, ən i wɪʃt ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst ɡoʊ əweɪ.

Glaring across the square at The Wandering Woman, Mat headed toward the river. Olver had not gone off with the street urchins half as often while they were staying at the inn; he had been too content ogling the serving girls and Setalle Anan's daughters. So much for the dice telling him he had to move into the palace. Anything he had done since leaving - anything he wanted to do, he amended, thinking of Tylin and her eyes; and her hands - any of it could have been done just as well from there. Those dice spun now, and he wished they would just go away.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə muv kwɪkli, dɑdʒɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli ɝaʊn tʃɹʌnlɪŋ kɑɹts ən wæɡənz, kɝsɪŋ ət lækɝd sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən koʊtʃɪz ðət nɪɹli ɹæn ɪm daʊn, aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv ə ɹɛd koʊt kloʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ðə bʌsəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits sloʊɾ ɪm tə ə miændɝ. wɪtʃ wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl, ɪn tʃɹuθ. noʊ pɔɪn dæʃɪŋ baɪ ðə bɔɪ wɪθaʊt siɪŋ hɪm. wɪʃɪŋ i hæd bɹɔt pɪps aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs steɪbəlz, hi fɹaʊn ət ðə pipəl stʃɹimɪŋ pæst; ə mæn ɑn hɔɹsbæk cʊɾə muv noʊ fæstɝ ɪn ðə θɹɔŋ, bʌɾ ʌp ɪn ðə sæɾəl, hi cʊɾə sin fɑɹðɝ. ðən əɡɛn, æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz fɹəm ə sæɾəl wʊɾə bɪn ɑkwɝd; nɑt mɛni foʊk æktʃəli  ɹoʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, ən səm pipəl hæɾ ə tɛndənsi tə ʃaɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɛniwʌn ɑn ə hɔɹs.

He tried to move quickly, dodging impatiently around trundling carts and wagons, cursing at lacquered sedan chairs and coaches that nearly ran him down, eyes darting in search of a red coat close to the ground, but the bustle in the streets slowed him to a meander. Which was just as well, in truth. No point dashing by the boy without seeing him. Wishing he had brought Pips out of the palace stables, he frowned at the people streaming past; a man on horseback could have moved no faster in the throng, but up in the saddle, he could have seen farther. Then again, asking questions from a saddle would have been awkward; not many folk actually rode inside the city, and some people had a tendency to shy away from anyone on a horse.

ɔlweɪz ðə seɪm kwɛstʃən. ðə fɝs taɪm i æskt wɑz əɾ ə bɹɪdʒ dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə mɔl hɛɹə, ʌv ə fɛloʊ sɛlɪŋ hʌni-beɪkt æpəlz fɹəm ə tʃɹeɪ hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə stʃɹæp ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. "hæv jə sin ə bɔɪ, əbaʊt soʊ haɪ, ɪn ə ɹɛd koʊt?" oʊlvɝ laɪk swits.

Always the same question. The first time he asked was at a bridge just below the Mol Hara, of a fellow selling honey-baked apples from a tray hanging from a strap around his neck. "Have you seen a boy, about so high, in a red coat?" Olver liked sweets.

"bɔɪ, maɪ lɔɹd?" ðə fɛloʊ sɛd, sʌkɪŋ ɪz fju ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ tiθ. "sin ə θaʊzən bɔɪz. doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ noʊ koʊt, ðoʊ. wəd maɪ lɔɹd laɪk wʌn æpəl, əɹ tu?" hi skupt ʌp tu wɪð boʊni fɪŋɡɝz ən pʊʃt əm ət mæt; ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɡeɪv ʌndɝ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, ðeɪ wɝ sɑftɝ ðən ɛni beɪkɪŋ kəɾ əkaʊn fɔɹ. "dɪd maɪ lɔɹd hɪɹ əbaʊt ðə ɹaɪət?"

"Boy, my Lord?" the fellow said, sucking his few remaining teeth. "Seen a thousand boys. Don't remember no coat, though. Would my Lord like one apple, or two?" He scooped up two with bony fingers and pushed them at Mat; the way they gave under his fingers, they were softer than any baking could account for. "Did my Lord hear about the riot?"

"noʊ," mæt sɛd saʊɝli, ən pʊʃt ɑn. ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, hi stɑpt ə plʌmp wʊmən wɪð ə tʃɹeɪ ʌv ɹɪbənz. ɹɪbənz hɛl noʊ fæsəneɪʃən fəɹ oʊlvɝ, bʌɾ əɹ ɹɛd pɛɾikoʊts flæʃt bɪniθ ə skɝt soʊn ʌp nɪɹli tə hɝ lɛf hɪp, ən ðə kʌɾ ə hɝ bɑɾəs ɹɪvild ɹaʊndəd klivədʒ tə ikwəl ɹaɪzɛlz. "hæv jə sin ə bɔɪ . . . ?"

"No," Mat said sourly, and pushed on. At the other end of the bridge, he stopped a plump woman with a tray of ribbons. Ribbons held no fascination for Olver, but her red petticoats flashed beneath a skirt sewn up nearly to her left hip, and the cut of her bodice revealed rounded cleavage to equal Riselle's. "Have you seen a boy . . . ?"

hi hɝɾ əbaʊt ðə ɹaɪət fɹəm hɝ, tu, ən fɹəm hæf ðə pipəl i æskt. ðət ɹumɝ, hi səspɛktəd hæd bɪɡʌn wɪð ɪvɛns əɾ ə sɝɾən haʊs ɪn ðə ɹæhəd ðət vɛɹi mɔɹnɪŋ. ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ wɪð əɹ lɔŋ wɪp kɔɪld ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ivən toʊld ɪm ðə ɹaɪət hæd bɪn əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, wʌns ʃi əlaʊɾ əz haʊ ʃi nɛvɝ noʊɾəst bɔɪz ənlɛs ðeɪ ɹæn ʌndɝ əɹ mjulz. ə skwɛɹ-feɪs mæn u soʊl hʌnikoʊm - ɪnkɹɛɾəbli dʒɹaɪ-lʊkɪŋ hʌnikoʊm - sɛd ðə ɹaɪət hæd bɪn daʊn nɪɹ ðə laɪt taʊɝ ət ði ɛn ə ðə beɪ ɹoʊd, ɑn ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə maʊθ ə ðə beɪ, wɪtʃ wɑz əbaʊɾ əz laɪkli ə pleɪs fəɹ ɹaɪəɾɪŋ əz ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə beɪ ɪtsɛlf. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ə θaʊzən ɹumɝz ɪn ɛni sɪɾi, ɪf jə lɪsənd, ən i wɑz fɔɹs tə lɪsən tə snætʃɪz ʌv ɔl ə ðɛm, ɪt simd. wʌn ə ðə moʊst ɹɪmɑɹkəbli pɹɪɾi wɪmən i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ə tævɝn - meɪlɪn wɑz ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl ət ði oʊld ʃip, bʌɾ əɹ oʊnli tæsk sim tə bi stændɪŋ aʊtsaɪd tə ətʃɹækt kʌstəmɝz, wɪtʃ ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd - toʊld ɪm ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə bæɾəl ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, ɪn ðə kɔɹdiz hɪlz wɛst ə ðə sɪɾi, ʃi θɔt. əɹ meɪbi ɪn ðə ɹænən hɪlz, əkɹɔs ðə beɪ. əɹ meɪbi. . . . ɹɪmɑɹkəbli pɹɪɾi, meɪlɪn, bʌt nɑt vɛɹi bɹaɪt; oʊlvɝ maɪɾ əv wɑtʃt əɹ fəɹ aʊɝz, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi nɛvɝ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ siɪŋ ɛni bɔɪ ɪn eɪ. . . . wʌt kʌlɝ koʊt hæɾ i sɛd, əɡɛn? hi hɝɾ əbaʊt ɹaɪəts ən bæɾəlz, hi hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɪnʌf stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz sin ɪn ðə skaɪ əɹ ðə hɪlz tə pɑpjəleɪt ðə blaɪt. hi hɝd ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz əbaʊt tə dɪsɛn ɑn ðə sɪɾi wɪð θaʊzənz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, ðət ði il wɝ kʌmɪŋ, ən ɑɹmi ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ - noʊ, ɪt wɑz ən ɑɹmi ʌv waɪtkloʊks; peɪdʒɹən naɪl wɑz dɛd, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɪntɛndəd tə əvɛnʒ hɪm, ðoʊ waɪ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli klɪɹ. jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ðə sɪɾi wəd bi hɪp-dip ɪn pænɪk wɪð ɔl ðə teɪlz floʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊnd, bʌt ðə fækt wɑz, ivən ðoʊz u toʊld ə teɪl juʒəwəli oʊnli hæf-bɪlivd ɪt. soʊ, hi hɝɾ ɔl sɔɹts ə nɑnsɛns, bʌt nɑɾ ə wɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɛni bɔɪ ɪn ə ɹɛd koʊt.

He heard about the riot from her, too, and from half the people he asked. That rumor, he suspected had begun with events at a certain house in the Rahad that very morning. A wagon driver with her long whip coiled around her neck even told him the riot had been across the river, once she allowed as how she never noticed boys unless they ran under her mules. A square-faced man who sold honeycomb - incredibly dry-looking honeycomb - said the riot had been down near the light tower at the end of the Bay Road, on the eastern side of the mouth of the bay, which was about as likely a place for rioting as the middle of the bay itself. There were always a thousand rumors in any city, if you listened, and he was forced to listen to snatches of all of them, it seemed. One of the most remarkably pretty women he had ever seen, standing outside a tavern - Maylin was a serving girl at The Old Sheep, but her only task seemed to be standing outside to attract customers, which she certainly did - told him there had been a battle that morning, in the Cordese Hills west of the city, she thought. Or maybe in the Rhannon Hills, across the bay. Or maybe. . . . Remarkably pretty, Maylin, but not very bright; Olver might have watched her for hours, so long as she never opened her mouth. But she could not remember seeing any boy in a. . . . What color coat had he said, again? He heard about riots and battles, he heard about enough strange things seen in the sky or the hills to populate the Blight. He heard that the Dragon Reborn was about to descend on the city with thousands of men who could channel, that the Aiel were coming, an army of Aes Sedai - no, it was an army of Whitecloaks; Pedron Niall was dead, and the Children intended to avenge him, though why in Ebou Dar was not exactly clear. You might have thought the city would be hip-deep in panic with all the tales floating around, but the fact was, even those who told a tale usually only half-believed it. So, he heard all sorts of nonsense, but not a word about any boy in a red coat.

ə fju stʃɹits fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ, hi bɪɡæn hɪɹɪŋ θʌndɝ, ɡɹeɪt hɑloʊ bumz ðət sim tə ɹoʊl ɪn fɹəm ðə si. pipəl lʊkt ʌp kjʊɹiəsli ət ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ, skɹætʃt ðɛɹ hɛdz, ən wɛn ɑn əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs. soʊ dɪd hi, kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɛvɹi sɛlɝ ə swits əɹ fɹuɾ i sɔ, ən ɛvɹi pɹɪɾi wʊmən əfʊt. ɔl tə noʊ əveɪl. ɹitʃɪŋ ðə lɔŋ stoʊn ki ðət ɹæn ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, hi pɔzd, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ dɑks stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ ən ðə ʃɪps taɪd tə ðɛm. ðə wɪn blu stʃɹɔŋ, hivɪŋ vɛsəlz ət ðɛɹ mʊɹɪŋ laɪnz, ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əm əɡɛns ðə stoʊn dɑks dɪspaɪt ðə bæɡz stʌft wɪð wʊl hʌŋ daʊn bɪtwin fəɹ fɛndɝz. ənlaɪk hɔɹsəz, ʃɪps dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəst oʊlvɝ ɪksɛpt əz ə weɪ tə ɡoʊ fɹəm hɪɹ tə ðɛɹ, ən ʃɪps wɝ mɛnz bɪznəs ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ivən ɪf ðə leɪɾɪŋ ðeɪ kæɹiɾ ɔfən wɑz nɑt. wɪmən ɑn ðiz dɑks wəɾ iðɝ bi mɝtʃəns kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðɛɹ ɡʊdz əɹ hɑɹd-ɑɹmd mɛmbɝz ə ðə kɑɹɡoʊ-loʊɾɝz ɡɪld, ən ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ swit-sɛlɝz hɪɹ.

A few streets from the river, he began hearing thunder, great hollow booms that seemed to roll in from the sea. People looked up curiously at the cloudless sky, scratched their heads, and went on about their business. So did he, questioning every seller of sweets or fruit he saw, and every pretty woman afoot. All to no avail. Reaching the long stone quay that ran the whole length of the river side of the city, he paused, studying the gray docks stretching out into the river and the ships tied to them. The wind blew strong, heaving vessels at their mooring lines, grinding them against the stone docks despite the bags stuffed with wool hung down between for fenders. Unlike horses, ships did not interest Olver except as a way to go from here to there, and ships were men's business in Ebou Dar even if the lading they carried often was not. Women on these docks would either be merchants keeping an eye on their goods or hard-armed members of the cargo-loader's guild, and there would be no sweet-sellers here.

əbaʊt tə tɝn əweɪ, hi ɹilaɪzd ɔlmoʊs noʊ wʌn wɑz muvɪŋ. ðə dɑks juʒəwəli bʌsəld, jɛɾ ɑn ɛvɹi ʃɪp i kəd si, kɹumɪn laɪn ðə ɹeɪlz ən hæd klaɪmd ɪndə ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ tə stɛɹ təwɔɹd ðə beɪ. bæɹəlz ən kɹeɪts stʊɾ əbændənd waɪl ʃɝtləs mɛn ən wɪɹi wɪmən ɪn ɡɹin lɛðɝ vɛsts kɹaʊɾəd təɡɛðɝ ət ði ɛnz ə ðə dɑks tə pɪɹ bɪtwin ðə ʃɪps, saʊθ, təwɔɹd ðə θʌndɝ. daʊn ðət weɪ, blæk smoʊk ɹoʊz ɪn θɪk taʊɝɪŋ kɑləmz, slæntɪŋ ʃɑɹpli nɔɹθ ɑn ðə wɪnd.

About to turn away, he realized almost no one was moving. The docks usually bustled, yet on every ship he could see, crewmen lined the rails and had climbed into the rigging to stare toward the bay. Barrels and crates stood abandoned while shirtless men and wiry women in green leather vests crowded together at the ends of the docks to peer between the ships, south, toward the thunder. Down that way, black smoke rose in thick towering columns, slanting sharply north on the wind.

hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ oʊnli ə moʊmənt, hi tʃɹɑɾəd aʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə nɪɹəs dɑk. ət fɝst, ʃɪps taɪd tə ðə lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝz ə stoʊn tə ðə saʊθ blɑkt ɪz vju ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə smoʊk. kəz ə ðə weɪ ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn leɪ, ðoʊ, itʃ dɑk stʌk aʊt fɑɹðɝ ðən ðə nɛks daʊn; wʌns i pʊʃt ɪndə ðə mɝmɝɪŋ kɹaʊɾ ət ði ɛnd, ðə bɹɔd ɹɪvɝ meɪɾ ən oʊpən pæθ ə tʃɑpi ɡɹin wɔɾɝ tə ðə weɪv-tɔs beɪ.

Hesitating only a moment, he trotted out along the nearest dock. At first, ships tied to the long fingers of stone to the south blocked his view of anything except the smoke. Because of the way the shoreline lay, though, each dock stuck out farther than the next down; once he pushed into the murmuring crowd at the end, the broad river made an open path of choppy green water to the wave-tossed bay.

ət lis tu dʌzən ʃɪps wɝ bɝnɪŋ aʊɾ ɑn ðə waɪɾ ɪkspæns ə ðə beɪ, meɪbi mɔɹ, ɪnɡʌlft ɪn fleɪm fɹəm ɛn tə ɛnd. ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sɛɾəld, oʊnli ə baʊ əɹ stɝn stɪl əbʌv wɔɾɝ ən ðət slaɪɾɪŋ ʌndɝ. ivən əz i lʊkt, ðə baʊ ʌv ə bɹɔd tu-mæstəd ʃɪp flaɪɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ bænɝ ə ɹɛɾ ən blu ən ɡoʊld, ðə bænɝ ʌv ɔltɑɹə, sʌɾənli flu əpɑɹt wɪð ə ɹɔɹ, ə bum laɪk θʌndɝ, ən fæst-θɪkənɪŋ tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk wɑftɪɾ əweɪ ɑn ðə wɪn əz ðə vɛsəl bɪɡæn sɛɾəlɪŋ baɪ ðə hɛd. hʌnʒɹədz ə vɛsəlz wɝ ɪn moʊʃən, ɛvɹi kɹæft ɪn ðə beɪ, θɹi-mæstəd si foʊk ɹeɪkɝz ən skɪmɝz ən tu-mæstəd sɔɹɝz, koʊstəl ʃɪps wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz, ɹɪvɝʃɪps ʌndɝ seɪl əɹ swip, səm fliɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ, moʊs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə biɾ aʊt tə si. skɔɹz ʌv ʌðɝ ʃɪps swɑn ɪndə ðə beɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪnd, ɡɹeɪt blʌf-baʊd vɛsəlz əz tɔl əz ɛni ʌv ðə ɹeɪkɝz, kɹæʃɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ weɪvz, θɹoʊɪŋ əsaɪd spɹeɪ. hɪz bɹɛθ kɑɾ əz i sʌɾənli meɪɾ aʊt skwɛɹ, ɹɪb seɪlz.

At least two dozen ships were burning out on the wide expanse of the bay, maybe more, engulfed in flame from end to end. A number of others had already settled, only a bow or stern still above water and that sliding under. Even as he looked, the bow of a broad two-masted ship flying a large banner of red and blue and gold, the banner of Altara, suddenly flew apart with a roar, a boom like thunder, and fast-thickening tendrils of smoke wafted away on the wind as the vessel began settling by the head. Hundreds of vessels were in motion, every craft in the bay, three-masted Sea Folk rakers and skimmers and two-masted soarers, coastal ships with their triangular sails, riverships under sail or sweep, some fleeing upriver, most trying to beat out to sea. Scores of other ships swanned into the bay before the wind, great bluff-bowed vessels as tall as any of the rakers, crashing through the rolling waves, throwing aside spray. His breath caught as he suddenly made out square, ribbed sails.

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," hi mʌɾɝd ɪn ʃɑk. "ɪts ðə fleɪmɪŋ sintʃæn!"

"Blood and bloody ashes," he muttered in shock. "It's the flaming Seanchan!"

"hu?" dɪmændəɾ ə stɝn-feɪst wʊmən kɹaʊɾəd nɛks tə hɪm. ə dɑɹk blu wʊlən dʒɹɛs ə faɪn kʌt mɑɹkt əɹ ə mɝtʃən əz mʌtʃ əz dɪd ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ʃi kæɹid fəɹ əɹ bɪlz ə leɪɾɪŋ əɹ ðə ɡɪl pɪn oʊvɝ wʌn bɹɛst, ə sɪlvɝ kwɪl pɛn. "ɪts ði ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi ənaʊnst ɪn toʊnz ə kənvɪkʃən. "aɪ noʊ tʃænəlɪŋ wən aɪ si ɪt. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɪl də fəɹ ðɛm, dʒʌst əz sun əz ðeɪ ɝaɪv. jəl si."

"Who?" demanded a stern-faced woman crowded next to him. A dark blue woolen dress of fine cut marked her a merchant as much as did the leather folder she carried for her bills of lading or the guild pin over one breast, a silver quill pen. "It's the Aes Sedai," she announced in tones of conviction. "I know channeling when I see it. The Children of the Light will do for them, just as soon as they arrive. You'll see."

ə læŋki, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ə ɡɹaɪmi ɡɹin vɛs twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə kənfɹʌn hɝ, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə wʊɾən hɪlt ə hɝ dæɡɝ. "hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, jə fleɪmɪŋ pɛni-ɡɹʌbɝ, əɹ əl pil jə ən stʌf ə waɪtkloʊk daʊn jəɹ bliɾɪŋ ɡʌlət!"

A lanky, gray-haired woman in a grimy green vest twisted around to confront her, fingering the wooden hilt of her dagger. "Hold your tongue about Aes Sedai, you flaming penny-grubber, or I'll peel you and stuff a Whitecloak down your bleeding gullet!"

mæt lɛft əm weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən pʊʃt klɪɹ ə ðə kɹaʊd, ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə ki. ɔlɹɛɾi hi kəd si θɹi - noʊ, fɔɹ - hjudʒ kɹitʃɝz sɝkəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi tə ðə saʊθ ɑn ɡɹeɪt pɪnjənz laɪk ðoʊz ʌv ə bæt. fɪɡjɝz klʌŋ tə ðə kɹitʃɝz' bæks, əpɛɹənli ɪn səm sɔɹɾ ə sæɾəlz. ənʌðɝ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝ əpɪɹd, ən mɔɹ. bɪloʊ ðɛm, fleɪm sʌɾənli faʊnteɪn əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps wɪð ə ɹɔɹ.

Mat left them waving their arms and shouting at one another, and pushed clear of the crowd, running for the quay. Already he could see three - no, four - huge creatures circling over the city to the south on great pinions like those of a bat. Figures clung to the creatures' backs, apparently in some sort of saddles. Another flying creature appeared, and more. Below them, flame suddenly fountained above the rooftops with a roar.

pipəl ɹæn naʊ, bəfeɪɪŋ mæt əz i stʃɹʌɡəl θɹu ðə stʃɹits. "oʊlvɝ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd, hoʊpɪŋ tə bi hɝɾ əbʌv ʌðɝ ʃaʊts fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd, ən ðə skɹimz. "oʊlvɝ!"

People ran now, buffeting Mat as he struggled through the streets. "Olver!" he shouted, hoping to be heard above other shouts from every side, and the screams. "Olver!"

əbɹʌpli, ɛvɹibɑɾi sim tə bi hɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ, bæɾɝɪŋ pæs hɪm. stʌbɝnli hi fɔɹst ɑn əɡɛns ðə taɪd. ən keɪm tə ə stʃɹit wɛɹ wʌɾ ɔl ðoʊz foʊk flɛd fɹəm wɑz meɪd pleɪn.

Abruptly, everybody seemed to be heading the other way, battering past him. Stubbornly he forced on against the tide. And came to a street where what all those folk fled from was made plain.

eɪ sintʃæn kɑləm ɹʌʃt baɪ, ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ mɛn ɪn hɛlməts laɪk ɪnsɛks' hɛdz ən ɑɹmɝ ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts, ɔl ɹaɪɾɪŋ ænəməlz laɪk kæts ðə saɪz ə hɔɹsəz, bʌt kʌvɝɾ ɪn bɹɑnz skeɪlz ɹæðɝ ðən fɝ. linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, blu-stʃɹimɝd lænsɪz slæntəd, ðeɪ ɡæləp təwɔɹd ðə mɔl hɛɹə wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪd. ðoʊ "ɡæləp" wɑz nɑt kwaɪt ðə wɝd fəɹ ðə weɪ ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz muvd; ðə spid wɑz ɹaɪt, bʌt ðeɪ . . . floʊd. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bi ɡɔn; pæs taɪm. əz sun əz i faʊnd -  əz ði ɛn ə kɑləm wɛn baɪ ə flæʃ ə ɹɛd, weɪs haɪ, kɑɾ ɪz aɪ əmʌŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪɑn ði ɪntɝsɛkʃən. "oʊlvɝ!" hi dɑɹɾɪd əkɹɔs ɔlmoʊst ɑn ðə hilz ə ðə læst skeɪl kɹitʃɝ, pʊʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn taɪm tə si ə waɪd-aɪd wʊmən snætʃ ʌp ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl ɪn ə ɹɛd dʒɹɛs ən ɹʌn wɪð ðə tʃaɪl klʌtʃt tə hɝ bʊzəm. waɪldli, mæt pɹɛst əhɛd, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ pipəl əsaɪd wən ðeɪ bʌmpt ɪndə hɪm, bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə mɔɹ ðən ə fju hɪmsɛlf. "oʊlvɝ! oʊlvɝ!"

A Seanchan column rushed by, a hundred or more men in helmets like insects' heads and armor of overlapping plates, all riding animals like cats the size of horses, but covered in bronze scales rather than fur. Leaning forward in their saddles, blue-streamered lances slanted, they galloped toward the Mol Hara without looking to either side. Though "gallop" was not quite the word for the way those creatures moved; the speed was right, but they . . . flowed. It was time to be gone; past time. As soon as he found -  As the end of column went by a flash of red, waist high, caught his eye among the crowd in the street beyond the intersection. "Olver!" He darted across almost on the heels of the last scaled creature, pushing into the crowd in time to see a wide-eyed woman snatch up a little girl in a red dress and run with the child clutched to her bosom. Wildly, Mat pressed ahead, shouldering people aside when they bumped into him, bumping into more than a few himself. "Olver! Olver!"

twaɪs mɔɹ i sɔ ə kɑləm ə faɪɝ ɹaɪz bɹifli əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps, ən smoʊk dʒɹɪftəd tə ðə skaɪ ɪn ə dʌzən pleɪsəz. sɛvɹəl taɪmz i hɝd ðoʊz bumɪŋ ɹɔɹz, mʌtʃ kloʊsɝ ðən ðə beɪ, naʊ. ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ; mɔɹ ðən wʌns ðə ɡɹaʊn kwɪvɝd bɪniθ ɪz buts.

Twice more he saw a column of fire rise briefly above the rooftops, and smoke drifted to the sky in a dozen places. Several times he heard those booming roars, much closer than the bay, now. Inside the city, he was sure; more than once the ground quivered beneath his boots.

ən ðən ðə stʃɹit wɑz klɪɹɪŋ əɡɛn, pipəl fliɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, daʊn æliz ən ɪndə haʊsəz ən ʃɑps, fəɹ sintʃæn ɑn hɔɹsəz wɝ kʌmɪŋ. nɑɾ ɔl wɝ ɑɹmɝd mɛn; nɪɹ ðə hɛɾ ə ðət smɔl θɪkɪɾ ə lænsɪz ɹoʊɾ ə dɑɹk wʊmən ɪn ə blu dʒɹɛs. mæt nu ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn əɹ skɝts ən bʊzəm wɝ wɝkt wɪð sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ. ə sɪlvɝ liʃ, ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, ɹæn fɹəm əɹ lɛft ɹɪs tə ðə nɛk ʌv ə wʊmən ɪn ɡɹeɪ, ə deɪmeɪn, hu tʃɹɑɾəd bɪsaɪd ðə sʌldəmz hɔɹs laɪk ə pɛt dɔɡ. hi hæd sin mɔɹ ə sintʃæn ət fɑlm ðən i wɑntəd tə, bʌɾ ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi pɔzd ət ðə maʊθ ʌv ən æliweɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ. ðə ɹɔɹz ən faɪɝz hæd ʃoʊd ðət sʌmbɑɾi ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪt bæk, ət list, ən naʊ hi wɑz gɑnə si sətʃ ən ətɛmpt.

And then the street was clearing again, people fleeing in every direction, down alleys and into houses and shops, for Seanchan on horses were coming. Not all were armored men; near the head of that small thicket of lances rode a dark woman in a blue dress. Mat knew the large red panels on her skirts and bosom were worked with silver lightning. A silver leash, gleaming in the sun, ran from her left wrist to the neck of a woman in gray, a damane, who trotted beside the sul'dam's horse like a pet dog. He had seen more of Seanchan at Falme than he wanted to, but unconsciously he paused at the mouth of an alleyway, watching. The roars and fires had showed that somebody in the city was trying to fight back, at least, and now he was going to see such an attempt.

ðə sintʃæn wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ɹizən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls hæd ɡɑɾən aʊɾ ə saɪt. ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə stʃɹit, ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd maʊntəd mɛn swʌŋ lɔŋ-pɔɪntəd lænsɪz daʊn. ðeɪ wɔɹ bæɡi waɪt bɹitʃɪz ən ɡɹin koʊts, ən ðə ɡoʊl kɔɹdz ɑn ði ɔfəsɝz hɛlmət ɡlɪɾɝd. wɪð ə kəlɛktɪv ʃaʊt, ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ ə taɪlɪnz soʊlʒɝz hɝl ðɛmsɛlvz təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾiz ətækɝz. ðeɪ aʊtnʌmbɝd ðə sintʃæn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm baɪ ət lis tu tə wʌn.

The Seanchan were not the only reason everyone else had gotten out of sight. At the other end of the street, a good hundred mounted men swung long-pointed lances down. They wore baggy white breeches and green coats, and the gold cords on the officer's helmet glittered. With a collective shout, a hundred or more of Tylin's soldiers hurled themselves toward the city's attackers. They outnumbered the Seanchan in front of them by at least two to one.

"blʌɾi fulz," mæt mʌɾɝd. "nɑt laɪk ðæt. ðət sʌldəm wɪl - "

"Bloody fools," Mat muttered. "Not like that. That sul'dam will - "

ði oʊnli muvmən əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn wɑz ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə laɪtnɪŋ-mɑɹk dʒɹɛs ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hæn tə pɔɪnt, əz wʌn maɪt lɔntʃ ə hɔk, əɹ sɛn ɔf ə haʊnd. ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə sɪlvɝi liʃ tʊk ə smɔl stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən kuld əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst.

The only movement among the Seanchan was the woman in the lightning-marked dress raising her hand to point, as one might launch a hawk, or send off a hound. The golden-haired woman at the other end of the silvery leash took a small step forward. The foxhead medallion cooled against his chest.

ʌndɝniθ ðə hɛɾ ə ði ɛbu dɑɹi tʃɑɹdʒ, ðə stʃɹit sʌɾənli ɪɹʌptəd, peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ən mɛn ən hɔɹsəz flaɪɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ wɪð ə dɛfənɪŋ ɹɔɹ. ðə kənkʌʃən nɑk mæt flæɾ ɑn ɪz bæk, əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðə weɪ ðə ɡɹaʊn sim tə lip fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz fit. hi pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɪn taɪm tə si ðə fɹʌn ʌv ən ɪn əkɹɔs ðə weɪ sʌɾənli kəlæps ɪndə ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə dʌst, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðə ɹumz wɪðɪn.

Underneath the head of the Ebou Dari charge, the street suddenly erupted, paving stones and men and horses flying into the air with a deafening roar.
