The concussion knocked Mat flat on his back, or maybe it was the way the ground seemed to leap from under his feet. He pulled himself up in time to see the front of an inn across the way suddenly collapse into the street in a cloud of dust, exposing the rooms within.

mɛn ən hɔɹsəz leɪ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, pisəz ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz, ðoʊz stɪl əlaɪv θɹæʃɪŋ, ɝaʊn ə hoʊl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn hæf əz waɪɾ əz ðə stʃɹit. skɹimz fɹəm ðə wundəd fɪl ði ɛɹ. fjuɝ ðən hæf ði ɛbu dɑɹi stæɡɝd tə ðɛɹ fit, deɪzd ən stʌmbəlɪŋ. səm sizd ʌp ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɔɹsəz əz wɑbəli-lɛɡəɾ əz ðeɪ, hivɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə sæɾəlz, kɪkɪŋ ði ænəməlz ɪndə səm sɛmbləns ʌv ə ɹʌn. ʌðɝz dʒʌst ɹæn əfʊt. ɔl əweɪ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn. stil ðeɪ kəd feɪs, bʌt nɑt ðɪs.

Men and horses lay everywhere, pieces of men and horses, those still alive thrashing, around a hole in the ground half as wide as the street. Screams from the wounded filled the air. Fewer than half the Ebou Dari staggered to their feet, dazed and stumbling. Some seized up the reins of horses as wobbly-legged as they, heaving themselves into saddles, kicking the animals into some semblance of a run. Others just ran afoot. All away from the Seanchan. Steel they could face, but not this.

ɹʌnɪŋ, mæt ɹilaɪzd, simd ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli faɪn aɪdiə ɹaɪt ðɛn. ə ɡlæns bæk daʊn ði æli ʃoʊd dʌst ən ɹʌbəl paɪld ət list ə stɔɹi haɪ. hi dɑɹɾɪd daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ əhɛɾ ə ðə fliɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹi, kipɪŋ əz kloʊs tə ðə wɔlz əz pɑsəbəl, hoʊpɪŋ nʌn ə ðə sintʃæn wəd θɪŋk i wɑz wʌn ə taɪlɪnz soʊlʒɝz. hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv wɔɹn ə ɡɹin koʊt.

Running, Mat realized, seemed a particularly fine idea right then. A glance back down the alley showed dust and rubble piled at least a story high. He darted down the street ahead of the fleeing Ebou Dari, keeping as close to the walls as possible, hoping none of the Seanchan would think he was one of Tylin's soldiers. He should never have worn a green coat.

ðə sʌldəm əpɛɹənli wɑz nɑt sæɾəsfaɪd. ðə fɑkshɛd wɛn kul əɡɛn, ən fɹəm bɪhaɪn ənʌðɝ ɹɔɹ hæmɝɾ ɪm tə ðə peɪvmənt, peɪvmən ðət dʒʌmpt ʌp tə mit hɪm. θɹu ðə ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, hi hɝd meɪsənɹi ɡɹoʊn. əbʌv hɪm, ðə waɪt-plæstɝd bɹɪk wɔl bɪɡæn linɪŋ aʊtwɝd.

The sul'dam apparently was not satisfied. The foxhead went cool again, and from behind another roar hammered him to the pavement, pavement that jumped up to meet him. Through the ringing in his ears, he heard masonry groan. Above him, the white-plastered brick wall began leaning outward.

"wʌt hæpən tə maɪ blʌɾi lʌk?" hi ʃaʊɾəd. hi hæd taɪm fəɹ ðæt. ən dʒʌs taɪm tə ɹilaɪz, əz bɹɪk ən tɪmbɝz kɹæʃt daʊn ɑn hɪm, ðət ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd hæd dʒʌst stɑp dɛd.

"What happened to my bloody luck?" he shouted. He had time for that. And just time to realize, as brick and timbers crashed down on him, that the dice in his head had just stopped dead.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi


CHAPTER 40

spɪɹz


Spears

maʊntənz ɹoʊz ɔl ɝaʊnd ɡəlinə kæsbən, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən lɑɹdʒ hɪlz bɪhaɪn bʌt snoʊkæpt piks əhɛɾ ən haɪɝ piks bɪɑn ðoʊz, jɛt ʃi ɹɪli sɔ nʌn ə ðɛm. ðə stoʊnz ə ðə sloʊp bɹuzd əɹ bɛɹ fit. ʃi pæntɪd, lʌŋz leɪbɝɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə sʌn beɪkt oʊvɝhɛɾ əz ɪt hæd fəɹ simɪŋli ɛnləs deɪz, bɝnɪŋ ðə swɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ ɪn ɹɪvɝz. ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən pʊɾɪŋ wʌn fʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sim bɪɑn hɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət wɪð ɔl ðə swɛt kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ, ʃi kəd nɑt faɪn ɛni mɔɪstʃɝ ɪn əɹ maʊθ.

Mountains rose all around Galina Casban, little more than large hills behind but snowcapped peaks ahead and higher peaks beyond those, yet she really saw none of them. The stones of the slope bruised her bare feet. She panted, lungs laboring already. The sun baked overhead as it had for seemingly endless days, burning the sweat out of her in rivers. Anything other than putting one foot in front of the other seemed beyond her. Strange that with all the sweat coming out of her, she could not find any moisture in her mouth.

ʃi hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fjuɝ ðən naɪnti jɪɹz, hɝ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ əntʌtʃt əz jɛt baɪ ɡɹeɪ, bʌt fəɹ nɪɹli twɛnti ʌv ðoʊz ʃi hæd bɪn hɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ - kɔl ðə haɪəs baɪ ʌðɝ ɹɛd sɪstɝz, ɪn pɹaɪvət; kənsɪɾɝd baɪ ʌðɝ ɹɛdz ikwəl tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit - ən fəɹ ɔl bʌt faɪv ə ðə jɪɹz ʃi hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl, ʃi hæd bɪn ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ɪn tʃɹuθ. nɑt tə ði ɪkskluʒən ə hɝ duɾiz əz ə ɹɛd, bʌt supɪɹiɝ tə ðɛm. hɝ pleɪs ɑn ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɑz nɛks tə ðəɾ ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪn hɝsɛlf, ən ʃi wɑz wʌn ʌv oʊnli θɹi hu nu ðə neɪm ə ðə wʊmən u lɛd ðɛɹ hʊɾɪd miɾɪŋz. ʃi kəd spik ɛni neɪm ɪn ðoʊz miɾɪŋz - ə kɪŋz - ən noʊ ðət neɪm bɪlɔŋ tə ðə dɛd. ɪt hæd hæpənd, wɪð ə kɪŋ ən wɪð ə kwin. ʃi hæd hɛlp tə bɹeɪk tu æmɪɝlənz, twaɪs hɛlp tɝn ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wʊmən ɪn ðə wɝld ɪndə ə skwilɪŋ ɹɛtʃ iɡɝ tə tɛl ɔl ʃi nu, hæd hɛlp meɪk ɪt sim ðət wʌn ə ðoʊz hæd daɪɾ ɪn əɹ slip ən hæd sin ði ʌðɝ dɪpoʊzd ən stɪld. sətʃ θɪŋz wɝ ə duɾi, laɪk ðə nid tə ɪkstɝməneɪt mɛn wɪð ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl, nɑɾ ækʃənz ʃi tʊk plɛʒɝ ɪn bɪɑn ðəɾ ə tæsks wɛl dʌn, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɛndʒɔɪd liɾɪŋ ðə sɝkəl ðət stɪl sɪuən sɑntʃ. ʃʊɹli ɔl ðoʊz θɪŋz mɛn ðət ɡəlinə kæsbən wɑz hɝsɛlf əmʌŋ ðə maɪɾiəst ə ðə wɝld, əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl. ʃʊɹli ðeɪ dɪd. ðeɪ mʌst. hɝ lɛɡz weɪvɝd laɪk spɹɪŋz ðət hæd lɔs ðɛɹ tɛmpɝɪŋ, ən ʃi fɛl hɛvəli, əneɪbəl tə kætʃ hɝsɛlf wɪð ɑɹmz ən ɛlboʊz taɪtli baʊn bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə wʌns-waɪt sɪlk ʃɪft, ði oʊnli ɡɑɹmən lɛf tə hɝ, tɔɹ əɡɛn əz ʃi slɪɾ ɑn ðə lus ɹɑks, skɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ wɛls. ə tʃɹi stɑp hɝ. feɪs pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ʃi bɪɡæn tə sɑb. "haʊ?" ʃi moʊn ɪn ə θɪk vɔɪs. "haʊ kən ðɪs hæpən tə mi?"

She had been Aes Sedai fewer than ninety years, her long black hair untouched as yet by gray, but for nearly twenty of those she had been head of the Red Ajah - called the Highest by other Red sisters, in private; considered by other Reds equal to the Amyrlin Seat - and for all but five of the years she had worn the shawl, she had been of the Black Ajah, in truth. Not to the exclusion of her duties as a Red, but superior to them. Her place on the Supreme Council of the Black Ajah was next to that of Alviarin herself, and she was one of only three who knew the name of the woman who led their hooded meetings. She could speak any name in those meetings - a king's - and know that name belonged to the dead. It had happened, with a king and with a queen. She had helped to break two Amyrlins, twice helped turn the most powerful woman in the world into a squealing wretch eager to tell all she knew, had helped make it seem that one of those had died in her sleep and had seen the other deposed and stilled. Such things were a duty, like the need to exterminate men with the ability to channel, not actions she took pleasure in beyond that of tasks well done, but she had enjoyed leading the circle that stilled Siuan Sanche. Surely all those things meant that Galina Casban was herself among the mightiest of the world, among the most powerful. Surely they did. They must. Her legs wavered like springs that had lost their tempering, and she fell heavily, unable to catch herself with arms and elbows tightly bound behind her. The once-white silk shift, the only garment left to her, tore again as she slid on the loose rocks, scraping her welts. A tree stopped her. Face pressed against the ground, she began to sob. "How?" she moaned in a thick voice. "How can this happen to me?"

æftɝ ə taɪm ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn pʊl tə hɝ fit; noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ʃi fɛl, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ bɪn əlaʊɾ ə moʊməns ɹɛspɪt. blɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ tɪɹz, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd.

After a time she realized that she had not been pulled to her feet; no matter how often she fell, she had never before been allowed a moment's respite. Blinking away tears, she raised her head.

il wɪmən kʌvɝd ðə maʊntənsaɪd, sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm skæɾɝd əmʌŋ ðə bæɹən tʃɹiz wɪð ðɛɹ spɪɹz, ðə veɪlz ðeɪ kəd ɹeɪz ɪn ən ɪnstən hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. ɡəlinə wɑntəd tə læf. meɪɾənz; ðeɪ kɔl ðiz mɑnstʃɹəs wɪmən meɪɾənz. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd læf. ət lis ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɛn pɹizɛnt, ə smɔl mɝsi. mɛn meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹɔl, ən ɪf wʌn kəd si hɝ naʊ, lɛs ðən hæf-kloʊðd. . . .

Aiel women covered the mountainside, several hundred of them scattered among the barren trees with their spears, the veils they could raise in an instant hanging down their chests. Galina wanted to laugh. Maidens; they called these monstrous women Maidens. She wished she could laugh. At least there were no men present, a small mercy. Men made her skin crawl, and if one could see her now, less than half-clothed. . . .

æŋkʃəsli, hɝ aɪz sɔt fəɹ θɛɝɑvə, bʌt moʊst ə ðə sɛvənti əɹ soʊ waɪz wʌnz stʊd təɡɛðɝ lʊkɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹðɝ ʌp ðə sloʊp, blɑkɪŋ əɹ vju. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə mɝmɝ ə vɔɪsəz fɹəm ðə fɹʌn ə ðɛm. meɪbi ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ kənfɝɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. waɪz wʌnz. ðeɪ hæd bɪn bɹuɾəli ɪfɪʃən ɪn titʃɪŋ əɹ ðə kɝɛk neɪmz; nɛvɝ dʒʌst il wʊmən, ən nɛvɝ waɪldɝ. ðeɪ kəd smɛl kəntɛmp haʊɛvɝ ʃi hɪɾ ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, jə dɪd nɑɾ əv tə tʃɹaɪ haɪɾɪŋ wʌt hæd bɪn sɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ju.

Anxiously, her eyes sought for Therava, but most of the seventy or so Wise Ones stood together looking at something farther up the slope, blocking her view. There seemed to be a murmur of voices from the front of them. Maybe the Wise Ones were conferring about something. Wise Ones. They had been brutally efficient in teaching her the correct names; never just Aiel woman, and never wilder. They could smell contempt however she hid it. Of course, you did not have to try hiding what had been seared out of you.

moʊst ə ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ lʊkɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt nɑɾ ɔl. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəɾ ə jʌŋ, pɹɪɾi, ɹɛd-hɛɹd wʊmən wɪð ə dɛləkət maʊθ u wɑtʃt ɡəlinə wɪð lɑɹdʒ, ɪntɛn blu aɪz. pɝhæps əz ə saɪn ə ðɛɹ oʊn dɪsdeɪn, ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən ðə wikəst ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ tə ʃild əɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. mɪkɑɹə wɑz nɑt tʃɹuli wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ - nʌn ə ðɛm wɝ ðət - bʌɾ ivən smɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ʃoʊldɝz tə niz əz ʃi wɑz, ɡəlinə cʊɾə bɹoʊkən mɪkɑɹəz ʃild wɪð lɪɾəl ɛfɝt. ə mʌsəl ɪn əɹ tʃik spæzmd ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli; ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd wən ʃi θɔɾ ʌv ənʌðɝ ɪskeɪp ətɛmpt. ðə fɝs hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf. ðə sɛkənd. . . . ʃʌɾɝɪŋ, ʃi fɔt nɑt tə sɑb əɡɛn. ʃi wəd nɑt meɪk ði ətɛmpt əɡɛn əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə kəmplit səksɛs. vɛɹi ʃʊɹ. æbsəlutli ʃʊɹ.

Most of the Wise Ones were looking away, but not all. The glow of saidar surrounded a young, pretty, red-haired woman with a delicate mouth who watched Galina with large, intent blue eyes. Perhaps as a sign of their own disdain, they had chosen the weakest of their number to shield her this morning. Micara was not truly weak in the Power - none of them were that - but even smarting from shoulders to knees as she was, Galina could have broken Micara's shield with little effort. A muscle in her cheek spasmed uncontrollably; it always did when she thought of another escape attempt. The first had been bad enough. The second. . . . Shuddering, she fought not to sob again. She would not make the attempt again until she was sure of complete success. Very sure. Absolutely sure.

ðə mæs ʌv waɪz wʌnz pɑɹɾəd, tɝnɪŋ tə fɑloʊ θɛɝɑvə wɪð ðɛɹ aɪz əz ðə hɔk-feɪst wʊmən stʃɹoʊd təwɔɹd ɡəlinə. sʌɾənli pæntɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ, wɪð æpɹɪhɛnʃən, ɡəlinə tʃɹaɪd tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɝ fit. hænz baʊn ən mʌsəlz wɔɾɝi, ʃi hæɾ oʊnli ɹitʃt əɹ niz wən θɛɝɑvə bɛn oʊvɝ hɝ, nɛkləsɪz ʌv aɪvɝi ən ɡoʊl klæɾɝɪŋ sɔfli. sizɪŋ ə hændfʊl ʌv ɡəlinəz hɛɹ, θɛɝɑvə fɔɹst əɹ hɛd bæk ʃɑɹpli. tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, ðə wʊmən dɪd ðəɾ ivən wən ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ, kɹænɪŋ ɡəlinəz nɛk peɪnfəli tə meɪk əɹ lʊk ʌp ɪndə ðə waɪz wʌnz feɪs. θɛɝɑvə wɑz sʌmwʌt stʃɹɔŋɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ðən ʃi, wɪtʃ ɹɛləɾɪvli fju wɪmən wɝ, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt meɪd ɡəlinə tʃɹɛmbəl. koʊl dip blu aɪz stæbd ɪndə hɝ oʊn, hɛld əɹ mɔɹ taɪtli ðən θɛɝɑvəz ɹʌf hænd; ðeɪ sim tə stʃɹɪp əɹ soʊl neɪkəɾ əz izəli əz ðə waɪz wʌn hændəl hɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt bɛɡd jɛt, nɑt wən ðeɪ meɪɾ əɹ wɔk ɔl deɪ wɪð hɑɹdli ə dʒɹɑp ʌv wɔɾɝ, nɑt wən ðeɪ fɔɹst əɹ tə kip ʌp əz ðeɪ ɹæn fəɹ aʊɝz, nɑɾ ivən wən ðɛɹ swɪtʃəz meɪɾ əɹ haʊl. θɛɝɑvəz kɹuəl hɑɹd feɪs, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn əɾ əɹ ɪmpæsɪvli, meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə bɛɡ. səmtaɪmz ʃi woʊk ət naɪt, stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt taɪt bɪtwin ðə fɔɹ steɪks wɛɹ ðeɪ baʊn hɝ, woʊk wɪmpɝɪŋ fɹəm dʒɹimz ðəɾ əɹ hoʊl laɪf wəd bi lɪvd ʌndɝ θɛɝɑvəz hænz.

The mass of Wise Ones parted, turning to follow Therava with their eyes as the hawk-faced woman strode toward Galina. Suddenly panting once more, with apprehension, Galina tried to struggle to her feet. Hands bound and muscles watery, she had only reached her knees when Therava bent over her, necklaces of ivory and gold clattering softly. Seizing a handful of Galina's hair, Therava forced her head back sharply. Taller than most men, the woman did that even when they were standing, craning Galina's neck painfully to make her look up into the Wise One's face. Therava was somewhat stronger in the Power than she, which relatively few women were, but that was not what made Galina tremble. Cold deep blue eyes stabbed into her own, held her more tightly than Therava's rough hand; they seemed to strip her soul naked as easily as the Wise One handled her. She had not begged yet, not when they made her walk all day with hardly a drop of water, not when they forced her to keep up as they ran for hours, not even when their switches made her howl. Therava's cruel hard face, staring down at her impassively, made her want to beg. Sometimes she woke at night, stretched out tight between the four stakes where they bound her, woke whimpering from dreams that her whole life would be lived under Therava's hands.

"ʃi ɪz kəlæpsɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi," ðə waɪz wʌn sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk stoʊn. "wɔɾɝ hɝ, ən bɹɪŋ hɝ." tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl, ɡəlinə kæsbən fɝɡɑɾən əntɪl ðəɹ wɑz nid tə ɹikɔl hɝ; tə θɛɝɑvə, ɡəlinə kæsbən wɑz lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ə stʃɹeɪ dɔɡ.

"She is collapsing already," the Wise One said in a voice like stone. "Water her, and bring her." Turning away, she adjusted her shawl, Galina Casban forgotten until there was need to recall her; to Therava, Galina Casban was less important than a stray dog.

ɡəlinə dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɹaɪz; ʃi hæd bɪn "wɔɾɝd" ɔfən ɪnʌf baɪ naʊ. ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ ðeɪ lɛɾ əɹ dʒɹɪŋk. eɪkɪŋ fəɹ mɔɪstʃɝ, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪzɪst wən ə blɑki meɪɾən tʊk əɹ baɪ ðə hɛɹ əz θɛɝɑvə hæɾ ən pʊld əɹ hɛd bæk. ʃi dʒʌst oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kʊd. ənʌðɝ meɪɾən, wɪð ə pʌkɝd skɑɹ slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs noʊz ən tʃik, tɪltəɾ ə wɔɾɝskɪn ən sloʊli pɔɹɾ ə tʃɹɪkəl ɪndə ɡəlinəz weɪɾɪŋ maʊð. ðə wɔɾɝ wɑz flæɾ ən wɔɹm; ɪt wɑz dɪlɪʃəs. ʃi swɑloʊd kənvʌlsɪvli, ɔkwɝdli, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ dʒɔz waɪd. ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz wɔɾɝ tə dʒɹɪŋk, ʃi wɑntəd tə muv əɹ feɪs ʌndɝ ðət θɪn stʃɹim, tə lɛɾ ɪt ɹʌn oʊvɝ əɹ tʃiks ən fɔɹhɛd. ɪnstɛd ʃi kɛpt əɹ hɛd vɛɹi stɛɾi, soʊ ðəɾ ɛvɹi dʒɹɑp wɛn daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. spɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ wɑz kɑz fəɹ ənʌðɝ biɾɪŋ; ðeɪ hæd θɹæʃt əɹ ɪn saɪɾ ʌv ə kɹik sɪks peɪsɪz waɪd fəɹ spɪlɪŋ ə maʊθfʊl oʊvɝ əɹ tʃɪn.

Galina did not try to rise; she had been "watered" often enough by now. It was the only way they let her drink. Aching for moisture, she did not resist when a blocky Maiden took her by the hair as Therava had and pulled her head back. She just opened her mouth as far as she could. Another Maiden, with a puckered scar slanting across nose and cheek, tilted a waterskin and slowly poured a trickle into Galina's waiting mouth. The water was flat and warm; it was delicious. She swallowed convulsively, awkwardly, holding her jaws wide. Almost as much as water to drink, she wanted to move her face under that thin stream, to let it run over her cheeks and forehead. Instead she kept her head very steady, so that every drop went down her throat. Spilling water was cause for another beating; they had thrashed her in sight of a creek six paces wide for spilling a mouthful over her chin.

wən ðə wɔɾɝskɪn wɑz faɪnəli teɪkən əweɪ, ðə blɑki meɪɾən hɔld əɹ tə hɝ fit baɪ hɝ baʊn ɛlboʊz. ɡəlinə ɡɹoʊnd. ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ ðɛɹ skɝts oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðɛɹ lɛɡz wɛl əbʌv sɑf ni-haɪ buts. ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɹʌn. nɑɾ əɡɛn. nɑɾ ɪn ðiz maʊntənz.

When the waterskin was finally taken away, the blocky Maiden hauled her to her feet by her bound elbows. Galina groaned. The Wise Ones were gathering their skirts over their arms, exposing their legs well above soft knee-high boots. They could not be going to run. Not again. Not in these mountains.

ðə waɪz wʌnz loʊp fɔɹwɝɾ əz izəli əz ɪf ɑn lɛvəl ɡɹaʊnd. ən ənsin meɪɾən kʌt ɡəlinə əkɹɔs ðə bæk ə hɝ θaɪz wɪð ə swɪtʃ, ən ʃi stʌmbəl tə ə sɛmbləns ʌv ə ɹʌn, hæf-dʒɹæɡd baɪ ðə blɑki meɪɾən. ðə swɪtʃ slæʃt əɹ lɛɡz wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ fɔltɝd. ɪf ðɪs ɹʌn kəntɪnjud ðə ɹɛst ə ðə deɪ, ðeɪ wəd teɪk tɝnz, wʌn meɪɾən wildɪŋ ðə stɪk ən ənʌðɝ dʒɹæɡɪŋ. leɪbɝɪŋ ʌp sloʊps ən nɪɹli slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn, ɡəlinə ɹæn. ə tɔni maʊntən kæt, stʃɹaɪpt ɪn ʃeɪdz ə bɹaʊn ən hɛviɝ ðən ə mæn, snɑɹəld əɾ əm fɹəm ə ɹɑki lɛdʒ əbʌv; ə fimeɪl, lækɪŋ ðə tʌfs ɑn əɹ ɪɹz ən ðə waɪd tʃiks. ɡəlinə wɑntəd tə ʃaʊɾ əɾ əɹ tə fli, tə ɹʌn bɪfɔɹ θɛɝɑvə kɑt hɝ. ði il ɹæn ɑn baɪ ðə snɑɹlɪŋ ænəməl, ʌnkənsɝnd, ən ɡəlinə wɛpt wɪð dʒɛləsi fəɹ ðə kæts fɹiɾəm.

The Wise Ones loped forward as easily as if on level ground. An unseen Maiden cut Galina across the back of her thighs with a switch, and she stumbled to a semblance of a run, half-dragged by the blocky Maiden. The switch slashed her legs whenever they faltered. If this run continued the rest of the day, they would take turns, one Maiden wielding the stick and another dragging. Laboring up slopes and nearly sliding down, Galina ran. A tawny mountain cat, striped in shades of brown and heavier than a man, snarled at them from a rocky ledge above; a female, lacking the tufts on her ears and the wide cheeks. Galina wanted to shout at her to flee, to run before Therava caught her. The Aiel ran on by the snarling animal, unconcerned, and Galina wept with jealousy for the cat's freedom.

ʃi wəd bi ɹɛskjuɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi nu ðæt. ðə taʊɝ wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ə sɪstɝ tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kæptɪvəɾi. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ə ɹɛd tə bi hɛld. ʃʊɹli ɑlviɛɝɪn wəd sɛn ɹɛskju. sʌmwʌn wʊd, ɛniwʌn, tə seɪv əɹ fɹəm ðiz mɑnstɝz, ɪspɛʃli fɹəm θɛɝɑvə. ʃi wəd pɹɑməs ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ðət dɪlɪvɝəns. ʃi wəɾ ivən kip ðoʊz pɹɑməsəz. ʃi hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən fɹi ʌv ðə θɹi oʊðz ɑn dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əm wɪð ə nu tʃɹɪnəɾi, bʌɾ ət ðət moʊmənt ʃi tʃɹuli bɪlivd ʃi wəd kip əɹ wɝd, ɪf ɪt bɹɔt ɹɛskju. ɛni pɹɑməs, tə ɛniwʌn u wəd fɹi hɝ. ivən ə mæn.

She would be rescued eventually, of course; she knew that. The Tower would not allow a sister to remain in captivity. Elaida would not allow a Red to be held. Surely Alviarin would send rescue. Someone would, anyone, to save her from these monsters, especially from Therava. She would promise anything for that deliverance. She would even keep those promises. She had been broken free of the Three Oaths on joining the Black Ajah, replacing them with a new trinity, but at that moment she truly believed she would keep her word, if it brought rescue. Any promise, to anyone who would free her. Even a man.

baɪ ðə taɪm loʊ tɛns əpɪɹd, ðɛɹ dɑɹk kʌlɝz feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəstəd maʊntənsaɪdz əz wɛl əz ðə kæt hæd, ɡəlinə hæd tu meɪɾənz səpɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ, pʊlɪŋ əɹ əlɔŋ. ʃaʊts ɹoʊz fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪd, ɡlæd kɹaɪz ʌv ɡɹiɾɪŋ, bʌt ɡəlinə wɑz dʒɹæɡd ɑn bɪhaɪn ðə waɪz wʌnz, dipɝ ɪndə ðə kæmp, stɪl ɹʌnɪŋ, stʌmbəlɪŋ.

By the time low tents appeared, their dark colors fading into the forested mountainsides as well as the cat had, Galina had two Maidens supporting her, pulling her along. Shouts rose from every side, glad cries of greeting, but Galina was dragged on behind the Wise Ones, deeper into the camp, still running, stumbling.

wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ ðə hænz lɛft əɹ ɑɹmz. ʃi pɪtʃt fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs ən leɪ ðəɹ wɪð əɹ noʊz ɪn ðə dɝɾ ən dɛd livz, sʌkɪŋ ɛɹ θɹu hɝ ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊθ. ʃi kɔft ɑn ə pis ə lif, bʌt ʃi wɑz tu wik tə tɝn əɹ hɛd. ðə blʌd paʊndɪɾ əɹ ɪɹz, bʌt vɔɪsəz keɪm tə hɝ ən sloʊli bɪɡæn tə meɪk sɛns.

Without warning the hands left her arms. She pitched forward on her face and lay there with her nose in the dirt and dead leaves, sucking air through her gaping mouth. She coughed on a piece of leaf, but she was too weak to turn her head. The blood pounded her ears, but voices came to her and slowly began to make sense.

". . . tʊk jəɹ taɪm, θɛɝɑvə," ə fəmɪljɝ-saʊndɪŋ wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd. "naɪn deɪz. wɪv bɪn bæk lɔŋ sɪns."

". . . Took your time, Therava," a familiar-sounding woman's voice said. "Nine days. We have been back long since."

naɪn deɪz? ɡəlinə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, skɹʌbɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. sɪns ði il hæd ʃɑɾ əɹ hɔɹs fɹəm ʌndɝ hɝ, mɛmɹi blɛndəɾ ɔl ðə deɪz ɪndə ə mɛlæŋ ə θɝst ən ɹʌnɪŋ ən biɪŋ biɾən, bʌt ʃʊɹli ɪt hæd bɪn lɔŋɡɝ əɡoʊ ðən naɪn deɪz. wiks, sɝɾənli. ə mʌnθ əɹ mɔɹ.

Nine days? Galina shook her head, scrubbing her face on the ground. Since the Aiel had shot her horse from under her, memory blended all the days into a melange of thirst and running and being beaten, but surely it had been longer ago than nine days. Weeks, certainly. A month or more.

"bɹɪŋ əɹ ɪn," ðə fəmɪljɝ vɔɪs sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli.

"Bring her in," the familiar voice said impatiently.

hænz pʊld əɹ ʌp, ʃʌvd əɹ fɔɹwɝd, bɛndɪŋ əɹ tə ɡoʊ ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ tɛnt wɪð ðə saɪdz ɹeɪzd ɔl ɝaʊnd. ʃi wɑz θɹoʊn daʊn ɑn leɪɝd kɑɹpəts, ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə ɹɛd-ænd-blu tɛɹən meɪz oʊvɝlæpɪŋ ɡɔɾi flaʊɝz bɪniθ əɹ noʊz. wɪð dɪfəkəlti, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd.

Hands pulled her up, shoved her forward, bending her to go under the edge of a large tent with the sides raised all around. She was thrown down on layered carpets, the edge of a red-and-blue Tairen maze overlapping gaudy flowers beneath her nose. With difficulty, she raised her head.

ət fɝst, ʃi sɔ nʌθɪŋ bʌt sɪvænə, siɾəd ɑn ə lɑɹdʒ jɛloʊ-tæsɛl kʊʃən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. sɪvænə wɪð əɹ hɛɹ laɪk faɪn spʌn ɡoʊld, hɝ klɪɹ ɛmɹəld aɪz. tʃɹɛtʃɝəs sɪvænə, hu hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd tə dɪstʃɹækt ətɛnʃən baɪ ɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪndə kɛɹhin, ðən bɹoʊkən əɹ plɛdʒ baɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɹi ælθɹ. sɪvænə, hu ət ðə lis maɪt teɪk əɹ fɹəm θɛɝɑvəz klʌtʃəz.

At first, she saw nothing but Sevanna, seated on a large yellow-tasseled cushion in front of her. Sevanna with her hair like fine spun gold, her clear emerald eyes. Treacherous Sevanna, who had given her word to distract attention by raiding into Cairhien, then broken her pledge by trying to free al'Thor. Sevanna, who at the least might take her from Therava's clutches.

ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld ʌp ɑntu hɝ niz, ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz ɪn ðə tɛnt. θɛɝɑvə sæɾ ɑn ə kʊʃən tə sɪvænəz ɹaɪt, ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə kɝvɪŋ laɪn ʌv waɪz wʌnz, fɔɹtin wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl ɪn ɔl, ðoʊ mɪkɑɹə, hu stɪl hɛl ðə ʃild ɑn hɝ, stʊɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə laɪn ɹæðɝ ðən sɪɾɪŋ. hæf ə ðɛm hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz u kæptʃɝɾ əɹ wɪð sətʃ skɔɹnfəl iz. ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əɡɛn bi soʊ kɛɹləs əbaʊt waɪz wʌnz; nɛvɝ əɡɛn. ʃɔɹt, peɪl-feɪs mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn waɪt ɹoʊbz muv bɪhaɪn ðə waɪz wʌnz, wɝdləsli ɔfɝɪŋ tʃɹeɪz ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ wɪð smɔl kʌps, ən mɔɹ dɪd ðə seɪm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt, wɛɹ ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ən il koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ə bɹaʊn ən ɡɹeɪ sæt tə sɪvænəz lɛft, ət ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə laɪn ə twɛlv stoʊn-feɪst ilmɛn. mɛn. ən ʃi wɔɹ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ əɹ ʃɪft, ɹɪpt ən ɡeɪpɪŋ ɪn ə nʌmbɝ ə pleɪsəz. ɡəlinə klæmpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌt tə staɪfəl ə skɹim. ʃi fɔɹst əɹ bæk stɪf tə kip fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɝoʊ ɪndə ðə ɹʌɡz ən haɪd fɹəm ðoʊz koʊl meɪl aɪz.

She struggled up onto her knees, and for the first time realized there were others in the tent. Therava sat on a cushion to Sevanna's right, at the head of a curving line of Wise Ones, fourteen women who could channel in all, though Micara, who still held the shield on her, stood at the foot of the line rather than sitting. Half of them had been among the Wise Ones who captured her with such scornful ease. She would never again be so careless about Wise Ones; never again. Short, pale-faced men and women in white robes moved behind the Wise Ones, wordlessly offering trays of gold or silver with small cups, and more did the same on the other side of the tent, where a gray-haired woman in an Aiel coat and breeches of brown and gray sat to Sevanna's left, at the head of a line of twelve stone-faced Aielmen. Men. And she wore nothing but her shift, ripped and gaping in a number of places. Galina clamped her teeth shut to stifle a scream. She forced her back stiff to keep from trying to burrow into the rugs and hide from those cold male eyes.

"ɪt simz ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən laɪ," sɪvænə sɛd, ən ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɡəlinəz feɪs. ðə wʊmən kəd nɑt noʊ; ʃi kəd nɑt. "ju meɪd plɛdʒɪz, ɡəlinə kæsbən, ən bɹoʊk ðɛm. dɪd jə θɪŋk jə kəd mɝɾɝ ə waɪz wʌn ən ðən ɹʌn bɪɑn ðə ɹitʃ ʌv əɹ spɪɹz?"

"It seems that Aes Sedai can lie," Sevanna said, and the blood drained from Galina's face. The woman could not know; she could not. "You made pledges, Galina Casban, and broke them. Did you think you could murder a Wise One and then run beyond the reach of our spears?"

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɹɪlif fɹoʊz ɡəlinəz tʌŋ. sɪvænə dɪd nɑt noʊ əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ. hæd ʃi nɑɾ əbændən ðə laɪt lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ʃi wʊɾə θæŋk ðə laɪt. ɹɪlif stɪld əɹ tʌŋ, ən ə taɪni spɑɹk ʌv ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. ðeɪ ətækt ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɝ æŋɡɹi wən səm ə ðɛm daɪd? ə taɪni spɑɹk wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd mænədʒ. æftɝ ɔl, wʌt wɑz sɪvænəz twɪstɪŋ fæks əlɔŋsaɪd deɪz ə biɾɪŋz ən θɛɝɑvəz aɪz? ə peɪnd, kɹoʊkɪŋ læf bʌbəld ʌp ət ði əbsɝɾəti ʌv ɪt. hɝ θɹoʊt wɑz soʊ dʒɹaɪ.

For a moment, relief froze Galina's tongue. Sevanna did not know about the Black Ajah. Had she not abandoned the Light long ago, she would have thanked the Light. Relief stilled her tongue, and a tiny spark of indignation. They attacked Aes Sedai and were angry when some of them died? A tiny spark was all she could manage. After all, what was Sevanna's twisting facts alongside days of beatings and Therava's eyes? A pained, croaking laugh bubbled up at the absurdity of it. Her throat was so dry.

"bi θæŋkfəl səm ə jə stɪl laɪv," ʃi mænədʒ pæst əɹ læftɝ. "ivən naʊ ɪts nɑt tu leɪt tə ɹɛktəfaɪ jəɹ mɪsteɪks, sɪvænə." wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi swɑloʊd ɹufəl mɝθ bɪfɔɹ ɪt tɝn tə tɛɹz. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ. "wɛn aɪ ɹɪtɝn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðoʊz u əsɪs mi, ivən naʊ." ʃi wəɾ əv æɾəd, "æn ðoʊz u də ʌðɝwaɪz," bʌt θɛɝɑvəz ənweɪvɝɪŋ stɛɹ sɛt fɪɹ flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl. fəɹ ɔl ʃi nu, θɛɝɑvə stɪl maɪt bi əlaʊd tə də wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɪʃt. ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə ɪndus sɪvænə tə . . . teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ə hɝ. ðət teɪstəd bɪɾɝ, jɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən θɛɝɑvə. sɪvænə wɑz æmbɪʃəs, ən ɡɹiɾi. ɪn ðə mɪdst ə fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ɡəlinə, ʃi hæd kɑt saɪɾ ə hɝ oʊn hæn ən dɝɛktəɾ ə bɹif, ædmaɪɹɪŋ smaɪl ət ɹɪŋz sɛt wɪð lɑɹdʒ ɛmɹəlz ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps. ʃi wɔɹ ɹɪŋz ɑn hæf əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ən nɛkləsɪz ə pɝlz ən ɹubiz ən daɪmənz fɪt fəɹ ɛni kwin dʒɹeɪpt əkɹɔs ðə swɛl ə hɝ bʊzəm. sɪvænə kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi kəd bi bɑt. θɛɝɑvə wɑz ə fɔɹs ə neɪtʃɝ; əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə baɪ ə flʌɾ əɹ ən ævəlæntʃ. "aɪ tʃɹʌs ðət jəl də wʌɾ ɪz ɹaɪt, sɪvænə," ʃi fɪnɪʃt. "ðə ɹɪwɔɹdz ə fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑɹ ɡɹeɪt."

"Be thankful some of you still live," she managed past her laughter. "Even now it is not too late to rectify your mistakes, Sevanna." With an effort, she swallowed rueful mirth before it turned to tears. Just before. "When I return to the White Tower, I will remember those who assist me, even now." She would have added, "and those who do otherwise," but Therava's unwavering stare set fear fluttering in her middle. For all she knew, Therava still might be allowed to do whatever she wished. There had to be some way to induce Sevanna to . . . take charge of her. That tasted bitter, yet anything was better than Therava. Sevanna was ambitious, and greedy. In the midst of frowning at Galina, she had caught sight of her own hand and directed a brief, admiring smile at rings set with large emeralds and firedrops. She wore rings on half her fingers, and necklaces of pearls and rubies and diamonds fit for any queen draped across the swell of her bosom. Sevanna could not be trusted, but perhaps she could be bought. Therava was a force of nature; as well try to buy a flood or an avalanche. "I trust that you will do what is right, Sevanna," she finished. "The rewards of friendship with the White Tower are great."

fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wɪspɝ ə ðə waɪt ɹoʊbz əz ðə sɝvəns muvd wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz. ðɛn. . . .

For a long moment, there was silence except for the whisper of the white robes as the servants moved with their trays. Then. . . .

"ju ɑɹ dætsæŋ," sɪvænə sɛd. ɡəlinə blɪŋkt. ʃi wɑz ə dɪspaɪzd wʌn? sɝɾənli ðeɪ hæd dɪspleɪd ðɛɹ kəntɛmpt pleɪnli, bʌt waɪ - ?

"You are da'tsang," Sevanna said. Galina blinked. She was a despised one? Certainly they had displayed their contempt plainly, but why - ?

"ju ɑɹ dætsæŋ," ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst waɪz wʌn ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪntoʊnd, ən ə wʊmən ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən θɛɝɑvə ɹɪpiɾɪd, "ju ɑɹ dætsæŋ."

"You are da'tsang," a round-faced Wise One she did not know intoned, and a woman a hand taller than Therava repeated, "You are da'tsang."

θɛɝɑvəz hɔklaɪk feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm wʊd, jɛɾ əɹ aɪz, fɪkst ɑn ɡəlinə, ɡlɪɾɝd əkjuzɪŋli. ɡəlinə fɛl neɪl tə ðə spɑt wɛɹ ʃi nɛlt, əneɪbəl tə muv ə mʌsəl. ə hɪpnətaɪz bɝd wɑtʃɪŋ ə sɝpən slaɪðɝ nɪɹɝ. noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ meɪɾ əɹ fil ðət weɪ. noʊ wʌn.

Therava's hawklike face might have been carved from wood, yet her eyes, fixed on Galina, glittered accusingly. Galina felt nailed to the spot where she knelt, unable to move a muscle. A hypnotized bird watching a serpent slither nearer. No one had ever made her feel that way. No one.

"θɹi waɪz wʌnz əv spoʊkən." sɪvænəz sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl wɑz ɔlmoʊst wɛlkəmɪŋ. θɛɝɑvəz feɪs wɑz stɑɹk. ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt laɪk wʌtɛvɝ hæd dʒʌs hæpənd. sʌmθɪŋ hæd hæpənd, ivən ɪf ɡəlinə dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə hæv dɪlɪvɝɾ əɹ fɹəm θɛɝɑvə. ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf.

"Three Wise Ones have spoken." Sevanna's satisfied smile was almost welcoming. Therava's face was stark. The woman did not like whatever had just happened. Something had happened, even if Galina did not know what. Except that it appeared to have delivered her from Therava. That was more than enough for the moment. More than enough.

wən meɪɾənz kʌɾ əɹ baʊnz ən stʌft əɹ ɪndə ə blæk wʊl ɹoʊb, ʃi wɑz soʊ ɡɹeɪtfəl ʃi ɔlmoʊs dɪd nɑt kɛɹ ðət ðeɪ tɔɹ ɔf ðə ɹɛmnəns ə hɝ ʃɪft fɝst, ɪn fɹʌn ə ðoʊz aɪs-aɪd mɛn. ðə θɪk wʊl wɑz hɑɾ ən ɪtʃi ən skɹætʃi ɑn əɹ wɛls, ən ʃi wɛlkəmd ɪɾ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ sɪlk. dɪspaɪt mɪkɑɹə stɪl ʃildɪŋ hɝ, ʃi cʊɾə læft əz ðə meɪɾənz lɛɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ fəɹ ðət dɪzaɪɝ tə vænɪʃ ɪntaɪɝli. ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk əɹ lɔŋ tə bɪɡɪn wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ bɛɡɪŋ ɑn əɹ niz bɪfɔɹ sɪvænə wəd də ɛni ɡʊd. ʃi wʊɾə dʌn ɪt, kəd ʃi hæv ɡɑɾən tə ðə wʊmən, ɪksɛp ðət mɪkɑɹə meɪɾ ɪt pleɪn ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ʃi wɑz nɑt toʊl tə ɡoʊ, əɹ spik ə wɝɾ ənlɛs spoʊkən tə.

When Maidens cut her bounds and stuffed her into a black wool robe, she was so grateful she almost did not care that they tore off the remnants of her shift first, in front of those ice-eyed men. The thick wool was hot and itchy and scratchy on her welts, and she welcomed it as though it were silk. Despite Micara still shielding her, she could have laughed as the Maidens led her out of the tent. It did not take long for that desire to vanish entirely. It did not take her long to begin wondering whether begging on her knees before Sevanna would do any good. She would have done it, could she have gotten to the woman, except that Micara made it plain she was not going anywhere she was not told to go, or speak a word unless spoken to.

ɑɹmz foʊldəd, sɪvænə wɑtʃt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə dætsæŋ, stæɡɝ daʊn ðə maʊntənsaɪɾ ən stɑp, bɪsaɪɾ ə meɪɾən skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ hilz wɪð ə swɪtʃ, tə dʒɹɑp ðə hɛd-ʃeɪp stoʊn ʃi hæd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ ɪn əɹ hænz. ðə blæk hʊd tɝn ɪn sɪvænəz dɝɛkʃən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt ðə dætsæŋ kwɪkli bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ənʌðɝ lɑɹdʒ stoʊn ən tɝn tə leɪbɝ bæk ʌp ðə fɪfti peɪsɪz tə wɛɹ mɪkɑɹə weɪɾəd wɪð ənʌðɝ meɪɾən. ðəɹ ʃi dʒɹɑp ðət stoʊn, pɪkt ʌp ənʌðɝ, ən stɑɹɾəd bæk daʊn. dætsæŋ wɝ ɔlweɪz ʃeɪmd wɪð jusləs leɪbɝ; ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz ɡɹeɪt nid, ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə kæɹi ivən ə kʌp ʌv wɔɾɝ, jɛt tɔɪl wɪθaʊt pɝpəs wəd fɪl əɹ aʊɝz tɪl ʃi bɝst ə ʃeɪm. ðə sʌn hæɾ ə lɔŋ weɪ tə klaɪm jɛt, ən mɛni mɔɹ deɪz leɪ əhɛd.

Arms folded, Sevanna watched the Aes Sedai, the da'tsang, stagger down the mountainside and stop, beside a Maiden squatting on her heels with a switch, to drop the head-shaped stone she had been carrying in her hands. The black hood turned in Sevanna's direction for a moment, but the da'tsang quickly bent to pick up another large stone and turned to labor back up the fifty paces to where Micara waited with another Maiden. There she dropped that stone, picked up another, and started back down. Da'tsang were always shamed with useless labor; unless there was great need, the woman would not be allowed to carry even a cup of water, yet toil without purpose would fill her hours till she burst of shame. The sun had a long way to climb yet, and many more days lay ahead.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəd kəndɛm hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə hɝ oʊn maʊθ," ɹiɑli sɛɾ ət sɪvænəz ʃoʊldɝ. "ɛfɑlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɔl bʌt ʃʊɹ ʃi oʊpənli ədmɪɾəd kɪlɪŋ deɪseɪn."

"I did not think she would condemn herself out of her own mouth," Rhiale said at Sevanna's shoulder. "Efalin and the others are all but sure she openly admitted killing Desaine."

"ʃi ɪz maɪn, sɪvænə." θɛɝɑvəz dʒɔ taɪɾənd. ʃi maɪɾ əv teɪkən ðə wʊmən, bʌt dætsæŋ bɪlɔŋ tə noʊ wʌn. "aɪ ɪntɛndəd tə dʒɹɛs əɹ ɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz ə sɪlk," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə pɝpəs ə ðɪs, sɪvænə? aɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv tə ɑɹɡju əɡɛns kʌɾɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊt, nɑt ðɪs."

"She is mine, Sevanna." Therava's jaw tightened. She might have taken the woman, but da'tsang belonged to no one. "I intended to dress her in gai'shain robes of silk," she muttered. "What is the purpose of this, Sevanna? I expected to have to argue against cutting her throat, not this."

ɹiɑli tɔst əɹ hɛd, kæstɪŋ ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns ət sɪvænə. "sɪvænə ɪntɛnz tə bɹeɪk hɝ. wɪv hæd lɔŋ tɔks ʌv wʌt tə də ʃəd wi kæptʃɝ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. sɪvænə wɑns ə teɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ tə wɛɹ waɪɾ ən sɝv hɝ. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn blæk wɪl də wɛl ɪnʌf, ðoʊ."

Rhiale tossed her head, casting a sidelong glance at Sevanna. "Sevanna intends to break her. We have had long talks of what to do should we capture any Aes Sedai. Sevanna wants a tame Aes Sedai to wear white and serve her. An Aes Sedai in black will do well enough, though."

sɪvænə ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl, ɪɹəteɪɾəd baɪ ðə wʊmənz toʊn. nɑt kwaɪt mɑkɪŋ, bʌɾ ɔl tu əwɛɹ ðət ʃi wɑntəd sʌmhaʊ tə juz ði ɛɛs sədaɪz tʃænəlɪŋ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ sɪvænəz oʊn. ɪt wəd bi pɑsəbəl. tu ɡeɪʃeɪn pæs ðə θɹi waɪz wʌnz, kæɹiɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ bɹæs-stʃɹæp tʃɛs bɪtwin ðɛm. ʃɔɹɾ ən peɪl-feɪst, hʌzbən ən waɪf, ðeɪ hæd bɪn lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi ɪn ðə tʃɹikɪlɝz' lænz. ðə pɛɹ baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz mɔɹ mikli ðən ɛni il ɪn waɪɾ ɛvɝ kəɾ əv mænədʒd; ðɛɹ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ taɪt wɪð fɪɹ ʌv ə hɑɹʃ wɝd, mʌtʃ lɛs ə swɪtʃ. wɛtləndɝz kəd bi teɪm laɪk hɔɹsəz.

Sevanna shifted her shawl, irritated by the woman's tone. Not quite mocking, but all too aware that she wanted somehow to use the Aes Sedai's channeling as though it were Sevanna's own. It would be possible. Two gai'shain passed the three Wise Ones, carrying a large brass-strapped chest between them. Short and pale-faced, husband and wife, they had been Lord and Lady in the treekillers' lands. The pair bowed their heads more meekly than any Aiel in white ever could have managed; their dark eyes were tight with fear of a harsh word, much less a switch. Wetlanders could be tamed like horses.

"ðə wʊmən ɪz teɪmd ɔlɹɛɾi," θɛɝɑvə ɡɹʌmbəld. "aɪ hæv lʊkt ɪndə hɝ aɪz. ʃiz ə bɝd flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə hæn ən əfɹeɪd tə flaɪ."

"The woman is tamed already," Therava grumbled. "I have looked into her eyes. She is a bird fluttering in the hand and afraid to fly."

"ɪn naɪn deɪz?" ɹiɑli sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, ən sɪvænə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd vɪɡɝəsli.

"In nine days?" Rhiale said incredulously, and Sevanna shook her head vigorously.

"ʃi ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ, θɛɝɑvə. jə sɔ hɝ feɪs ɡoʊ peɪl wɪð fjʊɹi wən aɪ əkjuz hɝ. jə hɝɾ əɹ læf əz ʃi spoʊk ə kɪlɪŋ waɪz wʌnz." ʃi meɪɾ ə vɛkst, æŋɡɹi saʊnd. "æn jə hɝɾ əɹ θɹɛɾən ʌs." ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn əz slɪpɝi əz ðə tʃɹikɪlɝz, spikɪŋ ə ɹɪwɔɹdz ən lɛɾɪŋ ðə θɹɛɾ ɪf noʊ ɹɪwɔɹdz keɪm ʃaʊt saɪlənli. bʌt wʌɾ ɛls kəd bi ɪkspɛktəɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ? "ɪt wɪl teɪk lɔŋ tə bɹeɪk hɝ, bʌt ðɪs ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl bɛɡ tə oʊbeɪ ɪf ɪt teɪks ə jɪɹ." wʌns ʃi dɪd ðæt. . . . ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt laɪ, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ɡəlinə tə dɪnaɪ hɝ ækjəzeɪʃən. wʌns ʃi swɔɹ tə oʊbeɪ. . . .

"She is Aes Sedai, Therava. You saw her face go pale with fury when I accused her. You heard her laugh as she spoke of killing Wise Ones." She made a vexed, angry sound. "And you heard her threaten us." The woman had been as slippery as the treekillers, speaking of rewards and letting the threat if no rewards came shout silently. But what else could be expected of Aes Sedai? "It will take long to break her, but this Aes Sedai will beg to obey if it takes a year." Once she did that. . . . Aes Sedai could not lie, of course; she had expected Galina to deny her accusation. Once she swore to obey. . . .

"ɪf jə wɑnə meɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ oʊbeɪ ju," ə mænz vɔɪs sɛd bɪhaɪn hɝ, "ðɪs maɪt hɛlp."

"If you want to make an Aes Sedai obey you," a man's voice said behind her, "this might help."

ɪnkɹɛdʒələs, sɪvænə spʌn əbaʊt tə faɪn kædɑɝ stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, ən bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ðə wʊmən - ði ɛɛs sədaɪ - mzə, boʊθ dʒɹɛst ɪn dɑɹk sɪlk ən faɪn leɪs əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɪks deɪz əɡoʊ, itʃ wɪð ə bʌlʒɪŋ sæk hæŋɪŋ ɪŋkɔŋɹuəsli fɹəm wʌn ʃoʊldɝ baɪ ə stʃɹæp. kædɑɝ hɛld aʊɾ ə smuð waɪt ɹɑɾ əbaʊɾ ə fʊt lɔŋ ɪn wʌn dɑɹk hænd.

Incredulous, Sevanna spun about to find Caddar standing there, and beside him the woman - the Aes Sedai - Maisia, both dressed in dark silk and fine lace as they had been six days ago, each with a bulging sack hanging incongruously from one shoulder by a strap. Caddar held out a smooth white rod about a foot long in one dark hand.

"haʊ dɪd jə kʌm hɪɹ?" ʃi dɪmændəd, ðən kəmpɹɛst əɹ lɪps ɪn æŋɡɝ. pleɪnli hi hæd kʌm əz i hæd bɪfɔɹ; ʃi wɑz dʒʌst sɝpɹaɪzd əɾ ɪm əpɪɹɪŋ hɪɹ, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kæmp. ʃi snætʃt ðə waɪt ɹɑɾ i ɔfɝd, ən əz ɔlweɪz i stɛp bæk bɪɑn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ. "waɪ hæv jə kʌm?" ʃi əmɛndəd. "wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs?" ə lɪɾəl slɪmɝ ðən əɹ ɹɪst, ðə ɹɑd wɑz smuð ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju ɑd, floʊɪŋ sɪmbəlz ɪnsaɪzd ɑn wʌn flæɾ ɛnd. ɪt fɛl nɑt kwaɪt laɪk aɪvɝi, nɑt kwaɪt laɪk ɡlæs. vɛɹi kul tə ðə tʌtʃ.

"How did you come here?" she demanded, then compressed her lips in anger. Plainly he had come as he had before; she was just surprised at him appearing here, in the middle of the camp. She snatched the white rod he offered, and as always he stepped back beyond arm's reach. "Why have you come?" she amended. "What is this?" A little slimmer than her wrist, the rod was smooth except for a few odd, flowing symbols incised on one flat end. It felt not quite like ivory, not quite like glass. Very cool to the touch.

"ju maɪt kɔl ɪɾ ən oʊθ ɹɑd," kædɑɝ sɛd, ʃoʊɪŋ tiθ ɪn wʌt wɑz daʊtləs mɛn fəɹ ə smaɪl. "ɪɾ oʊnli keɪm ɪndə maɪ hænz jɛstɝdeɪ, ən aɪ ɪmiɾiətli θɔɾ ə ju."

"You might call it an Oath Rod," Caddar said, showing teeth in what was doubtless meant for a smile. "It only came into my hands yesterday, and I immediately thought of you."

sɪvænə klæmpt əɹ hænz taɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɹɑd tə kip fɹəm hɝlɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ. ɛvɹiwʌn nu wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz oʊθ ɹɑd dɪd. tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑɾ ivən tə θɪŋk, mʌtʃ lɛs spik, ʃi θɹʌst ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt ən tʊk əɹ hænz əweɪ.

Sevanna clamped her hands tight around the rod to keep from hurling it away. Everyone knew what the Aes Sedai's Oath Rod did. Trying not even to think, much less speak, she thrust it behind her belt and took her hands away.

ɹiɑli fɹaʊn ət ðə ɹɑɾ ət sɪvænəz weɪst, ən əɹ aɪz ɹoʊz sloʊli, koʊldli, tə sɪvænəz feɪs. θɛɝɑvə ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ɪn ə klæɾɝ ə bɹeɪslɪts, ən ɡeɪv ə hɑɹd, θɪn smaɪl. ðəɹ wəd nɛvɝ bi ɛni tʃæns ʌv wʌn ə ðɛm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹɑɾ ən meɪbi noʊ tʃæns ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ waɪz wʌn duɪŋ soʊ iðɝ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ɡəlinə kæsbən. wʌn deɪ ʃi wəd bɹeɪk.

Rhiale frowned at the rod at Sevanna's waist, and her eyes rose slowly, coldly, to Sevanna's face. Therava adjusted her shawl in a clatter of bracelets, and gave a hard, thin smile. There would never be any chance of one of them touching the rod and maybe no chance of any other Wise One doing so either. But there was still Galina Casban. One day she would break.

ɹeɪvən-aɪd mzə, ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn kædɑɝ, smaɪld ɔlmoʊst əz feɪnli əz θɛɝɑvə. ʃi hæd sin, ən ʌndɝstʊd. ʃi wɑz əbzɝvənt, fəɹ ə wɛtləndɝ.

Raven-eyed Maisia, a little behind Caddar, smiled almost as faintly as Therava. She had seen, and understood. She was observant, for a wetlander.

"kʌm," sɪvænə toʊl kædɑɝ. "wi wɪl dʒɹɪŋk ti ɪn maɪ tɛnt." ʃi sɝɾənli wəd nɑt ʃɛɹ wɔɾɝ wɪð hɪm. lɪftɪŋ əɹ skɝts, ʃi stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə sloʊp.

"Come," Sevanna told Caddar. "We will drink tea in my tent." She certainly would not share water with him. Lifting her skirts, she started up the slope.

tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, kædɑɝ wɑz ɔlsoʊ əbzɝvənt. "ɔl jə nid də ɪz əv jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ" - wɔkɪŋ izəli bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ɪz lɔŋ lɛɡz, hi ɡɹɪn sʌɾənli, tuthəli, ət ɹiɑli ən θɛɝɑvə - "ɔɹ ɛni wʊmən u kən tʃænəl hoʊl ðə ɹɑɾ ən spik wʌtɛvɝ pɹɑməsəz jə wɪʃ waɪl sʌmwʌn tʃænəlz ə lɪɾəl spɪɹəɾ ɪndə ðə nʌmbɝ. ðə mɑɹks ɑn ði ɛn ə ðə ɹɑd?" hi æɾəd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɪnsʌltɪŋli. "ju kən juz ɪt tə ɹilis hɝ, tu, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz mɔɹ peɪnfəl. əɹ soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

To her surprise, Caddar was also observant. "All you need do is have your Aes Sedai" - walking easily beside her on his long legs, he grinned suddenly, toothily, at Rhiale and Therava - "or any woman who can channel hold the rod and speak whatever promises you wish while someone channels a little Spirit into the number. The marks on the end of the rod?" he added, raising his eyebrows insultingly. "You can use it to release her, too, but that is more painful. Or so I understand."

sɪvænəz fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃt ðə ɹɑd laɪtli. mɔɹ ɡlæs ðən aɪvɝi, ən vɛɹi kul. "ɪɾ oʊnli wɝks ɑn wɪmən?" ʃi dʌkt ɪndə ðə tɛn əhɛɾ ə hɪm. ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ðə liɾɝz ə ðə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz wɝ ɡɔn, bʌt ðə dʌzən tʃɹikɪlɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹɪmeɪnd, nilɪŋ peɪʃənli tə wʌn saɪd. noʊ wʌn pɝsən hæɾ ɛvɝ kɛpt ə dʌzən ɡeɪʃeɪn bɪfɔɹ, ən ʃi pəzɛs mɔɹ. ðəɹ wəɾ əv tə bi ə nu neɪm fəɹ ðɛm, ðoʊ, sɪns ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ pʊɾ ɔf ðə waɪt.

Sevanna's fingers touched the rod lightly. More glass than ivory, and very cool. "It only works on women?" She ducked into the tent ahead of him. The Wise Ones and the leaders of the warrior societies were gone, but the dozen treekiller gai'shain remained, kneeling patiently to one side. No one person had ever kept a dozen gai'shain before, and she possessed more. There would have to be a new name for them, though, since they would never put off the white.

"wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, sɪvænə," kædɑɝ sɛd, fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ ɪn. ðə mænz toʊn wɑz ɪnkɹɛɾəbli ɪnsələnt. hɪz dɑɹk aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð oʊpən əmjuzmənt. "ju wɪl əv tə weɪɾ əntɪl juv ælθɹ bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡɪv jə wʌt wɪl kəntʃɹoʊl hɪm."

"Women who can channel, Sevanna," Caddar said, following her in. The man's tone was incredibly insolent. His dark eyes shone with open amusement. "You will have to wait until you have al'Thor before I give you what will control him."

ɹimuvɪŋ ðə sæk fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hi sæt. nɑɾ ɑn ə kʊʃən nɪɹ hɝz, ʌv kɔɹs. mzə wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ə bleɪɾ ɪn əɹ ɹɪbz; ʃi laʊnʒd ɑn ən ɛlboʊ ɔlmoʊst ət sɪvænəz saɪd. sɪvænə aɪɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, ðən kæʒəwəli əndɪɾ ənʌðɝ leɪs ə hɝ oʊn blaʊs. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹikɔl ðə wʊmənz bʊzəm biɪŋ əz ɹaʊn əz ðæt. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hɝ feɪs simd ivən mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl, əz wɛl. sɪvænə tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ.

Removing the sack from his shoulder, he sat. Not on a cushion near hers, of course. Maisia was not afraid of a blade in her ribs; she lounged on an elbow almost at Sevanna's side. Sevanna eyed her sideways, then casually undid another lace of her own blouse. She did not recall the woman's bosom being as round as that. For that matter, her face seemed even more beautiful, as well. Sevanna tried not to grind her teeth.

"ʌv kɔɹs," kædɑɝ wɛn ɑn, "ɪf jə min səm ʌðɝ mæn - ðəɹ ɪz ə θɪŋ kɔld ə baɪndɪŋ tʃɛɹ. baɪndɪŋ pipəl u kænɑt tʃænəl ɪz mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən baɪndɪŋ ðoʊz u kæn. pɝhæps ə baɪndɪŋ tʃɛɹ sɝvaɪv ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, bʌt jəl əv tə weɪt waɪl aɪ faɪn ɪt."

"Of course," Caddar went on, "if you mean some other man - There is a thing called a binding chair. Binding people who cannot channel is more difficult than binding those who can. Perhaps a binding chair survived the Breaking, but you will have to wait while I find it."

sɪvænə tʌtʃt ðə ɹɑɾ əɡɛn, ðən ɪmpeɪʃənli ɔɹɾɝd wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn tə bɹɪŋ ti. ʃi kəd weɪt. kædɑɝ wɑz ə ful. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ i wəd ɡɪv əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəɾ ə hɪm. ən naʊ ðə ɹɑd kəd bɹeɪk mzə fɹi ʌv hɪm. ʃʊɹli ðən ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt pɹətɛk hɪm. fəɹ ɪz ɪnsʌls, hi wəd wɛɹ blæk. sɪvænə tʊk ə smɔl ɡɹin pɔɹsələn kʌp fɹəm ðə tʃɹeɪ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn hɛld ən ɡeɪv ɪt tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð əɹ oʊn hænz. "ɪɾ ɪz fleɪvɝd wɪð mɪnt, mzə. jəl faɪn ɪt ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ."

Sevanna touched the rod again, then impatiently ordered one of the gai'shain to bring tea. She could wait. Caddar was a fool. Sooner or later he would give her everything she wanted of him. And now the rod could break Maisia free of him. Surely then the woman would not protect him. For his insults, he would wear black. Sevanna took a small green porcelain cup from the tray the gai'shain held and gave it to the Aes Sedai with her own hands. "It is flavored with mint, Maisia. You will find it refreshing."

ðə wʊmən smaɪld, bʌt ðoʊz blæk aɪz. . . . wɛl, wʌt kəd bi dʌn tə wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd bi dʌn tə tu. əɹ mɔɹ.

The woman smiled, but those black eyes. . . . Well, what could be done to one Aes Sedai could be done to two. Or more.

"wʌɾ ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑksəz?" sɪvænə dɪmændəd kɝtli.

"What of the traveling boxes?" Sevanna demanded curtly.

kædɑɝ weɪv ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn əweɪ ən pæɾəd ðə sæk bɪsaɪd hɪm. "aɪ bɹɔɾ əz mɛni nɑɹbɑhə - ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ kɔld - əz mɛni əz aɪ kəd faɪnd. ɪnʌf tə tʃɹænspɔɹɾ ɔl ə jə baɪ naɪtfɔl, ɪf jə hɝi. ən aɪ wʊd, ɪf aɪ wɝ ju. ælθɹ minz tə fɪnɪʃ ju, ɪt simz. tu klænz ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə saʊθ, ən tu mɔɹ ɑɹ muvɪŋ tə kʌm daʊn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ. wɪð ðɛɹ waɪz wʌnz, ɔl ɹɛɾi tə tʃænəl. ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ tə steɪ əntɪl ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə jə ɪz dɛɾ əɹ ə pɹɪznɝ."

Caddar waved the gai'shain away and patted the sack beside him. "I brought as many nar'baha - that is what they were called - as many as I could find. Enough to transport all of you by nightfall, if you hurry. And I would, if I were you. Al'Thor means to finish you, it seems. Two clans are coming up from the south, and two more are moving to come down from the north. With their Wise Ones, all ready to channel. Their orders are to stay until every last one of you is dead or a prisoner."

θɛɝɑvə snɪft. "ə ɹizən tə muv, sɝɾənli, wɛtləndɝ, bʌt nɑt tə ɹʌn. ivən fɔɹ klænz kænɑt swip kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ ɪn ə deɪ."

Therava sniffed. "A reason to move, certainly, wetlander, but not to run. Even four clans cannot sweep Kinslayer's Dagger in a day."

"dɪdn aɪ seɪ?" kædɑɝz smaɪl wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plɛzənt. "ɪt simz ælθɹ əz baʊn səm ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɪm, tu, ən ðeɪv tɔt ðə waɪz wʌnz haʊ tə tʃɹævəl wɪθaʊɾ ə nɑɹbɑhə, oʊvɝ ʃɔɹt dɪstənsəz, ət list. twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi maɪlz. ə ɹisən ɹiɾɪskʌvɹi, ɪt simz. ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ - wɛl, tədeɪ. ɔl fɔɹ klænz."

"Didn't I say?" Caddar's smile was not at all pleasant. "It seems al'Thor has bound some Aes Sedai to him, too, and they have taught the Wise Ones how to Travel without a nar'baha, over short distances, at least. Twenty or thirty miles. A recent rediscovery, it seems. They could be here - well, today. All four clans."

meɪbi hi laɪd, jɛt ðə ɹɪsk. . . . sɪvænə kəɾ ɪmædʒən ɔl tu wɛl biɪŋ ɪn sɔɹɪliəz ɡɹɪp. nɑɾ əlaʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ʃɪvɝ, ʃi sɛn ɹiɑli tə ɪnfɔɹm ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz. hɝ vɔɪs bɪtʃɹeɪd nʌθɪŋ.

Maybe he lied, yet the risk. . . . Sevanna could imagine all too well being in Sorilea's grip. Not allowing herself to shiver, she sent Rhiale to inform the other Wise Ones. Her voice betrayed nothing.

ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndə hɪz bæɡ, kædɑɝ dʒɹu aʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn kjub, smɔlɝ ðən ðə kælbɑks ʃi hæd juz tə sʌmən hɪm, ən mʌtʃ pleɪnɝ, wɪð noʊ mɑɹkɪŋ bʌɾ ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd dɪsk sɛɾ ɪn wʌn feɪs. "ðɪs ɪz ə nɑɹbɑhə," hi sɛd. "ɪt juzɪz seɪɾɪn, soʊ nʌn ə jəl si ɛniθɪŋ, ən ɪts lɪməts. ɪf ə wʊmən tʌtʃəz ɪt, ɪt woʊnt wɝk fəɹ deɪz æftɝwɝd, soʊ əl əv tə hæn əm aʊt maɪsɛlf, ən ɪts ʌðɝ lɪməts. wʌns oʊpənd, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪl ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ ə fɪks taɪm, səfɪʃən fəɹ ə fju θaʊzən tə ɡoʊ θɹu ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt weɪs taɪm, ən ðə nɑɹbɑhə nidz θɹi deɪz tə ɹɪkʌvɝ æftɝwɝd. aɪ hæv ɪnʌf ɛkstʃɹə tə kæɹi əs wɛɹ wi nid tə ɡoʊ tədeɪ, bʌt. . . ."

Reaching into his bag, Caddar drew out a gray stone cube, smaller than the callbox she had used to summon him, and much plainer, with no marking but a bright red disc set in one face. "This is a nar'baha," he said. "It uses saidin, so none of you will see anything, and it has limits. If a woman touches it, it won't work for days afterward, so I will have to hand them out myself, and it has other limits. Once opened, the gateway will remain for a fixed time, sufficient for a few thousand to go through if they don't waste time, and the nar'baha needs three days to recover afterward. I have enough extra to carry us where we need to go today, but. . . ."

θɛɝɑvə lin fɔɹwɝd soʊ ɪntɛnli ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt tə fɔl oʊvɝ, bʌt sɪvænə hɑɹdli lɪsənd. ʃi dɪd nɑt daʊt kædɑɝ, ɪɡzækli; hi wəd nɑt dɛɹ bɪtʃɹeɪ ðɛm, nɑt waɪl i hʌŋɡɝd fəɹ ðə ɡoʊl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wəd ɡɪv hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ smɔl θɪŋz, ðoʊ. mzə sim tə stʌɾi hɪm oʊvɝ əɹ ti. waɪ? ən ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ nid fəɹ spid, waɪ wɑz ðəɹ noʊ ɝdʒənsi ɪn ɪz vɔɪs? hi wəd nɑt bɪtʃɹeɪ, bʌt ʃi wəd teɪk pɹikɔʃənz ɛniweɪ.

Therava leaned forward so intently she looked about to fall over, but Sevanna hardly listened. She did not doubt Caddar, exactly; he would not dare betray them, not while he hungered for the gold the Shaido would give him. There were small things, though. Maisia seemed to study him over her tea. Why? And if there was such need for speed, why was there no urgency in his voice? He would not betray, but she would take precautions anyway.

mɛɹɪk fɹaʊn ət ðə stoʊn kjub ðə wɛtləndɝ hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, ðən ət ðə . . . hoʊl . . . ðət hæɾ əpɪɹd wən i pɹɛs ðə ɹɛd spɑt. ə hoʊl, faɪv peɪsɪz waɪɾ ən θɹi haɪ, ɪn mɪdɛɹ. bɪɑn leɪ ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz, nɑt loʊ, kʌvɝd wɪð bɹaʊn ɡɹæs. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk θɪŋz tə də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ðə meɪl pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. sɪvænə stɛp θɹu ənʌðɝ, smɔlɝ, hoʊl wɪð ðə wɛtləndɝ ən ə dɑɹk wʊmən, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz sɪvænə ən ɹiɑli hæd tʃoʊzən aʊt. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ʌv waɪz wʌnz ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð ðə mɑʃeɪn ʃeɪɾoʊ. θɹu ðət sɛkən hoʊl, hi kəd si sɪvænə tɔkɪŋ wɪð bɛnhuən. ðə ɡɹin sɔls sɛpt wəd faɪn ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð fju waɪz wʌnz, tu; mɛɹɪk wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt.

Maeric frowned at the stone cube the wetlander had given him, then at the . . . hole . . . that had appeared when he pressed the red spot. A hole, five paces wide and three high, in midair. Beyond lay rolling hills, not low, covered with brown grass. He did not like things to do with the One Power, especially with the male part of it. Sevanna stepped through another, smaller, hole with the wetlander and a dark woman, following the Wise Ones Sevanna and Rhiale had chosen out. Only a handful of Wise Ones remained with the Moshaine Shaido. Through that second hole, he could see Sevanna talking with Bendhuin. The Green Salts sept would find themselves with few Wise Ones, too; Maeric was sure of it.

dɪɹəl tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm. "hʌzbənd," ʃi mɝmɝd, "sɪvænə sɛɾ ɪt wəɾ oʊnli ɹɪmeɪn oʊpən ə ʃɔɹt waɪl."

Dyrele touched his arm. "Husband," she murmured, "Sevanna said it would only remain open a short while."

mɛɹɪk nɑɾəd. dɪɹəl ɔlweɪz sɔ stʃɹeɪt tə ðə pɔɪnt. veɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, hi ɹæn fɔɹwɝɾ ən lɛp θɹu ðə hoʊl i hæd meɪd. wʌtɛvɝ sɪvænə ən ðə wɛtləndɝ sɛd, hi wəd sɛnd nʌn ə hɪz mɑʃeɪn θɹu bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt wɑz seɪf.

Maeric nodded. Dyrele always saw straight to the point. Veiling himself, he ran forward and leaped through the hole he had made. Whatever Sevanna and the wetlander said, he would send none of his Moshaine through before he knew it was safe.

hi lændəd hɛvəli ɑn ə sloʊp kʌvɝd wɪð dɛd ɡɹæs ən nɪɹli pɪtʃt hɛd-oʊvɝ-hilz daʊn ðə hɪl bɪfɔɹ i kɑt hɪmsɛlf. fəɹ ə moʊmən i stɛɹd bæk ʌp ət ðə hoʊl. ɑn ðɪs saɪd, ɪt hʌŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fʊɾ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

He landed heavily on a slope covered with dead grass and nearly pitched head-over-heels down the hill before he caught himself. For a moment he stared back up at the hole. On this side, it hung more than a foot above the ground.

"waɪf!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə dʒɹɑp!"

"Wife!" he shouted. "There is a drop!"

blæk aɪz lɛp θɹu, veɪld ən spɪɹz ɹɛɾi, ən meɪɾənz, ɔlsoʊ. əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɹɪŋk sæn əz tʃɹaɪ tə kip meɪɾənz fɹəm biɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə fɝst. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɑʃeɪn fɑloʊɾ əɾ ə ɹʌn, ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ ən waɪvz ən tʃɪlʒɹən, dʒʌmpɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə flaɪ, kɹæftsfoʊk ən tʃɹeɪɾɝz ən ɡeɪʃeɪn, moʊs pʊlɪŋ hɛvəli loʊɾəd pækhɔɹsɪz ən mjulz, nɪɹ tə sɪks θaʊzən ɔltəɡɛðɝ. hɪz sɛpt, hɪz pipəl. ðeɪ stɪl wəd bi wʌns i wɛn tə ɹɪɾiən; sɪvænə kəd nɑt kip ɪm fɹəm bɪkʌmɪŋ klæn tʃif fəɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ.

Black Eyes leaped through, veiled and spears ready, and Maidens, also. As well try to drink sand as try to keep Maidens from being among the first. The rest of the Moshaine followed at a run, algai'd'siswai and wives and children, jumping down on the fly, craftsfolk and traders and gai'shain, most pulling heavily loaded packhorses and mules, near to six thousand altogether. His sept, his people. They still would be once he went to Rhuidean; Sevanna could not keep him from becoming clan chief for much longer.

skaʊts bɪɡæn spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli, waɪl ðə sɛp stɪl ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ə ðə hoʊl. loʊɝɪŋ ɪz veɪl, mɛɹɪk ʃaʊɾəd ɔɹɾɝz ðət sɛn ə skɹin ʌv ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ təwɔɹd ðə kɹɛsts ə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪlz waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɹɪmeɪn kənsil bɪloʊ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ u əɹ wʌt leɪ bɪɑn ðoʊz hɪlz. ɹɪtʃ lænz, ðə wɛtləndɝ kleɪmd, bʌt ðɪs pɑɹt dɪd nɑt lʊk ɹɪtʃ tə hɪm.

Scouts began spreading out immediately, while the sept still rushed out of the hole. Lowering his veil, Maeric shouted orders that sent a screen of algai'd'siswai toward the crests of the surrounding hills while everyone else remained concealed below. There was no telling who or what lay beyond those hills. Rich lands, the wetlander claimed, but this part did not look rich to him.

ðə ɹʌʃ ə hɪz sɛp bɪkeɪm ə flʌɾ ʌv ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli tʃɹʌst, mɛn u hæd flɛd ðɛɹ oʊn klænz kəz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz tʃɹuli ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. mɛɹɪk wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf bɪlivd, bʌɾ ə mæn dɪd nɑɾ əbændən sɛpt ən klæn. ðiz mɛn kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz mɛɝeɪɾɪn, ðə bɹʌðɝləs, ə fɪɾɪŋ neɪm, ən i hæd tu hʌndɝ -  ðə hoʊl sʌɾənli snæpt ɪndə ə vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə sɪlvɝ ðət slaɪs θɹu tɛn ə ðə bɹʌðɝləs. pisəz ə ðɛm fɛl ɑntu ðə sloʊp, ɑɹmz, lɛɡz. ðə fɹʌn hæf ʌv ə mæn slɪɾ ɔlmoʊs tə mɛɹɪks fit.

The rush of his sept became a flood of algai'd'siswai he did not really trust, men who had fled their own clans because they did not believe Rand al'Thor was truly the Car'a'carn. Maeric was not sure what he himself believed, but a man did not abandon sept and clan. These men called themselves Mera'din, the Brotherless, a fitting name, and he had two hundr -  The hole suddenly snapped into a vertical slash of silver that sliced through ten of the Brotherless. Pieces of them fell onto the slope, arms, legs. The front half of a man slid almost to Maeric's feet.

stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə hoʊl hæd bɪn, hi stæbd ət ðə ɹɛd spɑt wɪð ɪz θʌm. jusləs, hi nu, bʌt. . . . dæɹɪn, hɪz ɛldəst sʌn, wɑz wʌn ə ðə stoʊn dɑɡz weɪɾɪŋ əz ə ɹɪɹ ɡɑɹd. ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn ðə læs θɹu. sɹeɪl, hɪz ɛldəs dɔɾɝ, hæd ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð ðə stoʊn dɔɡ fəɹ hum ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðə spɪɹ.

Staring at the place where the hole had been, he stabbed at the red spot with his thumb. Useless, he knew, but. . . . Darin, his eldest son, was one of the Stone Dogs waiting as a rear guard. They would have been the last through. Suraile, his eldest daughter, had remained with the Stone Dog for whom she was thinking of giving up the spear.

hɪz aɪz mɛt dɪɹəlz, əz ɡɹin ən bjuɾəfəl əz ðə deɪ ʃi hæd leɪd ðə ɹiθ əɾ ɪz fit. ən θɹɛɾənd tə kʌɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ɪf i dɪd nɑt pɪk ɪɾ ʌp. "wi kən weɪt," hi sɛd sɔfli. ðə wɛtləndɝ hæd sɛd θɹi deɪz, bʌt meɪbi hi wɑz ɹɔŋ. hɪz θʌm stæb ðə ɹɛd spɑɾ əɡɛn. dɪɹəl nɑɾəd kɑmli; hi hoʊp ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nid tə kɹaɪ ɪn wʌn ənʌðɝz ɑɹmz wʌns ðeɪ kəd bi əloʊn.

His eyes met Dyrele's, as green and beautiful as the day she had laid the wreath at his feet. And threatened to cut his throat if he did not pick it up. "We can wait," he said softly. The wetlander had said three days, but maybe he was wrong. His thumb stabbed the red spot again. Dyrele nodded calmly; he hoped there would be no need to cry in one another's arms once they could be alone.

eɪ meɪɾən keɪm skɪɾɝɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp fɹəm əbʌv, hɝidli loʊɝɪŋ əɹ veɪl, ən æktʃəli  bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. "mɛɹɪk," nɑaɪs sɛd, nɑɾ ivən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə si hɝ, "ðɛɹ ɑɹ spɪɹz tə ði ist, oʊnli ə fju maɪlz ən ɹʌnɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ ʌs. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹn. ət list sɛvən əɹ eɪt θaʊzən ə ðɛm."

A Maiden came skittering down the slope from above, hurriedly lowering her veil, and actually breathing hard. "Maeric," Naeise said, not even waiting for him to see her, "there are spears to the east, only a few miles and running straight at us. I think they are Reyn. At least seven or eight thousand of them."

hi kəd si ʌðɝ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. ə jʌŋ bɹʌðɝ tə ði iɡəl, kɛɹɾɪn, slɪd tə ə stɑp, spikɪŋ əz sun əz mɛɹɪk sɔ hɪm. "aɪ si ju, mɛɹɪk. ðəɹ ɑɹ spɪɹz noʊ mɔɹ ðən faɪv maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ, ən wɛtləndɝz ɑn hɔɹsəz. pɝhæps tɛn θaʊzən ʌv itʃ. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɛni ʌv əs bɹoʊk ðə kɹɛst, bʌt səm ə ðə spɪɹz əv tɝn təwɔɹɾ ʌs."

He could see other algai'd'siswai running toward him. A young Brother to the Eagle, Cairdin, slid to a stop, speaking as soon as Maeric saw him. "I see you, Maeric. There are spears no more than five miles to the north, and wetlanders on horses. Perhaps ten thousand of each. I do not think any of us broke the crest, but some of the spears have turned toward us."

mɛɹɪk nu bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹɪzəld wɔɾɝ sikɝ neɪm lɝəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. "spɪɹz kʌmɪŋ oʊvɝ ə hɪl θɹi əɹ fɔɹ maɪlz tə ðə saʊθ. eɪt θaʊzən əɹ mɔɹ. səm ə ðɛm sɔ wʌn ə ðə bɔɪz." lɝəd nɛvɝ weɪstəd wɝdz, ən i wəd nɛvɝ seɪ wɪtʃ bɔɪ, hu ɪn tʃɹuθ kəd bi ɛniwʌn wɪθaʊt ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, tə lɝəd.

Maeric knew before the grizzled Water Seeker named Laerad opened his mouth. "Spears coming over a hill three or four miles to the south. Eight thousand or more. Some of them saw one of the boys." Laerad never wasted words, and he would never say which boy, who in truth could be anyone without gray hair, to Laerad.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ weɪstɪŋ wɝdz, mɛɹɪk nu. "heɪməl!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. noʊ taɪm fəɹ pɹɑpɝ kɝɾəsi tə ə blæksmɪθ, iðɝ.

There was no time for wasting words, Maeric knew. "Hamal!" he shouted. No time for proper courtesy to a blacksmith, either.

ðə bɪɡ mæn nu sʌmθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ; hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə sloʊp, laɪkli muvɪŋ fæstɝ ðən i hæd sɪns fɝs pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə hæmɝ.

The big man knew something was wrong; he scrambled up the slope, likely moving faster than he had since first picking up a hammer.

mɛɹɪk hændəɾ ɪm ðə stoʊn kjub. "ju mʌs pɹɛs ðə ɹɛd spɑɾ ən kip pɹɛsɪŋ ɪt, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt hæpənz, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɔŋ ɪt teɪks fəɹ ðət hoʊl tə oʊpən. ðəɾ ɪz ði oʊnli weɪ aʊt fəɹ ɛni ʌv ju." heɪməl nɑɾəd, bʌt mɛɹɪk dɪd nɑɾ ivən weɪt fəɹ ɪm tə seɪ ðəɾ i wʊd. heɪməl wəɾ ʌndɝstænd. mɛɹɪk tʌtʃt dɪɹəlz tʃik, kɛɹləs ə haʊ mɛni aɪz wɝ ɑn ðɛm. "ʃeɪɾ ə maɪ hɑɹt, jə mʌs pɹipɛɹ tə pʊɾ ɑn waɪt." hɝ hæn stʃɹeɪd təwɔɹd ðə hɪlt ə hɝ bɛl naɪf - ʃi hæd bɪn ə meɪɾən wən ʃi meɪɾ ɪz ɹiθ - bʌɾ i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd fɝmli. "ju mʌs lɪv, waɪf, ɹufməstʃɹəs, tə hoʊl təɡɛðɝ wʌt ɹɪmeɪnz." nɑɾɪŋ, ʃi pɹɛs fɪŋɡɝz tə hɪz tʃik. hi wɑz əstɑnɪʃt; ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn vɛɹi ɹɪzɝvd ɪn pʌblɪk.

Maeric handed him the stone cube. "You must press the red spot and keep pressing it, no matter what happens, no matter how long it takes for that hole to open. That is the only way out for any of you." Hamal nodded, but Maeric did not even wait for him to say that he would. Hamal would understand. Maeric touched Dyrele's cheek, careless of how many eyes were on them. "Shade of my heart, you must prepare to put on white." Her hand strayed toward the hilt of her belt knife - she had been a Maiden when she made his wreath - but he shook his head firmly. "You must live, wife, roofmistress, to hold together what remains." Nodding, she pressed fingers to his cheek. He was astonished; she had always been very reserved in public.

ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz veɪl, mɛɹɪk ʃʌvd wʌn spɪɹ haɪ əbʌv ɪz hɛd. "mɑʃeɪn!" hi ɹɔɹd. "wi dæns!"

Raising his veil, Maeric shoved one spear high above his head. "Moshaine!" he roared. "We dance!"

ʌp ðə sloʊp ðeɪ fɑloʊd hɪm, mɛn ən meɪɾənz, nɪɹli ə θaʊzən stʃɹɔŋ kaʊntɪŋ ðə bɹʌðɝləs. pɝhæps ðeɪ kəd bi kaʊntəɾ əmʌŋ ðə sɛpt. ʌp ðə sloʊp ən wɛst; ðət weɪ leɪ ðə nɪɹəst ən ðə fjuəst. pɝhæps ðeɪ maɪt baɪ ɪnʌf taɪm, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ðæt. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ sɪvænə hæd noʊn ə ðɪs. ɑ, ðə wɝl hæd ɡɹoʊn vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ sɪns ɹænd ælθɹ keɪm. səm θɪŋz kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, ðoʊ. læfɪŋ, hi bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ.

Up the slope they followed him, men and Maidens, nearly a thousand strong counting the Brotherless. Perhaps they could be counted among the sept. Up the slope and west; that way lay the nearest and the fewest. Perhaps they might buy enough time, though he did not really believe that. He wondered whether Sevanna had known of this. Ah, the world had grown very strange since Rand al'Thor came. Some things could not change, though. Laughing, he began to sing.

"wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz, waɪl ðə sʌn klaɪmz haɪ.

"Wash the spears, while the sun climbs high.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz, waɪl ðə sʌn klaɪmz haɪ.

Wash the spears, while the sun climbs high.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz, waɪl ðə sʌn fɔlz loʊ.

Wash the spears, while the sun falls low.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; hu fɪɹz tə daɪ?

Wash the spears; who fears to die?

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; noʊ wʌn aɪ noʊ!"

Wash the spears; no one I know!"

sɪŋɪŋ, ðə mɑʃeɪn ʃeɪɾoʊ ɹæn tə dæns ðɛɹ dɛθs.

Singing, the Moshaine Shaido ran to dance their deaths.

fɹaʊnɪŋ, ɡɹeɪndəl wɑtʃt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊs bɪhaɪn ðə læst ə ðə dʒuməaɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðə dʒuməaɪ ən ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni waɪz wʌnz. ənlaɪk wɪð ði ʌðɝz, sɑmaɪl hæd nɑt sɪmpli nɑɾɪd ðɪs wɛb soʊ ɪt wəd fɔl əpɑɹɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ət list, ʃi əsumd i hɛld ɪt tə ðə læst; ðə kloʊzɪŋ, ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə hilz ə ðə læs bɹaʊn-ænd-ɡɹeɪ-klæd mɛn, wɑz tu fɔɹtuɪɾəs ʌðɝwaɪz. læfɪŋ, sɑmaɪl tɔst əweɪ ðə bæɡ, stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ə fju ʌv ðoʊz jusləs bɪts ə stoʊn. hɝ oʊn ɛmpti sæk wɑz lɔŋ sɪns dɪskɑɹɾɪd. ðə sʌn sæt loʊ bɪhaɪn ðə maʊntənz tə ðə wɛst, hæf ʌv ə ɡloʊɪŋ ɹɛd bɔl.

Frowning, Graendal watched the gateway close behind the last of the Jumai Shaido. The Jumai and a great many Wise Ones. Unlike with the others, Sammael had not simply knotted this web so it would fall apart eventually. At least, she assumed he held it to the last; the closing, right on the heels of the last brown-and-gray-clad men, was too fortuitous otherwise. Laughing, Sammael tossed away the bag, still holding a few of those useless bits of stone. Her own empty sack was long since discarded. The sun sat low behind the mountains to the west, half of a glowing red ball.

"wʌn ə ðiz deɪz," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ju wɪl bi tu smɑɹt fəɹ jəɹ oʊn ɡʊd. ə ful bɑks, sɑmaɪl? səpoʊz wʌn ə ðɛm hæɾ ʌndɝstʊd?"

"One of these days," she said dryly, "you will be too smart for your own good. A fool box, Sammael? Suppose one of them had understood?"

"nʌn dɪd," hi sɛd sɪmpli, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ ən stɛɹɪŋ ət wɛɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hæd bɪn. əɹ meɪbi ət sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑnd. hi stɪl hɛl ðə mɪɹɝ ə mɪsts, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ði ɪluʒən ʌv æɾəd haɪt. ʃi hæd dʒɹɑp hɝz əz sun əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊzd.

"None did," he said simply, but he kept rubbing his hands together and staring at where the gateway had been. Or maybe at something beyond. He still held the Mirror of Mists, giving him the illusion of added height. She had dropped hers as soon as the gateway closed.

"wɛl, jə sɝɾənli mænədʒ tə pʊɾ ə pænɪk ɪndə ðɛm." ɝaʊn əm leɪ ði ɛvəɾəns: ə fju loʊ tɛns stɪl stændɪŋ, blæŋkəts, ə kʊkpɑt, ə ɹæɡ dɑl, ɔl sɔɹts ə ɹʌbɪʃ laɪɪŋ wɛɹ ɪt hæd fɔlən. "wɛɹ dɪd jə sɛn ðɛm? sʌmwɛɹ əhɛɾ ʌv ælθɹz ɑɹmi, aɪ səpoʊz?"

"Well, you certainly managed to put a panic into them." Around them lay the evidence: a few low tents still standing, blankets, a cookpot, a rag doll, all sorts of rubbish lying where it had fallen. "Where did you send them? Somewhere ahead of al'Thor's army, I suppose?"

"sʌm," hi sɛɾ æbsənli. "ɪnʌf." hɪz stɛɹɪŋ ɪntʃɹəspɛkʃən vænɪʃt əbɹʌpli, ən ɪz dɪsɡaɪz əz wɛl. ðə skɑɹ əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs simd ɪspɛʃli lɪvɪd. "ɪnʌf tə kɑz tʃɹʌbəl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɪð ðɛɹ waɪz wʌnz tʃænəlɪŋ, bʌt nɑt soʊ mɛni ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wɪl səspɛk mi. ðə ɹɛst ɑɹ skæɾɝd fɹəm ɪljən tə ɡildən. əz tə haʊ əɹ waɪ? meɪbi ælθɹ dɪɾ ɪt, fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz, bʌɾ aɪ sɝɾənli wʊdn əv weɪstəd moʊst ə ðɛm ɪf ɪt wɑz maɪ wɝk, naʊ wəɾ aɪ?" hi læft əɡɛn; kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ɪz oʊn bɹɪljəns.

"Some," he said absently. "Enough." His staring introspection vanished abruptly, and his disguise as well. The scar across his face seemed especially livid. "Enough to cause trouble, particularly with their Wise Ones channeling, but not so many that anyone will suspect me. The rest are scattered from Illian to Ghealdan. As to how or why? Maybe al'Thor did it, for his own reasons, but I certainly wouldn't have wasted most of them if it was my work, now would I?" He laughed again; caught up in his own brilliance.

ʃi ədʒʌstəd ðə bɑɾəs ə hɝ dʒɹɛs tə kʌvɝ ə stɑɹt. kəmpiɾɪŋ ðət weɪ wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbli sɪli - ʃi hæd toʊl hɝsɛlf ðət tɛn θaʊzən taɪmz, ən nɛvɝ lɪsənd wʌns - ɹɪmɑɹkəbli sɪli, ən naʊ ðə dʒɹɛs fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt maɪt fɔl ɔf. wɪtʃ hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð əɹ stɑɹt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ sɪvænə hæd teɪkən ɛvɹi ʃeɪɾoʊ wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl wɪð hɝ. wɑz ɪt faɪnəli taɪm tə əbændən hɪm? ɪf ʃi θɹu hɝsɛlf ɑn dɪmɑndɝdz mɝsi. . . .

She adjusted the bodice of her dress to cover a start. Competing that way was remarkably silly - she had told herself that ten thousand times, and never listened once - remarkably silly, and now the dress felt as if it might fall off. Which had nothing to do with her start. He did not know Sevanna had taken every Shaido woman who could channel with her. Was it finally time to abandon him? If she threw herself on Demandred's mercy. . . .

əz ɪf ɹiɾɪŋ əɹ θɔts, hi sɛd, "jɔɹ taɪd tə mi əz taɪtli əz maɪ bɛlt, ɡɹeɪndəl." ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ɪz pɹaɪvət ɹumz ɪn ɪljən. "ðə tʃɹuθ dʌzn mæɾɝ ɛnimɔɹ, ɪf ɪɾ ɛvɝ hæz. jə ɹaɪz wɪð mi, əɹ fɔl wɪð mi. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ɹɪwɔɹdz səksɛs, ən hiz nɛvɝ kɛɹd haʊ ɪt wɑz ətʃivd."

As if reading her thoughts, he said, "You're tied to me as tightly as my belt, Graendal." A gateway opened, revealing his private rooms in Illian. "The truth doesn't matter anymore, if it ever has. You rise with me, or fall with me. The Great Lord rewards success, and he's never cared how it was achieved."

"æz jə seɪ," ʃi toʊl hɪm. dɪmɑndɝd hæd noʊ mɝsi. ən sɛmi-ɹədʒ. . . . "aɪ ɹaɪz əɹ fɔl wɪð ju." stɪl, sʌmθɪŋ wəɾ əv tə bi wɝkt aʊt. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd səksɛs, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt bi pʊl daʊn ɪf sɑmaɪl feɪld. ʃi oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə hɝ pæləs ɪn ɑɹæd dumən, tə ðə lɔŋ kɑləmd ɹum wɛɹ ʃi kəd si hɝ pɛts fɹɑlɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə pul. "bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ælθɹ kʌmz æftɝ jə hɪmsɛlf? wʌt ðɛn?"

"As you say," she told him. Demandred had no mercy. And Semi-rhage. . . . "I rise or fall with you." Still, something would have to be worked out. The Great Lord rewarded success, but she would not be pulled down if Sammael failed. She opened a gateway to her palace in Arad Doman, to the long columned room where she could see her pets frolicking in the pool. "But what if al'Thor comes after you himself? What then?"

"ælθɹ ɪzənt ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ ɛniwʌn," sɑmaɪl læft. "ɔl aɪ hæv tə də ɪz weɪt." stɪl læfɪŋ, hi stɛpt ɪndə hɪz ɡeɪtweɪ ən lɛɾ ɪt kloʊs.

"Al'Thor isn't going after anyone," Sammael laughed. "All I have to do is wait." Still laughing, he stepped into his gateway and let it close.

ðə mɹdʒɹɑl muv fɹəm ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz, bɪkʌmɪŋ vɪzəbəl. ɪn ɪts aɪz, ðə ɡeɪtweɪz hæd lɛft ə ɹɛzədu - θɹi pætʃəz ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ mɪst. ɪt kəd nɑt tɛl wʌn floʊ fɹəm ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt kəd dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ seɪɾɪn fɹəm seɪaɪdɑɹ baɪ ðə smɛl. seɪɾɪn smɛld laɪk ðə ʃɑɹp ɛdʒ ʌv ə naɪf, ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə θɔɹn. seɪaɪdɑɹ smɛl sɑft, bʌt laɪk sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd ɡɹoʊ hɑɹɾɝ ðə hɑɹɾɝ ɪt wɑz pɹɛst. noʊ ʌðɝ mɹdʒɹɑl kəd smɛl ðət dɪfɝəns. ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wɑz laɪk noʊ ʌðɝ mɹdʒɹɑl.

The Myrddraal moved from the deeper shadows, becoming visible. In its eyes, the gateways had left a residue - three patches of glowing mist. It could not tell one flow from another, but it could distinguish saidin from saidar by the smell. Saidin smelled like the sharp edge of a knife, the point of a thorn. Saidar smelled soft, but like something that would grow harder the harder it was pressed. No other Myrddraal could smell that difference. Shaidar Haran was like no other Myrddraal.

pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə dɪskɑɹɾɪd spɪɹ, ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən juzd ɪt tə ʌpɛn ðə bæɡ sɑmaɪl hæd dɪskɑɹɾɪd, ən ðən tə stɝ ðə bɪts ə stoʊn ðət fɛl aʊt. mʌtʃ wɑz hæpənɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə plæn. wəd ðiz ɪvɛns tʃɝn keɪɑs, ɔɹ. . . .

Picking up a discarded spear, Shaidar Haran used it to upend the bag Sammael had discarded, and then to stir the bits of stone that fell out. Much was happening outside the plan. Would these events churn chaos, or. . . .

æŋɡɹi blæk fleɪmz ɹeɪs daʊn ðə spɪɹ hæft fɹəm ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹənz hænd, ðə hæn ə ðə hæn ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ən ɪnstən ðə wʊɾən hæft wɑz tʃɑɹɾ ən twɪstəd; ðə spɪɹhɛd dʒɹɑpt ɔf. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl lɛt ðə blækən stɪk fɔl ən dʌstɪd sʊt fɹəm ɪts pɑm. ɪf sɑmaɪl sɝv keɪɑs, ðən ɔl wɑz wɛl. ɪf nɑt. . . .

Angry black flames raced down the spear haft from Shaidar Haran's hand, the hand of the Hand of the Shadow. In an instant the wooden haft was charred and twisted; the spearhead dropped off. The Myrddraal let the blackened stick fall and dusted soot from its palm. If Sammael served chaos, then all was well. If not. . . .

ə sʌɾən eɪk klaɪm ðə bæk ʌv ɪts nɛk; ə feɪnt wiknəs wɑʃt əlɔŋ ɪts lɪmz. tu lɔŋ əweɪ fɹəm ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ðət taɪ hæd tə bi sɛvɝd sʌmhaʊ. wɪð ə snɑɹl, ɪt tɝn tə faɪn ði ɛdʒ ə ʃædoʊ ðəɾ ɪt niɾəd. ðə deɪ wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ɪt wəd kʌm.

A sudden ache climbed the back of its neck; a faint weakness washed along its limbs. Too long away from Shayol Ghul. That tie had to be severed somehow. With a snarl, it turned to find the edge of shadow that it needed. The day was coming. It would come.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 41

eɪ kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz


A Crown of Swords

tɔsɪŋ, ɹænd dʒɹimd, waɪl dʒɹimz wɛɹ i ɑɹɡjud wɪð pɛɹɪn ən bɛɡd mæt tə faɪn ɪleɪn, wɛɹ kʌlɝz flæʃt dʒʌs bɪɑn saɪɾ ən pdən feɪn lɛpt əɾ ɪm wɪð ə flæʃɪŋ bleɪd, ən səmtaɪmz i θɔɾ i hɝɾ ə vɔɪs moʊnɪŋ fəɹ ə dɛd wʊmən ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ə fɑɡ, dʒɹimz wɛɹ i tʃɹaɪd tə ɪkspleɪn hɪmsɛlf tə ɪleɪn, tə eɪvinhə, tə mɪn, tə ɔl θɹi ət wʌns, ən ivən mɪn lʊkt əɾ ɪm wɪð skɔɹn.

Tossing, Rand dreamed, wild dreams where he argued with Perrin and begged Mat to find Elayne, where colors flashed just beyond sight and Padan Fain leaped at him with a flashing blade, and sometimes he thought he heard a voice moaning for a dead woman in the heart of a fog, dreams where he tried to explain himself to Elayne, to Aviendha, to Min, to all three at once, and even Min looked at him with scorn.

". . . nɑt tə bi dɪstɝbd!" kædzueɪnz vɔɪs. pɑɹɾ ə hɪz dʒɹimz?

". . . not to be disturbed!" Cadsuane's voice. Part of his dreams?

ðə vɔɪs fɹaɪɾənd hɪm; ɪn ɪz dʒɹim i ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ luz θɝɪn, ən ðə saʊn ɛkoʊd θɹu ə θɪk mɪst wɛɹ ʃeɪps muvd ən pipəl ən hɔɹsəz daɪd skɹimɪŋ, ə fɑɡ wɛɹ kædzueɪn fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɪmplækəbli waɪl i ɹæn, pæntɪŋ. ɑlɑnə tʃɹaɪd tə suð hɪm, bʌt ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə kædzueɪn, tu; hi kəd fil əɹ fɪɹ əz stʃɹɔŋli əz ɪz oʊn. hɪz hɛd hɝt. ən ɪz saɪd; ði oʊl skɑɹ wɑz faɪɝ. hi fɛl seɪɾɪn. sʌmwʌn hɛl seɪɾɪn. wɑz ɪt hɪm? hi dɪd nɑt noʊ. hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə weɪk.

The voice frightened him; in his dream he shouted for Lews Therin, and the sound echoed through a thick mist where shapes moved and people and horses died screaming, a fog where Cadsuane followed him implacably while he ran, panting. Alanna tried to soothe him, but she was afraid of Cadsuane, too; he could feel her fear as strongly as his own. His head hurt. And his side; the old scar was fire. He felt saidin. Someone held saidin. Was it him? He did not know. He struggled to wake.

"jul kɪl hɪm!" mɪn ʃaʊɾəd. "aɪ woʊn lɛt jə kɪl hɪm!"

"You'll kill him!" Min shouted. "I won't let you kill him!"

hɪz aɪz oʊpənd, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ əɹ feɪs. nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ʃi hæɾ ɪz hɛd ɹæpt ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz ən wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət sʌmwʌn əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɛd. hɝ aɪz wɝ ɹɛd. ʃi hæd bɪn kɹaɪɪŋ, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. jɛs, hi wɑz ɪn ɪz oʊn bɛd, ɪn ɪz ɹumz ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs. hi kəd si ə hɛvi skwɛɹ blækwʊd bɪdpoʊst sɛt wɪð wɛdʒəz ʌv aɪvɝi. koʊtləs ɪn ə kɹim sɪlk blaʊs, mɪn leɪ kɝld ɝaʊn ɪm pɹoʊtɛktɪvli, ətɑp ðə lɪnən ʃit ðət kʌvɝɾ ɪm tə ðə nɛk. ɑlɑnə wɑz əfɹeɪd; ðət leɪ ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. əfɹeɪd fəɹ hɪm. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðæt.

His eyes opened, staring up at her face. Not looking at him, she had his head wrapped in her arms and was glaring at someone away from the bed. Her eyes were red. She had been crying, but no longer. Yes, he was in his own bed, in his rooms in the Sun Palace. He could see a heavy square blackwood bedpost set with wedges of ivory. Coatless in a cream silk blouse, Min lay curled around him protectively, atop the linen sheet that covered him to the neck. Alanna was afraid; that lay shivering in the back of his head. Afraid for him. For some reason, he was sure of that.

"aɪ θɪŋk hiz əweɪk, mɪn," æmɪz sɛd dʒɛnli.

"I think he is awake, Min," Amys said gently.

mɪn lʊk daʊn, ən əɹ feɪs, fɹeɪmd ɪn dɑɹk ɹɪŋləts, bimd wɪð ə sʌɾən smaɪl.

Min looked down, and her face, framed in dark ringlets, beamed with a sudden smile.

kɛɹfəli - kəz i fɛlt wik - hi ɹimuvd əɹ ɑɹmz ən sæɾ ʌp. hɪz hɛd wɝl dɪtsəli, bʌɾ i fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf nɑt tə laɪ bæk əɡɛn. hɪz bɛd wɑz ɹɪŋd.

Carefully - because he felt weak - he removed her arms and sat up. His head whirled dizzily, but he forced himself not to lie back again. His bed was ringed.

tə wʌn saɪd stʊɾ æmɪz, flæŋk baɪ bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə. æmɪz' tu-juθfəl fitʃɝz bɔɹ noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən əɾ ɔl, bʌt ʃi bɹʌʃt bæk əɹ lɔŋ waɪt hɛɹ ən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl əz ðoʊ taɪɾiɪŋ hɝsɛlf æftɝ ə stʃɹʌɡəl. aʊtwɝdli ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ sɝin, jɛt wɪð dɪtɝmən sɝɛnəɾi, ə kwin ɹɛɾi tə faɪt fəɹ əɹ θɹoʊn, ə kʌntʃɹi wʊmən ɹɛɾi tə faɪt fəɹ əɹ fɑɹm. ɑdli, ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin θɹi pipəl stæn təɡɛðɝ - ən nɑt dʒʌs fɪzɪkəli - ɪt wɑz ðoʊz θɹi, ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ əz wʌn.

To one side stood Amys, flanked by Bera and Kiruna. Amys' too-youthful features bore no expression at all, but she brushed back her long white hair and shifted her dark shawl as though tidying herself after a struggle. Outwardly the two Aes Sedai were serene, yet with determined serenity, a queen ready to fight for her throne, a country woman ready to fight for her farm. Oddly, if he had ever seen three people stand together - and not just physically - it was those three, shoulder-to-shoulder as one.

ɑn ði ɑpəzət saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd, sæmɪtsu, wɪð ðoʊz sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ən ə slɛndɝ sɪstɝ wɪð θɪk blæk aɪbɹaʊz ən ə waɪld lʊk tə hɝ ɹeɪvən hɛɹ stʊd wɪð kædzueɪn, hu hæɾ əɹ fɪsts plæntəɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps. sæmɪtsu ən ðə ɹeɪvən-hɛɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔɹ jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔlz ən hæd dʒɔz sɛɾ ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz fɝmli əz bɛɹə əɹ kaɪɹunə, jɛt kædzueɪnz stɝn stɛɹ meɪɾ ɔl fɔɹ əpɪɹ hɛzɪɾənt. ðə tu ɡɹups ʌv wɪmən wɝ nɑt stɛɹɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ət ðə mɛn.

On the opposite side of the bed, Samitsu, with those silver bells in her hair, and a slender sister with thick black eyebrows and a wild look to her raven hair stood with Cadsuane, who had her fists planted on her hips. Samitsu and the raven-haired Aes Sedai wore yellow-fringed shawls and had jaws set every bit as firmly as Bera or Kiruna, yet Cadsuane's stern stare made all four appear hesitant. The two groups of women were not staring at one another, but at the men.

ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛd wɝ dæʃivə wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ən ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪz kɑlɝ, ən flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə, ɔl ɡɹɪm-feɪst, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ðə wɪmən ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə bɛɾ ət wʌns. dʒoʊnən ædli stʊd bɪsaɪd ðɛm, hɪz blæk koʊt lʊkɪŋ sɪŋʒd ɑn wʌn sliv. seɪɾɪn fɪld ɔl fɔɹ mɛn, tə oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ ɪt simd. dæʃivə hɛld ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ɹænd kəd hæv. ɹænd lʊk tə ædli, hu nɑɾəd slaɪtli.

At the foot of the bed were Dashiva with the silver sword and red-and-gold Dragon glittering his collar, and Flinn and Narishma, all grim-faced, trying to watch the women on both sides of the bed at once. Jonan Adley stood beside them, his black coat looking singed on one sleeve. Saidin filled all four men, to overflowing it seemed. Dashiva held almost as much as Rand could have. Rand looked to Adley, who nodded slightly.

əbɹʌpli, ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bɪniθ ðə ʃit ðət hæd fɔlən tə hɪz weɪst, ən nʌθɪŋ əbʌv ɪksɛpt ə bændɪdʒ waʊn ɝaʊn ɪz mɪɾəl. "haʊ lɔŋ əv aɪ bɪn əslip?" hi æskt. "haʊ ɪz ɪɾ ɪm əlaɪv?" hi tʌtʃt ðə peɪl bændɪdʒ dʒɪnʒɝli. "feɪnz dæɡɝ keɪm fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. wʌns aɪ sɔ ɪt kɪl ə mæn ɪn moʊməns wɪð ə skɹætʃ. hi daɪd fæst, ən i daɪd hɑɹd." dæʃivə mʌɾɝd ə kɝs wɪð pdən feɪnz neɪm ɪn ɪt.

Abruptly, Rand realized that he was not wearing anything beneath the sheet that had fallen to his waist, and nothing above except a Bandage wound around his middle. "How long have I been asleep?" he asked. "How is it I'm alive?" He touched the pale Bandage gingerly. "Fain's dagger came from Shadar Logoth. Once I saw it kill a man in moments with a scratch. He died fast, and he died hard." Dashiva muttered a curse with Padan Fain's name in it.

sæmɪtsu ən ði ʌðɝ jɛloʊ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd stɑɹɾəld lʊks, bʌt kædzueɪn mɪɹli nɑɾəd, ðə ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns ɝaʊn əɹ aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ bʌn sweɪɪŋ. "jɛs; ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ; ðət wəɾ ɪkspleɪn sɛvɹəl mæɾɝz. jə kən θæŋk sæmɪtsu ðət jəɹ əlaɪv, ən mæstɝ flɪn." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡlæns təwɔɹd ði ə ɡɹɪzəl mæn wɪð ɪz fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪt hɛɹ, bʌɾ i ɡɹɪn əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə baʊ; ɪn tʃɹuθ, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə jɛloʊz dɪd nɑd tə hɪm. "æn kɔɹəl, hɪɹ, ʌv kɔɹs," kædzueɪn wɛn ɑn. "itʃ əz dʌn ə pɑɹt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm θɪŋz aɪ θɪŋk əv nɑt bɪn dʌn sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ." hɝ vɔɪs tɝnd ɡɹɪm. "wɪθaʊɾ ɔl θɹi, jə wəd bi dɛd baɪ naʊ. jə stɪl meɪ daɪ ənlɛs jə lɛt jɝsɛlf bi ɡaɪɾəd. jə mʌst ɹɛst, wɪθaʊɾ ɪɡzɝʃən." hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəl sʌɾənli, laʊdli, ən ʃi æɾəd, "wiv oʊnli bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ ən bɹɔθ daʊn jə sɪns jə wɝ hɝt. tu deɪz ɪz ə lɔŋ taɪm wɪθaʊt fud fəɹ ə sɪk mæn."

Samitsu and the other Yellow exchanged startled looks, but Cadsuane merely nodded, the golden ornaments around her iron-gray bun swaying. "Yes; Shadar Logoth; that would explain several matters. You can thank Samitsu that you're alive, and Master Flinn." She did not glance toward the A grizzled man with his fringe of white hair, but he grinned as though she had given him a bow; in truth, surprisingly, the Yellows did nod to him. "And Corele, here, of course," Cadsuane went on. "Each has done a part, including some things I think have not been done since the Breaking." Her voice turned grim. "Without all three, you would be dead by now. You still may die unless you let yourself be guided. You must rest, without exertion." His stomach rumbled suddenly, loudly, and she added, "We've only been able to get a little water and broth down you since you were hurt. Two days is a long time without food for a sick man."

tu deɪz. oʊnli tu. hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ædli. "aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp," hi sɛd.

Two days. Only two. He avoided looking at Adley. "I'm getting up," he said.

"aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm kɪl ju, ʃifɝɾɝ," mɪn sɛd wɪð ən ɑbstənət ɡlɪn ɪn əɹ aɪz, "æn aɪ woʊn lɛt jə kɪl ju, iðɝ." ʃi pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əz ɪf tə hoʊld ɪm wɛɹ i wɑz.

"I won't let them kill you, sheepherder," Min said with an obstinate glint in her eyes, "and I won't let you kill you, either." She put her arms around his shoulders as if to hold him where he was.

"ɪf ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn wɪʃɪz tə ɹaɪz," æmɪz sɛd flætli, "aɪ wɪl əv nændɛɹə bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə meɪɾənz fɹəm ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. soʊmɑɹə ən ɪneɪlə wɪl bi ɪspɛʃli hæpi tə ɡɪv ɪm dʒʌs ði əsɪstəns i nidz." ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ maʊθ twɪtʃt təwɔɹɾ ə smaɪl. wʌns ə meɪɾən hɝsɛlf, ʃi nu kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ ə ðət sɪtʃueɪʃən. niðɝ kaɪɹunə nɔɹ bɛɹə smaɪld; ðeɪ fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əz əɾ ən æbsəlut ful.

"If the Car'a'carn wishes to rise," Amys said flatly, "I will have Nandera bring in the Maidens from the corridor. Somara and Enaila will be especially happy to give him just the assistance he needs." The corners of her mouth twitched toward a smile. Once a Maiden herself, she knew close enough to everything of that situation. Neither Kiruna nor Bera smiled; they frowned at him as at an absolute fool.

"bɔɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi sin mɔɹ ə jəɹ hɛɹləs bɑtɑmtʃiks ðən aɪ wɪʃ tə, bʌɾ ɪf jə wɑnə flɔn əm ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɔl sɪks ʌv ʌs, pɝhæps sʌmwʌn wɪl ɛndʒɔɪ ðə ʃoʊ. ɪf jə fɔl ɑn jəɹ feɪs, ðoʊ, aɪ meɪ dʒʌst spæŋk jə bɪfɔɹ aɪ pʊt jə bæk tə bɛd." baɪ sæmɪtsuz feɪs, ən kɔɹəlz, ðeɪ wəd bi hæpi tə əsɪs hɝ.

"Boy," Cadsuane said dryly, "I've already seen more of your hairless bottomcheeks than I wish to, but if you want to flaunt them in front of all six of us, perhaps someone will enjoy the show.
