If you fall on your face, though, I may just spank you before I put you back to bed." By Samitsu's face, and Corele's, they would be happy to assist her.

nɛɹɪʃmə ən ædli stɛɹɾ ət kædzueɪn ɪn ʃɑk, waɪl flɪn tʌɡd əɾ ɪz koʊɾ əz ðoʊ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɪmsɛlf. dæʃivə, ðoʊ, bɑɹkt ə ɹʌf læf. "ɪf jə wɑn əs tə klɪɹ ðə wɪmən aʊt. . . ." ðə pleɪn-feɪs mæn bɪɡæn pɹipɛɹɪŋ floʊz; nɑt ʃilz, bʌt kɑmplɛks wivz ə spɪɹəɾ ən faɪɝ ðət ɹænd səspɛktəd wəd pʊɾ ɛniwʌn ðeɪ wɝ leɪɾ ɑn ɪn tu mʌtʃ peɪn tə θɪŋk ə tʃænəlɪŋ.

Narishma and Adley stared at Cadsuane in shock, while Flinn tugged at his coat as though arguing with himself. Dashiva, though, barked a rough laugh. "If you want us to clear the women out. . . ." The plain-faced man began preparing flows; not shields, but complex weaves of Spirit and Fire that Rand suspected would put anyone they were laid on in too much pain to think of channeling.

"noʊ," hi sɛd kwɪkli. bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə wəɾ oʊbeɪ ə sɪmpəl ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡoʊ, ən ɪf kɔɹəl ən sæmɪtsu hæd hɛlp kip ɪm əlaɪv, hi oʊɾ əm mɔɹ ðən peɪn. bʌɾ ɪf kædzueɪn θɔt neɪkədnəs wəd hoʊld ɪm wɛɹ i wɑz, ʃi wɑz ɪn fəɹ ə sɝpɹaɪz. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðə meɪɾənz hæd lɛft ɪm ɛni mɑɾəsti əɾ ɔl. wɪð ə smaɪl fəɹ mɪn, hi ənwaʊn əɹ ɑɹmz, tɔs bæk ðə ʃit, ən klaɪmd aʊɾ ə ðə bɛɾ ɑn æmɪz' saɪd.

"No," he said quickly. Bera and Kiruna would obey a simple order to go, and if Corele and Samitsu had helped keep him alive, he owed them more than pain. But if Cadsuane thought nakedness would hold him where he was, she was in for a surprise. He was not sure the Maidens had left him any modesty at all. With a smile for Min, he unwound her arms, tossed back the sheet, and climbed out of the bed on Amys' side.

ðə waɪz wʌnz maʊθ taɪɾənd; hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si hɝ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə kɔl fəɹ ðə meɪɾənz. bɛɹə ɡeɪv æmɪz ən æɡənaɪzd, ənsɝɾən lʊk, waɪl kaɪɹunə hɝidli tɝn əɹ bæk, hɝ tʃiks dɑɹkənɪŋ. sloʊli hi wɔk tə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. sloʊli kəz i ɪkspɛktəɾ i maɪt ɡɪv kædzueɪn əɹ tʃæns ɪf i tʃɹaɪd tə muv kwɪkli.

The Wise One's mouth tightened; he could almost see her considering whether to call for the Maidens. Bera gave Amys an agonized, uncertain look, while Kiruna hurriedly turned her back, her cheeks darkening. Slowly he walked to the wardrobe. Slowly because he expected he might give Cadsuane her chance if he tried to move quickly.

"fɔ!" ʃi mʌɾɝd bɪhaɪn hɪm. "aɪ vaʊ, aɪ ʃəd smæk ðə stʌbɝn bɔɪz bɑɾəm." sʌmwʌn ɡɹʌntɪd wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn əɡɹimənt, əɹ dʒʌs dɪsəpɹuvəl ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ.

"Phaw!" she muttered behind him. "I vow, I should smack the stubborn boy's bottom." Someone grunted what might have been agreement, or just disapproval of what he was doing.

"ɑ, bʌɾ ɪts sətʃ ə pɹɪɾi bɑɾəm, naʊ ɪzən ɪt ðæt?" sʌmwʌn ɛls sɛɾ ɪn ə lɪltɪŋ mʊɹændiən æksɛnt. ðət mʌst əv bɪn kɔɹəl.

"Ah, but it's such a pretty bottom, now isn't it that?" someone else said in a lilting Murandian accent. That must have been Corele.

ə ɡʊd θɪŋ i hæɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. meɪbi ðə meɪɾənz hæd nɑt pild əweɪ əz mʌtʃ mɑɾəsti əz i θɔt. laɪt! hɪz feɪs fɛl hɑɾ əz ə fɝnəs. hoʊpɪŋ ðə moʊʃənz ə dʒɹɛsɪŋ wəd kʌvɝ ɛni wɑbəlz, hi klaɪmd ɪndə hɪz kloʊðz hɝidli. hɪz sɔɹd stʊd pɹɑpt ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, sɔɹd bɛlt waʊn ɝaʊn ðə dɑɹk bɔɹhaɪd skæbɝd. hi tʌtʃt ðə lɔŋ hɪlt, ðən tʊk ɪz hæn əweɪ.

A good thing he had his head inside the wardrobe. Maybe the Maidens had not peeled away as much modesty as he thought. Light! His face felt hot as a furnace. Hoping the motions of dressing would cover any wobbles, he climbed into his clothes hurriedly. His sword stood propped in the back of the wardrobe, sword belt wound around the dark boarhide scabbard. He touched the long hilt, then took his hand away.

bɛɹfʊt, hi tɝn bæk tə ði ʌðɝz waɪl stɪl taɪɪŋ ðə leɪsəz ə hɪz ʃɝt. mɪn stɪl sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɛɾ ɪn əɹ snʌɡ ɡɹin sɪlk bɹitʃɪz, baɪ hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən əneɪbəl tə dɪsaɪd bɪtwin əpɹuvəl ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. "aɪ nid tə tɔk wɪð dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən," hi sɛd. "əloʊn."

Barefoot, he turned back to the others while still tying the laces of his shirt. Min still sat cross-legged on the bed in her snug green silk breeches, by her expression unable to decide between approval and frustration. "I need to talk with Dashiva and the other Asha'man," he said. "Alone."

mɪn skɹæmbəld ɔf ðə bɛɾ ən ɹæn tə hʌɡ hɪm. nɑt taɪtli; ʃi wɑz vɛɹi kɛɹfəl ə hɪz bændədʒ saɪd. "aɪv weɪɾəd tu lɔŋ tə si jə əweɪk əɡɛn," ʃi sɛd, slaɪɾɪŋ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. "aɪ nid tə bi wɪð ju." ʃi ɛmfəsaɪz ðət dʒʌst ə tæd; ʃi mʌst əv hæɾ ə vjuɪŋ. əɹ meɪbi ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə hɛlp stɛɾi hɪz lɛɡz; ðəɾ ɑɹm sim tə ɔfɝ səpɔɹt. iðɝ weɪ, hi nɑɾəd; hi wɑz nɑɾ ɔl ðət stɛɾi. leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, hi sʌɾənli ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑn ði æʃəmən tə noʊ haʊ wik i wɑz ɛni mɔɹ ðən kædzueɪn əɹ æmɪz.

Min scrambled off the bed and ran to hug him. Not tightly; she was very careful of his Bandaged side. "I've waited too long to see you awake again," she said, sliding an arm around his waist. "I need to be with you." She emphasized that just a tad; she must have had a viewing. Or maybe she just wanted to help steady his legs; that arm seemed to offer support. Either way, he nodded; he was not all that steady. Laying a hand on her shoulder, he suddenly realized that he did not want the Asha'man to know how weak he was any more than Cadsuane or Amys.

bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə meɪd ɹɪlʌktən kɝtsiz ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wən æmɪz dɪd nɑt muv ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. "soʊ lɔŋ əz jə də nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə liv ðiz ɹumz," ðə waɪz wʌn sɛd, nɑɾ ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst əz ðoʊ spikɪŋ tə hɝ kɑɹəkɑɹn.

Bera and Kiruna made reluctant curtsies and started for the door, then hesitated when Amys did not move right away. "So long as you do not intend to leave these rooms," the Wise One said, not in the slightest as though speaking to her Car'a'carn.

ɹænd ɹeɪzd ə neɪkəd fʊt. "du aɪ lʊk əz ðoʊ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ?" æmɪz snɪft, bʌt wɪð ə ɡlæns əɾ ædli, ʃi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə ən dɪpɑɹɾəd.

Rand raised a naked foot. "Do I look as though I'm going anywhere?" Amys sniffed, but with a glance at Adley, she gathered up Bera and Kiruna and departed.

kædzueɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ oʊnli ə moʊmən mɔɹ ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ. ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd ɡɹin ɡlænst əɾ ædli, tu. ɪt kəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ ə sikɹət ðəɾ i hæd bɪn ɡɔn fɹəm kɛɹhin fəɹ deɪz. ət ðə dɔɹ, ʃi pɔzd. "doʊn də ɛniθɪŋ fulɪʃ, bɔɪ." ʃi saʊndəd laɪk ə stɝn æn kɔʃənɪŋ ə ʃɪfləs nɛfju, wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ ɛkspɛkteɪʃən i wəd lɪsən. sæmɪtsu ən kɔɹəl fɑloʊɾ əɹ aʊt, dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ fɹaʊnz bɪtwin ɪm ən ði æʃəmən. əz ðeɪ vænɪʃt, dæʃivə læft, ə ʃɑɹp wiz, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd; hi æktʃəli  saʊndəɾ əmjuzd.

Cadsuane and the other two were only a moment more in going. The gray-haired Green glanced at Adley, too. It could not be much of secret that he had been gone from Cairhien for days. At the door, she paused. "Don't do anything foolish, boy." She sounded like a stern aunt cautioning a shiftless nephew, without much expectation he would listen. Samitsu and Corele followed her out, dividing their frowns between him and the Asha'man. As they vanished, Dashiva laughed, a sharp wheeze, shaking his head; he actually sounded amused.

ɹænd stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm mɪn tə fɛtʃ ɪz buts fɹəm bɪsaɪd ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ən teɪk ə ɹoʊl pɛɹ ə stɑkɪŋz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. "aɪl dʒɔɪn jə ɪn ði æntəɹum əz sun əz aɪm buɾɪd, dæʃivə."

Rand stepped away from Min to fetch his boots from beside the wardrobe and take a rolled pair of stockings from inside. "I'll join you in the anteroom as soon as I'm booted, Dashiva."

ðə pleɪn-feɪst æʃəmən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. hi hæd bɪn fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ædli. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛd, pɹɛsɪŋ fɪs tə hɑɹt.

The plain-faced Asha'man gave a start. He had been frowning at Adley. "As you command, my Lord Dragon," he said, pressing fist to heart.

weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ðə fɔɹ mɛn wɝ ɡɔn, ɹænd sæt daʊn ɪn ə tʃɛɹ wɪð ə filɪŋ ə ɹɪlif ən bɪɡæn pʊlɪŋ ɑn ɪz stɑkɪŋz. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪz lɛɡz fɛl stʃɹɔŋɝ dʒʌs fəɹ biɪŋ ʌp ən muvɪŋ. stʃɹɔŋɝ, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl dɪd nɑt wɑnə səpɔɹɾ ɪm vɛɹi wɛl.

Waiting until the four men were gone, Rand sat down in a chair with a feeling of relief and began pulling on his stockings. He was sure his legs felt stronger just for being up and moving. Stronger, but they still did not want to support him very well.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ðɪs ɪz waɪz?" mɪn sɛd, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ, ən i ɡeɪv əɹ ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk. ɪf i hæd tɔkt ɪn ɪz slip dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz tu deɪz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ əv noʊn. æmɪz wʊɾə hæɾ ɪneɪlə ən soʊmɑɹə ən fɪfti mɔɹ meɪɾənz weɪɾɪŋ wən i woʊk.

"Are you sure this is wise?" Min said, kneeling beside his chair, and he gave her a startled look. If he had talked in his sleep during those two days, the Aes Sedai would have known. Amys would have had Enaila and Somara and fifty more Maidens waiting when he woke.

hi tʌɡd ðə stɑkɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ʌp. "du juv ə vjuɪŋ?"

He tugged the stocking the rest of the way up. "Do you have a viewing?"

mɪn sæt bæk ɑn əɹ hilz, foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə fɝm lʊk. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz nɑt wɝkɪŋ ən saɪd. "ɪts kædzueɪn. ʃiz gɑnə titʃ jə sʌmθɪŋ, jə ən ði æʃəmən. ɔl ði æʃəmən, aɪ min. ɪts sʌmθɪŋ juv tə lɝn, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, ɪksɛp ðət nʌn ə jəl laɪk lɝnɪŋ ɪt fɹəm hɝ. jə ɑɹən gɑnə laɪk ɪɾ əɾ ɔl."

Min sat back on her heels, folded her arms beneath her breasts and gave him a firm look. After a moment, she decided it was not working and sighed. "It's Cadsuane. She is going to teach you something, you and the Asha'man. All the Asha'man, I mean. It's something you have to learn, but I don't know what it is, except that none of you will like learning it from her. You aren't going to like it at all."

ɹænd pɔzd wɪð ə buɾ ɪn hænd, ðən stʌft ɪz fʊɾ ɪn. wʌt kəd kædzueɪn, əɹ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, titʃ ði æʃəmən? wɪmən kəd nɑt titʃ mɛn, əɹ mɛn wɪmən; ðət wɑz əz hɑɹɾ ə fækt əz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. "wi wɪl si" wɑz ɔl i sɛd.

Rand paused with a boot in hand, then stuffed his foot in. What could Cadsuane, or any Aes Sedai, teach the Asha'man? Women could not teach men, or men women; that was as hard a fact as the One Power itself. "We will see" was all he said.

pleɪnli ðət dɪd nɑt sæɾəsfaɪ mɪn. ʃi nu ɪt wəd hæpən, ən soʊ dɪd hi; ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ ɹɔŋ. bʌt wʌt kəd kædzueɪn pɑsəbli titʃ hɪm? wʌt wəɾ i lɛɾ əɹ titʃ hɪm? ðə wʊmən meɪɾ ɪm ənʃʊɹ ə hɪmsɛlf, ənizi ɪn ə weɪ hi hæd nɑt fɛl sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ fɛl.

Plainly that did not satisfy Min. She knew it would happen, and so did he; she was never wrong. But what could Cadsuane possibly teach him? What would he let her teach him? The woman made him unsure of himself, uneasy in a way he had not felt since before the Stone of Tear fell.

stæmpɪŋ ɪz fʊt tə sɛɾəl ɪɾ ɪn ðə sɛkən but, hi fɛtʃt ɪz sɔɹd bɛl fɹəm ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, ən ə ɹɛd koʊt wɝkt ɪn ɡoʊld, ðə seɪm i hæd wɔɹn tə ðə si foʊk. "wʌt bɑɹɡən dɪd mɛɹænə meɪk fəɹ mi?" hi æskt, ən ʃi meɪɾ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt.

Stamping his foot to settle it in the second boot, he fetched his sword belt from the wardrobe, and a red coat worked in gold, the same he had worn to the Sea Folk. "What bargain did Merana make for me?" he asked, and she made an exasperated sound in her throat.

"nʌn, əz ə ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "ʃi ən ɹæfɛlə hævən lɛf ðə ʃɪp sɪns wi dɪd, bʌt ðeɪv sɛn hæf ə dʌzən mɛsədʒəz æskɪŋ ɪf jəɹ wɛl ɪnʌf tə ɹɪtɝn. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ əz ɡɔn wɛl fəɹ əm wɪθaʊt ju. aɪ səpoʊz ɪts tu mʌtʃ tə hoʊp ðæts wɛɹ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

"None, as of this morning," she said impatiently. "She and Rafela haven't left the ship since we did, but they've sent half a dozen messages asking if you're well enough to return. I don't think the bargaining has gone well for them without you. I suppose it's too much to hope that's where you're going."

"nɑt jɛt," hi toʊl hɝ. mɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪt vɛɹi laʊdli, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ən wʌn aɪbɹaʊ ɹeɪz haɪ. wɛl, ʃi wəd noʊ moʊst ʌv ɪt sun ɪnʌf.

"Not yet," he told her. Min said nothing, but she said it very loudly, fists on her hips and one eyebrow raised high. Well, she would know most of it soon enough.

ɪn ði æntəɹum, ɔl ði æʃəmən ɪksɛp dæʃivə spɹæŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz wən ɹænd əpɪɹd wɪð mɪn. stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ ən tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, dæʃivə dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs əntɪl ɹænd ɹitʃt ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn sɛɾ ɪn ðə flɔɹ, ən ðən i blɪŋk sɛvɹəl taɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪzɪŋ.

In the anteroom, all the Asha'man except Dashiva sprang out of their chairs when Rand appeared with Min. Staring at nothing and talking to himself, Dashiva did not notice until Rand reached the Rising Sun set in the floor, and then he blinked several times before rising.

ɹænd ədʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf tə ædli waɪl fæsənɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən-ʃeɪp bʌkəl ə hɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. "ði ɑɹmiz ɹitʃt ðə hɪlfɔɹts ɪn ɪljən ɔlɹɛɾi?" hi wɑntəd tə teɪk wʌn ə ðə ɡɪldɪɾ ɑɹmtʃɛɹz, bʌt wəd nɑt lɛt hɪmsɛlf. "haʊ? ɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn sɛvɹəl mɔɹ deɪz ət ðə bɛst. ət bɛst." flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə lʊkt əz stɑɹɾəld əz dæʃivə; nʌn ə ðɛm hæd noʊn wɛɹ ædli ən hɑpwəl hæd ɡɔn - əɹ mɔɹ. dəsaɪɾɪŋ u tə tʃɹʌst wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə dɪfəkəlti, ən tʃɹʌst ə ɹeɪzɝz ɛdʒ.

Rand addressed himself to Adley while fastening the Dragon-shaped buckle of his sword belt. "The army's reached the hillforts in Illian already?" He wanted to take one of the gilded armchairs, but would not let himself. "How? It should have been several more days at the best. At best." Flinn and Narishma looked as startled as Dashiva; none of them had known where Adley and Hopwil had gone - or Morr. Deciding who to trust was always the difficulty, and trust a razor's edge.

ædli dʒɹu hɪmsɛlf ʌp. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz aɪz, bɪniθ ðoʊz θɪk aɪbɹaʊz. hi hæd sin ðə wʊlf, əz ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪn kɛɹhin. "ðə haɪ lɔɹd wɪɹɑmɑn lɛf ðə fʊt bɪhaɪn ən pɹɛs fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə hɔɹs," hi sɛd, ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ stɪfli. "ði il kɛpt ʌp, ʌv kɔɹs." hi fɹaʊnd. "wi ɪnkaʊntɝɾ il jɛstɝdeɪ. ʃeɪɾoʊ; aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ ðeɪ ɡɑt ðɛɹ. ðəɹ wɝ meɪbi naɪn əɹ tɛn θaʊzənd, ɔltəɡɛðɝ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪdn sim tə hæv ɛni waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl wɪð ðɛm, ən ðeɪ dɪdn ɹɪli sloʊ əs daʊn. wi ɹitʃt ðə hɪlfɔɹts ət nun tədeɪ."

Adley drew himself up. There was something about his eyes, beneath those thick eyebrows. He had seen the wolf, as they said in Cairhien. "The High Lord Weiramon left the foot behind and pressed forward with the horse," he said, reporting stiffly. "The Aiel kept up, of course." He frowned. "We encountered Aiel yesterday. Shaido; I don't know how they got there. There were maybe nine or ten thousand, altogether, but they didn't seem to have any Wise Ones who could channel with them, and they didn't really slow us down. We reached the hillforts at noon today."

ɹænd wɑntəd tə snɑɹl. livɪŋ ðə fʊt bɪhaɪnd! dɪd wɪɹɑmɑn θɪŋk i wɑz gɑnə teɪk pælɪseɪɾɪd fɔɹts ɑn hɪltɑps wɪð hɔɹsmən? pɹɑbli. ðə mæn pɹɑbli wʊɾə lɛf ði il bɪhaɪn tu, ɪf i cʊɾə aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛm. ful noʊbəlz ən ðɛɹ ful ɑnɝ! stɪl, ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. ɪksɛp tə ðə mɛn u daɪd kəz ðə haɪ lɔɹd wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz kəntɛmptʃuəs ʌv ɛniwʌn u dɪd nɑt faɪt fɹəm hɔɹsbæk.

Rand wanted to snarl. Leaving the foot behind! Did Weiramon think he was going to take palisaded forts on hilltops with horsemen? Probably. The man probably would have left the Aiel behind too, if he could have outrun them. Fool nobles and their fool honor! Still, it did not matter. Except to the men who died because the High Lord Weiramon was contemptuous of anyone who did not fight from horseback.

"ɛbən ən aɪ bɪɡæn dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðə fɝs pælɪseɪdz sun əz wi ɝaɪvd," ædli wɛn ɑn. "wɪɹɑmɑn dɪdn mʌtʃ laɪk ðæt; aɪ θɪŋk i wʊɾə stɑpt ʌs, bʌɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪd tə. ɛniweɪ, wi bɪɡæn sɛɾɪŋ faɪɝ tə ðə lɔɡz ən bloʊɪŋ hoʊlz ɪn ðə wɔlz, bʌt bɪfɔɹ wi mɔɹ ðən stɑɹɾəd, sɑmaɪl keɪm. ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ seɪɾɪn, ət list, ən ə lɑt stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛbən əɹ mi. əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ju, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, aɪd seɪ."

"Eben and I began destroying the first palisades soon as we arrived," Adley went on. "Weiramon didn't much like that; I think he would have stopped us, but he was afraid to. Anyway, we began setting fire to the logs and blowing holes in the walls, but before we more than started, Sammael came. A man channeling saidin, at least, and a lot stronger than Eben or me. As strong as you, my Lord Dragon, I'd say."

"hi wɑz ðəɹ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ?" ɹænd sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, bʌt ðən i ʌndɝstʊd. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ sɑmaɪl wəd steɪ seɪf ɪn ɪljən bɪhaɪn dɪfɛnsəz woʊvən ə ðə paʊɝ ɪf i θɔɾ i hæd tə feɪs ɹænd; tu mɛni ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd tʃɹaɪd, ən moʊst wɝ dɛd naʊ. ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, ɹænd læft - ən hæd tə hʌɡ hɪz saɪd; læfɪŋ hɝt. ɔl ðəɾ ɪlæbɹət dɪsɛpʃən tə kənvɪns sɑmaɪl i wəd bi ɛniwɛɹ bʌt wɪð ði ɪnveɪɾɪŋ ɑɹmi, tə bɹɪŋ ðə mæn aʊɾ ʌv ɪljən, ən ɔl meɪɾ ənnɛsəsɛɹi baɪ ə naɪf ɪn pdən feɪnz hænd. tu deɪz. baɪ ðɪs taɪm, ɛvɹibɑɾi hu hæɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn kɛɹhin - wɪtʃ sɝɾənli ɪnkluɾəd ðə fɔɹseɪkən - nu ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn leɪ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə dɛθ. əz wɛl tɔs wɛt wʊɾ ɑn ðə faɪɝ əz θɪŋk ʌðɝwaɪz. "mɛn skim ən wɪmən plɑt, bʌt ðə wil wivz əz ɪt wɪl"; ðət wɑz haʊ ðeɪ sɛɾ ɪɾ ɪn tɛɹ. "ɡoʊ ɑn," hi sɛd. "mɔɹ wɑz wɪð jə læs naɪt?"

"He was there right away?" Rand said incredulously, but then he understood. He had been sure Sammael would stay safe in Illian behind defenses woven of the Power if he thought he had to face Rand; too many of the Forsaken had tried, and most were dead now. In spite of himself, Rand laughed - and had to hug his side; laughing hurt. All that elaborate deception to convince Sammael he would be anywhere but with the invading army, to bring the man out of Illian, and all made unnecessary by a knife in Padan Fain's hand. Two days. By this time, everybody who had eyes-and-ears in Cairhien - which certainly included the Forsaken - knew that the Dragon Reborn lay on the edge of death. As well toss wet wood on the fire as think otherwise. "Men scheme and women plot, but the Wheel weaves as it will"; that was how they said it in Tear. "Go on," he said. "Morr was with you last night?"

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən; fɛdwɪn kʌmz ɛvɹi naɪt, dʒʌs laɪk hiz səpoʊz tə. læs naɪt, ɪt wɑz pleɪn əz ɛbənz noʊz wid ɹitʃ ðə fɔɹts tədeɪ."

"Yes, my Lord Dragon; Fedwin comes every night, just like he's supposed to. Last night, it was plain as Eben's nose we'd reach the forts today."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ɛni ʌv ðɪs." dæʃivə saʊndəɾ əpsɛt; ə mʌsəl ɪn ɪz tʃik wɑz twɪtʃɪŋ. "juv lʊɹɾ ɪm aʊt, bʌt tə wʌt pɝpəs? əz sun əz i filz ə mæn tʃænəl wɪð ɛniθɪŋ nɪɹ jəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ, hɪl fli bæk tə ɪljən ən wʌtɛvɝ tʃɹæps ən əlɑɹmz hiz woʊvən. jə woʊnt ɡɛɾ əɾ ɪm ðɛɹ; hɪl noʊ əz sun əz ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənz wɪðɪn ə maɪl ə ðə sɪɾi."

"I don't understand any of this." Dashiva sounded upset; a muscle in his cheek was twitching. "You've lured him out, but to what purpose? As soon as he feels a man channel with anything near your strength, he'll flee back to Illian and whatever traps and alarms he has woven. You won't get at him there; he will know as soon as a gateway opens within a mile of the city."

"wi kən seɪv ði ɑɹmi," ædli bɝst aʊt, "ðæts wʌt wi kən du. wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz stɪl sɛndɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒəz əɡɛns ðət fɔɹt wən aɪ lɛft, ən sɑmaɪl kʌts ɛvɹi wʌn tə ɹæɡz dɪspaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛbən əɹ aɪ kən du." hi ʃɪftəd ði ɑɹm wɪð ðə sɪŋʒd sliv. "wi hæv tə stʃɹaɪk bæk ən ɹʌn ɪmiɾiətli, ən ivən soʊ, hi nɪɹli bɝn əs wɛɹ wi stʊd, mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ði il ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ kæʒəwəltiz tu. ðəɹ oʊnli faɪɾɪŋ ði ɪliɑnɝz u kʌm aʊt - ði ʌðɝ hɪlfɔɹts mʌs bi ɛmptiɪŋ, soʊ mɛni wɝ kʌmɪŋ wən aɪ lɛft - bʌɾ ɛni taɪm sɑmaɪl siz fɪfti ʌv əs təɡɛðɝ, il əɹ ɛnibəɾi, hi ɹɪps əm əpɑɹt. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ θɹi ʌv hɪm, əɹ ivən tu, aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ aɪd faɪn ɛnibəɾi əlaɪv wən aɪ ɡoʊ bæk." dæʃivə stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf əɾ ə mædmæn, ən ædli ʃɹʌɡd sʌɾənli, əz ðoʊ filɪŋ ðə laɪtnəs ə hɪz bɛɹ blæk kɑlɝ kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən ɑn ði oʊldɝ mænz. "fɝɡɪv mi, æʃəmən," hi mʌɾɝd, əbæʃt, ðən æɾəd ɪn ə stɪl loʊɝ vɔɪs, "bʌt wi kən ət list seɪv ðɛm."

"We can save the army," Adley burst out, "that's what we can do. Weiramon was still sending charges against that fort when I left, and Sammael cuts every one to rags despite anything Eben or I can do." He shifted the arm with the singed sleeve. "We have to strike back and run immediately, and even so, he nearly burned us where we stood, more than once. The Aiel are taking casualties too. They're only fighting the Illianers who come out - the other hillforts must be emptying, so many were coming when I left - but any time Sammael sees fifty of us together, Aiel or anybody, he rips them apart. If there were three of him, or even two, I'm not sure I'd find anybody alive when I go back." Dashiva stared at him as if at a madman, and Adley shrugged suddenly, as though feeling the lightness of his bare black collar compared with the sword and Dragon on the older man's. "Forgive me, Asha'man," he muttered, abashed, then added in a still lower voice, "But we can at least save them."

"wi wɪl," ɹænd əʃʊɹd hɪm. dʒʌs nɑt ðə weɪ ædli ɪkspɛktəd. "jɔɹ ɔl gɑnə hɛlp mi kɪl sɑmaɪl tədeɪ." oʊnli dæʃivə lʊk stɑɹɾəld; ði ʌðɝ mɛn dʒʌs nɑɾəd. nɑɾ ivən ðə fɔɹseɪkən fɹaɪɾənd əm ɛnimɔɹ.

"We will," Rand assured him. Just not the way Adley expected. "You're all going to help me kill Sammael today." Only Dashiva looked startled; the other men just nodded. Not even the Forsaken frightened them anymore.

ɹænd ɪkspɛktəɾ ɑɹɡjəmən aʊɾ ə mɪn, meɪbi ə dɪmæn tə kʌm əlɔŋ, bʌt ʃi sɝpɹaɪz hɪm. "aɪ ɪkspɛk jə wəɾ əz sun noʊ wʌn faʊn aʊt jəɹ ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪv tə, ʃifɝɾɝ." hi nɑɾəd ən ʃi saɪd. pɝhæps ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd tə dɪpɛn ɑn pɪdʒənz ən aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz dʒʌs laɪk ɛniwʌn ɛls, bʌt biɪŋ tu ʃʊɹ kəd bi feɪɾəl.

Rand expected argument out of Min, maybe a demand to come along, but she surprised him. "I expect you would as soon no one found out you're gone before they have to, sheepherder." He nodded and she sighed. Perhaps the Forsaken had to depend on pigeons and eyes-and-ears just like anyone else, but being too sure could be fatal.

"ðə meɪɾənz wɪl wɑnə kʌm ɪf ðeɪ noʊ, mɪn." ðeɪ wəd wɑn tə, ən i wəd bi hɑɹd-pɹɛs tə ɹəfjuz. ɪf i kəd ɹəfjuz. jɛt ðə dɪsəpɪɹəns ivən ə nændɛɹə ən huɛvɝ ʃi hæɾ ɑn ɡɑɹd maɪt bi tu mʌtʃ.

"The Maidens will want to come if they know, Min." They would want to, and he would be hard-pressed to refuse. If he could refuse. Yet the disappearance even of Nandera and whoever she had on guard might be too much.

mɪn saɪɾ əɡɛn. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kəd ɡoʊ tɔk tə nændɛɹə. aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə kip əm aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ fəɹ ən aʊɝ, bʌt ðeɪ woʊn bi plizd wɪð mi wən ðeɪ faɪn aʊt." hi ɔlmoʊs læft əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪz saɪd; ðeɪ dɛfənətli wəd nɑt bi plizd wɪð hɝ, əɹ wɪð hɪm. "mɔɹ tə ðə pɔɪnt, fɑɹmbɔɪ, æmɪz woʊn bi plizd. əɹ sɔɹɪliə. ðə θɪŋz aɪ lɛt jə ɡɛt mi ɪntu."

Min sighed again. "I suppose I could go talk to Nandera. I might be able to keep them out in the hallway for an hour, but they won't be pleased with me when they find out." He almost laughed again before he remembered his side; they definitely would not be pleased with her, or with him. "More to the point, farmboy, Amys won't be pleased. Or Sorilea. The things I let you get me into."

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə tɛl əɹ i hæd nɑɾ æskt əɹ tə də ɛniθɪŋ, jɛt bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ ʌɾɝ ə wɝd, ʃi muvd vɛɹi kloʊs. lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu lɔŋ læʃɪz, ʃi pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, tæpɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi smaɪld wɔɹmli ən kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs sɑft, bʌt ðə fɪŋɡɝz wɝ ə ɡɪvəweɪ. "ɪf jə lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə ju, ɹænd ælθɹ, əl ɡɪv kædzueɪn ə hænd wɛðɝ ʃi nidz wʌn əɹ nɑt." hɝ smaɪl bɹaɪɾənd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɔlmoʊs tʃiɹəli, bɪfɔɹ ʃi tɝn fəɹ ðə dɔɹz. hi wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ; ʃi maɪt meɪk ɪz hɛd spɪn səmtaɪmz - nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʊmən i hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt hæd dʌn ðəɾ ət list ə taɪm əɹ tu - bʌt ʃi dɪɾ əv ə weɪ ʌv wɔkɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə wɑtʃ.

He opened his mouth to tell her he had not asked her to do anything, yet before he could utter a word, she moved very close. Looking up at him through long lashes, she put a hand on his chest, tapping her fingers. She smiled warmly and kept her voice soft, but the fingers were a giveaway. "If you let anything happen to you, Rand al'Thor, I'll give Cadsuane a hand whether she needs one or not." Her smile brightened for a moment, almost cheerily, before she turned for the doors. He watched her go; she might make his head spin sometimes - nearly every woman he had ever met had done that at least a time or two - but she did have a way of walking that made him want to watch.

əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪz dæʃivə wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əz wɛl. ən lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps. ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt laʊdli ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə saʊn ə ðə dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə pleɪn-feɪs mæn ɹeɪzd ɪz hænz dɪfɛnsɪvli. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ðoʊ ɹænd ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm; hi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət mɛn dʒʌs kəz mɪn wɔɹ taɪt bɹitʃɪz. sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ði ɛmptinəs ə ðə vɔɪd, hi siz seɪɾɪn ən fɔɹs fɹoʊzən faɪɝ ən moʊltən fɪlθ ɪndə ðə wivz fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ. dæʃivə lɛp bæk əz ɪɾ oʊpənd. meɪbi hævɪŋ ə hæn slaɪst ɔf wəd titʃ ðə mæn nɑt tə lɪk ɪz lɪps laɪk ə ɡoʊt. sʌmθɪŋ kɹʊkəɾ ən ɹɛd spaɪɾɝwɪbɛd əkɹɔs ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə vɔɪd.

Abruptly he realized Dashiva was watching as well. And licking his lips. Rand cleared his throat loudly enough to be heard over the sound of the door closing behind her. For some reason, the plain-faced man raised his hands defensively. It was not as though Rand glared at him; he could not go around glaring at men just because Min wore tight breeches. Surrounding himself with the emptiness of the Void, he seized saidin and forced frozen fire and molten filth into the weaves for a gateway. Dashiva leaped back as it opened. Maybe having a hand sliced off would teach the man not to lick his lips like a goat. Something crooked and red spiderwebbed across the outside of the Void.

hi stɛp θɹu ɑntu bɛɹ dɝt, wɪð dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪnd, ɹilisɪŋ ðə sɔɹs əz sun əz ðə læst stɛp klɪɹ. ə sɛns ə lɔs ɹʌʃt ɪn əz seɪɾɪn lɛft, əz əwɛɹnəs ʌv ɑlɑnə dwɪndəld. ðə lɔs hæd nɑt sim soʊ ɡɹeɪt waɪl luz θɝɪn wɑz ðɛɹ; nɑt soʊ hjudʒ.

He stepped through onto bare dirt, with Dashiva and the others right behind, releasing the Source as soon as the last stepped clear. A sense of loss rushed in as saidin left, as awareness of Alanna dwindled. The loss had not seemed so great while Lews Therin was there; not so huge.

oʊvɝhɛd, ðə ɡoʊldən sʌn wɑz mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə hɝaɪzən. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn swɛp dʌs fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz buts wɪθaʊt livɪŋ ɛni kulnəs bɪhaɪnd. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hæɾ oʊpən ɪn ə klɪɹɾ ɛɹiə, mɑɹkt ɔf baɪ ə ɹoʊp stʃɹʌŋ bɪtwin fɔɹ wʊɾən poʊsts. əɾ itʃ kɔɹnɝ stʊɾ ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɑɹdz ɪn ʃɔɹt koʊts ən bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz stʌft ɪndə ðɛɹ buts, sɔɹdz ðəɾ əpɪɹd slaɪtli sɝpəntaɪn hæŋɪŋ ət ðɛɹ saɪdz. səm hæd hɛvi mʌstæʃɪz ðət hʌŋ tə ðɛɹ tʃɪnz əɹ θɪk bɪɹdz, ən ɔl hæd boʊl noʊzɪz ən dɑɹk aɪz ðət sim tɪltəd. əz sun əz ɹænd əpɪɹd, wʌn ə ðɛm wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ.

Overhead, the golden sun was more than halfway down to the horizon. A gust of wind swept dust from under his boots without leaving any coolness behind. The gateway had opened in a cleared area, marked off by a rope strung between four wooden posts. At each corner stood a pair of guards in short coats and baggy trousers stuffed into their boots, swords that appeared slightly serpentine hanging at their sides. Some had heavy mustaches that hung to their chins or thick beards, and all had bold noses and dark eyes that seemed tilted. As soon as Rand appeared, one of them went running.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi duɪŋ hɪɹ?" dæʃivə sɛd, lʊkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli.

"What are we doing here?" Dashiva said, looking about incredulously.

ɝaʊn əm stʃɹɛtʃt hʌnʒɹədz ə ʃɑɹp-pik tɛns, ɡɹeɪ ən dʌsti waɪt, tɛns ən pɪkət-laɪnz ʌv ɔlɹɛɾi sæɾəld hɔɹsəz. keɪɛmlɪn leɪ nɑt mɛni maɪlz əweɪ, hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹiz, ən ðə blæk taʊɝ nɑt mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ, bʌt teɪm wəd nɑt noʊ ʌv ðɪs ənlɛs i hæɾ ə spaɪ wɑtʃɪŋ. wʌn ə fɛdwɪn mɔɹz tæsks hæd bɪn tə lɪsən - tə fil - fəɹ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə spaɪ. ɪn ə ɹɪpəl ə mɝmɝz spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊtwɝd fɹəm ðə ɹoʊps, mɛn wɪð boʊl noʊzɪz ən sɝpəntaɪn sɔɹdz ɹoʊz fɹəm ðɛɹ hilz ən tɝn tə stɛɹ ɪkspɛktənli təwɔɹd ɹænd. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wɪmən stʊɾ əz wɛl; sɑldəiən wɪmən ɔfən ɹoʊd tə ðə wɔɹz wɪð ðɛɹ hʌzbənz, ət list əmʌŋ ðə noʊbəlz ən ɔfəsɝz. ðəɹ wəd bi nʌn ə ðət tədeɪ, ðoʊ.

Around them stretched hundreds of sharp-peaked tents, gray and dusty white, tents and picket-lines of already saddled horses. Caemlyn lay not many miles away, hidden behind the trees, and the Black Tower not much farther, but Taim would not know of this unless he had a spy watching. One of Fedwin Morr's tasks had been to listen - to feel - for anyone trying to spy. In a ripple of murmurs spreading outward from the ropes, men with bold noses and serpentine swords rose from their heels and turned to stare expectantly toward Rand. Here and there women stood as well; Saldaean women often rode to the wars with their husbands, at least among the nobles and officers. There would be none of that today, though.

dʌkɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə ɹoʊp, ɹænd stʃɹoʊd dɝɛkli tə ə tɛnt noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə bænɝ ɑn ðə stæf ɪn fɹʌnt, θɹi sɪmpəl ɹɛd blɑsəmz ɑn ə fild ə blu. ðə kɪŋspɛni dɪd nɑt daɪ bæk ivən ɪn sɑldəiən wɪntɝz, ən wən faɪɝz blækən ðə fɔɹəsts, ðoʊz ɹɛd flaʊɝz wɝ ɔlweɪz ðə fɝs tə ɹiəpɪɹ. ə blɑsəm nʌθɪŋ kəd kɪl: ðə saɪn ə haʊs bæʃɪɹ.

Ducking under the rope, Rand strode directly to a tent no different from any other except for the banner on the staff in front, three simple red blossoms on a field of blue. The kingspenny did not die back even in Saldaean winters, and when fires blackened the forests, those red flowers were always the first to reappear. A blossom nothing could kill: the sign of House Bashere.

ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛnt, bæʃɪɹ hɪmsɛlf wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi buɾɪd ən spɝd, ən ɪz sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp. ɑmənəsli, dʒɹə wɑz wɪð hɪm, ɪn ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ðə seɪm ʃeɪɾ əz əɹ hʌzbənz ɡɹeɪ koʊt, ən ɪf ʃi wɔɹ noʊ sɔɹd, ðə lɔŋ dæɡɝ əɾ əɹ bɛlt ə hɛvi sɪlvɝ ɹɑndəlz wəd də tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð. ðə lɛðɝ ɡɔnləts tʌk bɪhaɪn ðət bɛl spoʊk ə sʌmwʌn minɪŋ tə ɹaɪd hɑɹd.

Inside the tent, Bashere himself was already booted and spurred, and his sword on his hip. Ominously, Deira was with him, in a riding dress the same shade as her husband's gray coat, and if she wore no sword, the long dagger at her belt of heavy silver rondels would do to go on with. The leather gauntlets tucked behind that belt spoke of someone meaning to ride hard.

"aɪ hædn ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs fəɹ deɪz jɛt," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ə foʊldɪŋ kæmp tʃɛɹ. "wiks, aɪ hoʊpt, ɪn tʃɹuθ. aɪ hæd hoʊp tə hæv moʊst ə teɪmz livɪŋz ɑɹm ðə weɪ jʌŋ mæt ən aɪ plænd - aɪv ɡæðɝɾ ɛvɹi meɪkɝ ə kɹɔsboʊz aɪ kəd faɪn ɪndə ə mænjəfæktɝi, ən ðəɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə pɹədus əm laɪk ə saʊ dʒɹɑpɪŋ paɪɡələts - bʌɾ əz ɪɾ ɪz, noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɪftin θaʊzən əv kɹɔsboʊz ən noʊ wʌt tə də wɪð ðɛm." wɪð ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊk, hi lɪftəɾ ə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ fɹəm ətɑp ðə mæps spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ɪz foʊldɪŋ teɪbəl. "du wɪv taɪm fəɹ pʌntʃ?"

"I hadn't expected this for days yet," Bashere said, rising from a folding camp chair. "Weeks, I hoped, in truth. I had hoped to have most of Taim's leavings armed the way young Mat and I planned - I've gathered every maker of crossbows I could find into a manufactory, and they're starting to produce them like a sow dropping piglets - but as it is, no more than fifteen thousand have crossbows and know what to do with them." With a questioning look, he lifted a silver pitcher from atop the maps spread out on his folding table. "Do we have time for punch?"

"noʊ pʌntʃ," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. bæʃɪɹ hæd spoʊkən bɪfɔɹ əbaʊt ðə mɛn teɪm faʊn u kəd nɑt lɝn tə tʃænəl, bʌɾ i hæd skɛɹsli lɪsənd. ɪf bæʃɪɹ θɔɾ i hæd tʃɹeɪn əm wɛl ɪnʌf, ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd. "dæʃivə ən θɹi mɔɹ æʃəmən ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd; əz sun əz mɔɹ dʒɔɪnz ðɛm, wɪl bi ɹɛɾi." hi aɪd dʒɹə ni ɡeɪlin tæʃɪɹ, taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ dɪmɪnjəɾɪv hʌzbənd wɪð əɹ hɔks bik ʌv ə noʊz ən əɹ aɪz ðət meɪɾ ə hɔks lʊk maɪld. "noʊ pʌntʃ, lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ. ən noʊ waɪvz. nɑt tədeɪ."

"No punch," Rand said impatiently. Bashere had spoken before about the men Taim found who could not learn to channel, but he had scarcely listened. If Bashere thought he had trained them well enough, that was all that mattered. "Dashiva and three more Asha'man are waiting outside; as soon as Morr joins them, we'll be ready." He eyed Deira ni Ghaline t'Bashere, towering over her diminutive husband with her hawk's beak of a nose and her eyes that made a hawk's look mild. "No punch, Lord Bashere. And no wives. Not today."

dʒɹə oʊpən əɹ maʊð, hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ɔl bʌt ɡloʊɪŋ sʌɾənli.

Deira opened her mouth, her dark eyes all but glowing suddenly.

"noʊ waɪvz," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz hɛvi ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik mʌstæʃɪz. "aɪ wɪl pæs ði ɔɹɾɝ." tɝnɪŋ tə dʒɹə, hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hænd. "waɪf," hi sɛd maɪldli. ɹænd wɪnst, maɪl toʊn əɹ noʊ, ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ði ɪɹʌpʃən.

"No wives," Bashere said, knuckling his heavy gray-streaked mustaches. "I will pass the order." Turning to Deira, he held out his hand. "Wife," he said mildly. Rand winced, mild tone or no, and waited for the eruption.

dʒɹəz maʊθ θɪnd. ʃi skaʊl daʊn əɾ əɹ hʌzbənd, ə hɔk ɹɛɾi tə stup ɑn ə maʊs. nɑt ðət bæʃɪɹ lʊkt ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ə maʊs, ʌv kɔɹs; dʒʌst ə mʌtʃ smɔlɝ hɔk. ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ; dʒɹə kəd meɪk dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ sim ə θɪŋ ðət ʃəd kɑz ði ɝθ tə tʃɹɛmbəl. ən ənhʊkɪŋ əɹ ʃið dæɡɝ fɹəm əɹ bɛlt, ʃi leɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hʌzbənz hænd. "wi wɪl tɔk ə ðɪs leɪɾɝ, dævɹæm," ʃi sɛd. "æt lɛŋθ."

Deira's mouth thinned. She scowled down at her husband, a hawk ready to stoop on a mouse. Not that Bashere looked anything like a mouse, of course; just a much smaller hawk. She drew a deep breath; Deira could make drawing a deep breath seem a thing that should cause the earth to tremble. And unhooking her sheathed dagger from her belt, she laid it in her husband's hand. "We will talk of this later, Davram," she said. "At length."

wʌn deɪ wən i hæd taɪm, ɹænd dɪsaɪɾɪd, hi wɑz gɑnə meɪk bæʃɪɹ ɪkspleɪn haʊ hi dɪd ðæt. ɪf ðəɹ ɛvɝ wɑz taɪm.

One day when he had time, Rand decided, he was going to make Bashere explain how he did that. If there ever was time.

"æt lɛŋθ," bæʃɪɹ əɡɹid, ɡɹɪnɪŋ θɹu hɪz mʌstæʃɪz əz i stʌf ðə dæɡɝ bɪhaɪn ɪz oʊn bɛlt. meɪbi ðə mæn wɑz sɪmpli suəsaɪɾəl.

"At length," Bashere agreed, grinning through his mustaches as he stuffed the dagger behind his own belt. Maybe the man was simply suicidal.

ðə ɹoʊp hæd bɪn teɪkən daʊn aʊtsaɪd, ən ɹænd stʊd weɪɾɪŋ wɪð dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən waɪl naɪn θaʊzən sɑldəiən laɪt hɔɹs ɝeɪd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪhaɪn bæʃɪɹ ɪn ə kɑləm ə θɹiz. sʌmwɛɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, fɪftin θaʊzən mɛn u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən wəd bi ɡæðɝɪŋ əfʊt. ɹænd hæd ɡlɪmps ðɛm, ɛvɹi wʌn ɪn ə blu koʊt meɪd tə bʌɾən ʌp ðə saɪd soʊ ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst wəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən. moʊs kæɹid stil-ɑɹm kɹɔsboʊz; səm bɔɹ hɛvi ənwildi ʃilz ɪnstɛd, bʌt nɑt wʌn kæɹiɾ ə paɪk. wʌtɛvɝ ɑd noʊʃən mæt ən bæʃɪɹ hæd kʊkt ʌp, ɹænd hoʊpt ɪt wəd nɑt lɛɾ ə lɑɾ ə ðɪs lidʒən tə dɛθ.

The rope had been taken down outside, and Rand stood waiting with Dashiva and the other Asha'man while nine thousand Saldaean light horse arrayed themselves behind Bashere in a column of threes. Somewhere behind them, fifteen thousand men who called themselves the Legion of the Dragon would be gathering afoot. Rand had glimpsed them, every one in a blue coat made to button up the side so the red-and-gold Dragon across the chest would not be broken. Most carried steel-armed crossbows; some bore heavy unwieldy shields instead, but not one carried a pike. Whatever odd notion Mat and Bashere had cooked up, Rand hoped it would not lead a lot of this legion to death.

mɔɹ ɡɹɪn iɡɝli waɪl i weɪɾəd, ɔl bʌt baʊnsɪŋ ɑn ɪz toʊz. pɝhæps i wɑz sɪmpli ɡlæd tə bi bæk ɪn ɪz blæk koʊt wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ, jɛɾ ædli ən nɛɹɪʃmə wɔɹ ɔlmoʊst aɪdɛntɪkəl ɡɹɪnz, ən fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, flɪnz wɑz nɑt fɑɹ ɔf. ðeɪ nu wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ naʊ, ən wʌt tə də ðɛɹ. dæʃivə skaʊld ət nʌθɪŋ əz juʒəwəl, hɪz lɪps muvɪŋ saɪlənli. əz juʒəwəl. ɔlsoʊ saɪlənt, skaʊlɪŋ, wɝ ðə sɑldəiən wɪmən ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn dʒɹə, wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm wʌn saɪd. iɡəlz ən fælkənz, fɛðɝz ɹʌfəld ən fjʊɹiəs. ɹænd dɪd nɑt kɛɹ haʊ ðeɪ ɡɹɪməst ən fɹaʊnd; ɪf i kəd feɪs nændɛɹə ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə meɪɾənz æftɝ kipɪŋ əm bæk fɹəm ðɪs, ðən ðə sɑldəiən mɛn kəd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛni nʌmbɝ ə lɛŋθi dɪskʌʃənz. tədeɪ, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, noʊ wɪmən wəd daɪ kəz ə hɪm.

Morr grinned eagerly while he waited, all but bouncing on his toes. Perhaps he was simply glad to be back in his black coat with the silver sword on his collar, yet Adley and Narishma wore almost identical grins, and for that matter, Flinn's was not far off. They knew where they were going now, and what to do there. Dashiva scowled at nothing as usual, his lips moving silently. As usual. Also silent, scowling, were the Saldaean women gathered behind Deira, watching from one side. Eagles and falcons, feathers ruffled and furious. Rand did not care how they grimaced and frowned; if he could face Nandera and the rest of the Maidens after keeping them back from this, then the Saldaean men could put up with any number of lengthy discussions. Today, the Light willing, no women would die because of him.

soʊ mɛni mɛn kəd nɑt bi laɪn ʌp ɪn ə mɪnət, ivən wən ðeɪ hæd bɪn əweɪɾɪŋ ði ɔɹɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪn ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ʃɔɹt taɪm, bæʃɪɹ ɹeɪzd ɪz sɔɹɾ ən kɔld, "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!"

So many men could not be lined up in a minute, even when they had been awaiting the order, but in a remarkably short time, Bashere raised his sword and called, "My Lord Dragon!"

ə ʃaʊt ɹɪpəl daʊn ðə ɡɹeɪt kɑləm bɪhaɪn hɪm. "ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!"

A shout rippled down the great column behind him. "The Lord Dragon!"

sizɪŋ ðə sɔɹs, ɹænd meɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪtwin ðə poʊsts, fɔɹ peɪsɪz baɪ fɔɹ, ən ɹæn θɹu əz i taɪɾ ɔf ðə wiv, fɪld wɪð seɪɾɪn ən ði æʃəmən ɑn ɪz hilz, ɪndə ə ɡɹeɪɾ oʊpən skwɛɹ sɝaʊndəd baɪ hjudʒ waɪt kɑləmz, itʃ tɑpt wɪð ə mɑɹbəl ɹiθ ʌv ɑləv bɹæntʃəz. ət ðə tu ɛnz ə ðə skwɛɹ stʊd nɪɹli aɪdɛntɪkəl pɝpəl-ɹuf pæləsəz ə kɑləmd wɔks ən haɪ bælkəniz ən slɛndɝ spaɪɹz. ðoʊz wɝ ðə kɪŋz pæləs ən ðə slaɪtli smɔlɝ ɡɹeɪt hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəl, ən ðɪs wɑz ðə skwɛɹ ə tæməz, ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ɪljən.

Seizing the Source, Rand made a gateway between the posts, four paces by four, and ran through as he tied off the weave, filled with saidin and the Asha'man on his heels, into a great open square surrounded by huge white columns, each topped with a marble wreath of olive branches. At the two ends of the square stood nearly identical purple-roofed palaces of columned walks and high balconies and slender spires. Those were the King's Palace and the slightly smaller Great Hall of the Council, and this was the Square of Tammaz, in the heart of Illian.

ə skɪni mæn ɪn ə blu koʊt, wɪð ə bɪɹd ðət lɛft ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ, stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ɹænd ən ðə blæk-koʊɾəd æʃəmən lipɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə hoʊl ɪn mɪdɛɹ, ən ə staʊt wʊmən, ɪn ə ɡɹin dʒɹɛs kʌt haɪ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ɡɹin slɪpɝz ən əɹ æŋkəlz ɪn ɡɹin stɑkɪŋz, pɹɛs boʊθ hænz tə hɝ feɪs ən stʊd ɹuɾəd ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, hɝ dɑɹk aɪz pɑpɪŋ. ɔl ðə pipəl wɝ stɑpɪŋ tə stɛɹ, hɔkɝz wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz, kɑɹɾɝz hɔltɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑksən, mɛn ən wɪmən ən tʃɪlʒɹən wɪð ðɛɹ maʊðz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

A skinny man in a blue coat, with a beard that left his upper lip bare, stood gaping at the sight of Rand and the black-coated Asha'man leaping out of a hole in midair, and a stout woman, in a green dress cut high enough to show green slippers and her ankles in green stockings, pressed both hands to her face and stood rooted right in front of them, her dark eyes popping. All the people were stopping to stare, hawkers with their trays, carters halting their oxen, men and women and children with their mouths hanging open.

ɹænd θɹʌst ɪz hænz haɪ ən tʃænəld. "aɪ æm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" ðə wɝdz bumd əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ, æmpləfaɪd baɪ ɛɹ ən faɪɝ, ən fleɪmz ʃɑɾ ʌp fɹəm ɪz hænz ə hʌnʒɹəd fit. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ði æʃəmən fɪl ðə skaɪ wɪð bɔlz ə faɪɝ stʃɹikɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ɔl seɪv dæʃivə, hu meɪd blu laɪtnɪŋz kɹækəl ɪn ə dʒæɡd wɛb əbʌv ðə skwɛɹ.

Rand thrust his hands high and channeled. "I am the Dragon Reborn!" The words boomed across the square, amplified by Air and Fire, and flames shot up from his hands a hundred feet. Behind him, the Asha'man filled the sky with balls of fire streaking in every direction. All save Dashiva, who made blue lightnings crackle in a jagged web above the square.

noʊ mɔɹ wɑz niɾəd. ə ʃɹikɪŋ flʌɾ ə hjumænɪɾi flɛɾ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, əweɪ fɹəm ðə skwɛɹ ə tæməz. ðeɪ flɛd dʒʌst ɪn taɪm. ɹænd ən ði æʃəmən dɑɹɾɪd əsaɪd fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ lɛɾ ɪz waɪldli skɹimɪŋ sɑldəiənz ɪndə ɪljən, ə flʌɾ ə hɔɹsmən weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz əz ðeɪ pɔɹɾ aʊt. stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd bæʃɪɹ lɛd ðə sɛntɝ laɪn ə ðə kɑləm, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hæd plænd wʌt sim soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, waɪl ði ʌðɝ tu laɪnz pild ɔf tə iðɝ saɪd. ðeɪ stʃɹimd əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹɾ ɪndə smɔlɝ ɡɹups, ɡæləpɪŋ ɪndə ðə stʃɹits liɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə skwɛɹ.

No more was needed. A shrieking flood of humanity fled in all directions, away from the Square of Tammaz. They fled just in time. Rand and the Asha'man darted aside from the gateway, and Davram Bashere led his wildly screaming Saldaeans into Illian, a flood of horsemen waving their swords as they poured out. Straight ahead Bashere led the center line of the column, just as they had planned what seemed so long ago, while the other two lines peeled off to either side. They streamed away from the gateway, breaking apart into smaller groups, galloping into the streets leading out of the square.

ɹænd dɪd nɑt weɪt tə si ðə læst ə ðə hɔɹsmən ɛɡzɪt. wɪð wɛl ʌndɝ ə θɝɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, hi ɪmiɾiətli woʊv ənʌðɝ, smɔlɝ oʊpənɪŋ. jə dɪd nɑt nid tə noʊ ə pleɪs əɾ ɔl tə tʃɹævəl ɪf jə oʊnli ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt dɪstəns. ɝaʊn ɪm i fɛl dæʃivə ən ðə ɹɛst wivɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡeɪtweɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stɛpɪŋ θɹu hɪz oʊn, lɛɾɪŋ ɪt kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɪm ətɑp wʌn ə ðə slɛndɝ taʊɝz ə ðə kɪŋz pæləs. æbsənli hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz dɛn bɑlɡɝ, ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, wɑz sʌmwɛɹ bɪloʊ hɪm ət ðət moʊmənt.

Rand did not wait to see the last of the horsemen exit. With well under a third out of the gateway, he immediately wove another, smaller opening. You did not need to know a place at all to Travel if you only intended to go a very short distance. Around him he felt Dashiva and the rest weaving their gateways, but he was already stepping through his own, letting it close behind him atop one of the slender towers of the King's Palace. Absently he wondered whether Mattin Stepaneos den Balgar, the King of Illian, was somewhere below him at that moment.

ðə tɑp ə ðə spaɪɹ stʃɹɛtʃt noʊ mɔɹ ðən faɪv peɪsɪz əkɹɔs, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə wɔl ə ɹɛd stoʊn nɑt kwaɪt tʃɛst-haɪ ɑn hɪm. ət fɪfti peɪsɪz, ɪt wɑz ðə haɪəs pɔɪn ɪn ɔl ə ðə sɪɾi. fɹəm ðəɹ i kəd si əkɹɔs ɹuftɑps ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ bɪniθ ði æftɝnun sʌn, ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin ən ɛvɹi kʌlɝ, tə ðə lɔŋ ɝθən kɔzweɪz ðət kʌt θɹu ðə væs tɔl-ɡɹæs mɑɹʃ sɝaʊndɪŋ sɪɾi ən hɑɹbɝ. ə ʃɑɹp tæŋ ə sɔl hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. ɪljən hæd noʊ niɾ ʌv wɔlz, wɪð ðəɾ ɔl-ɪnvɛləpɪŋ mɑɹʃ tə stɑp ən ətækɝ. ɛni ətækɝ u kəd nɑt meɪk hoʊlz ɪn ði ɛɹ. bʌt ðɛn, wɔlz wʊɾə dʌn noʊ ɡʊɾ iðɝ.

The top of the spire stretched no more than five paces across, surrounded by a wall of red stone not quite chest-high on him. At fifty paces, it was the highest point in all of the city. From there he could see across rooftops glittering beneath the afternoon sun, red and green and every color, to the long earthen causeways that cut through the vast tall-grass marsh surrounding city and harbor. A sharp tang of salt hung in the air. Illian had no need of walls, with that all-enveloping marsh to stop an attacker. Any attacker who could not make holes in the air. But then, walls would have done no good either.

ɪt wɑz ə pɹɪɾi sɪɾi, ðə bɪldɪŋz meɪnli ʌv peɪl dʒɹɛst stoʊn, ə sɪɾi kɹɪskɹɔs baɪ əz mɛni kənælz əz stʃɹits, laɪk tʃɹeɪsɝiz ə blu-ɡɹin fɹəm ðɪs haɪt, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt stɑp tə ædmaɪɹ ɪt. loʊ əkɹɔs ðə ɹufs ə tævɝnz ən ʃɑps ən spaɪɝd pæləsəz i dɝɛktəd floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, faɪɝ ən ɝθ ən spɪɹət, tɝnɪŋ əz i dɪd soʊ. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə wiv ðə floʊz, sɪmpli swɛpt əm aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi ən ə ɡʊd maɪl aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə mɑɹʃ. fɹəm faɪv ʌðɝ taʊɝz keɪm floʊz swipɪŋ loʊ, ən wɛɹ ðeɪ tʌtʃt wʌn ənʌðɝ ʌnkəntʃɹoʊld, laɪt flæʃt ən spɑɹks flɛɹɾ ən klaʊdz ə kʌlɝd stim bɝst, ə dɪspleɪ ɛni ɪluməneɪɾɝ maɪɾ əv ɛnvid. ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə fɹaɪɾən pipəl ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɛdz ən aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv bæʃɪɹz soʊlʒɝz, hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən, ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑt ðə ɹizən fəɹ ɪt.

It was a pretty city, the buildings mainly of pale dressed stone, a city crisscrossed by as many canals as streets, like traceries of blue-green from this height, but he did not stop to admire it. Low across the roofs of taverns and shops and spired palaces he directed flows of Air and Water, Fire and Earth and Spirit, turning as he did so. He did not try to weave the flows, simply swept them out over the city and a good mile out over the marsh. From five other towers came flows sweeping low, and where they touched one another uncontrolled, light flashed and sparks flared and clouds of colored steam burst, a display any Illuminator might have envied. A better way to frighten people under their beds and out of the way of Bashere's soldiers, he could not imagine, though that was not the reason for it.

lɔŋ əɡoʊ hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət sɑmaɪl mʌst əv wɔɹdz woʊvən θɹuaʊt ðə sɪɾi, sɛt tə ɡɪv ən əlɑɹm ʃəɾ ɛniwʌn tʃænəl seɪɾɪn. wɔɹdz ɪnvɝɾɪd soʊ noʊ wʌn ɪksɛp sɑmaɪl hɪmsɛlf kəd faɪn ðɛm, wɔɹdz ðət wəd tɛl sɑmaɪl ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ðət mæn wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ soʊ hi kəd bi dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɑn ði ɪnstənt. wɪð lʌk, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz wɔɹdz wɑz biɪŋ tʃɹɪɡɝd naʊ. luz θɝɪn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ sɑmaɪl wəd sɛns əm wɛɹɛvɝ i wɑz, ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns. ðət wɑz waɪ ðə wɔɹɾɪŋz ʃəd bi jusləs naʊ; ðət sɔɹt hæd tə bi ɹimeɪd wʌns tʃɹɪɡɝd. sɑmaɪl wəd kʌm. nɛvɝ ɪn ɪz laɪf hæɾ i ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃt ɛniθɪŋ i kənsɪɾɝd hɪz, haʊɛvɝ ʃeɪki hɪz kleɪm, nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪt. ɔl ðət fɹəm luz θɝɪn. ɪf i wɑz ɹil. hi hæd tə bi. ðoʊz mɛmɹiz hæd tu mʌtʃ dɪteɪl. bʌt kəd nɑɾ ə mædmæn dʒɹim ɪz fænsiz ɪn dɪteɪl, tu?

Long ago he had decided that Sammael must have wards woven throughout the city, set to give an alarm should anyone channel saidin. Wards inverted so no one except Sammael himself could find them, wards that would tell Sammael exactly where that man was channeling so he could be destroyed on the instant. With luck, every one of those wards was being triggered now. Lews Therin had been sure Sammael would sense them wherever he was, even at a distance. That was why the wardings should be useless now; that sort had to be remade once triggered. Sammael would come. Never in his life had he relinquished anything he considered his, however shaky his claim, not without a fight. All that from Lews Therin. If he was real. He had to be. Those memories had too much detail. But could not a madman dream his fancies in detail, too?

luz θɝɪn! hi kɔl saɪlənli. ðə wɪn bloʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪljən ænsɝd.

Lews Therin! he called silently. The wind blowing across Illian answered.

bɪloʊ, ðə skwɛɹ ə tæməz stʊd dɪzɝɾɪd ən saɪlənt, ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju əbændən kɑɹts. ɛdʒ-ɑn, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz ɪnvɪzəbəl ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wivz.

Below, the Square of Tammaz stood deserted and silent, empty except for a few abandoned carts. Edge-on, the gateway was invisible except for the weaves.

ɹitʃɪŋ daʊn tə ðoʊz wivz, ɹænd əntaɪd ðə nɑɾ ænd, əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋk fɹəm ɛɡzɪstəns, ɹɪlʌktənli ɹilist seɪɾɪn. ɔl ðə floʊz vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə skaɪ. meɪbi səm ə ði æʃəmən stɪl hɛld ɑn tə ðə sɔɹs, bʌɾ i hæd toʊld əm nɑt tə. hi hæd toʊld əm ðəɾ ɛni mæn i fɛl tʃænəlɪŋ ɪn ɪljən wʌns i hɪmsɛlf stɑpt, hi ɪntɛndəd tə kɪl wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə faɪn aʊɾ æftɝwɝd ðət ðə tʃænlɝ hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðɛm. hi lin ɑn ðə wɔl, weɪɾɪŋ, wɪʃɪŋ i kəd sɪt. hɪz lɛɡz ætʃt ən ɪz saɪd bɝn haʊɛvɝ i stʊd, jɛɾ i maɪt nid tə si əz wɛl əz fil ə wiv.

Reaching down to those weaves, Rand untied the knot and, as the gateway winked from existence, reluctantly released saidin. All the flows vanished from the sky. Maybe some of the Asha'man still held on to the Source, but he had told them not to. He had told them that any man he felt channeling in Illian once he himself stopped, he intended to kill without warning. He did not want to find out afterward that the channeler had been one of them. He leaned on the wall, waiting, wishing he could sit. His legs ached and his side burned however he stood, yet he might need to see as well as feel a weave.

ðə sɪɾi wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli kwaɪət. fɹəm sɛvɹəl dɝɛkʃənz i kəd hɪɹ dɪstənt ʃaʊts, ðə feɪn klæʃ ə mɛɾəl. ivən muvɪŋ soʊ mɛni mɛn tə ðə bɔɹɾɝ, sɑmaɪl hæd nɑt lɛft ɪljən ɪntaɪɝli ʌnpɹətɛktɪd. ɹænd tɝnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. hi θɔt sɑmaɪl wəd kʌm tə ðə kɪŋz pæləs əɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə skwɛɹ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bi sɝɾən. daʊn wʌn stʃɹiɾ i sɔ ə bæn ə sɑldəiənz klæʃɪŋ wɪð ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ə maʊntəd mɛn ɪn ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts; mɔɹ sɑldəiənz sʌɾənli ɡæləpt ɪn fɹəm wʌn saɪd, ən ðə faɪt vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz saɪt bɪhaɪn bɪldɪŋz. ɪn ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən i spɑɾəd səm ə ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, mɑɹtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ə kənælz loʊ bɹɪdʒ. ən ɔfəsɝ mɑɹk baɪ ə tɔl ɹɛd plum ɑn ɪz hɛlmət stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə səm twɛnti mɛn kæɹiɪŋ waɪd ʃilz əz tɔl əz ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, fɑloʊd baɪ pɝhæps tu hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ wɪð hɛvi kɹɔsboʊz. haʊ wəd ðeɪ faɪt? ʃaʊts ən stil ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn stil ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ðə feɪn skɹimz ə daɪɪŋ mɛn.

The city was not entirely quiet. From several directions he could hear distant shouts, the faint clash of metal. Even moving so many men to the border, Sammael had not left Illian entirely unprotected. Rand turned, trying to watch in every direction. He thought Sammael would come to the King's Palace or that other at the far end of the square, but he could not be certain. Down one street he saw a band of Saldaeans clashing with an equal number of mounted men in shining breastplates; more Saldaeans suddenly galloped in from one side, and the fight vanished from his sight behind buildings. In another direction he spotted some of the Legion of the Dragon, marching across a canal's low bridge. An officer marked by a tall red plume on his helmet strode ahead of some twenty men carrying wide shields as tall as their shoulders, followed by perhaps two hundred more with heavy crossbows. How would they fight? Shouts and steel ringing on steel in the distance, the faint screams of dying men.

ðə sʌn slɪd daʊnwɝd, ən ʃædoʊz lɛŋθən əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi. twaɪlaɪt, ən ðə sʌn ə loʊ kɹɪmzən doʊm ɪn ðə wɛst. ə fju stɑɹz əpɪɹd. hæɾ i bɪn ɹɔŋ? wəd sɑmaɪl sɪmpli ɡoʊ ɛlswɛɹ, faɪn ənʌðɝ læn tə mæstɝ? hæɾ i bɪn lɪsnɪŋ tə ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ɪz oʊn mæd ɹæmbəlɪŋz?

The sun slid downward, and shadows lengthened across the city. Twilight, and the sun a low crimson dome in the west. A few stars appeared. Had he been wrong? Would Sammael simply go elsewhere, find another land to master? Had he been listening to anything other than his own mad ramblings?

ə mæn tʃænəld. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɹænd fɹoʊz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ðət hæd bɪn ɪnʌf ə seɪɾɪn fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ; hi maɪt nɑɾ əv fɛlt ə mʌtʃ smɔlɝ tʃænəlɪŋ, ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə skwɛɹ. ɪt hæd tə bi sɑmaɪl.

A man channeled. For a moment, Rand froze, staring at the Great Hall of the Council. That had been enough of saidin for a gateway; he might not have felt a much smaller channeling, the length of the square. It had to be Sammael.

ɪn ən ɪnstən i hæd siz ðə sɔɹs, woʊvən ə ɡeɪtweɪ ən lɛp θɹu wɪð laɪtnɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə flaɪ fɹəm ɪz hænz. ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ ɹum, lɪt baɪ hjudʒ mɪɹɝd ɡoʊldən stænd-læmps ən ʌðɝz hæŋɪŋ ɑn tʃeɪnz fɹəm ðə silɪŋ, wɪð snoʊi mɑɹbəl wɔlz kɑɹvd ɪn fɹizɪz ʃoʊɪŋ bæɾəlz, ən ʃɪps kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə mɑɹʃ-bɔɹɾɝd hɑɹbɝ ʌv ɪljən ɪtsɛlf. ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, naɪn hɛvəli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪɾ ɑɹmtʃɛɹz stʊd laɪk θɹoʊnz ətɑp ə haɪ stɛɹ-fɹʌntɪd waɪt deɪz, ðə sɛntɝ tʃɛɹ wɪð ə bæk haɪɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ. bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹilis ðə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə taʊɝtɑp wɛɹ i hæd stʊɾ ɪksploʊɾəd. hi fɛl ðə wɑʃ ə faɪɝ ən ɝθ ivən əz ə stɔɹm ə stoʊn fɹæɡməns ən dʌst stʃɹʌk θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, nɑkɪŋ ɪm daʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs. peɪn stæbd ɪz saɪɾ əz i lændəd, ə ʃɑɹp ɹɛd læns dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə ðə vɔɪd wɛɹ i floʊɾəd, ən ðəɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls meɪɾ ɪm ɹilis ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz peɪn; sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz wiknəs. hi kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm, ɪn ðə vɔɪd.

In an instant he had seized the Source, woven a gateway and leaped through with lightning ready to fly from his hands. It was a large room, lit by huge mirrored golden stand-lamps and others hanging on chains from the ceiling, with snowy marble walls carved in friezes showing battles, and ships crowding the marsh-bordered harbor of Illian itself. At the far end of the room, nine heavily carved and gilded armchairs stood like thrones atop a high stair-fronted white dais, the center chair with a back higher than any other. Before he could release the gateway behind him, the towertop where he had stood exploded. He felt the wash of Fire and Earth even as a storm of stone fragments and dust struck through the gateway, knocking him down on his face. Pain stabbed his side as he landed, a sharp red lance digging into the Void where he floated, and that as much as anything else made him release the gateway. Someone else's pain; someone else's weakness. He could ignore them, in the Void.

hi muvd, fɔɹsɪŋ ənʌðɝ mænz mʌsəlz tə wɝk, pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp ən skɹæmbəld əweɪ ɪn ə lɝtʃɪŋ ɹʌn təwɔɹd ðə deɪz dʒʌst əz hʌnʒɹədz ə ɹɛd fɪləməns bɝn daʊn θɹu ðə silɪŋ, bɝn θɹu ðə si-blu mɑɹbəl flɔɹ ɪn ə waɪd sɝkəl ɔl ɝaʊnd wɛɹ ðə ɹɛzədu ʌv ɪz ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz stɪl feɪɾɪŋ. wʌn stæb θɹu ðə hil ə hɪz but, θɹu hɪz hil, ən i hɝd hɪmsɛlf kɹaɪ aʊɾ əz i fɛl. nɑɾ ɪz peɪn, ɪn saɪɾ əɹ fʊt. nɑt hɪz.

He moved, forcing another man's muscles to work, pushed himself up and scrambled away in a lurching run toward the dais just as hundreds of red filaments burned down through the ceiling, burned through the sea-blue marble floor in a wide circle all around where the residue of his gateway was still fading. One stabbed through the heel of his boot, through his heel, and he heard himself cry out as he fell. Not his pain, in side or foot. Not his.

ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑntu hɪz bæk, hi kəd si ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðoʊz bɝnɪŋ ɹɛd waɪɝz stɪl, fɹɛʃ ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt faɪɝ ən ɛɹ woʊvən ɪn ə weɪ hi hæd nɑt noʊn. ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊɾ ɪɡzækli ðə dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ hæd kʌm fɹʌm. blæk hoʊlz ɪn ðə flɔɹ ən ɔɹnətli wɝkt waɪt plæstɝ silɪŋ haɪ oʊvɝhɛd hɪst ən kɹækəld laʊdli ət ðə tʌtʃ ə ði ɛɹ.

Rolling onto his back, he could see the remnants of those burning red wires still, fresh enough to make out Fire and Air woven in a way he had not known. Enough to make out exactly the direction they had come from. Black holes in the floor and ornately worked white plaster ceiling high overhead hissed and crackled loudly at the touch of the air.

hɪz hænz ɹoʊz, ən i woʊv bɑlfaɪɝ. bɪɡæn tə wiv ɪt. sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz tʃik stʌŋ fɹəm ə ɹɪmɛmbɝd slæp, ən kædzueɪnz vɔɪs hɪst ən kɹækəld ɪn ɪz hɛd laɪk ðə hoʊlz ðə ɹɛd fɪləməns hæd meɪd. nɛvɝ əɡɛn, bɔɪ; jə wɪl nɛvɝ də ðəɾ əɡɛn. ɪt sim ðəɾ i hɝd luz θɝɪn wɪmpɝɪŋ ɪn dɪstən fɪɹ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt tə lus, wʌt hæɾ ɔlmoʊs dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə wɝld wʌns. ɛvɹi floʊ bʌt faɪɝ ən ɛɹ fɛl əweɪ, ən i woʊv əz i hæd sin. ə θaʊzən faɪn hɛɹz ə ɹɛd blɑsəm bɪtwin ɪz hænz, fænɪŋ aʊt slaɪtli ðeɪ ʃɑɾ ʌpwɝd. ə sɝkəl ə ðə silɪŋ tu fiɾ əkɹɔs fɛl ɪn stoʊn tʃɪps ən plæstɝ dʌst.

His hands rose, and he wove balefire. Began to weave it. Someone else's cheek stung from a remembered slap, and Cadsuane's voice hissed and crackled in his head like the holes the red filaments had made. Never again, boy; you wilt never do that again. It seemed that he heard Lews Therin whimpering in distant fear of what he was about to loose, what had almost destroyed the world once. Every flow but Fire and Air fell away, and he wove as he had seen. A thousand fine hairs of red blossomed between his hands, fanning out slightly they shot upward. A circle of the ceiling two feet across fell in stone chips and plaster dust.

oʊnli æftɝ i hæd dʌn ɪt dɪɾ i θɪŋk ðət ðəɹ maɪt bi sʌmwʌn bɪtwin ɪm ən sɑmaɪl. hi ɪntɛndəd tə si sɑmaɪl dɛd ðɪs deɪ, bʌɾ ɪf i kəd də ɪt wɪθaʊt kɪlɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛls. . . . ðə wivz vænɪʃt əz i pʊl hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit wʌns mɔɹ ən lɪmp hɝidli tə ðə dɔɹz ɪn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɔl, tɔl θɪŋz wɪð ɛvɹi pænəl sɛt wɪð naɪn ɡoʊldən biz ðə saɪz ə hɪz fɪst.

Only after he had done it did he think that there might be someone between him and Sammael. He intended to see Sammael dead this day, but if he could do it without killing anyone else. . . . The weaves vanished as he pulled himself to his feet once more and limped hurriedly to the doors in the side of the hall, tall things with every panel set with nine golden bees the size of his fist.

ə smɔl floʊ ʌv ɛɹ pʊʃt wʌn dɔɹ oʊpən bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɪt, tu smɔl tə bi dɪtɛktəɾ əɾ ɛni dɪstəns. hɑbəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, hi sæŋk tə wʌn ni. ðəɾ ʌðɝ mænz saɪd wɑz faɪɝ, hɪz hil æɡəni. ɹænd pʊld ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp ən lin ɑn ɪt, weɪɾɪŋ. ə klin-ʃeɪvən fɛloʊ wɪð plʌmp pɪŋk tʃiks pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ daʊn ðə weɪ; ɪnʌf ə hɪz koʊt ʃoʊd tə neɪm ɪm ə sɝvənt. ət list, ə koʊt ɡɹin ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən jɛloʊ ɑn ði ʌðɝ lʊk laɪk lɪvɝi. ðə fɛloʊ sɔ ɹænd ænd, vɛɹi sloʊli, əz ðoʊ hi maɪt nɑt bi noʊɾəst ɪf i muv sloʊli ɪnʌf, slɪd bæk aʊɾ ə saɪt. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, sɑmaɪl wəɾ əv tə. . . .

A small flow of Air pushed one door open before he reached it, too small to be detected at any distance. Hobbling into the corridor, he sank to one knee. That other man's side was fire, his heel agony. Rand pulled his sword up and leaned on it, waiting. A clean-shaven fellow with plump pink cheeks peered around a corner down the way; enough of his coat showed to name him a servant. At least, a coat green on one side and yellow on the other looked like livery. The fellow saw Rand and, very slowly, as though he might not be noticed if he moved slowly enough, slid back out of sight. Sooner or later, Sammael would have to. . . .

"ɪljən bɪlɔŋz tə mi!" ðə vɔɪs bumd ɪn ði ɛɹ, fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, ən ɹænd kɝst. ðət hæd tə bi ðə seɪm wiv i hɪmsɛlf hæd juzd ɪn ðə skwɛɹ, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi laɪk; ɪt ɹikwaɪɝd soʊ lɪɾəl ə ðə paʊɝ i maɪt nɑɾ əv fɛl ði æktʃəwəl floʊz hæɾ i bɪn wɪðɪn tɛn peɪsɪz ə ðə mæn. "ɪljən ɪz maɪn! aɪ woʊn dɪstʃɹɔɪ wʌt bɪlɔŋz tə mi kɪlɪŋ ju, ən aɪ woʊn lɛt jə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt, iðɝ. jə hæd ðə nɝv tə kʌm æftɝ mi hɪɹ? juv ðə kɝədʒ tə fɑloʊ mi əɡɛn?" ə slaɪ mɑkɪŋ toʊn ɛntɝɪŋ ðət θʌndɝɪŋ vɔɪs. "du juv ðə kɝədʒ?" sʌmwɛɹ əbʌv, ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ən kloʊzd; ɹænd hæd noʊ daʊt ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wɑz.

"Illian belongs to me!" The voice boomed in the air, from every direction, and Rand cursed. That had to be the same weave he himself had used in the square, or something very like; it required so little of the Power he might not have felt the actual flows had he been within ten paces of the man. "Illian is mine! I won't destroy what belongs to me killing you, and I won't let you destroy it, either. You had the nerve to come after me here? Do you have the courage to follow me again?" A sly mocking tone entering that thundering voice. "Do you have the courage?" Somewhere above, a gateway opened and closed; Rand had no doubt that was what it was.

ðə kɝədʒ? dɪɾ i hæv ðə kɝədʒ? "ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi mʌɾɝd, "æn aɪm gɑnə kɪl ju." wivɪŋ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, hi stɛp θɹu, tə ə pleɪs flɔɹz əbʌv.

The courage? Did he have the courage? "I'm the Dragon Reborn," he muttered, "and I'm going to kill you." Weaving a gateway, he stepped through, to a place floors above.

ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ hɔlweɪ, laɪnd wɪð wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz ʃoʊɪŋ ʃɪps ət si. ət ðə fɑɹ ɛnd, ðə læs kɹɪmzən slɪvɝ ə ðə sʌn ʃoʊn θɹu ə koʊlən-neɪɾɪd wɔk. ðə ɹɛzədu ʌv sɑmaɪlz ɡeɪtweɪ hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðə dɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ floʊz laɪk feɪnli ɡloʊɪŋ ɡoʊsts. nɑt soʊ feɪn ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk əm aʊt, ðoʊ. hi bɪɡæn tə wiv, ðən stɑpt. hi hæd lɛpt ʌp hɪɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə θɔɾ ʌv ə tʃɹæp. ɪf i kɑpid wʌɾ i sɔ ɪɡzækli, hi wəd stɛp aʊt wɛɹɛvɝ sɑmaɪl hæd, əɹ soʊ kloʊs əz meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. bʌt wɪð dʒʌst ə slaɪɾ ɔltɝeɪʃən; noʊ weɪ tə bi ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ðə tʃeɪnʒ wɑz fɪfti fiɾ əɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd, jɛɾ iðɝ wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf.

It was another hallway, lined with wall hangings showing ships at sea. At the far end, the last crimson sliver of the sun shone through a colon-naded walk. The residue of Sammael's gateway hung in the air, the dissipating flows like faintly glowing ghosts. Not so faint Rand could not make them out, though. He began to weave, then stopped. He had leaped up here without a thought of a trap. If he copied what he saw exactly, he would step out wherever Sammael had, or so close as made no difference. But with just a slight alteration; no way to be sure whether the change was fifty feet or five hundred, yet either was close enough.

ðə vɝɾɪkəl sɪlvɝ slæʃ bɪɡæn tə ɹoʊteɪɾ oʊpən, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ-kloʊkt ɹuənz ʌv ɡɹeɪtnəs, nɑt kwaɪɾ əz dɑɹk əz ðə hɔlweɪ. sin θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ðə sʌn wɑz ə slaɪtli θɪkɝ slaɪs ə ɹɛd, hæf-hɪɾən baɪ ə ʃæɾɝd doʊm. hi nu ðət pleɪs. ðə læs taɪm i hæd ɡɔn ðɛɹ, hi hæɾ æɾəd ə neɪm tə ðət lɪst ə meɪɾənz ɪn ɪz hɛd; ðə fɝs taɪm, pdən feɪn hæd fɑloʊɾ ən bɪkʌm mɔɹ ðən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, wɝs ðən ə dɑɹk-fɹɛnd. ðət sɑmaɪl hæd flɛd tə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ sim laɪk kʌmɪŋ fʊl sɝkəl ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðət wʌn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə weɪs naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz oʊpənɪŋ ðə weɪ. bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ stɑpt waɪɾənɪŋ, hi ɹæn θɹu ɪndə ðə ɹævɪdʒ sɪɾi ðət wʌns hæd bɪn kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl, ɹæn lɪmpɪŋ, lɛɾɪŋ ðə wiv ɡoʊ əz i ɹæn, buts kɹʌntʃɪŋ ɑn bɹoʊkən peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ən dɛd widz.

The vertical silver slash began to rotate open, revealing the shadow-cloaked ruins of greatness, not quite as dark as the hallway. Seen through the gateway, the sun was a slightly thicker slice of red, half-hidden by a shattered dome. He knew that place. The last time he had gone there, he had added a name to that list of Maidens in his head; the first time, Padan Fain had followed and become more than a Darkfriend, worse than a Dark-friend. That Sammael had fled to Shadar Logoth seemed like coming full circle in more ways that one. There was no time to waste now that he was opening the way. Before the gateway stopped widening, he ran through into the ravaged city that once had been called Aridhol, ran limping, letting the weave go as he ran, boots crunching on broken paving stones and dead weeds.

ðə fɝs kɔɹnɝ i keɪm tə, hi dʌkt ɝaʊnd. ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃʊk ʌndɝ ɪz fiɾ əz ɹɔɹz saʊndəd bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm, laɪt flæʃɪŋ ətɑp flæʃ ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪt dɑɹknəs; hi fɛl ðə wɑʃ ə ɝθ ən faɪɝ ən ɛɹ. ʃɹiks ən bɛloʊz ɹoʊz θɹu ðə θʌndɝəs kɹæʃɪz. seɪɾɪn pʌlsɪŋ ɪnsaɪd hɪm, hi hɑbəld əweɪ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk. hi ɹæn, ən wɪð ðə paʊɝ fɪlɪŋ hɪm, ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹk ʃædoʊz i kəd si klɪɹli.

The first corner he came to, he ducked around. The ground shook under his feet as roars sounded back the way he had come, light flashing atop flash in the twilight darkness; he felt the wash of Earth and Fire and Air. Shrieks and bellows rose through the thunderous crashes. Saidin pulsing inside him, he hobbled away without looking back. He ran, and with the Power filling him, even in the dark shadows he could see clearly.

ɔl ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi leɪ hjudʒ mɑɹbəl pæləsəz itʃ wɪð fɔɹ ən faɪv doʊmz ə dɪfɹənt ʃeɪps peɪntəd kɹɪmzən baɪ ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, bɹɑnz faʊntənz ən stætʃuz əɾ ɛvɹi ɪntɝsɛkʃən, ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛtʃəz ə kɑləmz ɹʌnɪŋ tə taʊɝz ðət sɔɹɾ əkɹɔs ðə sʌn. ðeɪ sɔɹd wən ɪntækt, ət list; mɔɹ ɛndəɾ ɪn əbɹʌp dʒæədnəs ðən nɑt. fəɹ ɛvɹi doʊm ðət stʊd hoʊl, tɛn wɝ bɹoʊkən ɛɡʃəlz wɪð ðə tɑp hækt ɔf əɹ wʌn saɪd ɡɔn. stætʃuz leɪ tɑpəld ɪn fɹæɡməns, əɹ stʊd wɪð mɪsɪŋ ɑɹmz, əɹ hɛdz. swɪfli dipənɪŋ dɑɹknəs ɹeɪst əkɹɔs spɹɔlɪŋ hɪlz ə ɹʌbəl, ðə fju stʌntɪd tʃɹiz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðɛɹ sloʊps twɪstəd ʃeɪps laɪk bɹoʊkən fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛns ðə skaɪ.

All around the great city lay huge marble palaces each with four and five domes of different shapes painted crimson by the setting sun, bronze fountains and statues at every intersection, great stretches of columns running to towers that soared across the sun. They soared when intact, at least; more ended in abrupt jaggedness than not. For every dome that stood whole, ten were broken eggshells with the top hacked off or one side gone. Statues lay toppled in fragments, or stood with missing arms, or heads. Swiftly deepening darkness raced across sprawling hills of rubble, the few stunted trees clinging to their slopes twisted shapes like broken fingers against the sky.

ə fæn ə bɹɪks ən stoʊn spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə weɪ fɹəm wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə smɔl pæləs; hæf ɪts fɹʌn mɪsɪŋ, ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kɑləm fəsɑd lin dʒɹʌŋkənli təwɔɹd ðə stʃɹit. hi stɑpt ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹit, dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə fæn, weɪɾɪŋ, filɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ tə juz seɪɾɪn. klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə saɪdz ə ðə stʃɹit wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, ən nɑt sɪmpli kəz ɛni bɪldɪŋ maɪt fɔl əɾ ɛni taɪm. ə θaʊzən ənsin aɪz sim tə wɑtʃ fɹəm wɪndoʊz laɪk ɡaʊdʒd aɪ sɑkəts, tə wɑtʃ wɪð ə nɪɹli pælpəbəl sɛns ʌv æntɪsəpeɪʃən. dɪstənli hi fɛl ðə nu waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd θɹɑbɪŋ, ə slæʃ ə fleɪm, ɛkoʊɪŋ ði ivəl ðət klʌŋ tə ðə vɛɹi dʌst ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ði oʊl skɑɹ klɛntʃt laɪk ə fɪst. ðə peɪn ə hɪz fʊt sim vɛɹi dɪstən ɪndid. kloʊsɝ, ðə vɔɪɾ ɪtsɛlf pʊlseɪɾɪd ɝaʊn hɪm, ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn biɾɪŋ ɪn taɪm wɪð ðə naɪf slæʃ əkɹɔs ɪz ɹɪbz. ə deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs baɪ deɪlaɪt, ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. baɪ naɪt. . . .

A fan of bricks and stone spread across the way from what might have been a small palace; half its front missing, the rest of the columned facade leaned drunkenly toward the street. He stopped in the middle of the street, just short of the fan, waiting, feeling for another to use saidin. Clinging to the sides of the street was not a good idea, and not simply because any building might fall at any time. A thousand unseen eyes seemed to watch from windows like gouged eye sockets, to watch with a nearly palpable sense of anticipation. Distantly he felt the new wound in his side throbbing, a slash of flame, echoing the evil that clung to the very dust of Shadar Logoth. The old scar clenched like a fist. The pain of his foot seemed very distant indeed. Closer, the Void itself pulsated around him, the Dark One's taint on saidin beating in time with the knife slash across his ribs. A dangerous place by daylight, Shadar Logoth. By night. . . .

daʊn ðə stʃɹit, bɪɑn ə spaɪɝd mɑnjəmən mɝækjələsli stændɪŋ stʃɹeɪt, sʌmθɪŋ muvd, ə ʃæɾoʊd ʃeɪp dɑɹɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə weɪ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ɹænd ɔlmoʊs tʃænəld, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bɪliv sɑmaɪl wəd ɡoʊ skʌɾəlɪŋ ðət weɪ. wən i fɝst stɛpt ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, wən sɑmaɪl tʃɹaɪd tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz ɡeɪtweɪ, hi hæd hɝd hɔɹəbəl skɹimz. ðeɪ hæd bɛɹli ɹɛdʒəstɝd, ðɛn. nʌθɪŋ lɪvd ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, nɑɾ ivən ɹæts. sɑmaɪl mʌst əv bɹɔt hɛntʃmən, fɛloʊz i dɪd nɑt maɪn kɪlɪŋ ɪn ən ətɛmp tə ɹitʃ ɹænd. meɪbi wʌn ə ðɛm kəd lid ɹænd tə sɑmaɪl. hi hɝid fɔɹwɝɾ əz fæst əz i kʊd, əz saʊnləsli əz i kʊd. ʃæɾɝd peɪvmən kɹʌntʃt ʌndɝ ɪz buts wɪð ə saʊn laɪk boʊnz snæpɪŋ. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz laʊɾ oʊnli tə hɪz seɪɾɪn-ɛnhænst ɪɹz.

Down the street, beyond a spired monument miraculously standing straight, something moved, a shadowed shape darting across the way in the darkness. Rand almost channeled, but he could not believe Sammael would go scuddling that way. When he first stepped into the city, when Sammael tried to destroy everything around his gateway, he had heard horrible screams. They had barely registered, then. Nothing lived in Shadar Logoth, not even rats. Sammael must have brought henchmen, fellows he did not mind killing in an attempt to reach Rand. Maybe one of them could lead Rand to Sammael. He hurried forward as fast as he could, as soundlessly as he could. Shattered pavement crunched under his boots with a sound like bones snapping. He hoped it was loud only to his saidin-enhanced ears.

stɑpɪŋ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə spaɪɹ, ə θɪk stoʊn niɾəl kʌvɝd wɪð floʊɪŋ skɹɪpt, hi pɪɹɾ əhɛd. huɛvɝ hæd muvd wɑz ɡɔn; oʊnli fulz əɹ ðə mædli bɹeɪv wɛn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ət naɪt. ði ivəl ðət steɪnd ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ði ivəl ðət hæd mɝɾɝd ɑɹɪdhɔl, hæd nɑt daɪd wɪð ɑɹɪdhɔl. fɑɹðɝ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit, ə tɛnʒɹɪl ə sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ fɑɡ weɪvɝɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə wɪndoʊ, kɹipɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ ðət keɪm tə miɾ ɪt fɹəm ə waɪd ɡæp ɪn ə haɪ stoʊn wɔl. ðə dɛpθs ə ðət ɡæp ʃoʊn əz ðoʊ ə fʊl mun leɪ ɪnsaɪd. wɪð ðə naɪt, mɑʃəɾɝ ɹoʊmd ɪts sɪɾi pɹɪzən, ə væs pɹɛzəns ðət kəɾ əpɪɹ ɪn ə dʌzən pleɪsəz ət wʌns, ə hʌnʒɹəd. mɑʃəɾɝz tʌtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzənt weɪ tə daɪ. ɪnsaɪd ɹænd, ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn bit hɑɹɾɝ; ðə dɪstən faɪɝ ɪn ɪz saɪd flɪkɝd laɪk tɛn θaʊzən laɪtnɪŋz, wʌn ɑn tɑp ə ðə læst. ivən ðə ɡɹaʊn sim tə paʊn bɪniθ ɪz buts.

Stopping at the base of the spire, a thick stone needle covered with flowing script, he peered ahead. Whoever had moved was gone; only fools or the madly brave went inside in Shadar Logoth at night. The evil that stained Shadar Logoth, the evil that had murdered Aridhol, had not died with Aridhol. Farther along the street, a tendril of silver-gray fog wavered out of a window, creeping toward another that came to meet it from a wide gap in a high stone wall. The depths of that gap shone as though a full moon lay inside. With the night, Mashadar roamed its city prison, a vast presence that could appear in a dozen places at once, a hundred. Mashadar's touch was not a pleasant way to die. Inside Rand, the taint on saidin beat harder; the distant fire in his side flickered like ten thousand lightnings, one on top of the last. Even the ground seemed to pound beneath his boots.

hi tɝnd, hæf-θɪŋkɪŋ tə liv naʊ. vɛɹi laɪkli, sɑmaɪl hæd ɡɔn, naʊ ðət mɑʃəɾɝ wɑz aʊt. vɛɹi laɪkli ðə mæn hæd lʊɹɾ ɪm hɪɹ ɪn ðə hoʊp i wəd sɝtʃ ðə ɹuənz əntɪl mɑʃəɾɝ kɪl hɪm. hi tɝnd, ən stɑpt, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ əɡɛns ðə spaɪɹ. tu tʃɹɑləks wɝ kɹipɪŋ daʊn ðət stʃɹit, bʌlki ʃeɪps ɪn blæk meɪl, hæf əɡɛn əz tɔl əz hi, əɹ mɔɹ. spaɪks stʊɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən ɛlboʊz ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ, ən ðeɪ kæɹid spɪɹz wɪð lɔŋ blæk pɔɪns ən wɪkəd hʊks. tə hɪz seɪɾɪn-fɪld aɪz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz stʊɾ aʊt klɪɹli, wʌn dɪstɔɹɾəd baɪ ən iɡəlz bik wɛɹ maʊθ ən noʊz ʃəɾ əv bɪn, ði ʌðɝ baɪ ə bɔɹz tʌsk snaʊt. ɛvɹi laɪn ə ðɛɹ kɹipɪŋ ʃaʊɾəd fɪɹ; tʃɹɑləks lʌv kɪlɪŋ, lʌv blʌd, bʌt ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ tɛɹəfaɪd ðɛm. ðəɹ wəd bi mɹdʒɹɑl əbaʊt; noʊ tʃɹɑlɑk wʊɾə ɛntɝd ðɪs sɪɾi wɪθaʊt mɹdʒɹɑl tə dʒɹaɪv ɪt. noʊ mɹdʒɹɑl wʊɾə ɛntɝd wɪθaʊt sɑmaɪl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ. ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ mɛn sɑmaɪl mʌst stɪl bi hɪɹ, əɹ ðiz tʃɹɑləks wəd bi ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡeɪts, nɑt hʌntɪŋ. ən ðeɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ. ðət bɔɹz snaʊt wɑz snʌf-flɪŋ ði ɛɹ fəɹ ə sɛnt.

He turned, half-thinking to leave now. Very likely, Sammael had gone, now that Mashadar was out. Very likely the man had lured him here in the hope he would search the ruins until Mashadar killed him. He turned, and stopped, crouching against the spire. Two Trollocs were creeping down that street, bulky shapes in black mail, half again as tall as he, or more. Spikes stood out on the shoulders and elbows of their armor, and they carried spears with long black points and wicked hooks. To his saidin-filled eyes, their faces stood out clearly, one distorted by an eagle's beak where mouth and nose should have been, the other by a boar's tusked snout. Every line of their creeping shouted fear; Trollocs loved killing, loved blood, but Shadar Logoth terrified them. There would be Myrddraal about; no Trolloc would have entered this city without Myrddraal to drive it. No Myrddraal would have entered without Sammael driving. All of which meant Sammael must still be here, or these Trollocs would be running for the gates, not hunting. And they were hunting. That boar's snout was snuf-fling the air for a scent.

əbɹʌpli ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn ɹæɡz lɛp fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ əbʌv ðə tʃɹɑləks, fɔlɪŋ ɑn əm wɪð spɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi stæbɪŋ. ən il, ə wʊmən, ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd bʌt veɪl hæŋɪŋ. ði iɡəl-bik tʃɹɑlɑk ʃɹikt əz əɹ spɪɹpɔɪn stæb dip ɪndə ɪts saɪd, stæbd əɡɛn. əz ɪts kəmpænjən fɛl, kɪkɪŋ, bɔɹ-snaʊt spʌn wɪð snɑɹl, θɹʌstɪŋ vɪʃəsli, bʌt ʃi dʌk loʊ ʌndɝ ðə blæk hʊk pɔɪn ən stæbd ʌp ɪndə ðə kɹitʃɝz stʌmək, ən ɪt wɛn daʊn ɪn ə θɹæʃɪŋ hip wɪð ði ʌðɝ.

Abruptly a figure in rags leaped from a window above the Trollocs, falling on them with spear already stabbing. An Aiel, a woman, shoufa wrapped around her head but veil hanging. The eagle-beaked Trolloc shrieked as her spearpoint stabbed deep into its side, stabbed again. As its companion fell, kicking, boar-snout spun with snarl, thrusting viciously, but she ducked low under the black hooked point and stabbed up into the creature's stomach, and it went down in a thrashing heap with the other.

ɹænd wɑz ɑn ɪz fiɾ ən ɹʌnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i θɔt. "laɪæ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. hi hæd θɔɾ əɹ dɛd, əbændən hɪɹ baɪ hɪm, dɛd fəɹ hɪm. laɪæ, ʌv ðə koʊseɪɾə tʃɑɝin; ðət neɪm bleɪzd ɑn ðə lɪst ɪn ɪz hɛd.

Rand was on his feet and running before he thought. "Liah!" he shouted. He had thought her dead, abandoned here by him, dead for him. Liah, of the Cosaida Chareen; that name blazed on the list in his head.

ʃi wɝl tə kənfɹʌn hɪm, spɪɹ ɹɛɾi ɪn wʌn hænd, ɹaʊn bʊl-haɪd bʌkəlɝ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ðə feɪs i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əz pɹɪɾi dɪspaɪt skɑɹz ɑn boʊθ tʃiks wɑz kəntɔɹɾəd wɪð ɹeɪdʒ. "maɪn!" ʃi hɪs θɹɛɾənɪŋli θɹu hɝ tiθ. "maɪn! noʊ wʌn meɪ kʌm hɪɹ! noʊ wʌn!"

She whirled to confront him, spear ready in one hand, round bull-hide buckler in the other. The face he remembered as pretty despite scars on both cheeks was contorted with rage. "Mine!" she hissed threateningly through her teeth. "Mine! No one may come here! No one!"

hi stɑpt ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks. ðət spɪɹ weɪɾəd, iɡɝ tə sik ɪz ɹɪbz tu. "laɪæ, jə noʊ mi," hi sɛd sɔfli. "ju noʊ mi. əl teɪk jə bæk tə ðə meɪɾənz, bæk tə jəɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz." hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hænd.

He stopped in his tracks. That spear waited, eager to seek his ribs too. "Liah, you know me," he said softly. "You know me. I'll take you back to the Maidens, back to your spear-sisters." He held out his hand.

hɝ ɹeɪdʒ mɛltəɾ ɪndə ə twɪstəd fɹaʊn. ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd tə wʌn saɪd. "ɹæn ælθɹ?" ʃi sɛd sloʊli. hɝ aɪz waɪɾənd, fɔlɪŋ tə ðə dɛd tʃɹɑləks, ən ə lʊk ə hɔɹɝ spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs. "ɹæn ælθɹ," ʃi wɪspɝd, fʌmbəlɪŋ ðə blæk veɪl ɪndə pleɪs əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs wɪð ðə hæn ðət hɛld əɹ spɪɹ. "ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn!" ʃi weɪld. ən flɛd.

Her rage melted into a twisted frown. She tilted her head to one side. "Rand al'Thor?" she said slowly. Her eyes widened, falling to the dead Trollocs, and a look of horror spread across her face. "Rand al'Thor," she whispered, fumbling the black veil into place across her face with the hand that held her spear. "The Car'a'carn!" she wailed. And fled.

hi hɑbəld æftɝ hɝ, skɹæmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ paɪlz ə ɹʌbəl spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, fɔlɪŋ, ɹɪpɪŋ ɪz koʊt, fɔlɪŋ əɡɛn ən nɪɹli ɹɪpɪŋ ɪɾ ɔf, ɹoʊlɪŋ ən pɪkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɑn ðə ɹʌn. ðə wiknəs ə hɪz bɑɾi wɑz dɪstənt, ən ðə peɪn ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ ivən floʊɾɪŋ dip ɪn ðə vɔɪd, hi kəɾ oʊnli pʊʃ ðət bɑɾi soʊ hɑɹd. laɪæ vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə naɪt. ɝaʊn ðə nɛks blæk-ʃæɾoʊd kɔɹnɝ, hi θɔt.

He hobbled after her, scrambling over piles of rubble spread across the street, falling, ripping his coat, falling again and nearly ripping it off, rolling and picking himself up on the run. The weakness of his body was distant, and the pain of it, but even floating deep in the Void, he could only push that body so hard. Liah vanished into the night. Around the next black-shadowed corner, he thought.

hi lɪmpt ɝaʊn ðəɾ əz fæst əz i kʊd. ən nɪɹli ɹæn ɪndə fɔɹ blæk-meɪl tʃɹɑləks ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl, ɪŋki kloʊk hæŋɪŋ ənnətʃɝəli stɪl daʊn ɪts bæk əz ðə feɪd muvd. ðə tʃɹɑləks snɑɹəld ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, jɛt ʃɑk læstəd lɛs ðən ə hɑɹtbit. hʊk spɪɹz ən saɪð-kɝv sɔɹdz ɹoʊz; ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz dɛd-blæk bleɪd wɑz ɪn ɪts fɪst, ə bleɪd ðət ɡeɪv wunz ɔlmoʊst əz dɛdli əz feɪnz dæɡɝ.

He limped around that as fast as he could. And nearly ran into four black-mailed Trollocs and a Myrddraal, inky cloak hanging unnaturally still down its back as the Fade moved. The Trollocs snarled in surprise, yet shock lasted less than a heartbeat. Hooked spears and scythe-curved swords rose; the Myrddraal's dead-black blade was in its fist, a blade that gave wounds almost as deadly as Fain's dagger.

ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɹɔ ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd. dɛθ ɪn ə tæɾɝd ɹɛd koʊt, hi tʃænəld, ən ə sɔɹɾ ə faɪɝ wɑz ɪn ɪz hænz, pʌlsɪŋ dɑɹkli wɪð ðə θɹəb ə seɪɾɪn, swipɪŋ ən aɪləs hɛd fɹəm ɪts ʃoʊldɝz. sɪmpəlɝ tə hæv dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əm ɔl ðə weɪ hi hæd sin ði æʃəmən kɪl ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, bʌt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə wivz naʊ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ, maɪt teɪk ə feɪɾəl moʊmənt. ðoʊz sɔɹdz kəd kɪl ivən hɪm. hi dæns ðə fɔɹmz ɪn ə dɑɹknəs lɪt baɪ ðə fleɪm ɪn ɪz hænz, ʃædoʊz flaɪɪŋ əkɹɔs feɪsəz əbʌv hɪm, feɪsəz wɪð wʊlvz' mʌzəlz ən ɡoʊts', feɪsəz kəntɔɹɾəd ɪn skɹimz əz ɪz faɪɝi bleɪd slaɪs θɹu blæk meɪl ən ðə flɛʃ bɪniθ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɔɾɝ. tʃɹɑləks dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn nʌmbɝz ən oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ fɝɑsəɾi; feɪsɪŋ hɪm, ən ðət sɔɹɾ ə ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv stʊd stɑk-stɪl, ənɑɹmd.

Rand did not even try to draw the heron-mark sword at his side. Death in a tattered red coat, he channeled, and a sword of fire was in his hands, pulsing darkly with the throb of saidin, sweeping an eyeless head from its shoulders. Simpler to have destroyed them all the way he had seen the Asha'man kill at Dumai's Wells, but changing the weaves now, trying to change, might take a fatal moment. Those swords could kill even him. He danced the forms in a darkness lit by the flame in his hands, shadows flying across faces above him, faces with wolves' muzzles and goats', faces contorted in screams as his fiery blade sliced through black mail and the flesh beneath as if they were water. Trollocs depended on numbers and overwhelming ferocity; facing him, and that sword of the Power, they might as well have stood stock-still, unarmed.

ðə sɔɹd vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz hænz. stɪl pɔɪzd ət ði ɛn ə ðə fɔɹm kɔl twɪstɪŋ ðə wɪnd, hi stʊɾ əmʌŋ dɛθ. ðə læs tʃɹɑlɑk tə fɔl stɪl θɹæʃt, ɡoʊt hɔɹnz skɹeɪpɪŋ ɑn ðə fɹæɡməntɪd peɪvmənt. ðə hɛdləs mɹdʒɹɑl jɛt flʌŋ ɪts ɑɹmz əbaʊt, ʌv kɔɹs, buɾɪd fit skɹæbəlɪŋ waɪldli; hæfmən dɪd nɑt daɪ kwɪkli, ivən hɛdləs.

The sword vanished from his hands. Still poised at the end of the form called Twisting the Wind, he stood among death. The last Trolloc to fall still thrashed, goat horns scraping on the fragmented pavement. The headless Myrddraal yet flung its arms about, of course, booted feet scrabbling wildly; Halfmen did not die quickly, even headless.

noʊ sunɝ dɪd ðə sɔɹd dɪsəpɪɹ ðən sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ læns daʊn fɹəm ðə klaʊdləs, stɑɹi skaɪ.

No sooner did the sword disappear than silver lightning lanced down from the cloudless, starry sky.

ðə fɝs boʊl stʃɹʌk wɪð ə dɛfənɪŋ ɹɔɹ nɑt fɔɹ peɪsɪz əweɪ. ðə wɝl tɝnd waɪt, ən ðə vɔɪd kəlæpst. ðə ɡɹaʊn baʊnst ʌndɝ ɪm əz ənʌðɝ boʊl stʃɹʌk, ən ənʌðɝ. hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd i wɑz ɑn ɪz feɪs əntɪl ðɛn. ði ɛɹ kɹækəld. deɪzd, hi pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp, hæf fɔlɪŋ əz i ɹæn fɹəm ə heɪl ə laɪtnɪŋ ðət ɹɪp ðə stʃɹiɾ əpɑɹt tə ə θʌndɝ ə kəlæpsɪŋ bɪldɪŋz. stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ i stæɡɝd, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wɛɹ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz əweɪ.

The first bolt struck with a deafening roar not four paces away. The world turned white, and the Void collapsed. The ground bounced under him as another bolt struck, and another. He had not realized he was on his face until then. The air crackled. Dazed, he pushed himself up, half falling as he ran from a hail of lightning that ripped the street apart to a thunder of collapsing buildings. Straight ahead he staggered, not caring where, so long as it was away.

sʌɾənli hɪz hɛd klɪɹɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə si wɛɹ i wɑz, ɹilɪŋ əkɹɔs ə væst stoʊn flɔɹ kʌvɝd wɪð tʌmbəl tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn, səm əz bɪɡ əz hi. hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, dɑɹk ənivən hoʊlz ɡeɪpt ɪn ðə flɔɹstoʊnz. ɔl ɝaʊn ɹoʊz haɪ wɔlz, ən tiɹ əpɑn tiɹ ə dip bælkəniz ðət ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd. oʊnli ə smɔl pɔɹʃən ʌv wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ə væst ɹuf ɹɪmeɪnd, ət wʌn kɔɹnɝ. stɑɹz ʃoʊn bɹaɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd.

Suddenly his head cleared enough for him to see where he was, reeling across a vast stone floor covered with tumbled chunks of stone, some as big as he. Here and there, dark uneven holes gaped in the floorstones. All around rose high walls, and tier upon tier of deep balconies that ran all the way around. Only a small portion of what had once been a vast roof remained, at one corner. Stars shone bright overhead.

hi lɝtʃt ənʌðɝ stɛp, ən ðə flɔɹ ɡeɪv weɪ bɪniθ hɪm. dɛspɝətli hi flʌŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænz; wɪð ə dʒoʊlt, ðə ɹaɪt hæn kɑt hoʊld ʌv ə ɹʌf ɛdʒ. hi dæŋɡəld ɪndə pɪtʃ blæknəs. ðə fɔl bɪniθ ɪz buts maɪt bi ə fju spænz ɪndə ə beɪsmənt, əɹ ə maɪl fəɹ ɔl i kəd tɛl. hi kəd lætʃ bænz ʌv ɛɹ tə ðə dʒæɡd ɹɪm ə ðə hoʊl əbʌv ɪz hɛd tə hɛlp pʊl hɪmsɛlf aʊt, ɪksɛpt. . . . sʌmhaʊ, sɑmaɪl hæd sɛns ðə ɹɛləɾɪvli smɔl əmaʊn ə seɪɾɪn juzd ɪn ðə sɔɹd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə dɪleɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪtnɪŋz stʃɹʌk, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt seɪ haʊ lɔŋ i hæd teɪkən kɪlɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks. ə mɪnət? sɛkənz?

He lurched another step, and the floor gave way beneath him. Desperately he flung out his hands; with a jolt, the right hand caught hold of a rough edge. He dangled into pitch blackness. The fall beneath his boots might be a few spans into a basement, or a mile for all he could tell. He could latch bands of Air to the jagged rim of the hole above his head to help pull himself out, except. . . . Somehow, Sammael had sensed the relatively small amount of saidin used in the sword. There had been a delay before the lightnings struck, but he could not say how long he had taken killing the Trollocs. A minute? Seconds?

wɪð ə hiv, hi swʌŋ ɪz lɛft ɑɹm ʌp, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə hoʊl. peɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bʌfɝd baɪ ðə vɔɪd stæb θɹu hɪz saɪd laɪk ə dæɡɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn. spɑts dænst ɪn ɪz vɪʒən. wɝs, hɪz ɹaɪt hæn slɪpt ɑn kɹʌmbəlɪŋ stoʊn, ən i kəd fil ɪz fɪŋɡɝz wikənɪŋ. hi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə. . . .

With a heave, he swung his left arm up, trying to catch the edge of the hole. Pain no longer buffered by the Void stabbed through his side like a dagger going in. Spots danced in his vision.
