Worse, his right hand slipped on crumbling stone, and he could feel his fingers weakening. He was going to have to. . . .

ə hænd ɡɹæbd ɪz ɹaɪt ɹɪst. "ju ɑɹ ə ful," ə mænz dip vɔɪs sɛd. "kaʊn jɝsɛlf lʌki aɪ doʊn kɛɹ tə si jə daɪ tədeɪ." ðə hæn bɪɡæn dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪm ʌp. "ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɛlp?" ðə vɔɪs dɪmændəd. "aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə kæɹi jə ɑn maɪ ʃoʊldɝz, əɹ kɪl sɑmaɪl fəɹ ju."

A hand grabbed his right wrist. "You are a fool," a man's deep voice said. "Count yourself lucky I don't care to see you die today." The hand began drawing him up. "Are you going to help?" the voice demanded. "I don't intend to carry you on my shoulders, or kill Sammael for you."

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz ʃɑk, ɹænd ɹitʃt ʌp ən ɡɹæb ðə ɹɪm ə ðə hoʊl, pʊlɪŋ dɪspaɪt ði æɡəni ʌv ɪz saɪd. dɪspaɪt ði æɡəni, hi mænədʒ tə əkwaɪɝ ðə vɔɪɾ əɡɛn, tu, ən siz seɪɾɪn. hi dɪd nɑt tʃænəl, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə bi ɹɛɾi.

Shaking off his shock, Rand reached up and grabbed the rim of the hole, pulling despite the agony of his side. Despite the agony, he managed to acquire the Void again, too, and seize saidin. He did not channel, but he wanted to be ready.

hɪz hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz keɪm əbʌv ðə flɔɹ, ən i kəd si ði ʌðɝ mæn, ə bɪɡ fɛloʊ lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən hi, wɪð hɛɹ blæk əz ðə naɪɾ ən ə koʊt blæk əz ən æʃəmənz. ɹænd hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ. ət list i wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən; ðoʊz feɪsəz i nu. hi θɔɾ i dɪd, ɛniweɪ. "hu ɑɹ ju?" hi dɪmændəd.

His head and shoulders came above the floor, and he could see the other man, a big fellow little older than he, with hair black as the night and a coat black as an Asha'man's. Rand had never seen him before. At least he was not one of the Forsaken; those faces he knew. He thought he did, anyway. "Who are you?" he demanded.

stɪl hivɪŋ, ðə mæn bɑɹkt ə læf. "dʒʌst seɪ ɪm ə wɑndɝɝ pæsɪŋ θɹu. dʒju ɹɪli wɑnə tɔk naʊ?"

Still heaving, the man barked a laugh. "Just say I'm a wanderer passing through. Do you really want to talk now?"

seɪvɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ, ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəld ʌpwɝd, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz tʃɛst oʊvɝ ðə lɪp, hɪz weɪst. əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ə ɡloʊ beɪðd ðə flɔɹ ɝaʊn əm laɪk ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ə fʊl mun.

Saving his breath, Rand struggled upward, getting his chest over the lip, his waist. Abruptly he realized that a glow bathed the floor around them like the glow of a full moon.

twɪstɪŋ tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hi sɔ mɑʃəɾɝ. nɑɾ ə tɛnʒɹɪl, bʌɾ ə ʃaɪnɪŋ sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ weɪv ɹoʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə bælkəniz, ɑɹtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz. dɪsɛndɪŋ.

Twisting to look over his shoulder, he saw Mashadar. Not a tendril, but a shining silver-gray wave rolling out of one of the balconies, arching over their heads. Descending.

wɪθaʊɾ ə θɔt, hɪz fɹi hæn ɹoʊz, ən bɑlfaɪɝ ʃɑɾ ʌpwɝd, ə bɑɹ ə lɪkwəd waɪt faɪɝ slaɪsɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə weɪv sɪŋkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm. dɪmli hi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ bɑɹ ə peɪl sɑləd faɪɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ mænz hæn ðət wɑz nɑt klæspɪŋ hɪz, ə bɑɹ slæʃɪŋ ði ɑpəzət weɪ fɹəm hɪz. ðə tu tʌtʃt.

Without a thought, his free hand rose, and balefire shot upward, a bar of liquid white fire slicing across the wave sinking toward them. Dimly he was aware of another bar of pale solid fire rising from the other man's hand that was not clasping his, a bar slashing the opposite way from his. The two touched.

hɛd ɹɪŋɪŋ laɪk ə stʃɹʌk ɡɔŋ, ɹænd kənvʌlsd, seɪɾɪn ən ðə vɔɪd ʃæɾɝɪŋ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz dʌbəld ɪn ɪz aɪz, ðə bælkəniz, ðə tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn laɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðə flɔɹ. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə pɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ mæn oʊvɝlæpɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, itʃ klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd bɪtwin tu hænz. blɪŋkɪŋ, ɹænd sɝtʃt fəɹ mɑʃəɾɝ. ðə weɪv ə ʃaɪnɪŋ mɪst wɑz ɡɔn; ə ɡloʊ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə bælkəniz əbʌv, bʌt dɪmɪŋ, ɹɪsiɾɪŋ, əz ɹændz aɪz bɪɡæn tə klɪɹ. ivən maɪnləs mɑʃəɾɝ flɛd bɑlfaɪɝ, ɪt simd.

Head ringing like a struck gong, Rand convulsed, saidin and the Void shattering. Everything was doubled in his eyes, the balconies, the chunks of stone lying about the floor. There seemed to be a pair of the other man overlapping one another, each clutching his head between two hands. Blinking, Rand searched for Mashadar. The wave of shining mist was gone; a glow remained in the balconies above, but dimming, receding, as Rand's eyes began to clear. Even mindless Mashadar fled balefire, it seemed.

ənstɛɾəli, hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fiɾ ən ɔfɝɾ ə hænd. "aɪ θɪŋk wi bɛs muv kwɪkli. wʌt hæpən ðɛɹ?"

Unsteadily, he got to his feet and offered a hand. "I think we best move quickly. What happened there?"

ði ʌðɝ mæn pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs ət ɹændz pɹɑfɝd hænd. hi wɑz izəli əz tɔl əz ɹænd, ɹɛɹ ɪksɛpt əmʌŋ ði il. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæpənd," hi snɑɹəld. "ɹʌn, ɪf jə wɑnə lɪv." hi suɾəd ɪz oʊn wɝdz ɪmiɾiətli, dæʃɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə ɹoʊ ʌv oʊpən ɑɹtʃəz. nɑɾ ɪn ðə nɪɹəst wɔl. mɑʃəɾɝ hæd kʌm fɹəm ðət wʌn.

The other man pushed himself up with a grimace at Rand's proffered hand. He was easily as tall as Rand, rare except among the Aiel. "I don't know what happened," he snarled. "Run, if you want to live." He suited his own words immediately, dashing toward a row of open arches. Not in the nearest wall. Mashadar had come from that one.

fʌmbəlɪŋ fəɹ ðə vɔɪd, ɹænd lɪmpt æftɝ ɪm əz fæst əz i kʊd, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ kəmplitli əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ, ðə laɪtnɪŋz fɛl əɡɛn, ə stɔɹm ə sɪlvɝ æɹoʊz. ðə tu ʌv əm dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ði ɑɹtʃweɪz pɝsud baɪ ðə θʌndɝ ʌv wɔlz ən flɔɹ kəlæpsɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, baɪ klaʊdz ə dʌst ən ə heɪl ə stoʊnz. ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt ən ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs, ɹænd ɹæn kɑfɪŋ θɹu ə bɹɔd ɹum wɛɹ tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ɑɹtʃəz səpɔɹɾəd ðə silɪŋ ən bɪts ə stoʊn ɹeɪn daʊn.

Fumbling for the Void, Rand limped after him as fast as he could, but before they were completely across the floor, the lightnings fell again, a storm of silver arrows. The two of them darted through the archways pursued by the thunder of walls and floor collapsing behind them, by clouds of dust and a hail of stones. Shoulders hunched and an arm across his face, Rand ran coughing through a broad room where trembling arches supported the ceiling and bits of stone rained down.

hi bɝst aʊɾ ɪndə ə stʃɹit bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt, stʌmbəlɪŋ θɹi stɛps bɪfɔɹ stɑpɪŋ. ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz saɪd meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə bɛn oʊvɝ, bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪz lɛɡz maɪt ɡɪv weɪ ɪf i dɪd. hɪz wundəd fʊt θɹɑbd; ɪt simd ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ ðət ðət ɹɛd waɪɝ ə faɪɝ ən ɛɹ hæd stæbd ɪz hil. hɪz ɹɛskjuɝ stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm; kʌvɝd wɪð dʌs hɛd tə toʊ, ðə fɛloʊ mænədʒ tə lʊk ə kɪŋ.

He burst out into a street before he knew it, stumbling three steps before stopping. The pain in his side made him want to bend over, but he thought his legs might give way if he did. His wounded foot throbbed; it seemed a year ago that that red wire of Fire and Air had stabbed his heel. His rescuer stood watching him; covered with dust head to toe, the fellow managed to look a king.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" ɹænd æskt əɡɛn. "wʌn ə teɪmz mɛn? əɹ dɪd jə titʃ jɝsɛlf? jə kən ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn, jə noʊ, tə ðə blæk taʊɝ. jə doʊn əv tə lɪv əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ." fəɹ səm ɹizən, seɪɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm fɹaʊn; hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ.

"Who are you?" Rand asked again. "One of Taim's men? Or did you teach yourself? You can go to Caemlyn, you know, to the Black Tower. You don't have to live afraid of Aes Sedai." For some reason, saying that made him frown; he could not understand why.

"aɪ hæv nɛvɝ bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə mæn snæpt, ðən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "ju pɹɑbli ʃəd liv hɪɹ naʊ, bʌɾ ɪf jə ɪntɛn tə steɪ ən kɪl sɑmaɪl, jə hæd bɛɾɝ tʃɹaɪ θɪŋkɪŋ laɪk hɪm. juv ʃoʊn jə kæn. hi ɔlweɪz laɪk dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ə mæn ɪn saɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðət mænz tʃɹaɪəmfs, ɪf i kʊd. lækɪŋ ðæt, sʌmwɛɹ ðə mæn hæd mɑɹkt əz ɪz wəd du."

"I have never been afraid of Aes Sedai," the man snapped, then drew a deep breath. "You probably should leave here now, but if you intend to stay and kill Sammael, you had better try thinking like him. You have shown you can. He always liked destroying a man in sight of one of that man's triumphs, if he could. Lacking that, somewhere the man had marked as his would do."

"ðə weɪɡeɪt," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. ɪf i kəd bi sɛd tə hæv mɑɹkt ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ɪt hæd tə bi ðə weɪɡeɪt. "hiz weɪɾɪŋ nɪɹ ðə weɪɡeɪt. ən hiz tʃɹæps sɛt." wɔɹdz əz wɛl, ɪt simd, laɪk ðoʊz ɪn ɪljən, tə dɪtɛkt ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ. sɑmaɪl hæd plæn ðɪs wɛl.

"The Waygate," Rand said slowly. If he could be said to have marked anything in Shadar Logoth, it had to be the Waygate. "He's waiting near the Waygate. And he has traps set." Wards as well, it seemed, like those in Illian, to detect a man channeling. Sammael had planned this well.

ðə mæn læft ɹaɪli. "ju kən faɪn ðə weɪ, ɪt simz. ɪf jəɹ lɛd baɪ ðə hænd. tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə stʌmbəl. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni plænz wɪl əv tə bi ɹɪleɪɾ ɪf jə lɛt jɝsɛlf bi kɪl naʊ." tɝnɪŋ, hi stɑɹɾəd əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit fəɹ ən æliweɪ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə ðɛm.

The man laughed wryly. "You can find the way, it seems. If you're led by the hand. Try not to stumble. A great many plans will have to be relaid if you let yourself be killed now." Turning, he started across the street for an alleyway just ahead of them.

"weɪt," ɹænd kɔld. ðə fɛloʊ kɛpt ɑn, nɑt lʊkɪŋ bæk. "hu ɑɹ ju? wʌt plænz?" ðə mæn vænɪʃt ɪndə ði æli.

"Wait," Rand called. The fellow kept on, not looking back. "Who are you? What plans?" The man vanished into the alley.

ɹænd tiɾɝd æftɝ hɪm, bʌt wən i ɹitʃt ðə maʊθ ə ðə nɛɹoʊ æli, ɪt wɑz ɛmpti. ənbɹoʊkən wɔlz ɹæn ə ɡʊd hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz tə ənʌðɝ stʃɹit, wɛɹ ə ɡloʊ toʊld ə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə mɑʃəɾɝ əbɹɔd, bʌt ðə mæn wɑz ɡɔn. wɪtʃ wɑz pjʊɹli ɪmpɑsəbəl. ðə fɛloʊ hæd hæd taɪm tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf i nu haʊ, bʌt ðə ɹɛzədu wʊɾə bɪn vɪzəbəl, ən bɪsaɪdz, ðət mʌtʃ ə seɪɾɪn biɪŋ woʊvən soʊ nɪɹ wʊɾə ʃaʊɾəd ət hɪm.

Rand teetered after him, but when he reached the mouth of the narrow alley, it was empty. Unbroken walls ran a good hundred paces to another street, where a glow told of yet another part of Mashadar abroad, but the man was gone. Which was purely impossible. The fellow had had time to make a gateway, of course, if he knew how, but the residue would have been visible, and besides, that much of saidin being woven so near would have shouted at him.

sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd nɑt fɛl seɪɾɪn wən ðə mæn meɪd bɑlfaɪɝ, iðɝ. dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðæt, ʌv ðə tu stʃɹimz tʌtʃɪŋ, meɪɾ ɪz vɪʒən dʌbəl əɡɛn. dʒʌs fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hi kəd si ðə mænz feɪs əɡɛn, ʃɑɹp wɛɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls blɝd. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əntɪl ɪt klɪɹd. "hu ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ ju?" hi wɪspɝd. ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt, "wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɑɹ ju?"

Suddenly he realized that he had not felt saidin when the man made balefire, either. Just thinking of that, of the two streams touching, made his vision double again. Just for an instant, he could see the man's face again, sharp where everything else blurred. He shook his head until it cleared. "Who in the Light are you?" he whispered. And after a moment, "What in the Light are you?"

huɛvɝ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ, ðə mæn wɑz ɡɔn, ðoʊ. sɑmaɪl wɑz stɪl ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i mænədʒ tə ɹɪɡeɪn ðə vɔɪd wʌns mɔɹ. ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd naʊ, hʌmɪŋ ɪts weɪ dip ɪndə hɪm; ðə vɔɪɾ ɪtsɛlf vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd. bʌt ðə wiknəs ʌv wɔɾɝi mʌsəlz ən ðə peɪn ʌv ɪnʒɝiz feɪɾəd. hi wɑz gɑnə kɪl wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən bɪfɔɹ ðɪs naɪt wɑz dʌn.

Whoever or whatever, the man was gone, though. Sammael was still in Shadar Logoth. With an effort he managed to regain the Void once more. The taint on saidin vibrated now, humming its way deep into him; the Void itself vibrated. But the weakness of watery muscles and the pain of injuries faded. He was going to kill one of the Forsaken before this night was done.

lɪmpɪŋ, hi ɡɑstɪd θɹu ðə dɑɹk stʃɹits, pleɪsɪŋ ɪz fit wɪð ɡɹeɪt kɛɹ. hi stɪl meɪd nɔɪz, bʌt ðə naɪt wɑz fʊl ə nɔɪz naʊ. ʃɹiks ən ɡʌɾɝəl kɹaɪz saʊndəɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. maɪnləs mɑʃəɾɝ kɪld wʌtɛvɝ ɪt faʊnd, ən tʃɹɑləks wɝ daɪɪŋ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ tənaɪɾ əz ðeɪ hæd wʌns lɔŋ, lɔŋ əɡoʊ. səmtaɪmz daʊn ə kɹɔsɪŋ stʃɹiɾ i sɔ tʃɹɑləks, tu əɹ faɪv əɹ ə dʌzən, əkeɪʒənəli wɪð ə hæfmən bʌt moʊst ɔfən nɑt. nʌn sɔ hɪm, ən i dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ ðɛm. nɑt sɪmpli kəz sɑmaɪl wəd dɪtɛkt ɛni tʃænəlɪŋ. ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl ðət mɑʃəɾɝ dɪd nɑt kɪl wɝ stɪl dɛd. sɑmaɪl hæɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli bɹɔɾ əm baɪ ðə weɪz, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli hi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz dʒʌs haʊ ɹænd hæd mɑɹk ðə weɪɡeɪt hɪɹ.

Limping, he ghosted through the dark streets, placing his feet with great care. He still made noise, but the night was full of noise now. Shrieks and guttural cries sounded in the distance. Mindless Mashadar killed whatever it found, and Trollocs were dying in Shadar Logoth tonight as they had once long, long ago. Sometimes down a crossing street he saw Trollocs, two or five or a dozen, occasionally with a Halfman but most often not. None saw him, and he did not bother them. Not simply because Sammael would detect any channeling. Those Trollocs and Myrddraal that Mashadar did not kill were still dead. Sammael had almost certainly brought them by the Ways, but apparently he did not realize just how Rand had marked the Waygate here.

wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə skwɛɹ wɛɹ ðə weɪɡeɪt leɪ, ɹænd stɑpt ən lʊkt ɝaʊnd. nɪɹbaɪ, ə taʊɝ stʊd simɪŋli hoʊl. nɑt nɪɹli əz tɔl əz sʌm, ɪts tɑp stɪl ɹoʊz mɔɹ ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə dɑɹk dɔɹweɪ əɾ ɪts beɪs wɑz ɛmpti, ðə wʊd lɔŋ ɹɑɾɪd əweɪ ən ðə hɪnʒɪz ɡɔn tə dʌst. θɹu blæknəs ɹɪlivd oʊnli baɪ feɪn stɑɹlaɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz, hi klaɪm ðə waɪndɪŋ stɛɹz sloʊli, smɔl klaʊdz pʌfɪŋ ʌp bɪniθ ɪz buts, ɛvɹi sɛkən stɛp ə stæb ə peɪn ʌp ɪz lɛɡ. dɪstən peɪn. ɑn ðə taʊɝtɑp, hi lin əɡɛns ðə smuð pɛɹəpət tə kætʃ ɪz bɹɛθ. ði aɪɾəl θɔt keɪm ðəɾ i wəd nɛvɝ hɪɹ ði ɛn ɪf mɪn lɝn ə ðɪs. mɪn, əɹ æmɪz, əɹ kædzueɪn fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Well short of the square where the Waygate lay, Rand stopped and looked around. Nearby, a tower stood seemingly whole. Not nearly as tall as some, its top still rose more than fifty paces above the ground. The dark doorway at its base was empty, the wood long rotted away and the hinges gone to dust. Through blackness relieved only by faint starlight through the windows, he climbed the winding stairs slowly, small clouds puffing up beneath his boots, every second step a stab of pain up his leg. Distant pain. On the towertop, he leaned against the smooth parapet to catch his breath. The idle thought came that he would never hear the end if Min learned of this. Min, or Amys, or Cadsuane for that matter.

əkɹɔs mɪsɪŋ ɹuftɑps, hi kəd si ðə ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ ðət hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn ɑɹɪdhɔl. wʌns ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv hæd kʌvɝd ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə lænd, bʌt wɪðɪn θɝɾi jɪɹz æftɝ ði oʊɡiɝ u hæd bɪl ði oʊldəs pɑɹts ə ðə sɪɾi dɪpɑɹɾəd, ðə ɹɛzəɾənts hæd kʌt daʊn ðə tʃɹiz tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ ɪkspændɪŋ ɑɹɪdhɔl. pæləsəz ən ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə pæləsəz sɝaʊndəd ðə hjudʒ skwɛɹ, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv mɑʃəɾɝ ʃaɪnɪŋ dip ɪnsaɪɾ ə fju wɪndoʊz, ən ə hjudʒ maʊn ə ɹʌbəl kʌvɝd wʌn ɛnd, bʌɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ stʊd ðə weɪɡeɪt, əpɛɹənli ə tɔl bɹɔd pis ə stoʊn. hi wɑz nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ðə dɛləkətli kɑɹv livz ən vaɪnz ðət kʌvɝɾ ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd meɪk aʊt ðə tɑpəl pisəz ə haɪ fɛns ðət hæd wʌns sɝaʊndəɾ ɪt. paʊɝ-ɹɔt mɛɾəl laɪɪŋ ɪn ə hip, ðeɪ ɡlimd əntɑɹnɪʃt ɪn ðə naɪt. hi kəɾ ɔlsoʊ si ðə tʃɹæp i hæd woʊvən ɝaʊn ðə weɪɡeɪt, ɪnvɝɾɪd soʊ noʊ aɪ bʌɾ ɪz kəd si ɪt. noʊ weɪ tə tɛl baɪ lʊkɪŋ wɛðɝ ðə tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən ɹɪli hæd pæs θɹu ɪt, jɛɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd, ðeɪ wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ. ə næsti θɪŋ. wʌtɛvɝ tʃɹæps sɑmaɪl hæd meɪd daʊn ðəɹ wɝ ɪnvɪzəbəl tə hɪm, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪkspɛktəd. laɪkli ðeɪ wɝ nɑt vɛɹi plɛzən iðɝ.

Across missing rooftops, he could see the great square that had been one of the most important in Aridhol. Once an Ogier grove had covered this part of the land, but within thirty years after the Ogier who had built the oldest parts of the city departed, the residents had cut down the trees to make room for expanding Aridhol. Palaces and the remains of palaces surrounded the huge square, the glow of Mashadar shining deep inside a few windows, and a huge mound of rubble covered one end, but in the center stood the Waygate, apparently a tall broad piece of stone. He was not close enough to see the delicately carved leaves and vines that covered it, but he could make out the toppled pieces of high fence that had once surrounded it. Power-wrought metal lying in a heap, they gleamed untarnished in the night. He could also see the trap he had woven around the Waygate, inverted so no eye but his could see it. No way to tell by looking whether the Trollocs and Halfmen really had passed through it, yet if they had, they would die before long. A nasty thing. Whatever traps Sammael had made down there were invisible to him, but that was expected. Likely they were not very pleasant either.

ət fɝst, hi kəd nɑt si sɑmaɪl, bʌt ðən sʌmwʌn muvd əmʌŋ ðə fluɾəd, flɛɹɪŋ kɑləmz ʌv ə pæləs. ɹænd weɪɾəd. hi wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ; hi hæɾ oʊnli wʌn tʃæns. ðə fɪɡjɝ stɛp fɔɹwɝd, aʊɾ ə ðə kɑləmz ən ə peɪs ɪndə ðə skwɛɹ, hɛd swɪŋɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. sɑmaɪl, wɪð snoʊi leɪs ʃaɪnɪŋ əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, weɪɾɪŋ tə si ɹænd wɔk ɪndə ðə skwɛɹ, ɪndə ðə tʃɹæps. bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə ɡloʊ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz ə ðə pæləs bɹaɪɾənd. sɑmaɪl pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs laɪɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ, ən mɑʃəɾɝ uzd aʊɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊz, θɪk bɪloʊz ə sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ fɑɡ slaɪɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, mɝdʒɪŋ əz ðeɪ lumd əbʌv ɪz hɛd. sɑmaɪl wɔkt ə lɪɾəl tə wʌn saɪd, ən ðə weɪv bɪɡæn tə dɪsɛnd, sloʊli pɪkɪŋ ʌp spiɾ əz ɪt fɛl.

At first, he could not see Sammael, but then someone moved among the fluted, flaring columns of a palace. Rand waited. He wanted to be sure; he had only one chance. The figure stepped forward, out of the columns and a pace into the square, head swinging this way and that. Sammael, with snowy lace shining at his throat, waiting to see Rand walk into the square, into the traps. Behind him, the glow in the windows of the palace brightened. Sammael peered into the darkness lying across the square, and Mashadar oozed out of the windows, thick billows of silver-gray fog sliding together, merging as they loomed above his head. Sammael walked a little to one side, and the wave began to descend, slowly picking up speed as it fell.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. sɑmaɪl wɑz hɪz. ðə floʊz niɾəd fəɹ bɑlfaɪɝ sim tə ɡæðɝ ðɛmsɛlvz, dɪspaɪt ðə fɑɹ ɛkoʊ ʌv kædzueɪnz vɔɪs. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd.

Rand shook his head. Sammael was his. The flows needed for balefire seemed to gather themselves, despite the far echo of Cadsuane's voice. He raised his hand.

ə skɹim tɔɹ ðə dɑɹknəs, ə wʊmən ʃɹikɪŋ ɪn æɡəni bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ. ɹænd sɔ sɑmaɪl tɝn tə stɛɹ təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪt maʊn ə ɹʌbəl ivən əz ɪz oʊn aɪz flæʃt ðət weɪ. ətɑp ðə maʊn ə ʃeɪp stʊɾ aʊtlaɪn əɡɛns ðə naɪt skaɪ ɪn koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz, ə sɪŋɡəl θɪn tɛnʒɹɪl ə mɑʃəɾɝ tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ lɛɡ. ɑɹmz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt, ʃi θɹæʃt əbaʊt, əneɪbəl tə muv fɹəm ðə spɑt, ən əɹ wɝdləs weɪl sim tə kɔl ɹændz neɪm.

A scream tore the darkness, a woman shrieking in agony beyond knowing. Rand saw Sammael turn to stare toward the great mound of rubble even as his own eyes flashed that way. Atop the mound a shape stood outlined against the night sky in coat and breeches, a single thin tendril of Mashadar touching her leg. Arms outstretched, she thrashed about, unable to move from the spot, and her wordless wail seemed to call Rand's name.

"laɪæ," hi wɪspɝd. ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi ɹitʃt aʊt, əz ðoʊ hi kəd stʃɹɛtʃ ɪz ɑɹm əkɹɔs ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ dɪstəns ən pʊl əɹ əweɪ. nʌθɪŋ kəd seɪv wʌt mɑʃəɾɝ tʌtʃt, ðoʊ, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ cʊɾə seɪvd ɪm hæd feɪnz dæɡɝ plʌnʒd ɪndə hɪz hɑɹt. "laɪæ," hi wɪspɝd. ən bɑlfaɪɝ lɛp fɹəm ɪz hænd.

"Liah," he whispered. Unconsciously he reached out, as though he could stretch his arm across the intervening distance and pull her away. Nothing could save what Mashadar touched, though, no more than anything could have saved him had Fain's dagger plunged into his heart. "Liah," he whispered. And balefire leaped from his hand.

fəɹ lɛs ðən ə hɑɹtbit, ðə ʃeɪp ə hɝ stɪl sim tə bi ðɛɹ, ɔl ɪn stɑɹk blæks ən snoʊi waɪts, ən ðən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, dɛd bɪfɔɹ əɹ æɡəni bɪɡæn.

For less than a heartbeat, the shape of her still seemed to be there, all in stark blacks and snowy whites, and then she was gone, dead before her agony began.

skɹimɪŋ, ɹænd swɛp ðə bɑlfaɪɝ daʊn təwɔɹd ðə skwɛɹ, ðə ɹʌbəl kəlæpsɪŋ ɑn ɪtsɛlf, swɛp daʊn dɛθ aʊɾ ə taɪm - ən lɛt seɪɾɪn ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɑɹ ʌv waɪt tʌtʃt ðə leɪk ə mɑʃəɾɝ ðət naʊ ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ, bɪloʊɪŋ pæs ðə weɪɡeɪt təwɔɹd ɹɪvɝz ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ ɡɹeɪ ðət floʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ənʌðɝ pæləs ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. sɑmaɪl hæd tə bi dɛd. hi hæd tə bi. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə ɹʌn, noʊ taɪm tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ɪf i hæd, ɹænd wʊɾə fɛl seɪɾɪn biɪŋ wɝkt. sɑmaɪl wɑz dɛd, kɪl baɪ ən ivəl ɔlmoʊst əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz hɪmsɛlf. ɪmoʊʃən ɹeɪst əkɹɔs ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə vɔɪd; ɹænd wɑntəd tə læf, əɹ pɝhæps kɹaɪ. hi hæd kʌm hɪɹ tə kɪl wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i hæd kɪld ə wʊmən i hæɾ əbændən hɪɹ tə hɝ feɪt.

Screaming, Rand swept the balefire down toward the square, the rubble collapsing on itself, swept down death out of time - and let saidin go before the bar of white touched the lake of Mashadar that now rolled across the square, billowing past the Waygate toward rivers of glowing gray that flowed out from another palace on the other side. Sammael had to be dead. He had to be. There had not been time for him to run, no time to weave a gateway, and if he had, Rand would have felt saidin being worked. Sammael was dead, killed by an evil almost as great as himself. Emotion raced across the outside of the Void; Rand wanted to laugh, or perhaps cry. He had come here to kill one of the Forsaken, but instead he had killed a woman he had abandoned here to her fate.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm i stʊɾ ɑn ðə taʊɝtɑp waɪl ðə weɪnɪŋ mun kɹɔs ðə skaɪ, ɔlmoʊst əɾ ɪts hæf, stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ mɑʃəɾɝ fɪl ðə skwɛɹ kəmplitli, tɪl oʊnli ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə weɪɡeɪt ɹoʊz əbʌv ðə sɝfəs ə ðə fɑɡ. sloʊli ɪt bɪɡæn tə ɛb əweɪ, hʌntɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ. ɪf sɑmaɪl hæd bɪn əlaɪv, hi cʊɾə kɪl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn izəli ðɛn. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðəɾ i wəɾ əv kɛɹd. faɪnəli hi oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ skɪmɪŋ ən meɪɾ ə plætfɔɹm, ə ɹeɪləs dɪsk, hæf waɪɾ ən hæf blæk. skɪmɪŋ wɑz sloʊɝ ðən tʃɹævlɪŋ; ɪt tʊk ɪm ət lis hæf ən aʊɝ tə ɹitʃ ɪljən, ən ðə hoʊl weɪ, hi bɝn laɪæz neɪm ɪndə hɪz maɪn əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, fleɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪt. hi wɪʃt i kəd kɹaɪ. hi θɔɾ i hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ.

For a long time he stood on the towertop while the waning moon crossed the sky, almost at its half, stood watching Mashadar fill the square completely, till only the very top of the Waygate rose above the surface of the fog. Slowly it began to ebb away, hunting elsewhere. If Sammael had been alive, he could have killed the Dragon Reborn easily then. Rand was not sure that he would have cared. Finally he opened a gateway for Skimming and made a platform, a railless disc, half white and half black. Skimming was slower than Traveling; it took him at least half an hour to reach Illian, and the whole way, he burned Liah's name into his mind again and again, flailing himself with it. He wished he could cry. He thought he had forgotten how.

ðeɪ wɝ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ɪn ðə kɪŋz pæləs, ɪn ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. bæʃɪɹ, ən dæʃivə ən ði æʃəmən. ɪt wɑz ɪɡzækli laɪk ðə ɹum i hæd sin ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə skwɛɹ, daʊn tə ðə stænd-læmps ən ðə sinz kɑɹvd ɪndə ðə mɑɹbəl wɔlz ən ðə lɔŋ waɪt deɪz. ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm ɪksɛp fəɹ biɪŋ slaɪtli lɑɹdʒɝ ɪn ɛvɹi dɪmɛnʃən, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə naɪn tʃɛɹz ɑn ðə deɪz, ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɪldɪd θɹoʊn wɪð lɛpɝdz fəɹ ɪts ɑɹmz ən naɪn fɪst-saɪzd ɡoʊldən biz ðət wəd stæn əbʌv ðə hɛɾ ə huɛvɝ sæɾ ɪn ɪt. wɛɹəli ɹænd sæt hɪmsɛlf daʊn ɑn ðə stɛps ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə deɪz.

They were waiting for him in the King's Palace, in the throne room. Bashere, and Dashiva and the Asha'man. It was exactly like the room he had seen at the other end of the square, down to the stand-lamps and the scenes carved into the marble walls and the long white dais. Exactly the same except for being slightly larger in every dimension, and instead of nine chairs on the dais, there was only a great gilded throne with leopards for its arms and nine fist-sized golden bees that would stand above the head of whoever sat in it. Wearily Rand sat himself down on the steps at the front of the dais.

"aɪ teɪk ɪt sɑmaɪl ɪz dɛd," bæʃɪɹ sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ɪm ʌp ən daʊn ɪn ɪz ɹæɡəd koʊɾ ən dʌst.

"I take it Sammael is dead," Bashere said, looking him up and down in his ragged coat and dust.

"hiz dɛd," ɹænd sɛd. dæʃivə saɪd laʊdli wɪð ɹɪlif.

"He's dead," Rand said. Dashiva sighed loudly with relief.

"ðə sɪɾi ɪz aʊɝz," bæʃɪɹ wɛn ɑn. "ɔɹ aɪ ʃəd seɪ, jʊɹz." hi læf sʌɾənli. "ðə faɪɾɪŋ stɑp kwɪk ɪnʌf wʌns ðə ɹaɪt pipəl faʊn aʊɾ ɪt wɑz ju. nɑt mʌtʃ tə ɪt, ɪn ði ɛnd." dʒɹaɪd blʌd meɪɾ ə blæk steɪn daʊn wʌn tɔɹn sliv ə hɪz koʊt. "ðə kaʊnsəl əz bɪn weɪɾɪŋ iɡɝli fəɹ jə tə kʌm bæk. æŋkʃəsli, jə maɪt seɪ," hi æɾəd wɪð ə ɹaɪ ɡɹɪn.

"The city is ours," Bashere went on. "Or I should say, yours." He laughed suddenly. "The fighting stopped quick enough once the right people found out it was you. Not much to it, in the end." Dried blood made a black stain down one torn sleeve of his coat. "The Council has been waiting eagerly for you to come back. Anxiously, you might say," he added with a wry grin.

eɪt swɛɾɪŋ mɛn hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum sɪns ɹænd keɪm ɪn. ðeɪ wɔɹ dɑɹk sɪlk koʊts wɪð ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə ləpɛlz ən slivz, ən fɔlz ə leɪs ət ðɛɹ θɹoʊts ən ɹɪsts. səm wɔɹ ə bɪɹd ðət lɛf ði ʌpɝ lɪp ʃeɪv klin, bʌɾ ɛvɹi wʌn hæɾ ə bɹɔd sæʃ ʌv ɡɹin sɪlk slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, wɪð naɪn ɡoʊldən biz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp ɪt.

Eight sweating men had been standing at the far end of the throne room since Rand came in. They wore dark silk coats with gold or silver embroidery on the lapels and sleeves, and falls of lace at their throats and wrists. Some wore a beard that left the upper lip shaved clean, but every one had a broad sash of green silk slanted across his chest, with nine golden bees marching up it.

ət bæʃɪɹz dʒɛstʃɝ ðeɪ keɪm fɔɹwɝd, boʊɪŋ tə ɹænd əɾ əbaʊɾ ɛvɹi θɝd stɛp, fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ðoʊ hi wɔɹ ðə faɪnəst ɡɑɹməns soʊn. ə tɔl mæn sim tə bi ðə liɾɝ, ə ɹaʊnd-feɪs fɛloʊ wɪð wʌn ə ðoʊz bɪɹdz, wɪð ə nætʃɹəl dɪɡnəɾi ðəɾ əpɪɹd stʃɹeɪn baɪ wɝi. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛd, boʊɪŋ əɡɛn ən pɹɛsɪŋ boʊθ hænz tə hɪz hɑɹt. "fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt lɔɹd bɹɛn də bi noʊwɛɹ tə bi faʊnd, ən - "

At Bashere's gesture they came forward, bowing to Rand at about every third step, for all the world as though he wore the finest garments sewn. A tall man seemed to be the leader, a round-faced fellow with one of those beards, with a natural dignity that appeared strained by worry. "My Lord Dragon," he said, bowing again and pressing both hands to his heart. "Forgive me, but Lord Brend do be nowhere to be found, and - "

"hi woʊn bi," ɹænd sɛd flætli.

"He won't be," Rand said flatly.

ə mʌsəl ɪn ðə mænz feɪs dʒʌmpt ət ɹændz toʊn, ən i swɑloʊd. "æz jə də seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi mɝmɝd. "aɪ də bi lɔɹd ɡɹɛɡɹɪn dɛn lʌʃɪnoʊz, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ɪn lɔɹd bɹɛnz æbsəns, aɪ də spik fəɹ ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn. wi də ɔfɝ ju. . . ." ə hæn əɾ ɪz saɪd weɪvd vɪɡɝəsli əɾ ə ʃɔɹɾɝ, bɪɹdləs mæn, hu stɛp fɔɹwɝd bɛɹɪŋ ə kʊʃən dʒɹeɪpt wɪð ə lɛŋθ ʌv ɡɹin sɪlk. ". . . wi də ɔfɝ jə ɪljən." ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mæn wɪp ðə klɔθ əweɪ, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə hɛvi ɡoʊl sɝklət, tu ɪntʃəz waɪd, ʌv lɔɹəl livz. "ðə sɪɾi də bi jʊɹz, ʌv kɔɹs," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn wɛn ɑn æŋkʃəsli. "wi dɪd pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ɔl ɹɪzɪstəns. wi də ɔfɝ jə ðə kɹaʊn, ən ðə θɹoʊn, ən ɔl ʌv ɪljən."

A muscle in the man's face jumped at Rand's tone, and he swallowed. "As you do say, my Lord Dragon," he murmured. "I do be Lord Gregorin den Lushenos, my Lord Dragon. In Lord Brend's absence, I do speak for the Council of Nine. We do offer you. . . ." A hand at his side waved vigorously at a shorter, beardless man, who stepped forward bearing a cushion draped with a length of green silk. ". . . we do offer you Illian." The shorter man whipped the cloth away, revealing a heavy gold circlet, two inches wide, of laurel leaves. "The city do be yours, of course," Gregorin went on anxiously. "We did put an end to all resistance. We do offer you the crown, and the throne, and all of Illian."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɹaʊn ɑn ɪts kʊʃən, nɑt muvɪŋ ə mʌsəl. pipəl hæd θɔɾ i mɛn tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf ə kɪŋ ɪn tɛɹ, fɪɹɾ i wəɾ ɪn kɛɹhin ən ændɝ, bʌt noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɔfɝɾ ɪm ə kɹaʊn bɪfɔɹ. "waɪ? ɪz mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz soʊ wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv ʌp ɪz θɹoʊn?"

Rand stared at the crown on its cushion, not moving a muscle. People had thought he meant to make himself a king in Tear, feared he would in Cairhien and Andor, but no one had offered him a crown before. "Why? Is Mattin Stepaneos so willing to give up his throne?"

"kɪŋ mæɾɪn dɪd dɪsəpɪɹ tu deɪz əɡoʊ," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn sɛd. "sʌm ʌv əs də fɪɹ. . . . wi də fɪɹ lɔɹd bɹɛn meɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ tə wɪð ɪt. bɹɛn dʌz hæv. . . ." hi stɑp tə swɑloʊ. "bɹɛn dɪɾ əv ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪnfluəns wɪð ðə kɪŋ, səm maɪt seɪ tu mʌtʃ, bʌɾ i dɪd bi dɪstʃɹæktəɾ ɪn ɹisən mʌnθs, ən mæɾɪn hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɹiəsɝt hɪmsɛlf."

"King Mattin did disappear two days ago," Gregorin said. "Some of us do fear. . . . We do fear Lord Brend may have something to with it. Brend does have. . . ." He stopped to swallow. "Brend did have a great deal of influence with the king, some might say too much, but he did be distracted in recent months, and Mattin had begun to reassert himself."

stʃɹɪps ʌv ɡɹaɪmi koʊtsliv ən pisəz ə ʃɝtsliv dæŋɡəld əz ɹænd ɹitʃt tə pɪk ʌp ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn. ðə dʒɹæɡən waʊn ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹɑɹm ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə læmplaɪɾ əz bɹaɪtli əz ðə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn. hi tɝn ɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. "ju stɪl hævən sɛd waɪ. kəz aɪ kɑŋkɝd ju?" hi hæd kɑŋkɝd tiɹ, ən kɛɹhin tu, bʌt səm tɝn ɑn ɪm ɪn boʊθ lænz stɪl. jɛɾ ɪt sim tə bi ði oʊnli weɪ.

Strips of grimy coatsleeve and pieces of shirtsleeve dangled as Rand reached to pick up the Laurel Crown. The Dragon wound around his forearm glittered in the lamplight as brightly as the golden crown. He turned it in his hands. "You still haven't said why. Because I conquered you?" He had conquered Tear, and Cairhien too, but some turned on him in both lands still. Yet it seemed to be the only way.

"ðæt də bi pɑɹt," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ivən soʊ, wi maɪɾ əv tʃoʊzən wʌn ʌv əɹ oʊn; kɪŋz əv kʌm fɹəm ðə kaʊnsəl bɪfɔɹ. bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪn jə dɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ sɛn fɹəm tiɹ əz jəɹ neɪm ɑn ɛvɹi lɪp wɪð ðə laɪt. wɪθaʊt ðæt, mɛni wəd bi dɛɾ ə stɑɹveɪʃən. bɹɛn dɪd si ɛvɹi stɪk ə bɹɛd ɡoʊ tə ði ɑɹmi."

"That do be part," Gregorin said dryly. "Even so, we might have chosen one of our own; kings have come from the Council before. But the grain you did order sent from Tear has your name on every lip with the Light. Without that, many would be dead of starvation. Brend did see every stick of bread go to the army."

ɹænd blɪŋkt, ən snætʃt wʌn hæn fɹəm ðə kɹaʊn tə sʌk ɑn ə pɹɪk fɪŋɡɝ. ɔlmoʊs bɛɹiɾ əmʌŋ ðə lɔɹəl livz ə ðə kɹaʊn wɝ ðə ʃɑɹp pɔɪns ə sɔɹdz. haʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ hæɾ i kəmændəd ðə tɛɹənz tə sɛl ɡɹeɪn tə ðɛɹ eɪntʃən ɛnəmi, sɛl ɪɾ əɹ daɪ fəɹ ɹəfjuzɪŋ? hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðeɪ kɛpt ɑn æftɝ i bɪɡæn pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz tə ɪnveɪɾ ɪljən. meɪbi ðeɪ fɪɹd tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp, bʌt ðeɪ hæd fɪɹd tə stɑp, tu. meɪbi hi hæɾ ɝn səm ɹaɪt tə ðɪs kɹaʊn.

Rand blinked, and snatched one hand from the crown to suck on a pricked finger. Almost buried among the laurel leaves of the crown were the sharp points of swords. How long ago had he commanded the Tairens to sell grain to their ancient enemy, sell it or die for refusing? He had not realized they kept on after he began preparations to invade Illian. Maybe they feared to bring it up, but they had feared to stop, too. Maybe he had earned some right to this crown.

dʒɪnʒɝli hi sɛt ðə sɝkəl ə lɔɹəl livz ɑn ɪz hɛd. hæf ðoʊz sɔɹdz pɔɪntəɾ ʌp, hæf daʊn. noʊ hɛd wəd wɛɹ ðɪs kɹaʊn kæʒəwəli əɹ izəli.

Gingerly he set the circle of laurel leaves on his head. Half those swords pointed up, half down. No head would wear this crown casually or easily.

ɡɹɛɡɹɪn baʊd smuðli. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɹænd ælθɹ, kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən," hi ɪntoʊnd, ən ðə sɛvən ʌðɝ lɔɹdz baʊd wɪð hɪm, mɝmɝɪŋ, "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɹænd ælθɹ, kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən."

Gregorin bowed smoothly. "The Light illumine Rand al'Thor, King of Illian," he intoned, and the seven other lords bowed with him, murmuring, "The Light illumine Rand al'Thor, King of Illian."

bæʃɪɹ kəntɛntəd hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə baʊ ʌv ɪz hɛd - hi wɑz ʌŋkəl tə ə kwin, æftɝ ɔl - bʌt dæʃivə kɹaɪɾ aʊt, "ɔl heɪl ɹænd ælθɹ, kɪŋ ə ðə wɝld!" flɪn ən ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən tʊk ɪɾ ʌp.

Bashere contented himself with a bow of his head - he was uncle to a queen, after all - but Dashiva cried out, "All hail Rand al'Thor, King of the World!" Flinn and the other Asha'man took it up.

"ɔl heɪl ɹænd ælθɹ, kɪŋ ə ðə wɝld!"

"All hail Rand al'Thor, King of the World!"

"ɔl heɪl ðə kɪŋ ə ðə wɝld!"

"All hail the King of the World!"

ðət hæɾ ə ɡʊd saʊn tə ɪt.

That had a good sound to it.

ðə stɔɹi spɹɛɾ əz stɔɹiz wɪl, ən tʃeɪnʒd əz stɔɹiz tʃeɪnʒ wɪð taɪm ən dɪstəns, spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ɪljən baɪ koʊstɪŋ ʃɪps, ən mɝtʃən tʃɹeɪnz ʌv wæɡənz, ən pɪdʒənz sɛn ɪn sikɹət, spɹɛɾɪŋ ɪn ɹɪpəlz ðət dænst wɪð ʌðɝ ɹɪpəlz ən meɪd nu. ən ɑɹmi hæd kʌm tə ɪljən, ðə stɔɹiz sɛd, ən ɑɹmi ʌv il, ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɪɹɪŋ fɹəm θɪn ɛɹ, ʌv mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪŋ bists, ivən ən ɑɹmi ʌv sɑldəiənz, ðoʊ nɑt mɛni bɪliv ðət wʌn. səm teɪlz sɛd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd bɪn pɹizɛntəd ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən baɪ ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn, ən ʌðɝz baɪ mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz hɪmsɛlf ɑn bɛndɪd ni. səm sɛd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd ɹɛntʃt ðə kɹaʊn fɹəm mæɾɪnz hɛd, ðən stʌk ðət hɛɾ ɑn ə spaɪk. noʊ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd ɹeɪzd ɪljən tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən bɛɹid ði oʊl kɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹʌbəl. noʊ, hi ən ɪz ɑɹmi ʌv æʃəmən hæd bɝn ɪljən aʊɾ ə ði ɝθ. noʊ, ɪt wɑz ɛbu dɑɹ i hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd, æftɝ ɪljən.

The story spread as stories will, and changed as stories change with time and distance, spreading out from Illian by coasting ships, and merchant trains of wagons, and pigeons sent in secret, spreading in ripples that danced with other ripples and made new. An army had come to Illian, the stories said, an army of Aiel, of Aes Sedai appearing from thin air, of men who could channel riding winged beasts, even an army of Saldaeans, though not many believed that one. Some tales said the Dragon Reborn had been presented the Laurel Crown of Illian by the Council of Nine, and others by Mattin Stepaneos himself on bended knee. Some said the Dragon Reborn had wrenched the crown from Mattin's head, then stuck that head on a spike. No, the Dragon Reborn had razed Illian to the ground and buried the old king in the rubble. No, he and his army of Asha'man had burned Illian out of the earth. No, it was Ebou Dar he had destroyed, after Illian.

wʌn fækt, ðoʊ, tɝn ʌp əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ɪn ðoʊz teɪlz. ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ə nu neɪm. ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz.

One fact, though, turned up again and again in those tales. The Laurel Crown of Illian had been given a new name. The Crown of Swords.

ən fəɹ səm ɹizən, mɛn ən wɪmən u toʊl ðə teɪlz ɔfən faʊn ə nid tə æɾ ɔlmoʊst aɪdɛntɪkəl wɝdz. ðə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ðeɪ sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ saʊθwɝɾ ɪn wɝi. ðə stɔɹm ɪz kʌmɪŋ.

And for some reason, men and women who told the tales often found a need to add almost identical words. The storm is coming, they said, staring southward in worry. The storm is coming.

mæstɝ ə ðə laɪtnɪŋz, ɹaɪɾɝ ɑn ðə stɔɹm, wɛɹɝ ʌv ə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz, spɪnɝ-aʊɾ ə feɪt.

Master of the lightnings, rider on the storm, wearer of a crown of swords, spinner-out of fate.

hu θɪŋks i tɝnz ðə wil ə taɪm, meɪ lɝn ðə tʃɹuθ tu leɪt.

Who thinks he turns the Wheel of Time, may learn the truth too late.

 - fɹəm ə fɹæɡməntɛɹi tʃɹænzleɪʃən ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ətʃɹɪbjəɾəd tə lɔɹd mæŋɡɹ kɹəmən, sɔɹd-bɑɹɾ ʌv ɛɹæmeɪɛl ən wɔɹɾɝ tə kæɹeɪɡən mɑkɑnɝ, ɪndə wʌt wɑz ðən kɔl ðə vʌlɡɝ tʌŋ (sɝkə θɹihʌnʒɹəd æb).

 - From a fragmentary translation of The Prophecies of the Dragon, attributed to Lord Mangore Kiramin, Sword-bard of Aramaelle and Warder to Caraighan Maconar, into what was then called the vulgar tongue (circa 300 AB).

ði ɛn ə ðə sɛvənθ bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). soʊ mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðəɾ ət ðɛɹ ɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ, pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi). ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌɾ oʊnli hɪstɔɹiənz naʊ ɹəfɝ tə ɪt. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The End of the Seventh Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai, recording years After the Breaking of the World (AB). So many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars that at their end there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar, proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrated freedom from the Trolloc threat and recorded each year as a Free Year (FY). The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but only historians now refer to it. After the death and destruction of the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

æɾəm (aɪ-dæm): ə dɪvaɪs fəɹ kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl, juzəbəl oʊnli baɪ iðɝ ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl əɹ ə wʊmən u kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl, ən hævɪŋ noʊ ɪfɛkt ɑn ɛni wʊmən u kænɑt tʃænəl. ɪt kɹieɪts ə lɪŋk bɪtwin ðə tu wɪmən. ðə sintʃæn vɝʒən kənsɪsts ʌv ə kɑlɝ ən bɹeɪslət kənɛktəd baɪ ə liʃ, ɔl ə sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl, bʌt wʌn ɪɡzæmpəl ʌv ə vɝʒən wɪθaʊt ðə liʃ əz bɪn meɪd, ən ənʌðɝ, junik, vɛɹiən ɪz bɪliv tə ɪɡzɪst wɪtʃ əlaʊz ə wʊmən tə kəntʃɹoʊl ə mæn u kən tʃænəl. ɪf sətʃ ə mæn ɪz lɪŋk baɪ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi æɾəm tə ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl, ðə laɪkli ɹɪzʌlt ɪz dɛθ fəɹ boʊθ. wən ən æɾəm ɪz wɔɹn baɪ ə wʊmən u kən tʃænəl, sɪmpli tʌtʃɪŋ ði æɾəm ɹɪzʌls ɪn peɪn fəɹ ə mæn u ɔlsoʊ kæn. si ɔlsoʊ lɪŋkɪŋ, sintʃæn.

a'dam (AYE-dam): A device for controlling a woman who can channel, usable only by either a woman who can channel or a woman who can be taught to channel, and having no effect on any woman who cannot channel. It creates a link between the two women. The Seanchan version consists of a collar and bracelet connected by a leash, all of silvery metal, but one example of a version without the leash has been made, and another, unique, variant is believed to exist which allows a woman to control a man who can channel. If such a man is linked by an ordinary a'dam to a woman who can channel, the likely result is death for both. When an a'dam is worn by a woman who can channel, simply touching the a'dam results in pain for a man who also can. See also linking, Seanchan.

eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz: eɪdʒ ɛndəd baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ə taɪm wən ɛɛs sədaɪ pɝfɔɹmd wʌndɝz naʊ oʊnli dʒɹimd ʌv.

Age of Legends: Age ended by the War of the Shadow and the Breaking of the World. A time when Aes Sedai performed wonders now only dreamed of.

il wɔɹ (naɪnsɛvənsɪkssɛvəneɪt ni): wən kɪŋ leɪmən (leɪ-mæn) ʌv kɛɹhin kʌt daʊn ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə, fɔɹ klænz ə ði il kɹɔs ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. ðeɪ luɾəd ən bɝn ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin əz wɛl əz mɛni ʌðɝ sɪɾiz ən taʊnz, ən ðə kɑnflɪkt ɪkstɛndəɾ ɪndə ændɝ ən tiɹ. baɪ ðə kənvɛnʃənəl vju, ði il wɝ faɪnəli dɪfiɾəd ət ðə bæɾəl ə ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz, bɪfɔɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn; ɪn fækt, leɪmən wɑz kɪld ɪn ðət bæɾəl, ən hævɪŋ dʌn wʌt ðeɪ keɪm fɔɹ, ði il ɹɛkɹɔs ðə spaɪn. si ɔlsoʊ kɛɹhin; spaɪn ə ðə wɝld.

Aiel War (97678 NE): When King Laman (LAY-mahn) of Cairhien cut down Avendoraldera, four clans of the Aiel crossed the Spine of the World. They looted and burned the capital city of Cairhien as well as many other cities and towns, and the conflict extended into Andor and Tear. By the conventional view, the Aiel were finally defeated at the Battle of the Shining Walls, before Tar Valon; in fact, Laman was killed in that battle, and having done what they came for, the Aiel recrossed the Spine. See also Cairhien; Spine of the World.

ədʒɑ (ɑ-dʒɑ): səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɛvən ɪn nʌmbɝ ən dɛzɪɡneɪɾɪd baɪ kʌlɝz: blu, ɹɛd, waɪt, ɡɹin, bɹaʊn, jɛloʊ ən ɡɹeɪ. ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛp ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn. itʃ fɑloʊz ə spəsɪfɪk fəlɑsəfi ʌv ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən ðə pɝpəsəz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ bɛnz ɪts ɛnɝdʒiz tə faɪndɪŋ mɛn u kən tʃænəl, ən tə dʒɛntəlɪŋ ðɛm. ðə bɹaʊn fɔɹseɪks ðə məndeɪn wɝld ən dɛɾɪkeɪts ɪtsɛlf tə sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ, waɪl ðə waɪt, lɑɹdʒli ɛʃuɪŋ boʊθ ðə wɝld ən ðə vælju ʌv wɝldli nɑlədʒ, dɪvoʊts ɪtsɛlf tə kwɛstʃənz ə fəlɑsəfi ən tʃɹuθ. ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ (kɔl ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz) hoʊlz ɪtsɛlf ɹɛɾi fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðə jɛloʊ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪts ɑn ðə stʌɾi ʌv hilɪŋ, ən blu sɪstɝz ɪnvɑlv ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð kɑzəz ən dʒʌstəs. ðə ɡɹeɪ ɑɹ miɾieɪtɝz, sikɪŋ hɑɹməni ən kənsɛnsəs. eɪ blæk ədʒɑ, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə sɝvɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪz əfɪʃəli ən viəmənli dɪnaɪd.

Ajah (AH-jah): Societies among the Aes Sedai, seven in number and designated by colors: Blue, Red, White, Green, Brown, Yellow and Gray. All Aes Sedai except the Amyrlin Seat belong to one. Each follows a specific philosophy of the use of the One Power and the purposes of the Aes Sedai. The Red Ajah bends its energies to finding men who can channel, and to gentling them. The Brown forsakes the mundane world and dedicates itself to seeking knowledge, while the White, largely eschewing both the world and the value of worldly knowledge, devotes itself to questions of philosophy and truth. The Green Ajah (called the Battle Ajah during the Trolloc Wars) holds itself ready for Tarmon Gai'don, the Yellow concentrates on the study of Healing, and Blue sisters involve themselves with causes and justice. The Gray are mediators, seeking harmony and consensus. A Black Ajah, dedicated to serving the Dark One, is officially and vehemently denied.

ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "faɪɾɝz ə ðə spɪɹ," əɹ "spɪɹ faɪɾɝz." ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə ðoʊz il u kæɹi ðə spɪɹ ən ɹɛɡjəlɝli teɪk pɑɹɾ ɪn bæɾəl əz əpoʊz tə ðoʊz u fɑloʊ kɹæfs.

algai'd'siswai: In the Old Tongue, "fighters of the spear," or "spear fighters." The name given to those Aiel who carry the spear and regularly take part in battle as opposed to those who follow crafts.

ɔltɑɹə (æl-tɑ-ɹɑ): ə neɪʃən ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ lɪɾəl junəfaɪz ɪɾ ɪksɛpt ə neɪm. ðə pipəl ʌv ɔltɑɹə θɪŋk ə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ɪnhæbəɾənts ʌv ə taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ, əɹ əz ðɪs lɔɹdz əɹ ðət leɪɾiz pipəl, fɝst, ən oʊnli sɛkən ɪf əɾ ɔl əz ɔltɑɹən. fju noʊbəlz peɪ tæksəz tə ðə kɹaʊn əɹ ɔfɝ mɔɹ ðən lɪp sɝvəs, ən ðəɾ ɔfən slaɪt. ðə ɹulɝ ʌv ɔltɑɹə (kɝənli kwin taɪlɪn kwɪntɑɹə ʌv haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ; taɪ-lɪn kwɪn-tɑɹ-ɑ; -soʊ-bɛɹ) ɪz sɛldəm mɔɹ ðən ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl noʊbəl ɪn ðə lænd, ən ət taɪmz əz nɑɾ ivən ɹɪli bɪn ðæt. ðə θɹoʊn ə ðə wɪnz hoʊlz soʊ lɪɾəl paʊɝ ðət mɛni paʊɝfəl noʊbəlz əv skɔɹn tə teɪk ɪt wən ðeɪ kəd hæv. ðə bænɝ ʌv ɔltɑɹə ɪz tu ɡoʊldən lɛpɝdz ɑn ə fil tʃɛk fɔɹ-baɪ-fɔɹ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blu. ðə sɪdʒəl ə haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ ɪz ə ɡɹin æŋkɝ ən sɔɹd, kɹɔst. si ɔlsoʊ waɪz wʊmən.

Altara (al-TAH-rah): A nation on the Sea of Storms, though in truth little unifies it except a name. The people of Altara think of themselves as inhabitants of a town or village, or as this lord's or that lady's people, first, and only second if at all as Altaran. Few nobles pay taxes to the crown or offer more than lip service, and that often slight. The ruler of Altara (currently Queen Tylin Quintara of House Mitsobar; TIE-lihn quin-TAHR-ah; MIHT-soh-bahr) is seldom more than the most powerful noble in the land, and at times has not even really been that. The Throne of the Winds holds so little power that many powerful nobles have scorned to take it when they could have. The banner of Altara is two golden leopards on a field checked four-by-four in red and blue. The sigil of House Mitsobar is a green anchor and sword, crossed. See also Wise Woman.

æmɪz (ɑ-mis): waɪz wʌn ə koʊld ɹɑks hoʊld, ən ə dʒɹimwɔkɝ. ən il ə ðə naɪn væliz sɛpt ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il. waɪf ə ɹəɑɹk (ɹɔɹk), sɪstɝ-waɪf tə ljɑn (li-æn), hu ɪz ɹufməstʃɹəs ə koʊld ɹɑks hoʊld. æmɪz ɪz sɪstɝ-mʌðɝ tə eɪvinhə.

Amys (ah-MEESE): Wise One of Cold Rocks Hold, and a dreamwalker. An Aiel of the Nine Valleys sept of the Taardad Aiel. Wife of Rhuarc (ROARK), sister-wife to Lian (lee-AHN), who is roofmistress of Cold Rocks Hold. Amys is sister-mother to Aviendha.

æŋɡɹil (æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðəɾ əlaʊ ɛniwʌn keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ tə hændəl ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðən ɪz seɪf əɹ ivən pɑsəbəl əneɪɾɪd. səm wɝ meɪd fəɹ jus baɪ wɪmən, ʌðɝz baɪ mɛn. ɹumɝz ʌv æŋɡɹil juzəbəl baɪ boʊθ mɛn ən wɪmən əv nɛvɝ bɪn kənfɝmd. ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn, ən fju ɑɹ noʊn tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛɡzɪstəns. si ɔlsoʊ sɑŋɡɹil; tɛɹæŋɡɹil.

angreal (ahn-gree-AHL): Remnants of the Age of Legends that allow anyone capable of channeling to handle a greater amount of the Power than is safe or even possible unaided. Some were made for use by women, others by men. Rumors of angreal usable by both men and women have never been confirmed. Their making is no longer known, and few are known to remain in existence. See also sa'angreal; ter'angreal.

æʃəmən (ɑ-ʃɑ-mæn): (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɡɑɹɾiən" əɹ "dɪfɛndɝ," wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ ɪmpləkeɪʃən ðət ðɪs ɪz ə dɪfɛndɝ ə tʃɹuθ ən dʒʌstəs. (tu) ðə neɪm teɪkən baɪ fɑloʊɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, mɛn u hæv kʌm tə wʌɾ ɪz naʊ biɪŋ kɔl ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lɝn haʊ tə tʃænəl. səm əv dʒɹimd ə tʃænəlɪŋ dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ðə daɪɹ ɹɪsks, waɪl ʌðɝz ɹɪmeɪn oʊnli kəz pæsɪŋ ðə tɛs fəɹ ði əbɪləɾi tə lɝn əz ɪtsɛlf stɑɹɾəd əm ɑn ðə ɹoʊd tə tʃænəlɪŋ, ən ðeɪ naʊ mʌs lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪt kɪlz ðɛm. ðeɪ tʃɹeɪn nɑɾ oʊnli ɪn juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪn ðə jus ə ðə sɔɹɾ ən ɪn faɪɾɪŋ wɪð hænz ən fit. ði æʃəmən, hu wɛɹ dɪstɪŋktɪv blæk koʊts, ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə lɛvəl ə nɑlədʒ ðeɪv ətʃivd, ðə loʊəs biɪŋ ə soʊlʒɝ. ðə nɛks lɛvəl ɪz ə dɛɾəkeɪtəd, mɑɹk baɪ ə pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd wɔɹn ɑn ðə koʊt kɑlɝ. ðə haɪəs lɛvəl ɪz kɔl sɪmpli ən æʃəmən, mɑɹk baɪ ə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊld ɪnæməl pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə dʒɹæɡən wɔɹn ɑn ðə koʊt kɑlɝ ɑpəzət ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd. ənlaɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu ɡoʊ tə ɡɹeɪt lɛŋθs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðoʊz ðeɪ tʃɹeɪn ɑɹ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə muv deɪnʒɝəsli fæst, ði æʃəmən ɑɹ pʊʃt hɑɹd fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, moʊst ɪspɛʃli ɪn lɝnɪŋ tə juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. əz ə ɹɪzʌlt, wɛɹ ðə dɛθ əɹ stɪlɪŋ ʌv ə nɑvəs ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ dʊɹɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ spoʊkən ʌv wɪð hɔɹɝ fəɹ jɪɹz, ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪts ɪkspɛktəd ðəɾ ə sɝɾən nʌmbɝ ʌv æʃəmən soʊlʒɝz wɪl daɪ əɹ bi bɝn aʊɾ ətɛmptɪŋ tə lɝn. ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə ði æʃəmən, ən ðɛɹ kənɛkʃən tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hæz kɑzd ə ɹiɪvæljueɪʃən əmʌŋ səm ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ði ɪmiɾiət nəsɛsəɾi fəɹ dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌt mɛni hæv nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ vju əɾ ɔl. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɛntəlɪŋ, stɪlɪŋ.

Asha'man (AH-shah-mahn): (1) In the Old Tongue, "Guardian" or "Defender," with a strong implication that this is a defender of truth and justice. (2) The name taken by followers of the Dragon Reborn, men who have come to what is now being called the Black Tower in order to learn how to channel. Some have dreamed of channeling despite all the dire risks, while others remain only because passing the test for the ability to learn has itself started them on the road to channeling, and they now must learn to control it before it kills them. They train not only in using the One Power, but in the use of the sword and in fighting with hands and feet. The Asha'man, who wear distinctive black coats, are divided according to the level of knowledge they have achieved, the lowest being a Soldier. The next level is a Dedicated, marked by a pin in the shape of a silver sword worn on the coat collar. The highest level is called simply an Asha'man, marked by a red-and-gold enameled pin in the shape of a Dragon worn on the coat collar opposite the silver sword. Unlike Aes Sedai, who go to great lengths to make sure that those they train are not allowed to move dangerously fast, the Asha'man are pushed hard from the beginning, most especially in learning to use the Power as a weapon. As a result, where the death or stilling of a novice of the White Tower during her training would be something spoken of with horror for years, at the Black Tower it is expected that a certain number of Asha'man Soldiers will die or be burned out attempting to learn. The existence of the Asha'man, and their connection to the Dragon Reborn, has caused a reevaluation among some Aes Sedai of the immediate necessity for gentling, but many have not changed their view at all. See also gentling, stilling.

əsunɑwə, ɹɑɾəm (ɑ-su-nɑ-wɑ, ɹɑ-dæm): haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt. ɪn ɪz aɪz, mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪz jusɝpɪŋ ðə kɹieɪɾɝz paʊɝ ən ɪz ðə kɑz ʌv ɔl ðə wɝlz ɪlz. hi wɑns mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛniwʌn ən ɛvɹiwʌn u kən tʃænəl əɹ ivən wɪʃɪz tə; ðeɪ mʌs kənfɛs ðɛɹ sɪn ʌndɝ ðə mɪnəstʃɹeɪʃənz ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, ən ðən daɪ. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Asunawa, Rhadam (ah-soo-NAH-wah, RAH-dam): High Inquisitor of the Hand of the Light. In his eyes, meddling with the One Power is usurping the Creator's power and is the cause of all the world's ills. He wants more than anything else to destroy anyone and everyone who can channel or even wishes to; they must confess their sin under the ministrations of the Hand of the Light, and then die. See also Questioners.

æθɑn maɪɹ (ɑ-θɑ-æn mi-ɛɹ): si si foʊk.

Atha'an Miere (ah-thah-AHN mee-EHR): See Sea Folk.

bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd: (wʌn) ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi bæn ə hɪɹoʊz (ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ) fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz u daɪɾ ət ðə bæɾəl ʌv æɛmənz fild, wən meɪnɛðɝən fɛl. (tu) ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən wɪtʃ ɡæðɝd tə fɑloʊ mæt kɔθən, ən wɪtʃ ɪz kɝənli ʃæɾoʊɪŋ ðə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmi wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə kæɹi ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ tə ɹænd ælθɹ ən seɪfti, ʃəd ʃi ɪkspɹɛs ə wɪʃ tə fli fɹəm əɹ kɝən sɪtʃueɪʃən, ən ɔlsoʊ ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝz u maɪt wɪʃ tə dʒɔɪn hɝ.

Band of the Red Hand: (1) A legendary band of heroes (Shen an Calhar) from the Trolloc Wars who died at the Battle of Aemon's Field, when Manetheren fell. (2) A military formation which gathered to follow Mat Cauthon, and which is currently shadowing the rebel Aes Sedai and their army with orders to carry Egwene al'Vere to Rand al'Thor and safety, should she express a wish to flee from her current situation, and also any other sisters who might wish to join her.

bɹəleɪn sɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ (bɛ-ɹɛ-leɪn sʊɹ peɪ-ɛn-dʒɹæɡ): fɝst ə min, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə weɪvz, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs pɹən (peɪ-ɛ-ɹɑn). ə bjuɾəfəl ən wɪlfəl jʌŋ wʊmən, ən ə skɪlfəl ɹulɝ. si ɔlsoʊ min.

Berelain sur Paendrag (BEH-reh-lain suhr PAY-ehn-DRAG): First of Mayene, Blessed of the Light, Defender of the Waves, High Seat of House Paeron (pay-eh-ROHN). A beautiful and willful young woman, and a skillful ruler. See also Mayene.

bɝdʒɪt (bɝ-dʒit-tɛ): wɔɹɾɝ tə ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, bɪliv tə bi pɑsəbli ðə fɝs fimeɪl wɔɹɾɝ ɛvɝ, ə fæk ðət kɑzəz ə nʌmbɝ ə dɪfəkəltiz, fju ʌv əm ɪkspɛktəd. bɝdʒɪɾ ɪz ɪn tʃɹuθ ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi hɪɹoʊ ʌv ðət neɪm, hu wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz baʊn tə bi kɔl bæk baɪ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɹɪpt aʊɾ ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ ɪndə ðə wɝld ə ðə flɛʃ dʊɹɪŋ ə stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð mɑɡiɾin ən wɑz oʊnli seɪv fɹəm dɛθ baɪ biɪŋ bɑndəd baɪ ɪleɪn. ɪksɛp fəɹ əɹ bjuɾi ən skɪl wɪð ə baʊ, ʃiz lɪɾəl laɪk ðə stɔɹiz ə hɝ. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən; hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ; wɔɹɾɝ.

Birgitte (ber-GEET-teh): Warder to Elayne Trakand, believed to be possibly the first female Warder ever, a fact that causes a number of difficulties, few of them expected. Birgitte is in truth the legendary hero of that name, who was one of those bound to be called back by the Horn of Valere, but she was ripped out of Tel'aran'rhiod into the world of the flesh during a struggle with Moghedien and was only saved from death by being bonded by Elayne. Except for her beauty and skill with a bow, she is little like the stories of her. See also Forsaken; Horn of Valere; Warder.

bɹaɪn, ɡɛɹɪθ (bɹɪn, ɡɑ-ɹɛθ): wʌns kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɪn ændɝ, naʊ kəmændɪŋ ən ɑɹmi fəɹ ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən. kənsɪɾɝd wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst dʒɛnɝəlz lɪvɪŋ. hɪz ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð sɪuən sɑntʃ tʃɹʌbəlz ɪm nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt dʌz hɝ. ðə sɪdʒəl ə haʊs bɹaɪn ɪz ə waɪl bʊl, ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ ɝaʊn ɪts nɛk. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪnz pɝsənəl sɪdʒəl ɪz θɹi ɡoʊldən stɑɹz, itʃ ə faɪv ɹeɪz.

Bryne, Gareth (BRIHN, GAH-rehth): Once Captain-General of the Queen's Guards in Andor, now commanding an army for those Aes Sedai in rebellion against the authority of Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan. Considered one of the greatest generals living. His relationship with Siuan Sanche troubles him nearly as much as it does her. The sigil of House Bryne is a wild bull, the rose crown of Andor around its neck. Gareth Bryne's personal sigil is three golden stars, each of five rays.

keɪɾɪnsɝ (kɑ-dɪn-sɔɹ): ɡɑɹb ʌv il ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ: koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ɪn bɹaʊnz ən ɡɹeɪz ðət feɪɾ ɪndə ɹɑk əɹ ʃædoʊ, əlɔŋ wɪð sɑft, leɪs ni-haɪ buts. ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɝkɪŋ kloʊðz," ðoʊ ðɪs ɪz ə kɔɹs ən ɪmpɹəsaɪs tʃɹænzleɪʃən. si ɔlsoʊ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ.

cadin'sor (KAH-dihn-sohr): Garb of Aiel algai'd'siswai: coat and breeches in browns and grays that fade into rock or shadow, along with soft, laced knee-high boots. In the Old Tongue, "working clothes," though this is of course an imprecise translation. See also algai'd'siswai.

kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn (kæd-su-eɪn mɛ-laɪ-dʒɹɪn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ hu hæz əpɹoʊtʃt lɛdʒəndɛɹi stæɾəs əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ waɪl stɪl əlaɪv, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ moʊst sɪstɝz bɪliv ʃi mʌs bi jɪɹz dɛd baɪ naʊ. θɔt tə hæv bɪn bɔɹn ɝaʊn sɛvənhʌnʒɹədfaɪv ni ɪn ɡildən, wɪtʃ wəd meɪk əɹ ði oʊldəs lɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪn ðə paʊɝ faʊn fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɹ mɔɹ əntɪl ði ædvɛn ə nɪneɪiv, ɪleɪn ən ɛɡwin ən ivən ðeɪ də nɑt fɑɹ aʊt-stɛp hɝ. ɔlðoʊ ə ɡɹin, oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ʃiz kənfɹʌntəɾ ən kæptʃɝd mɔɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl baɪ fɑɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ lɪvɪŋ sɪstɝ; ə lɪɾəl-noʊn ɑɾəti ɪz ðət ðə mɛn ʃi bɹɔt tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ tɛndəd tə lɪv mɑɹkədli lɔŋɡɝ æftɝ biɪŋ dʒɛntəl ðən ðoʊz bɹɔt baɪ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz.

Cadsuane Melaidhrin (CAD-soo-ain meh-LIE-drihn): An Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah who has approached legendary status among Aes Sedai while still alive, though in truth most sisters believe she must be years dead by now. Thought to have been born around 705 NE in Ghealdan, which would make her the oldest living Aes Sedai, she was also the strongest in the Power found for a thousand years or more until the advent of Nynaeve, Elayne and Egwene and even they do not far out-step her. Although a Green, over the years she has confronted and captured more men who could channel by far than any other living sister; a little-known oddity is that the men she brought to the White Tower tended to live markedly longer after being gentled than those brought by other sisters.

kɛɹhin (kaɪ-ɹi-ɛn): boʊθ ə neɪʃən əlɔŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. sævɪdʒ dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, ðə neɪʃən ə kɛɹhin wɑz ɪn noʊ weɪ fʊli ɹəkʌvɝd wən ði əsæsəneɪʃən ə kɪŋ ɡɔlʒɹiən (naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntieɪt ni) plʌnʒd ðə kʌntʃɹi ɪndə ə wɔɹ fəɹ ðə səksɛʃən wɪtʃ wɑz ɪtsɛlf ɪntɝʌptɪd baɪ ði ɪnveɪʒən ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ il ɪn wʌt mɛni kɔl ðə sɛkən il wɔɹ, ɔlðoʊ ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf wɑz seɪv baɪ il ɪntɝvɛntʃən ʌndɝ ɹænd ælθɹ. sʌbsəkwənli moʊs noʊbəlz ə kɛɹhin, əlɔŋ wɪð mɛni fɹəm tɛɹ, swɔɹ fiəlti tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌɾ ɪn ə lænd wɛɹ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz əz bɪn ɹeɪz tə ən ɑɹt, ɪts hɑɹdli sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ ivən mɛni hu swɔɹ ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə mənuvɝ fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ædvæntɪdʒ ðeɪ kən faɪnd. ðə bænɝ ə kɛɹhin ɪz ə mɛni-ɹeɪd ɡoʊldən sʌn ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn ə fild ə skaɪ blu. kæləndɝ: ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn deɪz tə ðə wik, twɛntieɪt deɪz tə ðə mʌnθ ən θɝtin mʌnθs tə ðə jɪɹ. sɛvɹəl fistdeɪz ɑɹ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni mʌnθ; ðiz ɪnklud sʌndeɪ (ðə lɔŋɡəs deɪ ʌv ðə jɪɹ), ðə fist ə θæŋksɡɪvɪŋ (wʌns ɛvɹi fɔɹ jɪɹz ət ðə spɹɪŋ ikwənɑks), ən ðə fist ʌv ɔl soʊlz sælveɪʃən, ɔlsoʊ kɔld ɔl soʊlz deɪ (wʌns ɛvɹi tɛn jɪɹz ət ði ɔɾəm ikwənɑks). waɪl mɛni fists ən fɛstəvəlz ɑɹ sɛləbɹeɪɾəd ɛvɹiwɛɹ (sʌtʃ əz ðə fist ə ðə laɪts, wɪtʃ ɛnz ði oʊl jɪɹ ən bɪɡɪnz ðə nu), ɛvɹi læn əz ɪts oʊn əz wɛl, ən ɪn mɛni ɪnstənsəz soʊ də ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz. ɪn dʒɛnɝəl, ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz əv ðə fjuəs fɛstəvəlz ən fistdeɪz, waɪl ðə sɪɾiz ʌv ɪljən ən ɛbu dɑɹ əv ðə moʊst.

Cairhien (KEYE-ree-EHN): Both a nation along the Spine of the World and the capital city of that nation. Savaged during the Aiel War, the nation of Cairhien was in no way fully recovered when the assassination of King Galldrian (998 NE) plunged the country into a war for the succession which was itself interrupted by the invasion of the Shaido Aiel in what many call the Second Aiel War, although the city itself was saved by Aiel intervention under Rand al'Thor. Subsequently most nobles of Cairhien, along with many from Tear, swore fealty to the Dragon Reborn, but in a land where the Game of Houses has been raised to an art, it is hardly surprising that even many who swore are ready to maneuver for whatever advantage they can find. The banner of Cairhien is a many-rayed golden sun rising on a field of sky blue. calendar: There are 10 days to the week, 28 days to the month and 13 months to the year. Several feastdays are not part of any month; these include Sunday (the longest day of the year), the Feast of Thanksgiving (once every four years at the spring equinox), and the Feast of All Souls Salvation, also called All Souls Day (once every ten years at the autumn equinox). While many feasts and festivals are celebrated everywhere (such as the Feast of the Lights, which ends the old year and begins the new), every land has its own as well, and in many instances so do individual towns and villages. In general, the Borderlands have the fewest festivals and feastdays, while the cities of Illian and Ebou Dar have the most.

kæɹeɪɡən mɑkɑnɝ (kɑ-ɹaɪ-dʒɪn mɑ-kɑn-ɑɹ): lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɡɹin sɪstɝ (tuhʌnʒɹədtwɛlv æbθɹisɛvəntiθɹi æb), ðə hɛɹoʊən ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd ædvɛntʃɝz, kɹɛɾətəd wɪð ɛksplɔɪts ðəɾ ivən səm ɛɛs sədaɪ kənsɪɾɝ ɪmpɹɑbəbəl dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ ɪnkluʒən ɪn ðə ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, sətʃ əz sɪŋɡəl-hændɪdli pʊɾɪŋ daʊn ə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn məsədʒɹɪn ən kwɛlɪŋ ðə koʊmeɪɾɪn ɹaɪəts əɾ ə taɪm wən ʃi hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝz. kənsɪɾɝd baɪ ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ tə bi ði ɑɹkɪtaɪp ʌv ə ɡɹin sɪstɝ. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ.

Caraighan Maconar (kah-RYE-gihn mah-CON-ahr): Legendary Green sister (212 AB373 AB), the heroine of a hundred adventures, credited with exploits that even some Aes Sedai consider improbable despite their inclusion in the records of the White Tower, such as single-handedly putting down a rebellion in Mosadorin and quelling the Comaidin Riots at a time when she had no Warders. Considered by the Green Ajah to be the archetype of a Green sister. See also Ajah.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: səsaɪəɾi ʌv stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, oʊɪŋ əlidʒəns tə noʊ neɪʃən ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ən ɪnkɹis ɪn dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi səsaɪəɾi. ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn bɪlifs, ən sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. kənsɪɾɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əm tə bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz. noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt. si ɔlsoʊ kwɛstʃənɝz.

Children of the Light: Society of strict ascetic beliefs, owing allegiance to no nation and dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years to proselytize against an increase in Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military society. Extremely rigid in beliefs, and certain that only they know the truth and the right. Consider Aes Sedai and any who support them to be Darkfriends. Known disparagingly as Whitecloaks. Their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white. See also Questioners.

dɑɹkfɹɛnz: ædhɪɹəns ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðeɪ bɪliv ðəl ɡeɪn ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən ɹɪwɔɹdz, ivən ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi, wən hiz fɹid. sikɹəɾɪv ə nəsɛsəɾi, ðeɪ ɔɹɡənaɪz ɪndə ɡɹups kɔld "sɝkəlz," wɪð mɛmbɝz ʌv wʌn sɝkəl ɹɛɹli ɪf ɛvɝ noʊn tə mɛmbɝz ʌv ənʌðɝ. ɹæŋk ɪn ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld əz noʊ bɛɹɪŋ ɑn ɹæŋk wɪð ðə sɝkəlz; ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin u wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd tə oʊbeɪ ə bɛɡɝ u ɡeɪv ðə pɹɑpɝ saɪnz. əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðeɪ səmtaɪmz juz ði eɪntʃənt neɪm fɹɛnz ə ðə dɑɹk.

Darkfriends: Adherents of the Dark One. They believe they will gain great power and rewards, even immortality, when he is freed. Secretive of necessity, they organize into groups called "circles," with members of one circle rarely if ever known to members of another. Rank in the outside world has no bearing on rank with the circles; a king or queen who was a Darkfriend would be expected to obey a beggar who gave the proper signs. Among themselves, they sometimes use the ancient name Friends of the Dark.

dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn: dʒɛnɝəl tɝm juz fəɹ səpɔɹɾɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, juʒəwəli baɪ ðoʊz u iðɝ əpoʊz ɪm əɹ ət lis θɪŋk tə ɹɪmeɪn nutʃɹəl. ɪn fækt, mɛni ɡɪvən ðət neɪm əv nɛvɝ swɔɹn ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv oʊθ, ən ɪts fɹikwənli əplaɪd tə bɹɪɡænz əz wɛl, səm ə hum kleɪm ðə neɪm ɪn ðə hoʊp ðəɾ ɪɾəl kwɛl ɹɪzɪstəns. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ətʃɹɑsəɾiz əv bɪn kəmɪɾəd baɪ pipəl kleɪmɪŋ tə bi dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn.

Dragonsworn: General term used for supporters of the Dragon Reborn, usually by those who either oppose him or at least think to remain neutral. In fact, many given that name have never sworn any sort of oath, and it is frequently applied to brigands as well, some of whom claim the name in the hope that it will quell resistance. A great many atrocities have been committed by people claiming to be Dragonsworn.

ɛbu dɑɹ: ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ɔltɑɹə. wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt pɔɹts, ən ə sɪɾi wɪð mɛni ɑd kʌstəmz fəɹ ən aʊtsaɪɾɝ tə əsɪməleɪt. si ɔlsoʊ ɔltɑɹə.

Ebou Dar: The capital city of Altara. One of the great ports, and a city with many odd customs for an outsider to assimilate. See also Altara.

ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən (ɛ-laɪ-dɑ doʊ -ɹɪ-ni ɑ-ɹɔɪ-hɑn): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, fɔɹmɝli ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, naʊ ɹeɪz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðoʊ əpoʊz baɪ ənʌðɝ kleɪmɪŋ ðət taɪɾəl. wʌns ædvaɪzɝ tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ʌv ændɝ. ʃi səmtaɪmz əz ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ.

Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan (eh-LY-da doh AHV-rih-nee ah-ROY-han): An Aes Sedai, formerly of the Red Ajah, now raised to the Amyrlin Seat, though opposed by another claiming that title. Once advisor to Queen Morgase of Andor. She sometimes has the Foretelling.

fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn: sɪmbəl ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə staɪlaɪzd ɹɛpɹəzɛnteɪʃən ʌv ə fleɪm; ə waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp, pɔɪn ʌpwɝd.

Flame of Tar Valon: Symbol of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat, and the Aes Sedai. A stylized representation of a flame; a white teardrop, point upward.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðʌs əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛvɝ noʊn, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə pɹɑməs ʌv ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi ən wɝ ɪmpɹɪzən əlɔŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn wən ɪz pɹɪzən wɑz ɹisild. ðɛɹ oʊn neɪm fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz wɑz "ðə tʃoʊzən." ðə neɪmz ɡɪvən tə ðɛm ɑɹ stɪl juz tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən. ðeɪ wɝ: eɪdʒɪnɝ (æɡ-ɪ-nɔɹ), æzmɑɾiən (ɑz-moʊ-di-æn), bælθəməl (bɑl-θɑ-mɛl), bɛləl (bɛ-lɑl), dɪmɑndɝd (di-mæn-dʒɹɛd), ɡɹeɪndəl (ɡɹɛn-dɑl), ɪʃəml (ɪ-ʃɑ-meɪ-ɛl), lænfɝ (læn-fɪɹ), mɛsænə (mɛ-sɑ-nɑ), mɑɡiɾin (moʊ-ɡɛ-di-ɛn), ɹɑvɪn (ɹɑv-ɪn), sɑmaɪl (sæm-meɪ-ɛl), ən sɛmɝhɪdʒ (sɛ-mɪ-ɹæɡ). ɪts bɪliv baɪ ðoʊz wɪð səm kɝənt nɑlədʒ ðəɾ oʊnli dɪmɑndɝɾ ən sɑmaɪl sɝvaɪv əmʌŋ ðə mɛn, ən oʊnli ɡɹeɪndəl, mɛsænə, mɑɡiɾin ən sɛmɝhɪdʒ əmʌŋ ðə wɪmən. ə nʌmbɝ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪnkaʊntɝz, haʊɛvɝ, sədʒɛs ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi iðɝ ðət sɛvɹəl nu tʃoʊzən əv bɪn səlɛktəd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɹ ðət lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv əz ɪn səm keɪsəz ɹitʃt bɪɑn dɛθ.

Forsaken, the: Name given to thirteen of the most powerful Aes Sedai of the Age of Legends, thus among the most powerful ever known, who went over to the Dark One during the War of the Shadow in return for the promise of immortality and were imprisoned along with the Dark One when his prison was resealed. Their own name for themselves was "the Chosen." The names given to them are still used to frighten children. They were: Aginor (AGH-ih-nohr), Asmodean (ahs-MOH-dee-an), Balthamel (BAAL-thah-mell), Be'lal (BEH-lahl), Demandred (DEE-man-drehd), Graendal (GREHN-dahl), Ishamael (ih-SHAH-may-EHL), Lanfear (LAN-feer), Mesaana (meh-SAH-nah), Moghedien (moh-GHEH-dee-ehn), Rahvin (RAAV-ihn), Sammael (SAHM-may-EHL), and Semirhage (SEH-mih-RHAHG). It is believed by those with some current knowledge that only Demandred and Sammael survive among the men, and only Graendal, Mesaana, Moghedien and Semirhage among the women. A number of strange encounters, however, suggest the possibility either that several new Chosen have been selected by the Dark One or that Lord of the Grave has in some cases reached beyond death.

ɡeɪɾɪn (ɡaɪ-din): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bɹʌðɝ tə bæɾəlz." ə taɪɾəl juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝz. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹɾɝ.

Gaidin (GYE-deen): In the Old Tongue, "Brother to Battles." A title used by Aes Sedai for the Warders. See also Warder.

ɡeɪʃeɪn (ɡaɪ-ʃeɪn): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "plɛdʒ tə pis ɪn bæɾəl" ɪz əz kloʊz ə tʃɹænzleɪʃən əz ɪz pɑsəbəl. ən il teɪkən pɹɪznɝ baɪ ʌðɝ il dʊɹɪŋ ɹeɪɾ əɹ bæɾəl ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd baɪ dʒiɾoʊ tə sɝv ɪz əɹ əɹ kæptɝ hʌmbli ən oʊbiɾiəntli fəɹ wʌn jɪɹ ən ə deɪ, tʌtʃɪŋ noʊ wɛpən ən duɪŋ noʊ vaɪələns. eɪ waɪz wʌn, ə blæksmɪθ, ə tʃaɪld, əɹ ə wʊmən wɪð ə tʃaɪld ʌndɝ ði eɪdʒ ə tɛn meɪ nɑt bi meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn. sɪns ðə ɹɛvəleɪʃən ðət ði ænsɛstɝz ə ði il wɝ ɪn fæk pæsɪfɪs fɑloʊɝz ə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif, ə ɡʊd mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹəfjuz tə pʊɾ ɔf waɪt wən ðɛɹ taɪm ɛnz. ədɪʃənəli, ɔlðoʊ baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən əz stʃɹɔŋ əz lɔ noʊ wʌn u dʌz nɑt fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ kən bi meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ il əv bɪɡʌn pʊɾɪŋ kɛɹhinɪn ən ʌðɝ pɹɪznɝz ɪndə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz, ən mɛni hæv kʌm tə bɪliv ðət sɪns ðiz pipəl də nɑt fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə ɹilis əm ət ði ɛn ə ðə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ.

gai'shain (GYE-shain): In the Old Tongue, "Pledged to Peace in Battle" is as close a translation as is possible. An Aiel taken prisoner by other Aiel during raid or battle is required by ji'e'toh to serve his or her captor humbly and obediently for one year and a day, touching no weapon and doing no violence. A Wise One, a blacksmith, a child, or a woman with a child under the age of ten may not be made gai'shain. Since the revelation that the ancestors of the Aiel were in fact pacifist followers of the Way of the Leaf, a good many gai'shain refuse to put off white when their time ends. Additionally, although by tradition as strong as law no one who does not follow ji'e'toh can be made gai'shain, the Shaido Aiel have begun putting Cairhienin and other prisoners into gai'shain robes, and many have come to believe that since these people do not follow ji'e'toh, there is no need to release them at the end of the year and a day.

ɡɔɪn (ɡɑ-wɪn) ʌv haʊs tʃɹəkənd (tʃɹɑ-kænd): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz sʌn, ən ɪleɪnz bɹʌðɝ, hu wɪl bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wən ɪleɪn əsɛnz tə ðə θɹoʊn. hæf-bɹʌðɝ tə ɡɑləd dəmədʒɹd. ə mæn kɑɾ ɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌn klf stɪk; hi dɪpaɪzɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ jɛɾ əz swɔɹn tə sɝv ðɛm, ən i heɪts ɹænd ælθɹ jɛɾ əz swɔɹn nɑt tə ɹeɪz ə hæn əɡɛns hɪm, ɔl kəz i lʌvz ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ bɪɑn ɹizən. hi dʌz nɑt noʊ ðəɾ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf əz nɑɾ oʊnli bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əpoʊzɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn i ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəz. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə waɪt bɔɹ.

Gawyn (GAH-wihn) of House Trakand (trah-KAND): Queen Morgase's son, and Elayne's brother, who will be First Prince of the Sword when Elayne ascends to the throne. Half-brother to Galad Damodred. A man caught in more than one cleft stick; he depises Aes Sedai yet has sworn to serve them, and he hates Rand al'Thor yet has sworn not to raise a hand against him, all because he loves Egwene al'Vere beyond reason. He does not know that Egwene herself has not only become Aes Sedai, but the Amyrlin Seat opposing the Amyrlin he recognizes. His sign is a white boar.

dʒɛntəlɪŋ: ðə ɹɪmuvəl ʌv ə mænz əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. kənsɪɾɝd nɛsəsɛɹi baɪ moʊs pipəl kəz ɛni mæn u tʃænəlz wɪl ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn fɹəm ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn ən ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli kəmɪɾ ətʃɹɑsəɾiz wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪz mædnəs bɪfɔɹ ðə teɪn kɪlz hɪm. wʌn u hæz bɪn dʒɛntəl kən stɪl sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌt kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs əz kʌm bɪfɔɹ dʒɛntəlɪŋ ɪz ɝɛstəd bʌt nɑt kjʊɹd, ən ɪf ɪts dʌn sun ɪnʌf, ðə ɹɑɾɪŋ dɛθ bɹɔt baɪ ðə teɪn kən bi əvɝɾəd. ə mæn u ɪz dʒɛntəld, haʊɛvɝ, ɪnɛvəɾəbli stɑps wɑntɪŋ tə lɪv; ðoʊz u də nɑt səksiɾ ɪn kəmɪɾɪŋ suəsaɪd juʒəwəli daɪ ɛniweɪ wɪðɪn ə jɪɹ əɹ tu. wʌns bɪliv pɝmənənt, dʒɛntəlɪŋ ɪz naʊ noʊn baɪ səm tə bi səsɛptəbəl tə ə haɪli spɛʃəlaɪz fɔɹm ə hilɪŋ. si ɔlsoʊ stɪlɪŋ.

gentling: The removal of a man's ability to channel. Considered necessary by most people because any man who channels will go insane from the taint on saidin and almost certainly commit atrocities with the Power in his madness before the taint kills him. One who has been gentled can still sense the True Source, but cannot touch it. Whatever madness has come before gentling is arrested but not cured, and if it is done soon enough, the rotting death brought by the taint can be averted. A man who is gentled, however, inevitably stops wanting to live; those who do not succeed in committing suicide usually die anyway within a year or two. Once believed permanent, gentling is now known by some to be susceptible to a highly specialized form of Healing. See also stilling.

ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk: neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹəfɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kleɪmɪŋ ðət tə spik ɪz tʃɹu neɪm wəd bi blæsfəməs.

Great Lord of the Dark: Name by which Darkfriends refer to the Dark One, claiming that to speak his true name would be blasphemous.

hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə: ðə lɛdʒəsleɪɾɪv bɑɾi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃɹədɪʃənəli kənsɪstɪŋ ə θɹi sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə hɔl fɹəm itʃ ə ðə sɛvən ədʒəz. ət pɹɛzənt, ðəɹ ɪz ə hɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wɪtʃ kənteɪnz noʊ sɪɾɝz fəɹ ðə blu, ən ə hɔl əmʌŋ ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ hu əpoʊz ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən. ðɪs ɹɛbəl hɔl kənteɪnz noʊ ɹɛd sɪɾɝz. waɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz baɪ lɔ ði æbsəlut paʊɝ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪn fækt əɹ paʊɝ əz ɔlweɪz dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn haʊ wɛl ʃi kəd lid, mænədʒ əɹ ɪntɪmɪdeɪt ðə hɔl, əz ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni weɪz ðət ðə hɔl kən bɔk ɛni æmɪɝlɪnz plænz. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu lɛvəlz ʌv əɡɹimən ðət meɪ bi ɹikwaɪɝd fəɹ aɪɾəmz tə pæs ðə hɔl, ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs ən ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs ɹikwaɪɝz ðəɾ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u ɪz pɹɛzən mʌst stænd, ən ðəɾ ə mɪnəməm ʌv ɪlɛvən sɪɾɝz bi pɹizɛnt; ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ət list wʌn sɪɾɝ fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ ɪz ɔlsoʊ ɹikwaɪɝd, ɪksɛpt wən ðə mæɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ɪz ðə ɹɪmuvəl ʌv ən æmɪɝlɪn əɹ kipɝ, ɪn wɪtʃ keɪs ði ədʒɑ fɹəm wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz ɹeɪzd wɪl nɑt bi ɪnfɔɹmd ə ðə voʊɾ əntɪl æftɝ ɪts bɪn teɪkən. ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs ɔlsoʊ ɹikwaɪɝz ə kwɔɹəm ʌv ɪlɛvən sɪɾɝz, bʌɾ oʊnli tu-θɝdz ə ðoʊz pɹɛzənt nid stæn fəɹ ən aɪɾəm tə pæs. ənʌðɝ dɪfɝəns ɪz ðət ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɹɪkwaɪɹmən fəɹ ɔl ədʒəz tə bi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ ɪn ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs ɪksɛpt ɪn ðə keɪs ʌv ə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌn ə sɛvɹəl mæɾɝz lɛf tə ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs wɪtʃ mɛni maɪt θɪŋk wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit meɪ kɔl fəɹ ɛni sɪɾɝ tə ɹɪzaɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ, əɹ ɪndid fəɹ ɔl tə, ən ðət kɔl mʌs bi hiɾəd. ðɪs ɪz sɛldəm dʌn, haʊɛvɝ, əz nʌθɪŋ stɑps ən ədʒɑ fɹəm ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə seɪm sɪɾɝ əɹ sɪɾɝz ɪksɛpt ə kʌstəm ðət sɪstɝz nɑt sɝv əɡɛn ɪn ðə hɔl æftɝ livɪŋ ɪt. əz ən ɪndəkeɪʃən ə haʊ sɪɹiəs sətʃ ə kɔl fəɹ ə mæs ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən wəd bi, ɪts ɹɪlaɪəbli bɪliv ðəɾ ɪts hæpən ɪɡzækli fɔɹ taɪmz ɪn ðə mɔɹ ðən θɹi-θaʊzənd-jɪɹ hɪstɝi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðət waɪl tu ʌv ðoʊz ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn ðə səlɛkʃən ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝli, əɹ nɪɹli, nu hɔl, ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən ən ɛɡzaɪl ə ði æmɪɝlɪn ɪnvɑlvd.

Hall of the Tower, the: The legislative body of the Aes Sedai, traditionally consisting of three Sitters in the Hall from each of the seven Ajahs. At present, there is a Hall sitting in the White Tower, which contains no Sitters for the Blue, and a Hall among those Aes Sedai who oppose Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan. This rebel Hall contains no Red Sitters. While the Amyrlin Seat is by law the absolute power in the White Tower, in fact her power has always depended on how well she could lead, manage or intimidate the Hall, as there are many ways that the Hall can balk any Amyrlin's plans. There are two levels of agreement that may be required for items to pass the Hall, the lesser consensus and the greater consensus. The greater consensus requires that every sister who is present must stand, and that a minimum of eleven Sitters be present; the presence of at least one Sitter from each Ajah is also required, except when the matter before the Hall is the removal of an Amyrlin or Keeper, in which case the Ajah from which she was raised will not be informed of the vote until after it has been taken. The lesser consensus also requires a quorum of eleven Sitters, but only two-thirds of those present need stand for an item to pass. Another difference is that there is no requirement for all Ajahs to be represented in the lesser consensus except in the case of a declaration of war by the White Tower, one of several matters left to the lesser consensus which many might think would require the greater. The Amyrlin Seat may call for any Sitter to resign her chair, or indeed for all to, and that call must be heeded. This is seldom done, however, as nothing stops an Ajah from returning the same Sitter or Sitters except a custom that sisters not serve again in the Hall after leaving it. As an indication of how serious such a call for a mass resignation would be, it is reliably believed that it has happened exactly four times in the more than three-thousand-year history of the White Tower, and that while two of those resulted in the selection of an entirely, or nearly, new Hall, the other two resulted in the resignation and exile of the Amyrlin involved.

hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ (vɑ-lɪɹ): ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi əbdʒɛkt ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, ɪt kən kɔl bæk dɛd hɪɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. ə nu hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn əz bɪn kɔld, ən swɔɹn hʌntɝz fəɹ ðə hɔɹn kən naʊ bi faʊn ɪn mɛni neɪʃənz. fju ivən əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ ðət ðə hɔɹn əz æktʃəli  bɪn faʊn ən juzd, əɹ ɪts ɪz naʊ hɪɾən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Horn of Valere (vah-LEER): The legendary object of the Great Hunt of the Horn, it can call back dead heroes from the grave to fight against the Shadow. A new Hunt of the Horn has been called, and sworn Hunters for the Horn can now be found in many nations. Few even among Aes Sedai know that the Horn has actually been found and used, or that it is now hidden in the White Tower.

ɪljən (ɪl-li-æn): ə ɡɹeɪt pɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðə neɪʃən ə ðə seɪm neɪm. ən eɪntʃən ɛnəmi ʌv tɛɹ. ðə bænɝ ʌv ɪljən ɪz naɪn ɡoʊldən biz ɑn ə fild ʌv ɡɹin.

Illian (IHL-lee-an): A great port on the Sea of Storms, capital city of the nation of the same name. An ancient enemy of Tear. The banner of Illian is nine golden bees on a field of green.

dʒulɪn sændɑɹ (dʒaɪ-lɪn sæn-dɑɹ): ə θif-kætʃɝ fɹəm tɛɹ. ə mæn ɪn lʌv wɪð pɝhæps ðə vɛɹi læst wʊmən i wəɾ ɛvɝ əv θɔɾ i kəd bi.

Juilin Sandar (JUY-lihn sahn-DAHR): A thief-catcher from Tear. A man in love with perhaps the very last woman he would ever have thought he could be.

lɛŋθ, junəts ʌv: tɛn ɪntʃəz ikwəlz wʌn fʊt; θɹi fiɾ ikwəlz wʌn peɪs; tu peɪsɪz ikwəlz wʌn spæn; wʌnθaʊzən spænz ikwəlz wʌn maɪl; fɔɹ maɪlz ikwəlz wʌn liɡ.

length, units of: 10 inches = 1 foot; 3 feet = 1 pace; 2 paces = 1 span; 1000 spans = 1 mile; 4 miles = 1 league.

lini (lɪn-ni): tʃaɪldhʊd nɝs tə ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn, ən bɪfɔɹ əɹ tə ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ, mɔɹɡeɪs, əz wɛl əz tə mɔɹɡeɪsəz mʌðɝ. ə wʊmən ə væst ɪnɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ, kənsɪɾɝəbəl pɝsɛpʃən, ən ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni seɪɪŋz, hu hæz nɛvɝ kwaɪɾ ədmɪɾəd ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz əz ɡɹoʊn ʌp kəmplitli.

Lini (LIHN-nee): Childhood nurse to the Lady Elayne, and before her to Elayne's mother, Morgase, as well as to Morgase's mother. A woman of vast inner strength, considerable perception, and a great many sayings, who has never quite admitted that any of her charges has grown up completely.

lɪŋkɪŋ: ði əbɪləɾi ʌv wɪmən u kən tʃænəl tə kəmbaɪn ðɛɹ floʊz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. waɪl ðə kəmbaɪn floʊ ɪz nɑɾ əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðə sʌm toʊɾəl ə ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl floʊz, ɪts dɝɛktəd baɪ ðə pɝsən u lidz ðə lɪŋk ən kən bi juz mʌtʃ mɔɹ pɹɪsaɪsli ən tə fɑɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɪfɛk ðən ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl floʊz kəd bi. mɛn kænɑt lɪŋk ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz wɪθaʊt ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ə wʊmən əɹ wɪmən ɪn ðə sɝkəl. ɛntɝɪŋ ə lɪŋk ɪz nɔɹməli ə vɑləntɛɹi ækt, ɹikwaɪɝɪŋ ət list əkwiɛsəns, bʌɾ ʌndɝ sɝɾən sɝkəmstænsəz, ə səfɪʃən sɝkəl ɔlɹɛɾi fɔɹm kən bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ wʊmən fɔɹsəbli ɪndə ðə sɝkəl əz lɔŋ əz noʊ mæn ɪz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. ɪnsəfɑɹ əz ɪz noʊn, ə mæn kænɑt bi fɔɹst ɪndə ə sɝkəl, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɑɹdʒ. ʌp tə θɝtin wɪmən kən lɪŋk wɪθaʊt ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ə mæn. wɪð ði ədɪʃən ʌv wʌn mæn, ðə sɝkəl kən ɪnkɹis tə twɛnti-sɪks wɪmən. tu mɛn kən teɪk ðə sɝkəl tə ɪnklud fɔɹɾi-θɹi wɪmən, ən soʊ ɑn əntɪl ðə lɪməɾ ə sɪks mɛn ən sɪksti-sɪks wɪmən ɪz ɹitʃt. ðəɹ ɑɹ lɪŋks ðəɾ ɪnklud mɔɹ mɛn ən fjuɝ wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪksɛpt ɪn ðə lɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌn mæn ən wʌn wʊmən, tu mɛn ən wʌn wʊmən əɹ tu mɛn ən tu wɪmən, ðəɹ mʌst ɔlweɪz bi ət list wʌn mɔɹ wʊmən ɪn ðə sɝkəl ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛn. ɪn moʊst sɝkəlz, iðɝ ə mæn əɹ ə wʊmən kən kəntʃɹoʊl ðə lɪŋk, bʌɾ ə mæn mʌs kəntʃɹoʊl ɪn ðə sɝkəl ə sɛvənti-tu əz wɛl əz ɪn mɪkst sɝkəlz ə fjuɝ ðən θɝtin bʌt mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ. ɔlðoʊ mɛn ɑɹ ɪn dʒɛnɝəl stʃɹɔŋɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ðən wɪmən, ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst sɝkəlz ɑɹ ðoʊz wɪtʃ kənteɪn əz nɪɹ əz pɑsəbəl tə ikwəl nʌmbɝz ə mɛn ən wɪmən.

linking: The ability of women who can channel to combine their flows of the One Power. While the combined flow is not as great as the sum total of the individual flows, it is directed by the person who leads the link and can be used much more precisely and to far greater effect than the individual flows could be. Men cannot link their abilities without the presence of a woman or women in the circle. Entering a link is normally a voluntary act, requiring at least acquiesence, but under certain circumstances, a sufficent circle already formed can bring another woman forcibly into the circle as long as no man is part of it. Insofar as is known, a man cannot be forced into a circle, no matter how large. Up to thirteen women can link without the presence of a man. With the addition of one man, the circle can increase to twenty-six women. Two men can take the circle to include forty-three women, and so on until the limit of six men and sixty-six women is reached. There are links that include more men and fewer women, but except in the linking of one man and one woman, two men and one woman or two men and two women, there must always be at least one more woman in the circle than there are men. In most circles, either a man or a woman can control the link, but a man must control in the circle of seventy-two as well as in mixed circles of fewer than thirteen but more than four. Although men are in general stronger in the Power than women, the strongest circles are those which contain as near as possible to equal numbers of men and women.

lɑɡən əblɝ (loʊ-ɡeɪn): bɔɹn naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntitu ni ɪn ɡildən, wʌns kleɪm tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. kæptʃɝɾ æftɝ kæɹiɪŋ wɔɹ əkɹɔs ɡildən, ɔltɑɹə ən mʊɹændi, hi wɑz teɪkən tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən dʒɛntəld, leɪɾɝ ɪskeɪpɪŋ ɪn ðə kənfjuʒən æftɝ sɪuən sɑntʃ wɑz dɪpoʊzd. ði æksədɛntəl ɹɛstɝeɪʃən ə hɪz əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl wɑz ðə fɝst ɪndəkeɪʃən ðət sətʃ ə lɔs wɑz nɑt pɝmənənt. kənfaɪn æftɝ ɪz hilɪŋ, hi ɪskeɪpt əɡɛn, ən ɪz pɹɛzənt wɛɹəbaʊts ɑɹ ənnoʊn. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɛntəlɪŋ; stɪlɪŋ.

Logain Ablar (loh-GAIN): Born 972 NE in Ghealdan, once claimed to be the Dragon Reborn. Captured after carrying war across Ghealdan, Altara and Murandy, he was taken to the White Tower and gentled, later escaping in the confusion after Siuan Sanche was deposed. The accidental restoration of his ability to channel was the first indication that such a loss was not permanent. Confined after his Healing, he escaped again, and his present whereabouts are unknown. See also gentling; stilling.

min (meɪ-ɛn): sɪɾi-steɪt ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, hɛmd ɪn ən hɪstɔɹɪkəli əpɹɛs baɪ tɛɹ. ðə ɹulɝ ə min ɪz staɪl ðə fɝst, wɪtʃ taɪɾəl wɑz wʌns ðə fɝs lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi; fɝsts kleɪm tə bi dɪsɛndəns ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ðə bænɝ ə min ɪz ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪɾ ɑn ə fild ə blu.

Mayene (may-EHN): City-state on the Sea of Storms, hemmed in and historically oppressed by Tear. The ruler of Mayene is styled the First, which title was once the First Lord or Lady; Firsts claim to be descendants of Artur Hawkwing.
