The banner of Mayene is a golden hawk in flight on a field of blue.

mæzɹim teɪm (-ɹɪm tɑ-im): ə mæn u ɹeɪz hævək ɪn sɑldɑiə əntɪl i wɑz dɪfiɾəd ən kæptʃɝd, ɔlðoʊ hi leɪɾɝ ɪskeɪpt, əpɛɹənli wɪð ði eɪɾ ə səm ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz. nɑɾ oʊnli eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, bʌɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ, hiz naʊ ðə l (mækeɪl; "liɾɝ," ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ) ʌv ði æʃəmən. si ɔlsoʊ æʃəmən.

Mazrim Taim (MAHZ-rihm tah-EEM): A man who raised havoc in Saldaea until he was defeated and captured, although he later escaped, apparently with the aid of some of his followers. Not only able to channel, but of great strength, he is now the M'Hael (MA'kHAIL; "leader," in the Old Tongue) of the Asha'man. See also Asha'man.

məleɪn (mɛ-leɪn): eɪ waɪz wʌn ə ði ɪɹæd sɛpt ʌv ɡoʊʃin il. ə dʒɹimwɔkɝ. mɑɾɝətli stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ. mɛɹid tə beɪl (beɪl), klæn tʃif ə ðə ɡoʊʃin. sɪstɝ-waɪf tə dɔɹinhə (dɔɹ-ɪn-dɑ), ɹuf-mɪstʃɹəs ə smoʊk spɹɪŋz hoʊld.

Melaine (meh-LAYN): A Wise One of the Jhirad sept of Goshien Aiel. A dreamwalker. Moderately strong in the One Power. Married to Bael (BAYL), clan chief of the Goshien. Sister-wife to Dorindha (dohr-IHN-dah), roof-mistress of Smoke Springs Hold.

mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd (mwɑ-ɹeɪn dæm-oʊ-dʒɹɛd): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ, bɔɹn ɪndə ðə ðɛn-ɹeɪnɪŋ haʊs ə kɛɹhin, hu vænɪʃt ɪndə ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn kɛɹhin waɪl bæɾəlɪŋ lænfɝ, əpɛɹənli kɪlɪŋ boʊθ hɝsɛlf ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən. sɪns ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi loʊkeɪɾəd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən kɪl ðə fɔɹseɪkən bɛləl, ʃiz ɔlɹɛɾi lʊkt əpɑn əz wʌn ə ðoʊz nɪɹ-mɪθəkəl sɪstɝz u ɑɹ hɛld əz lɛdʒəndɛɹi hɪɹoʊz. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹseɪkən.

Moiraine Damodred (mwah-RAIN DAHM-oh-drehd): An Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah, born into the then-reigning House of Cairhien, who vanished into a ter'angreal in Cairhien while battling Lanfear, apparently killing both herself and the Forsaken. Since she had already located the Dragon Reborn and killed the Forsaken Be'lal, she is already looked upon as one of those near-mythical sisters who are held as legendary heroes. See also Forsaken.

mɔɹɡeɪs (mʊɹ-ɡeɪz): baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd. naʊ ɪn ɛɡzaɪl ən bɪliv dɛd, mɝɾɝd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, əɹ soʊ mɛni θɪŋk. hɝ saɪn ɪz θɹi ɡoʊldən kiz. ðə saɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkən ɪz ə sɪlvɝ kistoʊn.

Morgase (moor-GAYZ): By the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of House Trakand. Now in exile and believed dead, murdered by the Dragon Reborn, or so many think. Her sign is three golden keys. The sign of House Trakand is a silver keystone.

nɪɹ-sɪstɝ; nɪɹ-bɹʌðɝ: il kɪnʃɪp tɝmz minɪŋ fɹɛnz əz kloʊs əz fɝst-sɪstɝz əɹ fɝst-bɹʌðɝz. nɪɹ-sɪstɝz ɔfən ədɑpt wʌn ənʌðɝ fɔɹməli əz fɝst-sɪstɝz ɪn ən ɪlæbɹət sɛɹəmoʊni kæɹiɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ waɪz wʌnz, æftɝ wɪtʃ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz baɪ ʌðɝ il əz tʃɹuli bɔɹn twɪnz, ðoʊ ə pɛɹ ə twɪnz wɪð tu mʌðɝz. nɪɹ-bɹʌðɝz ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ də ðɪs.

near-sister; near-brother: Aiel kinship terms meaning friends as close as first-sisters or first-brothers. Near-sisters often adopt one another formally as first-sisters in an elaborate ceremony carried out before Wise Ones, after which they are recognized by other Aiel as truly born twins, though a pair of twins with two mothers. Near-brothers almost never do this.

oʊðz, θɹi: ði oʊðz teɪkən baɪ ən æksɛptɪɾ ɑn biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. spoʊkən waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət meɪks oʊðz baɪndɪŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ: (wʌn) tə spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. (tu) tə meɪk noʊ wɛpən wɪð wɪtʃ wʌn mæn meɪ kɪl ənʌðɝ. (θɹi) nɛvɝ tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ɪksɛpt əɡɛns dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ ʃædoʊ-spɑn, əɹ ɪn ðə læst ɪkstʃɹim ə dɪfɛns ə hɝ oʊn laɪf, əɹ ðəɾ ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝ əɹ ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə sɛkən oʊθ wɑz ðə fɝst ədɑptəɾ æftɝ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ðə fɝst oʊθ, waɪl hɛl tə ðə lɛɾɝ, ɪz ɔfən sɝkəmvɛntɪd baɪ kɛɹfəl spikɪŋ. ɪts bɪliv ðət ðə læs tu ɑɹ ɪnvaɪələbəl.

Oaths, Three: The oaths taken by an Accepted on being raised to Aes Sedai. Spoken while holding the Oath Rod, a ter'angreal that makes oaths binding. They are: (1) To speak no word that is not true. (2) To make no weapon with which one man may kill another. (3) Never to use the One Power as a weapon except against Darkfriends or Shadow-spawn, or in the last extreme of defense of her own life, or that of her Warder or another Aes Sedai. The second oath was the first adopted after the War of the Shadow. The first oath, while held to the letter, is often circumvented by careful speaking. It is believed that the last two are inviolable.

oʊl tʌŋ: ðə læŋɡwədʒ spoʊkən dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɪts dʒɛnɝəli ɪkspɛktəd ðət noʊbəlz ən ði ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd kən spik ɪt, bʌt moʊst æktʃəli  noʊ oʊnli ə fju wɝdz. tʃɹænzleɪʃən ɪz ɔfən dɪfəkəlt, ɪts ɪz ə læŋɡwədʒ keɪpəbəl ə mɛni sʌɾəli dɪfɹən minɪŋz. si ɔlsoʊ eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Old Tongue: The language spoken during the Age of Legends. It is generally expected that nobles and the educated can speak it, but most actually know only a few words. Translation is often difficult, as it is a language capable of many subtly different meanings. See also Age of Legends.

pdən feɪn (pæd-æn feɪn): wʌns ə pɛdlɝ tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, hi wɑz tʃɹænsfɔɹmd ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, nɑɾ oʊnli tə ɛneɪbəl ɪm tə faɪn ðə jʌŋ mæn u wəd bɪkʌm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ə haʊn faɪnz pɹeɪ fəɹ ðə hʌntɝ, bʌt tə ɪnɡɹeɪn ðə nid tə faɪn hɪm. ðə peɪn ə ðɪs tʃɹænsfɝmeɪʃən ɪndust ɪn feɪn ə heɪtʃɹəd boʊθ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ə ɹænd ælθɹ. waɪl fɑloʊɪŋ ælθɹ, hi ɪnkaʊntɝd ðə tʃɹæp soʊl ə mɔɹɾɪθ ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ən ðɪs soʊl tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk feɪnz bɑɾi. kəz ʌv wʌt hæd bɪn meɪɾ ə feɪn, ðoʊ, ðə ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ən əmælɡəmeɪʃən ðət wɑz moʊsli feɪn ən ðəɾ əz əbɪləɾiz bɪɑnd wʌɾ iðɝ mæn hæɾ ɝɪdʒənəli, ðoʊ feɪn dʌz nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn əm fʊli jɛt. moʊs mɛn fil fɪɹ əɾ ə mɹdʒɹɑlz aɪləs ɡeɪz; mɹdʒɹɑl fil fɪɹ ət feɪnz ɡeɪz.

Padan Fain (PAD-an FAIN): Once a peddler trading into the Two Rivers, and a Darkfriend, he was transformed at Shayol Ghul, not only to enable him to find the young man who would become the Dragon Reborn as a hound finds prey for the hunter, but to ingrain the need to find him. The pain of this transformation induced in Fain a hatred both of the Dark One and of Rand al'Thor. While following al'Thor, he encountered the trapped soul of Mordeth in Shadar Logoth, and this soul tried to take Fain's body. Because of what had been made of Fain, though, the result was an amalgamation that was mostly Fain and that has abilities beyond what either man had originally, though Fain does not understand them fully yet. Most men feel fear at a Myrddraal's eyeless gaze; Myrddraal feel fear at Fain's gaze.

pɹɑfət, ðə: mɔɹ ɪlæbɹətli, ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. taɪɾəl kleɪm baɪ mæsimə dɑɡɝ, ə wʌntaɪm ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ, hu pɹitʃɪz ðə ɹibɝθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hiz ətʃivd ə ɡɹeɪt fɑloʊɪŋ ɪn ɡildən ən nɔɹðɝn ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ɪn pɑɹt kəz ə spɹɛɾɪŋ nɑlədʒ ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən əz ɪndid bɪn ɹibɔɹn ən ɪn pɑɹt kəz ə ði ɪkstʃɹim bɹutæləɾi hɪz fɑloʊɝz vɪzət nɑɾ oʊnli ɑn ɛniwʌn u ɹəfjuzəz tə æknɑlɪdʒ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌɾ ɑn ðoʊz u ɹəfjuz tə æknɑlɪdʒ ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə pɹɑfəɾ əz ðə hæn ən vɔɪs ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Prophet, the: More elaborately, the Prophet of the Lord Dragon. Title claimed by Masema Dagar, a onetime Shienaran soldier, who preaches the rebirth of the Dragon Reborn. He has achieved a great following in Ghealdan and northern Amadicia, in part because of spreading knowledge that the Dragon has indeed been Reborn and in part because of the extreme brutality his followers visit not only on anyone who refuses to acknowledge the Dragon Reborn, but on those who refuse to acknowledge the authority of the Prophet as the hand and voice of the Dragon Reborn.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ tə dɪskʌvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən ənkʌvɝ dɑɹk-fɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mænɝ ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ðeɪ ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, ðə hæn ðət dɪɡz aʊt tʃɹuθ, ən ət taɪmz ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪz ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, hu sɪts ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd. ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə blʌd-ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. Avowed purposes are to discover the truth in disputations and uncover Dark-friends. In the search for truth and the Light, their normal method of inquiry is torture; their normal manner that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. They refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light, the Hand that digs out truth, and at times act as if they were entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. The head of the Questioners is the High Inquisitor, who sits on the Council of the Anointed. Their sign is a blood-red shepherd's crook. See also Children of the Light.

ɹɪɾiən (ɹʌaɪ-di-æn): ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi, ði oʊnli wʌn ɪn ði il weɪst ən toʊɾəli ənnoʊn tə ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld. əbændən fəɹ nɪɹli θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz. wʌns mɛn əmʌŋ ði il wɝ əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ɹɪɾiən oʊnli wʌns, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə bi tɛstəɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt tɛɹæŋɡɹil fəɹ fɪtnəs tə bɪkʌm klæn tʃif (oʊnli wʌn ɪn θɹi sɝvaɪvd), ən wɪmən oʊnli twaɪs, fəɹ tɛstɪŋ tə bɪkʌm waɪz wʌnz, ðə sɛkən taɪm ɪn ðə seɪm tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðoʊ wɪð ə kənsɪɾɝəbli haɪɝ sɝvaɪvəl ɹeɪt ðən ðə mɛn. naʊ ðə sɪɾi ɪz ɪnhæbəɾəd əɡɛn, baɪ il, ən ə ɡɹeɪt leɪk ɑkjəpaɪz wʌn ɛn ə ðə væli ʌv ɹɪɾiən, fɛd baɪ ən ʌndɝɡɹaʊn oʊʃən ə fɹɛʃ wɔɾɝ ən ɪn tɝn fiɾɪŋ ði oʊnli ɹɪvɝ ɪn ðə weɪst.

Rhuidean (RHUY-dee-ahn): A great city, the only one in the Aiel Waste and totally unknown to the outside world. Abandoned for nearly three thousand years. Once men among the Aiel were allowed to enter Rhuidean only once, in order to be tested inside a great ter'angreal for fitness to become clan chief (only one in three survived), and women only twice, for testing to become Wise Ones, the second time in the same ter'angreal, though with a considerably higher survival rate than the men. Now the city is inhabited again, by Aiel, and a great lake occupies one end of the valley of Rhuidean, fed by an underground ocean of fresh water and in turn feeding the only river in the Waste.

sɑŋɡɹil (sɑ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðəɾ əlaʊ tʃænəlɪŋ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən ɪz ʌðɝwaɪz pɑsəbəl əɹ seɪf. ə sɑŋɡɹil ɪz sɪməlɝ tə, bʌt mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðæn, ən æŋɡɹil. ði əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðət kən bi wildɪd wɪð ə sɑŋɡɹil kəmpɛɹz tə ði əmaʊn ðət kən bi hændəld wɪð ən æŋɡɹil əz ðə paʊɝ wildɪd wɪð ði eɪɾ ʌv ən æŋɡɹil dʌz tə ði əmaʊn ðət kən bi hændəld əneɪɾɪd. ðə meɪkɪŋ ə ðɛm ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. əz wɪð æŋɡɹil, ðəɹ ɑɹ meɪl ən fimeɪl sɑŋɡɹil. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ɹɪmeɪn, fɑɹ fjuɝ ivən ðən æŋɡɹil.

sa'angreal (SAH-ahn-GREE-ahl): Remnants of the Age of Legends that allow channeling much more of the One Power than is otherwise possible or safe. A sa'angreal is similar to, but more powerful than, an angreal. The amount of the Power that can be wielded with a sa'angreal compares to the amount that can be handled with an angreal as the Power wielded with the aid of an angreal does to the amount that can be handled unaided. The making of them is no longer known. As with angreal, there are male and female sa'angreal. Only a handful remain, far fewer even than angreal.

si foʊk, ðə: mɔɹ pɹɑpɝli, ði æθɑn maɪɹ (ɑ-θɑ-æn mi-ɛɹ), ðə pipəl ə ðə si. ðeɪ lɪv moʊst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɪps ən stʃɹɔŋli dɪslaɪk ɡoʊɪŋ ɛni dɪstəns fɹəm ði oʊʃən. ɹɛləɾɪvli lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn ə ðɛɹ kʌstəmz, ɡɪvɪŋ ɹaɪz tə ən ɛɹ ʌv ɪɡzɑɾɪk mɪstɝi ən ɔfən tə fænsɪfəl teɪlz. moʊst sibɔɹn tʃɹeɪɾ ɪz kæɹid baɪ si foʊk ʃɪps, wɪtʃ ɪnklud ðə fæstəs baɪ fɑɹ ən moʊst ə ðə lɑɹdʒəst, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ kənsɪɾɝd baɪ ði ɪnhæbəɾənts ə pɔɹt sɪɾiz tə bi bɑɹɡɪnɝz u aʊtstʃɹɪp ðə mɔɹ waɪdli noʊn dəmɑni. əz sɝvaɪvəl ət si ɔfən dɪpɛnz ɑn ɪnstən oʊbiɾiəns, ɪt ʃəd bi noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðət ði æθɑn maɪɹ stɪk stʃɹɪkli tə ðɛɹ haɪɝɑɹki, ðoʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ fluɪɾətiz ət səm pɔɪns. ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə numɝəs klænz, boʊθ lɑɹdʒ ən smɔl, itʃ hɛɾəd baɪ ə weɪvməstʃɹəs. bɪloʊ hɝ ɑɹ ðə seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz, ðə ʃɪps' kæptənz ə ðə klæn. eɪ weɪvməstʃɹəs əz væst əθɔɹəɾi, jɛt ʃiz ɪlɛktəd tə ðət pəzɪʃən baɪ ðə twɛlv sinjɝ klæn seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz, hu ɑɹ ɹəfɝd tə əz ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ðət klæn, ən ʃi kən bi ɹimuv baɪ ði ɔɹɾɝ ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps əz ə lɛvəl ʌv əθɔɹəɾi ɛni ʃɔɹbaʊn kɪŋ əɹ kwin wəɾ ɛnvi, jɛt ʃi ɔlsoʊ ɪz ɪlɛktəd, fəɹ laɪf, baɪ junænəməs voʊɾ ə ðə twɛlv sinjɝ weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz, hu ɑɹ kɔl ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ. (ðə tɝm "ðə fɝs twɛlv" ɪz ɔlsoʊ juz fəɹ ðə twɛlv sinjɝ weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz əɹ seɪlmɪs-tʃɹɛsɪz pɹɛzən ɪn ɛni ɡæðɝɪŋ.) ðə pəzɪʃən ə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz ɪz hɛl baɪ ə mæn u meɪ əɹ meɪ nɑt bi ðə hʌzbən ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. hɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz ɑɹ ðə dɪfɛns ən ðə tʃɹeɪɾ ə ðə si foʊk, ən bɪloʊ hɪm ɑɹ ðə sɔɹdmæstɝz ʌv weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz ən ðə kɑɹɡəmæstɝz ə seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz, hu hoʊld laɪk pəzɪʃənz ən duɾiz; fəɹ itʃ ə ðɛm, ɛni əθɔɹəɾi aʊtsaɪd ðiz ɛɹiəz ɪz hɛld oʊnli əz dɛləɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə wʊmən i sɝvz. wɛɹ ɛni vɛsəl seɪlz ən wən ɪz ɔlweɪz ʌp tə ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs, bʌt sɪns tʃɹeɪɾ ən fɪnænsɪz ɑɹ toʊɾəli ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə kɑɹɡəmæstɝ (ɔɹ, ət haɪɝ lɛvəlz, ʌv ðə sɔɹdmæstɝ əɹ ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz), ə kloʊs dɪɡɹi ʌv koʊɑpɝeɪʃən ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd. ɛvɹi si foʊk vɛsəl, haʊɛvɝ smɔl, ən ɔlsoʊ ɛvɹi weɪvməstʃɹəs, hæz ə wɪndfɪndɝ, ə wʊmən u ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ən skɪld ɪn wivɪŋ ðə wɪnz, əz ði æθɑn maɪɹ kɔl ðə mənɪpjəleɪʃən ʌv wɛðɝ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps əz əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz tə ðə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz, hu ɪn tɝn əv əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ wɪndfɪndɝz tə ðə seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz ə ðɛɹ klænz. wʌn pɪkjuliɛɹəɾi ʌv ðə si foʊk ɪz ðəɾ ɔl mʌs bɪɡɪn ət ðə vɛɹi loʊəst ɹæŋk ən wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ ʌp, ən ðəɾ ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps kən bi dɪmoʊɾɪd baɪ ðoʊz əbʌv, ivən tə ðə vɛɹi bɑɾəm əɡɛn ɪn ɪkstʃɹim ɪnstənsəz.

Sea Folk, the: More properly, the Atha'an Miere (AH-thah-AHN MEE-air), the People of the Sea. They live most of their lives on their ships and strongly dislike going any distance from the ocean. Relatively little is known of their customs, giving rise to an air of exotic mystery and often to fanciful tales. Most seaborne trade is carried by Sea Folk ships, which include the fastest by far and most of the largest, and they are considered by the inhabitants of port cities to be bargainers who outstrip the more widely known Domani. As survival at sea often depends on instant obedience, it should be no surprise that the Atha'an Miere stick strictly to their hierarchy, though there are surprising fluidities at some points. The Atha'an Miere are divided into numerous clans, both large and small, each headed by a Wavemistress. Below her are the Sailmistresses, the ships' captains of the clan. A Wavemistress has vast authority, yet she is elected to that position by the twelve senior clan Sailmistresses, who are referred to as the First Twelve of that clan, and she can be removed by the order of the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere. The Mistress of the Ships has a level of authority any shorebound king or queen would envy, yet she also is elected, for life, by unanimous vote of the twelve senior Wavemistresses, who are called the First Twelve of the Atha'an Miere. (The term "the First Twelve" is also used for the twelve senior Wavemistresses or Sailmis-tresses present in any gathering.) The position of Master of the Blades is held by a man who may or may not be the husband of the Mistress of the Ships. His responsibilities are the defense and the trade of the Sea Folk, and below him are the Swordmasters of Wavemistresses and the Cargomasters of Sailmistresses, who hold like positions and duties; for each of them, any authority outside these areas is held only as delegated by the woman he serves. Where any vessel sails and when is always up to the Sailmistress, but since trade and finances are totally in the hands of the Cargomaster (or, at higher levels, of the Swordmaster or the Master of the Blades), a close degree of cooperation is required. Every Sea Folk vessel, however small, and also every Wavemistress, has a Windfinder, a woman who is almost always able to channel and skilled in Weaving the Winds, as the Atha'an Miere call the manipulation of weather. The Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships has authority over the Windfinders to the Wavemistresses, who in turn have authority over Windfinders to the Sailmistresses of their clans. One peculiarity of the Sea Folk is that all must begin at the very lowest rank and work their way up, and that anyone other than the Mistress of the Ships can be demoted by those above, even to the very bottom again in extreme instances.

sintʃæn (ʃɔn-tʃæn): (wʌn) dɪsɛndəns ə ði ɑɹmiz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, hu kɑŋkɝd ðə lænz ðɛɹ. ðeɪ bɪliv ðəɾ ɛni wʊmən u kən tʃænəl mʌs bi kəntʃɹoʊl fəɹ ðə seɪfti ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ən ɛni mæn u kən tʃænəl mʌs bi kɪl fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən. (tu) ðə læn fɹəm wɪtʃ ðə ʃɔn-tʃæn kʌm.

Seanchan (SHAWN-CHAN): (1) Descendants of the armies Artur Hawkwing sent across the Aryth Ocean, who conquered the lands there. They believe that any woman who can channel must be controlled for the safety of everyone else, and any man who can channel must be killed for the same reason. (2) The land from which the Sean-chan come.

ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl (ʃeɪ-əl ɡul): ə maʊntən ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz, bɪɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt. saɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən.

Shayol Ghul (SHAY-ol GHOOL): A mountain in the Blasted Lands, beyond the Great Blight. Site of the Dark One's prison.

sɪstɝ-waɪf: il kɪnʃɪp tɝm. il wɪmən u ɑɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝz əɹ fɝst-sɪstɝz, ən u dɪskʌvɝ ðeɪ lʌv ðə seɪm mæn əɹ sɪmpli də nɑt wɑn ə mæn tə kʌm bɪtwin ðɛm, wɪl boʊθ mɛɹi hɪm, ðʌs bɪkʌmɪŋ sɪstɝ-waɪvz. wɪmən u lʌv ðə seɪm mæn wɪl səmtaɪmz tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ðeɪ kən bɪkʌm nɪɹ-sɪstɝz ən ədɑptəd fɝst-sɪstɝz, ə fɝst stɛp tə bɪkʌmɪŋ sɪstɝ-waɪvz. ən il mæn feɪst wɪð ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən əz ðə tʃɔɪs ə mɛɹiɪŋ boʊθ wɪmən əɹ niðɝ; ɪf hiz ə waɪf u dɪsaɪdz tə teɪk ə sɪstɝ-waɪf, hi faɪnz hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə sɛkənd waɪf.

sister-wife: Aiel kinship term. Aiel women who are near-sisters or first-sisters, and who discover they love the same man or simply do not want a man to come between them, will both marry him, thus becoming sister-wives. Women who love the same man will sometimes try to find out whether they can become near-sisters and adopted first-sisters, a first step to becoming sister-wives. An Aiel man faced with this situation has the choice of marrying both women or neither; if he has a wife who decides to take a sister-wife, he finds himself with a second wife.

sɪswaɪəmən: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ: "spɪɹz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən," wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ ɪmpləkeɪʃən ʌv oʊnɝʃɪp. ðə neɪm teɪkən baɪ ə ɡʊd mɛni mɛn əmʌŋ ði il, bʌt noʊ wɪmən. ðiz mɛn də nɑɾ æktʃəli  æknɑlɪdʒ ðə neɪm - nɔɹ də ɛni ʌðɝz, ɪn fækt - bʌt ðeɪ wɛɹ ə stʃɹɪp ə ɹɛd klɔθ waʊn ɝaʊn ðə fɔɹhɛd wɪð ə dɪsk, hæf blæk ən hæf waɪt, əbʌv ðə bɹaʊz. ɔlðoʊ ɡeɪʃeɪn nɔɹməli ɑɹ pɹoʊhɪbəɾəd fɹəm wɛɹɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ðət wəd bi wɔɹn baɪ ən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ, ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn əv teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ ðə hɛdbænd. si ɔlsoʊ ɡeɪʃeɪn.

siswai'aman: In the Old Tongue: "spears of the dragon," with a strong implication of ownership. The name taken by a good many men among the Aiel, but no women. These men do not actually acknowledge the name - nor do any others, in fact - but they wear a strip of red cloth wound around the forehead with a disc, half black and half white, above the brows. Although gai'shain normally are prohibited from wearing anything that would be worn by an algai'd'siswai, a large number of gai'shain have taken to wearing the headband. See also gai'shain.

sɔɹɪliə (soʊ-ɹɪ-li-ɑ): ðə waɪz wʌn ə ʃɛn hoʊld, ə dʒɹə tʃɑɝin. bɛɹli eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, ʃiz ɔlsoʊ ði oʊldəs lɪvɪŋ waɪz wʌn, ðoʊ nɑt baɪ əz mʌtʃ əz mɛni θɪŋk.

Sorilea (soh-rih-LEE-ah): The Wise One of Shende Hold, a Jarra Chareen. Barely able to channel, she is also the oldest living Wise One, though not by as much as many think.

spaɪn ə ðə wɝld: ə taʊɝɪŋ maʊntən ɹeɪnʒ, wɪð fju pæsəz, wɪtʃ sɛpɝeɪts ði il weɪs fɹəm ðə lænz tə ðə wɛst. ɔlsoʊ kɔl ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl.

Spine of the World: A towering mountain range, with few passes, which separates the Aiel Waste from the lands to the west. Also called the Dragonwall.

stɪlɪŋ: ðə ɹɪmuvəl ʌv ə wʊmənz əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. ə wʊmən u hæz bɪn stɪl kən sɛns bʌt nɑt tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. əfɪʃəli, stɪlɪŋ ɪz ðə ɹɪzʌlt ə tʃɹaɪəl ən sɛntəns fəɹ ə kɹaɪm, ən wɑz læs kæɹiɾ aʊɾ ɪn eɪthʌnʒɹədfɪftinaɪn ni. nɑvəsɪz əv ɔlweɪz bɪn ɹikwaɪɝd tə lɝn ðə neɪm ən kɹaɪmz ʌv ɔl wɪmən u hæv sʌfɝd dʒudɪʃəl stɪlɪŋ. wən ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ɪz lɔst æksədɛntəli, ɪts kɔl biɪŋ bɝn aʊt, ðoʊ "stɪlɪŋ" ɪz ɔfən juz fəɹ ðəɾ ɔlsoʊ. wɪmən u ɑɹ stɪld, haʊɛvɝ ɪɾ əkɝz, sɛldəm sɝvaɪv lɔŋ; ðeɪ sim tə sɪmpli ɡɪv ʌp ən daɪ ənlɛs ðeɪ faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə ɹipleɪs ði ɛmptinəs lɛf baɪ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. waɪl ɪts ɔlweɪz bɪn bɪliv ðət stɪlɪŋ wɑz pɝmənənt, leɪtli ə mɛθəɾ ə hilɪŋ ɪts bɪn dɪskʌvɝd, ðoʊ ðəɹ əpɪɹ tə bi lɪməts tə ðɪs wɪtʃ ɑɹ jɛt tə bi ɪksplɔɹd.

stilling: The removal of a woman's ability to channel. A woman who has been stilled can sense but not touch the True Source. Officially, stilling is the result of trial and sentence for a crime, and was last carried out in 859 NE. Novices have always been required to learn the name and crimes of all women who have suffered judicial stilling. When the ability to channel is lost accidentally, it is called being burned out, though "stilling" is often used for that also. Women who are stilled, however it occurs, seldom survive long; they seem to simply give up and die unless they find something to replace the emptiness left by the One Power. While it has always been believed that stilling was permanent, lately a method of Healing it has been discovered, though there appear to be limits to this which are yet to be explored.

stoʊn ə tɛɹ: ə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv tɛɹ, sɛd tə hæv bɪn meɪd wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ sun æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ətækt ən bɪsidʒd ʌnsəksɛsfəli kaʊnləs taɪmz, ɪt fɛl ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl naɪt tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd il, ðʌs fʊlfɪlɪŋ tu pɑɹts ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən.

Stone of Tear: A great fortress in the city of Tear, said to have been made with the One Power soon after the Breaking of the World. Attacked and besieged unsuccessfully countless times, it fell in a single night to the Dragon Reborn and a few hundred Aiel, thus fulfilling two parts of the Prophecies of the Dragon.

tæləns: əbɪləɾiz ɪn ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn spəsɪfɪk ɛɹiəz. æptətuɾ ɪn vɛɹiəs tæləns vɛɹiz waɪdli fɹəm ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl tə ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl ən ɪz sɛldəm ɹɪleɪɾɪd tə ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. ðəɹ ɑɹ meɪdʒɝ tæləns, ðə bɛst-noʊn ən moʊst waɪdspɹɛɾ ʌv wɪtʃ ɪz hilɪŋ. ʌðɝ ɪɡzæmpəlz ɑɹ klaʊd dænsɪŋ, ðə kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv wɛðɝ, ən ɝθ sɪŋɪŋ, wɪtʃ ɪnvɑlvz kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ muvməns ə ði ɝθ, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl pɹɪvɛntɪŋ, əɹ kɑzɪŋ, ɝθkweɪks əɹ ævələntʃɪz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlsoʊ maɪnɝ tæləns, sɛldəm ɡɪvən ə neɪm, sətʃ əz ði əbɪləɾi tə si tɑvɝən əɹ tə dupləkeɪt ðə tʃæns-twɪstɪŋ ɪfɛkt ə tɑvɝən, ðoʊ ɪn ə vɛɹi smɔl ən loʊkəlaɪzd ɛɹiə ɹɛɹli kʌvɝɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fju skwɛɹ fit. mɛni tæləns ɑɹ naʊ noʊn oʊnli baɪ ðɛɹ neɪmz ən səmtaɪmz veɪɡ dɪskɹɪpʃənz. sʌm, sətʃ əz tʃɹævlɪŋ (ði əbɪləɾi tə ʃɪft fɹəm wʌn pleɪs tə ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊt kɹɔsɪŋ ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ speɪs) ɑɹ oʊnli naʊ biɪŋ ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd. ʌðɝz, sətʃ əz fɔɹtɛlɪŋ (ði əbɪləɾi tə fɔɹtɛl fjutʃɝ ɪvɛns, bʌɾ ɪn ə dʒɛnɝəl weɪ), ən dɛlvɪŋ (ðə loʊkeɪʃən ʌv ɔɹz ən pɑsəbli ðɛɹ ɹɪmuvəl fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɔlðoʊ ðə tɝm ɪz naʊ ɔlsoʊ juz fəɹ ðə vɛɹiən ə hilɪŋ wɪtʃ ɪz juz tə ɪɡzæmɪn sʌmwʌnz hɛlθ ən fɪzɪkəl kəndɪʃən) ɑɹ faʊn ɹɛɹli. ənʌðɝ tælən lɔŋ θɔt lɔst ɪz dʒɹimɪŋ, ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ ðə dʒɹimɝz dʒɹimz tə fɔɹtɛl fjutʃɝ ɪvɛns ɪn mɔɹ spəsɪfɪk fæʃən ðən fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. səm dʒɹimɝz hæd ði əbɪləɾi tə ɛntɝ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ən (ɪɾ ɪz sɛd) ivən ʌðɝ pipəlz dʒɹimz. ðə læst æknɑlɪdʒ dʒɹimɝ pɹiviəsli wɑz kɔɹiənɪn nɪdil (koʊ-ɹi-æn-ɪn nɛ-di-ɑl), hu daɪɾ ɪn faɪvhʌnʒɹədtwɛntisɪks ni, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz naʊ ənʌðɝ.

Talents: Abilities in the use of the One Power in specific areas. Aptitude in various Talents varies widely from individual to individual and is seldom related to the strength of the individual's ability to channel. There are major Talents, the best-known and most widespread of which is Healing. Other examples are Cloud Dancing, the control of weather, and Earth Singing, which involves controlling movements of the earth, for example preventing, or causing, earthquakes or avalanches. There are also minor Talents, seldom given a name, such as the ability to see ta'veren or to duplicate the chance-twisting effect of ta'veren, though in a very small and localized area rarely covering more than a few square feet. Many Talents are now known only by their names and sometimes vague descriptions. Some, such as Traveling (the ability to shift from one place to another without crossing the intervening space) are only now being rediscovered. Others, such as Foretelling (the ability to foretell future events, but in a general way), and Delving (the location of ores and possibly their removal from the ground, although the term is now also used for the variant of Healing which is used to examine someone's health and physical condition) are found rarely. Another Talent long thought lost is Dreaming, interpreting the Dreamer's dreams to foretell future events in more specific fashion than Foretelling. Some Dreamers had the ability to enter Tel'aran'rhiod, the World of Dreams, and (it is said) even other people's dreams. The last acknowledged Dreamer previously was Corianin Nedeal (coh-ree-AHN-ihn neh-dee-AHL), who died in 526 NE, but there is now another.

tɑlænvɝ, mɑɹɾɪn (tæl-læn-vɔɹ, mɑɹ-tin): fɔɹmɝ ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnən ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz, hu lʌvz mɔɹɡeɪs mɔɹ ðən laɪf əɹ ɑnɝ. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɹɡeɪs.

Tallanvor, Martyn (TAL-lahn-vohr, mahr-TEEN): Former Guardsman-Lieutenant of the Queen's Guards, who loves Morgase more than life or honor. See also Morgase.

tɑvɝən (tɑ-vɪɹ-ɛn): ə pɝsən ɝaʊn hum ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ laɪf-θɹɛdz, pɝhæps ɔl laɪf-θɹɛdz. ðɪs wivɪŋ ɪz lɪɾəl ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt simz ɪn mɛni weɪz ən ɔltɝeɪʃən ə tʃæns; wʌt maɪt hæpən, bʌɾ oʊnli ɹɛɹli, dʌz. ði ɪfɛkt kən ət taɪmz bi kwaɪt loʊkəlaɪzd. sʌmwʌn ɪnfluəns baɪ ə tɑvɝən meɪ seɪ əɹ də wʌt ðeɪ wəɾ oʊnli hæv sɛɾ əɹ dʌn wʌn taɪm ɪn ə mɪljən ʌndɝ ðoʊz sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪvɛns əkɝ ə simɪŋ ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi, sətʃ əz ə tʃaɪl fɔlɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd fit fɹəm ə taʊɝ ənhɑɹmd. əɾ ʌðɝ taɪmz ði ɪfɛk simz tə ɪkstɛn tə ɪnfluənsɪŋ hɪstɝi ɪtsɛlf, ðoʊ ɔfən baɪ minz ə ðə loʊkəlaɪzd ɪfɛks. ðɪs, ɪts bɪlivd, ɪz ðə ɹil ɹizən ðət tɑvɝən ɑɹ bɔɹn, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ʃɪf hɪstɝi ən ɹɪstɔɹ ə bæləns tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil.

ta'veren (tah-VEER-ehn): A person around whom the Wheel of Time weaves all surrounding life-threads, perhaps ALL life-threads. This weaving is little understood except that it seems in many ways an alteration of chance; what might happen, but only rarely, does. The effect can at times be quite localized. Someone influenced by a ta'veren may say or do what they would only have said or done one time in a million under those circumstances. Events occur of seeming impossibility, such as a child falling a hundred feet from a tower unharmed. At other times the effect seems to extend to influencing history itself, though often by means of the localized effects. This, it is believed, is the real reason that ta'veren are born, in order to shift history and restore a balance to the turning of the Wheel.

tɛɹ (tɪɹ): ə neɪʃən ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ɔlsoʊ ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən, ə ɡɹeɪt sipɔɹt. ðə bænɝ ə tiɹ ɪz θɹi waɪt kɹɛsən munz slæntɪŋ əkɹɔs ə fil hæf ɹɛd, hæf ɡoʊld. si ɔlsoʊ stoʊn ə tiɹ.

Tear (TEER): A nation on the Sea of Storms. Also the capital city of that nation, a great seaport. The banner of Tear is three white crescent moons slanting across a field half red, half gold. See also Stone of Tear.

tɛɹæŋɡɹil (tɪɹ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðət juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ənlaɪk æŋɡɹil ən sɑŋɡɹil, itʃ tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz meɪd tə də ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ θɪŋ. səm tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɑɹ juz baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ði ɝɪdʒənəl pɝpəsəz ə mɛni ɑɹ ənnoʊn. səm ɹikwaɪɝ tʃænəlɪŋ, waɪl ʌðɝz meɪ bi juz baɪ ɛniwʌn. səm wɪl kɪl, əɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ʌv ɛni wʊmən u juzɪz ðɛm. laɪk æŋɡɹil ən sɑŋɡɹil, ðə meɪkɪŋ ə ðɛm əz bɪn lɔst sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ æŋɡɹil; sɑŋɡɹil.

ter'angreal (TEER-ahn-GREE-ahl): Remnants of the Age of Legends that use the One Power. Unlike angreal and sa'angreal, each ter'angreal was made to do a particular thing. Some ter'angreal are used by Aes Sedai, but the original purposes of many are unknown. Some require channeling, while others may be used by anyone. Some will kill, or destroy the ability to channel of any woman who uses them. Like angreal and sa'angreal, the making of them has been lost since the Breaking of the World. See also angreal; sa'angreal.

tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn (tɑm mɛɹ-ɹɪ-lɪn): ə nɑt-soʊ-sɪmpəl ɡlimən ən tʃɹævəlɝ.

Thom Merrilin (TOM MER-rih-lihn): A not-so-simple gleeman and traveler.

tɪŋkɝz: pɹɑpɝli, ðə tuætɑn (tu-ɑ-θɑ-æn), ɔlsoʊ kɔl ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl. ə wɑndɝɪŋ foʊk u fɑloʊ ə toʊɾəli pæsɪfɪs fəlɑsəfi kɔl ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif, wɪtʃ əlaʊz noʊ vaɪələns fəɹ ɛni ɹizən. tuætɑn u fɔl əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs bɪlif ɑɹ kɔld "ðə lɔst," ən ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ æknɑlɪdʒ baɪ ɛni ʌðɝz.

Tinkers: Properly, the Tuatha'an (too-AH-thah-AHN), also called the Traveling People. A wandering folk who follow a totally pacifist philosophy called the Way of the Leaf, which allows no violence for any reason. Tuatha'an who fall away from this belief are called "the Lost," and are no longer acknowledged by any others.

tʃɹikɪlɝz: dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ tɝm juz baɪ ði il fəɹ kɛɹhinɪn, əlɔŋ wɪð "oʊθbɹeɪkɝz." boʊθ ɹəfɝ tə kɪŋ leɪmənz kʌɾɪŋ daʊn ʌv ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə, ə ɡɪft fɹəm ði il, ən ækt wɪtʃ vaɪəleɪɾɪd ði oʊðz ɡɪvən ət ðə taɪm ðə ɡɪft wɑz ɡɪvən. tə ði il, boʊθ tɝmz ɹæŋk wɪð ðə wɝs ðəɾ ɛniwʌn kən bi kɔld. si ɔlsoʊ il wɔɹ.

treekillers: Disparaging term used by the Aiel for Cairhienin, along with "oathbreakers." Both refer to King Laman's cutting down of Avendoraldera, a gift from the Aiel, an act which violated the oaths given at the time the gift was given. To the Aiel, both terms rank with the worst that anyone can be called. See also Aiel War.

vɑldə, imən (vɑl-dɑ, eɪ-moʊn): ən ɪmpeɪʃən lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, ə mæn u bɪlivz jə kæn meɪk dɪnɝ wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ɛɡz ən səmtaɪmz ɪts nɛsəsɛɹi tə bɝn daʊn ðə bɑɹn tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə ɹæts. hi siz hɪmsɛlf əz ə pɹæɡməɾɪst, ən wɪl teɪk wʌtɛvɝ ædvæntɪdʒ ɔfɝz ɪtsɛlf. hiz ʃʊɹ ðət ɹænd ælθɹ ɪz oʊnli ə pʌpəɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən vɛɹi laɪkli kænɑɾ ivən tʃænəl. heɪtʃɹəɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz (wɪtʃ ə kɔɹs ɪnkluɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ) ɪz ðə sɛntʃɹəl pɪlɝ ə hɪz laɪf. si ɔlsoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Valda, Eamon (VAHL-dah, AY-mon): An impatient Lord Captain of the Children of the Light, a man who believes you can't make dinner without breaking eggs and sometimes it is necessary to burn down the barn to get rid of the rats. He sees himself as a pragmatist, and will take whatever advantage offers itself. He is sure that Rand al'Thor is only a puppet of the White Tower and very likely cannot even channel. Hatred of Darkfriends (which of course include Aes Sedai) is the central pillar of his life. See also Children of the Light.

wɔɹɾɝ: ə wɔɹiɝ bɑndəd tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ: baɪ ɪɾ i ɡeɪnz sətʃ ɡɪfs əz kwɪk hilɪŋ, ði əbɪləɾi tə ɡoʊ lɔŋ pɪɹiədz wɪθaʊt fud, wɔɾɝ, əɹ ɹɛst, ən ði əbɪləɾi tə sɛns ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɾ ə dɪstəns. wɔɹɾɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɛɹ sɝɾən fɪzɪkəl ən ɪmoʊʃənəl nɑlədʒ ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ θɹu ðə bɑnd. soʊ lɔŋ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ lɪvz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hum hiz bɑndəd noʊz hiz əlaɪv haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ əweɪ hi ɪz, ən wən i daɪz ʃɪl noʊ ðə moʊmən ən mænɝ ə hɪz dɛθ. waɪl moʊst ədʒəz bɪliv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ hæv wʌn wɔɹɾɝ bɑndəd tə hɝ əɾ ə taɪm, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɹəfjuzəz tə bɑn ɛni wɔɹɾɝz əɾ ɔl, ən ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ bɪlivz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bɑn əz mɛni əz ʃi wɪʃɪz. ɛθɪkəli ðə wɔɹɾɝ mʌst æksid tə ðə bɑndɪŋ vɑləntɛɹəli, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn noʊn tə hæpən əɡɛns ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɪl. wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪn fɹəm ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə kloʊsli hɛl sikɹət. baɪ ɔl noʊn hɪstɔɹɪkəl ɹɛkɝdz, wɔɹɾɝz əv ɔlweɪz bɪn mɛn, bʌt ɹisənli ə wʊmən əz bɪn bɑndəd, ɹɪvilɪŋ sɝɾən dɪfɝənsɪz ɪn ði ɪfɛks. si ɔlsoʊ bɝdʒɪt.

Warder: A warrior bonded to an Aes Sedai. The bonding is a thing of the One Power: by it he gains such gifts as quick healing, the ability to go long periods without food, water, or rest, and the ability to sense the taint of the Dark One at a distance. Warder and Aes Sedai share certain physical and emotional knowledge of one another through the bond. So long as a Warder lives, the Aes Sedai to whom he is bonded knows he is alive however far away he is, and when he dies she will know the moment and manner of his death. While most Ajahs believe an Aes Sedai may have one Warder bonded to her at a time, the Red Ajah refuses to bond any Warders at all, and the Green Ajah believes an Aes Sedai may bond as many as she wishes. Ethically the Warder must accede to the bonding voluntarily, but it has been known to happen against the Warder's will. What the Aes Sedai gain from the bonding is a closely held secret. By all known historical records, Warders have always been men, but recently a woman has been bonded, revealing certain differences in the effects. See also Birgitte.

weɪt, junəts ʌv: tɛn aʊnsəz ikwəlz wʌn paʊnd; tɛn paʊnz ikwəlz wʌn stoʊn; tɛn stoʊn ikwəlz wʌn hʌnʒɹədweɪt; tɛn hʌnʒɹədweɪt ikwəlz wʌn tʌn.

weight, units of: 10 ounces = 1 pound; 10 pounds = 1 stone; 10 stone = 1 hundredweight; 10 hundredweight = 1 ton.

waɪldɝ: ə wʊmən u hæz lɝn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑn əɹ oʊn; oʊnli wʌn ɪn fɔɹ sɝvaɪv ðɪs. sətʃ wɪmən juʒəwəli bɪl bæɹiɝz əɡɛns noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪts ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf ðiz kən bi bɹoʊkən daʊn, waɪldɝz ɑɹ fɹikwənli əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə tʃænlɝz. ðə tɝm ɪz ɔfən juzd ɪn dɝɑɡətɔɹi fæʃən.

wilder: A woman who has learned to channel the One Power on her own; only one in four survive this. Such women usually build barriers against knowing what it is they are doing, but if these can be broken down, wilders are frequently among the most powerful of channelers. The term is often used in derogatory fashion.

waɪz wʌn: əmʌŋ ði il, waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ wɪmən tʃoʊzən baɪ ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz ən tʃɹeɪn ɪn hilɪŋ, ɝbz ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ðeɪv ɡɹeɪɾ əθɔɹəɾi ən ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, əz wɛl əz ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnfluəns wɪð sɛpt ən klæn tʃifs, ðoʊ ðiz mɛn ɔfən əkjuz əm ə mɛɾəlɪŋ. ə ɡʊd mɛni waɪz wʌnz kən tʃænəl tə wʌn dɪɡɹi əɹ ənʌðɝ; ðeɪ faɪn ɛvɹi il wʊmən bɔɹn wɪð ðə spɑɹk ɪn əɹ ən moʊst ə ðoʊz u kən lɝn. ðə fæk ðət waɪz wʌnz kən tʃænəl ɪz nɑt spoʊkən ʌv əmʌŋ il, baɪ kʌstəm; əz ə ɹɪzʌl mɛni il də nɑt noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ waɪz wʌnz kən ən wɪtʃ kænɑt. ɔlsoʊ baɪ kʌstəm, waɪz wʌnz əvɔɪɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ivən mɔɹ soʊ ðən ʌðɝ il. tʃɹədɪʃənəli, waɪz wʌnz əv stʊɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ɔl fjudz ən bæɾəl, bʌt ðɪs kʌstəm əz ɹisənli bɪn ʃæɾɝd, pɝhæps bɪɑn mɛndɪŋ. wʌt ðɪs meɪ də tə ðə pɹətɛkʃənz əkɔɹɾɪd waɪz wʌnz ʌndɝ ði il bɪlif ə dʒiɾoʊ hæz jɛt tə bi sin.

Wise One: Among the Aiel, Wise Ones are women chosen by other Wise Ones and trained in healing, herbs and other things. They have great authority and responsibility, as well as great influence with sept and clan chiefs, though these men often accuse them of meddling. A good many Wise Ones can channel to one degree or another; they find every Aiel woman born with the spark in her and most of those who can learn. The fact that Wise Ones can channel is not spoken of among Aiel, by custom; as a result many Aiel do not know for sure which Wise Ones can and which cannot. Also by custom, Wise Ones avoid all contact with Aes Sedai, even more so than other Aiel. Traditionally, Wise Ones have stood outside all feuds and battle, but this custom has recently been shattered, perhaps beyond mending. What this may do to the protections accorded Wise Ones under the Aiel belief of ji'e'toh has yet to be seen.

waɪz wʊmən: wʌn ə ðə feɪbəl hilɝz ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt baɪ ðə wɛɹɪŋ ʌv ə ɹɛd bɛlt. ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz wɪð ɝbz ən ðɛɹ mɛɾəkəl nɑlədʒ ɑɹ spoʊkən ʌv əz fɑɹ əweɪ əz ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz əz biɪŋ ðə nɛks bɛs tə æktʃəwəl hilɪŋ baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɔlðoʊ ɛbu dɑɹ ɪz ə kɑzməpɑləɾən sɪɾi wɛɹ aʊtləndɝz fɹikwənli dʒɔɪn ðə sɪɾiz mɛni ɡɪlz, ði ɑɾəti hæz bɪn noʊɾəd ðət waɪz wɪmən u æktʃəli  ɑɹ ɛbu dɑɹi ɑɹ ɪn tʃɹuθ kwaɪt ɹɛɹ.

Wise Woman: One of the fabled healers of Ebou Dar, distinguished by the wearing of a red belt. Their abilities with herbs and their medical knowledge are spoken of as far away as the Borderlands as being the next best to actual Healing by an Aes Sedai. Although Ebou Dar is a cosmopolitan city where outlanders frequently join the city's many guilds, the oddity has been noted that Wise Women who actually are Ebou Dari are in truth quite rare.

əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinfɔɹɾieɪt ɪn tʃɑɹlstən, saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə. hi tɔt hɪmsɛlf tə ɹid wən i wɑz fɔɹ wɪð ði ɪnsɪdɛntəl eɪɾ ʌv ə twɛlv-jɪɹz-oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, ən wɑz tæklɪŋ mɑɹk tweɪn ən dʒulz vɝn baɪ faɪv. hi wɑz ə ɡɹædʒəwəɾ ə ðə sɪɾədɛl, ðə mɪlətɛɹi kɑlɪdʒ ə saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə, wɪð ə dɪɡɹi ɪn fɪzɪks. hi sɝv tu tʊɹz ɪn viɛtnɑm wɪð ðə juɛs. ɑɹmi; əmʌŋ ɪz dɛkɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt flaɪɪŋ kɹɔs wɪð bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ðə bɹɑnz stɑɹ wɪð "vi" ən bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ən tu viɛtnɑmis ɡæləntʃɹi kɹɔsɪz wɪð pɑm. ə hɪstɝi bʌf, hi ɔlsoʊ ɹoʊt dæns ən θiəɾɝ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. hi ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊtdɔɹ spɔɹts ə hʌntɪŋ, fɪʃɪŋ, ən seɪlɪŋ, ən ði ɪndɔɹ spɔɹts ə poʊkɝ, tʃɛs, pul, ən paɪp kəlɛktɪŋ. hi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntisɛvən ən kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ɪz dɛθ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən.

About the Author Robert Jordan was born in 1948 in Charleston, South Carolina. He taught himself to read when he was four with the incidental aid of a twelve-years-older brother, and was tackling Mark Twain and Jules Verne by five. He was a graduate of The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, with a degree in physics. He served two tours in Vietnam with the U.S. Army; among his decorations are the Distinguished Flying Cross with bronze oak leaf cluster, the Bronze Star with "V" and bronze oak leaf cluster, and two Vietnamese Gallantry Crosses with Palm. A history buff, he also wrote dance and theater criticism. He enjoyed the outdoor sports of hunting, fishing, and sailing, and the indoor sports of poker, chess, pool, and pipe collecting. He began writing in 1977 and continued until his death on September 16, 2007.
